column2: The test of any program of propaganda -- which can be defined in its best sense as the dissemination of selected information -- is in its effectiveness. To be effective it must be basically sound. Then it must be skillfully carried out over a long period under continuing good direction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The issuance of authorizations to nine countries, Trieste and the Allied occupation zones of Germany to procure $104,941,449 worth of food, commodities and equipment under our global-aid program was announced today by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

John Mason Brown, as the "Critic-at-Large," will conduct a weekly series of informal discussions over WJZ-TV, beginning Wednesday night from 7:30 to 8 o'clock. Conversation, for the most part, is to cover books, plays, radio, newspapers and television. Three guests will be on hand for each telecast.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Bob Lemon pitched his seventh shutout and sixteenth victory before 45,286 fans today as the Cleveland Indians, American League leaders, swept a double-header from the Chicago White Sox, 6 -- 2 and 8 -- 0.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The general tenor of comment in the British financial press on the failure of the special session of the United States Congress to carry through President Truman's policy of deflation is one of despondence and alarm.

As a Greek national, I feel it my elementary duty to express to you my deepest gratitude for the admirable article which was published in the Aug. 10 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and which does justice to the Greek Army, the Greek people and their constitutional government.

NORTHFIELD, N.J., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias of Ferndale, N.Y., today won the women's national open golf tournament with an even 300 for seventy-two holes at the Atlantic City Country Club. She registered a 78 on the final eighteen holes.

A properly limited plan for stabilizing its employes' annual wages can be installed by any well established company, but such plans might weaken the national economy "if hastily taken in large doses," according to a report issued over the week-end by the National Planning Association.

Decisions to be made by Mayor O'Dwyer And the Board of Estimate within the next month on the pressing problems of waterfront rehabilitation and sewage and garbage disposal will be the controlling factors in shaping the content of the city's capital outlay budget for 1949, it was learned yesterday.

A growing crop of new ideas for extending the scope of advertising, mostly through the medium of sound, is causing experienced advertising observers to be apprehensive about their effect on all advertising, it was noted last week. Among the new schemes are ones for the broadcasting of commercials through amplifiers in low-flying planes; talking manikins to advertise merchandise in department stores; vending machines that play short commercials when operated, and jingle-playing faucets for soda fountains

A group of leading United States women's wear buyers and manufacturers, arriving on an Air France plane from Paris at 6:35 o'clock last night at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, said that the recent French fashion shows had displayed garments with no changes in the basic design in the "new look," with prices ranging up to 20 per cent higher than last year

The American Newspaper Publishers Association over the weekend reported stocks of newsprint on hand and in transit at the end of July increased to forty-four days' supply for daily newspapers covered in the survey. The amount represented an increase of ten days' supply compared with stocks on hand at the end of June.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- Jacob Lomakin, Russian Consul General in New York, was involved in the "shanghaiing" of a Russian sailor in 1943, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent here recalled tonight.

Although the wholesale apparel market here was quiet last week, mail-order business was good, with reorders centered mainly on fall ready-to-wear, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Under a three-point conservation program, the Union County Park Commission, in conjunction with national, state and county agencies, is providing a sanctuary for the many birds and small animals that abound in the Watchung Reservation.

A long-term program for raising the technical knowledge of retail jewelers to near-professional levels and eventual utilization of this knowledge as the main theme in local and national advertising campaigns will be started this week by the Diamond Council of America, Inc., in cooperation with the University of Pennsylvania.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Government troops have unleashed a two-prong drive against Communist-held Shuyang, 240 miles to the northwest, pro-Government reports said today. Shuyang, in Kiangsu Province, is 140 miles northwest of Nanking.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- The Soviet press and radio said today an assistant United States naval attache who left Moscow May 1 had been caught receiving secret information from a Russian and was sent home by demand of the Soviet Foreign Ministry.
Older workers are not as unwanted as has been believed, according to a survey of business and industrial concerns in New York State, made public yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 15 -- American Davis Cup selections were completely disrupted today as Frankie Parker of Los Angeles decisively defeated Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., in the final of the Eastern Grass Court men's singles championship at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, 6 -- 2, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 2.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 15 -- Israeli Army Brigade Headquarters here declared today that Arab forces had launched a general attack along the entire Jerusalem perimeter, from halfway to Bethlehem southward of the city to the northern district at Sheikh Jarrah.

Dr. Arthur Prudden Coleman, who resigned six weeks ago as assistant professor of Polish Language and Literature at Columbia University in protest against the acceptance of a grant from the Polish Government to establish a new chair of Polish studies, criticized again yesterday the acceptance of the funds by the university.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 15 -- A torrential rainfall did not diminish the enthusiasm of several hundred thousand persons here today from a joyous celebration of the first anniversary of India's independence.

An early conference between Mayor O'Dwyer and leaders in business and industry in the Manhattan area south of Fifty-ninth Street was suggested yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York as a first step toward solution of the problem of rush-hour congestion on the Manhattan subway lines.

PANAMA, Aug. 15 -- Although the press censorship, established here under the suspension July 4 of constitutional guarantees, has not been applied to foreign correspondents, news from the United States and the Canal Zone as well as local news is being censored.
RILEY, Kan., Aug. 15 (AP) -- In a head-on collision of two automobiles near here today Dr. Roy B. Kester of New York, Professor of Accounting at Columbia University, was critically injured.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A newly identified disease, allergic fever, was reported today by a University of California Medical School researcher. It is caused by foods to which the patients are especially sensitive.

One of the youngest "veterans" in politics is entering this fall active participation in her fifth national political campaign, her seventeenth by the annual election calendar. She is Gertrude Hess, the young, brunette secretary of the New York Republican County Chairman, and probably has seen and participated in more practical politics than most people cram into their whole lives.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- Keenly disappointed with the western policy of temporizing while discussions are continuing in Moscow, representatives industrial concerns in the western sectors said today that they believed the Russians were easily winning the economic and financial battle for Berlin.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15 -- United States Ambassador James Bruce, who in his year here has always had extremely cordial relations with the Peron regime, especially with President Juan D. Peron himself and Foreign Ministre Juan Atilio Bramuglia, has become also within the last week a strong personality to the man in the street.

Thomas Nichols, 22 years old, of 491 Columbus Avenue, was arrested yesterday and accused by the police of being the man who in recent months had robbed several West Side apartments occupied by single women, raping the occupants.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 4 -- Two international centers for "unaccompanied children," DP war orphans and children whose parents, are missing, emphasize the desperate outlook for one group of children who were victims of Nazi abuses.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- A yachtsman was burned seriously today when fire, resulting from a gasoline explosion, destroyed his 42-foot cruiser while it lay at a dock here.
SEOUL., Korea, Aug. 15 -- Korea greeted the rebirth of her freedom today with enthusiasm matched only by that which swept the country on her liberation from Japan three years ago.
The Indian and Pakistani communities of New York celebrated yesterday the first anniversary of the independence of their countries at meetings throughout the city.
Elizur Yale Smith, in a letter in THE TIMES Of Aug. 9, has taken the position that "our United States is a republic, not a democracy."

Leading fashion designers of France, acting through a firm of New York lawyers, will take steps to end the use by American dress manufacturers of famous Parisian labels on copies of French designed garments made here, usually to retail at lower prices.

In the issue for Aug. 3 there is a special dispatch from Lake Success stating that Aubrey S. Eban will, for the second month, be recognized as the representative of the Provisional Government of Palestine.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The United Nations Security Council will head into another stormy session tomorrow when the eleven members hear Britain reply to Yugoslav charges that the American-British administration of Trieste is exerting pressure to turn over the Free Territory to Italy.
The Rev. Dr. John S. Whale of the Mill Hill School in England delivered the morning sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church on "The Choice Before Us."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Army and the Air Force announced today that they were prepared to defer 118,600 young men enrolled in senior divisions of the Reserve Officers Training Corps in colleges in the coming academic year.

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, hero of Bataan and Corregidor, was one of almost 800 delegates to the twenty-seventh national convention of the Disabled American Veterans who registered yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel.

NEWARK, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Newark Bears returned home from an extended road trip today and swept a twin bill from Jersey City by 7-5 and 3-1 margins. The Bruins, strengthening their hold on second place, used the home run route to victory in both games.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Jack Grout, Harrisburg, Pa., professional and Craig Wood tied for top individual honors with 7-under-par 36-hole scores of 137 in the ninth annual Spring Lake Golf and Country Club pro-member tourney which ended today.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The major absentees of the 1948 Olympic Games -- Russia, Japan and Germany -- may compete in the 1952 games at Helsinki, Avery Brundage said today.

Officials of the Soviet consulate refused to permit the police to summon an ambulance immediately after Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina had leaped from a third-floor window of the building last Thursday, it was disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- French experts are studying a new agricultural plan, aiming not only at French independence of imports but in addition at allowing France to resume its role as an exporter of food products.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 15 -- Evidence is now at hand that Marshal Tito and the Yugoslav Communist party leadership have been striking swiftly and ruthlessly in the past weeks to remove sympathizers of the Communist Information Bureau from public office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Republican leaders in Congress took immediate exception today to President Truman's contention that the Government will have an operating deficit of $1,545,000,000 in the current fiscal year.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The ages of three flippers Eddie Sawyer tossed at the Giants before 18,168 fans at Shibe Park this afternoon encompassed 109 years, but the Giants were helpless before them, and dropping a double-header to the Phillies receded another half a length behind the leaders in the National League pennant struggle.

The various investigations of Communist activities in this country, coupled with the diplomatic exchanges over the dramatic escape of the three Russian teachers, rightly command the attention of the world because of the new light they throw on the nature of the Russian Government and its methods.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Stan Spence's three-run homer in the fifth inning lifted Boston to an 8-7 victory over Washington here today in the second game of a double-header. Washington won the first game, 5 -- 4, by checking a Red Sox ninth-inning rally marked by Ted Williams' twentieth home run with one aboard.

Her attention diverted by policemen rigging up a safety net to catch her Mrs. Doris Solana, 35 years old, of 830 East 163d Street, the Bronx, was seized by other policemen at 5:45 P.M. yesterday as she swayed on the roof ledge of a five-story building at 618 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx.
BERLIN, Aug. 15 (AP) -- German Communists attempted today, by threats of a winter blockade of Berlin, to incite the people against the anti-Communist city government.

The Yankees and Giants will set aside their pennant worries tonight when they engage in a benefit exhibition game at the Polo Grounds for the Mayor O'Dwyer Trophy. The major portion of the receipts will be turned over to the city's sandlot baseball agencies.

As departmental hearings begin today before the City Planning Commission in preparation of the new capital budget the city enters upon a period of decision on a number of physical improvements, both in and out of that budget, that are of great interest to the public.

A new North American College for the training of students from this country for the priesthood of the Roman Catholic Church will rise soon in Rome, it was learned yesterday. The cost will be $3,000,000, about half of which has been pledged.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Coffee drinkers in the United States eclipsed milk devotees by 1,000,000,000 gallons a year, statisticians reported tonight.

The American rubber industry has consumed 55 per cent more rubber in the three years since V-J Day of 1945 than it did in its three previous peak years added together, it was reported over the week-end by John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, Akron.

"The Lincoln Papers," edited by David C. Mearns, will be published on Oct. 22 by Doubleday. The 500 letters and memoranda are from the long guarded collection in the Library of Congress. They include letters from the Republican National Convention at Chicago's Wigwam in May, 1860, to Lincoln, apprising him of developments as the days passed.
The "race of life" was compared yesterday by Canon Bernard G. Newman to the contests in the recent Olympic Games in London.

The liner Excalibur, the first of four passenger ships being rebuilt for the American Export Lines by the Bethlehem Steel Company, will be completed within five weeks, it was announced here yesterday.

Domestic cotton prices last week had their sharpest declines since February as a result of issuance of the Crop Reporting Board's forecast of this year's production of the staple, which was much larger than the trade had expected.

Last week's foreign exchange market was a dull affair. This restriction of business and fluctuations was due to the "summer doldrums" and an easing of the tension which prevailed in the market prior to the opening operations of ERP.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement reviewing the budget of the 1948-49 fiscal year.
ZURICH, Aug. 15 -- On Friday the value of the free dollar in Switzerland dropped to 3.91 Swiss francs, the lowest since Sept. 22, 1947. The official rate is 4.28.
BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- Aristocratic dogs and cats must now scrounge for their food like mongrels and alley cats. And the scrounging isn't so good.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Rumors of negotiations for the union of Eire and Northern Ireland became so persistent today that it was thought necesary to issue denials in both London and Belfast.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 15 -- Today, on the 411th anniversary of the founding of this landlocked city that is now her capital, Paraguay inaugurated Juan Natalicio Gonzalez for a five-year term as President.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Olympic athletes from a number of eastern European lands, finding the atmosphere of political freedom in Britain to their liking, decided today not to go home.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 15 -- Six men are known to be dead as the result of a fire and explosion about 10 o'clock this morning in a line of one-story buildings on Lake Street, half a block from the Southern Pacific Railroad tracks.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger blanked the Cubs with three hits in the second game as Cincinnati and Chicago split a double header today before 16,473 spectators. The Reds won the second game, 5 -- 0, after the Cubs, struck twice in the ninth to win the first game 7 -- 6.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- An adequate relief job by Paul Minner and a most excellent one by Hank Behrman in the eighth and ninth innings saved a triumph for big Ralph Branca this afternoon as the Dodgers beat the Braves, 4 -- 2, before 28,420 fans, to even the series at two games each.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The State Department called a special press conference today to deny emphatically Soviet charges that a United States naval attache in Moscow had been packed off home when caught spying. A State Department spokesman said that the incident was a "plant" and was "arranged by Soviet authorities."

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 15 -- A Long Islander from Rockville Centre, Henry Sieck, whose red and white speedboat Pearl IV made a brave bid yesterday for the Guy Lombardo Gold Cup event here, today became the winner of the featured 225 cubic inch class race in a chain of happenings typical of this unpredictable sport.

A group of young Democrats, headed by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Erastus Corning 2d, Stanley Church and Robert F. Wagner Jr., is scheduled to bear the major responsibility for the Democratic speaking campaign in New York State, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Philip E. Mosely, Columbia University professor, stated today that Premier Stalin expressed regret during the Potsdam meeting over the agreement he had made at the Yalta conference to permit free elections in eastern Europe.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 15 -- Alarmed by the present international tension, the Swedes have taken a number of military security measures so they will be prepared if the storm breaks, according to reliable sources.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret, Ojai, Calif., dropped in a birdie 4 on the eighteenth hole to boost himself into a tie with Otto Greiner, Baltimore, at the end of 72 holes of play in the St. Paul open golf tournament today.

The sports pages of the daily press are being prettified these days by pictures of yachts and speed boats sailing high, wide and handsome and withal there is some stirring prose being written about regattas, leeward legs, spinnakers and dismastings.

In THE TIMES of Aug. 9 appear two letters presenting opposite points of view in regard to Congressional investigations. A.R. Graustein apparently favors no restrictions whatever on the methods employed by Congressional committees, whereas Clifford Forster of the American Civil Liberties Union seems to suggest that all inquiries which might lead to the discovery of crime should be hedged about with limitations that might easily render them completely futile.

Current offerings by the War Assets Administration in this region cover about $3,295,000 worth of goods, it was announced over the week-end by Walter F. Downey, regional director of the WAA for New York and New England.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- In Colombes Stadium, where the 1924 Olympics were held, the American track and field team of 1948 was unveiled today for the benefit of 18,000 Parisians and it continued the sweep which began in the games at London and continued through the meet with the British Empire.

Warning that continued city inaction on the parking problem would blight commercial areas and undermine the municipal tax structure, the Real Estate Board of New York called yesterday for a powerful independent traffic agency.

Better manners would go far toward making a better world, the Rev. William T. Greene, chairman of the music commission of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday. In a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, he scored a lack of "basic good manners" in daily life.

More than fifty young women from twenty-six countries will attend the first International Study Conference on Women and World Reconstruction, beginning Wednesday, it was announced yesterday. The sponsor is the Foreign Division, National Board of the Y.W.C.A.

A client of M.C. O'Brien, Inc., bought for investment from Mrs. Emma Stewart the five-story apartment house for twenty-two families at 1618 Beverly Road, corner of East Seventeenth Street, in Brooklyn.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Proposals to legalize bingo and provide for a veterans' bonus as well as completion of reorganization of state government under the new Constitution face the New Jersey Legislature when it convenes tomorrow.

NANKING, Aug. 15 -- The Communist radio reported tonight that at a nation-wide labor conference in Communist-held Harbin Shanghai's delegate said the workers of his city were carrying on an all-out effort to destroy the economy of the Chiang Kai-shek Government.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- A nonpartisan economic report published here today asserted that further inflation in Britain might entail the "risk of serious industrial trouble."

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug 15 -- The American Dance Festival, now in session at the Palmer Auditorium here, presented Jose Limon and his company in their first appearance in the series last night, and this afternoon offered the second program by Martha Graham and her company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Most American industries are making a higher return after taxes on stockholders' investments than they did before the war, a survey made by the Federal Trade Commission indicated today. The survey is based on a comparison of the rate of return for more than 500 identical manufacturing corporations in 1940 and 1947.
The schedule for interviewing buyers at Macy's handkerchief sample room, Corporate Buying Division, 1314 Broadway, has been changed from Thursday to Friday at 10 A.M.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug 15 (AP) -- Fred Scott of the Skaneateles Yacht and Country Club won the Rhodes Bantam Sloop International Championship today for the second year in a row. Scott, who had a total point score of 40 1/2 with two firsts and a third, captured the title with a sweeping victory in the third race on Chaumont Bay.

GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- Tomorrow will see the beginning of a great adventure in international economic cooperation. In Geneva, where twenty-three nations last year completed the biggest trade and tariff agreement ever negotiated, twenty-two of those countries will meet to constitute themselves history's first permanent multinational body devoted to the enforcement of a code of conduct to govern world trade.

The congregation of the Christ Lutheran Church, founded eighty years ago in a blacksmith shop in East Fourteenth Street, gathered yesterday for a ground-breaking service in the street opposite a vacant lot at Nineteenth Street and First Avenue, where a new church building will be erected.
Four new films, including importations from England, Germany and Argentina, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

When Estelle and Erwine Laverne, husband and wife design team, went to California last spring for the convention of the American Institute of Decorators -- whose award they won for the best fabric design introduced in 1947 -- they saw the works of artists across the country whose talents had not been applied widely to furnishings.
The Department of Marine and Aviation has included in its departmental capital budget estimates a full request for funds covering its proposed port rehabilitation program.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Frank Scarane of Maspeth, Queens, was elected commander of the New York State Department of the American Veterans of World War II (AMVETS) today.

The Yankees, after days of heroic struggling to keep themselves in the American League's epic pennant race, saw their hopes of an immediate leap to the top crash around their ears yesterday at the Stadium as they blew both ends of their twin bill with Connie Mack's amazing Athletics.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- The clash between United States military authorities in Germany and the Council of the Marshall Plan nations over dollar credits to be allotted to the German bizonal area in the current year under the European Recovery Program remained unsolved after two long sessions of the Council this afternoon and tonight.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 16 Two thousand National Guardsmen at Camp Smith here gave a review tonight in honor of the organized reserves. The review was taken by Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, Commanding General of the Seventyseventh Infantry Division, Organized Reserves.

Hanson W. Baldwin's defense of segregation in the Army published in THE TIMES of Aug. 8 is a distressing revelation of the inflexibility of the military mind. Because segregation has been the policy of the armed services is surely no justification for the continuance oft his anachronism.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 16 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the United States Military Governor, said at a press conference today that he knew of no plans for a change in United States policy with respect to instituting a trizonal government in Germany.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- The Progressive party filed its Illinois petitions for national and state candidates today. Also acting on the final day for filing were the Socialist and Prohibition parties. The Socialist Labor party filed last week.

ATHENS, Aug. 16 -- Aetomilitsa, the village in the heart of the Grammos Mountains that served long as capital for the guerrilla chief, Gen. Markos Vafiades, and as military headquarters of his movement to convert Greece into a Communist state, fell today to the Greek national forces, said late messages received by the General Staff.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 16 -- As an earnest of its intention to obtain complete segregation of races, the new Nationalist Government of South Africa applied "Jim Crow" regulations today to commuting in the Capetown area.

A moth and flame dance by twenty-four ballet dancers will be the climax and finale of the fashion show to be presented every night at the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition in Grand Central Palace. The dancers will be in addition to 125 models who will display hundreds of new dresses and accessories of all types, as well as prices.
Regardless of the outcome of the pennant races, the Yankees remain Manhattan's major league champions.

With the addition of fifteen vessels -- eight cargo ships and seven tankers -- the privately owned United States merchant fleet totaled 1,190 ships on Aug. 1, according to the National Federation of American Shipping's monthly survey.

Four "transfers of power" are needed in order to democratize the United States if it is ultimately to "succeed against communism," the Rev. Edward Dowling of St. Louis, a member of the executive council of the National Municipal League; declared here yesterday.

Kyle MacDonnell will be the "Girl About Town" when that program is introduced over WNBT Wednesday, Sept. 8, from 8 to 8:20 P.M. In her portrayal of the title role in a New York setting, she will introduce the television audience to people and places.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Britain's woolen and cotten industries, with current exports around 50 per cent better than last year, appear likely to exceed their ambitious production and export targets for 1948, Douglas Jay, Economic Secretary to the Treasury; said tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 16 (AP) -Newark's home-run punch carried the Bears to a third straight triumph over Jersey City tonight Two-run homers by Lou Novikoff and Hank Workman erased an early Little Giant lead and powered the second-place Bears to an 8-6 decision.

VIENNA, Aug. 16 The Russian occupation authorities today followed up their recent complaint to the Allied Council about "warmongering" activities of Austrian newspapers published in the Westernh)0*0*0*izones by banning seven of them from the Soviet zone for varying periods.
LONDON, Aug. 16 Pending the result of the meeting in Moscow scheduled for today, buyers held off in the stock market and idle conditions ruled.

ATHENS, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Later reports tonight said General Markos had transferred rebel headquarters to the village of Grammos and that his forces now were squeezed into an area about ten miles long and ten miles wide bordering on Albania.

A study of the leading figures in American political history by Richard Hofstadter, assistant professor of History at Columbia University, will be brought out by Knopf on Sept. 14. Entitled "The American Political Tradition and the Men Who Made It," the book contains twelve chapters, each dealing with a period and a leader.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The only American-born girl to whom American troops in the Pacific are believed to have applied the name "Tokyo Rose" will be brought to this country to face a treason charge. Attorney General Tomh)0*0*0*iClark announced today.

Jersey Joe Walcott and Gus Lesnevich, both of whom have been beaten in recent important tests, have agreed to meet in a fifteenround bout at Roosevelt Stadium Jersey City on the night of Sept. 21, it was announced yesterday by Andy Niederreiter, promoter for the relatively new organization, the Tournament of Champions.

The Department of Commerce has informed the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., that Brazil has lifted import controls on shipments of wheat and flour en route and ordered before Aug. 4, the effective date of the controls, the association announced yesterday.
Sir C. V. Raman worldfamous Indian physicist and Nobel prizeh) 0*0*0*iwinner, visited Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute yesterday, inspecting the laboratories and meeting with Indian science students.

A strike was called yesterday at thirty-seven office, loft and apartmenth)0*0*0*ibuildings in the Grand Central, Washington Heights and West Side areas by Local 32B, Building Service Employes Union, AFL.
PARIS, Aug. 16 -- The National Assembly, returning tomorrow from its mid-August holiday, will begin the crucial second reading of Finance Minister Paul Reynaud's financial and economic reforms.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 16 -The Provisional Government of Israel issued tonight a declaration of monetary independence. Beginning tomorrow, there will be Israeli currency completely divorced from British sterling or Palestinian pounds.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Knoll and Mrs. T. U. Lyman of Maplewood took qualifying honors today at the Crestmont Country Club in the second annual four-ball match play championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -City Manager Thomas V. Kennedy, in making public today the 1949 estimate of operating expenses for his own department of the city government, cut his own salary $2,000, reducing it from $12,000 to $10,000 a year.

The celebrations this week of a year of independence for India and Pakistan rightly called attention to the remarkable progress that has been made in twelve months by the two Dominions. This had been overshadowed in its earlier phases by the tragic communal rioting that was brought to an end only by the assassination of Mohandas Gandhi, the "Great Soul" of the Indian independence movement.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 10 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Three hours of closed-session questioning of Alger Hiss, former State Department official, left the House Committee on un-American Activities admittedly unable tonight to determine whether he or Whittaker Chambers, who accused him of leadership in an "elite" pre-war Communist "underground," was telling the truth.

Add to the list of films opening this week "Race Street," an RKO melodrama with George Raft, William Bendix and Marilyn Maxwell, which will arrive at the Mayfair on Saturday. Edwin L. Marin directed and Nat Holt produced from a screen play by Martin Rackin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A 15-year-old boy who saved the life of an abandoned puppy and a Canadian scientist who helped develop a vaccine against a bacterial disease were honored today by the American Veterinary Medical Association.
Heavy increases in prices of canned foods due to appear on retail shelves in from three to six weeks, mainly in fruits, is causing deep concern throughout the industry, it was learned here yesterday.

Samuel, Moses, Jacob and Nathan Katz have purchased the fivestory apartment house also containing five stores at 1469 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, from the estate of Hyman Katz. The property, on an irregular plot about 100 by 64 feet, is assessed at $62,000.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Isaac L. Kashdan of New York, one of America's international aces at chess, shook himself free from the field and held first place undisputed today in consequence of a well-earned victory over Anthony Suroci of New Haven, in the sixth round of the tournament for the United States championship at the community center.

A $600,000 civil anti-trust suit was filed in Federal court yesterday, charging four trade associations and sixty-eight of their corporate members with conspiracy to monopolize the linen and towel supply and flatwork business in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

A small percentage of the huge taxes collected by Federal, state, county and city governments on liquor could well be spent on research into the problems of alcohol, Dr. Alton J. Carlson declared yesterday. Dr. Carlson, Professor Emeritus and chairman of the department of Physiology at the University of Chicago, was the principal speaker at the opening meeting of the Institute in Alcohol Education, which began yesterday at the School of Education, New York University.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Slam Bang, a high-galloping 2-year-old bought with the intention of making him a jumper, today ran off with first money of $8,250 in the six-furlong Sanford Stakes at Saratoga.
Babe Ruth was the latest victim of cancer, the scourge that kills more than 170,000 Americans every year and is responsible for one out of every eight deaths.

TOKYO, Aug. 16 -- Japanese medical scientists have started, with some apparent early success, to make short people taller by grafting pituitary gland tissue from cows to the thighs of the patients, it was reported here.
ALBANY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The State Education Department announced today the winners of 100 special $450-a-year state scholarships.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A two-run double by Virgil Stallcup broke a 2-2 tie in the eighth inning and carried the Reds to a 5-2 victory over the Pirates tonight. Johnny Vander Meer went the route for the Reds to chalk up his tenth triumph for the Reds as against twelve losses.

Acting upon reports that complaints had been made to the Small Business Committee of the House of Representatives against member groups of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen, officers of thath)0*0*0*iassociation met yesterday at 1776 Broadway, to plan a course of action "to prove they are not in restraint of trade."

The Rev. Albert C. M. Steffens, chaplain at Manhattan College, will resume today his wartime rank of major in response to Cardinal Spellman's appeal for more chaplains for the armed forces. Major Steffens, who received the Silver Star, the Soldier's Medal and the French Croix de Guerre in World War II, will go today to Belleville, Ill., to join an Air Force unit.

The stock market quieted down yesterday to the slowest pace in four years and prices barely flickered. Quotations held at the approximate closing levels of last Friday, with changes of more than a fraction easily spotted in the list and the composite rate increased 0.03 point on the day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 (AP) -Tony Mottram, England's topranking tennis player, fell before the power-house slants of the Veteran Frank Shields of New York today in the twenty-ninth annual Newport Casino invitation grass courts tournament as the domestic seeded stars dominated the first day's play.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 16 -Forty-five solar flares in about one and one half rotations of the sun, about one flare every four hours, have been recorded on motion pictures shown here for the first time to astronomers assembled at the International Astronomical Union.

Brayton Eddy, Curator of Reptiles and Insects at the Bronx Zoo, decided yesterday that the time had come to divulge the story of the Bronx frog hunters. Not even Mr. Eddy knows all the details, though he has traded often with the hunters.

The Public Service Commission refused yesterday an application of the Staten Island Edison Company for sale of its assets to a new company, the Staten Island Electric Corporation, on the ground that the proposed sale was not in the public interest.

After several years of dramatic trail-blazing on the West Coast, the Circle Players, a group of young and talented hopefuls, have trained their sights on bigger game -- Broadway. They have dispatched Sydney Chaplin, son of Charles Chaplin, and Jerry Epstein, formerly of Brooklyn, to New York with the idea of making arrangements for a local presentation of "Caligula," the French success by Albert Camus.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 16 The Soviet Union and someh) 0*0*0*iother countries behind its Iron Curtain on present indications are boycotting the seventeenth Red Cross World Conference, opening here Friday. The boycott, if it materializes, is viewed in circles close to the Red Cross leaders assembling here as a protest against the participation of Spain.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 16 --h)0*0*0*iDr. Henry U. Barber Jr., 54 years old, an orthodontist of Scarsdale and New York, and his wife, Mrs. Priscilla McLeod Barber, 42, were killed early today when their automobile swerved from the Taconic State Parkway near East Fishkill, Dutchess County.

OTTAWA, Aug. 16 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal described today his conversation with Canadian defense authorities as "a very profitable, interesting and useful exchange of views on common defense problems."

Odd Fellows lodges in the United States have contributed $250,000 to rehabilitate member lodges in Europe "severly damaged and disorganized" in the war, it was announced yesterday at the opening session of the eighty-third annual meeting of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows, Grand Lodge of the State of New York, at the Commodore Hotel.

The next move in the efforts to keep the Metropolitan Opera House open during the coming season as the home of Metropolitan Opera will take place today at the scheduled meeting of its board of directors. It is understood that the principal item on the agenda will be action on a joint proposal by the twelve unions representing the opera's employes.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP) -- About 8,500 automobile workers, made idle last week by materials shortages, returned to their jobs today. Another 3,000 have been recalled for Wednesday after a three-weeks' lay-off.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 16 -- A four-way tie at 84 resulted as sixty-one women played in the qualifying round of the twentythird annual championship of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association at the Greenwich Country Club here today.

Out of the ten major classifications of goods analyzed and indexed by purchasing research agencies, nine show downward price trends, and only ferrous and nonferrous products reveal a slight upward trend, purchasing spokesmen disclosed here yesterday.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Miss Dot Kielty of Long Beach, California state golf titleholder, went into the lead for qualifying honors of the Trans-Mississippi women's golf tournament today with an even par 74.

An exhaustive report by the Police Department, made to Mayor O'Dwyer and turned over by him to prosecuting agencies, says flatly that the Soviet charges that Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina was kidnapped are "unfounded."

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California, the Republican candidate for Vice President, will receive a major role in the campaign to win votes for the party's national ticket headed by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of Newh)0*0*0*iYork, the candidate for President.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- Envoys of the United States, Great Britainh)0*0*0*iand France met with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov again tonight in the negotiations seeking to settle East-West differences in Berlin and Germany.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 16 -- An employer of union printers appealed to the embattled International Typographical Union, AFL, today to abandon its "tough" policy and cooperate with the industry in developing new printing methods and expanding the market for work.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, asserted today that he suspected the Communist spy ring stories were being foisted on the public by the Republicans to cover what he called the "glaring failure of the Eightieth Congress to take any action to protect the human needs of the American people."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Although a metropolitan P.G.A. tourney, practically the entire field of eighty-two pro-amateur teams represented the Westchester area in the best-ball event at the Fenway Golf Club today.

HEWLETT, L.I, Aug. 16 -- Al Brosch, Long Island open champion, won another district golfing honor when he teamed with Ray Torgerson, Cherry Valley amateur, to capture the Long Island amateur-pro title over the Seawane Harbor course with a best-ball score of 67.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 16 An Israeli Army communique said that Arab riflemen had slashed today at Israeli traffic on Jerusalem's outskirts, the first reported resumption of highway sniping in nearly three months.

The bodies of 5,864 United States service men will arrive here Thursday aboard the Army transport Lawrence Victory from Cherbourg and Antwerp, it was announced yesterday by the New York Port of Embarkation.

The Polish people have suffered as much as any in the cause of liberty and are "still suffering," Cardinal Spellman declared yesterday in accepting a miniature portrait of himself, the gift of the American Polish Citizen Intellectual Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 -Enterprise Productions, Inc., today said it was not renewing its lease at Enterprise Studio, and no official of the company would make a definite statement regarding future production plans.

Nestled amid the wooded hills and gleaming lakes of northern Westchester County, the town of Yorktown is rich in arcadian beauty and rural tranquillity. And the Taconic State Parkway that weaves its way northward through the township is one of the most useful in the nation for highspeed through traffic.

The steady flight of refugees from behind the Iron Curtain, illustrated by the dramatic escape of the three Russian teachers in New York, has been high-lighted anew by the decision of eight Olympic athletes in London not to return to their Communist-dominated countries but rather to seek a new life of freedom in the West.

Service For Palestine, Inc., 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, has just been established to send kosher food packages to Israel. As the only non-profit organization in this country to set up such a service, it arranges delivery in approximately four weeks on three parcels, which cost $6.80 (twelve pounds), $9.80 (fifteen pounds) and $12.80 (twenty pounds).

William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, said yesterday that an eight-foot model of a new stainless steel subway car would dominate the city's transportation exhibit at the Golden Anniversary Exposition in Grand Central Palace next week.

PARIS, Aug. 16 The European Council of the Marshall Plan Nations acknowledged its first prolonged deadlock when it officially revealed today its failure to agree on a division of United States aid for the current year after three days for discussion that often was heated.

LONDON, Aug. 16 With the announcement today from Tel Avivh)0*0*0*ithat the Israeli Government would issue its own currency, the British Treasury declared that the Palestine Currency Board would continue nevertheless to function as before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered twelve makers of crown bottle caps and the Crown Manufacturers Association to halt what the agency termed a "conspiracy to fix prices and suppress competition" in the sale of the products.

Babe Ruth died last night. The 53-year-old baseball idol succumbed to cancer of the throat at Memorial Hospital at 8 o'clock, less than two hours after a special bulletin had announced he was "sinking rapidly."
Following is the text of the statement issued last night by Jacob M. Lomakin, Soviet Consul General here:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- President Truman signed today the extra-session measure tightening consumer and bank credit and in doing so asserted that Republican leaders of the Eightieth Congress had served the ends of special privilege rather than the welfare of the whole nation.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 16 (AP) -Experience and ability to play under pressure paid off today for Jimmy Demaret, who took first prize of $2,450 from Otto Greiner, Baltimore, in the play-off of the St. Paul open golf tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Vergil D. Dardi, chairman of the Blair Holdings Corporation executive committee, said today he "definitely is negotiating" for the purchase of Rosenberg Bros. Co., dried fruit and nut processors.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets for the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Dr. Eugene Browning has purchased the two-story dwelling with studio and garage on Quaker Street, Chappaqua, N.Y., from Louise B. McKelvey. Francis P. Critchley was the broker. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 16 -- The United State, British and French delegations refused today to serve on the drafting committee to put the final touches on the Soviet draft convention as the Danubian conference entered its last days.
There were few empty seats on the "last train" that pulled out of Grand Central Terminal for Westport. Two heavily breathless men came into the smoking car as the train began to move.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Lithium Corporation of America, Inc., Minneapolis, Minn., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 100,000 shares of $1 par value common stock.

President Truman joined with leaders in the sports world and in other fields throughout the nation last night in expressing sorrow at the passing of Babe Ruth. Charles G. Ross, White House press secretary, said the President was informed of the baseball star's death soon after it was announced and arranged to send a message of condolence to Mrs. Ruth.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- Complete Communist domination of Berlin and the Soviet zone of occupation and an intense political campaign against Western rule in the Ruhr and Western Germany are the objectives of the present rigorous purge in the Socialist Unity [Communist] party, according to former members of the party.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The world's farms, factories and mines are producing more today than during pre-war days but paradoxically international trade has fallen off, United Nations economists reported here today.

Probably nowhere in all the imaginative field of fiction could one find a career more dramatic and bizarre than that portrayed in real life by George Herman Ruth. Known the world over, even in foreign lands where baseball is never played, as the Babe, he was the boy who rose from the obscurity of a charitable institution in Baltimore to a position as the leading figure in professional baseball.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Britain took the offensive today in the long diplomatic battle over Trieste, accusing Yugoslavia of incorporating her zone of the city into the Yugoslavia governmental system.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that Norman A. Cole, a field examiner, has been assigned to make an immediate investigation of beating and coercion charges filed against Local 65, Wholesale and Warehouse Workers, CIO, by two display card manufacturers.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 16 (AP) -- D. F. Harrington's Weathercock upset W. W. Water's favored Sassy's King, in the Wakefield Purse as Narragansett Park opened a 30-day meeting today.
First-day buying was brisk yesterday as a record number of exhibitors displayed a wide variety of new lines at the National Luggage and Leather Goods Show in the New Yorker Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 16 Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, reported today that 330,000 Arab and Jewish refugees were confronted with "a serious threat of typhoid, typhus and relapsing fever epidemics" and that he had appealed for help to members of the United Nations.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 16 -After a long inquiry into the hatch lifting dispute that virtually immobilized the port of Auckland for several weeks the investigating tribunal found that the hatch covers of the Government-chartered wheat ship Mount Park could not be lifted safely by hand during the first phase of the trouble between Feb. 20 and 28.

Jersey City, N.J., yesterday sold issues of $649,000 of water and emergency housing bonds to a banking syndicate headed by Bacon, Stevenson Co. at a bid of 100.20 for interest of 2.65 per cent. The bonds put up for sale consisted of a proposed issue of $500,000 of water obligations due Nov. 1 from 1949 to 1977 and $150,000 of housing bonds due Sept. 1 from 1949 to 1958.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 16 -- The Maine tuna tournament is now over, and the only comment that could be made on the contest is that it went the way of all big-fish derbies, primarily because of the weather.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The use of mental and social scientists at top policy-making levels of the United States State Department as well as in the Foreign Ministries of other governments throughout the world was urged here today by Dr. Carl Binger, associate Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Cornell University,h) 0*0*0*ias a vital step in preventing war.

It was Oct. 1, 1932. Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York, soon to be President, was one of the fifty thousand spectators who packed Wrigley Field in Chicago to see a World Series game between the Yankees and the Cubs. Up to the plate, in the fifth inning, stepped a bandy-legged figure, the one and only "Babe," George Herman Ruth.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The three Western envoys emerged grim and taciturn from-tonight's session. MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 16 (AP) -- First day play in the twentyfirst annual Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament reduced the field of fortyeight to seventeen today, but when the last volley was through all eight seeded players and lesser favorites were still in the running.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The domestic phosphate rock industry set some "startling new high records" in 1947, the Bureau of Mines said today.

GENEVA, Aug. 16 The executive board of the United Nations International Emergency Children's Fund has decided to devote $400,000 to feeding Arab mothers and children displaced by the Palestine war, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- September corn continued today to be the feature on the Board of Trade, fluctuating in an extremely nervous manner within a range of 3 1/4 cents and reacting after an early upturn that put the price to a new high since late last July and 10 3/8 cents above the low of last week.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Cardinals maintained their pennant drive here today when they unleashed a fourteen-hit assault, including three homers, to defeat the Cubs, 9 to 7, before 16,447 fans.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 16 - When is a beach cabana not a beach cabana? That question went to the courts today as the result of a disagreement between city officials and a private realty corporation.

The Pantepec Oil Company, C.A., announced yesterday that securities issued under the plan of reorganization dated March 1, 1948 will be delivered commencing Thursday. Directors declared a dividend of 2 bolivars, or 64 cents a share, payable on Sept. 23, to stock of record on Sept. 10.

WASHINGTON, Aug.16 -- Listing accomplishments of the Roosevelt-Truman administrations, Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic national chairman, asserted today that they would be "hammered home as a major part of the Democratic campaign."

New-financing totaling $14,796,250 was announced here yesterday. Private borrowing by stores from institutional investors accounted for $13,000,000 of the total. WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The various revelations of Soviet spy activities in the United States, with special concentration on Washington, may surprise, but they should not stun, close observers of the capital in the period from Munich to the end of the first year of the Truman Administration.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- The three Western powers are considering the establishment of a tripartite Kommandatura that would form the first line of defense against Soviet claims to supreme authority over all of Berlin, it was learned authoritatively today.

The wholesale price of highgrade butter declined 2 cents a pound here yesterday and one large chain announced that its retail prices would go down the same amount this morning. Other stores are expected to change their prices in a day or two.

Prices of television receivers probably will be increased shortly by most manufacturers because of mounting production costs, E. A. Nicholas, president, Farnsworth Radio Television Corporation, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Anny Blatt's cocktail frocks, hand-knit in a delicate lace pattern, are spider-web in texture. They look as light as air and should be invaluable for plane travel when space and weight count. What is more, they can be rolled up into any corner and still come out fresh, ready for late afternoon or an informal evening.
BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- The Dodgers left Boston on a high note for Philadelphia tonight and more than ever convinced that they are headed for a pennant.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -President Truman was accused today by Hugh Scott Jr., Republican National Chairman, of "drawing an iron curtain between himself and the Representatives of the people."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Saudi Arabia refused to accept a $15,000,000 American loan because of its displeasure with United States support of the Jewish cause in Palestine.

Record peacetime sales of $346,079,544 were reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 by the Goodyear Tire Rubber Co. and its subsidiaries. Net sales for the corresponding period a year ago were $316,467,215. Capacity operations were continuing in all plants, P. W. Litchfield, board chairman, said in announcing the mid-year results.

LONDON, Aug. 16 For the first time since Parliament adjourned on July 30 the British Cabinet was called into session by Acting Prime Minister Herbert Morrison today. Only six or seven senior Ministers were available in London and subordinates were summoned to fill the vacant chairs.

Morgan, board chairman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Up to 15,000 young men will be drafted into the country's new peacetime Army in the first half of November, it was disclosed today.

While a special committee appointed by the Greater New York Retail Furriers Association was scheduled to hold its first meeting today on the problem of regulating comparative price claims in fur advertising, the Better Business Bureau of New York reported yesterday that it had made some progress in its proposal for a trial elimination of the comparison device.

With fall dress reorders coming in very strong, cutters in the New York garment market are pressing fabric suppliers for quick deliveries on a variety of rayon goods, wools and wool mixtures, it was learned yesterday.

Last January President Truman presented his first tentative estimate of probable federal receipts and expenditures for fiscal 1949 -- that is, for the period July 1, 1948-June 30, 1949. Declaring that a speedy determination of the issues was important "for all concerned," Federal Judge Harold R. Medina declined yesterday to grant to twelve Communist leaders indicted on charges of conspiracy to overthrow the Government an additional ninety days in which to file motions attacking the indictment.

The eighty-room French chateau built by the late Otto H. Kahn, financier, at Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., in 1917 at a reputed cost of $1,500,000, has been acquired by a group of parents of Eastern Military Academy students. The academy, formerly operated at Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn., will reconstruct the chateau as a school, according to an Announcement made here yesterday.

GENEVA, Aug. 16 The failure of governments to live up to their obligations toward the victims of Nazi persecution may condemn 200,000 persons to remain forever in refugee camps, Dr. Carl J. Hambroof Norway told the United Nations Economic and Social Council today.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- Harrison Dillard, the man who almost missed the boat, today ran 200 meters around a curve within one-tenth, of a second of the fastest time ever turned in as the American Olympic athletes won seven of ten events for men in the concluding session of the international meet with France for a total of sixteen out of twenty-one in two days.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 16 -- The New Jersey Legislature returned to work today and, while the Senate buckled down immediately to measures implementing the new State Constitution, the Assembly was confronted with an attempt to get immediate action on a veterans' bonus financed by a state lottery.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Preliminary figures released by the Army Corps of Engineers covering receipts and shipments in the Port of Chicago during 1947 shows a record high traffic volume for the year -- 26,521,868 tons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, Democratic candidate for Vice President, asserted today that he did not believe the Congressional investigations into alleged Communist spy rings would provide a campaign issue.

Banking syndicates headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association of San Francisco bought yesterday bond issues of four California school districts totaling $7,474,000.

Marcel Cerdan of France, the European middleweight titleholder, is scheduled to arrive from Paris by air next Monday to commence training for his world championship bout against Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., at Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City, on Sept. 21.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Alger Hiss, former State Department official and now president of the Carnegie Foundation for International Peace, admitted today, according to Representative Richard M. Nixon, that he knew the man who has accused him of being a leader in a pre-war Communist "underground" in Washington, but knew him as "George Crosley."

RENO, Nev., Aug. 17 -- Mrs. Anna N. Sanford of Huntington, L.I., won a divorce here today from Henry Sanford, Jr., of "Oldfields," in Huntington, on the ground of cruelty. The parties agreed on the custody of their child. Mrs. Sanford, before her marriage in Smithtown, L.I., in May, 1944, was Mrs. Anna Nicodemus Holmes.

Consolidated net sales of the B. F. Goodrich Company amounted to $197,688,828 for the initial six months of this year, a decrease of 1.8 per cent from the $201,283,642 volume transacted in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the semi-annual statement issued yesterday after a meeting of directors.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- One month after the fall of Robert Schuman's cabinet the National Assembly today finally accorded to the successor government of Premier Andre Marie the powers to effecth) 0*0*0*ithe economic and financial reforms that Paul Reynaud framed to head France toward fulfillment of the Marshall Plan.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 17 (AP) -- The only race here today without a claiming clause was the six-furlong Convention City Purse and a stirring finish came about with Woodland Farm Blue Fedora, a 13-1 shot, winning by a half length.

Restrictive regulations affecting the exhibition of American movies in England and France were reviewed yesterday by top industry leaders at an all-day meeting of the board of the Motion Picture Export Association, held in the offices of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, 444 West Fiftysixth Street.

The purchases of two parcels of land in Nassau County by builders for improvement with communities of one-family houses and the acquisition of a corner plot in the Flushing section of Queens for a garden apartment project were among the realty activities reported yesterday on Long Island.

Two per cent of the 500,000 persons who contribute to Foster Parents Plan for War Children are using relief as a political weapon, Mrs. Edna Blue, international chairman, reported yesterday. They have refused to help support maimed and semi-orphaned children in Communistdominated European countries, particularly Poland and Czechoslovakia, she said.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 -Uranium has been discovered in lonely, mountainous Marshall Canyon, north of Beaumont, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Truman Administration was accused today, in a Republican campaign attack, of having largely caused the present high prices by "bungling" in foreign affairs, including "coddling" of the Soviet Union.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The United Nations Commission on Conventional Armaments wound up its first eighteen months of work today with the United States and Russia trading accusations of guilt for a world arms race.
DUBLIN, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A group of United States Olympic track athletes won five of ten events today in a meet with Ireland and Australia. The American boxing team also triumphed over the Irish.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Count Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator for Palestine, has accepted a British donation of 100,000 (about $400,000) worth of tents and medical supplies for the relief of Arabs who fled from Israeli-controlled areas of Jerusalem; a British spokesman said today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong in the late trading yesterday, recovering from an early dip, and closed 8 to 15 points higher.

Three of John van Druten's plays, one of them the hugely successful "Voice of the Turtle," have been produced by Alfred de Liagre Jr. Both the playwright and producer have profited from an enjoyable association and they mean to continue on that basis without interruption.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -The Buffalo Bills defeated the Brooklyn Dodgers, 21 to 19, in an All-America Football Conference exhibition before a crowd of 27,630 in Civic Stadium tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Congress has committed the Government to outlays in the present fiscal year amounting to $512,000,000 more than President Truman requested, Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democrat, of Kentucky, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -American exports declined from $1,102,900,000 in May to $1,013,100,000 in June, a decline of $89,800,000, while general imports increased from $549,300,000 to $615,600,000,h)0*0*0*ia gain of $66,300,000, the Bureau of the Census, Department of Commerce, announced today.

An appeal to former Communists in this country to "come forward and tell what you know" was made last night by Miss Elizabeth Bentley, self-confessed former spy for a Russian ring during World War II in this country.
A lanky, lazy-looking, bald man with a smile leaned back in a swivel chair yesterday and calmly declared that he was the greatgreat-grandson of Rip Van Winkle.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -The Federal National Mortgage Association said today it is ready to buy GI housing mortgages insured by the Veterans Administration.

The failure of the Eightieth Congress to remove the existing discriminations from the Displaced Persons Act had echoes in Geneva this week at a meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Council. A Russian delegate cited these discriminations as proving that the United States had "selfish purposes in enacting the law."

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President, told a delegation of Americans of Italian extraction tonight that he favored giving Italy administrative control of its former African colonies under a United Nations trusteeship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -The Government-owned blast furnace and coke oven plant at Cleveland has been leased to the KaiserFrazer Corporation, of Willow Run, Mich., by the War Assets Administration.

What has occasioned the decision of the Justice Department to bring home after three years the American-born Japanese girl who broadcast to American troops on Radio Tokyo during the war we don't know. It apparently took someone a long time to decide that Iva Ikuko Toguri d'Aquino (she married a Portuguese resident of Japanh)0*0*0*ijust before the end of the war) was guilty of treason in her radio activities for the other side during the war.

Most of Charles H. Roe's arguments against the Taft Education bill are assertions not based in fact. For instance, he writes that in states where there is a low expenditure per pupil they just don't care to spend more for education.

The cancer that killed Babe Ruth originated in the naso-pharynx, a part of the air passages back of the nose, in a place near the under surface of the skull that is inaccessible to surgery when involved by cancer. This was determined yesterday for the first time after an autopsy, according to a statement issued by Memorial Hospital, where Ruth died Monday evening.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Work was resumed today on the partly completed battleship Kentucky. Her future, however, appears uncertain.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 17 -- A Swedish "Kosenkina case," involving a 19-year-old Russian girl, is developing in Stockholm. The story has caused a sensation in Sweden and was published on the front page of every newspaper.

Your V-J-Day editorial contained the courageous and wise observation: "Even a poor peace is better than a war." You pointed to the fact that "you cannot convince otherwise the men who had to do the fighting, * * * who were forced to the cruel necessity of killing other men."

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- A warning to owners and trainers of race horses: If you must drink chocolate milk, don't let your horse see you. He might wheedle enough from you to win a race and then you'd be called on the carpet of the Illinois Racing Board just as was Charles (Frenchy) Pinon this morning.

If ever a decision was faced by the New York City government that involved the larger good of the greater number of its people, it is the imminent choice of a program and agency for modernization of the waterfront. We are a city of the sea. It has been estimated that one person in every ten in the port district is dependent on the port, directly or indirectly, for his livelihood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -Russia is reducing its government personnel in this country, and is making life increasingly difficult for American officials in the Soviet Union, according to a report today in diplomatic quarters.
The fight between right and left wing elements within the Transport Workers Union, CIO -- until now apparent but not public -moved out into the open for the first time last night.

A Mutt and Jeff robbery team escaped yesterday with a small safe containing between $8,000 and $10,000 worth of jewelry from a nine-room private home in Riverdale after locking three women in a pantry closet.

The well-known office building at 44 Court Street, opposite the Brooklyn municipal offices, has been acquired by the Omnibus Realty Corporation, representing Elias A. Cohen, from the Bank of New York Trust Company, acting for an estate.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 17 -- The Soviet bloc in the General Committee of the Danubian Conference today forced through the final articles and the protocol of the Soviet draft convention after defeating a last attempt by the Americans, French and British delegations to throw a "spanner into the works."
The Greater New York Safety Council ran the gamut yesterday from flea, through baby chick, kitten and rabbit to bull, in listing the creatures that offer danger to the unwary vacationer.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17 (AP) -Argentine meat shipments to Britain have declined some 8,000 tons a month because of cattlemen's reluctance to sell beef at present prices.

" Where Words Fail" ("Donde Mueren Las Palabras"), an Argentinemade romantic drama with music, which arrives at the Fiftyfifth Street Playhouse, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Enrique Muino, Dario Garzay, Linda Lorena and Hector Mendez head the cast.

Capt. Joseph Lloyd McGuigan, USN, has been named chief of the Bureau of Engineering of the United States Maritime Commission, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds James L. Bates, who will retire early next month as head of the technical division of the Government agency.

Despite sales of imported lead here at 2 1/2 cents above the domestic market, shortages are getting worse and manufacturing consumers warned here yesterday that a critical shortage may develop next winter.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 17 -- A 7 1/2 per cent hourly wage increase was won for 1,500 workers in the mold-making department of seventy-two glass companies in negotiations that ended here today at the Hotel Brighton.

The Republican leadership in New York County is scheduled to reject a suggestion from high Tammany sources that the Republicans withdraw George Frankenthaler, nominee for Surrogate, and endorse John A. Mullen, the Democratic candidate, in return for which the Democrats would endorse Mr. Frankenthaler for the Supreme Court and thus insure his election.
GENEVA, Aug. 17 -- Ambassador Daria Wilgress of Canada was elected chairman of the meeting of the countries participating in the Geneva Agreement on Tariffs and Trade at today's session.

WRITING about Babe Ruth is akin to trying to paint a landscape on a postage stamp. The man was so vast, so complex and so totally incredible that he makes mere words so puny and insufficient. They say that truth is stranger than fiction. So was Ruth. No Hollywood scenarist would dare borrow fragments of the Babe's life for use in a plot.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, whose wartime genius helped bring freedom to the people of Western Europe, called his countrymen last night to a new campaign, bringing food to the world's underfed children.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- All Cooperstown, where baseball was born in 1839, mourned today the death of Babe Ruth. For to everyone in this community, from shopkeepers to the Mayor, Babe Ruth was a friend.

CHICAGO. Aug. 17 LP)JohnnySchmitz, willowy southpaw, mesmerized the Cardinals once again]today with his assortment of curve1balls as he hurled the Cubs to a4-2 victory and a split of the twogame series.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Following is the text of an Encyclical Letter issued by the Lambeth Conference:
TULSA, Okla., Aug. 17 -- The Oil and Gas Journal will report in this week's issue that "the oil shortage is over."
The Hospital Council of Greater New York yesterday termed psychiatric service a vital part of comprehensive medical care in the general hospital.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 17 -While New Jersey has "slightly more" than its share of the 750,000 chronic alcoholics in the United States, facilities for the treatment of alcoholism in this state were described today as "woefully inadequate" in a report to the New Jersey legislature.
Butter declined another 2 cents a pound in wholesale trade here yesterday. The change will be reflected in many retail stores this morning.
Babe Ruth went to the Yankee Stadium for the last time yesterday. He will lie in state there until this evening so that his fans may see him for the last time.
Considerable progress has been made in the last eleven months in eliminating congestion along the New York waterfront, it was reported here yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 17 (AP) -The Iranian Parliament approved today an amnestly measure for Azerbaijan Province at a stormy session marked by an attempt to drag Premier Abdul Hussein Hazhir from the speaker's box.

The death of Harry White, the former Treasury Department official who was accused before the Un-American Activities Committee of engaging in treasonable activities against his Government, has made it impossible for these charges ever to be fully answered. He alone could have done that.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The War Office announced today men of Britain's famed Guards Brigade and certain other troops would be sent to Malaya as soon as possible "to restore order and confidence."

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 17 -A luxurious sixty-five-foot yacht went aground on Greens Ledge in Norwalk Harbor, between Sheffield Island and Greens Reef Light, at 7:30 o'clock last night and was badly damaged as it struck Old Baldy Rocks.

New ballasting with crushed rock of eighteen and six-tenths more miles of track has been completed by the Long Island Rail Road, it was announced yesterday by David E. Smucker, general manager. Before the end of 1950 155 miles of roadbed will be ballasted with crushed rock, replacing cinders, at a cost of $2,331,000, as part of the road's $17,656,000 improvement program now under way.
All the material collected thus far in the city's milk-price inquiry was presented yesterday to Federal anti-trust authorities.

In your recent editorial on Arab refugees, your appeal to charity distorts justice. While not intending to withhold sympathy from the undoubted suffering of individual refugees, I feel that the full truth of the case should be presented.
MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Western diplomats conferred again at the Embassy today on the progress of their talks in the Kremlin on East-West differences.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Jockey Tony Skoronski checked in from Chicago today, took his first ride around the Saratoga race track and enjoyed himself immensely. So did those who had backed his mount, the Maine Chance Farm's Myrtle Charm, into 3-to-2 favoritism in the fifty-seventh edition of the Spinaway Stakes for 2-year-old fillies.

A strike of 15,000 workers in the textile dyeing and finishing industry in the New York metropolitan area, originally scheduled to begin at midnight tomorrow, was averted last night when an agreement between the workers and the 300 employers was reached after the personal intervention of Emil Rieve, general president of the Textile Workers Union of America, CIO.
Workers at two sample card shops chose unanimously yesterday to be represented by a rightwing Congress of Industrial Organizations union rather than by their present left-wing group.

Don't look now, but Langdon Mitchell's "The New York Idea" is still a fascinating play. Since it is drawing-room comedy from 1906, modern theatregoers are supposed to look down upon it from a lofty altitude and regard it as quaint.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- The Russians are preparing the police of the Eastern sector of Berlin for duty in the Western sectors of the city in pursuit of a policy of winning complete political and economic control of this former German capital.

Frederick Brown has purchased the industrial property at 999 Saw Mill River Road, Yonkers, N.Y., from the Suntex Corporation. It comprises a one-story structure on a plot of 23,000 square feet, fronting about 200 feet on the Saw Mill River Road.
The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations to the voters in five contests for nomination to the State Legislature which will be settled at the primary election on Aug. 24.

BAILEY ISLAND, Me., Aug. 17 -- After spending four days watching fifty anglers competing in an effort to bring in enough tuna to tip the scales lower than the next man, we are firmly convinced that such competitions are decided by 90 per cent luck and 10 per cent skill.
C. S. Brach has been appointed cost and price manager of the specialties division of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company.

h)0*0*0*iCAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 17 -- Delegates of the Arab countries to the September session of the United Nations General Assembly will meet first in one of the Arab capitals to work out a united stand on Palestine and other issues, it was reported reliably today.

Fifty delegates to the first Y.W.C.A. international study conference on women and world reconstruction, which opens today at Teachers College, Columbia University, were welcomed yesterday at a reception in their honor at the headquarters of the Y.W.C.A. National Board, 600 Lexington Avenue.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 17 -At the centers of stars of great intrinsic brilliance there may exist small cores of extremely high density where the building of the elements in the universe takes place.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 17 -- The economy of Western Germany has improved so much since the currency reform that most of the incentive program for the Ruhr miners will be discontinued by Sept. 1, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the United States Military Governor, disclosed today.

The board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association turned down yesterday the request of the twelve unions representing its employes for the setting up of a system of social security. The board continued to maintain the position that it could not undertake a season of opera for the coming fall and winter unless the unions accepted the contracts that had prevailed last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator for Palestine, earnestly appealed to this country today to aid 337,000 refugees from the battles between Israel and the Arabs in Palestine. His communication, sent to Secretary of State Marshall, followed a message of the same general character received at Lake Success yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Twentyfour thousand workers in six plants of the International Harvester Company, including 4,000 at the Melrose Park Works near Chicago, walked out at 8 A.M. today as a result of a disagreement over grievance, time study, apprenticeship and arbitration issues.
The two big pro basketball outfits -- the Basketball Association of America and the National Basketball League -- are on the outs again.
