TEL AVIV, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The Israeli Supreme Court refused today to free two dissident leaders who took part in an attempt to land arms illegally from the ship Altalena during the truce two months ago.

Russeks' retail fur sales since the start of August promotions are 3.4 per cent ahead of last year, it was disclosed yesterday by David Nemerov, president. The gain is for all Russeks' stores inh)0*0*0*iNew York, Brooklyn, and Chicago.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Bishops of the world-wide Anglican Communion, meeting for the first time in eighteen years, found the menace of Communism to Christianity to be their greatest theme. This will appear clear to the layman from the encyclical, resolutions and committee reports, published today after deliberations in London from July 5 to Aug. 8.
Your editorial "Indians as Voters" on Aug. 5 was a distinct service to a public still woefully uninformed about the status, rights and problems of these almost forgotten first Americans.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -Twice-a-week pro football was envisioned today by two of the AllAmerica Conference's club leaders.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Communist-led insurgents captured the Rangoon Superintendent of Police today in a bold attack on Government motorboats at Syriam, fifteen miles east of the capital, Government officials admitted.

NANKING, Aug. 17 -- Communist forces foiled Gen. Fu Tso-yi's month-long "mopping up" campaign in eastern Hopeh and moved north, cutting two railways, and penetrated eastern Chahar in Inner Mongolia, according to today's news dispatches from Peiping.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 17 -- For the second time since he was defeated in the May election, former Prime Minister Jan Christian Smuts was busy today endeavoring to prevent the disruption of his United party, on which he must depend if he is to remain a potent figure in Parliament.

Several transfusions of blood have been given Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina, who leaped last Thursday from a third-story window of the Soviet consulate, it was disclosed yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. It was announced, at the same time, that X-rays taken on Monday showed injuries more extensive than could be determined when the Russian schoolteacher was first taken to the hospital.

Restoration of Governmental controls on consumer credit will result in substantial ales drops in several important home furnishings items, retailers predicted yesterday. They said that automatic electric washers, television receivers and expensive console radio combinations will be hardest hit, with sales of refrigerators and furniture dropping to lesser degree.

A derivative stockholders' suit filed in Federal Court yesterday asked that fifteen present and former officers and directors of theh)0*0*0*iUnited States Lines Company be required to account for losses which the company allegedly suffered as the result of a stock-purchase plan put into effect in November, 1943.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- A little coal mining town thirty miles from Pittsburgh today inherited millions of dollars left to it by a wealthy Philadelphia woman.

Consummation of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission's revenue bond financing yesterday saw the new long-term 3 1/4s continuing to approximate the one-point premium over issue price, while the old 2 1/2 per cent issue, now transformed pending retirement from a "revenue" to a "money" bond, was offered at 107 3/4, a yield basis of about 1.20 per cent to call.
Savings deposits in New York State savings banks declined in July for the first time in seventy-two months, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -Two banking groups have been awarded $14,589,000 of short-term loan notes by twelve housing authorities, the Public Housingh)0*0*0*iAdministration announced today.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The international scope of the Girl Guides and Girl Scouts twelfth biennial world conference being held here was emphasized today when women of three continents were elected to its world committee.

OTTAWA, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) -- The 1948 wheat crop for all Canada is estimated at 372,000,000 bushels, the Bureau of Statistics said today. This is 31,000,000 bushels greater than last year's crop but about 35,000,000 bushels below the 1938-47 average.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Four Russian newspaper men today accused the French of falsifying the death toll of the July 28 chemical plant explosion at Ludwigshafen, in the French zone. The correspondents said 628 persons were killed rather than 223, as officially announced.

The Danube Conference in Belgrade, proposed by the United States in an attempt not only to establish free and open navigation on Europe's principal waterway but also to solve the issues between Russia and the West on a piecemeal basis, is drawing to a close a total failure on both counts.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Mental specialists and psychologists should seek at once to influence the "framers of society" -- and especially the writers of tax laws -- Dr. Margaret Mead, associate Curator of Ethnology at the American Museum of Natural History, New York, told the International Conference of Mental Hygiene here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Registration statements covering 316,863 shares of common and 31,000 shares of capital stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.
A note of concern over the future welfare of disabled ex-service men was sounded yesterday onh)0*0*0*ithe second day of the twenty-seventh national convention of the Disabled American Veterans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -An over-all quota of 126,400 draft deferments for college students enrolled in reserve officer training programs has been assigned by Secretary of Defense Forrestal.

A technical rebound of sizable proportions yesterday lifted the stock market out of its stalemated condition and produced the second widest gains so far this month. The recovery on the Stock Exchange was sustained through the session and encompassed most major sections.

A banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and the Central Republic Company, Inc., will place on the market today a block of common stock of Central Illinois Public Service Company valued at $7,893,696 and representing about 25.74 per cent of the company's outstanding common shares.

A tall, gaunt man, who sold his up-state farm four years ago when he contracted a lung ailment, and his wife, who has been caring for him ever since, wept yesterday in mid-Manhattan Court as they pleaded for a summons against city authorities who, they said, had refused to give them home relief.

Exporters of apples, pears and grapes to South America are asking State Department action to bring about lifting of the "embargo" against these fruits in Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay, it was learned here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Grain markets showed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today and closing trades were about the bottom. September corn, which advanced fractionally early on professional buying, led the decline, breaking 2 3/4 cents a bushel from the top and closing with a net loss of 2 cents, with other deliveries off 3/4 to 1 1/8 cents.

The Third Avenue Transit Corporation reported yesterday that operations in the second quarter of this year resulted in a loss of $1,344,798, compared with a loss of $490,869 in the same period last year.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 (AP) -The bankrupt Electronic Laboratories, Inc., was sold in three parts at an auction today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- Neither the Phillies nor the 20,632 fans who watched them take a 10-1 beating at Shibe Park tonight soon will forget the extraordinary exhibition of base-running the Dodgers put on, nor the seven errors into which the locals were forced by the Dodger speed and daring.

h) 0*0*0*iDETROIT, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Rookie Ted Gray pitched his third straight victory tonight as the Tigers outlasted the White Sox, 6 to 4, before 35,430 fans. Gray needed the help of Relief Pitcher Virgil Trucks and Stubby Overmire to gain the decision over Chick Pieretti.

From our conversation with interested persons we conclude that many American creditors of German Reichsmark debtors are not sufficiently familiar with a phase of the recent German currency legislation by which American creditors are deprived of 90 per cent of their rights -- unless they act promptly.
PARIS, Aug. 17 -- American Olympic track and field and swimming squads competing here the last three days against France broke up into smaller parties today and fanned out over Europe.
The spell that Bill Voiselle has exercised over the Giants ever since he swapped his New York uniform for the regalia of the Braves remained in dire effect last night.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 -- Richard F. Walsh, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, AFL, asserted today that Russia was "doing everything possible" to bring on a third world war.

HARROGATE, England, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Gertrude G. Huitt, an Illinois lawyer, told the World Conference of Soroptimist Clubs today that the United States now had "a world point of view which America certainly did not have before the war."

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 17 -Miss Polly Andrews of Innis Arden not only captured her first-round match in the women's Westchester and Fairfield golf championship, but she also won the play-off for the qualifying medal over the Greenwich Country Club course today.

h) 0*0*0*iA 70-year-old landlady who had cited her own ill health as her reason for seeking to evict a tenant and take over his apartment, died of a heart attack yesterday in a hearing room of the City Rent Commission at 500 Park Avenue.

Only the naive will doubt that spies from many nations besides those cur're'ntly being exposed by the Un-Amer, ican Activities Committee infest our governmental departments seeking inside knowledge of our plans. Nor will anyone of average intelligence doubt that we too use secret agents/for ferreting out the plans of possible enemy countries.

One who was enabled this summer by a set of curious chances to occupy the country home (fully furnished) of a husband and wife, total strangers to him, who were summering elsewhere, was almost dissuaded from doing so by the fear that their unknown personalities, peeping, ghostlike, from amid alien Lares and Penates, might haunt him so disagreeably as to make theh)0*0*0*iplace unendurable to him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Truman joined 24,000 fans of the capital tonight to honor 78-year-old Clark Griffith, who was rounding out sixty years in baseball, and then remained to see the Yankees put on quite a demonstration of their own.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The committee to formulate a program for consideration by the North Atlantic Ports Conference date in September was named today. It was authorized at a recent meeting of representatives ofh)0*0*0*iNorth Atlantic ports and railroads serving them.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Board of Trade officials met with a deputation of the Tobacco Workers Union here today to discuss the cigarette shortage, which has reached famine proportions in many parts of the country.
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 17 (UP) -- The United States and Canada pledged continued cooperation on defense today following discussions in Ottawa.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll and Mrs. T. U. Lyman of Maplewood, defending champions, were pushed to an extra hole today before moving into the final round of the second annual four-ball match play championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at Crestmont Country Club.

A distinct post-Olympic atmosphere prevailed at La Guardia Airport yesterday as athletes from Peru, Chile and the United States arrived at intervals from London, scene of the fourteenth Olympiad of the modern era. This was the biggest day so far for returning Olympians, fifty-two debarking from American Overseas and PanAmerican Airlines planes.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, told the City Planning Commission yesterday that his institution needed $3,963,500h)0*0*0*iin capital funds for a new arts and student center building, including an auditorium, to complete its campus.
Johnny Mikrut of the Shore View Club fashioned a 33, 36 -- 69 for low gross honors in the oneday golf tourney of the Metropolitan Golf Association over the Oakland Golf Club in Bayside yesterday.

Big city display methods will help country housewives make extra pin money next summer under plans of the Woman's Council, New York State Department of Commerce. Specifications for a highstyle roadside stand that could in itself stop traffic were released yesterday at headquarters of the group, 342 Madison Avenue.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 17 -- In damage suits totaling $180,000 filed here today. Mayor Howard N. Deyo of Montclair and Walter T. Ackerly, also a resident of the town, are charged with having indirectly hastened the death in the Mountainside Hospital of J. Frank Flynn, 81 years' old, retired Montclair High School building superintendent.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Individual protests, but no organized opposition, greeted today the announcement of an increase in gas rates of the Westchester Lighting Company amounting to 31.61 per cent over-all, or $3,200,000 a year.
An Italian motor-boat reportedly capable of making more than 100 miles per hour arrived on the liner Sobieski yesterday en route to Detroit for the International Gold Cup race Aug. 28.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 17 -- The International Typographical Union Convention rejected today a proposal, which in effect would have censured the officers' handling ofh) 0*0*0*ithe union's defense fund.

ZEIST, the Netherlands, Aug. 17 -- A policy statement designed to establish and maintain permanent lines of communication between the Protestant and Orthodox churches of the world and international political bodies like the United Nations was adopted here today at the first full session of the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs since its formation, in 1946.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 17 Audiences in this country not only will get a full radio account of the General Assembly's session in Paris next month, but may even see the historic United Nations events on television.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 (AP) -Only one of the five foreign entries, Frank Sedgman of Australia, remained in the Newport Casino's singles tennis competition today after third-round matches reduced the bulky starting field to the round of 16.
DODGE CITY, Kan., Aug. 17 -- A "temperance tornado" struck Kansas tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein, Chief of the Imperial General Staff appealed today for the recruitment of 150,000 men and women for the Territorial Army -- Britain's National Guard -- before next spring.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, defending champion, came from behind today for a 2-and-1 victory over youthful Bee MacWane of Salt Lake City in the first round of the Trans-Mississippi women's amateur golf championship.

The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday a new high record for sales and earnings for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 12, increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock and noted that its over-all production today is higher than ever before.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -There was a fever of activity at all three Western embassies today,h)0*0*0*iespecially at the British where typists, Russian experts, cipher clerks and radio men were at work on the long full report of the three-and-a-half-hour meeting.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 -- Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, today taxed the Truman Administration with following the policy that "the public is too dumb to understand" important questions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Truman acted today to avert an imminent strike in the eastern maritime industry that threatened to tie up all shipping along the Atlantic Coast.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -By a vote that was virtually unanimous, the Film Actors of Hollywood have again gone on record in favor of continuing long-established union shop conditions in the motion picture studios.

July dollar sales of home furnishings in independent furniture stores throughout the country increased 9 per cent compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the monthly survey of the National Retail Furniture Association released yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Great Britain's coal exports both to the Marshall Plan countries and to other foreign customers have passed the half-way mark for the year, it was announced today byh)0*0*0*ithe National Coal Board.
An unexpected family reunion will take place today when the Marine Sparrow docks at Pier 95, North River.

Prices of gas-engine pump combinations are being raised by distributor here because engine prices have been increased varying amounts from 5 to 15 per cent. A. D. Nass, president of Steeltex Company, pump distributor, 754 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, revealed here yesterday.

Zot I. Chepurnykh, the Soviet Vice Consul here, issued a statement last night to give what he called the correct version of his visit last Friday to the bedside ofh)0*0*0*iMrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina at Roosevelt Hospital.

PRAGUE, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The United States took nine of ten first places today in the first session of a track and field meet among athletes of four nations. Finland, Czechoslovakia and Italy competed. The meet attracted a crowd of 45,000 -- the largest ever assembled for a track and field event here.

Prices of gas-engine pump combinations are being raised by distributor here because engine prices have been increased varying amounts from 5 to 15 per cent. A. D. Nass, president of Steeltex Company, pump distributor, 754 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, revealed here yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- A renewed steady rain in many districts of Britain today again interrupted the gathering of crops already heavily damaged by storms and overdue for harvesting.

Zot I. Chepurnykh, the Soviet Vice Consul here, issued a statement last night to give what he called the correct version of his visit last Friday to the bedside ofh)0*0*0*iMrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina at Roosevelt Hospital.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (AP) --h)0*0*0*iGene Bearden hurled his fourth shut-out and Ken Keltner rapped three hits tonight as the leagueleading Indians hiked their margin to two full games over the rainedout Athletics with an 8-0 victory over the Browns before 55,858 Municipal Stadium fans.
The call money rate has been increased for the first time since the summer of 1946, it was learned yesterday. The advance brought the new level to 1 3/4 per cent from 1 1/2 per cent.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Still undefeated after seven rounds, George Kramer of Queens, 1945 New York State champion, went into the lead today after defeating Paul Poschel ofh)0*0*0*iChicago in forty-two moves in the championship tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation at the Community Center.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Truman deplored today the "alarming" increase in industrial, traffic and domestic accidents and said he was doing his utmost to bring a halt to the trend.

On a huge, breeze-swept playground in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the Kingsborough athletes won yesterday on its home ground the first Junior Olympics of the New York City Youth Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Officials of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company and of representatives of holders of its securities appeared today before J. V. Walsh, an examinerh)0*0*0*ifor the Interstate Commerce Commission, in support of a plan for adjustment of the railroad's debt structure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Events of the next week or ten days will determine whether President Truman will go into the 1948 Presidential campaign with the formal support of organized labor, it was learned today.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Business in the stock market here today was confined to leveling up commitments before the opening of the new account tomorrow.

FITZWILLIAM, N.H., Aug. 17 -- Harry Dexter White, one of the world's foremost authorities on international monetary matters, and a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury who became a key figure in the Congressional investigation of Communist spy rings, died here yesterday on his farm of a heart attack. He was 56.

TUSKEGEE INSTITUTE, Ala., Aug. 17 -- Teachers of vocational education among Negroes in the South today praised their own folk for community betterment but took exception to higher pay for equal work, when done by white teachers.

ATHENS, Aug. 17 -- Greek Nationalist troops were continuing their general northward advance today following their successes at Aetomilitsa, Lykorrachi and Zerma, all of which they wrested earlier from the tight grip of the rebels.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Aug. 17 (AP) -- An official Trans-Jordan statement tonight said the Arab Legion had thrown back a heavy Israeli attack on legion positions in southern Jerusalem and killed "several hundred" Israeli troopers.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 17 (AP) -While all Baltimore today mourned the death of Babe Ruth and the flag at City Hall flew at half staff, the school where the baseball idol started his career was the center of interest.
ATHENS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Theh)0*0*0*iGreek Army announced new gains today in its tortuous advance into the rugged Grammos Mountains.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 17 -The State of Israel rolled out the red carpet today for Pavel I. Yershov, Minister of the Soviet Union, who presented his credentials at Hakirya, Israel's White House.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Two self-exiled Czechoslovakia Olympic swimmers reported today they had received permisson from the British Government to remain indefinitely in England. They were among eight Czechoslovakia and Hungarian competitors in the Olympics who had indicated their intention of not returning home.
Hope for a settlement of issues by the 60,000-man National Maritime Union, CIO, with employers on the Atlantic and Gulf Coastsh) 0*0*0*igrew brighter here last night.

Sixty-four freckles, clustered in one square inch on the left cheek of 9-year-old Edith Fitzer, were enough to declare her Queen of the Thirteenth Annual Freckle Contest conducted yesterday by the Children's Aid Society.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- The deadlock among European leaders over the division of dollar credits will prevent the rapid common action under the Marshall Plan that Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, urged when here, in the opinion of officials of several of the principal nations involved.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Seven of the eight quarterfinal brackets were filled for the twenty-first Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament today with the eighth left open for an extra day in deference to a sore arm suffered by one of the tourney's seeded stars.

ATHENS, Aug. 17 (UP) -- United States Air Secretary W. Stuart Symington and Air Force Chief Lieut. Gen. Hoyt Vandenburg conferred here secretly with leaders of the United States military mission in Greece last week-end, it was disclosed today.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Although growers have complained that cold nights and rain would prevent them from having flowers to exhibit, the fourth annual Eastern International Gladiolus show opened in Kalurah Temple today with the largest display in the show's history.

WARSAW, Aug. 17 -- Prof. Eugene Tarle, Soviet historian, and Prof. Sergei I. Vavilov, president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, were announced today as leaders of the Russian delegation to a World Congress of Intellectuals in Wroclaw [Breslau] Aug. 25-28.
A prison sentence of one to two and one-half years was imposed yesterday on Gus Fusaro, the $47a-week elevator starter convicted of losing $122,000 of his friends' money in stock market speculations.

Roger ercel's new novel, "Northern Lights," will be publistied by RandomHouse on Sept. 10.-It: is a story of lov and adventure set in the frozen north, centering about the son of an' Arctic scientist. Mr. Vercel is the author of "The Tides of Mount St. Michel" and "Madman's Menory,"

High food costs will be analyzed from the standpoint of the average housewife rather than in terms of economic theory in "The Hungry Dollar," a four-program documentary to be presented on WNBC next month. Exact dates and times are to be announced later.

ATHENS, Aug. 17 (UP) -- United States Air Secretary W. Stuart Symington and Air Force Chief Lieut. Gen. Hoyt Vandenburg conferred here secretly with leaders of the United States military mission in Greece last week-end, it was disclosed today.

The reports from Belgrade indicate that the Danube Conference is apparently another failure, in line with almost all previous meetings aimed at settling the complicated international problems cropping up in a "still disordered world."

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Only through a Republican victory in November can America be united to solve the problems created by the Democratic party during the past sixteen years, Gov. Earl Warren of California said tonight in his first campaign speech since he was nominated for the vice Presidency.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The hopes of the two-man Czechoslovak Davis Cup tennis team for victory in the inter-zone finals were revived today when they noted their luck in the draw for the opening singles matches with the favored Australian forces.

Thirty-two thousand four hundred Veterans of World War II reinstated their National Service Life Insurance term policies before the July 31 deadline in the New York branch area -- New York State and Puerto Rico -- the Veterans Administration here announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall indicated today that the United States in an early note to the Soviet Union would denounce as absurd and baseless the Russian accusations against American authorities in the cases of two Russian refugee school teachers in New York.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 18 -- The Danubian conference ended today at 5:30 P.M. in a dazzling display by the Soviet bloc of its seven votes against zero.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- One of Czechoslovakia's most popular women, Mrs. Marie Provaznikova, 57-year-old leader of the Czechoslovak women's contingent at the Olympic games, declared today that she would not return home but would seek asylum in the United States.

Crude oil output in the United States last week established a new peak of 5,507,050 barrels daily, an increase of 2,500 over the previous record of 5,504,550 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute: A year ago, production averaged 5,159,150 barrels daily.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- The French Cabinet today decided to name a delegation in support of the proposal for the creation of a European Parliament as an official aftermath of the unofficial European Federation Conference held recently at The Hague.

Chester B. Duryea, who thirty-four years ago killed his millionaire father in Brooklyn and told the police "the angels told me to do it," died yesterday morning in the South Side Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I.

WILMETTE, Ill., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Interim, sailed by Warner Wilcox of western Long Island Sound, N.Y., today won the first eight-mile race in the 110 class international yacht regatta's second day of competition.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A wild throw by Virgil Stallcup allowed Red Schoendienst to score with the winning run in the last of the ninth to give the Cardinals a 4-to-3 victory over the Reds tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The National Labor Relations Board, in a decision officially described as its most significant under unfair labor practice provisions of the Taft-Hartley Labor-Management Relations Act, ruled today that the union hiring hall as operated by the National Maritime Union on the Great Lakes was illegal.

Wall Street made another entry yesterday in the long roll of transfers of investments in what were once family-held enterprises to the public community of investors. This time it was $5,075,000 of common stock of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., marketed as a secondary distribution by Morgan Stanley Co. and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- George T. Christopher of Detroit, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, said today the automobile industry will finish 1948 with a still unfilled demand for 4,500,000 cars.

Parents should "go to day camp with their children." This theory, advanced by the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women and voiced by the co-chairman of its Council Day Camp, Mrs. Leon Stern and Mrs. Julius B. Friedman, was tested yesterday by parents of several of the 128 Bronx children on "parents visiting day" at the day camp.

For a considerable period of time have been meaning to write a letter expressing my gratification to THE TIME for the manner in which, generally you have distinguished between "Jew and "Zionist" in your representation o the Palestine situation.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Swedish Foreign Office said today it had renewed its warning to the Russians to keep away from 19-year-old Lydia Makarova, the "Swedish Kosenkina."

GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- The position of labor in countries where the government is the sole employer should be a matter of concern to the United Nations, Willard Thorp, United States delegate, told the Economic and Social Council today.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Two thieves held up the Floral Park Savings and Loan Association in the heart of this village at 1:20 P.M. today, herded the vice president and three tellers to the rear of the bank and escaped with $14,302.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 18 -- A 28-year-old public links golfer from Bridgeport, Conn., Julius Boros, stole the spotlight in the metropolitan district's qualifying test for the national amateur championship over the Deepdale course by scoring 135 for a new low for thirty-six hole trials in this area.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The National Military Establishment called upon Americans today to learn the proper measures against radioactive atomic warfare while there is still peace.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The New York Yankees snapped back from a 14-7 half-time deficit with three third-quarter touchdowns to beat the Chicago Rockets, 35 -- 27, in an All-America Conference football exhibition tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Prices of grains and lard declined sharply today on the Board of Trade. December corn and all deliveries of soybeans and lard sold at new seasonal low prices, and the markets showed little disposition to rally.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Carolyn A., named for Eddie Arcaro's daughter and ridden by Master Eddie, won the $10,000 added Diana Handicap at Saratoga today as Miss Grillo failed by a length in a grand bid for her third success in the stake.

A sharp upturn in the sales of oil burners is expected by equipment manufacturers during the last half of this year, although sales for the first six months were only 28.8 per cent of 1947 totals, it was declared here yesterday.

As Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina fought in an oxygen tent for her life last night, the Roosevelt Hospital physician who has been attending her invited Jacob M. Lomakin, Soviet Consul General here, to send a surgeon of his own choice for a full report and consultation.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 -- Deploring exchange restrictions which have caused "a sullen passiveness' between American and British film industries Thomas O'Brien, a Labor member of the British Parliament, called today for an international council to harmonize motion-picture making in the two nations.

The Economic and Social Council of the United Nations showed small faith in the generosity of the people of the world when it voted at Geneva to wash its hands of administrative responsibility for coordinating the world appeal for voluntary contributions to the International Children's Emergency Fund.

At least 15,000 new or almost new passenger automobiles are standing idle in used-car lots throughout the state awaiting the highest bidders, Charles D. Henderson, executive vice president of the New York State Automobile Dealers, declared yesterday.

It is consoling to read in THE TIMES of Aug. 10 that the House Public Lands Committee and the subcommittee headed by Representative Barrett have agreed to recommend that national forest lands should remain in Federal ownership.

A plan recently offered to the Economic Cooperation Administration, under which the agency would act directly to free blocked dollar exchange credits due American exporters in Latin America, was endorsed yesterday by the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association, Inc.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 18 -- More than a score of German experts from all states of the three Western zones wrote into the preliminary draft of the constitution, on which they are working today, a recommendation that the future German state share its sovereignty with "a higher community."

Bringing to reality a century-old dream of the steel industry, the Republic Steel Corporation of Cleveland and the Babcock Wilcox Tube Company of New York have developed a method and a simple machine that will revolutionize steel-making in this country, it was announced yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The Kensico Cemetery Corporation, operator of a burial ground near Valhalla, applied here today to Supreme Court Justice J. Gordon Flannery for permission to sell 73.84 acres of its property to the Hillbrook Cemetery Corporation, a new organization, but opposition came from the State Attorney General's office.

The three-story brownstone dwelling at 272 West Eighty-fourth Street, near West End Avenue, has been sold by Victor H. Lindlahr to Norman Brokenshire, a radio commentator, who insured title with the Home Title Guaranty Company.

PRAGUE, Aug. 18 (AP) -- America's Olympic athletes took six of nine first places today to complete a near sweep of the two-day international track and field meet. They won nine of ten events yesterday, making their over-all total fifteen victories in nineteen contests.

T. John McKee, who lived as a white man for forty-five years until last March when he became a claimant to the $800,000 estate of his grandfather, a wealthy Negro Civil War veteran, died on Aug. 4, it became known yesterday.

Under the benign influence of a good pitching job by Sheldon Jones, the Giants perked up the other phases of their game and handed the league-leading Braves an 8-to-2 trimming at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

One youth received a minor butlet wound in the left arm, another dived into the East River and vanished, two others were captured and a fifth got away from the police after an early-morning automobile chase through Astoria, Queens, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman, roving Ambassador for the Marshall Plan, today designated himself as chief of the special foreign aid mission to Germany's bizonal area and appointed Norman H. Collisson as his deputy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Five towns and one village in northern Westchester County are entering into a contractual agreement to retain a staff of planning technicians, Hugh R. Pomeroy, County Director of Planning, said today.

A feeble attempt was made yesterday by the stock market to extend the previous day's recovery, but further selling of limited proportion in the afternoon nullified the effort. Neither the early buying nor the scattered offerings later carried any force on the Stock Exchange and gains of a point or more were reserved for a few issues, while the composite rate showed a lift of 0.29 point on the day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The War Assets Administration disclosed today that the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, automobile manufacturer, of Willow Run, Mich., has received an option to purchase the steel producing facilities now operated by the Republic Steel Corporation for $14,200,000.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Every daily newspaper in Moscow today took up the case of Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina, Russian school teacher who lies critically hurt in a New York hospital after jumping from a third-floor window in the Soviet Consulate there.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 18 -- The Ministry of the Interior issued a communique today announcing that Col. Gen Arso Yovanovitch, former Chief of Staff, was shot and killed by a frontier guard early in the morning of Aug. 12 while attempting to flee into Rumania with two other high officers.

When the housewife must pay more than $1 a pound for steak, she has a right to expect top quality. This is the sentiment of Alfred Heiman, who owns the Grand Royal food markets at 631 Park Avenue and 1289 Lexington Avenue. It's more than just a matter of opinion with this grocer, though, it's a policy that he carries out in both establishments.

Furniture dollar volume in department and home furnishings stores from July 26 to date is running from 10 to 30 per cent ahead of the comparable August sale period last year, retailers reported yesterday. In many small independent stores, however, volume is either behind last year or barely even because of a slow start in the first two weeks, it was disclosed.

ROME, Aug. 18 -- The United States Embassy issued an urgent appeal today to all Americans whose property in Italy was sequestrated during the war and who had not yet filed applications for restitution to do so without delay.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 18 -- President Juan Naticilio Gonzalez said in an interview this morning that it was impossible to expect Paraguay or any other country to achieve true democracy when a large percentage of the populace was impoverished.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- On the eve of its new order curbing consumer credit, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight that American families had been saving less money and in 28 per cent of the cases, spending be- yond their income.
The United States Civil Service Commission announced yesterday the first Loyalty Board appointments for the second region, covering New York and New Jersey.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP) -- A sore arm forced Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of La Jolla, Calif., seeded second, to default her third-round match to Miss Betty Rosenquest of South Orange. N.J., today when wet courts forced a twenty-four-hour postponement of the singles competition in the Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tourney.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Representative Michael J. Kirwan of Ohio charged today that Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican House leader, spoke from "hindsight" in attacking the foreign policy of the Roosevelt-Truman Administration.

The Cities Service Company, holding company for oil concerns and public utilities, called yesterday for redemption on Oct. 1, $5,000,000 of its 5 per cent gold debentures due in 1958, at 102, as provided in the indenture.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Three of the six leaders in the United States chess championship at the Community Center advanced in the eighth round today. The notable exception was George Kramer of Queens, the 1945 New York State champion, who dropped from a tie for second to fifth place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The issuance of new Treasury savings notes, Series D, on Sept. 1, and termination of the sale of Series C notes on Aug. 31, was, announced today by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, announced yesterday that eighty-one new parking lots accommodating a total of 5,807 automobiles had been opened under a zoning amendment effective May 13.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The growth of production councils based on joint participation by the United States and Marshall Plan countries was advocated today by two labor advisers to the Economic Cooperation Administration.

Harriette Harra features slim lines in her fall and winter collection presented yesterday on the third floor salon of Stein Blaine. She does not ignore skirt fullness but she handles it so that it is never conspicuous, nor does it interfere with her design.

Isadore Landau, a garment union official, was returning along Eighth Avenue to his office about 5 P.M. yesterday, his coat pocket filled with shop complaints, when a presser's iron, falling from the eighth floor of 265 West Thirty-seventh Street, hit and killed him.

PARIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- France made the first official move by any nation toward setting up a Parliament of Europe when she decided to invite the Governments of five Western states to a preparatory conference.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- A contribution of $500 was made here tonight at the twelfth biennial world conference of the Girl Guides and Girl Scouts by the local committee. Mrs. H.S. Fenimore Cooper, who heads the local conference committee, said that the funds were collected so that the movie, "World Friendship," on the Girl Guide and Scout encampment here, could be distributed free of charge to other countries.

The New York City Government is now operating two parking lots, one on the old World's Fair site in Queens and the other in downtown Brooklyn on a cleared site intended eventually for the proposed Civic Center. Policemen are assigned to the operation, and others are on duty near by to direct the increased traffic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Sixty fledgling baseball players from North Carolina called at the White House today and got some advice from President Truman on how to be good losers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Truce observers, numbering 300 men from the armed forces of this country, France and Belgium, will be sent to Palestine, following a request by Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator, Secretary of State Marshall disclosed at a news conference today.

In your editorial of Aug. 10 you rightly praise the Greeks, the oldest democracy in the world, for their resistance to communism. You write: "The credit for this achievement goes first of all to the Greek people, who, in contrast to other East-European nations, refused to bow to a Communist tyranny after experiencing its horrors in their midst."

There are five ways small business companies can raise capital, despite the tightening of capital from normal sources, Leo M Cherne, executive secretary and treasurer, Research Institute America, Inc., 292 Madison Avenue, revealed here yesterday following disclosure of its latest survey of business credit methods.

Three Queens bus Companies told the Public Service Commission yesterday they would operate at a deficit even if they received a temporary fare increase to 7 cents. They are among fourteen private companies seeking permanent fares of 8 cents or higher.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- A new deadlock within the United Nations Military Staff Committee, which for more than two years has been trying to reach agreement on the establishment of an international police force, was reported to the Security Council today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 18 -- A stenographic report of the deliberations of the German Minister-Presidents of the Western zones a few days before they formally accepted the authorization to initiate a West German regime shows that the state chiefs were in agreement with the original six-power decisions in London.

A $32,000,000 contract for the construction of three round-the-world passenger-cargo liners for the American President Lines has been awarded to the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N.J., the Maritime Commission announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Department of Agriculture officially forecast for Europe today a food situation markedly improved by what may be some of the best crops during or since the war.

Eleven of the twelve unions representing employes at the Metropolitan Opera held meetings yesterday or Tuesday to decide whether they would accept status quo contracts for next season, thereby insuring continuance of opera at the Metropolitan.

A coordinated drive by the liquor industry and state control authorities to make package-store and tavern-license requirements more stringent and uniform throughout the country is being launched nationally, it was learned here yesterday.
NANKING, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A report that President Chiang Kaishek would cast off China's new cloak of democracy and rule by dictatorial decree in the deepening crisis was denied officially today.

Indicted by a Federal grand jury in Trenton, N.J., Nye A. Wimer, a stock promoter, surrendered to the United States Marshal in Los Angeles on Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. He is accused of conspiring to defraud dozens of mining stock investors in at least six states of an estimated $45,000.

Hezekiah Cobb says that never in his memory of many years has there been, down in his country, so long a vacation from the August heat. He hears, he adds, that the people from the city who nowadays play at being country squires in so many of the old plantation houses they have dolled up for that purpose have been lighting fires on the hearth in the evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- The season's largest night crowd at a National League game here, 26,720, gave Rex Barney as big a burst of cheers as ever he received at Ebbets Field, when the young ace right-hander trotted off the field tonight after having held the Phils to one hit for a 1-0 Dodger victory.

A Congressional subcommittee will investigate the affairs of the American Guild of Variety Artists, an affiliate of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, the parent American Federation of Labor body governing all entertainment unions, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Truman will carry his reelection campaign to all sections of the country and will be on the road almost continuously from mid-September until just before the November election.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The Soviet Union cast its twenty-seventh veto today to defeat Ceylon s application for membership in the United Nations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 18 -- A jeep load of United States officers, all United Nations observers, had to "hit the dust" four times today when fired upon by Arabs on the Tel Aviv-Jerusalem road. The first three times they were leading a convoy of sixteen trucks that had received permission from the Trans-Jordan Government to travel through Arab territory.

The political attachment of Marshal Stalin and Marshal Tito may have cooled but the change in temperature has not yet reached the Yugoslav steamship Radnik, which arrived here yesterday with cargo and thirty-one passengers. Reporters who boarded the ship at Smith Street, Brooklyn, saw that in the ship's library the large photographs of the Soviet and Yugoslav dictators were still framed on the wall.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Health conditions in the Far East have deteriorated critically as an aftermath of the Japanese occupation and the continuing political disorders in several of the countries, Dr. Thomas Parran, former Surgeon General, reported today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Three seeded American players and the last of the five foreign entries, Australia's Frank Sedgman, were eliminated today as the star-studded field in the Newport Casino tennis tournament was reduced to the quarter-finals in singles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Increasing mention is being made of the possibility that the Republicans will win the Presidency and achieve a larger majority in the new House of Representatives, and at the same time lose the Senate. But in this speculation small if any attention has been paid to the circumstance that such an unlikely decision by the voters would be the consequence of too much Republican success in the Congressional elections of 1946.

Reflecting a higher sales volume, the net profit of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries in the first six months this year increased to $20,235,006 after taxes and all charges from $16,460,339 earned in the initial half of 1947, according to the report issued yesterday by Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Three witnesses said to have known both Alger Hiss, former State Department official, and Whittaker Chambers when, Mr. Chambers charges, Mr. Hiss was a leader in a Communist "underground" in Washington were subpoenaed today by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Over the protest of Harry Fleischman, national secretary of the Socialist party, the Columbia Broadcasting System canceled a nation-wide radio talk by Prof. Maynard C. Krueger, Socialist nominee for Congress in Illinois, scheduled for 6:15-6:30 o'clock last night, and substituted a special CBS news broadcast from overseas.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Psychiatry must be employed to help prevent war, Dr. John Milne Murray, Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Boston University, told the International Conference on Mental Hygiene today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Western diplomats and Soviet officials appeared today to be nearing agreement on the calling of a four-power top level conference on the whole problem of Germany.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- Work on the San Francisco waterfront came to a stop tonight as members of Local 10 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, attended a meeting to hear a report of findings of the President's fact-finding committee dealing with the union's dispute with the Waterfront Employers Association.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- The United States Military Government is facilitating the "bootlegging" of news into the Soviet zone, it was learned today. To bypass Soviet regulations that have halted the flow of newspapers licensed by the Western allies into the Eastern Zone, the Military Government now is printing a special reduced-size edition of The Neue Zeitung, the United States-sponsored newspaper in Berlin.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Australia today defeated England by an innings and 149 runs in the fifth and last test match of the season. Australia took the series with four victories and one draw, thus retaining the mythical "ashes" which are the emblem of victory in cricket contests between the two countries.
Wage increases ranging from $5.23 to $30.32 a month were obtained here yesetrday for Atlantic and Gulf Coast members of the National Maritime Union, CIO.

A schism developed yesterday in the League for Non-Violent Civil Disobedience Against Military Segregation. A. Philip Randolph, international president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, AFL, and chairman of the League, declared the league officially at an end, but other "important officials" announced they were carrying on despite his withdrawal.
CAMP McNAIR, Japan, Aug. 18 -- American occupation troops today are undergoing active combat training in Japan under conditions simulating as closely as possible those of actual warfare.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A load of eighteen beef steers smashed through to a new record high price of $41.35 a hundred pounds here today. This broke by a dime the previous peak set Jan. 6 and matched four times in the last two weeks.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Prof. Richard Allen Lester has been appointed chairman of the Princeton University Department of Economics and Social Institutions to succeed Prof. Stanley Edwin Howard, chairman since 1934, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- Representatives of historical societies and a small crowd of antique collectors assembled on the east bank of the Delaware River a few miles below this city today in hopes of picking up a few relies from Davy Jones' locker.

The City Planning Commission turned down yesterday a request by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander that it designate the area occupied by the old Tombs and Criminal Courts Building as the site for a new $15,000,000 Police Headquarters Building.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Israeli soldiers were accused today by the pastor of a Greek Catholic Church in Jaffa of breaking into the church and carrying off religious objects.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Hollywood's screen actors, who had just voted by a large majority for continued union shop in the motion-picture studios, are now preparing to ask the producers through their guild for a contract which will establish rates of pay and working conditions for actors appearing in films made especially for television.

Following a settlement with the Textile Workers Union of America for higher wages and increased benefits, dyers and finishers of rayon fabrics gave notice yesterday of an immediate increase of about 10 percent on finishing charges.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The New Jersey Legislature moved into high gear today to complete Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's legislative program in the three weeks allotted by its leaders.
For the third successive day, the wholesale price of butter dropped yesterday. The new decline of 1 1/2 cents a pound on top grades sent prices to the lowest point this year.

TORONTO, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Premier Drew announced tonight the Austin Motor Company, Ltd., British automobile manufacturer, has completed arrangements to purchase a plant in Hamilton, Ont., where cars will be produced for the Canadian market.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- The Soviet blockade of Berlin has "failed" to starve "the democratic people" of the city into submission, Col. Frank L. Howley, commandant of the United States sector asserted tonight.

Literary works will be adapted for television under the general supervision of John Steinbeck for "Actors' Theatre," which will receive its premiere over WJZ-TV and the ABC video network on Sunday, Sept. 19, from 8:30 to 9 P.M.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, told reporters this afternoon following a visit with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey that President Truman had never shown any intention of controlling inflation.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Miss Lillian Quimby, last year's winner, gained the medal with 83 in the qualifying round of the fourteenth annual women's invitation tournament at Briar Hills Golf Club today. She went out in 41 and required one more stroke on the incoming route.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday because of pressure from New Orleans and the South, and final prices were 4 to 17 points net lower.

ZEIST, the Netherlands, Aug. 18 -- Complete religious freedom, including the right of churches to propagandize, exists in Communist-dominated Czechoslovakia, Prof. Josef L. Hromadka of Prague said here today.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18 -- The International Typographical Union convention called upon President Truman in a resolution today to investigate "unwarranted interference" by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the executive branch of the Federal Government.

Directors of the Continental Oil Company yesterday declared a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on Sept, 27. Previous payments were 75 cents each in March and June. Last year the organization distributed 50 cents in the first two quarters and 75 cents each in September and December.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Bampton and Mrs. Claire B. Schaefer bought apartments in the cooperative building at 880 Fifth Avenue through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., who also rented an apartment in 840 Park Avenue to Dr. Samuel Feigen.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 18 -- The second-round matches of the Westchester and Fairfield women's golf championship today over the Greenwich Country Club course resulted in the elimination of the defending champion and other favorites.

The National Maritime Union has won a wage increase after long and costly negotiations involving the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, White House intervention and a Federal injunction. It is likely that the seamen will ratify the agreement and that its pattern will be accepted by other Atlantic sea unions, thus avoiding once more a crippling strike.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Maurice J. Tobin, the new Secretary of Labor, used his first news conference today to attack the Taft-Hartley Law as a "blow at unionism."

In an expansion move, the Meadox Weaving Company, manufacturer of upholstery fabrics, has leased a unit of 17,400 square feet from the Marcalus Manufacturing Company in the latter's plant on Market Street in East Paterson, N.J. Meadox will continue to operate its factory in Waldwick.

After more than a decade of struggle, T.D. Lysenko, noted Russian plant breeder, has emerged victorious over Soviet geneticists who have long opposed his theories, articles in Pravda from Aug. 3 to 11 report.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 11, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Sailing home an easy victory in the afternoon event, John Field's Margot of the Pequot Yacht Club fleet took a seven point lead today in the five-race series for the Atlantic class championship. The final will be sailed tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Czechoslovakia announced today that she would ask the General Assembly to dismiss Dr. Jan Papanek, former delegate who broke with Prague in March 1948, from two elected posts that expire in 1951.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Registration statements covering more than $9,000,000 of new financing were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Tonight saw the second performance by Jose Limon and his company, with Pauline Koner as guest artist, in the American Dance Festival in the Palmer Auditorium. The program had as its special feature the world premiere of "Corybantic," choreographed by Doris Humphrey to Bela Bartok's sonata for two pianos and percussion, but there were other novelties as well.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Miami had a 1 per cent gross receipts tax on daily newspapers for about five hours today, until a city commissioner changed his mind.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, vigorously denied today that he planned to join the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association in California and parried questions relative to President Truman's prediction that the Government would end its present accounting year with a deficit.

An issue of $2,135,000 of bonds of Common School District No. 5 of Hempstead, L. I., was sold yesterday to George B. Gibbons Co., Inc., and Roosevelt Cross, Inc., at a bid of $1,000 premium for interest of 3.40 per cent; an interest cost of 3.395 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Truman today hailed the Government-industry cooperation which was enabling the country to revive a shipbuilding and merchant marine program which would "provide work for thousands" across the country.

ATHENS, Aug. 18 -- The Greek Government announced today that it had made representations to the Albanian Government, through the United Nations, demanding that Greek rebels who escaped into Albania be disarmed and interned in conformity with international law and the General Assembly's resolution of October, 1947.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 18 -- Haj Amin el-Husseini, Mufti of Jerusalem, issued a call from Damascus today to all Arab nations to rush troops of their regular armies to Jerusalem to save the city from occupation by Israeli forces.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Fire destroyed a large part of the Solberg-Hunterdon Airport eight miles northeast of here today.

Trading in apple futures, which was begun this week on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, will be suspended if its stabilizing influence and advantages are not felt by the industry "quick]y," O.W. Olson, executive vice president of the Exchange, declared yesterday.

Jack Resnick and Philip P. Zipes, operators, have purchased the building at 170-186 West Fordham Road and 2304 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, containing nine stores and fifty-seven apartments, from Samkoff Widelitz. The building is across the street from the apartment house development of the Equitable Life Assurance Society on the site of the former Webb Institute.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Confronted with a renewed warning that the United Nations Security Council would consider positive action if either side breaks the truce in Palestine, both Israeli and Arab representatives indicated today that they would continue to observe the Council's order.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Idle capacity of existing newsprint manufacturing equipment is largely to blame for the shortage of newsprint in many countries, J.M. Savage, secretary of the Newsprint association of Canada, said today.

New international contract bridge laws, to be promulgated by committees representing Great Britain and the United States, will go into effect Oct. 1. They will affect the card-playing habits of a world group of bridge players that has been estimated as high as 40,000,000 persons.

Two 26-goal teams are included in the field of four which will ride in the national open polo championship at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I. next month, it was announced yesterday by Devereux Milburn Jr., at luncheon in Cavanagh's.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Indians notched their seventh straight triumph and their third shut-out in a row tonight, blanking the Browns, 3 to 0, for a sweep of the two-game series. Southpaw Sam Zoldak scattered nine St. Louis hits as Cleveland increased its American League lead to three games.

The State Public Service Commission, showing commendable alacrity, began hearings yesterday on bus line petitions for a fare rise. It seems reasonable to suppose that an interim fare of seven cents may be granted these lines shortly, since the New York City Administration has in effect endorsed such a fare.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Yankees tonight made it two straight over the Senators as they bagged a rain soaked, abbreviated contest by a score of 4 to 1.

Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime head of the atomic bomb project, said yesterday that the atomic bomb not only ended the war but has also enabled us to "maintain our national integrity and to hold up our heads in the present state of world affairs."

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Aug. 18 -- Tuskegee Institute will assume the responsibility of teaching the Southern Negro that he has the "duty" to participate in Government, President Frederick D. Patterson said here today.

LEXINGTON, Mass., Aug. 18 -- Boston's short-wave radio station, known during the war as "The Voice of Freedom," began today a series of "grass roots" recordings that will be used to broadcast the message of democracy to the peoples of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's statement that he favored giving Italy administrative control of its former African colonies under a United Nations trusteeship caused consternation in high places today.

Two films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Capitol the attraction is "Pitfall," a melodrama starring Dick Powell and Lizabeth Scott. Samuel Bischoff produced and Andre De Toth directed the offering from a screen play by Karl Kamb and the novel by Jay Dratler.

Disclosure yesterday that the War Assets Administration has agreed to lease the Government's large blast furnace and coke oven facility in Cleveland to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation drew strong protests and demands for revocation of the agreement from the Republic Steel Corporation, the Gray Iron Founders Society, Inc., and the Tucker Corporation, an automotive concern.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Winning performances by the defending champion and the gallery favorite paced the parade through the second-round matches of the annual Tran-Mississippi women's golf tournament today.

Banking syndicates here announced yesterday effectiveness of public offerings of new issues of public utility and railroad obligations totaling $34,450,000, and an issue of new common stock of Continental Motors Company valued at $2,250,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- With ten months yet to go, the United States Air Force is within 53,000 of having recruited its authorized strength of 453,000 by June 30, 1949. Air Force headquarters said today its reports show it has 397,500 men, of whom 126,000 are overseas.
A court order challenging the authority of John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, to subpoena "confidential" records was obtained yesterday by the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association.
How a temporary resident of an old building can create a neat modern setting without costly architectural improvements was shown yesterday by the design team of Edith and William Hernandez.

I was indeed gratified to read the editorial "Climax in Greece," appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug 10, in which you comment on the winding up of the operations of the Greek Army against the Communist-led guerrillas who have festered my country since its liberation.
Wise, Smith Co., Inc,, a department store in Hartford, Conn., has become affiliated with the City Stores Company, which operates a group of department stores.

KLM, the Royal Dutch Airlines, brought its first regularly scheduled flight into New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, yesterday afternoon when it landed a Constellation with thirty-five passengers from Amsterdam.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Red Sox climbed over Philadelphia into second place by two percentage points today with a seventeen-hit attack and a 10-2 decision over the Athletics, who dropped into third place in the ever changing American League pennant fight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Pirates rallied for six runs in the eighth inning to rout Russ Meyer and defeat the Cubs, 7 to 4, today.

Three buildings in the East Fifty-seventh Street shopping district occupied by well-known concerns passed to new control yesterday when Webb Knapp, Inc., announced their purchase of the six-story and penthouse structure at 8-10 East Fifty-seventh Street and the two, two and three-story buildings abutting at 9 East Fifty-sixth Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Irisen, owned by Mrs. O. L. Nyberg of Baltimore, scored a front-running victory in the featured six-furlong Jersey Blue Purse at the Atlantic City race track today.

Advertisers and theirs agencies were cautioned yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau on using correct terminology for two widely different subjects -- air conditioning and golden slippers. It described air conditioning as "the control, by a mechanical device, of the temperature, humidity and circulation of the air within a structure," a definition endorsed by industrial and Government authorities.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- A new variety of gladiolus was adjudged the most beautiful spike of bloom in the Eastern International Gladiolus Show, which closed here tonight.

An Air France Constellation plane that was carrying twenty-seven passengers, including State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi, returned last night to the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, because of motor trouble.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, claimed victory yesterday over the Communists in their fight to "rule or ruin" the union.

Carl R. Gray Jr., United States Veterans Administrator, paid tribute yesterday to his predecessor, Gen. Omar N. Bradley, and to Maj. Gen. Paul H. Hawley for organizing the vast medical and surgical program of the Veterans Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -Representative George H. Bender of Ohio called on the War Assets Administration today to provide the House with full information concerning lease of the $28,000,000 Government-owned blast furnace and coke oven plant in Cleveland to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Aug. 18 -- A dozen angry housewives, whose homes are in a veterans housing project here, protested today, without avail, to members of the town commission an increase in their tax bills from $200 in 1947 to $362 this year.

The first rod and reel broadbill, a 256 1/2-pounder taken by Charles L. Campbell of Boston, seems to have stimulated the rest of the hopefuls, for reports are being received of a dozen fish baited and one hooked but lost.

Warnings that a shortage of popular glycol types of anti-freeze solutions is in the offing and those motorists who fail to hake heed are likely to be frostbound next winter were given yesterday by the National Automobile Dealers Association and the Automobile Club of New York.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Mental specialists disagreed sharply today over the question of whether German father or German mothers had more to do with turning their children into Nazis.

PARIS Aug. 18 -- Indications are now being received here of a strong new drive to extirpate or at least discourage religion within the Soviet Union. This applies not only to the traditional prejudices against the Orthodox Christian Church but also to the Mohammedan faith, which is widespread in the central Asian republics of U.S.S.R.
NEW ALBANY, Ind., Aug. 18 (UP) -- Three small boys strung up a playmate by his neck and tortured him, police said today, adding that they were re-enacting the plot of a comic book.

Stating that he was "tremendously proud" of the squad, Dean Cromwell, head coach of the United States track and field squad that scored such a smashing success in the 1948 Olympic Games, arrived in New York yesterday on his way to Los Angeles.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- A Foreign Office spokesman denied today that a secret agreement on Palestine had been made between the British and the Iraqi governments as stated by Gen. Nuri as-Said, veteran Iraqi politician in a pamphlet circulated in Baghdad.

Members of a fact-finding board appointed by President Truman under the Taft-Hartley Act to investigate a contract dispute between longshoremen and employers took steps here yesterday to avert a threatened work stoppage.

"He hasn't got a shirt to name" isn't heard often these days, says the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers. What does bother the association, however, is that it hasn't got a name for its shirt products.

John Golden is considering a new play by Thomas Coley and William Roerick called "The Happiest Years," which is being tried out this week at the Berkshire Playhouse, Stockbridge, Mass. The veteran producer, received a copy of the script yesterday, and may travel to Stockbridge to take in a performance.

Ray Robinson, welterweight champion of New York, will square off against Kid Gavilan of Havana in a ten-round over-the-weight match at Yankee Stadium on the night of Sept. 22, it was announced yesterday by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Continued uncertainty on the situation in Moscow kept business in the stock market here today at a minimum on the opening of the new account. The tendency, however, was fairly steady in most sections.

HAIFA, Israel, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Chief of Staff of the United Nations truce commission, Gen. A. Lundstroem, considers the recent shooting affrays in Jerusalem violations of the truce by both Arabs and Israeli elements, it was learned here today.
A new intellectual migration from Europe began yesterday with the disembarkation of three Lithuanian professors from the United States Lines refugee ship, Marine Swallow.

THERE are two outstanding varieties of English authors at the moment -- those who write about Britain and those who write about Hollywood. Aldous Huxley, like Evelyn Waugh, is entertaining us this summer in the second category. "Ape and Essence,"* his new novel -- or jeremiad, or lay-sermon, or lampoon, as you will -- wreaks (postdated) general havoc out there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States Government condemned tonight the Danube convention as the end product of Soviet "extortion" and as a proof of Russian designs for continued "enslavement" of the Danubian peoples.

Demolition of a substantial red brick residence on the southwest corner of Seventy-seventh Street and Madison Avenue will start on Monday to make way for a new home for the Parke-Bernet Galleries ,the country's leading auction house.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 14 totaled 891,277 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 12,378 cars, or 1.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 15,028 cars, or 1.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 3,724 cars, or 0.4 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINTON, Aug. 19 -- Executive officers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations did virtually everything today but formally endorse President Truman for a full term.

Directors of the Packard Motor Car Company are considering the reduction of the company's 15,000,000 outstanding shares by a one-for-three or one-for-five exchange into new stock, it was disclosed yesterday. There have been many stock split-ups in recent years, but this would be the first reverse stock-split in four years, or since the United Gas Improvement Company issued one share for every ten held, in September, 1944.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Joe DiMaggio, returning by plane after attending the Babe Ruth funeral services in New York, rejoined his Yankee colleagues in the third inning of their series finale with the Senators this afternoon and forthwith produced electrifying results.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Entered in the Lake George swimming marathon on Wednesday, Sept. 8, for the world long distance championship is Ben Gazelle, Toronto star who won the Toronto marathon swim at the Canadian National Exhibition last year.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The medical profession in North America was sharply criticized today for its alleged lack of leadership in having failed to use medical science to solve mental health problems in industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A diplomatic note denying accusations made by Soviet Russia against the United States Government in the cases of the refugee school teachers was delivered to Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin tonight.
The statement issued by Victor A. Kravchenko last night follows:

Reports from New Jersey to Massachusetts indicate that the bluefish are quite definitely making the comeback that has been prophesied for the past two years, and excellent catches of 2 1/2 to 5 pound blues are coming in from a score of fishing ports.

John Ullman has purchased the twenty-eight-family apartment house at 765 East 183d Street, the Bronx, also containing a store, from Rose Orelli. The property, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, is assessed at $65,000 and was sold for cash above a first mortgage of $38,300.

Integrated producers of rayon goods are taking orders for fourth-quarter delivery at prices substantially the same as those for the current quarter, it was learned yesterday, indicating that the trade can expect price stabilization for the balance of the year.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Next to last in the field of eight at the far turn, Deering Howe's Donor was first by a head at the end of the once-around-the track Class C Onondaga Handicap at Saratoga today. A sizeable contingent in the crowd of 12,347 thought that a perfectly charming result, for Donor was the $5.90-for-$2 favorite.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Exhibition baseball games may be played this year for a thirty-day period beginning Oct. 11, Commissioner A.B. Chandler announced today.

A declaration of war against Communists within the ranks of the Transport Workers Union, an admission by Douglas L. MacMahon, its international secretary-treasurer, that he has been a member of the Communist party for fourteen years, and an announcement by Michael J. Quill, international president of the union, that the city is about to start a full pension plan for transit workers marked a tempestuous meeting of the organization in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -The Field Artillery Journal today published what it described as Russia's secret schedule for gaining Communist domination of the world, with the United States the "ultimate objective."

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, predicted yesterday that the Democratic ticket of President Truman and Alben W. Barkley would run better in up-state New York than the Roosevelt-Truman ticket did in 1944. At that time the Republican majority up-state was held to 454,000 and the Democrats carried the state, with the help of the American Labor and Liberal parties, by a margin of 316,000 votes.
A nation-wide campaign for contributions to the United Service Organizations 1949 budget of $6,650,000 will be started the first week in October, it became known here yesterday.

President Truman and the Democrats are trying to face both ways on the inflation issue, Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, House Republican leader, declared yesterday after a visit with Governor Dewey, the Republican candidate for President.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today that it had approved a loan of $1,200,000 to Fabrica Victoria De Puente Alto, S.A., of Santiago, Chile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Awaiting his eighty-sixth birthday on Oct. 22, James W. Montee, the oldest licensed pilot in the country (and probably in the world), thinks, after twenty-five years of flying, that more old persons should learn to fly just for the fun of it.

A new enlistment plan for active service for the Army Enlisted Reserve Corps, designed to relieve an administrative personnel shortage in the recruiting service caused by increased enlistments, was announced yesterday by Col. L.R. Bullene, commanding officer of the Southern New York Recruiting District, Army and Air Force, 39 Whitehall Street.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California, Republican candidate for Vice President, declared today that our only armor against communism is "a firm belief in the soundness and the goodness of our own institutions and a determination that the freedom and opportunity they have afforded us will be passed on unimpaired to our children."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- A five-story apartment house at Addison Street and Chatsworth Avenue was swept by fire today, sending a pall of smoke over the business center and adjacent areas. Traffic on Boston Post Road, a block away, was detoured for three hours while firemen from Larchmont, Mamaroneck Village, Mamaroneck township and New Rochelle fought the fire.

A new group of decorative fabrics, said to have been inspired by the California gold rush days of 1849, is being introduced in four room settings in Macy's drapery fabric department. The collection, styled by Barbara Barondess MacLean, California designer for Schumacher's, is varied enough in texture and design to suit any room from bedroom to library.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Philadelphia's Athletics romped to a 10-3 victory over the Red Sox today, regaining second place in the American League, which the Bostonians had taken over yesterday.

BRIGHTON, England, Aug. 19 -- The United States Navy, as represented by the 3,200-ton destroyer Willard Keith, virtually took over this south coast resort today. At the invitation of the town, the warship arrived for a six-day visit, and her ten officers and 250 men became guests of the community.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- A decisive turn in the protracted Kremlin negotiations on Germany appeared to be approaching tonight.

"UNLESS the United States informs its friends abroad of American policies, others will misinform them." And the corollary of this statement from "Persuade or Perish,"* by Wallace Carroll, is that if we allow our friends to be misinformed we soon will have no friends.
