In this revolutionary era of naked force and cold wars no nation, no matter how powerful, can afford to alienate friends and antagonize people.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 19 -- In the face of a rebellion by the State Senate, administration leaders indicated today that, rather than risk its rejection, they are willing to compromise on some phases of a reorganization measure creating a new Department of Law and Public Safety.

Moore-McCormack Lines, shipping operators in Scandinavian and South American trades, opposed yesterday an application of the Shepard Steamship Company for an operating differential subsidy covering the route between Atlantic Coast ports and South American east coast ports.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, won an easy endorsement today of his policy of refusing to file non-Communist affidavits and financial data that would qualify the union to use the facilities of the National Labor Relations Board.
School and date clothes in a variety of styles were shown yesterday in Franklin Simon's Teen Age Shop. Some were made to please daughter; others were frankly shown to please mother too.

To provide additional space for its expanding business, Parsons, Brickerhoff, Hogan Macdonald, one of the oldest engineering firms in the city, has leased one-half of the second floor and the entire third, fourth and fifth floors in 51 Broadway through the Cruikshank Company.
The implications of Mr. Roe's letter attacking my position on federal aid to education reveal a serious attack on all public education under the guise of opposition to federal aid.

Jack Rosenberg bought the two-story dwelling at 1516 Dunbar Street, Far Rockaway, Queens from Charles Charkir for cash above a mortgage of $7,900. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured the title.

Issuance of the ANPA's tenth annual "Blue Book" "offers impressive additional evidence of the reasons why national advertisers are making by far the largest investment in newspaper space on record," Harold S. Barnes, the bureau's acting director, declared yesterday.
The Habimah Players, famed Palestinian theatrical troupe, were guests of honor last night at a party and reception given by the American Fund for Palestinian Institutions at the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A decline of 0.1 per cent was recorded in average primary market prices during the week ended Aug. 14, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Margot, sailed by John Field, successfully defended her Atlantic class championship today and returned the yachting trophy to the Pequot Yacht Club for the second straight year.

The oil industry was the principal beneficiary of loans by the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System last week, largely accounting for an increase of $18,000,000 in the banks' total of commercial, industrial and agricultural advances.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 19 -- Wage rates for civilian employes in the Army and Air Force will be coordinated through the operation of a new Joint Army and Air Force Wage Board, the two forces announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Shortstop Eddie Joost, sparkplug of the pennant-aspiring Philadelphia Athletics, is available to the A's on a lend-lease program with Graduate Hospital.

Plans of the New York Life Insurance Company to build a $90,000,000 apartment house on the old car-barn site on the East Side have been deferred and negotiations virtually have been completed to lease the valuable block for use as a parking lot, it was learned yesterday.

Many of the "insiders" of the recent United Air Lines, Inc., common stock offering -- this time the "insiders" were employes of the company as well as stockholders -- seem to have slept out the finish of the preferential offering, either not knowing or caring that they could buy for 10 3/4 stock which was selling 2 points higher in the public market.
May I suggest that our Government ought, in common humanity, to offer refuge and protection to Soviet Consul General Jacob M. Lomakin?

A novel of criminal impulse by Robert M. Coates, entitled "Wisteria Cottage," will be brought out by Harcourt, Brace on Sept. 9. It is a story about a young man who was invited to spend his summer week-ends in a cottage on the Long Island shore.

Users of pig iron, community leaders and a major segment of the steel industry united yesterday in vigorous protest to the proposed leasing by the War Assets Administration of its huge $28,000,000 blast furnace and coke oven plant in Cleveland to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- The division of Marshall Plan aid among European states that was proposed by a special committee of the European Council and is pending before that council, was learned today to be as follows:

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP) -- A resolution calling for expulsion of Russian diplomatic and consular officials who conspire against the American Government was approved today by the Supreme Council of the Knights of Columbus.

Hanson Baldwin says the "Army is aware of poor morale among Guardsmen and draftees" on duty pre-Pearl Harbor. One may hope the Army is also aware of why the Guardsmen's fine morale with which generally they answered calls in 1940 and 1941 lost edge before Japan's attack.
The needy couple who on Tuesday told a touching story in mid-Manhattan Court about their difficulty in getting home relief withdrew their application yesterday with the Department of Welfare.

Used car dealers depend upon quick sales and cannot risk holding vehicles for any long period on the chance of increased profits, Charles Kriesler, president of the New York State Used Car Dealers Association said yesterday.

"Stone walls do not a prison make" -- ah, but yes. Not only do stone walls make a prison, but walls of any type, so long as they are grouped in fours and are joined at the edges. Anything that shuts in a man creates a prisoner, and it is quite useless for poets to amble along in a discussion of the free spirit.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A combined naval and air attack today against a headquarters of renegade Burmese troops inflicted what the Government called the heaviest reverses in nine days of fighting.

A proposal that the individual states of this nation start building up reserve funds now for welfare and health purposes in less prosperous times was endorsed yesterday by public welfare leaders as a sound idea. There was disagreement, however, as to its practicality.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 19 (AP) -- A tale of near-mutiny and of the rescue of a 26-year-old ship's master from turbulent seas unfolded when the American tanker Halcyon III reached this Atlantic port yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- The United Nations Security Council today turned down Yugoslavia's demand to condemn United States and British policy on Trieste.

George Herman Ruth, concededly the greatest sports figure this nation has produced, received the final benediction of the Roman Catholic Church at a funeral service in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
Besides Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer, the honorary pallbearers at Babe Ruth's funeral included:

STEWART FIELD, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Two squadrons of active reservists of the Air Force's 320th Bomb Group (Light) are flying daily training missions out of this field and bombing simulated targets off Cape Cod as part of their two-week tour of duty in the field.
The Southern Pacific Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of $1.25 on the common stock, payable Sept. 20. The company previously paid $1 at quarterly intervals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A 10 per cent increase in passenger fares was agreed upon today by the Civil Aeronautics Board and officials of the country's fifteen airlines that operate domestically on scheduled trunk routes.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 -- The uneven fortunes of American movie companies in Argentina went both down and up today, apart from the strike of distributors' personnel, which virtually shut down all offices.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The racing career of the 5-year-old mare, Jupiter Light, owned by J.U. Gratton of Canada, came to an end here today when she was destroyed after breaking her left fore leg during the running of the fifth race.

NANKING, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Shanghai financial circles doubt that the drastic financial measures will succeed. They said they might wipe out the black market in currency, but, unless the new money had some substantial backing, the net result would be merely to cut off some of the zeros in the current astronomical transactions.

KOZANI, Greece, Aug. 19 (AP) -- High Greek officials expressed belief today that the summer offensive against the Communist-led guerrillas was "nearly over." Col. James F. Brittingham of Baltimore, chief of the United States military advisory group attached to the Greek Second Corps, with headquarters in this Macedonian town, supported this view.

The weatherman had said there would be cloudy skies and thunder-showers. His prediction was right, but the weather yesterday did not spoil the day for seventy-five grandmothers and grandfathers who romped through their annual outing as guests of Steeplechase Park on Coney Island.

The name of Rasa has been associated with the fish business for generations. Anyone in the Fulton Fish Market, hard by the East River, can tell you that from away back there has always been a Rasa as a fishmonger.
ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- State Senator Thomas C. Desmond said today that a newspaper men's confidence law would be a "strong weapon of democracy against Soviet or other foreign agents."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Criss-crossing the court with torrid volleys and dropping unreachable placements while making almost impossible saves, Philadelphia's Victor Seixas today startled the tennis world by eliminating the nation's second ranking Ted Schroeder from the Challenge Cup singles at the Newport Casino.

A consolidated net profit of $6,894,659 after taxes and all charges was reported yesterday for the twenty-six weeks ended on June 26 by the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and all subsidiaries, including the National Theatres Corporation and Roxy Theatre, Inc.

Louis Marchesi, stone renovator, has purchased the three-story dwelling at 786 Carroll Street, corner of Polhemus Place, Brooklyn, from Mrs. Ella M. Kuehn. He plans to remodel the building into apartments, one of which he will use for his own occupancy.
Members of the Grand Lodge of the Independent Order Of Odd Fellows in this state were urged yesterday to guard the future of their organization and its link to good government.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Truett (Rip) Sewell, long a thorn in the side of the Chicagoans, scattered eight hits to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory today and a sweep of the two-game series with the Cubs.

I noted with interest your news story in THE TIMES of July 23 relating to the proposal by Dr. Lawrence Kubie that a new curriculum be established leading to a Doctorate in Medical Psychiatry. Dr. Kubie believes that the shortage of psychiatrists can be met through the proposed curriculum and that the period for training specialists in psychiatry can be reduced from a twelve to sixteen years period to six to eight years.

The merchant steel exporter is being unfairly discriminated against in the issuance of licenses for export steel products by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce, according to a resolution adopted last night by the National Association of Steel Exporters, Inc., at a meeting at Essex House.

Residential building costs have advanced to a new peak in New York and elsewhere, further complicating and prolonging the housing crisis and making it more difficult than ever for the family of average means to own a new home.

As a result of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's appeal for aid to the underfed children of Europe and Asia, American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children received $30,000 in donations yesterday.
PRAGUE, Aug. 19 -- Czechoslovakia, despite its rigidly controlled economy, is having price and wage trouble. Rude Pravo, organ of the Czechoslovak Communist party and of the Government, says today:

HYDERABAD, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- Hyderabad, second largest princely state, announced today that it would take her accession dispute with India to the United Nations in the hope of "a peaceful and enduring settlement."

The 65 East Eightieth Street, Inc., Alvin G. Rowes, president, has sold for investment to Salvatore Pace, president of the Pace Holding Corporation, the house at 65 East Eightieth Street, which was altered into eight apartments about four years ago.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- The Winged Foot Golf Club's team, composed of nine of the section's outstanding amateurs and pro Claude Harmon, scored an aggregate of 771 over the Westchester Country Club's west course today to retain the Hoffhine Trophy.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Another victory in the ninth round today enabled Isaac I. Kashdan of New York to retain by a narrow margin his lead in the United States chess championship, which is nearing the half-way mark at the Community Center.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The Cubs were playing the Pirates at Wrigley Field, there was racing at Washington Park and other events were on the crowded sports calendar in the not-so-windy Windy City today, but most of the interest centered about the big football game to be played here at Soldier Field tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 14 were 15 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

Dairy equipment manufacturers are urging long range equipment modernization planning by dairy products processors as the only means of counterbalancing soaring production costs, R.E. Olson, president, Dairy Industries Supply Association revealed yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.
ATHENS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis issued an Order of the Day to the Greek Army tonight saying it had "won the Battle of Grammos."

There is meat of practical interest to the nation's 30,000,000 motorists in a report presented this week before the Society of Automotive Engineers with regard to new possibilities of fuel economy with automobile engines now being tested. This report was made by three technicians of the General Motors research laboratories division: John M. Campbell, Darl F. Caris and Dr. Lloyd L. Withrow.
A Coast Guard cutter forced a war surplus subchaser converted into a yacht to return yesterday to her East River pier after she had sailed for a foreign port.

Betty Jane Holder, 22-year-old New Orleans girl who had "adopted" the martyred French village of Mouleydier almost two years ago while still a student at the University of Alabama, returned to this country yesterday after a month's visit to "her" village.
The United States Attorney's office in the Eastern District of New York began yesterday to push the prosecution of persons charged with irregularities in the sale and financing of veterans' homes.

Retailers are urging clothing manufacturers to hasten shipments of boys' and men's suits for fall, according to trade sources yesterday. The clothes are wanted for filling out racks and for back to school and other advertising displays, it was said.

Governor Dewey's statement on Monday to a delegation of Americans of Italian extraction that he believed Italy should have administrative control of her former North African colonies has drawn the expected comment from President Truman. Mr. Truman told his news conference yesterday that the problem of these colonies could not very well be handled politically in the United States.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has invited shipyards to offer bids on construction of several new "defense" tankers of a design developed by the United States Maritime Commission and experts in the tanker operation industry, it was reported here yesterday.

With all due regard for the city administration's wishes, the State Public Service Commission will make its own decisions on applications for fare rises by private bus line operators, Commissioner Spencer B. Eddy declared yesterday. He was one of three commissioners conducting separate hearings on the applications of the Green Bus Lines, Inc., Jamaica Buses, Inc., and Steinway Omnibus Corporation, all Queens operators, in the commission offices at 233 Broadway.

Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina was feeling "a little better" yesterday for the first time since her leap on Aug. 12 from a third story window of the Soviet Consulate, but her name remained on the critical list at Roosevelt Hospital.

Twenty-one passengers aboard a Northwest Airlines plane bound from La Guardia Field to Minneapolis last night believed they were seeing double. On the door between the passenger cabin and the cockpit where the names of the crew are listed were these names: Capt. M. Freeburg, First Officer J. Freeburg, Stewardesses M. Kennedy and E. Braucher.

It's true Max Gordon has a crowded schedule. But he's a dynamic showman, who wouldn't avert his gaze for all the tea in China should the right script come along. That's how he feels about "Signor Chicago," the Edawrd Chodorov play derived from the Quintero brothers' "The Women Have Their Way." Furthermore, he's considering its production, a possibility which he confirmed yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Responding to an urgent appeal from Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator for Palestine, the Security Council today adopted a resolution calling on both Israeli and Arab forces to stop violations of the truce by either regular or irregular forces.
Allan S. Lehman, a partner in the Lehman Brothers banking firm, was married last Aug. 3 to Miss Ann Roach of New York City, he announced yesterday.

THE Babe would have gloried in it. The final tribute to him would have left him shining-eyed and choked up because he always had the soft-hearted sentimentality of a small boy. He probably never suspected in life what a truly great figure he was. It took his death to demonstrate it.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday in principle the three-year, $44,000,000 program for waste and garbage disposal submitted last week by Construction Coordinator Robert Moses.
O. John Rogge, the American Labor party candidate for the highly prized post of Surrogate of New York County, took the cover off usually private political negotiations yesterday.

A favorable trade balance of $32,500,000 was achieved by Brazil in June, reversing the previous United States-Brazil trend this year which had caused an average unfavorable balance for Brazil of $10,000,000 monthly, the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A proposal that the Big Four Foreign Ministers meet shortly on all fundamental German problems, but in the understanding that this was to be a conference actually to make a peace with Germany, was made today by Senator Tom Connally of Texas.

The hats that Jay Thorpe presented yesterday afternoon were truly pretty. They were the kind that men will like and will find nothing in to bring forth humorous remarks. These originals were created by the shop's design staff with special recognition given to Gustav Brandt, who showed his first collection for Jay Thorpe.
The Soviet Government was reported yesterday to be looking for another house on the East Side of Manhattan to purchase for use of its consular staff.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- July independent retail business dropped 8 per cent below June but was 9 per cent above July, last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A dull, dripping day along the waterfront was brightened considerably yesterday by the glitter of Olympic gold medals proudly displayed to welcoming friends at pierside by assorted United State heroes of the international games at London.

An improved salary schedule and constriction of employment opportunities have made teaching jobs more attractive, it was indicated yesterday at the Board of Education with the report that resignations from the New York public school staff have been greatly reduced.

The Liberia Company, organized last September as a "pioneer experiment" to develop the economy and social standards of the African republic with United States capital, announced yesterday the formation of a $100,000 subsidiary to carry on its development program.
The Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, major global migration agency, has allocated an extra $750,000 to move displaced persons to South America, Australia and other areas, it was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week rose to a level only fractionally below the peak recorded in early December last year, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. River tonnage and bank debits declined moderately; nearly all other activities increased, some of the gains being considerably larger than seasonal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations bitterly attacked today the ruling by the National Labor Relations Board outlawing hiring halls as they are operated by the National Maritime Union on the Great Lakes.

Stephen C. Stephano, vice president of Stephano Brothers, Philadelphia, formerly vice chairman of the Associated Tobacco Manufacturers, has been named chairman of the group. He succeeds T.F. Flanagan, who has resigned.

The drastic need of Queens for new hospitals has again been highlighted, this time by the Hospital Council of Greater New York, which recently gave the borough "top priority" in hospital requirements. It is a shocking thing that Queens should be found to have only 38 per cent of general care hospital facilities to meet its normal needs.
Newbold Morris and Michael Straight have become members of the New York State Board of Americans for Democratic Action, it was announced yesterday by Jonathan Bingham, state chairman of the group.

President Truman, at a White House press conference, rebuked Governor Dewey, his Republican adversary, by implication yesterday for injecting the disposition of Italy's African colonies in an American political campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Truman asserted today that the spy investigations of the House Committee on Un-American Activities were infringing on the Bill of Rights, as Alger Hiss, former State Department official, accused of leadership in an alleged pre-war Communist "underground," refused to take at this time the lie-detector test proposed by the committee.

A late run-up in the steel section on the Stock Exchange enabled the stock market to break out yesterday from a narrow and irregular drift which had been prevalent during the early hours. Final prices were firm, with alterations of a point or more reserved for the steel issues, while the composite rate was increased 0.11 point on the day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- United States fiscal authorities said today they knew nothing about the Chinese Government's new currency. A Treasury spokesman said that as far as he knew there were no talks between the United States and China looking to the use of American gold to back the new Chinese currency.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 19 -- Immediate restoration of New Zealand currency to parity with the British pound was announced by Finance Minister Walter Nash after he presented his budget in the House of Representatives today.

Counterfeiting, which reached record heights during the prohibition era and almost disappeared during the war, has revived in the last six months, the United States Secret Service reported here yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 19 -- The United States should work out a long range program with other wool growing countries to assure its wool supply in the event of national emergency, Eugene Ackerman, director of the American Wool Council, declared here today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Little Billy Sidwell, the 140-pound freshman on the Australian Davis Cup tennis team, probably moved his forces into the challenge round against the United States today by outbattling rugged Jaroslav Drobny, the Czechoslovak ace, for an upset 6-3, 6-2, 9-11, 14-12 victory before a skimpy crowd of 500 at Longwood.

Word was received yesterday by George W. Elder, president of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association, that thirty entries had been received for the Star world series event, to be held at Lisbon, Portugal, starting on Aug. 31 and running through Sept. 5.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- With more business passing in the stock market here today, slight improvements were noted in most sections.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 19 -Mrs. Edwin Longcope of Siwanoy and Miss Gail Wild of the home club today reached the final of the Westchester and Fairfield women's golf championship at the Greenwich Country Club course.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, who was a United States representative at an international conference on labor factors in the Marshall Plan in London last month, was among the 2,255 passengers arriving last night on the Cunard White Star Liner, Queen Elizabeth.

TOKYO, Aug. 19 -- Considerable resentment is developing here over a proposal of President Syngman Rhee of Korea that Korea take over the Tsushima Islands, just off the Japanese coast in the Japan Sea.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- An emergency shipment of eighty tons of food for Arab and Jewish children in Palestine refugee camps will leave here on Tuesday, it was announced today by officials of the International Children's Emergency Fund of the United Nations (UNICEF).
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- During the week ended Aug. 18, member banks reserve balances decreased $231,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today a proposed revision of its rules to limit to seven the number of AM (standard) stations which might be owned by one person or group, and, on a sliding scale, the number of stations in which less than controlling interest might be held by owners of AM, FM (frequency modulation) and television stations.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Second Chamber of the Netherland Parliament ratified tonight a constitutional amendment that clears the way for granting sovereignty to Indonesia and reconstructing the Kingdom of the Netherlands.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 -- United Nations negotiators, exerting their utmost efforts to maintain the truce in Jerusalem, faced one of their sternest tests today when the Egyptians threatened to open fire on a girls' farm school in the southern sector of the city unless Israeli troops evacuated the premises.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- Robert Ash, Washington tax attorney, said today that the next Congress could be expected to pass Federal tax legislation that would make taxation burdens lighter for both individuals and corporations.
DENVER, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, Tenn., who quit the dental profession to go after the big money on the pro golf circuit, jumped out in front today in the $12,500 Denver open.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Informed observers predicted today the three Western envoys would meet tomorrow with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov.

Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War and now president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York; former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler, and George S. Van Schaick, recently retired as vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, have accepted invitations to serve as judges in the annual contest of the Real Estate Board of New York to select the most ingenious brokerage transaction of 1948.

Dorothy Lamour will preside over the half-hour of variety to be heard Thursday nights from 9:30 to 10 o'clock on the NBC hook-up, beginning Sept. 9. The guest policy for the program calls for the appearance of two stars each week, one for a dramatic episode and the other for comedy. The assignment for music has been given to Henry Russell's orchestra and the Crew Chiefs Quartet.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- Paul Reynaud, who has been raised to a commanding position in the French financial emergency by special powers voted to him by the National Assembly, appealed tonight to all elements in the nation to help him to save French national independence.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The high price record on live hogs was broken twice today. In early dealing a new top price of $31.75 a hundred pounds broke the previous record of $31.50 set Aug. 5. This level quickly was topped by a load of Hampshires, which sold to an eastern buyer at $31.85. The load of forty head averaged 215 pounds apiece, bringing the total value to around $2,700.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The principle of a draft constitution leading to the establishment of an organization to be called the International Youth Assembly was accepted unanimously here today during one of the closing sessions of the International Youth Conference.
BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- The management of the radio stations situated in the United States zone will be restored to the Germans within the next few months, it was learned today.

After inspecting the city's forthcoming exhibition of progress made during the last fifty years, Mayor O'Dwyer asserted yesterday that every candidate for city office during the next fifty years should be "compelled" to see it.

The new low level of 85 cents for a pound of butter is expected to continue until Monday. This offers the housewife at least one opportunity to spend a little less for groceries today than she did last Friday. While the wholesale declines in butter this week have totaled 5 1/2 cents, the retail drop for the same period, according to the City Department of Markets, has been 4 cents.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 19 -- A picture of the confusion found in the legal world as a result of the war was presented in the Peace Palace here today by delegates to the conference of the International Bar Association.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly firmer yesterday and closed 5 to 11 points net higher. It opened 5 points up to 2 points down and held within a narrow range all day.

Victor A. Kravchenko, who found sanctuary in this country after quitting his wartime post as a Russian purchasing agent in Washington, revealed himself last night as the man who engineered the escape of Mikhail Ivanovitch Samarin several days ago from what he described as a manhunt in this state and in New Jersey by agents of the NKVD, now the MVD, the Soviet political police.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 19 -- The Soviet Union decided today to attend, in a nonofficial capacity, the International Red Cross conference, which holds its first plenary session here tomorrow under the chairmanship of Count Folke Bernadotte.

There often is a tendency in discussing national and international political situations to speak of them as though they existed in a vacuum. The survey of the health situation in the Far East for the United Nations by Dr. Thomas Parran, former United States Surgeon General, shows that politics is a vital element in national life and international affairs that can mean starvation, disease and death to millions of persons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- After being in Hollywood eighteen months and under contract to two studios at different times without getting into a picture, Corinne Calvet, French film actress, has been picked by Hal Wallis to co-star with Burt Lancaster in "Rope of Sand."

As summer pauses before the ebb the restless ocean is subdued. The tide surge is gentle compared with the waves of other seasons when winds help push the waters against the mainland. Breezes come easily from the west; hot sun spreads languor over the beaches and dunes.

John Gates, editor of the Communist Daily Worker, who was one of twelve Communist leaders indicted recently by a Federal grand jury, boasted openly last night at a meeting in Brooklyn that he was violating the terms of his bail by appearing there. A provision of his bail had restricted his movements to Manhattan and the Bronx.

A uniform pension system for veterans of all wars and an old-age pension for disabled veterans at age 55 and for non-disabled veterans at 60 were advocated yesterday by Ray Branneman, commander- in-chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
NANKING, Aug. 19 -- President Chiang Kai-shek placed China's currency on a gold basis tonight. He announced the issuance of a new "gold yuan" and promulgated drastic financial reforms.
BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- Violence flared tonight where the United States, British and Soviet sectors meet in the center of divided and blockaded Berlin.
Passengers who arrived here yesterday from Europe on the United States liner America contributed $3,784 for a cancer fund in memory of Babe Ruth.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Harry Brecheen pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 4-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today with the aging Terry Moore providing most of the batting punch.

The first authentic national report of the effects of f.o.b. mill pricing of steel were revealed here yesterday in a report prepared by the steel committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. The report was prepared under supervision of Fred G. Syberg, manager of purchases, Chain Belt Company, Milwaukee, Wis.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Top-seeded Miss Doris Hart of Jacksonville, Fla., was extended to three sets today to gain the semi-finals in the singles division of the Essex County women's tennis tournament. Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., and Mrs. Helen Pedersen Rihbany of Boston also advanced.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Aug. 19 -- With a roar awakening hundreds of island vacationists, the fishing boat Edrie L. exploded in Old Harbor here at 6 A.M. today and sank a few minutes later. The captain, Edward Conley, 27, a native of Block Island, suffered first and second degree burns of the face and arms and was rushed to South County Hospital, Wakefield, R.I., where his condition tonight was described as "good."
GENEVA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council decided today to set up the first international agency in history charged with the control of floods in Asia and the Far East.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 19 -- The mammoth job or excavating ground for the United Nations permanent site in mid-Manhattan will begin about Sept. 15, one month earlier than expected.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Liquidation and professional pressure caused a sharp break in grain and lard prices in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, but when shorts tried to cover they found offerings light and a strong rally followed under the leadership of September corn.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- The appointment of Judge William Clark of Princeton, N.J., as chief judge of the newly constituted Court of Appeals for the United States Military Government was announced today by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Military Governor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Controls on most consumer installment credit covering purchases between $50 and $5,000 will become effective on Sept. 20, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Known as Regulation W, the name applied to credit controls which expired last Nov. 1, the new regulation was authorized by the Republican-sponsored anti-inflation bill signed by President Truman on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Holly Sugar Corporation, Colorado Springs, Col., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 185,000 shares of $30 par value cumulative preferred stock, which will be convertible into common shares.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Controls on most consumer installment credit covering purchases between $50 and $5,000 will become effective on Sept. 20, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Known as Regulation W, the name applied to credit controls which expired last Nov. 1, the new regulation was authorized by the Republican-sponsored anti-inflation bill signed by President Truman on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Holly Sugar Corporation, Colorado Springs, Col., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 185,000 shares of $30 par value cumulative preferred stock, which will be convertible into common shares.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 19 -- A minority of the Christian Democratic-controlled Bizonal Economic Council pushed through today a measure against price gouging that the majority of the Opposition described as "nazistic."

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Proposals for a Western European assembly that won the French Government's approval yesterday are being studied by British authorities but there is no indication that the British Government is prepared yet to follow the French lead.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) -- This is a peculiar event -- the forty-ninth Grand American trapshoot which opened today and will run through Aug. 28.
The following books of a religious or inspirational nature have been published recently:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The United States today ordered the expulsion of Jacob M. Lomakin, Soviet Consul General at New York, because he had "abused" his position and "grossly violated" the proper standards of official conduct.

The observations of New Jersey's Commission on Alcoholism and Promotion of Temperance just submitted to the state's Legislature are of interest not only because of the soundness of their point of view, but also because the conditions observed are much the same in many other states besides New Jersey.

JAMESBURG, N.J., Aug. 20 -Johnny Kinder of Plainfield fired a two-over-par 73 at the Forsgate Country Club today and gained a tie for the lead at the halfway mark of the New Jersey State P.G.A. championship.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 20 (Ap) -An Air Force technician raised the hypothesis today that sabotage materials, ignited by radio waves, may be causing the strange fires on the Charles Willey farm near Macomb, Ill.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 20 Isaac I. Kashdan was defeated for the first time in ten games in the United States chess championship at the Community Center today. The New Yorker lost to Sol Rubinow of Philadelphia, a former C.C.N.Y. player, in forty two moves.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- With at least one more Kremlin meeting to be held, the outcome of fourpower Moscow negotiations on Germany appeared tonight to be still extremely uncertain.

A guard with drawn revolver yesterday escorted the Gutenberg Bible of the New York Public Library in its first trip out of the central building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Carefully wrapped against the light rain, the two valuable volumes, in the hands of another guard, were placed in an armored truck forh) 0*0*0*itransportation to the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition in Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- J. Peters, sought by the House Committee on Un-American Activities as the reputed top leader of all pre-war Communist undergrounds in the United States, was expected tonight to be under its subpoena within ten days.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- Five German policemen of the United States sector, two of whom later escaped, were kidnapped by Russian military policemen at gun point today during one of three large scale raids in which 2,500 Germans were arrested.

The "Voice of America" altered yesterday the pattern of its daily hour-long broadcast to Russia to present in the opening minutes the text of the State Department's note calling for the recall of Consul General Jacob M. Lomakin.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Mental illness, caused mainly by erratic industrialization, is spreading so rapidly as to present to mankind a problem of "greatest urgency," Dr. T. Ferguson Rodger, Professor of Psychiatry at the University of Glasgow, declared here today before the International Conference on Mental Hygiene.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 20 (AP) -- J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, said today the Republican party "is still dominated by the moneyed interests and the Congressional leaders who do their bidding."

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade today, but generally lower, paced by corn. Cash corn declined 5 to 10 cents a bushel with No. 1 yellow quoted at $1.87 at the last, compared with $1.97 early yesterday, and bids for the yellow grain for next week's shipment were down 15 cents from yesterday.

The scientific programs of Columbia, Yale, Harvard and Princeton Universities will be furthered by the income of a $40,000,000 trust fund established in the will of Eugene Higgins, once known as the "wealthiest bachelor in New York," it became known last night.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The plan of battle for Mrs. Corliss Sullivan's two-jumpers entry in the Beverwyck Steeplechase Handicap at Saratoga today was for Drift to force the pace, try to run the opposition out of wind, and then for The Heir to move into the fray in the late stages.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Pravda quoted United States Ambassador Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith today to dispute the United States State Department's version of the case of Lieut. Robert Dreher, who was accused of espionage by the Russians.
Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright was unanimously elected national commander of the Disabled American Veterans for 1948-49 yesterday at the closing session of the group's twenty-seventh annual convention.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -The War Assets Administration insisted today that it awarded the $28,000,000 surplus steel plant at Cleveland to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation to avert the plant's shutdown.

Two new films, including a French importation, will open in local houses today. "Race Street," a melodrama with George Raft, William Bendix and Marilyn Maxwell as its principals, will be presented at the Mayfair.... The Gallic offering, arriving at the Elysee, is a comedy called "The Honorable Catherine."

Although women's coat and suit production reached peak levels in the last week, the high rate of output must be maintained for the balance of the fall season if the industry is to equal last year's figures, it was pointed out yesterday. Manufacturers expressed the opinion that while they are ahead on dollar volume, thus far this year there has been some loss tn unit volume.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 20 (AP) -- United States District Judge Paul Leahy approved an order today enforcing part of the liquidation and dissolution plan of United Public Utilities Corp., which previously had been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Despite an increase of $3,400,000 in total revenues over the intake in the same period last year, Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., sustained a net loss of $466,305 in the second quarter of 1948 in contrast to a net profit of $409,279 in the same quarter of 1947, the airline reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- The Russians have informed the Western Military Governments that they cannot deliver to Berlin 5,000,000h)0*0*0*iReichsmarks' worth of goods due as part payment for reparations received from Western Germany because of transportation difficulties in the Soviet zone.

C. R. Smith, chairman of the board of American Airlines, denied yesterday that his company had entered into an informal agreement with other major domestic airlines and the Civil Aeronautics Board for a 10 per cent increase in air passenger fares.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Registration statements covering $75,000,000 of debentures, $20,500,000 of bonds, 385,000 shares of common and 46,177 shares of preferred stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by six companies.

Six leading Hollywood stars will rotate in principal roles when the Prudential Insurance Company begins a new winter series of dramatic broadcasts over CBS in its regular time period of 6 P.M. on Sunday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) President Frank C. Lane of the American Association today fined Umpire Bob Austin $25 for failure to observe baseball's adage that "bygones are bygones."

The advertising and promotional program for the Republican National Committee's Presidential Campaign has been awarded to Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., it was announced last night by Herbert Brownell Jr., campaign manager of the Dewey-Warren ticket, and William C. Murphy Jr., publicity director of the Republican National Committee.
TOKYO, Aug. 20 -- For the third successive year Japan will produce an excellent rice crop this fall, according to reports to the Agriculture Ministry.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 20 -- The Korean National Assembly today submitted to the legal drafting section of the Government a bill granting amnesty to prisoners. The legal department will prepare the act in proclamation form for the signature of President Syngman Rhee.

Felix H. Levy, a retired attorney formerly associated with the Department of Justice, suggested yesterday that Jacob M. Lomakin, Soviet consul general whose recall has been demanded by the State Department, seek asylum here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- This year's crop of College All-Stars was no match for the Chicago Cardinals, National Football League champions tonight at Soldier Field. Proving their superiority to the satisfaction of everyone in the crowd of 101,220, the pros virtually toyed with the opposition and romped to a 28-0 victory. It was the most lopsided triumph in the fifteen-year history of the "dream game."

Reports of a breach between the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers and the major companies represented by the Motion Picture Association of America circulated in trade circles yesterday after the last-minute cancellation by James Mulvey, representing the independents, of his scheduled trip to England with Eric Johnston.

Exports of British-made automomiles, textiles, pottery, whisky and other products to the United States now pay for one-third of British imports from the United States, according to a survey issued here yesterday by the British Information Services, agency of the British Government.
The Catholic Near East Welfare Association asked yesterday that the United Nations investigate desecrations of Catholic holy places in Palestine.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP) -- For the second successive year Mrs. Helen Pedersen Rihbany of Boston became a surprise finalist in the Essex Country Club Women's Invitation tennis tournament today. She won the right to face top-seeded Doris Hart of Jacksonville, Fla., in tomorrow's twentyfirst annual title round.

Kankakee, Ill., Park District sold yesterday an issue of $650,000 park improvement bonds due from 1949 to 1967 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 2.2136 per cent. The bid was 100.39 for 2 1/4s.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, who is in Rome on his way home after attending the Olympic Games in London, was received today by Pope Pius at Castel Gandolfo. At the end of the audience the Pope presented the Sovereign Order of the Golden Spur to the Shah.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, denied today a report published in the Russiancontrolled press here that he had demanded the French stop removing economic resources from their zone of Germany.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 (AP) -Second-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., and Harry Likas of San Francisco today joined Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Bill Talbert of New York in the semifinal round of the singles divisionh)0*0*0*iin the Newport Casino invitation tennis tournament.
Eighty newly arrived British exchange teachers were welcomed by Sir Francis Evans, the British Consul General, and Lady Evans at a reception yesterday afternoon in the English-Speaking Union.

PRAGUE, Czechoslavakia, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The threatened Communist purge of the Czech Sokol organization got under way today with the announcement that the entire leadership of the Moravian Sokol branch had been ousted.
WILSON, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP) --h)0*0*0*iRexford Guy Tugwell, former member of the Roosevelt Administration, said today he was no longer an official of the Progressive party led by Henry A. Wallace.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Conditions again were quiet in the stock market here today.

Angel Uriarte, 53 years old, of 481 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, shot and killed his estranged wife, Maria, 49, on a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon and then shot himself fatally, the police of the Fifth Avenue precinct reported.
PRAGUE, Aug. 20 -- New disciplinary measures are being introduced in Czechoslovakia to increase production by punishing laggards and alleged saboteurs.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- A star-studded field of seventy-five, including the six-time New York State titleholder, Ray Billows of Dutchess, who as defending champion qualified automatically, began a three-day trek after the Theodore G. Law Bowl in the qualifying round of the Briar Hills Golf Club's fourteenth annual invitation tourney today.h)0*0*0*iO

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug 20 (AP) -- Apprentice Jack Turner rode four winners here today, including Brookfield Farms' Istan in the featured six-furlong Cranberry Purse.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Latest returns from national campaigns in the Philippines, France, Switzerland and New Zealand have brought total proceeds of the United Nations Appeal for Children to approximately $17,000,000, it was announced here today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- The Bizonal Economic Administration of German officials for the joint United States and British zones was augmented today with the election of Anton Storch, a Christian Democrat from Lower Saxony in the British zone, to head the Department of Labor.

Faced with the imminent loss of his consular status, Jacob M. Lomakin, Soviet Consul General, asked yesterday that he and two physicians of his own choosing be permitted to visit and examine Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kasenkina at Roosevelt Hospital.

HYDERABAD, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- Syria has agreed to sponsor Hyderabad's case against India at the United Nations, it was learned here on reliable authority tonight. The Syrian representative at Lake Success will file a complaint at the United Nations Secretariat, it was understood.

It has been said truthfully that woman can pack into a suitcase what man cannot squeeze into a trunk. Man, however, would be reluctant to admit that were it not for woman vacation travel would break down under the sheer bulk of baggage and large numbers of those who now make annual pilgrimages to poison-ivied areas or rock-peppered shores would stay home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Truman left the White House today on a nine-day cruise aboard the yacht Williamsburg to rest in preparation for two months of almost continuous campaigning in all sections of the country and to write a few political speeches.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 20 -Thomas Saul, executive secretary of Local 1, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, announced today that the New York Shipbuilding Corporation had agreed to across-the-board wage increases for the 3,500 workers represented by the union.

The prevailing notion that alcohol plays a great part in crime was challenged yesterday by Dr. Ralph S. Banay as erroneous. Dr. Banay, research associate at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, addressed yesterday's meeting of the Institute on the Problems of Alcohol, sponsored jointly by New York University and the Research Council on the Problems of Alcohol.h)0*0*0*iO

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal left abruptly for Newport, R.I., with the Joint Chiefs ofh) 0*0*0*iStaff this afternoon for a discussion of "important policy questions." The conference got under way this evening at the Naval War College and is scheduled to continue until Sunday afternoon.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 (AP) -Satchel Paige shut out the White Sox with three hits tonight as the league-leading Indians triumphed, 1 to 0, before the largest nightgame crowd in major league history -- a standing-room-only assemblage of 78,382.

A dangerous type of black-market operation in child adoptions was revealed yesterday as welfare officials of New York State and New Jersey described the activities of unauthorized agencies from other states that place children without regard for the technicalities of the law.

Lumber production for the week ended Aug. 14 was 7.6 per cent above a year ago and 1.2 per cent above the preceding week. Shipments were 9.9 per cent over the like week last year and orders were up 10.4 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- The former Walker Cup player, Roland Mackenzie of Baltimore, led the field of 169 in the thirteenth invitation golf tourney of the Maidstone Club today with a medal-winning score of 72.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -Export controls will be dropped next Friday on shipments of wheat, wheat flour, oats, barley, grain sorghum and wheat semolina to Western Hemisphere countries and the Philippine Islands.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- Headed by Evan Just, the strategic materials division mission of the Economic Cooperation Administration, left today for London after four days of talks with the French Government and experts of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation on increased production of certain materials needed by the United States for strategic stock piling.

The cotton futures market yesterday closed 11 points lower to 16 points higher, with the near months relatively weaker than the distant, as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange continued moderately active.
Random notes.

Senator Styles Bridges, New Hampshire Republican, declared yesterday, after a conference with Governor Dewey, that the recent special session of Congress had provoked a reaction against President Truman and the Democrats.

Bells of Protestant and Easternh)0*0*0*iOrthodox churches across the country will peal hourly from 9 A.M., to 6 P.M. tomorrow, to herald the beginning of the first assembly of the World Council of Churches in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

In the delightful "Topics of the Times" of Aug 11, one headline describing the activity of the mother and father robins speaks of "Kibitzer in Feathers." Permit me to say that phrase contains a, perhaps, unconscious tautology.

Harold Lang, the young dancing star of last season's "Look, Ma, I'm Dancin'!", has been engaged for an important stint in the forthcoming Cole Porter-Sam and Bella Spewack musical, which is to be jointly produced by Lemuel Ayers and Arnold Saint Subber.

An increase in the voter registration in local elections and a widespread interest in civic affairs in many of the 256 cities visited by the Freedom Train with-its exhibits of documents important in the nation's history, was attributed yesterday to the project's support by women's organizations throughout the country.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 20 -- The Kraft Foods Corporation of Chicago today made the high bid of $611,000 on a giant war plant at Garland, near here, which originally cost the Government more than $2,000,000.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 20 -- Today's scheduled meeting between Egyptian and Israeli Army representatives, in the presence of United Nations truce observers and International Red Cross officials in southern Jerusalem, did not take place because the Egyptian officers said they needed more notice.

ATHENS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Greek Army General Staff spokesman said tonight the Communist-led guerrillas were in full retreat in the Grammos Mountains after the virtual collapse of their last defense line.

It was good to see America's leading newspaper remember Guadalcanal and Aug. 7, for this campaign not only enshrines the heroism of American arms against fearful odds but marks the beginning of the initiative which once secured, was never to be lost throughout the Pacific war.

The share market on the Stock Exchange climbed back yesterday into the price range of early August as sharp gains in a list of selected railway issues gave a better tone to the entire market. The steels enlarged further their recovery of Thursday, but the carriers exhibited the widest increases, which ranged to more than 4 points in Southern Pacific, while the composite rate rose 0.83 point.

Peron disavowed today any personal interest in the expulsion of Radical Deputy Ernesto San Martino from the Chamber of Deputies during an interview with a representative of the Democracia, a paper that is considered to be under the direct supervision of Senora Peron.
BEAVER FALLS, Pa., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Plans to license other steel companies to use a newly developed machine for the continuous casting of steel were announced today by the Babcock-Wilcox Tube Company.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 20 (AP) -The Government of Israel tonight asked the Security Council to approve its admission to the United Nations.
ALBANY, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Governor Dewey's State Police bodyguard has been doubled for the duration of the Republican Presidential candidate's nation-wide campaign.
ATHENS, Aug. 20 -- About 500 undernourished, ill-clad Greek children, aged 5 to 13 years, have just been rescued by the Greek Army near the Albanian border.
BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Home runs were the vogue today as Boston's Red Sox won both games of a double-header from the Washington Senators, 5 -- 4, in ten innings, and 10 -- 4.

THIS very earthy new book by Erskine Caldwell, "This Very Earth,"* is in the tellurian tradition that has made him one of the spectacularly popular authors of our time. It is at once too contrive (in plot) and too slapdash (in sty]e) for excellence. And to anyone who has read a number of Mr. Caldwell's novels it offers little in the way of freshness or strangeness or surprise.

Keeping their neighborhood streets clean is becoming as important to children today as keeping their teeth clean, Mrs. M. K. Graveson, director of sanitary education in the New York City Department of Sanitation, declared yesterday.

The Government-owned transport, Marine Carp, which was to have sailed at noon yesterday for Mediterranean ports, remained at her West Forty-fourth Street pier last night, the victim of a labor squabble.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- The Indian Defense Ministry denied tonight that Indian troops had occupied Sendri railway station and Yelasangi, a village in Hyderabad territory, as alleged by Hyderabad yesterday in announcing the decision to take Hyderabad's dispute with India to the United Nations.

Amid the noise and hubbub that precedes any show produced on a huge scale, the fashion show that is the highlight of New York's Golden Jubilee Anniversary at the Grand Central Palace held a dress rehearsal yesterday. Two robbers armed with pistols held up the bursar's office at Teachers College, Columbia University, and escaped with "about $9,900" yesterday morning.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Mayor Paul F. Cullum took issue today with statements made during and after a meeting of the Town Commission last Wednesday by William Schulman, president of the North Bergen Taxpayers Association and others who attended the meeting to protest an increase in assessed valuation of veterans'h)0*0*0*ihouses from $2,000 in 1947 to $4,200 this year.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Spokesmen of Britain's most representative Jewish organizations today vehemently denounced the anti-British boycott by the Sons of Liberty in the United States as "irresponsible," damaging to Anglo-American relations and harmful to the State of Israel itself.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Mrs. E. Swift Newton of Anselma, Pa., was elected chairman of the world committee of the world association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts here today. She will serve a two-year term. Mrs. Newton succeeds Mrs. John Corbett of Montreal, who presided here at the current twelfth biennial world conference of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals ganged up on their old nemesis, Fritz Ostermueller, for four runs in the sixth inning tonight and went on to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 to 4. The victory enabled the Cards to gain a half-game on both the Boston Braves and Brooklyn Dodgers, who were kept idle by rain.

Barney McLean of Denver, captain of the United States Olympic ski team, and Jack Reddish of Salt Lake City, fellow Olympian and national titleholder, left at midnight from Idlewild Airport aboard an FAMA airliner for Bariloche, Argentina, where they are to compete in the international ski races a week from tomorrow and Monday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 20 -Exploits of the United States Marines in the Pacific Theatre of Operations during the recent war will provide the material for one of Republic Studio's most ambitious forthcoming films. Based on a story entitled "Sands of Iwo Jima," the picture will be made with the cooperation of Marine officers and men stationed at Camp Pendleton, near San Diego.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -President Truman directed local draft boards today to begin mailing classification questionnaires to all single, non-father, non-veteran registrants by Sept. 7.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 20 -The validity of this city's parking meter ordinance was challenged today on the ground that it was being used solely for revenue rather than to control traffic in the congested resort community.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Army made public today instructions it issued on June 7 warning against unguarded disclosure even of unclassified or general information which might be of strategic importance to "potential enemies of the United States."

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Canada's adverse trade balance with the United States dropped sharply during the first six months of this year when the value of the country's foreign trade hit a new high, the Bureau of Statistics said today.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 20 -- The International Typographical Union, of the American Federation of Labor, gave its officers today a more liberal use of defense funds, including express authority to establish newspapers to compete with or replace publications whose printers are striking or threatening to strike.

The Long Island Rail Road, to obtain data on the habits and requirements of its 300,000 daily passengers, will issue temporarily new forms of commutation and other tickets, David E. Smucker, general manager, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug., 20 -- Third round wage and steel price increases raised the cost of materials purchased by many Chicago companies in July, the business surveyh)0*0*0*icommittee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (Science Service) -- A clutch device for motor vehicles, which combines the advantages of an electromagnetic clutch and the mechanical centrifugal type, earned two residents of Paris an American patent this week.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Playing through an all-day rain that made conditions extremely difficult, Miss Gail Wild of the home club won the twenty-third Westchester and Fairfield women's golf championship by defeating her favored rival, Mrs. Edwin Longcope of Siwanoy, 3 and 1, in the 36-hole final over the Greenwich Country Club course today.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 20 -- The major homeward-bound contingent of the United States' triumphant Olympic task force was sailing aboard the United States Line ship Washington tonight for New York and a royal reception by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall following a victory parade up Broadway at 1:30 next Friday afternoon.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 20 - Indications are unmistakable here that those charged with the implementation of United States policy are on the verge of committing what some observers describe as a mistake by ordering the abolition of Amerika Haeuser and their affiliated public reading rooms -possibly by the end of the present month.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 20 One hundred boys and girls who had not reached their eighteenth birthday set forth today from the Larchmont Yacht Club in more than a score and ten craft to compete in the third annual junior regatta of the New York Yacht Club, which in 1946 decided to encourage the aspirants to future success in sailing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A conference of telephone unions claiming to represent more than four-fifths of the organized workers in the industry mapped out today the official preliminaries forh) 0*0*0*ia drive for higher wages in the Bell System.

A preview of an atomic energy power plant of the future that regenerates its own fuel on a compound interest basis, producing more than one pound for each pound consumed, will be demonstrated for the first time at New York's Golden Jubilee Atomic Energy Exhibit, "Man and the Atom," which opens Monday at the Grand Central Palace.

Less than one-half of the export credit drafts paid by Latin-American countries as a whole during July were met promptly and more than one-fourth were paid over ninety days slow, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Dr. Francis E. Kent, Yonkers medical practitioner, was indicted here today by a Westchester County grand jury on a charge of first degree murder in the death of his wife, Helen. Patrolman Anthony J. Milano of the Yonkers Police Department was indicted on a charge of being an accessory after the fact.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- New and improved devices for land, sea and air defense mechanics were among the 489 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

Retail trade here this week made an increase despite several days of wet weather. Department store sales were estimated as about 6 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 10 per cent.
