Research on this phase has been too limited to permit blanket statements on the reaction of all foods under pressure. But at least studies on individual products are being completed that help in building up information.
An elaborate set-up for disposing of stolen automobiles broke down yesterday because of a 12cent oversight, the police reported.
PARIS, Aug. 20 -- In two long meetings, the French Cabinet examined today the cost of living as the discontent with prices was reviving labor protests throughout France.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 20 -Two of the nine incorporated villages on the Great Neck Peninsula are engaged in what is believed to be the first serious feud among the home-rule municipalities. Thomaston, a residential community incorporated seventeen years ago and built up into a section of small estates, and Great Neck Plaza, one year older, and having smaller homes and a business zone, have come to the parting of former friendly ways.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Third Baseman Bob Dillinger of the St. Louis Browns hit a home run in the tenth inning tonight to give the Browns a 5-to-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers in the opener of a three-game series. Relief Pitcher Karl Drews was credited with the triumph.
RAPID CITY, S. D., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Seventeen men were killed late today when a B-29 crashed and burned in a wheat field just off the edge of the Army Air Force field near here.

NANKING, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -Finance Minister Wang Yun-wu said today that China hoped to obtain a loan from the United States to back the new gold yuan currency directly or to stabilize the general economic position.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Truman directed the Attorney General today to seek an injunction putting off for more than two months an imminent strike by longshoremen against ship operators on the Atlantic Seaboard.

It is interesting to note that a great number of Soviet propaganda magazines and newspapers printed lavishly in English, French and German are being displayed at various New York newsstands, where those who are interested can purchase them freely.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 20 -Faced with the possibility that Newark may lose nearly $5,000,000 a year in tax revenues from its insurance companies, which would increase the city's tax rate 30 points next year, Mayor Vincent J. Murphy today said that he was preparing a fight in the courts and State Legislature to avoid what he termed a "catastrophe."

Several manufacturers will increase wholesale prices of metal lamps from 5 to 10 per cent on Sept. 1, Benjamin M. Robbins, executive secretary and counsel of the National Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association, disclosed yesterday.

A. N. Guy has been appointed manager of the allied products departmenth)0*0*0*iof the United States Rubber Company's tire division, succeeding C. E. Marshall, who has been granted leave of absence to serve with the Economic Cooperation Administration.
h)0*0*0*iIt might be assumed that a tiger's life in the Bronx Zoo is rather dull. But where else could a tiger feud with an electric eel?

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP) -- A marked overnight improvement, which produced a 10 -- 8, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4 doubles victory, put the Czechoslovak Davis Cup tennis forces back in the interzone final battle with the favored Australiansh)0*0*0*iat Longwood today.

The weather was unkind to everyone yesterday, including an expert meteorologist who came to the United States to make his home here, hopeful of leaving behind him the dampness and cloudiness of Ireland.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -Clinging tenaciously to the coat tails of the flying leaders, the Yankees tonight gained ground on one of the three front-runners by toppling Connie Mack's Athletics in the opener of a four-game series, 6 to 2.

The second round of price increases takes effect today and on Monday for a number of manufacturers of storage batteries, but other producers, and some dry cell makers, are still trying to hold the line on prices at the July level.

VIENNA, Aug. 20 -- W. B. Willcox, who will head the Economic Cooperation Administration representation in Austria, said at a press conference here today that he hoped to be able to survey the needs of all of Austria, including the Russian zone, and that his organization would do all it could to increase normal trade between Austria and the Eastern nations.
AMERICAN bridge players have bought millions of books on contract bridge since 1927, in which year the first book on the then-new game was published.

One of the least-contested primary elections in many years will be held here Tuesday. With hundreds of party nominations at stake in New York City alone, only twelve will be decided by that percentage of the electorate that sees fit to go to the polls. In all other cases the party designees are unopposed.

FRANCE is witnessing a strange phenomenon. One after the other, her best writers are leaping into the battle of politics. And not content with taking a position in the party of their choice, they seem to be insisting on the position of leader, or of chief political militant.

The world today faces five facts: The United States and the Soviet Union both assert their desire to prevent war. Yet they face varied situations any one of which could lead them accidentally into war unwanted by both. At the same time, neither has yet proposed to the other measures that would prevent any war any time.

GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- The Russians battled hard today to keep the convention on freedom of information from clearing the Economic and Social Council and thus avoid its presentation to the United Nations General Assembly.

FOR THIS WEEK: For handsome bloom, stake perennial asters and helenium, and feed chrysanthemums and dahlias with liquid manure. . . . Transplant biennial and perennial seedlings when the second pair of leaves appear. A flat is the safest place. . . . Plant bulbs of autumn crocus and colchicum three inches deep, sternbergia six inches. . . .

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 21 -- Tomorrow is the first anniversary of the Taft-Hartley amendments to the Wagner Act. The date means the end of all legal closed-shop, contracts in the United States, except for the few long-term agreements that were made before Congress passed the law over President Truman's veto.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. Aug. 21 -- Borba, official organ of the Yugoslav Communist party, compared today the case of Col. Gen. Arso Jovanovich, former Chief of Staff of the Yugoslav Army, who was shot to death by a border guard on the night of Aug. 10-11, with that of Marshal Mikhail Tukhachevsky, Chief of the Russian Army, who was purged and liquidated in Moscow for alleged collusion with the Nazi General Staff.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Seven League, conditioned by a race over the track here earlier in the week, proved a far sharper horse today in the mile-and-a-furlong Absecon Handicap. He galloped along in front of half a dozen rivals for the entire trip in the 3-year-old feature.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers won a disputed 6 to 5 decision over the St. Louis Browns today as Manager Zack Taylor of the Browns played out the game under protest after an unusual incident in which a newspaper photographer handled the ball while it was in play.

TED SHAWN'S first new work in four years will have its world premiere in the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass., on Friday afternoon at 4, with other performances scheduled for Saturday at 4 and again at 9.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Senator Edward Martin, Republican, of Pennsylvania, and James F. O'Neil, national commander of the American Legion, censured President Truman today for calling the Congressional spy inquiry a "red herring."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 21 -- The Soviet Union has opened a diplomatic offensive against Finland, advices from Helsinki political circles indicate. A note from the Kremlin asking when the Finns were going to complete the Salla railway, a strategic link between Murmansk and the Swedish-Finnish rail network seems to have been the significant opening.

Following is text of the letter addressed to Consul General Jacob M. Lomakin by Dr. Grant P. Pennoyer, resident physician at Roosevelt Hospital attending Mrs. Oksana S. Kasenkina, and delivered at the consulate by special courier:

A five-man board, made up of Coast Guard officers, held a series of meetings in Washington last week to consider qualifications of applicants for the posts of civilian examiners, who will hear and resolve cases of alleged misconduct, incompetence and negligence by mariners.

THE case for regionalism in literature and history has been aggressively put forth in recent years. So vigorous have been its defenders, so obvious its benefits, that hardly any responsible person today would deny the value of the grass roots approach.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- A strike of commercial printers which lasted nearly six months ended today with a two-year contract representing a compromise of the original wage demands.

SIX airlines last week announced reductions in roundtrip fares to Europe, effective Oct. 1, until spring. Travel officials hailed this move as a major step in the Continent's campaign to make the normally black fall and winter season a booming time for tourism.

ALONG with a of good many the ornery, Southern-fried inhabitants of Tobacco Road, Erskine Caldwell has moved into town. That was the case in his last novel ("The Sure Hand of God"), and it is the case in this newest one.

A THIRTY per cent increase in printing speed features the new Ansco Cykora chloro-bromide enlarging paper. Ansco describes the new paper as having a warmer image than formerly, an improved gradation of tone values in all the contrast grades, and a greater resistance to fogging and staining.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Boston's second-place Red Sox unleashed their power again today, thumping the Washington Senators by 10 -- 6 and moving within two games of the American League-leading Cleveland Indians.

A thorough inquiry into the survival of civil rights in the United States zone of occupation in Germany will be conducted by a committee of the American Civil Liberties Union at the invitation of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, accused Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today of "ducking the vital issue of public power."

The radioactive isotopes, man-made elements produced with atomic energy, that have given man the greatest tool he ever had for probing the mysteries of life and matter, will be put on public display for the first time at the Man and the Atom Exhibit of New York's Golden Jubilee Exposition at Grand Central Palace.

THE next big tussle between Hollywood actors and motion picture producers appears likely to concern a contract principle not heretofore applied in agreements between these two groups, but which the Screen Actors Guild will seek to establish with respect to films for television.

MILTON BERLE, recently signed to be master of ceremonies for the Texaco Star Theatre on the NBC television network Tuesday nights at 8 beginning Sept. 21, also will be the headliner for the radio broadcast series for the same sponsor scheduled to get under way over WJZ-ABC on Wednesday, Sept. 22.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, the States' Rights Democratic Presidential candidate, accused President Truman today of trying to hide the extent of Communist influence on the Government.

THE girl known as Blondie Iscariot is a woman of the streets who has risen to become the mistress of Michael Maguire, a big-time London racketeer. When Maguire's control of the rackets appears to be on the wane, Blondie shifts her allegiance, such as it is, to his rival gangster, Nick Valetta.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's great Citation, laid up for thirty days because of injury, returned to the races at Washington Park today and became an almost certain starter in the $90,000 American Derby next Saturday.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 21 -- Ten thousand workers, belonging to Communist-led and other unions, participated in an orderly demonstration today in the Zocalo or main square before the National Palace to emphasize their dislike of three Cabinet members whom they blamed for devaluation of the peso and high food prices.

David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, announced last night that this country, Britain and Canada were expanding their wartime system of cooperation and exchange of atomic research.

THE appearance of this slender volume, "Of Flight and Life," by Charles A. Lindbergh, constitutes news, even if superficially of an unspectacular nature. Mr. Lindbergh here attempts to present his personal views of our present dilemma, thus joining an ever increasing number of persons who have felt a similar compulsion to speak aloud -- for "time is short."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The extraordinary drama in the cases of Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kasenkina and Mikhail Samarin, the Soviet school teachers, may have thrown out of focus, some Government officials fear, the real picture of the problem presented by Russian citizens and other Eastern Europeans who want to get into this country and stay.
The major developments in Russian-American relations last week came in two kinds of diplomatic dealings.

IF, as Jacques Maritain said, art and poetry are more necessary than bread to the human race, then any attempt to bring poets and readers into a closer understanding is of the greatest importance. But many people are bored or exasperated by poetry because they claim they cannot understand it.

CHICAGO -- The Railroad Fair is a hit. The colorful exposition, sponsored by thirty-eight leading carriers, completed its first month of operation with an average daily attendance of 46,500 persons (the official figure for twenty-seven days is 1,256,110.) Fair officials are said to be considering extending the run to the end of September.
A standard billing-and-shipping order form, acceptable to retailers and manufacturers, is an aim of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was learned here last week.

FOR Ginnie Fellows the change from studying under Mother's tutelage, as the family moved from hotel to hotel, to settling down as a pupil in the Fourth Grade proved hard at first. Not knowing anyone in the school, being timid about playing a new game like tag, and disliking the mischievous Geneva who was natural leader of the class were hurdles to be cleared.

IT is never fair to judge one novel in terms of another. Each work of fiction, if it has any power at all in it, is peculiarly, and in a special way itself, offering its own experience and its own organization of values for our appraisal. A particularly grievous injustice may be done when an author's second book is considered as a mere continuation of the first.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Special treatment for 18-year-olds and veterans was directed by Selective Service headquarters today in a manual of instructions for the country-wide registration Aug. 30 through Sept. 18 of 9,500,000 men 18 through 25 years of age.

BEFORE he was 17 Don Morgan, who lived on the coast of British Columbia, had realized one of his ambitions. With the profits of his first trapping season he had purchased the 32-foot Mallard and was ready for a summer of trolling for bluebacks.

This article written by Milton Lehman, ostensibly a biographical sketch of myself, contains eighteen willful and malicious false statements.

DENVER, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans, playing his last two holes in a rainstorm, swept over the Wellshire course in 69 today to increase his lead in the $12,500 Denver open golf tournament.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Dethroned by George Stuhr Jr. a year ago, Billy Edwards of the home club regained his crown today when he defeated Tom Bowles of Cherry Valley in the final of the Long Island Golf Association junior championship at the Hempstead Golf Club course.

The signing of a temporary Federal injunction yesterday in the threatened strike of dock workers along the Atlantic Coast brought the majority of the nation's maritime workers under legal restraint in the most unusual kind of labor trouble ever faced by the industry, shipping men declared.

THE crispness that is already beginning to be felt in the mountain nights in the north woods is directing the thoughts of resort operators to the turning of the foliage, now only three or four weeks away.

ON a warm summer afternoon ex-Sgt. Steve Rowe, now an aspiring author, meets an old Army friend, ex-Pvt. Al Rolland. Steve accepts Rolland's invitation to make his headquarters at the Sherman Rolland Agency, a combination seraglio, theatrical booking agency and gambling den.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The American battle of the airwaves with the Soviet Union -- pushed into high gear by recent developments in the "spy" ease in Washington -- seems for the first time in many months to be swinging in favor of the United States.

QUEBEC CITY -- For Alfred, a Canadian caleche driver of Quebec, this has been a pleasant summer. Each morning at 10 he hitches Buster to his three-seater rig, with its big white wheels, folds the bright red blanket carefully over the seats and proceeds at a trot over the cobblestones to his regular stand at the Place d'Armes, in front of the Chateau Frontenac Hotel.

ROME, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Governor Dewey paid tribute to Premier Alcide de Gasperi's statesmanship in a message delivered today. He said Signor de Gasperi deserved "the encouragement of every freedom loving person."
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Princess Margaret of England, whom one British journal has called the "world's most widely watched teen-ager," today attained her eighteenth birthday and officially became of age.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- Playing steady, workmanlike tennis, Frank Parker of Los Angeles, Calif., and Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., won the Casino doubles championship today and virtually assured themselves of Davis Cup berths.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- If any general settlement on Germany is to be reached by the United States and the Soviet Union, a definite decision will have to be made in Washington as to the relative value to the United States of a Western German state and of the United States' position in Berlin.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- Business was brisk as usual for 14-year-old Hans Holdhauser, but there was an added excitement to it today as he peddled French, Swiss, British and American chocolate bars off the Potsdamer Platz. He could not tell whether the Americans, the British or the Russians were going to pull a raid.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 21 (UP) - Harrison Dillard, ex-GI from Baldwin-Wallace; Herb Barten of Michigan and Dick Ault of the University of Missouri led the barnstorming American Olympic track and field squad to a one-sided triumph today over the United States Occupation Army's best athletes.

ON a January day in 1476 the people of Brittany cheered the birth of a princess, destined to be crowned their sovereign only twelve years later. A gasoline seepage, apparently from the tank of a near-by gasoline service station, caused the Board of Transportation yesterday to order all trains on the Independent subway line to slow down approaching Eighth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. Fumes collected in the subway tunnel, but caused only minor delays.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- Regardless of the outcome of the current conversations in Moscow and ensuing negotiations, the feeling exists among the statesmen of Western Europe that the basic differences between East and West have small chance of being thereby settled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee scheduled today two closed-door hearings for Monday and Tuesday in a final effort to clear up conflicts in the testimony of Whittaker Chambers and Alger Hiss before they confront each other at a much-heralded public session Wednesday.

THE scheduled commercial airlines of the United States may now be entering a new phase of their long period of development. The pattern of their growth up to the present may be subject to considerable change.

A special edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, edited and printed in New York, will be distributed in Paris during the session of the United Nations General Assembly, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE TIMES.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Guardsmen of the 107th Infantry, the former Seventh, and of the 102d Engineers, together with those of smaller units from Brooklyn and the Bronx, started packing today at Camp Smith for the return to their homes tomorrow morning.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- The visit here last week of James Forrestal, United States Secretary of Defense has given rise to so many rumors and reports about future joint defense plans that, here at least, some authoritative statement as to what is and what is not intended is being asked for.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 21 -- The first annual novice championship regatta of the First Division International Star Class Yacht Racing Association got under way today with the home club holding the margin after the first two races. Sea Cliff compiled 20 points, the result of a third in the morning and a victory in the afternoon test by Skipper George Kelley and John Thomson.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 21 -- Western German leaders preparing for the Parliamentary Assembly now definitely scheduled to open Sept. 3 in Bonn, plan to issue a general invitation to all German areas outside the three Western zones to attend the session.

The huge grain and cotton crops now being harvested in the United States may prove rather costly to the Federal Government. Under the mandatory price support program, which was started to encourage farmers for greater yields in the war years, it is estimated that in excess of $1,500,000,000 may be required for non-recourse loans to farmers on this year's wheat, corn and cotton crops.

Retail activity here last week was stimulated by early fall buying, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Busiest departments were college shops, jewelry and blouses.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 -- Three streaks came to an end today for the league-leading Cleveland Indians.
Norman Thomas, Socialist party candidate for the Presidency, evaluated the major political parties and their candidates yesterday and conceded that the likely winner was Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- If Soviet Consul General Jacob Lomakin tries to buck American orders to leave the United States he will be deported anyway, official sources at the State Department said tonight.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 21 -- As leaders of world Zionism gathered for a momentous session of the World Zionist General Council which opens here tomorrow, tension mounted in the city today after a night and morning of fairly heavy shelling in the military sectors on the outskirts.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., Aug. 21 (AP) -- George Stewart, a Panamanian student at South Carolina A. and M. College for Negroes, and Althea Gibson of Wilmington, N.C., won singles championships of the American (Negro) Tennis Association today.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 21 -- The apparent defiance of the Finnish Communists and indirectly of Moscow by the Social Democrat Government was stress further today by the release of a Finnish "war criminal." This was Toivo M. Kivimaeki, former Minister to Berlin, who had served half the five-year sentence imposed upon him by a war responsibility court in line with the dictates of the Russo-Finnish armistice.

JAMESBURG, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Arelo Petraglia of the Fort Monmouth Country Club won the New Jersey State Professional Golfers Association championship at the Forsgate Country Club course today with a 72-hole total of 292.

A POOL does for a garden what a wall mirror does for a room -- reflecting beauty, suggesting space and possibly lending an air of enchantment. But it has a still more functional aspect. It serves as a unique bed for flowers that cannot bloom on dry land.

HAMPTON, Va., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A wind tunnel capable of 1,700 miles an hour is being readied at the Langley laboratory for study of supersonic aircraft designs. The laboratory is the oldest and largest of three research establishments operated by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA).

SARATOGA, SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Algasir, 2-year-old gelding that cracked a world record at Belmont Park in June and won the Flash Stakes here Aug. 2, today was purchased by Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark of Old Westbury, L.I., for $106,000 after a spirited check-book duel at the Saratoga sales paddock.

Despite an increase in reorders for fall ready-to-wear, activity in the wholesale apparel market here continued slow last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buying office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- For eight years a constant succession of international crises, spaced by war, has prevented the Republicans from voicing criticism of the foreign policy of the party in executive power to the degree that is usual for an opposition party. The last Republican National spokesman who felt free to do so was Wendell L. Willkie in 1940, and even his attacks were restrained by the mounting atmosphere of national danger.

Two locals, both members of the same international, the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, are competing for the right to represent 360 employes of the Hecht store, 53 Fourteenth Street, it became known yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 -- Los Angeles appeared to have ventured at least knee-deep this week into the knotty question of the legal status of sky-writing. DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, CIO, renewed his attack on the automobile industry's pricing system today, declaring that recent increases could not be justified on the basis of third-round wage rises.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Nazi radio's wartime "Axis Sally," Mildred Elizabeth Gillars, returned to the United States today to face treason charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--Gen. Carl Spaatz, reporting officially as the retiring Chief of Staff of the Air Force, advised Secretary of Defense James Forrestal today that present plans for the United States Air Force constituted a blueprint for a weapon "prepared for any emergency and immediately capable of rapid expansion" in the event of war.

THE tuneful and unaffected music put on the air these early Sunday evenings (6:30) by Jane Froman and Percy Faith automatically commends their program to the attention of the selective listener. Since their recent return to the CBS network for the new season their broadcast is indeed "The Pause That Refreshes."

The letter of William Lescaze about the new Princeton University Library prompted me to take an occasion for passing through Princeton during the past week to look carefully at the library and see to what extent his criticisms are valid. In so doing I discovered that to me, as a non-professional in architecture, Mr. Lescaze's adverse criticisms seemed to be very slightly valid and still less relevant.

WESTERLY, R.I., Aug. 21 -- Dredging of the Pawcatuck River here by the United States Army Corps of Engineers as part of a channel-deepening project has been stopped because of complaints of residents of Avondale, which adjoins Watch Hill, that fumes from muck dumped by dredgers has caused the paint on their homes to turn to a dirty brown color.

THE recent indictment of the leaders of the Communist party on the charge of conspiring to overthrow the Government of the United States by force confronts us with a problem whose perplexity is matched only by its gravity. For it involves far more than the fate of the Communist party alone -- a fate which cannot in itself be of very serious concern.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- With eight of the ten games in the eleventh round decided, the second stage of the United States chess championship at the Community Center was well advanced tonight.

BRIARCLIFF, MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Overcoming a lead of 3 up held at the turn by his opponent, Tucker Campbell, 16-year-old local club player, Ray Billows rached the semi-finals of the Briar Hills Golf Club invitation tourney today, 1 up.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Indian despatches from the front line in Kashmir said today that a mass migration of Moslems from areas occupied by raiders to territory occupied by Indian troops was taking place in Kashmir and Jammu.
Four crocodiles, two elephants, seven buffaloes, a lion, five leopards, three hippopotamuses, two rhinoceroses, several antelopes, one water buck and a hartebeest.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Aug. 21 -- Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth retained her women's trans-Mississippi golf championship today by defeating Miss Margaret Gunther of Memphis, 7 and 5, in the 36-hole final. The pair also met in the final a year ago.

THE New York City Opera Company, whose revival of "Don Giovanni" last fall proved one of its moat sucful productions, is adding another Mozart opera to its repertoire. It is "The Marriage of Figaro." All the singers are not known, but the Susanna will be sung by Virginia MacWatters and the Countess will be a newcomer.

Potential new demand for waste paper is likely soon to cause a serious drain on present sources of supply, it was stated yesterday by Colley S. Baker, director of the Eastern Conservation Committee of the Waste Paper Consuming Industries.

Upward revaluation of New Zealand's pound to parity with British money after eighteen years of discount status has intensified the scrutiny which is being given by the financial world to Britain's fight to maintain her pound at its current $4.03 1/4 rate of exchange with the dollar.

When Babe Ruth died last Monday evening, public interest was aroused in teropterin, which is the trade name of pteroyltriglutamic acid, the newest drug to be used in cases of cancer. Despite teropterin the Babe died, but there is reason to believe that it prolonged his life for months.

ANDRE GIDE, the Nobel Prize winner of 1947, has long been an enthusiastic moviegoer. Even at his present age of 78 his insatiable curiosity and love of the new have not flagged. Intimate friends tell of his insistence upon seeing the latest film even during his far-flung travels and in remote places.

GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- Eight countries that did not negotiate tariff reductions in Geneva last year have expressed interest in the new negotiations to be sponsored by twenty-two signers of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, it was announced here today.

THE girl called Kitten is never seen outside her room on the second floor of the home of the Corwith family. The only persons permitted to enter that room are the other members of the family, the physician and a few elderly visitors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Truman began the first full day of his "rest cruise" with a 7 A.M. plunge from the gangway of the yacht Williamsburg into the Potomac River off Blakistone Island, and tonight was cruising leisurely on Chesapeake Bay toward the Naval Academy at Annapolis.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- During the past week there was again a wide variation in retail business activity throughout the Twelfth district. Reports from larger stores showed sales ranging from plus 13 per cent in the Los Angeles area to only a 1 per cent gain in Salt Lake City.

Sir Arthur T. Harris, former Royal Air Force marshal and now managing director of the South African Marine Corporation, announced yesterday that the company would expand its services in the next few weeks and open a route between Canadian and South African ports.

IF the Boston Braves are going to win the pennant this season -- and any loyal Dodger fan would rassle you to a finish for daring to suggest such a thing -- the key operative could very well be a rookie shortstop named Alvin Dark. Louisiana State's gift to the major leagues has plugged that yawning hole at shortstop through which so many defeats had poured in the past.

" FREEDOM OF THE AIR" is a cry often raised by some critics of national radio. The interesting thing is that when you analyze the rhetoric of these people you find they are really not talking about freedom for all, but about privilege for a few.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Shooters from every part of the country converged on this little Miami Valley village today, all seeking a share of the $50,000 in prizes in the forty-ninth Grand American Trapshoot.

The response by duck hunters to the recent announcement on the 1948 waterfowl regulations has been greater in volume than ever before, but this year the protest concerns the premature decision reached by the agency drafting the regulations and not the regulations themselves.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Top-seeded Miss Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., today won the singles championship of the twenty-first annual Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament by defeating unseeded Mrs. Helen Pedersen Rihbany of Boston, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -The Army Finance Department is seeking to catch up on a tremendous bookkeeping job -- balancing the accounts of more than 11,000,000 officers and men in the last war.

AFTER reading a few chapters of this book one begins to wonder whether any of the leading characters in it are in full possession of their mental faculties. It is evident that at least one of them is mad and that some of the others are not far from it.
I am not what you'd call an ardent baseball fan, but when I read Lewis Nichols' "Baseball Is a Big Bore" I got the same clammy feeling I get when I see headlines on Communist activities in America.
The Federal Government, acting at the direction of President Truman, obtained yesterday a temporary injunction preventing a strike by 45,000 East Coast dock workers scheduled for last midnight.

IT literally took the fear of the 65-year-old roof caving in to provoke any kind of constructive rearrangement of paintings at the Metropolitan Museum. During repair eleven galleries have to be vacated. Consequently, the new curator, Theodore Rousseau Jr., decided temporarily to shuffle a group of pictures out of national and chronological order and to re-hang them according to broad categories -- portraits, landscapes, figure compositions - mixing old with new.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Eric Johnston, director of the Anglo-American Joint Film Council, who arrived here today to reopen negotiations with the British Government and motion picture officials concerning the showing of American films in Britain, characterized as "unjust" the boycott of British pictures now being conducted in the United States by the Sons of Liberty.

The dubious distinction of being the last borough in this city still to have trolley lines fell to Brooklyn early this morning when the Third Avenue Transit Corporation completed the motorization of all street lines in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -The late Father Flanagan, famed for his "Boys Town" in Nebraska, was disclosed today to have told the Army that a very bad influence on Austrian youth was being exercised by crime, detective and adventure films.

CONSIDER one gloomy item at the beginning of an uncommonly promising season. The future of the Experimental Theatre is in doubt. The Fact Finding Committee of the theatrical unions regards the Experimental Theatre as a device for cheap tryouts, which the committee believes threatens the structure of labor union security in the theatre The Fact Finding Committee would like to persuade Actors Equity to disavow the ET.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer scattered five hits to hurl the Cincinnati Reds to a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs today before 16,262 fans. It was his eleventh victory of the season.
OUTDOOR arrangements which have the elements to contend with and the outdoor scene to compete with, present problems quite different from those used indoors.

TOKYO -- United States Army Headquarters recently widened the tourist gate to occupied Japan by announcing that Americans would be permitted one-week stopovers in this country. A small number of Americans, going to and from the Orient, have already taken advantage of the opportunity to make a specially arranged tour.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Bethlehem-Sparrows Point Shipyard announced today that it had signed contracts to build eighteen large oil tankers.
PILOT KNOB, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A fire in a cottage at Lake George today cost the lives of a state official and his son, and three other persons were seriously injured.

CHRISTINA STEAD is a talented and often brilliant writer. Her previous novels ("House of All Nations," "For Love Alone," etc.) won her a loyal following and the acclaim of such discerning critics as Rebecca West and Diana Trilling.
HAVANA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Caribbean countries, where baseball is a major sport, will play their own "world series" in Havana starting next Feb. 20.
DENVER, Aug 21 (AP) - Professional basketball today claimed the Denver Nuggets, long-time power in A.A.U. court circles.

GO Climb a Pole Dept.: On a recent visit to Chicago, Glenway Wescott gave Fanny Butcher to understand that he liked the town. Whereupon Miss B. took the theme over: "He was," she wrote in her Sunday Tribune column, "genuinely thrilled with the city, with its expanding beauty, its zest, and its youthfulness, which is almost tangible.

The Greater New York CIO Council in a letter to Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard, made public yesterday, accused him of trying to institute "flophouse labor relations" in the department by means of his two recent orders banning distribution of union literature and abolishing grievance committees in the department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Soviet Embassy here maintained an unbroken silence today on the case of Consul General Jacob M. Lomakin in New York, who has been found persona non grata by the State Department.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Government's case against seven men in connection with an alleged bombing plot against Caracas, Venezuela, brought sentences ranging from eighteen month's imprisonment to two years' probation, imposed today by Federal Judge Frank Scarlett.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Loyal Legion, presumably the trail-blazer for his stablemate, Snow Goose, in the $29,000 Saratoga Handicap today, kept blazing all the way to give Walter M. Jeffords of Philadelphia the net of $19,950 at the end of the mile-and-a-quarter run.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- Paul Reynaud, Minister of Finance and National Economy, is the man to whom France has now turned for financial and economic recovery. On his success, it is agreed, depend the two vital elements in France's future:

ALDOUS HUXLEY'S new satiric fantasy, after the manner of his earlier "Brave New World," is a projection into the future; a conjecture, this time, on man's estate in the twenty-second century. What Mr. Huxley foresees is dire.

THESE two bibliographies are interesting jobs, not only for bibliophiles and collectors, but for students of Lawrence and Stephen Crane. Mr. Tedlock's task has been a particularly difficult one. D.H. Lawrence was one of the few first-rate English literary talents in a generation that included Aldous Huxley and E.M. Forster.

" To me," writes Lord Dunsany in his Introduction to this first novel by a young Irish-woman, "there is something unreasonable in a situation that Miss Crone assures me exists, which makes it quite impossible * * * for her novel to be published unless somebody who has already written books writes an introduction.''

" TODAY AND YESTERDAY" is the theme of the flower show sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State in conjunction with the Dutchess County Fair. It will be held from Aug. 31 to Sept. 4 at Springbrook Park, Rhinebeck, N.Y.

The Board of Education, which will spend $200,000,000 in 1948-49 to operate New York's $600,000,000 public school system, will give parents an opportunity to see how the money is spent when the city's golden anniversary celebration opens Monday at Grand Central Palace.

As part of the inauguration of Dr. Arthur Stanton Adams as its eleventh president on Oct. 9, the University of New Hampshire will present a three-day symposium on "The World Today." The series will begin Oct. 7 with a discussion of "The National and International Scene," and will include sessions on natural resources and their influence, economic forces and the military scene.

THE revival of Rossini's "Turco in Italia" at Tanglewood recently was artistic and diverting. The score of the little opera has delightful music. The libretto of Felice Romani is now useless. This music had long intrigued Helmuth Wolfes, who had done research on the opera, and brought the score to Mr. Goldovsky's attention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, of New York, made public today appeals to the White House and the Commerce Department for assistance in providing scarce building materials for New York's residential construction program.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- New England's Governors have demonstrated again their willingness to "transcend state boundary lines" in the interests of the common good. They have unanimously agreed to set up two twelve-member committees to study the possibilities of pooling institutional space and of coordinating facilities of the land-grant colleges.

OMAHA, Aug. 24 -- Millions of Midwest families are scrubbing the children's ears these days, getting ready for the annual trek to the state fair -- to enjoy its dust and cotton candy, its farm machinery exhibits and its pickled peaches competition.

The recalcitrant crew of the Government transport-type liner Marine Carp was ordered summarily by the National Maritime Union, CIO, to return to the vessel yesterday after a labor dispute had held the 12,420-ton craft overnight.

LONDON -- The Olympic Games were probably an incidental rather than the sole and exclusive attraction for the majority of the hundreds of thousands of visitors now in Britain. To that extent therefore, it meant less to this country, now definitely established as a tourist center, than it will mean to, say, Finland, host for the next Olympic Games.

Congratulations to Catherine Mackenzie for yet another valuable contribution to the field of education. In "Prejudice Can Be Unlearned" she opens up a vital problem from which too many of us still politely shy. We need to recognize the symptoms and to isolate the germ of prejudice before we can adequately fight it.

THE long-distance swimming contest, held once before on Lake George, will be resumed on Wednesday, Sept. 8, with possibly 200 candidates competing over a twelve-mile course for $6,000 in awards. The first competition was held in 1927.

IN 1944 the island of Walcheren was held and fortified by the enemy; and, sitting as it does across the mouth of the Scheldt River and jutting into the North Sea, it was a barrier which kept Allied shipping from the port of Antwerp.

JUST fourteen years ago this week in this Review: A firstnovelist called John O'Hara published "Appointment in Samarra" and thus, it was authoritatively said at the time, took his place "among those young writers concerned with the American scene whose work will bear watching."

KEN ENGLUND, a veteran Hollywood writer and the author of more than twenty successful screenplays, believes that one or the troubles with movies is that everybody, from producer to prop man, has a hand in the script.

GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- Three times in the last 130 years the urban and industrial areas of the world have faced protracted difficulties caused by the relative shortage of foodstuffs and raw materials. Each time renewed progress toward higher standards of living has been possible only after the opening of new agricultural areas, heavy foreign investment in raw material development and a fall in food and raw-material prices.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 21 -- A contest for the Democratic designation for the Assembly from the First District is the only battle scheduled for Tuesday's primary in Nassau County. The contest is between Francis X. McGlynn the organization's choice, and Mrs. Pearl H. Sokolski, until recently a Democratic county committee-woman and also candidate of the American Labor party.

In direct contrast to the popular conception of violence, suspicion and fear that too frequently are associated with mental institutions, there is a ward in the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital where a group of 15-and 16-year-old boys are finding affection, understanding and acceptance, many for the first time in their lives.

THE sun is shining bright and hot in Hollywood. The swimming pools are cool and refreshing. The market places abound with tantalizing fruits of nature and there is no apparent shortage of customers. Tourists are on hand in goodly numbers and clamoring to get inside the studio gates.

THE Czech-made Beaconlite enlargers for small negatives are again being imported by the Edbar International Corporation, 95 Madison Avenue, and are available at Abe Cohen's Exchange, 142 Fulton Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Another break in cash corn, making the third day of sharply declining prices, unsettled all grains on the Board of Trade today. Soy beans and lard also weakened, all contracts of the latter commodity sinking to new seasonal lows.

Patrick (Pat) B. McGinnis, that youthful looking Wall Street broker of a quarter of a century experience, was the man behind the scenes who directed the buying of stock which resulted in the coup of Frederic C. Dumaine in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

Early this week some 73,000 persons assembled in Cleveland's municipal stadium to watch their hometown Indians do battle with the New York Yankees. According to Mr. Lewis Nichols, most of them were in for a frightfully boring afternoon.
Great Britain served notice yesterday that she would refuse to vote for Israel's admission to the United Nations.

INVOKING author's prerogative, Arthur Miller, who wrote the prize-winning "All My Sons," has decided to pigeonhole "Plenty Good Times," which was to have been his next Broadway entry, in favor of "Death of a Salesman."

TWO-WAY automobile radio telephones are becoming so widely used in areas where facilities have been set up that they are now welcomed by highway officials as an important aid to highway safety. The mobile telephones have proved particularly helpful in calling police and medical aid to accidents in outlying areas in time to save lives and additional mishaps.

Grounds for complaint against methods used by certain regional trade show groups were disclosed last week after officials of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen announced they were taking steps to "refute and rebut" complaints which had been filed with the Small Business Committee of the House of Representatives in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Library of Congress has announced that it has just returned to Germany 412 cases of book and other library materials from the Deutsche Arbeitsfront (German Labor Front) collection.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 21 -- The International Bar Association closed its second annual conference here today by adopting a resolution favoring if possible amendment of the United Nations Charter by a simple majority vote.

Pardonably proud of their outstanding achievements, eleven of the superb watermen who participated in the unprecedented eight-event United States sweep of swimming and diving first places at London arrived back from the Olympics yesterday aboard an American Overseas Airlines Constellation.

SEATTLE, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren of California told the national convention of the Fraternal Order of Eagles today that "every working American should be entitled to the benefits of social security."

In big things and little the past ten days have witnessed a deterioration in relations between the Russian Empire (as we may again properly describe it) and the Western world. The Danubian conference ended as was expected, with Russia in actual -- though certainly illegal -- control of the river.

CENTERED around the ivory figure of a sea gull, this new story by the author-artist of "Paddle-to-the-Sea" and "Tree in the Trail" is a saga in miniature of a family of American seafarers. Ezra Brown carved Seabird from a walrus tusk during his first trip aboard a New Bedford whaler.

ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Forty-one contests for Congressional, State Senate and Assembly nominations will be decided in the New York State primary election Tuesday. Polls will be open from 3 to 10 P.M., Eastern Daylight time, in New York City and from 12 noon to 9 P.M., (EDT) elsewhere.

ABOUT half the poems in William Meredith's second volume, "Ships and Other Figures," owe their existence more or less directly to the poet's war experiences in the Naval Air Corps, although the book is in no specific sense a "war" book; the title suggests Mr. Meredith's attitude toward both aircraft carriers and performances of chamber music.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 21 -- Although Israel still is in a state of war and is concentrating most of her efforts in that direction, there is considerable interest in politics in view of the coming elections. Citizens from the age of 18 will go to the polls some time before Oct. 1, which is the deadline set by the United Nations when the Provisional Government was envisaged.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Bob Porterfield, the amazing young righthander who popped out of Newark a few weeks ago to give the Yankee pitching staff a vital shot in the arm, again came through handsomely for the Bombers today.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Ted Horn of Paterson, N.J., won a 100-mile automobile race marred at the outset by a collision which seriously injured Driver Mack Hellings of Burbank, Calif., at the Illinois State Fair today.

The Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York, AFL, added its name last week to a number of organizations opposing the Port of New York Authority's $114,000,000 proposal to take over operation and financing of city waterfront rehabilitation.

Alfredo Salmaggi has announced the cancellation of the winter season of his Popular Price Grand Opera Company that had been scheduled to begin its one-a-week performances at the Brooklyn Academy on Sept. 11. The decision was made Thursday after failure to reach an agreement with the American Guild of Musical Artists that controls singers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board and the Department of Justice were surprised today by President Truman's telegram to the International Typographical Union yesterday promising an investigation of an angle of the printers' strike against Chicago's newspapers, according to a dispatch to The Chicago Tribune from Washington.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- In a drying remnant of the wet Easterly, which built up East-Northeast and then kept gasping on, the fifty-fourth annual regatta of the Huguenot Yacht Club was held on Long Island Sound today.

A more hopeful attitude on foreign affairs, despite the cloak of mystery surrounding negotiations between Moscow and the Western Powers, was reflected last week in financial markets. Although prices of stocks were firmer, activity was limited as traders remained on the sidelines; the volume on the New York Stock Exchange dropped to the lowest weekly total in nearly a year.

THIS is an account, in diary form, of a newspaper man's six months' tour of Cuba and eight of the nine South American countries, covering June, 1947, to January, 1948. It is a generally well-informed, easily read, journalistic survey of contemporary conditions, more comprehensive than profound, but at least the work of a competent, hard-working reporter who has lived and labored at his profession in the territory he covers.

THE fact that 55,000,000 people look at comics and cartoons means they have a larger audience than any other graphic art and should be seriously considered on an art page. But now there is a more immediate reason for discussion.

ATHENS, Aug. 21 -- What may be considered the last pitched battle of the Grammos campaign was being fought tonight in the vicinity of the village of Slimnitsa, whence a final rebel escape route runs into Albania. Slimnitsa is three miles from the border.

THE late C.E. Montague, from whose books the passages in today's Treasure Chest are taken, was one of the best of latterday English essayists. He had in high degree certain qualities that are almost always present in masters of the art of informal discourse.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- The Australian Davis Cup tennis team called upon its freshman member, little Billy Sidwell, to pull it into the challenge round and he appeared to be well on his way to doing it until, by mutual agreement, the inter-zone final with the Czechoslovakians was suspended late today at Longwood.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 21 -- High prices, lack of housing and a bipartisan militaristic policy were listed by Henry A. Wallace as major campaign issues when he opened his Progressive party campaign for the Presidency in Candlelite Stadium here tonight.

IGOR STRAVINSKY wrote his Symphony of Psalms in 1930. It was "composed for the glory of God and dedicated to the Boston Symphony on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of its existence." Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony gave the work its first performance in this country late in 1930.

STIMULATED by the cooler weather that has prevailed in many sections of the country, consumer response to early fall merchandise offerings by retailers has been favorable. The latest weekly report of the Federal Reserve Board on nation-wide department store sales shows a rise of 15 per cent over last year, which is more than twice the rate of gain noted this year up to Aug. 14.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Air Force scientists are working on a guided missile capable of carrying an atomic warhead 5,000 miles, General Spaatz revealed in the report.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- A fight for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Twenty-Seventh Congressional District is the only contest to be settled on Tuesday in Westchester County's primary elections. However, in vitriolic accusations it is exceeding most other contests of recent years.

PROF. ALFRED WEBER is one of the most prominent of the older generation of German scholars. Before returning in 1946 to the University of Heidelberg where he taught before the National Socialist regime, he wrote the present book.

Because their school programs are still geared to the horse-and-buggy days of the nineteenth century, several million children living in the rural sections of the United States are receiving an inferior education today. Despite the advances made in recent years, there are nearly 100,000 one-room schools in this country, offering their pupils inadequate training.

Alger Hiss, former State Department official who is a leading figure in the Washington "spy" hearings, has ample grounds for refusing to submit himself to the indications of a lie-detector. Though the instrument is widely used by the police, banks, chain stores and insurance companies, the courts, with few exceptions, refuse to admit its evidence as conclusive or to accept its operators as qualified experts on mendacity.

New Yorkers learned on May 31, 1896, through the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES, that street riots in Crete might disturb the peace of Europe, that hundreds of peasants were trampled to death in Moscow at the coronation of Nicholas II, and that a 13-year-old girl was strangled on East Thirty-seventh Street.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Anna M. Dursch's 3-year-old Ann's Lee captured the 7,500 added Mary Dyer Stakes at Narragansett Park today. She came from behind to take command at the quarter pole and win by two lengths over Mrs. Lottie Wolf's Mayram.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A Congressional committee said today that the law on which the Federal Communications Commission was basing its crackdown on "give-away" radio programs had been repealed. It asked whether the FCC was going ahead with its campaign and, if so, how.

In a careless mood I wandered past the middle section Of The New York Times Magazine last week and found myself afloat in a strange world, where no man meets a friend. I passed cooking displays, an exposition of queer-looking furniture, women's fur coats designed to chill any male's financial status, on to a series of pictures titled "Dance Festival."
UNIVERSITY, Ala., Aug. 21 -- The majority of the student body at the University of Alabama would oppose the opening of the institution's classrooms to Negroes, it was reported here today.
The text of Henry Wallace's address at Bridgeport, Conn., last night, follows:

Your readers should know that in the background of Mr. Lewis Nichols' irresponsible attack on the noble invention of General Doubleday there is more than meets the casual glance. It is, simply, that Mr. Nichols is a frustrated baseball player.

The Associated Colleges of Upper New York, established two years ago to absorb the state's overflow college enrollment, have vacancies for 1,800 freshmen for the fall term which begins next month. No longer an emergency project, the Associated Colleges are expected to play a major role in meeting the academic needs of recent high school graduates and other non-veterans who cannot find openings elsewhere.
That pretty blue Brooklyn pennant flew briefly from the first-place spot atop the center field stands at Ebbets Field yesterday and 34,456 fans went wild when it was raised.
INTEREST in daylilies is soaring. An editor remarked recently, "Every time we even mention daylilies we are deluged with calls and letters asking for more information."

SALT HARBOR. ONLY a few days more, and the summer season will be over. Vacationists hereabouts are trying to make the most of the time between now and Labor Day for rest and recreation. Some are getting rest; but if the other word means a complete alteration job, other persons aren't getting their money's worth.

CHARLES GORHAM is the author of "The Gilded Hearse," a so-so item on last season's fiction list that achieved some headline notoriety when it came under the eye of Mr. John S. Sumner's Society to Maintain Public Decency.

In all our talk about modern warfare and the need for atomic controls, we have somehow assumed that the scientists were pillars of moral purity, and that the responsibility for atomic and bacteriological bombs lay with the politicians and the people at large. The fact is the reverse.

T. D. Lysenko, Vice President of the Supreme Soviet, President of the Lenin Academy of Agricultural Science, Academician, Member of the Presidium of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and director of four agricultural research stations, has burst into print again.

ALL over America today church bells will be ringing out hourly. In city and village the bells -- Presbyterian, Methodist, Baptist, Episcopal and many others -- will call Christians of all denominations to pray for the World Council of Churches, which holds the opening session of its first Assembly in Amsterdam, Holland, this afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Cardinals tightened the National League pennant chase tonight by taking an easy 9-to-2 victory from the fourth-place Pirates, and pulling to within a game of the pace-setting Boston Braves.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Discovery of nine new white dwarf stars, so dense a single cubic inch of them weighs as much as 2,000,000 pounds, was announced tonight by the University of Minnesota.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Until some time tomorrow afternoon, Joe Van Blerck Jr.'s Aljo V from Freeport, L.I., is enjoying the spotlight of appearing to be the best of the enormous record-sized fleet of speed boats in the sixteenth running of the National Sweepstakes Regatta after the first half of the program today.

High-compression automobile engines operating on high-octane gasoline promise large savings in fuel, one-third more mileage and a great stretching of available petroleum supplies, the Society of Automotive Engineers learned from John M. Campbell, Darl F. Caris and Dr. Lloyd L. Withrow, General Motors engineers.
By liquidating substantial portions of their stock in the last six weeks, dry goods jobbers now are enjoying a sounder inventory position, according to Worth Street sources yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Aug. 21 -- United States and British authorities announced today that industrial production in the bizonal area had leaped by 20 per cent in the month following currency reform, setting a post-war record both in the level attained and the magnitude of the increase during a single month.

LONDON, Aug. 21--The International Congress on Mental Health which has been meeting here for the last ten days ended this afternoon and turned over its work to the newly created permanent World Federation on Mental Health.
IT is strange to see an iris in bloom in midsummer, but at least one kind does flower now. This is the vesper iris, a vigorous and floriferous plant if there ever was one.

LONDON, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- About 1,000,000 fans welcomed the 1948-49 soccer season throughout England today and saw a number of upsets as the eighty-eight-club English League swung back into action after the summer lay-off.

TRIESTE, Aug. 21 -- All Communist party members and officials who have refused to accept the disavowal by the Communist Information Bureau of Marshal Tito and other leaders of the Yugoslav Communist party were expelled formally by a unanimous decision of hundreds of delegates at an extraordinary congress of the Trieste Communist party that opened here today.

TOKYO, Aug. 21 -- The wildcat strike of railroad employes, which has been tying up more than 100 trains daily in Hokkaido for weeks, apparently collapsed tonight after the Government had ordered the workers to return by 6 P.M. or face dismissal, fine or imprisonment.

DR. COHEN, who teaches the history of science at Harvard, gives us an amplification of Dr. James Conant's Yale lectures "On Understanding Science." The purpose is to tell readers who have taken a liberal arts course in college, but who know nothing of physics or biology, how great discoveries are made.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The New York Yankees cashed two intercepted passes to defeat the Brooklyn Dodgers, 14 -- 7, in an exhibition between the All-America Football Conference rivals tonight before 14,101 fans at Braves Field.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Winton E. Broidy, aged 34, of Garden City, L.I., was killed today when his F-61 Black Widow fighter plane crashed on a hill near the municipal airport here.

THE nation's first wildlife park and, as far as is known, the first such wildlife park in the world, was recently opened here at Jackson Hole in northwestern Wyoming. In an area of some 400 acres, hemmed in by practically invisible fence, the visitor may watch a remarkable collection of big wild creatures, all native Americans, living safe from hunters and reasonably untrammeled by their confines.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- The northern California fishing season now is three weeks old, and catches generally have been poor, especially in sardines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The United Mine Workers hailed today an announcement by officials of the UMW Welfare and Retirement Fund that application forms were in the mail and that aged coal miners would begin to receive their first pension payments next month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- Boycott of a National Labor Relations Board ballot on the "final offer'' made by waterfront employers in the West Coast maritime dispute was recommended today by a coastwise caucus of longshore and ship clerk locals of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Alleged monopolistic and unfair trade practices in twelve Midwestern and Southern cities will be investigated in a series of hearings by the House Small Business Committee. The committee announced today the hearings will begin Sept. 3 in Butte, Mont.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Aug. 22 -- The office of the Chief Signal Officer in Washington has received a citation and gold leg band from the First Retread Post, American Legion, Los Angeles, for Kaiser, believed to be the world's oldest carrier pigeon. The bird is living in retirement at the Army Signal Corps pigeon breeding and training center here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A new high record of nearly 32,000,000 youths will swarm into schools and colleges this fall, the Office of Education predicted today.

PRAGUE, Aug. 22 -- August Kliment, Communist Minister of Internal Trade and one of the rising leaders of the Czechoslovak Communist party, in an address today prophesied in effect that Germany eventually would become an Eastern bloc country as a result of the Moscow negotiations.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 22 -- Considerable interest is being shown here in the report of negotiations for the placing of $10,000,000 of bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development on the Amsterdam market.

Stewart Miller of the New York Athletic Club led a field of twenty competitors from start to finish yesterday to capture the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior long-distance swimming championship in the waters of Long Island Sound. The victory marked a successful defense of the title he gained last year for the first time.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Lofting a shot through the posts on a sixty-yard penalty drive with 2 minutes and 12 seconds of the sudden-death period elapsed, Alan Corey Jr. led his Meadow Brook side to a 7-6 victory over Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes in the final round of the National twenty-goal polo championship tournament at Bostwiek Field today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Northern Westchester's new planning program, stemming from an agreement among five towns and one village to coordinate their controls on future subdivisions, highways, airports and other revisions of the landscape, will begin to take shape on drafting boards in October, the County Department of Planning said today.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A new world record went into the books today as a huge field of scatter-gun artists wound up preliminary events in the 49th Grand American trapshoot.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- In a precedent-setting decision the National Labor Relations Board today dismissed a request by office-building employes for an election to determine a collective-bargaining agent.

BREUKELEN, the Netherlands, Aug. 22 -- The good burghers are quietly making plans to celebrate in ten days a double-barreled event, the like of which has not been seen in the modern history of the Netherlands.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 11 -- Sir Donald Simpson, New Zealand-born trade expert, has arrived here to organize opposition to the ratification of the Havana Charter on behalf of an influential London body of industrialists and statesmen, the Empire Industries Association.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Sid Luckman pitched three touchdown passes today to lead the Chicago Bears to a 28-14 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League exhibition witnessed by 33,506 fans. Johnny Clement scored both Steeler touchdowns.

A bunch of the fans were whooping it up at Ebbets Field yesterday -- 33,151 of them -- because the Dodgers had stolen eight bases, five in one inning, and were leading the Braves, 3 -- 2, going into the eighth inning.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Instead of any one boat running away with the cups, bowls and silver plate trophies, the two-day Red Bank regatta wound up tonight, as gray skies and the rumble of approaching thunderstorms began to darken the North Shrewsbury River, with three speed craft sharing top honors.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Olaf Ulvestad of Seattle gained his eighth victory in the twelfth round of the United States chess championship tourney today, beating Franklin Howard of East Orange, N.J., in forty moves. With the four games he has drawn the West Coast expert leads the field with a score of 10 -- 2, with seven more rounds to go.

Dr. Judah L. Magnes, president of the Hebrew University and chairman of the Ihud (Union) Association of Palestine, who is now in this country, announced yesterday his support of proposals to establish a Palestine Confederation of sovereign Arab and Jewish states, with Jerusalem as the capital.

PHILDELPHIA, Aug. 22 -- After getting off to another two-game flying start in their second successive week-end clash with the Athletics, the Yankees today again found it beyond them to sweep a four-game set from the Mackmen. But this time it wasn't the Bombers' fault.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Missouri Valley Conference football coaches held a clinic today in collaboration with the Mid-Western Intercollegiate Officials Association.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Non-profit Blue Cross hospital service plans now have an enrollment of 31,210,819 in the United States and Canada.

Gen. Nicolae Radescu, the last constitutional Prime Minister of Rumania, now residing here, issued a message last night urged renewed courage on his countrymen everywhere. The statement marked the fourth anniversary of King Michael's coup d'etat of Aug. 23, 1944, when Rumania broke away from the Nazis and joined the Allies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The West scored two runs in the second and another in the eighth to defeat the East, 3 -- 0, in the sixteenth annual Negro all-star baseball game before 42,099 fans in Comiskey Park today.

Rear Admiral Carl F. Holden of Bangor, Me., will assume command today of the United States Naval Base, New York, it was announced yesterday at Third Naval District Headquarters here. His office will be in the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn. He succeeds Vice Admiral Russell S. Berkey, now commander of Naval Forces, Far East.

A novice pickpocket, arrested with a Bible in one hand and a concealed length of pipe in the other, will be sentenced tomorrow for disturbing passengers asleep on a Third Avenue elevated train, the police reported yesterday.

New York's receipts on its 2 per cent sales tax showed a sharp increase, amounting to $8,700,332 for the first seven months of this year, with a total of $101,727,071 collected during that period, it was announced yesterday.

A middle-aged school teacher confirmed yesterday afternoon the old adage that "teacher knows best" when she freed a 2 1/2-year-old girl caught between two bars in an iron grill fence on East 211th Street, near Hull Avenue, the Bronx.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- In a long telegram today to Secretary of State George C. Marshall, Walt Disney Productions, through its president, Roy O. LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 22 -- A raiding party of Monmouth County detectives and State Troopers, led by Prosecutor J. Victor Carton, invaded the Hollywood Hotel in the West End section here last night and arrested three men on charges of bookmaking.

Dowling, president, to Greeff Fabrics, Inc., decorative and upholstery fabrics and wallpapers, in a transaction negotiated by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers. James D. Landauer Associates, Inc., realty consultants, represented the buyers, who insured title with the Lawyers Title Corporation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Heavy liquidation developed in lard futures on the Board of Trade last week, all deliveries selling at a new seasonal low, with closing trades Saturday at the bottom, showing losses of $1.65 to $1.77 a hundred pounds for the week.

Schwegler, director of the Swiss National Bank, and expected to silence critics once and for all, was made public last week.
Machinery without God is of no avail, the Rev. Harold A. Cockburn of Scotland warned yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

New York's serialized celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Greater City enters its climax today with the opening to the public of the Golden Anniversary Exposition at Grand Central Palace. This entertaining and enlightening show continues to Sept. 19, and will offer New Yorkers an opportunity to understand their city better.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- General liquidation developed last week in the grain markets on the Board of Trade. All deliveries of corn and soy beans, May and July wheat and September oats sold at new seasonal low prices, with September corn in the lead. The break in September corn was 12 3/4 cents a bushel from the high on last Monday.

The final decision on whether there will be a 1948-49 Metropolitan Opera season has been promised for today. The unions are expected to deliver their answer to the management's repeated requests for status quo contracts some time in the day and George A. Sloan, chairman of the board, said the Metropolitan's decision would be announced shortly afterward

Although the majority of delegates felt that improved mental health among the peoples of the world would achieve a substantial gain for peace, there were dissenting voices at the International Congress on Mental Health, the first American delegate to return from London declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Some of the most influential persons in the American Federation of Labor are opposed to the endorsement of a Presidential candidate by Labor's League for Political Education, the AFL's political arm.

Panama led Cuba by one point to take top position in both credit and collections in the first half of 1948, according to the fortieth semi-annual survey of commercial credit and collection conditions in Latin-American markets by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

In a transaction involving payment of cash over a mortgage of $101,616, the elevator apartment building for forty-nine families at 2916 Morris Park Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Terence Realty Company to Gertrude Schorr.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Aug. 17 -- The ten-month-old war in Jammu and Kashmir State has reached a stalemate. The Indian Army, in defensive positions, is facing Pathan tribesmen and Pakistan regular troops on six sectors.

ATHENS, Aug. 22 -- Today's reports from the Grammos area said heavy mop-up fighting was continuing in the Slimnista region.

As a memorial to George Herman (Babe) Ruth, a stadium named in his honor will be built on the grounds of Archbishop Stepinac High School, White Plains, Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday. With the signing of a temporary injunction against an Atlantic Coast longshoremen's strike, a majority of the nation's maritime workers, both sea-going and dockside, are now under legal restraint in labor disputes.
