Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and her daughter, Mrs. John Boettiger, will introduce a series of fifteen-minute radio discussions over the American Broadcasting Company network on Oct. 4, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Air Force and Navy are buying a number of newly developed pilotless jet planes to be used for target practice, it was announced today.

TRIESTE, Aug. 22 -- Marshal Tito's decision to pursue a policy designed to keep Yugoslavia outside the Soviet sphere of influence and insure her neutrality in the event of war between Russia and the West was the basic reason that led to the Communist Information Bureau's denunciation of the Yugoslav Communists, it was learned today.

George C. Cruise "daddy" of the group of veteran city employes who will be honored at the golden anniversary exposition, remembers the 1898 consolidation of the boroughs for a special reason. It resulted in his going to Brooklyn.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Three Princeton University professors, who retired recently after contributing a total of almost a century of service to the university, are remaining active in the fields of study where they won recognition, and found varied careers over the last forty years.

Prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market moved last week in a narrow and irregular range, but the trend was downward. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 14 to 50 points on 70 cents to $2.50 a bale from the week before, with the distant contracts again registering the greatest declines.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Paul Chotteau, 50 years old, who claims the long distance swimming championship of the world, made a two-mile swim in Lake George today after being dropped from a boat, his wrists handcuffed and his feet tied tightly together. A crowd estimated by the state police at 10,000 witnessed the event.

Long Island University will continue and expand its facilities in Brooklyn, but is ready, if a favorable ruling is made by the Court of Appeals, to set up quickly its planned branch at Brookville, L.I. Dr. Tristram Walker Metcalfe, president, said yesterday that the university had leased 8,600 square feet of new space at 380 Pearl Street, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Red Sox retained their grip on second place in the hot American League pennant chase today by defeating the Senators, 4 -- 1, their fourth triumph in a row over Washington. It was the Bostonians' tenth victory in their last twelve games and was accomplished before a paid crowd of 26,734.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 -- The future of United States-Argentine relations for a long time to come appears to depend on the outcome of conversations Ambassador James Bruce has been having with officials of the State Department and the Economic Cooperation Administration in Washington.

Moscow, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Western envoys negotiating with the Kremlin on the German situation conferred again here today and awaited a call to see Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov, but the call did not materialize.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Soviet official press said today that only forty of more than 2,500 persons seized in raids last week still were held. It declared twenty of them had been identified as stone throwers in the Potsdamer Platz riot.

A delegation of Hartford, Conn., admirers showered Walter Dubiel, an old Yankee, with gifts yesterday at the Polo Grounds and, in their own peculiar way, the Giants showered him with base hits to set the pattern for a twin victory over the Phillies, 9 to 4 and 3 to 0, and Leo Durocher's clan left for the West last night on the fringe of the first division.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Israeli Government made today a new bid for peace talks with the Arabs. An Israeli Foreign Office spokesman said that Israel was prepared to undertake "separate peace talks with each of the Arab countries."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The wife of Alger Hiss, one of the former Government officials alleged by a one-time Communist agent to have been part of a Communist espionage ring, has been questioned in secret by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The city's Golden Anniversary Exposition will be opened to the public today at Grand Central Palace. For 50 cents, visitors can see four floors of dramatic exhibits tracing the growth of Greater New York since its inception fifty years ago.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 22 -- A legal question, involving the relative authority of a shipmaster aboard his vessel and a member of his crew, on the one hand, and a policeman who complained that he had been shanghaied, confronted John A. Lyddy, superintendent of police here tonight.
BALDWIN, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Sol Korn and Ferdie Catropa, Peninsula, scored 32, 33 -- 65, six strokes under par, for the honors in the Willow Brook Club's third annual member-pro golf tournament today.

Retailers and apparel manufacturers took a more cheerful view of the fall season as early fall business gained momentum, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 22 -- Spread all over Long Island Sound, the larger racers in the Riverside Yacht Club's championship regatta today came tacking downwind in a breeze shortage, a fuel discrepancy such as neither man nor politician can correct.

Negotiators representing the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and employers are scheduled to meet in another bargaining session today at 10:30 A. M. at the regional office of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, 341 Ninth Avenue.

The controversy between airlines and the Port of New York Authority over leases and fees at New York International Airport at Idlewild was intensified yesterday by the executives of nine lines, who sent to Mayor O'Dwyer a letter charging the Authority with "persecution'' and "harassment."

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Dr. John A. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, Princeton, N.J., said in his address tonight that secular as well as religious writers have begun to see in Christianity "the one hope for mankind."

BERLIN, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Russian-controlled newspaper National Zeitung declared again today the Moscow diplomatic conferees had decided only the Soviet-sponsored currency should be used in Berlin and that the Western mark should be withdrawn.

American exporters have been placed at a competitive disadvantage as a result of the differential created by the exchange rate practices of the State of Israel on its new currency issue, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., advised the State Department yesterday.

ESTES PARK, Colo., Aug. 22 -- "The eagerness for learning on the part of children in bombed and blasted Germany and the idealism of their teachers in the face of terrible odds is the great hope for the future of our country," Dr. Elizabeth Winkelmann, German educator, declared today.

LOS ALAMOS, N.M., Aug. 22 (AP) -- "We are not going back to work until this matter is completely settled," 3,500 idle construction workers at the Los Alamos atomic weapons center were told today by W. T. Roberts and J. D. Qualls, their co-chairmen.

" Unity of the spirit in the bond of peace," was declared the goal of the World Council of Churches in Amsterdam by the Rev. Dr. Ernest M. Halliday, who preached yesterday morning at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.

In his sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday morning, the Right Rev. Austin Pardue, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Pittsburgh, reported to the New York diocese on the "true fellowship" achieved by the 330 Bishops and Archbishops at the Lambeth Conference in London, which ended on Aug. 8.

Efforts of the Four Chaplains Memorial Fund to construct at the Bronx Veterans Hospital a year-round swimming pool and therapy establishment for paraplegic, amputee and other patients there have been regrettably hampered by difficulty in raising the final funds needed to complete the project.

Right-wing Congress of Industrial Organizations unions in New York State will meet in Syracuse on Sept. 10 and 11 to formulate policy for the national election and to consider the question of endorsing candidates, it was announced yesterday.

John Carlos and Gaylord Van De Bogart of Niagara Falls, N.Y., bought the one-family dwelling at 530 Third Street, in Brooklyn, from Alma O. Smith in a deal negotiated by D.K. Purinton, broker. The property is assessed for $16,000 and was acquired subject to a purchase money mortgage of $8,000.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, has reminded members of that organization that the Communist party machine has not yet been eliminated from its ranks.

Winkelman, president of the Associated General Contractors of America, and head of the D.W. Winkelman Co., Inc., said today.

With the Actors Equity Association handling the production, the "Philco Television Playhouse" will open a weekly stand over NBC's video facilities Sunday, Oct. 3, from 9 to 10 P.M. Capehart is chairman, disclosed that only one letter has been received in favor of the decision and two requests to testify in its favor.

The new $750,000 building of the Brooklyn Jewish Home for Convalescents at 609 Beach Ninth Street in Far Rockaway, Queens, will open its doors today to receive its first patients.

NANKING, Aug. 22 -- President Chiang Kai-shek warned today that his Government would punish interference with the new currency reform and financial restrictions.

General Electric Company this week will present to supervisory personnel in its Schenectady home office the first performance of its company-developed "theatrical show," covering efforts to improve employe and community relations, L.C. Boulware, vice president in charge of employe and community relations, disclosed last week.

DENVER, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Methodical Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., overcame a two-stroke deficit on the final eighteen-hole round today to win the $12,500 Denver open golf tournament as Freddie Haas Jr. of New Orleans blew up on the last two holes.

A new two-year contract, retroactive to April 1 and covering about 3,200 employes of United Parcel Service, Inc., was ratified yesterday at a membership meeting of Local 804, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, at Manhattan Center.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 22 -- In the idyllic setting of a wooded isle in Chiemsee, more than an hour's drive from Munich, deliberations over the last fortnight have given form and structure to a future Western German state. The finishing touches are now being put to a 300-page document that will be the preliminary draft of the constitutions that the conclave was called to write.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Signs of a slow-down in the steady post-war climb of American industrial production were reported today by the Department of Commerce.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 22 -- After a week of storms which partially disrupted rail and road traffic from the south, the second Edinburgh International Festival of Music and Drama was inaugurated today under a sunny sky that showed off to the best advantage the flags and flowers with which Princes Street is gay.

Mrs. Kusum Nair admitted she had started the publishing excitement in India. Her husband, Pran Nath, took over from there. They are now making a rapid tour of the United States and Canada to study and find machinery to expand their personal industrial revolution.

MANILA, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Luis Taruc, Communist chief of the Hukbalahap peasant guerrillas, sent word to President Elpidio Quirino today that he had not gone underground but was merely "in the field," advising his men to keep the peace.

TUPELO, Miss., Aug. 22 -- Representative John E. Rankin, ardent advocate of "white supremacy," faces one of the toughest political battles of his career in the Democratic primary in the First Congressional District Tuesday.

Education should aim toward producing "a balanced personality," the Rev. Charles J. McManus of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn mass. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- There are 1,000,000 handicapped persons who could be trained for work in addition to 500,000 now able and willing, a union official said today.

If Christians cannot work together despite their differences, there is little chance for the world to achieve a degree of stability, the Rev. Dr. Altman K. Swihart of the faculty of Carthage College, Carthage, Ill., declared yesterday. He spoke at the morning service of the Middle Collegiate Dutch Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -- The first dispatching from a new longshore hiring hall, described as the most modern anywhere, will take place here by 7:30 A. M. tomorrow, while the legality of the hiring hall, as operated along the West Coast, is a subject of scrutiny by the National Labor Relations Board.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 16 -- Despite a slump in the volume of gift parcels sent by donors in the United States to relatives and friends in Berlin, uninterrupted transit for such cargoes has continued throughout the blockade.

The extent and number of campaigns being prepared for home decoration and maintenance products indicates that this kind of advertising will be 10 to 15 per cent greater this fall than last, advertising officials estimated last week. In addition to the usual appeals, it is expected that importance of preserving the now more-than-precious home will be strongly emphasized.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 -- Hundreds of Yugoslavs, including fifty members of the secret police, have been arrested in a ten-day purge of persons suspected of supporting the Communist Information Bureau against Marshal Tito, it was reported tonight.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22 -- Creation of a permanent Federal commission on civil rights to implement the recommendations of the report of the President's Committee on Civil Rights was urged by Henry J. McCarthy, executive secretary of the National Citizens Council on Civil Rights, in a speech at Touro Synagogue here tonight.
For the second successive month there has been a decline in the city's public assistance caseload, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Pirates broke up a pitchers' battle with three runs in the top of the tenth to whip the Cardinals, 4 to 1, today. Errors by Babe Young and Enos Slaughter helped the Pirate cause.

The Un-American Activities Committee and its investigations, though they are not characterized by specific indictments, are none the less trials. The subpoenaed party -- the accused, in fact -- is on trial for his reputation -- the press is utilized to render suspect the reputations even of innocent parties.

New, modern highways and parkways leading out of New York to the east, northeast and north have long since made possible a rapid, easy flow of traffic to and from Long Island, New England and Westchester. But New Jersey, whose roads must bear the brunt of New York travel south and west, long has lagged in the construction of arteries adequate to meet the demands made upon them.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Browns walloped the Tigers, 10 to 1, today behind the three-hit pitching of Fred Sanford. It was Sanford's ninth victory against fifteen setbacks and the ninth defeat for Hal Newhouser, who started for the Tigers.

A NOVEL which was rejected by nine English publishers (and blind as bats they must have been, too), which might never have seen the light of day at all without the intervention of an elderly author of forty years' celebrity, is published today. It is "Bridie Steen,"* by Anne Crone, unquestionably one of the few distinguished novels so far published in the year 1948.

Carrying 385 pounds of baggage and diplomatic pouches, three Soviet attaches took off yesterday from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, bound for Moscow via Stockholm, on an unannounced flight aboard a Scandinavian Airlines plane.

William R. Peer, former city official and newspaper man, has been named director of press and public relations for the New York County Democratic Committee, it was announced yesterday by Hugo E. Rogers, Manhattan Borough President and Tammany leader.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Using the deadly long-range aerial attack that carried them to two successive All-America Conference titles, the Cleveland Browns defeated the Buffalo Bills in an exhibition football game today, 35 -- 21.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Detachments of the State War Disaster Military Corps of the New York Guard from all parts of the state arrived today at Camp Smith for two weeks of training. With the departure this morning of the 107th Infantry and the 102d Engineers of Manhattan, together with smaller units from Brooklyn and the Bronx, camp tours of the federalized New York National Guard are completed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Cubs trounced the Reds, 10 to 3, today to reduce the Reds' seventh-place margin over them to one and a half games. Johnny Schmitz scattered eight hits for his fourteenth victory. The Cubs pounded Ken Raffensberger and two successors for twelve hits, including Bill Nicholson's sixteenth homer.

KLAMATH FALLS, Ore., Aug 22 (AP) -- Four prominent Oregon Republican party leaders and state legislators were killed today when their plane crashed into the Lake of the Woods in northern Klamath County.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Trader Bedford, a 6-year-old bay gelding owned by Arthur Nardin of New York City, was declared the jumper champion at the conclusion of the Brookville Horse Show at J. T. Bragg's Stables today.

Tomorrow Margaret Webster, an organizer par excellence, will buckle down to direct "Hamlet" and "Macbeth." With the exception of the pre-Christmas period, these repertory presentations have been booked solid from Sept. 27 (Buffalo) until April.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- A spokesman for Universal-International today said that a lawsuit it had brought against its star, Deanna Durbin, to collect $87,083, which it declares it had advanced her, would not affect her contract with the studio.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 (UP) -- Young Billy Sidwell gave Australia the right today to meet the United States for the Davis Cup when he completed a straight-set victory over Vladimir Cernik of Czechoslovakia, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, at Longwood.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 -- Upwards of a million industrial workers in nineteen states may be idle as a result of a "secret deal" by which the War Assets Administration leased to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation the $30,000,000 Cleveland blast furnace now operated by the Republic Steel Corporation, according to Raymond L. Collier, executive vice president of the Gray Iron Founders Society.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Nothing occurred last week to change the stock market scene. Prices of securities continued to sway slightly and without purpose, and new low records for turnover in the Stock Exchange were reached. The summer holiday factor in market inertia is now wearing thin, but people returning from vacations have no mind to look at the markets until something definite emerges from the diplomatic talks in Moscow.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 -- Steel ingot output last week was advanced a half point to 94.5 percent of capacity, an indication that despite metallic and ore tightness some improvement is being made. This slight increase, however, was more than offset by a heavier influx of new orders and a certainty that carryovers (material promised for shipment one month but carried to the next) will be bigger in months to come.

It has been said that every one in the United States is against inflation -- so long as it's the other fellow's inflation. That may go far to explain the fact that nearly everyone who hopes to be counted as a foe of high living costs has at one time or another advocated the raising of the gold reserve requirements of the Regional Federal Reserve Banks.

Many of the inexpensive floral prints that the Waverly Fabrics division of F. Schumacher Co. is introducing to local stores for home decoration can be combined with at least two other fabrics specially colored or designed to blend with them.

About $1,800,000 worth of consumer goods and supplies are now being offered by the War Assets Administration in this region, it was announced over the week-end by Walter F. Downey, regional director of the WAA for New York and New England.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- The Soviet arrests in Berlin extended to a United States citizen today when Thomas P. Headen of the Information Servive of the United States Military Government was seized by Russian soldiers and carried off to a Russian interrogation point.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 22 -- The American Dance Festival gave its twelfth and last performance here today in the Palmer Auditorium, with a program by Martha Graham and her company which contained the twice-postponed premiere of Erick Hawkins' "The Strangler."

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 22 -- The Republican party in the United States is dedicated to the preservation of world-wide peace, John Foster Dulles said here today after his arrival from New York by plane.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Six European countries, the Allied occupation zones of Germany and China have received authorizations to obtain $81,393,807 in commodities, materials and foodstuffs under our global aid program, the Economic Cooperation Administration said today.
I read in THE TIMES of Aug. 13 that our energetic Park Commissioner Moses is going to mediate in the controversy over the nature of the World War II memorial to be erected in Manhattan.

Sales of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., textile manufacturers, in the first half of this year aggregated $96,687,708, or 40 per cent above the $46,190,817 volume transacted in the corresponding period of 1947, the report showed today. Excluding inter-company transactions, the total was $69,564,215, or more than 50 per cent higher than a year earlier.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Dr. James R. Angell, former president of Yale University, was re-elected president of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory today.

A plan for large-scale immigration of Italian industrial and agricultural workers into the United States, financed in part by European Recovery Program funds, will be submitted early next month to the State Department by the ItaloAmerican Industrial and Commercial Association, Inc., it was learned yesterday.
RANGOON, Burma, Aug., 23 (AP) -- Premier Thakin Nu appealed tonight to the people of Burma to exert all-out efforts in the Government's moves to quash a rebellion.

The work of lengthening a 175foot oil barge by the addition of a 42.6-foot midsection, increasing the craft's carrying capacity from 6,000 to 10,000 barrels, has been completed by Todd Shipyards Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 23 (AP) -- In one of the closest and most exciting finishes of the Atlantic City race meeting, three horses were noses apart at the end of the Long Beach Island purse today.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y. Aug. 23 -- Isaac I. Kashdan of New York and Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, in second place-with scores of 9 -- 2, and pressing Ola Ulvestad of Seattle for the lead in the United States chess championship tournament, drew their unfinished game from the eleventh round today after forty-seven moves had been recorded.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -The Federal Government is ready to allot $10,780,620 to the states for restoration of wildlife resources during fiscal 1949.

Marcel Cerdan, European middleweight champion, who is to meet Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., in a world title match at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City on Sept. 21, is due to arrive here from Paris by plane today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that it will provide a market for flaxseed delivered at Minneapolis and Duluth at Government support prices. The announcement was made after processors withdrew from the market because, they said, they could not pay the basic support price of $6 a bushel under current market prices for their finished products -linseed oil and meal.

TRIESTE, Aug. 23 -- Led by Moscow, all Communist parties in the world, other than the Yugoslav, have decided to fight Marshal Tito and his supporters to the death, Vittorio Vidali, local Communist leader, announced at the extraordinary congress of the Triestine Communist party that is being held here this week.

Life insurance companies that sell Government securities for the purpose of making long-term credit freely available to industry and to individual business on mortgages are deliberately intensifying the inflationary spiral, according to some banking observers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -The Department of Commerce reported tonight that "most" papermaking mills have reduced production "rather than attempt to cut prices in order to obtain larger volume of business."

David L. Greenwood, 16-year-old high school graduate who scored 99.9 per cent -- the highest mark possible -- in the university scholarship competition sponsored by the State Education Department, returned to Brooklyn yesterday from his summer vacation to make plans for his college career this fall.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

A business information drive, to make known to American industry the strategic material stockpiling plans of the nation's national defense agencies, is being started by the National Industrial Council, a manufacturing trade associations group affiliated with the National Association of Manufacturers.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Thomas P. Headen, Deputy Chief of the Information Services of the United States Military Government, was released today, one day after he had been seized by Russian soldiers allegedly for attempting to photograph a troubled boundary section in Berlin.

HONOLULU, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Richard A. Dole, 40, of the famed Hawaii pineapple producers family and three yachting companions were saved and a fourth was drowned as their 22-foot sailboat was swamped by heavy seas off Diamond Head yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -The White House will have to settle the question of how long a potential draftee must be married to qualify for deferment, it appeared tonight.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 24 -Premier Stalin had a long meeting during the night with the envoys of the three Western powers. It led early today to a decision to continue the current Kremlin talks. The decision gave new hope for settlement of the deadlocked Berlin and German problems.

Fluctuating political developments in Eastern Europe make it impossible to determine with any certainty the future there for American motion pictures, although some momentary signs of improvement can be noted, according to Irving Maas, vice president and general manager of the Motion Picture Export Association.
PLAINVILLE, Conn., Aug. 23 (AP) -- A National Guard training plane crashed here today and exploded, setting three houses afire and damaging another.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, commander of United States Army forces in Korea, has been recalled to the United States to take up a permanent and as yet undisclosed assignment, the Department of the Army announced today.

A picture of beauty was brought in to me this morning through the good fortune I have of being a subscriber to THE NEW YORK TIMES. It was the picture entitled "A Poetry Class in Session at Fordham," with Rev. Alfred Barrett, S. J., reading under the famed Poetry Tree.
The most comprehensive drive against venereal disease in the nation's history will begin within the next two months, Dr. Leonard Sheele declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- In an atmosphere of great secrecy, the House Committee on Un-American Activities rounded up today a half dozen "obscure" witnesses. Through them it will attempt to bridge key conflicts in the sworn testimony of Alger Hiss, former State Department official, and Whittaker Chambers, who has accused him of leadership in a pre-war Communist "underground."

Brisk buying in smaller quantities was the keynote of the thirtyfifth semi-annual New York Gift Show that opened in the Pennsylvania and New Yorker Hotels yesterday. Buyer registrations for the first day at 2,540 were 340 greater than last year, according to the George F. Little Management Corporation, director of the show.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor proposed today that the Government call together representatives of business, agriculture and labor to work out a voluntary anti-inflation program.

Wine goes with fine cookery, the "quick-fixes" (canned soups and their like) with homespun meals. But wine needn't be considered solely for the use of high-capped chefs; one or two tablespoons enliven tinned hamburgers as they do guinea hen, and at no great cost.
It was very gratifying to read in THE TIMES of Aug. 8 the excellent resume that was written by your Mr. Robert Trumbull, captioned "India, Age One, Facing Big Internal Problems."

George Herman (Babe) Ruth, baseball's greatest hero, remembered in death the "kids of America" whom he loved. His will, filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday, provided for the eventual gift of 10 per cent of the residue of his estate to the Babe Ruth Foundation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Canned luncheon meat, known under a dozen different brand names but all similar in content, has grown into a multimillion dollar business fron small beginnings ten years ago as more homemakers become aware of its value.

WHEN I read Tom Marvel's "The New Congo" a few months ago a cloud of gloom engulfed me. What kind of an Africa was this, infested with air-conditioned movie theatres and defaced by modern industrial plants? What would Paul du Chaillu and Henry Morton Stanley think of such goings on, right in their own private preserves in the middle of the dark continent? the dark continent?

Zot I. Chepurnykh, Soviet vice consul here, announced yesterday that he would return to Russia soon. He will not, however, sail next Saturday with Jacob M. Lomakin, the consul general, for whom passage has been booked on the Swedish American liner Stockholm.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 23 -- As the aftermath of a complaint by a Bridgeport policeman that he had been shanghaied aboard an excursion steamer, City Prosecutor Michael Sicilian issued warrants today for the arrest of the vessel's master and three other men.

A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., was reported yesterday to have placed the highest bid with San Francisco, Calif., for three bond issues, totaling $9,075,000. The group's bids were as follows:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 23 -- The International Red Cross convention received today a memorandum from the World Jewish Congress urging the addition of special clauses to the draft convention on the treatment of civilians in war time.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Westchester officials rejected today complaints by the Automobile Club of New York that drivers were baffled and traffic was snarled at intersections in the county because of obscure directional signs.
The Edith Macy Training School, a national Girl Scout center for adults near Pleasantville, N.Y., will close its 1948 season today, it was announced yesterday by Miss Clara Allen, director.

Three former officers of the National Maritime Union, CIO, including Ferdinand C. Smith, against whom the Government has instituted deportation proceedings, were brought to trial before a union committee here yesterday. The charges included violation of the union's constitution and participation in a conspiracy to disrupt the labor organization.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (AP) -Relief pitcher Harry Gumbert, the first man up in the tenth inning, cracked a home run over the left field wall tonight to win his own ball game and give the Cincinnati Reds a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phils.

Harold Bauer, noted concert pianist, will enter the field of literature on Sept. 13 with the publication by W. W. Norton of his autobiography. "Harold Bauer, His Book," describes the world of music both here and abroad from the Victorian London of childhood to his activities in the development of the musical life of America.

A split second before an F-84 Thunderjet he was testing at 500 miles an hour disintegrated, Carl A. Bellinger, chief experimental test pilot for the Republic Aviation Corporation, parachuted 12,000 feet to safety yesterday. He landed in the Atlantic Ocean three miles off Quogue, L. I.
The opening gun "is ready to be fired by the Health Department in the citizens' warfare against rats," it was announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Swiss Government blocked today all Rumanian assets in Switzerland as a "precautionary measure." A communique said the intention was to protect Swiss interests in Rumania.

The sandy sections of the rim along the ocean change their accessory accoutrements after each tide. Twice in each lunar period, after the exceptionally high "spring" tides that coincide with the first and third quarters of the moon, there is likely to be a fascinating harvest.

BASEBALL is a funny game. It isn't funny ha-ha. It's funny peculiar. Just a week ago the Yankees were virtually out of contention as a pennant threat. The Red Sox were marking time by doing most of their running on a treadmill. The steady teams were the Indians and the Athletics with Cleveland the sounder club by far.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- The Chicago Convention Bureau has proposed that docking charges levied on steamships stopping here should be lowered to encourage shipping lines to bring more visitors to the city by water routes.
Your editorial refers to tipping as a custom; it might more appropriately be termed blackmail.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Forrest McNeir, 73-year-old Texan from Houston, stole the show today as the forty-ninth Grand American Trapshoot opened.

New York State's enrolled voters will go to the polls today in what is expected to be one of the dullest primary elections in recent years. There are only forty-one interparty contests in the state, twelve of them in the metropolitan area.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -Several hundred members of Local 136, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, formed a mass picket line at the strike-bound Proctor Electric Company plant today, keeping out fifty office employes who tried to enter the building.
A 55-year-old grandmother was named last night as "Miss Hello of 1948," the first operator to be so honored since the telephone was invented in 1836.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23 -- An additional protocol to the ArgentineYugoslav trade agreement of June 7 was signed tonight. Under its terms Argentina is obligated to acquire Yugoslav merchandise worth only 70 per cent of the price of foodstuffs acquired here by Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, disclosed today that the top-level conference on short and long range military strategy, held last weekend in Newport, R. I., had resulted in strengthening the lines of "responsibility" among the three armed services and given each a role of greater authority to do the defense job assigned it.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 23 -- TransJordan and Iraq signed an agreement today in Amman unifying the commands of their armies. Iraqi Premier Muzahim Amin elPachachi visited Egypt's Premier, Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, to discuss the possibilities of a more far-reaching unification of Arab commands.

Another labor-management agreement in the maritime industry appeared probable last night as negotiators for the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and employers extended a day-long bargaining session into the evening.
The text of the protest to the United Nations Economic and Social Council by the World Jewish Congress was made public here last night by officials of the congress.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 23 -- Opera is represented in this year's Edinburgh festival by two of Mozart's works, presented by the Glyndebourne Company. This evening the first performance was given of "Don Giovanni" with a first-rate cast of singers, under the direction of Rafael Kubelik before a distinguished and enthusiastic audience in the King's Theatre.

Three silhouettes -- the turban with back-tilted height, the snug, close-fitting cap that comes well down over the ears, and the small, deep-backed bonnet -- formed the basis for the fall millinery collection presented recently by the English designer, Otto Lucas.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- The American and British military governors today ordered further commercial restrictions between their combined area in Western Germany and the Soviet, placing a ban on automobile and truck movement of freight intended for the Leipzig Fair, at least until after decisions have been reached in the Moscow talks.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Clouds of grasshoppers invaded Watertown and the surrounding countryside over the week-end and today began attacking corn and vegetable crops.
Anne O'Hare McCormick does not often slip; but she did a few weeks ago when she described Switzerland, that 600-year-old marvel, as an example of pure democracy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- The first sustained heat wave of the summer sent the mercury soaring over most of the country today.

Sears, Roebuck Co. has little surplus to offer at this time, it was learned yesterday from Anthony P. Lombardy, who heads the recently formed surplus liquidation division of the company's eleven mail order branches at the New York headquarters.

Consolidated net profit of Textron Incorporated and its subsidiaries increased to a record high of $3,805,000 in the first half of this year, according to the report Royal Little, president, is releasing today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 (AP) -- With most of the star entries relaxing comfortably on firstround byes, four divisions in the National doubles tennis championships got under way with a slim total of thirty matches completed today at Longwood.

An attorney for the twelve Communist leaders accused of conspiracy to overthrow the Government by force charged in Federal Court yesterday that the indictment was "a Communist scare" by the Democrats in New York to offset "a phony spy case being conducted by the Republicans in Washington."

ABOARD THE PRESS YACHT WANDERER, In Delaware Bay, Aug. 23 -- President Truman went to work today aboard the White House yacht Williamsburg on the address that will officially open his re-election campaign in Detroit on Labor Day.

ATHENS, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Greek Army troops moved eastward today from the Grammos zone to establish a new front in the Vitsi Mountains, where General Markos is expected to establish his "Free Greece No. 2."

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- As midnight approached the British Foreign Office was still awaiting official news from the meeting between Premier Stalin and Foreign Minister Molotov and the envoys of the United States, Britain and France.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Russians released today two United States Military Government officials after having detained them for eighteen days in Gotha, twentyfive miles west of Weimar. Their detention was the longest by Russian officials in the recent series of arrests of Americans.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Plans for fighting a new threat to the earnings of American films in Britain were under discussion by American film representatives at a day-long meeting here today with Eric Johnston, President of the Motion Picture Producers Association of America, it was reported tonight.

Ted Lyons and his streak-bustin spoilers, sometimes called the White Sox, moved into the Stadium last night, intent on handing the Yankees the same sort of treatment they gave the Indians last week-end. Tail-enders though they are, the Chicagoans were more than anxious to add to their fame by snapping the New York string of victories at six.
An issue of $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes will be offered tomorrow by the City of Boston. The notes will be dated Aug. 30 and will be due on Dec. 1, 1948.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 23 -- With Bob Chappuis, Hank Foldberg, Dan Edwards, John Wozniak and George Strohmeyer, freshman aces, taking part in their first practice since they left to compete in the All-Star game in Chicago seventeen days ago, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers went through an intensive two-hour workout today.
PARIS, Aug. 23 -- Two committees of the National Assembly adopted today a motion to defer local district election scheduled to be held just before the voting for the Council of Republic in October.
City, state and Federal mediators began yesterday efforts to settle without a strike the deadlocked negotiations of employers and unions in the trucking industry in the metropolitan area.

Three teams clipped nine strokes from par to finish all square at 63 in the weekly amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association over the North Hills course in Douglaston yesterday.

The sale of Government bonds by the life insurance companies has made only an "indirect and comparatively unimportant" contribution toward inflation, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, declared yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 23 -- Mr. Muccio, special representative of President Truman to the Korean Republic with the personal rank of Ambassador, arrived here from Tokyo this afternoon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 23 -- The opportunistic character of the Soviet Union's political collaboration with the Yugoslav Government at the recent Danubian Conference at Belgrade was disclosed today. This came in the news that the quarantine of Yugoslavia by the Communist Information Bureau was being intensified to a point where all normal interchanges between citizens of the Cominform world and Yugoslavia was being banned.

Homemakers are living in a green world as far as the colors of furnishings go, but visitors to their houses may be seeing more purple heather tones in a matter of months, according to findings of nation-wide color surveys conducted among 115,000 shoppers by the Rahr Color Clinic and released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -The Justice Department announced today that its special lobbying investigation unit has been made a permanent part of the criminal division.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -America's total production of goods and services soared to a record rate of $248,000,000,000 a year in the second quarter of 1948, the Department of Commerce announced today.

GENEVA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The World Jewish Congress protested today against a decision of the United Nations Economic and Social Council to postpone consideration of what the congress called a "reign of terror" in Egypt against Jewish residents.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 23 (UP) -- A Negro minister filed an affidavit with the Justice Department today that he was clubbed, stabbed and left for dead while two policemen looked on after he voted in the Aug. 10 Democratic primary.

The counterpart of the major leagues' All-Star game will be staged by members of the Negro National and American Leagues tonight when an Eastern squad faces a team from the West in a single game at Yankee Stadium. The contest will get under way at 8:45 o'clock.

A possibility that building service unions here may seeks closed shops now that the National Labor Relations Board has ruled that they do not come within its jurisdiction was seen yesterday by union and board officials.
George Bernard Shaw, the world's most famous vegetarian, is under fire both here and in Britain for "serious deviations" from vegetarian ethics, it was learned yesterday.

CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 23 (AP) -- After nearly a month of training, which included three exhibition games, Coach Ray Flaherty today cut his football squad from seventy-one to forty-one for the New York Yankees All-America Conference inaugural Friday night at Ebbets Field against the Brooklyn Dodgers.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores were unchanged last week as compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 5 per cent.

Tammany Hall's hopes of getting a Republican endorsement for its candidate for Surrogate, General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, were dampened last night when it was learned that the New York County Republicans had turned their backs on the proposal of Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, Tammany leader.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -Veterans of the Spanish-American War heard an expression of gratitude from the Philippine Government today at the opening of their fiftieth national encampment.

The refusal of a visa to Dr. Johnson was described here yesterday by the Rev. William Howard Melish, chairman of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, as "another symptom of the deadly deterioration in the maintenance of the traditional American principles of free speech and free assembly."

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. C. C. Tanner's Colonel O'F breezed to a three-quarter length victory in the featured sixfurlong Glendale purse today at Narragansett Park before 10,272 fans. His time was 1:11 3/5.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 23 -No one hereabouts wants to believe it, but it looks very much as if Teddy, a St. Bernard dog beloved by the children of a local parochial school, has fallen into bad company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -High Government officials and representatives of Federal employes paid tribute tonight to Arthur S. Flemming, who is leaving the Civil Service Commission to become president of Ohio Wesleyan University.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 12 -- To take over and expand the public health and educational programs intiated by the United States Military Government during nearly three years of occupation of Southern Korea will be among the first challenges to be met by the new Republic of Korea.
PARIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Garry Davis, who recently gave up his United States citizenship to emphasize his belief in the need for a world government, indicated today he might want the citizenship back.

The Theatre Guild's blueprint of its first production of the season, "Set My People Free," calls for a New York opening on Nov. 1 at a Shubert playhouse and for rehearsals to get under way on Sept. 7, under the direction of Martin Ritt.

GENEVA, Aug. 23 -- The United States proposed today that the Western zones of Germany be made parties of the general agreement on tariffs and trade, the compact of the World Trade Organization that was drafted in Geneva and Havana during the past two years.

WARSAW, Aug. 23 -- The Polish organizing committee for the World Congress of Intellectuals opening Wednesday in Breslau (Wroclaw) refused today to grant credentials to report the congress to Sydney Gruson, THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in Warsaw.

EMPORIA, Kan., Aug. 23 -- An ironic turn in one of the state's most bizarre murder cases today apparently upset the carefully laid plans of an Emporia business and church leader who allegedly had himself slain so that he could leave enough insurance to secure his wife's livelihood.

SAN FRANCISCO. Aug. 23 -Despite a proposed boycott of the balloting by longshoremen, the National Labor Relations Board announced late today that it would grant to members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union the opportunity to vote on Aug. 30 and 31 on a "final offer" made by employers in the West Coast maritime dispute.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 23 -- The Soviet Union's answer to the invitation to attend the International Red Cross convention in session here scores the organization for not having protested against "Fascist atrocities in Spain, Greece, Indonesia and Vietnam" and scoffs at the invitation to such groups as the Boy Scouts and the Knights of Malta.

" That Lady in Ermine," a period musical with an Italian setting, directed and produced by the late Ernst Lubitsch, will open an engagement this morning at the Roxy. The Twentieth Century-Fox production, photographed in Technicolor, co-stars Betty Grable and Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and features Cesar Romero, Walter Abel and Reginald Gardiner.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Jim Grady of Cincinnati, a quiet 16-year-old Irish lad, captured medalist honors of the third National caddy golf tournament today with a 71, 72 -- 143, one under par for the 36-hole grind.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Isidore Bieber, who claimed the 3-year-old colt Up Beat from the Greentree Stable for $15,000 six days ago, received a 17 per cent dividend on the investment at Saratoga today. Up Beat kicked mud at the opposition from soon after the start of a six-furlong run, won by three lengths or so, earned $2,600 and made the favorite players happy.

Following our report on the opening of the New Jersey railbird season on Sept. 1, a flood of protest has swept in from Connecticut hunters, who want to know why they cannot take to the wild rice flats until Sept. 15. Several of them apparently had made arrangements for a boat and pusher, supposing that the season would open on the same date as in previous years.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- A long list of strategic raw materials, topped by manganese, rubber and tin, was presented to British officials today by Evan Just, director of the Strategic Materials Division of the United States Economic Cooperation Administration.

Rising costs, particularly on transportation and labor, is accelerating a movement among drug manufacturers to route distribution through wholesalers along the lines of branch warehouse systems used by other industries.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Triplecrown winner Citation, apparently recovered from a hip injury which shelved him for thirty days, will be galloping for big money again in the $90,000 American Derby at Washington Park on Saturday.

Results of the survey of housing construction costs published in this newspaper last week-end discourage any hope that the family of moderate means will soon be able to find a home it can afford. Within the last year the cost of building or buying a small house here has risen 12 to 15 per cent, and it is now 115 per cent above prewar cost.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission asked the Supreme Court today to review a final order of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, disapproving in part a plan of liquidation filed by the Engineers Public Service Company, New York.
GENEVA, Aug. 23 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council adopted today a resolution condemning legislative barriers to interracial marriage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A double-barreled Congressional investigation was ordered today into the leasing of a surplus Governmentowned blast furnace at Cleveland, Ohio, to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

Disturbed by the international political situation, and pressure from the prospects of a bumper crop of cotton, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued their downward trend yesterday and closed 25 to 55 points net lower.

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 23 -"Witch hunting" in the United States is growing worse from day to day, threatening "the very freedoms which our Constitution has guaranteed to us," Dr. Ernest O. Melby, Dean of the School of Education, New York University, declared here today.

In her first year in post-war transatlantic passenger service, which began when she arrived here on Aug. 5, 1947, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary has carried a total of 78,648 passengers, the line announced yesterday.
ELMIRAg N. Y., Aug. 23--Dr.Lewis .ldred, professor of education, has been appointed presidentof Elmira College, effective next[July 1. Dr. ,,ldred, who is 37 yearsold, will succeed Dr. W. A. Pott ]
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Apart from individual features, conditions in the stock market here were quiet today pending the outcome of the new talks scheduled for tonight in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Robert N. Denham, General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, discounted today as "artificial smoke and no fire" charges by the International Typographical Union that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio applied "unwarranted" pressure on his representatives.

There was weeping and wailing and gnashing of teeth in Brooklyn last night after 32,499 of the faithful had watched the Dodgers battle the Braves for three hours and forty-nine minutes, only to lose the all important game, 3 -- 2, in the fourteenth inning.

Another member of the State Public Service Commission asserted yesterday that body's independence in setting bus fares as he presided at a hearing on the East Side Omnibus Corporation's application for a fare rise. Commissioner George A. Arkwright reiterated the statement made last week by Commissioner Spencer B. Eddy, that the state agency was not bound by any agreement made by the city administration and the bus line operators.
Australia became a source of supply for the New York orchid market with the arrival yesterday of a shipment of the ever-popular cymbidiums that came by air half way around the globe.

GENEVA, Aug. 23 -- Nearly $10,000,000,000 in grants and loans for war reconstruction has been given by countries other than the United States, according to a United Nations economic report released today.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The "Red Dean" of Canterbury, the Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, disclosed today that the United States had refused him permission to enter, but said that he hoped to be admitted "when Mr. [Henry A.] Wallace is President, which I think is sure to be within three years."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 23 -State Banking Commissioner John Dickerson, acting on behalf of certificate holders of the defunct New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company of this city, took initial steps today in Chancery Court here to recover $60,937 from Pellegrino Pellecchia Sr., until recently president of the Columbus Trust Company of Newark.
An unusual complaint was read into the court record yesterday in Special Sessions, Long Island City, Queens.

Leading domestic air carriers in the United States stood firm yesterday against making a separate charge for meals aloft. The subject of free meals was discussed at last Thursday's meeting of the Civil Aeronautics Board and domestic trunk lines in Washington.

A price reduction of $6 a ton on pig iron for American buyers has been made by the United Austrian Iron and Steel Works Company, Linz, Austria, one of the two largest steel mills in that country, Dr. F. H. Leitner, Austrian Consul, 683 Fifth Avenue, said yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- German opinion in the Western zones, as reflected in newspaper editorials, generally is pessimistic about the possibilities of the Moscow talks' resulting in a satisfactory solution.
TOKYO, Aug. 23 -- Action intended to bar Communists from holding public office apparently is being prepared by the Cabinet.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Aug. 23 (AP) -Miss Grace Lenczyk, 21-year-old golf star from Newington, Conn., fired a 1-under-par 76 today to lead a field of 102 in the 18-hole qualifying round for the Canadian women's open golf title she captured last year.

Silver, a 9-year-old Arabian stallion valued at $2,500, was back in the old corral on West Sixtyseventh Street yesterday and New Yorkers may rest assured that the alleged horse thief is corraled in the City Prison.
New York's Golden Anniversary Exposition opened its doors to the public yesterday at Grand Central Palace.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 -A new independent film-producing company, Fidelity Pictures Corporation, entered the field here today with a tentative schedule of six features to be made within the next eighteen months. Heading the organization is Howard Welsch, a producer at Republic.

New York continues to hold a dominant position in the women's coat and suit industry with 74 per cent of the 1947 sales to its credit, according to a study of the Market Planning Service of the National Credit Office, released yesterday. Last year, 1,102 manufacturing concerns here produced a total of $709,408,000 worth of coats and suits.

With a newspaper and spot radio campaign beginning Sept. 14 in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, Bisceglia Brothers Wine Corporation, Long Island City, will introduce a twelve-ounce "Junior Jug" bottle, designed to make wine a popular item for picnics, lunch boxes and daily mealtime use, it was announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 23 -- A Zionist budget for war purposes and reconstruction totaling hundreds of millions of dollars was presented today by the Israeli Minister of Finance, Eliezer Kaplan, to seventyseven members of the Zionist General Council, supreme governing body of the Zionist movement.

A series of fifteen-minute interviews with staff members of THE NEW YORK TIMES will be broadcast by WQXR at 9:45 A.M., Mondays through Fridays, starting Sept. 1. Alice Pentlarge will conduct "Keep Up with The Times," as the programs will be called.
Skyrocketing food costs have forced a large number of persons receiving public assistance to use money given them for clothing to supplement their food allowance, it was learned yesterday.

An encouraging vista of the future of New York as the great air crossroads and generator of overseas flight for passengers and goods is to be found in the prophecy made by James C. Buckley, Director of Airport Development for the Port of New York Authority, before the Export Managers Club.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 23 (AP) -The Israeli Government said today that acts of desecration against Christian religious property by its soldiers had been "isolated transgressions by irresponsible individuals," who had been punished.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 23 -- The World Council of Churches, representing all the major Christian denominations except Catholic, was officially constituted here today by 450 religious leaders representing 50 Protestant and Orthodox church bodies in forty-two countries.

At least fifty American cargo ships are operating from the United States to Japan, China and the Philippines each month, filling in major part the gap left by the withdrawal of the Japanese merchant fleet in this trade area, according to the American Merchant Marine Institute.
There will be a 1948-49 season of opera at the Metropolitan Opera House, officers of the Metropolitan Opera Association announced yesterday.

ATHENS, Aug. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, chief of the United States Military Mission, sent a message today to Lieut. Gen. G. Tsakalotos, commander of the Greek Army's First Corps in the Grammos campaign, saying: "You and your officers and men have surpassed my most optimistic expectations."
President Truman has been urged by the Milk Dealers Association of Metropolitan New York to prevent a new milk-price increase here, it was learned yesterday.

Thirteen persons, including three fire lieutenants, nine firemen and a woman tenant, suffered minor injuries or were overcome by smoke yesterday afternoon in a two-alarm fire that burned out the fourth and fifth floors of a five-story old-law tenement at 202 East Ninety-sixth Street.
JACKSON, Mich., Aug. 23 (AP) -A massed line of 2,000 pickets today fought off a small band of office workers attempting to enter the strikebound Aeroquip Corp.
The issue of "demonstrations" by Welfare Department employes who are members of the United Public Workers of America, CIO, may be coming to a head, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Perhaps it is because cynics know from experience that the high emotional content of Presidential campaigns will overwhelm them in a sea of guff that they choose August for special activity before a quadriennial subsidence of two months' duration.
An extra of 10 cents on common and a regular quarterly dividend of 35 cents, both payable on Sept. 15, was voted by the American Chain Cable Co. This is the company's first extra.

THE TIMES editorial of Aug. 18, "The Waterfront Decision," is pertinent and timely. Its writer has made a concise and accurate estimate of the situation, but in advocating operation of the cityowned waterfront facilities by the Port Authority has departed from the realities.

Moving toward settlement of the differences between the Port Authority and nine scheduled airlines at La Guardia Field and Idlewild, Mayor O'Dwyer asked Commerce Commissioner Edward C. Maguire yesterday to attempt an amicable adjustment of the dispute.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 23 -- A 26-year-old former postoffice clerk who admitted he had robbed the mails to play the horses was put on probation today for three years and ordered to return the $690 he had stolen.
PARIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Olympic purists, a little staggered by the scope and success of the first post-war games in England, think the show ought to be cut.

Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, asked the City Planning Commission yesterday to approve a capital outlay of $9,472,177 for rehabilitation of some neighborhood welfare centers, described as "unbelievably sub-standard."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, with apparent reluctance, exempted today from the competitive bidding provisions of Rule U-50 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act the proposed sale of 200,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a subsidiary of the United Company.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a $251,421,000 call on its accounts with the Class B banks. The call, for 15 per cent of such deposits as of the close of business Aug. 20, is payable Aug. 30. Banks in this area will be required to provide $70,906,000 on the call date.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP) -- "I musta slept a year somewhere," Satchel Paige remarked today as he handed over a $500 check to a Cleveland man who proved Ol' Satchmo had played professional baseball before 1927.
Continued improvement in early fall retail trade will spur covering of Christmas holiday needs, purchase of which has been delayed in comparison with a year ago, market observers here said yesterday.

Sharply lower prices for commodities proved contagious yesterday as the stock market suffered its most severe slump in almost two weeks. Selling enlarged as the session progressed to bring the heaviest offerings in the last hour, with pivotal issues reduced from 1 to 2 points and the composite rate lowered 1.23 points on the day.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Shanghai Bankers' Association today set the interest rate on loans at 15 per cent a month.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A mission from the Economic Cooperation Administration visited three British agencies today trying to find out what Britain can contribute to a strategic materials stockpile in the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) -The Republicans probably will spend a great deal more than $1,000,000 on small-town newspaper advertising alone in the fall election campaign, the Republican National Committee's advertising agency announced today.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 23 (AP) -- This city, already noted as a world medical center, again is to the forefront with a program of free doctors' care for the poor.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- In his first official act on returning from his vacation, Prime Minister Attlee conferred today for two and a quarter-hours with the chiefs of the British military services and with some of his Ministers. They presumably discussed military problems arising from Britain's difficulties in Malaya and Germany.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway borrowed yesterday $5,500,000 on equipment trust certificates maturing over ten years at an interest cost of 2.744 per cent. It was the fourth equipment trust financing which the C. O. has consummated this year in which the borrowing has been margined by less than 1 per cent of the cost of the equipment to be acquired.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 -- The State Department of Education Division of Motion Pictures reported today that it banned five pictures and approved 1,653 during the 1947-48 fiscal year. The department also ordered eliminations made in 123 other pictures reviewed during the year.

MANILA, Aug. 24 -- Lingering Government hopes of restoring peace to Central Luzon under the armed truce conditions prevailing since the amnesty deadline expired on Aug. 15 are rapidly fading. Provincial reports to Manila newspaper are bringing guerrilla warfare back into the headlines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, and his Army, Navy and Air Force chiefs called upon the three armed forces today to stop their inter-service rivalry and observe the "intent, as well as the letter" of the Newport decisions.

Paul H. Hill has resigned as general sales manager of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, effective Sept. 15 to join the Mengel Company, Louisville, Ky., as vice president responsible for the distribution of Mengel permanized furniture.

DUBLIN, Aug. 24 -- After an absence of eleven years, an American team appeared in the fresh green, flower-lined jumping enclosure at Ballasbridge, where Dublin's great horse show opened today, to take part in the first international military event.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The State Department said today that the United States would protest to Israel over the kidnapping and maltreatment of a United States code clerk in Jerusalem.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The idea of controlling nationalized industries by joint boards representative equally of trade unionists and management has been emphatically rejected by the Economic Committee of the General Council of Britain's Trades Union Congress, the annual report of that body revealed today.

Such surprise touches as linings of shantung and taffeta enlivened the fall and winter collection by Brigance, which was previewed on Monday at Lord Taylor. Coats and suits with what this designer termed his "neat look" and a group of interchangeable separates for daytime and evening were featured.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- New financing in excess of $1,000,000 was disclosed today by three companies in registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The present 405-line definition and other technical characteristics that include the latest developments of the British Broadcasting Corporation's television broadcasting system will continue to operate in Britain for some years to come, it was officially stated today.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A patrol of British Gurkha troops today killed two Chinese insurgents carrying Siamese travel permits. It was the first documentary evidence of Chinese Communist infiltration from Siam into rebellious Malaya. The incident was in Kedah State.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 24 -A decision by Justice James T. Hallinan in the Supreme Court, Jamaica, Queens, upheld today Milton Gottlieb, corporation counsel of Long Beach, who has opposed a petition by the Sarber Realty Corporation for the construction of what it called "seventy-seven residence units and lounge."

Three former officers of the National Maritime Union, CIO, charged with violation of the union's constitution and conspiracy to disrupt the organization, walked out on a union trial committee yesterday, declaring that the proceedings were "rigged."

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- Zionism is reaching an important crossroads in its fifty years of existence as a movement to restore Jews to Palestine as discussions proceed here among top level leaders in the Zionist General Council on the question of divorcing the political functions and administrative organs of the newly created state of Israel from those so far maintained by the Zionist movement.

Mrs. Oksana Stepanovna Kasenkina consented yesterday morning to meet the press and answer questions about her relations with Soviet officials here before and after her jump from the consulate building on Aug. 12, but changed her mind later in the day.
DENVER, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The International Mailers Union, independent, ordered national and local officers today to comply with the Taft-Hartley Act while condemning it as unfair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Karl Drews checked a ninth-inning Washington rally which had produced four runs to give the St. Louis Browns a 6 -- 5 victory over the Senators tonight. It was Washington's ninth straight loss and a sixth triumph for Rookie Bill Kennedy, who allowed only three hits until weakening in the ninth.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Some 200 foundrymen who buy pig iron from the Republic Steel Corporation urged the War Assets Administration today to cancel the lease turning over the huge government-owned blast furnace here to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

Members of the Board of Estimate are expected to discuss the $30,000,000 proposal to install water meters in residential buildings when they meet in executive session at 2:30 P.M. today in City Hall, it was learned yesterday.

Adolphius Bell, who said he was a lawyer in Mississippi and Illinois as well as a professional song writer and piano player, was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of having defrauded a Harlem business man by some interesting forgeries in real estate and securities deals.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Jersey City ran its winning streak to three in a row and handed Buffalo its fifth and sixth straight defeats tonight by taking both ends of a double-header from the Bisons, 4 -- 0 and 3 -- 2.

This is the time of hushed tranquility. The urgency of spring has spent its force. The ocean lies brooding through hot days and starlit nights. This is the sea's peaceful interlude. Gentle rollers pulse landward and their breaking crests crochet long lines of lace across the beach front.

An unidentified man plunged 136 feet yesterday from the Washington Bridge into the Harlem River at 181st Street after tearing loose from the grasp of a junior high school teacher. His body was picked up by the crew of a passing tug.

A threat to withdraw his support from the Equity Library Theatre -- financially and otherwise -- was voiced yesterday by John Golden, veteran theatrical producer of philanthropic leanings, who has been cooperating with Actors Equity ever since ELT was founded five seasons ago.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 24 -- The Korean Government and the United States Army here have reached agreement on the turning over of the Korean security forces to the control of Koreans "as rapidly as possible consistent with the common security of the Republic of Korea and the United States Army forces in Korea."

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 25 -- The Soviet Union has rejected United States protests regarding the refugee Russian school teachers and has approved completely all actions taken by Consul General Jacob M. Lomakin, in the handling of their cases, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Three co-educational schools, on the lines of the American high school, will be started next month just outside London, the Middlesex County education authorities announced today. Existing schools will be used as it has not been possible to build new premises because of shortages of labor and materials.

Germany is still occupied by the victorious Allies. Every country formerly held by the Nazis as the result of ruthless aggression has been returned to its own people. Her colonial empire was taken from her following her defeat at the end of World War I.

A California court decision extending fair-trade law controls to the resale of war surplus trademarked commodities was hailed by drug trade spokesmen here yesterday as providing a doubly valuable precedent for the future.
RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Burma Government said tonight that a large number of rebels had surrendered to Federal forces.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- That last-ditch stand of the Giants in the National League pennant scramble got off in the right direction today at Wrigley Field, but with a stagger-start touch.

Four films will have local premieres today. "The Velvet Touch," a drama with a Broadway theatrical background starring Rosalind Russell with Leo Genn, Claire Trevor and Sydney Greenstreet, will open early this evening at the Rivoil. The picture is scheduled to have its first showing at 5:20 o'clock.
OTTAWA, Aug. 24 -- The heads of all the thirty-five diplomatic missions in Ottawa except the Russian gave a dinner tonight in honor of United States Ambassador Ray Atherton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The consumers' price index rose 1.2 per cent in the month which ended July 15, reaching a new high of 173.7 per cent of the 1935-39 average, the Labor Department Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 24 -- Following is the text of the address by John Foster Dulles before the Assembly of the World Council of Churches:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Diplomatic officials took a calm view tonight on a Russian note announcing the closing of the only two Soviet consulates in this country and demanding a similar shutdown of the sole United States consulate in Russia.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The itinerary for the visit of King George, Queen Elizabeth and Princess Margaret to Australia and New Zealand next year, outlined in a Buckingham Palace announcement today, shows that the tour will be a strenuous and comprehensive as was the royal party's visit to South Africa last year.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- What was described as a suggestion by Soviet Premier Stalin that would prolong the Moscow negotiations was said by high authorities here to be the result of yesterday's long talk between the Russian leader and the envoys of the three Western powers.

A three-run out burst in the third inning was the big factor in the 6 to 1 triumph of the Negro National League over the Negro American League at the Yankee Stadium last night in the third annual "Dream Game" between all-star teams representing these rival baseball circuits.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Exports of motion-picture film and equipment declined during the first half of 1948 compared with the first six months of 1947, the Department of Commerce announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- Glamorgan, the only Welsh county playing first-class cricket, today won the English county cricket championship for the first time in its career, heading such renowned opponents as Yorkshire and Middlesex.

The junior-sized miss was leading lady yesterday at Saks-34th in a showing which featured fashions for both college and a career. To strengthen the illusion of height, slim-skirted suits were used, particularly a gray worsted with a long jacket and a slender back-buttoned skirt.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers today filed an $8,750,000 anti-trust suit in the Federal Court here against two large local theater combines, demanding that they be dissolved.

Carrying an unusually large list of American diplomats, legislators, nuclear physicists and business men among her 960 passengers, the United States liner America sailed from Pier 61, North River, at 4 P.M. yesterday for Cobh and the Channel ports.

New Jersey bluefish are now reaching a peak of abundance, according to reports from a half-dozen fishing ports, and one angler fishing near the Shrewsbury Rocks on Monday brought in 175 fish ranging from 3 to 6 1/2 pounds each.

Frank Parker of Los Angeles, Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., Billy Talbert of New York and Gardnar Mulloy of Miama Fla., were named yesterday to represent the United States in the Davis Cup challenge round against Australia at Forest Hills, Sept. 4, 5 and 6, by Jones W. Mersereau, chairman of the United States Lawn Tennis Association Davis Cup Selection Committee.

Niles Olsen, 60 years old, of 25 Homestead Avenue, Port Richmond, S. I., a New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, worker, was injured fatally by an automobile late yesterday at Nassau and Navy Streets, Brooklyn. He died later in the Cumberland Hospital.

The Twentieth Century Sporting Club announced yesterday that the fifteen-round lightweight championship bout between Ike Williams and Jesse Flores and the supporting ten-round contest between Ray Robinson and Kid Gavilan will be staged on Thursday night, Sept. 23, at the Yankee Stadium, instead of on Wednesday, Sept. 22, as originally scheduled.

The Babe Ruth Foundation disclosed plans yesterday to increase its work with young boys and girls to carry out the late ball player's frequently expressed desire to help some of the nation's underprivileged children in their struggle to achieve mature citizenship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Aug. 24 -- Jeanne Crain and Dan Dailey Jr. will co-star in "You're my Everything," it was announced today by Twentieth Century-Fox. This will be their second appearance together on the screen, their first having been in the recent film, "You Were Meant For Me."
PRAGUE, Aug. 24 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist-run General Confederation of Labor is engaged in a propaganda campaign against the five-day week and for the six-day week.

The new one-story taxpayer containing a super-market and five retail stores at the southeast corner of Parsons Boulevard and Eighty-second Drive, in Jamaica, Queens, was bought by H. E. Kalichman from the Research Home Corporation builders, through the Taylor Company, brokers.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation has been informed that the United States Air Force plans to order eighty-eight aircraft of the new Curtiss Blackhawk type, the first multi-jet fighter designed for all-weather operation, Guy W. Vaughan, president, said yesterday in the company's first semi-annual progress report to stockholders.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 -- The Dodgers' pennant drive ran into another road block at Forbes Field tonight when Bob Chesnes held them to four singles while the Pirates lambasted four of Barney Shotton's hurlers for fourteen assorted hits to coast to a 9-1 triumph.

Russeks held a showing yesterday in the Chatham Walk at the luncheon hour that had but a single theme -- suits, and tailored suits at that. It was astounding to see what they accomplished with so limited a subject.

Accounts of increased operating costs, alongside decreases in the number of paying customers, were continued yesterday before Commissioner Spencer B. Eddy, as bus line operators offered evidence to support their pleas for rises in fares.

ATHENS, Aug. 24 -- Army reports published today showed that the national forces would have no inspite in the war against the Communist-inspired rebellion that received a crushing but not decisive blow in the Grammos Mountains.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Secretary of Defense Forrestal is preparing to establish "a top level central group of outstanding civilian scientists to guide the military high command in weighing the merits of future weapons and types of warfare," The Chicago Tribune will say tomorrow in a dispatch from its Washington Bureau.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- John A. Broughton, a 26-year-old foundry molder from Ferguson, Mo., won the North American clay target championship today at the Grand American trapshoot.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 24 -- A New Jersey Communist was barred today from addressing a civil rights hearing conducted by the Assembly's judiciary committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, and Frank P.
