Foisie, president of the Waterfront Employers Association, met for almost two hours today amid authoritative reports that the West Coast shipowners, in an effort to stave off a maritime strike on Sept. 2, were ready to follow the lead of Atlantic and Gulf operators on the hiring hall issue.

Leopold Stokowski and the New Fork Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will play nine contemporary compositions during a two-week autumn tour, it was announced yesterday. The tour opens in Syracuse on Sept. 20 and closes in Portland, Me., on Oct. 3.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and steady yesterday. Prices at the close were 1 point lower to 7 points higher.

Even allowing for the frightful maturity of the modern world, "Peg O' My Heart" is probably no different today than it was in 1912. It is a machine-made excursion into sentiment made bearable by a disarming part. In 1912 Laurette Taylor filled the part with a radiance that overshone the play and the natural skepticism of an audience.

TRIESTE, Aug. 24 -- The extraordinary congress of the Trieste Communist party, loyal to the Cominform [Communist Information Bureau], ended at dawn today by electing thirty members of the Central Committee and approving a motion that showed they would follow Moscow's lead on all international and domestic issues.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Chief item of business before the house today was the running of a $5,000 purse called The Delaware. The house was a good one -- 13,137 was the turnstile count -- and so was the performance of the Foxcatcher Farms' Manyunk in the Saratoga Association's main event.

When the Lloyd I. Seaman pulled away from East Twenty-second Street yesterday morning, bearing a jubilant crowd of 999 underprivileged children and mothers, it brought to close to the 3,000,000 mark the number aided in seventy-four years by the St. John's Guild hospital cruises.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The value of British exports last month reached the highest level in the long history of this trading nation. The Board of Trade disclosed that July exports were valued at 145, 600,000 (about $582,400,000), or 8,200,000 more than the previous record established twenty-eight years ago.

A full investigation of the quarrel between nine airlines and the Port of New York Authority over conditions at La Guardia Field and Idlewild was assured yesterday by Edward C. Maguire, the city's Commissioner of Commerce, who invited both sides to meet with him separately.
Top officials of the Welfare Department and of the United Public Workers of America, CIO, held a "friendly" meeting yesterday morning.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- The Hyderabad Government, formally petitioning the United Nations Security Council to take up discussion of the Princely State's quarrel with India, accused the New Delhi Government here today of endangering the peace of all Asia.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A highly informed source said today that a general area of agreement had been reached in the four-power Kremlin talks and that further lengthy negotiations would deal largely with technicalities. The technicalities are not trifles and will necessitate considerable negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- In another move to alleviate inflationary pressures, new and more liberal policies to govern reimportation into this country of surplus materials and products sold abroad by the Office of the Foreign Liquidation Commissioner were announced today by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce.

SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 24 (UP) -- Union leaders announced today that an agreement had been reached to end a seven-day strike of 3.300 members of the American Federation of Labor at the Los Alamos atomic energy project.
When the Board of Education meets tomorrow it is expected to award contracts totaling $4,424,032 for the construction of three new public schools, it was learned yesterday.

It is good news that the Metropolitan Opera will remain in business this year, after all. The Metropolitan's importance transcends its role in New York, where, since its opening in 1883, it has held a dominant place in the city's cultural life.

With the acquisition of a plot 50 by 100 feet on the east side of East Twenty-first Street, 144 feet south of Albermarle Road, in Brooklyn, from John Z. Derby, as administrator of the estate of Mary A. Derby, the Congregation Shaare Torah of Flatbush has completed the assemblage of four parcels comprising a plot 194 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of East Twenty-first Street and Albermarle Road.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Aug. 23 -- Two weeks of sounding opinions informally in shops, cafes, business houses and the bazaar streets of this picturesque city, capital of Kashmir, force the conclusion that religious prejudice is the dominant factor in politics here.
If I may, a reply to that editorial in the Aug. 20 issue concerning the fate of the Italian colonies, and the motives of Presidential aspirants in speaking on this issue.

The Saturday matinee performances of the Metropolitan Opera Association will again be broadcast by the WJZ-ABC network this season, it was announced yesterday. The opening date of the series is to be announced later.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 24 -- The Government moved against the International Typographical Union today in a contempt of court action reportedly aimed at cutting off its support of the Chicago newspapers printers' strike and condemning the competency (hiring) clauses the union has demanded in all its contracts.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 24 -- A spokesman for Western democracy and an apologist for Soviet communism outlined their divergent convictions here today at the third session of the first Assembly of the World Council of Churches.

The chairman of the Department of Higher Education of New York Unisity, Dr. Alonzo F. Myers, speaking at the annual Human Relations Conference at Chautauqua, N.Y., July 24, urged that Catholic, Jewish and Protestant teacher associations in New York City be disbanded on the ground that these organizations are "undemocratic."

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Full punishment of drunken drivers was urged today by the director of the state's recently established Safety Division, Thomas W. Ryan, in an address before the New York State Police conference.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The education committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce, ending a two-day session here today, reiterated its belief in state and local support of education and heard the proposed Federal aid to schools described as "a gamble with man's greatest blessing simply because it would be a short cut to a solution."

BLUE POINT, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Sister Marie Chantal, shy and diminutive nun of the nursing order of the Dames Hospitalieres, told today how she had worked actively in the Belgian resistance movement for three years during World War II and later had spent seventeen months in German concentration camps, including Ravensbruck.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Prof. Josef L. Hromadka, Czech theologian, told the World Council of Churches today:

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- A genuine desire to find a way out of the East-West impasse over Berlin was shown by both sides in the Kremlin talks last night, it was stated today after reports of the Moscow meeting had been examined in London.

Capital accounts of state chartered banks in the United States and Hawaii were increased $289,758,000 in the twelve months ending June 30, according to Richard Rapport, president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The stage was set tonight for the public "confrontation" tomorrow before the House Committee on Un-American Activities of Alger Hiss, former high State Depart ment official, and Whittaker Chambers, who has accused him of leadership in an alleged "elite" pre-war Communist underground.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- In an election conducted today by the National Labor Relations Board under heavy police guard, employes of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company plant here rejected a proposal to have Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electric Workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Marshall Plan shipments valued at $29,445,989 -- mostly industrial materials and equipment -- were approved today by the Economic Cooperation Administration. About one-third will be supplied by countries other than the United States.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Miss La Junta White of Dunwoodie led a field of seventy-eight contenders with a four-over-men's par 38, 37 -- 75 in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day event over the Piping Rock course today.

The National Union of Polish Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts, reported by Polish authorities on Monday to have joined forces with the Communist youth group, is an organization unrecognized by the Scout movement, it was announced yesterday.
Officials of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, moved decisively yesterday to suspend the leaders of four of its left-wing unions here and to replace them with administrators.
In one of the quietest primary days in years, New York State enrolled voters went to the polls yesterday to cast ballots for their party candidates.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Navy is stepping up its anti-submarine training program to meet what it terms "revolutionary developments" in underwater warfare.

The journalism division of the Department of Communication Arts of Fordham University, the Bronx, will offer twenty-six courses in journalism and allied fields during the coming semester, the Rev. Alfred J. Barrett, chairman, announced yesterday.

As a native of North Carolina, and a patriotic Southerner, I am impelled to write this letter of protest in order that it might be read by the intelligent type of individual so well represented in your readers.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- The difficult and at times desperate situation that overshadowed Berlin during the week-end has been eased by negotiations between the East and the West initiated by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, and aimed at withdrawal of all troops from the center of the city and cooperation by the three principal occupation powers against the black market.
While traffic was routed away from the area and a hundred passers-by stopped to watch, the first of 400 new aluminum lamps for Park Avenue was unveiled at 12:00 A.M. yesterday.
TORONTO, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The executive of the National Council of Canadian-Soviet Friendship today unanimously decided to write Dr. Johnson to make a cross-Canada lecture tour.
The prospect of Fordham's first victorious football campaign since 1942 was envisioned yesterday by Coach Ed Danowski as he conducted the first drill for Rose Hill's fifty-seventh gridiron season.

Six Air Force personnel going to a religious conference and three crew members of a C-47 transport were killed in a crash in northwest New Jersey yesterday afternoon after their plane was ripped in mid-air by the wing of an Air Force bomber traveling in the opposite direction.
Having announced Monday that there definitely would be a 1948-49 Metropolitan Opera season, the management yesterday started to set the wheels in motion for the season.

Unless raw material prices take a further substantial spurt, the start of the next fiscal year would be a good time for shoe manufacturers to switch to the LIFO (last in, first out) inventory method, according to an analysis made public yesterday by the National Shoe Manufacturers Association.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Braves had more on the bat than Harry Brecheen had on the ball tonight as they subdued the Cardinals with eighteen hits, 9 to 3, before 31,434 fans. The victory put league-leading Boston three and a half games in front of the second-place Redbirds.
A vigorous protest against any action that would forestall a scheduled increase in the farm price of milk destined for the metropolitan area was registered yesterday by five dairymen's groups.

Further evidence of the current downward trend in savings is contained in a report by the New York State Savings and Loan League, issued yesterday by Zebulon V. Woodard, vice president. According to the report, savings and loan associations in this state increased savings investments by $8,327,918 during July, but the gain is the smallest recorded this year and compares with increases of $16,880,738 in the previous month, and $9,982,036 in July, 1947.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Navy announced today that Rear Admiral Francis P. Old would replace Rear Admiral Harry R. Thurber as senior member of the Naval Advisory Group on the Survey Board in China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A Federal price support program which is likely to break all records in cash loans to farmers is getting under way as the result of bumper crop prospects and attendant price declines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Federal Communications Commission tentatively ordered today a six months' suspension of the amateur license of Reuben E. Gross, lawyer, of Staten Island, N.Y., for sending and receiving coded radio messages to and from Palestine and transmitting deceptive signals.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 24 -- "President Truman and his party have presided over the gradual liquidation of civil rights for the citizens of the United States -- 145,000,000 of them," Henry A. Wallace, Presidential candidate of the Progressive party, told the fiftieth anniversary national convention of the Grand Lodge of Negro Elks here today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24 (AP) -- The United States' newly named Davis Cup defenders, along with their Australian rivals, made impressive progress today in the second round of the National doubles tennis tournament at Longwood.

A new high record of $55,734,519 in completed contracts and sales was achieved by the Carrier Corporation during the twelve months ended last July, according to the report issued yesterday. The manufacturer of air conditioning and refrigeration equipment had a total of $46,120,771 for the similar period of the previous year.
The most welcome addition yesterday to the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition was a truckload of chairs.

GENEVA, Aug. 24 -- Russia proposed today that the International Civil Aviation Organization be suspended as a specialized agency of the United Nations until it complied with the resolution of the General Assembly to oust Franco Spain.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,688, against 1,432 last week and 987 in the similar week of last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 810 arrivals yesterday compared with 697 last Tuesday.

Harry Petreau presented his first millinery collection in his own salon at 8 East Fifty-third Street yesterday morning. His designs included some good wearable cloches, picture hats, bonnets and sailors. He used feathers and dark flowers for trimming as well as Leavy veiling tied loosely around the neck, giving the effect of a deep V neckline.

The six-story apartment house at 540 West 165th Street, southwest corner of St. Nicholas Avenue, adjoining the Audubon Theatre, has been sold by Mrs. Lucille P. Oestreicher to the H. B. Properties Corporation for cash above mortgages aggregating $193,000.

One well-timed single in the eighth or ninth inning would have kept alive the Yankees' winning streak yesterday at the Stadium, but when a hit was most needed none was forthcoming. As a result, Bucky Harris' revivified athletes suffered a severe blow in the form of a 6-5 setback at the hands of the White Sox.

The state of Oregon sold yesterday an issue of $3,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds due Oct. 1, 1959, and callable Oct. 1, 1953, to a banking group headed by the National City Bank at a bid of 97.30 for 1 1/2s, an interest cost of 1.7545 per cent.

Net sales of Reeves Brothers, Inc., manufacturers and converters of cotton textiles, increased 39 per cent to $68,410,034 in the fiscal year ended 'on June 30 from the $49,025,066 volume for the preceding fiscal year, J. M. Reeves, president, reported yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- With a slightly better feeling about the international situation, the stock market here today had a firmer appearance despite small amount of investment business passing.

Sixteen series of instruction classes for expectant mothers will start next week in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens under the auspices of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- As far as Canterbury's "Red Dean" is concerned, the United States can either receive him as a friend of Russia or do without his presence.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- The Orange County gambling investigation of last winter, which attracted national attention when two Newburgh newspapermen were jailed for refusing to disclose news sources to a grand jury, caused repercussions in the primary election here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Paul Kayser, president of El Paso Natural Gas Company, said today it was too late to ask competitive bids for financing his concern's proposal to increase its gas flow to California, Arizona and New Mexico.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The grain markets developed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today and closed about the top. Wheat gained 1 1/4 to 4 1/2 cents a bushel, September leading and going to 1 1/2 cents under December, compared with 3 cents at the close on Saturday.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- Mrs. Clara Colford Doreau, member of a family prominent in this city, New York and Newport, won another opportunity today to regain American citizenship.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Serving emphatic notice here today that she would continue to regard the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans as illegal and "contrary to peace," Albania rejected the committee's latest overture for cooperation.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- A report by Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok that tentative and exploratory peace talks had been held with "certain Arab leaders" was received here today with doubt and disbelief.
ESTES PARK, Colo., Aug. 24 -- President Truman and the governors of all states were urged today to defer teachers from the forthcoming draft.

The new Twentieth Century Limited will be initiated on Wednesday, Sept. 15, at 12:30 P.M. on Track 30 in Grand Central Terminal, the New York Central System announced yesterday. A similar ceremony will take place in Chicago at the same time for a twin unit.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 24 -- Everything indicates that the second Edinburgh Festival of Music and Drama will surpass the first in artistic and financial success. Already most of the performances are booked to capacity and outside the festival offices there is a constant kueue of hopeful enquirers for returned tickets.

Selective Service machinery started yesterday for an estimated 600,000 young New Yorkers. At the city's headquarters, at 516 West Thirty-fourth Street, a loft building near the Hudson River, the new draft set-up hummed in a brisk, business-like atmosphere -- this time without uniformed personnel or salutes.
The 35-year-old river liner De Witt Clinton, now named the S.S. Derecktor, lay at East Twenty-fifth Street yesterday while workmen prepared her for a new chapter in a career of infinite variety.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Favorites fell like well-aimed putts in the third national caddy golf tournament today, leaving only one of the form sheet choices still in the running after first-round match play.

The American Broadcasting Company rejected yesterday the request of the Communist party in the United States for free time in which to voice its objections to the network's documentary, "Communism -- U.S. Brand," which had been put on the air earlier.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 25 -- The text of the Soviet note to the United States rejecting the State Department's previous note on the Kasenkina and Samarin cases, as reported by Tass and broadcast by the Moscow radio:

RAVOLZHAUSEN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- Two C-47 Dakotas collided in mid-air this morning about 1,200 feet above this small village near Hanau, killing both two-man crews and bringing the total death toll in the Berlin air lift to nine since the Western Allies began supplying the blockaded former capital by air.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The family "market basket" cost more in June than ever before.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Flaxseed went begging today in the early hours of trading in the Minneapolis Grain Exchange.

Department and specialty stores, whose use of revolving credit has increased tremendously since the end of the original controls last fall, would be dealt a serious blow if present controls were tightened to their original form, it was generally agreed by credit men here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The fight over the War Assets Administration's decision to lease, effective Sept. 1, the $28,000,000 government-owned steel plant in Cleveland to the Kaiser-Frazer corporation, automobile manufacturer, was carried today to President Truman.

C.L. Kemper of Salem Va., has purchased the seven-room colonial residence at 818 Lupine Way, in the Forest Ridge section of Short Hills, N.J., from Frederick Rathgeber, of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, who has been transferred to the West Coast.

A decided change in the complexion of the news from the four-power talks in Moscow permitted yesterday a moderate improvement in the stock market. While the list was considered to be in a favorable position for a technical rebound, the indications of a break in the Kremlin's stalemated discussions over the blockade of Berlin provided a more tangible basis for the rally.

The latest conference between Premier Stalin and the Western envoys has aroused new hope that their negotiations may yet lead to some positive result, and that diplomacy may still find ways and means of ending the Berlin crisis and easing the perilous tensions between Russia and the West.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Tigers drove Lou Brissie from the mound with a six-run attack in the third inning and went on to defeat the Athletics, 7 -- 4, tonight. It was Philadelphia's fourth straight setback.

Plans for three of the large apartment units planned by the Equitable Life Assurance Society on the former Webb Institute site in the Bronx were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The estimated cost of these three units was more than $2,396,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 24 -- The rejuvenated political machine of the late Huey P. (The Kingfish) Long is bidding for a spot in the national political scene through the candidacy of Huey's son, Russell Long, for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

Steel allocations to warehouses and distributors in the New York area have been cut an average of 25 per cent for the fourth quarter, distributors revealed here yesterday during a canvass of deliveries of staple steel products.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company notified the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that at a meeting on Aug. 31 the directors would authorize payment on Sept. 1 of the company's fifteen-year secured 6 per cent gold bonds, due April 1, 1940.

VIENNA, Aug. 24 -- The Austrian Communist party in its small way also has been embarrassed by the split between Moscow and Belgrade. It has had to repudiate the Slovene national minority in Austria, which for so many years has represented Yugoslavia's desire to help herself to a generous slice of Austria's province of Carinthia.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- The Communist parties of the Soviet Union and its satellite states are now apparently engaged in coordinating new drives to purge their membership of "alien elements," to push collectivization of agriculture and to crush the remaining peasant opposition to these moves by a new campaign against "kulaks."
Proposed traffic improvements dominated the capital budget requests of the five Borough Presidents that were submitted yesterday to the City Planning Commission to the Manhattan Municipal Building.

Each man has his own day on which autumn begins. This day has nothing to do with the calendar's ordered markings. It may come in mid-September; it may not arrive until October; or today, suddenly, it will be here.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 24 (AP) -- The board of directors of General Mills today elected Frank Miller of Minneapolis president of the company's farm service division. The board also made Gordon C. Ballhorn a vice president. He has been controller since 1934.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Just four months before Dec. 25 a real, old-fashioned American Christmas will be celebrated here tomorrow at Camp Minisink, all-Negro summer camp of the New York City Mission Society.

Dense fog settled north of New York and in most of New Jersey yesterday morning delaying thousands of commuters in trains, automobiles and ferries. The thick blanket shut down Newark Airport with a zero-zero ceiling from 5 to 7 A.M.

Directors of the Derby Oil Company voted yesterday a stock dividend of one-half share of common for each share outstanding, payable September 30. The dividend is contingent on approval by stockholders of a recommended increase in the authorized common stock.

THE proposal already has been made on the continent, French and English sports authorities leading the way, to eliminate from the Olympic program all those superfluous sports which have given it the distressing appearance of the tail wagging the dog. According to their theory, a slenderizing operation is in order so that the next Games in Helsinki four years hence will bear a svelte and streamlined look.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- The first master compilation of laws on human rights throughout the world was published here today in a United Nations inventory of man's legislative freedoms in seventy-three countries.

MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 24 -- Though gourmets may rejoice that the "R" months start next week, the world's most extensive oyster research center, maintained here by the Government, takes no cheerful view of the local 1948-49 season.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A two-run homer by Vern Stephens in the ninth inning tonight lifted the Red Sox into first place in the American League, a half game ahead of the Indians, who were defeated, 9 -- 8, in a rousing finish at Fenway Park before 34,172 paying fans.

Prof. Anton R. Zhebrak, internationally known Soviet geneticist, has written a letter to Pravda, official Communist party organ, in which he announces his submission to the officially endorsed "party line" views on the genetics of T.D. Lysenko, his opponent in a fifteen-year struggle of "Marxist" versus "bourgeois" concepts of heredity.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 24 -- The premonitions of last week were fulfilled today when the news leaked out here that by a decree from Berlin, the Germans themselves now will be required to foot the bill for their United States-inspired "reorientation" -- retroactively to July 1.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The fifteen-nation International Sugar Council recommended tonight that the eleven-year-old world sugar agreement be continued until Aug. 31, 1949, despite changes in production caused by the war. It appointed a committee, representing all member nations, to investigate a Cuban request for a new agreement revising quotas to suit changes in the output of sugar-producing nations.

More than eighteen months after the Advertising Council first undertook preparation of a compaign to help a 4-A-ANA joint committee improve public understanding of the American free enterprise system, final minor revisions in eleven of a twelve-ad series have been completed, the council reported yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Dave Gorman took the lead in the race for jockey honors at the Atlantic City race track today when he made Bank Balance his eleventh triumph of the meeting.

Flowers' filled every room of the Charles W. Decker home at 43 Clinton Place, Port Richmond, S.I., yesterday, and the sprightly Mr. Decker also was wreathed in smiles. The occasion: his 100th birthday.
An injunction under terms of the Taft-Hartley Act prohibiting strikes and lockouts by longshoremen and employers on the Atlantic Coast before Nov. 9 was approved in Federal Court here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Through increased efficiency and strict economy the United Nations has succeeded in preparing a budget for 1949 that will be $1,355,608 below the current year's budget, Secretary General Trygve Lie informed the fifty-eight member countries today in his annual financial report.

One of my childhood school books carried a tale which concerned Benedict Arnold, who one day entered one of the houses of the English Parliament and seated himself in the visitors' gallery. A gentleman who was addressing the assembly stopped in the middle of a sentence, pointed his finger at the traitor, and declared in ringing tones, "While that man remains in this building I will not speak!"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The International Refugee Organization reported today that about 150,000 refugees still in European displaced persons camps would meet the priority list for professional and occupational skills set up in the United States Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 24 -- The aid of all the Protestant Episcopal parishes on Long Island was asked today at the Long Island diocesan dedication of the Protestant Episcopal Home for Boys, a small-scale "Boys' Town" project, on South Main Street here.
I have read with appreciation your Aug. 17 editorial, "A Year of Independence," dealing with India and Pakistan.
SEATTLE, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A new contract providing increased pay for longshore work in Alaska was announced today by spokesmen for two unions and three shipping companies.

A double-purpose drive, aimed at reducing costs of handling orders at the factory, and at diverting small orders to local distributors, has been started by the industrial products division of Stewart Warner Corporation, industrial purchasing sources disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- American lumber imports during the first six months of 1948 were 895,809,000 board feet, or an increase of 56 per cent over imports during the corresponding period of 1947, the Department of Commerce disclosed today.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Prime Minister Attlee today began enjoying the benefits of the free health service that his Government instituted in July. He is a patient at St. Mary's Hospital in Paddington, being treated for eczema of the feet.

MALMOE, Sweden, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Hustling Harrison Dillard set the pace for United States Olympic track and field stars tonight as they won six of nine events in an international track meet and tied the world's record for the 1,000-meter medley relay.

STOCHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 24 -- The United States met a rebuff at the Red Cross World Conference here today when a proposal to compel captured army doctors and sanitary personnel to stay with their own troops to care for their casualties was defeated, 31 to 8, in a subcommittee of the legal commission studying the revision of the 1929 Geneva Convention dealing with the sick and wounded.

Seeking to peak stocks for back-to-school selling in the next three weeks, retailers virtually have flooded the market with re-orders for children's and teen-age dresses, coats and suits, it was learned yesterday.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Play in the United States chess championship tournament at the Community Center grew in intensity today when no less than six of the ten games in the thirteenth round were adjourned without having reached a decision.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug, 24 -- Miss Pat Hinman of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club brought home the Cotton Candy in 53 minutes 50 seconds to win the Meteor Class competition at the tenth August Junior Regatta of the Port Washington Yacht Club today.
RANGOON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- Government successes in central Burma against the rebels were reported in tonight's communique on the fight against Communist-led insurgents.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, has requested the House Committee on Un-American Activities to provide any evidence it may have against Alexander Koral, an assistant mechanical engineer in the New York public school system, who was an uncommunicative witness in Washington on Aug. 9.
DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The speedboat Sant' Ambrogio, Italian challenger for the Gold Cup, missed her first test in American waters today because of a scarcity of lubricating oil.

THE President of the United States attended a night ball game last week. But Presidents have attended ball games in the past and will do so in the future. However, this was something special. Harry S. Truman didn't visit Griffith Stadium merely to watch the New York Yankees play the Washington Senators. He came specifically to add his tribute to Clark Calvin Griffith, the owner of the Senators.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 25 -- In a last minute attempt to bring the Soviet Union into the Red Cross line-up, the French delegation, headed by Ambassador Andre Francois-Poncet, sponsored an appeal to Moscow today to come in officially and not only by the two observers now attending the sev-teenth world conference here.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 25 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board filed in Federal District Court here today a petition asking that the International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, be held in contempt and required to cease paying benefits to striking Chicago printers.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 25 -- Perfection is a word that can rarely be applied to operatic performances, however good in individual detail. But it does no violence to the language to call the Glyndebourne Opera's second contribution to the Edinburgh Festival perfect, even though some individual details fell short of that absolute standard.
W.G. Holloway, chairman of the board of W.R. Grace Co., announced yesterday the award of the company's thirty-year service medal to Capt. Walter N. Prengel, senior port captain of the Grace Line.

Early discovery of a new fungus disease that could destroy the city's most extensively planted shade trees, the London planes, was reported yesterday by the Department of Parks and the New York Botanical Garden.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight the appointment of fifteen temporary trustees to manage the newly created State University and to plan for the future development of higher education in New York. Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, was designated as chairman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Prices probably will continue to rise between now and the November elections, with no significant downturn in prospect before next spring at the earliest, qualified economists said here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board, preparing to restore controls on instalment buying Sept. 20 to ease the upward pressures on prices, reported today the following developments:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Mill River Stable's Alablue had the flossy price tag, but Lester Manor Stable's Compliance, a $4,500 bargain as a yearling, had more run left for the stretch in the sixty-ninth edition of the $24,150 Alabama Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Saratoga today.
BRESLAU, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Mr. Fadayev, who is one of five presidents of the congress, which has drawn some 500 intellectual leaders from fourteen countries, charged:

The parade and reception for some 250 members of the United States Olympic team arriving in New York tomorrow has been called off, it was announced late last night by Charles L. Ornstein, a member of the executive committee of the United States Olympic Committee.

MALMOE, Sweden, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- While leading members of the touring United States Olympic track and field team took "a day off," athletes of other nationalities captured the gold medals today in the second day of an international track meet before 11,000 fans.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Paul Kohler of Tekamah, Neb., with his wife and three children cheering him on, broke 200 straight targets today at the forty-ninth Grand American Trapshoot to win the National Class AA championship.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- Members of the Bay Area locals of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union and the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards voted without dissent at a mass meeting today to follow recommendations for a boycott of a forthcoming National Labor Relations Board election in the West Coast maritime dispute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Whenever responsible members of this administration or of Governor Dewey's staff gather to discuss the problems that a change in the executive government next January would create the greatest attention is given to the Department of Defense.
The signing of contracts affecting an estimated 25,000 merchant seamen belonging to three unions was announced here yesterday.
PARIS, Aug. 25 -- France will postpone the local elections scheduled for October, the National Assembly decided today by a vote of 245 to 193.

The story of a non-political Russian family and its tragic fate, allegedly due to the displeasure of Soviet authorities, was told yesterday by its only surviving member, Mrs. Oksana Step anovna Kasenkina, from her bed in Roosevelt Hospital.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Two United States Davis Cup tennis players and the two women's singles finalists at Wimbledon, Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Mrs. Margaret Osborne duPont of Wilmington, Del., are being considered for a tour of Australia.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Miss Vivien Kellems, who was involved in a dispute with the Internal Revenue Bureau earlier this year because she refused to collect withholding taxes from her employes, was ordered today to move her cable grip company out of Westport.

The Russian Government has seen fit to reply to the expulsion of Consul General Lomakin for gross abuse of his prerogatives and mendacious charges against the United States by closing the Russian consulates in the United States and demanding, on the "principle of reciprocity," the closing of the single American consulate in the Soviet Union.

Robert E. Stripling, chief investigator for the House Committee on Un-American Activities, notified Board of Education yesterday that testimony concerning Alexander Koral, assistant mechanical engineer in the New York public school system, would be submitted to the school authorities before the end of the week.

The stock market was unable yesterday to generate any force in either direction. Pending some further developments in Soviet-American relations, traders used the weather as a ready excuse to allow the market to find its own level, but the meager volume of business in the Stock Exchange produced nothing more than fractional changes aside from a few major alterations due to individual corporate developments.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Prices of grains were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today. There was general commission house and local buying based on reports of sales of additional cash wheat to the Government, while less favorable comment on the Iowa and Nebraska corn crops was also a factor.
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith conferred with his chief advisers in the embassy today on the closing of the American Consulate in Vladivostok.

Under a stipulation filed in Federal Court yesterday, the Department of Justice dropped charges against Solomon R. Guggenheim of Port Washington, L.I., Albert E. Theile of Scarsdale, N.Y., and George K. Sturm of Woodbridge, N.J., in connection with a civil anti-trust suit alleging conspiracy to monopolize sales and inflate prices of gem and industrial diamonds.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 -- The Dodgers broke their losing streak at four games today by beating the Pirates, 11 -- 9, in a free-hitting contest, only to find that Manager Billy Meyer had filed a protest which President Ford Frick of the National League cannot avoid upholding.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 -- A search through New York's Fulton Fish Market failed to unearth a single authority on fish chowders and stews. New Yorkers know little of these dishes. Where to turn? This city was, of course, the answer.

TOKYO, Aug. 25 -- Occupation and Japanese Government efforts to break the "illegal" railway workers' strike by arrests and dismissals are making little progress. Although some workers are returning, others are quitting and the number involved is slow rising.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- At the end of the Hiss-Chambers hearing on Capitol Hill today, there seemed to be general agreement among objective observers on one point: That the most prominent and outspoken members of the House Un-American Activities Committee were unimpressed by the testimony of Alger Hiss, and seemed to some to adopt a prosecutor's attitude toward him.
The Department of Welfare declared yesterday that a war veteran, whose appeal for aid had been referred to it, had been touring the country with his family in an automobile.

A recording of Mrs. Oksana S. Kasenkina's replies to questions at yesterday's press interview in Roosevelt Hospital was made by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Mrs. Luba Terpak, the translator, addressed the reporters' questions to Mrs. Kasenkina in Russian, and Mrs. Kasenkina replied in Russian.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- A strike by employes of the Communist-dominated Labor Department of Berlin's City Assembly was called tonight as the Russians exerted maximum political pressure on that body in preparation for what probably will be the most stormy and perhaps the last meeting of the Assembly as a body representing the entire city tomorrow.

ATHENS, Aug. 25 -- While Archbishop Damaskinos publicly thanked the veterans of the Grammos campaign in the name of the Greek Orthodox Church "for the sacrifices you have made in blood," a Greek General Staff spokesman revealed the cold statistics thus far computed on that conflict.

A theory that noxious fumes from a fire-extinguishing agent seeped into the cockpit and felled the pilots of the United Air Lines DC-6 that crashed near Mount Carmel, Pa., last June 17, killing forty-three persons, was advanced strongly yesterday as the Civil Aeronautics Board opened its investigation into the accident.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Trading in flaxseed was resumed at the Minneapolis Grain Exchange today, with operators of terminal elevators buying for the account of the Commodity Credit Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- American schools should teach that war even against communism is not inevitable, the National Education Association said today.

An increase of 3 per cent in per cent in the price of its woven line of carpets, effective Sept. 1, was annouced yesterday by the Bigelow-Sanford carpet Company, Inc. Substantially increased costs of carpet wools, the major raw material entering into the finished product made the price advance necessary, the company stated.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 25 -More than 80,000 persons staged marches here today in protest against the high cost of living and threatened action unless prompt and effective measures were taken by the Bizonal Economic Council at Frankfort on the Main and in the Bavarian Parliament.

Testimony against three former officers of the National Maritime Union, CIO, who are charged with violation of the union's constitution and conspiracy to disrupt the organization, was presented before a union trial committee here yesterday.

Coffee and sugar futures were quiet and steady yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc. Coffee futures, supported by Brazilian interests held prices unchanged, with the exception of spot September, which was quoted 15 points higher. Sales totaled 4,250 bags.

We think it was Dr. Neilson who gave this sound advice to a graduating class at Smith College -- "Keep an open mind," he said, "but not so open that your brains drop out." We took it to heart the other day and produced the following:

In an editorial on Aug. 19 THE NEW YORK TIMES highly commended the new Marie Cabinet of France for initiating immediate negotiations with other democratic governments of Europe with the aim of convoking an assembly to draft a common constitution for a West-European federation.

The oppressive heat claimed Bob Porterfield as a victim yesterday but before the rookie right-hander blacked out he set the Yankees back on the winning road with seven innings of shut-out pitching against the White Sox at the Stadium.

The city of Boston, Mass., borrowed yesterday $5,000,000 on temporary loan notes dated Aug. 30 and due Dec. 1 at an interest rate of 1.15 per cent. The notes were awarded at competitive sale to the First Boston Corporation and Chemical Bank and Trust Company, whose bid carried a premium of $81.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The sworn testimony of Alger Hiss, former high official in the State Department, and Whittaker Chambers, who has accused him of leadership in a pre-war "elite" Communist underground, remained in sharp and bitter conflict tonight after many hours of facing each other in public before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Jess Larson, director of the War Assets Administration, said today that if the Republic Steel Corporation had not "bluffed" the WAA, he never would have made a deal to lease the Government-owned blast furnace in Cleveland, now operated by Republic, to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

Dr. John J. Brooks, in charge of teacher education at Oglethorpe University, Georgia, will be director of the Experimental School, Inc., when it opens at 31 West 110th Street, Sept. 27, it was announced yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 25 -- The first Assembly of the World Council of Churches today began six days of discussion of the role of organized religion in modern society. For this purpose the delegates were divided into four groups that meet simultaneously.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 18:

For the third successive week, crude oil production in the United States last week again reached a record daily rate, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Output averaged 5,521,300 barrels daily, an increase of 14,250 over the previous week, and compared with 5,152,800 a year earlier.
Today's young woman will look for her footwear styles to mother's and grandmother's day from all indications yesterday in the Frank Brothers' showing at 9 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Extraction from a microbe of a vitamin that builds red blood cells in victims of pernicious anemia was announced yesterday by a team of scientists of the Lederle Laboratories Division, American Cyanamid Company.

Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey directed yesterday that two law suits involving the left-wing and right-wing factions of the Council on African Affairs be consolidated, and fixed Sept. 20, the date of resumption of the trial calendar, for a hearing.

Stirred by a complaint, from an industrial chemical plant that its workers were harassed by professional gamblers, the office of the Union County, N.J., prosecutor arrested yesterday the alleged leader of a gang of horse-race bookmakers.

Although sales of the Stewart-Warner Corporation in the first half of this year declined 5.7 per cent from the volume transacted a year before, earnings were $507,729 larger, according to a report issued yesterday by James S. Knowlson, board chairman and president.
YORKTOWN, Va., Aug. 25 -- President Truman issued an order today revoking the credentials of Jacob M. Lomakin, Soviet Consul General in New York, on grounds of "highly improper conduct."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Joseph F. Reilly won the second leg on the New York Curb Exchange Five and Twenty Club's trophy with a low gross score of 78 at the club's annual golf tournament today at the Montclair Golf Club.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- If the target figure of a daily average of 4,000 tons of supplies is to be achieved this winter, approximately 138 more C-54's of the United States Air Force will have to be assigned to the Berlin airlift, an authoritative source said today.

Fast talking by Patrolman Joseph Cone of the Snyder Avenue station, Brooklyn, and his use of the word "buddy" halted a potential suicide who called the station house from a telephone three blocks away.

WOODMERE, L.I., Aug. 25 -- A broken pump at the Old Mill Road Pumping Station, one of the main artesian wells in this area, cut off the water supply of between 35,000 and 50,000 families in eight communities this evening.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 25 -"Strangers" who pursue the piscatorial art in Upper Greenwood Lake at West Milford, N.J., are adding insult to injury by taking fish placed in the lake by the Anglers Club, an auxiliary of the Upper Greenwood Lake Property Owners Association, the association complained today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Greece protested to Secretary General Trygve Lie today that the Government of Albania had stepped up assistance to Greek guerrillas in quick defiance of the latest peace attempt by the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States will accept the Soviet Government's order to close its consulate in Vladivostok, Secretary of State Marshall said today. He added that the closing, while regrettable, was not a serious matter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The two major political parties and all but one of the minor parties have overlooked a chance to have their Presidential candidates address a quarter-million potential absentee voters through Army broadcasts to its troops.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers who have been considering the disposal of Italy's former colonies completed the main part of their discussions today. All indications were that they had failed almost completely to reach agreement on the future administration of the territories.

A legal definition of "crimes against the peace" that would have declared "a war of aggression a crime only when perpetrated by the Axis powers" was proposed by Russia before the Nuremberg trials, Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson disclosed last night.

A record year in total dollar volume of sales of nails is now definitely indicated, and tonnage figures will equal or exceed the largest previous volume of output, hardware distributors here announced yesterday.
A group of writers and publishers asked yesterday that the Board of Education consider at its meeting today scheduling open hearings on the ban of the Nation from city schools.

The voters in this state who are enrolled in one of the political parties on Tuesday named their candidates for Congress, the State Assembly and some judicial posts. They had an opportunity to name them, that is. Actually, they largely took the men, who had been put on the ballot by their local political organizations.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Freddy Hutchinson went the route today for his fourth pitching victory of the season over the Athletics as Detroit pounded out a 10-to-4 victory. The defeat was the fifth successive setback for the Mackmen and left them two and a half games behind the third-place Yankees.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady 3 to 11 points higher yesterday with a moderate volume of business.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. T.U. Lyman and her brother, Wilkes McClave of Maplewood, retained their brother-and-sister championship today in a tournament held by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25 -- Foreign stars faded under a glaring sun and 90-degree temperatures today as the members of the newly named United States Davis Cup defending forces made impressive progress in the national doubles championship tennis competition at Longwood.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Charged with being active in the Socialist Workers party, James Kutcher, 35-year-old World War II veteran, decorated with the Purple Heart after he lost his legs in the Italian campaign, has been notified of his prospective dismissal as a clerk in the local office of the Veterans Administration.

A little war of nerves seems to be going on in the Government bond market as to just how much uncertainty should prevail in the level and constancy of the peg prices at which the Federal Reserve System will buy Treasury obligations in the open market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Washington unleashed its biggest hitting production of the season tonight to smother the Browns, 14 -- 6, and snap a nine-game losing streak. Ray Scarborough posted his twelfth victory for the Senators, who mauled five St. Louis pitchers for nineteen hits.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Braves pushed two runs across in the fifth inning as Warren Spahn hurled a 2-to-0 victory over the Cardinals tonight before 22,765 fans. The result left the Braves four games ahead of the second-place Dodgers.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- A process has been discovered by a German scientist that may solve the threatening world shortage of 400,000,000 units of insulin used to treat diabetes, the World Health Organization announced today.

Mayor O'Dwyer struck at Representative Vito Marcantonio yesterday and at the same time served notice that Communists and spokesmen for the "Communist-dominated" Greater New York CIO Council would not be welcome at City Hall so long as he is Mayor.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Brooklyn game with Pittsburgh was held up for about five minutes today by a melee in the Dodgers' dugout involving Associated Press photographer Danny Jacino.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Government said today that Communist-led rebel forces were in full flight from the Tharawaddy District in midwestern Burma, pursued by loyal troops who had split the rebels into two groups.
The autumn Collection of new handprinted wallpapers that Katzenbach Warren, 49 East Fifty-third Street, presented yesterday stresses soft designs and small motifs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Reduction by not less than 20 per cent of grants-in-aid from the Federal Government to state and local governments for the fiscal year 1950 was urged at the joint meeting of the tax committee of the Governors' Conference with Senators and Representatives here today.

Production of the Creole Petroleum Corporation for the first six months of this year continued at record levels, A.T. Proudfit, president, informs shareholders in the semi-annual statement to be issued today.

Tony Zale, the champion from Gary, Ind., and Marcel Cerdan, French challenger, yesterday signed official contracts for their fifteen-round middleweight title fight at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City on Sept. 21.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Connecticut Legislature passed today the Republican administration's program to alleviate the housing shortage, stay the eviction of tenants and increase old-age assistance payments.

Billy Graham, beaten only three times in eighty-one contests, will trade blows with rugged Terry Young in the feature ten-round contest of tonight's boxing program at Madison Square Garden. This is a neighborhood rivalry that has attracted considerable interest among local ring devotees, who are expected to turn out in the number of about 10,000.

NANKING, China, Aug. 25 -- The Chinese Government faced the first major test of the enforcement of its new economic reform measures today as prices began to show fluctuations. Reports from major cities throughout the country indicated price rises up to 100 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor, or its political arm, Labor's League for Political Education, will not endorse the Truman-Barkley ticket, but leaders of nearly all AFL unions, as individuals, are forming a committee that will do so.

The rather vague first statement of Defense Secretary Forrestal on the results of the Newport conference of the heads of the Armed Services has been clarified considerably at the meeting he and the three Chiefs of Staff held with senior officers of Army, Navy and Air oh Tuesday.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- Officials here who are in close touch with the Moscow negotiations said today they now expected a possibly prolonged pause in those exchanges between the Soviet Union and the West. They said the maximum achievement they thought might follow this pause was a more or less protracted respite in the struggle over Berlin, in which the Soviet Union is using the weapon of the blockade.
Joseph E. O'Grady, deputy director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, began yesterday efforts to avert a strike of the 350 drivers and mechanics employed by the Triboro Coach Company.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler suggests an expansion plan for the major leagues that eventually would create three loops of eight clubs each.

A biography of William Herndon, Lincoln's friend, law partner and biographer, will be issued by Knopf on Sept. 20. "Lincoln's Herndon," written by David Donald, is focused on the "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" days and on Herndon's long and wracking fight to publish his biography.

The liquor industry is not producing its full potential tax return to public treasuries because of sales lost to bootleggers, and an increase in bootlegging in this country is due mainly to high liquor prices resulting from high tax rates, it was said yesterday by R.E. Joyce, president of the Distilled Spirits Institute.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 25 -- The French Government would be ready to extend de facto recognition to the new state of Israel if the latter's government gave the firm assurances sought by cultural Continued on Page 10, Column 4 and religious interests in Palestine, it was disclosed today.

A heat "strike" yesterday slowed down one of the nation's largest industries in the Midwest and the fringes of its wave made New Yorkers uncomfortable as the mercury soared to 91.4 degrees at 5:50 P.M. The day was the hottest of the month and the second hottest of the year.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- A United States effort to have Germany accepted as an equal trading partner by the world's major trading nations got no support whatever today when it came up for discussion in a meeting of the Contracting Parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Frank Stranahan will run into quick trouble in his bid to add the United States amateur golf championship to the British and Canadian crowns that he won this season.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 25 -- Fighting flared up in Jerusalem during the early hours of this morning when Egyptian troops, established in new commanding positions near the Government House-Red Cross demilitarized area, tried to advance across No Man's Land toward Jewish suburb, according to an Israeli Army headquarters bulletin.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Joseph R. Watkins, 54 years old, a retired New York lawyer, of 293 Nassau Street, Princeton, was shot and killed under mysterious circumstances this evening as he sat behind the wheel of his automobile outside the Princeton Inn.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Over the vast terrain of this active Army post, the Army Advisory Committee, composed of twenty-five community leaders from the New York-New Jersey-Delaware area, witnessed at first hand today the rugged basic training by which military men hope to mold the new draftee into a soldier.

CHESTERFIELD, N.H., Aug. 25 -- State and nation joined today in honoring the memory of Harlan Fiske Stone, twelfth Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, who was born in this little New Hampshire town seventy-six years ago.

The failure of the people of the United States to support the merchant marine between World Wars I and II cost them $14,000,000,000, Sam Duvall Schell, vice president of the National Federation of American Shipping, declared at Kings Point, L.I., yesterday.

WARSAW, Aug. 25 -- At today's opening session of the World Congress of Intellectuals at Breslau (Wroclaw), a Soviet novelist, Alexander Fadayev, delivered a fiery speech in which he denounced not only "American imperialism" but what he called the "reactionary aggressive" elements of United States culture as well.

The Norco Realty Corporation, Louis Butensky, president, has purchased for improvement, with a one-story garage containing 30,000 square feet, the entire blockfront on the south side of Forty-first Street, between Twenty-second and Twenty-third Streets, Long Island City, Queens.

It is most ardently to be hoped in the interests of producing good citizens and curbing juvenile, delinquency that the Good Neighbor Federation in East Harlem will succeed in its efforts to raise $50,000 to reopen its settlement house. Begun in 1905, the settlement was forced by insufficient funds to close last August after it had done an invaluable job in an area which has low-grade housing, poor recreational facilities and crowded living conditions.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Russia's decision to close her consulates in the United States was viewed by competent observers today as the most striking sign of Soviet isolationism since before the "cold war."

A landmark in the downtown financial district that figured in the early history of the motion-picture industry here, and at the turn of the century housed the New York Register's Office, yesterday was reported sold by the Estate of Levi P. Morton, former Vice President of the United States, to a company controlled by Elias A. Cohen.

Italian economic activity is now apparently returning to the high levels of 1947, following the recession in the early months of this year, H. Gardner Ainsworth, second secretary and consul of the United States embassy at Rome, said at a conference yesterday in the offices of the Department of Commerce in the Empire State Building.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- James Nasser, film producer, today said he had purchased for $100,000 an original comedy by Lou Breslow and Joseph Hoffman entitled "You Made Me Love You." Nasser added that he was negotiating with Fred MacMurray and Madeleine Carroll for the top roles and with Lloyd Bacon to direct.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- A total of 256,000 refugees and displaced persons was repatriated or resettled during the first year's operations of the International Refugee Organization, it has been announced here.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that it was beginning a $216,700,366 building program, the largest in its history.

Warming up their "cold strike" against the Western Electric Company, several hundred telephone installation men walked off their jobs yesterday at the long lines building of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, 32 Avenue of the Americas.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Lewis W. Douglas, United States Ambassador in London and one of the chief consultants on the Western powers policy in the Kremlin ne gotiations on Germany, made a flying trip to Amsterdam tonight to talk with John Foster Dulles, Republican party's principal foreign affairs expert.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The Yugoslav Government today accused neighboring Rumania of grossly insulting the Tito regime and trying to bring about a revolt to overthrow Premier Tito.

Alfred Hitchcock's picturization in Technicolor of "Rope," based on a one-act play by Patrick Hamilton called "Rope's End," will have its local premiere this morning at the Globe. James Stewart, John Dall, Joan Chandler, Farley Granger and Sir Cedric Hardwicke are featured in the melodrama being released by Warner Brothers.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- James S. Schacht, 66 years old, treasurer of the Suffolk County Democratic Committee and a well-to-do real estate man, died in Mathew Memorial Hospital here today from multiple fractures of the neck received yesterday when he fell from his horse while riding at St. James, L.I.
Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday that he had applied for funds to permit a 25 per cent increase in the food allowance for families on relief.

URUMCHI (Tihua), Sinkiang, China, Aug. 18 -- A tenuous peace now prevails in Sinkiang, the "heart of Asia where the Soviet Union has carved out an economic, political, military sphere of influence in three districts governed by the autonomous "East Turkestan Republic."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson, New York State champion for the past three years, shot 39, 38 -- 77, two strokes over par, to win low gross honors at the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association' at the North Hempstead Country Club course today.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Assurance that the British coal industry need not fear competition from the development of oil, atomic energy or water power was given by Sir Ernest Smith, chairman of the Industrial Coal Consumers' Council when he addressed the National Coal Board's summer school at Oxford today.

Zot I. Chepurnykh, Soviet Vice Consul in New York, sailed suddenly for Russia last night with his family on board the 5,000-ton Russian freighter, Marshal Govorov, from the Claremont Terminal, Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Boston Maine Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to simplify its present capital stock structure by replacing eight classes of preferred and common stock, a total of 1,043,473 shares, with one issue of 816,653 shares of $100 par common stock.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Victory against the guerrillas in Greece grows nearer as a consequence of the Grammos Mountain campaign, Secretary of State Marshall said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- United States investments abroad jumped $8,100,000,000 last year to an all-time high of $28,800,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Spearheaded by four Olympic winners at London, college swimmers during the recently concluded season shattered ten records, two of them world marks, and schoolboys broke five and tied a sixth, it was disclosed yesterday when Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming records committee, released the list of standards approved by his committee.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- Approval to make the first guaranteed investment in post-war Western Germany has been granted to the Motion Picture Export Association [Germany] of the United States by the Bipartite Board of the United States and British zones.

A bronze head of Carlo Tresca, murdered New York anti-Fascist editor, has been placed in the public garden of Sulmona, Italy, adjacent to a square called Piazza Carlo Tresca, it was announced here yesterday by the Tresca Memorial Committee, 112 East Nineteenth Street.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Aug. 25 -- The Indian Army Intelligence Section here says that it is puzzled as to where its foe obtains ammunition. It is stated that this ammunition is being freely and even wastefully expended on the Kashmir fronts.

Two of the city's largest bus companies presented evidence yesterday of growing operating losses as the Public Service Commission accelerated its hearings on applications for fare rises in its offices at 233 Broadway. Another highlight was an assertion by Commissioner George A. Arkwright that the city's insistence that the lines obtain its permission before applying for fare increases was illegal.

A travel wardrobe made entirely of Australian wool was presented to Judy Gainford, the Miss Australia of 1947, at a luncheon held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Rupert R. Ellen, Trade Commissioner of Australia.

Martin Gosch and Eunice Healey, responsible for last season's presentation of "The Gentleman From Athens," a comedy by Emmet Lavery, will try their luck with a musical comedy this winter. The projected offering is tentatively labeled "Have a Heart."

New York traffic conditions were described yesterday as "impossible" by F.C. Lagache of Paris, general manager of the Touring Club of France, after a brief study of what keeps the wheels from going around in orderly procedure here.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- One of the largest fields on record competed in the nineteenth Westchester County father-and-son golf championship today. The result was decided by the matching of cards after play was completed over the historic Apawamis Club course.

Ellery W. Stone has been elected president and William H. Harrison has been made board chairman of both the Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation and its manufacturing and sales subsidiary, the International Standard Electric Corporation. The announcement was made yesterday by Sosthenes Behn, chairman and chief executive officer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, parent concern of the two companies.

Sharp and in some cases spectacular rises in unit labor costs in United States factories and plants since 1939 are shown in data gathered in a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES of labor costs and productivity in the American economy.

Directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., declared yesterday a special dividend of 50 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, both payable Oct. 1. The previous special was a similar amount in October, 1947.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- As a result of better news from Moscow and improvement in Britain's trade returns a firmer trend was seen in the stock markets here today and brokers were able to report a slight increase in business.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Tre Vit, 4-year-old filly owned by Charles U. Yaeger of Denver, established a new track record of 1:09 1/5 for six furlongs while scoring a brilliant victory in the $23,050 Great Western Handicap at Washington Park today.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Pressed to give the British Government's support to the movement for convening a Western European Assembly, Prime Minister Attlee said in a letter published today that he first wished to consult the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers who will meet here in October.

The Park Department presented yesterday to the City Planning Commission at a public hearing on 1949 capital budget requests a plea for funds to carry out plans for reconstruction of City Hall Park and development of park and parking lot facilities on the site of the old Tombs prison.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that United States cotton exports apparently hit a seventy-six-year, peacetime low in the crop year just ended.
George Shuler has been appointed sales manager of Venus Foundation Garments, Inc., Chicago. He was a sales representative in eastern Ohio.

WNYC's request for extension of the special authorization under which it is now operating at night was reported here yesterday to have been granted by the Federal Communications Commission. A spokesman for the city station said that the renewed permission would be good for six months or until a decision was reached by the FCC in the clear-channel hearings.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- That a hesitant and discreet exchange of views is now going on between the Provisional Government of Israel and certain Arab states appears to be the case. Whether these soundings will crystallize into peace negotiations is still impossible to foresee.
The split in the milk industry over the question of the price advance scheduled to take effect here on Oct. 1 widened yesterday.

First six months' spending rate for national advertising in newspapers promises to bring the year's total to about $423,984,000, a third consecutive record high, it was made known yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA. Should this spending rate continue, the gain will be 14.7 per cent or $55,000,000, over the record $369,000,000 high of last year, it was stated.

For four decades William B. Chase wrote about music and musicians and never said a word that would hurt or sting. He could censure with point and justice, but he did not know how to be harsh. It was simply not in his nature. He was fond of music, but he was much fonder of people.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Mrs. Iva Toguri d'Aquino, the United States-born Japanese disc jockey known as "Tokyo Rose" to thousands of American service men during the was, was arrested today on charges of treason.
The Eightieth Congress has joined its predecessors in history, but its deeds stay with us. So do the lobbies.

PRAGUE, Aug. 25 -- The Communist General Confederation of Labor today issued formal orders for the wholesale penetration and eventual taking over of the Sokol organization. The instructions called for the formation of Sokol clubs anywhere "where conditions are suitable" in plants, factories or establishments of any sort.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- As a lesson in transforming impending defeat into glorious victory what the Giants did to the Cubs on Wrigley Field in full view of 10,519 paid fans today will serve until a better one comes along. It will also do as the latest illustration of the late Harry C. Pulliam's remark that you can "take nothing for granted in baseball."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- From the Central African territory of Ruanda-Urundi, the United Nations has received four formal petitions of grievances from Moslem and Hindu inhabitants. The protests, made public here today, accuse the Belgian administering authorities of practicing or permitting discrimination against the Asiatic minority, which numbers about 800 persons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, today welcomed Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger home from Japan with a letter praising the general's record as both a warrior in the Pacific theatre and peacemaker after the end of hostilities.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- While Isaac I. Kashdan of New York added another point in the fourteenth round of the United States chess championship today, keeping his hold on first place, Weaver W. Adams of Dedham, Mass., handed Olaf Ulvestad of Seattle his first defeat.

RANGOON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- The Burmese Navy went into action in the Irrawaddy Delta area tonight while at the same time that Government land forces intensified their offensive against the rebels in central Burma.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- About 2,500 aircraft maintenance men will leave for England on Sept. 1 to care for both the sixty B-29 Superfortresses stationed there and the big transports performing in the airlift into Berlin, the Air Force announced today.
Those who lecture on atomic energy to visitors at the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition are not nuclear physicists or atomic scientists. Most of them are high school children.
Five administrators were appointed yesterday by the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO to take over the affairs of four of its left-wing locals whose leaders have been suspended.
New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $10,920,000 were cleared here yesterday for public offering by banking syndicates. The offerings are as follows:
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 25 (AP) --Season records in three harness horse classes were shattered today in Grand Circuit racing at the Wisconsin centennial exposition.

Twelve of the sixteen apartments in the fifteen-story and penthouse building at 1133 Fifth Avenue have been acquired by the tenants on a cooperative ownership basis from the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Norman Tishman, vice president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Long Island Lighting Company of Mineola, L.I. and three of its subsidiaries were ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to recapitalize on a one-stock basis.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Pero Popivoda of the Yugoslav Air Force said in a letter published today he had escaped by plane from Yugoslavia to Rumania Aug. 14.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Indians batted early and often today behind the four-hit shut-out pitching of erstwhile Outfielder Bob Lemon and regained first place in the American League's flag chase by thumping the Red Sox, 9 -- 0, with a nineteen-hit onslaught.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Sale of an estimated $297,287 in stocks and bonds from the estate of the late Mrs. Eleanor Medill Patterson, publisher of The Washington Times-Herald, has been authorized by Federal District Court.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 -- The afternoon tabloid Noticias Graficas, which for more than a year has been considered in President Juan D. Peron's camp, is to become the property of a Government-backed company, according to a deal that is expected to be signed soon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Alan Wood Steel Company of Conshohocken, Pa., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for public offering of $6,300,000 in first mortgage sinking fund bonds due 1963. The issue is to be underwritten by Drexel Co.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- Australia's master batsman, Don Bradman, celebrated his last appearance at the famed Lord's cricket ground today with a sparkling century against the gentlemen of England. He helped the Australians amass the big first innings total of 478 for three wickets by close of play.

Having been recalled from his vacation in Canada following Monday's news that there would be a Metropolitan Opera season, Edward Johnson, the general manager, arrived in town yesterday and went to his office in the opera house in the late afternoon.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- King Midas, a member of the Bobanet Stable owned by Bruce Livie of Baltimore, was a popular winner of the Beach Haven Purse here today.
The several thousand refugees from Eastern Europe who desire passage to America are as good as any immigrants who ever stepped off the Mayflower, Msgr. Luigi G. Ligutti declared here yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Jay Difani's single drove in Jerry Coleman in the ninth inning tonight to give Newark a 4-3 nightcap triumph over Montreal after the Royals captured the opener, 4 -- 2.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that Keith S. McHugh, vice president, has been appointed in charge of finance. Clifton W. Phalen has been elected a vice president of the company and succeeds Mr. McHugh as head of public relations.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Howie Fox, Cincinnati's 6-foot 3-inch righthander, handcuffed Philadelphia on six hits today as the Reds downed the Phillies, 5 -- 1.

After one of the dullest primary elections in years, it was agreed yesterday that the major parties had been completely successful in staving off attempts by the American Labor party here to make additional inroads in the Republican and Democratic ranks.

In the midst of the summer's most severe heat wave, football will make its 1948 metropolitan debut at Ebbets Field tonight, with the revamped Brooklyn Dodgers opposing the New York Yankees in the All-America Conference opener for both teams.

VIENNA, Aug. 26 -- American cigarettes purchased wholesale in the United States and France by a Hungarian black-market syndicate have become a chief threat to the stability of Austria's economy and thus the success of the European Recovery Program here.
All Manhattan traffic on the IRT and BMT subways and the Third Avenue Elevated Line was slowed down to a snail's pace from 8:15 to 9:10 o'clock last night as the result of power failures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- "What's this?" someone asked Secretary of Defense Forrestal on hearing that the Secretary of the Army is using tonight for an official conference the boat "Sequoia," which is permanently assigned to the Secretary of the Navy.
