"Is the Army, too, trying to chisel on the Navy in this unification or integration of the armed services?"

Tall elms in the meadows are a beautiful motif in Nature's canvas these brooding summer days. The river's quiet waters move slowly to the distant ocean; shaggy cumulus clouds accompany the sun as it courses near the pole of the horizon. The staccato burr of mowing machine knives blends with the alto flights of the grasshoppers. Sweet, pungent fragrance of curing clover and timothy fills the air.

The Navy announced yesterday that the 27,000-ton aircraft carrier Leyte would hold high speed maneuvers off the entrance to New York Harbor between 2 P.M. and 6 P.M. Sunday and warned all vessels, particularly pleasure craft, to avoid the area.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 -- Behind the six-hit pitching of California Joe Hatten, the Dodgers today made the ending of their four-game losing streak official with an easy 6-1 triumph over the Reds before a ladies' day crowd of 9,766 (5,739 paid).

Quick thinking by two men passengers averted a subway panic early yesterday morning in Brooklyn when a package carried by another rider burst into flame in a crowded car of the Culver-Nassau BMT line shortly after it left the Thirty-sixth Street Station, Manhattan bound.

The 25 per cent increase in the food allowance for families on relief which Welfare Commissioner Hilliard has suggested to Mayor O'Dwyer is consistent with cost-of-living facts, with the recommendations of the Welfare Council and with the dictates of humanity. It will cost nearly $15,000,000 a year, but it cannot be avoided if we are to live with our consciences.

Early sale of women's coats at retail has surpassed all expectations for the fall season, according to a survey made yesterday by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers. Many retailers have reported increases in their coat departments of 50 per cent over 1947 figures, it said.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, tonight called upon the Government to "get completely out of the picture" and give the disputants in the West Coast maritime controversy an "opportunity to seek settlement through official negotiations."
Times Square was filled with a strange lassitude yesterday as the temperature soared to its highest point in twelve years.

BROOKHAVEN, L. I., Aug. 26 -- Dr. W. Ralph Singleton, senior geneticist at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, in charge of studies on the effects of radiations on heredity, announced today that he had succeeded in redesigning the field corn plant, reducing it to the size of man and bringing its tall tassels within his reach.

ABOARD THE YACHT WANDERER IN CHESAPEAKE BAY, Aug. 26 -- President Truman aboard the Williamsburg was headed back to Washington by easy stages tonight, tanned and rested and professing some eagerness for the political campaign he will open with a series of Labor Day speeches throughout Michigan.

The executive committee of the New York County American Labor party unanimously adopted yesterday a resolution condemning Mayor O'Dwyer for refusing to confer on Wednesday with a delegation led by Paul L. Ross, the Mayor's former administrative assistant.

" Two Guys from Texas," latest in the Jack Carson-Dennis Morgan comedy series for Warner Brothers, opens an engagement this morning at the Strand. Dorothy Malone and Penny Edwards provide the romantic interest.

The vacant plot 52 by 125 feet on the west side of Broadway, 183 feet south of 231st Street, the Bronx, will be improved with a one-story business building by Land Properties, Inc., which acquired the property from the Connecticut-Providential Realty Incorporated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Harry Bridges, head of the CIO Longshoremen's Union, prepared today to meet waterfront employers in negotiations that may avert the threatened West Coast strike Sept. 2.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Any escape-minded refugees from civilization who might be planning permanent residence on American Samoa were firmly told by the United States Government today that practically no one-way passages would be permitted to the Polynesian paradise of the Pacific.

Deductions totaling $25,272,154 for Federal and New York estate taxes were listed in an intermediate accounting of the estate of Mrs. Edith Hale Harkness, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court in conjunction with a petition for final settlement of the estate.

A traffic fine of $241 -- which may be a record -- was paid yesterday in Uptown Traffic Court by a man whom the police arrested for failing to answer thirty parking summonses issued to him in the last three years.

Describing Mayor O'Dwyer as "a double-talking, double-dealing, double-crossing hypocrite," Representative Vito Marcantonio, State Chairman of the American Labor Party, denounced yesterday the Mayor's decision to oust from public employment all non-civil service Labor party members under his jurisdiction and that of Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 26 -- Delegates to the first Assembly of the World Council of Churches moved into the second day of closed sectional meetings here today with the major interest continuing to focus on the East-West cleavage in politics and religion.

In the Hudson River at West Forty-eighth Street yesterday afternoon the sun's heat made the tar ooze from the cracks between the deck planks on the U.S.S. Mississippi about as fast as it ever did during her long stay in the equatorial areas of the Southwest Pacific during the war.

Under the "limited" inflation control measure recently enacted by Congress provision was made for reimposing wartime restrictions on consumer credit. The Federal Reserve Board has now announced the terms that will govern time-payments after Sept. 20.

In an expansion move, the Maiden Form Brassiere Company of Bayonne, N.J., acquired the former Babcock and Wilcox Company's office building occupying the block bounded by Lexington Avenue, East Third Street, Hobart Avenue, and East Second Street, Bayonne, from the Divera Sportswear Company, Inc., manufacturers of ladies' sportswear.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 26 -- Davis Manufacturing, Inc., local farm implement manufacturer, has closed down indefinitely as the result of an inadequate distribution system. Three creditors of the company have filed suits in United States District Court here for recovery of $65,000.
A plan introduced March 1 to stagger pick-ups and deliveries in the garment area to relieve midtown traffic congestion has resulted in dismal failure, a survey showed yesterday.
GENEVA, Aug. 26 -- Dr. A.A. Arutiunian of Russia intervened briefly today in a debate in the Economic and Social Council to castigate New York as the locus of the United Nations.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Unasuming, workmanlike Bobby Doerr, whose fielding is approaching a record, proved once again today he is a dangerous man with a bat as his three-run homer led Boston's Red Sox into first place in the American League with an 8-4 triumph over Cleveland's Indians.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 26 -- "Diminished faith" in the efficacy of the present methods pursued by United Nations observers here to insure proper supervision of Jerusalem's truce, which he alleged had been constantly violated by Arab forces, was expressed this afternoon by Col. Moshe Dayan, Israeli brigade commander, at his first conference with correspondents here since he assumed command.

Flight tests made last January by the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the Douglas Aircraft Corporation showed that a strong concentration of carbon dioxide fumes gathered in the cockpit of a DC-6 when the remote-controlled fire extinguishing equipment was used.

BERLIN, Aug. 26--The resignation of all members of Berlin's Magistrat, or City Assembly, and Communist "rights" in Berlin's Western sectors were demanded tonight by the Soviet-sponsored Socialist Unity (Communist) party and the German Economic Commission of the Soviet zone after a mass demonstration organized by the Communists had forced the postponement of a meeting of the City Assembly.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The National Football League ruled today a rookie player need not jeopardize his future by playing in a college all-star charity game without "full" contract protection.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- The French Foreign Ministry formally denied today that Gen. Jean Ganeval, commander of the French sector of Berlin, had told a news agency that the four Military Governors would meet soon to discuss the Berlin currency problem.

John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy expert, returning last evening from a meeting of the World Council of Churches in Amsterdam, Holland, described the political atmosphere in Europe as calmer than in America. Mr. Dulles arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, at 6:15 P.M.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- The Government of the state of South Baden in the French zone resigned today. Leo Wohleb, Minister-President, declared he and his colleagues were not able to "bear the responsibility" because of the dismantling program.

First plans for the proposed $14,000,000 bridge to span the Hudson River between Kingston in Ulster County and Rhinecliff in Dutchess were made public here yesterday. With a main span of 1,700 feet, the bridge would become the eighth longest in the world, and among those across the Hudson it would be second only to the George Washington Bridge.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Jack Solomons, British fight promoter, announced today that Lee Oma, 31-year-old American heavyweight, will fight the British heavyweight champion, Bruce Woodcock, at Harringay Arena Sept. 21.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The National Military Establishment listed publicly for the first time today its immediate plans for enlarging a national security stockpile of twenty-eight "strategic and critical" materials.

Forty-five passengers wearing woolen clothing and top coats, who left Reykjavik, Iceland, yesterday when the temperature there was 52 degrees, stepped off a DC-4 into sweltering heat at 9:45 A.M. yesterday at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

ATHENS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Greek Army forces have opened a drive against 800 to 1,000 Communist-led guerrillas along the Greek-Yugoslav border northwest of Salonika, a communique said today. Fighting is going on in the area of Mount Kaimaktchalan, which lies astride the border.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs whipped the Boston Braves, 5 to 1 and 5 to 2, today in a wild double-header that twice was marked by demonstrations in the crowd of 27,316. It reduced Boston's first-place margin to two and a half games over the Cardinals and three games over Brooklyn.
Earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the second quarter ended on July 3 are estimated at $5,810,000 after taxes and all charges, it was reported yesterday.

WARSAW, Aug. 26 -- A British professor, the first of the Western delegates to pick up the Russian challenge, told the World Congress of Intellectuals today that "this has been a congress preaching war, and not a congress preaching peace."
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Arthur B. Cotnoir, a sea captain who liked to spin the yarn about the time he kicked a whale in the eye, died today in St. Luke's hospital. He was 56 years old.

Six hundred and twenty West Point cadets of the class of 1950 arrived yesterday at the New York Port of Embarkation for a training visit. The group debarked shortly after 2 P.M. at Pier 3, Brooklyn Army Base, from the transport General Daniel I. Sultan after completing summer maneuvers at Little Creek, Va.

Columbia's American Press Institute will conduct a special six-week seminar on the functions and techniques of a democratic press for fifteen German publishers and editors, Floyd Taylor, institute director, announced yesterday.

The ten-year program of the Department of Marine and Aviation, developed by Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti as a means of rehabilitating the city's pier system, was placed yesterday before the City Planning Commission. The program, calling for expenditure of $54,848,000 of city funds, eventually may be carried through by the World Trade Corporation, depending upon action to be taken by Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate before Sept. 15.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- With the thermometer doing its best to blow its top, this was no day for arguing. But in three successive races at Saratoga there were yowls of foul from jockeys, the "objection" neons glowed on the tote board and the stewards had to go into huddles with the parties of the first and second parts while many of the 11,132 customers argued about the merits of each case.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- British films will have a chance to test their popularity with the public here in competition with American pictures if plans now being worked out here by Hollywood interests are carried out. Under the proposal, United States producers would book "all-American" programs complete from feature pictures to short subjects into theatres that wanted them here and let the British producers do likewise.

Featuring both tall-crowned and small, cap-like silhouettes, Keneth Hopkins presented what he called "the pert look" in his fall millinery collection designed for Gunther and shown yesterday at the Chatham Walk.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- A team of top-notch English amateurs labeled Gentlemen of England put up good resistance to the Australian bowling today to score 237 for nine wickets at close of play in reply to Australia's 610 for five, declared.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- A Cabinet meeting attended by all principal Ministers examined today the prices and wages question as a preliminary to a full-dress Cabinet Council session tomorrow that will pass on the financial plan of Finance Minister Paul Reynaud.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Miss Vivien Kellems, who operates the Kellems Company, wire cable grip manufacturer, said today that all her property in Westport had been put up for sale because of a court order that directs her company to cease manufacturing operations by Dec. 1.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Preston Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, is advising his backers that the company "has signed an option agreement with a very substantial financial group."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Louis Budenz testified at a secret hearing last Tuesday that he and other pre-war Communist leaders had regarded Alger Hiss as a Communist, the House Committee on Un-American Activities disclosed today.

Following organization of the Committee for Economic Development on a new and permanent basis, Philip D. Reed, chairman of the board, General Electric Company, and newly elected chairman of the CED research and policy committee, described six points of the enlarged research activities of the organization yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Evidences in Government data of a trend toward sharply rising labor costs with inadequate or no offsetting gains in productivity in a substantial section of American industry are corroborated by the individual experience of many business executives.

Striking at profits through such devices as price ceilings on commodities, or new taxes on business enterprise, would be the "worst possible way" to combat inflation, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York asserts in its monthly review of business and financial conditions published today.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Moderate optimism on the outcome of the talks in Moscow had the stock market here today in a cheerful mood as brokers found more interest being shown by investors.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Without passing on the constitutionality of two municipal anti-noise ordinances, Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow denied today the Progressive party's application for injunctions to prevent Newark and Montclair from interfering with use of its sound truck. The court declared that "excessive noise presents one of the serious problems of life in an American city."

The Abbott Laboratories declared on common a quarterly dividend of 65 cents and an extra of 15 cents, both payable Oct. 1. In two preceding quarters 80 cents also was distributed, 50 cents regular and 30 cents extra.

' The Whole of Their Lives: Communism in America -- A Personal History and Intimate Portrayal of Its Leaders," by Benjamin Gitlow, will be brought out by Scribners in October. Mr. Gitlow, a former member of the party, and twice candidate for vice president on its ticket, traces the evolution of American communism from the first activity of various groups of political idealists and opportunists up to today's calculating and disciplined movement.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Dissatisfaction over the way the Government is controlling prices and profits is evidenced in almost a score of resolutions awaiting the attention of the annual Trades Union Congress, which meets in Margate in the week of Sept. 6.

Back in the days of personal initiative some of us can remember, every redskin who deepened his spring hoped that oil would gush forth, and today every coastal hamlet, from Passamaquoddy to Key West is trying to develop a fishing contest as a result of one large fish that wandered into the local waters.
Riders on privately operated buses in the city will continue to pay only the present five and ten-cent fares at least until mid-September, it became evident yesterday.

Registering the first decline after four consecutive weekly rises, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $21,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

Pretty "sissy" red flannels, practical warm wool separates and glamorous evening gowns were presented yesterday by Martin's in Brooklyn at a college fashion show. The clothes showed that college girls will combine usefulness with fashion when they shop.

Administrators appointed by the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, to seize control of four left-wing locals here were firmly rebuffed yesterday when they tried to do so at the offices of three of them.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 26 -Charles Hamilton Sanford Jr. of Syracuse, N.Y., has been appointed executive secretary of the Yale Alumni Board, according to an announcement issued jointly today by Dr. Charles Seymour, university president, and Clifford R. Beardsley, chairman of the Alumni Board.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said today he had been told by his advisers that the work of the committee preparing a draft constitution in Heerenchiemsee last week was "satisfactory."

Saratoga cronies of Fred Finklehoffe, Jed Harris' amiable partner, report that the conversation there isn't confined entirely to the improvement of thoroughbreds. Once in a while the stage rears its head, and that topic concerns this department.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Great Britain presented statistics to the United Nations today to support her long-standing contention that more than half of the European refugees resettled since the end of the war had found permanent sanctuary in the United Kingdom.

PRAGUE, Aug. 26 -- The steady expulsion of district and local Sokol leaders and members from the Sokol organization continues. Rude Pravo, central organ of the Czech Communist party, has announced the expulsion of twelve more leaders in Prague, publishing the full list of names, and also the expulsion of nine officials of the Sokol in Pilsen.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 26 -- A new plan for Government aid to those too old to work was announced today at the first general press conference ever held by Senora Eva Peron in Argentina.

Max Stark, alleged gambler, was taken into custody yesterday by agents of Walter D. Van Riper, New Jersey Attorney General, and subpoenaed to appear before the Bergen County grand jury on Tuesday in the investigation of gambling activities in Lodi, N.J., and at a "charity" affair in this city.

After returning on Wednesday from an abbreviated vacation in Canada, Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, said yesterday that details of the pending season would be announced in October. He also said that the opening date would be disclosed then.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago posted a five-under-par 67 today to take the lead in the $12,500 Utah Open golf tournament.

After a three-hour conference in the Federal Court House, Foley Square, Government authorities agreed yesterday to return to her owners the yacht Marge, which had been detained by Customs since last Thursday when she was halted by a Coast Guard cutter as she sailed from this port.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- Alarmed by the widespread resale of Australian wool by Europeans to United States dealers, Australian authorities in Europe are taking official steps to protect the dollar-hungry Dominion's principal source of United States credits.

Our friend to whom the freedom of the city is a precious privilege though never officially conferred upon him at City Hall -- and for whom the cozy contacts of suburban life have no appeal, has been spending some time of late in the real country where he was born and bred and from which in early manhood he escaped to the city.

Plans for a low-rental housing project to provide 1,266 apartment units at Pelham Parkway and Bronxwood Road, the Bronx to cost an estimated $15,656,000 were filed in the Municipal Building yesterday.

For the longest time it appeared yesterday at the Stadium that the Yankees would need nine Tommy Henrichs to beat the last-place White Sox. Old Reliable, as Henrich is called, fashioned a single and homer, the only two safeties against Southpaw Frank Papish, and when the heat overcame the Chicago Lefthander at the end of the sixth inning, the White Sox enjoyed a 2 -- 1 edge.

Two months ago 8-year-old Johnny "X", product of a broken home and a drunken mother who had little love for him, was a nearly incorrigible delinquent. Today the New York youngster is well on the road to being a "good boy" after eight weeks in a summer camp.

Publication of "One Hundred Best Retail Advertisements, a reference and source book for merchants" manufacturers and newspaper advertising and promotional staffs, was announced yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Thorough exploration of further Canadian-United States tariff adjustment possibilities on a "completely quid-pro-quo basis" was urged yesterday as a basic step in improving trade relations between the two countries.

In an all cash transaction, the Oil Distributors, Inc., have acquired the oil and gasoline storage bulk plant on Maspeth Avenue, extending through to English Kills, Brooklyn, from the Atlantic Hy-Lube Corporation through the James H. Burns Company, broker.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 27 -- Most London newspaper reviews cordially welcomed the revival of J.B. Priestley's "Eden End," which opened at the Dutchess Theatre last night. It was generally agreed that this fourteen-year-old play, set in a village doctor's household, was Priestley at his best.
The story of a strange disappearance at sea was reported yesterday by the Coast Guard here.
A red flag caused a brief delay yesterday in the beehive activity about the Soviet Consulate, 7 East Sixty-first Street, which the staff is preparing to vacate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Franklin P. Roosevelt Jr., and other officials of the American Veterans Committee, denounced today in strong terms a Veterans Administration proposal to raise the interest rate on GI home loans.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Aug. 26 -- Thirty-five hundred Roman Catholic high school, college and seminary students convened on the campus of Notre Dame University today for the national convention of the Catholic Students Mission Crusade, with the keynote "every Catholic student a missioner."
MOSCOW, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The diplomatic forecast changed from "fair" to "good" in Moscow tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 -- Leo Durocher subjected his Giants to the most violent shake-up of his regime today in a desperate bid to salvage something from an afternoon-night double-header that attracted an aggregate of 23,370 fans but the results were negligible.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Upsets marked the fifteenth round of the United States chess championship at the Community Center today. George Kramer of New York, dropping to third place, sustained his second loss, his first having occurred in the eighth round. The New Yorker bowed to Hermann V. Hesse of Bethlehem, Pa.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Sama Duwa Sinwa Nawng, Minister for the Kachins, today confirmed reports that an insurrection had broken out in the Kerenni Hill tracts, seventy miles northeast of Toungoo. In a letter to Sao Shwe Thaik, Burma Union President, he said: "The Karenni people are trying to wrest power from the Burma Union Government by armed force."

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Aug. 24 -- Hyderabad Government's announced intention to take its dispute with India to the United Nations has left Indian Government circles undisturbed and has had no ill effects on the delicate relations between the big princely state and the dominion that surrounds it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Soviet Government has made a hopeful, though evidently not quite satisfactory, offer for a settlement of the currency question in Berlin, it was learned today.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 (AP) -- In one of the biggest scoring sprees ever witnessed at the Grand American Trapshoot, Ray S. Painter, 35-year-old farmer from Lomax, Ill. (pop. 100), emerged today as winner of the preliminary handicap.

Coffee futures were firm yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc. Trade house buying and short covering, plus small Brazilian buying, advanced prices 35 to 40 points above the previous level. Profit taking and long liquidation provided the selling.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Lindsay C. Warren, Controller General, ruled today that three Federal judges, whose appointments lack Senate approval, could continue to serve and draw pay until after the new Congress convened in January.

URUMCHI, Sinkiang, China, Aug. 19 -- Sinkiang, whose northwest corner already has been shaved off by rebel Turki forces, is the lower flank of a prospective pro-Soviet border belt extending northeastward through Outer Mongolia and Communist-held Manchuria to the Sea of Okhotsk.

James A. Farrell Jr., president of Farrell Lines, Inc., yesterday signed a new pier lease with the city that may set a pattern for future pier contracts and help lift the city's financial burden in pier improvements.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The police conference of the State of New York closed its four-day session here today with adoption of forty-three resolutions calling for improved working conditions for its 40,000 members.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -Department of Commerce officials said today a license has been granted to export to Czechoslovakia 7,000,000 steel balls which could be processed in that country into ball bearings. The value of the shipment was "under $20,000," they said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Aug. 26--United Nations workers expressed their satisfaction today that the world organization's top officials had cooperated fully in denouncing "spy" charges that were leveled against foreign employes last month by three minor officials of the United States Department of State.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- William Rickenbacker of Sleepy Hollow, son of the noted war-time pilot, began defense of his Westchester junior golf championship at the Apawamis Club course today by winning the medal with a 73 in the morning qualifying round, then scoring a 7-and-5 victory over Howard Michalson of Vernon Hills, as match play opened this afternoon.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge left here by air for the United States at 10 o'clock this morning. After nearly three years as the commander of United States Forces in Korea, General Hodge will report to the Army Department for a new assignment.

BERLIN, Aug. 26 -- Work has been begun on the construction of a third runway at the Tempelhof Airfield as part of the program of increasing the flow of supplies into Berlin by air, Col. Reginald Whitaker, Chief United States Engineer in Berlin, announced tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 (UP) -- Helen Lee Worthing, once a Ziegfeld Follies beauty, died early today in a tiny cottage where she had lived for ten years. Death of the 43-year-old former actress was believed to have been natural, but a preliminary autopsy failed to show the cause and the coroner ordered chemical and microscopic tests.

Legal and financial aid was promised yesterday to assure the future in this country of Mrs. Oksana S. Kasenkina, the Russian teacher whose revolt against Soviet authority started a series of events that led to the severance of consular exchange between the United States and the U.S.S.R.
BERLIN, Aug. 26 -- Karl Siedel -- that's not his real name because he is afraid to give it -- attended two demonstrations today, the one staged by the Communists and the other by the anti-Communists.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 26 -- William Byrne Jr. of the Garden City Country Club carded 35, 40 -- 75 to win low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Glen Head Country Club today.

Wholesale fruit and vegetable centers bustled with activity yesterday as retailers stocked up on supplies for the week-end trade. At the Fulton Fish Market, too, business moved briskly as dealers disposed of liberal quantities of scallops, whiting and crabmeat.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP)--Pete Suder's two-run double in the eighth inning gave the Philadelphia Athletics a 4-3 decision over the Detroit Tigers and snapped their five-game losing streak today.

Reflecting the improvement in sales, the net income of the United Aircraft Corporation for the six months ended with last June increased to $5,743,731 after all charges from the $3,416,873 earned in the corresponding half of last year, according to the report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The National Automobile Dealers Association reported here today that there was an estimated backlog of 7,300,000 unfilled orders on the books of the automotive industry. This total represents an 11 per cent increase since Jan. 1.

The American Radio Association, CIO, representing 1,400 marine radio officers employed on ships operated by twenty-eight companies on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, is expected to sign a new contract here today.

ALBANY, Aug. 26 -- Motor vehicle accidents and deaths in New York during the first half of this year showed a marked decline from the same period of 1947, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Clifford J. Fletcher reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Photostatic copies of two letters said by Soviet Russia to have been written by Mrs. Oksana Stepanovna Kasenkina will be transmitted by the State Department to the New York police so that the refugee school teacher may have a chance to pass on their authenticity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The "big five" airlines will discuss passenger fares tomorrow with Joseph J. O'Connell Jr., chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board. The five are American. United, Trans-World, Eastern and Northwest Airlines.
ATHENS, Aug. 26 -- Minister of War George Stratos said today the Greek Government had tangible evidence that Bulgaria as well as Albania had aided the Greek rebels during the recent Grammos fighting.

PENNS GROVE, N.J., Aug. 26 -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced today that it intends to sell all of its 605 housing units in the Penns Grove-Carneys Point area, and relinquish all ownership of the Carneys Point village.

It is good news that the city's all-out offensive against its rat population is about to go into high gear. That population, alarmingly, is now estimated by the Health Department at 15,000,000, or nearly two rats per citizen. The only useful purpose which rats serve is as laboratory animals for war on human disease.
Sam C. Whitehouse, formerly assistant manager of the Kobuta Pa., chemical plant of Koppers Company, Inc., has been named export manager of the chemical division's sales department.

" Hometown Reunion," a sixty-minute period of hillbilly tunes and humor, is scheduled by CBS for its premiere on Saturday, Sept. 18, beginning at 10 P.M. Topping the cast will be Eddy Arnold, folk singer; the "Duke of Paducah," a mountaineer comedian; the Willis Brothers trio; Annie, Lou and Danny, a novelty vocal group, and the Hometown Band and Choir.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission resumed today its hearings on the Lehigh Valley Railroad system's application to modify its present debt structure.

Carbonated beverage sales, which have been running approximately 13 per cent below the corresponding period last year because of the weather, are expected to be even or slightly ahead by the end of August because of the unexpected heat wave during the last two days, officials of the New York State Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages, Inc., said yesterday.
The discovery, almost wholly by accident, of what may be the "patriarch" of all viruses causing various forms of encephalitis or sleeping sickness was announced today by the University of California.

Sweltering its way through a 426-item calendar, the Board of Estimate authorized yesterday bond issues totaling $36,649,000 to finance additional projects on the city's $200,000,000 program for low rental housing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 21 were 12 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

Coincident with the disclosure of a "large tonnage" scrap purchase in Germany by Carnegie Illinois Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, it was learned here yesterday from trade sources that plans are rapidly advancing for a Government-sponsored scrap-buying corporation to engage in preclusive buying and shipping of all remaining German scrap allocated to United States buyers.

The mercury went to 100.8 degrees here at 2:44 P.M. yesterday on the hottest day since 1936. It was the third hottest day on record in the city, the temperature falling one degree and a half short of the record high of 102.3 degrees recorded on July 9, 1936.

The heat wave extracted its toll yesterday on the stock market also in another dull and meaningless session. Most brokerage offices were deserted soon after midday except for skeleton forces and lapses between floor transactions were numerous during the day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- Barbara Stanwyck will star in "The File on Thelma Jordon" for Hal Wallis at Paramount, it was announced today, and for the third time at the studio will play the role of a murderer. The story, which has a California setting, is an original by Miss Marty Holland and has just been acquired by the producer.

Those folks who wondered what had happened to the pots and pans promised as premiums for the purchase of boxes of soap chips last spring learned the reason yesterday when a former messenger for an advertising promotion concern pleaded guilty in General Sessions to second degree grand larceny.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Buying of an estimated 2,000,000 bushels or more of September and December wheat by cash interests, regarded as removal of hedges against sales of actual grain to the Government, dominated trading in that grain on the Board of Trade today and at one time September sold within about 1/2 cent of December.

Threat of a strike by 350 drivers and mechanics of the Triboro Coach Corporation, serving 120,000 riders daily in Queens, was ended yesterday -- a few hours before the deadline -- after intervention by Mayor O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The United Spanish War Veterans today installed a former Marine as their national commander for the first time in the organization's fifty-year history. Charles R. Barefoot, 64, a Toledo, Ohio, lawyer, took office at the golden anniversary encampment of the veterans. He served with the Marines during the Philippines Insurrection from 1899 to 1902.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer announced today the soft coal industry has taken a first step toward getting a share of scarce steel set aside to assure maximum coal production.

A circus roustabout known as Willard Seymour, who died penniless a year ago in the Boston City Hospital, was the illegitimate son and only heir of the late Mrs. Mabel Seymour Greer, who died last August in her home at 399 Park Avenue, Surrogate James A. Delehanty ruled yesterday.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Morris Fishman's Canada's Teddy, a 10-to-1 shot, won the Oakley Purse at Narragansett Park today. The Nydrie Stable's Highfortitides was second, a length and a half back of the winner.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 26 -- The first of a series of food trains, transporting supplies destined for European relief and representing the cooperation of Protestants and Catholics, steamed out of two state capitols tonight.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 26 -School was over here today for sixty-five children ranging in age from 2 to 14 years who have been attending the Court Street School for Migrants since July 29, while their parents have been busy harvesting the potato crop in Monmouth, Middlesex and Mercer counties.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Undaunted by a blistering sun that sent the temperature soaring into the high 90's, the United States and Australian Davis Cup doubles teams coolly overcame top-flight opposition to gain the semi-final round of the national tennis tournament today at Longwood.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, hot as the 96-degree weather, bounced back into the first division today as they swept a double-header from the slumping Philadelphia Phils, 11 to 4 and 4 to 1. The Quaker losing streak was stretched to nine games.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, who met in Heidelberg this morning with Army officials for a regular commander's conference, confirmed the existence of plans for the evacuation of American civilians in Frankfort specifically and throughout the United States zone in general.

After seventy-eight years in the same ownership, the four-story building formerly occupied as a hotel at the northeast corner of the Bowery and West Third Street has been sold by the estate of Michael Ryan to the Salvation Army in a deal negotiated by John R. and Oscar L. Foley, brokers.

The "Anything on Wheels" derby conducted by the Children's Aid Society at its Sloane Center, 630 East Sixth Street, yesterday proved the surprise event in its ten-year history. For the "contraption on wheels" that proved the real winner over all the home-made scooters, pushmobiles and crepe-paper-festooned tricycles was a streamlined city sanitation truck.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The McClave family of Maplewood, N.J., added another intra-family golfing honor to its list today by winning the metropolitan father-and-daughter championship over the Leewood Club course with a gross score of 83.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Mrs M. M. Palmer of New Canaan won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association with a 43, 39 -- 82 over the Round Hill course today.

A slight, diffident man arrived in this country yesterday to attack the most baffling problem in North American archaeology; exactly when and where did the Scandinavians, who were on this continent long before Columbus' voyages, live?

Billy Graham beat Terry Young in the "battle of the East Side" at Madison Square Garden last night. The rangy Graham, a 1-to-2 favorite over his squat neighborhood rival, made the form stand up as he boxed his way to the unanimous decision before a crowd of 6,898 fans.
The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company came up yesterday with a bit of fine hot-weather reading involving a mysterious male passenger, a thirty-one-year-old train ticket and a cake.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Edward J. Becker, New Jersey's literary prisoner, can start selling his fiction stories again when he is released on parole next Monday from Bordentown Prison.

With James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, recognizing the general economic difficulties in the motion picture industry, the federation and eight major film studios announced here last night an accord to extend existing agreements for one year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Nevada's zinc production in 1947 dropped 25 per cent below the record total for 1946, the Bureau of Mines has reported.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- Another secret meeting of the Communist Information Bureau has been held to discuss the Yugoslav problem. It was resolved at this conference that the Belgrade Government either does not understand or pretends not to understand that its present policy is on the road to "betrayal" of Yugoslavia's national independence.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 26 (AP) -- All of the 13,411 fans at the Atlantic City race track sweltered today, but those who backed All in Fun in the feature race added a little extra perspiration before S.A. Mason's colt was declared the winner.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Persons suffering from high blood pressure can get relief by going on a near-starvation diet, three University of Minnesota scientists said today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Newspaper printers who struck more than nine months ago faced the prospect of losing their strike benefits today, but they expressed a determination to carry on with any voluntary aid that came their way.

It is hard to quarrel with the general argument made in John D. Hall's plea for a more enlightened United States colonial policy, as published in THE TIMES on Aug. 23. I would, however, question the wisdom of awarding American citizenship to Pacific islanders who still follow in large degree the traditions and culture of their ancestors.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (UP) -Mildred Viola Newton, 26 days old and weighing one pound nine ounces, was thriving tonight in an incubator at County General Hospital, where she has gained four ounces since birth.

Prudent bidding prevails in the market for municipal bonds as investment men -- both buyers and distributors -- submit gradually to the traditional coma of August's last days. This week San Francisco joined the parade of California borrowers in which school and sanitation districts have figured prominently lately.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The leading "shopper" for strategic materials for the United States defense stockpile reported "en couraging results" today from the first part of his search.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 21 were 900,572 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,295 cars, or 1.0 per cent more than for the preceding week, 323 cars, or .03 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 15,617 cars, or 1.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The American Federation of Labor executive council charged today that Congress "failed the nation" when it adopted the present housing law.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Britain's first Machine Tool and Engineering Exhibition in 14 years opened at Olympia Hall here today with more than three million pounds sterling (about $12,000,000) worth of new capital equipment on display.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 26 -- The Yugoslav protest to Rumania has shifted the Cominform struggle against Marshal Tito to a new plane and more dramatic developments may be expected.
A plea to conserve water in this city because of the hot weather was issued last night by Stephen Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
In a recent issue you published a communication from Arthur Upham Pope entitled "Virtues of Cats Upheld."

MADRID, Spain, Friday, Aug. 27 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco had a three-hour interview Wednesday with Don Juan, the Bourbon pretender to the Spanish throne, aboard the Franco yacht Azor in the Bay of Biscay off the French port of Arcachon, high Monarchist sources here said today.
GENEVA, Aug. 26 -- Steady progress in the battle for coal is reported in the July figures of European coal production released today by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- During the week ended Aug. 25, member bank reserve balances increased $65,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Infantile paralysis outbreaks have claimed more than 420 lives in the nation this year, a survey showed today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Ed Stewart squeezed Al Kozar across the plate in the ninth inning tonight to bring the Senators an 8-7 victory over the St. Louis Browns before 3,769 fans.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 2 to 14 points net higher. It started 1 to 2 points higher, eased slightly on a few hedge selling orders, but steadied later when the hedge selling dried up.

Alexandria, Va., sold yesterday $5,250,000 of public improvement bonds maturing Sept. 1 from 1950 to 1984 to a banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. at an interest cost of 2.9307 per cent. The bid was 100.18 for 4s and 2 3/4s. Bonds maturing from 1950 to 1969 were reoffered at prices to yield 1.20 per cent to 2.85 per cent; bonds maturing from 1970 to 1984 were not reoffered publicly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- An amended plan of recapitalization of the Lehigh Valley Transit Company, Allentown, Pa., was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The SEC said it would apply to the Federal District Court in Philadelphia for approval and enforcement of the plan.
GENEVA, Aug. 26 -- The United States urged today in the Economic and Social Council early action by the United Nations to place before the governments a completed text of a genocide convention.

With your comments on the absurdity of interpreting research procedures and results in accordance with sacred utterance (Marxist-Leninist) the writer is in full agreement. The fate of Dr. Vavilov at the hands of the ineffable Lysenko is deplorable. Nor is this one of the many pieces on Russia of the mote and beam school.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Another Kremlin meeting is scheduled to be held soon for the purpose of drafting a directive for four-power currency negotiations in Berlin, it was learned here today.

Although everything still depends on at least another conference at the Kremlin, it now seems that the Moscow negotiations are moving in the direction of transferring further discussions of the German problem to the Military Governors of the four occupying Powers in Berlin.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP) -- A small but vicious tropical hurricane, moving northwestward at 15 miles an hour, battered a Russian freighter some 1,000 miles southeast of Miami today as it churned the sea with winds up to 100 miles an hour.

Plans for the Army Corps of Engineers to spend $70,000,000 in 1948-1949 in Alaskan construction were outlined to prospective contractors here yesterday. Col. W.E. Potter, district engineer of Alaska, listed nineteen proposed contracts to build housing and base facilities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today a 10 per cent advance in passenger bus fares on a number of lines operating between New York and Rockland County, N.Y., and Bergen County, N.J.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 26 -- Believing that devaluation of the peso already is stimulating foreign trade, the Mexican Government decided today that the National Treasury also should benefit from this circumstance and a blanket 15 per cent ad valorem tax was placed on all exports in addition to existing duties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Average primary market prices reversed the decline of last week by advancing 0.1 per cent during the week ended Aug. 21, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index returned to the post-war peak of 169.2 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.6 per cent above four weeks ago and 10.2 per cent above the corresponding week of 1947.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Members of a joint Congressional investigating committee disagreed today on whether the Kaiser-Frazer corporation had a firm contract to lease a $28,000,000 Government-owned blast furnace at Cleveland from the War Assets Administration.

Agents for dealers in five countries in Europe are now offering to American non-ferrous metals foundries sizable deliveries of American aluminum ingot exported by this country within the last two years, metal purchasing sources revealed here yesterday.
by Farrell Linesh) 0*0*0*iOThe Maritime Commission has invited shipyards to bid on extensive reconversion jobs on two former transports for the Farrell Lines, it was announced yesterday.
Record orders, a high attendance and predictions for good fall and winter business marked the closing yesterday of the thirty-fifth semi-annual Gift Show at the Pennsylvania and New Yorker Hotels.

With the return of the main contingent of 164 athletes and accompanying officials on board the United States liner Washington yesterday morning, an "official" finis was written to a glorious adventure for the most successful of all United States Olympic teams.

Many varied factors besides the post-war wage-price spiral played a part in producing the trend toward sharply rising unit labor costs in a large section of American industry, a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES of available information on productivity and labor cost shows.
Certainly it is too hot to cook. And some say it's too hot to eat. But is it? Doesn't it depend on what one eats?

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Britain was reliably reported tonight to be prepared to accept in principle a United States proposal for international agreement covering a large part of the Antarctic Continent. The United States proposal does not mention the Soviet Union, which has no claims in that part of the world.
WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 27 (U.P.) The "temperance tornado" blew into southeastern Kansas today, with three star milers in the lead.
Schoolgirls who wear teen-age sizes will see clothes priced within their budgets at Gimbels' backto-school fashion show scheduled for 11 A.M. The selections were previewed on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Industrial production dropped off in July, largely due to employe vacations, after rising the preceding two months, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. Part of the loss was regained in the first half of August, the Board said.

Lumber production for the week ended Aug. 21 was 13.2 per cent above a year ago and 2.4 per cent above the preceding week. Shipments were 17.4 per cent above the like week last year, with orders down 1.3 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to associations
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Arthur J. Lopatka today sued the Philadelphia Phillies for $250,000 damages for allegedly "completely disabling him as a pitcher."

All airlines using the Douglas DC6 and the Air Line Pilots Association, AFL, received revised operating manuals for the big plane after fire-extinguishing tests last January by the manufacturing company and the Civil Aeronautics Administration, according to testimony given yesterday at the hearing into the DC-6 crash near Mt. Carmel, Pa., on June 17.

Many millions of Americans in this city and other cities and across parched countrysides have been waiting these past few days for the north wind bringing coolness. They have waited vainly, knowing that they dealt with a force no human power can yet control. Something like the same expectancy must be in a multitude of hearts and minds as they wait for news from Moscow and Berlin.

Dunninger, the "mentalist," and Paul Winchell, ventriloquist, and his dummy "Jerry Mahoney" will co-star in a new half hour television show scheduled to bow on Oct. 7 at 9:30 P.M. over WNBT and the NBC East Coast television network. The sponsor will be the Bigelow Sanford Carpet Company.

Seventeen busloads of Girl Scouts from all five boroughs surged into the sweltering city yesterday afternoon, returning after two weeks in the mountains. The returning scouts -- most of them in the 10 to 14 age group -represented the last contingent of summer campers.

VIENNA, Aug. 27 -- The Soviet delegation tried hard at today's meeting of the Allied Council to induce the Western powers to grant immediate approval of the formation of a new political party in the hope of weakening the People's party, majority political unit in Austria's coalition Government.

Wall Street's underwriting houses yesterday abandoned even the pretense of doing business as the heat wave stood by persistently to attend the summer's final pre-Labor Day gasps. In offices stripped of the top brass, secretaries and clerical assistants lounged at ease at arm's length from desks.
Rognvaldur Sigurjonsson, 29year-old Icelandic pianist who arrived from Reykjavik Thursday, was having difficulty practicing in the blistering weather here for his fall recital in Town Hall.

A drop of two degrees from Thursday's high temperature of 100.8 brought no appreciable relief to millions in the city yesterday as the mercury climbed steadily to a high of 98.8 degrees at 4:15 P.M. That was 7.8 degrees higher than the previous record of 91 degrees set for the day in 1900.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 -- The Dodgers moved once more into second place, two percentage points ahead of the Cardinals and within two games of the league-leading Braves, by nosing out the Reds, 3 -- 2, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Congressional committee set out today to define the radio rights of a person who wants to deny the existence of God.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 27 -Wolf, a two-and-one-half-year-old Dalmatian who served double duty as mascot of the Westbury Fire Department and watchdog of his owner's print shop up the block, has returned from a four-month sojourn on a New Jersey farm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Virgil (Fire) Trucks put the damper on two Washington late game rallies today and helped Detroit score a 3-2 victory over the Senators. Credit for the victory went to Bill Pierce, 21-year-old southpaw.
MOSCOW, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Academy of Sciences abolished a biological laboratory and "freed from their duties" two noted Soviet biologists by special decree today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dons made their one sustained drive pay off for a 7-0 victory over the "new" Chicago Rockets in an All-America conference opener before 26,479 fans at Soldier Field tonight.
HATFIELD, Hertfordshire, England, Aug. 27 -- The severest test a gas turbine engine has had ended here today in the De Havilland factory.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 27 -- Delegates to the National Student Association's convention here went on record today against participation by the organization in any "partisan political" or "sectarian religious" activity.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Interior Department reported today that it warned Governors of twelve states last April of disaster hazards in the coal mines of their states.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Reports alleging a rift between President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall over policies of this country in the Middle East, especially in Palestine, were flatly denied today by the Army and Navy Journal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Maj. Gen. Bryant E. Moore, chief of the Army's Public Information Division, received today a second Oak Leaf Cluster to his Distinguished Service Medal.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, said tonight that the Republicans brought on "the world's worst depression by thirteen years of open shop, wage-cutting, union-busting and economic do-nothing-ism."

OSTERVILLE, Mass., Aug. 27 -Charles Evans Hughes, eleventh Chief Justice of the United States, succumbed tonight to a heart ailment that gradually had taken his strength over the last several months. He was 86 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -Dr. James B. Fisk, research director of the Atomic Energy Commission, resigned today to accept a Harvard University faculty post held open for him for two years.

John A. Costello, Prime Minister of Ireland, declared here yesterday it was safe to assume his country "would be willing to enter into an agreement with the United States and Great Britain for strategic purposes to maintain peace," but said the ending of Irish partition was a prerequisite to such an agreement.

Selective gains peppered the stock market yesterday, and although interest failed to expand, a better type of buying prevailed. Dividend news continued to exert the top influence on individual issues on the Stock Exchange, while the heat wave again extracted a toll in trading volume.

SPARKILL, N.Y., Aug. 27 -Lawrence Brown, 22 years old, of Bergenfield, N.J., was released here today in $1,000 bail on a grand larceny charge accusing him of stealing $3,500 worth of orchid bulbs from his employer, Orchid Glen, a nursery at Tappan.

PRAGUE, Aug. 27 -- An official announcement was made today of the arrest of the Prior of the Dominican monastery at Znojmo, near the Moravian frontier with Austria, and of another priest and nine Catholic laymen on charges of having aided the escape of political refugees to Vienna.

The State of New York and the Federal Government will collect death taxes in an amount to be determined after the Surrogate's Court here surrenders the estate of $500,000 left by Mrs. Mabel Seymour Greer, attorneys in the case said yesterday.

Action of the Mexican Government in placing a 15 per cent tax on exports was seen here yesterday as putting a damper on shipments from that country that had been stimulated by the recent devaluation of the peso.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Senator W. Lee O'Daniel, Democrat, of Texas, said today in a farewell-to-Washington statement that one of the reasons behind his decision not to seek another term was that he "can see slight hope of saving our nation from going entirely socialistic or communistic."
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 27 -- The New Jersey House of Assembly moved today to impose a tax on consumer electric light bills as a means of financing a $100,000,000 bonus for New Jersey's 550,000 veterans.

DENVER, Aug. 27 (AP) --Mrs. D. C. Carson, chairman of a housewife movement to force meat prices down," quit today because she said that Wallace-for-president backers had taken control and turned meetings from discussion of meat to politics.
Random notes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that price-supporting loans on 1948-crop corn will be offered growers in all counties in twenty-three states.

The American Gas Association will augment its current $4,400,000 national advertising campaign, featuring automatic gas ranges, with a new merchandising program for all types of domestic gas ranges, the AGA's domestic range committee announced yesterday.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 27 (AP) -Former Gov. Coke Stevenson and Representative Lyndon Johnson traded final thrusts tonight in their duel for the vacated Senate seat of W. Lee (Pappy) O'Daniel.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Housing motor vehicles that were young when Southampton still was remembered as a one-time whaling town, the $100,000 Clark Automotive Museum was opened today for a preview. There were thirty-four models on display, with a 1902 curved-dash Oldsmobile and a Haynes Apperson surrey of the same year sharing patriarch honors.

BRESLAU, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Henry A. Wallace, a candidate for President of the United States, said today in a recorded speech broadcast at the World Congress of Intellectuals that mankind's existence was being threatened by rifts between the great powers.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- William Rickenbacker of Sleepy Hollow, son of the famous flyer, Eddie, retained possession of the Earl A. Ross trophy and the Westchester County junior golf championship that it symbolizes by defeating the Scarsdale club star, Robert Smith, 4 and 3, at the Apawamis Club today.

The special Federal grand jury that on July 20 indicted twelve top-ranking Communists on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government by force has been directed to reconvene Sept. 14 to hear additional evidence, it was announced yesterday.

A clash between workers returning to their jobs in the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation plant at 88-06 Van Wyck Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, and pickets from Local 1217, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, resulted in the arrest yesterday of seven men and three women.

With demand strong for finished rayon fabrics for fall dress re-orders, trade abuses absent from the market since the end of price control are again becoming prevalent, it was learned yesterday. Cutters charged that textile suppliers are diverting contract goods to spot purchasers willing to pay a premium in what was described as a revival of black market operations.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 27 -Twenty-one of the fastest speed boats the regatta world has ever known and constituting the largest entry fleet of the forty-four years of Gold Cup history are tonight stored and guarded in Detroit River berths, slips and boat wells awaiting tomorrow's running of America's ninety-mile classic.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Three aged and decrepit German field marshals and a colonel general whose protracted confinement as prisoners of war has recently aroused sympathy in Britain will be brought to trial as war criminals, the British War Office announced today.
The roster of officials who will direct the Welfare Department's new bureau of welfare administration was announced yesterday by Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 27 -Despite sizzling weather Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol played great golf to win the Women's New Jersey Association low gross honors with two over women's par 38, 40 -- 78 over the Forest Hill Field Club course today.

WARSAW, Aug. 27 -- Dr. Bryn J. Hovde, director of the New School for Social Research in New York, told the World Congress of Intellectuals in Breslau today that if the Communists believed what they had said about the United States, the American people must "unite in preparation for the worst."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- The Lebanese statecontrolled Beirut radio declared in a statement, monitored here today, that direct negotiations with Israel might bring a "reasonable solution" of the Palestine problem.

TORONTO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Earl Mountbatten of Burma officially opened the Canadian National Exhibition today. He paid high tribute to Canada's efforts as a member of the Commonwealth during war and peace.

Using strong August department and specialty store sales as a barometer, leading retailers in the metropolitan area are looking forward to a healthy increase in fall and winter sales, it was learned from a survey conducted here yesterday.

Refuting claims that Cuba was being used as a dumping ground for American textiles, Harold Bernstein, chairman of the export group of the Textile Distributors Institute, charged yesterday that Cuban textile manufacturers are seeking to impose a monopoly that would prove detrimental to the best interests of their country.

Charles Evans Hughes was one of America's great public servants. Indeed, he had a genius for service and dedicated his life to it. He never refused a call, never sought a reward and never failed at a task. Throughout his career, rooted in rugged character, he seemed like a tall tree that bore an unceasing abundance of fruitful achievement.

DUBLIN, Aug. 27 -- The United States Army team capped four days of superb jumping at this city's famous horse show today by winning the most coveted trophy, the Aga Khan Cup, in keen competition with teams from France, Sweden, England and Ireland.

ABOARD PRESS YACHT WANDERER, off Blakistone Island, Aug. 27 -- President Truman, like most citizens, was busy today trying to beat the heat, but unlike most of them enjoyed a measure of success in his air-cooled quarters aboard the yacht Williamsburg.

Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, called last night upon all peaceloving Americans to demand of President Truman that he extend immediately de jure recognition to the State of Israel, lift the arms embargo and lend the new state $100,000,000 for rehabilitation.

Maj. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, former head of the Manhattan Project that produced the atomic bomb, made his first visit yesterday to the Atomic Energy Exhibit at the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition and praised the high school students who are serving as guides.

The nation-wide grief occasioned by the passing of a great exponent of baseball prompts me to offer a thought which seems fitting at such a time. The general public knows little, indeed, about the origin of thc game of baseball, and it is safe to say that a very small percentage of the fans could, if called upon, give the name of its inventor.

Thomas J. Wertenbaker, author of "The Founding of American Civilization," has a new history coming from Scribners. It is "Father Knickerbocker's Rebels: New York City During the Revolution," which describes the city under British Military Government from September, 1776, to November, 1783.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 27 (AP) -Americans won ten events, including a surprising victory in the 1,500-meter run in a track and field meet tonight.

The "dismal failure" of the Police Department's plan to relieve congestion in the midtown garment area of Manhattan, as reported in a survey in our news columns yesterday, is disappointing. Commissioner Wallander worked hard on this plan, which involved staggered pick-ups and deliveries, and a spreading of truck activity into early morning and early evening.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Senator Albert W. Hawkes, Republican, of New Jersey, announced today the appointment of one New Jersey youth to West Point and three to Annapolis.

DURHAM, N.C., Aug. 27 (AP) -Reservations for Henry Wallace and his party for an overnight stop on Sunday at the Washington Duke Hotel here have been cancelled, Mary Price, North Carolina chairman for the Progressive party, said today.

Walter Wanger has taken an option on the screen rights to "Tomorrow We Reap," fourth in a series of novels by James Street dealing with the fictional Dabney family of Mississippi. The book will be published next year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -Negotiations between waterfront employers and CIO longshoremen will be resumed at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow, looking to an agreement in the West Coast maritime dispute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Department of Commerce reported today that newsprint consumption the first half of this year totaled 2,559,000 tons. This was an increase of 11.6 per cent over the corresponding period in 1947.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 27 -- The Relief Commission or the Red Cross' world meeting, now in its last stages here, passed a resolution today urging all governments and Red Cross, Red Crescent, Red Lion and Sun Societies to "do their utmost through normal channels to alleviate the suffering victims of hostilities [in Palestine] irrespective of race, creed or political status."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Patents were issued this week on 525 new inventions, a post-war "high" outnumbering by thirty-six last week's total, and including for the first time in years awards to the nationals of nine countries other than our own.

A burnt-out cable in a Consolidated Edison Company generating plant started a chain of events yesterday afternoon that for two hours wiped out electric power in the Lower Manhattan area from Fourteenth Street to Walker Street and from river to river.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Army announced today the retirement of Brig. Gen. Harold A. Nisley, Ordnance Officer for the Army Field Forces, after thirtyfive years of service.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Ted (The Kid) Williams and Dom (The Little Professor) DiMaggio shared the spotlight today as the Boston Red Sox downed the Chicago White Sox, 10 -- 5, before Fenway Park's smallest-paid crowd of the season, 6,285, which was increased by 3,840 youngsters, guests of the management.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Tourist List, owned by Lowry Watkins of Louisville and ridden by Franklin Hutcherson, an ex-Navy gent from Orange, Va., won the two-and-a-half-mile Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap today. As has become the custom in this theatre of turf operations, there was a claim of foul.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 27 -- Sitting at Maseru, capital of the British Protectorate of Basutoland, a High Court of Justice has sentenced to death a woman chieftain, Namakhabane, and twelve of her tribesmen for ritual murder. They killed an adult tribesman to "make medicine" from human flesh.

The threat of a strike at midnight Tuesday that would have dealt the city's economy a crippling blow was virtually ended yesterday as the result of an agreement reached by three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and five employer associations.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- The Communistled demonstrations in Berlin today against the city government and Western currency were regarded in diplomatic quarters here as designed to influence the Moscow negotiations on the Berlin situation.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 27 (AP) -- A pocket-sized but severe hurricane lashing the Atlantic with 115-mile winds slowed its forward pace tonight and its future movement became uncertain.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange failed yesterday to develop a definite trend, and closing prices were 6 to 14 points net lower.

Retail trade here this week showed a large decrease due to three days of extreme heat and humidity. Department store sales were estimated to be about 15 percent under the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 1 per cent.

SUILAI, Sinkiang, China, Aug. 20 -- The boundary between Chinesecontrolled Sinkiang and the autonomous "East Turkestan Republic" is less than five miles west of Suilai, Chinese brigade headquarters. The Manas River separates Chinese and Turki sentries, guarding 'outposts less than 200 yards apart.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Houston's 17-year-old Don Addington routed Johnny Barrett of San Antonio, 9 and 8, today to win the third annual national caddy golf championship.

In his reply of Aug. 20 to the letter of Marie Duff, who protested against the "barring" of the representative of the Arab Higher Committee from the discussions of the Security Council, because he had "walked out of his own accord," Benjamin Azkin is right in stating that Mr. Husseini is not barred at all, but free to resume his seat at the Council's table each time the Council deals with Palestine.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- A hesitant suggestion that the United States should assume the trusteeship over Tripolitania was put forward today by The Economist, London Liberal weekly.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Relief Pitcher Kirby Higbe hit a home run in the last of the ninth tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4 to 3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The blow came with one away and the score tied.
The fact that Alger Hiss declined to submit to the lie-detection test cannot at present be construed as an attempt to dodge the device the application of which would otherwise clear the issue.

THE red-hot American League pennant race moved into the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the Yankees and Indians clashed in a vitally important series. It was a fitting spot for it, too. The Stadium was a trifle on the warm side itself. Despite that obvious fact, however, a goodly number of our villagers were at hand.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs continued to wreck the first-place lead of the Boston Braves when they took their third straight victory from the league-leaders, 1 to 0, today before a ladies' day turnout of 19,967.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The United States Davis Cup four-man team, with half of it ousting Colin Long and Geoff Brown, the Australian international tandem, reached the final round of the men's national doubles tennis tournament in today's heat at Longwood.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The country's railroads today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to increase line haul freight rates on coal, coke and iron ore.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -Bill McCahan scattered seven hits and Hank Majeski banged out three doubles as the Philadelphia Athletics defeated the St. Louis Browns, 9 -- 1, in the second game of a twi-night double-header tonight after taking the opener, 6 -- 0, behind the three-hit pitching of Dick Fowler.
George Jung has been appointedh)0*0*0*iassistant in the general merchandise office of Interstate Department Stores, Inc. He formerly was manager of the domestic division of the Davenport store.

SOUTH KORTRIGHT, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Mrs. Elizabeth A. Major, director of the music center of the International Valley Foundation here, was killed and four other persons injured, one critically, today when a car she was driving left the road near here and struck a tree.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The amazing Citation, 3-year-old champion of 1948, returns to major racing competition tomorrow as favorite to win the $90,750 American Derby at Washington Park.
CHELTENHAM, England, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A four-nation committee was formed today to promote birth control on an international scale.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Two accidents on lakes north of this community sent three people to hospitals today. The victim of one of the accidents is reported to have but little chance for survival.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Two more legation officials of Soviet satellite countries -- one a Hungarian and one a Rumanian -- have joined the colony of those who do not want to return home, it was disclosed today.
Henry Cotton, British open golf champion, arrived from England yesterday for a seven-week stay during which he expects to play a number of exhibition matches.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 27 -- The status of women in the Christian church, particularly their right to full ordination in the Protestant ministry, may become one of the most controversial subjects confronting the first Assembly of the World Council of Churches here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -National Pictures, Inc., formed last May with Lester Cutler as its head, today announced that Laraine Day would play the top feminine role in "House of Cards," a mystery-comedy which the company has now put on the schedule as its first picture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Government officials today disclosed Britain and the United States are seeking agreement on a price to be paid for steel scrap imports from Germany. These officials said the United States believes $26 a ton is enough.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 27 (AP) -The six-man British team today won the International Wakefield Trophy in model airplane competition at Akron airport, defeating entries from five other countries.

MADRID, Aug. 27 -- Official confirmation of a meeting Wednesday of Don Juan, pretender to the Spanish throne, and Generalissimo Francisco Franco aboard the latter's yacht was given tonight by a Foreign Office spokesman here. He announced also that Don Juan had agreed that his son, Juan Carlos, Prince of Asturias, would be educated in Spain.

With the appointment of the fifteen temporary trustees to manage a publicly developed university in this state, Governor Dewey has again moved to expand our higher educational facilities. We are confident that under the able chairmanship of Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, the newly created State University will get off to a good start.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Indiana Michigan Electric Company, South Bend, Ind., received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $25,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due in 1978, at competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) - The Civil Aeronautics Board today authorized the Colonial Airlines to serve Allentown-Bethlehem, Pa., on its route between Scranton and Reading, Pa. This was one of several steps taken in revising the Middle Atlantic route case decision issued six months ago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor agreed today to join the AFL longshoremen in petitioning the Supreme Court for a rehearing of the so-called "overtime-on-overtime" pay case.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Grain markets closed easy on the Board of Trade today after a firm start. Wheat closed 1/2 cent a bushel lower to 1/2 cent higher, the former on September. Corn was off 3/4 to 2 5/8 cents and oats lost 3/8 to 3/4 cent.

Plans for improving the sixstory loft building on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 40 Wooster Street were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by Hale-Nass, Inc., manufacturers of metal products, from A. and M. Billet through the Murrimac Reaty Company, broker. The new owner will occupy the entire structure.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Leaders of a group that allegedly operated a cut-rate market in railroad tickets were seized here today in a raid on a concession in the Berkley-Carteret Hotel.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 27 -- Forty-three persons were sentenced to death today by a high court in Zagreb, Croatia, on charges of war crimes, espionage, terrorism and sabotage with the aim of overthrowing the present regime in Yugoslavia.
Renomination of Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien by both major parties seemed assured yesterday.
The broiling American League pennant race, keeping pace with New York's heat wave, saw no faltering in the ranks yesterday so far as the Yankees and Indians were concerned.

A prospect for the Broadway stage this season is an untitled musical play by Patsy Ruth Miller, who, after many years of renown as a silent screen performer, emerged as a short-story writer and dramatist. Represented last season by "Music in My Heart," for which she wrote the book, Miss Miller said yesterday that her latest work is about a ghost town located on the border line between Colorado and Nevada.

Last July three minor State Department officials, Messrs. Alexander, Harlow and Larkin, made serious charges against the United Nations Secretariat in testimony before a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary. These charges were that "several hundred subversive foreign agents have used the United Nations as a cover for their activities in this country."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Department of Commerce's lumber survey committee reported today that lumber is "currently flowing into markets in ample quantity to supply the recordbreaking volume of construction activity."

The latest stemware patterns from outstanding glass factories in Europe now being shown here point up the current trend toward graceful modern shapes devoid of cut or engraved decoration. Several collections also offer stemware and decorative pieces in new light tints.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -Irving McCann, counsel for a twoman Congressional subcommittee which has been conducting hearings here this week, said today that the hearings disclosed clear violations of the Taft-Hartley Act in the entertainment field.

Charles P. Taft, president of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, has announced an appeal to the Protestant churches of the United States for prayers of thankfulness on Sunday, Sept. 5, for help given to the spread of the Christian faith by Queen Wilhelmma and the people of the Netherlands.
