Is it not time for action when all around one sees and hears of chiselers taking five and six month vacations -year after year -- at the expense of their fellow citizens by drawing unemployment insurance? They say, "I'm only taking what is coming to me." They actually believe that they have paid for it; that it is theirs to draw whenever they choose; that it is smart to take advantage of one's insurance.

TOKYO, Aug. 27 -- The Tokyo District Court today acquitted Suehiro Nishio, socialist leader and former Minister Without Portfolio, of charges of perjury and misappropriation of 500,000 yen in party funds.

Maritime disputes involving three sea-going unions and threatening strike action in Atlantic ports next week appear to be settled, with waterfront peace assured until November, it was reported last night.
Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., were active and firm yesterday on trade covering in the near-by delivery positions and Brazilian buying in the more distant months.
The Board of Transportation sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday a contract for structural changes in the Queens Plaza subway station in Long Island City designed to improve rapid transit service.
Jacob M. Lomakin, officially stripped of his credentials as Soviet Consul General in New York, is expected to sail for home at noon today aboard the Swedish-American liner Stockholm.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov and his deputy, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, met with three Western envoys for almost three hours tonight in another of the series of conferences aimed at ending the Berlin impasse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission said today it was going right ahead with its proposal to outlaw radio programs whose principal appeal was through giving away big prizes.

Operations of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, in the quarter ended with last June, resulted in a net profit of $4,305,132 after all charges and including income from investments and dividend received from foreign companies, the report disclosed yesterday.

The City Planning Commission completed yesterday at the Municipal Building a series of hearings on the 1949 capital budget and the 1950-54 capital program. Three city departments submitted requests to the commission headed by Robert F. Wagner Jr.

At a time when there is a great shortage of facilities for taking care of the sick, the opening of the new 100bed, $750,000 building of the Brooklyn Jewish Home for Convalescents at Far Rockaway is welcome news. No one who can afford to pay can enter. All rooms are free to patients from any of the boroughs of New York on recommendations from physicians, hospitals and social agencies.

Two women, one 95 years old, and seven firemen were overcome by fumes last night in a small but smoky fire in a five-story reconverted brownstone studio apartment building at 24 West Tenth Street, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas.

LEE, Mass., Aug. 27 -- Ted Shawn, director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and its associated school near here, gave the premier this afternoon of his first new dance composition in four years. "Minuet for Drums."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The Government today accused Hungary's leaders of plotting to overthrow Premier Marshal Tito in an effort to seize control of Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Power Commission said today it would open a hearing in Washington Oct. 4 on an application for approval of a joint New York-Ontario power project on the St. Lawrence River.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Aug. 27 -Godfearing Americans must mobilize to save the United States from being destroyed by the forces of secularization, the Rev. Clifford J. King of Techny, Ill. told the Catholic Students Mission Crusade Conference at its second meeting today at Notre Dame.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Despite a small amount of profit-taking, the stock markets here today finished the week on a cheerful note.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret of Ojal, Calif., bagged six birdies and a 66 on the sloping Fort Douglas course today to barge into the lead of the $12,500 Utah Open golf tournament.

Directors of North American Aviation, Inc., yesterday resumed the payment of dividends on its stock with the declaration of 50h)0*0*0*icents a share payable on Sept. 29 to holders of record of Sept. 13. This is the first declaration since $1 a share was distributed in September, 1946.

GENEVA, Aug. 27 -- Russia was bluntly accused by the United States of trying to sabotage international conventions on the freedom of information in today's closing discussion on this issue in the Economic Social Council.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The United States Attorney for the District of Columbia received a complete transcript of the HissChambers case from the House Committee on Un-American Activities today and began a study to determine whether Alger Hiss or Whittaker Chambers should be tried for perjury.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 -- Rain tonight frustrated plans to play the third game of the Giants-Cardinals series at Sportsman's Park, where a crowd of about 15,000 had assembled to see if Eddie Dyer's squad could make it three in a row over Leo Durocher's band.

The major part of $20,000,000 out of a total of $23,210,000 for current plant construction projects will be spent here on steel mill equipment for India, officials of Tata, Inc., Indian industrial interests, disclosed here yesterday at the company offices, 90 Broad Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The earnest plea of Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator, for aid for 330,000 Arab and 7,000 Jewish refugees from the fighting in Palestine, has received a hearty response from agencies in the United States, it was shown today.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27 -President Juan D. Peron's economic director, Miguel Miranda, is now willing to use all the dollars acquired by selling certain surplus for paying off obligations in the United States, it was learned here today.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -The Australians beat England's best cricket amateurs, labeled Gentlemen of England, at Lords today by an innings and 81 runs.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- In a detailed breakdown of export accomplishments by British industry last month the Board of Trade today revealed that some industries already were exporting at a monthly rate in excess of targets set for the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -The Department of Commerce today estimated manufacturers' sales in July at $16,000,000,000. This is a drop of 10 per cent below June both in total value and in daily average rate of sales.

Football, unseasonable because of the date, unreasonable because of the competition and unbearable because of the heat, made its 1948 bow last night at Ebbets Field. The occasion was the official opening of the All-America Conference and the New York Yankees, launching the defense of their Eastern Division title, walloped the reorganized Brooklyn Dodgers, 21 -- 3.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Failing to do better than draw his adjourned fifteenth-round game with Franklin Howard of East Orange, Isaac I. Kashdan of New York nevertheless increased his score at the top to 13 -- 3 by winning today from Norman T. Whitaker of Shady Side, Md., in the tournament for the United States chess championship. Correct defensive tactics on the part of Howard yielded him a draw after fifty-six moves.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 27 -"Don't you Americans ever walk?" was the first reaction of Miss Mary V. Alexander, exchange teacher from England, to American customs as she finished a stroll today on a Westchester parkway.

Charles Evans Hughes was 54 years old when he was defeated for the Presidency of the United States in 1916 and might well have retired from public life, assured of a respected niche in American history. Instead, during the next troubled quarter-century, he responded to call after call for further distinguished service that established him as one of the great Americans of his time.

NEWARK, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Lefty Mal Mallette pitched Newark to a 5-2 two-hit triumph over Buffalo in the first game of a double-header tonight, but the Bisons came back and trounced the Bears 14 -- 2, in the nightcap to end a nine-game losing streak.

The American Export Lines, which plans to offer a de luxe passenger service to the Mediterranean in four reconverted liners soon to be completed, has initiated a training program for all catering personnel, it became known yesterday.

THE innocent young bystander who edited "The Pleasures of the Jazz Age"* -- one Master William Hodapp -- was all of 8 years old when that frequently and profitably lamented froth on the enigmatic surface of the Nineteen Twenties began to bubble. In rebuttal he might point out that Mr. Gibbon had not even been planned when Ancient Rome commenced to wear and tear.
Indianapolis, Ind., announced yesterday that it will receive bids Sept. 5 on $3,500,000 of gas utility revenue bonds dated Oct. 1, 1948, and due on June 1 from 1950 to 1969.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Pennsylvania truck gardener, 49-year-old John W. Schenk of Sharpsburg, jumped from nowhere today to win the Grand American Handicap, trapshooting's No. 1 prize, from the second largest field in history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Strong sympathy for the French plan to create a Parliament of the Western European Nations, with advisory powers, is felt by the United States Government, the State Department announced today.

The former de Rham estate Garrison-on-the-Hudson, Westche.i'ter County. has been purchasecl b Robert Jahn through Ruland ,i Benjamin, Inc.,' broker in -th' transaction. It consists of appro:I imately 400 acres, a main hous{ two tenant's houses and sever outbuildings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -American Airlines will force a showdown on extra-fare air travel by refusing to raise any rates above 6 cents a mile.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Alaska is experiencing its poorest salmon fishing season in history, Director Albert M. Day of the Fish and Wildlife Service said today.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The national draft director took to the air tonight to explain details of selective service which, he said, is being ordered "to avoid a war."

Memphis will be the site of real struggle next week -- struggle that the political machine of Boss Crump will be unable to influence. The cotton town plays host to the prize "plum" of simon-pure golfdom -- the National Amateur Championship. This is the first time that the Amateur has been held in the South, and our neighbors from below the Mason-Dixon Line are out to prove the old adage concerning their hospitality.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 27 -The veterans who fought in the China-Burma-India theatre in World War II opened their first national reunion here tonight.

The hunt for Henry M. Brooks, once wealthy stock promoter, for the slaying of Joseph R. Watkins, a pressing creditor and business associate, ended yesterday in the Albion Hotel at Asbury Park, N.J. He was found there with a bullet through his right temple. "Death by suicide," the county medical examiner said.

PARIS, Saturday, Aug. 28 -Hopelessly split over the application of the proposed Reynaud financial and economic reforms, the painfully constituted coalition Cabinet of Premier Andre Marie resigned early today.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 27 -The Republic Steel Corporation won a thumping, although still temporary, victory tonight in its struggle with the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation over control of the Government-owned blast furnace here.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Elmer Trueman's Send Off-entered the winners' circle for the first time in ten starts today when he beat six rivals in the six-furlong Freeholders Purse.
Your editorial "Queens Hospitals," in your issue of Aug. 20, comes as a surprise for which the people of Queens will be most grateful.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 27 -- Complaints were made last year by local patriots that the Scottish contribution to the arts and especially Scottish music, was inadequately represented in the Edinburgh Festival programs.

The Surface Transportation Corporation, bus operating affiliate of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, completed yesterday the presentation of its case for a temporary fare of seven cents on its forty-nine Manhattan and Bronx routes.
Railroad accidents killed 4,285 persons last year, according to statistics compiled by the Association of American Railroads and announced yesterday.

The old U.S.S. Mississippi -now an experimental gunnery vessel -- renamed the EAG 128 -rode anchor in the North River at Forty-eighth Street yesterday. Under an oppressive sun that baked the decks and steel armour, 1,500 persons went aboard to view the "Mighty Miss" that had survived everything the Japanese had hurled at her in the Pacific.
This piece is inspired by admiration, reluctant but none the less positive, for a great general, perhaps the greatest of all generals: the weather.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Although rumors of actual Arab-Israeli peace negotiations cannot be confirmed, in the best informed political circles in London speculation continues about preparations for such talks and the willingness of certain Arab leaders to participate in them.
A nationwide architectural competition, sponsored by The Museum of Modern Art and the Architectural Record to discover and encourage, latent talent, was announced yesterday by the museum.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- During the 1916 campaign for the Presidency, the famous editor of the Courier-Journal, Henry Watterson, was a strong supporter of Woodrow Wilson whom he had opposed for the nomination in 1912.

ATHENS, Aug. 27 -- Attacks by the Communist-led rebels on civilian centers, attacks such as a military spokesman said might be expected to continue while the National Army consolidated its Grammos victory, were reported in the past twenty-four hours in several parts of Greece.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- Anti-Communist political leaders of Berlin placed the responsibility for further meetings of the City Assembly and the continuation of its freely elected parliamentary government squarely upon the Russians tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 -- A delegation representing the Argentine League for the Rights of Man and the Uruguayan Educators Union has returned from a visit to Asuncion, where the new Paraguayan Government made it plain that it wished no questions asked by foreigners about political prisoners.
A 9-year-old boy received the rare opportunity of directing his mother's actions in an opera last night, before a sizable number of onlookers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The net income after taxes of all United States manufacturing corporations in the first quarter of this year amounted to $2,900,000,000, according to a joint report issued today by the Federal Trade Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Dr. J. Roswell Gallagher, physician of Phillips Andover Academy, has been keeping a record of swimming-pool attendance for seven years to determine the incidence of infections of the respiratory tract and communicable diseases among swimmers. The results are presented in The New England Journal of Medicine.

THIS is a very pleasant and readable book, a sort of "Garretson Chronicle" taken from real life, every bit as interesting in its way as its imaginative counterpart. It is the story of an archaeologist who quit the academic field for artisan pursuits.

IF you had to designate the corporeal center of the amorphous community of Hollywood you probably couldn't come much closer than the corner of Western and Melrose Avenues, site of the Western Costume Company.

A GOOD lawn for play purposes is not impossible when it is prepared from the ground up, rather than the surface down. It serves as a haven for the family, free of dust and mud, and is as functional as a recreation room with all the advantages of the big outdoors.

PHIL RIZZUTO is about as big as a minute and, to all intents and purposes, is a little boy playing a man's game. Small in size but huge in popularity, this likable and effervescent brat is having a day set apart for him. His legions of friends -- he has no enemies -- will gather at home plate in the Yankee Stadium this afternoon to shower praises on him.

ROME, Aug. 28 -- Achille Marazza, Under-Secretary of the Interior, this evening assured Harry H. Ness and Frary von Blomberg, representatives of the Federal Council of Churches, and other Protestant religious organizations in the United States, that the Italian Government intends to guarantee the freedom of worship in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Selective Service headquarters, anxious to dispel confusion, misunderstanding or just plain ignorance, issued today its final reminder of the new draft registration that begins on Monday.

FROM the time we brush our teeth in the morning until we wash the last dish at night we do a hundred household chores that can be abolished -- if we will stop indulging in outmoded habits and prejudices. Like swimming in hoopskirts, most of our present housekeeping methods would be better off in a Mack Sennett comedy than in a home of today.

Members of the national executive council of the United States first intercultural Greek-letter fraternity, Beta Sigma Tau, are meeting in Chicago Aug. 30 and 31. Beta Sigma Tau, whose constitution bars discrimination as to race, nationality and religion, was founded by the efforts of local intercultural fraternities at eleven colleges.

BRITISH pessimists, before the Olympic Games opened, wisecracked that the only thing Great Britain was likely to win was the gratitude of foreign competitors for organizing the affair so competently in difficult circumstances.

PRAGUE, Aug. 28 -- Discovery of another treason and espionage plot was announced by the police today following the disclosure yesterday of the arrest of a Dominican prior and other priests and Catholic laymen on charges of plotting against the security of the state.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Citation, the horse of the year, with Jockey Eddie Arcaro astride, rambled to a length victory in the $88,750 American Derby at Washington Park today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that "we are going to leave the Treasury in better shape than it was when we took it over." He made this prediction at a press conference called to discuss the 159th anniversary of the founding of the Treasury Department, which will be, observed next Thursday.

"KIEVAN RUSSIA," second volume of a monumental series on Russian history, is a welcome contribution to the literature in English on the subject. It aims at an evaluation of a land and a time too long left in obscurity.

ALTHOUGH Professor Lipson's primary subject is the evolution of government in New Zealand in its political, constitutional and administrative aspects, he has, by keeping large issues of social policy steadily in mind, also written a critical study of democratic socialism (or democracy socialistically inclined) which has almost universal reference.

HOLLY HOTEL, that quiet Scottish inn where apparently anything can happen, is again the scene of a great to-do. Molly Maitland, young daughter of the house, temporarily in charge of affairs, waits anxiously for a missing guest.

PANAMA CITY -- Central America is in the throes of a tourist buying spree that has American summer visitors taking home everything that isn't nailed down. There are two good reasons for the shopping boom: (1) the American dollar now buys more native money than it used to; (2) the change in customs which permits tourists to bring home $400 of purchases without paying duty on them.

IT'S one of the hoarier legends of travel lore that the customs inspector -- in whatever part of the world you find him -- can instinctively spot a tourist burdened with a guilty conscience. I wouldn't know. Having bared my soul at customs counters twenty-four times in the last fourteen months, I'm beginning to wonder if it's true at all.

Maj. Gen. Robert N. Webster, Commanding General of the First Air Force, took a helicopter yesterday from his headquarters at Fort Slocum, New Rochelle, N.Y., to Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, so that he would be on time to share a review. He made it -- with a few minutes to spare.

National Dog Week will be observed this year, Sept. 19 to 25, and sponsors of this movement are making an all-out effort to make the forthcoming observance -- the twenty-first consecutive one -- the most successful.

SEPTEMBER and October offer naturally favorable growing conditions for grass in all sections of the country. Those who must make a new lawn would be wise to plant during this ideal season. New home builders, who may have planned to postpone outside projects until next spring, will be well repaid for undertaking their lawn in the fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- An official of the War Assets Administration and Representative George H. Bender of Ohio today voiced satisfaction with yesterday's agreemeent between the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation to keep the Government's big blast furnace in Cleveland running until May 1 next.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The magazine "Factory" reported today that a survey covering 1,400,000 workers showed productivity up 4.4 per cent in the year ended Aug. 2.

Five firemen and six policemen were injured, some seriously, at 11:25 o'clock last night when a speeding hook and ladder truck and a police emergency wagon collided in Watkins Street near Liberty Avenue in the Brownsville district of Brooklyn.

"THERE is room for everybody in America!" declared Crevecoeur in 1782. This seemed literally true, for an endless stream of the dispossessed and the discontented, swarming out of Hogarth's prints and the pages of Ned Ward's picaresque reporting, had for almost two centuries been hazarding the formidable Atlantic crossing.

A DESCENT on the full-blown art colony is guaranteed to relieve any extreme solicitations about the artist's bad lot or misgivings about his powers to survive fairly trying circumstances. In Provincetown, at any rate, we can attest that a remorselessly vivid background of "tourism," strenuous enough to put the most eruptive metropolitan interlude to shame, seems to have left painting happily intact.

BELGRADE, Aug. 28 -- The purge of pro-Cominform, and therefore by definition of pro-Soviet, elements in the Yugoslav Communist party is being carried out thoroughly and relentlessly. Officially the purge involves those party members who have refused, or are suspected of refusing, to adhere to the party program laid down by the Fifth Congress of the Yugoslav Communist party during the latter part of July.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- United States endorsement of proposals to convene a representative European assembly was received today with surprise and gratification by British advocates of European unity. The State Department's announcement was front-page news in London papers.
IN Volume IX, between the summer of 1943 and January of 1945, Lanny Budd, as he has managed for thirty years, gets around.

The three new round-the-world passenger-cargo liners that are soon to be laid down in a Camden, N.J., shipyard for the American President Lines will be modern, streamlined vessels, with a superstructure design as yet unknown in the New York service, it was learned yesterday.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 28 -- Communism is at the same time both better and worse than fascism and nazism, Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr of Union Theological Seminary, New York, said here today.
NORWICH, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- "Tom Dewey is the one man who can clean up Washington and clean up this country," Senator Irving M. Ives said tonight at a rally of the Chenango County Republican Committee.

NORTH WEYMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 28 (UP) -- Twelve persons, including two children, were critically burned today when a gasoline tank exploded and set fire to a 34-foot cabin cruiser at the Wessagusset Yacht Club.

The action of the State Department in denying a passport to the "Red" Dean of Canterbury takes us back to 1790 and the attempt made at that time by Hamilton and the Federalists to keep out "foreign" ideas by keeping out foreigners under the Alien and Sedition Acts. More and more we find our Government swinging to Hamiltonian principles, which are at opposite poles to the democratic principles we profess.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Aug. 28 -- Tens of thousands of vocations are needed for Catholic mission work in all parts of the world, Archbishop John T. McNicholas of Cincinnati said in a message read here tonight at a general meeting of the thirteenth national conference of the Catholic Students Mission Crusade at the University of Notre Dame.

Gross state debt, averaged among the forty-eight states, showed an increase in the 1947 fiscal year, after dropping in the preceding five years, the Tax Foundation, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, reported yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 28 -- Utah's Progressive party is holding its state-wide convention this week-end -- in a court room. The nominating sessions are thus being held as required by law, but in a setting quite rare in political history.

AS I write, three serious novels are in the forefront of critical attention. Two of them, Norman Mailer's "The Naked and the Dead," and Graham Greene's "The Heart of the Matter," appear on the best-seller lists; by the time these words are in print, they will probably have been joined by Albert Camus' "The Plague."

It is always popular to ridicule the highbrows, and so George Soule's blast against the forecasters ("Boom Days for the Economic Prophets") will be read with wide approval. However, I wish to add my humble comment which is drawn from thirty years' experience in the investment business.
TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- Democracy is beginning to work in Korea, Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, homeward bound, said in a press conference today.

CHICAGO -- The emphasis was on new cameras and equipment for the amateur at the fifty-seventh annual convention of the Photographers' Association of America here last week, even though the PAA is a professional group.

Although the heat wave sharply cut retail activity here last week, retailers reordered merchandise in quantity compared to small initial orders, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Coats, school wear and main floor merchandise, the report indicated, were leading reorders.

Encouraging statistics on the improvement in the railroad accident picture have been made available by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Association of American Railroads to the American Museum of Safety here in New York. They show that fewer persons lost their lives in railroad accidents in 1947 than in any of the forty-nine preceding years covered by the records of the Commission.

With the departure last Friday for Rio de Janeiro of United States members of the Joint Brazil-United States Technical Commission, economic relations between the two countries may be entering upon a closer and more vigorous phase.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Much to the surprise of nearly everyone concerned, the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association was able to hold its regular regatta on schedule today. This, despite a veritable calm that existed as a fleet of 107 craft turned out for the competition.

P.J. PRETORIUS came of pioneer Boer stock -- Pretoria was named for one of his forebears -- and spent his entire life (1877-1945) as an African hunter. During World War I (he served as Smuts' chief of scouts and was twice decorated) he hunted the shrewder and somewhat more dangerous game which had taken the place of elephant, lion and hippo.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- The Communists demanded tonight that a twenty-one member "Special Committee" take over functions of the city assembly and the administration of Berlin as the city moved perilously close to complete divison between the East and the West.
TULARE, Calif., Aug. 28 -- Tulare's Olympic pride, 17-year-old Bob Mathias, arrived home to a tumultuous welcome today and soundly kissed his 16-year-old sweetheart.

"POWER GOLF," by Ben Hogan, is one of the most complete instruction books on golf that has ever been written. Moreover, no golfer has striven so hard for perfection as this young man from Texas, who started playing left-handed, shifted to right cross-handed, and tried right-handed interlocking and overlapping before inventing his own version of overlapping.

A SERIES of three models of the Kodak Tourist Camera, patterned after the original f/4.5 model, is announced by the Eastman Kodak Company. They are the Kodak Tourist f/6.3, the f/8.8 and the Kodet lens model. The cameras differ only in lens and shutter equipment.

TODAY, when high food prices make the front page, housewives in New York City can procure a quart of milk for only 7 cents. A product termed by an act of Congress as non-fat dry milk solids makes possible this unbelievably low cost.
A FALSE sense of satisfaction may be the result of viewing the lawn from a distance at this time of year. In localities where rain has been plentiful, the poorest lawn will be lush and green.

The alleged secret head of the Communist espionage network in the United States, identified as J.V. Peters, a resident of Queens for the last fifteen years, is to appear at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow at the New York Immigration headquarters, 70 Columbus Avenue, at a deportation hearing.

HERE is a convincing tribute to an outstanding teacher of the Christian faith whose students at Oberlin College and elsewhere, in their reverence for the man and his intellect, were proud to be called his disciples. Avoiding mere panegyric, Mr. Pye presents what Bosworth was and what he had to say -- a well-rounded life expressed in well-rounded language that leaves nothing uncertain yet jumps at no conclusions.
Ever since Drs. G.R. Minot and W.P. Murphy announced in 1926 that pernicious anemia responds to treatment with liver, the question has been asked: What is it in liver that has this effect?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- No one doubts now that the Republicans are going to use the Communists-in-Government issue for all it is worth in the campaign just getting under way. They are going to charge that despite a program that is costing $11,000,000 this first year, there are still disloyal people, meaning Communists or Communist sympathizers, on the Federal payroll.

BY conservative estimates there are some 6,000,000 pianos in serviceable condition in the United States today and only about 3,000 men professionally qualified to keep them in tune. Apartment house dwellers with musical neighbors may have been dimly though uncomfortably aware that there is an acute shortage of piano tuners, but Earle M. Turner, instructor in piano crafts at the New York Trade School, has the facts to verify their suspicions.

Rearmament orders, promised last spring, have started to move and will increase in volume during the fourth quarter. One-seventh of the $14,000,000,000 total has been placed in aircraft orders. These are to be expanded more than this amount within the next six months.

IN this introduction to science for older boys Mr. Crouse explains the operation of steam engines, gas engines, radios, cameras, jet planes, etc., but his explanations are often in terms of molecules, atoms, electrons, protons and neutrons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The rooted strength of the two-party system in the United States has never been made more manifest than by developments since the Democratic National Convention last month which have already had these effects:

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 28 -- Sixty-five delegates accompanied by at least 300 aides and representing eleven states of non-Soviet Germany will meet in the university city of Bonn next week to write a provisional constitution for the Western German regime authorized by the Western powers.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Phillies snapped a ten-game losing streak with a vengeance today, smashing out eight home runs to win both ends of a twin bill from the Pirates, 9 to 2 and 11 to 7.

THE nation's greatest peacetime arms program, recently approved by Congress, places a heavy burden in this summer of crisis on the shoulders of James Vincent Forrestal, philosopher at heart, pragmatist by conviction, Cabinet officer by circumstance.

WARSAW, Aug. 28 -- Seven members of the United States delegation and four Britons voted against a resolution adopted at the concluding session of the World Congress of Intellectuals in Breslau tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- William White, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, today was named to advise the Economic Cooperation Administration on the rehabilitation of European rail transportation.

MILTON GROSS has written about the Yankees so often that he is generally regarded as their all-but-official biographer: in "Yankee Doodles" are collected some of the better magazine pieces that won him this title. Notable among them is "A Crisis Kid," which is concerned with Joe Page's narrow escape from oblivion.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- When a British housewife goes shopping these days, she can usually find something to buy -- that is, if she has the money. Allocations and rationing have been somewhat relaxed; but Mrs. John Bull looks at price tags and quality more closely than she used to do.

Borough President Cornelius A. Hall of Richmond and Staten Island civic organizations announced yesterday that they would strenuously oppose service cuts by the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.

An unusual angle has crept into the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation into the part played by Otis Co., Cleveland banking house, in the Kaiser-Frazer stock debacle. Running parallel to the initial probe by the SEC into the withdrawal of the underwriters from the Kaiser-Frazer stock deal was one conducted by the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., commonly known as the NASD, which polices the financial industry.

JUST ten years ago this week in this review: Margaret Halsey's "With Malice Toward Some," a jubilant catalogue of Britons being sui generis to a fault, was being called "the only book written this year about Europe that will make you laugh." . . .

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The Caroline Mars -- largest flying boat in regular service anywhere in the world -- touched her keel to the waters of Chicago Harbor at 1:22 P.M. (EDT) today, exactly 24 hours and 9 minutes after leaving Honolulu.

WATERVILLE, Me., Aug. 28 -Reginald H. Sturtevant, 49 years old, Livermore Falls banker, has accepted the chairmanship of the $1,750,000 Mayflower Hill Development Fund of Colby College, Dr. Julius Seelye Bixler, Colby president, announced this week. The successful completion of the 1VIayflower Hill campaign will allow the college to erect new buildings.

FOR better or for worse, from its first playhouse, in 1786, Pittsburgh has had some form of commercial theatre. It now appears that the city will do well if it can long continue to make that statement.

A breakdown on the new wage scale for 40,000 truck drivers and helpers under a new two-year contract was given out yesterday by Frederick H. Bullen, executive secretary of the State Mediation Board. If ratified, the contract becomes effective next Wednesday.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 28 -- Kansans can't be kept down on the farm any longer. They are surging into the cities in numbers causing concern among the politicians. The realization is growing that once the urban vote outweighs the rural vote, which now controls the state government, there will be some changes.

THIS book by Kierkegaard has a significant place in the literature of serious meditation and the attainment of self-knowledge. Addressing "that individual whom with joy and gratitude I call my reader," Kierkegaard, Danish theologian and philosopher of the mid-nineteenth century, desired for readers of these pages an individual "willing to read slowly, to read repeatedly and to read aloud -- for himself to hear."

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Jeff Heath pounded an inside-the-park homer with two mates on the bases at Wrigley Field today to salvage a 5-to-4 victory for the Braves over the Cubs. It was the lone triumph of the four-game series for the National League leaders.

THE recent meeting in Washington of members of the Civil Aeronautics Board and officials of the five major domestic airlines of this country apparently left several problems unresolved, if not altogether untouched. It had been announced that the CAB and the heads of the big domestic lines would get together to study the acute financial problems of the air carriers.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- England's first soccer showpiece of the year -- last season's league champion, Arsenal, against the cup winner, Manchester United -- ended with the Gunners falling unexpectedly, 1 -- 0, today. There were 62,000 spectators.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, has asked that British movie-makers send a delegation to Hollywood for a "peace conference" with American producers, it was learned today.

FOR a fellow just back from a three-week complete separation from the screen, the past week of local movie-going has proved quite a harsh experience. Somehow, we'd seemed to have forgotten that it was really as brutal as this.

THIS massive text, so clearly presented as to require no technical legal competence on the part of the reader and so equipped with bibliographical aids as to guide the inquisitive student through most of the vast literature of a controversial subject, includes in its sweeping view of American constitutionalism the more salient developments, from John Locke to recent Supreme Court decisions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 28 -- The International Red Cross, in plenary session today, unanimously adopted a Greek resolution expressing the wish that deported children be repatriated as soon as possible.

BACH thought well enough of the music of Antonio Vivaldi to study it and transcribe some of it for new instrumental combinations. It was lively music two and a half centuries ago, and it remains charming today.

This season the coat has as much fashion significance as the dress. It follows the same trends. It is sufficiently voluminous to take care of all the fashion whims of the skirt -- flares, folds and flounces. It may have a considerable swing of its own.
IN a recent survey of life in the American family the importance of the father's role in the rearing of children was emphasized all over again.

For the first time since the National Air Races were resumed in 1946 the world's greatest air show will not be completely dominated by obsolete military aircraft. The "kitchen designer" and the "backyard builder" of airplanes will have his chance in the show to be put on in Cleveland over the Labor Day week-end.

Two of your Washington items recently have referred to the possibility of a draft of professional people, regardless of age, aimed specifically at obtaining veterinaries, doctors and dentists. The Army desires 6,900 medical officers, and for the first time in its history, also wants 1,300 recent graduates for interns and residents.
FROM southern Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware comes ominous news. Once again the tomato crop is being attacked extensively by late blight.

The recent release of New York University's nine-game football schedule for the 1948 campaign by Prof. John F. Sullivan, acting chairman of the Board of Athletic Control, augurs brighter prospects for Violet gridiron forces this fall as they will attempt to improve on last year's poor record of two games won, five lost and one tied.

COMPOSER, musical conductor, designer and master story-teller, Ernst Theodor Amadeus Hoffmann is remembered today mainly as the author of the "Tales," which have become a mainstay of many an operatic repertoire. Yet during the nineteenth century he was one of the major literary figures, widely read and enthusiastically praised not only in Germany but in France, Russia and the Anglo-Saxon countries as well.

THE child looks well and acts well, yet the doctor says to keep him in bed. Relatives and neighbors say that the mother is "babying" him -- or her. Requirements for prolonged rest in cases of rheumatic fever are hard on the child, who is usually feeling tip-top; hard on the mother, who rarely has special training in keeping this child comfortable, and occupied.

The season is fast approaching when Wall Street will be blamed again for the nation's economic maladjustments by some politicians seeking election to office in November. However, this shibboleth has lost much of its effectiveness as a vote-getter in the face of the nation-wide expansion of financial operations in the United States in recent years.

THE foremen of the jury is Alec Rambeau, and the man on trial is Mark Wissner, charged with murdering his wife by pushing her over a cliff. For some reason not clearly defined even to himself, Rambeau is determined that Wissner shall be found guilty, and he succeeds in winning over those members of the jury who are inclined to give the defendant the benefit of the doubt.

A new customer research and market-development center, said to be the largest and most complete laboratory of its kind in the glass-container industry, has been opened by the Owens-Illinois Glass Company in Toledo, Ohio, it was announced yesterday.

PICTURES done in words give this book its most obvious value. "Toward the Morning" is a long account of a short journey over the wagon trail that connected Fort Bedford and Boiling Springs in Pennsylvania in 1764, and of some weeks of wintering at Boiling Springs, which is just to the east of Carlisle.
MUNCIE, Ind., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Seven Negro laborers filed suit today, charging they had been held as slaves and asking the court to declare them free men.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- Foreign trade under bureaucratic control is proving something less than a howling success here. Reports from New York indicate that documents are arriving there on an average of more than eight weeks after the goods, while on this side stories of commodities intended for foreign markets "disappearing" somewhere along the processing line are becoming increasingly frequent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Consumers, for at least two to three weeks, will enjoy meat at lower prices at retail stores as a result of the substantial saving to slaughterers in the trade for live animals this week and a drive by wholesalers and retailers to move an accumulation piled up during this week's hot weather when consumer demand was abnormally low.

NEW international contract bridge laws are gradually coming into general use in clubs and serious bridge games, although they will not become "effective" until Oct. 1. Revised laws are always published some weeks in advance of the effective date, to give people a chance to learn them before using them; but ordinarily people put the laws into practice as soon as they know what they are.

Plans for international yachting on Long Island Sound off Oyster Bay next month that will bring together the best six-meter sloops on both sides of the Atlantic were completed yesterday by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. One contestant, which has been shipped back here, will be the Llonoria which, representing this country, took the top prize in the Olympic yachting.

A small book, turned up quite by accident in a dark and particularly dusty corner of the book shelves, proves to be a great help in these August doldrums. It is "A Century of English Essays" of the Everyman's Library, edited by one who modestly uses only the initials E.R.
A few weeks ago, with the concurrence of the three Western Military Governments in Germany, the reformation of the German currency system was carried out and put into legal form.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 28 -- The Yugoslav Government's complicated network of international treaties of friendship, cooperation and mutual assistance integrating Yugoslavia into the Soviet bloc is perilously close to destruction after two months party warfare inside the world of the Communist Information Bureau.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 28 -- Deering Howe's Donor followed the example set by his sire, Challedon, nine years ago with an astonishing victory today in the fourteenth running of the $25,000-added Narragansett Special.
The first major high-speed rotary dial telephone system in the United States was placed in operation yesterday by the Rochester Telephone Company.
PARIS, Aug. 28 -- After a day of consultation, France had not yet found a solution tonight to the crisis over prices and wages that had caused the sudden resignation of the Cabinet early today.

STAFF writers of THE NEW YORK TIMES will be featured in a new series of fifteen-minute interviews scheduled to start over WQXR at 9:45 A.M. on Wednesday. The Monday-through-Friday program, entitled "Keep Up With The Times," will be conducted by Alice Pentlarge, former moderator of the "What's on Your Mind?" forum.

"ESKIMO DOCTOR" is the story of a year spent by the author and his wife ministering to the medical needs of the Eskimos of Thule, Greenland, the northernmost human settlement in the world. Although the settlement was composed of hardly more than a dozen stone and sod huts, inhabited almost entirely by Eskimos, it comes alive for the reader as a small world in itself.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- Fitted out as the world's largest floating commercial fair, a chartered 10,000-ton vessel will put out from Antwerp in November to show Belgian goods to prospective buyers in North and South America.

The article by A.H. Raskin, titled "Dan Greco and That Thing Called Inflation," left a deep impression on me. We learn that THE TIMES wanted to find out "how * * * the average wage-earner [is] bearing up under the high cost of living."

The astronauts, or navigators of interstellar space in rockets, have always been an imaginative lot. Years ago Kurt Lasswitz wrote a novel in which he provided a filling station in space as a stepping-stone to Mars. Hermann Oberth, probably the leading authority on rockets, dealt with such a station with more technologic rigor and explained how useful it would be for scientific purposes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Senators tied their ball game with Detroit in the ninth inning today, but a two-run rally in the tenth gave the Tigers the game 7 -- 5.

IT is a quarter of a century since Allan Nevins published "American Social History as Recorded by British Travelers." And in that quarter of a century so much has happened to American social history and to the island whence the travelers came! What we have now is a new, better and even more entertaining anthology, with even better introductory essays and biographical notes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 28 -- It has been frequently predicted in the capitals of the world that if events in Palestine turned against the Arabs the Arab League would fall apart and Arab unity would disintegrate.

Jacob M. Lomakin, whose credentials as Soviet Consul General in New York were revoked by President Truman, sailed shortly after noon yesterday with his family for Goeteborg, Sweden. His destination was reported to be Paris, where he will take part in the sessions of the General Assembly of the United Nations, starting Sept. 21, but it was not made clear whether he would return to Moscow first.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Despite the heat, which took its toll even in this cooling-off place, competitors in the tournament for the United States chess championship, with few exceptions, were eager for the fray when the seventeenth round was started at the Community Center today.
LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Britain's Foreign Office was unusually reserved today in commenting on informal United States suggestions for "some form of internationalization" of Antarctic territories.

Girl Scouts will appear in new uniforms this fall, Mrs. C. Vaughan Ferguson, president of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., announced yesterday from its national headquarters, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

Flags on all Government buildings were lowered to half-staff yesterday by order of President Truman in memory of Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes, for whom funeral services will be held on Tuesday at 2:30 P.M. in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

THE program for the development of hotel accommodations and transportation facilities in the Virgin Islands in order to spur the territory's slowly growing tourist industry will be advanced Sept. 1 when the Interior Department opens bids for lease or purchase of Bluebeard's Castle Hotel.

THE family shopping for a moderate-priced house has a hard job trying to judge which is the best buy for them, unless, of course, father is an architect, builder or the like. One house offered for sale by a large-scale builder may be advertised at $11,850, another for $14,995.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- Appointment of Dr. Freddy Homburger, former head of the department of clinical investigation at the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, New York City, as research professor of medicine at the Tufts College Medical School and as head of the school's cancer research and cancer control units was announced today by Dean Dwight O'Hara.

THE publication of these two plays by Camus is somewhat overdue. They appeared in France about the same time as Sartre's first plays. "Cross Purpose" resembles "No Exit" in being a melodrama of modern life. "Caligula" resembles "The Flies" in being a melodrama of antiquity.

For only the second time in its history the United States tomorrow begins registering its young men for enforced military service at a time when the country is not at war. The call is, in fact, more of a break with the past than was the first peacetime call, in 1940. Eight years ago Europe was in flames.

E.C. Crocker, a chemist in the Arthur D. Little Laboratories, has recently been conducting experiments to determine whether the flavor of meat is found in the tissue or in the juice. It is in both, depending on whether the meat is raw or cooked.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -- For the first time since July 19 representatives of the International Longshoremens and Warehousemens Union, CIO, and the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast sat down this afternoon at a scheduled negotiating session.

A "blackout" of lights on side streets in lower Manhattan confronted repair crews of the Consolidated Edison Company last night as they were striving to restore normal electric power service to the area by the time full-scale business resumes tomorrow.
A water main broke at Broadway and Eighty-sixth Street shortly before 2 o'clock this morning, flooding the tracks of the Seventh Avenue IRT subway and stopping traffic.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The 33-day-old Government of Premier Andre Marie, a leader of the Radical Socialist party of France (a conservative group), resigned in the early hours of yesterday morning. It had been a short-lived Government -- even as French Governments go. It collapsed over the policies of its Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs, Paul Reynaud.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Albert J. Loveland, Under Secretary of Agriculture, said today that farmers are facing what probably is the "most serious" shortage of grain storage space in history.

THE world is naturally interested to know what is the nature of the quarrel that has arisen between the Cominform and the Yugoslav Communist party and how serious is this first rift in the bloc behind the Iron Curtain. There can be little doubt that the immediate cause of the quarrel is the fact that Marshal Tito and his Government have in many respects been acting on their own without consulting Moscow.

The Alcoa Steamship Company will transfer its general cargo operations on Wednesday from Pier 45, North River, to Pier 1, Erie Basin, Brooklyn. The last scheduled sailing of the line from the Christopher Street berth will be that of the Alcoa Patriot next Friday.

On last Friday night, around 8 o'clock, the envoys of the United States, Great Britain and France left Moscow's Kremlin in a steady drizzling rain. The latest in a month of meetings behind the pyramidal walls of Soviet Russia's "citadel" had just been completed.

Electric lighting costs will be reduced for many industrial and commercial concerns as a result of an important improvement in fluorescent lamps. There will be a saving of 14 per cent in current for the same amount of light, because it will be possible to use an 85-watt fluorescent lamp in place of the 100-watt size.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Aug. 28 -- Undeterred by the Berlin crisis and the talks in Moscow Western Germany's political leaders made final preparations over the week-end for convening the Parliamentary Assembly in Bonn on Wednesday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The favorites made it with the greatest of ease in the $58,950 Hopeful Stakes and the $16,425 Saratoga Cup marathon today as Saratoga ended its four-week run under a blazing sun before 19,680 sauted but resolute battlers of the pari-mutuels.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 -- A new peacetime ore shipping record will be established this season, Great Lakes vessel operators predicted today. At the same time, vessel owners expressed doubt that the 1948 goal of 86,000,000 tons, set at the opening of the navigation season, would be reached.

ANY youngster who has cherished dreams of helping the family in time of need will envy Pinto Goodluck his adventure in the mountains of New Mexico. With the war and the closing of the turquoise mines, hard times came to this Pueblo Indian family.

The fact-finding phase of the Civil Aeronautics Board's hearing on the crash of a Douglas DC-6 near Mount Carmel, Pa., last June 17, killing forty-three persons, including Earl Carroll, theatrical producer, was concluded early this morning.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 28 (AP) -- India today disputed the right of Hyderabad to seek intervention of the United Nations in the Princely State's differences with the Dominion.

ATHENS, Aug. 28 -- Greek troops were officially reported today to have occupied important heights in the mountainous region of Kaimaktchalan, where a rebel force estimated at 900 men is trying to maintain a foothold in the central Macedonian border area adjoining Yugoslavia.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- About the only encouraging aspect of the week's developments in the steadily worsening relations between Russia and the Western powers is that the Moscow talks on the Russian blockade of Berlin, now entering the fifth week, have not broken down completely.

A NEW light source for enlargers, the high-efficiency mercury-arc enlarging bulb, was introduced by the Elwood Pattern Works. Inc. of Indianapolis, at the Chicago convention of the Photographers Association of America last week.

Dr. Israel Goldstein, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, reported yesterday in a cabled message from Israel to the Appeal's offices here that Jewish life in Jerusalem was slowly returning to normal, although supplies were still "very short and prices very high."

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The downfall of the Cabinet of Andre Marie on the wage and price question has brought France to the brink of a new social conflict. Involved is the fate of French reconstruction and of the Marshall Plan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Two Republican Representatives from central New York, Kenneth B. Keating of Rochester and R. Walter Riehlman of Tully, announced plans today for a hurried "inspection and orientation" trip to Europe.

With association eliminations completed, six crews will start competition tomorrow for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy, emblematic of the women's national sailing championship. The event will be held by the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y.

Science is a wonderful thing, whether you want to shoot a rabbit or know where to dig a well, and the shooters who have been breaking clay birds at the Grand American trap shoot out in Vandalia, Ohio, have been running up against one of its devotees in the person of Bill Depperman of Winchester-Western.

THE other night we measured the actual pitches of the Boston Symphony during its performance at Tanglewood. The measurements corroborated the fact that the Boston Symphony Orchestra tunes to an appreciably higher pitch than any other major symphony orchestra in the world.

A MAN with a red beard brought in the August copy of Mademoiselle the other day and pointed dramatically to what some leading authors had been telling the young guest editors about their art. Through their advice he had just found his vocation.

It's late August. You can tell, if no other way, by the tang of vinegar and mustard seed and turmeric and peppercorns and onions and cucumbers. For now is the time when the cucumber vines come to fruit in profusion and to August heat must be added the heat of the pickling kettle. A savory time it is indeed.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- President Truman's projected swing through Michigan on Labor Day, Monday, Sept. 6, which is to be topped by a rally in Cadillac Square here, will find labor playing a conspicuous role, it became apparent today.

WITH the highway accident rate now reported on the decrease throughout the country, safety officials are particularly eager to alert motorists to the need for caution over Labor Day, lest the statistical curve rise sharply.

REASONED discussion among people qualified to cast opinions on a given subject is the sound basis upon which John Mason Brown conducts "Critic-at-Large" Wednesday nights at 7:30 o'clock on WJZ-TV, the local television station of the American Broadcasting Company.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- White and Negro troops of the State War Disaster Military Corps of the New York Guard from all sections of the state have been training together at Camp Smith the last week for the first time in the state's military history.

More than 1,000 sightseers trooped aboard the steaming decks of the Navy's EAG 128 yesterday and the first case of heat prostration since the ship was opened to visitors two days ago was treated. Better known as the U.S.S. Mississippi, her old name, the 32,000-ton experimental gunnery ship, is riding anchor in the North River at Forty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- There is only one issue in the 1948 campaign as far as labor leaders are concerned. That is the Taft-Hartley law. They are engaged in a tremendous campaign to sell that issue to their own people. They are staking everything on it. What are their chances of making good?

Financial markets, lacking any stimulating news, showed little disposition last week to change from the dull and uninteresting movements that have persisted for some time. Some of the gains scored in the preceding week were erased by the dip in prices on Monday, but traders generally were cautiously awaiting further developments abroad before changing their positions.
RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Government troops rushed northward today to relieve Prome, key city 160 miles from here, from the rebels, the Government announced.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A triple by Don White and Sam Chapman's single with one out in the tenth inning gave Philadelphia a 5-4 victory over St. Louis today for a sweep of the three-game series. It was the Athletics' fourth successive triumph.

The 6,000-ton training vessel Empire State, home from a 10,000-mile training cruise to West Indies and European waters, tied up yesterday at her home dock at the New York State Maritime Academy at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.

With store delivery costs continually increasing and competition from suburban stores becoming keener, retailers are currently faced with a complex necessity. They must reduce the percentage of deliveries to sales without cutting services essential to their competitive existence.

Plans for a new organization to represent salesmen in the wholesale lines who have no other trade or specialty organization were announced yesterday by Louis A. Capaldo, president of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, Inc., 80 West Fortieth Street.

During the last week in June New York's Grand Central Station teemed with children as thousands of younger apartment dwellers started off to camp. It was a scene that was repeated on a smaller scale in railway and bus terminals all over the nation. This week they are returning -- taller, heavier, browner, healthier. Their changes, however, are not all physical, for under the chigger bites and summer tan is a summer of rich experience.

Because of the excessive heat, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on the city's jubilee celebration, ordered the closing of the Golden Anniversary Exposition at the Grand Central Palace from 6 o'clock last night until tomorrow at 9 A.M. The exposition normally would have been open until midnight and all of today.

THE International Society for Contemporary Music has got its new festival -- the twenty-third -- planned well in advance. It will be held at Palermo, Sicily, from April 22 to 30, 1949. Already extra programs are being planned, besides those of the works selected by the international jury.

Junior year abroad, a popular pre-war educational institution was revived when fifty college students, thirty of them girls, sailed for Europe last night aboard the Mauretania. Their trip marked the first such mass movement of American students to Paris since 1939.

What governmental policies are in store for banking in the event of a new Federal administration? This consideration, with a whole series of component questions, is uppermost now in the minds of bankers.

ANNOUNCEMENT the other day that Miriam Hopkins had signed with the firm of Russell Lewis and Howard Young to go on the road in "Happy Birthday" threw light again on a couple of facts, one of which has been with us for a long while, the other of somewhat more recent vintage.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 -- Pitching his first complete game in three months, Preacher Roe today made it a three-hit whitewashing performance as the Dodgers beat the Reds, 2-0, for a sweep of the three-game series.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Provisional President of Israel, and other Israeli officials who are nationals of other states are preparing to assume Israeli nationality, Zionists here said today.

ROCK CREEK, Md., Aug. 28 (AP) -- William A. Tieman of Wyoming, Del., piloted his Here's Me across the finish line first in both beats for Pacific-One Design hydroplanes today in the initial feature of the Maryland Yacht Club's fortieth annual Star-Spangled Banner regatta.

MANILA, Aug. 28 -- For the first time since the earliest days of this republic, the Philippines are feeling general discomfort from a serious shortage of rice, the number one food staple. Government stocks, intended for controlling rising prices if hoarding practices should get out of hand, are seriously depleted.

The Division of General Education, the adult education branch of New York University, will start next month a newly devised "Great Books" program which, the university believes, will supersede similar projects in operation throughout the nation.
The national amateur golf championship will start in Memphis tomorrow with a field of 210 eligible players who will begin their quest for the title at match play.

PERHAPS the best way for succeeding generations of readers and students to understand the essence of a major historical figure and his relation to his times is to know thoroughly the man's public and private papers.

ABOARD PRESS YACHT WANDERER, Off Blakistone Island, Aug. 28 -- President Truman plans to carry his campaign for re-election to all parts of the nation and is looking forward to the experience "with a good deal of zest," the White House Press Secretary, Charles G. Ross, said today.

With New York's heat wave suddenly become an extraordinary ally of incalculable value, the Yankees yesterday came up with two runs that seemed to pop right out of the scorched ground in the last half of the ninth at the Stadium.

OXFORD, Ohio, Aug. 28 -- The vanguard of national officers and convention committee chairmen will begin to arrive here this weekend for the centennial convention of Phi Delta Theta fraternity on the Miami University campus, scene of its birth on Dec. 26, 1848.

Declaration of a state of emergency in Pakistan was not unexpected. Into its territory since the partition of India last year -- on which the Moslems insisted -- have swarmed an estimated 6,500,000 persons from Hindu India. Although a similar number, or only a slightly smaller number, fled out of Pakistan, the enormous job of resettling that many persons is not one to be accomplished without great labor.

IN 1845 Lady Caroline Washbourne had a young painter take luncheon at Otterley to make a preliminary survey of her husband's features for the portrait that he was to paint on the occasion of Sir Thomas' elevation to Lord Warden of the Privy Closet.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- In mid-July, a month after the currency reform in Western Germany, the average citizen of the United States zone said he had the equivalent of $6.75 to his name, an American Military Government report stated today.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Ecclesiastical leaders said today that the World Council of Churches would go on record acknowledging the guilt of the Christian Church for at least part of the racial strife over Palestine.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Because of the oppressive heat and in order to conserve the ponies for tomorrow's competition, the high goal polo match scheduled between Cecil Smith's Texas side and Wheatley Hills on the No. 2 field of the Meadow Brook Club today was called off.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- On a raging, angry Detroit River this afternoon America's high-priced fleet of Gold Cup speed boats lost an expensive battle when caught between a downstream current and an upstream wind that churned the oval three-mile regatta course into a mass of rolling seas.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug. 28 -- An observation by a student pilot flying out of Greenwich airport, six miles southwest of here, Friday afternoon, resulted in the rescue of two Salem County sportsmen from the muck and water of Delaware Bay marshes.

Viruses mutate. That is, they suddenly produce new species -- mutants -- which breed true, just as a cow sometimes gives birth to a legless calf or a two-headed calf which, if allowed to do so, would also breed true. It has been suggested that different breeds of virus -- cowpox and smallpox, for example -- are mutants that may have stemmed from a common ancestor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- When a major nation demands the severance of consular relations with another major nation, as the Soviet Union did in regard to the United States this week, the usual assumption is that the relations between those two nations are in a rapidly declining and even critical state.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Before some 18,000 sweltering fans here today, Rampart, owned by Mrs. Helene K. Haggerty of Hatboro, Pa., romped home with the third running of the $10,000 added Boardwalk Handicap.

DUBLIN, Aug. 28 -- The United States Army team rounded out a series of brilliant performances on the final day of the Dublin Horse Show by winning first prize in a field of forty-two from six nations competing in the international military jumping for the Horse Show Committee's Cup.

A projected transfer of Coast Guard headquarters in New York, removing seaman and other maritime activities from the center of the shipping industry, has been protested by steamship companies and official sea agencies, it was reported yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Sid Luckman completed six passes totaling 62 yards to set up the tying touchdown and winning point as the Chicago Bears defeated the Philadelphia Eagles today, 24 to 23, in a National Football League exhibition at Butler Bowl.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. John G. Winant's Champion Edgerstoune Pepper, Scottish Terrier handled by Phil Prentice, was selected as best in the all-breed show of the Northwestern Connecticut Dog Club at the White Memorial Foundation today. Mr. James M. Austin of Westbury N.Y., judged the final. Pepper scored in a field of 560.

French politics, with their multitude of parties and their swift changes of government, may be puzzling to Americans, but the reasons which brought about the resignation of Premier Andre Marie and his Cabinet early yesterday morning can easily be understood here. The issue was wages and prices.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 28 -- Matthew Mansfield Neely, a political veteran, and Chapman Revercomb, a relative neophyte, are meeting for the second time in six years in a West Virginia Senatorial contest, and there is a feeling that the 73-year-old Neely may be on his way to another comeback.

The eightieth anniversary of the founding of Cornell University will be observed Oct. 7-9. Four hundred twelve students matriculated in the first entering class in 1868. More than 10,000 students are now enrolled in the sixteen divisions of the university. Its original 200-acre site has been increased to about 6,500 acres.

Reclaiming the importance it had annually before World War II, the Eastern divisional championship regatta for outboard hydroplanes, which will be held Sunday and Monday, Sept. 5 and 6, at Agawam, Mass., on the Connecticut River, probably will attract the hottest fleet of contenders for the titles that has assembled in nearly a decade.

THIS week will see the start of the Labor Day exodus from the city, with holidayers -- heading for beach, country and mountains -- beginning the big push on Thursday and continuing it through Friday and Saturday.

The sharp upswing in prices following the summer wave of wage increases covered more materials and had effect on more business than in any period since price decontrol, according to the report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, released for publication today.

The national Congress of Industrial Organizations, in its first overt action against Saul Mills, executive secretary of the left-wing city CIO Council, has ousted him as a member of its Community Services Committee, it was announced yesterday.

ACCORDING to the bulletin of the North American Gladiolus Council, forty-seven shows have been held this summer throughout this country and Canada. A few are scheduled for the early part of September.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A summary of an interim report by the House Committee on Un-American Activities on its current investigation into Communist activities: follows:

MR. STONE is a first-rate biographer, and Mr. Warren is a man easy to like. Most people connected with politics in one way or another have been vaguely aware, for years, that they never heard anything derogatory about the California Governor who is now Tom Dewey's running mate.
IF film writers think their literary brain children get spanked too hard by newspaper critics, they ought to see the secret lashings their progeny get from the story analysts in movie studios.

A 9-year-old girl whom two United States Army sergeants noticed leaning on crutches near the chapel at Fort McAndrew, Newfoundland, will arrive in New York tonight en route to the National Infantile Paralysis Foundation at Warm Springs, Ga., her trip financed by United States service men stationed in New-foundland.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Vern (Little Slug) Stephens had a perfect day today -- four hits in as many times at bat -- as the American League leading Red Sox hammered 13 hits off Chicago pitching for a 6-2 triumph over the last-place White Sox. It was the Bosox' second victory in a row over the Chicagoans.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The forty-ninth Grand American trapshoot ended today. It was the biggest "Roaring Grand" in history, 1,267,500 targets being thrown and the same number of 12-gauge shotgun shells fired. A year ago, when the attendance was a bit above this year's, only 1,240,000 targets were tossed.

VALENTINA, a little girl making her sad way nowhere away from the Russian city where her mother and brother have been killed by bombs, is sheltered by the Shalikins. The Shalikins, mother, three children and grandfather, live on a farm; the father is fighting the Germans and has not been heard from in a long time.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 -- The Peron regime today made a major occasion of the promulgation of the new "Decalogue of the Rights of Old Age."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Long-range training missions by fifty United States Air Force bombers flying from scattered points across the world to "targets" in this country will mark, on Sept. 18, the first birthday of the Air Force as a co-equal branch of the armed services.

THE New York Central Railroad will receive this week from the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company shops in Chicago two spanking new Twentieth Century Limiteds. The new trains are scheduled to go into daily operation between New York and Chicago Sept. 17, replacing the two present Centurys which have been in service since June 15, 1938.
John A. Costello, Prime Minister of Ireland, toured Police Headquarters and the crime laboratory in the adjoining annex yesterday morning on his second day in the city.

WITH their "Spring in Park Lane" breaking all records around the provinces, and lines for every performance still in London, where the picture has been playing ever since Easter, Herbert Wilcox and Anna Neagle are preparing a new comedy with music on the lines of "Spring."

WHEN Harry D. White recently took the witness stand of the House Un-American Activities Committee he handed its chairman, J. Parnell Thomas, a note in which he stated that he was ill and asked to be granted rest periods during the questioning. Chairman Thomas proceeded to read the note aloud, implying that it had a deeper significance than the informal plea of a sick man for consideration.

FROM the short detective stories which have appeared in various magazines during this year, Mr. Cooke has selected twelve tales of outstanding merit. The authors represented are: Charles B. Childs, Q. Patrick, John and Ward Hawkins, Anthony Boucher, Lawrence G. Blochman, Margaret Manners, Ellery Queen, Harold Goldman, Samuel Bias, Alan Ritner Ander son, Hugh Pentecost and James A. Kirch.

BURTONWOOD, England, Aug. 22 -- At this vast airfield sprawled across the soot-blackened wastes of industrial Lancashire, America's newest step in meeting the threat of Russian expansionism is rapidly taking shape.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 28 -- Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., and Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago were deadlocked for the lead of the $12,500 Utah Open tournament at the end of 54 holes today with totals of 205.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, Democratic National Chairman, today made his first overture to the States' Rights Democrats to stick by the party for an unbroken front in November.
A LAWN free of crabgrass is the result of good care and constant attention through the years. Since permanent lawn grasses are somewhat dormant in summer, they are no match for this aggressive weed.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- The British Commonwealth, the Chinese and the Russian member of the Allied Control Council for Japan made clear today that they disliked Gen. Douglas MacArthur's July move to forbid the right to strike and to bargain collectively to Government employes.

Football drills will resume in high gear tomorrow at Fordham University with the first intra-squad scrimmage to mark the high point of the second week of preparations under the guidance of Coach Ed Danowski and his staff.

POMONA, Calif. -- What is extolled as the world's biggest county fair, and therefore is immediately identifiable with Los Angeles, is being revived this month after a seven-year hiatus caused by the war.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Prices of grains edged lower in a rather dull session on the Board of Trade today. Less demand from cash houses for wheat and rains over a good part of the Iowa corn territory caused moderate selling. There also was some profit-taking and evening-up for the week-end.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 28 -- As the United Nations truce regime over Jerusalem began its seventh week this city last night underwent one of the fiercest artillery batterings yet recorded, even during previous periods of hostilities.

THIS is a series of entertaining and informative essays on the behavior of living creatures of various kinds, from the simple existence of the ameba to the rather complicated design for living of the Genus Homo. The author, Dr. Gustav Eckstein, Associate Professor of Physiology at the College of Medicine of the University of Cincinnati, is known for his work with canaries; but in this gathering of articles, he ranges over a much wider field.

THE age of innocence is long past for travelers to the New World! The cinema has completed what the printed word began and no one now crosses the Atlantic without some sort of stereotype in mind. Even the most casual traveler has been inoculated, to his loss, against the thrill of the unexpected.

IN Los Angeles these days people talk almost as much about "paintings" as they do about "pictures," though the adjectives applied to the former are usually "exciting" and "superb" rather than "colossal" and "great." As an art center the sprawling city amid the camel-colored hills is busy and confusing.

SINCE the time of Tangoon, mythological father of the Korean nation, Koreans have been known as a people of rare creativeness. Their history since his death 4,000 years ago is renowned for its contributions to art and literature, but little today is known of its developments in music.

In twenty-four hours last Feb. 4, 149,888 persons dialed Weather 6-1212 in New York. That was a record. The people wanted to know how cold it was (14 degrees below zero) and how much snow was on the way.

R.V. COLEMAN has been managing editor for the past twenty years of Scribner's encyclopedic works on American history, especially The Dictionary of American Biography and The Dictionary of American History. His career has been chiefly the editi ng of books, but with "The First Frontier" he proves that he can also write one.

POMONA, Calif. -- What is extolled as the world's biggest county fair, and therefore is immediately identifiable with Los Angeles, is being revived this month after a seven-year hiatus caused by the war.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Prices of grains edged lower in a rather dull session on the Board of Trade today. Less demand from cash houses for wheat and rains over a good part of the Iowa corn territory caused moderate selling. There also was some profit-taking and evening-up for the week-end.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 28 -- As the United Nations truce regime over Jerusalem began its seventh week this city last night underwent one of the fiercest artillery batterings yet recorded, even during previous periods of hostilities.

THIS is a series of entertaining and informative essays on the behavior of living creatures of various kinds, from the simple existence of the ameba to the rather complicated design for living of the Genus Homo. The author, Dr. Gustav Eckstein, Associate Professor of Physiology at the College of Medicine of the University of Cincinnati, is known for his work with canaries; but in this gathering of articles, he ranges over a much wider field.
