PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Following is the text of Dr. Einstein's message to the World Congress of Intellectuals in Breslau. Dr. Einstein stated today that he knew nothing about the text that was credited to him in messages from Europe.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 28 -- Gunfire killed two French officers today while on a United Nations aerial coast patrol in the vicinity of Gaza, the Egyptian army base in Palestine, a United Nations announcement said. A United Nations source said that the United States pilot of the plane was hurt. His name was not learned here.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- President Truman and Attorney General Tom C. Clark were accused today by Senator Homer Ferguson, of Michigan, of hampering the inquiry into loyalty of Federal employes.

THE central Character in this remarkable story awakes from what seems to have been a dream to find himself lying in a ditch near the scene of an automobile accident in which a man has been killed. He does not know who or where he is, but he feels instinctively that he must remove himself from that place before his presence is discovered.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The first official statement on the Moscow talks, now expected within a day or so, will deal exclusively with the question of applying Soviet currency throughout Berlin and will announce an agreement upon this procedure only, according to high authorities here.

SUBSISTENCE farming, within commuting distance of the city, continues to exercise a fascination and challenge to many urban dwellers, particularly writers, as the steady flow of books about country living indicates. Near Danbury, Conn., the Tabers purchased a 200-year-old farmhouse and forty acres of land, where they could raise cocker spaniels and till the soil.

"Boom Days for the Economic Prophets" fails to mention one factor which may influence the possibility of another "bust" in the near future. That factor may be called "socio - political bulwarks" against depression.

"WELL, that's the way we heard it," shouted Trumpet. "Parson Pease-Porridge said, 'I'm going to get a new cat because my old cat's moth-eaten!'" When the parson had picked the mothballs out of the kitten's gluey fur, Gabriel really did look moth-eaten.

WARSAW, Aug. 28 -- On a tour of Europe to observe operations of the International Children's Emergency Fund of the United Nations, Mrs. Oswald B. Lord of New York left Warsaw for Prague today after a four-day visit in Poland. Mrs. Lord is chairman of the United States committee for the fund.
WITH the death of William Chase, once our senior in the music department of THE TIMES, a lover of music and a more affectionate friend than he ever would have admitted has gone.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 -- Everything happened to the Giants today to make life miserable as they made their farewell appearance of the year here by blowing a double-header to the rampant Cardinals.

STRICTLY in line of duty in a summer evening leaf-raking project, this department has been revisiting some of the town's most enjoyable musical shows -- "Finian's Rainbow," "Inside U.S.A.," and "Angel in the Wings."

MR. PEARSON is a writer of reputation in the field of the nature essay. His anonymous pastorals celebrating the beauties of the outdoors often appear, among other places, in the editorial columns of big city newspapers.

For almost a month the Hiss-Chambers affair has held the spotlight of the investigation into pre-war and wartime Communist activity by the House Committee on Un-American Activities. Yesterday -- so far as the public is concerned -- the record seemed to be about all in.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Jess Larson, War Assets Administrator, tonight approved the pact between the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation providing for operation of the Government's $28,000,000 surplus blast furnace in Cleveland.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Storm forecasters sounded a preliminary alert for the Georgia-Carolina coasts today as a small, violent hurricane slackened its forward pace.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The United States has proposed international control over Antarctica, for which seven nations have staked out overlapping claims.

A sure sign the yachting season is ending and winter is only just around the corner is the announcement by the New York Power Squadron of its autumn instruction courses. They will begin Sept. 13 at the Julia Richman High School, Sixty-seventh and Sixty-eighth Streets between First and Second Avenues, and will continue Monday evenings weekly.

Protest by the Textile Workers Union that major coton goods producers were cutting output to maintain "exorbitant prices and extortionate profits" highlighted the whole pricing problem of the industry last week.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Top-notch competition in the open jumper division highlighted the start of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club's sixth annual horse show which began its two-day stand on the club grounds today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities reported today that it had definitely established the wartime existence of "numerous Communist espionage rings" in the Federal Government.

National Airlines, which operates between New York and thirty cities in the southern United States and Cuba, will be the first American-flag line to move to New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, it was announced yesterday.

CAMILLA, Ga., Aug. 28 (AP) -- An escaped Florida convict has admitted orally a part in the moonlight beach murder of a young vacationing couple at Ormond, Fla., Deputy Sheriff Grover Jones said today.

WITH the return of more than a million veterans to the nation's campuses, and with a surprising post-war upsurge in enrollment, the resources of America's institutions of higher learning became sorely taxed. Many problems of curriculum development and administration arose.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- Helena Korelenko, 14-year-old cripple lying on a cot in a Berlin hospital is the center of a new dispute between the United States and the Soviet Union based on an old argument between democracy and totalitarianism over respect for the individual.

"Work hard and hurry up," will be the keynote of Columbia's preseason football practice, which will begin Thursday at Baker Field with approximately fifty candidates reporting to Coach Lou Little, starting his nineteenth year at the helm.

Extreme heat and the closing of some stores here on Friday afternoon because of power difficulties took toll of retail trade last week. Department store volume was estimated as ranging about 15 per cent under the comparative week of last year.

GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- The Economic and Social Council of the United Nations closed its seventh session here late tonight. In doing so it pushed forward to the General Assembly meeting in Paris in September a mass of controversial matters within its vast field of reference.

TERM contracts now in force in the studios will undergo considerable revision if the Screen Actors Guild succeeds in efforts it is now planning to make. At present the term contract binds players to employers for seven years while permitting the producers to discharge performers at the end of stated short periods within that time.

THE heat wave took toll of both trade and industry last week. In this area shopping discomfort cut sales 15 per cent under a year ago, according to estimates, and it is safe to assume that other territories also suffered. Industry shut-downs reduced production in several important areas.

THE International Dance Festival, which is to celebrate the Golden Jubilee of the City of New York at the City Center from Sept. 21 through Oct. 3, is to consist of eleven performances by the ballet of the Paris Opera, four by Ram Gopal and his company of Hindu dancers and musicians, and one by Charles Weidman and his company.

Wall Street's summer-long pre-occupation with the marketing of new multi-million-dollar issues of prime public utility preferred stock is now entering a new and perhaps even more significant phase. It has to do with whether the Public Service Electric and Gas Company will see fit to authorize the sale of $20,000,000 of new preferred stock under conditions currently prevailing in the investment market.

ALTHOUGH he is only 53, Robert Graves has been in the public eye for more than thirty years and has had a whole series of literary careers. Winning early fame as one of the candid and sometimes bitter young poets of the first World War, he wrote much poetry in the early Twenties and subsequently repudiated most of it.
The basis for Winged Foot's unchallenged supremacy in interclub competition is made clear in the revised handicap list released for publication today by the Metropolitan Golf Association.

GEN. THOMAS GAGE, Commander in Chief of the British Army in North America between 1763 and 1775, and the last Royal Governor of Massachusetts, played an important role in the events that led to our War for Independence.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The United Nations Security Council, which had adjourned to meet in Paris in September, was summoned today into special session Monday to consider again the use of sanctions to enforce the Palestine truce.

ONE of the few lights amid the encircling economic gloom here is the remarkable vigor displayed by a fourteen-year-old film, "The Crusades." When the religious spectacle was turned loose in an ailing market several weeks ago, it was with a pronounced uneasiness in official Paramount quarters.

IN HIS new novel, "The City Boy," Herman Wouk looks back before the war (and a gulf of five years spent turning out barbed thrusts for Fred Allen) and with gentle humor conjures up the last summer of the Coolidge era as it was spent by a small, fat and thoroughly likable little boy from the Bronx.

HOLLYWOOD' S independent producers served notice in more ways than one during the last several days that they are through with smoking the peace pipe so long as it entails, to their way of thinking, disadvantageous compromise either with major company interests or theatre owners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- American private enterprise is getting a sizable bite out of the multi-billion-dollar operations of the Economic Cooperation Administration. An even greater degree of participation is expected in the months immediately ahead as the program settles into full stride.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 28 -- Such long established tennis doubles teams as Gardnar Mulloy of Miami and Bill Talbert of New York and the invincible Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., ended a week's battle against torrid heat and red hot opposition with more national titles today at the Longwood Cricket club.

JESSSE M. DONALDSON, Postmaster General, made available last week a photograph of the design of the 3-cent stamp to be issued Sept. 22 to mark the centennial of the establishment of Fort Kearny in Nebraska.

New York may receive relief from the intense heat tomorrow, when a cold front now moving from Canada into the Great Lakes region is expected to arrive over the city, a Weather Bureau spokesman said last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- There is more than a trace of irony in recent reports that the nation "faces," as a calamity, the greatest outpouring of food American farms have ever produced.

National Airlines, Inc., serving many cities to the South, becomes the first scheduled domestic air carrier to sign up with the Port Authority for use of New York International Airport. This agreement derives its considerable interest, of course, because of the prolonged controversy over financial terms for occupancy at the airport.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 29 -- Communist chances of gaining ground in the elections for the Swedish Riksdag on Sept. 19 look exceedingly slim, observers said today. On that date the Swedes will elect 230 members of the lower Chamber of their Parliament for a period of four years, beginning January, 1949.

The growing hazard of offering thirty-day charge accounts to middle income groups under present economic conditions is being overlooked by many credit men, Arthur S. Wittner, credit manager of Browning King Co., warned over the week-end.
Nine new films, including importations from France and Italy, will open in midtown theatres during the week. The schedule follows:

Gertrude Lawrence is faced with a problem. This week she will decide whether to accept Hugh Beaumont's offer to act in the London presentation of the Daphne du Maurier play, "The Mother," or in the Gilbert Miller production of "Set-back for Don Juan," said to have been adapted by Clifford Bax from the French of Claude Andre Puget.

Four years ago this month the French people united in an inspiring outburst of joy and thanksgiving at their liberation from the Nazi yoke, and vowed through their spokesmen that France should have a new birth in freedom as a great nation and a great world power.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 17 you published parts of a report on the situation of the displaced persons in Austria, Germany and Italy submitted by the Secretary General of the United Nations to the Economic and Social Council. This report was prepared by Dr. C. H. Hambro of Norway and Pierce Williams of the United States.

Julius Christian, 22 years old, accused of attempting to run down a policeman with a stolen automobile, heard himself described as a "contemptible skunk" yesterday morning by Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Felony Court.

Results of numerous contest and premium promotions conducted earlier this year disclose the costliness of this device when used by the inexperienced, a number of research officials reported last week. Soap-makers and other advertisers long practiced in such campaigns have had good results generally, they noted.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- With the majority of the nation's top feminine golfers entered, the women's Western amateur championship will start here tomorrow at the Olympic Club lakeside course.

Refusing to be daunted by a .45caliber automatic pistol held against his ribs, Davis Lipschitz, 45-year-old proprietor of a delicatessen at 711 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, shot and seriously wounded a hold-up man early yesterday, and retained $700 that he was carrying to his home.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- A decree issued tonight by the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, legislative body of the Soviet Union, gave citizens the right to buy or build private houses, the Moscow Radio reported. The decree permits any citizen to buy or build a dwelling up to two stories in height and containing not more than five rooms.
The long arm of the law reached Rusty, the cat, yesterday, even though it had taken refuge three floors below the top of a chimney at 1279 Third Avenue.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 -- Record hot weather at steel centers last week did not prevent a small increase in steel production. Ingot output for the country was up one hall a point to 95 per cent of capacity. It was believed here that nothing now stands in the way of a peacetime record production in steel this year.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 29, (Reuters) -- Dr. J. Hutchison Cockburn, former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland, tonight appealed to the World Council of Churches to start long term planning not only to insure a revival of the church, but to meet the inroads of the state upon human rights.

The specter of heatless homes for millions of gas consumers in the New England and Middle Atlantic states during the winter of 1948-49 diminished perceptibly yesterday with disclosure by a Massachusetts utility of a revolutionary and comparatively inexpensive gas manufacturing process.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 (AP) -Myron Fohr of Milwaukee won the first AAA 200-mile auto race on a one-mile dirt track in history today -- and it was his first major triumph in big car racing.

CAIRO, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- The Egyptian Government sent a cable to Count Bernadotte today admitting that Egyptian machine-gun fire had killed two French United Nations observers yesterday as they cruised in a United Nations plane over Arab-held territory near Gaza, in southern Palestine.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Truman returned to the White House today, deeply tanned and rested after a nine-day cruise aboard the yacht Williamsburg.

There is a definite place for structures and monuments of enduring stone or bronze to keep alive the memory of the men who have risked and ofttimes given their all for sake of country. Even more appealing, however, to the cooperative sympathies of us all are living mementoes and activities of a dynamic character which perpetuate the remembrance we must always hold dear.
Registration of 25-year-olds for America's second peacetime draft will start at 8 A.M. today in 20,000 offices throughout the nation.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- While the prime objective of the Soviet zone's economic plan calls for closer ties with the Soviet Union, the Eastern zone must also establish trade relations with the Western countries, Heinrich Rau, chairman of the German Economic Commission of the Soviet zone declared today.

Asserting that the charge of Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, that the Progressive party was sponsoring candidates to defeat liberal members of Congress was based on a misunderstanding, C. B. Baldwin, campaign manager for Henry A. Wallace, called yesterday for "real working unity" between the CIO and the Progressive party to elect such Representatives.

When the long summer vacation ends soon, America's classrooms and campuses will be crowded as never before in the nation's history. Reports from the United States Office of Education indicate that thirty-two million youths will attend the schools and colleges.

For the first time people were able yesterday to sit at home in New York and watch naval operations taking place at sea. In an unprecedented experiment, naval and air maneuvers were televised successfully from the flight deck of the carrier Leyte.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29 -After having given the police a list of speakers in advance, the Radical party held a major outdoor meeting last night to protest the peronista plan to amend the National Constitution. The ousted Deputy, Ernesto Sammartino, was added to the list at the last minute, with police approval, and he received an ovation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 29 -- Israel and Egypt have agreed to proposals for bringing peace to the neutral area of Jerusalem, the chief of staff for Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator in Palestine, said tonight.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- Spitfires spearheaded the Burmese Government drive against rebel-held Prome -- immediate Government objective when the anti-guerrilla offensive was resumed this week-end.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Tourists will bring at least $150,000,000, or oneseventh of the credits France will obtain through the European Recovery Program, into the French treasury this year, according to official estimates.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, called yesterday upon Rexford Guy Tugwell, whom he termed the most prominent of the non-Communist supporters of Henry A. Wallace, to disavow his support of the Progressive party, because of his professed disquietude of the degree of Communist control of that party, as evidenced at the Philadelphia convention.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -For his direction of "The Search," Vienna-born Fred Zinnemann, who has been in Hollywood since 1929, has won top honors in the first quarterly competition conducted by the Screen Directors Guild among its members under a plan of awards recently announced.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -Greater food production for the world may be possible eventually through scientific control of plant life with "growth-regulating" chemicals, two Army chemists said today.

United States Air Force veterans who "flew 'em and kept 'em flying" in World War II will hold their first national reunion here on Sept. 25, Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, wartime commander of the Eighth Air Force, announced yesterday.

BRESLAU (Wroclaw), Poland, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The World Congress of Intellectuals, adjourning here announced the setting up in Paris of an "international committee in defense of peace" as part of a worldwide campaign to avert a new war.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- There was a wind over Long Island Sound today that must have come from the Iowa cornfields, whence originated the days of heat.

Among the most hackneyed expressions is the one about history repeating itself. Another, less frequently heard, but common among lovers of the greatest of novelists, is: "You can find everything in Dickens." Here is a striking example of history repeating itself, almost one hundred years after Dickens wrote on the same subject.

Transatlantic steamship booking offices, still struggling under the load of this year's record post-war summer travel rush, are already being deluged with inquiries and applications for the 1949 summer season, a survey showed yesterday.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $50,424,266,893. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtednes, bills and notes as follows:

WARSAW, Monday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Dr. Otto Nathan of New York declined early today to say why he decided not to present a special message from Prof. Albert Einstein to the World Congress of Intellectuals. The Congress adjourned Saturday night in Breslau (Wroclaw).
Bids for the construction of the $7,000,000 Battery Park underpass will be advertised this week, it was announced yesterday by Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan.

Up in Maine there's a saying that a girl isn't "fit to be married" unless she can make baking powder biscuits; down South hot biscuits are as essential to dinner as coffee is to breakfast. Actually, skill with them comes in handy not only in the country, but in the city, too, for biscuits may be varied almost beyond recognition.

Brooklyn's loyal legions may not know it but in their midst is a clergyman who roots for the Dodgers in three languages -- English, Spanish and Guarani. Incidentally, Guarani is the language of the Paraguayan people. The cleric is the Rev. Dennis O'Dwyer, Brooklyn-born, and now on leave as Father Rector of the Redemptorist Mission at Asuncion, Paraguay.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 29 -- The new Dutch cabinet is closely studying measures required for putting into operation the Benelux union of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. This is probably preliminary to the new Benelux round-table conference to be held shortly in which the governments will get down to business.

The survey OEDproach. recently condemned by the NationalBetter Business Bureau, Inc.. as aifast-growing "racket," had previously been round widespread na-]tionally in home appliance, bookIand magazine subscription selling,

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) -- George Fazio of Conshbhocken, Pa., and Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago tied for first place in the $12,500 Utah open golf tournament today with fourteen-under-par totals of 274 for the seventy-two holes.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29 (UP) -- A usually reliable source said today that more than 3,000 Albanians had been arrested by their Government in a two-month purge of pro-Yugoslav elements.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -A new weekly allotment of $57,477,236 in Marshall Plan aid was reported today, about 67 per cent of it for industrial "recovery" goods instead of food.
PARIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The fall of two French Governments within a month has caused concern out in the country districts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities announced today that it had established a link between the two Communist undercover organizations alleged by Whittaker Chambers and Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley to have operated in the Federal Government.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Aug. 29 -Greater application of Christian principles in education, government, race relations and other fields to help safeguard the American way of life, was pledged here today for several million Catholic students by their delegates, in resolutions adopted at the closing sessions of the thirteenth national conference of the Catholic Students Mission Crusade.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Winning his adjourned game with Sven Almgren of Los Angeles from the seventeenth round, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, National open champion in 1946, today forged to the front, half a point ahead of Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, in the biennial tournament for the United States chess championship at the Community Center.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. Aug. 29 -- Best of show in the annual event of the Great Barrington Kennel Club, held today on the grounds provided by the Barr Club, managed by president and show chairman, Edward R. Renner, went to the excellent Kerry Blue terrier, Ch. Mr. Deed's Show Off.

Paul V. Betters, executive director of the United States Conference of Mayors, announced yesterday that five representatives of that organization would sail for Europe tomorrow night on the liner Queen Mary. Their mission is one of cooperation with European municipal officers for advancement of the Marshall Plan at the local level.

DURHAM, N.C., Aug. 29 -Henry A. Wallace, Presidential candidate of the Progressive party, entered this city's Armory Building tonight to make an address before a mixed crowd of Negroes and whites, with a National Guardsman preceding him with a pistol in His hand.

Readers who have been following with interest news concerning the American Indians, especially the Navajos, will be pleased to know that Indians in New Mexico and Arizona now are permitted to vote provided they pass successfully the literacy test given to first-time voters.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 29 (AP) -Queen Wilhelmina will return tomorrow from rural retirement to celebrate her sixty-eighth birthday and her fifty-year span as ruler of the Netherlands.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Eighteen sailing yachts got under way tonight from the Genesee River piers for what is believed to be the longest fresh water race ever staged in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -A sp inquiry report demanding drastic revision of loyalty check procedure for Federal employees was predicted today by a Senate official. He said that the Senate Investigating Subcommittee headed by Senator Homer Ferguson was expected to urge:

DARK HARBOR, Me., Aug. 29 -Summer estate owners and townsfolk of this heat-parched island community joined today to fight a forest fire, which for a time, threatened a repetition of the disaster that swept Bar Harbor, thirty miles to the Northeast, last Oct. 23.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- United States Ambassador W. Bedell Smith, French Ambassador Yves Chataigneau and British Special Envoy Frank Roberts met for nearly two hours in Mr. Smith's office early today. The three Western spokesmen were believed to be awaiting a call from the Kremlin for another conference with Soviet leaders.

Some of the best therapy in the world is provided by the summer sixdays-a-week hospital cruises sponsored in near-by waters by St. John's Guild. These cruises have been going on now uninterruptedly since 1875, yet so matterof-fact are the sponsors about it all and so efficient is their operation that the public tends not to be especially aware of these unique trips until some special event calls them to mind.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Emigre movements from the communized Eastern European countries are commencing to coalesce their individual activities and appear to be working gradually in the direction of creating democratic "shadow governments."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -Prospects for settlement of the West Coast maritime dispute dimmed here tonight with a union statement that all employer offers to date were "wholly unacceptable."

The foreign exchange market during the past week experienced one of the dullest periods in some time. Business reported was very light and mostly routine. Quotations fluctuated within an extremely narrow range and changes for the most part were slight.

WESTBURY, L.I. Aug. 29 -Thomas Farina, who, with his wife and ten children, operates a 30-acre farm on Brush Hollow Road here, had more reason to lament the record-breaking heat wave than most persons today as he surveyed fifteen acres of ruined tomatoes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -State governments collected a record $7,900,000,000 in taxes in the 1948 fiscal year ended last June 30, an increase of $1,100,000,000 over the previous year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- After placing in all but one open jumping event during the two days of competition, the aged chestnut gelding Sun Beau, owned by the Sterling Smith Stables of Ravenna, Ohio, and handled throughout by George Braun of Port Chester, N.Y. annexed the jumper championship of the sixth annual Sleepy Hollow Country Club horse show at the club grounds tonight.
Nine scheduled airlines operating at La Guardia Field were accused by the Port Authority yesterday of trying to sabotage the city's airport program.

GENEVA, Aug. 29 -- Since the passage of legislation designed to admit 205,000 displaced persons to the United States, the actual movement of such refugees to America has stopped. Inquiries at headquarters of the International Refugee Organization reveal not only that no refugees are being moved out of camps but that there appears no prospect of an early movement on a scale called for by the law.

BURTONWOOD, England, Aug. 29 -- This could be wartime England all over again. This vast air base, which housed 30,000 United States soldiers at the war's peak, has been deserted since they left, except for a tiny Royal Air Force caretaker group and some civilian guards.

A hurricane centered about 390 miles east of Jacksonville, Fla., kept hundreds of thousands of persons out of the water yesterday on beaches along the Atlantic Coast as far north as Truro, Mass., on Cape Cod, 1,000 miles from the center of the disturbance.

The American Labor party will nominate Henry A. Wallace for President, and Senator Glen H. Taylor for Vice-President and name candidates for Presidential electors at a meeting tonight in the Commodore Hotel.

More than $4,600,000 worth of consumer and producer goods are expected to be conveyed through Government surplus sales during the first half of September, it was announced over the week-end by Walter F. Downey, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

As if things weren't bad enough when they blew a 6-2 lead and lost the opener, 9 -- 6, to the Tigers yesterday at the Stadium, the Yankees sped to an early 9-0 bulge in the afterpiece only to see the visitors score five times each in the sixth and seventh.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Aug. 29 -- Part of the war in Kashmir -in which a United Nations Security Council commission is attempting to negotiate a cease-fire arrangement with India and Pakistan -- is being fought at heights up to 19,000 feet in a land of eternal snow.

Capt. G. E. Cove, veteran Cunard White Star shipmaster, has been assigned temporarily to relief duty on the company's express liners, it was reported here yesterday. He was in New York on the bridge of the Queen Elizabeth on her last trip here and probably will come out in the next few weeks in command of the Queen Mary.

PRAGUE, Aug. 24 -- The antituberculosis program, or joint enterprise, of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund and the World Health Organization is receiving the full support and cooperation of the Czechoslovak Government.

The large number of reorders for coats and other ready-to-wear lines received by the wholesale apparel market here last week reflected unusually good sales of fall apparel at the retail level, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) -Jersey City made it five of six in its series with Montreal today by taking both ends of a doubleheader, 5 to 1 and 4 to 0, before a crowd of 5,000.

James O. A. Luckman's letter on the former Italian colonies sounds as if Mr. Luckman had been asleep from September, 1943, until today. Such expressions as "the Roman yoke," "the defeated Italian Government," "former tyrannical oppressors," and "giving men back into slavery," completely overlook the fact that there now exists in Italy a truly democratic government which is in no sense a successor to that which conquered and oppressed Ethiopia.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 29 (AP) -Buffalo's Jake Wade turned in a four-hit 8-3 triumph in the nightcap of a twin bill today after Newark had won the opener, 5 -- 4, with Frank Lamanna saving Dick Starr's thirteenth victory.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Home runs decided both games as the Boston Red Sox and St. Louis Browns split a double-header today before 27,522 fans. The American League leaders won the opener, 10 -- 2, and were subjected to a twenty-hit attack while dropping the nightcap, 12 -- 4.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Called into emergency session, the United Nations Security Council is scheduled to discuss tomorrow violations of the Palestine truce and the steps taken to bring about a settlement in the tenmonth-old India-Pakistan dispute over Kashmir.

The Christian leadership needed in the world today calls for the fullest development of the individual's mental capacities, social responsibilities and moral sensitivity, the Rev. Dr. Alden Mosshammer, pastor of the Faith Congressional Church in Springfield, Mass., declared yesterday.

DOUGLASTON, L.I., Aug. 29 -- The end of the world as we know it now can be put off with a $10,000,000 engineering project, Hugh Auchincloss Brown said today in the comfortable oldfashioned library of his home here.

More than 60 per cent greater production from the same number of employees has been obtained by a department of Warner Electric Company, St. Louis, through quality control methods which reduced defective output from 4 to 1 per cent, C. W. Kennedy, quality control engineer of the Federal Products Corporation, Providence, R.I. disclosed over the week-end.

The new Fifth Avenue Shop on the third floor of Gimbels' Market Street store in Philadelphia will be opened Sept. 15, it was announced over the week-end by Arthur C. Kaufmann, executive head of Gimbel Brothers, Philadelphia.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 -- Today's furiously fought double-header will long remain in the memories of the Dodgers and Cardinals and every one of the 33,826 fans who formed the season's record crowd at Sportsman's Park.

On his final day of a three-day stay in the city, John A. Costello, Prime Minister of Eire, attended mass yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral and later had luncheon as the guest of Cardinal Spellman.

High construction costs have forced the city to reduce both the size and scope of the proposed new ferry terminal at St. George, Staten Island, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday. Revised plans for the structure and its traffic approaches are based upon an estimated cost of $20,000,000, rather than the $26,500,000 called for in an earlier plan prepared by the Department of Marine and Aviation.

Thousands of dollars in shipping charges have been saved by a reduction of trucking delays on the congested waterfront, according to the executive committee of the Steamship-Motor Carrier Bureau of New York, Inc.

TOKYO, Aug. 29 -- The pre-war standard of living has been virtually restored after three years' occupation in the rural districts of Japan, according to a number of competent observers both American and Japanese. They have known the Japanese farm belt both before and after the conflict.

The building containing two stores and six apartments and occupying a lot 30 by 95 feet at 846 Gates Avenue, in Brooklyn, was sold by the Lycidas Holding Corporation to the Atlantic Hendrix Corporation. Brownstein Brownstein were the attorneys for the seller of the property, which is assessed for $10,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Speaking for its more than 28,000 members, the national board of Americans for Democratic Action, of which Leon Henderson is national chairman; today "emphatically" endorsed the candidacies of Harry S. Truman and Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, nominees for President and Vice President respectively on the Democratic ticket.
Your editorial "Katydid," of Aug. 22, impressed me that a great newspaper could be so expertly entomological. Allow me please to add a brief footnote to a splendid essay on August night noise.
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- When Wynford Vaughan Thomas, television broadcaster, came home with a bandaged finger last night, Mrs. Thomas knew without being told that he had tangled with an irritated reptile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The National Munitions Board today listed uranium and radium among a score of strategic materials not being stored up for reasons of storage problems in the country's $3,403,000,000 stockpiling program.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- After Paul Ramadier, Socialist Premier of the first Cabinet in the fourth French Republic, had renounced today an effort to form a ministry, President Vincent Auriol called upon former Premier Robert Schuman tonight to assume the task.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Although the practice of the president of the British Board of Trade in giving advance details of Britain's overseas trading robs the actual returns of some of their interest, full figures for July contained many interesting facts; some favorable; some unfavorable.

With two-thirds of the New York racing season written into the records, the runners will be back at work on Long Island today after the four-week stay at Saratoga. Three meets remain before the close of activities Nov. 15, and the first of the three will be the Queens County Jockey Club's twoweek session at Aqueduct, the track that is only a dozen miles from Manhattan.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 29 -- Choral music on a grand scale was not represented at the first Edinburgh Festival a year ago. That omission, happily, has been corrected this year by the engagement of the Huddersfield Choral Society to take part in two concerts with the Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, under Sir Malcolm Sargent's direction.
Wage rises of $1.80 to $4 a week have been awarded to 33,000 hotel employees, it was announced yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, impartial chairman of the industry.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 29 (AP) -- This city has awarded the Goethe prize to Fritz von Unruh, a German writer whose books were burned publicly by the Nazis.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- It appeared tonight that another Moscow meeting between Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov and envoys of the United States, Britain and France would be required before a communique could be issued announcing a four-power decision to hold a technical conference in Berlin on its currency problem.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- A welcome change has come over the stock markets in the past week, and this reflects the more cheerful sentiment felt in the city generally. The recovery in the markets has been nothing to shout about, and it must be confessed that it is not based upon particularly sound foundations and certainly not upon any noticeable increase in public support.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a very nervous manner on the Board of Trade last week within a wide range, an early break carrying all deliveries of grain and soy beans except September and December wheat to new seasonal low prices.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- Better protection for witnesses against defamatory statements was called for today by Paul A. Freund, Professor of Law at Harvard University in a four-point proposal for reforming the procedure used by Congressional investigating committees.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 29 -Dr. Albert Einstein charged here today that the Polish version of his message to the World Congress of Intellectuals at Breslau had been changed without his authorization or his knowledge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -Jake Early's sixth-inning double off Relief Pitcher Bob Feller with the bases loaded was the big blow as Washington defeated Cleveland, 5 -- 2, in the second game of a doubleheader here today. Cleveland won the first game, 6 -- 0, on the three-hit pitching of Bob Lemon as Joe Gordon slammed his twentythird homer of the year.

A syndicate representing French realty interests has purchased The San Jacinto, an eight-story apartment hotel at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street adjoining the French Institute of the United States. Assessed at $600,000, of which $445,000 is land value, the property is 50.5 by 90 feet and was acquired from the 649 Madison Avenue Corporation, Carl Scholtz, president.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Secret diplomacy lately has been reintroduced in Europe, and the United States, which once stood for "open covenants openly arrived at," is participating in and sometimes encouraging this closed-door policy.

ATHENS, Aug. 29 -- A Greek Army spokesman reported tonight that operations in the Vitsi Mountains of Western Macedonia, representing the first post-Grammos phase of Greece's war to end the Communist-led rebellion, were now under way. The offensive was expected to be in full swing by sunrise tomorrow.

Too many chroniclers of New York ignore the urban scene as it is today and are reluctant to look at a famous thoroughfare or beautiful park without reconstructing its entire history to the detriment of its present function.

Normal service on the West Side IRT Subway between Times Square and Ninety-sixth Street was restored yesterday morning after it had been cut off for more than seven hours by the bursting of a thirty-six-inch water main at the northwest corner of Broadway and Eighty-sixth Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- San Francisco's high scoring Forty-niners, behind a smart aerial game and tremendous ground power, opened the All-America Conference professional football season today with a 35-14 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

The House Committee on Un-American Activities has just issued an interim report in which it asserts that it has ascertained certain facts and repeats certain recommendations for legislation. The Committee believes that it has "definitely established" the existence of "numerous Communist espionage rings at work in our executive agencies" during and since the Second World War and that "Russian Communists have worked hand in hand with American Communists in these espionage activities."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Wilford Wehrle, golfer declared ineligible by the United States Golf Association to compete in the national amateur tournament, told a reporter here tonight, "I got a raw deal."

One Army prisoner was captured and two others were still at large after the trio had plunged into the strong currents of Buttermilk Channel from Governors Island and swam about a third of a mile across the channel to Brooklyn at noon yesterday.

The real struggle today is between the material and the spiritual forces in life and not between political "isms," the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, Director of Community Relations, Protestant Council of the City of New York, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
TRUMBULL, Conn., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Leslie James Bailey, 26, of Farmington, was killed instantly today, state police said, when he fell from a car on the Merritt Parkway.

ZURICH, Aug. 29 -- Despite grumbling in the Swiss press at technical flaws and structural blemishes, the new trade agreement between the American and British occupation zones in Germany and Switzerland, signed in Frankfurt on Aug. 23 and since ratified, has met with warm approval in trade and banking circles here.

For the fifth consecutive week, cotton prices in the domestic market last week again closed in lower ground. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 21 to 55 points.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Cubs divided a twin bill with the Phillies today, losing the opener, 1 to 0, and then capturing the second, 10 to 4, before a crowd of 34,804.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -The White Sox snapped a fivegame Philadelphia winning streak today by clubbing out a 7-to-2 victory in the second game of a double-header. Carl Scheib pitched and batted the Athletics to a 5-4 triumph in the opener.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- A Midlands Conference of Democratic candidates for United States Senator and Governor from eleven central states will be held here tomorrow and Tuesday to "revitalize the tradition of American liberalism in its birthplace."

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A four-run rally in the seventh inning gave Pittsburgh a 5 to 2 victory over the first-place Boston Braves in the nightcap of their double-header today after the Pirates had captured the opener, 6 to 1.

The D. Gregory Volkert estate with two-story dwelling and three acres of land on Greenvale Road, adjoining the Engineers Golf Club, in Roslyn Harbor, L.I., was purchased by Harold Dreyer of Great Neck in a transaction negotiated by Henry Brady, broker.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Hassan Abd el Rehim, 41-year-old Egyptian landed last night near St. Margaret's Bay, Kent, after swimming the English Channel in 17 hours 38 minutes. He started at 4:50 A.M. from Cap Griz Nez, France.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Dr. Peter Zenkl, former Deputy Premier of Czechoslovakia, arrived in London by air today after a dramatic escape from his country. He expects to leave for the United States in about two weeks.

PRAGUE, Aug. 29 -- A pastoral letter from the Roman Catholic Bishops of Czechoslovakia, read from pulpits this morning, charged that an anti-church and antireligious campaign had been started by the Prague Government.

The heat wave that has had this city in its grip for the last four days is breaking up. Last night's forecast for New York and vicinity was for highest temperatures in the mid-eighties today -- a modest figure compared with the broiling heat of recent days.

Fred M. Vinson, Chief Justice of the United States, is among the speakers listed to be heard over the CBS network in the Labor Day week-end. On Saturday at 10 P.M., he will discuss the Phi Delta Theta Centennial Convention to be held Wednesday through Sunday at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, which he will attend.
East met West last week in the third floor dress department of Lord Taylor, when a collection designed in Beverly Hills and one created in New York were shown at the same hour.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The American Municipal Association announced today it had appointed a fourteen-member committee to study civilian defense problems in cities as preparation for any future national emergency.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 29 -Under a scorching sun, most of the 210 competitors who have a role in the forty-eighth United States amateur golf championship, starting over the Memphis Country Club course tomorrow, struck their final preliminary blows today.

Melvin Hall, author of "Journey to the End of an Era," continues his autobiography with a new volume of memoirs, "Bird of Time," which will be published by Scribners in October. Mr. Hall again tells of his experiences in his world travels and around his home in France.

Considerable evidence that in a large section of American industry productivity has failed to rise at all or to increase enough to offset the burden of rising payrolls has appeared in data gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES in a survey of available information on productivity and labor cost.

With the European Recovery Program now well established, the United States should lose no time in strengthening inter-American ties, particularly in the fields of trade and military cooperation, it was declared here last week by Dr. O. Miro Quesada, Peruvian publisher, who is regarded as one of Latin America's foremost economists.

Drop in sales of knitted textile products has resulted in a sharp curtailment of orders for knitting machines, it was learned yesterday. Machine builders who had a six to eight month backlog of orders at the beginning of the year can now make comparatively quick delivery, according to trade sources, and in some instances have cut down their output.

Despite American military and financial aid to Greece as a key point in our system of defensive alliances in Europe, the Greek people face grave difficulties in keeping their country going, according to advance releases yesterday of a "Report on the Greeks" which the Twentieth Century Fund soon will publish.

Two men who had started the day with a speedboat ride, only to decide that an airplane flight would be more exhilarating, ended their holiday with a 400-foot swim at West Sixth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, after their rented seaplane capsized and sank in choppy water.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -The Bureau of Mines is swapping shale and shale oil for information on experiments with the material. It said it had started shipping out small quantities of shale and shale oil from its mines and demonstration plant near Rifle, Col.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Liquidation was on in lard futures on the Board of Trade last week, all deliveries selling at new seasonal low prices. Although the latter were not maintained, closing trades yesterday showed losses of 30 cents to $1.05 per 100 pounds, compared with prices a week earlier.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 29 -- Ralph (Scooter) Earhart, making his professional football debut, furnished the deciding margin between the Green Bay Packers and New York Giants in an exhibition professional football game today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 29 -The Hurricanes, aided by a four goal handicap and sparked by the fine individual play of ten-goal Cecil Smith, turned back the Great Neck poloists, 9 -- 6, in the high goal feature on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, president of New Brunswick Theological Seminary, New Brunswick, N.J., declared yesterday in a sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, that there was "a vast difference between religion and theology which we often overlook."
WINONA, Minn., Aug. 29 -Thirty-six persons were killed late today when a Northwest Airlines passenger plane crashed into a 500-foot Mississippi River bluff during a severe storm.
A ten-minute movie short on juvenile delinquency, titled "Families First" and sponsored by the New York State Youth Commission, will open today at first-run Broadway movie theatres.

LAKE MOHAWK, N.J., Aug. 29 (AP) -- John (Bud) Stillman and his sister, Patricia Ann, 19, of the Money Island. N.J., Yacht Club won the north Atlantic Coast snipe racing championship today by sailing their Jolly Roger to victory in the final race.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 -- A proper program to promote the sale of men's wear in this country will remove most of the evils attendant upon overproduction, it was emphasized here today by M. J. Lovell, director and counsel of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 29 -- The last-inning jinx that has dogged the footsteps of the Giants since this fatal last swing through the West got under way sent Leo Durocher's band down to fresh depths today on Crosley Field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today completed payment of a $239,000,000 advance from the Federal Government when Maple T. Harl, head of the corporation, gave a check for $12,604,306 to John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- There has been a delay in the announcement of a limited Big-Four agreement on the Berlin currency problem, but officials here remain moderately confident that progress is being made.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- With the addition of a "hard top convertible" to its line, the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation showed its 1949 models today to seven hundred distributors and the press at the company's plant at Willow Run.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The stock market here continued cheerful today despite nearness of the end of the account, in which the last dealings take place tomorrow.

The bitter fight on political policy being waged between the national office of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and leftwing affiliates over the Presidential candidacy of Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party standard bearer, arose again yesterday on the local labor front.

Maurice J. Tobin, the new Secretary of Labor, will speak at the meeting of the State Committee of the Liberal party in the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow evening. Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman, announced yesterday.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 30 -- Henry A. Wallace, his shock of gray hair stained with the yolk of eggs thrown by sidewalk hecklers, clashed in oral tilts with angry crowds of South erners on five occasions today as he continued his political tour.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Istan, speedy gelding in the Brookfield Farm Stable of Harry Isaacs of Baltimore, ran the fastest six furlongs of the meeting today when he beat five 3-yearold rivals in the Mainland Purse.
Confronted yesterday with a mass of rumors that he had died suddenly, Mayor O'Dwyer assured City Hall reporters that he was very much alive.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Willys Overland Motors, Inc., and eleven of its directors were named defendants today in a suit filed in Chancery Court here by Hyman Krinsky of Norfolk County, Mass., who said he is the registered owner of 100 shares of Willys' common stock.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Corn showed a strong undertone from the start on the Board of Trade today and finished around the top with gains of 2 1/2 to 3 cents a bushel, September and December showing the most strength. Wheat gained 7/8 cent to 2 1/4 cents, July leading, and oats were 3/8 cent to 1 1/8 cents.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- A threatened ending of negotiations between West Coast longshoremen and waterfront employers was averted today by an agreement in principle on the hiring hall issue and a new offer of a 10-cent-anhour wage increase.

Henry A. Wallace launched his campaign in the South Sunday night with a typical gesture. Speaking at Durham, N.C., he declared that the Progressive party was prepared to give the South a "real states' rights" program. Under this program, he told his audience, the South would be delivered from the economic bondage in which it is now held by "Wall Street and absentee industrial emperors."

While most of the United States sweltered during the recent heat wave, passengers aboard the Holland-America liner Veendam, bound here from Southampton and Rotterdam, were wearing fur coats, it was reported when the ship docked yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The ultimate objective of American policy must be "a real settlement" with the Soviet Union, while war with that country would "almost inevitably" result should the independence of Western Europe collapse in Soviet conquest, five central Western Democratic candidates for the Senate declared here tonight.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 30 -- A delegation of Western German MinisterPresidents told Generals Lucius D. Clay and Sir Brian Robertson, United States and British Military Governors, today, they planned to proceed Wednesday with the parliamentary assembly for a Western German Government regardless of the Moscow talks unless specifically ordered not to do so.

Standing committees of the Interstate Oil Compact Commission met in all-day sessions here yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt to complete reports on oil development and conservation studies made during the last several months. The reports will be submitted to the commission today and tomorrow.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- The fortyseven electors who will cast their votes for President and Vice President if the Republican party carries New York State this November were named today by the Republican State Committee.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 30 -- Gov. Lucio Cornejo of the northern province of Salta has publicly rebuked a civil judge for a decision that brought the national regime into disrepute when it was reported in the North American press.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -Following is the text of the Army's draft call today:

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- A month ago the Japanese Cabinet, primed by a letter of "advice" from Gen. Douglas MacArthur to Premier Hitoshi Ashida, issued an order banning strikes and collective bargaining among public employes. Today it is confronted with one of the most prickly political situations in Japan since the surrender.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -Top-seeded Miss Beverly Baker of Santa Monica, Calif., chalked up two victories today to advance to the third round of the thirty-first annual national girls' tennis championships at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

MT. PALOMAR, Calif., Aug. 30 -- A new three-cent postage stamp, honoring the Mt. Palomar Observatory, site of the recently installed 200-inch telescope, was placed on sale at ceremonies here today. The stamp, believed to be the first featuring an observatory, will go on general postoffice sale tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- This country has no choice other than to keep more than 1,000,000 men under arms until the United Nations has proved beyond all reasonable doubt that it can provide for our safekeeping and until this country is relieved of its occupation tasks, Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, asserted today.
PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 30 -- A four-day-old fire in the woods at Mount Abram, Franklin County, was the most serious of about a dozen blazes in Maine today, according to the State Forestry Commission.

Four of the ex-officio or socalled "synthetic" votes in the Tammany executive committee are scheduled to be restored by a change in the party rules at a meeting Thursday evening of the Democratic County Committee of New York County at Central Commercial High School, 214 East Forty-second Street.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30 -- One of the nation's oldest dwellings, the Mulford house which has been standing in this community since 1683, was purchased today by the East Hampton Historical Society, and thus saved from extinction.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 30 (AP) -The Russian puppet regime in North Korea, in a broadcast intercepted by the United States Army and made public today, has threatened to "destroy" the Government in the United States zone of South Korea set up after the election sponsored by the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations paved the way for its expected endorsement of the re-election of President Truman today with an all-out attack on the record of the Eightieth Congress as "a complete and abject failure."
Governor Dewey declared here yesterday that his campaign for the Presidency would be "intensive and rugged."

A proposed City Charter amendment reducing the transit fare to five cents and setting up a new Department of Transportation will be filed with the Board of Elections on Thursday, it was disclosed yesterday.

Acting on published charges by labor officials that the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, has been dominated by Communists, a subcommittee of the House Labor Committee will begin questioning past and present leaders of the union on Thursday.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 30 -- The Halle orchestra gave the first of two concerts in Usher Hall this evening and, under the direction of John Barbirolli, vindicated the honor of British orchestral playing, which, except at the opera, has not so far shone too brightly in the Edinburgh Festival.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 30 -William Wilton Tilton, a retired butcher who served a specialized public of North Shore estate owners for thirty-five years, is now catering to his own fancy. He raises dahlias in the gardens of his home on Forest Avenue, where passers-by stop their cars nowadays to wonder about the parasols that dot the grounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Air Force today suspended the fulltime operations of its "all-weather airline" which operated between the Clinton County Air Base at Wilmington, Ohio, and the Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Arnold Bernstein, New York ship operator, today described plans for operation of passenger services between New York and the Dutch ports of Rotterdam and Antwerp for round-trip fares ranging between $280 and $300, with a few accommodations possibly available at $250.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -A misty rain kept clockings well above record figures today in the second day of an international track meet, but a crowd of 12,000 was on hand to cheer another sweeping day of victory for American athletes.

KUALA LUMPUR, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- A total of 135 rebels have been killed and seventy-two wounded since the middle of June when Communist insurgent action flared up, a Government communique stated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -A high bid of $554,000 was submitted jointly today by L. B. Foster Company and Hamilton Company of Pittsburgh for the surplus New York Ordnance Works at Baldwinsville, N.Y. The War Assets Administration said two types of bids were asked, one on the works as a whole, including land, and another for improvements only, without the land.

ENOS SLAUGHTER is one chap who never could obey the sign: Walk. Do not run to the nearest exit. The tireless Cardinal outfielder never walks when he's on a ball field. He runs out to his position. He runs in from it. He even runs when he gets a base on balls, jogging rapidly down to first and then poising himself to tear around the paths at any opportunity.

In a report issued yesterday for publication today, Robert E. Gross, president of Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, disclosed that in the first half of 1948 the company cleared $5,310,151. Gross sales in the period were $65,981,050. The profit was in contrast to the net loss of $4,890,694 sustained in the 1947 half-year, and in addition a reduction of $34,000,000 was made in the company's bank debt.

Twenty teams, representing angling clubs from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania will fish it out in the sixth U.S. Atlantic Tuna Tournament, which opens this morning for a four-day run and will be based at Freeport.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A Canadian boat showed the way today on the first leg of a 335-mile international yacht race on Lake Ontario as three of the eighteen starters suffered mishaps in a twenty to twenty-five mile an hour wind.

WARSAW, Poland, Aug. 30 -Russian and Polish Orthodox churches have re-established relations as a result of negotiations in Moscow early this week between leaders of the Russian church and a Polish delegation headed by Archbishop Timoteusz of Bialystok

Directors of the Packard Motor Car Company declared a 20-cent dividend yesterday, payable to common stockholders on Oct. 18. This is 5 cents more than the disbursement in March, the only other made this year. In 1947 shareholders received only one dividend, 15 cents in April.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- While British police were keeping watch for a band of Zionist terrorists allegedly operating in this country, a young grocer from the East End of London was brought into court here today on a charge of possessing unlawfully a large cache of explosives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A group of ex-GI's carried to Capitol Hill today their complaint that they were better off financially as German war prisoners than as witnesses in the "Axis Sally" treason case.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- The United States role in the prospective fourpower talks on the introduction of Soviet currency into Berlin will be to prevent the Soviet Military Administration from winning complete economic domination and eventual political control of the city through the manipulation of currency.
Tens of thousands of young Americans who fought for their country in World War II registered for the draft yesterday for the second time in recent years.

Cecil B. De Mille, noted film producer, who left a $2,100-a-week radio job four years ago rather than pay a $1 assessment imposed by the American Federation of Radio Artists, will return to the microphone for the Mutual Broadcasting System, it was announced yesterday.

Walter Cartier, 161, the Bronx, knocked out Stanley (Baby) Sims, 160, Harlem, in 2:17 of the fourth of the listed eight-round feature bout at Croke Park before 3,500 fans last night. In the semi-final, a scheduled six-rounder, Jimmy Flood, 158, Yorkville, registered his fifteenth victory in succession by knocking out Pat Gill, 160, Harlem, in 54 seconds of the second frame.

A concerted effort to reduce freight losses and rates through a packaging and shipping standardization program has been launched on a national scope by the porcelain enamel industry, it was announced yesterday in Washington. The program is sponsored by the Porcelain Enamel Institute, national trade association of the enamelers and their suppliers.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A pair of ex-Brooklyn Dodgers kept Pittsburgh in the thick of the pennant fight tonight as the sizzling Pirates took their third straight from Boston's Braves, 2 to 1. Dixie Walker provided all the batting punch with a two-run homer in the first, while aging Fritz Ostermueller scattered nine hits.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- A "cruel waste of manyears," as well as of public funds, is being made by those vocational programs that are not equipped to train veterans for gainful occupations, Col. David B. Page, Deputy Administrator, United States Veterans Administration, told the American Legion convention today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The national military establishment put in a call today for 10,000 young men to be drafted into the new peacetime army during November.

KITAI, Sinkiang, Aug. 22 -- A continually restive international frontier runs through the remote snow-capped peaks of Peitashan (North Pagoda Mountain) along Sinkiang's northeast border. Maj. Gen. Han Yu-wen, commander of the Seventh Cavalry Brigade, noted here today that thirteen border clashes had taken place between Chinese and Outer Mongolian troops in this area since June, 1947.
RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Government announced today the recapture of Thayetmo, petroleum center held by rebel forces since Aug. 10.
Cotton futures closed unchanged to 11 points lower than Friday's final levels on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday after fluctuating narrowly throughout the session.

Net earnings of $3,651,000 for the six months ended on June 30 were reported yesterday by Jack Frye, president of the General Aniline and Film Corporation. These were equal to $4.98 a share on the common A stock and 50 cents on the common B stock.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- In a sharp rebuff to Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Jacob A. Malik here today the United Nations Security Council summarily rejected a Russian demand for an immediate "emergency" discussion of the Kashmir and Palestine problems.

United States industry and "American know-how" will be welcomed in Venezuela without any fear of discrimination, Romulo Betancourt, former president of Venezuela, told a group of American business leaders, bankers and officials of oil companies last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Federal Trade Commission's ruling

Louis J. Glickman has acquiredthe former Fanny Farmer CandyCompany factory at 79-89 CliftonPlace, near Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, from a client of Harry Halter,attorney. The brokers were Sigmund I. Natanson and Louis Carreau, Inc.
NAPANOCH, N.Y., Aug. 30 -Thirty-nine City College football candidates, headed by Coach Harold J. Parker, arrived today for five days of pre-season training and engaged in an afternoon workout.

Eleven young American singers will sail for Italy on the Queen Mary today to study for a year at the opera school carried on in conjunction with La Scala of Milan. They were selected from 150 applicants who received auditions in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

Mayor O'Dwyer will present a diamond ring at the Golden Anniversary Exposition, to the couple with the longest marriage record in this city, it was made known yesterday at Grand Central Palace. The announcement was made after the ceremony at which golden wedding rings were presented to twenty-six couples married fifty years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -The Senate Trade Policies Committee today asked chambers of commerce, trade associations and labor unions for information on the economic impact of the Supreme Court decision in the cement case.
Farms near the metropolitan area suffered a variety of losses -- and a few benefits -- as a result of the heat wave, a survey showed yesterday.

Rowland J. Miller, formerly general sales manager for appliances of Ohio Fuel Gas Company, serving communities from Cincinnati to Toledo, has joined Clayton Lambert Manufacturing Company as special assistant to Charles F. Lambert, president.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 30 -- Queen Wilhelmina, who will be 68 years of age tomorrow, rode into the central square, The Dam, this beautiful summer evening for the last time as ruler of the Netherlands. Many thousands of weeping, cheering citizens lined the route through the capital and were massed in front of the Royal Palace.

After several weeks of search, Michael Todd has finally found the performer to play the important role of the nation's first woman President in his forthcoming musical production. "As the Girls Go." She is Irene Rich, the well-known motion picture actress, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. Oksana S. Kasenkina is recovering so well at Roosevelt Hospital that no further operations will be required if her gain continues, the hospital reported yesterday. X-rays taken after an operation Saturday on her fractured right knee showed that "the bones are knitting very well," a hospital spokesman said.

The Twenty-third Street crosstown line of the New York Omnibus Corporation was halted for two hours last night after the drivers of nine buses refused to operate the vehicles in protest over the arrest of a fellow driver for parking in a restricted zone.

Horse-of-the-day honors went to Greentree Stable's Coincidence at Aqueduct yesterday as racing returned to the metropolitan area after the four-week time-out for the Saratoga Association's home meeting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -Six admirals have received new assignments the Navy said tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Jackie Pung of Honolulu and 14-year-old Marlene Bauer of Long Beach, posted par 76's today to share the lead in the qualifying round of the women's western amateur golf championship.

There is, understandably, confusion regarding blueberries, huckleberries, and allied family members. The Heaths have some 1,100 species divided among sixty genera. But without delving into family divergences too deeply, it must be said that when it comes to blueberry pie, the huckleberry is definitely out of the running.

First definite word was received here yesterday that the Economic Cooperation Administration has rejected the suggestion that ECA funds be used to free blocked dollar exchange credits due American exporters and forwarders in Latin America.

Howard Hughes, who owns a controlling interest in RKO-Radio Pictures, has concluded an agreement with United Artists whereby the Hughes Tool Company will invest "approximately $750,000" in three pictures to be delivered to U.A., according to Gradwell L. Sears, president of the distributing company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Hope for early correction of a situation whereby immigration of displaced persons to the United States has been reportedly halted abroad, was expressed by State Department officials today.

ATHENS, Aug. 30 -- Today's General Staff communique said the Greek Army troops fighting northeast of Kastoria in the new Vitsi offensive had "improved their positions." Front reports indicated the Communist-led rebels' resistence had appreciably stiffened on the approaches of Mount Vitsi.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The first refugees seeking permanent homes in the United States under the recently enacted displaced persons law, will leave for this country "within a matter of weeks," Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, stated here today.

MILFORD, Conn., Aug, 30 -High temperatures during the last few days suffocated the thousands of small fish that were found washed up on the beaches of the Woodmont section last night, a Government scientist reported this afternoon.

Alexander Stevens, alias J. V. Peters, was brought before the House Committee on Un-American Activities yesterday after a year's hunt and was denounced at a public hearing in the Federal Building here as a master of international Communist intrigue.

Saul Mills, secretary of the Greater New York CIO Council, ousted last week as a member of the CIO Community Services Committee, replied yesterday to the charges of "disloyalty" and "sabotage" made against him in the announcement of his dismissal.

George Whiteside, attorney for nine scheduled airlines operating at La Guardia Field, declared last night that legislation should be adopted at Albany removing the immunity of the Port Authority from lawsuits.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 30 -Eleven hours after the first round of the forty-eighth United States amateur golf championship was started at the Memphis Country Club, today, four former champions in the tournament as well as the defending titleholder had passed safely through the arduous test.

The Police Athletic League justifiably may claim a large share of credit for figures showing that in 1947 the Juvenile Aid Bureau arrested only 3,516 youngsters for various offenses, as compared to 4,683 the previous year. In 1910, when the city's population was far less than now, there were 10,914 juvenile arrests.

Coffee futures rose 5 to 6 points yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., with most of the activity centered in the 1949 positions. Trade houses were the suppliers of contracts and Brazilian interests were on the buying side. Sales totaled 7,000 bags.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- With the chess championship of the United States in the balance, Isaac I. Kashdan of New York and Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, who have shaken off the rest of the field in the tournament at the community center, were tied at 14 -- 4 at the end of the five-hour session of the nineteenth and final round tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 -A protest against proposed revision of the Byrnes-Blum agreement regulating the importation of American motion pictures into France, which was sent on Aug. 21 by Walt Disney Productions to Secretary of State Marshall is understood here to have at least temporarily delayed final action on the new pact.
ROME, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Communists shouted insults and trampled cigarettes tossed to Italians by American Catholic pilgrims at Genoa, members of the party said today.

Magistrate Peter Abeles in Bronx Magistrates Court dismissed yesterday a summons issued against an official of Americans for Democratic Action for using a loudspeaker without a police permit at a political street meeting.

The stock market was unable yesterday to hold its ground and, after a morning rally in the rails, prices reacted in the late trading to produce the sharpest drop in a week. The sudden reversal of form was not the result of bad news; in fact, the market had the advantage of generally favorable spot developments.

Morris Bienenfeld, who died in the Northwest Airlines plane crash, was the founder and president of Bestform Foundations, Inc., 64 West Twenty-third Street, manufacturers of girdles, corsets and brassieres. He lived at 1435 Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, and was 44 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -The Chicago White Sox came from behind in the ninth-inning with a five-run rally after two were out to defeat the Philadelphia Athletics, 9 to 6, before a crowd of 6,380, tonight. It was the A's second straight defeat at the hands of the White Sox in their current series.

Production of 16-inch metal television receiving tubes is now being carried on at the rate of 100 units a day. Samuel Kagan, president of the Tel-O-Tube Corporation of America announced yesterday at a demonstration at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- In a dancing breeze that started northwest, once fell flat but regained its feet, the National Women's sailing championship was started today by the American Yacht Club.

FAIRFIELD, Calif., Aug. 30 -Communist forces of North Korea may start guerrilla warfare with South Korea "as soon as the American troops pull out -- or maybe sooner," Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge said today on arrival at FairfieldSuisun Army Air Base from Seoul.

OXFORD, Ohio, Aug. 30 -- Protestant Episcopal laymen in the United States were urged today to follow the example of their British counterparts in carrying "the timeless good news of Christianity." The appeal was made by Samuel S. Schmidt of York, Pa., president of the organization, at the opening session of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew.

Questionable use of survey material in efforts to promote television is evident in a number of recent research studies of video audiences, a top research executive declared yesterday. "Misleading and dishonest use of research is already under heavy fire as harmful to all advertising, and it would appear obvious that this action would deter such practices in a new media," he commented.

The inquiry which began yesterday into the controversy between domestic airlines and the Port of New York Authority over financial terms for use of New York International Airport has great importance to the future of this city, not only as a center of air travel but also for its bearing on modernization of our seaport facilities.

Three pickets were arrested yesterday at the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation plant, 88-06 Van Wyck Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, as strikers tried to prevent workers from entering the plant. Magistrate John A. Dwyer in Rockaway Beach Magistrate's Court held them in $100 bail each for hearing on Sept. 16 in the same court.

Mayor O'Dwyer's "purge" of the city payroll to get rid of followers of Representative Vito Marcantonio began yesterday when the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity informed sixteen corporation inspectors, getting from $1,080 to $1,800 annually, that their services would not be required after tomorrow.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Committing nine errors in the second game, Syracuse dropped a double-header to Jersey City tonight, 4 -- 1 and 15 -- 11.
TAUNTON, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- The Australian Cricket Tourists beat Somerset by an innings and 374 runs here today.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Newspaper circles were virtually unanimous tonight in the opinion that the British Government neither would nor could allocate dollars to purchase newsprint in America, even were United States newspapers to make stocks available from their reserves.

SPINAGAR, Kashmir, Aug. 30 -Native Kashmiris, who lost their wives, families and homes when hordes of Pathan tribesmen swept into this state looting, burning and slaying last October, have been formed by the Indian Army into a militia and are the "most fiendish fighters on earth," says their commander, Col. B. M. Kaul.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- A true democracy is impossible without a free press, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared here today.

Nearly two years ago President Truman made a moving appeal for the admission of at least a few of the European displaced persons to this country and issued orders to the executive agencies concerned to do what they could within existing laws. Nothing much was done.
