ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- Before the largest weekday crowd of the season here, the Dodgers today completed a sweep of the fourgame series with the Cardinals by winning both ends of the doubleheader, 6 -- 5 and 6 -- 1, and took a little firmer grip on first place.
Three hundred veterans of the Eighty-fourth Infantry Division met yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel as members of the Railsplitter Society.

Already charged with illegal entry into the United States, Alexander Stevens, alleged Communist underground leader, who was also known as J. V. Peters, had two additional charges placed against him yesterday by the United States Department of Naturalization and Immigration.
GENEVA, Aug. 30 -- Restoration of Western Europe's imports from Eastern Europe to pre-war levels would cut Western Europe's trade deficit with the Western Hemisphere by about 30 per cent.

The Jack Smith show will discard its guest star policy on Monday, Sept. 13, adopting instead a schedule of appearances by performers who will become a regular part of the show. Consequently, Martha Tilton will be heard Mondays and Thursdays, while the Clark Sisters are to perform Tuesdays and Fridays.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Ohio Edison Company has been called for Sept. 20 to vote on an increase in the authorized common stock from 2,000,000 to 4,000,000 shares. All of the currently authorized shares are outstanding and the increase is necessitated by the company's plan to offer existing common stockholders the right to purchase 285,713 additional shares in the ratio of one share at $27.50 for each seven shares held.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Another East-West meeting was held in the Kremlin today and an authoritative source said the only bar to a procedural agreement on the Berlin impasse had been the insistence by a Western power on technicalities and phrasing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -Satchel Paige stopped Washington on seven hits here tonight as Cleveland mauled four Senator pitchers for 13 hits and a 10-1 victory. The victory moved the third place Indians within a game and a half of the league-leading Boston Red Sox.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago won the $12,500 Utah open golf championship today by defeating George Fazio of Conshohocken, Pa., in an eighteen-hole play-off.

The American Palestine Trading Corporation, which has been helping to finance developments in Palestine since 1942, announced yesterday the effectiveness of an offering of $10,000,000 of ten-year 3 per cent debentures to further this financing, especially for housing, transportation and industrial cooperatives for the new state of Israel.

Today one of the truly unique and outstanding characters of this city celebrates his ninetieth birthday. Charles C. Burlingham, a distinguished lawyer and a leader in almost every worth-while forward-looking civic enterprise in this great city for over half a century, is a wonderful man.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 30 -- The "hermit" of the New Jersey State Prison here, who twice cheated the electric chair because of a technicality in the law, died tonight in the prison hospital of old age and infirmities.

WINONA, Minn., Aug. 30 (AP) -An unexpected thirty-seventh body was recovered from the tangled wreckage of a Northwest Airlines plane today as authorities studied the debris to learn the cause of the crash, which occurred yesterday during a severe wind and electrical storm.

NIANTIC, Conn., Aug. 30 -- Ten years ago one of the many civic associations of which Charles C. Burlingham is a member adopted, on the occasion of his eightieth birthday, a formal resolution declaring that "the age of Charles C. Burlingham may not be measured on any dimensional basis."

PRAGUE, Aug. 30 -- The officials of the entire Pilsen district of the Sokol, one of the largest and most important sections within the national sports organization, have been expelled, according to an official announcement today.
Three former officers of the National Maritime Union, including Ferdinand C. Smith, one of the founders of the organization, were expelled from membership last night at a meeting in Manhattan Center.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores decreased 16 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Sales for the four weeks ended last Saturday were unchanged.
Hope that slumping waste paper prices will make their customary post-Labor Day recovery is being replaced by fear that the downward trend will continue, trade dealer spokesmen said yesterday.

During the recent war everyone willingly gave up a compelling voice in the foreign and domestic policies of our Government. We all thought a great deal and talked a great deal about these policies -- and we half suspected that what we said and thought might in some degree prove valuable knowledge for the beleaguered wartime Government.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 -- The use of inexpensive "expendable" cardboard pallets for long-distance freight shipments was appraised by a group of shipping experts as a distinct success today following the safe arrival here of a test cargo dispatched by ship from Brooklyn.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 30 (AP) -- No changes were reported early tonight in the respective Israeli and Arab positions in the disputed Red Cross area west of the former Government House in Jerusalem. Thus far, neither Egyptian nor Israeli troops have withdrawn from their established positions.
Five days of broiling heat ended yesterday but a new threat, the season's first hurricane, was causing growing concern in this area.
LEIPZIG Germany, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The famed Leipzig Industrial Fair, which used to attract buyers from all over the world, opened yesterday with only a handful of non-Germans present.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State, told a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities yesterday that he had taken every action that seemed warranted in 1939 after Whittaker Chambers had come to him with a story of Communist intrigue in Government circles.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 30 -- New Jersey legislative leaders announced tonight that action on a bonus for the state's veterans would be "left over" until Wednesday's session after a proposal for a twin increase in beer and gasoline taxes to support the bonus failed to muster sufficient votes at a party caucus.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 -President Truman asked Federal employes today to help rid the Government service of inefficient workers and those found to have subversive beliefs.

Long low fruit dishes and bowls that went on display yesterday in the gallery of Georg Jensen Inc., 667 Fifth Avenue, have unusual free-form shapes that make the accesories look decorative even when they are empty. Twenty pieces in the collection, which will be exhibited through Sept. 8, are the works of Rolf Key-Oberg, New York ceramist, who favors simple, modern shapes, line decoration and soft, earthy colors.

As director of the Pen Friends Division of the English-Speaking Union of the United States, A. B. Grant, a retired English business man, has become the catalyst par excellence of "pen friendships" that circle the globe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Cattle fed on diets deficient in copper have been observed to develop a disease resembling in many respects arthritis in humans, it was reported today at the annual autumn meeting here of the American Chemical Society.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- The feasibility of consolidating several midwestern Stock Exchanges to form a single large and powerful Exchange to serve the Midwest and central areas has been under discussion by brokers in several cities, it was learned today.
The possibility of a more severe break in grain prices this fall, which could have a corresponding effect upon food prices, was seen by commodity and grocery industry officials here yesterday.

A 493-page book published yesterday by Simon Schuster deals with nothing but the use of commercially frozen (or home frozen) products (pies, biscuits, cakes, cookies, vegetables etc.). "The Frozen Food Cook Book" the first of its kind, will be valued by those who (a) have access to a variety of frozen wares larger than those at the corner grocery, and (b) who have more space than the icecube compartment for storing purchases.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 30 (AP) -Andy Varipapa, Hempstead, N. Y., trick-shot artist, was named "bowler of the year" today by the National Bowling Writers Association.

Federal funds, quoted at 3/4 of 1 per cent on Friday, fell to 1/2 of 1 per cent yesterday. The member banks here, after reporting excess reserves of $15,000,000 on Wednesday, registered an improvement on this position to $137,000,000 by the end of the week -- $8,000,000 of which represented a decline in requirements.

Rumors that Gus Lesnevich, former world light-heavyweight champion, who will face Joe Walcott in one of the two headline attractions at Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City, on Sept. 21, had injured himself tumbling over one of his child's toys were dispelled by his manager, Joe Vella, yesterday.

MONTREAL, Aug. 30 -- Benjamin Carlin and his 31-year-old wife, Elinore, arrived in Montreal early this morning on the United States oil tanker New Jersey and said they expected to make a third attempt to cross the Atlantic in their twenty-four-foot amphibian craft "within three weeks, possibly from Halifax."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Western Pioneer Automotive Insurance Company, Oakland, Calif., has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 18,000 shares of $10 par value common stock that is to be offered publicly at $20 a share.

As a printer, now retired, I read with understandable interest anything about Gutenberg. So I read that his original Bible, insured at $500,000 by the City of New York, kept in the Public Library at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue, was transferred to the exposition of the Golden Jubilee at the Grand Central Palace.

Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, wartime head of the United States Office of Strategic Services, expressed the belief here yesterday that no vital wartime secrets had ever been turned over to unauthorized persons by members of that agency.

With Representative Vito Marcantonio describing Henry A. Wallace as "the lineal political descendant" of Franklin D. Roosevelt, the State Committee of the American Labor party last night nominated Mr. Wallace for President and Senator Glen H. Taylor for Vice President.

War is a preventable disease, a mass expression of neurotic disturbances that manifest themselves in the individual in such social forms a delinquency, divorce and suicide, Dr. Carl Binger, psychiatrist, declared yesterday on his return from London.

Frank (Spec) Shea, the Freshman sensation of 1947, when he helped pitch the Yankees to the world championship, regained a measure of last year's glory last night at the Stadium. Never better, the Connecticut Yankee fashioned his greatest mound performance as he blanked the Tigers, 3 -- 0, yielding only one hit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- In recent articles on the integration of the armed forces there was mention here of flaws in the so-called unification law which have hampered the Secretary of Defense, Mr. Forrestal, and it was suggested that his powers in formulating the military budget estimates are somewhat limited.

" The Set of the Sails," an autobiography by Alan Villiers, his first book in eight years, will be published by Scribner in October. The author of "Grain Race," "The Cruise of the Conrad" and "Sons of Sinbad" describes his experiences of almost thirty years under sail in British, Scandinavian and Finnish ships, whalers and Arab dhows.

Dr. Jan Papanek, Communistrepudiated Czechoslovak representative at the United Nations, charged yesterday that a secret medical report showed that Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk had been brutally murdered.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 30 -- At tonight's public session of the World Council of Churches, Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr of New York assessed the shortcomings of the church in the modern world and proposed a course for remedying them.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- Robert Schuman, Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Marie Cabinet, who was overthrown by a Socialist revolt in his Cabinet five weeks ago tonight, agreed today to make an effort to form a new Ministry. He said, however, that his task would not be easy.

SINCE 1932 a British aeronautical engineer named Nevil Shute has been industriously turning out a succession of entertaining novels. The eleventh is called, "No Highway"* and is published today. In all essentials it is much like the others, which means that it is readable, filled with interesting technical information, completely shallow in characterization and harmlessly sentimental in its point of view.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- The Soviet Union is in favor of open zonal frontiers, the lifting of all frontier barriers and the resumption of normal trade relations in the country, Walther Ulbricht of the Central Committee of the Communist party said today.

Thomas English Muffins, Inc., baking concern, has purchased from the Manqueen Corporation the two-story business building at 32-37 to 32-45 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, Queens. A purchase money mortgage of $45,000 was executed at the closing.

When the New York football Yankees play their second game in the All-America Conference on Sunday at Baltimore they will face two former teammates now playing with the Colts. They are Johnny Sylvester, fullback, and Ralph Stuart, center, who have been sent to Cecil Isbell's club by Ray Flaherty, Yankee coach.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 31 -- Youth delegates attending the first assembly of the World Council of Churches here received today an opportunity to air their own opinions on such subjects as war, communism and racial tensions.
Is there space in your columns for an American citizen's grateful acknowledgment of pleasure and profit in seeing a chapter of his country's history projected, unforgettably, in an art form?

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Another Soviet Army colonel, an aircraft engineer and rocket expert who asserts he has executed "special tasks" for Premier Stalin himself, has fled from the Soviet zone of Germany and taken refuge in this country.

PRESSMEN'S HOME, Tenn., Aug. 31 (AP) -- George L. Berry, president of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants' Union, AFL, took an indirect dig today at the International Typographical Union.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 31 -- The North Korea Soviet-controlled radio has announced that the "Supreme Korean People's Assembly" will meet for the first time in Pyongyang, capital of the Russian zone, on Thursday.

There is a new spirit on the countryside when September steps over the threshold. Gone are August's slow, slouching steps. The ninth month strides briskly over the land. There is an invigorating crispness at dawn when the sun lifts above the mountains. Flocks of goldfinches swirl over fields and gardens practicing maneuvers for the southward journey.

With their reserves of rich ore deposits in Minnesota's Mesabi Range rapidly diminishing, four iron and steel companies announced yesterday that they have banded together to purchase a substantial interest in Butler Brothers, a large operator on the Mesabi, to increase their holdings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -The Commerce Department said today it has under consideration a request to free some lumber products from export controls, including oak lumber generally and all hardwood flooring except oak.

READERS who appreciated the quiet distinction of William Maxwell's story of adolescent turmoil in the Middle West, "The Folded Leaf," won't want to miss Mr. Maxwell's new novel, "Time Will Darken It."* Unfortunately, although they will find many of the same virtues in this subtle and carefully wrought study of the clash of personalities and the slow corrosion of living, they probably will be disappointed.

A 4-year-old international air traveler named Etienne Bjorkvall-Garde is scheduled to fly from Long Island to the West Coast this morning watched over by forty-three husky "baby sitters" whose regular business is anything but tenderness.

WARSAW, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Communist-led Polish Government today arrested the Rev. Zygmunt Kaczynski, vigorous spokesman for the Catholic hierarchy and director of the Catholic weekly Tygodnik Warzawski.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Tender of 2,068,000 bushels of cash wheat and 8,720,000 pounds of lard on September contracts started liquidation today in those two commodities on the Board of Trade by longs who did not want to take delivery. The result was that wheat broke 3 cents a bushel and lard 30 cents a 100 pounds before the decline was checked.

"Take It or Leave It" maintained its hold on first place in the C.E. Hooper organization's latest assay of the popularity of evening radio programs. The report also stated that "Stop the Music" continued in second place.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 31 -- The Bulgarian Parliament today lifted immunity from seven of nine Social Democratic Deputies, six of whom were arrested and bound over for trial on charges of "anti-people's activity" during the past recess of Parliament.
Alexander Stevens, alias J. Peters, was identified yesterday by former party functionaries as the one-time representative of the American Communist party to the Comintern in Moscow.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 31 -Fourteen members of Princeton's 1947 "Big Three" championship football squad, including Captain-elect Ed Mead, will be among the sixty-two candidates for positions on this year's varsity eleven reporting to Coach Charlie Caldwell on University Field Thursday for the opening practice.

Because of serious congestion in the port of Bombay, India, which threatens, according to shipping men here, to "immobilize the port completely," shipping lines have placed a 25 per cent surcharge on rates covering all Bombay cargoes, it was announced yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- In their final action as a committee before the opening of the Parliamentary Assembly in Bonn tomorrow, the Minister-Presidents of the eleven Western states voted to extend a credit of 75,000,000 Deutsche marks to beleaguered Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The National Guard Bureau announced today that the Guard would not tolerate Communists in its ranks.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 31 -- A pair of young golfers, unheralded until today, assumed roles of importance in the United States amateur championship at the Memphis Country Club by eliminating two former holders of the title.

An extra dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 27, and a regular of 25 cents payable on Oct. 20, have been voted by Cunningham Drug Stores, Inc. Payments were 25 cents each in each of the three preceding quarters. The fiscal year ends on Sept. 30.

Attacking those who say that the reported profit figures of American corporations are greatly overstated because they include temporary or "paper" inventory profits, Prof. Charles A. Bliss of the Harvard Business School declares that business profits have not been inflated by rising inventory values.

TORONTO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Theodore S. Clark of the Sea Cliff (L.I.) Yacht Club took today's second race for the Star Class championship at the Canadian National Exhibition, leading a fleet of twenty-one boats. The victory and yesterday's second put him in the lead in the three-race series for the J.A. Scythes Trophy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today endorsed President Harry S. Truman for election in November. The vote was 35 to 12.
TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- The occupation authorities today move to meet a new Communist threat, this time on what might be called the "housewives' front."

FREEPORT, L. I., Aug. 31 -- Despite the threat of a wind of gale force reported moving northward from Hatteras, the sixty fishing cruisers bearing the contestants from twenty fishing clubs pushed through Jones Inlet at Daybreak this morning, opening the sixth United States Atlantic tuna tournament.

Harry C. Kane, attorney, was named yesterday as referee to take testimony and report on the advisability of merging the Surface Transportation Corporation with its parent organization, the Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The volume of installment credit rose $184,000,000 during July. On July 26 Congress, in special session, gave the Federal Reserve Board authority to reimpose controls on time-buying effective Sept. 20.

Lloyd L. Harvey has been appointed manager of the trade promotion office that the Port of New York Authority is opening today l in Washington in the StoneleighI Court Building, 1025 Connecticut I Avenue, N.W. In announcing the appointment, Howard S. Cullman, I chairman of the authority, said yesterday that Mr. Harvey had been executive general agent of i the Port of New Orleans with headquarters in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Witnesses for the United States Lines Company today described the proposed steamship service of the Arnold Bernstein Line as nothing new and of uncertain success.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Don Petty, general counsel of the National Association of Broadcasters, accused the Federal Communications Commission today of expressions which represented a degree of radio program "control" tantamount to being "thought police."

Your editorial entitled "Primaries and Non-Voters" was timely and instructive. The records of the Board of Elections in the City of New York show that 2,362,748 voters registered and enrolled in the four political parties in the City of New York in 1947. Yet, on Primary Day this year, only about 72,000 voters -- as one radio commentator facetiously put it -- were able to gather up enough strength to go to the polls.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Increased Federal aid to needy children was unanimously recommended in a report on public assistance issued today by the Advisory Council on Social Security headed by Edward R. Stettinius of the University of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, "respectfully" declined today to appear on invitation of a House Labor subcommittee to testify on communism in labor unions.

With an estimated 55,000 wartime babies now old enough to enter kindergarten, officials at the Board of Education were looking forward yesterday to an estimated public school enrollment of 883,096 boys and girls when the 1948-49 academic year opens on Sept. 13.
I have just been reading a letter by A.R. Lateiner in your columns on the subject of safety for scaffold workers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Although she has never before appeared on the screen, Joan Eunson, 14, daughter of Dale Eunson and Katherine Albert, New York magazine writers and playwrights, has been named by Samuel Goldwyn to play the title role in his forthcoming picture, "Roseanna McCoy."
A four-cornered race for one of the three vacancies on the Supreme Court bench in the First Judicial district appeared to be in prospect yesterday.

PRAGUE, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- Dr. Josef Beran, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Prague, today said the Czechoslovak Minister of Health, the Rev. Josef Plojhar, had received preferential treatment as a German priest in a concentration camp during the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Truman denounced today the acts of rowdyism throughout North Carolina against Henry A. Wallace, his Progressive party opponent, as "a highly un-American business" and as violating the national spirit of fair play.

Fifteen hundred persons attended a funeral service for Charles Evans Hughes, former Chief Justice of the United States and former Governor of New York, yesterday afternoon in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

A new plan under which community banks will be encouraged to handle the financing of appliance purchases by local Westinghouse dealers and their individual customers was announced yesterday by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Federal Works Administration tonight divided $450,000,000 among the states for highway improvements during the 1950 fiscal year beginning next July 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau led the Indians to a 6-to-1 victory over the Athletics tonight with a single, a double and a triple which drove in two runs. Relief Pitcher Bob Lemon retired three Philadelphians in succession without allowing a run after they had loaded the bases in the ninth with none out.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- Well-informed Japanese who are interested in the occupation's attempt to introduce democracy into local Japanese communities are considerably worried by the apparent apathy that is being displayed in municipalities outside Tokyo in regard to elections of local officials and by-elections for positions in the central Government.

Sale of a $1,000 debenture of the American Palestine Trading Corporation yesterday to Edmund I. Kaufmann, Jewish civic leader and philanthropist and president of Kay Jewelry Stores, marked the opening here yesterday of the first public financing enterprise undertaken for industrial and social development of the new state of Israel.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Baltimore, the home of Babe Ruth, today took steps to help in the campaign to fight cancer the disease which took the life of the home-run king.

A strike today by 40,000 truck drivers in the metropolitan area appeared likely early this morning as the result of first returns of a vote by members of Local 807, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, on a tentative agreement reached last week with five employer associations.
TROY, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- David Banks Plum, 78 years old, publisher of The Record newspapers, was killed instantly at 10 A.M. today when he fell twenty feet into a press pit.

The course of farm commodity prices is now receiving marked attention from retail concerns and buyers for stores in the agricultural areas, it was learned here yesterday. In some quarters, the view was held that a drop in agricultural commodities was the "only threat" discernible at this time to a record Christmas selling period.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- The Soviet sponsored Socialist Unity (Communist) party received "fraternal greetings" from the Communist party in the United States today as the struggle for control of the city continued.

The new Presto Fry-Master, a skillet-shaped pressure cooker, will be introduced with the National Pressure Cooker Company's largest black-and-white advertising campaign, it was announced yesterday. Ads will appear in newspapers in all United States cities having a population of 50,000, or more, and will start in the New York area and along the Eastern seaboard on Sept. 9. Ads in other areas will follow as distribution progresses.
W.H. Shepler has been appointed general service manager of Underwood Corporation. He succeeds George H. Crossan who will retire today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Long echoes of a wartime rift in State Department circles over the policy to be pursued toward Russia entered today into the investigation by the House Committee on Un-American activities centering on Alger Hiss.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Bear covering on the last day of the account sent prices up in most sections of the stock market here today.

Mr. Hugh A. Brown, who is an electrical engineer and therefore well informed in some phases of physical science, warns that the rapidly increasing weight of Antarctic ice can tip the precariously balanced earth at any moment, "just as you might roll a pumpkin over, so that a frosted side could thaw out in the sun."
SARANAC INN, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The New York State Publishers Association ended its semi-annual meeting here today.

Long lines of 24 and 25-year-olds clogged Selective Service offices all over the city yesterday as men waited from one to eight hours to register for the draft. The lines were much longer and the griping louder than on Monday, the first day of registration for America's second peacetime draft. There was much confusion at each of the twenty-two high schools where men were being registered, but no serious disorder.
The hurricane that had threatened the Atlantic seaboard for six days had barely blown to sea yesterday before warnings of another, moving up from the Caribbean, were posted.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- The Statei Board of Law Examiners announced today that 599 of the 1,184 applicants for admission to the bar l had passed the examination held June 24 and 25. Twenty-one of the-successful candidates are woInert.

Sophie, who is the dominant spirit of the Salon Moderne at Saks Fifth Avenue, opened yesterday the season, fashionwise, for the couture collections of New York City. She did it with great eclat. In her presentation she sounded the note for a return of glamorous formal attire.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Queen Wilhelmina told her people today that they must be "a strong people" if their wartime dreams of prosperity were to be realized.

A Presto pressure cooker shaped like a frying pan will be introduced in retail stores here about Sept. 10. In addition to its unusual design, the so-called Fry-Master is an innovation in another way. Besides cooking food, especially meat and poultry, under pressure, it doubles as a skillet or as a steamer -- an invaluable asset when storage space is limited.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. S.C. Steckler's Coyote scored a three-quarter-length victory over Jerry's Best today in the Toms River Purse. Touch Control, a fast finisher, was third, a neck farther behind, while Blue Fedora finished fourth among a half-dozen 3-year-olds.

Albert J. Fitzgerald, president of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, who has been named as a prospective witness in a House Labor Committee hearing on the union, termed last night the hearings an attempt to snatch "headlines" from the House Un-American Activities Committee.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- The four Military Governors of Germany met today in the Council Room of the Allied Control Authority Building to work out the manner in which a Moscow decision to give the Soviet Union the right to issue Berlin's only currency could be reconciled with four-power rule of the city and to discuss the technical procedure by which the Soviet Military Administration would lift the blockade of Berlin.

It would be curious, indeed, if the Port of New York Authority, whose chief purpose is to encourage commerce in this port and to develop its facilities, were to propose a course that was diametrically opposed to these purposes which it has pursued with vigor for a quarter of a century.

All consigned stock contracts for marketing steel pipe by Republic Steel Corporation terminate today, it was learned yesterday. It was estimated that about 50 per cent of the total national output of merchant pipe would be sold on a non-consignment basis after similar cancellations by other producers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Truman decided today to begin six weeks of intensive campaigning with a barnstorming tour of the farm belt and a major speech on the agricultural problem at Dexter, Iowa, on Sept. 18.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 31 -- A 14-year-old Italian war victim, cheered by a letter from 400 of his crippled friends in an Italian orphanage overseas, today underwent successfully an operation at Newark's Hospital and Home for Crippled Children, so that artificial arms might replace those he lost during a German bombing in 1943.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,341, compared with 1,688 last week and 304 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Food allowances for families on relief here will be raised by 25 per cent starting Oct. 16, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 31 -- As the United States trade advisory mission nears Rio de Janeiro, the Communist press is increasing its tirades against the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. has begun nationwide distribution of its 1948 midseason fall catalogue featuring price cuts in a wide variety of lines in addition to the display of the usual seasonal merchandise.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Republic Steel Corporation charges War Assets Administrator Jess Larson with making a misleading statement concerning its new contract to continue operating the Government's huge blast furnace in Cleveland. Its president, C.M. White, advised Mr. Larson in a telegram last night that the steel company has no intention of building any new facilities in order to supply foundries with pig iron after May 1, 1949.

CHAUTAQUA, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Support of the basic tenets democratic government and "new pioneering in international cooperation" were urged today before delegates from 150 New York State communities at the opening discussions of the seventh annual conference of the New York State Community Service Council of Young Adults.

Plans for reconstruction of City Hall Park, to convert what Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, calls a "nightmare" into a suitable setting for the historic seat of municipal government, were made available yesterday.

New securities offered publicly here in August consisted principally of State and municipal bonds and public utility stocks, with the total of bonds marketed the largest for any August in over twenty years and the stock emissions the heaviest for the month since 1946.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 -- Marshal Tito shook up his Cabinet today and established a stronger front against the Communist Information Bureau's challenge to his leadership. Elevated to more strategic posts were Vice Premier Edvard Kardelj and Interior Minister Col. Gen. Alexander Rankovitch.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Development of a new chemical shown in tests on animals to produce "the most lasting effects of any drugs of its kind" in lowering blood pressure was reported here today at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.
GENEVA, Aug. 31 -- The United States has launched a drive to get the European countries to stop their wastage of fuels.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Tucker Corporation, builder of an as yet unmarketed new type automobile, today was named defendant in a Federal court suit for an unspecified amount of salary, commission and bonus.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Former Judge John J. Rafferty of the State Court of Errors and Appeals, spokesman for the four Roman Catholic dioceses in New Jersey, indicated today that there might be some opposition on their part to the proposed $50,000,000 state bond issue for hospitals and additional buildings for Rutgers University and the State Teachers College.

The Port of New York Authority defended yesterday its $114,000,000 port rehabilitation program against charges that it proposes unreasonable pier rentals that would drive shipping away and that the Authority would make a "profit" of $60,000,000 out of the proposed fifty-year rental of the city-owned piers.

Of all the requests being submitted by city departments to the City Planning Commission for major improvements to be included in the capital outlay budget, none strikes us as more poignant than that of Raymond Hilliard, the Commissioner of Welfare. Here is a department that must deal with people who are down and out, who are unfortunate and who need hope and encouragement as well as more material and physical aid.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- Still being tossed about wildly on the sea of misfortune, the Giants bowed into their seventh straight defeat at Forbes Field tonight as the Pirates charged to a position two games off the National League lead on a 5-4 victory.
Plans for a three-year study to determine the psychology that underlies the decisions that businessmen make and their effect on future business developments were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The United States Government, it was revealed today, has undertaken a basic review of its reparations policy in Germany to determine whether it is entirely consistent with the objectives of the European Recovery Program.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The seventy-two-foot Canadian ketch Nonchalant docked at 11:38:05 A.M. today to complete a grueling 335-mile Lake Ontario distance regatta with an elapsed time of 41 hours 35 minutes 38 seconds.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- In a finish that was hailed fully as a grandstand one. Miss Aileen Shields today won the national women's sailing championship and its emblematic novelty, a silver beer stein.

An agreement under which the Sunday afternoon broadcasts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra over the facilities of the Columbia Broadcasting System will be sponsored this season is being negotiated with the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), it was reported yesterday.

Standby offerings of common stock to stockholders now in progress instance the efforts being made by West Coast banking and insurance enterprises to increase capital so that such funds can keep pace with the increasing economic activity of the California region.

Ten executives in the field of Jewish social work received yesterday the first certificates to be issued by the Jewish Communal Service Training Bureau, 145 East Thirty-second Street. They had completed a fifteen-month course of study, including nine months of supervised placement work.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Red Munger hurled the Cardinals to a 5-to-0 victory over the Phillies tonight and put St. Louis back in the National League race. Enos Slaughter, who celebrated his "day," stopped a brief hitting spree by Philadelphia with a sensational catch and batted in Stan Musial with the final run.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The quota system used for Negroes during World War II is not part of the new peacetime draft, according to an announcement by military authorities today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Navy today backed a proposal that 40,000 tons of steel a month be set aside for construction of eighty-one oil tankers.

For the next five years Australia plans to broaden its basic industries rather than develop further the "superstructure" of consumer goods industries, H.P. Breen, director of the industrial division of the Australian Ministry of Postwar Reconstruction, said here yesterday.
Orvis Brothers Co., commodity and stock brokers, have opened an office in New Orleans with Edwin G. Pinac, a member of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange, as manager.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 31 -- The international committee of the Red Cross and the League of Red Cross Societies have developed a working plan for relief in the Middle East, President Paul Ruegger of the former and Basil O'Connor, chairman of the board of governors of the latter body announced today.

Flying high with a six-run lead over the Browns last night, the Yankees suddenly slipped into a dizzy tailspin that gave 41,335 witnesses at the Stadium an acute case of the jitters before they righted themselves to land safely with a 10-9 triumph over the lowly St. Louis club.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -Miss Beverly Baker of Santa Monica, Calif., continued her sweep through the National girls tennis championship today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club, but two other seeded stars were eliminated as the field was reduced to sixteen.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Pensions for veterans of all wars of the United States, putting World Wars I and II on an equal footing with Spanish War veterans in that respect, were urged in a resolution adopted by the New York State American Legion at today's session of its thirtieth annual convention. The plan proposes $55 a month at the age of 55 years and $60 a month at 60 years.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Lefty Mel Parnell maintained his perfect record against the Tigers by holding them to eight scattered hits as his Red Sox protected their slim American League lead with an 8-4 victory tonight before a capacity crowd of 33,310.

The railroad issues showed to advantage yesterday in relation to the rest of the stock market as prices closed the month on an irregularly lower note. Changes throughout the session were narrow, except in isolated instances, with the composite rate declining 0.51 point due to another sharp decline in the industrial components, especially in the key chemicals.
PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, after a cautious statement of policy to the National Assembly, tonight obtained a vote of confidence of 322 to 185, investing him as Premier.
PRAGUE, Aug. 31 -- The condition of 64-year-old former President Eduard Benes was said tonight to be extremely serious, in an announcement by his doctors from his summer home at Sezimovo Usti.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 -- The time has come when gains made by veterans since the end of the war should be solidified and made permanent, Carl R. Gray Jr., Veterans Administrator, told the forty-ninth annual encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today.
Virtually no major opera house or symphony orchestra in the world expects to pay its own way next season or in the foreseeable future.
The San Francisco Housing Authority announced yesterday the sale of $3,194,000 of short-term notes maturing Feb. 25, 1949, to Salomon Brothers Hutzler at a bid of 1.16 per cent interest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Miss Alice Bauer, 20-year-old Long Beach girl, chalked up a first-round upset in the women's Western amateur golf championship today when she defeated Mrs. Jackie Pung of Honolulu, 1 up.

Nine scheduled airlines using city airports wound up two days of testimony before Commerce Commissioner Edward C. Maguire yesterday with additional complaints against operating policies of the Port Authority.

As a result of Mayor O'Dwyer's recent decision to abandon the proposal for an annual tax of $5 on passenger automobiles and $10 on commercial vehicles, the City Council formally killed the measure yesterday by a vote of fifteen to two.
Demand for petroleum products will be 7 per cent greater this winter than last winter, it was estimated yesterday by the Economics Advisory Committee of the Interstate Oil Compact Commission.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Completely shackled by the almost perfect pitching of Hank Borowy in the first game and baffled by their own general ineptitude in the second one, the proud Dodgers today dropped both ends of a double-header to the Cubs, 3--0 and 7--2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Ed Stewart and Al Evans blasted inside-the-park home runs tonight as Washington raked Chicago pitching for fourteen hits and a 7-1 victory. Sid Hudson, who limited the White Sox to Four hits, scored his first victory since June 20 and his fourth against thirteen defeats.

Net sales of Servel, Inc., for the nine months ended with last July increased 39 per cent to a new high mark of $54,136,500 from the $39,004,600 volume for the corresponding period of the previous year, Louis Ruthenburg, president, reported yesterday.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in August was the smallest since the corresponding month of 1947. Sales were below the million-share mark in every session except that of Aug. 11, when the turnover was 1,307,150 shares.

An Army chaplain presented yesterday at the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, 120 Broadway, a check of $4,200 for treatment of an 8-year-old daughter of a civilian worker at the United States Air Force base in Newfoundland who had been stricken two years ago with poliomyelitis.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Col. Gen. Andrei A. Zhdanov, chief of the Communist Information Bureau, secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party and regarded as one of the most likely successors to Premier Stalin, died today, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

The world heavyweight boxing picture, muddled since Champion Joe Louis announced his contemplated retirement, is beginning to take on a clearer hue as the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday disclosed that it had signed Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati and Joe Baksi of Kulpmont, Pa., for a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 12.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -- As the Sept. 2 deadline for a threatened West Coast maritime strike drew near, negotiators for the Waterfront Employers Association and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, held afternoon and evening sessions today.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, issued a call last night to the Dress Joint Board, an affiliate of the union, to raise a $100,000 political fund to help elect President Truman and defeat members of Congress who voted for the Taft-Hartley Act.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- The death of Mr. Zhdanov removes from the Politburo, the real government of the Soviet Union and of international communism, one of the principal forces in the direction of the world-wide Communist crusade for power and a leading aspirant for Premier Stalin's position upon the latter's death.

Hezekiah Cobb says he doesn't want to bore his city friends with rustic lore. But he'd like to remind us that our esteemed eigtheenth-century forebears attached great importance to a long view of things, for'ard and aft, to put it so.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- A competitive battle for patronage of British filmgoers will open here Oct. 1 between British and American film producers, Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers Association of America, declared today at a press conference here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The State Department announced today that Ugo Carusi, chairman of the Displaced Persons Commission, who will fly to Germany Monday, would meet immediately with military and consular officials, representatives of the International Refugee Organization and voluntary agencies, and others participating in the displaced persons resettlement program.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- Laurence F. Whittemore, 54-year-old president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, was elected today president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. His election came at the first meeting of the board of directors of the railroad to be held in Boston in twenty-five years.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Boston's Braves climbed to within two percentage points of the pennant-chasing Dodgers tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Reds. Red Barrett limited Cincinnati to seven hits and the Reds' only run came on Grady Hatton's ninth homer.

Indique carried the colors of Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin to victory in the Southport Purse, mile and a sixteenth feature at Aqueduct yesterday. Under the expert guidance of Doug Dodson, the 5-year-old son of Andy K. crossed the finish line two lengths ahead of the Sanmar Stable's Fulgor II, while the favored Cencerro, sent off at 29 to 20, could do no better than third.
Col. Gen. Andrei Alexandrovitch Zhdanov, Premier Stalin's deputy for the Communist party of the Soviet Union, was one of Russia's top half-dozen leaders.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 31 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands celebrated the golden jubilee of her reign today on her sixty-eighth birthday. The entire country heralded the event, made more poignant by the knowledge of her coming abdication in a few days.

International control of atomic energy will be the chief problem before before the coming session of the United Nations General Assembly, Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States representative on the Security Council, said yesterday as he boarded the liner Queen Mary bound for the meeting.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 31 -- Henry A. Wallace and his retinue of political associates headed for the deep south tonight after a turbulent day which saw irate Southerners continue to pelt the Wallace group with eggs and tomatoes until they reached this resort city in the western hills of North Carolina.

Today opens the season for oysters. Today you may order oysters to the limit of your appetite and pocketbook because September has an "R" in it and, by the well-publicized slogan, "Oysters R in Season."

Whether Henry Wallace's non-segregation trip through the South will be helpful to interracial relations there, whether it will help break down the barriers of prejudice that stand between the man of color and that equality of opportunity that is a basic American principle is, we believe, beside the point.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The Midlands Conference of thirteen Democratic candidates for Senator and Governor in eight Central states adjourned today with a "Midlands Declaration" in which support was welcomed from "liberal-minded independents and rank-and-file Republicans."

The Museum of Modern Art opens to the public today an exhibition which looks backward on a museum activity that has closed and looks forward to an enlargement of the activities in a new project. The exhibition consists of painting, drawing, sculpture, woodworking, ceramics and design executed in classes of the War Veterans Art Center during the four years which ended on June 30.

THE Detroit Tigers going nowhere in particular this season despite the fact that they supposedly possessed the strongest pitching staff in either major league. That's what it appeared to be in the spring and that's why the majority of the so-called experts picked them to finish third. Steve O'Neill's hurlers had such overpowering class that they certainly could more than compensate for a lack of balance elsewhere.

The names of ten present or former Government officials alleged by Whittaker Chambers to have been members of a ring that turned over confidential information to Soviet agents have not yet been made public, it was asserted yesterday by Isaac Don Levine. Mr. Levine sought in 1939 to bring Mr. Chambers' story to the attention of the late Franklin D. Roosevelt.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 31 -- Several hundred million dollars' worth of art treasures from many parts of the world were transferred here this afternoon to the custody of the German authorities. Chief among the assets involved were the art collections of Adolf Hitler and Hermann Goering.

The protracted Moscow negotiations achieved their first positive result when the American, British, French and Russian Military Governors resumed their meetings in Berlin in an effort to work out detailed arrangements for solving the currency problem and ending the Russian blockade of the German capital.

"Blackstone and White Rock," by Milton Farber, is an autobiographical account of the law and its practice in a small town in the Middle West. Mr. Farber got his early training as a lawyer in "The White House" saloon, rustling sandwiches and booze for his mentor, "Justice" Ankrom, part-time blacksmith and ranting attorney.

Something else that the heat wave did was knock the price of lemons up into the high branches. California growers and shippers kept up all right with the busy fruit extractors in homes and bars but wholesale prices yesterday were more than double those of a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Attorneys for Otis Co., Cleveland investment bankers, indicated today they would attempt to postpone a hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission which has been set for Sept. 20 to determine whether the company's broker-dealer registration should be revoked.

WARSAW, Aug. 31 -- Differences within the Polish Communist party involving Vice Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka have been sufficiently healed for the moment at least to allow him to return to work, it was reported authoritatively today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closed 1 to 13 points net higher.

BALBOA, C.Z., Aug. 31 (UP) -- Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, was among eight men charged today by the District Attorney of the Canal Zone, Daniel E. McGrath, with "conspiring to obstruct justice."

Americans desiring to make charitable, personal and family remittances to the United States, British and French occupied zones of Germany will be enabled to do so for the first time under arrangements announced here yesterday.

J. J. Slater opened a new shoe shop at Fifty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue yesterday, ninety years after James and John Slater started the business with their first shop on Cortlandt Street in downtown New York.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -A deadlock for medalist honors resulted when Thomas J. Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club and William Kuntz of the home club each posted 71 in the Westchester County amateur golf championship over the Bonnie Briar Country Club course today.
MAIDSTONE, England, Aug. 31 -- Blue skies and warm sunshine have suddenly smiled on the rich farms and orchards of Kent, the "garden county" of England.

PRAGUE, Aug. 31 -- Under new regulations now being introduced workers in the Czechoslovak mining districts will be subject to investigation by members of the Mine Council, who are nearly all Communists, if they fail to report for work regularly.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Some Hudson River shipping interests today opposed the proposed plans for a $14,000,000 bridge to span the river from Kingston to Rhinecliff.

The controlling interest in five acres of waterfront property and two Hudson River piers in Hoboken, N.J., has been sold to the Todd Shipyards Corporation, it was announced yesterday afternoon by William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, Inc., of 383 Madison Avenue.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The chess championship of the United States, which hereto-fore has been well-nigh monopolized by Samuel Reshevsky of Roxbury, Mass., passed into new hands today when the biennial meeting of the United States Chess Federation, in session at the Community Center since Aug. 10, was concluded.

Two new films are due in town today. The Paramount will present Hal Wallis' production, "Sorry, Wrong Number," based on the popular radio-drama. Barbara Stanwyck and Burt Lancaster are the principals and the supporting company includes Ann Richards, Wendell Corey and Harold Vermilyea...

Highly pleased over Monday night's reception of "The Silver Whistle" in Westport, the Theatre Guild yesterday confirmed its intention of bringing the Robert McEnroe comedy to New York as its first entry of the new season. This step was corroborated by Lawrence Langner, co-administrator of the Guild.

All post-war trading records in hide futures were broken yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, Inc. Heavy selling occurred in the December and September contracts particularly and drove prices down 190 to 100 points in those deliveries. The more distant deliveries of March and June, 1949, sold 90 to 60 points lower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, New York, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell, at par, one-year promissory notes aggregating $5,000,000 and bearing interest at the rate of 3 1/2 per cent per annum.

One frequently hears mention of the need for water conservation, for new sources of water and water metering. Mention of water conservation sounds like a good project to the civic-minded, but to those more directly concerned with the project there is a serious confusion of mind.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 31 -- Max Stark of 721 Mildred Avenue, Teaneck, charged with operating a check-cashing business for New Jersey gamblers and for New York patrons who attended the Park Avenue "charity" games, was cited for contempt of court here today when he refused to reveal to the Bergen County Grand Jury or to Common Pleas Court Judge A. Demorest Del Mar his list of customers.

The New York Board of Rabbis has joined the nine other organizations supporting the suit brought by two Brooklyn parents against the Board of Education and the State Education Commissioner to end released-time religious instruction in the New York public schools, it was learned yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 1 -Its guns trained on a major ninegame schedule that includes opposition from the East, South, Midwest and Far West, Army launched its fifty-eighth football season in earnest today. Heavy contact work predominated.
PRAGUE, Sept. 1 -- The present Czechoslovak Government is now undertaking before the courts to break the reputations of two of the Communists' principal opponents here.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Premier Stalin, his bare head bowed, joined the guard of honor tonight at the flag-draped bier of Col. Gen. Andrei A. Zhdanov, the man many thought would succeed him.

Next to white potatoes and cauliflower, the best known product of Long Island vegetable farms is lima beans. This year, to enhance further the reputation of their crop, farmers around Orient, Cutchogue, Peconic and Southold are grading and cleaning their beans as soon as they are picked.

Your editorial "Housing Costs Still Rise," which appeared in THE TIMES of Aug. 24, should be read and carefully considered by all Americans appreciative of our national background and who are also concerned with the America of today and tomorrow.

MADRID, Sept. 1 -- The Spanish Cabinet, meeting in Generalissimo Francisco Franco's summer palace in San Sebastian, decreed tonight that local elections would be held in the nation's 9,620 municipalities during the first part of November.
INTERLAKEN, Switzerland, Sept. 1 -- The second European Parliamentary Congress got off to a shaky start today, lacking several delegations and feeling the absence of leaders.

A contract was signed yesterday by officials of the national board of the Y.W.C.A. with the United Social Agencies Employes, Local 1, an affiliate of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

An offer by the Soviet Consulate here to pay the hospital bills of Mr. Oksana Stepanovna Kasenkina, the Russian school teacher who leaped from the window of the East Sixty-first Street building, was disclosed yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Federal Judge Gunnar H. Nordbye has approved an amended plan for stockholders' participation in dissolution of the Northern States Power Company, a Delaware corporation.

Cooler weather performed a double service for New York and other areas along the northeastern seaboard yesterday. Temperatures near record lows for the date completed the welcome shift from last week's sizzling heat. In addition, the advancing cold front pushed the northeast-bound hurricane farther out to sea.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Julian Huxley, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, issued a strong criticism today of the recent World Congress of Intellectuals at Breslau [Wroclaw], to which he had been invited as one of its five chairmen.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UP) -- The United Auto Workers, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, reached a contract agreement early today with International Harvester Company today and ended its sixteen-day-old strike against the firm.

Four New York-bound passenger vessels have been delayed from fifteen to twenty-four hours by the tropical hurricane that was reported yesterday to be blowing itself out in the North Atlantic after threatening the Atlantic seaboard as far north as Cape Hatteras for the last six days.
Faced by deficits that appear to be inevitable for years to come, many of America's music organizations plan to turn to the Federal Government for a measure of relief, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission assured all radio stations today that they will not be punished if they refuse broadcast time to atheists.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 1 (AP) -The votes of Louisiana's country people put Russell Long, son of the late Huey P. Long, 6,950 votes ahead of Judge Robert Kennon today in a race for the United States Senate.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- In an effort to contest the validity of the new Danubian statute agreed to by the roughshod majority rule of the Soviet Union and its satellite states at the recent Belgrade conference, Great Britain and France are understood to plan to request the International Court of Justice to review the legality of the arrangement sponsored by the Moscow bloc.

There are certain everyday services on whose continuing performance the complex life of New York City is peculiarly dependent. When any of these functions is suspended it means at best widespread public inconvenience and serious economic loss; at worst the toll may have to be counted in terms of impaired public health and even in the loss of human lives.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission received today from its Division of Public Utilities a recommendation that it approve a plan of reorganization of the Electric Power and Light Corporation, subject to modification covering the participation of the $7 second preferred stock.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 -- A miniature battle, fought last night around Mount Zion, re-emphasized Jerusalem's desperate need for a really effective settlement to supersede the present patchwork system of truce enforcement.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 1 -- Another Atlantan loomed on the golfing horizon today in the person of Gene Dahlbender Jr., who defeated, in successive rounds, the defending titleholder and the country's top intercollegiate player in the United States amateur championship at the Memphis Country Club.

The basing-point decision by the United States Supreme Court in the case against the cement industry was aimed at collusive action and injury to competition, according to Corwin Edwards, chief economist of the Federal Trade Commission.

The New York Age of 230 West 135th Sweet, one of the oldest Negro newspapers in the country, has been sold to a white Englishman who said yesterday that he wanted to live among Negroes the rest of his life, and make their battles his battles.

Louis F. Budenz, who once was an editor of The Daily Worker and who renounced Communism in 1945, named Alexander Stevens, alias J. Peters, yesterday as the chief underground link between the Communists here and the Soviet secret police.

LONDON, Sept. 1-- Calling for 100,000 volunteers for Britain's Territorial Army, which is the equivalent of the United States National Guard, Secretary for War Emmanuel Shinwell declared tonight that the possibility of trouble in the world was much more likely than it appeared twelve or eighteen months ago.

LONDON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The death of Mr. Zhdanov appeared today to have opened a way to end the row between the Soviet-dominated Cominform and Yugoslavia. It also removed a major obstacle in the path to power of Foreign Minister Molotov, whose name has rivaled that of Mr. Zhdanov in speculation over a successor to Premier Stalin.

More steel must be made available to the American oil industry if it is to meet the increasing demands of the public for petroleum fuels, William J. Murray Jr., a member of the Texas Railroad Commission, told the Interstate Oil Compact Commission yesterday at its closing session here in the Roosevelt Hotel.

The stock market broke the stalemate yesterday and, in volume unmatched in more than a month and gains unsurpassed since mid-May prices, climbed 1 to 2 points. Spearheading the advance were some of the prime industrial issues such as United States Steel, Bethlehem and du Pont, with the quality of trading unequaled in several months.

ON a tropical evening last week we dozed while reading "One Clear Call,"* the latest -- although merely the ninth -- volume in Upton Sinclair's guntherized, perpetual-motion historical novel of the modern world, and dreamed we were talking to the hero of it himself, Lanny Budd, the Tom Swift. of destiny.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Coincidence altered abruptly today the course of a move to ask the United Nations to help Sidi Mohamed al-Moncef, exiled ruler of Tunisia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Adolf A. Berle Jr. spoke to the House committee out of a rich and active experience in the guerrilla wars of the Roosevelt Administrations when he described how the Communist apparatus in this country captured and hopefully prepared for future service an unknown number of young intellectuals in the Government.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Favorites crashed through to the quarter-finals today with second-round victories in the women's Western amateur golf championship.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Red Sox held their one-game American League lead today by defeating Detroit, 10-1, for right-hander Jack Kramer's fifteenth victory. It was the Tigers' final visit to Fenway Park, where they lost nine of eleven games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Applications of three southwestern companies to expand their pipelines for the transmission of natural gas between Texas and California went today to the Federal Power Commission for a decision.
The income of 260 hospitals in and near New York will be affected directly from now on by the fluctuations of two Federal cost- of-living indices.

Life's strongest love is not that of a man for a maid but that of a woman for a postcard. It takes precedence over the maternal instinct, the instinct that yearns for a new dress, hat and handbag, and the one that prefers restaurant food over that cooked by herself.

A tall and a short man worked a $20 swindle last night on the cashier of the Alden Theatre, a motion picture house at Broadway and Sixty-seventh Street, and were trying the same thing at the Studio Theatre, Broadway and Sixty-fifth Street, when a pistol-carrying hold-up man interrupted and took $400 from the cashier's till.
Temple's jewelry store at 732 Fifth Avenue, opposite Tiffany's, lost a $1,450 diamond wedding band yesterday in a strange theft.

NANKING, Sept. 1 (AP) -- China has secretly barred all foreign planes except Russian from far northwest Sinkiang Province in what some quarters interpret as appeasement of Moscow, it was disclosed today.
Mr. and Mrs. Ellis S. Middleton of Stamford, Conn., came home yesterday after visiting the grave of their son in a United States military cemetery in Belgium.

The American-Hawaiian Steamship Company has rejected an offer by the Maritime Commission of $158,000 as insufficient compensation for one of the eight vessels requisitioned from the company by the Government during the war, Edward P. Farley, chairman of the company's board of directors, said yesterday.
QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 1 -- Ecuador is expected to have real freedom of the press under President Galo Plaza Lasso, who started a four-year term today apparently with great popular support.

A newspaper advertisement calling for "one girl who speaks New Yorkese, has bad diction and careless enunciation" has brought a surprising response to radio station WNEW, which is preparing a new program on "How to Speak Better English."

It is heartening to learn that, at the conclusion of its second term of operation, the Court Street School for Migrants in Freehold, N.J., is considered a pronounced success. Since it is supposed to be the only school of its kind in the United States, it now may well serve as an example that will be copied elsewhere.

The Browns don't beat the Yankees often but they don't give up easily, either. It took the Bombers twelve innings to edge out the lowly St. Louis entrant, 5--4, in another harrowing contest at the Stadium yesterday.
The city and nearly 200 business concerns appointed special assistants yesterday to help Selective Service officials register men in the 18-to-25 age group for the draft.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 1 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club and Mrs. F.K. Thayer Jr. of Piping Rock shot 36, 35 -- 71 to win low gross honors in the one-day best-ball tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association over the Nassau Country Club course today.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept 1 (AP) -- A $4 a week wage increase for 12,000 telephone operators employed by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company was ordered today by an arbitration panel. A similar increase was granted Monday to maintenance workers by another panel. Today's award was retroactive to Aug. 1.

The Isthmian Steamship Company has suspended for two months a freight rate increase originally scheduled to go into effect yesterday on shipments from Hawaii to United States Atlantic and Gulf Coast parts, it was announced yesterday.
The State of New Jersey announced yesterday that it will receive bids Sept. 21 on an issue of $5,000,000 of highway bonds, dated July 1, 1948, and due July 1, 1950 to 1983.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 1 -- Military Government officials of the United States zone have been notified from Berlin that Gen. Lucius D. Clay has disapproved the transfer to occupation costs of the information centers and reading rooms originally provided as a United States gift to the German people.

STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 1, (AP) -- Hjalmar Schacht was acquitted by a German appeals court today on charges he was a major Nazi offender. The former wizard of German finance still was held in an internment camp tonight, however, pending a United States Military Government decision on the validity of the verdict.

The American Gas Electric Company announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the Indiana and Michigan Electric Company, had started construction of a new $15, 000,000 steam power plant near Lawrenceburg, Ind. The plant will have a capacity of 185,000 horse-power (137,500 kilowatts) and is expected to go into operation in December, 1950.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 25, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- Pension increases for the dependents of dead and seriously disabled veterans went into effect today.
Robert H. Andrews has been appointed assistant to the president of Houdry Process Corporation, Philadelphia. He also will serve as assistant secretary and assistant treasurer of the corporation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 1 -- Nordic customs union and adherence of the Scandinavian countries to an eventual European customs union were discussed by the Ministers of Denmark, Iceland, Sweden and Norway during a two-day conference that ended here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The American Association of Railroads announced today that an embargo on virtually all freight shipments to West Coast ports would become effective tomorrow if a maritime work stoppage developed there.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren of California, Republican vice presidential candidate, will open a tour of five eastern states with a rally in New York Sept. 30.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- A wage increase of five shillings (about $1) a week was recommended for machinists and other metal workers tonight by a court of inquiry set up to examine wage claims of about 2,000,000 workers engaged in that industry.

A group of thirty hand-blocked prints displaying an unexpected mixture of New England motifs with advanced abstract design was the high spot of yesterday's opening at the decorator's showroom of Arundell Clarke, 31 1/2 East Sixty-fifth Street.

The New York Giants will appear in nine of the twelve professional football games booked for ABC's Eastern television network, of which WJZ-TV is the outlet here. The pick-ups of the local team will cover its complete home schedule of six contests and three out-of-town engagements in Boston, Washington and Philadelphia.

Directors of the Continental-United Industries Company, Inc., and the American Steel Copper Industries, Inc., have approved a merger of the two companies and have ordered that the proposal be submitted to stockholders at special meetings, it was announced yesterday by Ernest G. Jarvis, president of Continental-United.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 25 James Luckman, a former missionary to Ethiopia, protested against the return to Italy of her pre-World War I colonial possessions. His protest is based on three false axioms.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- Leading independent film producers appeared uncertain here today as to just what course they will take in connection with the showing of their pictures in Great Britain now that the Motion Picture Producers Association of America, representing the majors, a decided to rent its pictures to British exhibitors only in units, each consisting of an "A" and "B" feature.

A new football era began at Brooklyn College yesterday as the newly appointed coach, Ted Rosequist, welcomed a forty-five-man turnout at the Kingsmen's opening practice session. It marked the first time since the school was founded twenty-three years ago that Lou Oshins, who was dismissed last winter, was not at the coaching helm.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The War Assets Administration dropped today its priority system and prepared to offer about $400,000,000 of war surplus goods "to all comers." Until now purchase preference was granted to Federal agencies, veterans, state and local governments and nonprofit hospitals and schools.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- With dealers taking a more encouraging view of the news of the Berlin situation, the stock market here today made a good start as the new account opened.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Bob Feller gave his second straight fine pitching performance tonight as the Indians swept their two-game series with the Athletics, winning, 8--1, before a crowd of 24,607. Feller fanned nine batters while permitting six hits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A special investigating committee named by Secretary of State George C. Marshall stamped as false today assertions to Congress by State Department officials that hundreds of subversive aliens had entered this country under credentials of the United Nations and other international organizations.

WASHINGTON Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today ordered Florida Airways to cease operations after March 28, 1949, on the ground that it cannot continue in business without a prohibitive Government subsidy.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- The Public Service Commission acted today to prevent an automatic increase in the fares charged by .thirteen privately operated New York City bus companies pending its decision on the companies' requests for fare rises.

Your recent editorial on the primary well recounts the advantages of our regulated primary over the unregulated one of long ago. I wonder, however, whether there is not one item in our primary law that tends to make the primary an uncontested yes-man affair. I refer to the statement in the enrollment blank that the enrollee is in general sympathy with the principles of the party.

Evidence that American industry still retains its predominant trend toward more efficient production, the source of the constantly rising standard of living, in spite of statistical measures to the contrary, was encountered in a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES of available information on productivity and labor cost.

NANKING, China, Sept. 1 -- The Communist North Shensi radio tonight announced the formation of a "North China People's Government,'' calling it the forerunner of a future "people's government" for all of China. Officers were elected and laws passed by a representative assembly, the radio reported.

"China Changed My Mind," by David Morris, has been scheduled for publication next year by Houghton Mifflin. It tells of the author's experiences as a conscientious objector who distributed food to the bombed-out in London, drove a truck over the Burma Road for the Friends Ambulance Service and later enlisted in the British Army.
Sixteen letter men will be among the fifty Columbia football players who will report to Coach Lou Little at Baker Field today for the Lions' first fall practice session.

The Sally Milgrim custom-order showing, which took place in the salon of the West Fifty-seventh Street shop yesterday morning, modish, there is no spectacular stands for two things -- refinement of taste and delicacy of detail. While the clothes are all extremely exaggeration about them.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Although about 45 per cent of new cars purchased in the New York metropolitan area are on the time-payment basis, the sales volume will not be affected by the new Federal credit regulation that will go into effect on Sept. 20. A.W. Boettcher, vice president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, said today.

Reflecting a 19.4 per cent rise in sales, net profit of the Lerner Stores Corporation for the six months ended with last July increased to $2,931,108 from the $1,876,087 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, the report said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Cattle set a new record high price of $41.50 a hundred pounds today in a market which generally ranged from 50 cents higher to 50 cents lower than yesterday. A load of choice to prime steers pushed the price up 10 cents over the previous mark made only last Monday and equaled yesterday and earlier today.

Algasir, the 2-year-old gelding for whom Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark of Old Westbury, L.I., had put a record $106,000 on the line at Saratoga two Saturdays ago, paid an $8,775 dividend at Aqueduct yesterday when he dashed off with first money in the Babylon Handicap.

Alice Orovan's couture collection for fall and winter, presented yesterday at her salon at 785 Fifth Avenue, was marked for its simplified adaptation of Directoire styles and for its rich fabrics. Miss Orovan is introducing a new method of construction that will eliminate some fittings and lessen the cost of custom-made clothes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer today "regretfully" accepted the resignation of John C. Virden, department official who came under Congressional attack last May because his daughter works for the Russian News Agency, Tass.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 1 -Tommy Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club, a co-medalist yesterday with William Kuntz Jr. of Bonnie Briar, reached the semifinal round of the Westchester amateur golf championship at the Bonnie Briar Country Club course today.
General Eisenhower's statement that teachers' Salaries should be doubled and your editorial comment emphasize the plight of teachers during the past ten years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Espionage for Soviet Russia by atomic scientists will be the principal subject of a series of hearings which the House Committee on Un-American Activities is to begin next Tuesday.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- Transport problems connected with the relaxation of the Russian blockade of Berlin were discussed at a second meeting of the four military governors today and it became evident that the Soviet Union attached maximum importance to a renewal of normal trade between Western Germany and the Soviet zone.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Armed Services Personnel Board has submitted to the Secretaries of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Treasury a three-point proposal for dealing with both suspected and proven cases of subversive or disloyal conduct in the Armed Forces, it was learned today.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 1 -- Despite a Communist attempt to disrupt it, the Parliamentary Assembly of the eleven Western German states was formally constituted today. Its task was officially described as an attempt to draft a provisional constitution covering 46,000,000 persons in Western Germany.

Net profit of Dresser Industries, Inc., for the nine months ended with last July amounted to $5,623, 586, exceeding the net profit of $4,439,189 shown for the full previous fiscal year, H. N. Mallon, president, reported in the statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.
