WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The European Cooperation Administration announced today all United States sales of grain to Marshall Plan countries will be made by private American suppliers beginning on Dec. 1.

Financial circles believe that the forthcoming "third round" of state referendums on bonuses for veterans of World War II should provide a significant commentary on the public's attitude toward inflation and public expenditures. In a half-dozen or more states voters will be required to give the say-so in November on cash bonuses running to beyond $1,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Truman received in separate White House conferences today pledges of the support of a majority of the leaders of organized labor in his election campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Employes who strike for "economic" reasons and not because of unfair labor practices by the employer may not vote in collective bargaining elections held during the walkout if they have been replaced, according to a ruling today by the National Labor Relations Board.

History is no longer a chronicle of battles and conquests or of the deeds of great rulers and statesmen, but a record and an interpretation of the way restless, fighting, ambitious, supine or oppressed men respond to social forces. One of the American pioneers who thus conceived history, especially the history of the United States, was Charles A. Beard, who singly or with his wife, Mary, wrote a dozen books about which academicians still quarrel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Bouncing back from yesterday's double defeat behind the four-hit pitching of Preacher Roe, who did his second straight whitewashing job, the Dodgers today downed the Cubs, 6--0, to establish a half-game lead over the second-place Braves.
ALBANY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Fifty-dollar fines levied against two New Yorkers for displaying a woman's hat adorned with bird of paradise feathers were approved today by the State Conservation Department.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept 1 (AP) -- A veteran Toledo, Ohio, sailor and his 9-year-old sloop Avilion today won the Snyder trophy after a 335-mile grind around Lake Ontario.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said tonight the job of cleaning Communists out of Washington would get under way "as fast as a Republican President can be elected." The statement by the Republican nominee for President was at a joint news conference he held with Harold E. Stassen, one of those he defeated for the nomination.

The extremely sharp rise in exports of automobiles and machinery to the United States, along with more moderate gains in traditional soft goods items, is chiefly responsible for the increase of 50 per cent in British exports to this country so far this year over all of 1947, Neville Blond, trade advisor to the British Ambassador, said here yesterday.

Most home furnishings outlets will end their August furniture sales this week with dollar volume running 5 to 65 per cent ahead of the comparable merchandising period last year, executives representing different types of stores reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Truman called for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act in a Labor Day message tonight. He said inflation must be curbed "before it leads us to economic disaster."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The White Sox poured three runs across the plate in the ninth inning tonight but the rally was checked by Forrest Thompson and Washington escaped with a 5-4 victory. The victory moved the Senators into sixth place, ahead of the Browns, in the American League.

The Rev. Arthur House Stain-back, pastor of the Wadsworth Avenue Baptist Church for the last three years, has been appointed pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church at Thirty-first Street and will preach his first sermon to his new congregation on Sunday morning.
New York's intricate economic machine began to slow appreciably yesterday under the impact of a walkout by 9,400 truck drivers that threatened to spread among 30,000 others in the metropolitan area.

The small, close-fitting shape, developed in calots, cloches, bonnets and berets, was the important silhouette in a showing yesterday of Jeanne Tete hats at Jaeckel. The preview marked the opening of this shop's new millinery salon, where the Jeanne Tete label will be carried exclusively in New York.

Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin called last night upon all liberals to unite to elect a Democratic President and a Democratic Congress, as the Liberal party endorsed Harry S. Truman for President and Senator Alben W. Barkley for Vice-President. The party nominated forty-seven candidates for Presidential electors, identical with the list to be named today by the Democratic State Committee.

The draw for the Davis Cup final between the United States and Australia will be held at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills today. C.V. Kellway, Australian Consul General in New York, will preside at the function that will determine the line-ups of the opposing teams for the challenge round to be held Saturday, Sunday and Monday at the West Side Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Airline fares began rising today to the highest level since 1935, but on many heavily traveled routes they still were generally competitive with railroad Pullman rates.

The Park Department, in rearranging its plans for necessary changes in the Van Cortlandt Park golf courses so as to save most of the four-acre marsh area at the north tip of Van Cortlandt Park Lake, seems to have done its utmost to preserve this wild spot where wild birds dwell in their natural environment.

No new capital projects can be undertaken by the city in 1949 or 1950 without deferral or abandonment of projects already on its capital program, Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson declared yesterday in a report to Mayor O'Dwyer.

Scrap dealers and brokers here have been notified by their industry trade association that a general meeting will be held at the Department of Commerce in Washington on next Wednesday at the invitation of the Secretary of Commerce to consider a proposal by the Government that the industry form a corporation to purchase German scrap metal for shipment to the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- A maritime strike in West Coast ports was set for 10:30 A.M. tomorrow by Harry R. Bridges, long-shore union leader, as a negotiating session with waterfront employers broke up without agreement late tonight. Mr. Bridges predicted a three-months walkout.
ALBANY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Representative William T. Byrne and five others on the Democratic ticket in Albany County formally rejected American Labor Party endorsement today.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- Answering press criticisms and a rumor campaign that even hinted at possible disorders if Cabinet changes were not made, President Miguel Aleman today reviewed the accomplishments of his second year in office, defended the devaluation of the peso, and suggested remedies for Mexico's more pressing economic difficulties.

Members of the Association of Rain Apparel Contractors, Inc., are refusing to accept orders from manufacturers belonging to the New York Rainwear Manufacturers Association, Inc., following inability of the two organizations to agree on a collective bargaining contract, it was said last night by John P. Gilbert, president of the contractors' group.

Less than a week after he had completed a two-year prison term in another state, a 39-year-old bookkeeper, described as "extremely dexterous with figures," was accused yesterday in General Sessions of perpetrating a $117,000 swindle on a wholesale perfume concern here.
A new man-made chemical of the sulfa type has "successfully halted a polio virus in the mouse," it was announced yesterday by Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- In THE NEW YORK TIMES of last Friday in reporting the testimony of Louis Budenz before the House Committee on Un-American Activities an incorrect reference was made to Lieut. Andrew Roth. The news account incorrectly stated that Lieutenant Roth was convicted and fined in connection with the unauthorized removal of documents from the State Departments in 1945.

The system first used by the Republicans in the 1940 campaign to evade the spending limit of $3,000,000 placed on national committees by the Hatch Act will be adopted by the Democrats for the 1948 campaign, it was disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Army, under present policy, will assign Negro draftees to Negro units. However, these units, ranging in size from company strength of about 200 men to regiments of about 3,000, constitute parts of white divisions of about 14,000 men.

"The Loves of Carmen," which follows the Prosper Merimee story rather than the opera, will open an engagement today at Loew's State. Rita Hayworth and Glenn Ford share co-starring honors in this Technicolor romantic drama produced by Columbia.
BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- The United States Military Government has started operating its own railroad in the United States sector with wo locomotives and twenty freight cars "borrowed" from the Russians.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, said tonight that the problem of inflation threatened "an economic disaster of the first magnitude" if it was not solved.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 1 -- Arab League headquarters disclosed today a detailed Arab plan for the demilitarization of Jerusalem, under which the Arabs and Jews would run and police their separate areas in a clean-cut division of the city.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press ) -- The Empress of France, latest addition to the Canadian Pacific Steamships' transatlantic fleet, today sailed for Montreal on her first post-war voyage.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) -The top favorite, Miss Beverly Baker of Santa Monies, Calif., gained the quarter-finals of the United States girls' tennis singles championship today by defeating Ruth Pate of Forth Worth, Tex., 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Taking time off from his efforts to form a new Cabinet, Robert Schuman, French Premier designate, formally turned over today the Palais de Chaillot, where the United Nations General Assembly will convene Sept. 21, to Secretary General Trygve Lie.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Newspaper critics gave the J. Arthur Rank organization's Technicolor production, "The XIV Olympiad -- The Glory of Sport," an ovation after its first showing here today.

A nineteen-page defense of the manner in which the city's milk-price inquiry has been conducted was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh. The statement was entered in response to a court order obtained recently by the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association requiring him to show cause why one of his subpoenas served on the league should not be vacated.

The identities of the major party nominees for the one contested vacancy on the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District -- Manhattan and the Bronx -- were disclosed yesterday. The Republican candidate for the vacancy caused by the death of Lloyd Church is Thomas J. Crawford, and the Democratic candidate, barring a last-minute switch, will be S. Samuel Di Falco.

Doug Ratford, Brooklyn welterweight, will make his first start as a headline performer in Madison Square Garden when he opposes Tommy Bell, seasoned campaigner from Youngstown, Ohio, tonight. The battle is listed for ten rounds.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Israeli diplomatic representatives and foreign Zionist supporters of the new state are conducting a quiet but intense campaign of persuasion and propaganda to obtain British recognition of Israel, it was disclosed today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 1 -- Henry A. Wallace came to the deep South today and was received courteously by farmers and mill workers in the rural areas, while the city fathers in large industrial communities invoked segregation laws which drove the Wallace party away with wrathful mutterings.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 -- The Hudson Motor Car Company today displayed its new convertible brougham model to the press here. Similar showings will be held in seventeen other cities, George H. Pratt, vice president in charges of sales, said.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 1 -- The first assembly of the World Council of Churches hurdled a major theological stumbling block today when it gave tentative approval to a section of a report incorporating within the council's framework two basically divergent points of view regarding apostolic succession.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 1 -- An impassioned plea that the League of Red Cross Societies to take steps to prevent repetition of cruelties that befell Jews in the last war was made today by the World Jewish Congress in an address to Basil O'Connor, president of the council of governors of the Red Cross League.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The United States apparently has made strong protests to Czechoslovakia in connection with the illegal shipment of airplanes and arms by air from that country to Israel.

Kermit Bloomgarden and Walter Fried, combining forces for the first time, concluded arrangements yesterday under which they will bring to Broadway this season Arthur Miller's play, "Death of a Salesman."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (UP) -- The Baseball Commissioner's Office today revealed it was investigating numerous player deals in Texas, but refused to confirm or deny reports of an imminent purge of the Detroit, Pittsburgh and Dallas rosters.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Honeymoon, $135,000 California-bred, equaled Armed's track record of 1:35 for a mile in the $32,700 Beverly Handicap for fillies and mares at Washington Park today.

TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- Japan, after three years of Allied occupation, has become "an asset upon which the free world may confidently count" in a time of international tension, Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today in a public statement issued for the third anniversary of V-J Day.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Robin Roberts' wildness and Ron Northey's home run combined to give the Cardinals a 4-to-2 triumph over the Phillies tonight and enable St. Louis to wrest third place from the Pirates. Andy Seminick and Bama Rowell hit circuit blows for Philadelphia's tallies.

Two thousand painters went on strike yesterday in Queens against twenty-two employers in an effort to break a deadlock in negotiations that have extended a month beyond the expiration of their contract.

George V.P. Marks and John Mueller have been elected vice presidents of Julius Kayser Co., it was announced yesterday. Mr. Marks is director of purchases and manager of fabric sales for the organization. Mr. Mueller is general superintendent of the company's manufacturing plants in the United States.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 1 -- An annual custom will be observed Sept. 26 when residents of this state show the cream of their crops at the New Jersey State Fair, which was first held in 1745.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 -- Robert Mitchum, 31-year-old film star, was arrested with Lila Leeds, 20- year-old actress, and two other persons in a raid late last night by local and Federal narcotics officers at Miss Leeds' Hollywood cottage in which a quantity of marijuana cigarettes were seized.
PARIS, Thursday, Sept. 2 -- Socialist demands for wage compensations held up the formation of a new Schuman Cabinet last night as they caused the Reynaud plan and the Marie government to founder.

The nation's crude oil production averaged 5,528,850 barrels daily last week, a new record, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represented an increase of 7,550 barrels over the daily average of 5,521,300 in the preceding week.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 1 -- A program of cooperation between Fairleigh Dickinson College, a co-educational institution here with 400 students, and Mexica colleges and universities was announced today by the college. It was arranged by Dr. Peter Sammartino, president of Fairleigh Dickinson, on a recent trip to Mexico.

The detective credited with having saved the life of the late Mayor William J. Gaynor in an attempted assassination in 1910 applied yesterday for retirement after having served forty years in the New York Police Department.
Federal Judge John W. Clancy declined yesterday to grant three indicted Communist leaders permission to travel throughout the United States at will while they are free on bail.

The reports by radio concerning a thirty-mile-an-hour wind whistling through the rigging of the lightship kept the sixty boats participating in the sixth United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament moored to their docks yesterday, but with a promise of light, southerly winds the horse mackerel derby will continue today.

MANILA, Sept. 1 -- An erratic typhoon carrying heavy rains crossed central Luzon last night causing serious new floods in the Philippines' so-called rice basket, with untold fresh damage to seedling crops. It further displaced thousands of Filipinos in the embattled Hukbalahap areas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A new laminated plastic cloth material said to have proved itself in tests "to be stronger than steel" and "to withstand shell fragments as successfully as armor plate" was described here today at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 -- General Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, declared today that the Air Force can and will keep Berlin supplied with food and fuel but warned that the American people must be prepared to accept, in the cost of "operation vittles" the cost in lives and airplanes.

Trade hedge covering in the near-by positions, coupled with Brazilian buying in the far-off months enabled the coffee futures market yesterday to continue its advance during the greater part of the trading session on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc.

A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., will increase prices of its Gulistan carpets from 2 to 5 per cent, effective Sept. 7, it was announced yesterday. The average increase will amount to 3 per cent. The company stated that the price advances are necessary because of the increasing cost of carpet wools.

McCarthy Interests of Texas, owner of the Shamrock, de luxe $18,000,000 1,100-room hotel now under construction in Houston, Tex., has appointed Ruthrauff and Ryan, Inc., as advertising agency, it was announced yesterday. Glenn McCarthy, who heads sixteen corporations, including oil, gas, chemical, publishing, motion picture, radio concerns as well as McCarthy Center, site of the hotel, said the opening date would beannounced soon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were unsettled today. September corn continued to show strength and gained 1 7/8 cents net a bushel after being up 3 1/4 cents at one time. Deferred deliveries of corn lost 3/8 to 3/4 cent.
Chain food stores and the garment industry were the principal sufferers yesterday as the truckmen's strike surprised and confused many New York shippers.

Arthur A. Shuck, until recently Scout Executive of the Los Angeles Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America and a veteran of thirty-five years in the movement, took over yesterday at the organization's national headquarters, 2 Park Avenue, its highest administrative post, that of Chief Scout Executive.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- Pope Pius XII appealed today to the member states of the United Nations to devote their sternest efforts to solving the problems of permanent peace and security at the next General Assembly, scheduled to open Sept. 21 in Paris.

TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- Inflation may not have run its full course in Japan but indications are multiplying that it is reaching a point where it may be controllable. Fruit and vegetable prices in the open market have been below the official ceilings since spring.

Believed to be the longest-wed couple in the city, a Woodside, Queens, couple married seventy years ago will receive in the near future a visit from Mayor O'Dwyer and a diamond ring, it was announced yesterday. The recognition is part of the city's Golden Anniversary celebration.

WARSAW, Sept. 1 -- M. Borejsza charged today that the "American gutter papers" were conducting a "lying campaign" about the message of Prof. Albert Einstein to the intellectual congress. M. Borejsza said that the "original text" of Professor Einstein's "letter of welcome" was read to the congress Aug. 26 and subsequently published.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Braves lost ground in their battle to regain first place in the National League today as they split a double-header, taking the nightcap, 11--1, after the Reds had won the opener, 3--1.
Sales for Manhattan and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 4 per cent in August, as compared with August of last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Raising bank-reserve requirements as a device to restrict lenders without precipitating an undesired curtailment of business activity, "is a blunt instrument, a blunderbuss," the National City Bank of New York asserts in its Monthly Letter, published today.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday registered declines of from 4 to 9 points on the day. All the activity for the trading session was in the 1949 positions, with Brazilian buying in the distant July position.

@0*0*0*Many managements in American industry have been pushing to completion a program to provide for their labor forces the new and improved tools and plants needed to meet demand and help reduce rising unit labor costs, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES of available information on productivity and labor cost.

Taking no chances, despite ample current supply of food and other necessities, Mayor O'Dwyer reactivated yesterday his Board of Planning and Operations to handle whatever emergencies might arise from the truck strike.
INTERLAKEN, Switzerland, Sept. 2 -- The Congress of the European Parliamentary Union, representing twelve countries, proposed today the holding of a European assembly in December, 1948.

The six-story apartment house containing forty-eight suites at 1410 Plimpton Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Reply Realty Corporation to the Josger Realty Corporation for investment for cash above existing mortgages totaling approximately $105,000.

X0*0*0*Additional data for eight industries compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics bring to thirtytwo the industries for which the bureau has recently prepared 1947 data on output a man-hour. The changes indicated are commented upon by Aryness Joy Wickens, Acting Commissioner of Labor Statistics, in a letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES published on the editorial page of this issue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The ten-year program for this country's health asked by President Truman last January was made public today by the White House in the form of a 186-page report from Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator.

Hey, fellers! Let's go fishing. Up in the Seventy-second Street Lake in Central Park. Nobody has to watch out for the cops, because it's legal now. There are signs all around the shore saying O.K. for anybody under 16 years old to fish there any time before dark so long as he uses a pole.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A general decline for most farm products and foods was mainly responsible for a decrease of 0.5 per cent in average primary market prices for the week ended last Saturday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- President Truman's legal advisers have prepared for his use in the campaign a book-length memorandum designed to prove his right to refuse to deliver any papers or information held by him or his Cabinet officers to the Congress or its committees.

MANILA, Sept. 2 -- The eruption of a supposedly extinct volcano on a small island in the central Philippines combined with disastrous floods in central Luzon following a typhoon, an alarming rice shortage affecting all parts of the country and the resumption of open conflict in the Hukbalahap rebellion have hit this nation simultaneously.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 -- By an overwhelming voice vote, the Veterans of Foreign Wars recommended today Federal and state legislation to curb the privileges of Communists "which might further their nefarious activities."

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade developed a reactionary trend today with wheat closing about the bottom and all deliveries of rye going to a new seasonal low. Much selling was reported to be based on a statement by former Governor Harold Stassen, that food prices must come down.

BERLIN Sept. 2 -- The United States presented today a threepoint program for the control of Berlin's currency when it is issued by the Russians. The plan was submitted at a meeting of the four military governors and a preliminary meetings of the trade and finance committees.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People protested yesterday to the New York State Commission Against Discrimination over a decision involving seven Negro employes of the Sunnyside yards of thc Pennsylvania Railroad.

The board of directors of the Bulova Watch Company, Inc., authorized yesterday the payment to common stockholders on Oct. 1 of an extra dividend of 50 cents a share, together with the regular quarterly distribution of 75 cents a share.

Net profit of Canadian Breweries, Ltd. for the nine months ended on July 31, was $4,670,418, equal to $2.12 a common share, the report disclosed yesterday. For the similar period of the previous year, the net profit was $4,321,945 or $2.16 a common share.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The reorganized Detroit Lions, cellar dwellers of the National Football League for the past two seasons, showed plenty of offensive power tonight while bowing to the Philadelphia Eagles, 37 to 35, in an exhibition game.

Both Democrats and Republicans renominated Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien, a Democrat, and nominated Justice Eugene L. Brisach, a Republican, on the bench by appointment of Governor Dewey, at their First Judicial District Conventions last night.

Like a couple of bird-dogs on a warm scent, George Weiss and Bucky Harris apparently are set on flushing up another pennant for the Yankees as the final month of the race opens with the Bronx Bombers a mere length out of first place.

Nine ends were among the fifty candidates to report at Baker Field yesterday morning for Columbia's opening football practice. However, none of the wingmen happened to be named Bill Swiacki or Bruce Gehrke -- and that is Coach Lou Little's chief concern as he commences his nineteenth season at the helm of the Light Blue eleven.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told a Congressional subcommittee today that the United Electrical Workers, which he once headed, was a "Communist front on many questions" and that most of its officers and staff acted like Communists.
More than 92,000 young men have registered for the draft here so far this week, it was announced last night at Selective Service headquarters, 516 West 34th Street.

The world would give a great deal to know the thoughts that passed through the mind of Stalin at the bier of the man who was regarded by many as his most probable successor. Only the No. 1 man can tell whether Zhdanov or Molotov was No. 2 in the line of succession to the Soviet high command.

ATHENS, Sept. 2 -- The Greek Ministry of the Press supported in part today a Salonika dispatch printed in the conservative newspaper Embros to the effect that the murder of George Polk, correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, whose body was found in Salonika Harbor last May 16, had been solved.

The drab outlook for domestic shipping and the increasing operatingcost differential between United States and foreign vessels are among the factors tending to discourage private investment in the American maritime industry, it was reported here yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- A strong bid for all the corn and other animal feeding stuffs that Russia can furnish will be made by Britain in the course of trade talks with the Soviet Union that opened here today.
LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 2 (AP) -The American craft Twin Star, from Wilmette Harbor, Ill., led a field of twenty-seven tonight at the end of two races in the Star Class world sailing championships.

Initial preparations are being rapidly completed for the purchase of $10,000,000 in American merchandise by a purchasing mission from Colombia for reconstruction of buildings in Bogota damaged in the rioting there last April, it was learned here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 2 While more than 1,000,000 citizens in this country have responded to the global campaign of the United Nations Appeal for Children (UNAC), large corporations and business concerns have contributed very little to the $60,000,000 drive that was organized to help underfed children of all nations.

Plans for altering the five-story apartment and store building at 331 East Seventy-fifth Street were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Marr Holding Corporation to the Winston Park Realty Corporation, Jack E. Cooper, presider, who will occupy the store.

The four-story Kisco Garden Apartments at the corner of Carpenter and Bedford Avenues, Mount Kisco, Westchester County, were sold by the Ramsil Realty Corporation to the Kisco Garden Apartments, Inc. The building, which occupies an irregular plot 140 by 111 feet, contains thirty-two suites.

A national study of buying habits in more than 3,500 retail jewelry stores has been started under joint sponsorship of the Jewelry Industry Council and the Retail Division, Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, it was announced yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Sept. 2 -- A section report describing both communism and capitalism as incompatible with the Christian way of life was received formally here today by the first assembly of the World Council of Churches.

The four-story apartment house containing twenty-six suites at 2313 Benson Avenue, northwest corner of Bay Thirtyfourth Street, Brooklyn, was purchased by Sam Steingart from Nathan Zlasney. Title to the property, which occupies a plot 80 by 97 feet, was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

Tourist List, who rarely fails to get at least a portion of the purse, took the winner's share of it at Aqueduct yesterday in the $11,625 Harbor Hill Steeplechase. It was his second stakes victory in six days; last Friday he had led 'em home in the Saratoga Steeplechase.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 -- The authority in a brace of home runs exploded by Walk Cooper and Lucky Jack Lohrke swept Larry Jansen to his sixteenth victory the campaign on Forbes Field today as the Giants conquered the Pirates, 5 to 4.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 2 -- A broadcast of the secret "Azerbaijan radio" announced that an "Azerbaijan Free Government" had been formed by Gen. Gholan Yahya Daneshian, with himself as chief of state and army commander in chief.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Opening the defense of his Westchester open 54-hole medal play championship, Claude Harmon of Winged Foot led a field of fortyeight professionals and twenty-five amateurs by one stroke as he posted an even par 37, 34 -- 71 over the Knollwood Country Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The National Democratic organization moved today to drive a wedge between the States Rights movement and rank and file Southern voters, offering its blessing to any state Democratic committees pledged to support the Truman-Barkley ticket in the November election.

The visitor, trailing wisps of pipe smoke of an essence surely never intended by any tobacconist, turned out to be our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn, armed with his favorite corncob burley burner.
I have just read the article "Should We Outlaw the Communist Party?" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine.

OTTAWA, Sept. 2 (Canadian Press) -- High officers of twenty-three international unions in the Canadian Trades and Labor Congress, revolting against what they termed Congress tolerance of Communist members, set up today a committee pledged to clean out the Communists from the organization.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Virtually the entire might of Britain's Royal Air Force together with a major part of three United States longrange B-29 bomber groups now stationed in the United Kingdom will be launched tomorrow at the start of the three-day "Exercise Dagger," designed to test every aspect of the air defenses of the British Isles.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 -- State Education Commissioner Francis T. Spaulding refused today to grant a rehearing in the case of Dr. Francis J. Thompson, whose reinstatement as a City College teacher was ordered by the department last year following his dismissal on charges that he was a Communist.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The Foreign Office confirmed tonight that as part of his mission in Washington, Gladwyn Jebb, Assistant UnderSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs, was holding informal discussions with State Department officials on military aspects of the Western Union.

William Susman has been elect.[ed executive vice president ofFashion Rite Gloves, Inc., it was,announced yesterday. He will begeneral assistant to the president'and will supervise all plant opera-,tions.

A committee of preferred stockholders of the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company, claiming ownership of 2,500 of the 66,860 outstanding shares of the cumulative preferred stock, filed suit in State Supreme Court yesterday for $11,249,853 against the Long Island Lighting Company, parent organization, three subsidiaries and five past and present officials of the companies.

The second volume of "F. D. R.: His Personal Letters," edited by Elliott Roosevelt, has been scheduled for October publication by Duell, Sloan Pearce. It will cover the period from 1905 to 1928. Eleanor Roosevelt has supplied a foreword to the illustrated edition.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 5 to 28 points net lower, with 1949 positions weakest.

The recent sharp drop in prices:of lnost major farm productsbelow their support levels hasresulted in a general lowering of[prices. Although the Bureau of.Labor Statistics showed a slightI drop last week in the wholesale]price level, the index still is above[that of a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a regional director cannot even grant a hearing to a labor organization that has not complied with the filing and registration requirements of the Taft-Hartley Act.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 2 -An atom-smashing "cannon" with a barrel 160 feet long, designed to fire nuclear projectiles with energies of more than 1,000,000,000 electron volts, will be built on the campus of Stanford University, it was announced today.

Six goals, including the establishment of a School of Foreign Law and Advanced International Studies, are being considered for Columbia's School of Law, Young B. Smith, dean of the school, announced yesterday in a report.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Preliminaries in the 1,500-meter free-style event opened the National A.A.U. 1948 senior men's outdoor swimming and diving championships today at suburban ,Cuyahoga Falls pool.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 -Twelve ships got clear of Los Angeles Harbor before the deadline for the beginning of the strike today, but it appeared that as many as fourteen others might be caught here. One of the latter is the Matson Line Lurline, due in Saturday from Hawaii.

MONTREAL, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The governors of the National Hockey League laid plans today for a possible seventy-game schedule for each club in the 1949-50 season, more than double the playing dates of a quarter-century ago.
Samuel Seabury leased anapartment in 840 Park Avenue]through the Payson McL. lVrer-]rill Company, broker, and]Brown, Wl{eelock, Harris,]SteYens. Inc.. agent.

PARIS, Friday, Sept. 3 -- Premier Robert Schuman, faced with the refusal of the Socialist party to participate in the Government, tried through most of the night to form a Cabinet without the Socialists.

ALBANY, Sept. 2-- Harold E.Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, charged today that the Truman Administration had deliberately attempted to sustain high food prices in the face of bumper crops here and improved crops abroad.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The Big Four powers have reached general agreement to award Italian Somaliland to Italy as custodian under a United Nations trusteeship and to grant Ethiopia an outlet to the Red Sea by partitioning Eritrea and giving the port of Assab and the region of Danakil to Emperor Haile Selassie.

Mayor O'Dwyer was urged yesterday by the Civil Service Reform Association to take steps to abolish the positions of corporation inspectors and to assign regular city employes with civil service status to the job of inspecting street openings by public utility companies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- We must maintain the nonpartisan attitude on foreign policy in the future as we have in the past, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. declared today in th'e keynote address to the national convention of the American Veterans of World War II.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Sept. 2 -- Mrs. Morton M. Palmer Jr. of New Canaan and Mrs. John Bartol of Greenwich, the WestchesterFairfield open champion, turned in identical halves of 40, 38 at Westchester Hills today to tie at 78 for low gross honors in the weekly one-day event of the Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association, which attracted a field of seventy.

Signing of a contract between the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association and Local 1 of the United Social Agency Employes, an affiliate of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, was protested yesterday by members of Local 19 of the Social Service Employee Union.

The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, formerly of Vine Street Temple, Nashville, Tenn., took over his duties yesterday as senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. He succeeded the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, who became rabbi emeritus on Jan. 1. He was welcomed by Rabbi Nathan A. perilman.

GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- The Franco Government in Spain will collapse in a few months if United States financial aid is withheld, a source high in the Spanish conservative Opposition to Generalissimo Francisco Franco predicted today.

We have read with considerable interest the series of articles on productivity by Will Lissner appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES, beginning on Aug. 26. They illustrate the complexity of the problem of measuring recent changes in productivity in American industry.

SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 2 -Henry A. Wallace switched to the attack today in his embattled southern political tour, denouncing sidewalk hecklers and accusing the vice-presidential candidate of the States' Rights ticket with being prejudiced in racial matters.

Tommy Bell, veteran Cleveland welterweight, had all he could do to outpoint Doug Ratford of Brooklyn in the ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. The Ohioan won after a spotty fray in which there was bristling action at times and utter lack of it at other times.

A French nun, who invoked the powers of prayer and pen to save Jewish children from the Gestapo during the war, was honored yesterday on her first visit to America at a luncheon given by the War Relief Services-National Catholic Welfare Conference in the Empire State Building.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Col. Gen. Andrei A. Zhdanov was buried in the Kremlin wall tonight after one of the Soviet Union's most magnificent funerals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP)~ -President Truman emphaticallyendorsed today compulsory healthinsurance and a five-point publichealth program.

Garson Kanin must be beaming from ear to ear these days. Why? Several. outstanding stars are said to be enthusiastic over a script, one of three written by him, called "The Smile of the World." From Hollywood came word that no less a personage than Bette Davis, absent from Broadway .since "Solid South" (1930), is one of them.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 2 (UP) -United States Olympic track and field stars, making their final post-Olympic appearance in Scandinavia, suffered some unexpected defeats today in an international meet along with scoring a few victories.

James T. McNamara, Democratic nominee for Assemblyman in the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District, filed yesterday in Supreme Court a petition for a recount of the ballots cast in the Liberal party primary in that district.

Hugo E. Rogers, Tammany leader, cemented his hold on the leadership of that organization yesterday when the party stalwarts approved the creation of three new votes in Tammany'sh)0*0*0*iexecutive committee. These are apart from those held by district leaders, and the three votes were immediately given to Rogers supporters.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 (AP) -- American Military Government finance officials say they are "surprised to hear" that Western Germany Deutsche marks are for sale in New York. They said they doubted this traffic could be very large.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Following is the draft report of the World Council of Churches section on "The Church and the Disorder of Society":
A check for $100,000 from a Chicago camera manufacturer and a dime from a New York schoolboy yesterday helped get the Babe Ruth Cancer Fund under way.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The hopedfor increase in meat production may be delayed a month or two longer than expected as a result of the large corn and grain crops this year, Col. Edward N. Wentworth, director of Armour Co. Livestock Bureau, declared today in an address before the Investment Analyst Club of Chicago.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The European council of the Marshall Plan nations resumed today its effort to break the deadlock that developed a fortnight ago over the question of dividing the United States dollars for the first year of the plan.
Those Who live outside the law are frequently unwilling to cooperate with enforcement agencies. Such was the case with Nathan Katz, Brownsville hoodlum.

Continuation of a walkout by 9,400 New York truck drivers until next Tuesday became a certainty last night with the announcement that representatives of the union and employers would not meet again until then to discuss new demands.

MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Shakeups in six Ministries and in other Soviet agencies were disclosed today in the Journal of Decrees and Orders. New Deputy Ministers were named for Railways, Foreign Trade, Internal Affairs, Finance, Shipbuilding and Communications.
Girl Scouting is firmly established in Germany, Miss Gertrude Bruns, in charge of Girl Scout activities in the United States occupation zone during the last year, reported yesterday.

ATHENS, Sept. 2 -- Several documents, considered here to be sensational, were released for publication last night in an effort to bring to an end to a quarrelsome situation occasioned by Lieut. Gen. James A. van Fleet's "off the record" conference with exclusively United States newspapermen last Saturday.

ROBERT GRAVES, who is 53, has written more books than he is years old. Some of them are excellent -- his poetry, his youthful autobiography and several of his brilliant historical novels. Some of them are exceedingly queer; but none is as queer as "The White Goddess."*

OTTAWa, Sept. 2 -- "Pen pals" in the Soviet zones of Europe have written Canadians, asking them to exchange letters and send pictures of docks and harbors in northern Canada, a spokesman of the External Affairs Department said today.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Community programs "to meet the challenge of communism realistically and without hysteria" were advocated today by Earlh)0*0*0*iHutchinson of the United States Office of Education.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 2 -Bavarian boys and girls who returned yesterday to their class rooms will get the benefit during this school year of free tuition and free text books, according to a directive of the United States Military Government, despite the failure of the Landtag [State Parliament] to take action on legislation requested by United States officials.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Strong buying from the Cape led to further sharp rises in gold-mining shares on the stock market here today. Heaviest buying was in Orange Free State issues. With low grade issues, also receiving support, gains were general throughout the list.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 2 -- The belief that the visit of fifteen members of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee of the United States House of Representatives would result in effective cooperation by the United States in the development of Mexico's oil resources was expressed today by their chairman, Charles A. Wolverton, just before their return by air to Washington.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 2 -Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, today warned more than 500 delegates at the closing session of American Institute for Cooperation that "there's going to be a big anti-farm drive."
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 -- Tomoya Kawakita, 27-year-old California-born Japanese who worked as a guard in a Japanese Army prisoner-of-war camp, today was convicted in Federal District Court of treason.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced with "the greatest regret" today the resignation of Charles H. Sells as superintendent of the State Department of Public Works, effective Sept. 30. Mr. Sells will return to his private engineering practice.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 2 -- In quest of a title that twice has eluded him, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., moved into the semi-finals of the United States amateur golf championship at the Memphis Country Club today with a stunning 7-and-5 victory over Frank Stranahan, holder of both the British and Canadian crowns.

ABOARD THE LINER STOCKHOLM AT SEA, Sept. 2 -- Jacob M. Lomakin, former Soviet Consul General in New York, disclosed today that his report to Moscow would carry his strong personal recommendation against the re-establishment of Russo - American consular relations.

Chain store customers may find perishable foods in limited quantity today, but those who trade in independent markets are assured of normal stocks. Deliveries to at least two major chains have been tied up by the truck strike, which has not yet spread to drivers supplying other groceries.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 2 -- On the heels of the arrest of four film colony figures in a marijuana raid, the motion picture industry today hastened to issue a formal denial of "implications" that there was appreciable drug addiction among movie people.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., was restrained temporarily here today by the Federal District Court from continuing certain phases of its investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Blue Holly, from the Bobanet Stable of Bruce Livie of Baltimore, stepped six furlongs in the good time of 1.11 1/5 to beat six 3-yearold rivals in the Pulchritude Purse today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 (AP) -Miss Alice O'Neal, 21-year-old Indiana State champion, scored the major upset of the forty-eighth annual women's Western amateur golf championship today when she eliminated Miss Dorothy Kirby, Atlanta, 1 up on the nineteenth hole, in their quarter-final match over the Olympic Club course.

The United States Lines has completed negotiations with the United States Maritime Commission for resumption of its operating differential subsidy under the merchant marine laws, it was announced yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was notified by letter today that John Colier, 29year-old fugitive from a South Carolina chain gang whose extraditionh) 0*0*0*ihe refused last month, now has a $65-a-week job as an auto mechanic in East Orange.

THE month of decision is at hand as the twin pennant races roar the September homestretch without showing the slightest signs of slackening their dizzy pace. Much has happened in the past fortnight of East-West series. The Boston Braves were jostled from first place by the sensational Brooklyn Dodgers but by way of keeping Boston on the alkaline side the Red Sox nudged the Cleveland Indians out of the lead in their league.

Price reductions on cashmere fabrics made in Japan were announced yesterday by the SCAP New York Foreign Trade Office. The new prices range from $2.57 on a light weight suiting to $6.41 on some overcoating fabrics, all prices f.o.b ocean vessel, Japanese port.
Supreme Court Justice Irving Levey upheld yesterday an arbitration award thane would give bricklayers here a wage of $27 for an eight-hour day.

Record high prices are being offered by oil refinery purchasing departments for immediate delivery of large lots of steel pipe, but sellers cannot accept their orders, steel distributors here revealed yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, 72-year-old President of the West German Parliamentary Assembly, believes that even if the Soviet zone is lost to the West, the projected government will be capable of taking its place with other nations of the world.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Three ground fires burning since Sunday night forced A. K. Morgan, chief engineer and general manager of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, to close today for public use all woodlands and hiking trails in the 42,000acre Harriman-Bear Mountain Park and other parks under the commission's supervision.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 2 -Princeton University's 1948 football squad, facing what Coach Charlie Caldwell terms an "all-major-game schedule," started practice today with sixty-one men on hand, including fourteen lettermen

RAPID CITY, S.D., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Six of the Indians who took part in the Custer massacre held a reunion today. They are old men now. But as to the massacre which they call a battle, their opinions are unchanged. They would do it again.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Sept. 2 -The Indian Army is fighting two enemies in Kashmir. One is the socalled Azad (free) Kashmir troops; the other -- and tougher -- is the mountain terrain of almost unparalleled heights and roughness. Beating the second has called for engineering feats of extreme difficulty, to which Indian road builders have proved equal.
Bendel's brought the term "ball gown" back in the grand manner yesterday when it offered its winter custom order collection for view.

The stock market attained yesterday the best levels in a month under only moderate demand, with the steels, rails and oils strongest. Some opposition developed at times on the Stock Exchange, but this centered mainly in the final hour and impaired increases only slightly.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Moscow radio tonight announced the death of Sergei Georievich Lukin, Deputy of the Supreme Soviet and a member of the Communist party's Central Control Commission. [Mr. Lukin was the third high-ranking Communist whose death has been announced in the last week, The United Press noted.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 2 The meeting of the Arab League Political Committee, scheduled to open in Alexandria next Monday, was described by competent Arab officials today as the "most important since the League was founded in October, 1944."

Commerce Commissioner Maguire has concluded his very brief inquiry into the controversy between the domestic airlines and the Port of New York Authority. In his report to Mayor O'Dwyer he emerged with the only finding that could make sense, "that the most salutary thing to do at this time was to strongly urge the parties to meet immediately and continue in session until their differences are resolved."

Railroad, bus and air lines prepared yesterday for a heavy burden of travelers over the four-day Labor Day week-end. The rush is expected to begin today and reach its peak on the holiday, when home-coming summer vacationists will add to the stream of returning week-end trippers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- The hopes of Latin-American countries to get Spanish accepted as one of the working languages in the United Nations dropped sharply here today when officials announced that it probably would cost $1,236,031 to adopt the idea.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The text of a statement issued today by President Truman in connection with the nation's health follows:

Fifty of the nation's most prominent scholars will meet next week at Columbia University in an attempt to define the goals of American education. They will hold a series of discussions at the Men's Faculty Club, 400 West 117th Street, from Tuesday afternoon through Friday morning, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Lyman Bryson, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Prices of hogs dropped today to their lowest top value in two months in a market which was generally steady to strong. Lambs likewise reached their lowest daily peak of six weeks when sheep prices proved generally steady to 50c lower. Cattle, however, held to their recent ranges, with prices steady to 25c higher.

Alexander Stevens, alleged Communist underground leader, admitted yesterday for the first time that he had been an active member of the party. His attorney further identified him as J. Peters, who wrote the Communists' "Manual on Organization."

Neither safety on the road nor good intersectional public relations are served by the persistence of the oldfashioned speed trap and the conniving traffic officer and justice of the peace or his counterpart, which still are found in too many states. The attitude of "soak-the-stranger" is illustrated by many specific instances in an article in Collier's Magazine based upon reports from its many clubs by the American Automobile Association.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony filed a seven-page memorandum with the Treasury Department in Washington three and a half months ago stating the case for repeal of the Federal admissions tax to help out non-profit, cultural institutions that operate on a deficit, it was learned yesterday.
Charles O. l~ader, formerly commercial sales promotion, managerOf the Koppers Company, Inc.,Pittsburgh, has been' named salesmanager of the Aer-a-so! Productsdivision of the Bridgeport BrassCompany.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -The first film story purchased since Howard Hughes took over control of RKO probably will be a murderdrama with anti-Red implications, "I Married a Communist," according to the information obtained at the studio today.

Edward C. Maguire, the city's Commissioner of Commerce, denied yesterday a charge by Howard Cullman, chairman of the Port ofh)0*0*0*iNew York Authority, that his interim report on the controversy between the bi-state agency and the airlines was "just an attempt to bolster up a case for withholding the waterfront rehabilitation job from the Port Authority."

Two units of the Holland-America Line's transatlantic passenger fleet, its flagship Nieuw Amsterdam and the Veendam, will be placed on winter cruise service between New York and South American and Caribbean ports, it was announced yesterday.

Earle Smith of Wayne, Pa., vice president of the American Locker Service of Philadelphia was lost when he fell from his new 50-foot motor-sailer off Matinicock Point in Long Island Sound about 8 o'clock last night.

An agreement designating the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn as a 1,000-bed general hospital under the post-war affiliation program of the War Department was signed yesterday by representativeshf the Army Medical Corps and the Brooklyn institution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Consumers groaning under the prices of food and other commodities are beginning to understand that, as long as the government maintains price supports at 90 per cent of "parity," not bumper crops, demobilization or other changes in the ratio of supply and demand will bring down food prices materially.

The security of the United States is not threatened by "several hundred" foreigners, using the United Nations as a cover-up for subversive activities. Secretary of State Marshall did not think so last July when three subordinate officials of the State Department's visa division -- Robert G. Alexander, William McGrath Harlow and R. Clyde Larkin -- gave testimony to that general effect before a Senate subcommittee.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Dissatisfaction over the size of the wage increase award recommended for machinists and other metal workers by a government court of inquiry yesterday was widespread today in the union ranks affected.

Additional impetus to moderate cost cooperative housing for veterans, sponsored by city, state and Federal authorities, was provided yesterday with the filing of an application for Federal Housing Authority insurance for Bell Park Gardens in Bayside, Queens.

Resuming the seasonal upward trend after registering a decline the week before, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $12,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

@0*0*0*WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The charge of Harold E. Stassen at an Albany press conference that Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan sought "to raise food prices when they should be going down" was answered both by President Truman in his press conference and by Secretary Brannan in a statement issued today.

Mill prices of Douglas fir dimension lumber have dropped $2 to $4 a thousand board feet in the last ten days, Sol Kaplan, president of the New York Lumber Trades Association, reported yesterday. He said that local yard interests regard further price declines in this type of lumber, among the most popular for building purposes, as certain.
The Public Service Commission failed yesterday to stay a 50 per cent reduction in non-rush hour rail passenger service on Staten Island. The curtailment will go into effect Sunday morning.

Two themes -- stoles and the whole gamut of browns from a creamy beige to a deep taupe -were thoroughly explored by Macy's yesterday in a fall showing enlivened by original French millinery models and an exciting use of accessories.

FREEPORT, L. I., Sept. 2 -- If sharks had been eligible for entry the fish brought in by a few of the anglers participating in the United States Atlantic tuna tournament, now in its second day here, would have scored some points for their teams, but with all the boats in except one not a tuna is on the dock.

Thunderstorms, engine failure and fires in the air are among the many difficulties encountered by air-crews that can be simulated closely by a new flight training device demonstrated yesterday at La Guardia Field before a group of high ranking Air Force, Navy and Government officials.

Five youthful members of the Israeli Army, including two women, who arrived yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, asserted that the women of Israel were "taking an active part in the war and fighting in the front lines with the men."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP) - The two top-ranking players andh)0*0*0*itwo who were unseeded moved into the semi-final round of the national girls' tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 28 were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

The American Labor party filed with City Clerk Murray Stand yesterday a petition seeking a restoration of the five-cent fare on the city's rapid transit lines. If the petition is held legal the city's voters would have a chance to decide the question on election day.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- Fritz Zoepel believes that the worst thing that ever happened to him was the discovery of atomic energy. Two of his friends, Willy Schmidt and Horst Gilbert, completely share his views.
The opening verses of the Book of Genesis in two of the Bibles most frequently used today and in the new version of the Roman Catholic Church:

Visible for miles, a spectacular fire swept early today through a long three-story brick factory building on First Street between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Avenues in Astoria, Queens. A small army of firemen, summoned on five alarms fought the blaze for two hours.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 AP -The railway union newspaper, "Labor," said today the Hoover Commission on Government Organization was "working on a proposal for outright abolition of the Department of Labor."

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2 -- The theft of four pieces of jewelry valued at $36,000 from the summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kelland was reported here today after several days of secreth) 0*0*0*iinvestigation by local, county and state police.

Four new films will open at midtown theatres today. "The Room Upstairs," a French production costarring Marlene Dietrich and Jean Gabin, will be presented at the Avenue Playhouse. The Winter Garden's new tenant is "Larceny," a melodrama from UniversalInternational with a cast headed by John Payne, Joan Caulfield, Dan Duryea and Shelley Winters.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 2 -- As a result of negotiations with Austria, Argentina is about to enter a new phase in her relations with the Economic Cooperation Administration.

CHICAGO, Sep. 2 -- The Dodgers beat Johnny Schmitz for the first time yesterday but when Jolly Cholly Grimm sent his southpaw back as a relief pitcher today it was a different and sadder story, the Bruins winning, 7 -- 6, to take the series, three games to one.

Revision of current beer excise taxes aimed at giving small brewers competitive equality with large producers may be asked at the next session of Congress by the Small Brewers Association, it was learned yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 -West Coast longshoremen went on strike today upon dissolution of ah)0*0*0*iFederal court injunction issued under the Taft-Hartley Law. They were joined by members of seagoing unions to paralyze port operations from Puget Sound to San Diego.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 (AP) -Hanging a $2,000 fine on the Pittsburgh Pirates today, Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler began carrying out a warning he issued a month ago that clubs violating the rules of the game would be punished severely.

NANKING, Sept. 2 -- The Nanking Government has notified the Soviet Union of its desire to terminate the Sino-Soviet ten-year Sinkiang airline agreement, Government spokesman Hollington K. Tong announced this afternoon.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 2 (AP) -The Southern Conference executive committee ruled today that Lucian Gambino, the University of Maryland's All-Conference halfback, had used up his three years of varsity eligibility and was ineligible for further conference competition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The discovery that the tiny, rod-shaped bodies in all living cells, known Mitochondria, serve as the power plants in which the body burns fats and sugars to keep the fires of life going, was described here today before the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Department of the Navy announced plans today to replaceh)0*0*0*ifourteen ships in the Mediterranean with sixteen vessels, two of them in a heavier class, from stations on the East Coast.

While the Big Four Powers are conducting strenuous negotiations in an effort to settle their disputes about Germany, the Germans themselves are beginning to shake off the stunned apathy that engulfed them after the collapse of the Third Reich and to give voice to their own views regarding their future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- President Truman hurled the charge of "lie" today to anyone suggesting that he was "protecting" Communists within the Federal Government. He reminded his news conference with unaccustomed vigor that never, in his life had he defended a disloyal person.

Displaced by Ted Schroeder in Melbourne in 1946 and on the sidelines again in 1947, Frank Parker will join with Schroeder in heading the United States' defense of the Davis Cup against Australia in the challenge round starting tomorrow in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club.

A four-month strike waged byLocal 1217 of the United Electrical and Machine Workers of America, CIO, against the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation plant at 88-06 Van Wyck Boulevard, Richmond Hills Queens, ended yesterday on the manegement's terms.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- The Roman Catholic Church has begun publication of a new English translation of the Old Testament, it was announced here today. It will replace the Douay version for public reading in the United States. The Douay version has been in use since 1609.

Mrs. Gladys M. Petch of 108 East Fifty-sixth Street, radio consultant for the Royal Norwegian Information Services, who broadcasts over WNYC and other stations, received yesterday King Haakon VII's Freedom Cross from Martin Bolstad, acting Norwegian Consul General.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The National Maritime Union, CIO, has concluded negotiations which retain the hiring-hall clause in its Great Lakes contracts pending a final court decision on the issue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 28 were 891,495 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,077 cars, or 1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 34,217 cars or 3.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 16,945 cars, or 1.9 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 2 -- The suggestion by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, that United States newspapers help British papers to get newsprint -- and thereby support freedom -- was praised in an editorial today in Prensa, liberal and independent-minded Buenos Aires paper.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 2 -- The suggestion by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, that United States newspapers help British papers to get newsprint -- and thereby support freedom -- was praised in an editorial today in Prensa, liberal and independent-minded Buenos Aires paper.

Favored by sunny skies, hundreds of thousands of Labor Day vacationists laden with luggage and sports equipment left the city yesterday by train, bus, automobile and plane for visits to country and seashore in the mild season.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced today the appointment of Bertram D. Tallamy of Buffalo as Superintendent of the State Department of Public Works. He succeeds Charles H. Sells of Pleasantville, whose resignation was announced yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 3 -Retirement of Maj. Gen. Cornelius W. Wickersham, veteran National Guard officer and commanding general of the Forty-second Division, N.Y.N.G., was announced at Camp Smith today by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of New York's military forces.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 3 -At midnight tonight 1,300 refugees quartered in a German-administered camp outside Dachau began a hunger strike against the conditionsh)0*0*0*iunder which they are forced to exist. They were joined immediately by 500 inmates of a neighboring camp at Allach.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The lowly Chicago Cubs went on a seventeen-hit spree tonight to overwhelm the Pittsburgh Pirates, 10 to 1, and give Russ Meyer his tenth victory of the season against the same number of defeats. Catcher Al Walker drove in five runs, getting a homer, double and single in five trips.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -Gov. Earl Warren told fellow members of the American Legion today that uncertainty and fear would continue to rule in the world until "international intrigue" was abandoned or "until its futility is made clear to those who use it."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- President Truman today named a commission headed by William H. Davis of New York to study and report on labor relations problems as they affect the atomic energy program.

The coffee futures market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was firm yesterday in the early part of the trailing session with some months up 9 to 10 points above the previous close. The market eased toward the close because of some scattered offerings by trade houses.

The body of Earle Smith, 53 years old, of 23 Windsor Avenue, Wayne, Pa., was found in Long Island Sound off Eaton's Neck, L.I., early yesterday afternoon, some distance from the spot off Mattinecock Point, L.I., where he disappeared from his fifty-foot motor-sailer, the Pennessewassee, II around 7 o'clock on Thursday night.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 3 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands will end a fifty-year reign tomorrow when she abdicates in favor of her daughter, Princes Juliana.
Work on New York State's Freedom Train will start Tuesday at the West Albany shops of the New York Central Railroad, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The British shipbuilding industry is prepared to make a stiff fight against any relaxation of the allied ban against the use of German shipyards for the construction of ocean-going vessels, it was made clear here today.

The nation's financial and commodity exchanges will be closed on Monday in celebration of Labor Day. Banks will be closed, as will most of the businesses throughout the United States. The major markets in Canada will also be closed, but the London Stock Exchange will operate as usual.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -The White House announced today the complete schedule for President Truman's railroad tour into Michigan, where he will make a major speech before a Labor Day meeting in Detroit's Cadillac Square on Monday at 1:30 P.M. (Eastern daylight saving time).
MANILA, Sept. 3 -- The eruption of Hibok-Hibok posed a major relief problem for the Philippine Government today.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Labor-management relations in New York State were cited in a Labor Day proclamation today by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, as setting an example for harmony that might well be followed throughout the nation.
GENEVA, Sept. 3 -- The Paris committee of the United Nations Assembly on non-self-governing territories met today and promptly found itself smothered with information.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The United States open champion, Ben Hogan, and a little known amateur from Sacramento, Frank Toronto, carded five-under-par 67's today to share the lead in the opening round of the 72-hole $25,000 Reno open golf.

In the years between the wars Dr. Benes of Czechoslovakia was easily one of the most prominent figures on the European scene. His death under tragic circumstances, a prisoner in his own house, recalls the days when the nimble-witted, active, perennially cheerful little Czech statesman played a role second to none in international affairs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -Permanente Metals Corporation, a Henry Kaiser interest, today was awarded a lease of a big aluminum mill at Newark, Ohio, by the War Assets Administration.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Industrial production in the Soviet Union in the second quarter of this year was 48 per cent higher than in the corresponding quarter for 1946, according to information published here today in the latest issue of the United Nations Monthly Bulletin of Statistics.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 3 -- In one of its final acts as New Jersey's highest tribunal, the State Court of Errors and Appeals ruled today that the victim of "what is known as a hotfoot" may sue the owner of the bar in which it was administered.
PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Former King Humbert II of Italy would be ready to resume the throne as a "supreme arbiter" to settle disputes and dissensions provided that such a call were by popular assent.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Reports of how young adult citizens of New York fought seemingly invincible organized political machines, in one case helping to elect a Mayor and two members of the Town Board from their own membership and in another installing three Democratic Councilmen in a Republican city government, today featured the "practical-politics" discussions of delegates of the Community Service Council.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 3 -Preparing for the seventy-sixth season of Yale football, a squad of fifty-four candidates reported to Coach Herman Hickman at Anthony Thompson Field today for the opening of pre-season practice.
Fear that chain food stores would be forced to close when present stocks were exhausted because deliveries from warehouses were tied up by the truck strike was expressed yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

When the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was launched on Jan. 1, 1934, the funds for its capital stock were provided by the United States Treasury and the Federal Reserve banks. The former put up $150,000,000, the latter, in round figures, $139,000,000, or $289,000,000, all told.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- A break of 12 to 14 cents a bushel in cash corn started general selling of the September delivery today on the Board of Trade. The September was off 4 7/8 cents at one time and finished with a net loss of 3 7/8 cents, short covering having caused a rally from the early low.

VIENNA, Sept. 3 -- A determined effort is being made by the Austrian Government to stop the black market sale of United States-produced cigarettes in Austria by introducing an American blend domestically manufactured brand known as the "Jonny" cigarette.

Members of the American Cryptogram Association, who are known to one another by noms de plume such as Abie Seedy, Madda Boutem, Rinkld Brow and Will Triem, gathered at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday from twentyfour states for their annual convention.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Closer teamwork between management and labor in an effort to obtain increased production has been pledged by the Federation of British Industries and the Trades Union Congress, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, disclosed today.

Because of the wartime devastation of railroad and housing facilities it will be years before tourist travel to the Orient can be resumed on a pre-war basis, according to Frank Groves, vice president of the American Express Company in India and the Far East.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, Sept. 3 -Proposals calling for legislative changes in the New York State tax laws to advance sound forest management were adopted by state forestry officials attending a conference sponsored by the Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation which was concluded here today.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Mary Garden, famed dramatic opera star in the United States before the first World War, was invited today to return there to explain and interpret the roles she created.

Strikes and constant strike threats in the Port of New York endanger the port's supremacy and may accelerate the rapid decline in commerce volume, Collector of the Port Harry M. Durning declared yesterday. He reported that export declarations, by which the Custom House measures the volume of cargo bound for foreign ports, had dropped to an average of 150,000 a month.

Retail trade here this week made a fair increase over the corresponding period last year, although several factors make a true comparison difficult. Department store sales were estimated as about 7 per cent above last year's figure. There was one more business day this week due to Labor Day falling on a different date and temperatures during the week were cooler, with the exception of Monday, than last year.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- An unforeseen note of grim realism was injected today into Britain's threeday air exercises two hours after they had started when a dramatic SOS from a participating United States B-29 revealed that the crew was being forced to bale out and abandon ship over the Netherland coast as a result of engine trouble.

South America is continuing to import United States textile machinery on a substantial scale, with exchange payments facilitated by the high priority rating given to this equipment as essential, it was reported here yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -Thirty-six yachts started the Stamford Yacht Club's annual long distance race tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -Meat eaters can expect little betterment this winter in the supply of beeksteaks, lamb chops and pork, the Department of Agriculture said today. The forecast was made in spite of banner livestock feed supplies and a record-breaking corn crop.

PRAGUE, Sept. 3 -- Dr. Eduard Benes, second President of the Czechoslovak Republic, and together with Thomas G. Masaryk its principal architect, died at 6:10 o'clock this evening at his country home in Sezimovo Usti at the age of 64.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Registration statements covering $4,000,000 of bonds, 197,580 shares of common, 25,000 shares of preferred, 2,000 participating shares and 1,500 employes' shares of stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.

TORONTO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Stephen Wozniak, 33-year-old Buffalo, N.Y., veteran, outlasted a field of fifty-four today to win the men's world professional swimming championship and $5,000 first money in the Canadian national exhibition's annual ten-mile event.
I have read carefully A. U. Malik's letter in your issue of Aug. 24 about conditions in India.

Affairs do not improve in Paris. M. Schuman, called back to power in a deepening crisis, has failed to form a Cabinet and France now enters a second week without a government in power. Socialist opposition wrecked M. Schuman's efforts, just as Socialist opposition brought down the earlier Schuman Cabinet in July and the succeeding Cabinet of M. Marie.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- Harold E. Stassen came to Philadelphia on non-political business today, but reports from Washington prompted him to repeat charges that the Truman Administration had deliberately sustained food prices.

DETROIT, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Ill luck that has plagued the Italian speed boat Sant' Ambrogio since its arrival in this country last month struck it again today as the craft sank during its final tune-up for the first heat of the Silver Cup trophy race tomorrow.

The World Bank is now engaged in an active "merchandising" effort for the future sale of its securities in Europe, it was learned yesterday. Officials of the bank, including E. F. Dunstan, marketing director, and Eugene Black, executive director, have conferred this summer on the subject with leading commercial and investment bankers abroad, as well as with the heads of the foreign central banks.

A survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES of available information on productivity and labor costs threw some light, however faint and flickering, on current economic developments. Interpretations suggestedh)0*0*0*iby the data are summarized below:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Negro aide to Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall reported today that the Army had been more attentive to the problem of race relations than any other Government department.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 3 -Henry A. Wallace, nearing the end of a political junket that has stirred a storm of resentment in the South, expressed today for the first time his reasons for making a "frontal assault" on the racial segregation practices of the region.

Canned salmon will be conspicuously scarce on grocery shelves this winter. The little that is available will be as much as 10 cents a tin higher than it was a year ago. This prediction is based on the unhappy fact that catches of the fish both in Alaska and on the Columbia River have been the lightest in years.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A 17-year-old Akron lad, Jack Taylor, won the 1,500-meter free-style event at the National A.A.U. senior men's outdoor swimming and diving championships tonight, upsetting Jimmy McLane, Olympic champion who has held the title for three straight years.
