Some furniture manufacturers whose volume is derived entirely or largely from small neighborhood furniture stores are experiencing a serious slump, local wholesale salesmen revealed yesterday. They expressed concern over the situation, since the beginning of September is normally one of the most active times of the year as far as small store buying is concerned.

Construction of a new one-and-onethird-mile-long $14,000,000 bridge across the Hudson River as now proposed between Kingston in Ulster County and Rhinecliff in Dutchess County should facilitate travel on several main highways and be a boon to the numerous bustling communities on both sides of the river.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The national convention of the American Veterans of World War II urged today that the United States immediately prohibit the shipment of all war goods to Russia and herh)0*0*0*isatellites.

More than 10,000 tennis permits at $3 each have been bought by residents of our city. The facilities offered them are in a sad state. The asphalt courts in Central Park have bumps, hollows and cracks. They are not fit to play on and are a physical hazard. Many players have been injured on them.

Homecoming for the Dodgers yesterday was on the dismal side but the Giants were quite happy about taking both ends of a double-header, 7 -- 5 and 6 -- 3, at Ebbets Field. The nightcap went only eight innings, for with Whitey Lockman at bat in the top of the ninth, Umpire Beans Reardon decided suddenly that there wasn't light enough for further operations.
BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- A trade agreement calling for an exchange of $21,500,000 worth of goods between the bizonal area and Denmark has been approved by the United States and British Military Governors.

The arrival of a couple of fancy rats yesterday brought to light a serious housing shortage in the small mammal house at the Bronx Zoo. Between now and Monday, Lee Crandall, the zoo's general curator, will have to evict some animal to make room for the newcomers -- a pair of hutias, giant rats, just in from Cuba.

Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare, Commissioner, said yesterday that he was well pleased over the first month's showing of a new job placement plan that found work for 14 per cent of persons referred from public assistance rolls.

Two United States delegates to the World Congress of Intellectuals held last week in Breslau [Wroclaw] issued statements here yesterday denying press reports that the conference was "Moscow-controlled" or undemocratic in its procedures.

The progress of democratic ideals has been slower in the universities of Germany than in any other field of activity in that country, Dr. John W. Taylor, president of the University of Louisville, said yesterday on his arrival here after a four-week survey of higher education in Germany.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Col. G. Tokayev, Soviet Army officer who states that he served two and a half years in the Soviet Military Administration in Germany before fleeing to Britain, has issued a warning to the Soviet people that their country's policy in Germany is "like playing with fire near a powderkeg."

" We Live Again," first post-war Yiddish film to come out of Europe, will be presented today at the Stanley. Much of the film was made in France with a non-professional cast of players. Also on the program are "Overture to Glory," featuring singing by Moyshe Oyshir, and Yiddish dialogue newsreels and short subjects produced in Russia.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Tony Manero, 44-year-old professional from Hubbard Heights, who swept into the national limelight in 1936 when he won the United States Open, showed his old form today when he turned in two fine rounds to capture the 54-hole Westchester Open Golf at the Knollwood Country Club course.

WARSAW, Sept. 3 -- The Polish Communist party admitted publicly today that there had been a "rightist and nationalist" deviation in the party. It announced also that President Boleslaw Bierut had agreed to "return to active political work" in the party as a result of the crisis.
Dr. Eduard Benes, one of the founders of the democratic Republic of Czechoslovakia, suffered the tragic fate of twice being unable to save the country he headed from totalitarian aggression.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP) --h)0*0*0*iMrs. Val Mikiel, a Detroit bowling instructor, today was named "Woman Bowler of the Year" by the National Bowling Writers Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Experiments that have provided the first answers to an important problem on the basic protein requirements in nutrition, which chemists the world over have been trying to solve for a hundred years, were reported at the meeting of the American Chemical Society, which ended today.

Definite signs pointed last night to a continuation of the strike by 9,400 truck drivers beyond next Tuesday when employer and union representatives will meet for the first time in a week to talk over new teamster demands.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The $53,750 Princess Pat Stakes, a sixfurlong sprint for juvenile fillies, will be decided at Washington Park tomorrow.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Herb McKenley of Jamaica, B. W. I., stole the show with an unofficial world record in the 300meter run tonight in the second day of an international track and field meet in Olympic Stadium, before 20,000 fans.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 3 -- Miss Mary Holt of Portland, Me., has taken over her new post as general secretary of the Smith College Alumnae Association, it was announced here today. The association has 25,000 members in forty-eight states and forty-four countries.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 3 -- For the first time since the Argentine Institute for the Promotion of Trade was created by a decree in May, 1946, the Government issued last night a general balance sheet of its controversial operations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board today moved to enforce its recent ruling against use of hiring halls to compel employers to violate the Taft-Hartley Act.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -Washington barbers serving the public have asked for Congressional permission to charge $1.25 instead of $1 for a haircut.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -Joe Dobson shut out the Philadelphia Athletics, 2 -- 0, with four hits tonight as the Boston Red Sox retained first place in the American League by one-half game over the New York Yankees. Birdie Tebbetts accounted for the second Boston run with a homer in the seventh.

The Ewings, Marjorie and Sherman, are back in town again after a quick trip to London and things are expected to get going soon on the forthcoming "The Rape of Lucretia." In the British capital for one week, the Ewings arranged to bring over the scenery designed and painted by John Piper for the English presentation of the Benjamin Britten opera.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Otis Co., of Cleveland, investment banking concern, asked the Federal District Court here today to enjoin the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearings scheduled for Sept. 20 to determine whether the broker-dealer registration of the company should be revoked.

The championship program at the annual session of the New York State Chess Association will open today at En-Joie Park, Endicott, with the type of play to be determined at a preliminary meeting of officials and players. Two or more classes in the general tournament will compete for prizes independently.

Pre-holiday influences were encountered yesterday by the stock market and trends of prices became mixed. The list was jolted in the morning by an unexpected announcement that Armour Co. would make no dividend payment, but subsequently some firmness developed on the Stock Exchange and the final composite rate showed an impairment of only 0.08 point.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- South African gold shares provided the brightest feature in a generally cheerful stock market here today. Cape and London buying resulted in advances in the more speculative favorites. Prices of many of the dividendpayers also finished better on hopes that the lower trend of costs as shown in the latest monthly returns will be continued.

WARSAW, Sept. 3 -- The Polish security police released Msgr. Zygmunt Kaczynski from prison tonight after having detained him for seventy-two hours. He is the chief spokesman for the Catholic hierarchy in Poland, as chief editorial writer and director of the influential Catholic weekly newspaper, Tygodnik Warzawski.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- Despite a long and generally satisfactory meeting of the four military governors on measures involved in the lifting of the Soviet blockade of Berlin, the situation here deteriorated seriously today when a Communist-backed "democratic bloc" entered the City Hall in the Soviet sector and usurped the functions of the regularly elected City Assembly.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Bob Lemon pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 7-0 victory over St. Louis tonight for his nineteenth victory and tenth shut-out of the season, but the Browns came back to top the Indians, 4 -- 3, in the second game of a twi-night doubleheader.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Sept. 3 -Four persons lost their lives early today in a fire of undetermined origin that did $100,000 damage to Crystal Brook Inn, a popular cafe-restaurant on Route 35 here. An investigation into the cause of the disastrous blaze was begun immediately by County Prosecutor J. Victor Carton of Monmouth County.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Robert Schuman gave up today his effort as Premier-designate to form a Cabinet. Tonight President Vincent Auriol was engaged in a desperate effort to refloat a sinking parliamentary regime.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Despite two touchdowns by Los Angeles in the last 33 seconds, the All-America Conference champion Cleveland Browns launched their 1948 season tonight by defeating the Dons, 19 to 14, before 60,193 fans.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- A strategic materials mission of the Economic Cooperation Administration has just closed an agreement with British authorities for a supply of raw rubber, it was learned authoritatively here tonight. Board of Trade officials declined to divulge the amount of rubber sought by the United States, but said a satisfactory arrangement had been worked out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Disclosures concerning a third Communist spy ring allegedly involving Government employees will begin on Capitol Hill about the second week in October, the House Committee on Un-American Activities announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- More than 6,000 carats of diamonds taken by the Nazis during the war have been put on display for prospective buyers at the United Nations Manhattan Building, First Avenue and Forty-second Street, it was announced here today.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 (AP) -A gulf hurricane roaring toward the Louisiana coast tonight trapped sixty oil workers on two drilling barges ten miles offshore.

IF you want to know how dreadful California is, read Evelyn Waugh's "The Loved One." If you want to know how dreadful California is going to be, read Aldous Huxley's "Ape and Essence." If you want to know how dreadful California used to be, read "Dreadful California,"* an ancient chronicle by Hinton Helper (18291909), newly edited by Lucius Beebe and Charles M. Clegg, aficionados of the Iron horse and the ironic horse-laugh.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -While charges flew yesterday in Washington that the United Electrical Workers Union was a "Communist front," workers at the Royal Typewriter Company here voted overwhelmingly to separate from U.E. and to join the Congress of Industrial Organization's United Automobile Workers.

Cornelia Otis Skinner, who has distinguished herself in two different arts, acting and writing, will have a new book published next Tuesday. The co-author of "Our Hearts Were Young and Gay" and of many New Yorker sketches has written an account of her famous theatrical family which begins with her father, Otis Skinner's, childhood and ends with her own first appearance on the stage.

The owner of a chain of residence halls in this city, a socially prominent woman in her mid-thirties,h)0*0*0*isuccessfully resisted yesterday the efforts of two thugs to rob her as she was entering one of the homes, and by her alertness brought about the arrest of one suspect.

An insurance company executive who on Thursday reported to hotel detectives at the Waldorf-Astoria the loss of his wallet containing $5,335, told a story yesterday of a taxi cab driver's honesty in returning the money to the police.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Sept. 3 -- The World Council of Churches today called on its 150 member bodies in forty-four countries to denounce anti-Semitism as "absolutely irreconcilable with the profession and practice of the Christian faith" and a "sin against God and man."

Brooklyn Bridge, for sixty-five years one of New York's most imposing symbols, will add another chapter to its countless legends beginning Tuesday when the city signs a contract with an engineering firm that will devote a year to drawing plans for modernization of the world-famed structure.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 3 -- Willie Turnesa of Elmsford, N.Y., gained the final round of the U.S. amateur golf championship at the Memphis Country Club today along with Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie.

The Golden Anniversary Exposition at Grand Central Palace will be closed tomorrow and Monday to give "loyal city employees and other citizen volunteers" assigned there the benefit of the Labor Day weekend, Grover A. Whalen, exposition chairman, announced yesterday.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during August totalled 10,571,021 lines, a gain of 8.49 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were automotive, up 21.50 per cent; classified 19.69 per cent, and retail 8.28 per cent.

Your editorial: "The Draft Begins" sums up in many ways the attitude of the American people toward the draft and indicates the procedures in policy which must be observed in its administration if it is to prove itself a workable democratic institution.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The Soviet Ambassador in London has suggested a meeting of the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers before Sept. 15 to discuss the disposal of Italy's former colonies in Africa, the Moscow radio reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (AP) -Bob Snyder resigned as head coach of the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League late today. Clark Shaughnessy was named as his replacement.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 3 (UP) -Joseph M. Dodge, president of the American Bankers Association and president of the Detroit Bank, Detroit, Mich., said tonight that bankers failed to meet their responsibilities if they tried merely to do a good job in their local communities.

Plans to liquidate the Seaboard Commercial Corporation, whose home office is at 1819 Broadway, were revealed late yesterday after the Baltimore Stock Exchange had suspended dealings in the company's preferred and common stocks.

Shouted down the previous night by their own members at a mass meeting in Manhattan Center, two left-wing international officers of the Transport Workers Union issued yesterday a statement calling for a strike of private bus line employees.

The golden jubilee of Wilhelmina as Queen of the Netherlands and the relinquishing of her throne to Princess Juliana will be celebrated tomorrow in New York churches and today in New York Synagogues. h)0*0*0*iThe Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, has authorized a prescribed "Order of Service" to be used in whole or in part by the churches in the diocese.

Demands for lead for national defense stockpiles may not be as large as has been estimated up to this time because Army and Navy inspectors have located large quantities in stocks remaining in shipyards and arsenals and in the hands of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, metals specialists said yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Sinclair Weeks, Republican National Committeeman from Massachusetts, gave a bright picture today of the Republican chances for victory in his state.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- Picket lines were thrown up today in strike-bound West Coast ports as the shipping industry, accepting a fight-for-survival challenge of longshore union leaders, held "communism in the leadership of its labor unions" to be responsible for the walkout which began yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Representatives in London of both Right and Left in Czechoslovak politics paid their tributes to Eduard Benes tonight. Although he could not unite them in his lifetime, Dr. Benes commanded their respect in death.

The turf courts of the West Side Club in Forest Hills will echo to the sharp slashing of tennis ball against racquet this holiday week-end as the outstanding netmen of this country and Australia renew their rivalry in the Davis Cup Challenge Round for the silver trophy, now in possession of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Senate investigating subcommittee headed by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, feels that President Truman, by refusing to release departmental loyalty files, has created a stalemate in security which can be broken only by his own reconsideration or the election of another President with a different viewpoint.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A new combination jet propulsion-conventional engine attack bomber to operate from aircraft carriers has successfully completed its first flight tests for the Navy, it was announced today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- A "grass roots" revolt against what wash)0*0*0*idescribed as "dictatorial" methods in the selection of national officers and a fight over the racial segregation issue rocked the final session of the Veterans of Foreign Wars' encampment today.

After he had cashed three checks in rapid succession for a total of $3,366, using the purported signature of a lawyer, a salesman offered a fourth one for $500 more yesterday, while the lawyer was in the bank, and was arrested on a forgery charge.

Greentree Stable's 3-year-old filly Paddleduck, an absentee from winners' circles since she took three in a row at Aqueduct in June and July was back at the Queens County Jockey Club's track yesterday and had the role of favorite in the Class C Gloriosa Handicap.

PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Playing in her first women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament since last July, Miss Maureen Orcutt of the home club won low gross honors with a card of 42, 37 -- 79 over the west and east nines of the Ridgewood Country Club course today.

Discussions about the future of the Metropolitan the Opera House are inspiring a series of reminiscences from a veteran New York opera "fan" about the singers and conductors and audiences of our local Temple of Opera during bygone operatic seasons when both he and it were younger.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The United Nations has been called upon by an African tribal ruler -- the Mwami of Urundi -- toh)0*0*0*iright an injustice that the chieftain insists was committed against his domain more than a quarter of a century ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Democratic National Committee informally requested today that Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, Presidential candidate on the States' Rights ticket, resign his Democratic party post as national committeeman from South Carolina.

The last days of Eduard Benes, following so closely on the violent end of Jan Masaryk, epitomize the tragedy of Czechoslovakia and of the epoch in which its dead President played a leading role. During his mature years Dr. Benes saw the Czech republic rise out of the ashes of the Austrian Empire and flourish for two proud decades as the most progressive democracy in Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A statement from the Radio Corporation of America today said that Sam Basmajian was not discharged by RCA Victor as charged before a House subcommittee yesterday but is on leave at the request of the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers Union, CIO.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, unchanged to 9 points higher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Administration fired back at Harold E. Stassen and the Republican leadership today on the issue of high food prices. Republican headquarters, meanwhile, followed through on Mr. Stassen's accusations and also pressed President Truman for a statement on the Communist endorsement of his candidacy for the Vice Presidency in 1944.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3 -Floyd Odlum will resign as chairman of RKO's board of directors at a special meeting of the board to be held in New York on Tuesday, according to information obtained at that studio today, and with N. Peter Rathvon, until recently RKO president, will turn to financing and producing pictures independently.
FREEPORT, L. I., Sept. 3 -- The Sheepshead Bay Tuna Club, with a score of 900 points, took first place in the four-day United States Atlantic tournament, which was completed tonight.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Reports of a pilotless B-29 zooming across the Soviet zone of Germany toward Russia were almost as numerous today as the flying saucer rumors of last summer.h)0*0*0*iO

All of the available steel and iron scrap allocated to the United States in Germany has already been applied for, in license applications granted or still pending, it was reported yesterday. More than 24,170 tons arrived in the United States during late July and August and more than 50,000 tons were shipped from Germany, according to reports from trade sources.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 3 -More than 26,000 National Guardsmen and New York Guard members received field training this summer, staff headquarters at Camp Smith announced today.

The theme of the seventy-eighth annual meeting of the American Congress of Correction at Boston this week has been "Unifying the Correctional Process," and the keynote itself invites attention to one of our most challenging American paradoxes. Nowhere in the civilized world have enlightened penal procedures been more generally accepted, yet our crime rate is one of the highest.

For the hundredth time yesterday city children cheered as the buck-toothed magician on the trailer stage carved his sister, Salami in two and then -- lo! -- restored her again. Once more, assembled small fry clapped hands rhythmically -- as they had been doing all summer long in playgrounds throughout the five boroughs -- keeping time with the redwigged music-maker pounding on a bass drum.

The American Cyanamid Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30 a net income of $10,225,911 excluding the equity in undistributed income of associated companies 49 or 50 per cent owned.

SHANNON, Ireland, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Reacting to a passenger sitdown strike, Pan American Airways tonight promised extra planes for forty-nine New York-bound travelers put off its planes here in the last week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- More than twenty improved devices for aircraft were among the 498 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

Before the season got under way, Joe DiMaggio was asked what he would consider a good year for Joe DiMaggio. "Another pennant for the Yankees, of course, and thirty-five homers, plus 150 runs-batted-in for me," he replied. There have been times since when all three targets appeared beyond grasp, but yesterday the picture was brighter.

INTERLAKEN, Switzerland, Sept. 3 -- The question of why animals cannot reproduce at high altitudes and why or whether insects can is occupying scientists gathered here under the auspices of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to consider the problems ofh)0*0*0*ihigh mountain research.

The initial draft quota for New York City is 383 men, who will be called into service in November. This was announced yesterday by Col. Candler Cobb, Selective Service director for the city, after instructions were received from Washington.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 -- Stanton Griffis, the new United States Ambassador to Egypt, announced today that in response to his personal telegraphed appeal three days ago Basil O'Connor, head of the American Red Cross, would send two top American Red Cross officers to Cairo to survey the desperate plight of Arab refugees from Palestine.

Any and all features that women consider essential or desirable in such diverse products as easy chaairs, vacuum cleaners and socks for children will be analyzed this year by consumers throughout the country. The subjects are the focal points of discussions in the 1948-49 program of the "Consumer Speaks" project of the American Home Economics Association.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Implementation of the Marshall Plan appeared stalled tonight after the European Council had failed again to agree on a division of the first year's dollars to be supplied by the United States. Pending such an agreement the self-help by European states, which is the essential counterpart to United States aid, is in abeyance.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- A speech today by the head of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission to Italy, championing the free enterprise system, was expected to bring to a head a conflict known to exist within the Italian Cabinet between those who advocate nationalization and those who favor free enterprise.

The greatest contribution of physics to human life during the last 100 years has been in teaching that man must not extend his theories beyond the range in which they can be experimentally proved, Dr. Robert A. Millikan declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Vic Wertz's pinch single sparked a three-run ninth inning rally for Detroit as the Tigers defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5-2, before 10,285 fans here tonight.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Boston Braves were held to three blows by right-hander Emil Leonard, but they made such good use of them, thanks to Jeff Heath's seventeenth homer, that they defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 1, today in the opener of a four-game series.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- For the first time in the history of the airplane, an attempt will be made here tomorrow to set an official world speed record before a paid audience. Such assaults on world speed records are usually made in the privacy of testing fields far from the eyes of civilian onlookers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- Many issues were involved in negotiations between maritime unions and employers before the West Coast shipping strike began, but the hiring hall and wages received top billing.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 3 (AP) -Karen tribesmen living on the southern coastal strip of Tenasserim have rebelled and seized the cities of Moulmein and Thaton, it was officially announced tonight. Both towns are across the Gulf of Martaban from Rangoon and less than 100 miles from the capital.
George W. Thomas has been appointed manager of the Governor Clinton Hotel. He formerly was manager of the Wardman Park Hotel, Washington. He succeeds Edward L. Buckley who has resigned.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 3 (AP) -- An official Israeli announcement tonight said that today's truce conference here between Arab and Israeli representatives ended "without any final decisions being adopted."

Edward C. Maguire, City Commerce Commissioner, was notified yesterday that spokesmen for the Port of New York Authority and nine scheduled airlines with leases at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, would resume negotiations next Wednesday in an effort to settle their pending controversy.

The National Labor Relations Board will conduct an investigation of unfair labor practice charges filed by Oppenheim Collins Co. against Local 1250 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union of America, CIO, Charles T. Douds, NLRB regional director, said last night.

The blue-ribbon event of lawn tennis, the Davis Cup challenge round, will start today in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club. For the third year in succession the issue will be joined between Australia and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -The Commerce Department acted today to ease export license restrictions affecting New York and West Coast ports because of the strikes by cargo handlers.
This city's younger Izaak Waltons demonstrated an all-embracing compassion for the fish they caught yesterday.

Among the recommendations for a ten-year national health program submitted to President Truman last Thursday by Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, are a number that will be both praised and denounced vigorously by medical and lay persons interested in health.

IT IS rare that a scholarly book of nearly seven hundred pages, published by a university press, promises and deserves to be read by a large public. The unsensational style of the present volume lacks brilliancy and emotional appeal, but for that very reason it carries conviction and firmly drives home an authoritative explanation of the most significant events of our time.

WALLACE CARROLL has written the definitive report of the American operation in psychological warfare in the Western area in World War II. He relates what was done, how it was done, how it failed or succeeded, and why.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Undefeated Sequence, a dark bay 2-year old daughter of the famed Count Fleet, sped to a sensational nose triumph in the $53,150 Princess Pat Stakes at Washington Park today.
OMAHA, Sept. 4 -- Does the Great Plains region, the bread-basket area between the Texas Panhandle and Canada, face the threat of a new dust bowl?

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 4 -- Americans of Japanese descent are apparently winning their uphill fight against racial discrimination. Delegates to the tenth biennial convention of the Japanese American Citizens League under way here optimistically report that Nisei and their parents have "regained the high regard" of their fellow Americans, even in such states as California and Oregon.

With an estimated net excess of oil imports of about 200,000 barrels a day needed to meet domestic requirements this winter, the time appears to be at hand when a determined effort should be given toward the development of a synthetic fuels industry in the United States.

"TO arrive at some idea of the culture of a certain street in a Middle Western small town shortly before the First World War, is a * * * delicate undertaking," runs one meditative chapter-ending in this novel. But even more delicate, and more difficult, is the projection in fiction of the breathing people, the living relationships, the very air and feeling of such a time and place.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Preservation of two basic freedoms of the American way of life, freedom of thought and of the ballot, was urged today upon delegates of 30,000 nonpartisan citizens aged 18 to 30 from 150 communities in the state.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- No development in the Berlin crisis or in the whole course of Soviet-American relations this year has aroused so much debate and, in certain quarters, apprehension as the convening of the four Military Governors of Germany in a "working committee" of the Moscow Conference.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser notched his sixteenth victory today when he pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 4-3 triumph over the Chicago White Sox Newhouser allowed nine hits in gaining his first victory in five starts since Aug. 8 as Chicago scored all its runs in the sixth inning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Monday will witness the kickoff in the current renewal of the great quadrennial political classic that will keep American fandom on its toes from now until the first Tuesday in November.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- While awaiting new textbooks and revised curriculums, biology teachers in the Soviet secondary schools have been told to revise their courses to make them conform to the Marxist conception of genetics that has recently been adopted as official Communist party dogma.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- With a long week-end holiday coming up, the grain market on the Board of Trade was allowed to drift today. It drifted lower.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Pitcher Ned Garver won his own game with a tenth-inning single that drove in Dick Kokos to give the Browns a 4-3 verdict over the Indians tonight before 17,092. Leroy (Satchel) Paige, the famed Negro pitcher, was knocked out by the Browns in the fifth. Ed Klieman was the loser.
LONDON. PETER USTINOV, who will produce, direct, adapt and play the title role of Eric Linglater's "Private Angelo," is all set to fly to Italy for preliminary exterior shooting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The loyalty program set up by the executive branch of the Government had failed to deal effectively with subversive activities among the 2,000,000 Federal employes, a Senate Sub-committee investigating Communists in United States positions charged today.

AMID the beauty of the Long Island countryside, on a 300-yard carpet of green turf that has been the stage for intense drama in the past, one of America's traditional sports events will be renewed this afternoon.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of a twelve-man commission to handle housing and employment problems expected to arise here in connection with the Federal law admitting displaced persons to the United States.
While millions of Americans spent yesterday at resorts, a couple of hundred of them from all over the country sat around the New Yorker Hotel for the better part of an afternoon working puzzles.

CRACOW, Poland, Aug. 28 -- Here, in this ancient university town that was the "capital" of the German occupation Government of Hans Frank, the Nazis' demographic war against the Polish children is still paying off. That part of the Hitler genocide program was so to starve and weaken the children of this country by systematic malnutrition that those who might survive to adolescence would nevertheless be marked for life.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 4 (NANA) -- The Dixiecrats don't like the name "Dixiecrats."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The United States today cleared the way for emigration of Jews of military age, but not trained fighting personnel, to Israel from the United States zones of Germany and Austria. The government notified Israel that American commanders would expedite the movement of Jews who qualify for admission to the state under regulations laid down by Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator.

TWO girl hikers have disappeared in a mountainous region of Australia, and a detective sent out to search for them has been murdered. Clearly this is a case for Inspector Napoleon Bonaparte, Australia's greatest detective.

PUTTING one thought after another, it doesn't look too promising for the firm of Robert Joseph, Frank Satenstein, Mark Marvin and Canada Lee to be putting on William Saroyan's "Jim Dandy." Although it is claimed that money is not the reason, there seem to be other problems, and, to satisfy the conditions under which the option was given, a first-class production must be ready by Nov. 1.

IN a parents' discussion group a mother said that her child refused to eat cereal and milk at breakfast, and asked what to do. When it was suggested that she try something else, that maybe toast and cocoa would be Just as nutritious, the mother exclaimed, "But won't I 'spoil' her if I give in?"

HAVANA -- Cuba, long a vacationland for Americans, is seeing a reversal of the tide of travel this summer as thousands of its own citizens visit the United States. Florida is the main tourist objective. According to Francis J. H. Dever, the officer in charge of immigration at Miami, 16,345 Cubans arrived there during June and July.
OF the four foreign masters of this shattered city, the Russians are by far the most strange and contradictory. They are at once arrogant and homesick, dynamic and sluggish, efficient and ignorant.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley arrived in Rome by air this afternoon to attend the thirty-seventh conference of the Interparliamentary Union, which will meet in the Italian Chamber of Deputies throughout next week.

William C Wessell, national director of cub scouting for the Boy Scouts of America, will depart Wednesday for Frankfort on the Main, Germany, to train leaders for three Scout organizations that have been recognized by the United State Military Government, it was announced yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Members of the State War Disaster Military Corps, New York Guard, finished their packing tonight at Camp Smith preparatory to leaving for their homes tomorrow morning. Final inspections of equipment were completed. Departure of these troops ends the season at camp.

MANILA, Sept. 4 -- The Philippine Court of Industrial Relations ruled today that Manila's Evening News does not have to retain as its editor Cipriano Cid, veteran newspaperman and labor leader. Mr. Cid's contention that the publisher, Ramon Roces, had dismissed him for his labor activities caused an editorial department strike lasting five weeks.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- Ernest Wilson of Ingersoll, Ont., captured th first heat of the Silver Cup power boat races on the Detroit River today by going the 45 miles with his Miss Canada III in an average speed of 73.881 miles an hour. The second and final heat is scheduled for Monday.

TO a world still shuddering from the impact of the second cataclysmic war to mark the twentieth century and in a state of rising anxiety lest a third and even more devastating conflict break out, the question of what forces cause war and how wars may be averted holds a vivid interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The House Labor Committee's initial sortie into Communist influence among trade unions this week may provide a new legislative springboard from which to attack the problem of Communist infiltration.

WHEN the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opens its tenth anniversary season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 18 there will be not only five glamorous guest artists names on the roster but also a number of new names down through the ranks.

WHATEVER was ailing them, the young men and women who glittered around for a decade after World War I were interesting to read about. But the lost generation which has come out of the recent war is different.

Leo's mother had warned him that out of her litter of four he would not be chosen to go to the Swiss Alpine hospice where the monks trained their dogs, unless he showed signs of being smart.

ADD to the lengthening list of critical and instructive books on cinema an excellent little volume entitled "The Art of the Film," which embraces a clear, concise analysis of all the techniques of film creation. Written by Ernest Lindgren of the staff of the British Film Institute and curator of the National Film Library, it fills a long-felt need for a handbook that will serve the film craftsman, critic, student and customer alike.

The heat hastened the turn, but it was the seasonal time for the trees to begin to show weariness; and now they show a faint bronze tone where so recently all was deep, lush green. The elms particularly show it. They have lost a good many leaves already, in part because the Japanese beetles have been at work on them but also because they don't stand on ceremony when their summer's work is done.

After several months of planning, the city is ready to start its first unsubsidized public housing project for veterans as part of the $200,000,000 program approved by the Board of Estimate last March.

A letter just received from Peter Barrett, now on a busman's holiday out in Sun Valley, Ida gives some interesting proof on the reasons behind the tendency of many anglers to follow Horace Greeley's much quoted advice, if only for their too brief vacations.

THE balance of power theory has long been a whipping boy of liberal publicists and commentators on international affairs. In the popular mind it is associated with "professional diplomacy," "secret treaties," "power politics" and other forces supposedly destructive of international harmony.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 4 -- Only children under 14 years of age and older persons in the refugee camps at Dachau and Allach near Munich ate their usual meals today, in compliance with a vote taken last night to go on a hunger strike.

ONE reads with more than ordinary curiosity manuscript chapters of the forthcoming book. "The Music of Israel," by Dr. Peter Gradenwitz, the composer and musicologist of Palestine, to which he soon returns after a prolonged and busy sojourn in America.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Before a crowd of 21,296 spectators, the Brookfield Farms' Imacomin streaked to victory in the third running of the World's Playground Stakes, first of two juvenile stakes to be decided here. The Helopolis filly reached the finish of the three-quarter-mile dash three lengths before Mrs. Willis Sharpe Kilmer's Sun Bahram to pick up $9,950 for owner Harry Isaacs of Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Chicago's post-war street repaying and repair program is lagging nearly 50 per cent behind schedule because of a shortage of cement, Lloyd Johnson, Commissioner of Streets and Electricity, said this week. At present, he said, all maintenance and repair work requiring concrete has been suspended.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Truman and Governor Dewey contended today for the allegiance of American Federation of Labor members in Labor Day messages written for The American Federationist, the AFL's monthly magazine.

More insistent consumer demands for quality in merchandise and less evidence of price resistance keynoted August retail business in the New York area, it was reported here last week. With the month showing a department store increase of 4 per cent. despite a week of extremely hot weather, as compared with August of last year, most retailers expressed themselves as satisfied with results.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 4 -- Jimmy McLane of Akron, 17-year-old Olympic champion, today snapped back from a surprise defeat to win his third straight senior men's 400-meter free-style championship in the National A.A.U. outdoor swimming meet.

TORONTO, Sept. 4 -- Although he, himself, has given no public indication of his intentions and hopes, it is confidently stated by his friends here that Premier George A. Drew of Ontario will be a candidate for the leadership of the Conservative party in the Federal Parliament and that he will be elected to the position by the party convention, which meets in Ottawa in a few weeks.

A NEW Roosevelt myth is in the making. From the documents and diaries, the papers and the prejudices of those who during the tumultuous years of the longest Presidency in our history worked with him and against him there is emerging a portrait that bears little resemblance to the man we thought we knew.
THE master of modern cookery wrote in his cook book: "And, indeed, it is a great mistake to suppose that, in order to do good cooking, it is necessary to be extravagant in one's use of all things."
Two young men accused of looting a summer apartment in Brooklyn and threatening some of the occupants with knives were captured later sitting on a bench and held for grand jury action yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- Meeting in the middle of a feverish, uncertain city the four military governors made reasonably good progress today toward an agreement on the timing and methods for the lifting of the Russian blockade of Berlin.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (Reuters) -- Portsmouth, the surprise package of the new English football season, gave 30,000 fans another thrill today with a 1-to-0 triumph at Stoke City and took over undisputed leadership of the first division.

ELY CULBERTSON says that 98 per cent of all bridge players use the Culbertson System of bidding. Maybe he is right, maybe he is wrong, maybe he uses pardonable poetic license. He says further that the worst bridge player in the world is the one who plays the Culbertson System 100 per cent, unless it is the one who plays it less than 80 per cent.
Albert Eckhardt Jr. has been elected commodore of the junior division of the Larchmont Yacht Club. Buddy Bombard is the vice commodore and Miss Anne Carr the rear commodore.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 4 -- Willie Turnesa is once more amateur golf champion of the United States.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Lefty Ken Raffensberger again proved his mastery of St. Louis today as he set the Cards down on five hits for a 3-1 Cincinnati victory.
The tonnage of shipbuilding on order in private American yards has increased five-fold in the last year, chiefly as a result of tanker orders, a survey of the industry indicates.

Darvisul is a new chemical compound which attracted attention a few months ago because of its remarkable effect on animals that had been artificially inoculated with an especially potent strain of poliomyelitis virus.

PLOVDIV, Bulgaria, Sept. 4 -- United States, Swiss and German industries are impressively represented at the twelfth international fair being held in this city by a formidable array of Soviet copies of their heavy machine tools, centrifugal pumps, electrical equipment, agricultural machines, precision instruments, automobiles, typewriters and other industrial products.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Revolt-swept Southeast Asia is becoming one of the major danger spots in a troubled world.

Five thousand chemists flocked to Washington last week to attend the 114th annual meeting of the American Chemical Society, one of our largest scientific organizations. Several hundred papers on highly technical phases of chemistry were read, most of them intended for specialists.

The successful experiment of the States Terminal Corporation with a low-cost monorail lift system for moving unboxed automobiles onto the upper deck of Pier 51, North River, has attracted interest in shipping circles and brought inspection visits from Government, port and steamship company officials.

THIS vigorous book, like two other recent historical novels about Florida, is chiefly interesting for its vivid setting and bustling melodrama. While Robert Wilder's "Bright Feather" and Baynard Kendrick's "The Flames of Time" draw from the state's earlier history, "Three Roads to Valhalla" is a less adventurous and a more subtly feminine study of the mad, murderous, more recent Reconstruction era.

In a Labor Day statement issued yesterday, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, declared that virtually all gains made by labor in New York State under the administrations of three Democratic Governors, Alfred E. Smith Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman, had been wiped out by the administration of Governor Dewey.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Leaders of the European Council for the Marshall Plan have appealed to United States officials to break the prolonged deadlock that has frustrated the Council's effort to divide dollar credits among the European recipients.

A SIGNIFICANTLY sharp drop in the number of Russian films exhibited by theatres in South America has occurred during the last eight months. Observers interested in such developments from a commercial and political standpoint informed this department that theatre owners are shying away from Soviet pictures even though they can be obtained for practically nothing.

IN an author's note Mr. Shute explains that he has written his latest novel to underline the point that "the scrupulous and painstaking investigation of accidents is the key to all safety in the air and demands the services of men of the very highest quality."

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Fourteen countries and a number of major relief agencies have pledged emergency aid of foodstuffs, medicines and special supplies to more than 400,000 Arab and Jewish refugees in the Holy Land, it was disclosed here today.

With thousands of veterans in the New York area still looking in vain for suitable living quarters within their means, the GI home-mortgage market here and elsewhere is drying up in the face of a prospective increase in interest rates that would send inflated housing costs still higher, it was learned yesterday.

ORPHANED just as her ship enters New Amsterdam Harbor, Ulrica, friendless in Peter Stuyvesant's colony, has her own way to make, and finds it a rocky one. She is turned over to a feminine Simon Legree who keeps a tavern.

Spread of New York's four-day-old truck walkout to 20,000 drivers in six New Jersey locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, after midnight tomorrow appeared a virtual certainty yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin today credited "the vital force of labor" for this country's high standard of living.

After offering for nearly two years the only American college course devoted entirely to "dating," Bowling Green State University at Bowling Green, Ohio, has found that: (1) students who frequently "date" make better grades than the stay-at-homes; (2) inadequate training within the family is responsible for ignorance about "dating" courtship and marriage; (3) ideally, the course should not need to be taught at all.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 -- The barring of Henry A. Wallace's Progressive party from the November ballot in Missouri has touched off political fireworks that may involve a bitter legal tangle.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The visit to Washington of Gladwyn Jebb, British representative on the permanent commission of the Brussels treaty powers, has focused attention again on the problem of expanding the Western European Union by the adherence of other European powers.

United States exporters do not regard the answer made last week by the Economic Cooperation Administration as invalidating the proposals they made to ECA for liquidation of past-due obligations owed them in Latin-American countries. Such frozen funds were estimated as running into hundreds of millions.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 4 -- In the closing minutes the final plenary session of the assembly of the World Council of Churches agreed today to revise the report formally received Thursday, urging the churches to reject the ideology of both communism and capitalism.

Crystalline procaine penicillin G, the latest and most useful form of penicillin, was synthesized for the first time a few months ago. Already it has risen to a position of prominence in the medical profession's roster of accepted therapeutic agents. Because it is only slightly soluble in water, crystalline procaine penicillin G is injected intra- muscularly, suspended in sesame oil.

The Rural Electrification Administration struck back at its critics yesterday with accusations of "ingenious blending of facts and distortions" after issuance of a study by officials of REA electric cooperatives in Minnesota, North Dakota and Wisconsin in which that Federal agency was charged with inefficient financial operations.

Retail activity here last week recovered from the heat wave and business was stimulated by new season merchandise, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. College shops, misses' dress and shoe departments reported highest sales.

ESCALDAS, Andorra -- A trip to this little republic in the Pyrenees cannot be planned with the help of elaborate travel brochures, nor can the tourist get information from the local embassy, for Andorra maintains no diplomatic representation in the United States.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 -- Paul Mantz, Hollywood stunt pilot, won the Bendix Trophy race today for the third time in three years, but failed to break the record he established last year.

Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party nominee for President, will give his answer to the endorsement of President Truman by the executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations tomorrow afternoon before the thirteenth annual convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- Independent nominating petitions for President and Vice President were filed with the Secretary of State just before today's 5 P. M. deadline by the Socialist Workers (Trotskyists) and the Industrial Government (Socialist Labor) parties.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 -- Almost 16,000 employes of nine oil companies went on strike early today, shutting down California refineries which supply 95 per cent of the gasoline and petroleum products used in the whole West Coast region.

The investigation into Communist activity in the United States last week was a three-ring affair. There was an addendum to the investigation of the House Committee on Un-American Activities into the Whittaker Chambers-Alger Hiss affair. There was a tangential investigation by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service in the case of Alexander Stevens, alias J. Peters, alleged leader of the Communist underground in the United States.

SWAYING cornfields and rows of beans are not usually associated with New York City, but the city's men-with-the-hoes made their contribution to the country's record crop output this year. THE "Theatre Guild on the Air" returns to WJZ-ABC next Sunday at 9:30 P. M. and in preparation for the 1948-49 season. Guild heads have struck on the eminently sound idea of having well known playwrights prepare the radio adaptations to be heard on the hour-long radio series.
A song writer's informal efforts to present one of his latest creations to a pre-holiday Times Square throng ended in his arrest last night and the snarling of traffic.

PRAGUE, Sept. 4 -- A state funeral for former President Eduard Benes will be held Wednesday in Prague. His body will be buried at his country home in Sezimovo Usti on Thursday or Friday in a quiet corner garden where he requested that his grave should be.

After two months of disappointing price changes, the stock market ushered in the usual September pre-Presidential election year upturn last week. Rising prices in he London market, reflecting more optimistic views abroad on the "bargaining" negotiations with Moscow, evidently gave the cue.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- As Britain's air exercises moved into their second day -- with one United States and one British airman dead as a result of air accidents -- senior Royal Air Force officers expressed the conviction today that Britain's air defenses were "sound."

THE controversy between the Port of New York Authority and nine scheduled airlines operating out of the New York area appears to be about where it was six or more months ago. But even more disturbing to New Yorkers and airline travelers is the strong indication that neither party to the dispute shows the slightest signs of weakening.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 4 -- A program of training marine biologists, now relatively few in number, is being planned by the Narragansett Marine Biological Laboratory. Closed since 1942, the laboratory was re-established this week at Fort Kearney, Saunderstown, R. I.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Miss Beverly Baker, 18-year-old Santa Monica, Calif., girl who plays equally well with either left or right hand, today won the national girls' tennis championship and shared in the doubles crown.

IN some ways this is an unusual historical novel. For one thing it is brief. For another, not a sword is drawn in its fewer than 300 pages. No underclad hussy adorns the book's jacket, and no Amber cavorts within. It is, in short, the most wholesome hammock-companion of the season.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Mounting prices have had no elect whatever on demand for new passenger automobiles. This is the conclusion of many industry analysts closely checking on order accumulations and production volume. The National Automobile Dealers Association, which has made the most recent survey of the unfilled order backlog, places the total at 7,300,000.

JASPER, Alberta -- The continuous rains in the West, which are giving the American and Canadian prairies one of the largest harvests in years, have also considerably damaged the local tourist business. During the month of August Jasper National Park has counted twenty-six straight days of rain.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Best-in-show honors among 990 dogs at the Interstate Kennel Club fixture on the Washington Irving High School grounds today went to a Doberman pinscher, Ch. Baptiste's War News, owned by Mrs. A. C. Langshaw of Gaylordville, Conn., and handled by Nate Levine.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet news agency Tass said tonight that Chinese Gen. Feng Yu-Hsiang and his daughter were among the "victims" of a fire aboard the Russian motorship Pobeda, in the Black Sea. It did not say how badly they were burned.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The national economy appeared basically sound to the doctors this week. But they noted, judiciously, that as in even the healthiest human organism, weaknesses can quickly develop which demand prompt attention and care.
ORIENTAL poppies belong on the list of plants for which planting or division begins in late summer. These May flowers are dominant in the pageant of spring bloom.

A New York automobile owner could get his car washed yesterday in considerably less time than it takes to fill his gasoline tank -- a little over a minute. That is, if he went to one of the thirty automatic "assembly line" car washers that have sprung up in the Metropolitan area in the last few months.

Fragments of a shattered hurricane are due to sweep up the Atlantic Coast and the Ohio Valley today, bringing gentle rains to millions of holiday visitors.

In the top engagement of this week-end's All-America Football Conference schedule, the New York Yankees will tackle the Baltimore Colts today at Baltimore's Municipal Stadium. BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4 -- More than two months have passed since Premier Tito's expulsion from the Cominform world. Developments since that event indicate that Marshal Tito and his co-leaders of the Yugoslav Communist party will continue to resist successfully the combined efforts of the Soviet-bloc parties to oust them from power.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Sun Beau, 10-year-old chestnut gelding from the Sterling Smith Stables, Ravenna, Ohio, took first place in the $250 open Jumper Stake, closing event on the first day's program at the fall horse show of the Rice Farms today.

Tomorrow -- Sept. 6, 1948 -- the summer vacation season comes to a close. It has been, on the whole, a bonanza season. Travel agencies estimate that 70,000,000 Americans -- half the population -- have had a summer respite; that 10,000,000 more American workers had paid vacations than in pre-war summers.

ATHENS, Sept. 4 -- Greek Army reports today spoke of continued local operations against the Communist-led guerrillas over most of the length of the northern frontiers from Pogonion, in Epirus, to Ano Drossini in Thrace. From the strong resistance the Army encountered, the rebels were fighting hard to keep open their supply lines to the Balkan-Soviet-bloc states.

IN the ancient Nieuwe Kerk of Amsterdam tomorrow a quiet young matron with no love for the limelight will become Queen of the Netherlands. Juliana Louisa Emma Maria Wilhelmina, Princess of Orange-Nassau, is taking over the burden of office from her mother, Queen Wilhelmina, who has reigned half a century and is now beset by illness and fatigue.

FALL asters may be seen in bloom during the next few weeks. Selected for color and height, they may be transplanted immediately to one's own garden. The ease with which they may be moved is a good trait, for too often the planting of fall flowers is neglected in spring, so that September finds us with a dreary, wintry-looking scene that needs quick refurbishing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, and Oscar L. Chapman, Undersecretary of the Interior, will be chairman and vice chairman respectively of the United States delegation to the first Inter-American Conference on the Conservation of Renewable National Resources, the State Department announced today.

PARIS, Sunday, Sept. 5 -- After night-long negotiations, Robert Schuman, former Premier and Popular Republican leader, was reported to have formed his second Cabinet, including the Socialists, at 7 o'clock this morning. M. Schuman took up the Premiership again yesterday, after having quit Cabinet-forming efforts Friday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 4 -- Henry A. Wallace headed home to New York tonight after completing a seven-day campaign tour of the South that produced a mixture of public demonstrations featuring gifts of eggs and tomatoes, apathy and occasional enthusiasm.

Retailers reported a rapid turnover in all departments last week, and consequently reorders received by apparel wholesalers, particularly for ready-to-wear and sportswear, were heavy, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buying office. Deeply concerned about the effect of the trucking strike on business, retailers sought ways to get around the delivery stoppage in order to obtain shipments of ordered merchandise.

YONKERS, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- A 48-year-old weaver of this city drowned this afternoon in the Hudson River after he had fallen off his homemade cabin boat and two men aboard were unable to stop the craft's engine or turn her about in time.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 4 -- Encouraged by official moves in the United States to modify the German reparations program, German leaders are pressing not only for a halt in dismantling but also for reconsideration of the restitution program as well.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- In Interlaken, Switzerland, this week the project for a federated Europe was again discussed by the European Parliamentary Union and a sample constitution for such a federation was drafted.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Beneficial radioactive isotopes from the United States atomic laboratories here are now available to twenty-one countries, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

Six men, accused of beating a policeman, were arraigned on charges of felonious assault yesterday in Felony Court before Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 4 (UP) -- New Orleans escaped major damage today from a "surprise" hurricane.

MANILA, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Thirty thousand persons have fled by sea from the volcano-ravaged island of Camiguin, and the remaining 15,000 population fearfully await rescue from its ash-clad shores, the Philippines Government reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The story of every Presidential campaign is a story of extremes. Each party whoops up its own record and kicks around the opposition's. Each has its professional politicians, who think only of the next election, and its statesmen, who can also think of the next generation. Sometimes the Republicans win and sometimes the Democrats win, but in the heat of the contest, truth always suffers.

A study expected to encourage enactment by more states of laws prohibiting any form of tampering with serial numbers and other identification on electrical or mechanical devices was announced yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc. The chief purpose of such laws would be to curb "pirating" of refrigerators and other brand-name appliances.

The airlift to Berlin is not cheap. It costs $260,000 a day, not counting the goods or their transportation to Germany. Barge, road or overland could supply Berlin more economically and with bigger cargoes. BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- The introduction of a continuous work week into western Germany's steel industry as a means of spurring production was proposed in a report submitted by a working party assigned to investigate the shortcomings of the industry, it was learned today.

Complaining that he had been delayed two days after he had obtained a reservation for a flight from Shannon Airport, Franklin G. SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Sept. 4 -- A record was bettered at the all-breed dog show here yesterday in which Champion Stowaway at Deer Creek, a Labrador retriever, was adjudged best in show and best American-bred in show.

LAKE MOHAWK, N. J., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Nineteen - year - old Mary Frances Cunningham of Nutley added the A.A.U. women's national junior three-meter diving crown to her laurels today at the Lake Mohawk Marine Pool.

THE New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, offers six courses in gardening and nature study, the first of them to start Saturday. "Field Botany," with G. L. Wittrock as instructor, will be given on Saturdays from 1:30 to 3 P. M., starting this week. Planned for adults who wish to become acquainted with the trees and wild flowers of the New York area, it will include lecture tours of woodlands and meadows.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The California wine grower is about to assume his annual role of unofficial host and unpaid guide for tourists in the "Wineland of America." Since the days of the Spanish padres, who planted the first vineyard in California at Mission San Diego in 1769, the tradition of hospitality to visitors has been maintained along the "winery trail," which now stretches from near the Mexican border northward 700 miles toward Oregon.

AZOR had that gift of which nearly ever child secretly dreams. Animals talk to him, telling him important and useful things, such as who sent him a valentine and where to find Mrs. Woodfin's lost earring. But Azor's family and friends were worse than skeptical; a 6-year-old boy, they said, was too big for such foolishness.

CALIFORNIA design and California designers have received a good deal of acclaim lately and Eastern homemakers could hardly have missed the California labels on numerous fabrics, pottery and other products in the accessory class. AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 4 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands abdicated the throne here in the capital this morning after having reigned longer than any living sovereign. She succeeded her father, King William III, upon his death Nov. 23, 1890, when she was 10 years old.

Selective Service headquarters will begin sending out mobile squads Tuesday to help speed registration whenever and where-ever they are needed throughout the city. This was announced yesterday by Maj. Paul Akst, in charge of registration.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 4 -- With the promulgation last night of a constitutional reform law after a speech hailing it mainly by denouncing his Opposition, President Juan D. Peron may be said to have reached one of the recurrent peaks in his career.

NEW YORK children entering school this fall are in for a surprise: they're not going to be taught "penmanship." Instead, as the result of a recommendation by the Board of Superintendents, they'll be allowed to use the "manuscript" or block system of writing, which seems to be the natural way for kids to write; and the way the early monks wrote, too.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The United States is reported to have paid the equivalent of 22 cents a pound for 30,000 tons of raw rubber in a deal concluded here this week by the strategic materials mission of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Seventy-one persons will make up the United States delegation to the third session of the General Assembly of the United Nations, opening at Paris Sept. 21, the State Department announced today.

The United States open polo championship will get under way today at Meadow Brook's International Field in Westbury, L. I., with a Westbury team headed by Mike Phipps opposing a Great Neck quartet that includes George Oliver and Alan Corey.

HALLOWELL, Me., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Forty-nine thousand gallons of gasoline which leaked from a tanker moved seaward down the Kennebec River today as patrols sought to prevent ignition of the volatile fluid.

A FEW years ago Mr. Hayek, like a twentieth-century pamphleteer, wrote "The Road to Serfdom," practically a best seller. GENEVA, Sept. 4 -- European farmers are gathering in their best harvest since the war. With news arriving from America of another bumper crop of grain, the post-war food crisis appears to be over.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 4 -- Texas voters will not know until Sept. 14 whether they nominated former Gov. Coke Stevenson or Representative Lyndon B. Johnson, for the United States Senate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kielty of Long Beach won the forty-eighth annual Women's Western amateur golf championship today from her Curtis Cup team-mate, Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex. The California state champion finished the 36-hole final round 1 up.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 4 -- Georgia's bitter political rivals, M. E. Thompson and Herman Talmadge, the principals in the state's two Governors' controversy of 1947, are winding up another heated fight for the Governorship in next Wednesday's state Democratic primary.

TO commemorate "the 100th anniversary of the achievement of responsible government" in Canada, the Dominion postal authorities will release on Oct. 1 a 4-cent blue-gray stamp picturing the Parliament Buildings in Ottawa and bearing portraits of Queen Victoria and her great-grandson George VI.

Willie Pep, Hartford (Conn.) battler who holds the featherweight championship of the world, will be in action at Madison Square Garden for the first time in two years when he tackles Paddy De Marco of Brooklyn in the main event on Friday night. Nearly 75 per cent of the Armed Forces Leave bonds, popularly called Terminal Leave bonds, have been cashed in by veterans of World War II in the first year since the privilege of surrendering them for cash before maturity was granted.

And although the weekly battle between the weeds and the hammock is almost over, the talk about the tomato that was "this big!" and that mammoth-sized zinnia will go on all winter.

Steps that can help alleviate the steel industry's most serious problem -- dire shortage of scrap metal that threatens curtailment of steel production next winter -- will be taken this week in Washington at two meetings convened by the Department of Commerce, according to industry sources.

In a "Labor Sunday Message" to be read today in churches throughout the country both labor and management are asked by Protestant leaders to consider the welfare of all, and not merely that of their own economic group.
Hanging on with bulldog tenacity to the pace of the flying leaders in the American League pennant race the Yankees pummeled the Senators into submission by a score of 9 to 7 at the Stadium yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- The Boston Red Sox made three of their eight hits, a walk and two Philadelphia mistakes good for three runs in the eighth inning today as they whipped the Athletics. 5---3, and retained first place in the American League race.

Further development of the discussion among bankers and life insurance executives regarding problems of money management discloses that the views of Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, on some points at least, are in accord with those of bankers.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Robert F. Wagner Jr. said tonight that "reactionary forces" sought to destroy labor gains in the United States and that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey could not "disassociate himself" from the record of the Eightieth Congress.
BOSTON, Sept. 4 -- Splitting a double-header with the Philadelphia Phils, the top-place Boston Braves pulled two games ahead of the defeated Brooklyn Dodgers today before 17,884 fans.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 (AP) -- One of the nation's big steelmasters today asked his customers to help the campaign to legalize the steel industry's traditional pricing methods. He is Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board of the National Steel Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- A new edition of the Bible becomes available at Sabbath observances for the first time tomorrow.

THE newly redecorated Governors' Room at the Senate House Museum in Kingston, N. Y., will be formally reopened to the public on Saturday. Among the exhibits on display are those which were presented to the state by the late Judge Alton B. Parker, whose home was near Kingston.

MEXICO CITY -- The recent devaluation of the Mexican peso from its official rate of 4.85 to the new level ranging from 6.75 to 6.85 to the dollar spells increased purchasing power and less expensive vacations for the American visitor to Mexico.

Sudden death on the wings of a Navy Corsair fighter struck four persons yesterday afternoon when the plane crashed into a four-family home one block from the Bayside station of the Long Island Rail Road. The victims included the pilot, a Marine Corps reserve officer on his first day of a two-week reserve training course, two women occupants of the house at 39-29 212th Street and a woman visitor.

A program for improving conditions among salesmen was disclosed yesterday when Louis A. Capaldo, president of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, announced the opening of a Northwest regional office of the council in Minneapolis. Derso Sebeok Shybekay, member of the University of Minnesota faculty and author of nearly sixty textbooks on industrial management, market research and related subjects, will head the new office as Northwest regional representative of the National Council.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Coincident with the start of registering an estimated 9,600,000 young civilians, defense authorities announced this week that in the first month of draft operation only 10,000 men would be called into the Army, none into the Navy and none into the Air Force.

PRAGUE, Sept. 4 -- An extraordinary people's tribunal sentenced today in absentia Vladimir Krajina, secretary general of the late Eduard Benes' National Socialist party and a leading Czech anti-Communist, to twenty-five years in prison. A report of the trial issued by the official news agency made no mention of any defense. The accused man is in London.

All along, the head of the house had a disturbed feeling that no good would come of staying in tourist cabins. Accustomed to living graciously on expense accounts, he had settled contentedly into the hotel rut and he wished to remain there.

QUEENSTON, Ont., Sept. 5 (Canadian Press) -- William (Red) Hill Jr. 34-year-old riverman riding the Niagara River rapids in a steel barrel, ended his five-mile trip tonight after twice becoming trapped at treacherous points in the river.

The question of what form war memorials shall take is so productive of controversy that any new proposal must be offered with full discount in advance for expected criticism and sometimes even ridicule. Nevertheless, we venture to make a suggestion to groups in the various boroughs of New York City that they consider, among the many good ideas already brought forward, the possibility of building public library branches in areas not now served.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 6 (UP) -- A Moscow radio broadcast on the Soviet request said that Soviet Ambassadors in Washington, London and Paris had delivered notes to the three governments Saturday, saying that:

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 5 -- So far the European Recovery Program ish) 0*0*0*ishowing little visible influence on the economy and finances of the Netherlands except that doubtless a sharp recession has been avoided.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs roared back with a vengeance today to take the nightcap, 11 to 3, after dropping the first game of a double-header to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 to 3.
PARIS, Sept. 5 -- What follows is a report on the situation in Yugoslavia. It can be described as coming from expert, intelligent and customarily accurate sources.

A Lido deck and outdoor swimming pool, the first ever to be built on a liner designed for the Atlantic northern route, will be one of the innovations on the new Caronia, which Cunard White Star hopes to have ready to enter service in November.
AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 5 (AP) -Jimmy McLane and Joe Verdeur, two Olympic titleholders, splashed to victories today in closing events of the National A.A.U. outdoor swimming championships.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 5 -Larry Evans, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, and Aaron A. Rothman of the Bronx took the lead late tonight in the tournament for the New York State championship. Both have two straight victories to their credit.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 5 -Bringing to a climax the Lebanese national festival of Al-Mahrajan here today, Dr. Stephen B. L. Penrose, president-designate of the American University in Beirut, hailed the influence of Lebanon as one of the factors in American greatness.
On Aug. 28 you printed a letter from E. M. Cousins entitled "Abuse of Unemployment Insurance."
PARIS, Sept. 5 -- French financial experts today are gravely concerned over the fate of French finances as a result of the present political crisis.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Grain markets were on the upgrade in the forepart of last week, due to short covering in wheat and corn and on a tight cash corn situation, but when longs tried to take profits they found support slow and the markets reacted quickly.

The relatively small segment of the advertising trade that produces the gadgets and gifts offered by large companies for box tops and a nominal fee expects to gross a record $150,000,000 this year, it was learned last week.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 5 -Soft clams, mysteriously missing from Rhode Island waters for the past five years, have returned by the millions to scattered points in Narragansett Bay.

Despite the well-known French axiom, the provisional has not turned out to be enduring in France. There is little hope that a second Schuman Government will last as long as the first. What endures in that unhappy land, in mind and character the land of reason, is political disorder and irrational partisanship.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, will open its thirteenth annual convention here today, with anti-Communist forces renewing their fight to oust leftists from control of the union.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- A shortage of breeze during the major part of the afternoon played havoc with the twenty-third Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta, sponsored by the Port Washington Yacht Club today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 -- An unofficial world's speed record of 669.75 miles an hour was set at the National Air Races here today by Maj. Richard L. Johnson of the United States Air Force, flying a North American F-86 jet fighter. However, hitches in timing the plane with cameras forced further trial runs tomorrow and no official record was allowed.
Earle Horace Daniel thinks -- and has always thought -- that a man ought to stand on his own feet, even if they are artificial. He has dedicated his life to that proposition.
Broader understanding between labor and management was urged yesterday in Labor Day sermons in city churches.

Aided and abetted by Joe DiMaggio's thirty-third homer of the campaign, a freakish two-bagger that popped off the Clipper's bat in the sixth, and some old-fashioned relief pitching by Joe Page, the Yankees toppled the Senators, 5 to 3, at the Stadium yesterday to the eminent satisfaction of 24,655 onlookers.

ZURICH, Sept. 5 -- Resisting all pressure from British authorities, the Italian Government confirmed last week its refusal to take proposed action aimed at making the sterling-dollars cross rate on the free exchange market in Italy identical with the parity of sterling in dollars at the official rate.
MANILA, Monday, Sept. 6 (AP) -Fiery Mount Hibok Hibok erupted with new vigor today, its outpouring of lava and ashes burying five persons alive. It presented an even greater menace -- poison gases.

AGAWAM, Mass., Sept. 5 -- The first half of a two-day regatta for the Eastern outboard hydroplane championships was concluded this afternoon on a smooth, sunbathed stretch of the Connecticut River.
