More than 10,000 spectators saw Vic Scott, veteran Forest Hills, L.I. daredevil, retain his Class B professional crown won here last summer.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren moved quickly today to protect California's multi-million dollar fruit and farm crops during the oil refinery strike.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- The Soviet Government announced today that a note had been sent to Britain, the United States and France calling for a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers to consider the question of the former Italian colonies.
General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will be installed as the thirteenth president of Columbia University on Columbus Day, Oct. 12, it was made known yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5 (AP) -Howie Pollet's eight-hit pitching and a spurt of wildness by Redleg Kent Peterson combined today to give St. Louis a 5-1 victory over Cincinnati in the Cards' final appearance of the season at Crosley Field.
BERKELEY, Calif, Sept. 5 (AP) -General Feng's daughter-in-law today raised the possibility here that he might have been the victim of his own motion picture hobby.

Revival of inactive department and specialty store accounts will be a major responsibility of credit departments during the latter part of this month and through October, a credit survey disclosed here last week.

This is the jelly-making season. Fall fruits are ripening and housewives are assembling glass jars and kettles. Apples, grapes, crab apples and peaches are being converted into tart, delicious jellies that will lend color to many a winter table.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 -Western motorists stampeded for the gasoline pump today in fear of a strike-induced fuel drought.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- The death of Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang, China's fabulous "Christian general," aboard a Russian ship in the Black Sea was announced in the Moscow press today. General Feng was 67 years old.

A 50 per cent cut in non-rushhour service on the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, became effective at 3:01 A. M. yesterday. The railroad also instituted at the same hour schedules calling for a reduction in rushhour service and the cancellation of all night trains after 1:29 A.M.
The crippling effects of New York's five-day-old truck strike spread to the populous industrial area of northern New Jersey last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Left-handed Frankie Albert passed for three touchdowns and ran another across himself to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 36-20 victory over the Brooklyn Dodgers in an All-America Conference pro football game today. Some 32,606 fans saw the 49ers triumph.

BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- Settlement of Austro-German boundary problems has been speeded considerably by ratification of a treaty between Austria and the bizonal area reconciling various Austrian and Bavarian projects for the diversion of water from border rivers, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Legislation to protect witnesses from prosecution on the basis of selfincriminating evidence they might give to Congressional committees is being considered by House investigators.

WARSAW, Sept. 5 -- Poland's Communist Workers party split wide open tonight over the issue of whether to follow the Moscow Communist line or remain a nationalist group. The party's Executive Committee announced it had dismissed Vice Premier Wladislaw Gomulka, who backed Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia against the Moscow-led Communist Information Bureau, as secretary general.

Eddie Condon and his band will be featured in "Floor Show," forty minutes of informal variety to be introduced tomorrow night at 9:05 o'clock over television station WPIX. Guest entertainers, among them musicians playing Manhattan night spots, will be invited to appear on the programs.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 (AP) -Ted Williams' double and a single by Wally Moses in the tenth inning carried the league-leading Boston Red Sox to their third straight victory over the Philadelphia Athletics by a 4-3 score today. The setback was the seventh in a row for the Athletics.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, the triple golf champion, put on the pressure today to draw away from the field in the $25,000 Reno Open. He shot a 7-under-par 65 for a 54-hole total of 201.
h)0*0*0*iOToday marks the sixty-sixth anniversary of an institution that may well be said to symbolize the American way in its origin and spirit -- the Labor Day holiday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 -- A new cry -- "lockout" -- was raised along the West Coast's strikestilled waterfront today.

An issue of major importance to the efficiency and morale of the armed forces, service pay, has been under intensive study by a civilian advisory committee, appointed last December by Secretary of Defense Forrestal.

Apparently hopelessly beaten by Big Jawn Mize's second home run in the twelfth inning of a magnificent pitchers' battle between Montia Kennedy and Preacher Roe, the Dodgers yesterday sent all Flatbush into a state of hysteria by scoring three runs after two were out to beat the Giants, 4 -- 3.

PRAGUE, Sept. 5 -- The body of former President Eduard Benes, who died on Friday, will lie in state in Memorial Hall in Prague from tomorrow morning until Tuesday midnight, it was announced today. The body will be brought to Prague from his home at Sezomovo Usti tonight and will be returned there for burial after state funeral ceremonies in the pantheon of the National Museum on Wednesday.

Although ship accommodations for the 205,000 displaced persons scheduled to come to the United States from Europe by 1950 are not regarded as a major problem, the migration will require intensive efforts by agencies involved.

Accused of brutally beating his son Joseph, 3 years old, Patrolman Milton G.C. Woodbridge, 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighing 250 pounds, was held yesterday in bail of $5,000 on a charge of felonious assault.

New Yorkers homeward bound from the three-day Labor Day week-end will travel under cloudy skies and not in the rainstorm that previously had been forecast for this afternoon and tonight, the Weather Bureau said last night.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 5 -- The real work of the Western German Parliamentary Assembly is due to begin this week in Bonn, when discussions will be opened on the writing of a constitution. Although in theory all known constitutions are to be placed under consideration, the Germans actually are studying the details of three proposals and may add a fourth, documents prepared by the Soviet zone People's Congress.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 5 -Rhode Island textile workers are receiving non-productive "fringe issue" benefits which add $9,381,000 annually to industry payrolls, according to a survey released this week. In addition, the survey reported, they receive $7,893,200 for shift differentials and overtime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -The Textile Workers Union, CIO, asserted today that Henry A. Wallace's Progressive party would achieve nothing but "the defeat of liberals and the election of reactionaries" by entering third-party candidates in Congressional contests.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 -- Japanese writers are complaining widely of the venality of organized religion here since the surrender, according to a study conducted for the headquarters of Gen. Douglas MacArthur. This applies not only to the Shinto faith, which lost its state subsidy in 1945 under an Allied directive, but also to many Buddhist sects.
The housing shortage at the Bronx Zoo was solved temporarily yesterday. A cat was evicted from its cage in the small mammal house to make room for a couple of over-sized rats from Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The heads of the two largest American labor organizations used Labor Day statements today to attack the Taft-Hartley Law and the record of the Eightieth Congress.
ALBANY, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A State Department of Commerce employe was found slain in a hotel room here early today, trussed with a bedsheet in what police described as a "Japanese knot."

BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- The explosive situation brought about for Berlin by creation of the Communistsponsored "democratic bloc" will reach a crisis tomorrow when the city's legally elected Assembly plans to meet in defiance of Communist threats.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 5 -- The Press Department of the Bulgarian Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement today saying that Donald Freeman Ewing, a United States vice consul, had been called home last July from his post in Sofia after he had allegedly committed acts of espionage in connection with two followers of Nicola Petkov, Agrarian leader who was executed last September on charges of treason.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 -- Japanese trade union members in increasing numbers have begun to fight back against the Communist domination under which their organizations have been operating since the beginning of the occupation, according to many indications today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 5 -Getting greater speed from their ponies and stringing out play more effectively, Alan Corey's Great Neck team rode into the final round of the National open polo championship today by topping Mike Phipps' Westbury quartet, 6 to 5, in a semi-final on International.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Denuded of defending fighters by a skillful feint, London was heavily "bombed" early today as the attack scored points in the biggest British air maneuvers since the war.

A proposal that the city purchase and operate the bus lines of the East Side Omnibus Corporation and the Comprehensive Omnibus Corporation as elements of the municipal transit system, will be considered tomorrow by the Board of Estimate, it was reliably reported last night.
Another long expedition in quest of the Davis Cup ended in failure for Australia yesterday in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club.

BERLIN, Monday, Sept. 6 (UP). Four United States citizens have been missing for more than twelve hours in Germany's Russian zone, the United States military police announced early today. United States officials asked Soviet authorities whether the Americans had been arrested.

Impressive ceremonies honoring Princess Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, who abdicated as Queen Saturday after a fifty-year reign, were held yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. International diplomatic, consular and military officials were among the 3,000 persons who attended the service.

Harry L. Spencer, formerly vice president in charge of manufacturing of Bendix Applianceh, Inc., has been appointed director of manufacturing of all five plants of the Norge division, Borg-Warner Corporation, Detroit. He succeeds J. Nall Candler, who was named assistant general manager of the Norge division.

MONROE, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- A boy caught a five-pound bass. A man landed a 21-inch perch. A few young women tried to sell pamphlets with the imprint of the International Workers Order, but were stopped. Nearly everyone had a picnic lunch. And thus was opened today the attempt of the Arow Farm Association, Inc., to do something for Russian-Americans.

Interest in the foreign exchange market last week was at its lowest ebb in months, a reflection of the caution of buyers in the face of the long holiday and the modest amount of balancing called for at the month-end. The net result of this inaction left the major currencies at substantially the same price level that ruled in the preceding week.

MANCHESTER, England. Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Raw Cotton Commission has notified British spinners raw cotton prices will be reduced tomorrow. Cuts of between one penny (1.6 cents) and sixpence (10 cents) a pound were announced for the more expensive types of Egyptian cotton.

h)LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The stock markets here last week gave further evidence of their sensitiveness to political influences. Increased hopes of some sort of settlement of the Berlin deadlock arose from the diversion of discussions to the military governors for settlement of the currency problem.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 5 -- The second week of the Edinburgh Festival ended with two concerts by the BBC Orchestra from London, under the direction of Sir Adrian Boult, and a recital of chamber music by the Hungarian String Quartet.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 5 -The red shirts are coming tomorrow, coming in droves from all parts of the Hudson Valley for the wind-up of a three-day celebration of the 100th anniversary of Columbian Hose Company No. 1.

If the American Cryptogram Association and the National Puzzlers League had spent another day in adjoining rooms at the Hotel New Yorker a pact might have been arranged to end their sixteen years of aloofness.

Ugo Carusi, chairman of the Displaced Persons Commission, Washington, will leave La Guardia Field this morning for Germany. He is to confer with officials active there in the selection of persons to emigrate to the United States and to expedite the process.
ROME, Sept. 5 -- Pope Pius XII told German Catholics today they might have to fight "to the last drop of blood" for the independence of the Roman Catholic Church.

The appointment of James B. Robbins as executive secretary of the American Society of Travel Agents, Inc., was announced last week by Harry M. Paulsen, president of the organization. Mr. Robbins, who has resigned from his post as general passenger manager of the Hudson River Day Line succeeds Fred M. Dietz, executive secretary fo rthe agents' society for the last nine years.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The new $4,200,000 Archbishop Stepinac High School here for Roman Catholic boys of Westchester County was near completion today. On Wednesday pupils will report to receive class schedules. Cardinal Spellman will dedicate the school next Sunday and class work will begin the following day.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 5 -- About 300 delegates representing twenty countries in Europe, the Americas and Asia gathered in Luxembourg today for the second conference of the World Movement for a World Federal Government. The first conference was held in Montreux, Switzerland, last summer.

As the result of Sterling Drug's victory in a recent California court decision extending fair trade protection to the resale of trade-marked commodities in war surplus, three other drug manufacturers are considering similar action to halt such sale of their products, it was laerned over the week-end.

Two young Korean musicians arrived in New York yesterday from Seoul. They are Wonsik Lim, conductor of the Korea Symphony Orchestra, and Kisun Yun, pianist who has often appeared on Mr. Lim's programs.

The Rev. Arthur House Stainback, recently elected pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, Madison Avenue and Thirty-first Street, preached his first sermon to his new congregation yesterday morning.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5 -- First of the All-America Conference elevens to feel the effect of the league's decision to strengthen the Baltimore Colts is Ray Flaherty's Yankees. Others are likely to feel it, too, if a stunning 45-28 upset victory by the Colts over the New Yorkers today means anything -and it does.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Peter Stambolitch, head of the Yugoslav People's Front, was made President of Serbia today in a further reshuffling of top Communist leaders. His appointment as head of the nation's biggest republic was made at an extraordinary session of the Serbian Parliament.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- Premier Robert Schuman's new coalition Cabinet, formed about 7 A.M. today after all-night consultations, met this afternoon and as its first official act approved a straight wage bonus, of 2,500 francs (about $8.35) to all workers in private industry in France.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -Bright Light, from the Seven Star Stables of Dover, Mass., and Southern Pines, N.C., took the conformation hunter championship as the two-day fall horse show at the Rice Farms closed today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 -- Demand for steel last week showed no signs of a downward trend. In many cases sales officials reported that the supply situation was tighter than ever. Furthermore, there was no evidence that there would be any change for the better in months to come -- certainly not before early next year, if then.

Overcoming the lag in coal output which held back the expansion of Soviet industry, the Soviet coal industry is exceeding this year the prewar level of production, according to information published in Pravda, Moscow Communist party organ.

Chairman Styles Bridges of the Senate Appropriations Committee chose the Labor Day week-end to worry out loud over the "waste and extravagance" of unnecessary Government publications. There are certainly a lot of such publications. Profs. Herbert S. Hirshberg and Carl H. Melinat, compiling a subject guide to them last year for the American Library Association, found that the indexes alone would occupy "nearly 15 running feet of shelf space."

ATHENS, Sept. 5 -- Attacks upon the Greek National forces from the Albanian side of the border, as the Greek Army seeks to clean up the Communist-led rebels in Epirus, are increasingly causing concern to Athens officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Resistance to terms of United States loans has put the lending phase of the foreign recovery program far behind schedule as the Economic Cooperation Administration enters its sixth month of operation.

By a vote of 19 to 5 the leftistcontrolled international executive board of the Transport Workers Union yesterday "categorically rejected" the Presidential candidacy of Harry S. Truman. It thus became the first Congress of Industrial Organizations international union to repudiate the endorsement given Mr. Truman last week by its own parent body, the CIO executive board.

Apprehension over lagging business conditions has permeated the machinery industry here, Edward F. Schill, president of Edward Franklin Schill Corporation, 39 Cortlandt Street, and vice-chairman of the New York chapter of the Machinery Dealers National Association, said in an interview here last week.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5 -- A parade of early-model automobiles and bicycles, floats, old-time fire apparatus, clowns and animal impersonators attracted an estimated 20,000 persons to Newport today.

ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- Republican State Chairman Glen R. Bedenkapp predicted today that labor in New York would give recognition at the polls in November to Governor Dewey's labor and housing record, which the chairman recalled, won a majority of the labor vote when the Governor was re elected by a record majority.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- In response to efforts to break the deadlock in the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation over the division of Marshall Plan dollars, suggestions for a compromise between the Council and German bizonal authorities have been submitted to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, by Lawrence Wilkinson, his economic adviser.

SEATTLE, Sept. 5 (AP) -- James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, dodged foreign policy questions today at a news conferenceh)0*0*0*iand said the State Department now was a place of opportunity for young men. Both salaries and opportunities for advancement have improved in the department, he said.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Bestin-show at the all-breed exhibition of the Yonkers Kennel Club today went to the wire foxterrier, Ch. Radar of Wildoaks, owned by Mrs. R. C. Bondy of Golden's Bridge, N.Y. Stanley J. Halle of Chappequa judged.

Although the trend among women the world over is toward political, social and economic independence, the campaign is an uphill battle and conditions are still far from what they should be. This is the consensus of more than fifty delegates from Young Women's Christian Association offices abroad who are here attending the first International Study Conference on Women and World Reconstruction.

After an interregnum of eight days that handicapped all the Western Powers in their critical negotiations with Moscow, France has again a Government, and the Parliamentary system of the Fourth Republic that was threatened with imminent breakdown has obtained a new lease on life.

A failure to understand the nature of man results in a refusal to recognize his rights, the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, assistant chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 -- Outstanding recent successes in vitamin therapy have been achieved in cases of pernicious anemia through treatment with both Vitamin M, or folic acid, and the newly-discovered Vitamin B-12, according to Dr. Paul L. Day of the University of Arkansas.

With a pioneering spirit which has characterized many of its operations, Pan American World Airways announces tourist-class service between New York City and San Juan, Puerto Rico, at sharply reduced fares at a time when fare increases have been advocated by several airlines and a policy of a general 10 per cent increase domestically has been approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
A 17-year-old Latvian who joined the Boy Scouts while in a Displaced Persons camp in Germany will be the guest of honor at a party tomorrow at Boy Scout national headquarters, 2 Park Avenue.

Darryl Zanuck, executive producer of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, denied yesterday that there was any widespread addiction to narcotics in the Hollywood motion picture colony and declared moral standards there were as high as anywhere in the world.

HIGHMOUNT, N.Y., Sept. 5 - The national convention of the Agudath Israel Youth Council of America adopted a resolution today condemning the recently enacted displaced-persons bill on the ground that it would "bar admission to those who bore the brunt of Nazi persecution."

ABOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL TRAIN, Sept. 5 -- President Truman was on his way to Michigan tonight to start his election campaign with whirlwind visits to five industrial cities and with as many speeches scheduled in which he will ask labor's vote of confidence in his administration.

Time to cut brush is during the ebb tide of summer, so countrymen say. High tide of the season's growth has been reached; now the sap-soft shoots are beginning to harden. Along miles of stonewall-lined roads, around sidehill fields, along pasture fences and meadow boundaries, the ever-eager forest extends its fingers each year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- The convention of the American Veterans of World War II adjourned here today after a futile effort to catch up on a day's arrears in the agenda, which became bogged down in parliamentary matters.

CAIRO, Sept. 5 -- The "Supreme Guide" of the Moslem Brotherhood, Sheikh Hassan el-Banna, threw his support today behind a project to form an army based on Palestinian Arabs and a Palestine Arabh)0*0*0*iGovernment based on the Palestine Arab Higher Committee, of which Haj Amin el-Husseini.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Violent price fluctuations continued last week in cash and September corn in the grain markets. Cash corn advanced 34 cents a bushel from the low mark of Aug. 23 to a top of $2.12 and broke back to $1.92 1/2 in three days under the pressure of country offerings.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Lard staged a strong rally on the Board of Trade last week after breaking to a new seasonal low owing to liquidation by holders of September contracts after heavy deliveries of the cash product.

THE note was a stunner. It came from W. K. Ressler of Lancaster, Pa. It said: "In a recent column you spoke of the grace of Shoeless Joe Jackson and Ted Williams' at bat. I have seen Williams but Jackson is a stranger to me. An article on him would be of great interest to many of your younger readers, including myself."

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Rookies Bobby Layne and Johnny Lujack and Veteran Sid Luckman totaled four touchdown passes today as the Chicago Bears smashed the Boston Yanks, 42 -- 7, in a National Football League exhibition game.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- The relentless offensive that the Vatican is waging to check communism received today new impetus when Pope Pius XII urged thousands of militant Catholic girls to become fearless propagandists and bring back to the Church's fold all those who, he said, had been led astray by the anticlerical parties in Italy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Luke Appling's single with the bases full and two out in the ninth inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 7,253 fans today. The victory, Allen Gettel's fifth of the season, was Chicago's only decision of the three-game set.
SANDY HOOK, N.J., Sept. 5 -Two men and two boys were rescued by Coast Guardsmen here this afternoon from a two-masted schooner that had gone aground on Romer Shoal, near the Ambrose Lightship.

Prices of cotton for future delivery continued last week to hold to a narrow trading range and closed the period with irregular changes. At the end of trading on Friday active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were from 23 points higher to 24 points lower than the week before.
MIDDLEBURG, Va., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Stymie, the greatest moneywinner in turf history, may race again next year.

With the arrival of John van Druten from the Coast today or tomorrow, production activities on "Make Way for Lucia," Mr. van Druten's dramatization of the E. F. Benson stories, which also is to be staged by him, should be accelerated.

With strong support already assured for the proposed code on use of marketing research in advertising, research officials declared here last week that the problem of "policing" the code presents a serious obstacle to its success. Research groups are scheduled to begin action on the proposals next week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The State Department in a statement of "facts in the matter" today bluntly described the Bulgarian account as a "transparently fabricated maneuver."

MARGATE, England, Sept. 5 -This British seaside resort will be host tomorrow to the annual Trade Union Congress, which will open a wee' of sessions. This powerful central body, representing close to 8,000,000 of the nation's organized workers, is due to lay down policies that it has good reason to believe the present Labor Government will heed during the coming twelve months.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -Matthew Rapf, writer-producer, announced this week-end that he planned to form his own independent film company and that as its first picture it would make "Silhouette" of which he is the author.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Righthander Red Barrett pitched his best game of the year today in twirling the National League leading Boston Braves to a five hit 5-1 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies before 16,487 fans. Barrett's best previous effort was a six-hit 3-2 triumph over the Brooklyn Dodgers April 27.

Mayor O'Dwyer's advisers on city finances were expected yesterday to recommend soon that the city itself carry out and finance rehabilitation of its piers and other waterfront facilities. A report to be submitted to the Mayor will indicate that such a policy is preferable to one under which the piers would be leased for long terms to either the Port of New York Authority or the State-chartered World Trade Corporation for development.

Bertrand Russell, British philosopher and authority on nearly everything, has completed another philosophical work that Simon Schuster will publish in November. "Human Knowledge: Its Scope and Limits," "charts and clarifies such basic subjects as the meaning of meaning, the tests of credibility, the nature and gradations of probability, the degrees of certainty -the foundations and range of knowledge itself."

With President Harry S. Truman scheduled to begin his speaking campaign today with a series of addresses in Detroit and other Michigan cities and with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, due to start a transcontinental trip later this month, several of the main issues on which the 1948 campaign will be fought have now become apparent.
A United Press story in THE TIMES of Sept. 1 reported: "Newsprint Share to Britain Backed -- Most Publishers of New York State Said to Agree With Sulzberger Suggestion."

The McCullough Report's recommendations of a 4 per cent limitation on fire insurance company dividends or a 6 per cent limitation on combined investment and underwriting earnings would make the industry dependent ultimately upon government capital, according to Shelby Cullom Davis, former New York State Deputy Superintendent of Insurance and now a partner in a New York Stock Exchange firm specializing in insurance stocks.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 -- Two of the nation's top research directors warned tonight that atomic energy as now envisioned is not inexhaustible and that danger to scientific progress in the United States lies in a specialized approach to the study of sciences.

URUMCHI, Sinkiang, Aug. 26 -- Several hundred Turkis, many illiterate but all highly aware of their cultures and traditions, crowded into the Uighur Cultural Club to attend a performance of native Sinkiang singing and dancing.
Three Cunard White Star liners will be used for cruises from New York to the West Indies and South America in the winter, it was announced here yesterday.

WARSAW, Sept. 6 -- Vice Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka today publicly avowed his acceptance of the Polish Communist party's denunciation on his "errors" and endorsed the newly ordered purge of the followers of the "alien opportunistic" ideology that led to his dismissal as the party's secretary general.

LA GRANGE, Ga., Sept. 6 (AP) -- A Chicago scientist who was engaged in cosmic ray research leaped to his death from a burning B-29 Army bomber today. Soon afterwards, the plane, with the fire under control, was brought safely down at Maxwell Field, Ala.

Pretty soon now schools and colleges, fresh-swept and echoing to the rattle of fall term registration paper work, will be taking under their spires, colonnades and domes large numbers of young men and women who will find themselves away from home for the first time.

Vincent Astor has acquired from a syndicate represented by Riker Co., Inc., the two-story taxpayer at 18-22 Purchase Street, Rye, Westchester County. The two large ground-floor stores are occupied by the F.W. Woolworth Company and Safeway Stores, Inc.

AGAWAM, Mass., Sept. 6 -- A South Jersey veteran of the regatta circuits, Harper Chance of Pennsauken, reclaimed his former Class F Eastern outboard hydroplane championship today in a furious Connecticut River battle against his two old New York rivals, Emil Mayer Jr. of College Point, Queens, and Victor Scott of Forest Hills.

Boston Insurance Company is offering to its stockholders until Sept. 20 rights to subscribe to 100,000 shares of capital stock at $42 per share on the basis of one additional share for each three shares held on July 28. The sale will increase capitalization to 400,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, proposed today that a voluntary steel allocation program be inaugurated in the farm-machinery industry to end the shortages suffered by the small producers.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 6 -- Ch. Tempo's Trueluck, a liver and white pointer belonging to Clayton S. Purdy of Stamford, fulfilled the promise of long standing by getting best in show in the 500-dog thirteenth annual all-breed event of the Ox Ridge Kennel Club today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills opened their 1948 All-America Conference home football season today with a 42-7 victory over the Chicago Rockets before 25,816 spectators in Civic Stadium.

Eight intercollegiate football games to be played during the 1948 football season will be carried by WPIX, the television station of The New York Daily News, beginning Sept. 25 and extending through Nov. 13
Walter M. Jeffords' Loyal Legion won what amounted to a no-contest decision in the $28,100 Edgemere Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

"Labor Day for me," said the cab driver in a flat voice, "is just like any other day, only worse." He waved a hand at the neckcraning thousands drifting along Broadway past his idle cab. "This," he said, "is a walkin' day. When they get tired we'll get 'em.

September offers a real variety of hunting and fishing activities, and a number of sportsmen are willing to put up with the heat of the summer in order to take their vacations during this month, when they can get a combination of both sports in many areas.

DALLSA, Tex., Sept. 6 -- Four presentation of the annual Neiman-Marcus awards "for distinguished service in the field of fashion" were made here today as Neiman-Marcus of Dallas, a leading specialty store, opened its eleventh annual fall fashion exposition.

ATHENS, Sept. 6 -- Premier Themistoces Sophoulis, aged Liberal party leader, indicated today that, because of forthcoming Greek Army operations in the Peloponnesus against the Communist-led rebels, affairs in Athens would keep him from going to Paris as head of the Greek delegation to the United Nations General Assembly this month.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Jersey City and Newark both smashed losing streaks by dividing a double-header here today before 4,500.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- An adjourned game from last night's session, which went to eighty-two moves and lasted over seven hours, provided the sensation in the annual championship tournament at the meeting of the New York State Chess Association and completed the second round today.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Dr. Cabot Seton Bull, a leading atomic research scientist, has been removed from his post at the Government's atomic research station at Didcot, Berkshire, as a result of a purge of Communists in state defense departments, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities is trying to find out why a group of scientists has chosen a part of Africa, rich in uranium, to set up a $9,000,000 astronomical laboratory.

Real estate security prices have moved within a relatively narrow margin since the beginning of the year, according to Amott Baker Co., Inc. The effect places the market on a more highly selective basis than at any time since the end of World War II.

BOSTON, Sept. 6 -- Everybody in Beantown was happy tonight but the folk of Flatbush must have been sad, indeed. Their Dodgers, after battling the league-leading Braves tooth and nail for fourteen innings, only to lose the opener, 2 -- 1, then subsided meekly, 4 -- 0, in the six and one-half inning nightcap, curtailed because of darkness.

Governor Dewey's contention that he has increased state aid to schools in New York State by 80 per cent was challenged yesterday in a statement by James A. Cullen of Mount Vernon, state director of the National Education Association.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 6 -- There is a growing sentiment among informed Communists that the time is at hand for a temporary truce in the Soviet-United States political struggle. They believe that, should a truce not emerge from the current Moscow negotiations, the prevailing conditions in the balance of forces will bring it about in the not too distant future.

The first nation-wide factory-sponsored price mark-down program in its history was announced over the week-end by RCA Victor Records. The program was undertaken, it was said, to stabilize inventories of retail record dealers so that they may capitalize fully on the peak season of consumer buying in the final quarter of 1948.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 6 -- "Wildcat" strikes, of which this hard-pressed country has had more than a thousand since January, were condemned as "disloyal" by Britain's organized labor movement today. The powerful Trades Union Congress, at which representatives of close to 8,000,000 organized workers are gathered for the annual stock-taking of labor's position, voted overwhelmingly to endorse a resolution embodying this condemnation.

Sprinter Barney Ewell, veteran member of the United States Olympic squad, came home from Europe yesterday looking for a professional career and still a little peeved over the mix-up which nearly cost him his only gold medal in the games at London.

Joseph (Little Joey) Franco, veteran East Harlem gang member, was shot and killed last night in front of the Dolores Restaurant, 2047 Second Avenue, near 105th Street. He was 39 years old and had been in hiding at an address on Seventy-sixth Street, Elmhurst, Queens, in fear of deportation to Italy on a Federal narcotics charge.

Eight of the country's leading atomic scientists charged yesterday that the Thomas un-American Activities Committee was endangering national security through its "objectionable smear tactics." These tactics, they held, were driving the most competent scientists out of Government service at a dangerous rate.
Following is the text of President Truman's speech in Detroit yesterday, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 -- Anson Lynn Johnson, a pilot of 28 from Miami Springs, Fla., won the Thompson Trophy Race here today at the relatively slow speed of 383.767 miles an hour. In addition to first-place money, amounting to $16,000, he will collect lap prizes for at least two laps.

The New York Public Library will continue this fall its "Great Books", discussion program started last year at branch libraries in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond. it was announced yesterday. The program, which is free, will offer group discussions of firstseries and second-series readings to all interested persons.

The suspension of three officers of Local 3 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, on charges that they refused to sign non-Communist affidavits was upheld yesterday by Samuel Wolchok, international president. The suspended officers represented employes of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept 6 -- The annual conference of the National Urban League heard a warning tonight from a Southern newspaper editor that the "current political dancing and whooping" may result in holding back a truly effective program of race relations.

To introduce a new Twentieth Century Limited as part of New York Central's fleet of "Dreamliners," a national newspaper and magazine campaign has been planned for September and October. Newspapers in New York and Chicago will carry 1,200 line ads announcing the first run of the train on Sept. 17, followed shortly by 1,500 line ads inviting the public to an exhibition of the train in those cities.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 6 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin today joined with William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a Labor Day plea for the defeat of a "reactionary" Congress.

Evidence that the scope of company medical services has "expanded widely" during the last few years is contained in a survey of industrial health and medical programs released over the weekend by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Beginning in the fall, students from Latin-American universities will come to the United States for a year of study at City College and part-time work in American concerns engaged in foreign trade. Next spring City College students will leave for South and Central American universities for a year of study and work.

Thirteen evening courses in filmmaking for professionals and beginners will be offered this season by the Film Institute of City College, it has been announced by Prof. Hans Richter, director of the institute. The courses will cover such subjects as the history of motion pictures, the documentary film and fundamentals of film production.

GENEVA, Sept. 6 -- A United States proposal to open for signature a multilateral agreement providing nondiscriminatory treatment for the trade of Western Germany was approved today by fifteen nations.

Broadway first-nighters, after a summer-imposed period of inactivity, will start their theatre going season in earnest this evening with the scheduled presentation of a new play, "Sundown Beach," and the revival of a popular item, "Show Boat."
PARIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Five European trade union groups sent greetings to American labor organizations tonight pledging their support for the European Recovery Program.

The last party of boys and girls broke camp last night at Rabbit's Hollow and Forest Lake, two camps in Winchester, N.H., and started for New York. Some of the children had been away from home since July 6 -- the less lucky had been at camp two weeks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, ordered an inquiry into the publications of Government agencies today because his "sense of thrift is outraged."
RENO, Nev., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Ben Hogan added the $25,000 Reno open to his list of victories today when he posted a 72-hole total of 269, or 19 under par for the four rounds.
SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- China prohibited travel to the British colony of Hong Kong today to prevent "black market operators and other profiteers escaping" from Shanghai.

ABOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL TRAIN, Sept. 6 -- President Truman told a succession of Labor Day audiences in opening his election campaign today that a Republican victory in November threatened the wages and living standards of organized labor and would result in "an era of fear."

Reopening today of the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition in Grand Central Palace after a two-day Labor Day closing will be marked by Mayor O'Dwyer's proclamation of the "Second Manhattan Project" to highlight the exhibit "Man and the Atom."

As a contribution toward the bipartisan efforts to preserve the bipartisan character of American foreign policy during the Presidential campaign, former Secretary of State Byrnes appealed last night for the continuation of that policy as the best means of coping with "the greatest danger in the world today -- the danger of continued aggression on the part of the Soviet Union."

The 100th anniversary of Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens, was observed yesterday morning with special services at which the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, presided. About 300 persons attended.

In a major bid for rank-and-file labor support, Henry A. Wallace charged yesterday that top leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations were following a "policy of appeasement" in backing President Truman.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom Clark today challenged the Republicans "and their old-guard grundy bosses to name any Communists now in the executive branch of the Federal Government."

Major efforts of the Democratic campaign in this city and state will be aimed at keeping as low as possible the vote for Henry A. Wallace and his Progressive ticket, represented here on the ballot line of the American Labor party.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production faltered a bit this week as a Labor Day holiday and some continuing materials shortages halted assembly lines. The longer range outlook for production volume, however, looked considerably better than it has at any time since last March when United States factories built 492,013 cars and trucks for a postwar high mark.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- A man who allegedly fled with a $22,038 payroll of the United States Gypsum Company's plant in Riverside, Calif., was arrested by police today as he kept a rendezvous with his wife and child.

An increase in liquor sales during the final months of 1948, particularly on brands of recognized quality, was forecast over the week-end by Arthur D. Schulte, president of Park Tilford, Inc. The expected upswing, Mr. Schulte said, is based upon the generally favorable business outlook and upon the fact that the downward sales trend which began late in 1946 has already been reversed.

It was with keen interest that I read your editorial entitled The Draft Begins. Not only because I fall within the registration age but more particularly because I noted your apparant nonchalance about exempting the men who sailed in the merchant marine during the war.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Installment credit has accounted for 62 per cent, or $5,200,000,000 of the $8,500,000,000 rise in total consumer credit in the three years since the end of the war, Business Comment, publication of the Northern Trust Company, says in its September issue.

Activity on a pre-war scale is expected on New York piers today when more than 6,000 passengers are scheduled to arrive from Europe. South America and the West Indies on nine liners and Army transports.
With 12,900 truck drivers on strike in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area, little hope for an early settlement was seen yesterday on either side of the Hudson River.

President Truman's speeches in Michigan and Ohio yesterday formally opened the 1948 campaign and presumably identified the issues which the Democratic leadership counts as most hopeful to its cause. To win the election in the face of the present odds against him. Mr. Truman must hold the great bulk of the "labor vote" against possible inroads by both Mr. Dewey and Mr. Wallace.

Betty, a duckbill platypus, died on Sunday night in the Bronx Zoo after living there for one year, four months and eleven days, it was announced yesterday by William Bridges, curator of publications. The zoo's general curator, Lee S. Crandall, estimated that Betty must have been about 2 years old.

"Our New National Labor Policy: The Taft-Hartley Act and the Next Steps." which is scheduled to appear at the end of this month, is the work of an author who speaks with some authority about the controversial bill, Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. himself.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 6 -- Juliana of Orange and Nassau was solemnly sworn in as Queen of the Netherlands at an investiture held in the fifteenth century Nieuwe Kerk here this morning in the presence of European royalty, representatives of foreign governments and a cross-section of her own subjects.

WHEELING, W.Va., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Philip Murray, president of the CIO, said today the labor movement in this country "is burdened with legal shackles * * * that threaten its eventual destruction." Also, Mr. Murray spoke out against the Taft-Hartley Law and the Eightieth Congress, generally, in a Labor Day speech that was broadcast over a nation-wide hookup by the CBS network.

JAMES JOSEPH DYKES, an unemployed thinker, has probably not yet started to read the classified ads in search of a position. But he's out of a job. Just the other day the flippant Dykes resigned as manager of the Hollywood club of the Pacific Coast League where he had been serving time until another major league post was made available for him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 6 -- Robert Rossen, writer-producer and head of Robert Rossen Productions, Inc., said today he had bought the screen rights to the novel, "The Outer Edges," by Charles Jackson, author of "The Lost Weekend."
SAN FRANCISCO. Sept. 6 (AP) -- A showdown between striking longshoremen and the Army is due tomorrow. The Army said today that its supplies must move, strike or no strike.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- United States officials indicated today that Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American commander in Germany, was about to make substantial concessions to settle his dispute with the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation over the share of Marshall Plan dollar credits that the Council had proposed to allot to the German "bizone" -- the joint American and British occupied areas.
The nation's biggest union, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, announced yesterday that it would leave political action in the current campaign up to its local unions.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Gerry Priddy sparked St. Louis to an 11-10 victory over Detroit today after the Tigers had walloped the Browns, 8 -- 1, in the opener of a double-header witnessed by 6,871 fans.

New York's public schools should set a national example by emphasizing in their courses of study the practical instead of just the theoretical aspects of democracy, Mrs. Sabra Holbrook, executive director of Youthbuilders, Inc., declared yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Rippey, champion sprinter of the East, proved unable to cope with seemingly inferior rivals in the $10,000 Pageant Handicap, feature at this course today. He was a well-beaten fourth as Circus Clown drove through on the inside to gain a half-length verdict from the pacemaking Erigeron.

IT'S only sixty miles or so from Oxford, Miss., where William Faulkner lives, to Carrolton, Miss., where Elizabeth Spencer was born and brought up. Both towns are east of the Yazoo River, which means east of the rich black earth of the Delta cotton country. Mr. Faulkner has put Oxford prominently on the literary map of the Deep South.
A ruling on New York State stock transfer taxes which was regarded as important has been handed down by the New York State Tax Commission.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept 6 -- Jacob M. Lomakin arrived here today and went straight to the Soviet Embassy and said flatly that he hoped that ended all speculation that he might not return to Moscow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 -- The first steps are about to be taken in a survey authorized by Congress of the tuna industry in the Pacific. Meanwhile, scientists are still trying to solve the mystery of the vanishing sardine along the West Coast.

GENEVA, Sept. 6 -- A Russian delegate to the United Nations Committee on Colonies was charged with being ignorant and talking foolishness today by a spokesman for the colonial powers who were defending the records of colonial administrations as they have been reported to the United Nations.

First place in the American League's grueling pennant race was still dangling at the end of a rainbow for the Yankees yesterday as Bucky Harris' Bombers brought their last long home stand of the year to a close at the Stadium by breaking even with the Athletics.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 6 -- The charge that the United Nations "failed in its duty" to exert pressure upon the Arab States to meet the Israeli Government in direct peace negotiations was made here tonight by Aubrey Eban, Israel's chief representative at the Security Council.

Representatives of the proposed $1,000,000 Sidney Hillman Health Center to serve clothing workers in the metropolitan area will take possession of the former Margaret Louisa residence club of the Young Women's Christian Association at 14 East Sixteenth Street today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- The Giants won a race against time at Shibe Park today as they downed the Phillies in both ends of a double header before 20,572 onlookers.
BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- The legally elected Government of Berlin was smashed completely today by Communist violence under Russian guidance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Storm rangers to patrol the Arctic Ocean and Greenland with dog teams or motor sledges are urged by Dr. William H. Hobbs of the University of Michigan, and a veteran explorer of the Far North.
The international executive board of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, administered a series of rebuffs yesterday to Michael J. Quill, international president of the union.

Negotiations for a new contract between the Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and a group of forty Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators will start Sept. 15, it was made known yesterday by Capt. William C. Ash, national vice president of the union. The present agreement will expire at midnight Sept. 30.

The truck strike in New York City will be one week old tonight. As such strikes have had a way of doing in the past, this one has been growing worse instead of better. It is earnestly to be hoped that the three-man mediation panel which is to meet today can produce some results.

Despite the rising costs of maintaining a farm, American agriculture is in a sound financial condition, according to a survey by the agricultural commission of the American Bankers Association. The survey is based on an analysis of bank lending.
PARIS, Sept. 6 -- French labor received coldly today the new Schuman Cabinet's first moves to settle the wage issue, maintaining a threatening attitude until the full program had been made known.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Two laughing desperadoes today killed a policeman and abducted the assistant chief of New Orleans detectives in front of his own headquarters but later released him unharmed.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- While Britain's state-owned coal industry reported a profit during the first half of 1948, a warning went out today of new power cuts during the coming winter to save fuel.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Goose, owned by George W. Nichols of Cold Spring Harbor and skippered by Briggs Cunningham, captured the first trial race to determine the American boat in the six-meter Gold Cup competition with Norway and Sweden in Long Island Sound off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Miss Canada III breezed to a straight-heat victory for power-boat racing's Silver Cup here today, showing the way to four finishers by doing the second and final heat of the 90-mile run at 68.471 miles per hour.

The post-war expansion in uses of plastic materials into almost every phase of day-to-day living is dramatized in the choice of twenty-nine winners of the seventh Modern Plastics Competition, it was announced over the week-end.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- After three practically breathless days on Long Island Sound, a nice southwest breeze appeared to waft 133 sailing craft around courses this afternoon in the fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, its last championship one of the season.

TOKYO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Returning to their attack on Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Japanese labor policies, the Russians predicted today that "a large wave" of protest strikes by Japanese would be "natural."

It all started after the first World War. Women had been preserving food. But with the stress over, they were transferring the water-bath canner and glass jars to the attic. It wasn't that their families hadn't liked the fine, old-fashioned flavor of carefully-canned-at-home fruits and vegetables; it was just that canning was "an awful lot of bother."

LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- A court inquiring into the disappearance of the 7,219-ton British cargo ship Samkey, with her crew of forty-three, found that she was "lost with all hands due to a sudden shift of the solid ballast between decks during heavy weather," it was announced today.

As the 1948 challenge round for the Davis Cup came to an end in the Forest Hills Stadium yesterday, Australia found itself back where it stood at the end of the series in Melbourne two years ago -- on the short end of a 5-0 score.

Activity in the apparel lines, both at the retail and wholesale level, improved considerably here last week after the slowdown caused by the recent heat wave, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- When he made his first public appearance in London today Lieut. Col. Gregory Tokayev, former Soviet Air Force engineer, was called a "traitor" by a correspondent of Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., Sept. 6 (AP) -- An automobile and an airplane were in collision on United States Highway 40 near this community today in one of the holiday's most unusual accidents. Two persons were sent to a hospital for treatment.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- A strenuous defense of the veto power in the United Nations and of Russia's use of it was made today by Vladimir Simitch, head of the Yugoslav delegation, in the first day's meeting of the Interparliamentary Union in Rome.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's Fervent just managed to win the $51,400 Washington Park Handicap by a nose today to give Warren Wright's racing establishment its third consecutive triumph in the mile-and-a-quarter stake.
An individual's finger-painting may reveal significant personality traits, thereby opening a new path to the diagnosis and treatment of the mentally ill, according to an occupational therapy expert.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- By American custom Presidential campaigns begin in earnest with this holiday, which means that with growing intensity from now on Mr. Truman and Mr. Dewey will try to pound in reasons why each should be chosen over the other.
Since turn-about is fair play, I should like to answer "Fair Play," the architect who suggested the lifting of all rent ceilings in your columns recently.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Sandy Strand Stable's Manna H. today won the $7,500 added Pawtucket Handicap at Narragansett Park with the favorite, C.T. Chenery's Mangohick, running last before 26,289, the largest crowd of the meeting.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The employment of civilians by the Federal Government increased at a rate of 482 persons a day in July, Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, reported today.

PRAGUE, Tuesday, Sept. 7 -- Former President Eduard Benes' fellow-citizens stood on a line more than a mile and a half long yesterday afternoon to pay their last respects to him. It was taking a person in this queue nearly seven hours to pass the body lying in state.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- The contention of Tass that Italy is attempting to avoid the delivery of ships that she is committed to give to Russia under the terms of the Italian peace treaty was hotly denied today by the Rome press. It maintained that no action had been taken on the question because conversations still were under way between Rome and Moscow.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 (UP) -- The Ministry of the Interior announced today that Col. Vlado Daptchevitch was captured last Saturday night at the Hungarian border.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 6 -- James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, tonight attacked the Soviet Union for breaking "nearly all" of its agreements with the United States and Great Britain and denied that the late President Roosevelt acted "naively" in drawing up the wartime compacts.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Two hundred persons witnessed the unveiling this morning of a bronze portrait plaque at the entrance to the Theeodore Roosevelt Memorial Park on Oyster Bay Harbor. The plaque, the work of Julio Kilenyi, is imbedded in a rough boulder at the gate opposite the Long Island Rail Road station where the late President used to board the train when he lived at Sagamore Hill, his summer home here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Some State Department officials expressed today the fear that Russia and her satellites were attempting to retaliates for the unfavorable publicity of the affairs of the Russian teachers. Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kasenkina and Mikhail Samarin, who refused to return to the Soviet Union.

Returning crowds strained the transportation systems here yesterday to the extent of an average Labor Day. On the whole travel from inland points appeared to have increased slightly and that from beaches to have decreased.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 6 -- President Truman told a railroad station crowd here tonight that "before this campaign is over I expect to visit every whistle stop in the United States." He said that it was to be the most important Presidential campaign since the Lincoln-Douglas debates.
A combined team of New York American and Brookhattan soccer players defeated the Carsteel and Stelco selection from Montreal at Sterling Oval, yesterday, 1 to 0, before 2,500.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, who don't do too well against the tail-enders but are murder against the pennant contenders, climbed back into third place today with a double victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The State Department today confirmed the receipt of a Soviet note asking for new four-power talks on the disposal of Italy's former African colonies. However, it appeared likely from the attitude of Department officials that the proposal would be rejected, thus permitting the United Nations to decide the question.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 6 (YP) -- The Cubs divided a twin bill with Cincinnati (r)today to retain seventh place in the National League, one percencage point ahead of the :Reds.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Heavy buying of Orange Free State gold mining issues was the feature of the stock market here today. Although the market here still has no word about expected developments on the St. Helena property, Johannesburg was a strong buyer of the company's shares.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Joe McCarthy's Red Sox boosted their American League lead to a game and a half by sweeping a double-header with Washington, 14 -- 6 and 2 -- 1, today, as Philadelphia and New York split a twin bill.

Displaced Persons, under the unfair, inadequate and until now almost inoperative legislation passed this summer by the Eightieth Congress, will begin to arrive in this country in October. About 40,000 of the two-year quota of about 205,000 may come during the next eleven months.
BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- There was a knock on the door and a voice shouted "Police" in a tone familiar throughout Eastern Europe.

Your editorial "The Answer on Pier Rents," of Sept. 1, continues the useful service of pressing for better port facilities, promptly provided and fiscally prudent. Unfortunately, it also continues to advocate the appointment of the unregulated nonsuable Port Authority as landlord.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 6 -- One feature of the Edinburgh music festival is the series of chamber concerts given by celebrated musicians. This year these have been entrusted to Yehudi Menuhin and Louis Kentner, the latter a pianist of mid-European origin but British nationality, who have played Beethoven's Sonatas for Pianoforte and Violin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The dollar value of housing construction accomplished in the first eight months of this year set a record, the Commerce Department reported tonight. It was 55 per cent more than in the same period of 1947.

FARIBAULT, Minn., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today the Eightieth Congress "has had no inclination to legislate in the interests of either the farmer or of the laboring man."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The threat of a serious surplus of grains which hangs over the economy has brought the farm and business interests in the Cabinet into a head-on conflict of national proportions.

Ugo Carusi, chairman of the Displaced Persons Commission, left La Guardia Field at 9:25 A.M. yesterday for Frankfort on the Main, Germany, to help expedite the selection of emigrants to the United States. Accompanying him were six representatives of the Army, Immigration and Naturalization Service and Department of Justice, to aid in the screening work.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Whitehall offered no encouragement today to a Soviet proposal for a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers of Britain, the United States, the Soviet Union and France to consider the disposal of Italy's former colonies in Africa.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Cleveland dropped four a half games behind the American League-leading Boston Red Sox by splitting a double-header with the Chicago White Sox before 40,176 fans today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- The establishment of an international guard force of several thousand men to help the United Nations preserve peace was recommended here today by the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Although the development of Russian air power "remains an enigma," the Soviet Union has made "remarkable progress" in recent years, according to the 1948 edition of "Jane's All the World's Aircraft," published here today.

The coffee futures market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., opened firm yesterday and maintained the advance. Contracts were supplied by profit-taking on the scale-up with trade house covering and some small interest shown by Brazil in the far 1949 months. The near-by positions were up 36 to 35 points, while the remainder of the market was 26 to 23 points higher for the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered the Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation of Jersey City, N.J., to liquidate its holdings in three public utility companies. These are the York County Gas Company, York, Pa.; the Newport Gas Light Company, Newport, R.I., and the North Shore Gas Company, Ipswich, Mass.
Following is the text Harold E. Stassen's speech in Detroit last night as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Fresh outbreaks of trouble in Berlin, coupled with news of early power cuts in Britain were signals for profit-taking in the stock market here today.

The weeks around Labor Day are a time of festival and pageantry for the corps of citizens known as volunteer firemen. Now is the blossoming of parades, contests, clambakes, hamburger roasts. The Columbian Hose Company No. 1 in Peekskill marked its 100th year with a three-day fandango for thirty-one companies from up and down the Hudson Valley.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Robert Mitchum and Lila Leeds, film actors, and two other persons were indicted by the Los Angeles County grand jury today on charges of possessing marijuana and criminal conspiracy.

Two thousand members of the Macey department store local voted last night to disaffiliate from the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, in protest against the parent union's suspension of the local's officers and its appointment of two administrators to run the organization's affairs.

Nine young French Army officers, graduates of the Ecole Polytechnique this year, and one first-year cadet of that institution, here on an exchange arrangement between the French and the United States Armies, began their tour of New York yesterday with visits to the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition and Rockefeller Center.

THREE years and a little more ago the monstrous spectacle of the obliteration of Hiroshima and Nagasaki brought the second World War to a grim close, with the military might of the Germans and Japanese destroyed and no other problems solved. The peace which we have been waging since has been a dismal business.

A stock distribution of one new share of common stock for each three shares held was declared yesterday by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company. The stock will be distributed about Nov. 12 to stockholders of record on Oct. 20.

Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, was sworn in by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday as chairman of a twel e-man committee, whose members were appointed at the same time, to assist displaced persons arriving here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- Because Sid Gordon constituted himself a one-man wrecking crew, the Giants celebrated their farewell to Shibe Park today with a double victory over the Phillies and gained a length on the leaders in their desperate bid to remain in the Pennant race.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- The oil industry of the Pacific Coast began preparations today to ration gasoline and petroleum supplies in the event that the four-day-old strike of oil workers persists for another week or more.
New Yorkers may be traveling in jet-propelled buses within a few years, it was reported here yesterday by Col. Sidney H. Bingham, commissioner of the New York Board of Transportation.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Ugo Carusi, United States Commissioner for Displaced Persons, arrived here today for a month-long series of conferences and investigations to speed implementation of the new United States displaced persons act.

Education can help men attain freedom, hold to ethical considerations and attain spiritual values in life, it was declared last night as the ninth annual conference on science, philosophy and religion opened at the Columbia University Men's Faculty Club, 400 West 117th Street.
President Truman, Governor Dewey and Henry A. Wallace all will wind up their campaigns for the Presidency in the New York metropolitan area, tentative schedules, of the three rivals showed yesterday.
NANKING, Sept. 7 -- The Chief Secretary of the Finance Ministry, Hsu Pai-chi, today was formally suspended from office because of his involvement in a Shanghai stock dumping scandal.

It is greatly to the credit of the American Merchant Marine Library Association that in spite of drastically limited finances it was able in the past year to provide 2,802 merchant vessels, United States Coast Guard and Navy and Army transports with library units.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The monotony of the present British diet, with its low percentage of fats and proteins is seriously hampering the full productivity of farm labor throughout Britain, Dr. Nevil Leyton, Harley Street dietitian, declared today in correspondence to appear here in The Medical Press.

The first public offering of common shares of Television Fund, Inc., first mutual, open-end investment company specializing in the field of television, electronics and radio, will be made to investors today.

The Metropolitan Opera has been conferring with executives of three of the largest motion picture concerns "in regard to the possibility of filming some of our productions, in whole or in part, and preferably in Technicolor," it became known yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Names of the winners of state war-service scholarships in New York State institutions of higher learning, effective as of Sept. 1, were announced today by the State Department of Education. Of the winners 655 live in New York City. The competitive examinations were held Aug. 2.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- When Mr. Harriman flew back from London today, it was said in authoritative United States circles that the demands of Gen. Lucius D. Clay had been reduced to "manageable proportions." That concession, it was said, permitted some hope of successful negotiation between him and the sixteen European governments that had sided against him in the allocation of dollars.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador-at-Large for the European Recovery Program, had a private talk in London today with Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in what was believed to be an effort to settle an acute dispute over the distribution of funds for the first year of the program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, made public today a report by sixteen Negro civilian leaders urging seven far-reaching proposals to end segregation and provide "equal racial opportunity" in the armed services.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- A former German occupation official in France is expected tomorrow to open the general debate in the West German Parliamentary Assembly at Bonn where he is rapidly becoming one of the leaders in the writing of a provisional constitution.

A new novitiate of the Pious Society of the Missionaries of St. Charles Borromeo, or Scalabrinian Fathers, was dedicated yesterday morning in Dongan Hills, S. I. Thirteen candidates for the priesthood were invested as novices, beginning a year of trial, at the end of which they expect to take the first vows of the order.

Although the life-expectancy of the Federal Reserve "peg prices" for buying Treasury bonds in the open market is the No. 1 question in financial circles, the market for Government bonds has seemingly become inured anew to the "open mouth," and the going level of bond prices, so far as can be tested in the prevailing quiet market, continues to be firm.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- "Blood Brother," a 1947 novel of frontier days in Arizona by Elliott Arnold, has been bought for the screen by Norma Productions, of which Burt Lancaster and Harold Hecht are the principal figures. Announcing the purchase today, they said the story would be filmed next spring as one of the company's most important pictures, with Julian Blaustein producing.

"Music Manuscripts of the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries'' is the name of a new exhibition opening today in the Central Building of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 7 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister for Economic Affairs, today endeavored to head off a rising labor demand for higher wages and for legal curbs on dividends and profits.

At a moment when the "technical" negotiations between Soviet Russia and the West regarding the Berlin crisis begin to show some signs of progress, Russian authorities have seen fit to precipitate a series of events in the German capital which puts these negotiations under an added strain.
RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Burma Government said tonight that the Shan States bordering China and Siam were beset with unrest "due to an outside influence."
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 (AP) -Meek surrender on the steps of a country store today ended a nightong search for two men who killed a New Orleans detective and abducted the assistant chief of detectives.

The Board of Elections as divided 2 to 2 yesterday on a motion to invalidate a nominating petition of the United Laborite party bearing the names of thirty-three candidates. Thirteen nominees were ruled off the ballot because their petitions did not contain the required number of signatures.

GENEVA, Sept. 7 -- The colonial system under which native populations are beaten down into forced labor for the greater wealth of their European masters exists only in the imagination of Russian propagandists, a French spokesman told a United Nations subcommission on nonself-governing territories today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The Government soon will offer to American concerns nearly $1,000,000,000 in "phantom" war contracts under its mobilization plans, it was disclosed today.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 7 -- Sources here in close touch with the struggle in Burma asserted today that the Karen revolt marked an entirely new phase in the civil war there. The Karen uprising, these sources said, is against both the Government and the Communist rebels and is aimed at the restoration of order in the countryside and the setting up of a new anti-Communist regime in Burma.

Frankly conceding that endorsement of any Presidential candidate would "split the organization wide open," the nation's biggest leftwing union withheld its official backing yesterday from Henry A. Wallace.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Using the press as its medium, the British Foreign Office let the Soviet Union know today that the London Government took a serious view of the repeated demonstrations organized by German Communists against the Berlin city administration.

New York's potentially disastrous truck strike ended its first week on a distinctly pessimistic note yesterday when an employers' negotiating committee rejected the union's "rock-bottom" counter-proposals formulated last week.

PRAGUE, Wednesday, Sept. 8 -- Many thousands still waiting to see the body of former President Eduard Benes, which has been lying in state since yesterday morning, rioted when the police started to close the doors of Memorial Hall shortly before midnight Tuesday.

While visitors noted a resemblance between art expressions of schizophrenic patients and those of abstract art devotees a psychologist related yesterday how creations by the mentally ill have proved valuable in their diagnosis and treatment.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Count Bernadotte charged in a cable received here today that Egyptian authorities bore "very grave responsibility" for the death of two French military observers at Gaza on Aug. 28. He told the Security Council that he had asked the Egyptian Government to punish the offenders and make immediate redress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, denied today all charges of violating the injunction against it. The union contended that the Government in effect was asking the court to support adamant publishers on disputed issues not covered by the injunction.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation reported today a net loss of $205,696 for the six months ended on June 30. This compared with a loss of $210,934 for the corresponding period in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- More than three-fourths of all arthritis victims can be helped and possibly cured by the right kind of early treatment, according to Dr. Le Moyne C. Kelly, assistant professor of clinical medicine at the Yale University School of Medicine.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The ancient pitching arm of Fritz Ostermueller lifted Pittsburgh into second place, a fraction of a percentage point ahead of the idle Dodgers, as the Pirates defeated the Cardinals, 6 to 2, before 36,136 cheering fans at Forbes Field tonight.

Steel distributors yesterday took a pessimistic view of their business future as a result of the elimination of discounts on all stainless steel products by several big mills. The action by the various mills was taken last week.
May I make rebuttal to Gilbert A. DiLucia's remarks, as published in your issue of Aug. 25, concerning the fate of Italy's "former" colonies?

Garry Davis, son of Meyer Davis, the orchestra leader, was misquoted by a press service on Aug. 23 in a dispatch from Paris saying "he might want his citizenship back," he has informed THE NEW YORK TIMES by letter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration today approved use of $12,250,000 in recovery funds to buy Japanese cotton fabrics for shipment to the Netherlands-Indies.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- William J. Goble, New York and Westchester County building contractor since 1903, died here today in his home at 125 South Broadway of a heart attack suffered yesterday when he tripped while watering the lawn. His age was 76.

This is the pleasantest period in the year so far as fresh vegetables are concerned. Near-by gardens reach their peak; the trip to town is so short no loss in flavor can occur. And not only are quality and quantity excellent, but variety, too.
In none of the couture showings reviewed to date has the modernization of the Empire line been as strongly stressed as it was at Jay Thorpe's yesterday in the fall and winter custom-made collection.

Negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association will be resumed tomorrow at 11 A.M. under the auspices of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service, Thomas R. Steutel, mediation commissioner assigned to the dispute, announced yesterday afternoon.

DENVER, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals, champions of the National Football League, had all the earmarks of sure-fire repeaters last night as they battered the Washington Redskins, 46 -- 20, in an exhibition that drew 18,000 fans.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Sept. 7 -- The racial problems that have dominated the South African scene since the Nationalists came to power last May have been intensified by the revelations of a Pretoria correspondent of The Cape Argus.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- After consultation with Washington and Paris, the British Government replied today to the Soviet Union's proposal for a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers of the Big Four powers to discuss the disposal of Italy's former colonies in Africa.

In an effort to reduce the jarring effects of frequent alarm signals upon the health of the city's firemen, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle will place in operation today a system of "selective transmissions" during night hours.

BERLIN, Wednesday, Sept. 8 -- The Soviet military administration had permitted the Germans to leave after announcing that its forty-hour siege of Berlin's City Hall had been lifted. Earlier this morning the Russians had lifted the restrictions on Allied personnel in the City Hall but had retained the blockade of the Germans inside.
