ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The grouse hunting season has been extended one week in each shooting zone of the state, the Conservation Department announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- An editorial in Borba, official Yugoslav Communist party organ, charged today that the Balkan and Danubian countries that had supported the Communist Information Bureau's campaign against Yugoslavia were, in fact, serving "imperialist interests."
BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A major cause of airplane accidents, discovered by the Air Force, was reported to the American Psychological Association today.

A study of European history, covering from the fourth century to the twentieth century, has been written by Louise Fargo Brown, Professor Emeritus of History in Vassar College and George B. Carson, Chairman of the Social Studies Division of New York State Teachers College, under the title "Men and Centuries of European Civilization."

WASHINGTON, Sept 7 -- The Kansas City Southern Railway Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to authorize payment of $50,000 to Kuhn, Loeb Co. for services rendered in preparing a plan for the refunding of securities that would have fallen due in 1950.

Parents who take their children to register for the first time in New York's public elementary schools and kindergartens this week were advised yesterday never to use the school or the teacher as a threat against unruly behavior.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept 7 -- Less than twenty-four hours after taking action denounced from the floor as "plumb ridiculous" and "done in a spirit of hysteria," the House of Delegates, legislative body of the American Bar Association, today modified a program for "purging" the association of members who refused to reveal whether or not they were Communists.

The supply of heavy duty electric power to nearly 350 business land industrial buildings in Brooklyn was cut off for about two hours yesterday, as the result of a short circuit and flash fire in the Consolidated Edison Company generating plant at Gold Street, on the East River.

Although buyer attendance was down, salesmen exhibiting at the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart in the New Yorker Hotel reported yesterday that they had made a good start on late fall and Christmas business. The show, featuring infants and children's wear for buyers in the metropolitan area, will continue through Monday.

The Consulate General of the Soviet Union at 7 East Sixty-first Street will be closed "in the near future." The closing will be as soon as the household and office effects of the consulate and its staff can be moved out, a member of the staff said yesterday.

After eleven months of workshop practice, the Actors Studio has put on its first public production, Bessie Breuer's "Sundown Beach," which opened at the Belasco last evening. There seems to be some jumble of proportions here.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president Dr. of Brooklyn College, assailed yesterday the decision of Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Education Commissioner, not to set aside a previous ruling that reinstated Dr. Francis J. Thompson as a City College instructor.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A strike which union leaders said would cripple the country's telephone service was called today for Sept. 17.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Australian sports writers today bitterly criticized the Dominion's tennis administration and Davis Cup Captain Adrian Quist. One commentator called Quist "a champion sniveler and squealer."

John H. Vincent in his recent letter under the heading of Attitudes Toward Science fails to understand the fundamentals of scientific thinking to such an extent that I hasten to make one or two corrections in order to set your readers straight.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- Sufficient time has now elapsed since the death of Andrei A. Zhdanov, popularly considered to be Premier Stalin's most trusted henchman, to speculate upon who has succeeded the Leningrad boss, at least temporarily, in the private hierarchy of the Kremlin.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- Unbridled reckless driving and "gray market" car sales at excessive prices were described today as a national disgrace at the annual conference of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators which opened here.

"Wholehearted endorsement" of three Democrats and one Republican who are incumbent Representatives running for re-election to Congress was announced yesterday by the New York Regional CIO-PAC committee on endorsements, through Louis Hollander, president of the New York State CIO.
PARIS, Sept. 7 -- Precipitating the third governmental crisis in the last six weeks, the French National Assembly today placed the second Schuman Cabinet in a minority by a vote of 295 to 289.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, opened the Republican Presidential campaign here tonight by replying to the Labor Day message delivered here Monday by President Truman.

PRAGUE, Sept. 7 -- Punishment is now being meted out rapidly to persons charged with having exposed to the view of outsiders the measures taken within the Communist Ministry of the Interior and the national police force.

The interim report of the Senate Investigations Subcommittee headed by Senator Ferguson that has been probing the operation of the loyalty check on present and would-be federal employes calls for prompt corrective action in the matter of administration loopholes and delays.

The managing directors of three of Belgium's largest department stores arrived here yesterday on the Queen Elizabeth to make an intensive six weeks' survey of what makes American department and chain stores "tick." They are particularly interested in the methods of scientific distribution that these stores pursue and the reasons why they are able to offer the consumer merchandise at attractive prices.

Because of the rise in poliomyelitis, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis spent $1,091,917 in March of Dimes emergency funds last month, it was announced yesterday. With this sum, the total of its epidemic reserve fund expenditures since Jan. 1 reached $2,815,476, officials reported at foundation headquarters, 120 Broadway.

Although contracts haven't been signed, Gertrude Lawrence has selected her next starring vehicle, it was learned yesterday. It will be the new Daphne du Maurier play, hitherto called "The Mother." Miss Lawrence isn't enthusiastic about the title and therefore it will be changed to something else.

Freeman Gosden and Charles Correll have sold to the Columbia Broadcasting System all rights to their radio characterizations of "Amos 'n' Andy," it was announced yesterday. The two comedians will continue, however, to appear in their original roles.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- The breakdown of United Nations attempts to restore peace between India and Pakistan over Kashmir raised the strong feeling here today that quick Security Council action might be needed to retain the smoldering war on the sub-continent.

The Commission to Study the Organization of Peace -- an unofficial group of well informed and deeply interested students of international affairs -- has proposed the establishment of an International Guard Force of several thousand men to help the United Nations preserve peace.

Members of the Board of Estimate laid the groundwork yesterday for approval tomorrow of a proposal that the city take over six Manhattan lines of the East Side and Comprehensive Omnibus Companies at a maximum cost of $1,200,000.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday. Final prices were 6 to 14 points net lower.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. S.G. Steckler's Coyote today won his second race here when he accounted for the featured six-furlong By the Sea purse. Coyote, a 5-to-1 shot, survived a claim of foul lodged by Jockey David Gorham, who had finished third on Mr. Buster.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Approximately seventy new British aircraft went on view today at the opening of the ninth annual flying display and exhibition of the Society of British Aircraft Constructors, held at Farnborough, in Hampshire.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Olaf Ulvestad of Seattle, a strong favorite in the New York State chess championship, today defeated Jack W. Collins, champion of the Brooklyn Chess Club, in the third-round game they had adjourned last night.

EAGLE BRIDGE, N. Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Grandma Moses was the life of her eighty-eighth birthday party today. She was hostess all day to more than fifty friends and neighbors who joined her in celebrating her twelfth anniversary as an artist as well as her birthday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7 -- Marshal Tito's commissars are raiding the farms of so-called rich peasants throughout Yugoslavia. These men are seizing nearly all the pigs and turning them over to state-owned farms and peasant cooperatives.

The Republican campaign against Vito Marcantonio's re-election to Congress from the Eighteenth New York District will begin tomorrow night with a rally opening headquarters for John Ellis, the Republican nominee, at 245 East Eighty-sixth Street. Glen R. Bedenkapp, Republican state chairman; Alger Chapman, state campaign manager, and Thomas J. Curran, New York County chairman, will speak. John S. McCook, campaign manager for Mr. Ellis, will preside.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A broad vocational analysis by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, on the outlook for women in science, soon will be available to the 200,000 or so girls who will enter college this fall.

DENVER, Sept. 7 -- The welfare of the people of the Americas for generations to come is the dominant note of the first inter-American conference on the conservation of renewable natural resources which opened a two-weeks' meeting here today.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The six-meter yacht Goose, owned by George Nichols of Cold Spring Harbor, earned the right to defend her International Gold Cup title today after three straight victories in the waters off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

TOKYO, Sept. 7 -- Floors have been set under export prices for cotton, rayon and woolen piece goods and yarn below which Japanese makers will not be permitted to sell, occupation textile officials announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Heavy short covering in September corn on the Board of Trade lifted that delivery today 5 7/8 cents a bushel over Saturday's finish and the close was at the top. Deferred deliveries of corn, after an easy start, rallied with September and gained 2 to 2 1/4 cents.

BERLIN, Wednesday, Sept. 8 -- Nineteen Western sector German policemen were kidnapped by rival Russian-backed policemen and Soviet tommy-gunners today as they left the Berlin City Hall under a Russian safe-conduct guarantee.
Milk companies managed yesterday to deliver this city's normal supply of 3,000,000 quarts of milk despite the halt in the supply of paper containers due to the trucking strike.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 7 -- The St. Cecilia Orchestra, known as The Augusteo, has arrived from Rome to take its part in the Edinburgh Festival, and give its first of six concerts in Usher Hall tonight. The illness of Molinari, who had been engaged to conduct, necessitated changes in the programs, including the omission of some interesting modern Italian works.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 7 -- An undisclosed number of casualties were inflicted on Israeli troops and civilians today while Arab forces in northern Jerusalem suffered three killed and six wounded in a violent artillery and machine gun battle in Jerusalem that continued from dawn until almost noon.

Reorders for women's coats, suits and dresses are coming in strong again after a letdown induced by the recent heat wave and the Labor Day holiday, a survey of the New York market showed yesterday. With a heavy backlog of fall orders placed previously, manufacturers said they had been working at peak capacity.

A sizable rally was staged yesterday by the stock market after weathering a period of indecision. A buying rush in the steels encouraged modest bidding in other sections in a post-holiday session which saw volume approach 1,000,000 shares.

GRAFENWOEHR, Germany, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The American crack First Infantry Division and a British paratroop battalion joined in maneuvers today to prevent a mythical enemy from sweeping west to the Rhine.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- The strike-crippled West Coast shipping industry today asked for and got the unanimous support of San Francisco businessmen who must stand the estimated $4,000,000-a- day loss of the strike.
The executive board of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union of America, CIO, voted yesterday to dismiss Harry Sacher, its counsel, from his $6,000-a-year job.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 7 -- Circuit Judge Miles W. Lewis ruled today that Presidential electors were free to vote as they pleased in the electoral college.
BERLIN, Wednesday, Sept. 8 -- A small, wiry French captain last night earned the grudging admiration of the Soviet sector German police by slugging his way into the then besieged City Hall.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 1 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks ended last Saturday a decline of 2 per cent was shown.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Sept. 7 -- A good run of big stripers rewarded the anglers who came here for the week-end, for a southwest wind moved the bass inshore and surfcasters as well as those who cast from boats took plenty of fish ranging from twenty-five to thirty-eight pounds.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- With $6,000 in cash prizes and a dozen handsome trophies at stake for the fastest and the most enduring, upward of 100 men and women swimmers will strike off into the chill waters of this deep, spring-fed lake at 8 A.M. tomorrow in the Lake George marathon swim.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 -- Gasoline and fuel oil can be produced from other than petroleum for about the same price, it was stated here today by petroleum experts attending the American Chemical Society's midwest session.
MONTEVIDEO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The value of the Uruguayan peso depreciated today as the Banco de la Republica resumed operations in the "free market" after a one-month suspension.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 7 -- Leon H. Keyserling, vice-chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisors, proposed today that the United States establish a "national prosperity budget" for use in measuring the national capacity to achieve major goals in employment, production, housing, health and education.

Lock and Key, 4-year-old filly owned by Crispin Oglebay, took the $11,625 Bushwick Hurdles Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing against nine others in the twenty-seventh running of the field event over a distance of about two miles, the daughter of Easton and Level Head was pressed to the limit to win.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Truman presided this afternoon at a special meeting of the National Security Council, which deliberated on the crisis in Berlin. No intimation was given of the results of the meeting.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The National Union of Manufacturers, in endorsing today's call by Sir Stafford Cripps for a united effort to attain greater production, suggested that the Government set an example by reducing public expenditures, taxation and administration.

Intercollegiate basketball will usher in its fifteenth consecutive season at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, Dec. 2, when the first of twenty-five doubleheaders is played with New York University facing Baylor and St. John's tackling Tennessee.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 7 -- The United Nations has decided to open a central field office here within a week to deal with Arab displaced persons from Palestine, now estimated to total 400,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- A committee to develop greater use of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and to bring more financial business into Pennsylvania was formed today by the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce.

John P. McGrath, Corporation counsel, informed Murray Stand, City Clerk, yesterday that in his opinion the American Labor party petition for the restoration of the five-cent transit fare was "illegal and invalid."
MANILA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Philippines Air Lines today asked for Government protection from the "ruinous and unjustifiable" competition of two United States airlines operating into this country.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Fish and Wildlife Service said today that tuna have been landed in Alaska on a commercial scale for the first time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Bohus Benes, nephew of the late Dr. Eduard Benes, former President of Czechoslovakia, said today he had resigned as Czech Consul here because he "is not, and cannot be, a Communist."

A flood of mysterious inquiries about American shipbuilding, merchant marine plans, vessel designs and other data concerning the industry is reaching shipping companies and maritime agencies, it became known yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Delegates of Russia's satellite states severely attacked the Marshall Plan and the idea of a European federation in today's sittings of the thirty-seventh conference of the Inter-parliamentary Union. Yesterday, only speeches favorable to a European federation were heard, for not even the Yugoslav delegation attacked it directly.

C. S. Jackson, an international vice president of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union, CIO, and head of District 5, the union's Canadian affiliate, was taken into custody by immigration officials at La Guardia Field yesterday as he stepped from a Trans-Canada Airlines plane.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Prisjoe Stable's Our Birthday led from start to finish to win the Coventry purse by a length today from the favored Stan Tracy, owned by P.H. Sampliner, at Narragansett Park. The 7-year-old son of War Hero ran the mile and a furlong in 1:54.

Frank Parker, runner-up to John Kramer last year and winner of the title in 1944 and 1945, heads the draw for the men's National amateur tennis championship, which will start Friday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
ATHENS, Sept. 7 -- Interest in the war against the Communist-led rebels has swung over to the naval side of operations. The Ministry of Marine published the news today of several sea exploits.

It seems likely that a decision will be made at City Hall within a week on what plan and what agency will be used for modernization of the city's waterfront. This decision is inseparable from capital budget making, and by next Wednesday Mayor O'Dwyer must under the City Charter, certify to the Planning Commission the maximum amount of debt that the city may incur for capital projects during 1949.

Passenger and cargo traffic at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, last month was nearly triple that in July, according to a report released yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

William P. Buckner, once convicted of taking part in an $8,500,000 bond fraud, and Charles (Chic) Farmer, former East Side night club press agent, were accused yesterday with a third defendant, a professional gambler, of staging the so-called Park Avenue charity gambling party.

WHEN the Yankees were playing the Cleveland Indians a week or so ago, someone remarked to Bucky Harris, "This is the big one." Thereupon Mr. Harris retorted softly but sagely, "At this stage in the season every game is a big one." No one could fault him on that statement. However, he won't be facing any bigger games than the three his Yanks will be playing in Boston, starting tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Railway Express Agency today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a single scale of rates for nation-wide application in place of the two scales now applying, one west of the Mississippi River and between that area and the East, and one east of the Mississippi.

With the last of the thirty-six starters in the 255-mile Stamford-Vineyard Lightship race checked off, John M. Timken's yawl Kitty Hawk yesterday was revealed the winner of the long-distance event as the Stamford Yacht Club's race committee completed its computation of corrected times.
WARSAW, Sept. 7 -- President Boleslaw Bierut, newly appointed secretary-general of the Polish Communist party, will head a United Workers party to be formed soon from a merger with the Socialists.

While the Trades Union Congress at Margate debates issues which have an important bearing on the course, and survival, of the British Labor Government and a compromise Cabinet has failed again in a desperate effort to save the present parliamentary system in France, the battle for the control of Berlin has gone into the streets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today the Government would not be able to reduce the $253,000,000,000 national debt during the next ten months.

Remington Rand, Inc., is beginning today an extensive national promotional campaign for its new Remington Electric Deluxe typewriters, using large-space advertising in leading newspapers. This campaign will be assisted also by four-color and black-and-white pages in national weeklies, general monthly magazines and leading trade publications.

City Stores Company, in the three months ended with last July, increased its consolidated net sales by 7 per cent over the volume for the corresponding period of 1947, while earnings were raised 18 per cent, according to the report issued yesterday.
New Selective Service registrations fell several thousand short yesterday of the working quotas set by draft officials.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President, listened tonight at the Executive Mansion to the speech delivered by Harold E. Stassen in Detroit which formally opened the Republican national campaign.
BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Sept. 7 -- The excursion steamer Naugatuck, out of Providence, went hard aground in a dense fog early this afternoon about 200 feet from the narrow opening into New Harbor here.

Commissioner of Investigation John J. Murtagh moved in Supreme Court yesterday for a warrant of attachment instructing the Sheriff of New York County to compel the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association to produce hooks and records pertaining to its milk sales.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities began today to round up more than a score of witnesses as a prelude to a public investigation into whether Russia has obtained atomic secrets from American scientific projects and, if so, to what extent.

A hotel night manager was shot dead early yesterday because he did not have keys to a hotel safe deposit vault. It was learned later that the keys to the safe would have been useless because inside were smaller metal receptacles, the keys to which were held by the hotel guests.

URUMCHI, Sinkiang, Aug. 27 -- Top Chinese authorities here are the first to confess that bad administration in the past is primarily responsible for the difficulties that Nanking is now encountering in Sinkiang. China is still paying for the excesses of Gen. Sheng Shih-tsai, warlord Governor of Sinklang from 1934 to 1944, and the long history of graft, corruption and cultural arrogance on the part of independent-Chinese administrators.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- In a preliminary to the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship which starts tomorrow over the same course, Frank Slate of Aiken, former steeplechase rider, and Al Ciuci, president of the Long Island P.G.A., captured the amateur-pro competition at the Cold Spring Country Club with a best ball score of 62.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Philip K. Gilman, Clinical Professor emeritus of Surgery at Stanford University Medical School and chief of the Bureau of Hospitals of the State Department of Public Health, died at his home in San Anselmo, Calif., today. He was 69 years old.

Louis F. Reed Jr. brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday against his socially prominent former wife, Mrs. Marie Hartford Hofman Robertson, for $28,050 allegedly due him under a contract entered into on June 18, 1935, by which he was to receive $1,650 a month or life in return for consenting to appear in a divorce action in Reno brought by his wife.

FLINT, Mich., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions registered their first victory under the coaching of Bo McMillin tonight, beating the New York Giants by 23 to 20 in a National Football League exhibition game before an estimated crowd of 8,500 at Atwood Stadium.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- A settlement of the bitter dispute between Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor in Germany, and European officials over the division of dollars under the Marshall Plan was predicted today by W. Averell Harriman, special United States Ambassador under that plan.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 8 -- The sixteenth annual fall race series of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club opened today with 276 starting craft, a new record for the initial regatta. There will be five programs, running through Sunday.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 8 -- The Polish Communist party have promised peasants in this country that membership in the production cooperatives designed to speed up socialization of the countryside would be "voluntary."

Two biographies of Nathaniel Hawthorne have been scheduled for publication a week apart. Rinehart will bring out on Sept. 30 Robert Cantwell's "Nathaniel Hawthorne: The American Years," an account of his life up to the time of the publication of "The Scarlet Letter."
The report of the Lone Stew Steel Company announced yesterday a net income of $2,101,794 after all charges, including $1,320,241 provision for taxes, in the seven months ended on July 31.
ALBANY, Sept. 8 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey will make the first speech in his bid for the Presidency at Des Moines, Iowa, on Sept. 20, it was announced here today.

Your editorial of Sept. 5, 1948, entitled "'Displaced' Children" expresses indignation at the proposal made by the United States, British, Netherlands and Brazilian delegates to the United Nations Economic and Social Council that all "unaccompanied children'' under 16 years of age in the Displaced Persons Camps of Europe be returned to their countries of origin.

David Dubinsky, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, demanded last night the fullest protection from Communist reprisal for militant trade unionists in Germany, and particularly in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Athletics swept a twilight-night double-header from Washington tonight, surviving a ninth-inning rally to capture the opener, 10 -- 7, and winning the nightcap, 5 -- 2, behind the seven-hit pitching of Carl Scheib.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Approximately fifteen ineligible Big Nine athletes -- a majority of them football players -- have been weeded out in "operation sanity code."

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Miss Tilly, Charles Thellies' outstanding bay filly, today won the $34,246 Horseman Stake for 2-year-old trotters at the Indiana State Fair. Fred Egan piloted the filly to victory in two straight heats.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Joan Fontaine's next picture for Rampart Productions will be "A Very Remarkable Fellow," based on a story which Rampart has obtained from RKO. William Dozier, president of the company and husband of the star, said the film would go into production in February.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A witness accused of selling forged export licenses today refused to testify to the transactions on grounds of self-incrimination and was excused by a Senate investigating committee on his promise to return later and "tell just how it was done."

Mrs. Harry S. Truman and Margaret Truman will accompany the President on his campaign trips, it was made known here yesterday. Mrs. India Edwards, chairman of women's activities for the Democratic National Committee, inadvertently disclosed the plans at the opening of the women's division headquarters on the fourth floor of the Biltmore Hotel.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- Picking themselves off the floor after sustaining a bruising first-round cuffing, the Red Sex tonight raised Boston's pennant hopes to fever pitch as they promptly retaliated in kind and went on to crush the Yankees, 10 to 6, in the opening clash of a three-game series ushering in the stretch drive of the American League's seething race.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 -- President Juan D. Peron, whose anger at any or all persons who dare to oppose his plans to reform the Argentine Constitution has illumined his every recent utterance, today lashed out again in what was considered here to be the most furious tirade in his career.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The refusal of the British Trades Union Congress today to vote support of the World Federation of Trade Unions was interpreted here as freeing the hands of the TUC's General Council to take whatever action it may desire, even to the point of leaving the World Federation.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- Will Brandt, Berlin representative of the Executive Committee of the Socialist Democratic party, said today he wanted the world to listen to a story identical to one it had not wanted to heed during the Nineteen Thirties.

In a quick turnover of a property in the fur district, the three-story building used as a school for fur designing at 253-55 Seventh Avenue, between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Streets, has been resold by Henry Goelet, operator, to an investing client of Alfred Lifschitz, broker.

ATLANTA, Thursday Sept. 9 -- Herman Talmadge, son of the late Gov. Eugene Talmadge, held a steady lead of almost three to one in indicated county unit votes early today and declared "victory is ours" in Georgia's Democratic primary for Governor.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Sixteen non- operating unions made railway labor's formal opening countrywide bid for a third round wage increase today as union chiefs and carrier representatives started negotiations here.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Sept. 8 (UP) -- Earl Cochell, 26-year-old San Franciscan, scored a stunning upset over Davis Cup player Bill Talbert of New York today, 9 -- 7, 8 -- 6, 6--4, to win the postponed men's singles final of the sixtieth Seabright invitation tennis tournament.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- The Commonwealth Edison System beat a shortage of power today by asking big customers to turn off an unneeded motor here and there.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Uncertainty as to the outcome of the Berlin talks, coupled with French political developments, depressed the stock market here today.

Full scope of a plan to finance trade opportunities under the Economic Cooperation Administration was outlined yesterday by Sylvan Gotshal, counsel to the Textile Distributors Institute, upon his return from a five-week visit to industrial centers abroad.

GENEVA, Sept. 8 -- The contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade approved today a United States proposal to grant preferential tariff arrangements in favor of United States trust territories in the Pacific.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 5 -- Costa Rican officials are conferring daily with representatives of the International Monetary Fund on how to provide dollars to pay for the machinery and equipment and clothing that this country must import to subsist.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (AP) -- An infield error with the bases filled enabled the Indians to edge the Tigers, 8 -- 7, in the eleventh inning tonight before a crowd of 43,707.

The six-story ninety-six-family apartment house at 1775 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Joseph E. Lehrer, Herman and Harry Boslow and Lillie and Jacob N. Kliegman to an investing client of Geis, Forman Schulze for cash above mortgages of $530,000.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 8 -- Contrasting British and United States productivity in his Presidential address to the British Association for the Advancement of Science here tonight, Sir Henry T. Tizard said that the greater productivity in the United States could not be explained merely in terms of the disparity of natural resources.

The twenty-sixth edition of the Cowdin Stakes for 2-year-olds produced the expected results at Aqueduct yesterday. The four contestants finished in the order of favoritism, with Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Algasir looking better than ever in winning by a couple of lengths.
Mayor O'Dwyer presented yes: terday to ten members of the department for sanitation medals awarded for valor and monitorious.
Officials of the Transport Workers Union conferred an hour yesterday with Public Service Commissioner Spencer B. Eddy at 233 Broadway regarding bus-fare increases.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The United States came out today in full support of a modest international guard force to strengthen the hand of the United Nations and help keep peace throughout the world.

Some reduction in supplies of aluminum pots, pans and other kitchenware will occur in the fourth quarter as a result of growing shortages of the metal, producers' spokesmen declared yesterday. They declined to estimate the amount of the reduction.

WASHINGTON, Sept 8 -- As a result of the transportation tie-up caused by the West Coast maritime strike, the Association of American Railroads imposed an embargo today on freight moving to Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports for shipment by water to the Pacific Coast.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- This year's flue-cured tobacco crop is expected to continue in strong demand, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
Gov. Earl Warren of California will carry his campaign as the Republican Vice Presidential nominee into New York State and New England late this month, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- With the defeat of Aaron Rothman by Larry Evans, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, last night, there was no one among the other twenty-two contestants in a position to equal Evans' score of 4 -- 0, when play was resumed today in the four adjourned games from the fourth round of the New York State championship.

The stock market broke sharply yesterday as the foreign situation took a turn for the worse. The emphasis placed by Secretary of State George Marshall on the seriousness of the friction between the Soviet and the Western powers led to price declines of 1 to as much as 4 points in some of the vulnerable stocks, while the index slipped 1.38 points.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, speeding their rebuilding program for the National Football League campaign, today acquired four new players and moved to chop off four others. After a quickly maneuvered series of deals, Coach Bo McMillin announced that the Lions had:

The Marine Tiger, a Government-owned C-4 type emergency-class passenger vessel, which is due here tomorrow, will make a quick turnaround and substitute for the strikebound Marine Jumper, Maritime Commission officials announced yesterday. The Tiger was to have entered a local shipyard for repairs.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 8 -- President Syngman Rhee today said that he would offer to relieve Gen. Douglas MacArthur of responsibility for "Korean trouble-makers" in Japan. He added that he intended to visit General MacArthur soon.
BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- The United States protested vehemently today to the Soviet Military Administration against Communist mob violence as the struggle for the now divided city raged unchecked.

Retirement of Leonard M. Holden, secretary-treasurer of the Tea Bureau, Inc., after forty years in the industry was announced yesterday at a luncheon held in his honor at the Biltmore Hotel. J.S. Graham, chairman of the International Tea Marketing Extension Board, official representatives of principal tea producers of the world, and Antony Tasker, assistant organizing director of the board, both from London, commended Mr. Holden for his contributions to the industry.

Common stockholders of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company today will be offered the right to subscribe to 316,863 additional shares of common stock at $16.25 a share, at the rate of one new share for each eight shares held.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 8 -- The Communists have "captured" the World Federation of Trade Unions and agents of that organization now are busy fomenting trouble in Malaya: other parts of Asia and in Africa, the annual British Trades Union Congress here was told today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (UP) --A meeting between Harry Bridges, president of the. CIO Longshoremen's IYnion, and Army transportation officials broke up tonight with no announced solution for the problem of loading military supplies tied up by the week-old maritime strike on the West Coast.
Hudson County, N.J., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Sept. 23 on issues of bonds totaling $435,000. Dated Oct 1, 1948, the bonds will come due Oct. 1, from 1949 to 1966.

The New York City Opera Company will open its fall season at the New York City Center Thursday night, Oct. 7, with Puccini's "Tosca," which will be presented with a cast headed by Suzy Morris in the title role, Mario Binci as Cavaradossi, and Walter Cassel as Scarpia.

In regard to your article in THE TIMES on Aug. 22 under the heading "Stray Paper Adds to Civil War Data," may I point out that The Vicksburg Daily Citizen of July 2, 1863, printed on wallpaper, is all old story? Even if Mr. Zilko's copy is an original, it is one of at least fifteen in the country, of which the Western Reserve Historical Society has five.

Renegotiation of defense contracts is "definitely undesirable in peacetime," according to nine out of ten executives surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board on problems of industrial remobilization, it was announced yesterday. Four out of ten opposed renegotiation of wartime contracts and the other six qualified their endorsements, the board said.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Schools in Westchester opened on schedule today for most of the county's 70,000 children of elementary and high school age despite a moderate increase in infantile paralysis cases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 1, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

"The Hollywood Theatre of Stars," a half-hour dramatic offering to be presented five afternoons a week, will be carried in the fall by WOR, starting on Oct. 11. It will be presented at 1:30 P.M., Monday through Fridays, and may prove to be a formidable rival to the soap operas.

Brand name fashions will be offered by Gimbels today in a showing at the store. Among the well-known names to be represented are Henry Rosenfeld, Paul Prescott, Majestic, McKettrick, Bedford Casuals and Tommie Austin.

ATHENS, Sept. 8 -- A subcommittee of the United Nations Special Commission on the Balkans at an open meeting here this morning announced the outcome of its deliberations on the charge that Albania was aiding the current rebellion against Greece.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- A strong rebuttal of charges made yesterday by delegates of Russia's satellites that the United States had imperialist aims of which the Marshall Plan was an instrument, was delivered by United States Senator Alben W. Barkley this afternoon at the thirty-seventh conference of the Interparliamentary Union.
New York will formally observe the establishment of the Republic of Israel next Wednesday as part of the celebration of the city's Golden Anniversary, it was announced yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 8 -- A public referendum on a $50,000,000 state bond issue to finance new buildings for Rutgers University, welfare institutions and teachers' colleges was authorized tonight at the close of the summer session of the New Jersey Legislature.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 -- Orlando Maroglio, president of the Central Bank, who shares with Miguel Miranda the management of Argentina's controlled economy, will leave by plane for Miami Monday, accompanied by several experts of the bank's staff.

For the next fortnight the City Center will be playing host to an excellent revival of "Show Boat" and this ought to compensate for any imperfections that may exist elsewhere in Cosmopolis at the moment. For "Show Boat" is one of the immortal works of the musical stage, deserving as much respect as Gilbert and Sullivan and considerably more affection.

Thirty oil companies had a combined net income last year of $1,219,000,000, which was $456,000,000, or 60 per cent more than in 1946, according to a compilation made by Joseph E. Pogue, vice president of the Chase National Bank, and his staff associate, Frederick G. Coqueron.

Your editorial rightly criticized as "callous" the proposal made by the United States, British, Netherlands and Brazilian delegates to the U. N. Economic and Social Council that all "unaccompanied children" under sixteen years of age be returned to their countries of origin.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Pirates exploded for four runs in the eighth inning tonight to defeat the Reds by 5 -- 1 and strengthen their second-place position in the National League pennant race. Tiny Bonham set the Reds down on four hits for his fifth victory against nine defeats.

Hattie Carnegie's collection is above all one of distinction. A consistent fashion philosophy prevailed throughout yesterday afternoon's showing. The clothes were designed for simplicity and elegance. The fabrics were beautiful, the colors delicately muted.

John M. Franklin, president of the United States Lines, declared here yesterday that he believed the passenger ship of the future would carry a minimum of cargo. He was interviewed aboard the United States liner America, on which he returned after a five-week trip to Europe.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Leaders of American tennis, gathered today for the international club matches at the Rockaway Hunting Club, came to the defense of the members of the Australian Davis Cup team who have been under heavy fire at home following their 5-0 defeat by the United States in the challenge round at Forest Hills.

Charged with hiring an automobile, selling it for $2,100 and then stealing it and returning it to the rental agency, William G. Stone, 25-year-old longshoreman of 38 Rivington Street was held yesterday in $5,000 bail by Magistrate William Klapp in Bronx Magistrate's Court for a hearing on a grand larceny charge next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- This country hopes to recognize Israel as a full-fledged nation within the next few weeks, Secretary of State Marshall said today. He explained at a news conference that the ultimate decision would lie with the White House, but he left no doubt that full diplomatic status would be granted to the new Government of Israel soon after an October election is held in that country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board, in another move to check "inflationary expansion" of bank credit, today ordered reserve requirements of its member banks increased about $1,900,000,000.

The convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers voted yesterday to condemn James B. Carey, national secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and former president of the electrical union, for testifying before a Congressional committee last week that the union operated as a "Communist front" on many issues.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The National Hockey League announced today a 180-game schedule for the 1948-49 season, with the Chicago Black Hawks raising the lid against the Red Wings at Detroit Oct. 13 in the earliest opening game on record.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company announced yesterday plans for increasing its capital funds by $86,000,000. The company, one of the nation's three leading manufacturers of tobacco products, proposes to issue an additional $26,000,000 of preferred stock, previously authorized by stockholders, and $60,000,000 in twenty-five year debentures subject to a sinking fund.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Spokesmen for manufacturers groups swore before a House Labor Subcommittee today that a Communist-dominated union had established such a complete "dictatorship" over the country's fur industry that it threatened ruin to that business.

A small hand vacuum cleaner that can be converted into a midget upright model and a new device to pick up hard-to-remove threads and similar surface litter on rugs were among vacuum cleaner developments announced yesterday by two companies.
Dwight Griswold, chief of the American Mission for Aid to Greece, declared here yesterday that Greece had been saved from Communist domination through the efforts of the United States.

WEDGEPORT, Nova Scotia, Sept. 8 -- This small fishing village, the acknowledged mecca for anglers whose primary interest is the taking of giant tuna, today threatened to banish the jinx which always has haunted big-game fishing contests and insured that the fifth international tuna cup match would be the most successful ever held.

A virtual unofficial embargo by many American foreign traders here of exports to Argentina was indicated yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Pennsylvania Hotel. The stoppage of shipments has followed the request of that country for credit terms of one year or more when payment in dollars is requested.

Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., the defending titleholder in the women's singles, will play the opening match tomorrow as the combined men's and women's National tennis championships start at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

A fashion writer reviewing a series of collections such as those taking place now in New York, when the city's topflight couture designers are exhibiting their best efforts of the season, perforce selects the most dramatic thing in each to write about.
"Luxury Liner," a musical romance in Technicolor, produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and featuring Jane Powell, George Brent, Lauritz Melchior and Frances Gifford, will open this morning at the Capitol.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- Henri Queuille, veteran Radical who has probably served in more ministries than any other member of the National Assembly, was today charged with the task of forming a French Cabinet. After having consulted throughout the day in an atmosphere that hourly became more and more somber, M. Queuille reported that he would make a report to President Vincent Auriol by noon tomorrow.
EDMONTON, Alberta, Sept. 8 -- Three members of the United States Air Forces were killed last night when their parachutes failed to open after they bailed out of a stricken C-47 transport plane.

Clarence S. Jackson, head of the Canadian affiliate of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, who was taken into custody by immigration authorities upon his arrival here Tuesday, lost a court battle yesterday to obtain his release from Ellis Island to attend the union convention at Manhattan Center.

Lively bidding yesterday for a relatively small issue of equipment trust certificates of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway was the market's first pricing job on a substantial succession of railroad equipment borrowings slated for this month.

The Triboro Coach Corporation and Local 1175, Amalgamated Association of Street Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes, AFL, agreed yesterday to mark time in their dispute over wages and working conditions of company employes until the Public Service Commission acts on the company's pending application for an increased fare.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 -- There is great danger that the vital work of building up and extending the body of pure science will not be done satisfactorily unless there is an independent national science foundation to supplement present scientific programs, Prof. Linius Pauling, president-elect of the American Chemical Society, asserted here today.

In a radio broadcast delivered yesterday from City Hall in the presence of seventy-five top ranking officers of the Police Department, Mayor O'Dwyer declared that he would not tolerate in New York the type of interference with free speech encountered by Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, on his recent campaign tour.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Establishing a course record of 66, Clarence Doser, 39-year-old Rochester-born professional of the Scarsdale Golf Club, gained the lead by one stroke in the opening round of the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship over the Cold Spring Country Club today.
Original French models shared honors yesterday with a collection of this season's high fashion small fur pieces in Russeks showing at Chatham Walk.

Governor Stassen, in his reply to Mr. Truman's Labor Day speech, not only confined himself to a few carefully selected facts, but stated them clearly and with a minimum of exaggeration. Altogether, although his talk did not contain a great deal that was new, it was a thoughtful and dignified performance.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Pravda, the official newspaper of the Communist party, charged today that Marshal Tito had joined the imperialists and was waging a terrorist campaign of "repressions, mass arrests and murders" against a majority of the Yugoslav party.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Lottie Wolf's favored Floral Trail captured today's feature at Narraganset Park by two lengths over the Murlogg Farm's Gee Whizz before a throng of 7,819.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States agreed today to Soviet proposals for a meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers within a week concerning the fate of Italy's pre-war colonies. In London the British Government also announced its agreement to a meeting.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 -- The Bonine- Tripp Labor Law, a subject of controversy in Michigan since its passage last year, was declared null and void today by the State Supreme Court.

W.F. Watkins, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, made public yesterday the names of six additional aliens suspected of advocating the overthrow of the government by force and now facing deportation action.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Cotton prices paid farmers dipped below parity for the first time in three years in August, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 8 -- The International Club of Great Britain defeated the International Club of the United States today in their annual tennis match on the turf courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club, 29 points to 17.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Hope of quick agreement among the four Military Governors on four power currency regime for Berlin almost vanished here today when reports of first weeks negotiations reached London.

The local bank account of Max Stark, alleged New Jersey gambler and head of a check-cashing concern that deposited $7,500,000 in checks in eighteen months, is being scanned by the rackets bureau of the New York County District Attorney, a spokesman revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A bumper 15,219,000-bale cotton crop, valued at about $2,785,000,000 at current prices at the farm, was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture. Such a dollar return would be the biggest on record -- half a billion dollars more than last year.

C.B. Baldwin, Progressive party campaign manager, predicted yesterday that 70,000 New Yorkers would pay to get into the Yankee Stadium tonight to hear Henry A. Wallace officially open his New York State campaign for the Presidency. Mr. Baldwin said the crowd would form the largest paid-entrance political rally in American history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A drop of one-fourth in the number of divorces in this country in 1947, as compared with the year before, was reported today by the National Office of Vital Statistics. Last year's total was estimated at 471,000, against 610,000 in 1946, an all-time high.

Endorsement of a plan to establish a single corporation, financed and staffed by the domestic scrap metal trade, to purchase in Germany scrap metal needed for American steel mills and foundries was given yesterday in Washington by scrap dealers from all sections of the country at a special meeting called by the Department of Commerce.

The dizzy merry-go-round of French politics, whirling along at rising speed, has unseated another Cabinet, and France is again without a Government at a time when the governmental weakness of France becomes, as in 1938, the weakness of the whole Western World in the struggle against totalitarian aggression.

An unusual instance of unpaid devotion to a sentimental but laborious task was related yesterday at Hart Island, scene of the City Cemetery, which is generally thought of as potter's field. On a high point, inmates of the penitentiary, which shares the island, are building a tall white monument to the city's unbefriended dead.

I would like to correct an impression I feel might prevail because of an Associated Press report of Aug. 31, which appeared in THE TIMES the day following, in relation to the public hearing held here by the Department of the Army, Corps of Engineers, New York District, on that date.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Johnny Schmitz limited the Cardinals to two hits as the Cubs beat the Red-birds by 4 to 2 before 10,546 fans tonight. It was the Cardinals' fourth consecutive loss and further darkened what pennant hopes St. Louis had left.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 8 (UP) -- The United States team of track and field stars which recently toured Scandinavian countries was hailed by the Swedish press today as "the ideal athletic team."

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- In the view of the British Government the dismantling of German industrial plants for delivery to the Allied powers as reparations should be continued and completed as soon as possible.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The Moscow radio announced tonight that the Soviet Government had suggested Friday as the date for a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris to consider disposing of Italy's former colonies in Africa.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Jerry Kerschner, who sacrificed his excellent chances of gaining Olympic swimming glory in favor of turning professional on his discharge from the Navy two years ago, scored his first important success in open competition today by winning the first prize of $1,500 in the $6,000 Lake George marathon swim.
MADRAS, India, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Moslem Nizam of Hyderabad has rejected as "out of the question'' the sending of Indian troops into his predominantly Hindu state.

Vaudeville, or what is left of the once popular institution, will essay a stand on Broadway this evening when Ken Robey and Stan Zucker present Morey Amsterdam's "Hilarities" at the Adelphi Theatre. Heading the cast of the entertainment, besides Mr. Amsterdam, who is starred, are Betty Jane Watson, George Tapps, Connie Sawyer, Larry Douglas, Haul and Eva Reyes and Gali Gali.
The resurging Giants appeared to have wrapped up their fifth straight triumph over the Phillies last night at the Polo Grounds when they rallied for two runs and a 4-3 edge in the eighth inning.

HELSINSKI, Finland, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Finnish Communist party congress denounced Marshal Tito today. It declared that Finland must join forces with the "anti-imperialist" camp against the United States and other Western powers.

A capacity crowd filled the 18,000-seat Madison Square Garden last night for the fourteenth annual Harvest Moon Ball, the amateur dancing competition sponsored by The News Welfare Association, to watch forty-one couples compete for prizes.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of the Piping Rock Club, who relinquished the title a year ago to Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, took a seven-stroke lead in the opening round of the seventeenth Women's Long Island Golf Association medal play championship with a card of 33, 37 -- 70, over the Nassau Country Club course today.
The Louisville Gas Electric Co. (Kentucky) declared yesterday a 40-cent dividend payable to common stockholders on Oct. 15. Previously shareholders received 37 1/2 cents quarterly.

Representatives of all large unions of telephone workers will meet tomorrow in Washington to plan their strategy in the event that the strike called for Sept. 17 against the Western Electric Company develops into a general shutdown of telephone service.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Jersey City's Little Giants closed their home season tonight by blowing an early lead and losing to Newark's Bears, 7 to 5, at Roosevelt Stadium.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 -- Highway safety was emphasized today as an outstanding factor in automotive development by Charles F. Kettering, research consultant and director of General Motors Corporation, at the conference of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators here.

The upholstered sectional pieces, sofas and chairs that the Mansfield Furniture Company, 203 East Eighteenth Street, introduced yesterday were designed for those who like to sink deep into thick cushions for lounging comfort. The down cushions in most of the pieces are supported by gracefully curved, firmly bolstered frames that help to minimize their thickness.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Cash corn advanced today 5 to 10 cents a bushel and September corn was up 4 3/8 cents at one time on the Board of Trade. Although September receded sharply from the top, it finished with a net gain of 1 cent.

TOKYO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur struck hard at his Soviet critics today accusing Russia of increasing its military potential by working Japanese war prisoners under "conditions approaching slave labor."

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 8 -- The Fatherland Front will celebrate tomorrow the fourth anniversary of the insurrection of Sept. 9, 1944, which marks the liberation of Bulgaria in the calendar of the present regime.

Dr. W. E. B. DuBois, writer and research director for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, accused the association yesterday of abandoning efforts to ease the world plight of the Negro peoples to serve the interests of President Truman's Administration.

Taking a cue from its customers, Swift Co. has prepared a folder of recipes that use its diced "junior" meats in dishes with appeal for adults. These products, five in number, are canned in five-ounce containers; they are ideal for the cuisine of the one or two-person household so common in large cities.
Lack of transportation was reported yesterday to be creating serious newsprint supply problems for newspaper publishers here and elsewhere in the nation.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Sept. 8 -- Count Bernadotte today encountered growing Arab determination not to continue discussions on the continuation of the truce and the eventual settlement of the Palestine problem unless Arab refugees, numbering about 360,000, were returned to their homes.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Under a guard of 500 steel-helmeted policemen marshaled from all parts of the city, the lumber schooner Rolando was unloaded by her American Federation of Labor crew today behind a picket line of striking CIO longshoremen.

All the world must view anxiously the disputes between the Indian Union and the Princely State of Hyderabad and between the Union and Pakistan over the former Princely State of Kashmir, which threaten momentarily to flame into open war. That might mean a revival of the tragic communal rioting that followed India's independence and separation into two Dominions last year and that subsided only after the assassination of Gandhi in January.

Using regular insertions in 375 daily newspapers in 232 cities, 160 life insurance companies will begin a joint campaign next Monday to show how typical American families are finding opportunities for progress despite living costs and other problems, it was announced yesterday by the Institute of Life Insurance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission has ordered investigations into rates charged by three natural gas companies -- including the vast Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company -- and two electric power companies in New England.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 8 -- A 20-year-old Army recruit was seized today at the camp here and handed over to an Albany, N.Y. detective after having signed a statement that allegedly implicated him in the slaying last week-end of a New York State employe in a hotel room there.

The Very Rev. Quentin B. Olwell, Superior of the Passionist Order in Hunan, China, who is returning to his missionary duties there after visiting in this country since last November, was the guest of 100 lay and clerical friends and associates at a farewell dinner last night in the Granada Hotel, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Cubs today had 21-year-old Danny Lynch Jr. under contract. Lynch last week was declared a free agent by Baseball Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandler, who removed the 175-pound 6-foot shortstop from the Pirates after ruling that the Bucs violated the bonus clause.
Selective Service headquarters announced last night that 168,651 young men had registered for the peacetime draft through Tuesday. An additional 27,000 were estimated to have enrolled yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 8 -- The National Urban League, which started thirty-eight years ago in New York City with a one-man staff and a budget of $2,500, is now operating in fifty-six principal cities with a total secretariat of 450 persons and an annual expenditure of $1,250,000.

A new and far-reaching agreement that education must be redesigned to teach men to serve one another, rather than merely to provide a means for attaining individual power, evolved yesterday from discussions during the ninth annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion at Columbia University.

If your youngster shouts, "Tiger, tiger!" when he sees a chipmunk in Central Park, don't be dismayed and don't assume a superior attitude, for that is what pictures of tigers may look like to him, a specialist in the child's world of play advised yesterday.

Those who like to analyze trends of public opinion by following closely the various polls conducted nowadays by individuals, periodicals and organizations should not lose sight of the fact that they also have open to them another means of indulging their hobby which, though not regularly classified as a poll, may prove just as valuable as a trend revealer.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Radiant glass heat panels, one of the latest devices for the electrical heating of homes and offices, had its first dealer showing this evening at the newly opened showrooms of the Radiant Glass Heat Systems, Inc., 109 East Post Road.

Those who like to analyze trends of public opinion by following closely the various polls conducted nowadays by individuals, periodicals and organizations should not lose sight of the fact that they also have open to them another means of indulging their hobby which, though not regularly classified as a poll, may prove just as valuable as a trend revealer.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Radiant glass heat panels, one of the latest devices for the electrical heating of homes and offices, had its first dealer showing this evening at the newly opened showrooms of the Radiant Glass Heat Systems, Inc., 109 East Post Road.

Merger of two of New York's oldest furriers, C.G., Gunther's Sons and Jaeckel, Inc., was disclosed yesterday by I.M. Wheeler, president and treasurer of Gunther's. While details of the financing involved were not announced, Mr. Wheeler said the two firms were merged through an exchange of common stock, adding that Gunther's had purchased all of the outstanding shares of Jaeckel.

The breach between the left and right wing factions in the Transport Workers Union moved toward the breaking point yesterday as Michael J. Quill, international president of the union, predicted total victory for his anti-Communist forces at the union's biennial convention starting in Chicago on Dec. 6.

The Gerosa Paladino Holding Corporation has acquired the industrial building and the vacant plot 50 by 100 feet at 447-53 East 147th Street, near Willis Avenue, the Bronx, from Elias A. Steinhorn and others. The purchaser plans to rehabilitate the building, which upon completion will contain over 10,000 square feet of space.

Five employer associations in New York's strike-bound trucking industry filed unfair labor practice charges yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board against Local 807, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- American wool growers, benefiting from a strong demand and short supply of better qualities, have enjoyed an upswing in the prices they are getting on this year's clip.

Liquor sales in the fall will exceed high levels reached in the same period last year, Victor A. Fischel, president of the Seagrams-Distillers Corporation, predicted yesterday at the company's annual sales and advertising meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., yesterday declined 55 points in the spot September in the morning session of trading. The decline was attributed to the issuance of eight transferable notices, the first issued so far this month.

Commuters, representatives of civic groups and Borough President Cornelius A. Hall registered strong complaints yesterday against crowding and curtailed service on the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway. The protests were made at a Public Service Commission hearing before Commissioner George A. Arkwright at 233 Broadway, called to investigate a reduction of service of almost 50 per cent that became effective last Sunday.

The General Assembly of the United Nations will convene in Paris at a critical moment in world affairs. To many observers the unfinished business and the crowding new disputes it has to cope with make the coming session, the first to be held outside the United States, a life-and-death test of the organization.

TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- The central strike policy committee of the Japanese Government railway workers' union today sent orders to its locals throughout the country to end the series of sporadic walkouts. These have been occurring since the Cabinet last month banned strikes and collective bargaining to Government employes at the behest of Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

PRAGUE, Sept. 8 -- The state funeral of Dr. Eduard Benes, long one of the principal figures of democratic Europe, took on the appearance today of a triumph for the armed Communist militia over the opponents, real or imagined, of the present Communist Government in Czechoslovakia.

The fatal shooting of Harold Morris, night manager of the Greystone Hotel, during a holdup there early Tuesday morning, was admitted yesterday by Robert Brown, 20-year-old ex-Marine, dishonorably discharged and on parole from the Elmira Reformatory, Assistant District Attorney William Keating announced after Brown was taken into custody.

Willie Pep, world featherweight champion from Hartford, Conn., and Paddy De Marco of Brooklyn finished training yesterday for their ten-round over-the-weight bout tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- What President Truman did yesterday after returning from his tour of Michigan as a candidate points up one of the less appealing operations of the American political system.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 8 -- Forty-four persons, most of them circus performers, are missing in the Caribbean Sea after their small ship, laden with lions, tigers and other wild animals, overturned and sank in the early morning darkness of Sept. 1.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 -- A strike by 170 protective employes of the Briggs Manufacturing Co. plunged into idleness today more than 50,000 workers in the automotive industry. More may be laid off tomorrow.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Arab Legion offered today to withdraw from the eastern slopes of Mount Zion in Jerusalem if Israeli forces quit the commanding heights.
The number of deaths in New York in the recent heat wave was more than double the normal average, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard reported yesterday.

Paintings by well-known artists will be auctioned at the Wildenstein Galleries on Oct. 27 for the benefit of the United Hospital Fund, which will open its seventieth annual campaign in the fall. The art auction was originated last year by the late Frank Crowninshield and was held at the Knoedler Galleries.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Dr. Stanton, the Canadian pacing champion, has drawn the fifth post position for the $40,000 Nassau two-mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway Friday evening. A field of eleven has been named as starters, with another Canadian standout, Tip Abbe, drawing the pole. The winner's share of the richest purse for aged pacers is $18,000.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 8 -- A call for judges in "these critical days" to "speak frankly and plainly on the great issues coming before them" was voiced tonight to members of the American Bar Association by Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court.

The fatal shooting of Harold Morris, night manager of the Greystone Hotel, during a holdup there early Tuesday morning, was admitted yesterday by Robert Brown, 20-year-old ex-Marine, dishonorably discharged and on parole from the Elmira Reformatory, Assistant District Attorney William Keating announced after Brown was taken into custody.

Willie Pep, world featherweight champion from Hartford, Conn., and Paddy De Marco of Brooklyn finished training yesterday for their ten-round over-the-weight bout tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -The Chicago Bears cut loose with three touchdown passes tonight to defeat the Boston Yanks, 28 -- 14, in an exhibition football game before an overflow crowd of 17,351 at the Hershey Stadium.

Whatever may be the result for Georgia of the gubernatorial primary which Herman Talmadge has won, the cause of racial understanding in the South has suffered a bad defeat. Mr. Talmadge made his whole campaign on the issue of white supremacy and the question of civil rights, which was not really at issue since Governor M. E. Thompson had not supported the Truman program.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 9 -Sixth-round matches in the New York state chess championship were started tonight, with Larry Evans of New York City pacing the field and still undefeated. With first place at stake, he discussed a Nimzowitsch defense adopted by Olaf Ulvestad of Seattle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Truman today proclaimed Oct. 24 as United Nations Day, it being the third anniversary of the date on which the international organization was brought into being. In his proclamation the Chief Executive said the people of the United States are firmly resolved to cooperate with other nations for "peace, freedom and justice."
Long distance telephone calls New Yorkers put through to Boston from now on may travel by radio waves rather than by conventional wires -- but difference no in the transmission will be noticed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -The United States received its first major dividend today from the Marshall Plan investment -- 25,000 tons of high-grade rubber for its stockpile of strategic materials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Sharply lower prices for fresh meats and livestock and poultry more than offset higher prices for most grains and resulted in a decrease of 0.6 per cent in average primary market prices for the week ended on Sept. 4, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP) -A stockholders' suit in United States District Court today asked the court to compel the General Steel Casting Corporation to pay accumulated dividends of $5,859,000 to holders of 100,000 shares of preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 4 were 16 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

The Western Electric Company, faced with the possibility of a strike of 25,000 communication equipment workers in forty-three states next Friday, announced yesterday that it would "short-time" 250 local installation employes this week and possibly a like number next week, because of its inability to move materials as a result of the truck strike.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- A British experimental jet aircraft De Havilland 108 has flown faster than sound, according to a Ministry of Supply announcement tonight. The speed achieved was not disclosed but was believed to have been around 700 miles an hour.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 9 -- Heckling by delegates from other areas all but halted an address today by a Bavarian representative in the Constitutional Assembly here.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- Henri Queuille, Radical, agreed today to try to form a new ministry. He will go before the National Assembly tomorrow afternoon to ask for investiture as Premier. It was granted that he had a fair chance of success.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 -- Heavy explosions late tonight from the Mount Zion sector around the Old Jerusalem walls indicated that a new artillery battle between the Trans-Jordan Arab Legion and the Israeli forces was under way.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 9 -- A group of United States scrap dealers in Germany charged today that the United States and British delay in approving contracts was intolerably retarding the scrap collection and shipping program and endangering it by forcing the undertaking of the work in winter.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 9 -- Opponents of President Truman's civil rights program acclaimed today the sweeping victory of Herman Talmadge in yesterday's gubernatorial campaign, and there was immediate speculation whether he would call for support of the States Rights Presidential ticket.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The numerous new tactical units which the Army will form during the next year with the help of the draft will progress from "paper" strength to large-scale field maneuvers in about one year, according to the activation schedule prepared by the Department of the Army.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 9 -- One of those breezes that sailors wish for and occasionally get sprang up this afternoon for the second session of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fall race series.

With Borough President Rogers' announcement of the impending completion of the West Side Highway and his advertising of bids for the $7,000,000 Battery Park underpass, we can feel that substantial progress is being made in bringing vitally needed traffic relief to southern Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -An increased flow of scrap metal from the junk piles to the steel mills was urged by top Government officials today as essential to American prosperity and European recovery.

Artloom Axminsters Up 3% Artloom Carpet Company, Inc., has increased prices of its Allister axminster carpet line 3 per cent, it was announced yesterday. The company stated that prices of other fabrics are still being studied in the light of recent carpet wool price increases.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- The bullet had to travel only three feet before it penetrated the right side of his chest. The man in a shabby blue suit who had been undaunted by clubs with which the Soviet sector police had beaten him was also unafraid of the revolver that was waved in front of him.

In his second transaction in the area this week, Henry Goelet, operator, has purchased from City Associates, Inc., the eleven-story loft building at 27 to 35 West Twenty-fourth Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas.

Credit expansion last week in the form of business loans in the New York area for the second consecutive period carried this item to the highest level since last year despite the efforts of the Government to discourage further borrowings. Figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for its reporting member banks showed a rise of $27,000,000 to a total of $5,394,000,000 during the week ended Wednesday.

The Association of Comics Magazine Publishers, Inc., announced yesterday that fourteen publishers who have subscribed to its new code of ethics have been notified to submit copies of all their publications immediately for review.

Myriam Ferretti, Italian soprano, made her American debut last night at the Broadway Theatre in a variety-concert scheduled for a three-week run and presented under the auspices of Rene S. Pagani of the New York Center of Lyric Artists, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A world wheat export of 900,000,000 bushels this year, 35,000,000 less than last year, about half of which will be shipped by the United States, was estimated today by the Department of Agriculture.

The family of a convicted slayer awaiting execution in the Sing Sing death house next Thursday has offered a $5,000 reward for information leading to the apprehension of a companion in a fatal hold-up.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A possibility that President Truman might relax his withholding of Government employment records from Congressional investigating committees was predicted widely after an unusual three-hour conference on Capitol Hill today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission announced today it was placing the responsibility for drugged horses back on the trainers. For some time state stewards assumed responsibility for horses after they had entered the "receiving barn" and passed the pre-race saliva test.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 9 -- Weeding out unfit and irresponsible drivers through mandatory re-examination for licenses after three accidents, minor or otherwise, occurring within eighteen months, was urged today by Commissioner Clifford J. Fletcher of the New York Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Truman has put a $15,000,000,000 limit on expenditures for national defense in the fiscal year 1950. This is only about $200,000,000 more than estimates of military costs for the year ending next June.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Stan Musial and Lefty Harry Brecheen put life back into the Cardinals tonight as they defeated the Cubs, 4 to 0, before 11,403 fans. Stan hit four for four, including a triple. He batted in two runs and scored the other two.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's Pirates kept in the running for the National League pennant by beating Cincinnati, 6 to 1, today in a game in which Bucky Walters, new Reds' manager, took himself off the mound after a spell of wildness.

WASHINGTON, Set. 9 -- The Nizam of Hyderabad has unsuccessfully asked President Truman to use his good offices to settle the dispute with India, it was learned today. In effect, President Truman told the Nizam that both sides would have to make such a request, and that this Government had not heard from India on the matter.
MANILA, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Deadly gases from a volcano late tonight imperiled the lives of 15,000 Filipinos marooned on the tiny island of Camiguin.

ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey received his first declared support from organized labor in his campaign for the Presidency today when William L. McFetridge of Chicago, general president of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, announced that the executive board of the union had endorsed the Republican nominee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A prediction that lower food prices were on their way as a result of record farm production this year was made today by officials of three major farm organizations in a joint statement which had for its purpose the defense of the price support system.
