Four editors and publishers from the American Zone of Occupation in Germany, the first of a group of fifteen German newspaper and magazine publishers and editors flying to the United States to study "the functions and techniques of a Democratic press" at the American Press Institute, Columbia University, arrived at La Guardia field yesterday from Frankfort on the Main.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Truman announced today a fifteen-day, 9,500-mile campaign tour beginning next Friday that will carry him to the West Coast and return through at least sixteen states with a total of 225 electoral votes. Major speeches are scheduled at Dexter, Iowa; Denver, Salt Lake City, San Francisco and Los Angeles.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday his belief that the city "should take over at the earliest possible moment every franchised bus company that operates on its streets and run them all in a uniform way."

A record number of 75,000 new pupils is expected to be enrolled in the 1A grades of New York's public elementary schools when the three-day registration period ends this afternoon, it was forecast yesterday.

After a lean summer interlude of scattered shows, local art galleries are resuming activity this week, with a dozen new openings listed. Prominent among them are a group of oils by American "primitives" and folk artists, under the title "The American Family" at the Downtown Gallery, and paintings by faculty members of the Brooklyn Museum Art School at the Norlyst Gallery.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, today reserved his "final judgment" on the merits of immediate development of St. Lawrence River power.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 9 -The Labor Government today won endorsement of its economic stabilization program from the annual convention of the Trades Union Congress, representing nearly 8,000,000 British workers.

A drenching rain, accompanied by thunder and lightning, caused a postponement of the "Yankee Doodle rally" for Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, at the Yankee Stadium from last night to tonight.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 9 -After several years of neglect, the old Customs House here, a landmark from Colonial days and a monument to the time when, a century ago, Sag Harbor was one of the world's great whaling ports, is to be moved and restored, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -Federal Judge F. Dickinson Letts took under advisement today a motion by Otis Co., Cleveland investment bankers, in the latest legal skirmish in the ill-fated Kaiser-Frazer stock deal.

Featuring a sharp increase this year in the shipment of cold-rolled steel sheets, used principally by the automotive industry and manufacturers of other consumers' goods, shipments of all finished steel products in the first seven months of 1948 were more than 1,300,000 tons greater than in the corresponding period of last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Concrete plans for a military "Atlantic Pact" that in event of war would pool the global resources of the United States and Canada with those of Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have made rapid progress here in the last few weeks, it is learned now.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 9 -- In anticipation of an invasion of the independent Princely State of Hyderabad by the Indian Army "to preserve order," Americans and other foreign nationals in Hyderabad will be evacuated this week to Madras, India, by air. Indications are that the invasion may take place in about four days unless the situation improved unexpectedly.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- The trophy that Mr. and Mrs. Theodore G. Law put into competition in 1941 as being symbolic of the Westchester husband-and-wife golf championship today went to Mr. and Mrs. Saul Lantzis of Fenway, who scored a surprising victory at the Westchester Hills course.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the World Trade Corporation, declared yesterday in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer that the corporation would establish "reasonable" rentals for municipal piers if its offer to take over and rehabilitate those facilities is accepted by the city.

Flattering gowns of brocade, satin and lace with low circular necklines were among the custom-made clothes presented yesterday by Harry Collins at his salon, 647 Fifth Avenue. The daytime suits and dresses illustrated the designer's fine workmanship. Many of the wool costumes were trimmed with velvet, others had openwork at the neckline.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Some Americans, accepting critical statements that General Clay makes hot-headed decisions on his own and that his Army staff in Berlin is fumbling, have largely attributed to these supposed circumstances our difficulty with the Soviet authorities in the German capital and its grave implications.

Plagued with a series of engine failures, the Maritime Commission vessel Ernie Pyle, with 595 passengers aboard, has been delayed at Falmouth, England, since Labor Day. A spokesman for the United States Lines, operators of the ship, said yesterday that British immigration restrictions have prevented the transfer of passengers ashore.

"Sundown Beach," which ushered in Broadway's theatrical term of 1948-49 on Tuesday night, is the burgeoning season's first cropper. Tomorrow night the Bessie Breuer play will close down at the Belasco after a limited span of seven performances there.

I read with sympathy the letter by Robert P. Moran protesting the draft of merchant marine veterans, while non-combat veterans of the Army and Navy who never left the territorial United States are exempt.

The people of New York City who were listening on WNYC and the top-ranking officers of the Police Department who were his immediate audience could not mistake Mayor O'Dwyer's sincerity in his talk ordering the most thorough protection of free speech during the political campaign.

Expense items for entertainment purposes by officers of two bus companies seeking interim fare rises were subjected to discussion by Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright at a hearing yesterday at 233 Broadway.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Raymond Hilliard, New York City Commissioner of Welfare and former public aid director for Illinois, today warned that so-called "rich" states like Illinois and New York would pay the cost of "easy money' public aid programs of the nation's so-called "poor" states.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Youth and speed are the twin trademarks of the 1948 New York football Giants, who will be put on display at the Polo Grounds next Tuesday night when they meet the Chicago Bears in the eleventh annual benefit game for The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Eddie Robinson singled in the thirteenth inning tonight to drive in a Cleveland run that beat the Tigers, 3 to 2. For the second night in a row Sam Zoldak earned an extra-inning victory with fine relief hurling for the Indians.

In this era of the lively ball and short fences such as menace a pitcher at the Polo Grounds, the achievement of Rex Barney last night under Coogan's Bluff will long linger in the memory of every one who saw him fashion a superlative no-hitter against the Giants.

The Federal Reserve Board's requirement of higher bank reserves is being translated by municipal credit specialists as meaning at this time an increse of from 1/20th to 1/10th of 1 per cent in the interest cost of new borrowing by prime names.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -A Senate investigator testified today that the Government's export controls were a "farce."

Although the September crop estimate confirmed expectations of a cotton surplus, textile prices held their ground in the primary market, according to Worth Street commission men yesterday. Generally, they said, there is a firm undertone in the market, with an increasing number of sales and numerous inquiries for cotton goods in the mail.

Baruch Zuckerman, president of the American Labor Zionist Organization and member of the World Zionist Executive, said last night that the American General Zionist delegates at the recent meeting of the World Zionist Actions Committee in Tel Aviv, Palestine, were not able to establish the principle of separation between the World Zionist Movement and the State of Israel.

OSCEOLA, Iowa, Sept. 9 -- Representative Clifford R. Hope, chairman of the House Committee on Agriculture, today criticized fellow Republicans who may have blamed the increased cost of food on farm price supports.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has settled the long-brewing dispute within the United Nations high command by abolishing the post of assistant secretary general for the executive office and general coordination, it was announced today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Directors of the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad were told today by President I.B. Tigrett that negotiations are in progress between the G.M. O. and the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroads for sharing of trackage between here and Kansas City, Mo.

Leaders of Local 807-New York's striking teamsters union -announced yesterday that they would revert to the strategy that broke the 1946 trucking tie-up and seek to sign contracts with individual employers.

The combined men's and women's national amateur tennis championships start today at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills with a large foreign representation and a particularly attractive opening program.

ATHENS, Sept. 9 -- One Yugoslav officer and eight soldiers have been killed and three others captured in fighting on Greek territory, War Minister George Stratos told the press tonight. All of them wore Yugoslav uniforms, he said.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -Sound waves from high speed jet planes are producing some unusual symptoms in air crewmen, Dr. Julia F. Herrick of the Mayo Foundation reported today.

BERLIN, Friday, Sept. 10 -Amid a flurry of Russian shots, German youths, part of an antiCommunist throng of more than 250,000, hauled down a Red flag atop the Brandenburg Gate, spiritual center of Berlin, last evening.

Sharply punctuating the battle for control of the Transport Workers Union between right and left wing leadership, threats came yesterday of a strike that would tie up the Third Avenue Transit System's line in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester.

The West Coast, which can be counted upon to enliven almost any summer, has just turned in its copy for 1948. At Omak in the State of Washington, the UP report read, a group of telephone workmen was attempting to run a wire through a sixteen-inch conduit.

Julius Fine, Harry Alpert and Herman Hinderstein, doing business as the Parkcrest Realty Company, purchased the five-story building at 2084-2086 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, containing fifty-two apartments, from the R.R.L. Realty Corporation.

Thirty manufacturers of summer and casual furniture meeting in the Chatham Hotel yesterday formed the first trade association in the field. The first action of the new group, known as the National Association of Summer Furniture Manufacturers, was to authorize an industry-wide simultaneous fall showing of new lines from Oct. 25 through 29 instead of presenting new styles at the over-all furniture markets in January.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Cardinal Spellman will dedicate on Sunday afternoon the $4,200,000 Roman Catholic high school for boys here. The school will be named for Archbishop Aloysius Stepinac, Primate of Yugoslavia, who is now a political prisoner of the Communist Government of that country.
PARIS, Sept. 9 -- The long-delayed division of the dollars that the United States is offering to Europe will be attempted again when the European Council under the Marshall Plan meets tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Making arrangements for both Governors Thomas E. Dewey and Earl Warren to speak here, Herbert Brownell, Jr., Republican campaign manager, said today that the Republican national ticket would carry Illinois by "a handsome majority."

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- September corn fluctuated nervously on the Board of Trade today within a range of about 4 cents a bushel, advancing early only to weaken later and close to 1 cent lower than yesterday. Deferred deliveries of corn were down 1/2 to 5/8 cents. Wheat lost 5/8 cent to 1 3/4 cents.

Up New Haven way yesterday an event of historic importance -- at least to philatelists and one segment of industry in this country -- took place with the first-day sales of a new three-cent stamp to mark the centennial of the American poultry business.

Nathan Sachs, who arrived yesterday at the New York International Airport Idlewild, Queens, after completing a four-week tour of Europe as a member of the La Guardia delegation of the One World Award Committee, asserted that "people everywhere want peace intensely, desperately and passionately."

VALHALLA, N. Y., Sept. 9--Parched rims of rock and mud on the perimeters of New York reservoirs in Westchester and Putnam Counties caused reports today that the water was dangerously low, but watershed engineers said conditions were normal for September and a serious threat to the supply could come only from a continuing drought.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns swept their first double-header of the season today, defeating the Chicago White Sox, 5 to 2 and 4 to 2.

From the perspective of Europe the refusal of an American visitor's visa to Dean Hewlett Johnson of Canterbury on the apparent grounds that he and the National Council for American-Soviet Friendship, who invited him for a lecture tour, are in fact interested in making Americans more friendly to the U.S.S.R. appears as one of the stupidest blunders our Government has yet made.

Colonial Court, a five-story apartment building accommodating fifty-two families, at 208 Centre Avenue, New Rochelle, N.Y., has been sold by Fabian M. Crystal to Robert H. McCullough, operator and banker, who plans to hold the property for investment.

"Everyman Looks Forward," by Lancelot Law Whyte, an analysis of the next twenty years as determined by United States-Soviet relations, will be brought out by Holt on Wednesday. Mr. Whyte is the author of "The Next Development in Man."

This is the first season for some years that American travelers in number have been in Paris, and others beside myself must have been receiving the usual sheaf of postcards which usually show the bookstalls on the Seine. Others besides myself must have been reminded how attractive a feature of Paris this is, and wondered whether a similar feature could not be one of the attractions of our own bookish center, New York.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The Government's take-over price of about 6 ($24) for 1 ($4) ordinary share of Thomas Tilling, Ltd., motor bus interests, announced late yesterday, substantially exceeded the market's estimates and as a result, heavy dealings were seen in all bus shares on the stock market here today.

GENEVA, Sept 9 -- The United States hauled Cuba into court today on charges of nullifying and impairing the tariff concessions on textiles granted by Cuba in last year's multilateral negotiations at Geneva.

True to their motto, "Be Prepared," 125 Girl Scouts representing 37,556 members of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York staged a four-part pageant yesterday at Grand Central Palace, only a week after they had been asked to take part in the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition.

A television version of "Meet the Press," the program on which figures in the news are questioned extemporaneously by reporters, is to be heard regularly at 8:30 P.M. Sundays over the NBC video network, beginning next Sunday. It replaces an audience-participation program entitled "Try and Do It," which did not fare too well at the hands of the critics.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (UP) -The Government today accused three of the world's largest farm machinery manufacturers in price fixing. The Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice filed a civil suit against International Harvester Company, J. I. Case Company, Deere Co., and nine Deere subsidiaries.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 9 -Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of the Piping Rock Club virtually clinched the 1948 medal play championship of the Women's Long Island Golf Association by adding a 73 today to her first-round 70 for 143 and a fourteen-stroke lead with eighteen holes to play at the Nassau Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Truman asserted today that this country would not withdraw from Berlin under Russian provocation and reiterated a determination to continue negotia tions there, ever hopeful for a peaceful settlement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 9 (AP) -- A couple of hundred well-wishers of Yale's gridiron team got together on a field in the shadow of the Bowl late today where they heard Clinton R. (Cupie) Black Jr., tell them that win, lose or draw Coach Herman Hickman was at Yale to stay.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 9 -"Government by crisis" was deplored tonight by Frank E. Holman of Seattle, as he assumed the presidency of the American Bar Association at the annual dinner concluding its seventy-first convention.

Ten of the twelve Communist leaders indicted by a special Federal grand jury on July 20 received permission from Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday to travel throughout the continental limits of the United States while they are free in bail.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 9--Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation and national chairman of United Nations Week, opening on Oct. 17, announced plans today for the formation of a national business and industry committee to help conduct a nation-wide celebration of the event.
WASHINGTON, Sept 9 -- During the week ended Sept. 8, member bank reserve balances increased $93,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- Today's crisis in France, which, in exaggerated form, is symptomatic of Western Europe's post-war malady, is more largely political than it is elsewhere.

The stock market suffered yesterday its second successive setback, with losses exceeding those of Wednesday and the list returning to the lowest mark since mid-August. The new selling reduced quotations 1 to 3 points, put the price index back 1 1/2 points and encompassed every major section of the market.

The executive board of James B. Carey's home local set itself up as a trial board last night and exonerated the national secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations of the charges directed against him Wednesday by the convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

Each of the three new carpeting materials that Edward Fields, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue, introduced yesterday is made of different types of yarns and weaves to serve a different purpose in a home. The star of the group is solid-color carpeting made entirely of synthetic yarns that have a soft luster.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Truman today declined to reply to assertions by Harold Stassen, erstwhile candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, that Mr. Truman had tried to start a class conflict with his Labor Day speeches in Michigan.

Willie Pep and Paddy De Marco will meet in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Their clash, listed for ten rounds, will signalize the return of "big league" boxing to the Eighth Avenue arena, where a succession of ordinary shows was presented on Thursday nights through the summer.
SALTSBURG, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -Olympic champion Bob Mathias 17, has left his decathlon conquests behind him -- and wishes everybody else would, too.
CINCINATI, Sept. 9 -- Scientists of the Institutum Divi Thomae reported here today at their annual conference that they had made progress in the treatment of Cancer, including certain human types.

Apparently, if we were to go on vacation from New York City today and not return until late 1950 or early 1951 we wouldn't recognize Brooklyn Bridge. For the famous old structure is going to have a genuine, thoroughgoing $5,100,000 face-lifting and improvement that will increase its capacity from the present 20,000 a day to 6,000 an hour.

A few fish made better citizens this summer of underprivileged youngsters, whose marine museum at Forest Neighborhood House in the Bronx has proved that for vacation fun live projects are more exciting than books.

Following guarded and obscure references in the press during the last few weeks, THE NEW YORK TIMES published on Sept. 1 an article by James Reston according to which the President appointed a Cabinet subcommittee to study the question of German reparations (of which dismantling is the crux) and Paul G. Hoffman, the Administrator of ECA, is "studying the Cabinet reparations committee's top secret report."

LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Shipbuilders J.B. Woodward Jr., and H. Franklin Harvey Jr. of Newport News, Va., after a quick survey in the United Kingdom believe the British will be shipbuilders to the world for a long time to come.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The American mining industry and the United Mine Workers of America passed a landmark in their long history today when a pension of $100 a month was paid to the first qualified miner by the United Mine Workers of America Welfare and Retirement Fund.

Plans to coordinate units of the Roman Catholic Holy Name Society in English speaking areas throughout the world into an international organization were announced here yesterday by the Very Rev. Harry C. Graham, national director of the society in the United States.

The beauty of fine furs, combined with painstaking workmanship, spoke for itself at Jaeckel's custom showing yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel. The silhouette endorsed was one with a flat back, shoulders slightly padded for proper balance, and fullness stressed at the sides.

A new national newsweekly, National Guardian will make its first appearance during the week of Oct. 17, it was announced yesterday. The magazine, described as an "independent, progressive newsweekly," will be under the editorship of Cedric Belfrage and Jim Aronson.

It is now more than a fortnight since you published the news that the Dean of Canterbury had been denied a visa to enter the United States and the statement of our Department of State that it was not "in the public interest" that he should revisit our glimpses. And THE TIMES has made no editorial comment on this flagrant and foolish violation by our Government of the constitutional right of freedom of speech.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Marshall Plan has saved Western Europe from threatened Communist domination and has helped it attain an industrial output substantially above pre-war levels, according to statements made today by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, and Camille Gutt, managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- Pope Pius XII entrusted a "personal message of good-will and friendship" for President Truman to Senator Alben W. Barkley at an audience today for delegates to the Interparliamentary Union conference here.

PARIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers Association of America, sent a cable today to the New York Board of Rabbis in reply to their protest against the British film, "Oliver Twist," one of his assistants said.

THE way fine women will sacrifice themselves for worthless men is a common spectacle in life and a common theme in fiction. In his new novel, "The Precipice,"* Hugh MacLennan has run it through the wringer again with considerable skill. Mr. MacLennan is the young Canadian who did so much to explain the conflict between Anglo-Canadians and FrenchCanadians in "Two Solitudes," a novel that made him overnight the best-known Canadian writer in this country.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range all day yesterday and closed 2 points lower to 8 points higher.

A new approach to understanding and treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, the most vicious and crippling of joint diseases, through use of a chemical substance, was reported yesterday at the annual convention of the American Occupational Therapy Association in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
The Port of New York Authority confirmed yesterday the lease of space at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to National Airlines, Inc., serving many cities in the South and Cuba.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 9 -- Clarence Doser, Scarsdale Golf Club pro, maintained his lead at the halfway mark of the metropolitan P.G.A. championship over the Cold Spring Country Club course today with a round of 68 to bring his 36-hole aggregate to 134.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 9 -- A five-hour parade today commemorated the fourth anniversary of the Bulgarian insurrection of Sept. 9, 1944, which the present regime celebrates as the liberation from German and Bulgarian Fascist control.

Curtain and uphholstery fabrics once fashionable in mansions around New York and elsewhere are vividly presented in the exhibition of reproduction textiles opening this morning at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Agreeing that existing educational institutions are not preparing students for life in a world of crisis and strife, scholars participating in the ninth annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion at Columbia University called yesterday for the evolution of a "bold and positive" philosophy of contemporary life.

A survey of prices in retail food stores, reported yesterday by the City Department of Markets, shows that no more than normal fluctuations have taken place during the week despite the truck strike. In fact, the strike continues to have but one apparent effect -- that of halting deliveries to at least two major chains. Independents remain well stocked.

A business associate of Max Stark, whose multi-million dollar check cashing concern is under scrutiny by the New York County District Attorney, was held yesterday by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen in $25,000 bail as a material witness.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- A license was obtained today from the Lord Chamberlain to produce "People Like Us," a play by Frank Vosper based on a murder of twenty-six years ago. Percy Thompson, a London shipping clerk, was stabbed to death, while walking in the street, by his wife Edith's paramour.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- What could well be the beginning of the end, so far as the continued reign of the Yankees as champions is concerned, was believed to have been written across the rolling green of the fens today as the Red Sox, to the cheers of 28,002 rabid Boston enthusiasts, again rode roughshod over the Bombers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Mounting tension in the international situation has prompted a new study in aviation circles of the question whether the financially failing certificated air transport companies may not have to be maintained on a straight subsidy basis as a major defense arm.

Hopes that the proposed new Madison Square Garden will become a reality soon were expressed to 1,000 Rotarians by Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, at a luncheon yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -- A motion picture dealing with the Floyd family of Oklahoma, whose most conspicuous member was the bandit killer, "Pretty Boy" Floyd, will be filmed soon by John Shelton, actor-producer, in association with Leo Popkin, as co-producer, according to information Shelton telephoned to his office here today from Ada, Okla.

Since Morey Amsterdam is starred in Morey Amsterdam's "Hilarities," and since Morey Amsterdam has written some of the sketches, there is quite a lot of Morey Amsterdam in the rickety vaudeville show which opened at the Adelphi last evening.

Television has begun to add to the problems of managing low-rent public housing, members of the National Association of Housing Officials said yesterday. The organization's Middle Atlantic section opened a two-day conference in the New Yorker Hotel.

Jane Powell, now seen about town in "A Date With Judy" and "Luxury Liner," is the number one choice in the eighth annual "Stars of Tomorrow" poll conducted by The Motion Picture Herald among the nation's theatre owners. The theatre operators, according to the rules of the sounding device, select potential star players strictly on the basis of their earning power at the box office.

A 19-year-old wife and mother, who was arrested yesterday on complaint of a Fifth Avenue department store, was said to have told authorities that she had obtained $250 worth of merchandise from shops during the last few months through nonexistent charge accounts, according to detectives of the auto and forgery squad.

The Long Island Rail Road promised better on-time service to its passengers yesterday as the result of the construction of several new electrical power sub-stations. New power will speed up forty-nine trains in morning rush hours a total of 107 minutes, David E. Smucker, general manager, announced.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Material commitments for thirty days or less are increasing as deliveries continue to improve, a survey of business conditions at the end of August indicated. The survey, made among members of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago by an association committee, showed 21 per cent of those replying maintained a buying policy of thirty days or less compared with 15 per cent the month before.

United States Mediation and Conciliation Service officials resumed efforts yesterday to bring about a settlement of the contract dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association after a two-week cooling-off period.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The United States notified the Soviet Union today that a meeting of the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers tomorrow to discuss the disposition of Italy's pre-war colonies would be far too soon, and suggested Monday instead.

The market for high-grade bonds declined fractionally yesterday in adverse reaction to the raising of bank reserve requirements by the Federal Reserve System. There was no heavy volume of offerings, either of Treasury obligations or corporate securities, however.

Baltimore County, Md., sold bond issues yesterday totaling $11,700,000 and maturing from 1949 to 1988 to a banking group headed by the National City Bank here, at an interest cost of 2,549 per cent. The winning bid was 100.02 for 5s, 2 1/4s, 2 1/2s and 2 3/4s.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -Negotiations between the CIO Oil Workers Union and six major oil companies continued at an accelerated pace here and in Los Angeles today but produced no bright hopes for an early end to the six-day strike.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -The Air Force increased the number of men permanently assigned to overseas bases by 35,000 during the last year.

TOKYO, Sept. 9 -- Japanese war prisoners still held in Russian territory are being informed by Soviet officials that their homecoming has been delayed because of the failure of the Japanese Government and the United States occupation authorities to provide sufficient shipping, Japanese officials connected with the repatriation program said today.

Crude oil production in the United States last week established a new peak at a daily average of 5,531,450 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was 2,600 barrels more than the daily average of 5,528,850 for the previous week. A year earlier, output averaged 5,173,050 barrels daily.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -Two Congressional witnesses testified today that union "fear" tactics are forcing New York fur workers to contribute money to Henry A. Wallace's Presidential campaign.

The two-day registration for the peacetime draft of the men born in 1926 ended yesterday, with the enrollment of an approximate additional 27,000 reported by Col. Cardler Cobb, New York City Director of Selective Service.
The coffee futures market was mixed yesterday, with the spot September advancing 5 points on the day, according to the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Eleanor Benedict of Hudson River finished with a trio of birdies at 2 -- 4 -- 2 for 41, 38 -- 79 at the Innis Arden Club today to win the weekly one-day event of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association by a stroke over Mrs. John Bartol of Greenwich C.C., who scored 41, 39 -- 80.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 9 -Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale's Glen Erin was a standout performer during the first day of the North Shore horse show on the grounds of the Old Field Club today. The event is being held for the benefit of Mather Memorial Hospital.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 9 -- A flat warning that any Negro who votes for a candidate other than President Truman in the national election this year is "betraying his race" was made tonight by Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, an appointee of Mr. Truman.

Consolidated net earnings of the Electric Auto-Lite Company for the first half of this year amounted to $4,785,773, equal to $3.20 a share, compared with $5,057,865 or $3.38 a share in the first six months of 1947, it was reported yesterday.

A plan for redevelopment of a four-block area on the lower East Side near the Manhattan Civic Center into a shopping center was presented yesterday to Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan and Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, by Joseph Platzker, former Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, on behalf of the East Side Chamber of Commerce.
The cleaning out of Russian consular establishments in his country moved into high gear yesterday.

For a long time it has been argued that all that was necessary to ease international tension was to resume negotiations between Russia and the Western Powers. The way to peace, it has been repeatedly said, lay in a frank discussion of our differences with the Soviet leaders.

A group of nineteen New York City school teachers who recently returned from Puerto Rico feel that their trip will aid them definitely in understanding Puerto Rican children and their problems, it was announced yesterday.

Runner-up in the event a year ago, Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Trough Hill was the winner by half a dozen lengths in the thirtieth Glendale Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Four started; three finished. It was not a polished exhibition of jumping; bobbling was the order of the day.

WEDGEPORT, N.S., Sept. 9 -The International tuna matches finished their second day in fog and occasional showers, but when the scores were added up the United States team was still in the lead, with the British team a close second.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff granted an injunction in Queens Supreme Court yesterday remaining Local 1250 of the Department Store Employes Union, Cross, from picketing the Oppenheim Collins store at 730 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, L. I. The union was not represented at the hearing, and the injunction was granted by default.

EVERYWHERE one goes these days folks are asking the same question. It is: "Have there ever been two pennant races as close and as exciting as the ones this season?" Oddly enough, everyone seems to expect a shake of the head and a violent denial. There are still four weeks of the campaign left and the flag chases might blow wide apart any minute.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The negotiations in Berlin for four-power currency control have reached such an impasse that envoys of the three Western powers in Moscow will be asked to seek another interview with Foreign Minister Molotov in an effort to resolve the difficulties, a report here today said.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 9 -The world's food problem and pressure of increasing population dominated the discussions at the second day's meetings of the British Association for the Advancement of Science here today.

Mayor O'Dwyer met yesterday with a group from the New York City Committee for Servicemen on the subject of the city's plans to provide adequate recreation facilities for visiting members of the armed forces at the World War II canteen, 99 Park Avenue.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 9 -A small-scale respirator, on the "iron lung" principle, may eventually prove practical in treating certain forms of poliomyelitis as the result of a development announced at Yale University today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- When the Clara Dudley workshop opens here at 193 East Post Road on Sept. 20 under the auspices of Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company, there will be no merchandise for sale -- not even rugs.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- An Italian-French customs union came measurably nearer today when Count Carlo Sforza, the Italian Foreign Minister, inaugurated the work of a mixed committee that is to put finishing touches to a plan for merging the Italian and French economies.

Arthur G. McKee Co. yesterday voted a dividend of $1 a share on the class B stock, payable on Oct. 1. Shareholders received 75 cents in July and 50 cents each in April and January and an initial of 50 cents last December.

It is a pleasure to give recognition to a new young designer whose name was announced to the public for the first time yesterday. The designer is Lepole; the occasion of making his authorship of a good collection known, the season's opening of the Salon de Couture, at Bonwit Teller's.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, who has just completed a two-month study of religious conditions in ten European countries, declared today that the "saddest spot in Europe with respect to religious freedom is Spain."

In the forty-second annual report of the Electric Bond and Share Company, released for publication today, Curtis E. Calder and George G. Walker, chairman and president, respectively, told stockholders that earnings would not change appreciably the rest of the year, due largely to the fact that plans for reorganization of the system are still pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

An insistance on the slim silhouette ran throughout the first custom order collection to be presented by Harriette Harra. Seen yesterday at Stein Blaine, this collection also reflected the influences of the Empire and Directoire periods in its sheathlike skirts that rose to high bodices, its cutaway jackets and flaring revers collars.

The one-story taxpayer containing seven stores at 64-64 to 64-76 Dry Harbor Road, Middle Village, Queens, has been purchased by Nathaniel and Yetta Agris from the Najem Enterprises, Inc., for cash above mortgages of $34,000. The property, on an irregular plot about 124 by 126 feet, is assessed at $40,000.

New issues of securities will begin to reappear in the market in volume next week, with state and municipal Governments accounting for most of the borrowing. On Monday, the New York Central Railroad will offer $13,800,000 of equipment trust certificates at competitive bidding, and on Tuesday the Indiana' Michigan Electric Company will take bids on $25,000,000 of bonds.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, whose retirement as commanding officer of the New York National Guard was announced today, urged that the historic American attitude of opposition to centralized power be kept in mind when considering the proposal to federalize the National Guard.

A special dividend of 35 cents together with the quarterly of 25 cents were voted on the common stock of the Central Steel and Wire Company for payment Sept. 30, and a second special dividend of 35 cents and a 25-cent quarterly for payment on Dec. 18.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 10 -- A two-alarm fire swept the coal cribs of the Erie Railroad here today causing damage estimated by a railroad official at $100,000. A fireman and a news photographer were slightly injured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The United States Air Force has proposed the immediate use of about $200,000,000 for sharply expanding the nation's arsenal of jet bombers, fighter planes and other combat weapons of the air, it was announced today.

We judge from recent plans submitted by the Board of Transportation to the Board of Estimate that there will be considerably less stair-climbing in store for weary Queens subway riders as soon as contemplated structural changes in the IRT-BMT Queens Plaza subway station at Long Island City are finished.

The Wallace rally in Yankee Stadium last night was unique in the city's political history. It was a weird combination of the old-fashioned open-air church revival meeting, of chanting and song-fest and of evangelical fervor in mass.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 10 -- Dr. Hornell Hart, Professor of Sociology at Duke University, received tonight the Edward L. Bernays Atomic Energy Award for the best research in the social implications of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Truman will sweep through five North Central States and Pennsylvania immediately after his forthcoming Western campaign trip, and then after a pause will invade the Northeast, with several speeches scheduled in New York State.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Drawing with Charles F. Rehberg in the seventh and semi-final round, Larry Evans of New York City, 16-year-old champion of the Marshall Chess Club, today became assured of the New York State championship.

For the first time in years ice cream will be on the New York public school lunch menus occasionally during the new term starting Monday, and Board of Education officials hope this will help to sweeten for pupils the hard pill that the lunches will be 15 cents, 3 cents higher than last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -An examiner of the Civil Aeronautics Board today recommended more air service for California, Nevada and Oregon.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Mechanical caddies -- jeeps driven by chauffeurs -- were resorted to today by members and guests of the Piping Rock Club as substitutes for the human carriers who went on strike in a demand for increased fees.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Champion Magic of Mardormere, owned and bred by Mrs. George A. Anderson's Mardormere Kennels, captured best of breed honors today in the annual specialty show of the Greyhound Club of America.
PARIS, Saturday, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Marcel Cerdan lost his French middleweight title at midnight last night because of a technicality.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 10 -- Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharial Nehru said today that the Indian Government was convinced that the only means of keeping order in Hyderabad was for Indian troops to be stationed in the independent princely state.

The Order of Solomon, Ethiopia's highest decoration, and a jungle shield, sword and spear -- each of gold -- were presented yesterday afternoon to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, by Ras Imru, Ethiopian Minister to Washington.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, closed its thirteenth annual convention yesterday by adopting a resolution condemning the European Recovery Program as a "big business plan" designed to swell the profits of large corporations and depress the living standards of the American people.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10 -Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow upheld today the constitutionality of New Jersey's public utility anti-strike law under which the state seized the facilities of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company in an effort to promote compulsory arbitration during last year's national telephone strike.

At the forthcoming united Nations General Assembly in Paris the United States will seek to win Russian support for the atomic control plan through the pressure of world public opinion, especially that behind the Iron Curtain.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- Russian fighter planes, stunting in the high sky over Berlin, failed to prevent United States and British cargo planes from establishing today a new record for the airlift of about 5,000 tons in twenty-four hours.

The report of F.E. Myers Bro. Company, manufacturer of pumps and farm equipment, issued yesterday, disclosed a net profit of $1,237,171 after all deductions, equal to $6.18 a share for the nine months ended on July 31.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Any European country that sets up a Fascist government will be barred from aid under the Economic Cooperation Administration as surely as one establishing a Communist government, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administration, said today.
Following is the text of the speech delivered by Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President at the rally in the Yankee Stadium last night:

GLEN COVE, L.I. Sept 10 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of the Piping Rock Club created a new 54-hole record of 220 in regaining the Women's Long Island Golf Association medal play championship at the Nassau Country Club today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- Bryan Foy, former vice president in charge of production at Eagle-Lion, who recently formed his own independent unit at that studio, said today that he would concentrate on the filming of documentary pictures, of which the first to be made will be "Port of New York."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- A New York furrier protested to a House Labor subcommittee today that mass union picketing was becoming "an instrument of insurrection" in the hands of communistic labor leaders.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Harry Luzerne Mitchell, president of the West Penn Power Company and the affiliated West Penn Railways Company, died tonight after an illness of a few days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Reports circulated here tonight said that the Western powers would take up the Berlin issue again in Moscow and, if that failed, they would put the question before the United Nations. Official confirmation was lacking.
PRAGUE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Former President Eduard Benes was buried in a tomb in the garden of his country home at Sezimovo Usti today, with two religious services at the graveside.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Three of four Chicago White Sox pitchers issued 15 bases on balls, three within tying the major league record, as the St. Louis Browns defeated the American League cellar dwellers, 10 -- 7, before 5,603 fans tonight.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- The Pope was said to be suffering today from a slight hoarseness that he caught last Sunday during a speech delivered in the rain in Saint Peter's Square to members of the Young Women's Catholic Action Association.
The police charged a man with assault and robbery last night after he was alleged to have shifted his interest quickly from pecan rolls to the cash register of a candy shop.

NANKING, Sept. 10 -- The Legislative Yuan -- the National Government's Parliament -- rejected tonight a proposal that it give unequivocal approval to the Presidential mandate on currency and economic reform.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 10 -- The "touchy" subject of "purgings" of Communist workers in Government defense departments provoked a row at the closing sessions of the annual Trades Union Congress here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark today approved regulations for alien displaced persons to change their status from temporary to permanent residents of the United States.

Rabbi Nathan Baruch, who has been in Germany for three years directing the activities of Vaad Hatsala, the agency charged with the religious rehabilitation of European Jews, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard a Pan American World Airways plane from Frankfort on the Main.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A trailer truck loaded with iron safes left here for New York late today under orders to run through the crumbling strike lines at all costs.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Traders placed a somewhat bearish construction on the Government's estimates of the corn and oats crop issued today. Both were raised slightly, compared with a month ago.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 -- The Yugoslav Ministry of Foreign Affairs this afternoon handed to the Greek Charge d'Affaires in Belgrade a note demanding the immediate return of wounded and missing Yugoslav soldiers and the bodies of their dead, left behind in Greek territory during a serious border incident.

Numerous offers of terry cloth and seersucker have been made by leading cotton mills, but at prices which are out of line with the former established relationship of price per pound of fabric to raw cotton, Leo C. Safir, president of the Safir Plan, Inc., makers of Rabhor Robes, said yesterday.

Representations are being made to the Government of India by Tibet to obtain dollars for exports of Tibetan wool and other products to the United States instead of payment in rupees, it was disclosed yesterday at a luncheon at the Century Club held in honor of the Tibetan Trade Mission now in this country.

Prices of Treasury bonds eligible for ownership by commercial banks moved downward again yesterday, but among the fully taxable issues the declines were limited to 1/32 or 1/16 point and the volume of offerings was appreciably less than on Thursday.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Three former pilots of the Air Transport Command and a Boston broker were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in connection with the alleged smuggling into this country and subsequent disposition of about $500,000 in American bonds stolen by the Nazis from their Dutch owners.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Six hundred officers and men of the Seventy-seventh Division, Organized Reserve Corps, under the command of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, arrived here late today for a two-day special demonstration of warfare techniques and equipment.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10 -The 1948 election was pictured today, as fateful for organized labor as the state Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee convened here for a two-day session to map its participation in a campaign to return President Truman to the White House.

Next week millions of American youngsters will walk through school doors to take their seats in classrooms. They will not march through these doors in military fashion. They will not wear uniforms. They will walk to school as free and unregimented individuals, from free and unregimented homes.

Advertising in the eight major New York City daily newspapers during the first eight months of 1948 totaled 93,906,787 lines, a gain of 5.33 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were automotive, up 26.64 per cent; retail, 7.8 per cent, and classified, 2.81 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The First Iowa Hydro-Electric Cooperative won a seven-year fight today for permission to build a power plant on the Cedar River near Muscatine, Iowa.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Ralph Graham and his guest, Doug Ford of Bonnie Briar, tied today with Tom Green and Julius Boros of the Fairchild Wheeler Country Club in Connecticut for the medal honors in the annual member-guest tournament of the Plandome Golf Club with 68s.
Two young policemen killed one robber, wounded another and arrested two others in stopping a holdup yesterday morning in a Flushing real estate office.

Rained out yesterday, the Giants and Dodgers will clash in a double-header at the Polo Grounds today, with Larry Jansen and Andy Hansen hurling for the home side against Joe Hatten and either Preacher Roe or Ralph Branca. The curtain-raiser will get under way at 1:30 P.M.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The Austin Motor Company of Birmingham announced today that after secret tests on the Continent to prevent premature disclosure here, its new Model A-90, the Atlantic Sports Tourer priced at $3,975, was ready for the United States market.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Clarence Doser, Scarsdale Golf Club professional, won the Metropolitan P.G.A. title at the Cold Spring Country Club today with a seventy-two-hole score of 279.

HONOLULU, Sept. 10 -- The retail board of the Honolulu Chamber of Commerce met here yesterday with wholesale and retail merchants to work out a plan for keeping this territory supplied with essential commodities during the West Coast maritime strike.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 10 -- President Truman's name was knocked off the Louisiana ballot today and he will be only a write-in candidate in the Nov. 2 general elections.

New York's Motor Vehicle Commissioner struck at one of the fundamentals of the highway safety problem before the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators the other day. Mr. Fletcher advocates a much closer check on the behavior and attitude of the individual driver.

The Swedish American liner Gripsholm sailed for Goeteborg at noon yesterday with two members of the staff of the now-closed Soviet Consulate among her 600 passengers. They were Leonid Fedotov, Consulate secretary, with his wife and daughter, and Capt. Nikolof Morvov.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, former commanding general of United States forces in Korea, will probably discuss American policy in that part of the world with Secretary of State Marshall before the Secretary leaves to attend the United Nations General Assembly in Paris next week, it was disclosed today.

The Soviet demand that new regulations be set up for air traffic which would hamper the Western air supply route into the beleaguered capital of Germany indicates that Moscow has lost hope that time and bad weather will close that sole remaining free avenue to the only Four-Power occupation area.

Approximately 23,000 men born in 1927 registered here yesterday for the draft, it was said at Selective Service headquarters, 516 West Thirty-fourth Street. An equal number in the same age group was expected to register today.

New York's ten-day-old truck tie-up cracked wide open yesterday with individual operators rushing to sign new compromise terms agreed on a few hours earlier by Local 807, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today approval of financing plans for seven subsidiaries of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

Mayor O'Dwyer's last minute intervention brought a postponement of a strike vote last night that would have tied up all bus lines of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation serving more than 2,000,000 riders daily in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Earl Mann, president of the Atlanta Crackers of the Southern Association, announced here today that he had picked Catcher Cliff Dapper, 29, or the Montreal Club, to be the next manager of the Crackers.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Sept. 11 -- Adhering to a program of initiating the formation of the Korean Republic that it has vowed to destroy, the Soviet-sponsored North Korean Communist "National Government" has announced the setting up of a Cabinet.
OTTAWA, Sept. 10 -- Lester B. Pearson, who served as Canadian Ambassador in Washington during 1945-1946, was today appointed Secretary of State for External Affairs in place of Louis St. Laurent.

The failure of the voluntary plan for easing traffic congestion in the garment district serves to give new point and urgency to a recommendation made by a committee of the City Club several years ago. I wrote the report of that committee as its acting chairman.

Martin S. Owens, acting lieutenant of detectives in command of the Fifth Avenue squad and forty-one years on the force, applied yesterday for retirement, it was announced at Police Department Headquarters.

The South Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association plans to open a Bensonhurst branch at 1972 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, where it has purchased a two-story building from Morris Kaplan. Slomka Brothers were the brokers and the attorneys were Daniel McNamara for the buyer and Louis Kaplan for the seller.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 4 totaled 895,279 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,784 cars or 0.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 86,340 cars or 10.7 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 100,796 cars or 12.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Bureau of the Budget made public today excerpts from a memorandum to James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, stating that President Truman has placed a limit of $15,000,000,000 on military expenditures for the fiscal year 1950.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered four motion picture producers today to cease discouraging membership in the International Association of Machinists, and to make up any pay lost by ten employes by reason of discrimination against them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, officially proposed late today to the Waterfront Employers Association that negotiations be resumed looking to settlement of the maritime strike that has paralyzed port activities on this coast for eight days.

Two meetings yesterday with committees representing the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and North Atlantic coast employers were described last night by United States Mediation and Conciliation Service officials as continued exploration of the proposed formula for resolving the overtime-on-overtime problem, so far the principal stumbling block.

Taking an extremely serious view of the current Berlin crisis, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg delivered a warning last night that the United States was united against aggression and to protect its rights everywhere, regardless of political differences at home.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board was asked today to nullify the union shop clause of John L. Lewis' wage contract with the steel industry, on the grounds that it violated the Taft-Hartley law.
Properties in the Harlem area formed the bulk of realty that passed to new control in transactions reported yesterday.

Three cheers and a tiger for the touring United States track team members who asked only taxi fare back to town, "if you can afford it," from a small Swedish sports club for whom they had competed against Swedish track and field stars. They were apparently no less temperate in their requests for expenses from other Swedish clubs, for one Stockholm paper called the Americans "the ideal athletic team."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- This year, as usual, there are several minor party Presidential tickets. Some of them will get on the ballot in only a few states.

The coffee future market yesterday closed unchanged for the spot month and 25 to 26 points lower on the remainder of the active months, according to the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange Inc. The liquidation was from trade houses with producing interests awaiting on the sidelines.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Some nineteen dozen thoroughly soaked sailors and sailorettes sailed and drifted through the third session of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fall race series today.

Declaring that it was "far worse to steal from the dead than the living," General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein sentenced Frederick Lasch, 56-year-old undertaker, to a state prison term yesterday for having conspired in a plot to obtain the $280,000 estate of an elderly spinster.

Jean Anouilh's "Le Voyageur Sans Bagages" is to be the next theatrical venture tackled by the industrious team of Gilbert Miller and Henry Sherek, both of whom arrived from London this week to be on hand for their American presentation of the much anticipated, "Edward, My Son," the Noel Langley -- Robert Morley play, opening at the Martin Beck Theatre on Sept. 29.

Harry A. Cokeley reports that he has just made the fastest sale of the forty-one years he has been in the real estate business in the Bronx. Within four hours after Anna E. Hill listed her home at 1833 Pilgrim Avenue with him for sale, he said, she received a deposit from Michaele Signorile.
WEDGEPORT, N.S., Sept. 10 -- The two fish taken by members of the United States team on the final day of the international tuna matches gave us the winning score and the Alton B. Sharp Trophy.

The immediate need of expanding vocational rehabilitation programs for Europe's displaced Jews to stave off "mass tragedy and complete demoralization" was asserted yesterday by Mrs. Ludwig Kaphan, president of Women's American ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation through Training).

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 10 -- A new British development of an anisotropic permanent magnetic alloy containing columbium, many times more powerful than anything at present existing, was reported today to the British Association for the Advancement of Science by D.A. Oliver.

The French liner De Grasse arrived from English Channel ports at 1 P.M. yesterday with 742 passengers. Among them was Anne Morgan, daughter of the late J. Pierpont Morgan and founder of the American Friends of France, who spent the summer visiting centers established by her organization in France.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger in the last twenty minutes of trading yesterday and closed 12 to 19 points net higher.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Land owners have ordered war graves authorities to evacuate a United States military cemetery near Liege "within eight days," but the Belgian Government announced today that the land would be condemned before the notice expired.

Emergency contributions in the United States to maintain thirteen colleges in China for the last year totaled $1,421,000, according to the annual report of the United Board for Christian Colleges in China, made public yesterday.

Man, restless soul, constantly is striving to make things appear to be what they are not. This is, of course, not unexpected, inasmuch as man often attempts to make himself seem to be what he is not, frequently with indifferent success.

After a full year of "investigation," the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board has quietly dismissed unfair labor practice charges growing out of an inter-union jurisdictional dispute in the construction of the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- Czechoslovakia owes her independence not to Woodrow Wilson or even to Franklin D. Roosevelt but to the Soviet Union, said Czechoslovak Deputy Jaromir Berak at this afternoon's meeting of the Interparliamentary Union Conference.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- A proposal to increase the German bizonal area's share in dollar aid in the current year by $50,000,000 and to improve its trading position by $80,000,000 was submitted today to the European council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

VIENNA, Sept. 10 -- Austria was accused by the Soviet representative at today's meeting of the Allied Council of protecting Nazis and permitting Nazi ideas to creep back into her educational system. American and British occupation authorities were charged with aiding and abetting all this.

Retail trade here this week showed little change, even with one less business day and some unfavorable weather. Department store sales were estimated to be down about 1 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 4 per cent.

Lumber production for the week ended Sept. 4 was 25.8 per cent above the like week last year, which included the holiday, with daily average production up 13.3 per cent. Compared with the preceding week there was a decline of 9.7 per cent. Shipments were up 15.1 per cent compared with a year ago and orders up 20.6 per cent according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade association.

Works by Mozart will hold a prominent place on the programs of the New Friends of Music, which opens its thirteenth season, Sunday, Oct. 31, at 5 P.M., in Town Hall. The other composers to be represented at the sixteen chamber music concerts are Bach, Brahms and Schoenberg.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Chicago Rockets gained their first All-America Football Conference victory of the season when they upset the Baltimore Colts, 21 -- 14, before a crowd of 14,642 tonight at Soldier Field.

GENEVA, Sept. 10 -- About 120,000 eligible persons not now receiving care and maintenance from the International Refugee Organization would seek such aid if funds were available, the organization estimated in a report released today.
BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- With an effort born of despair, Joe DiMaggio swung from the heels today and as a consequence the Yankees are not ready yet to be counted out of the American League flag race.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The white miniature poodle, Champion Snow Boy of Fircot, and the Welsh terrier, Champion Bodie's Temptation, were the main winners today in the specialties of the Interstate Poodle Club and the Welsh Terrier Club of America on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm.

European orders for machinery how being booked by New York companies have started to raise the operating rate of metal-working and equipment manufacturers where, a canvass of plants showed yesterday. The Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, makers of power plant and process equipment, have received their first $500,000 increase in sales from Economic Cooperation Administration sources, according, to Clarence E. Searle, the president.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 10 -- Ten armed Arabs were killed early this morning when a detachment from the Fighters for the Freedom of Israel (Stern Group) "prevented a serious breach of the truce" in an Arab village named Beit Iksa, three miles northwest of Jerusalem, according to a statement apparently passed by the Israeli military censorship.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., -- Sept. 10. -- A C-47 Army plane with a faulty landing gear came in to the Army Air Field here late today after the pilot had circled the field for forty-five minutes to lighten his gasoline load. The plane's seven passengers and three crew members were unhurt, but the two-engined craft was slightly damaged.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- Renewing an oft-broken party truce, the National Assembly tonight voted to invest as Premier Henri Queuille by 351 to 196. This lacked one vote of the total given Andre Marie when he was confirmed as Premier but was twenty-nine votes above that given Robert Schuman.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10 -- The assurance of President Juan D. Peron Wednesday that his voice would not tremble as he ordered all domestic enemies hanged has spread fear and indignation here that have been expressed far from adequately by the mild protests that have been made public so far by the opposition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A post-war record for patents issued was established this week with the listing of 535 inventions in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office. The figure exceeds by ten the previous high set two weeks ago.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- A blond young Englishman with the icy composure of a born fighter pilot quietly narrated today how on Monday he had dived his tailless jet-propelled airplane from 40,000 feet, surpassing the speed of sound and becoming the first man ever to do so in Europe.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept 10 -- The Heckler, an aged chestnut gelding, owned and ridden by Gene Manning of New Rochelle, continued to give an impressive exhibition during the second day of the North Shore Horse Show on the grounds of the Old Field Club today as he bolstered his bid for the jumper championship.

The stock market underwent yesterday another wave of liquidation which carried prices to new low levels for the current decline, but when selling evaporated quotations firmed. Early losses on the Stock Exchange ranged to 2 points but these were reduced generally to fractional decreases by the close of trading, leaving the composite rate down 0.23 point on the day.

Held up by rain, the national amateur tennis championships will start today at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. The same program scheduled for yesterday will be carried out this afternoon. In addition, the veterans' singles will get under way at noon, with J. Gilbert Hall as the defending titleholder.

Some persons pay for mud baths. Jockeys were paid for taking them yesterday at Aqueduct, where the downpour made the track a perfect place for the fashioning of mud pies. Customers stayed away from the proceedings in unprecedented numbers, the turnstile count of 14,179 being the smallest of the Long Island campaign.

Willie Pep beat Paddy De Marco of the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Pep, the Hartford (Conn.) veteran who holds the featherweight championship of the world, had some trouble with his younger rival, but there was no doubt in the mind of anyone except De Marco as to who won.
TRENTON , N.J., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The State Board of Education ordered the John Marshall Law School of Jersey City today to show cause on Nov. 5 why its right to confer degrees should not be revoked.

Station WPIX announces a complete revision of its television schedule, effective tomorrow. The changes were said by Robert L. Coe, manager of the video outlet, to be designed to meet the fall and winter looking and listening habits of television audiences.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- An American-born woman accused of broadcasting a series of "Home, Sweet Home" programs over the German radio to American troops in Europe was indicted for treason today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A former Office of International Trade official testified under oath today that he had approved export licenses for excessive shipments of scarce materials and had on two occasions altered export records.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime chief of the Army's atomic bomb development, indicated today that there well might have been leaks of its secrets to Russia.

Using the radio for the first time to speak directly to New York's 33,000 public school teachers, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, officially opened the 1948-49 academic year yesterday by calling upon his stall to develop in pupils a deepened understanding of the American heritage.

WASHINGTON, Sept 10 (AP) -United Air Lines announced today that it would drop the 10 per cent extra fare on DC-6 flights beginning Tuesday. Fares had been raised generally 10 per cent on major airlines Sept. 1, with all except American retaining the premium for its DC-6 "luxury" service.

The upturn of oil-burner sales during the third quarter of the year has been larger than was expected by the industry, and consequently estimates of sales for the first quarter of 1949 have been substantially increased, W.A. Matheson, an executive of the Oil Heat Institute, a national trade association, said yesterday at his offices here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Possible joint action by all telephone workers' unions for wage increases was discussed today at a meeting of spokesmen for 375,200 telephone employes, but no action was taken.

A touch of fine professional cookery may be introduced into your own kitchen with the sextette of seasonings prepared by Edward Ehrhardt. They are available for $2, plus postage, from Mr. Ehrhardt's company, Chef's Tasty-Flavor Mixtures, 440 Fourth Avenue, New York 16, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Individual incomes for the nation as a whole declined at an annual rate of about $1,000,000,000 in July from the June record high, the Department of Commerce reported today.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 -- The annual maintenance fund drive conducted annually for the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and Hebrew Union College -- Jewish Institute of Religion, will be directed this year by Dr. Samuel S. Hollender, Chicago business leader, it was announced today. The goal is $1,829,000, and is almost double the amount sought last year.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin made a full report to the British cabinet today on the lagging negotiations or a settlement of the Berlin crisis and on the grave incidents in Berlin that have overshadowed the four-power talks and, to some extent, have nullified them.

MANILA, Sept. 10 -- A second mass evacuation of the estimated 25,000 remaining inhabitants on Camiguin Island in the central Philippines was proceeding tonight in response to emergency calls from Government scientists watching the eruption of Hibok volcano.

As the "laboratory model" of a democratic procedure for resolving widely differing personal interests into agreement for common action, participating scholars declared that the Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion, which ended at Columbia University yesterday, had come to several important realizations.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Despite a rain-soaked course and a last-minute caddy strike, Mrs. E.H. Gerry and James Knott of the host club carded a 39, 38 -- 77 today to win the medal at the annual Piping Rock Club mixed-foursome golf tournament from an unusually large field of sixty-six teams.

We like to think of the splendid opportunity given to the people of Sayville, L.I., to set an example of fine citizenship and true Americanism to the youngsters who, beginning about Nov. 1, will start attending the Episcopal Home for Boys in that community. As a small-scale "Boys Town," the institution will be given over to wayward and underprivileged youth under the supervision of the Brothers of St. Joseph.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board set up official yardsticks tonight for figuring out what terms can be granted on automobile installment sales after credit curbs go into effect Sept. 20.

Contemporary designers who have criticized lamps which are merely of vases wired for electricity are introducing a variety of table models they think might be doubly decorative. The new designs are attractive in themselves when their lighting facilities are not in use -- which is, after all, the majority of the time.

The arrest in deportation action of Mrs. Zdena Peach, a former war bride, as she was about to board the Queen Elizabeth on Wednesday, was revealed yesterday by W. Frank Watkins, district director of immigration and naturalization.

The value of developing a "small-town attitude" among big city apartment house dwellers was extolled yesterday by Naudin Oswell, manager of Marcy Houses, a 1,717-apartment project of the New York City Housing Authority. Mr. Oswell addressed members of the National Association of Housing Officials at the closing session of a two-day regional conference in the New Yorker Hotel.
PARIS, Sept. 10 -- Hubert Ripka, former Czechoslovak Minister of Foreign Trade, announced today the formation of a "council of free Czechoslovakia."

President Truman has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the 1948 Worldwide Bible Reading Program planned by the American Bible Society. This was announced here yesterday at the headquarters, 450 Park Avenue. The promotion of the campaign will be assisted by a National Sponsoring Committee of Laymen.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Stan Musial singled to drive in Red Schoendienst with the deciding run with two out in the ninth as the Cardinals gained a 6-5 triumph over the Red tonight before 10,683 fans. It was Musial's 200th hit of the season.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which supplies coins and bills to meet the trade demands in New York, Connecticut and a part of New Jersey, reported yesterday an outward flow of 15,000,000 pennies in the last two weeks.

"North African Prelude: The First 7,000 Years," by Galbraith Welch, has been scheduled for November publication by Morrow. It is a history of Africa from the myth of Antaeus to General Eisenhower reviewing the troops at the end of World War II.

Harry Sacher was dismissed yesterday as general counsel of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL. Action severing him from his $8,500 a year position was taken at a special meeting of the local's executive board.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 11 -- The Soviet news agency Tass said today that Russia "will not object" to a four-power conference Monday in Paris on the fate of Italy's pre-war colonies. The agency's dispatch quoted a Soviet note addressed to the United States.

Brig. Gen. Julius Klein, national commander of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, urged yesterday that the Government afford immediate de jure recognition to Israel. Such action, he said, would take the issue "out of partisan politics and the forthcoming Presidential campaign."

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- Governor Dewey accepted today "with the greatest regret" a request of Lt. Gen. Hugh A. Drum to be transferred, effective Oct. 1, from his post as commanding general of the New York National Guard to the state reserve list. General Drum, will be 69 on Sept. 19.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that the nation's farmers this year will produce the biggest volume of food in history. In return, they may get more dollars than ever before.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- The Chamber of Commerce announced today that capital up to $20,000,000 has been assured for the development of an "Industrial City" within Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall today stressed the importance of the State Department's educational exchanges with foreign countries in welcoming members of the United States Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange as they began a three-day conference on policies and programs involved in the project.

Gustave R. Geiger has been appointed supervisor of quality control of the main plants of SKF Industries, Inc., in Philadelphia. He succeeds Gustave A. Johnson, with the firm for 27 years, who has been named night superintendent of the main plants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Philadelphia captured a twilight-night double-header from Washington tonight, mauling Sid Hudson for seventeen hits and a 9-6 victory in the opener before Phil Marchildon unleashed a three-hit effort to win the second game, 3 -- 0.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Southpaw Gene Bearden hurled a neat six-hitter for his fourteenth triumph today as the Indians rolled to their fourth, straight victory by trouncing the Tigers, 10 -- 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 -- Until an effective atomic energy control plan is established it is best for this country to manufacture as many of the bombs as it can, John M. Hancock of Boston, a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission during 1946, declared here today.
"Thanks for the buggy ride" was no more slang expression yesterday as the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition honored 130 employes who served the city in 1898, year of the borough consolidation.

Speaking at the postponed "Yankee Doodle" rally at Yankee Stadium, Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, declared last night that the significance of his recent campaign through the South lay in the fact that he had been able to hold two dozen completely unsegregated meetings there, not in the violence to which he had been subjected.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 10 -- The press was barred today from the trial of Count Heinrich von Einsiedel, great-grandson of Bismarck, "the Iron Chancellor," who was sentenced to six months imprisonment for possession of a false document implying he had been a victim of fascism when the court felt that he was not.

GENEVA, Sept. 10 -- A committee of four was appointed today by contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to examine United States charges that Cuba had nullified the tariff concessions on textiles agreed at the Geneva tariff conference last year.

New York City's Golden Anniversary Exposition, which opened on Aug. 23, has only a short time to run.
