It is an interesting show, and a generous, yet painless, education in our city government and its many diverse functions. The scope of it cannot be fully appreciated without a visit to Grand Central Palace, where four floors are packed with exhibits.

The American Labor Party professes to be seeking a restoration of the five-cent fare for noble motives -- to relieve the effect of the high costs of living on families of low income -- but the result, if it were successful, would be financial chaos for the city government, drastic curtailment of city services and probably cruel hardships for city employes.

Nothwithstanding his implied blanket damnation of "interfering outsiders," to say nothing of his aspersions upon their patriotism, I would feel remiss indeed if I were to let go unanswered the letter of Claude H. Moore of North Carolina.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 10 -- A nation-wide system of clinics and institutes to provide "a more vigorous program of education for Negro workers" was advocated tonight in an address before the National Urban League by Dr. William H. Gray Jr., president of Florida Agriculture and Mechanical College.

A labor dispute on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company resulted yesterday in a strike call and an announcement of the loss of jobs of two railroad executives who had negotiated an agreement with the dissatisfied employes.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- Drastic Procedures to curb drunken drivers and "jaywalkers" were urged today at the closing session here of the annual conference of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators.

The management of the Rivoli Theatre, now in the midst of a "How I Would Run a Movie Theatre" contest in connection with the theatre's observance of Youth Month, is finding out that young moviegoers have a "surprising awareness of what constitutes good movie theatre operation," according to Montague Salmon, the managing director.
LONDON Sept. 10 -- Much to the surprise of brokers in the stock markets here today, the latest Berlin developments had no adverse effects and a cheerful windup for the week was seen.

TENAFLY, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Playing in a drizzling rain which slowed up the course considerably, Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge registered a 78, only three over women's par, to capture low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association here today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 10 -- After yesterday's repeated violations of Danish territory by Russian military planes some citizens of Copenhagen had a brief scare today when thirty-nine bombers and fighters roared over the city.

No longer can the Berliner be considered a negligible quantity in the Berlin equation. For a long time the population was as much a part of the background of the show as the jagged walls you see behind the crowds in today's news pictures. Berlin was the ghost of a city populated by ghosts.

ANTWERP, Brussels, Sept. 5 -- In a few days the steamship Scaldis, carrying the members of the Piccard-Cosyns expedition, will lift anchor here and set out for its great adventure. For the first time men will try to descend two and one half miles into the depths of the sea.
The Holland-America liner Volendam will make her first appearance here in four years when she arrives from Rotterdam tomorrow morning. The vessel is under the command of Capt. C.N. Kleyn.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The State Banking Department today gave unqualified support to legislation designed to curb abuses in the installment plan system.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Establishment of a press council to act as a self disciplinary body within the newspaper industry was recommended today by a large majority of special delegates from the National Union of Journalists meeting in Manchester.

In Paris -- one week from this Tuesday -- the United Nations General Assembly will meet for its third regular session. At that session -- in the Palais de Chaillot, across the Seine from the Eiffel Tower -- the great powers will renew their bitter "war of words."

THE National Air Races, held in Cleveland annually on the Labor Day week-end, are unquestionably the world's greatest aerial spectacle. They combine military, private and sports flying as well as professional speed racing on a level not approached by any other air show.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 11 -- A Senatorial battle reminiscent of 1938 is taking shape in Iowa between Senator George A. Wilson and former Senator Guy M. Gillette. Mr. Gillette alone among the major office candidates on the Democratic ticket withstood the Republican onslaught which in 1938 recaptured the State House after six years of Democratic rule.

SEPTEMBER is springtime in the greenhouse. There are many jobs to be done. Spring outdoors means seeding and planting and preparing the growing areas. In the greenhouse this month the same kind of work is in order.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 11 -- Some farmers in the Rocky Mountain area will be forced to sell their share of the 1948 bumper wheat crop at a "loss" because of a serious shortage of storage facilities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- More than $50,000,000 of new construction for Chicago's medical center district on the Near West Side will take place in the next five years, Dr. Walter H. Theobald, president of the Medical Center Commission, said this week.

Wall Street is standing today at the threshold of another season carrying the prospect of substantial new-money financing, but what the effect will be on interest rates, on industrial initiative, and on the function of the public securities markets, nobody knows. Even after a year of adjustment to the reappearance of a nearly forgotten economic force -- a buyers' market for bonds -- financiers confess to perplexity at the questions popping up all over.

A SENTIMENTAL visit to the Sutton Theatre the other day to catch the modernized revival of Robert Flaherty's classic document, "Nanook of the North," started our thoughts to buzzing about what might possibly be done to restore to profitable circulation any number of great but moldering silent films.
OSCEOLA, Iowa, Sept. 11 -- The dramatic soil-surgery demonstrations staged throughout the country's breadbasket this summer are providing ample evidence of the great need and value of conservation.

ON the basis of first-day sales and cover-cancellation figures made available by the Postoffice Department in connection with releases of new United States stamps this year, it is possible to estimate that philatelists will pay more than $1,000,000 for stamps at first-day sales before 1948 ends.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- A motion laying upon all states the duty of agreeing on "international control, inspection and supervision" of atomic weapons "with a view to their final abolition" was approved by 305 votes to 5, with 72 abstentions at the final sitting of the Interparliamentary Union Conference this evening.

MR. GANDHI'S autobiographical writings are scattered through half a dozen different volumes and innumerable issues of the various periodicals to which he contributed during a long, indefatigable life. Of this material, "My Experiments With Truth," now published for the time in the United States, is the most important: it illumines with candor all the developing phases of a great spirit.
HONOLULU, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The talent laden Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League rolled to a 42-to-7 victory over the Hawaiian Warriors last night in an exhibition game.

Darius the Great, it is rumored, acceded to the crown because his horse beat a rival's horse in a chariot race. As King he later became the first and probably the greatest breeder of horses of all time.

MY wife's nephew dropped in the other day to regale me with tales of the Army life that he had experienced during a recent tour of duty with the Twenty-sixth Infantry Division at Camp Edwards. They sounded exactly the same as the tales I had told about Fort Bragg in 1941 and the tales I had heard from my uncle about Camp Mills in 1918.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Immediate discontinuance of export controls and allocations on feed grains and protein meals was urged today by Walter C. Berger, president of the American Feed Manufacturers Association, who recently returned from a thirty-day visit to eight European countries where he studied the feed supply situation.

The $55,000,000 program of pier rehabilitation and development drawn by Commissioner of Marine and Aviation Joseph Minetti could be executed more advantageously by the city itself than by the state-chartered World Trade Corporation, according to a report made public yesterday at City Hall.

SEATTLE, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Aeronautical Mechanics Union, an independent, called off its 140-day-old strike against the Boeing Airplane Company last night, but complications hindered return-to-work plans.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- The Soviet Union will "destroy" all those who attempt to create a fourth Reich or restore "institutions of fascism" as the "American Monopolists," are now doing, Col. Serge Ivanovich Tulpanov, one of the most important Russians in Germany, told German Communists tonight.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Billy Goodman, Red Sox first baseman, probably never will get such a peculiar hit as he did today against the Philadelphia Athletics.

CAUX, Switzerland, Sept. 11 -- Dedicated to the proposition that the practical application of brotherhood, understanding and Christian love to everyday life is the only way to save mankind from communism, materialism generally and secularism, nearly 1,200 delegates from thirty-three countries gathered today for the second World Assembly for Moral Rearmament.

Four years ago last week Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York launched his first campaign for the Presidency. He toured the country for eight weeks, making seventeen major speeches. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in his fourth Presidential campaign, spent most of the time in the White House, got started late in September, made only nine speeches.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- A spokesman for the Democratic National Committee today likened the removal of Truman-Barkley electors from the Louisiana general election ballot to Soviet tactics.

ONLY in the most comprehensive histories of the Civil War will one find mention of James J. Andrews' raid on the Western Atlantic Railroad, south of Chattanooga, in the spring of 1862. It receives only two long paragraphs, for example, in Stanley Horn's "The Army of Tennessee," yet had Andrews' desperate adventure been successful it might have greatly shortened the war.

COMPARED with some other immigrants, the Irish who came to America had an easy time of it. They had the language, for one thing. In many cases, they fled oppression or famine or both, and had everything to gain by the move, except perhaps scenery.

One of the most efficient but least publicized wheels in America's huge industrial machine is the Ore and Coal Exchange at Cleveland. Unlike other exchanges, where commodities or securities change hands, at least on paper, nothing changes hands at the Ore and Coal Excllange.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune, Scottish terrier imported by Mrs. John G. Winant some months ago, lived up to his reputation by getting best in show in the fifteenth all-breed event of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- The three Western envoys have asked for a new appointment at the Kremlin to discuss Germany on the instructions of their governments, according to usually well informed Western circles here tonight.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 11 -- American-bred Black Tarquin staged a storming stretch drive today to capture Britain's richest racing prize, the classic St. Leger Stakes, for owner William Woodward of New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Shorts in September corn got no encouragement today out of the forecast by the Department of Agriculture for a record-breaking new corn crop. Instead, they found themselves again buying on a rising market. The September delivery on the Board of Trade advanced a couple of cents a bushel.

Last week's divisional championships for the outboard hydroplanes in five sections of the country were the curtain raiser for the season's ultimate in outboard racing, the national championships, which will be held Saturday and Sunday at Celina, Tenn.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- United Nations observers on the Greek border have confirmed Greek charges that Yugoslav troops operated inside Greece last Wednesday, it was announced today. This was believed to be the first time that United Nations representatives had seen uniformed foreign fighters in Greece.

IF developments of the past week reach their logical conclusion, radio coverage of the November elections will mix the merits of commercial products as expressed by their advertising agencies with the merits of the candidates for public office as expressed at the polls by the voters.

ATLANTIC CITY -- The combi[_nation of early season rains and the cost-of-living spiral that compelled vacationists to hold down spending of heir pocket money served to keep the volume of business at most New Jersey resorts this summer below the 1947 level.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Well removed from their arch tormentors in Boston, the Yankees found far more congenial surroundings as they opened a two-game series with the Senators today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Construction of the United Nations headquarters on Manhattan's East River will start Tuesday with a ground-breaking ceremony at noon, it was announced today.

At last week's Boston meeting of the American Psychological Association, the Thompson Revision of the Murray Thematic Apperception Test was discussed. The revision is designed to leap the hurdle that Negroes face when they try to identify themselves ("empathize" is the technical word) with white persons, especially in areas where there are insuperable racial barriers.
EVEN though it still may be warm enough for a swim, youngsters are returning to school, shop windows are full of tweeds and the theatrical season already is off to a start on Broadway.

HOOD RIVER, Ore., Sept. 11 (UP) -- A Japanese-American war hero was honored today by friends and townspeople in this city where names of Nisei once were stricken from the honor roll in wartime bitterness.

Dr. Bryn J. Hovde, director of the New School for Social Research, said last night on his return from Europe that he was permitted to answer attacks on the United States at the recent World Congress of Intellectuals in Breslau, Poland, only after he had threatened to walk out on the sessions.

In recent experiments conducted by Drs. Vincent J. Schaefer and Bernard Vonnegut, General Electric scientists sowed clouds with dry ice and thus caused snow to fall. Snow crystals were changed by introducing foreign vapors into a cold-chamber snowstorm. Under ordinary conditions, cold-chamber snowstorms usually form hexagonal plates.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- The Boston Braves increased their National League lead to 3 1/2 games tonight by thumping the Philadelphia Phillies twice, 3 -- 1 and 13 -- 2, in a day-night twin bill. Bob Elliott's twentieth homer with two men on was the deciding blow in the day contest.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note of Sept. 10 on the proposed meeting of the Big Four on the Italian colonies, as unofficially translated by the State Department:

INTERNATIONAL agencies traditionally are not supposed to be very practical or effective mechanisms for the attainment of international cooperation. For thirty years their record in the main has been one of jealousies, squabblings, frustrations and failures. They have served chiefly as forums for the airing of national and political differences, and the more the talk the greater the misunderstanding.
CORNING, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- This industrial city opens a week-long centennial celebration tomorrow, a feature of which will be the dedication of a memorial stadium.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- A Federal judge yesterday ruled illegal the "performance fee" that owners of music copyrights have collected from theatres exhibiting movies containing the tunes.

The American Merchant Marine Conference, sponsored by the Propeller Club of the United States, comes at a most critical time in the post-war era of the country's merchant fleet, Arthur M. Tode, honorary president of the organization, declared yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 11 -- Sharp issue was taken with the Supreme Court of the United States today at the opening session of the convention of the National Council of Catholic Women.

AN Englishman named Rudyard Kipling, visiting the American West six decades ago, was struck by the proximity of the wilderness to urban comforts. "You may Bit in a bedizened bar-room furnished with telephone and clicker,'' he wrote, "and yet in half an hour be in the deep woods."

CHICAGO -- More vacationists visited rest and re creaton spots in the Central West this summer than in any post-waryear, but they were less free with their money, so that the gross dollar volume of vacation business wa about the same as in the peak years of! 1946 and 1947.

SCRANTON, Pa. -- Pennsylvania's hard-coal country around Scranton abounds in interest for the tourist, although it draws few of the thousands of visitors who vacation at the Pocono lake and mountain resorts on the fringes of the anthracite region.

THE new season is upon us. It gets under way on Saturday evening when the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo puts the big pot in the little one, as the saying goes, and celebrates its tenth anniversary with a bang-up schedule and roster at the Metropolitan Opera House.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (AP) -The Cleveland Indians took both ends of a double-header from the St. Louis Browns today, 4 -- 1 and 9 -- 1, to run their current victory string to six games. Bob Lemon's six-hitter in the nightcap made him the first twenty-game winner in the majors this season.

Fog up the Hudson was held responsible for the death of hundreds of migrating birds that crashed into the Empire State Building early yesterday morning and plummeted to the street or setbacks of the skyscraper.

Modern public housing meets not only the needs of the ill-housed, but aids a municipality in dealing with the problems of refuse disposal, fire hazards and police protection, James H. England, executive director of the New York City Housing Authority, emphasized in an interview yesterday.

TOKYO, Sept. 11 -- Signs are beginning to appear that Japanese bureaucrats and their American occupation counterparts are gradually being persuaded to relax some of their controls over Japanese economy. The Ministry of Commerce and industry announced Wednesday that it planned to remove on Jan. 1 the controls over fifty of the 250 basic raw and semi-finished materials upon its present allocation list.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and considered by many as the nation's No. 1 banker, is believed to be the most likely choice as the next chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in the event that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey lands in the White House.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 11 -- The Soviet-controlled North Korea radio last night served notice that the Communist dominated "People's Republic," established in North Korea and proclaimed yesterday, "is now the sole legal legislative body of all Korea."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -The current outbreak of poliomyelitis in the United States could turn out to be the country's worst in more than thirty years. Already, more cases of the affliction, popularly called polio or infantile paralysis, have been reported than at the same date in 1946, and 1946 saw the worst epidemic since 1916, when the peak was almost 30,000 cases.

Professor Commager drives home many a good point in his "Should We Outlaw the Communist Party?" It would be interesting to use as corroborating evidence the results of outlawing CPs in other democratic countries.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- What has happened in Berlin during the past seven days reflects with considerable accuracy the general course of the political struggle between communism and democracy in the remainder of Germany. It also mirrors what is happening in many other parts of Western Europe today.

IT is scarcely possible to walk through woods or along open embankments without noticing some odd and lowly plants known as scouring rushes or horsetails. Some species are much at home on sandy railroad banks. Others prefer deep woods or grow in shallow streams.

MOUNT VERNON, Ga., Sept. 11 (AP) -- A Negro, the father of six children, was shot and killed because he had insisted on voting in Georgia's Democratic primary election, Sheriff R.M. McCrimmon reported today.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and Luigi Antonini, first vice president of the union, received last night the award Star of Italian Solidarity from the Italian Government "for the contribution they and their organization have given to the work of reconstruction in Italy."

A WINSOME miss with green eyes and ash-blonde hair named Beatrice Pearson, who not long ago was dressing store windows in Manhattan, is currently in the rather unusual process of making her Hollywood debut as a full-fledged star.

THE British were awful, but the Japanese were worse. And now the British are back, and they're better than the Japanese anyway. That, in short, is the tragic fact implicit in "Red Sun South," Oswald Wynd's novel about the occupation and relief (or reoccupation) of Singapore.

ALPINE, N. J., Sept. 11 -- Three hundred volunteer Boy Scout leaders from New York City's five boroughs attended a demonstration of Scouting activities this afternoon and evening at the Alpine Scout Camp here.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Aneurin Bevan, flamboyant Minister of Health who has long been regarded as the stormy petrel of British politics, was publicly accused today of having "lied" to House of Commons about housing statistics.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 11 -The decision of President Truman and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to bring their Presidential campaigns to Iowa next week is being viewed here as a Republican desire to compliment the farm belt and a forlorn Democratic hope to win away some of the big agricultural states.

Photographs taken under water to reveal the flow pattern of ships constitute a research tool which will help naval architects design more efficient hulls. This research technique, now being used by the Experimental Towing Tank Laboratory of the Stevens Institute of Technology, resembles the "tuft" technique used in wind-tunnel tests of aircraft.

BY PLANTING a selection of little whitish, cinnamon colored or dark brown bulbs this September and October, the gardener can have sheets of color in the garden from earliest March through May next year. Blossoms of several kinds are synonymous with spring.

DURING the last few decades there have been many kinds of studies of political and economic power. Harold Lasswell, author of many books on politics and now on the faculty of the Yale University Law School, in his latest book applies psychoanalytical discoveries to the study of the holders of power and to those who hunger for it.

THIS volume is a collection of speeches, a debate and a pageant, presented in connection with the celebration of the University of Hawaii's fortieth anniversary, March 17 to 25, 1947. The presidents of three leading American universities are among the contributors.

The National Committee of the Progressive party at a meeting in the Commodore Hotel adopted yesterday a resolution charging Presiden Truman with being "hypocritical" in his opposition to the Taft-Hartley Act. It also challenged him "to use his influence as leader of the Democratic party to oppose the re-election of all Democrats in Congress, 106 in the House alone, who voted to override his veto of the act."

REMOVAL of tree stumps from home properties is a problem that has been stumping the experts for a long time. In recent years some tall claims have been made for chemical "disintegrators," but there is no magic formula to avoid the plain, hard work involved.

Retail activity here last week was stimulated by a step-up in sales of seasonal merchandise, school wear, shoes and millinery, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.
HYDERABAD, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- The Hyderabad Government has rejected India's demand to station Indian troops in Secund erabad, official sources stated here today.

MANY a good writer has begun his career with a less impressive novel than this first one by Elizabeth Spencer. Through the submerged antagonism between two families in a small Mississippi town, she reveals a long history of the citizens, their pattern of life and the conflict of their personal and community values.

NANKING, Sept. 11 -- Hollington Tong, a Government spokesman, said today that the Government was reserving comment on the death of the famed Christian general, Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang, until the facts concerning his presence on a Russian ship en route to the Soviet Union at his death in a fire were more fully known.

On Sept. 15 the General Assembly of the United Nations will meet in Paris, and the Korean question is expected to come up for deliberation during October. It is a propitious time for earnest consideration of Korea's case.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Four New England states vote next week -- with a good chance a woman will make political history for this region.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 11 (UP) -- A pretty, willowy brunette will become the "Cinderella bride" next week of Francis Hitchcock, polo-playing scion of one of America's wealthy society families.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11 -Authorization for Austria to purchase quebracho extract here will be followed by price negotiations between Argentina and France and Italy that, if satisfactory, will bring this country considerably more dollars than the Austrian wood deal, it was learned today. Quebracho extract is used for dyeing and medicinal purposes.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- The European Council of the Marshall Plan provisionally adopted today a division of dollar aid and of intra-European aid for the first year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -There was a complete reversal of retail activity in the Twelfth District during the past week. Following the losses of the previous week, marked advances over the same period last year were reported by larger stores in all areas.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Boston's Red Sox moved three games ahead of the rest of the field in the American League flag chase tonight by shading the Philadelphia Athletics, 2 -- 1, behind the slick pitching of Lefty Mel Parnell.

THE J. Arthur Rank Organization, like the man juggling a hot potato but not wanting to drop it, doesn't quite know what to do about "Oliver Twist." The picture, in which Mr. Rank has invested heavily, has become the target here of criticism by the Anti-Defamation League and other groups which claim that the representation of Fagin, patterned after the Cruikshank illustrations in the Dickens story, is manifestly anti-Semitic.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -- The West Coast shipping industry today rejected a proposal, transmitted through Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, that it handle Army cargoes in the West Coast maritime strike.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 11 -- The record of the Eightieth Congress was denounced today by Daniel W. Tracy, president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, as "one of the worst, from the standpoint of all the people."

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 11 --Goose Bay, 4-year-old son of Volomite and her Ladyship, by Abbedale, owned by Saunders Mills of Toledo and driven by Jimmy Cruise, set a world record of 4:17 3/5 while winning the second annual $40,000 two-mile Nassau Pace before 27,913 spectators at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Poplar Byrd was second and Forbes Chief third.

Governor Dewey declared yesterday after a conference with Governor Robert F. Bradford of Massachusetts at the Roosevelt Hotel that closer cooperation between the Federal and state Governments would be a matter of the greatest importance to the next national administration.

THE success of the dome railroad car, first introduced by the Burlington in 1945 and the greatest innovation in rail travel since the introduction of the lightweight, high-speed streamliner, has led to unexpectedly heavy passenger demand for this type of travel and the placement of a large number of orders for new dome coaches.

BRAZIL has honored Uruguay's President Luis Batlle Berres, on his arrival in Brazil this month, with a 1.70-cruzeiros light blue stamp bearing his portrait and with 'Visita do Presidente Berres" inscribed. MANILA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- One United States Army transport was removing 8,000 refugees from the volcano-ravished island of Camiguin tonight and another was en route to help rescue additional thousands.

IF Thomas Edmund Dewey is chosen by the voters this fall as the next President of the United States, the "team" of confidential, trusted advisers with whom he has surrounded himself will rank in importance with the late Franklin D. Roosevelt's "Brain Trust," Herbert Hoover's "Medicine Ball Cabinet" or Andrew Jackson's "Kitchen Cabinet."

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Sept. 11 -- Gov. James H. Duff charged today that the Democratic party for sixteen years had resorted to "hunches and experiments" instead of a study of "the realities" which have made the nation great.

Plans have been completed by merchant factors in New York to increase two-way trade with Benelux countries and Western Germany without intermediate steps by the Economic Control Administration, it was learned here yesterday. Products which will be increased in supply in both Western Europe and the United States as a result of this new formula include textiles, chemicals, steel and some varieties of consumer goods made of metals available in ample supply in Europe.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- Sweeping powers have been granted to the newly established Central Control Commission of the Soviet zone of Germany, which is charged with detecting sabotage directed against the two-year economic plan of the zone, a study of the commission's charter showed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The political reaction in the South confirms opinion of those temperate and enlightened Southerners who believed it would surely follow the current types of agitation for quick and drastic change in the social-economic system below the Mason-Dixon Line. Cumulative concern over the tension in Berlin and the successive steps taken by the Government to tighten credit had a depressing effect on financial markets last week. After one day of rising prices, stocks began sinking to their lowest levels since mid-August and then closed with the widest losses for any week in a month.

A squat, dark-haired man in brown slacks and sports shirt hung a sign on an iron picket fence yesterday reading "Artist Across the Street." Then he adjusted some paintings, crossed the street to a chair placed in the shade of a park tree, and sat down.

A VISUAL report to America upon the speed-up in British industry and the manner in which the Economic Cooperation Administration's aid is being utilized in British economy is due to be released in the United States late next winter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The continued insistence of Henry L. Stimson upon a strong united diplomatic front against Japan during the Far Eastern crisis with Japan in 1931 and 1932 when he was Secretary of State is set forth in two volumes of Foreign Relations of the United States for the year 1932 published by the State Department tonight.

FRITZ HENLE uses the interpretive approach to travel photography in his picture book, "Hawaii" (New York: Hastings House. $5), published last week. Rather than record objectively, in the manner of the conventional traveler-photographer, he tries to get into his pictures something of what he sees, feels and understands about the island and its people.

Bobby Rhawn, utility infielder just recently recalled from Minneapolis, sank a home run into the lower right-field stand at the Polo Grounds yesterday which may prove the blow that sank Brooklyn's hopes for a pennant.

Outdoor playgrounds equipped for shuffleboard, table tennis, basketball and other games will open next Sunday in twelve of the seventeen outdoor swimming pools that close today, the Department of Parks announced, yesterday.
With all hands hopeful the fine weather would hold, thirty-three craft started in the City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight races to Cornfield Lightship and Stratford Shoal Lighthouse yesterday.

BOSTON -- New England's vacation business ran into a buyers' market this year, but the end result for resort operators was about up to their expectations. Resort hotel occupancy was off 5 per cent from a year ago, but receipts were up 3 per cent.

With competition in fashion apparel keener now than at any time in the last decade there is a growing awareness among garment manufacturers about the need for protection against design piracy, it was asserted last week. CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner, who had hit only one grand slam home run in his major league career, banged another in a pinch-hitting role with two out and two strikes on him in the eighth inning today to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 13-12 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

GENEVA, Sept. 11 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization voted unanimously today to withdraw its recommendation that a deadline of Feb. 1, 1948, be established for the admission of refugees to the organization's camps.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- In a last-ditch effort to put the name of Henry Wallace and its state candidates on the Illinois ballot, the Progressive party today asked permission of the State Supreme Court to file a petition for a writ of mandamus to the State Certifying Board.

DAYTON, Ohio., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Air Force said today it set an aerial photographic record by filming a strip of the United States from coast to coast in a single flight. Photographers of the Air Materiel Command at Wright Field shot 325 feet of film, 390 individual photographs, in the Sept. 1 flight from Santa Barbara, Calif., to Mitchel Air Force Base, N.Y.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 11 -- The Department of Agriculture's estimate of the greatest corn crop in history poses a serious storage problem for the Corn Belt farmer. It is so acute that Government officials are warning that it could cause a serious economic loss to agriculture.

The correspondent who signed himself Shigotta Ganai in your letter columns was making a jocular nomen of the common Japanese expression "Shikata ga nai," which is used in situations in which we would say, "It can't be helped," or "What's the use?"

DETROIT, Mich. -- In a country-wide campaign to eliminate careless, irresponsible and dangerous drivers, twenty-three states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have joined to formulate procedures for dealing with this problem.

Warm weather retarded expansion of consumer demand for fall merchandise here last week. Comparison was also affected by the fact that there were five selling days in the week against six last year owing to the shift in Labor Day observance.

WHEN in doubt, ask the policeman. When in trouble, call the police. Both are good rules to follow, especially in a great city like New York. For the job of the man in blue is to guide, advise and protect.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Department of Commerce announced a series of rigid amendments to this country's export regulations today.

MONTY STRATTON, one-legged baseball pitcher, is due to arrive here this week from his home in Greenville, Tex., to toss up a bit of technical advice while Metro makes a motion picture of which he himself is to be the hero.

"FULL FATHOM FIVE" is the Gulf of Mexico come to life, its mysterious glistening quiet, its tempestuous treacherous storms, its fascinating creatures, some fierce, some friendly, who live beneath the waters. It is the story of the life of the Greeks of Tarpon Springs, Fla., a people made strong by loving God and wresting a living from the bottom of the sea.

EXCEPT for the production of "The Glass Menagerie," which was started during your correspondent's vacation and therefore cannot receive first-hand treatment here, no theatrical event of the first importance has happened recently in London.

Substantial sentiment in favor of giving more information in corporate reports about the relation of increased costs of plant and machinery to current income is indicated in the results of a survey by the American Institute of Accountants, released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- New York State, which is favored with superior economic and social advantages, is better equipped than most states to provide the sort of health services that the Federal Security Administration would like to see for the United States as a whole.

A DOZEN openings in the Labor Day week served as prelude to the new season. The range and distribution of accent in the three shows that seem to call for special comment took on familiar, predictable contours. A large group show swinging between matter-of-fact realism and spectacular doomsday vision; the ubiquitous Germanic influence mirrored freshly in a first one-man show; and refinements along nonobjective lines provide typical contrasts of the week.

THE three constants in the life of Charles Baudelaire were, Mr. White finds, his genius, his debts and his love for his mother. This novel begins with the stiff family party given to celebrate the twenty-first birthday of the poet who wrote "The Flowers of Evil" and it ends with the warm, intimate gathering of his literary friends and cronies for his forty-third.

WEDGEPORT, N.S., Sept. 11 -- The tiny fishing village of Wedgeport, unlike many coastal fishing ports that have become concentration centers for anglers during the past ten years, evidences no outward change as a result of its rise to world-wide fame as a sports fishing resort.

The business meeting of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York on Wednesday evening, which will open the fall season of the club's thirty-fourth year, is expected to result in the streamlining of the organization's bylaws and much greater participation in the port's activities, club officials said yesterday.

EARLY announcement of winter cruises gives hope to prospective tourists who recall the tight space, or no space at all, on southern cruises in recent years. Both Cunard White Star and the Holland-America Line have scheduled cruises to the -- West Indies and South America for the winter months. Moore McCormack's Argentina and Brazil will each make a forty-five-day cruise to the Rio de Janeiro Carnival in February.

THE investigation into the killing of Frederick Trivett is hampered by the evasions and downright lies of person who should have known better. This is a situation not at all unusual in fiction or, for that matter, in real life.

Although its words were carefully chosen for the express purpose of curbing any false hopes, the cold announcement that came last week from Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons of the remarkable cures effected by darvisul in mice inoculated with poliomyelitis created a sensation.

WEST POINT, Sept. 11 -- A full tactical training schedule that included demonstrations, discussions of tactics and techniques and firing of new weapons kept the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division, Reserve, busy from sunrise to sunset today at the military academy's training center at Camp Buckner.
SAN FRANCISCO -- A spotty summer vacation season, marked by a tightening of purse strings, has been the lot of Northern California and the Pacific Northwest.

SINCE last season opened with a fine case of dementia praecox entitled "The Magic Touch," it is encouraging to note that the current-season opened with Bessie Breuer's "Sundown Beach." It was a scrambled and elusive drama that closed last night with full public approval.

THE thirteen essays in "Man in the Modern World" have been taken from two older books by Julian Huxley, "Man Stands Alone" and "On Living in a Revolution." Since all of the essays have at least some bearing on man's position in a world that includes many other living things, the book lives up to its title.
Customs officials reported yesterday that they had taken a 46-year-old French Line stewardess and a Swiss-born watchmaker into custody on charges of smuggling watch parts and perfumes.

ON a plane trip from Hawaii to San Francisco Peter Clancy, the red-headed detective, becomes interested in some of his fellow passengers, including John Murdock, who dies of heart failure before the plane reaches its destination.

JUST as it's the poor that gets the blame, it's the small leftist parties that gets the intellectuals. We'd been hearing about how many writers were supporting the Progressive party and Henry Agard Wallace (and there are a flockful) -- fellows like Louis Adamic, Albert Deutsch, Howard Fast, Dashiell Hammett, Lillian Hellman, Ira Hirschmann, F.O. Matthiessen, Frederick L. Schuman, Donald Ogden Stewart, Louis Untermeyer and Mark Van Doren.

The talk of George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State, before the United States Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange pointed to one of the basic differences between a totalitarian state and a democracy. The former denies its citizens, and particularly its younger students, free access to knowledge.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 11 -- The social character, economic fabric and political appearance of the newly-born State of Israel will depend largely on the number and type of the new immigrants entering the country during the coming five years. By that time, if all goes according to plan, the present population of 750,000 should be almost doubled.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Congressional spy investigators said today that an Army expert on atomic energy was "certain" Russian agents stole some wartime atom bomb secrets.

JOAN EVANS, who is 14 years old and attractive, had no serious intention of becoming an actress, much less a screen star, before Samuel Goldwyn suddenly became interested in her a couple of weeks ago as the potential heroine of "Roseanna McCoy."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission has authorized three natural gas companies to build facilities costing more than $66,000,000an Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California. The companies are the El Paso Natural Gas Company, Southern California Gas Company, and Southern Counties Gas Company of California.

Last week, in one of New York's large hospitals, group of young women stood intently watching two men play a game of checkers. The game was played slowly and deliberately, several minutes elapsing sometimes between moves. Checkers had odd shapes -- disks, hexagons, cylinders, cones, and the board had ridges to prevent the players from pushing the checkers rather than picking them up.

NO field commander in World War II faced a greater tactical problem than Brig. Gen. William C. Menninger, Chief Consultant in Neuropsychiatry to the Army, in his battle for the understanding and utilization of psychiatric knowledge.

TO her first book for children Miss Godden brings the same sensitive play of imagination and delicacy of characterization which mark her adult novels. The Plantagenet family of dolls will surely enchant little girls of 6 to 9 for a long time to come.

THERE has been considerable news in the papers of late about the two boxing shows scheduled for next week. The brash and nouveau riche Tournament of Champions organization is flaunting a double attraction before the eager gaze of the cash customers, dangling before their eyes the Zale-Cerdan bout for the middleweight championship and the Lesnevich-Walcott match for heavyweight recognition of sorts.

STREET play is an old story in any big city. Attending a six weeks' Workshop in Human Relations, fifty-five out-of-town students of New York University's School of Education recently learned what children did for recreation in one crowded section of Manhattan. The students -- both men and women, most of them teachers -- made field trips through the area between Fourteenth Street and Twenty-third Street, from Avenue of the Americas to the Hudson River.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 11 points net higher. Trading was resumed for the first time since the summer Saturdayshutdowns. There was a moderate volume of business. Speculative buying increased, and brokers with New Orleans connections were credited with buying close to 15,000 bales of December and March.

Major New York truck operators -- banded together in five employer associations -- closed ranks tightly yesterday and pledged unanimously not to sign contracts with Local 807 on the basis of the striking union's new compromise proposals.

SO many of the oriental rugs in our homes today were bought for such irrelevant motives that it is hard to see a rug itself for the clouds of associations and reminiscences that hover about it. Some rugs may recall the clipper ship voyages of adventurous ancestors. Others may remind us of a later day when only an oriental was considered a good rug or, at least, the thing to have.

Your picture of the National Security Council on Pages 10 and 11 of the Aug. 29 issue illustrates a significant milestone in the development of American government. I doubt whether most citizens recognize the extent to which our beloved nation has succumbed to military domination in the years since the close of World War II.

IN THE present struggle for survival, democracy must rely heavily on the effectiveness of its schools. It needs responsible, clear thinking, self-confident citizens who know how to attack a job and work cooperatively until it is successfully finished. Many critics claim that today's schools do not produce such individuals.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 11 (UP) -- A tropical storm built up rapidly over the Atlantic tonight into a "full-grown" hurricane with highest winds shrieking at 115 miles an hour.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 11 -- Rampart romped to her second consecutive stakes victory of the meeting as she easily accounted for the mile-and-a-quarter Olympic Handicap at the course on Black Horse Pike. Mrs. Helena Haggerty's banner bearer was slightly more than a length in advance of her stable-mate, Petrol Point, who closed gamely to take the place by half a length from Brown Mogul.

THE discovery, as recently as 1934, of the sole extant manuscript of Malory's cyclic work, has proved to be an important literary event. The unprinted copy in the Winchester College Library differs strikingly from Caxton's version.

Continuing where it left off in late June, when it closed the season with a lucrative sale of loot retrieved from the Nazis, the Parke-Bernet Galleries. 30 East Fifty-Seventh Street, will open the 1948-49 season on Tuesday with a series of similar auctions for the International Refugee Organization.

MORE transient vacations and shorter stays at resort hotels were the major trends in New York State's summer. The increase in motorized holidays was evident in crowded highways and the heavy demand for roadside overnight accommodations.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Leon Hale, farm editor of The Houston Post today declined an invitation by Governor Dewey to go to Pawling, N.Y., to discuss farm problems. Answering what he described as the longest telegram he had ever received -- and the first from a Republican -- Mr. Hale wrote this to Governor Dewey:

LOUIS KAUFMAN, the violinist, has made a practice of playing American music on his programs. Where other fiddlers offer the same old chestnuts over and over again, usually as the last group on their programs, Mr. Kaufman has found worthwhile native works to introduce.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Five women and four men representing Israel front-line veterans today placed a wreath on the grave of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

SINING, China, Sept. 3 -- Traveling through northwest China as "yellow fish" in antediluvian trucks over washed-out mountain roadways is an adventure packed with peril, amusement and a thousand trials to the patience. Somehow or other, however, the "yellow fish" always seems to get to his destination -- eventually.

SANTA FE, N.M., Sept. 11 -- Clinton P. Anderson, who resigned as Secretary of Agriculture to run in New Mexico for United States Senator, has at this stage of the campaign a perceptible lead. Most higher-up politicos hold this view. At least some Republicans actively campaigning for Patrick J. Hurley admit, off the record, that their candidate's chances of election are doubtful.

WELLINGTON, N.Z. -- New Zealanders have got their commercial ears hard to the ground listening for the most dreaded of all rumblings--the first tremors of another depression. Having had their morale lifted by the raising of their currency to parity with sterling, they are now fearful of a break between sterling and the dollar.

Favored by idyllic weather and with one of the largest opening-day crowds on record in the stands, the national amateur tennis championships got off to a belated start yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

LONDON, Sept. 11 (AP) --The Moscow radio said tonight that the United States and Britain had made a meeting of the Big Four Foreign Mnisters on the disposition of Italy's pre-war colonies impossible by having refused to send their top men.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sunday, Sept. 12 -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, first Governor General of Pakistan, died of heart failure yesterday at the age of 71.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- A Czechoslovakia-bound shipment labeled "diplomatic mail," but reportedly containing machinery and electrical goods, has been held up by United States Customs officials at New York, it was learned today.
In THE TIMES Magazine of Aug. 29 you show pictures of the prohibition movement in Kansas and state that Kansas, Oklahoma and Mississippi are dry states.

AMONG the millions of GI's who were in Africa, Italy and France there are many who hear a bell ring when the name Cerdan comes up. A stocky Frenchman dances forward, takes one, gives two, and knockout! Monsieur Cerdan of the French Navy gave those GI's who foolishly bet on their own compatriots a very hard time.

TOKYO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Robert Nishiyami, 23, a former Kamikaze pilot, left by plane today to learn the American way of life His four-year odyssey and education will be financed under the will of an American soldier, Robert Johnstone of Dowlington, Pa.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Central Committee of the Communist party imposed drastic changes today on Crocodile, Russian humor magazine.

SUMMER is always a busy time in sports, but the summer of 1948 bristled with more athletic activity than any for an even dozen years. The main reason. That greatest Games, was restored to the calendar after its wartime hibernation.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 11 -- The entries of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., captured two championships, the conformation hunter, with Golden Hill the defending champion, and the young hunter, with Glen Erin, as the annual North Shore horse show closed on the grounds of the Old Field Club today.

HOUGHTON, Mich., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan said today that there was "a lack of appreciation of the peril to our institutions from within by those in control of our destiny."

EVEN before World War I Karel Hasler of Prague had made a name for himself singing his songs of freedom with a guitar. When the Nazis took over Czechoslovakia they threw Hasler into a concentration camp, where, one winter morning in 1942, he was dragged from his bed, "bound on a sawhorse, and left under a cold shower."

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- The persistent disproportion between prices and wages that has prevailed since the liberation has been the underlying factor in French cabinet difficulties and remains the first problem facing the Government now.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- After difficult negotiations with the various parties, Henri Queuille, invested Friday as the new French Premier, presented formally tonight his new Ministry, formed to "save the franc," to President Vincent Auriol.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- Pennsylvania's resorts, jampacked since July, are reporting a decided trend toward fall vacations. Advance reservations have been so heavy, according to the State vacation and Recreation Bureau, that many spots, particularly in the Pocono Mountain area, which usually close soon after Labor Day, have made special preparations for autumn visitors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Air Force reported today that it had come up with a whole batch of new gadgets to make military flying safer and better.

MAISIE WARD, after the singular success of her biography of Chesterton, turns in this book to the early life of John Henry Newman. Nothing could be more natural than that the daughter of Wilfrid Ward (his is still the best biography of Newman after his conversion) should write an interesting and lively study of this remarkable religious genius before that conversion.

THE most esoteric and highly paid branch of radio writing has been vigorously dealt with in this four-part volume written by Art Henley. "Gag-Writing," "Situation Comedy," "Comedy Characterization," and "Comedy Construction" are the sub-titles for the various sections.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Delegates to the conference here of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations unanimously endorsed today the TrumanBarkley ticket. The expected action culminated a two-day session called to chart the state CIO-PAC's part in the 1948 election and placed the state organization formally in line with the policy laid down by the national CIO executive board last Aug. 30.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- Qualified sources expressed the belief today that the Big Four conference on the Italian colonies probably would indulge in shadow boxing until the whole problem was referred to the United Nations General Assembly.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Supporting a pair of southpaws with a dozen hits in each game, the Detroit Tigers defeated the lowly Chicago White Sox twice today, 4 to 1 and 6 to 4. Ted Gray and Stubby Overmire took credit for the victories.

I have read with interest THE TIMES account of the arrival in New York of the "Norse expert," Professor Broensted of Copenhagen, come "to attack the most baffling problem in North American archaeology," the time and whereabouts of the Scandinavians who were on this continent long before Columbus.

EARLY in World War II the German Army gave a clear illustration of what paratroops could accomplish by their masterful use of them in the invasion of Holland. By suddenly seizing and holding objectives far beyond their national borders, the troopers made it possible for an armored column to do in hours and days what the Dutch thought would require weeks. And the Netherlands was quickly overrun.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Sept. 11 (AP) -- A radio message from the master of the Norwegian motor vessel Caribe said today three crewmen and nine passengers had survived the sinking of the circus ship Euzkera.

WE never did like those sharp-pointed filing spindles that some people keep on their desks. They're dangerous, as you shall see. One of them has pierced Nellie Brent's heart, and when Tim Briscoe finds her she is dead.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Dr. Edmund E. Day, president of Cornell University, today urged the strengthening of private educational institutions as a means of preserving the American democratic tradition.
Schoolhouse bells will toll the end of the summer vacation and the beginning of the 1948-49 academic year tomorrow morning for 1,160,500 New York children.

CAPPY, a retired polo pony, was Sam's own. At least Sam had always thought so until the day he was offered $175 for the pony and realized that the money would enable his father to buy the new tractor he needed to keep the farm going.

Dr. Stephen B. L. Penrose, who will take office on Oct. 1 as president of the American University of Beirut and of the International College of Beirut, Lebanon, left yesterday by plane for damascus. He was accompanied by Mrs. Penrose and their children, margaret Dale Jr., 11 years old, Mary Shipman, 7, and Stephen B. L. III, 4.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 11 -- The office of Hyderabad's Agent General in Pakistan tonight quoted the Hyderabad radio as having stated that Indian troops were reported to have entered Hyderabad territory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The State Department in a memorandum delivered to the Soviet Embassy tonight formally announced the readiness of the United States Government to attend the meeting in Paris Monday of representatives of the Big Four on the disposition of the former Italian colonies.

The Chicago Bears football squad, thirty-eight players and six coaches strong, arrived in town yesterday morning from Philadelphia and a few hours later started practice at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island field for its Herald-Tribune Fresh Air Fund charity contest with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds Tuesday evening.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Liberal Party Council, meeting here today, condemned as "completely inconsonant with the principles and practice of British justice" the British Government's decision to bring to trial as war criminals four elderly German generals after three years of captivity.

ONE of the most bustling musicologists of our day, an authority on Latin-American and all contemporary music, now comes up with a divertimento that is, as the author himself says, "a browsing book intended for non-consecutive reading."

HERE, complementing one another nicely, are three books for the record collector, but of extraordinary value to any one interested in music, discophile or not. Of the three, the most impressive is David Hall's mammoth "The Record Book," in which the author has so expanded, revised and brought up to date material and ideas presented in his first "Record Book," published in 1940, that it is virtually a new volume.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Truman's political swing in Michigan rallied his adherents in the ranks of organized labor this week to throw all their forces into the campaign for votes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The American Federation of Labor said today that it was time for "self-respecting" labor organizations to quit the World Federation of Trades Unions.

The grave events that have taken place in Berlin and Paris during the past week have again thrown a revealing light on the dilemma confronting the Western World as a result of the great war. On the one hand we see, in Berlin, the continued application of a new pattern of conquest by a totalitarian Power which has already overrun half of Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The trusty toe of big Ventan Yablonski helped boot the Chicago Cardinals to a 23-9 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles tonight in the eleventh annual Inquirer Charities football game. A crowd of 65,000 watched the ex-Columbia University star placekick three field goals and two points after touchdown.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahus, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, consecrated and blessed two chapels this morning at the $4,200,000 Archbishop Stepinac High School, Westchester's first Roman Catholic students in its first classes on Mon-high school for boys, on Mamaroneck Avenue at Ridgeway here.

For over a generation population experts have been echoing the Malthusian note of alarm. World population is increasing more rapidly than food supply. At last week's meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, Sir Henry Tizard considered the question in his presidential address, and so did Dr. G. Scott Robertson.

IT is hard for me to say in which role John McCormack was at his best -- as husband and father or as artist. To me he was perfect in both. But it is only within the past few months, the first time since his death on Sept. 16, 1945, that I have been able to think about his stature as a musician.

"Probably most of the increased crop yields reported by Japanese farmers after the atomic bombings in Hiroshima and Nagasaki can be attributed to the beneficial effects of burned soil and especially to ash accumulated from organic matter and burned buildings rather than to the effects of radioactivity per se," declares Dr. C. L. W. Swanson, head of the Department of Soils of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station, New Haven.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 11 -- The Hungarian Government declared tonight that rumors of a rapprochement between the Yugoslav Government and the West had been confirmed fully. This allegation was made in a note replying to a protest by Marshal Tito's regime against Hungarian Communist attacks on Belgrade policies.
Your issue of Sept. 5 carries an interesting letter by Prof. Hans Heymann concerning relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

The New Times, internationally-circulated Moscow journal through which the Soviet Foreign Office on frequent occasion makes known its views on foreign policy to Communists abroad, has taken the measure of Henry A. Wallace as the Presidential candidate of the Progressive party.

Despite a three-year loss of time in military service and a consequently higher average age of 24, more than two-thirds of the men who were graduated last June from St. John's College of St. John's University, Brooklyn, will continue their education in preparation for professional careers.

THEATRE party agents who have listed the firm of Rodgers and Hammerstein in their special hate book ever since those worthies barred their productions ("Annie Get Your Gun," "Happy Birthday" and "John Loves Mary") to theatre parties may now add the name of Moss Hart, whose "Light Up the Sky" comes to town soon under the aegis of Joseph M. Hyman and Bernard Hart.

Only a week remains in which the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition at Grand Central Palace can be seen, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's exposition committee, warned yesterday. Open daily from 9 A. M. to midnight, it will close next Sunday night.

Despite pig iron and scrap shortages, many Eastern foundries are operating at 100 per cent of capacity and backlogs are now extending beyond 90 days because of increased buying of castings. C.E. Herington, director of engineering service at Meehanite Metal Corporation, New Rochelle, said yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 11 -- For the combined Yacht Racing Association championship event and another of the regattas of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club fall series, there was a white-tufted cloud breeze today that obligingly settled in just before the start from west-southwest at twelve knots.

Warning against impatience in international diplomacy, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, declared yesterday that "what we need as a nation and as a civilization is patience."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Secretary of State Marshall conferred separately today with Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador, and Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, in circumstances indicating that the Berlin crisis was on the threshold of another sharp turn.

TOKYO, Sept. 11 -- Everything that the occupation has done toward democratizing Japan will be wasted unless the intrenched bureaucracy is cleaned out, Blaine Hoover, chief of headquarters' civil service division, declared today in an interview.

ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- A resolution urging autonomy for the National Guard and expressing opposition to a Federalized reserve was obtained today at the convention of the National Guard and Naval Miliatia Association of New York.

THE fall flower show held in connection with the Mineola Fair will be staged at the Fairgrounds, Mineola, L.I., Tuesday through Saturday. Sponsored by the Queens-Nassau Agricultural Society, it will be in two parts; one to last the first two days of the fair and the other to be seen from Thursday on.

THE Boyce Thompson Institute in Yonkers, in the period covered by this book, has become a world leader in research into fundamental life processes. Probably it is best known for its discovery of a number of growth promoting chemicals. It has contributed greatly to knowledge of the role of light, temperature and moisture in germination, dormancy and growth of seeds and plants.

As the major party candidates for national office square off for the election it is fitting to call attention to the important place occupied in public affairs by the League of Women Voters. Founded in 1920 by Carrie Chapman Catt on the basis of the Woman Suffrage Amendment, the organization steadily has broadened its scope to provide a unique nonpartisan service for all citizens.

GENEVA, Sept. 11 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration has been having growing pains. Its European other-self, the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, has been having more serious difficulties. The OEEC is composed of representatives of the sixteen nations participating in the Marshall Plan, plus delegates from the Allied administrations in the western zones of Germany.

VERY occasionally a new novel comes along whose author so obviously knows exactly what he is doing and who does it with such skill and intelligence that the reader can enter into its enjoyment with the thankful relaxation of absolute confidence. Such a novel is Robert M. Coates' "Wisteria Cottage."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Pinch batter Danny Litwhiler's two-run double in the seventh gave the Cincinnati Reds a 3-2 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight before a crowd of 15,577. A threatened Cardinal uprising in the ninth collapsed when Stan Musial and Enos Slaughter were run down and tagged out by Ray Lamanno on Don Lang's grounder in an unusual double play.

A group of agriculturists, sent here by the Government of Tunisia, will leave New York soon for Hardin, Mont., where its members will make an intensive study of methods used in the production of wheat on the 43,000-acre farm of Thomas D. Campbell.

THE recent difficulties of the Metropolitan Opera have thrown into high relief once more the recurrent problem of art and money. In the best of all possible worlds art would pursue its lofty paths without any concern for such mundane things as budgets, payrolls and the other items that trouble the wakeful hours of the business manager.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- In the first case of its kind the Princely State of Hyderabad sent an appeal to the United Nations today for permission to carry the State's dispute with India to the International Court of Justice.

WASHINGTON -- The Mid-south vacation belt, which stretches from the nation's Capital southeast along the Atlantic and southwest into the Appalachians, reports a spotty sea son, in general under last year's. Raw weather slowed up the beach resorts early in the summer; an infantile paralysis epidemic hurt most of the mountain areas later on.

Foremanship in industry in the Soviet Union is characterized by "a complete lack of training in human relations," the Labor Relations Institute a private industrial advisory vice concluded yesterday from a research study of Soviet industrial supervisory techniques.

Reviewers exposed to his best-selling first novel, "The History of Rome Hanks," a few years back, were visibly impressed and, fumbling around for comparisons, came up with such names as Wolfe and Faulkner, even Proust.

HUSBAND-and-wife teams seem to offer a winning combination these days for timely books to guide prospective buyers, builders and remodelers of houses. The practical viewpoint of the experienced housewife may serve to supplement and temper the ideas of an architect in planning space for modern living.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Congress of World Government Federalist Movements adopted a "Luxembourg Declaration" today, holding that government on a world level alone could avert catastrophe and establish peace.

An "extraordinarily poor public relations job" has been done by the Economic Cooperation Administration in supplying essential trade information, according to James B. Herzog, president of Stern, Morgenthau Co., Inc., exporters of this city. He charged yesterday this is one of the important reasons why thus far the average American exporter "has profited little from ECA operations."

Hers is a text on mechanics; the force is dollars; the body acted upon is the generation from nursery school to Ph.D.

Probably without exception the most uneconomic and destructive tax upon earnings of business organizations was the undistributed profits tax of 1936 and 1937. This levy was imposed frequently whether or not a surplus existed and with little or no consideration for the solvency of the corporation. The trail of litigated oases under this principle is still in evidence by occasional court decisions.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- A reconvened session of the eightieth annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Central New York would be held at Trinity Church here on Wednesday to elect a Suffragan Bishop, the Right Rev. Malcolm E. Peabody, Diocesan Bishop, announced today.

THE American National Theatre and Academy, including board, corporate members and staff, have eagerly examined every manifestation of the theatre, every trend -- in fact, one might almost say every individual move -- to determine where expansion will come or where, with attentive care and encouragement, expansion can be achieved.

HERE is a survey and synthesis of the history of building in America, which relates architects, builders and theorists and their work to the whole current of American life. From almost every viewpoint it is an admirable book, original, provocative, full of familiar facts appraised from new angles, and unfamiliar information of great practical importance.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 140,012, against 130,985 a year ago, an increase of 6.9 per cent and for 1948 to date totaled 4,617,437, compared with 4,950,621 last year, a decrease of 6.7 per cent.

PARIS, Sept 11 -- Garry Davis, who renounced his United States citizenship at the Consulate here on May 25 to become a citizen of the world, will take refuge tomorrow in United Nations territory at the Palais de Chaillot, he said today, after being told by French authorities he could no longer remain in France.
ATLANTA, Sept. 11 -- States Rights Democrats today jubilantly claimed forty-five electoral votes from six states and, in addition, had a place on the general election ballot of four others.

AS traditionally Southern as corn pone and fried chicken. the lovely crepe myrtle thrives here in the North, too, where it is now in flower. Widely planted from Philadelphia southward, its delicate, crimped "crepe paper" blossoms flaunt themselves on the landscape.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- Titoism or the Titoite heresy, as it is likely to be known in future dictionaries of dialectical materialism, is spreading. It has caused a slight crisis in Poland -- slight as compared with the one in South Slavdom. Murmurs have been heard in Czechoslovakia and a party boss would not need a stethoscope to detect symptomatic sounds in Hungary and Rumania.

I approve highly of Jane Nickerson's food column, but a recent one puzzled me. Almost every recipe for "economical sauces" prescribed "egg yolks, slightly beaten." What do I do with the whites, if I am not to end up with a couple of spare parts which must be thrown in the sink ?

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- The recent Hollywood marijuana arrests have highlighted a major controversial feature of California law which will come under the scrutiny of the state's legal leaders this week.
AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 11 -- Maine, traditional curtain-raiser and cue-caller in Presidential years, will go to the polls Monday with the Republicans worried more about apathy than about Democrats.

A SEQUEL to "The Three-Two Pitch" this tells the exciting story of Bronc Burnett and his Sonora baseball team-mates in the state finals of the American Legion tourney. The Sonora team learns to overcome its superstitions as they play brilliant ball in one game, go to pieces and blow the next.

NANKING, Sept. 11 -- The Executive Yuan today set Sept. 30 as the deadline for the registration of assets deposited abroad by banks and other financial organizations. It threatened those who fail to comply with the order with the suspension of business.

THESE two volumes, though essentially different and published for different publics, have certain similarities. Both are reprints of early works about California; both adopt a negatively critical attitude; both are comparatively minor works of men much more widely known for other books.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- Italy's basic recovery problem, for which no solution has yet been found, is her surplus population, Premier Alcide de Gasperi told Edward Corsi, New York State Labor Commissioner during a conversation today.

TORONTO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Two members of the new Toronto local of the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, CIO, J. H. Pomeroy and John Stewart, sent a telegram to President Truman today requesting an investigation of their exclusion from the United States.

Retail holiday promotions will be started much earlier this year in an effort to exceed last year's volume, Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Good Association, disclosed yesterday following his return from a six-week nation-wide tour of retail stores.
BEING on the Board of Education which rented a high school auditorium to a summer theatre two years in succession, I took an active interest in the whole business.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., Sept. 11 --Adding to his other laurels, which include the State championship and custody of the Binghamton Challenge Trophy, Larry Evans, 16-year-old expert from New York City, today captured the rapid transit championship of the New York State Chess Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -The Navy is turning once again to blimps in its search for ways to kill off any enemy high speed submarines.

A pair of oarsmen from the New York Athletic Club, Joe Angyal and Jack Sulger, were the star performers in the New York Rowing Association's metropolitan championships on the Harlem River off the Nonpareil Rowing Club yesterday.

ANYONE who engages in bridge post-mortems knows how often a discussion will center on the play of some contract that was not actually bid. For some reason, what did not happen arouses much more interest than what did happen.

THIS dramatic story of an English bulldog that joined a polar expedition and scoured the Arctic wastes with the StollMcCracken Arctic Expedition reads like fiction, but is a true tale. And as Mr. McCracken points out, Toughy, hero of the story, had a bang-up time too.

To help students "achieve a full and practical understanding of arbitration in the fields of labor, commerce and international trade," St. Peter's College in Jersey City will begin this month an undergraduate workshop in "actual" arbitration. The course, which requires two semesters' work, is one of three of this type being offered in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The biggest Government spending program in peacetime history will be laid before the next Congress by President Truman, authoritative sources predicted today.

BACK in 1940 Clarence Love-Joy, for many years associated with Columbia University, wrote "So You're Going to College," which provided essential details for the prospective student. He has now enlarged and revised the earlier edition, placing greater emphasis on the importance of selecting the right college for the individual student.

Although agreeing in substance with Henry Steele Commager that to outlaw the Communist party would be unwise, I believe he is on weak ground when he contends that the Communists have never elected a single Congressman.

HAVING made a sizable dent in the adult concert-goer's market with his Little Orchestra Society last year, Thomas K. Scherman now lets it be known that he has plans for the small fry. The society has scheduled six programs to be presented on alternate Saturday mornings in Hunter College Assembly Hall, beginning Oct. 23 and in the Mosque Theatre, Newark, beginning Oct. 30.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 11 -- Bobby Riggs, United States professional star, today advocated open tennis tournaments among Australian, British and French players and said the United States quickly would join such a movement.
Mr. Moore is master of ceremonies for "Take It or Leave It" on NBC.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday adoption of a standard fire signal for ships using its Port Newark Marine Terminal.

The second day of registration for the draft of men born in 1927 resulted yesterday in the enrollment of approximately 24,000, Col. Candler Cobb, New York City Director of Selective Service, announced at his office, 516 West Thirty-fourth Street.
Three faculty members of Teachers College, Columbia University, will leave this afternoon from La Guardia Field for Puerto Rico to survey the island's educational system.

The Maritime Commission vessel Ernie Pyle, with 595 passengers aboard, left Falmouth, England, at 8:30 P.M. Friday bound for New York after being delayed in that port since Labor Day by a series of engine failures. Originally due here today, the ship is now expected to reach its North River pier next Sunday.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Britain's Labor Government will face this fall a grim test of its ability to keep the "lid" on wages as a key part of its current fight against inflation.

THE United States is on the threshold of a profound chemical revolution. The next ten years or fifteen-will see the rise of a massive new industry which will free us from dependence on foreign sources of oil. Gasoline will be produced from coal, air and water on a scale so huge that it will dwarf even the giant synthetic rubber industry born in desperation during World War II.

VICTORIA, B.C., -- Here in British Columbia's island capital, eighty miles distant by sea from Seattle and Vancouver, there is never a day in the year when you cannot play golf and hardly a Christmas when you cannot pick a rose.
