DUESSELDORF, Germany, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Socialists from eleven European countries pledged today to work for a united Europe dedicated to opposing dictatorship in any form.

Despite some progress in recent months, America's elementary and high schools still do not offer an adequate program of education for international understanding. When the nation's 29,000,000 school children return to classes this month, they will find that much of the teaching in this area is superficial and out of date, concerned mainly with mere descriptions of the world as it was before 1939.

Culminating four years of costly litigation, the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company last week defeated efforts of the City Council to force it to reduce its electric rates by 15 per cent and won a rate increase from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio that will add $2,500,000 to its annual revenues.

MOST cultural institutions in America owe their existence largely to the enthusiasms, consciences or tax problems of the patrician rich. Sometimes social feuds or jealousies in a particular city lead to the founding of rival institutions.

THIS new story by the author of "Yankee Ballerina," who is herself a well-known American dancer, carries on the career of Sylvia Allen, who becomes prima ballerina of the Metropolitan Opera Company. Thus it is both a look backstage into one of the world's most famous and glamorous theatres and a true-to-life, step-by-step account of an artist's growth and progress.
Congratulation to Professor Commager for writing "Should We Outlaw the Communist Party?" and to you for printing such a forthright, clear case against outlawing any political party.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Goose, the American defender owned by George Nichols and sailed by Briggs Cunningham, scored a runaway victory over Swedish and Norwegian Six-Meter rivals in the opening race of the international challenge series for the Scandinavian Gold Cup off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.

Apparel manufacturers fear that a prolonged trucking strike will curtail their shipments from textile mills and this in turn, they said, will result in widespread although temporary unemployment in the garment industry here, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 11 -- In a grueling test, said to be the toughest in America for racing thoroughbreds, Replica II, a post-and-rail jumper with plenty of heart and lots of stamina, captured the ninth running of the Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase today.

CAMERA clubs starting the new season this month announce a program of amateur movies, color slide and print competitions, an exhibition and a beginners' course. And a new camera club and a lecture series has been started.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The new Miss America, Beatrice Shopp, will head homeward tomorrow about $18,000 richer and with her course for the next few years at least definitely decided.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics slowed down the Boston Red Sox pennant drive by blasting four pitchers for fifteen hits and a 10-4 victory to celebrate their final 1948 Fenway Park appearance today before a crowd of 29,100 fans.

As President Truman and Governor Dewey, his Republican opponent, prepared for intensive speaking tours, political developments during the past week indicated that the 1948 campaign might follow the pattern of that of 1912, in which the Republican party split between President William Howard Taft and former President Theodore Roosevelt, who became the candidate of the then Progressive party.

Five new pictures will have local openings this week. The first entry, arriving tonight, is the French "Symphonie Pastorale," based on the Andre Gide story and featuring Pierre Blanchar and Michele Morgan. The premiere will mark the opening of the Paris Theatre in Fifty-eighth Street.

Describing American help to Europe as a humanitarian bulwark against communism, Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, said last night that this country's aid was not based on any desire to control other countries.
GENEVA, Sept. 12 -- After twenty-one months of preparation the International Refugee Organization will come officially into being tomorrow when its General Council meets here.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Sorrowing Pakistan buried Mohammed Ali Jinnah, Governor General and founding father of this Moslem Dominion, with full military honors tonight. Mr. Jinnah, 71, died last night after a heart attack.

A fight about a fish between two amateur fisherman resulted in one man being taken to a hospital in critical condition and another being held without bail for inflicting several knife wounds on the former.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Britain's Parliament will reconvene Tuesday in a short special session, the scheduled business of which is to assure completion of the Labor Government's five-year program for the socialization of industry.

Through the "articulate atheism of one parent" the "rights of all parents to freedom of religious education for their children are in danger of being invaded in this country," Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary for education of the Archdiocese of New York, charged yesterday.

A new venture in small-scale grand opera production was launched by the Amato Opera Theatre at Our Lady of Pompeii Theatre in Greenwich Village last night, and a more promising start could hardly be hoped for.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, declared here yesterday that the Marshall Plan was "a strong move in the direction of producing European stability."

DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox whipped the Detroit Tigers, 5 to 2, today in their final meeting of the 1948 American League season. Detroit won the season series, 14 games to 8. Four of the five Chicago runs were scored on homers by Tony Lupien, Aaron Robinson and Don Koloway.

While the Western Powers were considering their next move in the effort to resolve the battle of Berlin, the Russians yesterday staged an organized mass demonstration in the German capital in a further attempt to enlist the Germans in their drive against the West.

Further evidence of the National Maritime Union's determination to rid itself of all disruptive elements within the union's ranks was shown last week when David Drummund, New York port agent, filed charges against seven leaders of a group that invaded the NMU headquarters Sept. 2 and attempted to force the holding of a special meeting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 -- The strike-bound West Coast waterfront was quiet today, the eleventh day of the tie-up. Both unions and employers were waiting to see what the Army will do about moving cargo.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The selection of Philip D. Reed, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, as chairman of the United States group to sit on the new United State-British Council on Productivity was announced here today and brought expressions of satisfaction from British industrial interests.

ROME, Sept. 12 -- Pope Pius XII, in a clear reference to atomic energy, advocated today the employment of modern scientific discoveries for the promotion of peace. He scathingly denounced the use that he said dictatorships were making of what he called "ultra-powerful modern technical methods."

Austin Hogan, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, took issue yesterday with the proposal of Michael J. Quill, international president, that the city purchase all private bus lines.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 12 -- An albatross captured off the Cape of Good Hope will be exhibited at the 106th annual Mineola Fair, which opens here Tuesday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, United States Air Force commander in Europe, said today, "We can keep this air lift [to Berlin] up all winter and the Russians can't bother us."

BELGRADE, Yugolavia, Sept. 12 -- Food shortages have developed in recent weeks in Belgrade and other urban and industrial centers in Yugoslavia. Meats, fats and wheat cereals are in very short supply in the public markets and there is grumbling among the urban population, which normally supplements its Government issue of food rations with purchases of unrationed foodstuffs.

In the narrowest call experienced by any of the American favorites thus far, Earl Cochell broke the shattering service of Fred Kovaleski of Hamtramck, Mich., when all seemed lost in the fifth set yesterday to gain the third round of the National Amateur Tennis Championship at Forest Hills.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 12 -- hurricane with winds of 150 miles an hour is expected to pass close to Bermuda between 6 A. M. and noon tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -- Samuel Goldwyn today cast the 23-year-old actor, Farley Granger, in top roles of two pictures and announced that Joan Evans, 14-year-old New York girl whom he signed recently, will co-star in one of them. The latter will be a Technicolor film, as yet untitled, with the United States Naval Academy as its principal setting.

OFTEN when the conversation turns to literature the question is debated as to who are the great American novelists of this century. Critics and book-lovers being as prejudiced and opinionated as most people, no decision is ever reached. But three names are likely to lead all the rest. They are Theodore Dreiser, Ernest Hemingway and Willa Cather.
Charles Carroll, formerly clothing buyer for Gertz, Jamaica, will join Arnold Constable on Oct. 1 as manager of the men's clothing and men's hat departments, succeeding Malvin Dougherty, resigned.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Maybe VI, the Swedish challenger, finished 42 seconds ahead of Goose, the defending champion from the United States in the second race of the International Challenge series for the Scandinavian Gold Cup off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.
MIAMI, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Atlantic hurricane picked up speed tonight and at 9:15 P. M. was moving north northwest at 18 to 20 miles an hour.

Every seat and possible perch in Grand Central Palace was filled yesterday as one of the biggest crowds of the Golden Jubilee Expostition craned to see its fashion show. Toddlers sat on fathers' shoulders, older boys clambered up anything climable, adults and children alike peered through cracks in partitions and openings in draperies, intent on getting a good look at the most-talk-about fashion show in town.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 -- The "pastor who ponders man's blessed immortality and forgets his stomach is doomed to failure," the Most Rev. Robert E. Lucey, Archbishop of San Antonio, declared tonight at the convention of the National Council of Catholic Women.

Prof. Harlow Shapley of Harvard University, chairman of the National Council of the Arts, Sciences and Professions, announced yesterday that the group had formed a Commission for Academic Freedom to safeguard democratic rights.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 -- Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, challenged President Truman tonight to oppose for re-election those Democratic Representatives who voted to override his veto of the Taft-Hartley Act.

One element in the high costs of construction on which this convention may be helpful is inadequate, antiquated and greatly diverse building codes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration has neared the three-quarter mark in its program to distribute $2,000,000,000 in recovery grants in its first six months.

Food prices are in for a "prolonged downward drift," Gordon C. Corbaley, president of the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., predicted in an interview last week.

ZURICH, Sept. 12 -- Last Thursday a stranger dumped a packet of 160,000 Deutsche marks onto the counter in a leading commercial bank in Zurich, demanding Swiss francs in exchange. This seems to be a new record size for any single deal in Switzerland since the new bank notes were issued by Western Germany on last June 20th.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 12 -- Dealing with industrial cooperation of the United States and The Netherlands, Dr. Hendrik Albarda, manager of the Netherlands Trading Society, said in last week's Economisch Statistische Berichten that Europe's political troubles formed a serious handicap for such cooperation as well as handicaps specifically to Dutch developments.

SAN FRANSICO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- San Francisco Forty-niners, scoring in every period, crushed the New York Yankees, 41 -- 0, in an All-America Football Conference game before an overflow crowd of 60,927 today.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Rev. Alfred J. Sienkiewicz, feared missing on a trip to Poland, returned to his home here tonight. He had arrived in the United States more than twenty-four hours ahead of the party that reported his "disappearance."

The Rev. Arthur R. Kleps preached his final sermon as pastor of the Immanuel Evangelical Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at Eighty-eighth Street, yesterday morning. The congregation he has served for the last twenty-two years filled the church and was visibly moved by his words.

Heading a list of eleven new exhibitions in the second week of the fall art season, the Whitney Museum reopens tomorrow with a selection of work in various media from its permanent collections of contemporary American art.

Although the period of the Louis may have provided inspiration, there's nothing costumed or quaint about the collection of fall shoes at Delman's. It is essentially modern, designed for women who dislike extremes of fashion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The National Cancer Institute disclosed today that it was setting up a largescale project to check up on a wide variety of tests to detect cancer in its early curable stages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Bucky Harris and his Yankees who, come what may, seem determined to play out their string to the bitter end, saw their pennant hopes in the 1948 race receive a fresh shot in the arm today.
PAWLING, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey cut short today his week-and at his farm here to get an early start on final arrangements for his campaign tour to the West Coast.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- All eyes in the city last week were upon Berlin and Margate. Berlin supplied possible explosive material in international politics and the Trades Union Congress at Margate at times threatened domestic economic peace.

TOKYO, Sept. 12 -- The Japanese Socialist party is demanding the enactment of a program of "true Socialist legislation" as the price for remaining within the coalition Government of Premier Hitoshi Ashida. The alternative would be the collapse of the Cabinet in which the Socialists hold the greatest number of Ministries, followed by a general election, which would probably return a conservative majority.

An old East Side holding that had been in one family ownership since 1878 passed to new control with the sale by the Jewett Estate of the six-story Jewett Building at 22 East Fifty-fourth Street to Fred H. Hill, representing the Philger Realty Corporation.

Department and specialty stores had a record high in dollar sales volume in the first half of the current fiscal year but net profits, after estimated taxes, declined to 2.9 per cent of net sales from 3.4 per cent for the like period last year, the National Retail Dry Goods Association announced over the week-end.

Buying was active in the wholesale garment market here last week and a fair increase was shown in orders for holiday ready-to-wear lines, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- France is preparing shortly to open conversations with the United States Government with regard to French financial and monetary problems, it is learned from reliable sources here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Dr. Aake Ording of Norway, director of the United Nations Appeal for Children, resigned his post here today to make an eleventh-hour attempt at reviving the campaign to help 230,000,000 needy youngsters of the world.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Garry Davis, 26-year-old former bomber pilot, who renounced his United States citizenship three months ago, carried his bedding to the Palais de Chaillot today and said he would stay there until the United Nations recognized him as "the first citizen of the world."

Superlatives are in order for the three weeks of horse racing starting today at Belmont Park. Fifteen stakes, carrying $480,000 in added money, will be the headline events of the session, and the speediest thoroughbreds in the land, including some that have been flown in from California, will run in them.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 12 -- W.H. Stanley's Bumble Bee today captured the International Class series of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's sixteenth fall racing program.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Alvin Dark's single in the thirteenth inning and his daring race to third on Earl Torgeson's, sacrifice followed by Bill Salkeld's fly gave the Boston Braves a 2 to 1 victory over Philadelphia and an even split in today's double-header.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- A highly informed source said tonight resumption of the four-power talks in Moscow was "quite likely" this week. The informant made his prediction following the arrival in Moscow of Francois Seydoux, political and diplomatic adviser to Lieut. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig, French Military Governor in Germany.

SYOSSET, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Mrs. Lewis M. Gibb's brown gelding, Halethorpe, from Old Westbury, won the Conformation hunter championship during the Helping Hand Horse Show for the benefit of the Community Church today. The event was staged on the property of Mrs. M. B. Hewlett on Woodbury Road.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Daniel W. Tracy, president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, declared tonight that trade unions resented being singled out to take oaths of anti-communism, and termed as "unfounded and unjust" the suspicion cast upon their leaders.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 12 -- President Truman was described here today by a member of his Cabinet as a graduate of the "school of hard economic knocks * * * who knows what is it for a struggling family to try to make ends meet on a small salary or a small wage in times of rapid inflation."

Psychiatry today has neither the tools nor the knowledge to be able to run the world and should not attempt to "sit in with the diplomats," in the opinion of Dr. Carl F. Sulzberger, newly appointed psychiatric consultant to the staff of the United Nations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Despite the second biggest wheat crop of record, some grain market analysts are predicting an artificial "shortage" of wheat as a result of Government support of farm prices and export programs.

The Lebanon Steel Foundry of Lebanon, Pa., announced yesterday that it has acquired licenses from Firth-Vickers Stainless Steels, Ltd., of Sheffield, England, for secret British processes used in making super-alloy castings required for the most modern types of jet propulsion airplane engines.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Truett (Rip) Sewell, who beats the Cubs almost by force of habit, pitched the second-place Pirates to a 7-to-3 victory over Chicago today. A crowd of 27,967 saw the veteran right-hander record his seventh decision of the season over the Cubs, yielding five hits.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- India's Governor General, Chakravarthi Rajagopalachari, tonight telegraphed to the Nizam of Hy derabad, "The Government of India can not any longer be silent spectators just maintaining a position at the border."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Alexej Cepicka, Communist Minister of Justice and son-in-law of President Klement Gottwald, charged today "foreign agents" were under orders to kill M. Gottwald as revenge for the death of former President Eduard Benes. He did not identify these "agents."

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Lou Novikoff's fifteenth home run of the season behind a two-out pass to Blank Workman in the fourth inning combined with Les Mueller's three-hit pitching gave Newark a 2-1 nightcap triumph over Syracuse today.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Final matches in the annual championship tournament sponsored by the New York State Chess Association were contested today at En-Joie Park. Larry Evans, the 16-year-old New York City expert who clinched the title in the semifinal round, gained another point and wound up his schedule with a score of 7 1/2 -- 1/2.

The suicide death by gas of a former merchant seaman in a seventeen-story apartment house at 200 West 108th Street set off an explosion yesterday morning that killed two other tenants of the building and injured ten more persons.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- While Premier Henri Queuille and his new Cabinet, at their first meeting here today, were seeking the means to rescue France's shattered finances, Charles de Gaulle called again for new elections as he addressed a crowd of 40,000 persons at Nice.
For the second time in as many years, Carnegie Hall has undergone extensive redecorations and improvements intended to bring the appearance of the once-Victorian auditorium up to date.

It didn't rain rain yesterday at the Polo Grounds. It rained singles -- Giant singles that sent the home side off to a 3-0 lead over the Dodgers in the first inning. Subsequently, this flying start secured victory for Leo Durocher and his lads, 5 -- 3; and that loud noise heard in Harlem was the Brooks dropping into fourth place as the Giants made it three straight over their interborough rivals.

Despite reports of opposition, action will be taken this week to spur final adoption of a proposed code regulating use of comparative price claims in fur advertising, it was learned over the week-end. The opposition is held to be minor, but support of the entire trade is viewed as essential to making the code more than a "piece of paper."

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 12 -- After four months of intensive research, Samuel T. Sukel, a collector of Americana here, announced today that he had "positively identified" Nathaniel Hawthorne as the author of fourteen hitherto "unknown" short stories.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 12 -- The Dominion of India officially joined with Pakistan today in mourning the death of Mr. Jinnah. Flags on all Indian Government buildings and military establishments were flown at half staff. A Gazette Extraordinary expressed the Government's "deep regret" at the passing of the man who, more than any other, was responsible for the division of India into Hindu and Moslem Dominions.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions scored a touchdown in the opening minute today on a 23-yard pass from Fred Enke to End Cecil Souders and romped on to a 38-10 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National League football exhibition before 23,398 fans.

MT. VERNON, Ga., Sept. 12 (AP) -- J. A. Johnson, was charged with murder today in the death of a Negro the night of Georgia's primary election, Sheriff R. M. McCrimmon said. He is being held in the Montgomery County Jail following his arrest early today, the sheriff said.
SHANGHAI, Monday, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Chiang Ching-kuo, son of China's president, told a cheering throng today that China was "in the midst of social revolution."
Quick action by personnel of the Holland-America liner Volendam saved the life of a California student who fell overboard at sea Saturday, it was reported here yesterday.

The Rev. William Howard Melish, associate rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, citing the resolutions of the Lambeth Conference in support of full freedom of speech, conscience and belief, declared yesterday that "this concept of freedom is being directly challenged in America today."
BELGRADE, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The solid support of the Yugoslav Navy has been pledged to Marshal Tito in defense of the country's independence.

Inasmuch as many Americans have received a rather melancholy picture of conditions prevailing in England, one is surprised upon arriving in a London hotel to find an abundance of food, if not as wide a choice as in the United States, and excellent, courteous service.

Consolidated net income of the Bendix Aviation Corporation for the ninth months ended with last June rose to $7,019,489 from $4,644,992 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year, according to the report released today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Charges that establishment of a legitimate theatre in Washington is now being blocked by Marcus Heiman of New York were made tonight in a radio discussion on Station WINX here.

CAIRO, Sept. 12 -- The Arab League Political Committee weighed the possibilities today of assigning one of the Arab States to mediate in the conflict between Hyderabad and India. It acted on the basis of a proposal submitted by Pakistan's Minister of Finance and Pakistan's Ambassador to Egypt and of reports that Hyderabad had appealed for intervention by one of the Arab states.

The number of workers throughout the country that will be affected by the peacetime draft will be relatively small, according to a study made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
WARSAW, Sept. 12 -- Complete reorganization of Polish life to shape every phase of activity into a Marxist pattern is in prospect as a result of the recent Communist party crisis.

MONTREAL, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The pennant-winning Montreal Royals knocked the Toronto Maple Leafs out of the International League play-offs today by beating the Leafs, 7 -- 5, in the second game of a double-header. The Leafs won the opener, 9 -- 4.
Unexpected relief from the impact of the truck strike was provided last night in an employer announcement that a new group of 4,500 idle drivers would return to work this morning.

The French Cabinet crisis and the extremely serious situation which continues to prevail in Berlin where the Western Powers are locked with Russia over the peaceful occupation of that city, made for a soft undertone in the foreign exchange market last week.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Expecting failure, Hector McNeil, Minister of State in the British Foreign Office, left London today to represent Foreign Secretary Bevin at tomorrow's Big Four meeting in Paris to discuss the disposition of Italy's former colonies in Africa.

Automobile traffic was tied up for about an hour, beginning at 8:40 o'clock last night, after a series of rear-end collisions involving five cars on the Triboro Bridge extension of Grand Central Parkway, near Seventy-eighth Avenue, in Forest Hills, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- In the midst of a flurry of strikes, the National Planning Association today exhibited an example of industrial peace -- fourteen years of industrial harmony in the West Coast pulp and paper industry.

Plodding with unfaltering strides over 26 miles 385 yards of traffic-clogged, heat-blistered Queens highways, gritty little Johnny Kelley of West Acton, Mass., yesterday captured the National A.A.U. marathon championship for the first time in his long and illustrious road-running career.

The South Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association plans to open a Bensonhurst branch at 1972 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, where it has purchased a two-story building from Morris Kaplan. Slomka Brothers were the brokers and the attorneys were Daniel McNamara for the buyer and Louis Kaplan for the seller.
The first formal steps toward revoking the charter of the left-wing Greater New York CIO Council will be taken this week, it was learned last night.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The Pilgrim Baptist Church at 43 Charles Street was filled to capacity tonight and a good part of the congregation did not attend to worship.

Is another feud flaring up between the Shuberts and the Dramatists Guild? For many years Lee and Jake Shubert, non-signators to the Guild's basic agreement, have vehemently opposed the Guild on general principles. What brings the powerful brothers into the picture again is "My Romance," the musical play with tunes by Sigmund Romberg, an ardent and loyal Guild member.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Archbishop Stepinac High School, the first Roman Catholic high school for boys in Westchester County, was dedicated by Cardinal Spellman this afternoon. Four thousand persons attended the ceremonies on a broad lawn in front of the main entrance to the $4,200,000 brick building on Mamaroneck Avenue at Ridgeway here.

Four hundred persons attended a memorial service for President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia yesterday morning at the Jan Hus Bohemian Brethren Presbyterian Church, 347 East Seventy-fourth Street. They heard tributes paid to Dr. Benes by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of the Free Synagogue and by Mrs. Jan Papanek, wife of the former Czechoslovak delegate to the United Nations, whose break with the Communist regime in his homeland resulted in the loss of his position.

The effect of tying wages to cost-of-living statistics, labor-management cooperation on wages, employe production incentives and employe, community and union relations will be discussed at the American Management Association's conference of 1,500 industrial relations and personnel executives from more than 1,000 companies in the Pennsylvania Hotel on Sept. 23 and 24.

More than one-eighth of New York City's population of 8,000,000 persons will move from home into the classroom today with the opening of a new school year. Of these 1,160,500 children, 883,000 will attend the public schools, operated by the city's Board of Education at a cost of about $200,000,000 a year.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12 -- Seven women who had been sentenced to thirty days in jail for an "unauthorized meeting" in Calle Florida, Wednesday at which cries of "viva la constitucion" were heard were ordered released under provisional liberty yesterday without prejudice to the legal continuance of the action.

The cooperation of employers in helping disabled veterans find useful places in business and industry will be sought in "Operation Success," a joint production of the DuMont television activity and the United States Veterans Administration.

Radio sets and loudspeakers have been installed in the public buses of twenty cities, with the prospect that twenty more will soon be added to the list. News, music, "commercials" and all that is good and not so good in broadcasting pour into the cars of passengers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, accused the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress of "double-crossing" American farmers by extending price supports without giving enough space to store crops to the Commodity Credit Corporation.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 12 -- The atomic bomb has shaken not science but religion and philosophy, Viscount Samuel, president of the Royal Institute of Philosophy, told a meeting here tonight of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Representative John Jennings, Republican, of Tennessee, has released a letter from Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York "enthusiastically" endorsing the Tennessee Valley Authority but not recommending the "central authority" system for development of resources in other parts of the country.

Basil R. McAllister, a $75-a-week bank teller with a penchant for philanthropy, arrived at the New York International Airport yesterday afternoon from a trip to Finland, where he had visited some of the twenty-five needy families to which he has sent food and clothing parcels during the last three years.

The death of Dr. Eduard Benes recalls the last conversation I had with him, in October, 1943. Among other educators, I had been invited to England by the British Government and devoted most of my time to discussions with officials of the Governments in exile as to the best methods whereby educational reconstruction might be undertaken in the devastated countries.
Bishop Howard D. Higgins marked his twentieth anniversary as rector of the First Reformed Episcopal Church, 317 East Fiftieth Street, in a service there yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- September corn again was the dominating influence in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week. Wide swings in prices with a large trade were a daily occurrence in the current delivery of corn. Still wider price changes are anticipated from now on, owing to a large open interest, around 18,000,000 bushels of which must be evened up in the next nine business days.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Eleven Big Nine athletes were declared ineligible for one year of Conference sports competition today.

Women are playing a major role in the battle of Berlin. Owing to their great numerical preponderance in the population, this is true of all of Germany, but it has special significance in Berlin because the Soviet Military Government recognized the decisiveness of the woman vote and the weight of woman power, both in industry and politics, long before the Western authorities gave it a thought.
EDINBURGH, Sept. 12 -- The Edinburgh Festival ended today with an afternoon concert by the Augusteo Orchestra and one in the evening by the Glasgow Orpheus Choir, directed by Sir Hugh Roberton.

Twenty years ago today a little single-engine airplane carrying four passengers made a flight of 600 miles from Lima to Talara, Peru. This was the first scheduled air transportation along the west coast of South America. It was one of those flights which are all too easily forgotten in the rush of development in the air and the present-day comings and goings of our international air transport.

The prospect of Government control over cotton crops next year, coupled with expectations of heavy loan entries and the corollary tightening of the "free" supply, were the sustaining factors in the narrow trading range that characterized activity on the New York Cotton Exchange last week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- The nation's savings and loan groups took in a record $1,888,000,000 during the first six months of this year, but withdrawals were greater than receipts The United States Savings and Loan League made the report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation called on bankers today for "every effort" to maintain a strong banking system, since funds available to the corporation for protection of depositors com-price only a small fraction of the deposits insured.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Western powers' next move in the Berlin crisis seemingly ran into delay today while the United States sought to block out a course of action with Britain and France.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 (AP) -- India has announced anew her determination to take whatever action she considers necessary in the Hyderabad crisis, but a report that Indian troops had invaded the Princely State was officially denied today.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 12 -- The Government of India released today the texts of the latest correspondence between India and Hyderabad. It indicated that India held herself free to invade the independent Princely State without further negotiation.

"The Quest for Security" was the sermon subject yesterday of the Rev. Dr. Albert J. McCartney, pastor of the Chicago Sunday Club and former pastor of the National Presbyterian Church, Washington, at the Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 -- Steel output last week was unchanged at 95 per cent of capacity. Indications are that the same or slightly higher level will prevail this week. Most steel companies in recent months have been obtaining a greater percentage of finished steel from ingots produced than was the case a year ago.

Various pressing needs for improving visual health and safety conditions for New York school children were outlined yesterday as an estimated 1,160,500 boys and girls were scheduled to flock back to classrooms in the city this morning.
CORNING, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared here today that war was justified only in defense of the American way of life.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Cardinals nosed out the Reds, 7 to 6, today for two out of three victories in the current series. Johnny Wyrostek and Hank Sauer led Cincinnati batting with two home runs. A last-minute Red rally in the top of the ninth was stopped by Ted Wilks after Marty Marion had singled home the leading run in the eighth.

KESHENA, Wis., Sept. 12 -- The family homestead of the late Angus F. Lookaround, who distinguished himself as an athlete, musician and teacher in relations between American Indians and whites, was the scene today of a memorial observance to him.

BUFFALO N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The champion All-America Conference Cleveland Browns took their second straight victory of the pro football season by whipping the Buffalo Bills, 42 -- 13, today before 35,340 in Civic Stadium.
TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 12 -- On Wednesday, New Jersey will-set in operation its new streamlined court system.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- New York's first state fair since the war will open tomorrow, but on a' limited basis. The exposition will run throughout the week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The American Association for the Advancement of Science, now 100 years old, suggested today that the world looks to science for an example of unity.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- A remarkable Labrador retriever, Stowaway at Deer Creek, belonging to Gerald M. Livingston of New York, added to his considerable stature today by taking best in show at the record Westchester Kennel Club event, one of the nation's foremost outdoor bench competitions.

CAUX, Switzerland, Sept. 12 -- The United Nations is doomed to failure unless statesmen can bring to it a moral and spiritual dynamic based on Christian principles, A.R.K. MacKenzie, a member of the British delegation to the United Nations and adviser to Sir Alexander Cadogan, Britain's permanent representative in the Security Council, said here today.

Representatives of leading civic organizations in Manhattan will meet in the Municipal Building next Monday afternoon to coordinate plans for a master program of improvement projects, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers announced yesterday.

Twenty-two obsolete military reservations, some of them historic sites of former forts and many of them on small islands in excellent fishing waters along the New York and New England coasts, will be sold as surplus property by the War Assets Administration in a series of sealed bid sales beginning this fall, it was announced yesterday.
Maine votes today and politicians will eye intently the size of the expected Republican majority. The largest yet recorded was 83,000.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 -- After reaffirming support of President Truman, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today renewed his assault upon the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:The case of the Soviet teachers, Mrs. Oksana Kasenkina and Mikhail Samarin, has aroused much interest both in the United States and abroad, and has led to important political consequences. It seems essential to record the true sequence of events, and to supplement the incomplete, though lengthy, statement of Victor A. Kravchenko which appeared in THE TIMES of Aug. 20.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians and the Browns battled to a 3-to-3 tie today in a contest called because of darkness at the end of twelve innings and 3 hours and 15 minutes of play. Cleveland took the opening contest in the double header, 6 to 4.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sep. 12 -- Following a debate in the Arab League's political committee on Palestine's political and military status, Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the League, announced tonight that irregular volunteer forces sponsored by the League in Palestine would become eventually the regular army of a Palestinian Arab state.

A daredevil driver from Kentucky and a shiny mahogany creft from Ohio came East yesterday and showed Metropolitan New York watermen how to battle tides, currents and driftwood along the Hudson, East and Harlem Rivers and how to win the Around-Manhattan 28-mile speed boat race for the Harwood Trophy and cash prizes.

Gordon Barnett's Butterfly, a 48-foot sloop, was first home yesterday from Cornfield Lightship and won by just over an hour on corrected time in the featured Class C, for auxiliaries, in the annual City Island Yacht Club overnight races.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Sept. 12 -- A message from Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, in Germany, to the congress of the party here, cautioned the Western Allies this afternoon against the acceptance of the Soviet East mark as the only Berlin currency.

EAGLES MERE, Pa., Sept. 12 -- The perils of demagogic misuse of public opinion polls, as well as the great potentiality of such polls for building international understanding and cooperation, were stressed here tonight as 250 specialists in the survey field opened a four-day conference.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin called members of

JERUSALEM, Sept. 12 -- Ten Israeli civilians and soldiers lost their lives and seventeen other persons were injured during the last twenty-four hours by Arab field guns shelling residential areas outside the walled Old City, as the United Nations "cease-fire" in Jerusalem began its ninth week.

The sudden death of Mohammed Ali Jinnah, Governor General of the Dominion of Pakistan, adds a further complication to the already complex situation on the Indian sub-continent. Pakistan has been left leaderless. Mr. Jinnah had resigned his presidency of the Moslem League (which actually governs Pakistan), holding that it was inappropriate for the Governor General to be also the titular head of a political party.

Altered conditions in the selling field during the post-war era, and the need for greater cooperation among salesmen and salesmen's groups, were stressed by Irvine Lefcourt, executive director of the Women's Wear Salesmen of New York, Inc., in drawing up his annual report to be presented at the yearly installation meeting of the organization tonight at the New Yorker Hotel.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- An official of the United States Treasury Department said today that the size of the national debt "is nothing to be disturbed about" if a high level of prosperity was maintained.

Despite a walkout yesterday by eight-two compositors and mailroom employes of The Journal of Commerce, an edition of the 121-year-old commercial newspaper was published at 11:30 P. M. after editorial employes took over mechanical jobs at the plant at 63 Park Row.

The expectation that the nursing shortage would be relieved at the expiration of wartime demands has not been realized, according to a report on "Nursing for the Future" made public yesterday. The report was prepared for the National Nursing Council by Dr. Esther Lucile Brown, who urged far-reaching changes in nursing practice and education.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 (;P)--Thel Soviet Union marked Tank Day today with large portraits of Premier Stalin in all newspapers and with an order of the-day calling for "new successes in the development of our armored and mechanized armies."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A government advisory commission said today that cultural relations with Communist areas in Europe posed a "perplexing" problem in developing the student exchange program under a 1943 law.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Mounted so strongly that the opposition often was practically left standing still, Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes whipped Henry Lewis' Long Island quartet, 14 to 6, in a semi-final of the National Open Polo Championship Tournament on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

Nestea, new soluble tea product of the Nestle Company, Inc., maker of Nescafe and other grocery products, will be introduced late this month with a newspaper and spot radio campaign in Boston, New York and Philadelphia, it was announced over the week-end.
Thousands visited Greenwich Village yesterday afternoon as the thirty-fourth semi-annual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit went into full swing.

Priscilla Gillette, youthful soprano from Tenafly, N. J., who has the leading role of Fiona in "Brigadoon", gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Instead of the comparatively simple ditties allotted her in the musical, the ambitious program she had prepared was a difficult one, in which, despite her immaturity as vocalist and interpreter, she disclosed marked talents.

Dr. W. E. B. DuBois, militant Negro leader and director of special research for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was told yesterday that his employment by the association would end on Dec. 31 when his contract expires.
ROME, Sept. 13 -- The Vatican completed plans today for an all-out drive to break the grip the Communist party has on Italian labor.

More newspaper men cover City Hall today than ever before, Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett said yesterday. He spoke for Mayor O'Dwyer on a program saluting the New York press, as part of the Golden Anniversary Exposition in Grand Central Palace. Grover A. Whalen and representatives of fourteen newspapers also took part.

In your letter column of Aug. 28, R. W. Hubbell pays tribute to Gen. Abner Doubleday as the inventor of baseball and adds a little nonsense of his own to the groundless legend that has grown up about the general, who earned fame enough as a soldier without begging any he does not deserve.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- With buyers marking time on political events, conditions in the stock market here today were quiet.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Big Nine now can get down to drafting a football schedule for the next three years after some whip-cracking on athletic policies which was more a threat than anything else.

The Journal of Commerce published an edition again last night despite the walkout Sunday of eighty-two members of the International Typographical Union in the composing and mail rooms. A front-page editorial said that "competent" personnel would be hired to fill the vacancies and, "in addition, different, new types of typesetting techniques will be utilized in the publication of the paper."
On net sales of $46,208,932 the Motor Products Corporation realized a net profit of $2,861,863 in the fiscal year ended on June 30, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President, was described today as "sympathetic" to a proposal for the creation of a joint Congressional committee, with close White House liaison, which would be charged with a study designed to stabilize the dollar.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- A sharp difference of view between British and United States officials over what both consider a vital part of the intra-European trade scheme was regarded today as the next major hurdle facing common European action under the Marshall Plan.

The city of Chicago, Ill., sold yesterday an issue of $3,500,000 of water works system revenue certificates due on Sept. 15 from 1962 to 1964 to a banking group headed by Glore, Forgan Co., at a bid of 102.31 for 2 3/4s. The bonds were re-offered at prices to yield 2.40 per cent to 2.50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities reported material progress today in the building of a factual case against "one of the most important Soviet agents" in wartime espionage for American atomic and radar secrets.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores decreased 7 per cent last week under the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 5 per cent.

Athough we may be guilty of wishful thinking, there seem to be some signs of awakening public interest in smoke abatement, even reaching into official circles. One such evidence is the publication of a booklet, now being distributed, called "An Analysis of the Air Pollution Program in New York City."
Fred Smith came to THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen yesterday to cook a Brunswick stew. He was qualified for the job on two counts.

The clothes that the Tailored Woman presented at its showing at the St. Regis Roof yesterday, expressed the good judgment of those responsible for their selection. From start to finish they were definitely modish, but never did they go beyond the boundaries of good taste.

I have made a very rough calculation that between June 25 and Sept. 2, 1948, "Operation Vittles" has flown into Berlin 280,000,000 pounds of various merchandise. Why go to all this trouble? Why not evacuate the people of the American, British and French sectors to the Western zone? I am sure- that the three Western zones could find room for these. Berlin evacuees.

Ten vessels -- eight cargo ships and two tankers -- were added to the privately owned United States merchant marine in August, and on Sept. 1 private vessels totaled 1,200, according to the monthly survey of the National Federation of American Shipping.

India's invasion of Hyderabad brings to a crisis a dispute that is more basic than the Indian charge of lawlessness within the Princely State. What is at issue is the refusal of the Nizam, Hyderabad's ruler, to accede to the Dominion of India.

EAGLES MERE, Pa., Sept. 13 -- The executive council of the World Congress on Public Opinion Research protested today the State Department's failure to grant a visa to Dr. Laszlo Radvanyi, director of the Mexican Institute of Public Opinion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- Just before the Army Department decision today to hire longshoremen to handle supplies destined for personnel in the Pacific, Waterfront employers accused longshoremen of "a work interruption and contract violation every second or third day for fourteen years."

As he traveled through the United States in the early nineteenth century that shrewd French observer, De Tocqueville, made a few notes about American science. "The immediate and useful practical results of the sciences" were bound to be developed first, he decided.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 -- With Manager Bucky Harris and his Yankees sitting in the stands, watching the proceedings with a critical and perhaps even an evil eye, the Indians suffered a rather severe blow to their own pennant chances today as they dropped the final engagement of their series with the Browns, 3 to 2.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 13 -- Maine Republicans captured all top offices in today's general election, the first in the country. It was the party's seventh straight "clean sweep" in the state.

Maine has gone Republican, but the old adage about the rest of the nation going as Maine goes hasn't the authority it once enjoyed. Democrats haven't captured a major political office in Maine's unique September elections since 1934, but have done well enough on a national scale to win three Presidential elections in the intervening years.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 13 -- Literally putting out his tongue at his audience, Dr. Cyril Darlington, a fellow of the Royal Society, a geneticist, declared that language and dialect and speech characteristics depended on heredity.

Bidding today for $25,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds of the Indiana and Michigan Electric Company will mark the opening of the marketing season for new long-term corporate debt. Four syndicates are expected to compete for the business.

Prices of hides futures on Commodity Exchange, Inc., climbed steadily in yesterday's trading to net gains of 51 to 75 points. Closing prices were near the tops for the day. Trading volume was 124 lots, or 4,960,000 pounds.

Rayon yarn and staple, shipments totaled 93,200,000 pounds in August, a gain of 15 per cent over the corresponding month last year, according to the September Rayon Organon, statistical bulletin of the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

"Maedchen in Uniform," produced before Hitler's rise to power and recognized as a German film classic, will be revived for the first time in sixteen years, beginning Oct. 1, at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. The picture, which ran twenty-two weeks at the old Criterion when first presented here, has been equipped with a new set of English title translations of the German dialogue.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Deciding matches in the third and fourth rounds of the inter-county competition for the Genesee Cup and the inter-club contests for the Susquehanna Cup, completed today the program at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association at En Joie Park.

Commuters who have been protesting the curtailment of service on the lines of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company won a partial victory yesterday. At a conference in the offices of the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway, the railroad agreed to add four trains and to extend the schedule of four others, effective today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Declaring that the Wage-Hour Act has become obsolete by reason of the mounting price level, Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, said today the act must be made effective again by establishing a new minimum wage floor.
How a walkie-talkie was used to gather evidence against two narcotics peddlers, alleged members of a nation-wide syndicate, was revealed yesterday in Kings County Court.
Members of the United States delegation to the forthcoming meeting of the United Nations General Assembly in Paris left here yesterday aboard the United States liner America.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Diminutive Mrs. Bettye Mims White of Dallas won medal honors of the forty-eighth national women's amateur golf tournament today.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Shafiq Ades, widely known Jewish merchant, was sentenced to death today by a military court and fined 5,000,000 dinars ($20,000,000) on charges of aiding the Jews in the Palestine war and organizing Zionism in Iraq.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- The thud of a power shovel will signal at noon tomorrow the start of construction of the United Nations headquarters on the shore of Manhattan's East River. Hoisting of the initial scooprul of earth also will mark the end of quiet for residents of the area.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Government of Yugoslavia has paid $17,000,000 to the United States to settle claims, the State Department announced today.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Premier Henri Queuille worked throughout the day today with his ministers on a program of urgent financial measures to strengthen France's weak economic foundations The preparation of these measures is not expected to be completed before Wednesday morning when the full Cabinet will meet.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Members of the New York State Saving and Loan League were urged today to maintain a minimum liquidity of 15 to 20 per cent to forestall a demand for legislative actions.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies increased 13.1 per cent in August, compared with the corresponding month in 1947, according to compilations covering forty-four companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13 -- Orlando Marogio, president of the Argentine Bank, accompanied by several aides, left here by plane for the United States this morning. Due in Miami tomorrow morning, he will visit New Orleans, Washington and possibly New York.

Officials of the Actors Equity Association and the American Federation of Radio Artists are expected to meet Thursday to initiate negotiations looking toward eventual merger of the two A. F. of L. unions. Should agreement be reached, the provisions of a merger pact would have to be submitted to the executive boards and memberships of the two organizations, a procedure which probably would take a couple of months to complete.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 13 -- The Goose and the Fox proudly came back together this afternoon. The Goose is George Nichols' ten-year-old six-meter yacht defending the Scandinavian Gold Cup for the Seawanhaka Corinthian Club. The Fox is her tender.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Increased activity in the field of low-budget film production was indicated today by an announcement by Monogram that the company would release fifty-one films during the coming year under its own name and ten films under the name of its subsidiary, Allied Artists.

Prices on the stock market drifted yesterday close to the lows set early in August with losses of slightly more than a point in a variety of key issues and the composite rate reduced 0.53 point. Final quotations were generally above the worst marks of the session although the list leaned heavily to the lower side in terms of stocks to lose ground.

Fifteen German editors and publishers, here for a six-week Columbia University seminar, agreed yesterday that there was virtually no danger of a third World War as a result of the present struggle for Berlin.

The two-day registration for the peacetime draft of youths born in 1928 began yesterday. Approximately 27,000 enrolled here, according to Col. Candler Cobb, city Selective Service director. He predicted that about as many in the age group would, register today.

The late fall opening of a new production, "Quick Service," was announced yesterday by Montgomery Ford, who says he will place it in rehearsal "within two weeks." The script, described as a comedy, is a dramatization by Mr. Ford and P. G. Wodehouse, British humorist and author, of the latter's novel of the same name.

KEMPTVILLE, N. S., Sept 13 -- There may be some remote corner of the continent with a larger population of woodcock and deer per mile than here, but we have never found it, and although the primary purpose of our expedition was to try for some of the squaretail trout, we encountered signs of game on every hand.

Professional football in the interest of charity -- the Herald-Tribune Fresh Air Fund -- will be presented at the Polo Grounds tonight, with the New York Giants engaging the Chicago Bears in an exhibition game that, so far as local gridiron fans are concerned, will shed a true light on the improvement in Steve Owen's aggregation.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Mrs. T. Lyman of Maplewood shot a 78 at Baltusrol today to win the qualifying medal from a field of 115 in the State open match play championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.

The opening last night of the Paris Theatre, 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, was hailed by Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador, as foreshadowing "closer cooperation between the French and American film industries." The Ambassador's statement was read from the stage of the theatre by Ludovic Chancel, the French Consul General in New York.

The sixth non-jury water-color exhibition, open to all artists living or working in the Village, has just been announced to the Village Art Center. There will be no jury of admission, only a jury to award prizes, which include a one-man show and participation in a group show.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Britain, France and the United States have agreed on the next step to be taken in negotiations with the Soviet Union on the Berlin blockade. The Foreign Office stated today that new instructions had been or soon would be delivered to the three Western envoys in Moscow.
TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 13 -- The judges of New Jersey's new court system were told by the administrative head today that they must earn their increased salaries by expediting justice.

RHODES, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, ordered Israel today to readmit Arab refugees to three villages and to rebuild their shattered homes. He said 8,000 Arabs had been driven out and their homes smashed by the Israeli Army in violation of the truce.

In a return to her championship form of 1946, C. V. Whitney's First Flight made an up-and-at-'em finish to win the $31,700 Fall Highweight Handicap yesterday as Belmont Park's three-week fall meeting opened with 21,289 in attendance.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- The first radioactive detecting safety devices to protect America's armed forces and the public from future atomic warfare have been reduced to low costs and are being mass produced for eventual sale in department stores, if necessary, it was disclosed at the opening of the Third National Instrument Conference and Exhibit at Convention Hall here.
Government, management and labor should give-serious attention to wise cooperation in a sound program of accident avoidance, Governor Dewey declared yesterday.

Newspapers take 43.2 per cent of the dealers' advertising expenditure, according to a post card survey taken by the National Office Machine Dealers Association, Dayton, Ohio. The average amount spent for advertising by the 189 dealers who responded to the poll was 2 cents of every dollar taken in.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- A Russian military tribunal sentenced five youths, none older than 20, to twenty-five years imprisonment at hard labor each for their part-in last Thursday's anti-Communist demonstration.

Outlining the city's multi-million-dollar construction program, Mayor O'Dwyer renewed his plea yesterday for a stabilization agreement of three or five years between the building trade unions and employers, to enable the city to accept bids without "blushing," and to facilitate completion of public improvements.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 13 (AP) -- India's drive into Hyderabad today was spearheaded with tanks and armored cars and covered with air support. Telephoned messages from inside Hyderabad quoted official sources as saying that the Indian Air Force had raided airfields in Warangal and Bidar, two towns in the central part of the state.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Small-scale production of titanium metal for research into its use as an industrial raw material strong as stainless steel and only half as heavy was announced today by the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A 14-year-old crippled girl claimed by the Soviet Union as a Soviet citizen has been turned over to the Russian authorities on order of the United States Military Commandant of Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announced $47,687,179 of authorizations to Marshall Plan countries today, including $33,400,000 for the United Kingdom. More than $44,000,000 of the amount authorized to eight participating countries was for purchases outside the United States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Led by Henry A. Wallace's Progressive party, all political parties except the Socialist party have operated financially in the red this year.

Carrying on in their self-appointed task as "spoliers," the Giants, having dealt Flatbush pennant hopes a telling blow, last night jarred Pittsburgh flag prospects with a victory that snapped a Pirate winning streak of seven in a row.

The construction of the new headquarters of the United Nations will start at noon today at a point on Forty-third Street midway between First Avenue and the East River Drive. The event will be commemorated in a brief ceremony at which Mayor O'Dwyer will represent New York City and Acting Secretary General Cohen the United Nations.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- British, French and United States diplomats and oil company officials have been informally exploring ways and means of resuming the output of oil from Haifa, Israel. Until now, it was reported, these inquiries have come to nothing. Middle Eastern oil is considered vital to the success of the Marshall Plan.

It was not in the cards for Rex Barney to pitch a second successive no-hitter, as the Dodgers returned to the more friendly surroundings of Ebbets Field last night. In fact, the Speedy right-hander from Omaha, Neb., was, for the longest time, in danger of losing to the Cubs, who enjoyed a 3-0 bulge going into the sixth inning.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum's retirement as commanding general of the New York National Guard as he reaches the age of 69 invites a review of the exceptional services that this distinguished citizen has performed for his country. The son of a soldier, he was born in an Army post, and was already a second lieutenant on duty in the Philippines hostilities of 1898 before he was 20 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- President Truman charged here tonight that scientific work "indispensable for national security "may be made impossible by the creation of an atmosphere in which no man feels safe against the public airing of unfounded rumors, gossip and villification."

Policemen wearing gray helmets, handlebar mustaches and the brass-buttoned uniforms of the Gay Nineties marched last night with representatives of today's force in the opening parade of Coney Island's "Golden Jubilee" Mardi Gras.

LONDON, Sept 13 -- A last-ditch fight to avert nationalization has been organized by steel interests under the leadership of Alfred Edwards, Labor Member of Parliament, who was ousted by his party in May for his stand against the proposed Government ownership of the iron and steel industry.

Foregoing her almost characteristic jeweled and flowered furbelows, Lilly Dache created an audible stir yesterday in her fall and winter presentation with a daytime collection of close-to-the head designs that were all line with little trim.

BACK in 1936 the New York Football Giants had the worst season in their history. The usual procedure in cases of that sort is to fire the coach. But Tim Mara and his sons, Jack and Duke, are much too shrewd for that. They fired the team, cutting seventeen adrift from the twenty-five-man squad. And the rebuilding operation was such a huge success that the Giants went on to one championship after another.

Inflationary aspects of consumer credit are being overemphasized, members of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York declared yesterday. While admitting that cautious policies are always advisable in an inflationary economy, warning was issued against conservatism being carried to extremes.

With the exception of Frank Parker and Richard Gonzales, who were idle, all of the American favorites moved ahead in the National amateur tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday while Colin Long of Australia and Enrique Morea of Argentina were passing from the scene.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 13 -- Without electricity in most parts of Bermuda and all telephone lines out, the islanders tonight were trying to assess the damage in the wake of a hurricane which passed about fifty miles to the west during the afternoon.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- The first Hyderabad reports on the fighting in the State came tonight from Radio Pakistan, Lahore, which quoted the Hyderabad radio as having announced that the Indians were meeting with resistance and that the situation on all sectors was "satisfactory."

Carrie Munn, who presented her autumn collection of dresses, suits and evening gowns at her salon, 640 Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon, might have dedicated her designs to the young-of-heart. Almost all had a delightfully fresh approach to the fashion trends of the day.

"Anatomy of Paradise: Hawaii and the Islands of the South Seas," by J. C. Furnas, will be published by William Sloane Associates on Oct. 11. It deals with the facts and the legends, the tragedies and comedies, the people and the lands of the Pacific.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- The Westchester Park Commission's request for development of a $3,500,000 recreation center at the county's Saxon Woods Park in Scarsdale and Mamaroneck was pigeonholed today by the Board of Supervisors.
DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- Kaiser-Frazer Corporation filed a counter claim in Federal Court today asking $38,552,118 in damages from Otis Co., a Cleveland investment house.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, who hopes to step into Joe Louis' job as heavyweight champion, took a long stride in that direction tonight by winning a well-fought ten-round decision over Jimmy Bivins.

Setting the date of the fall meeting of the Westchester Racing Association one week earlier than usual failed to keep members of society of the Long Island summer colonies, New York and many parts of the east and south from attending the opening program yesterday afternoon at Belmont Park.
Students from Europe who are here to study in the United States were finding yesterday on their sightseeing trips that New York was interesting -- but not America.
Prices held firm yesterday at the opening of advance spring lines of women's shoes by the fourteen members of the Guild of Better Shoe Manufacturers at their showrooms here.
President Truman received the official support of two more unions yesterday in his campaign for re-election.
Institutions for the mentally ill in New York State are slowly shifting their programs from mere custodial care to treatment and research, a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES disclosed yesterday.

Reports on the relatively depleted condition of New York City reservoirs in Westchester and Putnam Counties serve to emphasize the earnest pleas being made by city officials to New York residents to conserve water. We can well understand how the leaky faucets in hundreds of buildings and the untended mechanical lawn sprays around the city might easily add up to a serious drain on New York's water resources at a time of continued drought.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- John Golden, theatrical producer, is enjoying his stay in London. Here for a holiday and to see plays, he finds that he is working every minute.
The cost of meeting injury and damage claims against the New York City Omnibus Company has soared "like everything else," according to testimony before the Public Service Commission yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- September corn advanced 3 3/8 cents in the early trading on the Board of Trade today and while it failed to hold the full advance, the finish was at gains of 2 1/8 to 2 1/4 cents. Deferred deliveries of corn lost 1/2 to 7/8 cent.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- After three of the sixty-four competing pro-amateur teams had tied for low best-ball honors at 66, four under par, in the one-day tournament sponsored by the Westchester County Golf Association at Quaker Ridge this afternoon, the Genway pair, Herman Barron and Charles Goldman, took first prize on a matching of cards.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- Appointment of an advisory council to assist the Department of Mental Hygiene in the expansion of the state's mental health program to cope with growing community needs was announced today by Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, with the approval of Governor Dewey.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 13 -- Successful fattening of poultry, hogs and cattle on chemically treated sawdust was reported today at a meeting of the American Chemical Society.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 13 -- A severe hurricane raked Bermuda today with winds of 100 miles an hour. No loss of life was reported and property damage was slight.
READING, Pa., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Joseph Rose's Kroger Babb of Philadelphia today won the eleventh renewal of the Reading Fair Futurity for 2-year-old trotters to open a five-day Grand Circuit meeting.

Left and right-wing factions of Local 3 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, representing Bloomingdale workers, clashed last night at a meeting at which disaffiliation from the parent union was voted.

M. C. Berg, operator, has resold the three-story dwelling at 141 West Eighty-seventh Street for the second time within five months. He acquired the property last April from Dr. Mildred C. Munier and immediately resold it to Henry J. Rorke of Cleveland, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Plans were announced today for the presentation of a panorama of a ceremony and a half of American history at Washington's Sesquicentennial Exposition two years hence.

No word yet from Moscow on prior Soviet invention of the "cloth" that's stronger than steel, which was unveiled last week by the American Chemical Society. When continuous casting of steel was announced recently the Russians shrugged it off as a steal from the steppes. Marconi has long been a well-known Muscovite.

Benjamin Lazrus, president of the Benrus Watch Company, has been named chairman of the thirty-first annual campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the federation, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

In a legal action without precedent in this state, a New York County grand jury returned a criminal information yesterday against two men, charging that they had conspired to violate the gambling laws of New Jersey.

With August output at 7,417,599 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, domestic production of raw steel in the first eight months of 1948 was raised to 57,553,535 tons, a peacetime record and more than the full year's production in every year in the nineteen-thirties, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The city's jumbled trucking situation reached new depths of confusion last night when Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, confronted employers with stiffer wage and welfare demands than those sought by striking members of Local 807.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's talk tonight to the American Association for the Advancement of Science:

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake directed the reorganization trustee of the Central Railroad of New Jersey this afternoon to pay $4,772,000 in interest for 1940-1941 on the general mortgage bonds of the line.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- In a search for more mill hands to keep production up and to increase it where possible, steel companies in this area have been forced into fields not normally related to steel manufacture, it was learned today.

Appliance dollar volume in independent furniture stores is running 10 per cent ahead of last year, a local representative of the National Retail Furniture Association reported yesterday. He attributed the steady improvement in sales since the middle of last month to a "last-minute rush" of consumers to avoid higher down payments and a shorter period to pay when consumer credit controls are restored on Sept. 20.
SKOWHEGAN, Me., Sept. 13 -- Friends thronged into the sitting room of a small white frame house here tonight to congratulate Mrs. Margaret Chase Smith on her election to the United States Senate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- The parkway network extending from New York toward Albany will be 21.11 miles nearer its destination some time in 1949, Charles H. Sells, State Superintendent of Public Works, said today in announcing award of a $4,610,524 construction contract.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- A desire for an "increasing degree of union between all the countries of Western Europe" was expressed by the British Government today through the medium of the King's speech read at the prorogation of the current session of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Soviet demands for free and unobstructed access to Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kasenkina and Mikhail Ivanovitch Samarin, the refugee school teachers, have again been refused by the United States Government, which now considers "the matter closed."

DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- A new line of heavy-duty air-cooled engines for use in military vehicles was announced today by C. J. Reese, president of the Continental Motors Corporation. The six models range from 125 to 1,040 horsepower.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- A new Fifth Avenue shop, designed to provide feminine shoppers with the latest in fashion in a luxurious setting, was previewed today by Gimbel Brothers' Philadelphia store.

CAUX, Switzerland, Sept. 13 -- Fred Copeman, ex-Communist and onetime British delegate to the Comintern, told the second World Assembly for Moral Rearmament here today that Marxist communism never could be defeated by force or military might.

Disappearance of a "key" Government witness under subpoena to testify yesterday at a deportation hearing against Claudia Jones, 33-year-old Communist leader, caused the abrupt adjournment of the proceeding, according to W. Frank Watkins, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Four service men were honored yesterday at the monthly inspection at the Naval Air Base, Floyd Bennett Field. The awards were made by Capt. Donald E. Wilcox, commanding officer of the naval air station.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Ireland has been excluded from the meeting of the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth that, it was announced tonight, will begin Oct. 11. The meeting will be attended by Prime Ministers or other prominent Ministers of nine countries, and will last probably for two weeks.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 18 points lower to 12 points net higher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The American Federation of Labor today protested to Herbert Hoover, chairman of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, against placing in the hands of Dr. Lewis Meriam the commission's social insurance study.
The first telephone call from New York to the Merchant's Limited, a New Haven train en route to Boston was put through at 5:55 P.M. yesterday.

Two drawings by Georges Pierre Seurat and a gouache and a drawing by Vincent van Gogh, the last gift of the late Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will be exhibited tomorrow on the museum's main floor for the first time.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- Public opinion about the possibilities of the United States-British air lift supplying Berlin through the winter changed radically last month, an official Military Government survey said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Countess Felicia Gizycka, only child of the late Mrs. Eleanor Medill Patterson, attacked her mother's will today, with allegations that Mrs. Patterson was of unsound mind, and the victim of fraud, deceit, undue influence, duress and coercion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Trucks are getting a steadily increasing share of the nation's freight-hauling business, the Department of Commerce said today.

Forty-two families living in four old-law tenements between Sixtieth and Sixty-first Streets on West End Avenue were ordered yesterday evening to evacuate their homes after the Fire Department found a "dangerous amount of gasoline seepage" in the cellars.

Mrs. Nancy Fletcher Choremi and two other women who had been convicted on vice charges received three-month suspended sentences when they appeared yesterday before Magistrate Arthur Markewich in Women's Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, recently retired commander of the Eigth Army in Japan, recommended today the establishment of a Japanese constabulary sufficiently strong to assure internal security.

SALEM, N. H., Sept 13 (AP) -- After coming from behind, Mort Stuart's Halbarail, the 6-4 favorite, swept past Mrs. C. C. Tanner's Colonel O'F at the sixteenth pole and won going away in the Kenmore Allowance Purse today before a 6,327 crowd at Rockingham Park.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Radio station WARL of Arlington, Va., today denied charges that a "Dollars for Answers" program it had broadcast violated the lottery section of the Communications Act.

KARACHI, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Today's invasion of Hyderabad by forces of India has caused many competent observers to fear that, if the fighting continues, a full-scale communal war might be touched off between India and Pakistan.
