WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Columbia Gas System, Inc., today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to issue an additional 1,223,000 shares of common stock.

ATHENS. Sept. 13 -- While in a supplementary report from the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans, published here today, all Greece's northern neighbors were accused of disregarding the United Nations General Assembly's injunction "to do nothing which could furnish aid and assistance" to the guerrillas fighting in Greece, Air Minister Anastasios Bakalbassis indicated that the Greek Government might bring against Yugoslavia a new charge of infringement of international law.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The United States and Britain have proposed placing Cyrenaica under a United Nations trusteeship system, with Britain as the administering authority, but they desire to postpone a decision on the remainder of Libya for one year, it was disclosed tonight.

It will be difficult to maintain the present favorable position of either the employe or the cotton textile industry itself unless the downward trend in output per employe per hour in the industry is halted, G. E. Huggins, committee chairman of the Textile Information Service, said yesterday.

Acting Sgt. Patrick B. Cline of the Fortieth Precinct will not have much time to help with his son's schoolwork this fall, it became evident yesterday. For Sergeant Cline was one of the eight candidates who won full scholarships to the Evening Division of New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Sciences.
A prediction that Henry A. Wallace would carry the three Pacific Coast stakes and some others was made yesterday by C. B. Baldwin, Progressive party campaign manager.

As summer vacations faded into pleasant memories, homework assignments became the hard reality for 1,160,500 New York children who trudged off yesterday morning for the opening of the 1948-49 academic year.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 13 -- The Indian Army invaded Hyderabad, independent Princely State situated in the middle of the Indian Dominion, this morning at 4 o'clock with troops 'supported by aircraft. The Indians encountered stiff resistance from Hyderabad forces at several important points but by afternoon had secured positions and roads thirty miles inside Hyderabad's border.

The question of Germany's democratization seems to be much debated at present in the United States. May I say, as an observer on the spot, that democracy is making very little progress in Germany -- that, indeed, its chances are rapidly deteriorating. There are many reasons for this development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- President Truman today closed an informal conference with officials of the American Hospital Association on the subject of compulsory health insurance by arranging to go more deeply into the matter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Army announced tonight that it would attempt to handle West Coast cargoes with workers hired outside union channels.

The Cunard White Star liners Queen Mary and Mauretania docked at North River piers yesterday with a combined complement of 3,141 passengers, among them Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of Boston and Basil O'Connor, president of the American Red Cross.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 13 -- The Karen revolt in Burma has reached a critical state, messages sent by secret channels to Calcutta disclosed today. The latest Karen success, according to these sources, is the capture of Shwegyin, south of Papun, after a brief battle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today advanced the date for beginning 1948-crop corn loans and purchases, under the price support program, to "time of harvest'' instead of Dec. 1, as previously announced.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Hyderabad sent an urgent appeal to the United Nations today asking for an immediate Security Council meeting to stop Indian action against the Princely State.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Full preparedness for war by the United States is the only argument that will prevent an attack by Russia, according to Capt. E. V. Rickenbacker.

After a lapse of sixty days, cotton and rayon textile exports to Cuba were resumed yesterday, according to New York exporters. Cabled advices from their agents in Cuba revealed that the Cuban Government had rescinded Resolution 530, imposed July 12, which restricted imports of American textiles.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 13 (AP) -- News that Indian troops had invaded Hyderabad touched off demonstrations today calling for Pakistan to declare war on India.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept., 13 -- Standing before more than 2,000 women tonight at the convention of the National Council of Catholic Women, Ernest A. Blaes of Washington, president of the National Council of Catholic Men, ventured an appraisal of women's modern day advantages, their shortcomings and some of the dangers which confront them.

LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The text of the Order of the Day to Indian troops invading Hyderabad by Lieut. Gen. Maharaj Shri Rajendrasinhji, commander in chief of the Dominion's southern command, as broadcast by the All-India Radio and recorded in London by Tele-radio listening post:

The New York Central Railroad sold yesterday $13,800,000 of equipment trust certificates maturing in ten years at an interest cost of about 2.65 per cent. The issue marks the road's first borrowing of this kind since last March, when it sold $12,600,000 of securities of like maturity at an interest cost of 2.486 per cent.

PHILALDELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Cardinals clung grimly to their fast-fading pennant hopes tonight as Harry (The Cat) Brecheen pitched them to an 8 -- 0 victory over the Phillies. St. Louis edged into undisputed possession of fourth place, a half-game ahead of the idle Giants and 5 1/2 games behind the pacesetting Braves.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Overeating is as bad for your teeth as it is for your figure, Dr. John H. Greene bf Philadelphia warned today at the annual meeting of the American Dental Association here.

A huge stack, which will weigh 125 tons with its mechanical equipment installed, recently has been placed aboard the Cunard White Star liner Caronia, which is under construction at John Brown's shipyard, Clydebank, Scotland.

ROME, Sept. 14 -- A vast plan to modernize agriculture in southern Italy was outlined by James D. Zellerbach, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission to Italy, in a speech that he delivered to the Marshall-Plan congress in Bari today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A policy of cooperation in Egyptian-United States relations was mutually pledged today when Ambassador Mohamed Kamel Abdul Rahim Bey presented his letters of credence to President Truman at the White House.

" The Luck of the Irish," co-starring Tyrone Power and Anne Baxter, will open an engagement this morning at the Roxy. Henry Koster directed this Twentieth Century-Fox production, which features J.M. Kerrigan, Cecil Kellaway and Lee J. Cobb.
A dividend of 60 cents a common share, payable on Sept. 30, has been voted by the American Brake Shoe Company. Other payments this year were 40 cents in March and 50 cents in June.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., Sept. 14 -- Business will be good for a long time on "a new and healthier, but perhaps slightly lower, plateau," it was predicted here today by Harry L. Erlicher, vice president of the General Electric Company in charge of purchasing and traffic.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Americans were told tonight they may "now feel confident" that France and other free nations of Europe will remain free.

NANKING, Sept. 14 -- The six-month national budget approved in July has been spent in two months, members of the Legislative Yuan learned today. They will be asked soon to approve a supplementary budget that will approximately triple the estimated national expenditures for the second half of 1948, the legislators were told in a closed session by Finance Minister Wang Yun-wu, according to legislative sources.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 14 (AP) -- Forrest S. Rutherford, Washington representative of the Republic Steel Company since 1932, died in his home here last night at the age of 67.
ALBANY, Sept. 14 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President, cautioned his party against overconfidence today in commenting on yesterday's GOP sweep in the Maine State elections.

Conflicting ideologies may end the dream of Kirkor Sarkisian, janitor who left part of his estate to build a schoolhouse as a memorial to his father in his native Armenia. This was disclosed yesterday when his niece, Huranoosh J. Geragosian of New Britain, Conn., petitioned Surrogate James A. Delehanty for a construction of her uncle's will.
William Talbert's quest for the National tennis championship, for which he has twice been runner-up, ended in the fourth round yesterday at Forest Hills.

Yesterday's bidding in the municipal bond market shows how far apart can be the opinions of underwriters risking their own money when it comes to pricing certain types of credit following upon the effectiveness of a new expedient of the official money managers.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Francis Hitchcock, wealthy sportsman, was free today to marry Stephany Saja, daughter of a Pennsylvania coal miner, when a circuit judge granted a final divorce decree to his second wife.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The United States served notice on Rumania in a note delivered in Bucharest on Sept. 7 that she would be responsible for the return of American properties seized under the Rumanian nationalization legislation or for prompt payment of adequate and effective compensation.

TOKYO, Sept. 14 -- The Communist-led union, of Japanese electrical workers tonight joined in the series of sporadic walkouts that has followed General Douglas MacArthur's order last month against strikes by government employes. Strikers pulled switches in ninety-eight Tokyo substations, darkening the capital block by block.
The Italian liner Saturnia, which was scheduled to sail yesterday at noon for the Mediterranean was delayed for at least twenty-four hours because engine-room repairs could not be completed on time.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Announcement by the Department of Agriculture that a Government loan on the 1948 corn crop would be made available at harvest time instead of on Dec. 1 as originally planned started a short covering movement in the new crop deliveries of that grain and also closing of spreads with September.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The leadership of the Republican Party hailed today Margaret Chase Smith's election to the United States Senate by a record-breaking majority, both in point of majority and percentage of total vote, as unmistakable evidence that a Republican President would be elected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The first instance in which the Taft-Hartley Act caused the office of Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, to prosecute both employer and employe in the same case, came to light today.

The Public Service Commission will hold a hearing this afternoon on consolidating the requests of thirteen privately owned bus lines for a higher fare. The commission agreed to the hearing after receiving letter from Corporation Counsel John P. McGrath.

A deep bow should be accorded Castillo for the collection presented yesterday at the Elizabeth Arden salon, 691 Fifth Avenue. Inspired by Maria Taglioni, nineteenth century ballerina who was the idol of Europe for her lightness and grace, he devised fabulous wing-like folds at the shoulders of many of his garments.

Now that Denmark has ratified the constitution of the International Refugee Organization, IRO is a respectable United Nations agency, with full power to levy assessments on its member governments and act on behalf of the displaced persons it seeks to protect and resettle.

SINING, China, Sept. 5 -- The bustling, clean-swept main street of Sining, capital of Tsinghai Province in China's northwest, presents the unusual spectacle of businessmen swatting flies with scientific precision and depositing carefully the dead pests in little paper bags.

The New York State Fair Educational Practices Act becomes effective today. The first state law of its kind in the United States, it outlaws racial and religious discrimination in the admission of students to all the state's colleges and universities.

The care of the mentally ill in the institutions of New York State no longer, can be considered apart from other mental health needs of the communities, according to authorities interviewed in a survey conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 14 -- The concussion of mortar shells fired by Arab batteries into the Jewish areas of Jerusalem echoed this morning as Israel's new Supreme Court was inaugurated formally in the same courtroom occupied for twenty-eight years by the British judiciary.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Sept. 15 -- Forty home-bound American soldiers were killed last night and at least sixty were injured when a local train crashed into two rear cars of the Korean Liberator, 120 miles south of here.

VIENNA, Sept. 14 -- Foreign Minister Karl Gruber told the Austrian Cabinet tonight that Austria was not negotiating a customs union with Italy at the moment and intimated that she had no intention of doing so under present conditions.

Selection of Harlow H. Curtice, general manager of the Buick Motor division, as executive vice president in charge of all general staff activities of the General Motors Corporation, highlighted a sweeping shakeup in the administration and organization of the corporation announced yesterday by C.E. Wilson, president.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- Striking maritime unions of the West Coast leveled a "strike-breaking" charge today against the Department of the Army. They moved at once to forestall a program, announced in Washington by Secretary Kenneth C. Royall, which calls for direct hiring of stevedores by the Army in strike-bound ports to load ships with food and other essentials for Army personnel in the Far East and the mid-Pacific.

I thoroughly agree with your editorial in THE TIMES of Sept 10, in which you comment on Mayor O'Dwyer's proclamation to extend free speech to all persons participating in political rallies on public squares and street corners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Science and engineering have developed principles, techniques and materials for the mass production of comfortable and hygienic homes, but these efforts of the scientists to solve the housing problem are being largely ignored, it was asserted here today at a symposium on housing at the centenary meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

ABOARD THE TWENTIETH CENTURY LIMITED, Sept. 14 -- This ultra-modern new $2,000,000 train is speeding along the Hudson River Valley on its way back to Grand Central Terminal in New York City after a trial run to Poughkeepsie.

The special Federal grand jury which on July 20 indicted twelve Communist leaders on conspiracy charges and which has been recessed since then reconvened at the Federal Court House; Foley Square, yesterday morning.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of New Jersey's new Supreme Court announced today assignments of twenty-six superior court judges to appellate, law and equity and county work in the revised court system.

With the city's truck tie-up getting worse instead of better at the end of its second week, Mayor O'Dwyer decided yesterday to name Hugh E. Sheridan, impartial chairman of the local trucking industry, as his personal representative in seeking a settlement of the tangled labor dispute.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Reduction of the number of corporate officers of Northwest Airlines and realignment of their official responsibilities was announced today by Croil Hunter, president. He said the moves were to "simplify the company's management."

ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICA AT SEA, 14 -- A positive proposal to establish a permanent international guard force of about 500 men to police the world's trouble spots will probably be submitted to the United Nations General Assembly at the coming session in Paris, it was learned here today.

To speed up official approvals of $150,000,000 worth of American machine tools in current order backlogs of European distributors American machine tool builders will ask the Economic Cooperation Administration to add a machine tool section, Alexander G. Bryant, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association revealed yesterday in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BERLIN, Wednesday, Sept. 15 -- The Democratic parties of Western Berlin yesterday demanded revision of the Russian sentences on five German youths for their part in last Thursday's anti-Communist disturbances, and expressed general anger at the "cruel and inhuman" penalties imposed by a Soviet military court.

That deliciously edible member of the morning glory family -- the sweet potato -- will be in short supply this season. The total crop is expected to be not only less than last year's, but as much as a fifth under the ten-year (1937-46) average.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle appeared before the Welfare Committee of the City Council yesterday to urge approval of an amendment to the Administrative Code that would define the duties of the Chief of the Fire Department in the light of the newly created post of Chief of Staff and Operations.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Commercial air lines of the world will go bankrupt unless governments stop insisting that they pay larger shares of airport and ground costs without raising rates, Sir William R. Hildred, director-general of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) said today.

It was with interest that I read the Reuters dispatch from Hamburg, Germany, in THE TIMES of Sept. 10, concerning the revival of Germany's cutlery industry at Solingen. Described were the tableware, knives and cutting instruments that were made there before the war and sold throughout the world.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- The envoys of Britain, the United States and France resumed their conferences with Foreign Minister Molotov after a fifteen-day lapse today. The Western powers were trying to bring the Berlin talks to a definite conclusion.

The first issue of a special edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, to be edited and printed in New York for circulation in Paris while the United Nations General Assembly is in session, will be shipped today by Air France and distributed in the French capital tomorrow.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 14 -- Sir Lawrence Bragg, Nobel prize winner in physics, said today that he had been moved from incredulity to admiration of the ingeniousness of the new super-microscope that was described here to the physics section of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

A hearing into the activities of the Teachers Union, Local 555, and its parent organization, the United Public Workers, CIO, will be conducted here by a subcommittee of the Committee on Education and Labor of the House of Representatives, it became known yesterday.

MADRID, Sept. 14 -- Enrique Cardinal Pla Y Deniel, Cardinal Primate of Spain, in an ecclesiastical bulletin published today in the Toledo Archidiocese, denounced for "eucharistic errors" the newest editions of the Father Ripalda catechism and prohibited its use in archdiocese schools.

We do not agree with President Truman that Congress is attempting to drag a red herring across the path of its own blunders when it investigates the tie-ups that federal employes may now have, or may have had in the past, with Communist and Communist-front organizations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration authorized another $64,971,059 of advances to seven countries today and set a new high in a single day's authorizations for the second time this week.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- The Communist-sponsored Volksrat, the self-styled "People's Parliament" for the Soviet zone has virtually put the finishing touches to a draft of a constitution for the eastern zone, reliable sources reported today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Mrs. Anita McCormick Blaine, daughter of Cyrus H. McCormick, who founded the International Harvester Company, said here today she had donated $1,000,000 for the founding of a new organization with headquarters in New York, the Foundation for World Government.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The British Government reacted today to the delicate world situation by announcing in Parliament that men due for release from the armed forces would be kept in service for an extra three months.

The invasion of the State of Hyderabad by the Dominion of India is a further tragedy for the sorrowful subcontinent. That it was not prevented long since is still another testimonial to the weakness of our machinery for keeping the peace and a witness to the shortness of national tempers.

Motion picture companies here, with one exception, have notified both the Screen Publicists Guild and the Screen Office and Professional Employes Guild, both GIO, that the companies cannot participate in contract renewal discussions because of the failure of the unions to comply with the non-Communist affidavit provision of the Taft-Hartley Law.
CAIRO, Sept. 14 -- An Arab spokesman disclosed today that Lebanese Premier Riad el Solh had offered Lebanon's services to "explore the possibilities of mediation between Hyderabad and India."

The Fire Department's Division of Combustibles used for the first time yesterday an oil separator and ejector which it had-devised to pump water and gasoline from the cellars of four evacuated tenements between Sixtieth and Sixty-first Streets on West End Avenue.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 -- The Yankees today kept the embers of their 1948 pennant hopes glowing while all but dousing those of the Indians, by downing Lou Boudreau's Tribe, 6 to 5, in a nerve-tingling game. This was the final meeting of these two rivals this year and drew 34,064 onlookers.

A trial of five members of the National Maritime Union, CIO, two of whom are former officials of the union, began yesterday. The men are charged with being ring-leaders of a mob that held a meeting in the union's hall unconstitutionally and over the head of David Drummond, New York port agent.

GENOA, Italy, Sept. 14 -- The parliamentary and business representatives and trade experts from thirty-five countries met here today to consider the ways and means of expanding international trade. This first "congress" of its kind gathered in stately Saint George's Hall, rebuilt after having suffered heavy bomb damage, amid the symbols of power and splendor of the medieval city-states' merchant rulers.
PARIS, Sept. 14 -- The United Nations Security Council was summoned today to meet in special session on Thursday to consider Hyderabad's plea for action against the invasion of the State by India.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 14 -- Indian troops converging on the capital city of Hyderabad made important gains today against strong opposition and counter- attacks by forces of the independent Princely States, an Indian Defense Ministry communique said tonight.

Plans for a national unified armed services prestige advertising campaign to open on Armistice Day were approved yesterday at a meeting in the White House of representatives of the Army, Air Force, Navy, Marine Corps, the Advertising Council and the staff of John H. Steelman.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Ellis Kinder's five-hit pitching and Ted Williams' clouting, which drove across three runs, carried American League-leading Boston to a 4-1 triumph over the last-place White Sox before 15,622 fans at Comiskey Park tonight.
New Danish silver patterns plus the latest decorative vases from several Swedish glass factories were shown yesterday by R.F. Brodegaard Co., Inc., 225 Fifth Avenue.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 14 -- The Connecticut Republican convention today chose Governor James C. Shannon by acclamation to run for his first full term as Governor.

A substitute teacher's two-year fight to obtain a regular teaching license in the New York public school system has been lost because he allegedly was "untruthful and evasive" about reported membership in a Communist youth organization, it was learned yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Sept.14 -- The son of President Chiang Kai-shek today threatened to seize Shanghai factories if they try to shut down because of the Government's freeze of prices.

Operations of Goodall-Sanford, Inc., manufacturer of suitings and other textiles, and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended with last June, resulted in a net income of $2,133,658 after taxes and all charges, Elmer L. Ward, president, reported yesterday.

Spanish language interpreters to aid in registering draft eligibles were asked for yesterday by Col. Gandler Cob, city Selective Service director, who said that the language problems of Harlem youths of Puerto Rican origin were resonsible for the slow-moving lines at the Haaren and Julia Richman High Schools.

Approval of a number of rule changes, among them a completely revised set-up for the registration of kennel names, was granted by the delegates of the American Kennel Club at their quarterly meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.
Mixing pleasure with business proved the undoing yesterday morning of a Times Square gunman, who prefaced an unsuccessful hold-up attempt with a liberal drinking bout.

An all-day discussion of air line leases at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, by officials of the Port of New York Authority and representatives of nine major air lines ended late yesterday afternoon with the announcement that "satisfactory progress was made."

The operations of a stock market forecaster who for thirty-two years has been divining his tips from secret code messages that he says were hidden by big Wall Street manipulators in a newspaper comic strip were halted yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 14 -- A resolution branding the Kinsey report as "an insult to the American people" was under consideration here today at the convention of the National Council of Catholic Women. It also assailed the report as "a disservice to the nation which can only lead to immorality."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Members of the American Federation of Labor will be called upon to raise a million dollar war fund to be used to defeat eight United States Senate candidates and 113 Congressional aspirants in the coming November election.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 14 -- Bermuda was rapidly being restored to normal today following the hurricane yesterday. Although no accurate estimate of the total damage was possible yet, the consensus was that the colony escaped with considerably less effects than in the hurricane here last year, when the over-all figure of 100,000 ($400,000) was given as the damage estimate.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Stewart McDonald of 570 ParkAvenue, New York, Palm Beach, Fla., and this community, gave a supper-dance this evening in the gardens of Cherrywood, their estate on Piping Rock Road, to introduce to society Mrs. McDonald's daughter, Miss Signa J. Lynch.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- In the newly named British Victory tournament, Joseph Gagliardi of Winged Foot, recent winner of the Westchester amateur golf title, and Doug Ford of Bonnie Briar, the 1947 Westchester champion, shared the opening round honors today with scores of 74 at the Metropolis Country Club.

Reporters, editors and publishers of The Journal Of Commerce set their own type by four different methods last night to get the paper out in spite of a continued walkout of composing room and mailing room employes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized Madison Gas and Electric Company, of Madison, Wis., to borrow $2,000,000 from banks on an eighteen-month note.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- White Feathered Goose stuck out her neck, spread her wings and streamlined to victory today, thus successfully defending for the third time the Scandinavian Gold Cup which she brought from Finland ten years ago to the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The British Government said today that it "deplored the very unfortunate state of affairs" in Hyderabad. The statement made by Viscount Addison, Government leader in the House of Lords, during the opening debate of the session of Parliament that began this afternoon.

Relative control of tuberculosis in disease-ridden Europe as a result of large-scale employment of BCG vaccine, initiated early this summer, was forecast yesterday by Dr. Henry F. Helmholz, chief medical consultant for the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

Ceramic pieces by Wayne Long in the new exhibit at America House, 485 Madison Avenue, could add decorative accents to table tops or walls. The vases and plates in the group have textured finishes or rich colors such as orangy red. Sculptured figurines are whimsical.

The hurricane that struck Bermuda on Monday was continuing northeastward yesterday in the Atlantic and endangering shipping in the busy sea lanes, according to The Associated Press. Its speed was expected by the Weather Bureau to increase in the next twenty-four hours.

An industry code governing the use of comparative prices in fur advertising will be adopted by the Greater New York Furriers Association within "four or five weeks," Charles Gold, legal counsel for the association announced yesterday following a meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

Molding a revue to lure the hit trade is probably the most exacting and laborious task confronting even hardened producers. Innumerable factors must dovetail just so before the finished product smacks of success. The expense attached to floating such a hazardous undertaking isn't insignificant, either.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- Scores of persons suffered minor injuries or were overcome by tear gas today when more than 2,000 striking oil workers, members of CIO unions, tried to stop maintenance workers, who are AFL men, in crossing picket lines around the Richmond Refinery of the Standard Oil Company of California.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Herbert C. Hoover returned a soft answer today to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who complained yesterday that the-Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government had placed its social insurance study in the hands of Dr. Lewis Meriam, vice president of the Brookings Institution.

A warning against "undue complacency and exaggerated optimism" on the final outcome of the political and military struggles still in progress in Israel was sounded yesterday by Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 -- The importance of caring for the new infant in such a way that it will grow into a well-adjusted normal child and adult is stressed in a publication by the State Health Department.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Six educational institutions were among the beneficiaries of the will of Charles Evans Hughes.
By proclamation of President Truman, National, Guard Day will be celebrated tomorrow throughout the nation.

Mobile County, Ala., sold yesterday $2,000,000 of school tax warrants maturing from 1949 to 1965 to a banking group headed by Equitable Securities Corporation at an interest cost of 2.79 per cent. The bid was 99.26 for 2 3/4s.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Eddie Joost batted safely five straight times and Ferris Fain batted in four runs as the Athletics with nineteen hits, slammed their way to a 12-2 victory over the Browns tonight. Philadelphia picked up 10 tallies in the first three innings, five of them in the third.

A 67-year old tailor who was fond of playing the violin on his doorstep for the entertainment of children in the neighborhood was found dead yesterday morning in the back of his shop at 265 East Tenth Street, a hand towel knotted around his face.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,590, compared with 550 last week and 1,221 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,279 arrivals yesterday against 146 last Tuesday.

ONE of the more spectacular publicity stunts evolved by the Tournament of Champions organization for promoting the Tony Zale-Marcel Cerdan middleweight championship fight in Jersey City next Tuesday was to import Cerdan's compatriot, Gorgeous Georges Carpentier, as an al fresco good-will ambassador. The famed Orchid Man of France has been wandering about our village for quite a few days now.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Bettye Mims White of Dallas, tournament medalist, and Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, a strong contender, chalked up victories today in first-round matches of the forty-eighth women's national amateur golf championship.
PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Premier Henri Queuille obtained a vote postponing interpellations in the National Assembly today by 340 to 227.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Hatch Act prohibiting "pernicious political activities" by Federal employes was denounced today by President Truman and Attorney General Tom C. Clark before an audience of about 130 United States attorneys and their relatives in the Rose Garden of the White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Paul A. Fitzpatrick, Democratic chairman in New York State, told President Truman today he would carry the state, but strongly urged two campaign swings, one through upstate cities and the other in New York City.
The Communist party has ordered the formation of a third labor federation in competition with the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor, it was charged yesterday.

Station WHN, second oldest in the city, formally changes its call letters to WMGM in a special three-hour program this evening, starting at 8 o'clock. The headquarters of the outlet also will be moved today from Loew's State Theatre Building on Broadway to 711 Fifth Avenue.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 14 -- A man-made vitamin, a chemical derivative of the natural vitamin K, protects foods from spoilage, according to a report to the American Chemical Society today by four representatives of the University of California's College of Pharmacy.

Because four newborn puppies were deprived of their own mother's milk and love, Mrs. Robert Adamson of 205 West Tenth Street issued a plea yesterday for a qualified canine volunteer to become their foster mother for three weeks.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Henry A. Wallace stood tonight on a towering blue platform in Wrigley Field and hurled a challenge at the Illinois Supreme Court, which earlier in the day had denied places on the Nov. 2 ballot to him and other state-wide candidates of the Progressive party.

Atomic energy workers must guard against occupational illnesses similar to the effects noted in those exposed to benzol, the annual meeting of the International Association of Industrial Accident Boards and Commissions was told yesterday.

Considerable doubt was expressed during the war as to whether all United States soldiers knew what they were fighting for. The late Robert Johnstone of Dowlington, Pa., who died in the Philippines while a member of the Army, had a good answer to that question, and he did something about it.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 14 -- With 75,000 exhibits, including a champion stuffed albatross, prize oxen and obsolete farm and household utensils linked with the early history of Long Island, the Mineola County Fair opened today for its 106th season.

PARIS, Wednesday, Sept. 15 -- Representatives of the Big Four, having failed to reach an agreement on the future of Italy's former colonies, decided this morning to present the case to the United Nations General Assembly for its recommendations.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Johnny Sain, righthanded ace of the Braves, entered the National League's inner pitching circle by becoming a twenty-game winner for the third season today with a 10-3 victory over the Cubs as Boston increased its league lead to five games.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 15 -- Russian authorities returned to the American zone today one of the two United States air lift fliers who parachuted over the Soviet zone yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer, in addressing the Building Officials Conference, of America, gave the people of New York some insight into the problems the city faces in its capital budget. He told, for instance, of an increase of 145 per cent over 1939 levels in construction costs. Sewer costs have multiplied three times.
LONDON, Sept 14 -- Something like a showdown between the Western powers and the Soviet Union is believed here to have taken place in Kremlin tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 President Truman's speech last night assailing what he called the "vilification" of scientists employed by the Government was warmly praised today by William A. Higinbotham, vice chairman of the Federation of American Scientists, and associated head of the Electronics Division of the Brookhaven National Laboratory at Upton, N.Y.

In token of tomorrow's hopes of international peace and amity, the United Nations broke ground here yesterday for its world headquarters. The half-hour ceremony, in which Mayor O'Dwyer joined, symbolized New York's good-will and friendship for an organization that has now become officially part of the city's life.

American industrial production is the ace-in-the-hole on the nation's diplomatic front, it was pointed out yesterday by Charles Luckman, president of Lever Brothers Company and former head of the President's Citizens Food Committee.

Bloomingdale's presented yesterday for fall its Green Room styles. Featured were coats falling from natural shoulders in supple folds, suits of tweed and others of broadcloth in citifed moods. Slim wools, satins and silk taffetas for winter's formal functions were shown.

John Rosenblum, Inc., submitted the lowest bid, $1,027,000, for the excavation and foundation construction contract of the Pelham Parkway Houses, Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, announced yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer was taken to task mildly yesterday for his declaration that city engineers had "found 25 per cent to 30 per cent padding" on bids for construction of hospitals and schools. The reply came from Joseph G. Fink, counsel for the Building Traders Employers Association of New York City, who said "there is a sinister connotation in the suggestion of padding."

Something has been wrong with this summer, and it requires very little research to find what it is. To put the matter bluntly, no great and outstanding event has taken place. Late in the spring a fisherman rode a whale off Provincetown, but neither swallowed the other, and so that was only a minor sensation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -Another Congressional investigation of the leasing of the Government-owned blast furnace at Cleveland, Ohio, to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation was announced today.

Because a few boys wanted to see what would happen if they forced an escalator to stop, two women were in City Hospital and several other passengers left the Fifty-third Street and Lexington Avenue Station of the IND line yesterday morning with cuts and bruises.
Random notes:

OTTAWA, Sept. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's 1948 wheat harvest was placed at 391,000,000 bushels today in the second estimate of the Bureau of Statistics. This compares with harvests of 340,767,000 bushels in 1947 and 413,725,000 in 1946. The first estimate of the 1948 harvest, made onto Aug. 17, was 372,000,000.
LONDON, Sept.14 -- The gold share gamble in the stock market showed signs of spreading today despite the fact that it was the last day of the account.

The Paris meeting on the disposition of the Italian colonies is a farcical performance. Today is the deadline fixed by the Italian peace treaty for Big Four decision on this question. Last night's failure to agree evoked decision to turn it over to the General Assembly of the United Nations.

Local 1250 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union of America, CIO, Was enjoined last night in a Federal court order signed by Judge Samuel H. Kaufman from further picketing of the Oppenheim Collins Co. stores, it was announced by Gordon K. Greenfield, secretary-treasurer of the company.

EAGLES MERE, Pa., Sept. 14 -- The American Association of Public Opinion Research declined today to adopt a code of professional standards and practices submitted by six of its members, and decided to await further developments of survey techniques and science before establishing such a code.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- More than one out of every ten working persons in this country is employed by Government, Federal, state or local.

A first novel by David Ballantyne, a New Zealand newspaper man, has been scheduled for publication next month by Vanguard. It will be entitled "The Cunning-hams." The author received recently a grant of u100 from the State Literary Fund Committee, set up by the New Zealand Government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- Enterprise, the Charles Einfeld-David Loew Motion Picture Company formed nearly three years ago, will abandon production for an "indefinite period" as soon as three films, now in the cutting rooms, are delivered to their distributor, M-G-M, it was learned today.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Newark broke out of its long batting slump tonight with a rash of extra base hits, including a pair of home runs by Ken Silvestri, to thump Syracuse, 12 -- 5, in the opening game of their first-round Shaughnessy play-off series before 3,194 fans.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Rate schedules that would cost telephone subscribers an additional $16,036,000 were filed today by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company with the Public Utilities Commission. All classes of telephone service throughout New Jersey would be affected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- The premiere here last night of Ruth Gordon's "Leading Lady," in which the author-actress starred, was well received, the audience according the star six curtain calls. It was Chicago's first premiere since "The Glass Menagerie" at the end of 1944.

A funeral service for Alexander E. Patterson, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, was held yesterday morning in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, officiated.

Georges Hirsch, director of the Paris Opera and a former group leader in the French resistance movement, denied yesterday charges that Serge Lifar, maitre de ballet of the opera, had collaborated with the Germans during the occupation of France.

The stock market experienced yesterday an abrupt reversal of form which eliminated the losses incurred in the two preceding sessions. Prices rallied as much as 2 points in key issues. The composite rate rose 0.93 point under the leadership of the steels, particularly United States Steel.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Favorites came through with ease today in the first round of the open match-play championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association over the upper course of the Baltusrol Golf Club.

Faraway of the Glen. Riddle Farms left all the others way back in the one-mile Castleton Purse at Belmont Park yesterday. Ridden by Larney Hansman and carrying only 105 pounds, the 3-year-old son of War Relic romped to an eight-length victory over WL Sickle, who, in turn had a head over Doubtless II.

Walter F. White, secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, will receive a leave with pay, for one year, beginning about Dec. 1, the association announced yesterday. The reason given was Mr. White's health.

The Brooklyn Trust Company instituted suit yesterday in Kings County Supreme Court for $250,000 damages against Local 96, Financial Employes Guild, and its parent union, the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO, as well as eleven of their officials.

Jim Thorpe, former great all-around American athlete, was announced as trainer for the Israel national soccer team at a United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York luncheon at Toots Shor's yesterday. Haim Glovinsky, president of the Israel Football Association, made the announcement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A House subcommittee on Un-American Activities voted unanimously late today to cite for contempt a Communist party official who, it reported, had refused to answer "most pertinent questions" concerning Soviet attempts to "obtain our atomic bomb secrets."

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 14 -- The record breaking personal triumph of United States Representative Margaret Chase Smith today paced the Republican ticket to a virtual sweep in a Maine election which Republicans throughout the country deem highly significant in a Presidential year.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Kwaja Nazimuddin was sworn in today as Acting Governor General of Pakistan. He succeeds Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder of the Dominion, who died suddenly on Saturday.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 14 Trail, 7-to-10 choice of the crowd of 7,664, today won the New Shoreman Purse at Narragansett Park. The 3-year-old daughter of High Breeze led throughout the six-furlong sprint to beat C.S. Popovitz' Scotch Bim by a length.

The hide futures market declined in yesterday's trading on the Commodity Exchange. Prices closed 10 to 30 points net lower, eliminating nearly half the gains on Monday. Transactions were seventy-three lots aggregating 2,920,000 pounds. The heaviest trading was in the December delivery, which closed off 30 points. Some switching was recorded.

PARIS, Sept. l4 -- The French Government hopes by Friday to plan the next stage in its continuing battle against inflation. Victory in this battle would enable France to remain eligible for dollar aid under the Marshall Plan and to play out her allotted role in European recovery.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Texas Democrats today promised their twenty-three electoral votes to President Truman, ejected four anti-Truman delegations, and roared applause to a keynoter who called for total party loyalty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Former President Herbert Hoover, chairman of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, declared today that it was "transcendently important" that there be "bold and drastic steps" to achieve greater governmental efficiency and economy.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Two leaders in the men's clothing industry today called for lower prices as a means of boosting sales volume in men's wear stores.

JOHN FRANCIS TOYE, distinguished English music critic, should be a happy man, in spite of the state of the world which offends his aristocratic tastes and convictions. Mr. Toye has spent most of his life doing exactly what he wanted to do. He loved his work and excelled in numerous subdivisions of it. He loved good food, good wine and good company, and always had plenty of them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- President Truman said in a letter released today it was "entirely improper" for a senator to attempt to "put the heat" on officials of the Executive Branch of the Government.
GREEN LAKE, Wis., Sept. 14 -William H. Jasspon, president of the Perkins Oil Company of Memphis, Tenn., today urged a three-point government program on oilseed crops. He proposed:

The fall and winter look is luxurious, according to Martin's in Brooklyn, where a fashion show was presented yesterday. Deep fur capes trimmed both fitted and flaring winter coats shown in new shades of cinnamon and fawn.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- The top United States officials in Germany are decidedly pessimistic about the prospect of reaching a satisfactory agreement with the Russians over Berlin or the future of Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Scientists took stock here today of what science had wrought in the past hundred years and visioned a dark outlook for the human race in the next century. They linked this outlook to overpopulation and the dwindling of natural resources, both of which are the direct consequences of progress in science and technology.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Senators sank to their fourteenth straight defeat today by dropping a double-header to the Tigers. Hal Newhouser hurled a six-hit game winning the opener, 2 to 1, in eleven innings and Virgil Trucks limited Washington to three hits in taking the nightcap, 12 to 1.
In Cavanagh's in West Twenty-third Street yesterday golden brew poured freely from beakers, oysters came up crisply brown, and beefsteak melted smoothly on the diners' tongues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Following is the correspondence between President Truman and David P. Findling, Associate General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, on the case of the International Typographical Union.

As persons concerned with the refugee problem for the past two and a half years, we strongly endorse your editorial of Sept. 5 disapproving the decision of the United States, Britain, Brazil and the Netherlands in the U.N. Economic and Social Council to send back "unaccompanied" children to countries of origin within the Soviet sphere.
PHILADELPHIA Sept. 14 (AP) -- Joe Louis said tonight he wasn't sure he wants to retire as the world heavyweight boxing champion and would take the full six months to make up his mind.
Happy days are in store for the New York Football Giants in the immediate future if what they accomplished against the Chicago Bears last night at the Polo Grounds may be used as a standard.

The City Council at its meeting yesterday made short shrift of a resolution calling for a boycott of British-manufactured goods and movies by the city and its people until Great Britain "ceases active and passive support of the nations attacking Israel."

Thousands of Long Island Rail Road commuters were delayed up to an hour in getting home yesterday evening as a result of a fire in an empty train near Woodside Both eastbound and westbound trains were stalled until the fire was extinguished at 5:15 P.M.

Pennant hopes are crashing after the manner of the 1929 stock market. Having had their own flag aspirations so recently shattered by the Giants, the Dodgers yesterday turned on the upstart Pirates and battled them down in both ends of a double-header, 8 -- 5 and 7 -- 3, at Ebbets Field.

With strong interest shown on new finishes and colors, a new record for attendance was set yesterday at the opening of the spring (1949) leather show of the Tanners Council of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A steady stream of complaints from owners that the post-war American motorcar is difficult to drive and park, and costly to garage and to repair, was announced yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York, 28 East Seventy-eighth Street.

The Indiana and Michigan Electric Company yesterday sold an issue of $25,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds to a banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation. The transaction was the first substantial test of the nigh-grade bond market since threats of higher bank reserve requirements brought a firmer tone to basic money rates.

More than thirty-five industrialh) 0*0*0*iengineers from leading oil, chemical, mining, paper, electrical products and metal products industries participated in first sessions of the five-day training course on industrial experimentation which opened at Columbia University on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The State Department, it was revealed today, has formally charged Robert C. Alexander, assistant chief of its visa division, with misconduct and neglect of duty as a result of his testimony before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee in July that subversive agents from Communistcontrolled countries had entered the United States as employes of the United Nations.h)0*0*0*iO

The Board of Estimate has rejected unanimously the proposals of the Port of New York Authority and the state-chartered World Trade Corporation for rehabilitation and development of city piers, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

Military engagements are usually won by that side having the greater concentration of force at a particular place at a particular time. This, however, does not rule out the possibility of an individual taking a strong hand in a situation and thus turning the tide.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall called today for "genuine spirit of tolerance and understanding" as "the first ingredient in making the kind of world we want." In an address upholding the efficacy of the United Nations before a luncheon of the Federal Bar Association in the Department of Justice, he said:

Sharp expansion of the industrial use of plastics in proved fields, particularly the urea-formaldehyde thermo-setting type, was predicted here yesterday by W. W. Knighth) 0*0*0*iJr., general manager of the plaskon division of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company.

Reflecting labor difficulties in California, the nation's crude oil production recorded last week the sharpest drop in years. Output was estimated by the American Petroleum Institute at an average of 5,346,050 barrels daily, a drop of 185,400 barrels from the record level of 5,531,450 in the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The effect of the recent action of the Democratic State Central Committee of Louisiana was to prevent the appearance on the November ballot of a set of candidates for Presidential and Vice Presidential electors under pledge to cast their votes, if chosen by a majority at the polls, for President Truman and Senator Barkley.

WALGROVE SNOOD -- a man immensely interested in books he will never read -closed his newspaper half an hour after the 5:58 for Niblickdale left the Pennsylvania Station and explained lavishly what is wrong with the contemporary American novel.

Starting a series of fashion shows, B. Altman Co. presented a collection of Jacques Heim originals with their American adaptations plus a group of their Young Colony styles yesterday afternoon on the third floor of the store.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Women leaders at Republican headquarters today hailed the Maine election of Representative Margaret Smith as a "boost to all qualified women who aspire to public office." At Democratic headquarters women were jubilant over the imminent return of former Representative Chase Going Woodhouse of Connecticut to the political arena as a candidate.
The life expectancy of the leftist Greater New York CIO Council was shortened appreciably yesterday as the result of a move by right-wing forces in the State CIO Council.
Sales and earnings above last year were reported yesterday by Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., and Abraham Straus, Inc., both controlled by Federated Department Stores, Inc.
The cotton futures market continued to hold within a narrow range yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final prices were 4 points higher to 2 points lower than the previous close.

Your editorial of Sept. 13, "Population and Food", dealt with just half of the problem posed in the title, so that it seems appropriate to discuss some of the means and plans now being worked on to help solve the other half.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Britain's civil defense system, which won world renown in the London blitz but disintegrated after the war, is to be partly revived and eventually revised to meet the threat of new weapons and new methods of warfare.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Defiance of Congressional investigation into alleged Communist activities spread to a second House inquiry group today.
ANTWERP, Belgium, Sept. 15 -- Prof. Auguste Piccard sailed from here today aboard the Belgian vessel Sealdis, mothership of his deep-sea expedition.

In a continuation of the stampede that engulfed William Talbert, Tom Brown Jr. and Billy Sidwell of Australia on Tuesday, Gardnar Mulloy and Adrian Quist came to their undoing yesterday in the national amateur tennis championship at Forest Hills.

Somewhat battered and bruised after two straight setbacks, the New York Football Yankes will open their home campaign tonight against Baltimore. It was the renovated Colts who started Ray Flaherty's club on the skids ten days ago.

The cost of industrial accidents to the employer and workers in this country totals at least $6,000,000,000 to $7,000,000,000 annually, John R. Kumpel of the United Rubber, Cork, Linoleum and Plastic Workers of America, CIO, estimated yesterday.

Citation was kept behind the scenes, but Warren Wright's Calumet Farm had a couple of capable understudies to the 3-year-old champion on the job in the seventyninth running of the Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 15 -Indian troops captured Aurangabad, a city of nearly one million inhabitants and second largest in Hyderabad, without resistance this morning after troops of the Princely State had evacuated the historic former capital of the Mogul Emperors, an Indian communique announced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Ras H. S. Imru, Ethiopian Minister to the United States, was requested to leave the diplomatic section in Constitution Hall here Monday night at the session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science addressed by President Truman, it was disclosed today.

Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, charged last night that an "advance man" for Governor Dewey and the Republican National Committeeman from California had rented an empty stadium to bar use of the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles by President Truman when he speaks in that city next Thursday.

Ground will be broken tomorrow afternoon for a new school at Tomkins Avenue and Hill Street, Stapleton, S.I., the Board of Education announced yesterday. Mayor O'Dwyer will give the principal address and will turn the first spadeful of earth.
The State of Tennessee announced yesterday that it would receive bids Sept. 29 on bond issues totaling $12,000,000. Dated Oct. 15, 1948, the bonds will mature Oct. 15 from 1950 to 1952.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Mr. Buster, recently claimed by C. W. Pershall from the Rarco Stable for $10,000, won today against seven 3-year-old rivals in the six-furlong Board of Freeholders Purse.
Anjour division of Campana Sales Company (the perfume "Apropos"), to the Muriel Johnstone division of Hixson-O'Donnell Advertising, Inc. National magazines and newspapers.

Where and how man first made a fire only some ages-dead cave dweller could tell us. There is no secret, though, as to how the fires are set in our forests that yearly burn over 30,000,000 acres of woodland, destroying enough timber to build 86,000 five-room houses or furnish enough pulp for newsprint for all the country's newspapers.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 15 (AP) -- O. K. Laroque, a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, urged bankers today to be "cautious and realistic" in home financing.

GENOA, Italy, Sept. 15 -- Permanent discrimination against United States trade in the markets of Europe, South America and the British Commonwealth was advocated by a British economist today in a paper delivered at the Genoa Congress for the Development of International Trade.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 15 -Mrs. T. U. Lyman of Maplewood was defeated in the New Jersey State Women's Gold Championship, 4 and 3, by Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. at the Baltusrol Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -Indiana and Illinois appealed today to the Federal Power Commission for help in averting a curtailment of supplies of natural gas which an Indiana state official said would throw 35,000 men out of work in his state.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower praised the nation's railroad industry yesterday for its "forwardlooking attitude." He spoke at ah)0*0*0*itrackside ceremony in Grand Central Terminal sponsored by the New York Central System to dedicate its new Twentieth Century Limited.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The American Airlines, Inc., today opened arguments for the certificated airlines before the Civil Aeronautics Board in opposition to requested certification of airlines proposed for the exclusive haulage of freight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Publicly reported cash dividend payments by United States corporations last July aggregated $498,200,000, or 10 per cent more than the $451,400,000 reported in July of last year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

If a proposed draft of renegotiation regulations now being circulated in industry for comment by Secretary of Defense James V. Forrestal is adopted, normal advertising and sales expenses will be considered a necessary cost of doing business before determination of profit in renegotiation of defense contracts, it became known yesterday.

In the second largest post-war daily turnover, sales of cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday totaled 325 lots. Although there was active buying on a scale down, rallying power was feeble and prices closed 75 to 115 points lower.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Contrasting the falling prices of wheat on the farms with rising costs ofh)0*0*0*ibread, Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, warned today that an economic crash of unprecedented proportions would come "soon" unless prompt action was taken to prevent further breaks in farm prices.

Walter S. Mack Jr., chairman of a committee to screen suggestions for the erection of New York City's memorial to those who served in World War II, declared yesterday that he had resigned his position to help settle differences between those who favor a usable memorial and those who favor the symbolic.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 15 -The plan for a European assembly to achieve unity on the Continent is still regarded coldly by Belgium and the Netherlands as unrealistic approach to the problem and premature at this time.

The appointment of a temporary and a permanent receiver for National Airlines, Inc., was asked in a derivative stockholder's suit filed in Federal Court yesterday against the line and George T. Baker, its president and principal stockholder.
The Maritime Commission will investigate alleged discriminatory shipping policies of South American countries, it became known here yesterday.

Primary elections on Tuesday in a half dozen states tended chiefly to confirm the availability of present holders of national and state offices. Senator Ball in Minnesota and Senator Johnson in Colorado, Governor Bradford in Massachusetts and Governor Gibson in Vermont, all won easy victories.

h)0*0*0*iOROME, Sept. 15 -- The failure of the Big Four to reach a decision on the final disposition of the former Italian colonies was learned with great disappointment and not a little resentment in Italy.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 15 -- Sir Frank Whittle, Britain's pioneer designer of jet engines, told representatives of fifty air lines here today that most of their troubles, technical and commercial, would be resolved if they prepared for the use of high-speed planes driven by turboprop engines.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 15 -Seventeen scientists and research technicians of Princeton University and other Princeton institutions will receive Certificates of Merit here on Sept. 24 at a joint Army-Navy ceremony, it was announced today. Maj. Gen. Arthur A. White, head of the Ninth Infantry Division, will make the presentations in Nassau Hall.

George Hewitt, former Communist party functionary whose disappearance on Monday caused adjournment of a deportation hearing against Claudia Jones, leading woman Communist, was a witness yesterday in another proceeding at the Department of Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue.

The failure of the Hukbalahaps to take advantage of the amnesty offered to them by the Philippine Government and accepted by their leader, Communist Luis Taruc, would seem to prove two things about the movement. First, the refusal of all but a few to turn in or register their arms would indicate that Taruc does not have the control he would like the world to believe that he has.

Employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries will be offered sometime in December, the right to purchase about 1,400,000 shares of the company's capital stock at a price $20 below the market price when payment, through payroll deduction is completed.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin, goaded by United States criticisms, made a spirited defense before the House of Commons today of Britain's role in fostering European unity.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Despite references in the House of Commons yesterday to the uncertainty of the international situation the stock market here today made a good start on the new account.

Asking $500,000 in damages, Oppenheim Collins Co. charged in a suit filed in Federal court yesterday that Local 1250 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, had violated the Taft-Hartley Act by continuing to strike and picket against its stores after another union had been certified as collective bargaining representative for its employees.
h)0*0*0*iKANSAS CITY, Sept. 15 (AP) -The House Small Business Committee was urged today to recommend legislation restoring the steel pricing system.

Monte Proser, in association with Ned C. Litwack, will introduce this evening at the Century Theatre the week's second musical offering, "Heaven on Earth." Of the opinion that there is a definite trend toward the old-fashioned musical form, Mr. Proser and his associate have organized what they describe as "a hoofing show," with little or no emphasis on the ballet.

These are the days of fish stories, for the anglers who labored on the waters during the spring and summer but failed to take the big one refuse to be thwarted by such mundane things as fact. Even the long table at the Anglers' Club is rather short for some of the tales which flow around its rim.

A syndicate represented by Harold L. Luxenburg, attorney, has purchased the fifteen-story office and apartment building at 36 Central Park South from Adolphe Kramer in a transaction negotiated by Cushman Wakefield, Inc.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Britain, France and the United States now are planning to appeal to the United Nations unless the Moscow negotiations to remove the Soviet blockade of Berlin show definite signs of succeeding within the next few days, it was strongly indicated here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -Harry Bridges' striking longshore union accused the United States Army of strike-breaking today. The charge followed an announcement from Secretary Royall that troops will be used to load military cargoes at strike-bound West Coast ports if direct hiring andh)0*0*0*icontract fail.

Abraham Landres, 45-year-old druggist, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of having dispensed the wrong drug in fillingh) 0*0*0*ia prescription with the result that the customer died. The defendant, who faces a maximum sentence of three years, was convicted after trial before Justices Irving Ben Cooper, Thomas F. Doyle and Frank Oliver.

TOKYO, Sept. 15 -- The strike of Japanese electric power workers continued today. The Japanese press says power strikes are in progress in thirty-five communities including Tokyo and are planned in regions embracing all central Japan for Sept. 20.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- An advisory council representing industry, labor and agriculture began today a study of pricing policies for a Senate subcommittee with a view toward possible recommendations of legislation to clarify present anti-trust statutes.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey completed plans today for the first phase of his campaign for President at an all-day conference with leading advisers. Afterward Herbert Brownell Jr., his campaign manager, said the Republicans will make the most intensive drive in the modern history of the party to secure his election and retain control of Congress.
Incumbents almost to a man swept the top races in Tuesday's primary elections in seven states.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Nobody knows where it will be, but the first game of the world series will be played Oct. 6 in the home city of the team which wins the National League pennant.

High construction costs and possible means of effecting economies occupied the attention of the Building Officials Conference of America and the Building Officials Foundation in their joint meeting yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

When your Nature Editor, whose writings always make delightful reading, finished his effort on "Berries and Berries," we have no doubt he leaned back in his swivel chair with a twinkle in his eye and mumbled, "Now we will get something started!" We will rise to the bait.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Tom Robbins of Winged Foot, the former Texan who is making his debut in Westchester senior golf competition with this tournament held a two-stroke lead at the half-way mark of the Westchester Association championship by scoring 37, 35 - 72, two over par, at the Westchester Hills course today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 15 -- The fast-growing Communist activity in Indonesia will be outlawed and fought by the Government "with all the legal means at its disposal," it was announced today simultaneously in Batavia and The Hague.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -A Federal Court today issued an injunction halting temporarily twin inquiries into the collapse of a $10,000,000 stock issue of the Kaiser-Fraser Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Scientists working on means for utilizing atomic energy as a vast new source of power are already studying the possible harnessing of the atom in the propulsion ofh)0*0*0*ispace ships which would escape the gravitational field of the earth.

Giuseppe Berto, whose novel, "The Sky Is Red," will be published by New Directions Sept. 30, is young Italian war veteran who enlisted in the army because he could not find a job on his graduation from high school. He served for four years in Ethiopia and in North Africa, where he was captured by French troops fighting with the British Eighth Army.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Marked advance of women in political and civic life the world over was reported here today by fifty young women leaders of twentysix countries, here to take a special post-war reconstruction training course of the Young Women's Christian Association.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- Street fighting broke out briefly in Paris today for the first time since the November general strike as new strikes spread through the Paris region and the provinces. It was at a moment when the new Queuille Government was asking calm and the de Gaulle organization announced the launching of a nationwide poster campaign calling for new elections.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -Senator Ferguson Republican of Michigan, heatedly denied today that Congress is to blame for irregularities in the export control program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -After a breakdown in contract negotiations between the Screen Writers Guild and the Artists Managers Guild, the writers resolved by a membership vote that no member of their group shall sign or renew a contract with an author's agent unless the agent is franchised, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Secretary of State Marshall indicated at his weekly news conference today that the negotiations with the Soviet Union over the Berlin blockade as well as other recent developments in East-West relations had produced little encouragement.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, said today that a "tense situation" had developed in Yugoslavia's relations with Rumania and Hungary because of their attempts to stir up a revolt against Premier Tito and because of punitive measures taken in those countries against any elements sympathizing with the Yugoslav party leadership.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. said today that labor's campaign in the coming election to defeat members of Congress who voted for the Taft-Hartley Act would be a "dismal failure."

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- The Soviet Union intends to use the question of the former Italian colonies as a starting point for an all-out attack in the United Nations General Assembly on the "imperialism" of the Western democracies, sources close to the United States State Department predicted today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Selling of September corn against purchases of December combined with persistent selling of September outright in small lots by commission houses resulted in the current delivery closing at the low point of the day on the Board of Trade with net losses of 6 to 6 1/8 cents a bushel.

A college student can ask a girl out for a cup of coffee without having marriage in mind and the girl who says no once to an invitation is not forever lost, a group of foreign students learned yesterday.

Herman E. Cooper, counsel for the National Maritime Union, CIO, said yesterday there was no needh)0*0*0*ifor further action by the National Labor Relations Board in the NMU's contract dispute with Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators.
Three hundred youthful agriculturists living in the vicinity of York Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street began yesterday their annual Harvest Day celebration, which will continue through tomorrow.
The ballroom at the Astor Hotel was packed yesterday noon with fashionists eager to learn the latest reports from the Paris openings. The occasion was a meeting of the Fashion Group.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Commenting today on President Truman's charges against Senator Robert A. Taft, regarding the Washington conference between the Chicago publishers and National Labor Relations Board attorneys, John F. O'Keefe, secretary of the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association, said:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Although he worried about the way he was putting, Doug Ford of Bonnie Briar, former Westchester amateur champion, won the British Victory Tournament over the Metropolis Country Club course with a fifty-four-hole score of 225.
The following telegram was sent yesterday to Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, by Arthur Lourie, Consul General of Israel in New York:

After an all-day meeting, the board of directors of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company approved late yesterday afternoon a wage agreement covering 300 clerical and sub-station workers, averting a strike that had been set for last midnight.

NANKING, Sept. 15 -- President Chiang Kai-shek announced tonight the launching of what he termed a "revolutionary social movement" through which he hoped to inspire the people to reduce consumption and increaseh)0*0*0*iproduction.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, indicatedh)0*0*0*iyesterday that a decision by the commission on the application of the city's thirteen private bus lines for fare increases might be expected today.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kirby, Atlanta's outstanding woman amateur, shot spectacular golf this afternoon to defeat the medalist, Mrs. Bettye Mims White of Dallas, 3 and 2, in the third round of the national championship.
Cardinal Spellman dedicated yesterday the building at 221 East Seventy-first Street, which is to be used by Marymount College, conducted by the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary.

Decorative metal accessories by blind craftsmen were exhibited yesterday at a tea of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, 1880 Broadway. The new pieces, for sale through the guild's gift center, are in modern shapes andh) 0*0*0*ibear the impressions of numerous hammer taps.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Army will use troops, if necessary, to load military cargoes on the Pacific Coast during the strike of longshoremen, Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall said here today. His statement was made twenty-four hours after the Army attempted with only limited success to hire longshoremen in San Francisco and other coastal cities for this purpose.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today made a bitter attack upon Soviet Russia, the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and United States "big business." He accused Russia of seeking "world-wide domination," the CIO of "in effect supporting a cause which is hostile to this country," and business of "playing into the hands of the Communists."

The future of the domestic steel industry is bright in terms of potential markets and the availability of raw materials, but the industry's survival also hinges upon public understanding of its problems, T. M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, declared yesterday in a statement issued to the Association of Ironh) 0*0*0*iand Steel Engineers in advance of the organization's annual convention late this month.
New York and Paris designs were presented yesterday by Gunther's at a luncheon in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The United States Air Force ordered forty more C-54 type transports today to join the 105 of the same type now participating in the Berlin supply duty. Thus it pressed closer to the indicated goal of 5,000 tons of supplies a day.
The text of an official Dutch communique issued in Batavia and The Hague, as released by the Netherlands Information Bureau in New York:

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 15 -- An effort by a liberal bloc of California lawyers to force the Los Angeles Bar Association to admit Negroes to its membership was rebuffed today at the annual convention of the state bar of California.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Accusing the four outstanding meat packers of the country of monopolistically suppressing competition in the sale of their products, the Federal Government today demanded that the quartet be split into fourteen distinct and rival concerns.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- A press council with statutory powers and public representation in its membership might become the entering wedge for state control over newspapers, J. Murray Watson, editor of The Scotsman, declared in his presidential address to the Institute of Journalists conference in Edinburgh today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Six communities in Westchester County are joining in an appealh)0*0*0*ito the Public Service Commission for suspension of the Westchester Lighting Company's new interim rates that add $3,200,000 a year to gas bills, but the County Attorney's office said this afternoon it would not participate in a review.

Progress toward getting three key unions of truck drivers to unify their demands for settlement of the wage dispute that has tied up a large part of the local trucking industry and disrupted the city's commerce was reported last night by Hugh E. Sheridan, Mayor O'Dwyer's personal representative.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Dr. Federico Henriquez y Carvajal, venerable Dominican historian, writer and educator, will be 100 years old tomorrow.
Edwin J. Heimer, former president of Barrett-Cravens Company, Chicago, has joined Clapp and Poliak, Inc., exposition management firm, as vice president of its newly opened San Francisco office.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 15 -- A strong belief prevails in wellinformed Israeli quarters that Arab League military commanders are planning to launch a new offensive against Israel before the United Nations General Assembly opens next week in Paris.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Brig. Gen. Julius Klein of Chicago, national commander of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, opening the group's annual convention here today, asserted that the reinstitution of Selective Service "was inadequate to cope with defense needs in a world of growing international tensions."
