LONDON, Sept. 15 -- A young London grocer who was said to have applied to emigrate to the United States with his mother was sent back to jail today after bail had been denied him on a charge of possessing explosives illegally.

Tentative slogan for Father's Day next year will be "Today's Children Are Tomorrow's America. Remember Father, Builder of Our Nation's Future." This was announced yesterday by Alvin Austin, executive chairman, at a luncheon meeting of industry chairmen of the Father's Day Council at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
Boston, Sept. 15 -- New Hampshire today joined Massachusetts in closing its woodlands and Maine put a partial closure into effect as drought conditions persisted in New England with no rain in sight.

VIENNA, Sept. 15 -- Charles Peyer, former leader of the Hungarian Social Democrats, who escaped to this country, has summoned the "first free congress of the Hungarian Social Democrats," to take place in Paris in October.

Hungary will manufacture 900 freight cars for use in bizonal Germany, it was made known yesterdayh)0*0*0*iby Harry L. Schein, New York attorney. The contract signed Sept. 10 was negotiated by him on behalf of Deak Co., a New York export-import firm, and is one of the first large orders under the Marshall Plan made with a country in the Russian sphere.

Governor Dewey said last night that "the directors of WHN have shown, like American editors generally, that they need no censorship and can be trusted to guide themselves by the canons of public interest and good taste," in a message read for him over the radio station.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Boston's American League lead melted to a game and a half today as last-place Chicago exploded for ten runs in the seventh inning and a 17-10 decision over the Red Sox in a zany season finale between the clubs.
The immediate future in Berlin, and perhaps its ultimate fate in the great struggle for power occurring in Europe, is now being settled in Moscow.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 15 -The old Sag Harbor Customs House and Postoffice, built soon after the Revolution and used as a customs house from 1789 until 1915, began today its slow, threeday journey from its former location on Union Street to the new position on the estate of Charles Edison, former New Jersey Governor.

To provide for the possible future expansion of its facilities in the area, the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation has purchased seventeen and one-half acres of vacant land at Oyster Bay, near Hicksville, L.I., on the west side of South Oyster Bay Road and bounded on the south by the Long Island Rail Road.

WASHINGTON, Sept 15 (AP) -Gordon P. Street, president of the Wheland Company of Chattanooga, Tenn., said today that his company was acting independently in its protest of the lease of a blast furnace at the Cleveland KaiserFrazer Corporation.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Six direct descendants of Count Leo Tolstoy demanded today that American "political gangsters" stop trying to cover their "sinister deeds" under the name of the great Russian writer.
A formal tribute was given yesterday by the City of New York to the new Republic of Israel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today that the Federal Reserve Board's new action to curb bank lending was "necessary and proper in our general anti-inflation program."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Labor's League for Political Education, political arm of the American Federation of Labor, announced today support for eighteen Democratic candidates for the United States Senate.

A weekly program devoted to the presentation of old and new musical comedy and operetta successes will have its premiere at 8 P.M. Monday, Oct. 4, over the ABC network. The program, which will feature Gordon McRae as singing host and master of ceremonies, will be sponsored by the Association of American Railroads.

Operations of the Bulova Watch Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries for the three months ended with last June, resulted in a new high record for earnings for any similar quarterly period, John H. Ballard, president, reported yesterday.

Initial organizational steps in the formation of the first trade association to represent virtually all the city's independent appliance and radio dealers as well as those in Westchester County have been taken, Gerard I. Nierenberg, counsel for the Queens Electrical Appliance Merchants Association, disclosed yesterday.

Samuel I. Hartman, who was appointed referee by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Null to hear and report on a proposed settlement of a bondholders' suit for a receivership of the $130,060,O00 Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, filed his report yesterday with the court, approving the settlement.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- The Soviet Union's latest change in policy concerning the future disposition of the Italian colonies in Africa could be indicative of the Kremlin attitude in current strategy vis-avis the Arab world.

ON THE WARREN CAMPAIGN TRAIN, Sept. 15 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California set out today on a thirty-two state campaign trip voicing confidence of a Republican victory in November "if we work hard enough."

Probably the woman who bakes the best homemade bread in this country is Mrs. Clara Gebhard Snyder. She directs the Wheat Flour Institute of Chicago, a nonprofit trade organization engaged in educating consumers on the uses of this product.

The starting line-up of the Israeli soccer team that will meet the United States Olympic squad at the Polo Grounds Sept. 26 in the opener of a four-game tour is beginning to take shape. Coach Egon Pollack yesterday announced the names of six more players who will start for the visitors.

The lightning-change performance of the Soviet representative in jumping from one extreme to the other on the disposition of the Italian colonies is a vivid illustration of the Moscow idea of negotiation. Month after month in the two-year-long discussion of this issue by the deputies of the Foreign Ministers the Russians have held out for turning the territories back to Italian administration.

The stock market made little effort yesterday to further Tuesday's rally. Only a handful of issues showed changes of a point or more, and the composite rate edged up only 0.11 point. Business on the Stock Exchange approximated the previous session's total of 710,000 shares.

As the United Medical Service enrolled its millionth member yesterday, Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, its president, defended the health services available to the people of this state on a voluntary basis in comparison with the system of compulsory health insurance proposed recently by Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The agent for the Russian-chartered American freighter Moses Brown said today that the vessel had radioed that two unidentified planes had circle and had dropped parachute flares Saturday night but that the ship had not been fired upon.

Unfortunately the wonders of "Small Wonder" are uniformly small and become uniformly monotonous. Neither the writers nor the performers have scope enough to break the mood. As put on at the Coronet last evening, the town's newest musical revue has considerable virtue within its small compass.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Development of a new revolutionary type of high voltage X-ray machine for treatment of deep-seated cancers and innumerable industrial uses was announced today at the annual meeting of the American Roentgen Ray Society here.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- Premier Henri Queuille announced today that he had asked the Parliament to approve new measures to bring into the national Treasury some eighty billion francs. He implied that if this were not done, he would resign.

" Good Sam," co-staring Gary Cooper and Ann Sheridan, will open an engagement today at theh)0*0*0*iRadio City Music Hall. The comedy romance was directed and produced by Leo McCarey for RKO Radio Pictures. . . . Also opening today is "Marriage in the Shadows," a German film dealing with Jewish persecution under Hitler, which will be presented at the Little Met Theatre.

Permit me to correct two errors of fact which appear in the praiseworthyh)0*0*0*ieditorial "A New School Year," published in your issue of Sept. 13. Referring to the school building program, you state that "by the end of 1949 twenty-three new buildings and additions to existing schools are scheduled for completion" and that "more than $33,000,000 is being spent on the construction to be finished by the end of Mayor O'Dwyer's four-year term."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- George Munger pitched a threehit 2-to-0 victory over the Phillies tonight, vaulting the resurgent Cardinals into a third-place tie with the Dodgers. Stan Musial smashed two singles and a triple as St. Louis moved within five and one-half games of the pace-setting Braves and only five percentage points behind the runner-up Pirates.

The four headline fighters on the Tournament of Champions card at Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City, next Tuesday night will submit to physical examinations today. Middleweight champion Tony Zale and challenger Marcel Cerdan and Heavyweights Joe Walcott and Gus Lesnevich will appear at Jersey City Gardens at noon to undergo tests conducted by representatives of the New Jersey State Boxing Commission.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -California's oil strike, which produced violent street fighting in Richmond yesterday, returned to peaceful discussion and negotiation today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -The Emergency Court of Appeals held invalid today a 1946 ruling of the Office of Price Administration which put all multi-family dwellings in Long Beach, L.I., under ren control.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- Hyderabad will go before the United Nations Security Council tomorrow prepared to ask for an immediate cease-fire order and the withdrawal of all Indian troops as conditions of mediation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- At least seventy-six persons, including fiftysix scientists, have been victims of "allegedly unfair clearance procedures" involving loyalty, a committee of scientists said today it had been informed. The report was made in the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists by the committee on secrecy and clearance of the Federation of American Scientists.

Continued selling of Government bonds to the Federal Reserve System on the eve of the effectiveness of higher bank reserve requirements serves to point up from a new angle the fundamental difficulty which the credit authorities face in their effort to curb inflationary borrowing without sacrificing the 2 1/2 per cent ceiling on the basic long-term interest rate.
Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander was welcomed back to his job yesterday at Police Headquarters by Mayor O'Dwyer, who declared that "the whole city is delighted to have you back."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) -Abe Greene, president of the National Boxing Association since 1941, today was elevated to a newly created position of commissioner of boxing.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Sept. 15 -- Speculation as to the possibility of the Union of South Africa raising a loan in the United States was renewed today when the weekly statement of the reserve bank showed that the ratio of gold reserves to liabilities had fallen to 34.5 per cent.

G. D. Bruce in a letter in your Sept. 4 issue complains that persons are permitted to change their names at will, without a court order. Under Common law a person may change his name as often as he changes his shirt. However, provision is made by statute in New York for the issuance of a formal court order granting leave to assume a new name.

TOKYO, Sept. 15 -- United States big business is showing a marked lack of enthusiasm over regaining its pre-war stake in Japan's economy. Three years after the surrender, not a single American corporation has moved to recover its productive plant here or its shares in Japanese concerns.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate have made their decision on modernization of the waterfront and have unanimously chosen what is secondbest for the city and its people. The city administration thus maintains the status quo of city operation, a policy which has brought the piers to their present condition of shame to the city.

Negotiators facing the possibility of an advance of a strike deadline of 25,000 equipment installers in the nation's telephone exchanges to 6 A.M. today held a session last night in an effort to reach agreement on wage increases.
It's a Bowery rule to keep your mouth shut.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- With their favorite "cousins," the Cubs,h)0*0*0*ibeating themselves with four costly errors, the Braves protected their first-place lead of five games today with a 5-2 victory over the National League's cellar dwellers in their final 1948 meeting.
The second division chickens always come home to roost at this stage of a pennant race.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 -- Following is the text of Senator Robert A. Taft's reply to President Truman's charge that he had acted improperly in connection with the International Typographical Union's strike in Chicago:

Celebrating its 123d anniversary, Arnold Constable gave a broad picture of fall fashions yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The showing included styles for the very young, the teen-ager, youthful sophisticate and chic matron.

The Maritime Commission hash)0*0*0*ineither the intention nor the desire of usurping the functions of management in the operation of the American Merchant Marine, beyond the limits set up in the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, Joseph K. Carson Jr., a member of the commission, declared yesterday.

The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to hold public hearings at 2:30 P.M. on Sept. 29 on proposed zoning amendments applicable to public and private airports and on the location of medical and dental offices on the second floors of multiple dwellings in residential areas.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Frankfurter Neue Presse said tonight Fritz Thyssen, once Germany's richest industrialist, had been found guilty today of having been a minor Nazi offender. The newspaper said the German denazification court ordered Thyssen, now 74, to surrender 20 per cent of his property as a penalty.

A community experiment in international understanding for children of fourteen different nationalities began at 9 A.M. yesterday with the opening of the International Nursery School of Parkway Village, Kew Gardens, Queens. Classes were held in Apartment GB in the development, which is inhabited principally by United Nations personnel.

The fundamental issue confronting the world today was outlined anew when Foreign Secretary Bevin told Parliament yesterday that the Communistdominated countries headed by Soviet Russia are pursuing a concerted plan to stir up civil war throughout the world as an instrument of their foreign policy.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 15 -Presented as a new type of power unit providing increased fuel economy and energy, a 1949 automobile engine of reduced size was shown today at the opening of the fouracre engine production plant of the Oldsmobile Division of the General Motors Corporation here.

The roster of leading singers for the New York Opera Company's fall season at City Center will include eleven new artists and four who have been re-engaged, besides those who have appeared with the organization for varying periods, it was announced yesterday by Laszlo Halsz, artistic and musical director.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A Congressional joint committee of a dozen members is preparing to leave San Francisco before midNovember to investigate the administration of the former Japanese mandated islands in the Pacific under United Nations trusteeship.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, speaking yesterdayh)0*0*0*iat a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club at the SherryNetherlands Hotel, declared that the "Wallace type of appeasement of Russia would only postpone, not avert, war and in the process impair all the standards of public morality in a democracy."

The annual rate of retail sales for the first six months of 1948 reached $127,000,000,000, a gain of almost 12 per cent over last year, according to an analysis of movements of retail sales released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Describing himself as "a small town general practitioner," Dr. Donald E. Callar of Staunton, Va., explained tonight to a thousand dentists from all over the country how fixed bridges that do not show any gold might be put in the front of the mouth -and how important it is to do it that way.

Lieut. Gale S. Halverson, a softspoken 27-year-old bachelor who admitted he was "very fond of children," recounted yesterday how he and other American pilots flying the airlift into blockaded Berlin had bombarded the German children of the American sector with candy and chewing gum.

As enlistment opportunities for women were offered yesterday in the expansion of the nation's military establishment, large numbers sought to be included in the limited quotas that have been assigned the New York area.

An investment banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation will place on the market today a new issue of $25,000,000 of 3 per cent first mortgage bonds of Indiana and Michigan Electric Company due in 1978 at 100.79 to yield about 2.96 per cent.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, submitted last night to the record and transcription companies his first formal proposal for ending his union's ban on the manufacture of new disks. The ban has been in effect since Jan. 1

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, denying that he had "put the heat" on the National Labor Relations Board as asserted by President Truman, struck back today with the charge that the Chief Executive "has encouraged the open defiance of the (Taft-Hartley) law now engaged in by some of the more radical labor bosses."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 15 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said today "neither the Germans nor the Allies in the Western Sector (of Berlin) were very putschable."

Fines of $10 each were imposed yesterday by Magistrate Morris Ploscowe in Municipal Term Court, Brooklyn, on two of three men who had received what court attaches said were the first summonses issued under the city's new ordinance prohibiting airplanes from towing advertising banners or using loud speakers over the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Planning and conferences relating to President Truman's political campaign dominated most of the activity at the White House today, and an itinerary of his forthcoming trip to the West and Southwest showed that he may make up to 100 appearances in eighteen states.

Instead of freshening the Giants for a late drive into a high payoff position in the National League pennant race, their Tuesday respite served only to throw them out of winning stride. Resuming their interrupted series with the Pirates yesterday, the New Yorkers disappointed 9,180 Polo Grounds loyalists by dropping an 8-to-3 decision.

Fira Benenson, well-known designer, has translated into readyto-wear the exquisite detail that made her custom fashions famous. It was a difficult thing to do, but she succeeded with fine artistry. Her accomplishment was seen yesterday afternoon when her first ready-to-wear collection, exclusive with Lord Taylor in New York, was shown at that store.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 15 -Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce at first refused to speak at tonight's dinner of the National Council of Catholic Women because four Negro delegates were not seated but changed her mind when she learned this was due to a state law.

ST. Louis, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Ferris Fain doubled in the twelfth inning to score Eddie Joost as the Athletics beat the Browns, 8 to 7, tonight. Jerry Priddy had tied the score in the ninth with a St. Louis home run. Philadelphia swept the two-game series in its last appearance here this season.
BERLIN, Sept. 15 -- The Soviet Military Administration began today another secret trial, despite a United States Military Government request that United States observers be present.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Spokesmen for the big four meat packers at once branded the Government's anti-trust suit against them as political in nature, inspired by the coming election.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 15 (AP) -Johnny Hetki relieved Lefty Frank Fanovich in the eighth inning to stop a Newark rally tonight as Syracuse evened their first round International League play-offs at a game apiece by taking a 4-2 decision.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 8:

DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- With Joe DiMaggio sound again in wind and limb, the Yankees today were eagerly looking forward to resumption of their pennant chase tomorrow, when they open a fourgame series with the Tigers.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A rookie battery fresh from the minors collaborated today to spark the Tigers to a 4-to-2 victory over the Senators, extending Washington's longest losing streak to fifteen games.

Decorative fabrics designed to help amateurs achieve harmonizingh)0*0*0*ieffects without having to go out of their price range to complete room scheme were shown yesterday at Gimbels. The group, known as "Fabriganza," includes seventeen colors and twenty different fabrics, each of which is offered in five color choices.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The twelfth annual Antiques Sale and Exhibition opened this morning at the Y.M.C.A. headquarters with sixty exhibitors. Hours are from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily through Saturday.

One of the most elaborate art books ever produced in America is scheduled for publication on Oct. 29 by Coward-McCann. It is "Great Paintings in America: 101 Masterpieces in Color," edited by Fiske Kimball and Lionello Venturi.

City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly, the American Labor party candiciate for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District, and two other ALP candidates filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to enjoin Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander from interfering with their use of loudspeakers at street campaign meetings.

Communism is not a threat to France in peacetime but could be dangerous in the event of a war, Pierre de Gaulle, "Mayor of Paris" as president of its Municipal Council and younger brother of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, declared yesterday.

Twenty-two scientists and engineers from the metropolitan area, formerly members of the wartime Office of Scientific Research and Development, were honored yesterday by receiving the Presidential Certificate of Merit for outstanding service to the Government during World War II.

Two mobile units consisting of single-deck Fifth Avenue coaches were put in service yesterday by the city Selective Service to speed registration of youths born in 1929, for the second peacetime draft in the history of the nation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Circuit Judge Harry M. Fisher yesterday signed an extensive order declaring unconstitutional the state Liquor Mandatory Fair Trade Act, thereby opening the way for a price war in Illinois.
The text of Governor Warren's address in Salt Lake City last night, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Thomas Robbins of Winged Foot, transplanted from Texas many moons ago, stayed around long enough to become a member of the Westchester Seniors Golf Association and today, in his first attempt at the title, walked off with the championship at Westchester Hills.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 -The strike of CIO oil workers neared the end of its second week today in an atmosphere of peaceful picketing and renewed negotiations.

BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 16 (UP) -Premier Mohammed Hatta of the Indonesian Republic bitterly denounced the Indonesian Communist party in Parliament today as LeftWing and Right-Wing forces resumed civil strife in Surakarta, largest town in Republican-held Indonesia.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 16 (AP) Miss Helen Sigel of Philadelphia defeated Miss Peggy Kirk, Findlay, Ohio, 5 and 3, today in a quarterfinal round match of the fortyeight women's National Amateur Golf tournament.

New York is passing through an epidemic of Paris fashions. Yesterday it was Macy's turn. In the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel this store showed a duet collection which included twenty-nine originals from the couture and their copies.

The City Planning Commission at a special meeting yesterday approved plans for what it described as "a suitable approach" to the United Nations site on the East Side. The street changes will be made in East Forty-second Streeth)iand the East River Drive.
Your editorial "Conserving Water" in THE TIMES of Sept. 10 is most timely in the light of the water meter proposal now pending before the Board of Estimate.

The Electric Power Board of Chattanooga, a $20,000,000 municipal power system that serves about 58,000 customers in Tennessee and Georgia, declared in its ninth annual report, issued yesterday, that since the system was purchased from the Tennessee Electric Power Company in 1938, the average home cost per kilowatt hour of electricity has dropped from 2.64 cents to 1.36 cents.

From the American as well as the international point of view the coming session of the General Assembly promises to be the most crucial in the brief and turbulent history of the United Nations. Some wonder if the battered ship will not sink in the storm it must meet at this meeting.

Will Quaytman, editor of The Transport Bulletin, official publication of the Transportation Workers Union, CIO, was looking yesterday for a new office for his paper as the result of the newest flare-up in the fight between the union's right and left wings.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -Senate investigators asked the Department of Justice today to look into alleged fraud by two New York City exporters.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 16 -The Shell Chemical Corporation's $8,000,000 synthetic glycerine plant was dedicated today at Deer Park, a suburb.

Separate Campaigns for Autosh)0*0*0*iOHenceforth there will be separate and complete campaigns for the Kaiser line and the Frazer line of motor cars, it was announced yesterday by the Kaiser-Fraser Corporation, through H. M. Swartwood, advertising manager.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 16 -Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol moved into the final of theNew Jersey State women's golf championship today by scoring a 1-up victory on her home course over Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Hollywood.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Sept. 16 -- Grants to foreign countries for political purposes should not be disguised as loans, Eugene R. Black Jr., United States executive director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said here last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic candidate for Vice President, will embark Saturday upon a two-week campaign tour that will take him into eight key Eastern states for fifteen speeches, it was announced today within a few hours after his return from a Government mission in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -President Truman was urged today to take the lead in promoting a United Nations investigation of conditions in three Baltic States absorbed by Soviet Russia.

The following table, prepared by the Public Service Commision, shows estimated additional rrevenues to be realized by private bus companies from the onecent fare increase, also the companies estimates of the annual cost of wage increases and the excess of revenues after the wage increases are met. The companies and their employes have entered into agreements calling for wage increases of 24 cents an hour, conditioned upon an increase in fare.
The Rev. Eugene A. Gisel has been appointed head of the Department of Chemistry at Fordham University, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Truman announced tonight that he would form a Civilian Advisory Commission on religious and moral welfare and character guidance in the armed forces to assure character guidance and recreation for the thousands of young men who will go into the armed forces under the new Selective Service Act.

The State Public Service Commission's decision yesterday to allow a one-cent interim fare increase to the privately operated bus lines in New York City is addressed solely to the financial emergency created for these thirteen companies by the conditional, retroactive wage rise granted to their employes to remove a strike threat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The State Department said today it was watching closely the Communist movement in Southeast Asia and that there were indications sincere Nationalist leaders there were not deceived by Communist pretensions of support.

The hide futures market on the Commodity Exchange registered further decline yesterday. The market closed barely steady with net losses of 15 to 35 points. Transactions totaled 1,440,000 pounds.h)0*0*0*iHeaviest trading was in the December delivery.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 16 -A main armored spearhead of Indian troops advancing along the Sholapur-Secunderabad road from the west moved thirty miles deeper into Hyderabad in the last twenty-four hours, the Indian Defense Ministry announced tonight.

Startling crimson skies accompanied the hurricane that has been sweeping the North Atlantic recently, it was reported here yesterday when the transport Marine Swallow arrived from Bremerhaven with 600 passengers.

Fifty-four master works of painting belonging to Berlin museums that have been under Army and New York police guard for the last two days at the New York Port of Embarkation at Stapleton,h)0*0*0*iS. I., will start for Germany at 10 A.M. today.

The pilot and a woman passenger of a light, single-engined plane were killed last night when the craft crashed in a salt marsh a mile and a half southwest of the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. The plane previously had made several attempts to land at both La Guardia Field and the Idlewild field, the police said.
The cotton futures market closed 6 to 20 points net higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with a moderate volume of activity.

All-night negotiations in which Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and Stanley Bracken, president of the Western Electric Company, participated, ended yesterday in agreement on a wage increase for 25,000 telephone installers. The workers are members of the Association of Communication Equipment Workers, CIO.

VIENNA, Sept. 16 -- Another attempt by Austrian communism to exploit economic problems by a wildcat "general strike" call was defeated today when a new wage price agreement was achieved by Austria's coalition Government and accepted by the trade unions.

As the climax of a birthday party which bore strikingly few resemblances to a saturnalia, there was presented a salmon rod, complete with case. It was accompanied by a speech notable for its omissions, although containingh)0*0*0*ia hint or so that the days of tennis might wisely be done, that properly they should be one with the snows of yesteryear.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers Association of America, is to see Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav Molotov in the Kremlin tomorrow. He told correspondents tonight that he would discuss with Mr. Molotov the possible sale of American movies to the Soviet Union "and also other things."

CAIRO, Sept. 16 -- A provisional Arab Government of Palestine, with a twelve-man Cabinet headed by Ahmed Hilmi Pasha as Premier, will be proclaimed if no unforeseen obstacles arise before the United Nations Assembly meets Tuesday, a spokesman of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee announced today.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- With the approval of the Soviet Military Administration, the German Economic Commission of the Soviet zone has begun large-scale smuggling to get vitally needed industrial goods from Western Germany, it was learned today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 16 -- The National Petroleum Association was told today that this nation has a maximum life supply of petroleum of forty to fifty years and "a pessimistic minimum of some twenty to twenty-five years."

Tony Pellone, Greenwich Village welterweight, will return to action at Madison Square Garden tonight when he boxes Paddy Young, a sectional rival, in the star bout of ten rounds. Out of action for several months because of a nose injury, Pellone is back in top conditionh) 0*0*0*iand is confident that he will outscore his youthful foe.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- Governor Dewey proclaimed the week of Oct. 3 to 9 today as "employ the physically handicapped week" and appointed a seventeen-member sponsoring committee to coordinate activities during that period.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Strong attacks were directed against the Taft-Hartley Act today by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, and Louis Sherman, general counsel of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, in speeches at conventions here.
One of these days the new Policeh) 0*0*0*iInformation Booth in Times Square at Forty-third Street will be opened formally, with the usual fanfare of official oratory. The date is nebulous.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Slow progress is reported in evening up September corn contracts, and price changes in that delivery on the Board of Trade today were extremely nervous within a range of 4 5/8 cents a bushel. The close was 1/2 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher than yesterday.

The headstone marking the grave of the late former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx, will be unveiled at 2 P. M. on Sunday, one day before the first anniversary of his death, it was announced yesterday by the La Guardia Memorial Association.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Fears of a breakdown of the Berlin talks restricted business in the stock market here today.

The Heir, owned by Mrs. Corliss Sullivan and trained by her son, Rigan McKinney, accounted for his fourth stakes success of the year in the Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. He made it by about three lengths at the end of the two mile journey over a dozen jumps.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board today authorized additional service in the Caribbean area to be flown by Caribbean-Atlantic Airlines and Pan-American Airways.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- The establishment of a department of civil defense, under the direction of a Federal official "with the rank of secretary," was advocated here today in a resolution adopted by the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, holding its annual convention.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 16 -The lack of adequate and safe air traffic control throughout most of the world was sharply attacked today at a meeting of the International Air Transport Association in a report of the technical committee headed by K. William Ferguson of the Northwest Airlines.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 16 -Affiliated Fashionists have keyed their winter cruise-resort collections to the moods of music, from pianissimo to fortissimo. The fashions of eight women designers who form this group were presented at Ocean House, formerly the Santa Monica beach house of Marion Davies.

CAPETOWN, South, Africa, Sept. 16 -- Great significance for the Union of South Africa attaches to the results of the national elections in Southern Rhodesia, which were announced today as a landslide for Prime Minister Sir Godfrey Huggins and his United party.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The Quad Cities Industrial Union Council, which is the CIO council for Moline, East Moline and Rock Island, Ill., and Davenport, Iowa, was ordered today to cease all thirdparty Presidential political advocacy and informed that a new socalled right wing group had been picked to lead CIO membership in all matters of politics.

The ease with which your editors fall in with the pattern of criticism uttered by the opposition to the President is cause for some reflection. Thus, on Sept. 9, Stassen's charge of class war was "thoughtful and dignified." The President at Detroit talked straight from the shoulder as a campaigner, but where did he preach class war?

An offering of 185,000 shares of $30 par value 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of Holly Sugar Corporation was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Central Republic Company. The stock was priced at $30 a share.

Eugene F. Hartley, formerly executive secretary and economist for the International Business Machines Corporation, has been retained as special consultant on the mechanization of office operations by Tecco Systems Company, office methods and systems engineers.

After meeting for two and a half hours and hearing several witnesses, the special Federal grand jury which indicted twelve leading Communists on July 20 on conspiracy charges recessed yesterday until next Tuesday. The jury was reconvened Tuesday after a recess since the day the indictments were returned.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Federal Government today sued a brewery for $735,000 for calling its beer "Canadian" without informing the public it is not brewed in Canada. The suit, charging violation of a Federal Trade Commission order, was brought against the Canadian Ace Brewing Company, 3901 Emerald Avenue.
PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The Soviet Union has served notice that it will reopen here the long-standing United Nations disarmament debate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -A peaceful settlement of the Berlin crisis was predicted by Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democrat, of Kentucky, today on his return from a European tour that took in the blockaded German capital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Development of facilities for handling waterborne traffic at Edgewaterh)0*0*0*iDocks, N.J., may be expected if the Interstate Commerce Commission accepts recommendations made today by one of its examiners that would put the docks on a parity with Hoboken in connection with all-rail rates from inland points.

Although manufaCturers and trade groups are agreed on the need for fair-trade rules on promotion and selling of shrink-resistant wool products, sharp differences of opinion as to their final wording were expressed yesterday at a trade-practice conference in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The "House of Years" at W. J. Sloane will reopen Monday morning for inspection by home decorators who are gathering ideas for fall furnishing. As in past seasons, analysis of the ten generous rooms will reveal many uses of materials and arrangement details that may be adapted to other less lavish layouts.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 16 -- The home club champion, James Tierney, assumed an appropriate role in the Arcola Country Club's silver anniversary invitation tournament by winning the medal today with a 75 in the field of 121 competitors.

The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the Government of Iceland signed an agreement in Montreal yesterday under which the ten nations now operating commercial airlines over the North Atlantic will share the cost of navigational facilities based in Iceland.

A Coast Guard cutter and two merchant ships rescued seventyeight men and a dog yesterday from two hurricane-battered vessels on the North Atlantic. Seven other crew members were reported missing from the two foundering craft.

Moore McCormack Lines has been awarded the bronze "Oscar of Industry" trophy in the field of shipping by an independent board of judges for the Financial World Annual Report Survey, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The investment of Hyderabad by Indian troops is not "an invasion in the ordinary sense," but an effort to restore law and order preliminary to a plebiscite determining the political future of the area, the Ambassador of India, Sir Benegal Rama Rau, said today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Members of society and horse fanciers from Maryland, Virginia, New Jersey, Connecticut and the Nassau and Suffolk County colonies attended the opening program today of the three-day forty-third annual Piping Rock Horse Show on the grounds of the club.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- If the French currency counterpart fund frozen under the Marshall Plan is not released for use by the French Government, "the situation will become singularly perilous," Maurice Petsche, Under-Secretary for Economic Affairs in the Cabinet, said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -United States exports of food in the first half of this year were $314,381,000 -- or 20 per cent -- less than in the first half of last year.

Two of the top players of the younger generation, Earl Cochell and Harry Likas, both of San Francisco, followed William Talbert, Gardnar Mulloy and Australia's Adrian Quist out of the National Tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday and Miss Doris Hart of Miami was eliminated from the women's singles.

WARSAW, Sept. 16 -- A Polish Government spokesman said today that "false rumors" about the probability of war and the immediate collectivization of land in Polandh) were to blame for the food shortage that has struck Warsaw in recent weeks.

What women embroiderers are doing today is graphically presented in an exhibition of American amateur needlework that will open this morning at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to be on view through Oct. 17.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 (AP) -The Moskowitz-Rose Syndicate announced today that it has acquired control of substantially all outstanding common stock of the Standard Gas Equipment Corporation, Baltimore, Mfd.

An unceremonious blast of thirty pounds of dynamite opened yesterday afternoon a new link between Manhattan and Brooklyn -the easterly, or Manhattan-bound of the two tubes of the BrooklynBattery Tunnel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Exuding confidence on the eve of his departure on a gruelling campaign trip, President Truman told about 250 officers of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association tonight that he still expected to be President next year.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Today's reports of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -The Department of Commerce said today it has begun licensing shipment of residual fuel oil against an export quota of 1,450,000 barrels for the fourth quarter of the year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The Greater Chicago Hotel Association today informed the national headquarters of the American Legion that if the 1949 convention was held in Chicago arrangements had better be made to "prevent recurrences" of damages suffered by hotels during the recent state convention of the Legion's Illinois Department.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Three new developments in the battle over the $16,500,000 estate left by Mrs. Eleanor Medill Patterson, publisher of The Washington Times-Herald, came today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, warned today that the success of the atomic energy program was facing "a dangerous situation" that "imperils some of the broadest, deepest and most immediate interests of the people of this country."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- An official investigation into the presence of an American freighter in a Siberian coal-carrying voyage for Russia is under way at the Maritime Commission, it became known today.

Although our stricken nation has only just recovered from "Up in Central Park," a little something has come to replace it. "Heaven on Earth," which opened at the Century last evening, sets a very high standard for mediocrity and drives all our happy dreams away.
Alger B. Chapman, Republican state campaign manager, announced yesterday the appointment of Miss Jane Todd, vicechairman of the Republican State Committee, as associate campaign manager.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- While scientists have learned a great deal about the atom of matter, they are still abysmally ignorant about the atom of society, the human individual, a much more explosive entity than the atomic bomb, Prof. Roger J. Williams, noted Texas University biochemist, told the closing session of the centenary meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science tonight.

Expansion of business loans in this area last week, amounting to $149,000,000, was one of the largest ever to be recorded in a single week and brought the total of such credit outstanding to a new high of $5,543,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

Two vice presidents of the Fur and Leather Workers Union, CIO, have joined the lengthening list of those who refuse to answer when they are asked by a Congressional committee whether they are or have been members of the Communist party.

A plea to Puerto Ricans here to support the Good Neighbor Federation, which is seeking funds to resume its activities as a community center at 115-9 East 106th Street, was made last night by Mrs. Joseph B. Thorman, president of the federation.

Kelly, president of the Machinery and Allied Products Institute, research association. WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered American Light and Traction Company, Chicago holding company, to take immediate steps to retire its outstanding preferred stock.

The Union of South Africa may have to impose import controls as it is using up its dollar reserve and its gold "faster than it can be mined," Atherton Clark, assistant export manager of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Ben Gold, fiery president of the Fur and Leather Workers Union, CIO, told a House Labor subcommittee proudly today that he was and had been a member of the Communist party for a quarter of a century.
Hugh E. Sheridan, appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer to bring peace to New York's strike-bound trucking industry, summoned the union area-wide committee yesterday to meet with him this morning.

Hollywood, France and Italy will be represented on local screens by films opening today. The domestic contribution is "Miraculous Journey," an adventure story featuring Rory Calhoun, Audrey Long and Virginia Grey, opening at the Rialto.

TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 16 (UP) -- Fred Haas Jr., the hard luck golfer from New Orleans, tied the Fircrest course record with a 65 today to lead the field at the end of eighteen holes in the $12,500 Tacoma Open.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- George M. Weiss, general manager of the Yankees, tonight added his weight to the flood of denials emanating from the Bombers' front office recently, that there has been any rift between himself and manager Bucky Harris.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The sentencing to jail terms of three of the worker demonstrators who clashed with the Paris police yesterday was a subject of widespread labor protests as the strike move ment multiplied in France today.

WHEN Joyce Cary's "The Moonlight" was published here last year it brought great joy to a small group of enthusiasts. Where, they wanted to know, had this brilliant English novelist been hiding? Why hadn't his many books been published in this country? Why, when there is never enough really good fiction, had so finished a master of the craft been so neglected?

The model building code prepared in abridged form for smaller communities received the official sanction of the Building Officials Conference of America at the concluding session of their convention yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Sun Beau, from the Sterling Smith Stable of Ravenna, Ohio, won the first division of the $500 William S. Blitz Memorial Trophy event, high spot on the opening program of the forty-third annual Piping Rock Horse Show today.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 A new program for teaching American history, designed to furnish high school students with an understanding of the civic, economic and social problems that confront this country, was made public by the State Education Department today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The State Department announced today the recall of four members of the United States Legation staff in Bucharest on demand of the Rumanian Government, which arrested them ten days ago and held them incommunicado for sixteen hours without food or water on a charge of having taken photographs in a restricted area.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 16 -Henry A. Wallace said tonight that he and other New Dealers had been "pikers" in their spending of public money for recovery compared to the way he said the nation's funds were being spent today under a bipartisan policy of preparing for war.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 16 -- Abe J. Greene, chairman of the New Jersey Boxing Commission, today supervised the physical examinations of the four boxers who will appear in the "double-header" conducted by the Tournament of Champions at Roosevelt Stadium next Tuesday night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The National Council of Parents and Teachers today demanded that state laws be passed prohibiting objectionable comic books and urged the formation of local committees to evaluate comics, radio programs and motion pictures.

Quality controls developed by the United States Army Ordnance Department were recommended yesterday to aid industrial buying through four important techniques of improvement. Col. L. E. Simon, director, Ballistics Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, Aberdeen, Md., outlined the procedures to more than thirty-five representatives of oil, chemical and other industries during the third session of the Training Conference on Industrial Experimentation being conducted at Columbia University this week.

The Israel soccer team is scheduled to arrive by plane next Tuesday at Idlewild International Airport for its four-game campaign in this country, Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz, chairman of the Sponsors Committee, announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (AP) -Larry Doby's first-inning home run with the bases full enabled the Cleveland Indians to beat the Washington Nationals, 6 to 3, tonight before 25,521 fans. Pitcher Gene Bearden, who yielded seven hits, got credit for handing the Senators their sixteenth loss in a row.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.4 per cent in the week ended on Sept. 11, reversing the downward movement of the preceding two weeks, according to the bureau of labor statistics of the Department of Labor.
PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The United Nations Security Council voted today to give Hyderabad a hearing in its demand for action against the Indian march into the Princely State.
BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- The German Communists were warned today against "any form of nationalism" -- that is, independence.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Extra work efforts by Britons, coupled with their willingness to sacrifice immediate comforts for the export trade, enabled the nation to reduce its trading deficit by more than one-half in the first six months of this year, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today.

New York's part of the national campaign against venereal disease begin on Nov. 8, with the goal of bringing an estimated 250,000 "hidden" cases in the city under treatment, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today urged Kenneth C. Royal, Secretary of the Army, to rescind the decision to hire West Coast longshoremen off the streets and to take "appropriate measures to compel the ship companies to live up to the terms of their contracts to move Army cargoes."

WARSAW, Sept. 16 -- A purge of the Polish Communist party's provincial leadership has begun with the dismissal of two party chieftains in Lodz for their "conciliatory attitude" toward the policies of Vice Premier Wladislaw Gomulka, ousted party secretary general.
Population growth and inadequate school facilities have caused a virtual breakdown in the educational system of one section of this city, it was charged-yesterday.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 16 -After hoping for a further reprieve almost to their last hour, Milton Shaket, 34 years old, and John Reilly, 33, were put to death tonight in Sing Sing Prison for a New York City murder.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 16 -Medium artillery, and mortars roared out in Jerusalem tonight as Arab Legion and Israeli gun positionsh)0*0*0*iengaged in one of the heaviest duels since the truce was officially decreed for the Holy City July 17.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- Dean Alfange, a founder of the Liberal party and the 1942 American Labor party candidate for Governor, announced today his support of Governor Dewey for President. The declaration followed a personal visit with this year's Republican standard bearer.

Zero Mostel and Joey Faye, night club and musical comedy comedians, have been signed for a new television series which will have its premiere at 7 P. M. Tuesday on the DuMont Television Network and WABD. Mostel will be cast as "a millionaire disk jockey," with Faye assisting him at the turntables.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -The Ethiopian Legation demanded today punishment of persons responsible for ejection of Ras Imru, Ethiopian Minister, from his seat with the diplomatic corps at a science meeting here.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- As long ago as 1943, Premier Stalin foresaw the inevitability of a third World War and indicated his belief that this would be caused by the Germans, it was recorded by the late President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia in notes he dictated to his private secretary during a visit to Moscow.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov has asked Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Military Governor in Germany, for his comment on the joint British, French and United States memorandum charging the Marshal with responsibility for the lack of progress in the Berlin currency negotiations.

CENTER ISLAND, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Star Wagon and Llanoria rivals for the honor of representing the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club in the Seawanhaka International Challenge Cup series with Sweden starting on Tuesday, split the first two trial races in the Sound here today.

READING, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP) - White Mountain Boy, roan colt from the E. P. Cray stable of Bellows Falls, Vt., added new laurelsh)0*0*0*ito his brilliant record by racing to a straight-heat victory in the 2-yearold pacing division of the Reading Fair Futurity at the Grand Circuit meeting today.

Possibly indicating a trend, two additional savings banks in the metropolitan area yesterday announced plans to increase their dividend rate from 1 1/2 to 2 per cent, thus making three such announcements this week. In Manhattan, the Excelsior Savings Bank reported that, with earnings continuing satisfactorily, it expects to pay the higher dividend for the quarter ending on Dec. 31 this year on all sums of $5 to $7,500.

For good and sufficient reason, Lee Sabinson, co-producer of the prosperous "Finian's Rainbow," is all a-twitter these days over a new acquisition. A report from the Coast that he had bought "Aching Rivers," a play by Dalton Trumbo, considered one of Hollywood's outstanding scenarists, was confirmed by Mr. Sabinson yesterday.

Many of the voluntary hospitals in the city will have to curtail their services unless they are provided with funds, the United Hospital Fund of New York warned yesterday as it announced its goal of $2,845,9884 for the 1948 campaign, which opens on Thursday, Sept. 30.

Because of his refusal to answer questions about the operations of an alleged Russian spy ring, Alexander Koral, engineer for the Board of Education, may lose his job, it developed yesterday. The board disclosed that it had been advised by the corporation counsel that by his refusal to answer questions put to him by the House UnAmerican Activities Committee, Koral had violated the city charter.

The Screen Publicists Guild and the Screen Office and Professionalh)0*0*0*iEmployes Guild, both CIO unions, took their grievances against motion picture companies here to the public yesterday by distributing handbills outside the Radio City Music Hall and the adjoining RKO Building, 1270 Avenue of the Americas, during the noon hour.
Work began yesterday under new contracts that will advance the construction of a 1,275-acre bathing beach, boating area and waterfront park on the Lower Bay at Great Kills, S.I.

LONDON, Sept 16 -- British experts on India, including government officials, seem to have the impression today that Hyderabad will put up a good fight before that Princely State succumbs to Indian invasion.

Victor Pintacuda, 25-year-old grocery clerk and part-time musician accused in the theft of a pocketbook containing 91 cents, was ordered held in $2,500 bail yesterday for the grand jury on a charge of robbery. He lives at 345 East Seventy-eighth Street.
The retail price of milk in this city is 3 cents above the average price in the nation's twenty-five principal cities, Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh asserted yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16 -- Strong evidence has come to light that the Yugoslav Government is reviewing its export trade policy in view of the discrimination and losses suffered by the country's economy at the hands of the other "peoples' democracies."

Net income of the Cities Service Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on June 30 amounted to $15,741,220, equal to $4.25 a share. While no comparison with the same quarter in 1947 is available, the second-quarter earnings this year were $4,235,356 below the net income of $19,976,576 reported for the first quarter of this year, when earnings amounted to $5.39 a share.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- The Yankees, whose pennant hopes took on such an added glow during their off-day yesterday, came perilously close to being snuffed out today as they tangled with the fifth-place Tigers in a twin-bill before a gathering of 18,452.

Scientific methods of work measurement and accurate cost control, with an accompanying reduction in office overhead and assurance of a "fair day's work" on the part of clerical employes, will solve many of the problems confronting office workers and their employers, it was said last night by Paul B. Mulligan, management consultant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Department of Justice is investigating failure of the States' Rights Democratic party to file a statement of campaign contributions and expenditures on Sept. 10 as required of a political committee by Federal law, it was learned tonight.

AN 18-year-old kid from Atlanta played in his first National Open at Inverness in 1920. He was a pleasant-looking youngster with a chubby face and a golfing swing of liquid beauty. The committee made a gracious gesture by pairing the relatively unknown Georgia amateur with the mighty Harry Vardon. Little did they dream of the career they thus were launching, a career of unsurpassed brilliance.

Upward changes in the retail prices of butter, eggs, poultry and meat were reported yesterday by the City Department of Markets. Its bulletins, disheartening enough to give most consumers a case of "budget blues," were lightened somewhat by the news of decreaseshiduring the week in prices of fresh fruits.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- As agents of the District Nursing Association of Northern Westchester County -- first rural organization of its kind in the nation -they originally were horse-andbuggy nurses, looked upon with suspicion by physicians and patients alike.
City Controller's Day was celebrated yesterday at Grand Central Palace, where the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition is being held.

There has been a great deal of editorialh)0*0*0*isupport in recent weeks on behalf of continuation of the United Nations Appeal for Children. All this is very praiseworthy, in the same manner as it is good to keep ahead of us the goal of one world through the peaceful cooperation of all peoples of all nations.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 16 (AP) -- About 1,400 items of more than 4,000 were sold for an estimated $100,000 return in the first day's auction at the SymingtonGould Corporation's closed plant here.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Abandonment of intensive night bombing by the German Air Force in May, 1941, came just as the Royal Air Force was poised to inflict a crushing defeat on it, Lord Douglas, former Air Marshal Sir Sholto Douglas, chief of the fighter command, revealed in a report published tonight.

National Bellas Hess, Inc., retail mail-order and chain-store operator, has established new high records in earnings and sales for the fourth consecutive year, George Marks, president, informed shareholders in the annual report released today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, demanded at a meeting of the Far Eastern Commission and in a public statement today that the commission request Gen. Douglas MacArthur to revoke his no-strike directive to Japanese Government employes and a Japanese Government ordinance of July 31 putting it into effect.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The first regular delivery of THE NEW YORKTIMES by air for sale in Europe began today with the arrival of the first number of a special United Nations edition that will continue throughout the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly here.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- Soviet Army patrols made three forays into the United States sector of Berlin today but on each occasion returned to their own zone when confronted by United States military policemen without serious incident.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Sept. 11 were 788,700 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 106,579 cars, or 11.9 per cent fewer than were loaded in the preceding week, 133,679 cars, or 14.5 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week last year, and 118,469 cars, or 13.1 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of 1946.

Members of Local 1250 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, are continuing to hold demonstrations in front of the Oppenheim Collins Co. stores on Thirty-fourth Street and in Brooklyn in "complete disregard" of an injunction granted earlier this week by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman, Gordon K. Greenfield, secretary-treasurer of the company, charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Department store Sept. 11 were 2 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. How ever, allowance should be made in the weeks ended Sept. 4 and 11 for the fact that Labor Day fell in the latter while last year it was in the former.

An interim increase of one cent over the present bus fares of the city's thirteen privately owned bus lines was approved yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The increase will remain in effect until Dec. 31, pending determination of a permanent fare.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 -Military cargo, held up by the West Coast maritime strike, was loaded on two Army-chartered ships by Army-hired longshoremen today, according to reports confirmed by an Army spokesman.
The New York Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Sept. 23 for an issue of $24,286,000 of temporary loan notes dated Oct. 18, 1948, and due on April 15, 1949.

Overcoming the effects of a gland-slam home run in the first inning by big Hank Sauer, as well as the first major league homer ever struck by Pitcher Ken Burkhart, the Dodgers yesterday breezed home to a 12-6 victory over the Cincinnati Reds at Ebbets Field.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Internal Revenue Bureau is about to tell taxpayers how to cut their payments to a minimum.

Nottingham Apartments, Inc., sold The Notingham, a nine-story and penthouse structure for fortyfour families at 33-35-37 East Thirtieth Street to an investing client of Benjamin Hintz, attorney, for cash over a mortgage of $117,000. Assessed at $240,000 and occupying a plot 65 by 98.9, the building was remodeled in 1941 at a cost of $110,000.

Arnold J. Olenick, American Labor party candidate for the Assembly from the Eighth District, intervened yesterday at resumed hearings before the Public Service Commission in the Woolworth Building on the application of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for annual gasrate increases amounting to $11,417,000.

Unless increased public support helps to defray part of the rising tuition costs, medicine may become the profession of the well-to-do, Dean Currier McEwen of New York University College of Medicine said yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations was accused by Pravda today of "taking sides" with the Anglo-American bloc in international affairs. Jacob Victorov, foreign editor of the Communist party newspaper, made the charge in a critical analysis of Lie's recent annual report.

J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturers, in its consolidated statement of operations covering the nine months ended on last July 31, reported yesterday an increase in sales to $207,315,367 from the $160,958,304 volume for the nine months ended on Aug. 2, 1947.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Truman today accepted the resignation of Thomas J. Hargrave, president of the Eastman Kodak Company, as chairman of the Munitions Board of the National Military Establishment, and appointed Donald F. Carpenter of Southport, Conn., to succeed him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 - Howard Hughes' first important production deal since his acquisition of RKO was announced today by the studio and will bring Ann Sheridan to the RKO lot for three films. The agreement, completedh)0*0*0*iby Hughes with Polan Banks Productions, Inc., provides that Banks, novelist and scenarist, will produce three films during the next two years at RKO, with bliss Sheridan as the star, the studio disclosed.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Indian Army's timetable appeared to call for victory in less than a week from the time the campaign was launched last Monday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Joe Louis is still recognized as heavyweight champion of the world and the National Boxing Association said today there is no "logical contender" for his title.
A first-division finish by the Giants became increasingly remote yesterday when they bowed to the second-place Pirates for the second day in a row.

Keith Lorenz, a member of the State Labor Relations Board, declared in an opinion yesterday that he did not regard a Court of Appeals order to the board to conduct a collective bargaining election among a group of supervisory employes as preventing him from refusing to direct such an election in a future case.

A battered copper box, encased in the three-ton cornerstone of the old Criminal Courts Building, was retrieved yesterday by demolition workers, when opened it was found to contain gold coins and police badges, as well as a soggy mass of public records and newspapers dated Oct. 25, 1890.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns defeated Boston's high-flying Red Sox, 3 -- 1, tonight, cutting Boston's American League lead over the second-place New York Yankees to one game. Cliff Fannin held the Red Sox scoreless until the ninth inning, while the Browns rapped Mel Parnell in each of the first seven innings for a total of eleven hits.

The board of directors of the Derby Oil Company (Kansas) voted yesterday to increase the authorized common capital stock from 500,000 shares to 1,000,000. Immediately following that action, directors formally declared the previously proposed 50 per cent stock dividend on the common stock, payable on Sept. 30.

Salt meadows brood in mellow autumn sunshine. Weather-tanned fields and ledge-laced pastures stretch upward from the edge of the flat marshes. Seaward white-capped rollers write long changing lines on the page of clear blue-green waters. Marsh hawks circle high in the sky and sandpipers take short circling flights over the grasses before returning to the firm wet sand of the beach.

The stalemate in the stock market persisted yesterday and final prices showed only a slight advance due mainly to strength in some of the key rails. Major changes again were scarce as the industrials hardly budged from the previous close, the composite price index gaining only 0.16 point.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of the Christian Herald and president of the World and International Societies of Christian Endeavor, today became chaplain of the Chapel of the Four Chaplains.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 16 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California formally opened the Republican national campaign here tonight with a national unity appeal embodying an implied promise on behalf of his own party to keep the drive for votes "vigorous but friendly" and "free from the prejudice of party, class or race."

Commissioner of Welfare Raymond M. Hilliard disciplined fifty-three employes of the Tremont Welfare Center at 1918 Arthur Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday for violation of his recent order forbidding mass demonstrations on the premises of the Department of Welfare.
YORK HARBOR, Me., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Cotton goods prices will remain at current high levels for some time, Russell T. Fisher, president of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Truman, advancing to the most extreme position he has taken in his attacks on Congress as a branch of the Government and on the Eightieth Congress as a group, has announced this as an ethical guide for members of the national legislature:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- A plan for the United Nations to raise the salaries of its employes and then tax away the exact amount of their rise was made public here today. It is designed to solve a long-debated taxation snarl that now makes other countries, including the Soviet Union, pay dollars that eventually end up in the United States Treasury.

Six inquiries to bid on heavy machine tools and accessories have been announced by the Ordnance Department, Detroit Arsenal, Center Line, Michigan, it was disclosed here yesterday by the Department of Commerce of New York City. Items to be purchased include grinders, lathes, milling machines, screw machines, shapers, drills and sheet metal working machines, amounting to more than 350 units, they said.
A committee of common stockholders of the Long Island Lighting Company declared yesterday that it planned to hold a meeting to prepare for the election of a new board of directors for the utility.
Mayor O'Dwyer broke ground yesterday afternoon for a new public school at Tompkins Avenue and Hill Street, Stapleton, S.I.

Efforts by Hugh Sheridan, Mayor O'Dwyer's personal representative, to settle New York's eighteen-day-old truck strike apparently collapsed yesterday when leaders of Local 807 failed to appear at a meeting called by him.

While two middle-aged women engaged in a hair-pulling, face-scratching struggle in the upper deck, the Dodgers succumbed meekly to the Cardinals yesterday at Ebbets Field. Although the female belligerents were flanked by male escorts, they did not get from them nearly the protection that Howie Pollet got from Stan Musial, whose three spectacular outfield catches insured a 4-2 victory for the St. Louis southpaw stylist.

Although the cotton textile market appears to be in the midst of another price shakedown, sellers expressed confidence yesterday that prices will level off early next month and remain steady for the balance of the year.

Count Folke Bernadotte, steeped in the tradition of service to his country and to men everywhere, sought actively to make the phrase "peace on earth" come true. Traine as a soldier for Sweden, he fought his biggest battles to end wars in other countries.

Allow me to comment on Dr. E.M. Medlar's recent letter regarding the proposed mass vaccination against tuberculosis with B.C.G. in Europe. Dr. Medlar feels that it would be most unfortunate to create the impression that a single vaccination with B.C.G. "offers the modern, sure, ready and cheapest method of giving the widest protection," as stated in your editorial.

The stock market erased yesterday most of the advances made during the mid-week in a slow settling process which reduced prices from fractions to 2 points. Corporate developments accounted for the wider swings in individual issues, while the loss of 0.62 point in the composite rate reflected the declines in the majority of stocks.

Tony Pellone had little more than a brisk workout in gaining the decision over Paddy Young, his neighborhood rival from Greenwich Village, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
Milk companies in the metropolitan area "cannot possibly" absorb impending increases in their costs, a spokesman for the major dealers here asserted yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Zionists in London were fearful tonight that the assassination of Count Bernadotte might harm the state of Israel's standing before world opinion and the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The first national conference on the selection and training of school bus drivers was announced at a press conference today by the National Education Association. The sessions will be held Oct. 3 to 8 at Jackson's Mill, W. Va.
NANUET, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Three does and a fawn paid this community's Main Street an unexpected and unruly lunchtime visit today that will be long remembered by the 2,500 townspeople.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Truman asserted today that he would continue to fight to the fullest extent to keep the subject of atomic energy out of partisan politics regardless of opposition of persons "however highly placed'' who failed to grasp its significance.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- The national defense program now unfolding presents manufacturing problems far more complicated than those which machine tool distributors helped to solve during World War II, R.L. Giebel, newly elected president of the American Machine Tool Distributors Association, declared today.

Plans for an office building in the Grand Central area costing about $1,000,000 were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of a vacant plot 84 by 100 feet at 225-27-29 East Forty-third Street, between Second and Third Avenues, by Post Office Garage, Inc., headed by H. E. Wittemann, a builder.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Sylvester Gardiner and John Sheary of Ithaca, N.Y., scored 34, 36 -- 70, to win the medal during the qualifying round of the Nassau Country Club, member-guest golf tournament today.

The Canadian salvage tugs Foundation Lillian and Foundation Josephine were racing late yesterday to the hurricane-crippled freighter Leicester, which was abandoned by her crew in the North Atlantic on Thursday.

College football will make an enterprising start today. Half a dozen full-fledged major games are on the schedule as more than a score of important teams jump the gun by a week on the rest of the field.

The first Hebrew word that Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, learned while in Israel was "Shalom," which is used to mean "Peace be with you." He was quite proud of it because it symbolized his mission.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 17 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, and another United Nations official, detached from the French Air Force, were assassinated this afternoon within the Israeli-held area of Jerusalem.

Although reports from a number of New York counties indicate that the pheasant population has shown an increase over last year, the picture is not sufficiently bright to justify an increase in the bag limit or the length of the open season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Michigan Bell Telephone Company, Detroit, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a public offering of $75,000,000 in forty-year debentures.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Llanoria, six-meter yacht owned by H. F. (Swede) Whiton, Lee Loomis and Doug Dillon of Oyster Bay and skippered by Whiton, earned the right to sail against the Maybe VI of the Royal Swedish Yacht Club in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club International Challenge Cup series starting Tuesday as the result of a double victory over Star Wagon in the Sound today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Two St. Louis pitchers had trouble finding the plate as the league-leading Red Sox maintained their one-game margin over the Yankees by defeating the Browns, 9 -- 3, today.
BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Unofficial reports said today that the Indonesian Republic's Communist troubles apparently had spread from Java to West Sumatra.

Brooklyn's war memorial committee approved conditionally yesterday a $56,000 contract for the architectural work in connection with the construction of the borough's $500,000 monument in honor of the men and women who served in the last war.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 17 -- Hundreds of special teams raided homes of suspected speculators and hoarders during the night as the Polish Government moved to break the artificial food shortages created in the country's leading cities and towns during recent weeks.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Getting back into stride after her mid-day lead of 4-up was wiped out by the superb play of her rival, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of the home club won her third New Jersey State women's golf championship at the Baltusrol course today.
PEIPING, China, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Quick striking Communist forces today captured the Manchurian city of Suichung and had surrounded or taken Liushouying, thirty miles south of the Great Wall.

Expressions of shock at the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte in Jerusalem, of condemnation of the act and anxiety as to its effect were voiced last night in circles here most closely concerned with Palestine developments.

LEXINGTON, Va., Sept. 17 -- The necessary growth of administrative agencies in the Federal Government has forced adaptation of the Constitution to permit transfer of greater authority from the Congress to those agencies, Fred M. Vinson, Chief Justice of the United States, said here today.

The Texas Company declared yesterday a dividend of one share of its capital stock for every forty shares held, payable Nov. 15 to stock of record Sept. 27. The company designated the stock dividend as "an extra." It follows the declaration on Aug. 6 of the regular quarterly payment of 75 cents a share, which will be paid on Oct. 1.

Municipal bond circles heard yesterday that Louisiana has decided to join the group of states to vote in November on bonuses for veterans of World War II. The bonus proposed in Louisiana is $60,000,000, which would be financed by a bond issue, which, in turn, would be served by a tax on bottled beer.

TALLULAH, La., Sept. 17 (UP) -- Gov. Fielding L. Wright of Mississippi, States' Right candidate for Vice President, said today that President Truman, Governor Dewey and Henry A. Wallace were campaigning for the White House on a platform of unconstitutionality."

Members of the United Public Workers, CIO, picketed Department of Welfare centers in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens yesterday in protest against punishment of workers for participating in mass demonstrations on departmental premises.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The United States Army is reviewing its system of chartering Government-owned ships from private firms as a result of protests filed with the Maritime Commission by officials of other ship lines who charge that these vessels are competing with them.
