HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Increasing opposition to Germany's industrial exports constituted the real underlying causes of the two World Wars, asserts Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, former Reichsbank president and financial expert for the Hitler regime, in his first article published since his release after more than four years imprisonment.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 3, today in a battle to stay out of the National League cellar.

The India Union's arms have prevailed against Hyderabad, as had been expected. The 100-hour war between the last of the Princely States and the largest of Britain's two newest Dominions ended with the Nizam's cease-fire order to his troops yesterday as the Indian Army neared his capital city.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said at a press conference here today that the coming Presidential campaign would be built around "food" -- the cost of living -- with the Democrats being presented as able to stop inflation "before it is too late."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Six Midwestern utility companies were directed tonight by the Federal Power Commission to accept a 50 per cent cut in certain gas deliveries from the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company. The commission said it has been advised by Panhandle that the curtailment in deliveries will be effective on next Monday.

ROME, Sept. 17 -- An anti-Communist labor movement came into existence in Italy today when the Congress of the ACLI (Catholic Association of Italian Workers) by overwhelming majority appointed a committee to organize "free and independent" labor unions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Houston Chronicle, published by Jesse H. Jones, a member of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Cabinet, recommended today the election of Thomas E. Dewey and Earl Warren.

" Rachel and the Stranger," with Loretta Young, Robert Mitchum and William Holden playing the lead roles in this drama of pioneer days in the Northwest, will open this morning at the Mayfair. Norman Foster directed this RKO production, which is based on one of a series of short stories in the Howard Fast collection, "Patrick Henry and the Frigate's Keel."

PARIS, Sept. 17--Officials at the Palais de Chaillot, waiting today for a formal notice of the withdrawal of Hyderabad's complaint against India, were convinced that the United Nations had not heard the end of the case.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, moved today for dismissal of the Government's contempt-of-court charges without a trial and suggested that the court condemn the conduct of the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board who filed the charges.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 -- Aviation's critical hour still lies ahead, unless quick action is taken, according to Louis E. Leverone, president of the National Aeronautic Association. Speaking at a luncheon session yesterday of the association's Southern California chapter, the Chicago industrialist assailed the Veterans Administration and called upon the Government to keep the aircraft industry healthy.

EGLIN FIELD, Fla., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Five men were dead today and twenty-nine injured as a result of live bombs from high-flying B-29s missing their mark yesterday and plummeting into maneuvering troops.
TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans scored a two-under-par 69 today to lead with 134 at the half-way mark of the seventy-two-hole $12,500 Tacoma Open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Truman said today in a letter to Premier Alcide de Gasperi of Italy that the American people supported the European Recovery Program for humanitarian as well as for practical reasons in a world in which the nations have become mutually dependent.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 17 -- The effort to formulate an "international bill of rights" in the United Nations actually has developed into a program for the establishment of state socialism, "if not communism," throughout the world, it was charged today by Frank E. Holman, president of the American Bar Association.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Despite Sir Stafford Cripps' encouraging statement on Britain's position in balance of payments in the House of Commons yesterday, there was no increase of business in the stock markets here today. Uncertainties about conditions in Berlin and the French political situation exerted a more powerful influence.

Loyalty to the United States was pledged yesterday by more than 2,000 persons of several races and religions who spent their lunch hour in front of the United States Sub-Treasury Building in celebration of the 161st anniversary of the signing of the Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- New and improved devices, from a bomb fuse to building blocks, were among the 494 inventions listed this week by the United States Patent Office.

Two unions representing 18,000 telephone workers of the Bell System held wage negotiations yesterday with two subsidiaries of the company after Thursday's settlement between the Western Electric Company and the Association of Communication Equipment Workers, CIO.

Giant bombers, swift jet fighters and a variety of transport, reconnaissance and training planes will flash in the sky over every part of the nation today as the United States Air Force celebrates its first anniversary as a co-equal of the Army and Navy in the national military establishment.

Retail trade here this week showed an increase due mainly to more favorable weather for shopping. Department store sales were estimated as about 8 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were down 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A House subcommittee on Un-American Activities served notice today that "in spite of" President Truman, David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, and "a few misguided scientists," it would reveal "within the next few days * * * a shocking chapter in Communist espionage in the atomic field."

American industry will participate and cooperate in a number of major projects planned by the new State of Israel, Charles Ress, president of the Palestine Foundation Fund (Keren Hayesod), said here yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Events in Hyderabad are certain to weaken links of the British Commonwealth of Nations, according to Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, who gave a news conference in London today.

Despite larger sales, the net profit of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for the first eight months of this year declined to $3,762,875, equal to $2 a share, from $4,136,808, or $2.20 a share for the corresponding period of last year.

Burton Stevenson, whose "The Home Book of Verse" and "The Home Book of Quotations" long have been household standbys, has done it again. His new magnum opus, an even more monumental book than its predecessors, is "The Home Book of Proverbs, Maxims and Familiar Phrases."

Your Zurich correspondent's story in the Sept. 13 financial pages on speculation in the new German currency by Allied Military Government personnel deserves close scrutiny by the highest authorities in Washington. Not only will these smuggling operations lower our prestige in the eyes of the Germans still more -- Russian propaganda will certainly make the most of it -- they will also undermine the weak foundations of the new Germany economy.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 7 points higher to 10 points lower than the day before.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17 -- James O'Donnell, Washington chain drug store operator, and now of Middletown, R.I., today announced that he had reached an agreement with John Jacob Astor for the purchase of the latter's Newport villa, Chetwode, for $70,000.
San Francisco received a typical New York greeting yesterday complete with motorcade and reception at City Hall.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Cleveland Indians' catcher Jim Hegan batted in three runs with his thirteenth homer and a single today as his battery-mate, Bob Feller, fanned eleven and handed the Washington Nationals their seventeenth straight defeat, 4 -- 1.

Going through the motions in perfunctory style, the Giants went down to their third straight defeat yesterday to remain firmly anchored in fifth place. The Reds beat them, 5 -- 3, in sepulchral silence at the Polo Grounds, sparsely populated by the season's smallest paid attendance of 2,279.

It happens that the first General Assembly of the United Nations to be held in Europe coincides with the electoral campaign in the United States. Or perhaps it does not happen. The best reason for moving the great forum across the ocean this fall is to plant it nearer the center of the world's heightening tension.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 17 -- The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, voted today to withdraw from the AFL's building and construction trades department if such action is necessary to protect the members of the union.

Governor Warren of California has chosen to open the Republican national campaign in a highly unorthodox manner. He does not find all the good on one side, all the evil on the other. He neither points-with-pride nor holds-up-to-scorn. He does not even blame the party now in power for not having had the right immediate answers for all of the difficult problems created by "world forces beyond the control of the American people."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 17 -An official United Nations telegram to the Security Council declared that the two men had been "brutally assassinated by Jews of unknown identity in a cold-blooded attack."

There long has been complaint about the diminishing boundaries, of adventure. Now that airplanes have gone faster than sound, there remains only a plane that will go faster than sight. Most of the tall mountains have been climbed, and many of them now have excellent state roads to the summits.

The one-story industrial building at 93 Walworth Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the New York Cleaners, Inc., from Philip Kuhlman, executor of the estate of Michael A. Montague. The property, assessed at $12,500, occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet.

Two new shows, "Heaven on Earth" and "Hilarities," may be added to this week's casualty list. Their fate will be determined after performances this evening. The first of these, introduced only last Thursday at the Century Theatre by the team of Monte Proser and Ned C. Litwack, already has posted up its closing notice.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- Reports that the Army has contracted with a Seattle stevedoring firm to handle all military cargo for the Far East entered the involved West Coast maritime strike today.

Saying he was out of sympathy with the present policy of the Zionist Organization of America, of which he was a former vice president. Rabbi James G. Heller of Cincinnati has resigned as a member of that organization and affiliated himself with the Labor Zionist Organization of America, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator in Padestine, today rocked and dismayed Official Washington.

The deportation of Michael J. Obermeier, alien labor leader and admitted former Communist, for membership in a subversive organization, has been recommended, W. Frank Watkins, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- The Yankees held fast to the pace in the American League flag race today and they did so with considerable noise and gusto. They tore off six runs in the first inning at Briggs Stadium and from there went on to trample the Tigers, 13 to 5.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Retail furniture sales have increased 10 to 12 per cent over record 1947 volume, while manufacturers' shipments have risen 11 per cent and wholesale volume has gained 25 per cent, members of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers were informed at their annual meeting here.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Otto Graham, Cleveland quarterback, scored one touchdown himself and threw three scoring passes as the Browns gained their third all-America Conference victory by overwhelming the Chicago Rockets, 28 -- 7, before 30,608 tonight.

With the recovery yesterday of the bodies of a young man and woman who had crashed in a marsh near the New York International Airport at Idlewild Thursday night there came to light an air tragedy that may never be explained completely.

Miss Frances N. Douglass, Negro educator and sociologist, was sworn in by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday as a member of the Board of Higher Education. She succeeds the Rev. John M. Coleman, also a Negro, who resigned to accept appointment to the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The State Department informed the Ethiopian Legation today that the removal of its Minister, Ras Imru, from his box at Constitution Hall at the opening session of the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science on Sept. 13, was all a mistake.

Seven ships bringing German iron and steel scrap cargoes valued at $2,250,000 and amounting to 56,000 tons, have started to arrive at Eastern ports on a contract schedule which continues through next Saturday, Richard M. Egan, foreign sales manager of Great Lakes Carbon Corporation, 18 East Forty-eighth Street, revealed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The largest peacetime pig crop in history was called for today by the Department of Agriculture, the object being the quickest possible addition to the country's meat supply.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley asserted today that only a prepared nation was a secure one, saying that while American veterans did not want another war "we nave learned that only the strong can remain free."

A new British color printing process, using a press capable of printing as many as seventy-seven colors and shades with one impression at the rate of 1,200 an hour, has attracted widespread attention in this country. The process has been developed by McCorquodale Co., Ltd., one of Great Britain's largest graphic arts concerns.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Parliament wound up its five-day debate on the King's speech today in a mood of jubilation. The whole country, in fact, judging from the newspapers and other comment, has been electrified by statistics that Sir Stafford Chipps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, gave yesterday showing immense improvement in Britain's industrial and trade position.

Establishment of a national Advertising Hall of Fame, to be set up in the New York Advertising Club's new building on Park Avenue, was unanimously approved by the board of directors of the Advertising Federation of America yesterday at a meeting in the club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- James Forrestal, the Secretary of National Defense, struck back sharply tonight against persons who accuse the government and big business of trying to lead the country into war.

Third-quarter retail home furnishings dollar volume throughout the country increased from 10 to 40 per cent, according to a report to the trade issued yesterday by Arthur Fertig, head of the company bearing his name. In some instances, he said, increases were out of line and were caused primarily by early announcement of the restoration of consumer credit controls which go into effect on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Thirty-three manufacturers in fifteen states, including five in New York and two in New Jersey, and six trade associations operating for them in New York City, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease from conspiring further to "fix prices and eliminate competition" in the manufacture and sale of tickets and related products.
Tonight's events: "Don Giovanni," Lemonade Opera, Greenwich Mews Playhouse; Stan Kenton, jazz concert, Carnegie Hall; People's Songs, folk music concert, Town Hall, all at 8:30.

Some years ago I visited Ethiopia as a guest of Emperor Haile Selassie. In the course of a conversation he remarked that he had long wished to visit the United States but was deterred by reports of the discourteous treatment accorded "those with dark skins."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Expressing the belief that the Russians appeared anxious "to avoid the war which some of our more foolhardy generals threaten," Henry A. Wallace charged tonight that war scares were being deliberately whipped up in this country to help some industrialists.

John Foster Dulles, Governor Dewey's adviser on foreign affairs, announced yesterday that he was going to the United Nations Assembly meeting, which opens in Paris next Tuesday, not only in his official capacity as American representative but also as a Republican "with the approval and support" of Mr. Dewey.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- French gendarmes called by the United Nations ejected Garry Davis tonight from the grounds of the Palais de Chaillot where he had been camping out since Sunday. [He was shortly released after he had been taken to the police station.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 17 -- A 19-year-old student at Oglethorpe University, Ray Gebhardt, scored two surprising victories in the opening match play rounds of the twenty-fifth annual Arcola Country Club invitation tourney today.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S CAMPAIGN TRAIN, Sept. 17 -- An exuberant, confident President Truman headed west on his first major extended campaign tour today, declaring his intention to "fight hard" and 'give 'em hell" in a back-breaking, no-quarter contest for the Presidency between now and Nov. 2.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Superior officers in Police Department were reported banding together today into a superior officers' association as a protective move after two of their members, Capt. Eugene A. Wild and Capt. George Bengert, were ordered to traffic duty at schools here by Police Commissioner Harry Gourley.

PUEBLO, Col., Sept. 17 -- A crusade on "what is right with America" was proposed tonight by Gov. Earl Warren of California to combat the influences of followers of "false gods" who, he said, were "hiding" in the Presidential campaign under the "Progressive" banner. Carrying his Vice Presidential drive through the scenic mountains and gorges of Colorado, the Republican nominee attacked Communists in government and society.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 17 -The second annual harvest show arranged by the Westchester County Horticultural and Agricultural Association and the horticultural committee of the Purchase community house was presented this afternoon and evening at the community house.

The Allen B. Dumont Laboratories, Inc., in an expansion move, purchased the plant facility on Shafto Street at Scholes Avenue in Clifton, N.J., from William R. Warner Co. The Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization was the broker.

From the half-mile pole to the wire the order of the first four was unchanged in the $10,000 added Busher Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. That situation gave favorite players nothing to cheer about, for the W-L Ranch's Honeymoon was not a member of the quartet.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- Five trustees of the State University system met today with the Board of Regents to discuss informally the budgets for the thirty-two state-operated colleges. The trustees are charged with reviewing and approving the budgets for the state colleges.

Fifty-four master works of painting found in a German salt mine at the close of the war and brought to this country for exhibition started their homeward journey yesterday aboard the Army transport General Daniel I. Sultan.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 17 -- Placed on a difficult spot by high prices, the cigarette vending machine business stands in a precarious position, John Moran; of the Rowe Manufacturing Company, declared here today. He addressed the National Automatic Merchandising Association which opened a two-day meeting here.

Ray Flaherty, head coach of the New York Football Yankees since the team became a member of the All-America Conference in 1946, resigned yesterday. In making the announcement, Publicity Director Arthur E. Patterson said that Flaherty "has resigned under pressure from the club."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 -- "Liberty, while still talked about at meetings such as this, is largely receding from the minds of people as a guide for life and government," Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, Ohio, told 500 men and women at a Constitution Day luncheon celebration of the Sons of the American Revolution here today.

The City Investing Company, one of the country's largest real-estate and theatre owning corporations, is expanding its motion-picture interests by entering into the foreign film distribution and exhibition field as a partner in Lopert Films, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

CUXHAVEN, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The British liner Samaria, one of two Cunard liners to help in the Government-sponsored project to transfer emigrants from Germany to Canada, left Cuxhaven today for Canada with 1,200 displaced persons from western German camps.
Our home economist, Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, came back from Hampshire House the other day with the news that she had lunched on some of the finest frozen foods she had yet tasted.

Frank Parker went the way of all the American favorites in the National amateur tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday and the rout of both the United States and Australian Davis Cup teams was complete.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 17 -- Hyderabad surrendered today to Indian troops that had entered the independent Princely State at dawn on Monday "to restore order."

WASHINGTON, Sept 17 (AP) -- Congress carefully considered the war service of young members of the merchant marine before deciding to include such persons among those subject to draft, Representative Clarence Cannon of Missouri was told today.

The Board of Estimate, at a special meeting early last night, granted to the thirteen private bus companies operating under city franchises conditional permission to file with the Public Service Commission new tariffs increasing their present fares by 1 cent.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Fleet-footed Ralph Earhart took off on a 63-yard touchdown race from scrimmage to highlight the powerful Green Bay Packers' 31-0 victory over the Boston Yanks in the National Football League's opening game tonight before a crowd of 15,443 at Fenway Park.

Patrolman Warren Bohlmann, attached to Traffic B, became inquisitive when he saw a large number of cars, all different makes and models, being driven in and out of the garage next to his home at 67-41 Fifty-third Drive, Maspeth, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today shifted from Washington to Boston a hearing on a proposal of the Boston Maine Railroad Company to modify its capital structure by issuing one class of new common stock for eight classes of now outstanding stock.

A convoy of five golden buses filled with city officials, department store executives and members of the Fifth Avenue Association honored last night New York's famed "Golden Mile" -- the section of Fifth Avenue between Fortieth and Sixtieth Streets.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- The United States Air Force in Europe pledged itself today to fly a record 5,000 tons of coal into Berlin in twenty-four hours in an expansive, politically shrewd salute celebrating Air Force Day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Inflammation of the thyroid gland, a toxic and painful condition in the lower throat which often defies other treatment, responds "promptly and completely" to X-ray treatment, the annual meeting of the American Roentgen Ray Society was told today as sessions ended.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Attorney General George F. Barrett of Illinois today threw cold water over any possibility of a liquor-price war, announcing he will appeal a Circuit Court ruling that the State Liquor Price Act is unconstitutional.

Nearly 1,000,000 women throughout the country are in business for themselves, Miss Jane H. Todd, Deputy Commissioner of the State Department of Commerce and chairman of the New York Woman's Council, declared yesterday. Census Bureau statistics list 962,000 women as "proprietors, managers and officers," she reported.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Officials of sixteen non-operating railroad unions authorized the distribution of a strike ballot among the unions' 1,000,000 members today. The action was taken immediately after the union chiefs and railroad officials reached a deadlock in their negotiations over wages and hours. These talks have been in progress in Union Station here since Sept. 8.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 17 -- Gloom descended over Sweden tonight when it became known that Count Folke Bernadotte had been murdered. Ever since he succeeded his royal uncle, Prince Carl, as president of the Swedish Red Cross and carried through his admirable work for inmates of Adolf Hitler's concentration camps the Count has been one of the most respected and popular men in the country: His work in Palestine had won new respect for him.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 -- The Cleveland Indians' game with the league-leading Boston Red Sox next Wednesday has been changed from a day to a night game with all proceeds above the current advance sale going to Don Black, Tribe hurler who suffered a brain hemorrhage last Monday.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Boston's hustling Braves took a long step toward their first pennant in thirty-four years when they vanquished the persistent Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 -- 2, today behind their leading pitcher, righthander Johnny Sain, who won his twenty-first victory.

HAWTHORNE, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Northrop Aircraft took the wraps off two of the country's most carefully guarded military secrets today -- its XF-89, an all-weather fighter, and its X-4, a tiny sonic research craft.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 17 -United Nations truce officials here today were wondering whether the end of their mission was imminent, following yesterday's grim warning by the chief operations officer of the Israeli General Staff that increased Arab military preparedness presaged an early resumption of hostilities.

CAIRO, Sept. 17 -- In telephone messages from Alexandria, Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha and Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, the shock and grief of Arab leaders at the death of the man who had won their respect and confidence even, if he did not succeed in converting them to his views.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, in a statement issued here tonight, declared that he subscribed firmly to the principals of the farm price support program approved by the Eightieth Congress, "both for the present and the future."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- The following is the text of the report of the assassination as cabled today to the United Nations Security Council in Paris by Ralph Buncke, who has been designated new head of the United Nations Mission in Palestine:

The report on Palestine which Count Folke Bernadotte was to have presented to the United Nations Assembly in Paris next week will not be delivered by him. Gangster bullets fired in Jerusalem yesterday ended forever the efforts of this brave and earnest mediator to bring peace to the Holy Land.

BERLIN, Sept 17 -- In the biggest post-war battle over the control of European radio frequencies, the United States and British Military Governments disclosed today they would not limit the scope of German broadcasting activities in their zones.

DENVER, Sept. 17 -- A declaration of principles stating the belief that the peoples of the world are trustees charged with maintaining unimpaired the inheritance of the earth's renewable resources was presented tonight to the first Inter-American Conference on Conservation of Renewable Natural Resources.
PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Premier Henri Queuille's tax bill to check inflation was reported favorably by the Finance Committee of the National Assembly today. The bill will go before the Assembly tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - World tensions have sharpened the vigilance of immigration officials and account, in part, for recent excluisons of aliens who sought to attend conventions of labor unions and other organizations in this country, according to the State Department.

AN ARAB VILLAGE IN ISRAEL, Sept. 17 -- The Sheikh Yushef Abu Gosh, Arab Stern Group leader, promised today a wave of terrorism throughout the Middle East against British-led Arabs and political assassinations of the Arab Legion commander, Brig. John Bagot Glubb Pasha and other Britons.

Rights to televise the World Series have been sold for a reported price of $175,000, a substantial increase over the figure paid a year ago for the privilege of reporting baseball's classic on the video screen, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The State Department announced today that all American consular offices in Germany and Austria, acting under the Displaced Persons Act, will now accept applications for registration as intending immigrants to the United States from persons residing in the American, British and French zones of Germany and Austria and in the American, British and French sectors of Berlin and Vienna.
MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A 24-year-old former convict, accused of killing six persons in a fourteen-day crime orgy, must die in the electric chair Jan. 3.

Daily average lumber production for the week ended Sept. 11 was 4.4 per cent above the preceding week and 6.8 per cent above the like week a year ago. Shipments, compared with a year ago, were down 20.6 per cent and orders down 26.9 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Miss Helen Sigel of Philadelphia and Miss Grace Lenczyk of Newington, Conn., will meet tomorrow over thirty-six holes for the forty-eighth women's national amateur golf championship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Frank Capra's first picture under his Paramount contract, signed more than a year ago, will be "Woman of Distinction," a screen story by Ian Hunter and Hugo Butler which the studio has just acquired, it was learned today.

Heavyweight champion Joe Louis announced yesterday that he had changed his mind about retiring. The Brown Bomber, visiting the offices of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, said that he would return to competition next June against the winner of the fight between Ezzard Charles and Joe Baksi in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 12.
All branches of the nation's armed services offering enlistment opportunities to young women reported being satisfied yesterday with the results of the first three days of their recruiting drives.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Miss Helen Sigel of Philadelphia and Miss Grace Lenczyk of Newington, Conn., will meet tomorrow over thirty-six holes for the forty-eighth women's national amateur golf championship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Frank Capra's first picture under his Paramount contract, signed more than a year ago, will be "Woman of Distinction," a screen story by Ian Hunter and Hugo Butler which the studio has just acquired, it was learned today.

Heavyweight champion Joe Louis announced yesterday that he had changed his mind about retiring. The Brown Bomber, visiting the offices of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, said that he would return to competition next June against the winner of the fight between Ezzard Charles and Joe Baksi in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 12.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale's aged jumper General, winner of the national championship in 1945, took the second division of the William S. Blitz Memorial Trophy competition with Stuart Lanham riding today at the annual Piping Rock horse show.

Roman Catholic and Protestant churches in Manhattan will join in the ringing of bells and chimes all over the world tomorrow "as a call to prayer for world leaders who gather in Paris for the General Assembly of the United Nations," opening on Tuesday.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- The reduction of the sentence of Ilse Koch, wife of the former Nazi commandant of the Buchenwald concentration camp from life to four years, has aroused a storm of Communist criticism and grave misgivings among Germans who are strongly anti-Communist.

There was unusual pep and dash in the first single football practice session for Columbia yesterday at Baker Field. In addition to trying to impress Head Coach Lou Little, the Morningside aspirants were "going all out" for their university president, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, an unexpected spectator. For forty minutes, the General closely appraised the formations.

Cloverlly, the estate property of the late Mrs. Annie S. Arnold on the Montauk Highway in the Babylon-Bay Shore section of Long Island, has been sold by the Dominican Fathers of the Province of St. Joseph to Cadman H. Frederick, who plans to offer it as homesites.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 17 -Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, grandson of an American slave, has been appointed to succeed Count Folke Bernadotte as head of the United Nations mission in Palestine, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (Science Service) -- An agricultural machine combining the functions of a mold-board plow and disk harrow in one operation (No. 2,449,062) was patented this week by Edward B. Dewey of Washington, D.C. First a roller crushes flat all stubble and trash.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, as head of a Senate subcommittee investigating communistic activities that allegedly have included espionage on behalf of Soviet Russia, called on Tom C. Clark, Attorney General, today to assemble grand juries in six cities with a view to possible indictment of more offenders in and outside Government posts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Treasury announced today plans to refund all of $6,913,092,000 in 1 per cent Government securities falling due on Oct. 1 by offering the owners higher interest if they reinvest.

A civil anti-trust suit instituted by the Department of Justice in 1940 against the American Optical Company of Southbridge, Mass., the Bausch Lomb Optical Company of Rochester, N.Y., and thirty-three other defendants in the optical field was terminated yesterday through a consent decree signed by Federal Judge John C. Knox.
The hide futures market on the Commodity Exchange firmed in yesterday's trading after two days of declining price levels. At the close, all deliveries showed gains ranging from 10 to 24 points.

World control of "weapons of mass destruction," whether those of atomic energy or biological warfare, is the "heart question of the peace," Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut, original chairman and present member of the Senate-House Committee on Atomic Energy, asserted yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Sentiment turned to the bull side of the grain markets on the Board of Trade today. September corn and oats opened easy, but the deferred deliveries and wheat showed a firm undertone from the start and final trades were about the top.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 17 -- A universal commercial language of the air for both passengers and goods was brought many steps closer here today with reports of committees of the International Air Transport Association. Samuel E. Gates of the American Overseas Airlines, Inc., as chairman of the legal committee, reported he had managed to reconcile various national codes to make possible "legally sufficient" statement of new and universal conditions of carriage.

The expulsion of three anti-Communist leaders from the Bloomingdale department store local last May first attracted widespread attention to the extent to which Communist elements had won control of CIO store and warehouse unions in this city. In ordering the three men reinstated, the international executive board of the parent union, the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, asserted that they had been ousted solely because of their hostility to Communist doctrines.

Presidential Certificates of Merit were awarded yesterday to twenty-one scientists and engineers from the metropolitan area for their services as members of the war-time office of Scientific Research and Development. Twenty-two certificates were issued Thursday.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- A special meeting of the United Nations Security Council will be held at 3 P. M. tomorrow in the Palais de Chaillot to consider what action should be taken regarding the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator, in Palestine.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics rallied for five runs in the ninth inning here tonight to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 9 -- 6, before 6,196 fans. Walt Holborow, fourth of five Philadelphia pitchers, was the winner for his first victory. Howie Judson was charged with the loss.

The people who reckoned that Rockefeller Center was the ideal background for a county fair showed imagination but overlooked a few items. The result, however, when the fair opened officially yesterday, was striking.

A bit of Paris came to New York yesterday in a group of six original Piguet models flown here for a showing in recognition of the fourth anniversary of the liberation of France and also in honor of this French designer's two new perfumes.

An unidentified man who had leaped from behind the wheel of a stolen automobile that the police were chasing was shot and killed last night by a radio car patrolman on Eighteenth Street, near the Avenue of the Americas.

ATHENS, Sept. 17 -- A Greek Army spokesman said today that the last rebel-held feature of strategic importance in the Mourgana Mountain mass on the Albanian border had been captured by infantry assault. This means, he said, that the whole mountainous region that juts into Greek Epirus -- a zone that had been described in recent broadcasts of Gen. Markos Vafiades' rebel radio as an "unassailable castle" is now in Government hands.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 17 (UP) -John A. Cassidy, 47, a member of the international executive board of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, was beaten by a fellow union member here today while "about 20" other union men stood by and watched.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- State Conservation Department officials, alarmed over the growing fire hazard caused by the prolonged drought, weighed the possibility today of asking Governor Dewey to issue an executive order closing the forests to the public.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Sept. 17 -- Marshall Vance, the United States consul at Frankfort, today announced the reopening of normal immigration from Germany and Austria, effective immediately. A quota of 28,000 has been assigned, he stated, although it is anticipated that about 2,000,000 will apply.

TOKYO, Sept. 17 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today in one of the most tartly worded statements he has made since the war rejected the charger made before the Far Eastern Commission by Soviet Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin that his "advice to the Japanese Government to ban strikes by public employes is in violation of international agreements.''

May an ex-teacher, through the generous offices of THE TIMES, comment upon the criticisms of education as discussed by educators at the recent conference at Columbia University? It seems as if they are trying to find the shortest way home by traveling ways too newly blazed to be trustworthy.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Consul General John J. Macdonald's first report on the murder of Count Folke Bernadotte stated that the assassination had been presumably the work of the "Stern Gang" or, as it calls itself, the "Fighters for the Freedom of Israel."

AMMAN, Trans - Jordan, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Mediator was shot down in Israeli territory while on an official truce inspection tour of the "trigger-happy" city, a phrase that the Count himself had used a few hours before to describe conditions within Jerusalem.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber reserved decision yesterday on a motion made by Representative Vito Marcantonio to bar the name of the newly created United Laborite party from the voting machines in the November election on the ground of fraud.

Streptomycin has been crystallized. The achievement is announced in the Journal of the American Chemical Society by three biochemists in the Squibb laboratories -- Drs. Eric T. Stiller, Leon J. Heuser and Morris A. Dolliver. The crystals are pure trihydrochloride of streptomycin and mannosidostreptomycin.

ROME -- Officials of Ente Nazionale Industrie Turistiche, the official body in charge of promoting tourist trade, are encouraged by the gradual increase in the number of foreign visitors who have come to Italy this summer.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Carpenters and plasterers were still bustling around the Palais de Chaillot today, and in their own unofficial communiques announced they would still be hammering away when the United Nations Assembly opened on Tuesday.

SOME of the old-timers never thought they would see the day. But it's here. Broadway's three D's -- drama, dance and downbeat -- are being combined for the first time with the public school system's three R's in an old, red schoolhouse near the heart of Times Square's theatre district.

BECAUSE I rarely read short stories in magazines, I marvel at the prodigious labors of Miss Foley and Mr. Brickell, who read hundreds of them in the course of a year. Their labors are useful, too, for they do come across a good many interesting failures and a few real successes.

PROFESSOR FEDOTOV, who teaches at the Orthodox Theological Seminary of St. Vladimir in New York and who wrote a monumental history of the Russian religious mind, gives now to the American reader the first representative survey of Russia's spiritual life, of the religious experiences and attitudes of its church.

Although the statement may appear anomalous, it is a fact that the owner of real estate who loses his property through foreclosure of mortgage can, on the same transaction, realize taxable gain. The Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has so held, affirming the findings of the United States Tax Court (R. O'Dell Sons Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Respondent, decided July 19, 1948).
BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- Birth control, an explosive subject in Massachusetts politics, promises to bring additional thousands of voters to the polls on Nov. 2.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18 -- State visits by President Juan D. Peron to Madrid and Generalissimo Francisco Franco to Buenos Aires hinge on the answer to the Spanish question provided at the United Nations General Assembly session in Paris, according to excellent diplomatic sources here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A Congressional committee today assailed two rulings of the Federal Communications Commission dealing with atheism and with political broadcasts as "dangerous and mischievous." The one touching on atheism was described as "a dangerous and unwarranted policy of 'thought policing' that has no basis in law."
Columbia and Holy Cross gave the Baker Field gridiron a thorough going-over yesterday morning as the two teams went through a three-hour scrimmage session.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP) -- California, the West Coast's popular choice to go to the Rose Bowl this season, unveiled its football powerhouse today with a 41-19 victory over Santa Clara. An opening day crowd of 45,000 saw the Golden Bears drive to one or more touchdowns in every period.
Describing yesterday's Queens Golden Anniversary parade as the greatest demonstration ever seen in the borough, President James A. Burke said he planned to make the parade an annual event.
Following is the text of President Truman's speech yesterday at Dexter, Iowa, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark declared tonight that "we have the fifth column on the run in the United States."

IN America we call them Okies and they ride in jalopies, and Steinbeck has written about them. In Britain they call them tinkers and they ride in pony-drawn barrows, and a young Scotsman named Ian Niall has written a remarkably good first novel about them.
Fight fans in the metropolitan area -- and from other points as well -- will have their fill of their favorite sport this week when a pair of outdoor shows will be offered.
BROWSING a few miles from the capital are a hundred animals of greater interest to humanity than any since Noah marched his flock out of the ark.

Twenty-year-old Richard (Pancho) Gonzales stepped upon the stage at Forest Hills yesterday to prevent the United States from being shut out of the national championship tennis singles final for the first time since Fred Perry of Great Britain and Jack Crawford of Australia met for the crown in 1933.

CELINA, Tenn., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Two world's records were set -- one by a woman -- in the 1948 National Outboard championships, which opened a three-day stand on spacious Dale Hollow Lake near here today.

As the last of the 18-year-old men in the city were enrolling for the peacetime draft, eleven men and three women, among them a husband and wife, were arrested yesterday afternoon as they picketed the Washington Irving High School registration center, Seventeenth Street and Irving Place, urging youths not to register.

IT is apparently a temperamental necessity for Miss Vance (Grace Zaring Stone) to combine the suspense of a thrilling physical situation with that of an urgent moral or intellectual problem. Her theory of fiction seems to be that the inwardness of character becomes most readily manifest under unusual pressures of circumstances, and she uses a thrilling situation to concentrate and isolate the problem of character and to speed its solution.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 18 Government "through political trickery and chicanery" was deplored today by Gov. Earl Warren of California as he carried his Republican Vice Presidential campaign through southern Colorado and New Mexico.

THE Western film -- "horse opera" to the connoisseur -- has survived two World Wars, the talkies and Technicolor. According to some authorities, it is Hollywood's most energetic, characteristic and universal contribution to the art of film. Its cowhands, Injuns and endless herds of cattle, moving fast and furiously against a vast background of desert and mesa, are regularly and wholeheartedly cheered in movie houses throughout the world.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- A Communist was killed, three de Gaullists were severely wounded and a score or more persons were injured in an armed clash today at Grenoble just after Charles de Gaulle had made there one of his almost daily campaign speeches.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 18 -- President Truman moved swiftly through Illinois, Iowa and into Missouri today, charging that his political opponents were "gluttons of privilege" and "Wall Street reactionaries" who already have "stuck a pitchfork in the farmer's back."

Lucky Jack Lohrke dug a hole which swallowed up Clint Hartung's chances of getting above the .500 mark yesterday at the Polo Grounds. But, that old pro, Big Jawn Mize, supplied the master's touch that gave the Giants a victory over the Reds and kept that first division berth for the New Yorkers a strong possibility. The score was 12 to 7.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Sept. 18 -- For the first time in its eight decades under American sovereignty, Alaska is to have a year-round industry employing a substantial number of men. This is the meaning to the Territory of the vast pulp mill, soon to be built on the wooded shores of Ward Cove, six miles from Ketchikan.

RHUBARB and asparagus, once established, seem to get along by themselves for several seasons, but this is no reason to neglect them. If care is omitted too many times after harvesting, the plants deteriorate and pickings become lean.

WILKES BARRE, Pa., Sept. 18 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic nominee for Vice President, opened his campaign today with the charge that the Republican-controlled Congress impeded the European Recovery Program, first by failure to act on inflation, then by approving ill-advised tax reduction.

Many parties will be given at the opening performance in this country of the Paris Opera Ballet Tuesday night at the City Center. The event is presented under the sponsorship of many prominent persons in civic life and society, headed by William M. Chadbourne.

For the second successive week a tie-up of private bus transportation was threatened yesterday and, as he had done a week ago, Mayor O'Dwyer stepped in to avert the newest strike threat. Late yesterday afternoon the Mayor summoned bus line representatives and officials of the Transport Workers Union to City Hall for a conference at 10 A. M. today.

DESIGNS of the twenty-first, twenty-second and twenty-third stamps on Washington's 1948 philatelic program were made available last week by the Postoffice Department. These are the Volunteer Firemen tercentenary, the Indian centennial and Rough Riders' semi-centennial commemorative items; scheduled for October.

" THE only way you 'ave peace and quiet in this part o' the world," the corporal of the Royal Marines told the author as their plane was coming down at Lydda airport, "is when you Yanks and us British work together, like in Trieste.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The price of bread went up 50 per cent in France this week. At any time that would be important news in France. At the present time, with Governments toppling and falling because of the conflict between static wages and a rapidly increasing cost of living, it is of tremendous importance.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 18 -- Now that the incidentals of the primary are over, Republicans and Democrat - Farmer - Laborites are digging in for what promises to be a strenuous battle for the United States Senatorship in Minnesota.

The 60,000 members of the National Maritime Union, CIO, are to get the opportunity to decide whether or not they want their union's officers to comply with that provision of the Taft-Hartley Law that calls for the signing of non-Communist affidavits, it was made-known yesterday.

Petroleum development in the Middle East promises to be a means by which the countries of the area can emancipate themselves from the extreme poverty which is general because of their restricted agricultural economies, according to a research study prepared for the Arabian American Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Admiral W. H. Standley, retired, has told the House Committee on Un-American Activities that when he was Ambassador to Russia, President Roosevelt used the Navy's secret codes to send some messages to him because the security of the State Department codes could not be trusted.

WHITEHORSE, Pa., Sept. 18 -- Repose, a 4-year-old brown gelding owned by F. Ambrose Clark of Westbury, N. Y., won along on the Fairy Hill Challenge Cup today in the leading event at the second annual fall race meeting of the Radnor Hunt Club.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 18 (AP) -- A heavy Texas Christian University football team outlasted Kansas' Jayhawks for a 14 to 13 victory today in a game marred by fumbles and blocked kicks.
BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- The Berlin airlift not only is a magnificent technical achievement but in many ways it is the most effective educational force the United States has in Europe today.

THE venerable firm of Dodd, Mead Co. is 109 years old, and Bernard Shaw is a mere 92. But the junior is still quintessentially Shavian. Dodd, Mead were all set to entitle Shaw's forthcoming volume of memoirs "Sketches of Autobiography," and so announced it in their fall catalogue.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 18 -- Mrs. John G. Winant's imported Scottish terrier, Walsing Winning Trick, was named best of some 480 dogs today at the fourteenth annual show of the Lehigh Valley Kennel Club.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian, Minister for External Affairs, is a leading candidate for President of the United Nations General Assembly that convenes here Tuesday, it was learned today.

Did the author of the letter, "Toro, Toro," actually sign himself "Pedro Henriques y?" According to the Hispanic tradition Peter Hendricks' full name would be Peter Hendricks and Smith, supposing his mother's maiden name was Smith.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 18 -- The text of the prepared address by Senator Alben W. Barkley at a labor rally here today follows:

AS an owner and sponsor of a summer theatre I wish to reply to the letter of Francis J. Bassett of Ridgefield, Conn. Although most of what Mr. Bassett says is true, I wish to point out that there are still rustic summer theatres with the pre-war purpose of developing young talent and presenting new plays, although they are far too few.

CONSIDERING the army of would-be actors, singers and assorted entertainers who try to crash Broadway and Hollywood, there should be a ready market for "Your Career in Show Business." The book attempts to explain not only how to choose such a career but also how to get started and succeed in it.

A COMPOST pile does not need to be an eyesore, hidden from sight in a completely inconvenient spot. It should be put in an accessible place, preferably on poor soil that needs enriching. If that happens to be the middle of the garden, put it there.

COMPOSTING waste material, such as grass clippings, weeds, leaves and roadside cuttings, has given us an excellent natural fertilizer which has been an important factor in making our garden productive. Green material should be allowed to wither somewhat before being incorporated.

ARTHUR BLISS is writing an opera titled "The Olympians" in collaboration with J. B. Priestley, according to our London scout. The work will adorn the Covent Garden Opera late this season. As nearly as this corner can determine, it will be the first venture in the medium for either artist.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Halsgal, an invader from Long Island, broke the stakes-winning streak of Rampart, champion mare of the New Jersey circuit, when she outgamed her older rival in a bitter stretch duel in the mile-and-a-furlong Miss America Handicap.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Philadelphia athletics used three scoring innings to rout the Chicago White Sox, 11 -- 3, today for their fifth straight victory. The A's scored once in the first and polished off production with four in the fifth and sixth runs in the eighth.
Retail activity showed a seasonal increase here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Sportswear, dresses and coats were leading departments.

Hundreds of homeward-bound subway patrons watched the capture of two youthful hold-up men at 10:20 o'clock last night in the shuttle entrance to the Times Square subway station at Forty-third Street and Broadway. The thugs had taken over the change booth for fifteen minutes, with one alternately making change at the window and scooping up cash from the till.

THE town of Kalaroo had an extra kangaroo -- that's what started it all. After the Mundys, "the most circus-going people in the United States," buy her, they decide that they want an entire circus. So the Mundy family, including 10-year-old Cappy, go to Africa.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- Henry A. Wallace was booed roundly this afternoon by baseball fans at Braves Field and was acclaimed just as vociferously tonight at the Boston Garden by supporters of his Progressive party candidacy for President.

IN spite of the unusual features of New Orleans life and history that stimulate literary production into mounting numbers of books, most writers have been content to luxuriate in the glamour of its past eras. Few novels have been concerned with contemporary New Orleans, except in a curious how-mad-it-all-is, how-almost-like-the-Left Bank manner.

In the course of their recent meetings both the British and American Associations for the Advancement of Science restored Malthus to his pedestal and urged even stronger reasons than there were in 1798, when he wrote, for believing that the world cannot produce enough food to support a population which is increasing at the rate of 20,000,000 annually.

HUNGARY is making a bid for United States dollars and British pounds through sale of postal paper presenting heads of American and British past notables. Each stamp in a series being issued this week will sell at Hungarian postoffices for double face value, the surtaxes to be divided equally between a hospital for postal employes and a fund for reconstruction of the Nazi-ruined Chain Bridge at Budapest.

The New York Telephone Company has substantially reduced turnover of its operators by new objective hiring methods, C. T. Schrage, employment engineer, disclosed last week. The new methods, he said, eliminate most job applicants who are not likely to remain with the company long after they are hired.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 18 -- The executive committee of the Southern Regional Council stepped into the civil rights controversy today with a formal charge that the matter has been "grossly misrepresented." It declared that the solution was to insure that economic reform went hand-in-hand with current legal efforts to guarantee human rights.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 18 -- Second class international air fares as a means of fighting the competition of charter and unscheduled incursions into the field, particularly on contracts for the transporting of displaced persons from Europe, became a distinct possibility here as the International Air Transport Association ended today its session of fifty lines from forty nations.

WITHIN the next five years the commercial airlines of the world can expect to have transport planes powered by turbine-driven propellers, Sir Frank Whittle, inventor of the Whittle gas turbine, predicted last week.

JUST twenty-two years ago this week in this review: "Debits and Credits," a book of short stories by Rudyard Kipling, had the page one spotlight. Taking a statistical hint from the title, the reviewer found it to be Mr. Kipling's first book of non-fiction in ten years and the fifty-first book he had written.

New protests last week over the recent sale of the Government-owned blast furnace in Cleveland to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation hinted eventual legal action to attempt revocation of the sale. Three court cases contesting the transaction may develop, according to trade sources.
As an analyst of what's wrong with housework Charles K. Agle sounds like an architect with a week off taking over the home while his wife visits Aunt Matilda. * * *
The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday a schedule for construction bids for five public housing projects that will provide homes for approximately 5,500 families.

TO hear the chiropodists tell it, our feet are killing us. The New York State Podiatry Society reports that 80 per cent of Americans old enough to vote have something wrong with their feet. And though 95 per cent of babies are born with good feet, 8 per cent of them have some sort of incipient foot trouble as early as the end of their first year.
In the note to the cover of your magazine of Sept. 5, 1948, you state that "today only five (European monarchs) besides Queen Juliana still rule."

HERSHEY, Pa. Sept. 18 (AP) -- The cost of food for city dwellers "is getting too high," the Rev. William J. Gibbons of New York, told the annual conference of the National Decentralist Institute here today.

SEEING the old, long-established English ivy cut down from a near-by house recently, impressed one gardener with the great difference a vine makes. A building that had looked beautiful a week before seemed, once the ivy was removed, to be a blatant, ugly intrusion in the natural landscape around it.

AT afternoon and evening performances today at the City Center the current revival of "Show Boat" will conclude a fortnight's engagement. It is a pity that the engagement has to be so brief. For "Show Boat" is a classical musical drama that has become part of our cultural heritage.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Foreign Office officials awaited the latest report from Moscow on the Berlin situation tonight with grim pessimism. As Foreign Secretary Bevin leaves tomorrow morning for Paris to lead the British delegation to the United Nations Assembly session, the report of the Western envoys talk with Mr. Molotov this afternoon was rushed to him tonight.

Dr. William Benenson, Assistant Queens County Medical Examiner, said last night that an autopsy he had performed on the body of Jesus Meneu Monleon, 32-year-old flier who crashed in swampland off Jamaica Bay Thursday night, showed that Mr. Monleon had stabbed himself in the heart before the plane came down, and that the wound was the primary cause of his death.

Slight progress was made in security markets last week as values followed a familiar pattern. Fluctuating within a narrow range, in slow trading, stocks toward the end of the third quarter of the year are at approximately their first-of-the-year levels.

DRIVEN from their traditional tenting grounds, the metropolitan area canoe campers have become the displaced persons of the lower Hudson River. Weary of back and sore of muscle, the tribe has diminished in the nine years that the Palisades Interstate Park Commission has waged war on the paddle-pullers, from the shadows of the George Washington Bridge to the New York-New Jersey State line and, finally, as far north as Haverstraw Beach.
ALL preparation and planning for the spring bulb garden must be done many months before the flowering season. Happily, few flowers fulfill the expectations of the catalogues as well as the bulbs.

SPRING flowering bulbs have become so popular during the last decade that hybridizers have concentrated on developing new varities. Although there are hundreds of older kinds from which to choose, the discriminating gardener this fall will want to add a few of the latest to his collection.

MITCHEL AIR BASE, Sept. 18 -- The United States Air Force celebrated today its first anniversary as an autonomous arm of the national defense establishment with an awesome show of aerial might and the announcement that a new and official world speed record had been set by one of its jet fighters.

The enterprising business man who finds himself duped by a smooth-talking oil-stock salesman has unwittingly set the stage for the crime, suggests Dr. Hans von Hentig of Yale, whose specialty is criminology.
THIS is the story of Hirsch Schwartzberg and his "passport to nowhere" -- the story of the last remnants of Jewish Displaced Persons who have moved from tragedy to tragedy, outcast and forgotten.

PAWLING, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told a group of farm editors today that he hopes, if he is elected President, to have much closer relations with Congress than now prevail between the White House and Capitol Hill.

DARRYL F. ZANUCK'S recent announcement that Twentieth Century-Fox will make twelve pictures in Europe this year has caused a good deal of excitement and apprehension in Hollywood and particularly at his own studio, but Zanuck last week reaffirmed his decision in a statement in which he said: "Locales in all parts of Europe are to be embraced in the activities which these twelve pictures involve.

Polo of the highest order is expected to be unfolded this afternoon when Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes ride against Great Neck in the final-round match of the national open championship on famed International Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

THE 1948 European summer-tourist season, now ending with thousands of American travelers arriving in New York every day by westbound ship and plane, enveloped the pleasure traveler with an international economic importance he never before enjoyed.

Gordon Stott dropped an eight-foot putt for a birdie 4 at the second extra hole to enable him and his guest, Dr. Gerald B. Harrigan of Sands Point, the medalists, to gain the semi-final round of the eighth annual North Hills Golf Club member-guest tournament yesterday in Douglaston.

Reorder buying of women's apparel for fall has exceeded all expectations, according to manufacturers in New York's garment market. Out-of-town buyers were here last week to fill out stocks for October and pre-holiday business, and made strong efforts to obtain additional merchandise for special promotional events.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 18 -- The Princely State of Hyderabad will be under Indian military government until "normality is restored," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced in a broadcast tonight. He said a Constituent Assembly would be elected in Hyderabad to decide the state's political future.

EVERY three or four years many established garden plants grow into crowded tangles of roots and foliage, with only sparse and inferior bloom to remind us of their former pinnacle of performance. When that time arrives it is necessary to rejuvenate the plant by lifting and dividing the roots and replanting them in a more fertile soil.

English and American furniture, Georgian silver, Chinese cloisonne enamels, sculptures, Oriental rugs and a large variety of porcelains and other decorations will be auctioned on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernat Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

THIS blithe and headlong novel concerns the amazing adventures of an extraordinary young English girl. Her love is a handsome Austrian lieutenant, and her pursuit of him involves her in Austria's pre-Anschluss troubles.

There are still a few old-fashioned individuals who sigh for the days when a man went fishing merely for the fun of fishing, and was unconcerned with the possibility of any reward other than the thrill of taking a big fish on rod and reel.

MURDER is done in the Randall School of Languages, where Haila Troy has been taking lessons in Spanish from Gerald Stewart, the man who has been eliminated. That is sufficient reason for Haila's husband, Jeff Troy, to take a hand in the investigation, particularly since sleuthing is Jeff's hobby.

THE joint project of Mr. Prokosch's four protagonists is to reach a mountain peak in the heart of Africa. Throughout it all, as is usual with this poet, turned novelist, he keeps the souls of his characters very much in the foreground -- if only as the subject of grave discourse.

AN amateur, according to Webster, is "one who dabbles." On the basis of the forthcoming exhibition of "Paintings by Famous Amateurs," the meaning might be changed to "one who daubs." Modern art is apparently becoming something that adults, as well as "a 5-year-old child," can do. Painting is, it would seem, the part-time preoccupation of everbody who is anybody in society and cafe society, on stage and screen, in the sport and political arenas.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 18 -- An official Israeli spokesman gave tonight the Government's view of Dr. Bunche's reference to Foreign Minister Shertok's statements criticizing the mediation proceedings. He said:

Last week the American Association for the Advancement of Science met in Washington to celebrate its centenary. It was so important an occasion that President Truman used it to dwell on science's role in the development of the country and the part it was destined to play in the future.

An officer of the hurricane-battered Freighter Leicester told yesterday how four crewmen were swept overboard while others clung to deck rails singing to keep up their courage. Six men were reported lost from the British ship.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Coasting behind the fourteenth homers of Manager Lou Boudreau and Jim Hegan, the third-place Cleveland Indians today handed the Washington Nationals their eighteenth straight loss -- two short of the Major League record.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The assassination of Count Bernadotte and a French aide by Jewish terrorists in Jerusalem was condemned today by delegates to the United Nations Security Council as "senseless," "dastardly" and "tragic."

PROVINCETOWN, MASS. -- Cape Cod's famous whale, Willie, which is almost as well known here as the Pilgrim Memorial, is at it again. Last week he poked his head out of the calm Atlantic to race circles around the fishing yacht Katharine II and then, while its twenty passengers (including this reporter) watched in amazement, dive playfully beneath it.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 18 -- Capitulation of Hyderabad four and a half days after the Indian Army crossed the borders of the state is expected here to eradicate the last flaw in the unified structure of India so far as the Princely States are concerned.

Installment purchases made before tomorrow, Sept. 20, the effective date of new credit controls, of merchandise that cannot be delivered until after that date will not be affected by the new law, an official of the Federal Reserve Bank declared here yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Leaders of both the Stern group and the Irgun Zvai Leumi, other dissident group, in Jerusalem denied responsibility for the killings. Up to noon today, the Stern group had issued no official announcement. Heretofore it has announced always by radio or poster within twenty-four hours any act for which it admitted responsibility.

THIS story will have special appeal in those homes where "I don't want to AND I WON'T" is frequently heard. The Little Old Automobile said just that whenever he was asked to wait until someone could get out of his way. Of course 4 to 7 year olds and their parents know that calamity must overtake anyone so impudent and stubborn.

The Western European Union -- its hopes and its military potentialities -- was the subject of much quiet and confidential discussion in Washington, London and Paris last week, as it has been throughout the summer.

PUTTING the soil into good condition is the first essential for any garden, be it old or new. In fall, many planting and transplanting jobs must be done, but before any of these can be started some attention should be given to the soil.

Yesterday in Moscow the envoys of the United States, Great Britain and France drove in the rain through streets that have become especially familiar to them -- the streets leading to the Kremlin. The envoys had an appointment to see Russia's Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, in another of the long series of conferences on the crisis of Berlin.
MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- The Western envoys met today with Foreign Minister Molotov possibly to receive the final Russian word on proposals for settling the Berlin crisis.
IN many a garden no permanent planting stands in greater need of attention than does the lawn. Repairing or remaking a lawn and sowing a new one are better done in fall than in spring.

THE particular point in my review which Dr. Gates has objected to amazes me. My statement that "Gates traces mankind back to several different kinds of anthropoids" obviously did not imply that these ancestral anthropoids were the contemporary trio mentioned by Klaatsch.

PARIS -- France's most successful tourist season since 1931 appears to be exceeding the hopes of the French Government, which has so far welcomed 74,000 American tourists and hopes for 25,000 more dollar-spenders before the end of the year.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Christian, Jew and Arab expressed tonight the world's sorrow over the slaying of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine -- and wondered whether his death would bring new bloodshed to Palestine.

LAKELAND, Fla., Sept. 18 -- Depression and dissension are plaguing Florida's citrus industry as harvesting of a record crop of more than 100,000,000 boxes begins. Many growers lost money last season after having enjoyed fabulous prosperity during previous years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall received the International Humanitarian Award tonight from the Variety Clubs International as the Outstanding Man of the Year in that field. The presentation was a dinner at the Statler Hotel.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- A celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the incorporation of Croton as a village will begin tomorrow and continue for eight days. Parades, exhibitions, fireworks, public speaking and radio broadcasting are on the program.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
TOKYO Sept. 17 -- Agitation against continuing unneeded economic controls, especially those over prices, has assumed the proportions of a national movement.

REVERSING Mr. Dickens' aphorism about a little red ink at the end of the year meaning misery, the amiable band of Hollywood luminaries incorporated as the Actors' Company are deriving quit satisfaction from the modicum of debit that stands as they wind up their second year of La Jolla straw-hatting and head into their second ambitious year of "winter" producing.

WORD comes from Germany that the fifty-two paintings from the famous "salt-mine" Kaiser-Friedrich Museum collection, which were returned to Germany last May, have been drawing extraordinary crowds of about 2,000 to 3,000 people daily.

" INFORMATION PLEASE," usually a regular feature on the early fall radio schedule, this year finds itself with unsettled plans. After last spring's legal tiff with the Mutual network, the pionieer quiz show is certain not to return to that chain, but where it may turn up in the future is a moot question.

NOT so long ago a well-known New York architect and designer was on his first visit to California and, like all visiting firemen, he felt his vacation would not be complete without a tour of one of the major studios.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Before a watching throng of 15,000 persons at the Battle of Britain air display near Margate, Kent, today a twin-engined Mosquito completed half an acrobatic maneuver and then suddenly dived out of control into a line of motor cars and cycles on way to the air show.

LONDON -- Up to the end of July, 300,000 tourists, 46,000 of them from the United States, had visited Britain this year. By the end of 1948 the total is expected to exceed half a million visitors whose expenditures are estimated to reach $160,000,000.

FEDERAL Regulation W limiting installment buying, which goes into effect tomorrow, will affect thousands of automobile purchasers. About 45 per cent of all the vehicles bought in the New York metropolitan district are acquired on the partial-payment plan.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 18 -- The Korean National Assembly ratified today a financial and property agreement signed early this week by representatives of the United States and the Korean Republic.

The Excalibur, first of the American Export Lines' new "Four Aces," completed her nine-hour sea trials yesterday and is being prepared to depart Friday for her maiden voyage to the Mediterranean. The tests were made outside the harbor.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 18 -- In replying to the protest by Dr. Bunche, an Israeli Government representative said today that the assassination was planned days in advance of the press conference at which Foreign Minister Shertok and an Israeli Army officer made the statements of which the United Nations official complained.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 18 (UP) -- The remodelled Mountaineers of West Virginia University started on the road back today under their new coach, Dudley DeGroot, by steaming over Waynesburg for a 29-to-16 victory.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's endorsement of the long-range farm-support program brought some buying into deferred wheat contracts on the Board of Trade today. At one time the July, 1949, delivery rose again above $2 a bushel.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Hospital Commissioner, said yesterday that the city's bed capacity for cancer patients would be increased from 287 to 504 with the completion of the new 307-bed Francis Delafield Hospital for Cancer, the cornerstone of which will be laid on Tuesday afternoon.

A Wall Streeter by day and by night investment-banker extraordinary to the American theater. That's Howard S. (Stix) Cullman, who, among his many and varied financial, business, civic and philanthropic interests, also is chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

ALTHOUGH novice and veteran gardeners are finding that an orchard presents an increasing problem of disease and insects, there is no reason why such a planting cannot again become the main attraction in home gardens.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Miss Grace Lenczyk of Newington, Conn., 21-year-old intercollegiate and Canadian golf champion, today won the United States women's amateur crown by defeating Miss Helen Sigel of Philadelphia, 4 and 3, in a scheduled thirty-six-hole match.

IT is gratifying and encouraging to see at last a new French film which has the depth and maturity of some of the great pre-war pictures from France. And, indeed, it is even more encouraging to have a new theatre open here with emphasis on taste and decorum and dedicated to the decent showing of foreign films.

THE Man of the Hour right now at the country and shore resorts is a man in a blue denim shirt, disreputable pants and perfectly disgraceful hat. Chews tobacco, too. Probably takes a drink of'ner'n he should. Yet he is more popular than a white-flanneled doubles partner or a Hollywood-shirted fourth at bridge.

NANKING, Sept. 18 -- The two-month relative lull in military operations has been broken by Communist attacks in two separate areas -- one in East China centering around Tsinan, the capital of Shantung Province; the other along the Peiping-Mukden railroad and now focused on the northeast Hopei port of Chinwangtao.

ON Tuesday evening the ballet from the Paris Opera makes its local bow after performances in Montreal and Chicago, as part of the Mayor's Committee's International Dance Festival at the Center Theatre in celebration of New York's Golden Jubilee.

IN spite of the invigorating tang of autumn air that makes planting of perennials, shrubs and trees a pleasure, some limits should be imposed on this enthusiasm. Certain kinds, for example, will be more likely to succeed if they are not set out until spring.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte by terrorist gunmen in Jerusalem brought danger of resumption of Arab-Jewish hostilities which were suspended through his efforts as United Nations Mediator. It also presented the United Nations, now meeting in Paris, with what may prove to be a crucial test of its value as an instrument for preserving world peace.

Many adolescents would lead a dull life without the vicarious experiences offered by the radio, comic strips and motion pictures. And until something more wholesome can be substituted, adults must recognize such forms of entertainment as a "very important contribution to youthful happiness."

THE HAGUE -- The summer tourist season been a good one, particularly with respect to Americans who have shown an increase of about 25 per cent in their numbers and, more important, who have spent approximately $3,000,000 here.

Declaring that some street peddlers are fined $2 as many as thirty or forty times a year, James N. Spear, president of the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association, urged the city administration yesterday to curb street peddling at once.

EFFECTIVE shrub planting on the small property is a study in proportion and year-round appearance. The number of shrubs is restricted by the space limitations, so each plant must be as carefully chosen as the basic items in a well-planned budget wardrobe.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Crispin Oglebay's Noble Impulse, 2-year-old-son of Bull Dog, led all the way to gain a three-length victory today in the $10,000 added James H. Connors Memorial Stakes, feature of Narragansett Park's closing day.
