" HE has such a deep voice. He should be a radio announcer." How many times have people come to me with that story! How many people in the country are convinced that the only requisite for success in the field of radio announcing is an echo chamber in the chest!

WAS there any feeling of love between man and woman before there was a consciousness of sin to be suffered and forgiven? What have been the determining passions, insights and masteries that have led by slow steps and grand leaps to the complex human personalities of modern society?

With the help of municipal housing and planning officials, a group of civic leaders has completed plans for an $8,000,000 non-profit cooperative apartment center for 728 families on ten acres in Queens, it was learned last night.

It was refreshing to read Henry Steele Commager's article. The Mundt-Nixon school of thought is basically an attack upon communism, while Mr. Commager faces the problem of perpetuating our democratic government.

MR. MORGAN ran across the trail of the Shenandoah when he was doing research on the Aleutians, the subject of his recent book, "Bridge to Russia." Near those islands the Confederate commerce raider burned a large fleet of United States whalers in June, 1865, the last of her total of thirty-eight ships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Marshall Plan's "big push" is on, the Economic Cooperation Administration disclosed tonight by earmarking $1,769,000,000 for European recovery in the next three months.

MEXICO'S motion-picture industry is experiencing a serious slump, although devaluation of the peso, combined with other cheaper operating costs, has made it possible, according to experts, to produce films here at one-fourth the expenditure required in Hollywood.

TWO 8mm magazine-loading DeJur movie cameras, a single-lens and a turret model, both featuring built-in professional control of fade-in and fade-out of scenes, were introduced at a press preview last week. The single-lens Standard Model 100, with a coated Cine Raptar Special 13mm f/2.5 lens, will sell for $127.50; with an f/1.9, $149.50.
The United States Air Force celebrated Air Force Day all over this country yesterday and also in other parts of the world where the United States still maintains occupation forces.

STARTING activities with a two-week pre-season tour, which opens tomorrow night in Syracuse, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will have presented two extensive contemporary works new to its repertory before it returns to Carnegie Hall for its 107th annual series.

THIS is the first volume of an elaborate series dealing with the manifold historical, literary, ethical and religious aspects of the Jewish and Christian Scriptures. The series will consider the various texts and translations, the commentaries and references from the Talmudic period to modern times, and the authorship, style, background and content of each book of the Bible.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 18 -- The Communists are expected to lose same of their fifteen seats tomorrow when the Swedes go to the polls to elect 230 members to the second chamber of the duo-cameral Riksdag for four-year terms from January, 1949.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- The spring remaining in the aged heels of Sun Beau brought cash, two trophies and a championship to the Sterling Smith gelding from Ravenna, Ohio, on the pleasant closing afternoon of the forty-third Piping Rock horse show today.

TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff of Memphis smashed the Fircrest course competitive record with a 64 today, but failed by a single stroke to catch Fred Haas Jr., of New Orleans in the third round of the $12,500 Tacoma open golf tournament.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 18 -- The Texas Longhorns showed power and speed aground today as they whipped the Louisiana State Tigers, 33 -- 0, with the largest opening-game attendance in history -- 47,500 -- watching the one-sided game.
Dispatches which have appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES dated Munich, Aug. 20, Aug 24 and Sept. 1, followed by your editorial in THE TIMES of Sept. 5, are inaccurate and based on partial facts only.

Ira A. Hirschmann, member of the Board of Higher Education, said yesterday he had asked Ordway Tead, president of the board, to place on the agenda of the Sept. 27 meeting an inquiry into the conduct of Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College.

A YEAR ago the Giants bounced so high off the home run springboard that there were strong hopes this season that the Clout Circu would bounce even higher. But all of the muscle men suffered a simultaneous attack of anemia of the batting average and of shrinkage of the distance drives. Since there wasn't much pitching strength on the premises anyway, the Polo Grounds tenants collapsed and buried poor Mel Ott Under the wreckage.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 -- The Boston Red Sox came from behind and made much of a fine opportunity this afternoon, defeating the St. Louis Browns, 11 to 6, thereby increasing their lead in the American League to two games over the New York Yankees.

THE Palais de Chaillot in Paris is exquisitely ready for the opening on Tuesday of the meeting of the United Nations Assembly. The burgundy-satin and antique-gold background has been arranged in the grand manner inherited from Le Roi Soleil. The City of Light is making of the occasion, solemn as it is, almost a fiesta.

POPULAR misconceptions about camera lenses were discussed by Dr. Konstantin Pestrecov of Bausch Lomb Optical Company at the season's first meeting of the New York section of the photographic Society of America's Technical Division.

LILY bulbs should be planted in fall if they are to establish their finest heads of bloom the first summer. The ideal planting time is shortly after the stems have died down and the new bulbs for the following season have fully matured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Labor unions which have not complied with the non-Communist affidavit requirement of the Taft-Hartley Act have been "behind the eight-ball" for more than a year. They have had to suffer disabilities which have been extremely costly.

AT first Peter Duluth thinks it was an accident -- that Deborah Brand missed her footing and fell into the deep well that once was the final resting place of the maidens sacrificed to the rain god by the ancient priests of Chichen-Itza.

American colleges and universities, especially on the graduate level, maintain inadequate standards for the training of social scientists. Mediocre and inferior students are permitted to graduate from the social science departments, often with the Doctor of Philosophy degree, much to the detriment of the profession.

SOME people are put off by the words "honest" and "serious" in a review. They think the book is dull. Before saying anything about Harry Sylvester's honesty or seriousness some arresting statement is necessary: there are fourteen stories in this book, and only a fire-bell or a scream in the next room would make you stop reading at least ten of them.

An investigation of violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, created last year by Congress to give "interested parties" the opportunity of stating their views on any regulation proposed by a Government agency, will soon be undertaken, it was learned here at the week-end.

TIMING is an essential part of the play of a bridge hand. According to tradition, it is something that cannot be taught. Generalizations are considered pernicious because the average player tends to consider them axioms and will follow them blindly even when they do not apply.
The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, former rabbi of Vine Street Temple, Nashville, Tenn., will be installed as the senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El on Friday evening.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Sept. 18 -- Without a hitch in the smoothness of its normal operations the Wiesbaden Airbase welcomed today 10,000 American and German guests to the celebration of the first anniversary of the United States Air Force. The major feature of the program for the visitors proved to be the departure of the daily quota of planes of the Berlin airlift.

ONE of the interesting problems to a playwright in writing a fantasy is the curious relationship which must be maintained between the play and its audiences. In the so-called "straight" play which offers the illusion of natural experiences, a constant appeal must be made to five senses.
WHILE slender spires of purple and white liatris rise against masses of pink hardy asters this month, gardeners can be busy planting columbines and blue flax for another display next May and June.

ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S CAMPAIGN TRAIN IN THE MIDDLE WEST, Sept. 18 -- Personally convinced that by hard work he can turn the tide of public opinion now running in favor of his Republican opponent, President Truman moved today, through the Corn Belt, headed for the Pacific Coast.

American U.--Washington study Five schools this fall will join the American University, Washington, D. C., in sponsoring a unique interinstitutional honors program. Known as "the Washington Semester," the program frees selected junior-year students from academic routine to allow them to devote themselves to individual research.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (Reuters) -- -- Portsmouth, unbeaten this season, maintained the lead in the English League's first division today though playing a 1-1 draw with Manchester City.
SEVERAL weeks must pass, we know, before anyone can obtain rose bushes from the nurseries. But gardeners who know their rose-growing are already deep in the fall catalogues.

The next few months will tell whether the current financial reform in China will be a success. Up to the present, reports from China indicate that the Chinese government, determined to save the country from utter economic ruin, is pushing through with vigor its policies to maintain the value of the new currency -- the gold yuan.

ARCOLA, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, who holds a unique place in New Jersey golfing annals by being the only amateur who has won the state open championship, gained the final of the Arcola Country Club's twenty-fifth invitation tourney along with the current state champion, Joe McBride of Arcola.

Members of the Episcopal Actors Guild have taken over the performance of "Life With Mother" on the night of Nov. 5 at the Empire Theatre to raise funds for the organization. The occasion will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Guild, which maintains its national headquarters in the Guild Hall of the Little Church Around the Corner, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

IT would be interesting to know exactly which scores of Dimitri Shostakovich incurred the displeasure of the Russian authorities some months ago. Here is the Third Quartet, Op. 73, composed in 1946 and recorded by the Fine Arts Quartet of the American Broadcasting Company (Mercury, four twelve-inch disks), and one wonders whether it would pass official muster.

THROWN in without cost to patrons who pay their dimes for a ride in New York subways is an exhibition of art. It is modern in style, but has an old-fashioned Victorian quality about it, too -- because it teaches a lesson and tells a moral tale.

HAIFA, Palestine, Sept. 18 -- A Swedish ambulance driven by a lone United States Marine brought the flag-draped bodies of the assassinated Count Folke Bernadotte United Nations Mediator for Palestine, and Col. Andre Pierre Serot, his French aide, from Jerusalem to Haifa today.

The National Citizens Committee for the Reelection of President Truman, with headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel, issued a statement yesterday saying that editors and publishers of twenty Negro newspapers had announced their support of the President and had joined the committee. The list follows:
Frank Herbst, representative of Local 1, United Public Workers, CIO, asked Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to intervene in the dispute between the union and Commissioner of Welfare Haymond M. Hilliard.

SINING, China, Sept. 6 -- During the Kuomintang revolution of 1911 the Chinese Mohammedans in the northwest sided with the Manchus against the republican rebels from the south. Now that the Kuomintang is in power, the Mohammedans are allied again with the status quo, even though Moslem authorities here complain against Nanking for "insufficient" allocation of arms to provincial troops.
ASKED by a neighbor whether he thought he would like school, Stephen said: "Well, I don't know. There's too much. There's a too muchness in it."

MOUNT WASHINGTON, MASS. THE law -- abiding citizens of this South Berkshire town (pop. 53) are calm and unruffled as they regard the swift movements of a frenzied, puzzled world. Their greatest qualities, however, are probably independence and pride in the town.

CAPT. DUANE HOGAN is sent to Djibouti on a hush-hush mission. He doesn't like Djibouti. Nobody does. The Arabs say that the place was made from scraps that were left over when Hell was finished. Hogan is inclined to believe it until he meets the blonde.

At 11:06 A. M. last Friday a seventeen-car special train pulled out of Union Station in Washington. Its No. 1 passenger was President Harry S. Truman, off on his first extended tour in his first campaign for the Presidency.

Some time ago I read with interest "Dan Greco and That Thing Called Inflation." More recently, in your Letters column, I read a comment on the Greco family written by a Mr. Octavus Platt. Now it seems to me that Mr. Platt has the wrong slant on happiness and contentment.

UNNOTICED in the flood tide of Britain's economic crisis, a tiny redoubt of foreign blood and customs in this kingdom is slowly disappearing from view. Britain's gypsies -- now numbering no more than thirty thousand -- are merging inescapably into the bloodstream of the population.

THIS year's Salzburg Festival was closer to the pre-war international pattern than has been the case in any previous post-war summer. The musical fundament was again provided by the Vienna State Opera and the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, but there was much to be seen and heard beyond the normal fare of a Vienna winter season.

The United States Air Force celebrated its first anniversary yesterday as a co-equal member of our unified defense team in two striking ways. Over the United States it gave evidence of its primary purpose -- war action -- by sending in its giant bombers from overseas bases for a simulated attack on twenty-five American cities and deploying its fighters over twice as many more.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 125,064, as against 146,889 a year ago, a decrease of 7 per cent. Wholesale and retail interests since Labor Day have been covering seasonal requirements in general merchandise.

A simple plan transformed an area thirty feet wide by fifty feet long into an attractive garden for Mr. and Mrs. George Plumly, Philadelphia, Pa. Shrubs and vines give privacy and background and, with the lawn, form a setting for flowers. The summerhouse and pool are focal points of enjoyment. Borders around the four sides of the garden are filled with a succession of bloom from early spring until frost.

A MAN with a neat mind and a love of system and order is not usually a man of imagination or of large vision. If there is a rule to this effect, the late Dr. S. S. Goldwater certainly was an exception to it. It was precisely because he was as systematic as an engineer and as idealistic as a social reformer that he was the outstanding figure in this country on hospitals.
EVERY Sunday night up to 1,000 visitors enter the National Gallery of Art not to see the Rembrandts, Tincorettos and Titians, but to hear Bach, Mozart and Aaron Copland.

THIS will be September's theatre week. Four productions are listed and by Friday's dawn the first-nighters should be acknowledging a malady not far removed from vertigo. Considerable attention, of course, will be focused on the musical, "Magdalena," at the Ziegfeld tomorrow mostly because it represents the first contribution to the theatre by the Brazilian composer, Heitor Villa-Lobos.

Following are excerpts from an introductory chapter by Sir Laurence Olivier in the book, "Hamlet: The Film and the Play," published by Saturn Press, London, England. The film "Hamlet" will open on Sept. 29 at the Park Avenue Theatre.

A wind and rain storm, described by the Weather Bureau as a line squall, caused considerable damage last evening in parts of New Jersey, Westchester County and Connecticut. The storm, accompanied by thunder and lightning, passed over the city about 7 o'clock but did no harm here.

FALL is a season for planting as well as for harvest. The cycles meet, and no one day can be set aside for gathering crops or for planting. Both march in orderly progression through the next three months.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- All records for the United States airlift into Berlin and for the combined United States and British supply of city were smashed today in a convincing demonstration of the Western powers' ability to feed and fuel Western Berlin despite the three-months-old Russian blockade.

Improved styling and mechanical advances are emphasized in the 1949 Kaiser special and de luxe models announced yesterday by Edgar F Kaiser, vice president and general manager of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation. The cars will be displayed tomorrow in dealer showrooms here and throughout the country.
Virtual disappearance of the conventional paper check of varying size and texture, for corporate dividend payments and other large-scale distributions, is foreseen by bank observers here.

NORMAN COLLIN'S last book was a novel of teeming London town, published in this country a few years ago as "Dulcimer Street." Demonstrating a stylish change of pace, Mr. Collins now delivers from his native Britain a novel which spurns cities and sidewalks and the noise of the madding crowd.
New York's four municipal colleges will open their doors tomorrow to an estimated 28,896 day-session students.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- With only one opposing vote, the top executive group of the American Veterans Committee voted today to oust John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, from membership in the organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The convention in Washington this week of the American Association for the Advancement of Science has afforded a sounding board for an attack on a problem of government administration which is rapidly becoming acute -- the reluctance of scientists to work for the Government.

MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Sept. 18 -- W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, said today that the Air Force already had fifty-five combat groups and the goal of seventy such divisions was in prospect.

The sun sinks west, by the compass; dawn rises clear out of the east; there is only a few minutes' difference between the span of a day's light and darkness. Thus ends the summer, with the scarlet feathers of the sumac thrusting from roadside thickets, symbolic of the Indian Summer to come.

September is, among other things, the month for memories. It is in September that mortal man, glancing up from his desk in the middle of the morning, looks mistily back to July and August. September is, among other things, the month of ambition.
PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Never in the history of the United Nations as a peacetime organization has the world been so bitterly divided as on the eve of the third regular session of the General Assembly.

The brutal murder of Count Folke Bernadotte and his aide, Colonel Andre Serot, in Jerusalem on Friday has given a new and sinister turn to the situation in unhappy Palestine. The members of the Stern Gang, some of whom boasted of this crime, were yesterday being hunted down.

EVERY gardener has his own method of making a compost pile, but the results are generally pretty much the same. The procedure actually is controlled by the place, the materials available and the needs of the garden.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Brig. U Tin Tut, a leader in the fight against Burma's Communist-led rebellion, was near death in a hospital today from wounds inflicted by an assailant who booby-trapped his car.

THERE are many gaps in the records of Robert Bruce's life, lacunae especially tantalizing to young people hot for certainties. Yet out of the legends, the apocryphal stories, the conflicting viewpoints of chroniclers whose estimates differed according to their sympathies, Mrs. Baker, one of our most accomplished biographers for young people, has welded a vivid, integrated, convincing life of the Scots liberator.

OF all the paradoxes of the Soviet Union probably the most difficult to understand is the Russian mentality. Americans read of outstanding Soviet scientists, editors, composers and artists being suddenly accused of deviation from or distortion of the true Marxian "line" and they read soon afterward that the accused have admitted their faults, renounced all that they had previously been famous for and promised a complete about-face.

THE so in our flower borders and vegetable garden is a heavy clay, slow to dry out in spring, and baked hard at the first touch of summer heat. Our compost pile. therefore, is not only a matter of pride, but one of absolute necessity.

OKLAHOMA CITY -- Travel by bus over the far reaches of this plains country is something everyone should experience at least once, especially Easterners, who, as historians have noted, develop early a kind of personal isolationism whenever traveling in a public conveyance.

A REBIRTH of hiking for pleasure among a large section of the country's vacationers has been given added impetus with the improved facilities along existing trails and the construction of hiking paths in nearly all the new parks in the Eastern states.

WITHOUT passing over the hard work of clearing fields, mending fences, and fall planting, Katherine Southwick Keeler nevertheless manages in her third story about Meadow Brook Farm to make autumn as agreeable a season as she already has made spring and summer.

A large number of out-of-town buyers visited the wholesale apparel market here last week and covered their needs in all ready-to-wear lines, particularly holiday wear, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

THE prospect of wholly tax-supported museums usually induces shuddering negatives. Turn our culture over to politicians? Think of the fate of the State Department pictures! Look at opportunities for graft! What happens to art budgets when streets need repairing?

As a result of help with their emotional problems, as well as the use of medicine, 80 to 85 per cent of the several thousand persons who have received treatment at the Headache Clinic of Montefiore Hospital have been relieved considerably, it was reported yesterday.

In your issue of Aug. 22 there appeared an article titled "Should We Outlaw the Communist Party?" by Henry Steele Commager, from which I quote the following: "The newly formed States' Rights party (Dixiecrats) of the South, a party formally dedicated to nullifying the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments of the Constitution."
As a regular in the line-up Pistol Pete Reiser may be a bust, but as a pinch hitter he is tops on Manager Barney Shotton's list.

THE family cook, it is estimated, uses a knife in some sort of task about 129 times daily. Despite its importance, that blade may be as dull as a rusty can-opener. Knowing a bit about kitchen efficiency, chefs show knives more respect than most of us women do.

THE most popular small fruits for the home garden are raspberries, strawberries, blueberries and grapes. While all of these require a certain amount of space, even a small plot can produce an amazing amount of fruit.

THORNECLIFFE, England, Sept. 18 -- From the depths of this narrow valley near Sheffield, fingers of smoke from hundreds of factory chimneys shoot straight into the air, bow in unison before the wind and blend lazily into an amorphous mass that hides the feverish hum of an industry far below.

FLORIDA'S resort business has only two seasons, summer and winter, each six months long. While the current summer season will not end until winter season schedules are adopted in November, hotel men who operated throughout the summer are already saying that this has been an unprecedented season from the standpoint of Latin-American tourists, even though domestic trade was definitely off.

All last week delegates from fifty-eight nations were converging on Paris for the third regular meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, opening this Tuesday. The agenda for the Assembly contains sixty-odd items, many of them dealing with critical questions in the struggle between Russia and the West.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- President Truman named tonight a seven-member committee to examine methods and procedures of eliminating racial discrimination in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The train on which President Truman will make his campaign for election consists of 17 cars. His private car is the Ferdinand Magellan, officially United States Railroad Car No. 1. One Diesel engine will haul the train when the going is easy; an extra one in the mountains.

The first step in a move to form a Joint Bureau of National Salesmen's Associations will take place in Washington tomorrow when a group of executives will meet in the Statler Hotel to set a date and agenda for the first formal meeting of the group, which tentatively comprises the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen, the National Association of Men's Apparel Clubs and the National Shoe Travelers Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Dave Beck has captured actual control of the AFL teamster's union from Daniel J. Tobin, the president, and has set his sights for control of the entire labor movement, according to Lester Hunt, who worked as a publicist for both men.

IN his second novel, some two years after "Mr. Adam" exploded into the best-seller lists, Pat Frank has changed his mood, if not his tense. He still has his sights trained squarely on tomorrow's news stories, but he doesn't think they are so funny any more.

IN January, 1947, the Haganah sponsored ship Exodus 1947, formerly the river boat President Warfield, put out from an American port with the intention of picking up refugee passengers and landing them in Palestine against the British blockade.

In contrast to the mistrust and suspicion that have marked many conferences of the United Nations and its specialized agencies, the recent meeting of the World Health Assembly in Geneva, Switzerland, achieved an inspiring degree of cooperation and agreement.
Large equipment manufacturers took steps here yesterday, at an off-the-record meeting, to be fully prepared to meet any one of three developments which may occur within the next sixty days.

THE 1948 art season got under way last week with activities at the Whitney, the Museum of Modern Art and the Morgan Library; a group annual, two outstanding sculpture shows and a variety of other events.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Rallying in the final two periods the 16-goal Westbury polo team came from behind to defeat Long Island, 8 -- 6, in the opening-round match of the annual Monty Waterbury Cup series on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

New electrical equipment capable of analysis of living matter, without drastic chemical changes in the process, was exhibited yesterday at a meeting on recent progress in electrophoresis at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

THE vagaries of reviewers are sometimes difficult to account for. That is not the case, however, with the review of my "Human Ancestry," by Dr. Robert C. Cook. This book is a straightforward account of the main discoveries of fossil man, which have been made in recent years, including some account of the implements and weapons they used.

In the article "Close-Up of Our Wildlife," by Lorus J. and Margery J. Milne, it is stated that the Jackson Hole Wildlife Park is "the first such wildlife park in the world." Is not the Kruger Park in South Africa such a park?
New York's eighteen-day-old truck tie-up virtually came to an end yesterday when the resistance of major employers to wage demands by Local 807 finally cracked.

DURING the next few years many more varieties of hyacinths will be introduced to the discriminating American gardener. Each year the growers in the Netherlands extend their stock of new seedlings but since the cycle for hyacinths is longer than for tulips, introductions are necessarily fewer in number.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- College football, unmindful of the early start by the professionals, moved back into the sports picture today as Villanova overpowered Texas A. and M., 34 -- 14, before a shirt-sleeved, sun-drenched crowd of 35,000 persons at Franklin Field.
A 9,000-ton cargo of Army wheat bound for Germany is to be unloaded here and transferred to another ship because of the West Coast maritime strike, it was reported here last night.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 -- The Yankees' persistent pursuit of the elusive first place in the American League flag race ran head on into Hal Newhouser's willowy left arm today and the result was about the same as one usually gets when one cracks into a door in the dark.

It was father-and-son day yesterday afternoon when Josh White and 7-year-old Josh Jr. gave a joint folksong recital at Town Hall. A large audience hung on every note of the ballads, work songs and blues sung to the virtuoso accompaniment of Josh's guitar playing.

" EXPRESS your individuality," say the mentors of home decoration. And many a homemaker taking this to mean. "You must be novel," ends up with an assortment of eccentricities that look as labored as they do quaint.

New York City has two budgets. One is the executive budget, which covers operating costs. For 1948-49 that budget totals $1,160,538,857; it is met out of current taxes. It was approved by the Board of Estimate last spring.

New York City has two budgets. One is the executive budget, which covers operating costs. For 1948-49 that budget totals $1,160,538,857; it is met out of current taxes. It was approved by the Board of Estimate last spring.
MONROE, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Shifting winds, blowing at from 40 to 45 miles an hour, caused a forest fire to break out anew late today atop Schunemunk Mountain.

COOL, brisk weather here and in other sections of the country last week was welcomed by retail merchants because it meant that they were provided with a practical way of testing out fall demands. In this area sales picked up and, according to estimates, ran about 8 per cent over a year ago as against an official decline of some 5 per cent in the previous week.

WITH the exception of Elisha Macomber and the other Pemberthy Islanders, all of the characters in this story are connected in one way or another with the publishing business -- authors, publishers, editors and agents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- If the public-opinion pollsters are correct, and they were never more unanimous or certain of their findings, President Truman is launched on a speaking campaign to persuade a majority of the American voters to change their minds toward him before Nov. 2, the date of the general election, and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has undertaken a similar tour to hold the majority he already has.
WHAT effect can a single individual have in these cataclysmic times -- one man or woman among hundreds of millions, seemingly helpless as a sparrow in the path of a tornado?

MISS HELEN MEARS is a great admirer of the Japanese. She lived among them for eight months in 1935 and wrote a book about her experiences called "Year of the Wild Boar." It was published in 1942 and was praised by many critics.

The current international crisis, centering in Berlin, has already called forth an ample number of sage warnings, based upon the parallel of Munich. Such warnings could not be repeated too often, were it not that their point might be blunted. To quote Winston Churchill, however, is never tedious.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 18 -- Men and women who have deliberated two weeks on how best to attack the pressing problem of conservation in the Western Hemisphere saw today an American farm fitted for the future.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Previous sessions of the United Nations General Assembly have finally emerged on the side of success after teetering the edge of failure. But to judge from the views of a number of the delegates who have now arrived for the 1948 session that convenes next Tuesday, this meeting will be a resounding triumph or a complete disaster.
SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 18 -- Adherents of President Truman have taken heart from the result of Tuesday's primary election in Washington.

HEALTH is everybody's business and everybody must make it his business. Because of the nature of the problem, government on national, state and local levels must inevitably play an important part. But the real impetus must come from the people. We must dramatize the health problem and organize our resources in an effort to solve it.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Princeton University will officially open its 202nd academic year tomorrow when President Harold W. Dobbs addresses the undergraduate body at the opening convocation ceremonies in the university chapel. Classes are scheduled to start Monday morning.

THE National Broadcasting Company, at the first convention of its affiliated stations, went on record a year ago expressing disapproval of crime, horror or mystery shows which either were specifically addressed to children or were presented at an hour when they might be heard by youngsters.

THE joys of motoring as it should be -- and seldom is -- await the driver who makes a late-season visit to Yellowstone National Park in the next few weeks. He will have this showcase of the West's wonders and nature's pranks practically to himself, and for good measure a pleasant drive out, with accommodations assured, pleasant autumn weather, and highways banked with early fall foliage.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The new Turkish Ambassador today proposed the establishment of two new defense systems to help guard against aggression in the European area.

THE letter which appeared in the Drama Mailbag last Sunday from Francis J. Bassett of Ridgefield, Conn., reveals how far from the ideal held by many lovers of the drama some summer theatres have departed. Mr. Bassett is correct in pointing to mounting costs, raw apprentices who must have Equity contracts after three speaking parts, and expensive stars who often bring "package" productions.

MOST people think they know when they are free and won't read this book to find out. But the problem of freedom, in society, isn't that simple. It is tough, and likely to remain tough; complicated and likely to remain complicated.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 18 -- Full-scale search operations by the Israeli Army and by military and civilian police in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv today netted 200 persons suspected of complicity in yesterday's assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, and his French aide, Col. Andre Pierre Serot.

Proposals to set up a monetary commission to revamp the nation's credit structure are receiving new scrutiny in the financial district in the light of a further recommendation that the powers of the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury to control credit and manage the public debt be merged into a new type of single authority answerable to Congress.

WITH the season only just under way the Artists' Gallery has stolen a march on its more desultory neighbors by staging what has been heralded as one of its most important events of the year. This is a joint show of sculpture by Saul Baizerman and paintings by his wife, Eugenie.

HERE is a touching and original novel. It is the story of the Babes in the Wood, except that the innocents do overcome the enemy in the end of "City Limit," and convincingly, though almost miraculously. The author has set the story in a small Kentucky town, in the high school, one or two interiors and a country spot just outside the city limit.

MANILA, Sept. 18 -- President Elpinio Quirino has completed the long-contemplated shake-up in the executive family he inherited from the late Manuel A. Roxas. He replaced five department secretaries in the twelve-man Cabinet and let it to be known that he would recall Ambassador J. M. Elizalde from Washington to become Secretary of Foreign Affairs "on designation."

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Billings, blaze-faced colt that races for Ralph W. McIlvain of Chicago, routed ten rivals in the $22,960 Autumn Handicap before 21,104 racegoers at Hawthorne today. The handsome chestnut took the lead leaving the far turn and coasted home by five lengths. Norman W. Church's May Reward, also a 3-year-old and a 17-1 shot, nipped a Woolford Farm's delegate for second.

Two cablegrams from United States Army headquarters in Germany (which are quoted in the Letters column today) say that recent stories from there reporting plans for a cut-back of reading libraries in our occupation zone and saying that the costs of the libraries are to be charged to the Germans do not correctly picture the situation.

IN the last Presidential election 48,100,000 votes were cast, but 40,000,000 people of voting age did not vote: our Chief Executive was elected by only slightly more than half the adult citizens of the country. Only 34,400,000 citizens took part in the Congressional elections of 1946, and in most local elections the percentage of those casting ballots was even lower.

BERLIN, Sept. 18 -- Most German insurance companies will face bankruptcy if another disaster comparable to the explosion in the I. G. Farben plant in Ludwigshafen occurs, leading insurance officials said today.

Authorities in Washington are much concerned over adequate oil supplies in the event of another war. Realizing that the next war might require double the 1,600,000 barrels a day which was supplied at the height of the last conflict, officials are striving to get sufficient reserves in this hemisphere to assure enough oil for military and essential civilian requirements in another emergency.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 11 -- Milk, cod liver oil, shoes: The story of shortages affecting child health that is true for most European countries toured by this reporter during the last ten weeks is true for tens of thousands of Hungarian youngsters under 15.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 18 -- The United Nations principal representative in Palestine told the Israeli Government, in a message made public today, that it must take "full responsibility" for the assassination of Count Bernadotte, United Nations mediator, and of his French aide, Col. Andre Serot.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Gen. Aage Lundstroem, Count Folke Bernadotte's chief of staff, who was at his side when he was shot, reported today that he was convinced that the killing had been "deliberate and carefully planned."

Frank L. Weil, president of the National Jewish Welfare Board, denounced lad night the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations mediator in Palestine, as an utterly insensate and brutal murder.

After the first sixteenth of a mile, the forty-second running of the Matron Stakes, alias "the Fillies' Futurity," was just a pleasant romp in the sunshine for the Maine Chance Farm's unbeaten Myrtle Charm at Belmont Park yesterday.

GENEVA -- Switzerland has been having a good tourist year, all things considered. More American visitors have come than in the years immediately before the war despite high prices and the shortage of good ship places.

Harrison Dillard, Olympic 100-meter champion, captured the two feature events on the program of the Junior Olympic Sports Carnival sponsored jointly by the Department of Parks and The Daily Mirror at Triborough Stadium yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Bucking a brisk southwest wind and a head ebb tide, more than 100 racing craft came plunging and splashing down on the finish line today in the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club regatta, next to the last one of the Long Island Sound championship season.
WOODSTOCK, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Three New York business men drowned today when their boat capsized in storm-swept Ashokan reservoir.

TO pay or not to pay the music performance royalty demanded by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers is the big dilemma of theatre owners in view of two Federal District Court decisions, one in Minneapolis and the other in New York, which seriously question the legality of ASCAP's position. Theatres, it is estimated, contribute $1,500,000 a year to the ASCAP treasury.
BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 19 -- Communists have overthrown the Government in Madiun, a city in the Indonesian Republic, and set up a "Soviet" regime, President Soekarno announced today.

At Purdue University not long ago researchers analyzed the breakfasts women students ate, then compared them with the standards for "a good breakfast" laid down by physicians and nutritionists who were consulted especially for this study.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- Governor Dewey appointed today the nine physician members of the medical advisory board of the State Athletic Commission, created by the 1948 Legislature to prepare stricter standards for the physical examination of boxers and wrestlers.

While buyers sought holiday and promotion merchandise, heavy reorders for women's fall apparel accounted for much of the activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

In this late summer of 1948, children of many countries show signs of giving up their four to ten year struggle with "civilization" as they have known it. They are the uncounted thousands who have never known what milk looks like. They are the ragged, the barefooted and the stunted who lack the nourishing, body-building foods.

Joseph James, Negro baritone who sang the part of Jake in "Porgy and Bess," made his recital debut at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Because of his pleasing voice, his thoughtful presentation, his feeling for the shape and intensity of a melody and his excellent diction it would be a pleasure to turn in a favorable report.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 --For the next several months steel-consuming groups which do not now have the benefit of voluntary steel allocations will be exerting pressure to obtain such a status, market reports here indicate. Many steel customers are becoming a little wary of the successes obtained by other steel users who have been placed in the voluntary allocation classification.

THORNECLIFFE, England, Sept. 19 -- There is a minor social revolution going on in this "company owned" valley near Sheffield. For 4,000 men and women working in the Newton Chambers Company's steel works, foundries, forges and chemical plant it is like a fresh wind blowing in new hope, better conditions, greater security and higher production.

The liberal Southerner's approach to civil rights has rarely been better described than in a statement made public yesterday by twelve members of the executive committee of the Southern Regional Council, after a meeting in Atlanta. This document belongs on the same shelf with the monumental report of the President's Committee on Civil Rights, published last October.

The usefulness of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche as acting United Nations mediator in Palestine has ended because of his charge that the state of Israel was responsible for the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte and his French aide, Col. Andre P. Serot, Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, head of the American section of the World Zionist Organization, declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates all but dropped out of the National League pennant race today when they lost a doubleheader to the Philadelphia Phillies and fell eight games back of the pace setting Boston Braves.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said tonight he seemed to have reached an agreement with Russia on the sale of United States movies here.

The 1948 Presidential campaign enters its intensive phase this week, with both major party candidates, President Truman, Democrat, and Governor Dewey, Republican, on transcontinental speaking trips to the Pacific Coast.

BRIDGEPORT, Sept. 19 -- Price increases on several household appliances manufactured by General Electric Company, were announced here today by C. R. Pritchard, manager of marketing in the GE appliance and merchandise department.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Sept. 19 -- New York's Mayor, William O'Dwyer, will be guest of honor and principal speaker tomorrow night at the opening ceremony starting West New York's two-week observance of its Golden Jubilee.
Three disabled veterans of World War II for whom the Veterans Administration is seeking on-the-job training will demonstrate their abilities to prospective employers by television tomorrow evening.

NANKING, China, Sept. 19 -- Tsinan, Shantung's provincial capital, site of a long Communist siege, faced a new threat today. with the loss of its main airfield, some four miles west of' the city. The Communists took the airfield at noon yesterday, according to reports from commercial airline pilots who have been taking regular flights into Tsinan.

Friday night blood was drawn in air armed clash between Communists and Gaullists in the beautiful old university town of Grenoble, in the south of France. The shots exchanged in the Place Mistral following a speech by General de Gaulle sounded like the beginning of that "battle of the streets" which stalks like a specter in the back of the French mind.
Pickets on land and in the air demonstrated yesterday at ceremonies marking the beginning of flight operations by National Air Lines, Inc., at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- State Department officials took the position tonight that the next step in the Korean situation was up to the United Nations.

Governor Dewey and Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, will be the speakers on Oct. 21 at the fourth annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. This was announced yesterday by Cardinal Spellman, who is president of the foundation.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- The assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, may seotch completely the quiet diplomatic negotiations that had been making gradual headway toward peace in Palestine. It is still too early to gauge how much permanent damage has been done and whether the effect of these peace maneuvers has been negated entirely.

ON PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S CAMPAIGN TRAIN, Sept. 19 -- Refreshed by a night and day of his native Missouri countryside after a gruelling thirteen-speech Saturday, President Truman headed West tonight into the Rocky Mountain region where he is expected to renew his attack on Republican "gluttons of privilege."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 19 --Carrying cardboard shoeboxes containing their sole belongings and wearing clothes supplied by members of the crew of the American liberty ship Cecil N. Bean, which rescued them last Thursday, twenty survivors of the British freighter Leicester were landed here early today.

Aghast at the continued reign of violence and bewildered by the multiplicity of issues confronting it, the world turns its eyes with hope and prayer to Paris, where the General Assembly of the United Nations begins its third regular session tomorrow as a focal point of all world problems. It meets in what Secretary of State Marshall rightly characterized as an "unusually critical world situation."

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Seventeen physically handicapped children between the ages of 5 and 11 are "going to school" here in a hospital in a special class designed to rehabilitate them vocationally and socially.

CONSIDERING the fact that he's such a pleasant and agreeable chap, his stubborn refusal came as something of a surprise. A committee had approached Charlie Keller with the suggestion that he give his consent to having a special day set apart in his honor. King Kong shook his head. "No thanks," he said. "I'm no hero. Give a day to some guy who really deserves it."

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept 19 -- New Jersey's champion Joe McBride, a member of the home club and a former Georgetown golfer, vanquished Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, six-time amateur and former state open title holder by 4 and 3 in the Arcola Country Club's silver anniversary tournament final today.

After five years of playing in small theatres and, more particularly, the City Center, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo returned to the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday evening to open its tenth anniversary celebration season. Quite apparently it had taken a new lease not only on the opera house but also on life.

ATHENS, Sept. 19 -- Greek claims to Cyprus have been raised again at a time when reports from that British island colony in the eastern Mediterranean indicate an increase of Russian influence working through a small but powerful Communist party.

In a surprise announcement last night on the occasion of the closing of the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition at the Grand Central Palace, Mayor O'Dwyer disclosed that the exhibits would be placed in storage and eventually made part of a permanent exhibition.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 19 -- The familiar pattern of truce violations continued in Jerusalem today.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Roving Communist strong-arm squads seized Western Berlin newspapers in the Soviet sector of the city today in a move to embargo all non-Soviet publications. Communist-controlled postal employes in the Russian sector said they would refuse to handle the Western papers because they were "warmongering."
Church congregations of all faiths in New York and other communities joined yesterday in special prayers for the success of the United Nations General Assembly meeting that opens tomorrow in Paris.

The Metropolitan Opera Company will begin its sixty-fourth season with the first subscription performance on Monday, Nov. 29, Edward Johnson, the general manager announced yesterday. The season will continue for sixteen weeks, two fewer than last year.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- The ten-weeks strike in the lead belt collapsed today when the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union, CIO, at a special meeting, suddenly reversed its position and voted to go back to work.
The rankest outsider of modern times sits on the tennis throne today.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- As a result of the steady increase in Russian pressure on Berlin during the last month, senior United States representatives here believe that absolute control of this city, rather than cancellation of the Western plans for a state in Western Germany, is the immediate objective of Soviet foreign policy in Germany.

Pearl Palmason, Canadian violinist of Icelandic parentage, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The youthful artist could achieve real emotional warmth in her readings, and her playing could be commended for its vigor and vitality. But she was under two handicaps, one being the weather conditions and the other an unwisely chosen program.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Rochester evened the semifinal International League playoff series with Montreal at two games apiece today, beating the Royals, 1-0.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- The passage early today by the National Assembly of an economy bill designed to bolster the franc by eighty billion francs in new tax receipts would, it was hoped, pave the way for special assistance for France from the Marshall Plan.

Cotton prices here were somewhat firmer last week, despite day-to-day irregularities. Futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed advances on Saturday of 10 to 72 points for the week, following gains the previous week of 10 to 26 points.

MADRID, Sept. 19 -- Officials here are displaying more confidence than at any time in the last two years that Spain would get favorable treatment when Poland introduced the question of her United Nations status at Paris.
The joint jinx of Lefty Johnny Schmitz and the Chicago Cubs was chased into the limbo of forgotten things by the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday.

The new Hoegh Line motorship, Hoegh Silverwave, is now loading at Pier 35, Brooklyn, for the second leg of her maiden voyage, spokesmen for the Kerr Steamship Line, Inc., general agents, said yesterday. The vessel is scheduled to sail for India, via the Mediterranean, on Saturday.

The Giants said good-by for the year to the Cardinals yesterday without adding the time-honored parting courtesy, "It's been pleasant." The fact is that the New Yorkers derived little enjoyment from their dealings with the Redbirds, whose final visit to the Polo Grounds resulted in a double victory, 4 -- 3 and 3 -- 1, before 34,113 fans.

Nikos Gounaris, Greek balladier, earned double credit at his Carnegie Hall show last night. He not only amused a large audience of his compatriots with songs of the homeland, but introduced to New York a young lady who will certainly make a future mark here.

French Line baggage officials, struggling to sort and load close to 1,000 pieces of luggage in time for the sailing of the liner De Grasse were taken aback last week when a woman demanded a trunk she said she had left on a pier thirty-four years ago.

Referring to Frank R. Crosswaith's recent letter regarding "public housing," this term so frequently used needs clarification. It is not "public housing" in the way that public institutions are generally known, as the public at large has no access to them. The municipal lodging houses are the only real public housing we have.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark today accused the investigation subcommittee headed by Senator Homer Ferguson of making "a mass of incorrect and misleading statements" on President Truman's loyalty program in its report of Sept. 4.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 19 -- A governmental communique published tonight by the official Anatolian Agency condemned activities of Eastern European political refugees here, which appeared to have increased with the arrival in Turkey four days ago of Ferenc Nagy, former Hungarian Premier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Strides made in industrial development were credited today with giving the South and West the biggest income gains in the nation from 1929 through 1947. Government payments helped, also.

The first major exhibitions of the new art season open this week, including a show of collages at the Museum of Modern Art, the opening at the Riverside Museum of a group show by members of the Silvermine Guild of Artists and an exhibition of prints, designs and books from George Chaffee's distinguished ballet collection at the Cultural Division of the French Embassy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) --Payments to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by twenty-two associated companies will be reduced Oct. 1 from 1 1/2 per cent of the companies' gross revenues to 1 per cent, according to Matt L. McWhorter of Georgia, chairman of the special telephone committee of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners.
Herrick, Waddell Reed, Inc., announce the election of Eugene H. deBronkart as vice president. He will be in charge of syndicate participations.

TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The $12,500 Tacoma open golf tournament wound up in a five-way tie today with Ed Oliver, Seattle; Charles Congdon, Tacoma; Fred Haas New Orleans; Vic Ghezzi, Englewood, N.J., and Cary Middlecoff, Memphis, all even at 274 for the 72-hole event.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 -- The surging Indians rolled to within one-half game of the American League-leading Red Sox today with 5-3 and 2-0 victories over the Athletics while the Tigers thumped the Bosox twice at Detroit.

"Stalingrad," by Theodore Plievier, which Appleton-Century-Crofts will publish on Oct. 15, will be the first major war novel to show the German Army from the inside. Mr. Plievier is an anti-Nazi writer who fled Hitler's Germany. For this book he interviewed many survivors of the Stalingrad battle. In its various European editions it has already sold more than one million copies.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- Governor Dewey left here this afternoon on a seventeen-car special train for an 8,000-mile compaign trip as the Republican candidate for President. During the swing, which will take him to the West Coast, New York's chief executive will speak in thirteen states, six of which have potentially close contests for United States Senate seats.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, made a plea here today for all groups to unite in the interests of national security. He stressed that all veteran organizations had a "heavy responsibility" in forestalling "insidious probings" of any potential fifth column.

CELINA, Tenn., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Eight new titleholders were named and a third world record fell as the 1948 national outboard racing championships were completed over the Dale Hollow Lake course today.

The person who assassinated Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations mediator for Palestine, struck at the heart of Israel and is guilty not only of a despicable crime but of the deepest folly, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise said yesterday.
SEOUL, Monday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee of the new republic in South Korea said today that he welcomed Russia's plan to withdraw her troops from North Korea, and added:

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Philip J. Fournier, 34-year-old volunteer fireman of 136 Union Street, here, died, apparently of a heart attack, at the rear tiller of a big hook and ladder truck answering an alarm this morning. The call proved to be a false alarm turned in by a 6-year-old boy.
G.M. Howard, formerly president of Howard Engineering Manufacturing Co., Cincinnati, has been appointed sales manager of the food processing equipment division of the Detrex Corporation, Detroit.
The cornerstone for the new Shirley Joyce Katz Pavilion of the Jewish Sanitarium and Hospital for Chronic Diseases was laid yesterday at Rutland Road and East Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn.

Gordon Stott and Dr. G. B. Harrigan, Sands Point, fashioned a 33, 32 -- 65, seven under part, to defeat Malcolm Grant and Mike Cestone, Crestmont, by 1 up in the final of North Hills' eighth annual member-guest golf tournament in Douglaston yesterday.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 19 -- The Netherlands budget is due to be presented Tuesday and is awaited with more than usual interest.
Child members of the Police Athletic League will take part in an after-school program of fun and recreation, ranging from basketball to ping pong and from jitterbug dancing to chess, beginning today.

The National Jewish Welfare Board, through its Jewish Center Division Committee, will re-establish local committees to work with the United Service Organizations, it was announced yesterday. The local committees will be asked to stimulate cooperation of volunteers throughout the country in behalf of religious, morale and welfare services for Jewish members of the armed forces.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Senators ended their eighteen-game losing streak today, defeating the White Sox, 10 to 7 and 8 to 6, in a Comiskey Park doubleheader. The second game was called after six innings because of darkness.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 19 -- A spokesman for the anthracite industry denied tonight that collieries were operated a sixth day yesterday at premium pay for employers to keep mine workers from attending a rally addressed by Senator Alben Barkley, Democratic nominee for Vice President.

Following the news that Tony Zale, middleweight champion, had ended his training chores yesterday for his title bout with Marcel Cerdan, French challenger, at Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City, tomorrow night, came an announcement that the title-holder would receive $120,000 or the privilege of accepting forty per cent of the receipts from the bout.

In the first change of ownership since its erection twenty years ago, the one and two-story garage building on Crown Street, between Bedford and Franklin Avenues, in Brooklyn, has been purchased by Louis Schleifer, operator, as president of the Interstate Holding Corporation, from the Ednin Construction Company, Arthur A. Iba, president, the builders.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Sept. 19 -- Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, former president of Antioch College here, has accepted the invitation of the Government of India to serve on a nine-man commission to study India's system of higher education. He will fly abroad within a few days, to remain on the sub-continent until next July.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Championship racing over the long summer season on Long Island Sound that began in May ended today with the regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club. Thirty-nine sessions had been scheduled by the Yacht Racing Association, and all but the few that were blotted out by calms were concluded.
Average weekly benefit payments have kept pace with rising living costs, according to an analysis of trends in unemployment rates issued by the National Industrial Conference Board over the week-end.

Preaching yesterday at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, 211 West Fifty-sixth Street, the Rev. Frederick L. Fagley declared that it was high time that the church stopped cataloguing its woes and began instead to count its, blessings.

Ever since he announced, several months ago, after a number of conversational gambits which failed to disguise his inner turmoil, that he would like to have the rifle as his birthday present, the house had been divided into two camps.

SINCE 1865 roughly fifty books a year have been published about Abraham Lincoln. The frontier lawyer and politician has been a revered saint of democracy and an American folk hero for so long that only the specialists in Lincolniana, all ten thousand of them, remember the book which did more than any other to create the legend which is known to everyone.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- American dollars authorized for foreign aid under the Economic Cooperation Administration last week reached $239,429,532, the highest weekly total yet. The allocations bring to $1,685,893,147 the amount so far allocated to the sixteen participating nations of Europe and to China.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 19 -- With twenty-two important addresses still ahead of him on his transcontinental campaign tour, Gov. Earl Warren of California devoted part of today to putting his speech of tomorrow night at Tulsa, Okla., into shape.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) --A small Export-Import Bank loan rather than a Marshall Plan for South America was put forward today as a solution for the southern continent's economic difficulties.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Sept. 19 -- It is maintained in Belgium that a serious situation is developing because the Joint Export-Import Agency in Frankfort on the Main refuses to release Rhine traffic for the Low Country ports. Responsible Belgians even say a "criminal attempt" is being made to play off Antwerp against Rotterdam, a policy that would undermine the purpose of Benelux, the economic union of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Union announced today that Russian troops would be entirely withdrawn from Korea by Jan. 1, 1949.

Collaboration among architect, interior designer and artist to make "the modern house come alive" is the theme of a new exhibit opening today at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. To show the interplay of fabrics, sculpture, paintings and furniture in a room scheme, Miss Schaefer has selected a few samples of each for small-scaled model rooms.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Extreme irregularity is expected to develop this week in September corn on the Board of Trade as the result of evening-up of uncompleted contracts which, at the close of business yesterday, were estimated to call for 12,000,000 bushels.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 19 -- A salvage tug plowed through stormy seas tonight to reach the British freighter Lochmonar, battered by gales and reported "in bad shape" with seventy-three persons on board.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Twenty-seven women officers from New York are among the first 288 selected for commissions in the Regular Navy under the new Women's Armed Services Integration Act.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The cost of Britain's new defense and rearmament plans will be discussed in Washington by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who left London by plane this morning. He will go first to Montreal, but after talks with the Canadians all this week, he will go to Washington for the annual meetings of the Governors of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

New York City's aim in its part of the national campaign against venereal disease -- complete elimination of the scourge -- is a rigorous one, but with wholehearted support by the public there is no reason why this ambitious objective cannot be reached. Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard is certain of receiving the cooperation he seeks from newspapers, radio, Government departments, large business concerns, labor unions and fraternal societies.

Instead of settling arguments with fist fights, frequenters of taverns in the Saratoga district of Brooklyn now repair to the public library for the arbitration of reference books, Miss Cecile J. Lynch, librarian of the Saratoga branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, Hopkinson Avenue and Macon Street, reported yesterday.

Your press release entitled "Spain Protestants Held Persecuted," published Sept. 10, forces us to make the following declarations which we think would be conducive to the enlightenment of the American people in regard to the alleged "persecution" of Protestants in Spain.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, criticized today the recent report of the President's Commission on Higher Education for lending its support to attacks on the American college by "some professional educators."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- Quiet continued along the waterfront here today, the eighteenth day of the Pacific Coast maritime strike, as longshoremen made ready to begin loading Army ships.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- The Italian Government was understood today to be pressing for a year's postponement of final disposition of its former colonies in Africa. The question is scheduled to come up before the United Nations General Assembly opening here Tuesday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 19 -- The flight of Nathan Friedman Yellin, said to be the leader of the Stern group, and Dr. Israel Scheib, his political adviser, to an "unknown destination" was reported today as the Israeli Government continued its widespread search for the assassins of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, and his French aide, Col. Andre Pierre Serot.

As a poor boy in Brooklyn, David B. Steinman fell in love with Brooklyn Bridge. While other boys on his block played ball and tag, young David would linger in the shadows of the span to admire its rugged beauty and to wish that he could work the wonder of hanging a roadway of stone and steel over wide waters.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Lard futures fluctuated nervously on the Board of Trade last week, the action of cottonseed oil having considerable influence. Spreading operations were evident, with some selling yesterday based on disappointing fourth-quarter export allocations.

With the city's costly truck strike limping to an end Mayor O'Dwyer made it plain yesterday that he had not abandoned his efforts to stabilize the local trucking industry through establishment of uniform wage scales.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 --- Secretary of State Marshall today stepped aboard a plane for the Paris meeting of the United Nations Assembly after having made a terse statement that the world was in an "unusually critical" situation.

According to the books, weather is caused by chain reaction between masses of earth's atmosphere which have "horizontal homogeneity." Huge globs of air stagnate long enough to take on cool, warm, dry or moist characteristics from the surface beneath them.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sep. 19 -- Soviet Russian Marxist theoreticians were searchingly criticized today for the first time since the Communist Information Bureau started its quarrel with Yugoslavia. Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, found them guilty of a sterile dogmatism that finds a refuge in the past and turns its back upon the living reality of present day experience.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Henry J. Kaiser proposed late yesterday that the Government-owned blast furnace here be expanded to supply pig iron "without any profit to us" to a cooperative company that would be formed by members of the Gray Iron Founders Society.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -- The medical center of the future that does not assume a regional responsibility will have difficulty justifying its existence, Graham L. Davis, president of the American Hospital Association, predicted today.

The preliminary screening by the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the national defense budget for the next fiscal year was in its final stages last week as the armed services -- moving gradually toward better coordination -- worked under new directives.

Declaring that America was a captive of materialistic forces of the present day, the Rev. Dr. Ernest R. Palen told his congregation in the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church yesterday that the outstanding need was "a return to the things of God."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A field goal by Fred Venturelli in the last minute of play gave the Chicago Bears a 17-14 victory over the Washington Redskins in a National Football League exhibition game here today.

The foreign exchange market milled between the depressing influence of the foreign political situation -- particularly the French Cabinet crisis -- and the news which came late in the week of the creditable showing of the British trade figures for the first six months of 1948. It was this latter incident which changed sentiment and quickly punctured the earlier gloom.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The United States provided $1,800,000,000 more in goods and services to foreign countries than it got from them in the April-May- June period.

I hope your readers will not gain the impression from the letter of William R. Huntington that the Society of Friends as a whole thinks that the Dean of Canterbury should have been admitted to this country.

For the third successive month August showed a decline in the public assistance caseload in this city, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday. Relief cases for the month totaled 137,382, representing 263,552 persons, a net reduction of 733 cases, or 1,864 persons, he said.

American manufacturers have many pointed questions about selective service rules applying to industrial employes, according to their replies to a preliminary survey conducted by the American Management Association, in advance of their annual personnel conference of 1,000 companies, scheduled for the Pennsylvania Hotel Sept. 23 and 24.

ZURICH, Sept. 19 -- Under startling headlines such as "Our National Capital in Danger!" Swiss financial newspapers this week-end are-ardently supporting a campaign just started by the Alliance of Industrial Holding Companies -- a body working hand in hand with the Swiss Bankers Association -- demanding reasonable compensation for those Swiss investors who have suffered in consequence of nationalization of industry by postwar Governments.
"Magdalena," a sun-kissed product of California, cradled in Los Angeles and San Francisco, begins its New York career at the stroke of 8:15 tonight at the Ziegfeld.

Lower construction and operating costs are possible on large-scale commercial building projects using new design principles, Robert McGovern, New England manager of the Preload Corporation, New York and Boston, disclosed last week at the equipment exhibit of the Water and Sewage Works Manufacturers Association, Inc., at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

A youthful scoutmaster, active for thirteen years here in Troop 522 of the Boy Scouts of America, is reorganizing the troop on an international footing to promote better cultural understanding among the American and foreign-born members of his group.

The Rev. Dr. Sidney Malcolm Berry of London, secretary of the International Congregational Council, will spend the next nine weeks in this country preaching and holding conferences with Congregational ministers and laymen throughout the country. His purpose is to promote the growth of the council.

Three four-story store and loft buildings in the wholesale fur district that were erected as dwellings some time before 1878 passed to new control with the sale by the estate of Elizabeth A. French of 106-08-10 West Twenty-eighth Street to the store tenants.

Simonis billiard cloth, reputed to be one of the world's oldest branded products, will be advertised in this country beginning this fall, it was announced over the week-end. The cloth has been made in Belgium since 1680 and is imported here solely by H.W.T. Mali Co.

The television industry takes a major step forward today with the inaugural of network operations in the Mid-West. The new link for video outlets runs from Buffalo to St. Louis, with Chicago as the focal point for program production for the chain.

Appointment of twelve special assistant Attorneys General for duty in this city to work with the regular Election Frauds Bureau of the State Attorney General's office was announced yesterday by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The special session of Parliament which opened last week was called for one specific political purpose only, but it already has served a much more useful purpose than that for which it was designed originally in throwing some light upon international political affairs and upon Britain's economic situation.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Signs in and about the Foreign Office here today indicated that a situation of heightened crisis had been reached in the forthcoming negotiations concerning Berlin.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- The Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. announced today that an "improved and enriched" curriculum would be introduced in its church schools on Sunday, Oct. 3.
Three new films are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

BUFFALO, Sept. 19 -- Asserting that this country lacked a real "people's party, definitely concerned with winning plenty, peace and freedom," Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, urged tonight that trade unions and consumer organizations support his party until they built up a "great mass electoral party" of their own.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Members of the Bear Mountain Trailside Museums staff today started their annual pre-fall housecleaning job of returning to their natural habitat the snakes, turtles, flying squirrels, raccoons, skunks and other animals that have been on exhibition here all summer to the thousands of visitors.

ROME, Sept. 19 -- The bodies of Count Bernadotte, assassinated United Nations Mediator for Palestine, and of Col. Andre Pierre Serot, his French aide, arrived by air at 6:15 P. M. today at Ciampino Airport in Rome.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The death of a 71-year-old Philadelphia woman raised the possibility today that a bequest of $12,000 "pin money" might be paid annually to the nation's First Lady.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- An atmosphere of highly tentative optimism was prevalent here today as the delegates prepared for what is expected to be the most critical session yet held by the United Nations General Assembly.

The threatened strike of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, against the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, the New York City Omnibus Corporation and affiliates and the Third Avenue Transit System was averted yesterday after nearly ten hours of conference at City Hall. The walkout, set for 4 A. M. today, would have left 3,500,000 riders in Manhattan and the Bronx without surface transportation, except for emergency service by city-owned buses.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Tucker Corporation, Chicago automobile manufacturer, today confirmed the resignations of two more directors, making five who have left the business in the last twelve months.
MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Medical care and rations were provided on an austerity basis when Henry Hands went to sea on a British sailing ship in 1876.

London, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Soviet monitor distributed today the following text of a Moscow radio broadcast concerning Russian troop withdrawals from Korea. The monitor said that poor radio reception conditions made it "subject to correction and addition."

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- On the eve of the largest inter-American meeting of business men to be held in the Western Hemisphere, delegates from twenty-two Latin-American countries and business leaders from all over the United States were arriving here today for the fourth plenary meeting of the Inter-American Council of Commerce and Production.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Monday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Social Democrats (Socialists) won 112 of the 230 seats in the lower house of Sweden's Parliament in the elections yesterday, maintaining their position as the nation's leading party.

A simple ceremony was held yesterday afternoon at the grave of former Mayor Fiorello. H. La Guardia in Woodlawn Cemetery to dedicate a monument and also commemorate the first anniversary of his death on last Sept. 20.
PARIS, Sept. 19 -- United Nations staff workers, still exploring Paris after hours, were speculating pleasantly today on the chance of spending the next General Assembly session in Latin America.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- The Yankees' amazing faculty for falling upstairs was still standing them in good stead today as they split a double-header with the lowly Browns in 96-degree heat.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Representatives of stock exchanges from six cities will meet in Chicago on Oct. 1 and 2 to discuss the possibility of merging into one large middle western exchange, James E. Day, president of the Chicago Stock Exchange, disclosed today.

In a reversal of conventional school procedure, Brooklyn College students have graded their teachers "A" in proficiency, but just about "D" in giving fair examinations. This was disclosed yesterday in the report of a twelve-month survey of student evaluation of teaching at the college.

Good men cannot be destroyed no matter how great a disaster comes to a nation, the Rev. Henry Beltman, president of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

LICHFIELD, England, Sept. 19 -- Johnsonians from Britain and the United States attended the annual supper held here last night to celebrate the 239th anniversary of the birth of Dr. Samuel Johnson, the lexicographer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- San Francisco's Forty-Niners, making their strongest bid for the all-America conference football championship, chalked up their fourth successive league victory today, beating the Los Angeles Dons, 36-14.
