Body measurements for the sizing of apparel for infants, babies, toddlers and children, as set forth in Standard #CS151-48 of the National Bureau of Standards, were discussed by spokesmen for manufacturers and retailers of infants and children's dresses at a meeting held last week by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, 100 West Thirty-first Street.

BUFFALO, Sept. 19 -- Following is the text of the speech tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, before the administrative council of the Mechanics Educational Society of America:

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Hunters and jumpers had their innings today at the tenth annual Watchung Hunter Show at the grounds of the Union County Park Commission on Glenside Avenue. All classes were well filled and there was a predominance of juvenile riders, many of whom excelled their elders.

The assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte and his French assistant is a sympton of increasing world "irresponsibility to God" that is making peace an impossibility, Msgr. Christopher J. Weldon asserted yesterday in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Msgr. Weldon is executive director of New York Catholic Charities.

That differences of opinion make for progress and progress brings diversity of opinion is well illustrated in objections by some members of the Automobile Club of New York to new-look curves and contours built into post-war cars. Handicapped by lack of materials and adverse economic conditions, the automotive industry is seeking doggedly to keep alive a cherished spirit of beneficial competition despite an estimated backlog of 7,300,000 unfilled orders.

CAIRO, Sept. 19 -- Six Arab delegations have departed for the Paris meeting of the United Nations in an atmosphere of restrained hopefulness that the Arab case in Palestine will -- for the first time as they see it -- receive sympathetic consideration.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Jerry (Scat) Davis, Chicago Cardinals explosive rookie halfback, flashed 76 and 53 yards today to spark the National Football league champions to a 35-14 exhibition triumph over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Boston's Braves protected their lead in the waning National League pennant fight today by coming from behind to clip the Cincinnati Reds, 4 -- 2, before a crowd of 19,489. It was the sixth victory in a row for the league leaders, who now have won twelve of their last thirteen games.

"Private Enterprise Can Do the World's Job" will be the central theme of the thirty-fifth National Foreign Trade Convention, the National Foreign Trade Council announced over the week-end. A record attendance of 2,500 delegates from all sections of the country are expected to attend the gathering which will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel from Nov. 8 to 10.

The Transportation Association of America announced yesterday the completion of a digest of all Federal transport law. Donald D. Conn, executive vice president of the association, stated that in the past eighteen months a group of legal experts has explored the entire United States Transport Code and produced in one document a comparative tabulation of all Federal statutes.

Senator Alben W. Barkley, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, will make his first speech here this week to aide the vote registrationdrive, it was announced yesterday. Senator Barkley's New York appearance will be at Manhattan Center, on West Thirty-fourth Street, Thursday evening, under the auspices of the Liberal party, which is supporting the Truman-Barkley ticket in this state.

The first assembly of the World Council of Churches will constitute one of the greatest gatherings in the history of Christianity if it achieves its destiny, the Rev. Ira W. Langston declared yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- With the United Nations now assembled in the heart of their capital, the French people for the first time are beginning to show a general interest in the workings of the international organization.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Cecil Smith, ten-goal star, brought the national open polo championship to Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes today, but a man named George Oliver stole the show.

After reading your editorial "Radio for Buses" I want to lodge my emphatic protest against any attempt at punishing the strained nerves of the inhabitants of this noisy metropolis by another unrequested offering.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- Allyn Baum of Chicago, a photographer for International News Photos, was arrested this afternoon by two Soviet guards as he attempted to take pictures of the border between the United States and Russian sectors.

MOSCOW, Sept, 19 (AP) -- American diplomatic circles today expressed surprise at the Soviet announcement on Korea. Informants said that they did not expect the Russians to withdraw from Northern Korea until the Americans had evacuated Southern Korea.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 19 (AP) -- An official announcement said today that Kazim Razvi, leader of Hyderabad's Moslem Razakars [Volunteer Corps], had been arrested. One of the reasons that India gave for the invading of Hyderabad last Monday was that the Nizam [ruler] of the holdout state had refused to disband the Razakars, blamed by India for stirring up border trouble.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly yesterday, 20 points lower to 13 points higher than Saturday's final levels.

Five thugs stalked into the offices of the city's biggest union late yesterday afternoon and beat three organizers, injuring one so badly that he required seven stitches in his scalp and hospital attention.

ON BOARD TRUMAN CAMPAIGN TRAIN, Sept. 20 -- President Truman warned applauding Colorado audiences today that the Republican party sought national power on the "most hypocritical" platform ever written and that, if it won the election, it would try again to make the West "an economic colony of Wall Street."

A request that the Public Service Commission take over jurisdiction of electric rates charged to the city for street lighting and public buildings was withdrawn yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company. The withdrawal was contained in a letter sent to Milo R. Maltbie, PSC chairman, by Ralph H. Tapscott, president of the company.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The new flare up of Communist violence in East Java, following on widespread Communist-led disorders in Burma and Malaya, is being carefully watched by the British Government.

New York's most native and almost original summer entertainment, the County Fair, is now moving along at high gear and will continue that pace until September makes its exit. Once again there is square and modern dancing and "fiddlin'," contests in milking, shearing and oxen-pulling, and the usual variety of exhibits, with awards for the best livestock, poultry, fruits, flower, vegetable and handiwork.

An exhibition rich in period dance memorabilia and otherwise composed of souvenirs, books, designs and pastels that document the history of the Paris Court and Opera Ballet had its formal opening last evening at the Cultural Division of the French Embassy at a reception honoring the Paris Opera Ballet company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, and his wife became qualified voters in New York State this afternoon when they passed routine literacy tests here and filed declarations of residence with the Westchester County Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic candidate for Vice President, will pick up the campaign trail again tomorrow in Delaware. He plans to spend the whole day going over the state by motor in what is essentially a handshaking tour.

The Commissioners of Sanitation and Housing said yesterday that they were discouraged about the filthy lots and courtyards and the garbage-littered streets that give many visitors their first impressions of New York.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 20 -- Testimony that five persons were admitted to full membership in the International Typographical Union. American Federation of Labor, without any composing room training was offered by the Government today as hearings on contempt of court charges against the union got under way before Judge Luther M. Swygert in United States District Court.

Reversing the normal pattern of labor relations, the two biggest unions in the Hudson Manhattan Railroad announced yesterday their determination to force reinstatement of two top management officials who were ousted eleven days ago by the company's board of directors.

Ads in metropolitan New York daily newspapers will set the pace for promotion of "Sweetest Day," gift-merchandising event on Saturday, Oct. 16, it was announced yesterday by Sidney Bielfield, campaign director. The day, designated as one "to remember someone less fortunate with a kind deed," has been proclaimed officially by Mayor O'Dwyer.h)0*0*0*iO
DENVER, Col., Sept. 20 (AP) -Following is the prepared text of President Truman's address on the Capitol Grounds here today:

Active steps to promote the use of the Economic Cooperation Administration's label is urged in letters sent to ECA mission chiefs in Europe by Aubrey E. Harwood, ECA director of operations, it was learned here yesterday.

Miss Louise Brough and Tom Brown from the West Coast scored a 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4 victory over Mrs. Margaret duPont and William F. Talbert to win the mixed doubles championship as the 1948 National tennis tournament closed at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday afternoon.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Claude Harmon of Winged Foot, the Master's champion, scored a brilliant 36, 30 -- 66, seven under par, at Gedney Golf Club this afternoon to add to his morning round of 70 and capture the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association championship by three strokes with a 36-hole total of 136.

This community will watch with interest the progress on the new nonprofit cooperative housing project in which Louis H. Pink, Gerard Swope and others are taking the initial risk and furnishing the leadership as a public service. This $8,000,000 development, proposed for a four-block site in Queens, is unique in several respects.

PARIS, Tuesday, Sept. 21 -- A close contest for the Presidency of the General Assembly was in the making today after it had been reliably reported that twenty Latin-American delegations had decided to support Dr. Juan Bramuglia, Foreign Minister of Argentina, who will be Provisional President when the Assembly convenes this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The National Mediation Board will confer in Chicago on Thursday with the spokesmen for sixteen "nonoperating" unions whose wage conferences with the railroads collapsed last Friday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -National income rose to an annual rate of $221,400,000,000 in the second quarter of 1948, the Commerce Department reported today. This is an all-time high.

Up From the Carribbean This is the hurricane season. Today is the tenth anniversary of the great storm of 1938. On Sept. 21 of that year there were more than forty houses on the sanded curve of beach at the head of Bay Street in Watch Hill, R.I.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- The United Nations must force a compromise settlement on the Arab countries and Israel if the Palestine war is to be ended, Count Folke Bernadotte declared in his final report to the General Assembly, received here after his slaying and released today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Communism has destroyed freedom in almost half of the world and now seeks to undermine freedom in the United States, Gov. Dwight H. Green said tonight at the Diamond Jubilee Banquet of the Polish Roman Catholic Union of America.
A military assistant to the Secretary of Defense has been appointed, in the person of Major Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, director of the joint staff of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

It is gratifying to the members of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association of the City of New York to note the publicity and interest you are displaying in the problem of smoke abatement. In your editorial of Sept. 14 you report on the work being done by various public and private groups.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- French officials said today that they hoped Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, would release to them a first slice of the Marshall-Plan counterpart fund in time to enable the French Treasury to meet the obligations that fall due at the end of this month.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's address in Des Moines last night as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

VIENNA, Sept. 14 -- The main guiding factor in implementing the displaced-persons legislation approved last June by Congress will be "to keep families united," Ugo Carusi, chairman of the United States Displaced Persons Commission, declared today in explaining the selection machinery.

The New York Chapter, American Red Cross, began yesterday a three-week campaign to recruit new and reactivited volunteers to fill demands for Red Cross services in Manhattan and the Bronx. The objective, according to Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, volunteer services administrator, is a 20 per cent increase in volunteer hours above that of the year that ended on June 1, when 502,231 hours of service were contributed through the chapter's ten volunteer services.

PRAGUE, Sept. 20 -- While Premier Antonin Zapotocky and his Minister of the Interior continued in weekend speeches to threaten "reactionary" opponents of the Communist regime, detection of new alleged spy plots was announced today and the newly created "state courts" imposed sentences in record time.

BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 20 -- The Indonesian Republic's Provisional Parliament at a special session today granted unlimited power for a period of three months to President Soekarno to cope with the situation arising from a Communist coup in East Java Province and the city of Madiun.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20 -A new invitation to speak in the United States has been extended to the Very Rev. Dr. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury Cathedral, it was disclosed today by Dr. Ralph Barton Perry, professoremeritus of philosophy at Harvard University.

It is a tribute to our perennial Socialist candidate for the Presidency that the saying, "Maybe I'll have to vote for Norman Thomas," crops up regularly in every election year when unattached voters are finding it hard to make up their minds. For those who are not Socialists and not pacifists and who want to have some say as to what goes on in Washington voting for Mr. Thomas is no real solution.
The killing of U Tin Tut, former Burmese Foreign Minister, adds another chapter of violence, horror and frustration to the early days of Burmese independence.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 20 -- A Government spokesman said tonight that Karl Ruedemann and George Bannentine, the American heads of the Hungarian American Oil Company [Standard Oil], had been "interrogated" and had confessed they had ordered sabotage of production by the company reasons.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Britain's Labor government is expected to modify but not abandon its plan for nationalization of the iron and steel industry in the face of implied criticism of the program by Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

The high-grade bond market, assured that small A-rated issues of new public utility bonds can find willing buyers at a yield of 3 per cent, will face today its greatest test since the Treasury and Federal Reserve Board tightened shortterm money rates and bank reserve requirements.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- The United Nations Security Council gingerly put aside Hyderabad's complaint against India today for a few days to give the delegation from the Princely State time to withdraw it.
Your editorial of Sept. 5 captioned "Displaced" children briefly mentions a course that is simple. Does not history show government seldom does things simply?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Mr. Truman, speaking in Iowa, did not specify at what point in their gorgings the "Wall Street gluttons of privilege," whom he described as the masters of the Republicans, turn into the "economic tapeworm" which devours the fruits of the labors of the American farmer and other worthy citizens.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Faced with the distinct possibility that the United Nations General Assembly will refuse to grant a trusteeship to Great Britain in Cyrenaica, the United States may withdraw its support of Britain and join hands with Russia to place all the former Italian colonies under the United Nations Trusteeship Council, it was stated here today.

While Selective Service officials set to work yesterday analyzing and filing the papers of 437,758 young men who had registered here under the new draft law, additional men who had failed to meet last Saturday's deadline came into offices in the various boroughs to sign up.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Trygve Lie, United Nations Secretary General, presented to the General Assembly today the United States-backed proposal for a small United Nations armed guard to be recruited on a worldwide basis.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, denied yesterday charges that he had overstepped his authority in using "his freshman class at Brooklyn College as a sounding board for his personal, political views."
The changeover yesterday from a five to a six-cent fare on seven of the thirteen private bus lines operated on city franchises was effected with slight delays, most noticeable at the rush hours.

Dr. Frank G. Slaughter, popular author of many historical romances that combine the melodrama of medicine with the action of history, will have his new novel, "Sangaree," published by Doubleday on Oct. 7. A tale of postRevolutionary Savannah, it describes a young surgeon's struggle with "prejudice, pirates and plague."
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -A dozen witnesses told the House Small Business Committee today about practices they consider monopolistic by big business -- including the United States Government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The Marshall Plan approach to the problem of financing increased productivity and larger purchasing power in Latin-American countries came under critical discussion today at the opening of the fourth plenary meeting of the Inter-American Council of Commerce and Production here, to which Governor Thomas E. Dewey sent a message hailing hemispheric solidarity in the democratic way of life.

The short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange was reported below a million shares for the first time since Jan. 15, 1947, with a Sept. 15 figure of 950,168 shares. This was 59,144 shares fewer than the 1,009,312 shares reported as of Aug. 13, 1948, the Exchange announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Democratic national leadership, it became known today, expects to get Truman-Barkley electors on the ballot under the Democratic emblem without a court fight in every state in the South except Louisiana and Alabama.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 7 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 2 per cent.

The first middleweight title bout with international appeal in twentyone years is scheduled for tonight in Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City, when Tony Zale, Gary, Ind., ring veteran, defends his 160-pound crown against Marcel Cerdan, the Frenchman from Casablanca, in a struggle listed for fifteen rounds.

In a town hall atmosphere, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers heard yesterday of the need for various public improvements for Manhattan. Thirty-three civic leaders told his advisory board, headed by Robert W. Dowling, how the borough could be improved.

TULSA, Okla., Sept. 20 -- President Truman by his own "belligerent" language has proved that the national Administration is "dispirited, chaotic, quarrelsome and desperate," Governor Earl Warren of California declared here tonight.

HAVANA, Sept. 20 -- The Army took over maintenance of public order in this city tonight as the hurricane struck. Police and soldiers patrolled the streets. Civilians were ordered to remain indoors. The greater part of the city was without lights as current was cut off when wires were torn down.
PARIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The text of the conclusions made by Count Folke Bernadotte in a 35,000-word report to the United Nations on his work as Palestine Mediator:
Please permit me to answer the letter of Henry Waldman appearing Sept. 16.

Two Brooklyn criminal lawyers, Leon Fischbein and Emanuel Rosenberg, cited by the Brooklyn Bar Association for unethical practices, appeared before Charles C. Lockwood, official referee, yesterday in a disbarment hearing ordered by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Department.

Psychiatry has an important role to play in the treatment of tuberculosis, Dr. Allan Hurst, medical director of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, declared yesterday. He spoke at the opening fall meeting of the hospital's New York women's division in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -Joe Louis showed tonight there's plenty of zip in the old heavyweight champion yet as he boxed a fast six-round exhibition bout with Pat Comiskey.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- A three-act play, the background of which is used for introduction of the latest ideas in men's wear as conceived by Great Britain's leading custom tailors, was presented here today under auspices of the Board of Trade.

TONY ZALE had just crashed a final explosive left hook on the unprotected jaw of Rocky Graziano in Newark last June and the Rock toppled to the canvas. He lay full length on his back, arms outstretched. Nat Fleischer, the editor of Ring Magazine, was serving as the knockdown timekeeper. He leaned across the ring apron with his huge watch in his hand and tolled off the seconds.

Heitor Villa-Lobos, the Brazilian composer, has written the score for "Magdalena," which was put on at the Ziegfeld last evening. Although he has been certified as authentic by qualified musicologists, it is impossible to have much of an idea about the score for a very unfortunate reason.

DENVER, Sept. 20 -- Delegates to the First Hemispheric Conference on Conservation of Natural Resources heard President Truman express the conviction today that if such a program as they have been working on is carried out there will be peace and prosperity for the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Preventive medicine for adults, such as is assured by pediatricians for children, was urged by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, at today's opening assembly of the George Washington University Medical School.

DES MOINES, Sept. 20 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York formally opened his campaign as the Republican candidate for President tonight with a pledge that his administration, if he is elected, will be devoted to restoring unity to the American people.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Sept. 20 -- Because of competition from synthetic fibers and the possibility of an economic recession it is essential that those directing the South's cotton-breeding programs "have a better understanding about what quality factors are most desired by a majority of the industry's spinners."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Reduction of the United States armed forces in Southern Korea has already started, but our soldiers will not finally withdraw until the General Assembly of the United Nations has discussed the future of Korea at the Paris meeting.

A fifty-year career at the New York Public Library, much of it spent guiding professional and amateur researchers through the intricate branches of their family trees, will end today when Henry C. Strippel, chief of the Genealogy and Local History Division, retires.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 20 -Dr. Louise Doddridge Larimore, who retired as head pathologist at the Greenwich Hospital about two years ago, was found dead this evening in a consulting room at her home on Lake Avenue. The police said a bottle that had contained pills was found near her body, and listed her death as possibly a suicide.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Secretary of State Marshall, Foreign Secretary Bevin and Foreign Minister Schuman met briefly today in what was described officially as an informal get-together prior to the opening of the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Some progress was reported to have been made today to even up the unusually large amounts of September corn contracts open, which amounted to 12,143,000 bushels when trading started on the Board of Trade.

Hank Borowy, who shut out the Dodgers on one hit the last time he opposed them, felt the lash of Brooklyn's vengeance yesterday at Ebbets Field. The Cub righthander was put to rout in the very first inning after yielding all the runs of the 4-2 triumph achieved by the Brooks behind the stalwart pitching of Preacher Roe.

Promptness of American export collections paid by Latin-American countries in August improved for the first time since February, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The report was based upon export data provided by twelve New York banks.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The gathering in Paris of United States, British and French Foreign Ministers with their experts on the Berlin problem is regarded in British diplomatic circles today as a very important development in Western efforts to defeat the Soviet blockade of Berlin.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 20 -Textron, Inc., was forced to close the Nashua, N.H., mills because of competitive conditions which made further operation of its sheet and blanket business unprofitable, Royal Little, president, declared here tonight. The mills were closed Sept. 8.

BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- The Soviet Military Administration is planning to permit a new Eastern zone Government of Germany to establish a militia of 100,000 men, it was reliably reported today. Plans for setting up the new Government, which, it is believed, would have Leipzig as its provisional capital, are being integrated rapidly, according to well-informed sources from the Soviet zone.

Because food is the key to freedom in Europe, CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe) began a new program yesterday to enable Americans to become friends in deed to needy strangers in foreign lands.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -Jack Graham, San Diego's man with the big stick, today was named the Pacific Coast League's most valuable player for 1948.

Slowed down shipments of men's, children's, and women's seamless hosiery has brought manufacturers' inventories to or above the "normal" two months' supply, according to hosiery manufacturersh)0*0*0*iyesterday. Lessened demand at retail level, they said, has been a factor in curtailment of production in higher price categories to avoid accumulation of stock beyond safe limits.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 -- R. L. Collier, executive secretary of the Gray Iron Founders Society, said today he was "dubious" about Henry J. Kaiser's plan to build a cooperative blast furnace adjoining the Government furnace here, but added that it was up to the foundrymen to decide.

MONTREAL, Sept. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The survivors of the British ship Leicester, landed here on the rescue ship Tropero, today discounted Bermuda reports that sharks had "got" any of their shipmates in a hurricane-lashed sea.

Representatives of 14,000 unionized maintenance and plant employes of the New York Telephone Company will vote today on acceptance of a company offer of wage increases ranging from $3 to $6 a week. Most of the workers would receive increases of $5 and $6 under the proposal, union officials said.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 20 -The weekly amateur-pro of the Long Island Professional Golf Association at the Hemsptead Club today wound up in a four-way deadlock for top position.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 20 (Reuters). -- Seven persons have been arrested in connection with the assassination of U Tin Tut, Burma's First Foreign Minister, who died yesterday from wounds received in a bomb attack.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 -Larry Parks and Columbia Pictures have settled the controversy which has kept Parks off the screen for a year and a half (except for one film made under a legal stipulation), the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff have delivered to the Munitions Board of the National Military Establishment a tentative schedule of requirements of the armed services against a possible "mobilization day," it was learned today.

ATHENS, Sept. 20 -- Two persons held in custody since midAugust and constantly questioned, were today formally arrested in connection with the killing last May of George Polk, correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, according to a report from Salonika.

The National Retail Furniture Association requested yesterday that the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System abandon its proposed amendment to Regulation W, which would make unenforceable any time payment contract which does not conform toh)0*0*0*ithe regulation's provisions on down payments or maturities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The memory of forty-five war correspondents who lost their lives in World War II was honored when their photographs were permanently placed upon a plaque today in the National Military Establishment press room in the Pentagon.

The latest addition to the Avenue's array of stores, Bond Fifth Avenue, will open its plastic doors tomorrow morning at the northwest corner of Thirty-fifth Street, after a ceremony in which city officials will cut the tape at 9:15 A.M.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- Reuters News Agency today announced an agreement for the transfer of the ownership and control of its fifty-year-old subsidiary company, The Associated Press of India, Ltd., to Indian newspapers, which also will become partners in Reuters.
BATAVIA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Communists called tonight for the complete overthrow of the Indonesian Government and brought the young Republic to the brink of civil war.
A single assassination, more than mass murders, has a way of bringing matters to a head.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Sept 20 -- The Arab League announced today the creation of an Arab Government for Palestine. King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan promptly served notice that he would bar it from the Holy Land.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The Labor Government rammed its amendment to the Parliament Act through the House of Commons today by a vote of 319 to 192. This was the second of three readings necessary before the bill can go to the House of Lords.

If you don't take too long a look at the Columbia team that lines up against Rutgers at Baker Field in one of Saturday's big opening football games, you might jump to the conclusion that it is the same eleven that ran up 27 points in the first seventeen minutes of their 1947 meeting, fell behind at 27 -- 28 and came on in a roaring finish to win, 40 -- 28.

The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes entering into the stalemated contract renewal negotiations between UniversalInternational Films, Inc., and the Motion Picture Home Office Employes Local No. H-63, it was announced yesterday after a meeting between Richard F. Walsh, president of the IATSE, and John J. O'Connor, vice president of the film company.

The DuMont television station, WABD, announced yesterday that it would be the first video outlet to offer a full schedule of daytime programs on a regular basis, beginning in early October. Programs specifically designed to interest the whole family at breakfast time and the housewife for the remainder of the day will be offered from 7 A.M. to 6 P.M., Monday through Friday.
LOS ANGELES Sept. 20 (AP)--The California Horse Racing Board today announced it had revoked the license for one year of Jack T. Engle, trainer for the Robert S. Howard racing stable.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Guided by Secretary General Trygve Lie, President of the Republic Vincent Auriol today inspected the alterations that have been made to the Palais de Chaillot in preparation for the General Assembly's opening there tomorrow afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Del Ennis powered his twentyninth and thirtieth home runs of the campaign today to lead the Phillies to a day-night double victory over the skidding Pirates. The Phils took the afternoon game, 5-2, and the night contest, 7-4.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- Joe DiMaggio operated on only one leg today and couldn't even play out the full game. But while he was in there the Clipper did more than his share in keeping the Yankees in the American League's blistering flag race.

The Board of Elections has set up 4,365 election districts and has immediately available 5,000 voting machines to handle what it believes will be a record registrationh)0*0*0*iand vote in the November election, it was announced yesterday.
Meat may become more abundant next year and in 1950, the forty-third annual meeting of the American Meat Institute in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was told yesterday.

After rejecting a plea for a month's extension, Federal Judge Edward A. Conger agreed yesterday to give attorneys for three of the twelve Communist leaders indicted on July 20 on conspiracy charges an extra week in which to file motions attacking the indictments.

BERLIN, Sept. 20 -- The United States-British air lift, hurdling the Soviet blockade of Berlin, should be capable of maintaining the normal economic life of the Western sectors of the city during all but the two worst months of the coming winter, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor and commander in chief, declared today.

Lethargy characterized trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, with hides futures prices near their best levels at the close of the session. The turnover totaled 3,600,000 pounds. The December delivery attracted the most interest, closing at 23 1/2 cents a pound, up 31 points.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -Military supplies and foodstuffs, needed in the Orient and in Pacific outposts, will go aboard Army transports in this port tomorrow, despite the coastwide maritime strike.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Supreme Court's decision outlawing the basing point pricing system should not occasion excitement or clamor about business exploiting the public, or Government persecuting business, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP) -- A severe tropical hurricane boiled over into the Florida Straits tonight and headed toward southeast Florida. It was expected to hit Miami in the morning.

GRAFENWOEHR, Germany, Sept. 20 -- The commander of the United States ground forces in Europe appealed today to his soldiers in Germany to extend their enlistments because of the grave international situation.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Rochester's resurgent Red Wings nosed out the champion Montreal Royals tonight, 6-5, to gain a 3-2 edge in their best-ofseven, first-round Governors' Cup play-off series.

Bergdorf Goodman showed opulent and individualized furs yesterday. Mink followed Persian in silhouettes seen recently in couturier collections in cloth. Soft sloping shoulders with a narrow look between edges were stressed.

Eliahu Epstein, special representative of Israel to the United States, who has just spent ten days conferring with his Government at Tel Aviv, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard a Trans World Airline plane from Paris. He had left Israel on Sept. 13, Mr. Epstein said, and had no first hand knowledge of the effects of the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator for Palestine.

Hour-apart deadline bidding for two public utility bond issues of like credit rating made for tenseness in bond houses yesterday in the period just before noon. The reaction of institutional investors to the bidding for the Toledo Edison bonds caused several of the syndicates in the running for the Wisconsin Power and Light issue to revise tenders they had first set up.
THE PAS, Man., Sept. 20 -Messages spelled out on the ground of the bleak North Manitoba country aroused hope tonight for the five persons lost Sept. 12 when a United States Navy plane disappeared.

With the city's up-state reservoirs only 75 per cent filled, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, made a renewed appeal for water conservation yesterday to all users in the city.

From the fur-lined coat to the handsome evening ensemble of satin with its jacket boasting mink lapels, De Pinna included a great variety of the new winter fashion trends in a showing at the St. Regis yesterday. There were many and sumptuous clothes with the price range as wide as the style range, from a low of $59.95 to a high of $595.
The Landur Realty Corporation sold the one-story taxpayer containing three stores at 414-22 South Broadway, Yonkers, N.Y., to the Portchester Realty Corporation through Thomas M. Graham Co., brokers.

The week's second stage entrant, "A Story for Strangers," Marc Connelly's first play in six years, will be submitted this evening at 8 o'clock at the Royale Theatre. Dwight Deere Wiman is sponsor of the project, his fifty-third Broadway venture.

Two young victims of Nazi persecution stepped off a Belgian plane here yesterday to start a new life as the adopted children of an American family, only to be told that the adoption was off because their foster-mother-tobe had died suddenly.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox held fast to their American League lead today, defeating the Detroit Tigers, 7 to 2, after a shaky start as lefthander Mickey Harris restricted Detroit to four scattered singles.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 20 (AP) -Ten crewmen suffered burns today in an explosion aboard a Greek freighter that caught fire after having grounded in the Strait of Belle Isle, near Newfoundland's northern tip.

The work of the passenger landing agent has long been considered in the exclusive preserve of men, because of its exacting and strenuous nature, but an increasing number of women are entering the field.

In a revival of earlier charges of anti-Semitism, twenty students at City College walked out yesterday from the first session of a class in Spanish literature conducted by Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, head of the Department of Romance Languages.

Loomis J. Grossman, operator, bought the vacant plot, 100 by 91 feet, at the southwest corner of Queens Plaza South and Twentyeighth Street, Long Island City, Queens, from Naomi Martin and resold it to Saul Seigel, builder, who intends to improve it with a one-story store building.

TACOMA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The man mountain from Seattle, Ed (Porky) Oliver, jammed down an eagle 3 to win the Tacoma open golf tournament today on the first hole of a sudden death play-off against Cary Middlecoff of Memphis.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Rhode Island's Republican primary tonight saw a slate backed by the old-line GOP state committee score an impressive victory over one led by a World War II hero.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Mrs. Louise Bransten Berman refused today to testify whether she had given aid to wartime spies in their alleged efforts in behalf of the Soviet Union to obtain this country's atomic secrets. The refusal was on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate her, it was announced by Representative John McDowell, chairman of a House subcommittee on un-American activities.

When Mr. Truman told a Denver audience yesterday that Republican opposition was primarily responsible for the rejection of the public housing sections of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner bill, and that a powerful real-estate lobby in Washington worked to achieve this rejection, he was speaking by the record.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP) -Cleveland's revived Indians maintained their spot one-half game behind the league-leading Boston Red Sox tonight, defeating the Philadelphia Athletics, 6 to 3, before a crowd of 44,442.

The State Racing Commission is willing to consider reviving the daily double form of wagering at New York race tracks next year, an official said last night. The betting device, which was abolished in 1946, allows a bettor to couple a horse in the first race with one in the second.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 20 -Stringent penalties for political offenses were adopted as the Israeli Government enacted tonight "emergency regulations for the prevention of terrorism." These were part of the moves to track down the organization behind the slaying of Count Bernadotte.

The election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Henry R. Luce and Walter C. Baker to the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was yesterday announced by Roland L. Redmond, president of the board.

WASHINGTON, Sept 2O (AP) -The Ethiopian Legation rejected as "unacceptable" today the State Department's explanation of an incident in which the Ethiopian Minister was asked to change seatsat a science meeting.

Samuel Reznick, operator, has purchased the three-story garage building at 535 West Twentyseventh Street, extending through to 534 West Twenty-eighth Street, from the Lusonn Realty Corporation. The property, occupied under a fifteen-year lease by the Ranger Motors, Inc., is assessed at $155,000.

DURING the last few years a fictional pattern has emerged for what, in want of a better name, might be called the New York novel. The typical New York novel has nothing to say about most of the people who live and work in New York. Its cast is composed of the talented, the famous, the successful and the filthy rich.

The striper fishing is holding up quite well along Rhode Island and Cape Cod, and is improving on the Vineyard, according to late reports. The best fish seem to be falling to boat fishermen, but an occasional big one falls to a surfcaster.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Cattle flooded into the major stockyards of the nation today in the largest numbers in almost a year. A total of around 129,000 head was recorded for twelve principal terminals, compared with 143,000 on last Oct. 6, the most recent larger day.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Britain is prepared to veto an Israeli application for membership in the United Nations, according to responsible sources. This would be her first veto.

With seven of the contests booked as afternoon affairs, the New York Knickerbockers will play nineteen Basketball Association of America engagements at Madison Square Garden during the 1948-49 season.

The General Assembly of the United Nations meets today in Paris under the shadow of the continued deadlock in the Four-Power negotiations over Berlin. These negotiations were undertaken as a crucial test of the proposition that the new post-war world would be founded on cooperation between Soviet Russia and the West.

When smoked salmon is packed in a vacuum tin, the high temperatures necessary during this operation rob the fish of some of its pleasing characteristics. That's probably why the Bell Smoked Fish Company of San Francisco avoids the vacuum type seal.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 20 -- P. James Pellecchia, who resigned as Newark Police Judge July 12 after confessing he misappropriated more than a half million dollars from the Columbus Trust Company, of which he was vice president and counsel, entered today a plea of non vult to a criminal information containing twenty-one accusations of embezzlement.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Frankie Davis' bases-loaded single with one out in the twelfth inning gave the Syracuse Chiefs a 2-to-1 victory tonight and kept them in their semi-final series with the Newark Bears. The Bears now lead three games to two.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Big Nine today announced a revised athletic code establishing stiff academic standards for athletes receiving scholarships or other financial aid.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Wheland Company, foundry operators at Chattanooga, Tenn., filed suit if the Federal District Court here today against Jess Larson, War Assets Administrator. The suit charged that Mr. Larson's action in leasing a Governmentowned blast furnace in Cleveland to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation violated the Surplus Property Act of 1944 and WAA regulations.

A combination of indecision and extensive switching yesterday caused the sharpest decline in the stock market in two months. Prices sank 1 to 3 points to the lowest level since April under offerings which surpassed the millionshare level for the second time this month.

The Paris Opera ballet company, which opens tonight at the City Center, received the city's welcome yesterday. Mayor O'Dwyer thanked the ballet company's staff of ninety dancers and technicians for participating in the city's Golden Anniversary international dance festival, which the ballet company will open.

The two four-story buildings at 320-322 New York Avenue, southwest corner of Union Street, Brooklyn, accommodating twenty-four families, have been purchased by William Cohen from Eva Lippman for cash above a mortgage of $51,337.
The booming premium industry, built largely on articles to aid sales promotion, is finding a new large field in men's merchandise, it was learned yesterday.
Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., passenger and cargo ship operator, will revise its plans for construction of new liner tonnage for the New York-South American route, it was reported here yesterday.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 -- Newsprint requirements of the country's daily papers over the next twelve years were projected here today by representatives of leading newspapers in the United States.

One thing the United States cannot afford to do in Germany is to coddle those who were guilty of crimes against mankind under the Nazi regime. Justice demands otherwise -- the fact that the Nazis are now beaten and cowering does not absolve them of their offenses.

The Department of Immigration and Naturalization Service began yesterday a deportation hearing against a 69 year-old unemployed machinist, who came to this country from Lithuania in 1906 and has admitted having been a member of the Communist party from 1924 to 1926.

President Truman will tour New York City in a parade on Oct. 29, the Friday before election day, accompanied by Mayor O'Dwyer and local Democratic leaders, it was announced yesterday. The parade will bring to a climax three days of campaigning by the President in an effort to capture New York State's forty-seven electoral votes.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Ten years ago tomorrow this 300-year-old village was battered, along with the rest of Long Island, New York City, Westchester and six Northeastern States, by a tropical hurricane. The storm caused a death toll of 680 persons and property damage estimated at $400,000,000 over the entire area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The West Coast refineries strike, if it continues, may develop a fuel shortage to be felt throughout the country next winter, Max W. Ball, director of the Interior Department's Oil and Gas Division, said today.

Negotiators for stevedoring concerns and longshoremen will resume contract talks here Thursday under the supervision of Commissioner Thomas R. Steutel of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Mindful of the difficulties encountered in obtaining approval of the far-reaching program he presented to the United Nations General Assembly last year, Secretary of State Marshall is expected to move cautiously at the session that convenes tomorrow afternoon in the Palais del Chaillot.

LUSHAR, China, Sept. 7 -- An 11-year-old boy, Kum-bu-tze-den, is being educated by Tibetan seers here in the Kumbum Lamasery in Tsinghai Province to take over the spiritual leadership of the Tibetan people as the tenth reincarnation of the Panchen Lama and as the Living Buddha of Boundless Light.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Berlin uncertainties and the forthcoming meeting of the United Nations General Assembly in Paris kept the stock market subdued today.

Tammany Hall's attempt to get a second line on the voting machines for its local candidates, under the name of the United Laborite party, ended in at least temporary failure yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber ruled the new party line off the November ballot.

A twenty-man soccer team, led by Coach Egon Pollack, is scheduled to arrive today at Idlewild Airport from the new State of Israel for a four-game goodwill tour of this country. The visitors are all on furlough from the Home Defense Army, many of them having served with the Jewish Brigade during World War II.

The Lawrence Realization turned out to be a matter of frustration to the great majority of the 19,910 fans that witnessed the racing program at Belmont Park yesterday. And the Futurity Trial might just as well have been called the Futility as far as the chalk players were concerned.

The mass suicide of migratory birds that created such a big sensation in Manhattan is a well-known occurrence in Germany at the isle of Helgoland. There, on foggy fall nights, every year, not hundreds but thousands of birds, on their way from the polar regions, fly against the giant light of the lighthouse, dying on the ground.

The Continental Motors Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended with last July a net profit of $2,536,129 after provision for taxes and income applicable to minority stockholders of the Wisconsin Motor Corporation.
LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Bruce Woodcock, who was knocked out in training by a punching bag, predicted today he would stop Lee Oma of Detroit in his ring comeback tomorrow.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- The following is the order of business at tomorrow's opening session of the third General Assembly of the United Nations:

ALPAUGH, Calif., Sept. 20 -- A B-45, North American, four-jet bomber which was on a test flight from the Muroc Air Force Base, crashed on a grain field this noon and burned, killing its two crew members.

With the great bulk of the city's trucks back on the streets, the Association of American Railroads took steps yesterday to lift the railroad freight embargo that went into effect when the truck tie-up began three weeks ago.
The first American tour of a foreign orchestra since the war will begin on the evening of Oct. 17, when Charles Munch will conduct the Orchestre National of France in Carnegie Hall.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Don Gilmore figures he'll play baseball again -- maybe even make the St. Louis Cardinals -- although he can barely wriggle the toes of his right foot.
With Mayor O'Dwyer taking a personal hand, the city's law-enforcement agencies went into action yesterday to prevent a resurgence of racket rule in the garment industry.

The stock market staged one of its familiar reversals yesterday when, after the set-back sustained on Monday, prices rebounded and recovered about half the ground lost then. While the session was not devoid of pressure, it was confined to opening transactions and thereafter the advance was unbroken.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission today resumed consideration of a plan for modification of outstanding securities of the Central Railroad of New Jersey in an effort to bring its reorganization proceedings to an end.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 21 -Llanoria, the six-meter Olympic champion, made her first appearance in home waters today and took the opening race in defense of the Seawanhaka Cup, oft called the "Little America's Cup," from the Royal Swedish Yacht Club Challenger, Maybe VI.
The City Council voted yesterday to give the Police Department new authority to regulate the use of sound trucks in the city.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California received a tumultuous welcome here today on his arrival to deliver a speech in which he denied that the Republicans had stabbed the farmers in the back with a pitchfork. Invading President Truman's home state for a major campaign address, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee was welcomed by a crowd of from 50,000 to 75,000 persons who watched a parade through the downtown streets.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin is returning by night train to London to make a speech to the House of Commons tomorrow afternoon on German affairs.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Navy disclosed plans today for turning this area into a major fleet air base for the country's largest carriers.

The long lines division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company offered its 25,000 employes wage increases ranging up to $6 a week yesterday in negotiations with the American Union of Telephone Workers, CIO.

A pint of AB blood was delivered yesterday by the Red Cross laboratories at 4 East Thirty-seventh Street to Crown Heights Hospital, Brooklyn, in time to save the life of a patient in urgent need of it.
India has completed plans for construction of its first newsprint mill, which is expected to be in operation before the end of next year.
The $1,000,000,000 Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., disclosed yesterday that it has taken preliminary steps to purchase the 38-year-old Long Island Lighting Company.

Erwin Piscator's Dramatic Workshop of the New School for Social Research will open its March of Drama Repertory season early next month with a program of plays prepared by the Veterans' Memorial Stage, under the chairmanship of Leon Askin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -Chairman Fred A. Hartley Jr., of the House Education and Labor Committee, suggested today that management-labor disputes of airlines possibly should be placed under jurisdiction of the TaftHartley law.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands Sept. 21 -- Queen Juliana in her speech from the Throne opening the Dutch Parliament today declared that the expenditure on the Netherlands' land forces was being directed almost exclusively toward the maintenance of an army in Indonesia "capable of handling the task allotted to it."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- In a decision handed down today the Securities and Exchange Commission announced that it would permit Hammill Co., San Francisco investment firm, to withdraw its broker-dealer registration. The commission commented that, despite that fact that "a case for revocation has been made out, the protection of investors might be better served."
BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Mrs. Margaret Chase Smith, Republican Senator-elect from Maine, asserted today that "war may come at any time; the situation is far more dangerous that we realize."

The National Broadcasting Company made public yesterday a revised code of standards for programming operations. Most of the provisions of the code have been in effect for some months, but for the first time the document also will apply to television.

The future of the 5-cent candy bar is not in danger, two prominent candy manufacturers told members of the Affiliated Drug Stores and their suppliers yesterday at the semi-annual convention being held in the New Yorker Hotel.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Big Nine's proposed new code affecting scholarship legislation does not sanction athletic scholarships, Commissioner K. L. (Tug) Wilson said in a statement today.

The revelation in Washington that the Joint Chiefs of Staff have presented to the National Munitions Board a tentative schedule of the requirements of the Armed Services for a full mobilization of resources for war should not be taken as an indication that the Joint Chiefs believe war is imminent.

MIAMI, Wednesday, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The tropical hurricane was pointed toward Florida's citrus belt early today and the Weather Bureau said it probably would split the peninsula from Everglades City to Daytona Beach. It moved north northeastward at about eight miles an hour.

The Museum of Modern Art is opening to the public today a retrospective exhibition of collages -- more than a hundred examples by some thirty European and American artists. Most of the third floor gallery space has been given over to the display.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Crawford, appointed by Governor Dewey to fill the vacancy created by the death of Justice Lloyd Church, was inducted yesterday morning in the Trial Term of the County Court House. Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division directed the procedure.

A request that City College permit volunteer instructors to teach the nineteen students who walked out of Dr. William E. Knickerbocker's Spanish class on Monday was turned down yesterday by Dr. Morton Gottschall, Dean of Liberal Arts and Sciences at the college.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) -- It's "pennant or peanuts" tomorrow so far as Cleveland is concerned.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- British consumers will pay in further restrictions on domestic supplies of consumer goods for the nation's rearmament efforts, officials of the major ministries agreed today.

We invite the attention of Mayor O'Dwyer, his Cabinet and the Board of Estimate to a set of conditions in East Harlem that add up to a disturbing problem. The photographs published in this newspaper yesterday, along with a descriptive article by Charles Grutzner, told of one element in this problem.

Officials of the Port of New York Authority met yesterday with representatives of nine airlines to renegotiate the terms of the leases at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Beyond saying that negotiations would continue, spokesmen for both sides declined to comment on the session, which lasted from 10:30 A.M. to 2 P.M.

Robert Thompson, 33 years old, state chairman of the Communist party and one of twelve Communists who are under Federal indictment on charges of advocating the overthrow of the United States Government by violence, was stabbed and beaten early today by three unidentified men near his, home in Sunnyside, Queens, according to word received by Communist party officials here.

Norman (Red) Strader formally took over as head coach of the New York Yankees football team yesterday and in his first press conference indicated that there'll be no drastic changes made in the personnel of the slumping A.A.C. eleven.

The International Festival sponsored by the Mayor's Committee for the Commemoration of the Golden Anniversary of the City of New York got under way last night at the City Center and its environs with assorted fanfares and eclat.

Here to engage in the first international sports event for the new State of Israel, eighteen soccer players from Tel Aviv and their coach arrived at Idlewild yesterday from Brussels aboard a four-engined plane of the Sabena Air Line.

The mist that enclosed New York harbor as the Queen Elizabeth sailed into port early yesterday morning lifted too late for twenty-three British schoolboy passengers to see the Statue of Liberty. But their first glimpse of the city and its people made them decide that "Americans are even more American than we thought."

Robert Stubbs of Spring Lake, N.J., and Jack Marsh of the Rock Hill Tennis Club, Kansas City, were among the victors as play in the second fall tournament of the Professional Lawn Tennis Association began yesterday at the Cresthaven Country Club, Whitestone.

The New York State Teachers Retirement Fund made a permanent mortgage loan of $1,800,000 at 4 per cent interest for ten years to Sam Minskoff Sons, builders, on the eighteen-story and penthouse de luxe cooperative apartment hotel in the course of construction at 1 East Sixty-sixth Street, north corner of Fifth avenue, according to Jerome Minskoff, vice president of the building firm.

WARSAW, Sept. 21 -- The Polish Socialist party's National Socialist Council is in the midst of an important meeting that has already resulted in the resignation of Edward B. Osubka-Morawski, former Premier, from the party's Central Committee, it was learned today.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Count Bernadotte's proposals for peace in Palestine were commended by authoritative British quarters today. Both Arabs and Israelis were advised to give serious consideration to the recommendations, which are regarded here as sound and impartial.

ATHENS, Sept. 21 -- A Greek Army spokesman announced a major victory over the Communistled rebels tonight. He stated that 375 rebels had been killed in a single action lasting a little more than twenty-four hours. The bodies, he said, had been counted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The National Advisory Cancer Council today announced that a national conference for the purpose of reducing deaths from gastric cancer will be held in San Francisco Dec. 13 and 14.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 21 -- A white United Nations plane filled with flowers brought the body of Count Folke Bernadotte home to Sweden early this evening. Coming from Paris, where United Nations dignitaries paid their respects to the slain Mediator, the plane landed at Bromma Airport after an intermediate stop at Copenhagen.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 21 -Charles Aso Clough, for twelve years vicar of Trinity Mission House, New Lork, was ordained Bishop of the Springfield Episcopal Diocese today in consecration ceremonies at St. Paul's Cathedral here.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Braves all but hoisted the National League pennant to their flagpole today by twice drubbing the Cardinals, 11-3 in the opener as Johnny Sain pitched his twenty-second victory and 4-0 in the second game in which rookie right-hander Vern Bickford twirled his first major league shut-out.

WASHINGTON, SEPT. 21 (AP) -An eight-state Midwestern region is listed as surpassing all others in major new industrial construction during the first three postwar years. In it 792 plants worth more than $548,700,000 have been built.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 21 -- Marcel Cerdan's dressing room was the scene of unrestrained joy after the Frenchman took the world middleweight championship from Tony Zale tonight. The room was packed to the bulging point with friends and well-wishers, and it seemed that almost everybody, from Abe Greene, New Jersey State Athletic Commissioner, down to the attendant at the door, was the recipient of an unblushing kiss from the new titleholder.

J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, yesterday characterized Governor Dewey's address in Des Moines, Iowa, as "full of noble sentiments, most of which were in conflict with the performance of the Republican Eightieth Congress."

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Almost 40 per cent of Britain's motion-picture houses are expected to win exemptions of one sort or another from the Government's new regulation requiring them to give at least 45 per cent of their screen time to British first-feature productions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Evidence justifying, the indictment of three persons for wartime atomic espionage has been gathered by a House Subcommittee on Un-American Activities, its chairman asserted today.

Mrs. Robert H. Ellinger, who heads the committee for the dinner dance in behalf of the United Hospital Fund on Oct. 5 at the St. Regis Maisonette, and members of her committee, including Mrs. Frank E. Adair, chairman of the women's committee for the Fund, will attend the luncheon to be given tomorrow in the Louis XVI Suite of the hotel by Henry M. Stevens.

The one-cent fare increase sanctioned by the Public Service Commission became effective at one minute after midnight this morning on the remaining six of the thirteen private bus lines operated under city-granted franchises. Fares went from 5 to 6 cents on five of the lines and from 10 to 11 cents on the Fifth Avenue Coach Company's buses.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- In a suit which may establish an important precedent, the Philco Corporation today asked the Federal District Court to compel the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to accept and to furnish certain television programs.

Mayor O'Dwyer appealed yesterday for support of his $135,000,000 hospital construction program. He made the appeal at the official laying of the cornerstone of the Francis Delafield Hospital, being built at 163d Street and Fort Washington Avenue at a cost of $6,200,000.
Columbia's football team ran through a brisk scrimmage drill at Baker Field yesterday, aided by cool autumn weather.
The strike-bound cargo of wheat on the Army freighter Cardinal Gibbons has been withdrawn and will be stored in New York in a grain elevator, the Army announced in Washington yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 21 -- Government lawyers prosecuting the International Typographical Union on contempt-of-court charges bore down today on hiring procedures demanded by the union.

Mathematically eliminated as a National League pennant contender when the Braves beat the Cardinals twice, the Giants also lost ground in their fight for a first-division berth when they bowed to the Cubs, 3 -- 2, in the afterpiece of a day-and-night twin bill at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Experiments with 100,000,000volt X-rays on a "phantom" patient indicate that these high voltage X-rays, produced by the betatron, may prove of great value in cancer therapy because of their high penetrating power and lower surface absorption as they pass into matter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The military planning program of the United States has now progressed so far that the country is in its strongest position since the start of the so-called "cold war," military observers said today.
Moderate declines spread across the commodity list yesterday in an apathetic session.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -Growers of two major oil-seed crops -- soy beans and flaxseed -received new assurances from the Government today of support prices for these products. Because of big yields of these crops, prices have tended to drop below the levels promised by the Government.

LONDON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Bruce Woodcock, British Empire and European heavyweight champion, started his comeback campaign tonight by knocking out Lee Oma of Detroit in the fourth round of a scheduled eight-round bout.

The formation of a local section of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice to handle complaints of small business men in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut regarding practices involving monopoly or restraint of trade was announced yesterday by J. Francis Hayden, chief of the division's New York field office.

A possibility that the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, might try to induce its three feuding locals in the general trucking industry here to agree on uniform wage rates was indicated yesterday by union spokesmen.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- Lasting industrial peace can be achieved "through continuing and scientific study of the mutual problems confronting labor and management," Benson-Ford, vice president of the Ford Motor Company and director of its Lincoln-Mercury Division, asserted here today.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21 -- An informed public is "the greatest bulwark against communism," Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of The New York Times, said in an interview today. General Adler is one of about thirty-five newspaper management executives conferring here regarding the current newsprint situation.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21 -- Hopes of the country's top newspaper management executives that the Canadian newsprint industry might increase production with new mills and more equipment received little encouragement here today at a two-day conference of the executives with the manufacturers.

Deposits made in the nation's mutual savings banks in August resumed the upward trend which had halted in July, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. The report, issued by William L. Maude, president of the association and president of the Howard Savings Institution, Newark, N.J., disclosed a net gain of $22,000,000 during the month.
John A. Costello, Prime Minister of Ireland, was guest of honor yesterday at the official opening of the new Irish Consulate at 33 East Fiftieth Street.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 21 -- Repeal of the Federal oleomargarine tax, lifting "tax exemption privileges" from cooperatives, and defeat of the proposal to raise the minimum wage scale will be the principal objective of the United States Wholesale Grocers Association, Inc., before the Eightyfirst Congress, E. H. Rowe of Washington, D.C., vice president and secretary of the association, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that coastwise freight handled through Gulf of Mexico ports should continue to enjoy the right of storage-in-transit without a change in rate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The second annual Westchester Better Homes Exposition opened here today at the County Center with $500,000 worth of merchandise displayed by 100 manufacturers and retailers. Latest machinery materials and furnishings for building, equipping and maintaining a home were exhibited.

Pittsburgh's slumping Pirates dropped into Ebbets Field with a six-game losing streak yesterday and, within the space of 2 hours and 4 minutes, won two decisions from the Dodgers. The first, retroactive to Aug. 25, came on the replay of part of the ninth of the protested game at Pittsburgh, and in three minutes an apparent 11-9 Brooklyn victory was transformed into a 12-11 Pittsburgh triumph.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Czechoslovakia has demanded that France extradite Dr. Jan Papanek, former United Nations delegate, and send him to Prague for trial on charges of embezzlement, it was learned today.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- In a welcoming speech to the delegates of the third United Nations General Assembly, the President of the French Republic, Vincent Auriol, solemnly asked them to rush their work of organizing peace and suggested that a United Nations armed force be set up immediately.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 21 -- The administration of Hyderabad, the vast Princely State in the middle of India that asserted its sovereign independence when the subcontinent was split into two dominions, has now been assumed almost entirely by a military gov ernment set up by the Dominion of India.

Henry A. Wallace brought to light last night what appeared to be a fundamental difference of opinion between himself and his campaign manager, C. B. Baldwin. Speaking from the same platform at a dinner here after Mr. Baldwin had spoken he placed himself in opposition to a policy of supporting "liberal" Democrats for election in the current campaign, a policy Mr. Baldwin had just outlined and defended.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 21 -- The creation here of a Reconstruction Loan Corporation, similar to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the United States, to hasten the economic revival is expected daily.

Vladimir Zenzinov's account of the case of the Soviet teachers, Mrs. Oksana Kasenkina and the Samarins, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 13, contains an important omission. Mr. Zenzinov states that on July 29 Mrs. Kasenkina asked him to help her remain in this country.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- The three Western commandants of Berlin established today a new procedure for four-power rule in Berlin. German agencies will act as liaison bodies between the Western powers and the Soviet Union.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- A new type of X-ray microscope, the first device of its kind, has been constructed by scientists at Stanford University. Announcement of the device today said it was expected, to be of great value in revealing the structural secrets of minerals, fabrics and living cells.

FARGO, N.D., Sept. 21 (AP) -Pupils in a dozen public schools in North Dakota were getting accustomed to a novel sight -- Roman Catholic Sisters in the same sort of dress as their regular teachers wear.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Sept. 21 -The bracing fall weather that greeted the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B competition found only a small field of twenty-six players at the Fairview County Club today.

Net sales and earnings of the Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries for the three, six and twelve months ended on July 31 were substantially larger than those of the corresponding periods for the preceding year, according to the report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 21 -Universal-International has signed Barbara Stanwyck to play the leading role in "Gambling Lady," formerly "The Gay Goddess," which is now scheduled for production early next year, the studio announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21 -- Accustomed as they are to the odd automobiles that appear on their streets, the citizens of New Haven gasped today when a gleaming red Franklin, circa 1902, rolled through town at a respectable clip behind a broadly smiling police escort.
The women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York met yesterday in "political convention style" to prepare for the forthcoming Federation fund-raising campaign.
GENOA, Italy, Sept. 15 -- United States aid in a form more valuable than dollars is helping to revive the ancient port of Genoa.

Governor Dewey's first speeches in the West reveal the same pattern of confidence and good temper that was displayed by his running-mate, Governor Warren, when he opened the Republican campaign last week. Mr. Dewey has leveled no wild charges, at the opposition.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 21 -After eleven years of underground activity and four months of public existence Irgun Zvai Leumi disbanded today. Its members began joining the regular army of Israel this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Business income figures as reported by accountants are adjusted by economists in preparing estimates of the national income, both with respect to inventory profits and depreciation, it was emphasized here today by Solomon Fabricant of New York, Professor of Economics at New York University.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Curtis E. Calder, chairman of the board of the Electric Bond and Share Company, today deplored both statism and "misguided nationalism" as barriers to the international flow of private capital, and gave his views as to legitimate concerns of governments in foreign investments.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 21 -President Truman asserted tonight that the West had been "cruelly and wickedly cheated" by a Republicanbacked "power lobby," and said that another Republican victory in November would strangle and stop a vast New Deal-inaugurated program of irrigation, reclamation and hydroelectric power development.

Only Ray Robinson, the welterweight champion, of the four principals involved in the feature events at tomorrow night's Twentieth Century Sporting Club show in the Yankee Stadium failed to complete hard training yesterday.

An arbitration plan which is expected to benefit both linen supply companies and their customers has been adopted by leading linen suppliers, doing about 70 per cent of the business, it was announced yesterday by Jacob Landau of the law firm of Landau and Friedman.

A series of surveys indicating that there has been an increase in home sewing was made public yesterday by the National Needlecraft Bureau. In a kit containing twelve pages of charts and summaries, the group representing several branches of the needle industry reported:

The New York State equivalency examination will be resumed at five centers in the city on Tuesday for men and women who wish to qualify for a high-school diploma, Dr. Burnell Shafer, director of equivalency examination at the Board of Education, announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 21 -- The creation by the next Congress of a national foundation for more intensive research into the causes, prevention and cure of sickness and disease was predicted tonight by Senator Lister Hill of Alabama.

DESPITE the vast attractiveness of the current pennant races, baseball fighting a losing battle to football which is muscling more and more into public consciousness. Before this week-end is over the gridiron game will be advancing in full stride on every front. Baseball, like the rivals of the Boston Braves, is running out of time.

The news item which stated that Ilse Koch, convicted of war crimes of the most repulsive and sadistic sort, will be freed by the United States Military Government in 1949 will give rise to some pardonable curiosity on the part of war veterans and others familiar with the circumstances of the case.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 21 -- Tony Zale weighed 159, one pound more than his opponent, for the defense of his world middleweight title against Marcel Cerdan at Roosevelt Stadium tonight.

Although a few preliminary pigskin skirmishes have already been fought around the country, most gladiators of the gridiron are waiting till this Saturday to cross blocks and tackles for the glory of alma mater and the greater joy of alumni. Will we see "super" teams flattening all opposition?
The Refrigerated Steamship Line will not resume its services between Florida and New York at this time, it was announced yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 21 -The world middleweight championship in boxing, an exclusive American property since Ruby Robert Fitzsimmons gave up the title, went to foreign lands tonight when Marcel Cerdan, doughty French gladiator from Casablanca, knocked out tough and rugged Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., in the twelfth round of their championship battle in the Roosevelt Stadium.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 21 (AP) -The Rival Manufacturing Company announced today a 10 per cent price reduction on its household steam iron.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -United States diplomats believe that Russia has called in leaders of the Soviet satellite countries for secret conferences on the next major move of the Communist bloc.

Lin Yutang, who has written so many books about his native China, finally has written a novel about life in the United States. But he has not abandoned the Chinese, as his title, "Chinatown Family" indicates. John Day will publish it Oct. 7.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, Acting Governor General of the Netherlands East Indies, declared on leaving the airport to return to Batavia today that "events in Indonesia have taken such a serious turn that I can no longer remain absent."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- William Green predicted today that control of the Senate would be returned to the Democrats by the November elections. He was certain that labor would help swing the four votes necessary. Following a meeting of the administrative committee of Labor's League for Political Education the president of the American Federation of Labor also said he hoped the Democrats would regain control of the House.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Britain's balance of trade took a turn for the worse last month, leaving the nation with a gap of 39,100,000 [about $156,400,000] between the value of her exports and the cost of her imports. The figure was 5,500,000 greater than the visible adverse balance of trade reported for July.

Mal Galletta of the home club clipped four strokes from par with a 34, 34-68 to take low gross prize among the Class A performers, scratch to nine strokes, during the final one-day tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the North Hills Golf Club in Douglaston yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Short covering and buying of September corn against sales of December corn advanced the current delivery 8 cents a bushel, the daily limit, on the Board of Trade today. The finish was at the top. New crop deliveries of corn declined 1/4 cent as the result of the closing of spreads with September.

With the estimated insured value of whiskey reserves having increased from about $650,000,000 in 1939 to nearly $2,000,000,000, one distiller, Schenley Distillers Corporation, holds 12,000 separate insurance policies on its whiskey stocks, Col. William Schiff, president of Schiff, Terhune Co., insurance brokers, said yesterday.
