PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Dr. Herbert Vere Evatt of Australia, who has taken a prominent role in United Nations activities since the San Francisco conference in 1945, was elected President of the General Assembly at the opening session today, the first held on the European continent.
Tonight's events: Ruth Geiger, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Sara Reale, soprano, and Edward Utley, piano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; "The Duenna," Lemonade Opera Company, Greenwich Mews Playhouse, 8:30.

The French liners Ile de France and Liberte will re-enter service within the next two years on the North Atlantic as almost-new ships, Jean Marie, chairman of the board of the line, announced here yesterday.

New testimony in the disciplinary hearing on a complaint of unethical practices filed against Leon Fischbein and Emanuel Rosenberg, Brooklyn criminal lawyers, indicated yesterday that a policewoman had obtained evidence bearing on the allegations of Nunci Citro, 57-year-old convicted auto thief, who had accused the attorneys of promising to "fix" his case in consideration of a high fee.

Though it has many critics, the "Voice of America" in Germany is building up a good-sized audience, six German broadcasters said yesterday at Columbia University's Bureau of Applied Social Research. They have just completed a five months study of American radio conducted by the Columbia bureau and will sail today on the Washington.
The Commerce and Industry Association announced yesterday that it would make a study of "featherbedding" in building construction.

Reviving a successful wartime procedure, the Association of Better Business Bureaus' committee on installment contracts issued yesterday a set of voluntary rules for making installment loans or credit advertising statements conform to new Federal credit regulations.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Charles de Gaulle's Government-supplied motorized bodyguard was withdrawn by the French Government today as the National Assembly voted a motion asking the Government to keep order and to defend the republic from such outbreaks as took place last week in Grenoble.

HAVANA, Sept. 21 -- About eighty persons were injured and sixty houses destroyed and 400 damaged in the Matanzas Province as a result of the hurricane which passed over the Island Republic last night to the East, Army Headquarters here reported today.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- American military guarantees to Western Europe are urgently needed to dispel the shadow of the Russian armies over the continent, Lester Markel, Sunday Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said today.

According to the program, Marc Connelly's "A Story for Strangers," which opened at the Royale last evening, is a parable. That is one explanation for the confusing garrulity of Mr. Connelly's modern miracle-play. But unfortunately it is no excuse for a rambling excursion into the world of makebelieve by the man who dramatized "The Green Pastures" eighteen years ago and can still get no higher than heaven.

Two plans for increasing industrial output to meet national defense and stockpiling requirements are in prospect and either or both may be put into effect on a national basis, Dr. Howard Lewis, professor of marketing, graduate school of business administration, Harvard University, declared yesterday.

Opposition to capitalism by delegates to the meeting of the World Council of Churches in Amsterdam this month was based upon misunderstanding of that system as it exists in the United States, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- With an open date in their schedule, the Yankees arrived today to enjoy a brief, breathing spell before plunging into the final and most crucial stage of the American League flag race.
ALBANY, Sept. 21 (AP) -- More than a thousand World War II state veterans bonuses remain unpaid because the Bonus Bureau cannot locate the former GI's.
The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company had a net income of $14,102,601 in the first six months of this year after all deductions, according to figures filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Potassium chlorate (KClO3), an oxidizing agent that keeps lighted cigarettes from going out, also causes most of the nation's destructive fires, a fire prevention expert declared here yesterday.

For better or worse, the American Theatre Group hopefully launches its career tonight at Henry Miller's (the advertised curtain time is 8:20) as the sponsor of Albert Wineman Barker's play, "Grandma's Diary," billed as a satirical comedy.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 21 -- The president of an international airline who has effected a 10 per cent reduction of his costs this year over last year despite a general increase in operating expenses said today that the airlines were "eating fruit from an unripe orchard; they should plan to eat the ripe fruit now and let the other mature."

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Representatives of Britain's leading newspapers heard a two-hour tirade this morning from the Indian High Commissioner in London, Krishna Menon, who objected to the manner in which the invasion of Hyderabad had been reported.

NANKING, Sept. 21 -- Communist Gen. Chen Yi was reported tonight to be throwing additional troops into the battle for Tsinan, Shantung Provincial capital. The semi-official Central News Agency said that the Communists were carrying out an "all out" attack on the city's outskirts and were bringing up reinforcements from North Kiangsu as the battle entered its sixth day.

Declaring that a free economy was the foundation of a free country, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told 1,200 business leaders yesterday that when property rights are abolished all other rights disappear as well.

The State of New Jersey sold yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 highway bonds due July 1 from 1950 to 1983 to a banking syndicate headed by Shields Co. at an interest cost of about 2.049 per cent. The bonds will be used to finance construction of new bridges at Manasquan and Island Heights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Mrs. Alicia Patterson Guggenheim of Hempstead, L.I., was chosen today as one of the three trustees of a charitable trust established by the will of Mrs. Eleanor Medill Patterson, publisher of The Washington Times-Herald, who died here on July 24.

New York State Masons gave a $200,000 medical grant to seven colleges and universities yesterday for research in rheumatic fever. This initial gift is the start of a long-range program by the fraternity to wipe out or control "the dread scourge of childhood."

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- The Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France decided today to avoid breaking off the Moscow negotiations on the Berlin crisis despite the dwindling hope that these talks would lead to any solution.

Annette Simons has resigned as buyer of blouses and accessories at Saks Fifth Avenue, effective on Oct. 1. She has been associated with the store since 1930 and also bought for the Beverly Hills, Chicago, Detroit, Miami and Palm Beach branches.
A fall wardrobe of five items costing less than $125 was shown yesterday at the Anson-Jones' fashion exhibit presented for members of the Invitation Club at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday and closed 3 to 26 points net higher than Monday's final levels.

TOKYO, Sept. 21 (~P)--The Japanese Board o.f Trade has contracted.through Barkley Co., Inc., ofSeattle, to buy 250,000 tons of iron iore from South America, Allied]Headquarters announced today. IThe first shipments under the contract will leave Rio de Janeiro nextImonth and will continue at therate of 50,00D tons a month.

Textile bag production in August showed an increase over the previous month, according to manufacturers at the fall meeting of the Textile Bag Manufacturers Association in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday. Cuttings of cotton sheetings for bags were up 30 per cent since May, it was learned, and burlap yardage consumed showed an increase of 8 million yards during August.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 21 -The Polish press greeted the opening United Nations General Assembly today by echoing Pravda's recent attack on Secretary General Trygve Lie and with a general assault on the United States policy toward the United Nations.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 21 -- Following is the text of Secretary General Trygve Lie's speech at the opening of the United Nations General Assembly in Paris today:

Now it's a swan. Long Island commuters have become accustomed to pretty broad variety in the things interfering with the orderly progress of their trains, but until yesterday swans had not been among them.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Peripheral negotiations concerning some of the most difficult questions that may be brought before the United Nations Assembly meeting already appear to be under way as the disputants on the basic issues seek to improve their relative positions.

A note of optimism has crept into Wall Street's discussion of the dividend outlook for the fourth quarter of 1948. The basis for the new mood appears in two developments: (1) Corporate payments are beginning to reflect earnings higher than those reported for 1947, and (2) in 1947 industry was preoccupied with building up working capital; hence, only about 40 per cent of net earnings went to shareholders.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Dr. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury, said today he would accept an invitation to visit the United States extended to him by a group of prominent Americans if he could get an entry visa.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -Army cargo moved normally through Pacific Coast ports today for the first time since longshoremen and four seagoing unions struck twenty days ago.

Whether or not the conflict, in Berlin is formally referred to the United Nations, the negotiations on the secondary level are over. The scene has shifted from Moscow and Berlin to Paris. With the exception of Molotov and the Soviet commander in Berlin, the frustrated negotiators of the past six weeks are reviewing their labors and debating what to do next in the temporary capital of the congress of the world.

A. E. HOUSMAN wrote that poetry seemed to him more physical than intellectual. He could recognize the symptoms it aroused in him, the bristling skin, the constricted throat, the odd sensation in the pit of the stomach. Fiction that rises above the plane of entertainment into the realm of literature can do the same thing.
Several elections and promotions among the officers of the New York Trust Company took place yesterday at the board of trustees meeting, John E. Bierwirth, president, announced.

J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, rejected last night a suggestion, emanating from Russell Long, slated to be the new United States Senator from Louisiana, that the Truman-Barkley ticket might receive a separate line on the ballot in that state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- It was intimated at the State Department today that Dr. Hewlett Johnson, the so-called "Red" Dean of Canterbury Cathedral, might have a very good chance of obtaining a visa to come to the United States under the sponsorship of ninety-three Americans bishops, college presidents, authors and other educators who have invited him in the interests of "free and open discussion."

The Supplies for Overseas Survivors (SOS) collection of the Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that on Oct. 1 it would open a special 4,000,000pound campaign for relief supplies for Europe's needy Jews.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -John (Jock) Thompson, rookie southpaw from Toronto, held Cincinnati to five hits in his major league debut tonight as the Phillies won the second game of the day-night doubleheader, 6 -- 1. The Reds took the daytime game, 6 -- 5, on eighth-inning hits by Frankie Baumholtz and Steve Filipowicz.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- The United Nations General Assembly opened its third regular meeting today in the Parisian splendor of the massive Palais de Chaillot, but the somber mood of the occasion was symbolized by the black garb of the Swedish delegates and their wives, who are in mourning for Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, who was assassinated in Jerusalem.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Red Sox made hay today while their American League pennant rivals were idle, slapping the Tigers, 10 to 2, to increase their firstplace margin to a full game over Cleveland and a game and a half over the Yankees.

Many who read the reports on the recent meeting of the International Association of Game, Fish and Conservation Commissioners were impressed by the seriousness of the wildlife situation throughout the country, but were disappointed that, despite this massed meeting of minds, no constructive program was evolved which might offer a solution.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 21 -Attacking the record of the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress on eight major counts, Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, declared tonight that that record gave Americans "a sample of what they would get under a completely Republican administration."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The legal tangle surroundings the investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common-stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation became more involved today when the Securities and Exchange Commission appealed to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here to set aside a decision of the Federal District Court which temporarily halted action by the SEC.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 21 (AP) -Syracuse squared its semi-final International League play-off series with Newark at three games apiece tonight as the veteran Dixie Howell shut out the Bears, 9 -- 0, with seven hits, at Ruppert Stadium.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Pravda, newspaper organ of the Russian Communist party, published a four-column article today givin an exposition of the Russian position on Anti-Semitism, Zionism and Israel.

The 277 Park Avenue Corporation, in a new effort to retain control of the $6,000,000 apartment house at that address, yesterday requested the Supreme Court, New York County, to allow the corporation's stockholders to continue in possession of the building after the present lease expires on Sept. 30.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 21 -First-hand reports of events at the Paris session of the United Nations General Assembly, which opened today, will be carried to the American public by fifty-five observers, all representatives of leading religious, labor, civic and educational groups in this country.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Sept. 21 -- Robert B. Evans, agricultural economist for the Southern Regional Research Laboratory, submitted to the country's leading cotton breeders and spinners today a five-point program designed to help cotton maintain its markets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -The Department of Commerce reported today that July 31 inventories of dry goods wholesalers were 23 per cent above the level of a year ago, though virtually unchanged from June.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 21 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York promised the voters of the West tonight that if elected President he would set up a vigorous, longrange conservation program, designed to restore and increase the productivity of the country's farm, mine and timber resources.
In behalf of the American Labor party, may I request publication of the following reply to your Sept. 11 editorial entitled "The ALP and the Fare."

The thirty-fourth annual show of the American Dahlia Society opened yesterday on the roof garden of the Pennsylvania Hotel. For two days dahlia growers throughout the East transfer their activities to New York.

BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- From incognito traveler from Moscow to President of Java's self-proclaimed Communist Republic in thirty-seven days is the meteoric rise to fame of Muso, Indonesia's 50-year-old stocky Communist leader who was once an obscure young school teacher.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals scored four runs in the first three innings off Bill Reeder tonight and went on to defeat the Rochester Red Wings, 5 -- 2, and square their best-of-seven International League semi-final play-off series at three games apiece before 15,264 fans.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Secretary of State Marshall announced here today that the United States would press in the General Assembly for full acceptance of the recommendations of the late Count Folke Bernadotte for a compromise on the Palestine question.

Rule of former Italian colonies in Africa by the present Italian Government would establish a force against any future Russian fifth column there, a resolution adopted by the Italian-American Labor Council declared last night. The resolution called for return of Eritrea, Somaliland and Libya to Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A registration statement covering 71,362 shares of $12.50 par value common stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Sioux City Gas and Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The State Department said today that the Government took "a serious view of the action by the Hungarian Government" in arresting in Budapest Karl Ruedemann, president, and George Bannentine, director of the Hungarian-American Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

The 50,000 displaced persons from Europe who may be settled on farms and in cities of New York State are of the same high calibre as any of their predecessors who in the past helped build the United States, Edward Corsi, chairman of the New York State Commission on Displaced Persons, declared yesterday upon his arrival in New York from Brussels.

Those who mark the favorites off their programs prior to paying their respects to the ticketsellers had a pleasant time watching the main act of the Belmont Park show yesterday. The outsiders in the betting, also the lightweights in the eight-horse line-up, had the race between them all the way.

Several dinner parties were given in advance of the opening performance in this country of the Paris Opera Ballet last night at the City Center. The event is one of many to be given in observance of the Golden Anniversary of the City of New York.

" For the Love of Mary," which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Deanna Durbin, Edmund O'Brien, Don Taylor, Jeffrey Lynn and Ray Collins head the cast of the Universal-International romantic comedy with music.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 21 -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha and other high Arab League and Egyptian officials today vigorously rejected the last proposals of the late Mediator, Count Folke Bernadotte, for a solution of the Palestine problem.

Olives just harvested in California groves, are beginning to appear on grocery shelves here. Whether large or small, they are a stand-by for tempting appetites. Enticing as they are when presented plain, olives -- especially the big, meaty ones -- are extra good if they're spiced.

Meeting in an hour of widespread tension and strife, the General Assembly of the United Nations was called upon yesterday by speakers at its opening session to throw away indecision and give a lead in the establishment of a system of law that will banish force and restore peace on the basis of cooperation among all and domination by none.
ROME, Sept. 21 -- The Italian press and public opinion have their eyes fixed on Paris and the United Nations Assembly there.

A "bad speech contest" announced a while ago and aimed at discovering New York's edition of Eliza Doolittle, and reforming her English, has come, somewhat belatedly, to the attention of a rustic friend of ours and produced in him mixed emotions -- in spite of the laudable objective proposed.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 21 -- A speech and two long statements by Maj. Gen. Jose Humberto Sosa Molina, Minister of War, who recently returned from the United States, were widely discussed here today. The head of the Army is always an important figure in Argentina, and when he speaks of political matters there is always a special reason.

Visiting buyers registered the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 2,060, against 2,590 last week and 1,325 in the similar week last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 978 arrivals yesterday compared with 1,279 last Tuesday.
Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, widow of the steel manufacturer and philanthropists, left an estate of $20,620,000, an appraisal filed yesterday with state tax authorities showed.

Adrian, Hollywood designer whose collection was presented yesterday at Gunther's, has a highly individual approach to fashion. He designs with authority and, above all, he is modern. One may not always agree with what he does, but one must respect it, for behind his creations there is thought and purpose.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The stock market here remained subdued today under the influence of the international situation and yesterday's setback on Wall Street.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 21 (Canadian Press) -- An embargo was placed today on shipments of livestock to the markets here and in St. Boniface, Man., and will continue "until further notice," officials announced. Livestock already in transit does not come under the embargo.

The - "by:product" Of marketdata contained in Federal so~ialsecurity and old age benefit st~tistics will be issued in more comp~ehensiYe form by the Department ofCommerce late this year; membersof the Government statistics andI reporte group,'New York Chapter,of the American Marketing Association, were told yesterday byNelson A. Mitler, chief of.the department's marketing division, atthe Sheraton Hotel.
Political tempers were strained yesterday in the City Council chamber, which echoed to cries of "traitor" and "dirty liar" and to threats of physical violence.

A set of Lloyd's Registers, dating from 1835 to 1900, has been presented to the Mariner's Museum of Newport News, Va., by Lloyd's Register of Shipping in London. In announcing receipt of the gift yesterday, the Museum Library added that its set of registers is now one of the most complete in this country.

The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company borrowed $75,000,000 yesterday on thirty-five-year debentures at an interest cost of about 3.12 per cent. Last March the company sold a like amount of thirty-year debentures at a cost of 3.142 per cent.

The problems of a big demand for meat, conditioned by consumer resistance to high prices, occupied speakers before the American Meat Institute in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday, but Samuel Slotkin, a director who was not on the program, had a sharp rebuke for the organization, in a statement after the meeting.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 -- The newly appointed Board of Trustee of the State University system agreed at their first organization meeting today to give top priority in their work during the next few months to the question of a state subsidy for teacher education in New York City.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 22 -- President Syngman Rhee announced today that steps were under way to increase South Korea's power supply through the addition of five American Diesel electric generators.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation does not anticipate at present any increases in prices of its appliances, J.H. Ashbaugh, vice president of the electrical appliance division, announced yesterday. Mr. Ashbaugh's statement was made following careful studies of the effect of recently increased production costs on the company's appliance price structure.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Central Land Board today announced it will intervene in United Kingdom real estate transactions if the price asked is too high and may buy land compulsorily at a rate it considers proper.

Although the three-year postwar boom is leveling off, the nation's economy is in a "remarkably sound" position and the generally high level of prices is likely to continue for some time, Sumner H. Slichter, Lamont Professor of Economics at Harvard University, declared here yesterday.

Establishment of a picket line at City Hall to protest against present wages and working conditions in the Department of Sanitation was voted last night by 900 members of the Sanitation Workers Union, Local 333 of the United Public Workers, CIO, at a meeting in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -Fidelity Pictures, Howard Welsch's new independent company, has borrowed Jane Russell from Howard Hughes to play the leading feminine role opposite George Brent in "Montana Belle," Fidelity's first picture, which will go before the Trucolor cameras next month at Republic.

EDWIN WAY TEALE speaks kindly of plants, brilliantly of bugs, and tells wonderful stories about beasts, men and birds. He is a distinguished naturalist. His wildlife photographs are works of art. His books are a pleasure to read. The latest and best is "Days Without Time,"* a fine portfolio bulging with twelve dozen pictures and forays ranging from the Span ish moss of the Confederacy to the owls of the Arctic tundra.

With all the headlines about the ill treatment of scientists by secrecy conscious agencies and Congressional committees there has developed certain amount of impatience both among reporters and newpaper readers. A frequent reaction is that "scientists say these things, but where are the facts?

Only time will tell whether the new law to regulate use of sound trucks, passed by the City Council by a vote of 15 to 3, will pass muster before the Supreme Court. That Court, on June 7, in a 5-to-4 decision in the Lockport case, created considerable uncertainty over just what steps local authorities could take constitutionally to protect the public against abuse of the privilege of amplified free speech.

The reappearance of gang influence in the garment district must bring a shudder to every New Yorker who remembers the extent to which racketeers victimized large sections of the city's industry in the Twenties and the early Thirties. No business was too large or too small to escape the attention of hoodlums who used machine guns, blackjacks and lead pipe to establish their domination.

The floundering Giants dropped both ends of a double-header with the Cubs before 3,816 silent sufferers at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Chicago captured the opener, 3-2, with young Bob. Rush pitching a three-hitter, and came back to out-scramble the home forces, 11-7, in the free-hitting nightcap.
A strong tone developed in hide futures trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday as prices closed 5 to 71 points higher in a market that moved steadily upward during the session.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 22 -- Declaring that the American people are confronted with two fundamental problems -- one to establish a lasting peace and the other to avoid a disastrous inflation -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey urged tonight that United States assistance to Europe be used to promote a federation of western Europe.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, pledged the full resources of his group yesterday to defeat attempts by left-wing store unions here to secede from their international union and the CIO.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- In a brief meeting this morning the General Assembly made amends to the Soviet Union for a slight yesterday, when the Soviet bloc was kept out of six chairmanships of main committees, by electing Poland as well as the Big Five and Mexico to vice presidencies of the Assembly.

WARSAW, Sept. 22 -- The Polish Socialist party tonight removed the last barrier to its pending merger with the Communists by purging sixteen of its leaders convicted in varying degrees or charges of nationalism.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- The InterAmerican Council of Commerce and Production today unanimously adopted resolutions calling for removal of deterrents to the international flow of private capital and recommending treaties to insure favorable conditions for export and import of private capital.
ATHENS, Sept. 22 -- Official reports from Kastoria today placed the number of rebel dead found on the battleground north of the town at 423 and the captured at 123.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- The United States is fully prepared, for the first time, to answer charges that it discriminates against Eastern European countries in its international trade policy, it was learned here today. This is generally agreed to be the most important issue on the agenda of the General Assembly.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Sept. 22 -A request that the United Kingdom's Raw Cotton Commission in Liverpool be informed through "high level authoritative sources" of any developments concerning raw cotton in this country was made today by Hugh Arrowsmith, general manager of the Raw Cotton Commission.

FIFTY million Frenchmen can't be wrong and it seemed that all fifty million of them climbed into the Jersey City ring the night before last when Marcel Cerdan knocked the world middleweight crown off the wearied brow of Tony Zale. No sooner had Referee Paul Cavalier signaled the championship victory of the Casablanca Clouter than every Gaul in the joint leaped into action.

To Colosal, 5-year-old gelding bought by Trainer Ivan Parke for Fred W. Hooper in Buenos Aires last year, went first money of $22,300 in the $31,350 Vosburgh Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. He hugged the rail all the way in the seven-furlong run and moved out of the pack to take command at the sixteenth pole.

For reading in bed lighting fixtures attached to the wall above the bed are kinder to the eyes than a lamp clamped to the headboard. Wall units best meet the two requirements of adequate uniform light on the page and general room illumination, according to a study made by Westinghouse among seventeen bed-light installations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A new type of export license, printed on a "unique forgery-proof paper," has been adopted by the Office of International Trade to guard against counterfeiting, it was announced today by the Department of Commerce.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 22 -- Asserting that the rights and privileges of labor were at stake, Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic nominee for Vice President, called upon organized labor tonight to marshal its forces to insure a Democratic victory.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 22 -Led by Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol, the Women's New Jersey Golf Association team of fifteen players won the annual inter-association match by defeating their rivals from Westchester and Fairfield, 34 points to 11, over the Montclair Club course today.

With the new United Nations, headquarters near the East River beginning to cover the reputed site of Nathan Hale's execution, an example to the world of amity between former enemies was seen yesterday as the British joined in honoring the American patriot they hanged as a spy 172 years ago to the hour.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 22 -- Following is the text of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's address here tonight:

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin, in a speech to the House of Commons this afternoon, made it perfectly clear that the Western Allies' attitude toward Moscow on the Berlin issue was one of absolute firmness and refusal to countenance any appeasement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- In asking the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve issuance of $9,675,000 of its equipment trust certificates, Series U, the Pennsylvania Railroad indicated that proposed purchases of new equipment to cost $39,637,500 may be scaled down by $13,725,000.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- The three Western powers delivered today identical notes to the Soviet Union designed to bring a show-down on the question of whether Premier Stalin intends to recognize their rights in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- An ambitious plan to stimulate employment and production in Italy through a $300,000,000 works program financed from Italy's own counterpart fund under the Marshall Plan was made public today with the disclosure of secret correspondence between the Economic Cooperation Administration and its Rome mission.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Dr. Jose Arce, permanent Argentine representative to the United Nations, said tonight he would attempt to push through the General Assembly Italy's admission to the United Nations, regardless of the opposition he might meet from the big powers in the Security Council.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 22 (AP) -Completing a brilliant comeback after being on the brink of elimination by losing three of the first four games of the preliminary round of the Shaughnessy playoffs, Syracuse moved into the final round tonight by beating Newark, 11-4, in the seventh and final game to make it three in a row.

LOUISVILE, Ky., Sept. 22 (AP) -Gov. Earl Warren asserted tonight that America's bipartisan foreign policy "must be a two-way street" if American unity is to be preserved in the vital and critical field of foreign affairs.
Construction will begin tomorrow on the twenty-second and twenty-third new schools in the Board of Education's post-war building program. The schools will cost an estimated $2,500,000.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 22 -Up went the American flag above the Swedish one on the Sewanhaka Yacht Club flagpole late today. The six-meter racer Llanoria, sailed by Herman Whiton, had taken her second straight race in defense of the Seawanhaka Cup against Sven Salen's Maybe VI.

Forty-one-year-old Truett (Rip) Sewell, who up to the day before the 1948 season opened was listed as a coach for the Pirates, yesterday pitched his club to a 5-1 victory over the Dodgers at Ebbets Field. Sewell's semi-soft offerings had the Brooks so puzzled it was not until a pinch single by Duke Snider in the sixth that the home side got its first hit.

NANKING, Sept. 22 -- The battle for Tsinan, Shantung's Provincial capital, entered its seventh day today. Nine Communist columns are now attacking the "immediate outskirts" of the besieged city on all sides, according to a Defense Ministry bulletin.

The Brake Lining Manufacturers Association, Inc., was dissolved and with seventeen of its corporate members and nine officials of the concerns was fined a total of $152,000 through an order signed by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The creation of a joint United States-British commission to supervise the spending of the sterling equivalent of $1,000,000 yearly to promote educational and cultural ties between two nations was announced here today by the Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -An Italian wine concern filed suit in Federal District Court here today charging that a United States Army officers' club in Europe went back on a contract and owes the company for about 1,000,000 bottles of cognac and chianti.

A vacant plot of land fronting 425 feet on the east side of Bruckner Boulevard near 141st Street, the Bronx, has been leased by the Car Washing Corporation, of which Jack Davis is president, from J. P. McCann for improvement with a gasoline and service station.
The American Sumatra Tobacco Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on July 31, last, a net income of $2,383,955 after taxes and all charges.

Beset by injuries and handicapped by a lack of experienced talent, New York University's football squad will return to the city today from its Lake Sebago training camp before opening the 1948 season on Saturday against Cornell at Ithaca.

Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh's milk investigation received a setback yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan quashed a subpoena requiring the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association to produce its books and records.

Fall is here but the dry weather continues, and unless sufficient rain falls in the New England area during the next two weeks there is a possibility that the woods and fields will be closed to hunting until the fire hazard disappears.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Moscow newspapers published prominently today a Paris dispatch asserting that a greedy "Americancontrolled majority" grabbed all the chairmanships in United Nations Assembly organizational elections in Paris yesterday.

After twenty-five years of research a two-volume "collectors' edition" of a biography and bibliography of the cowboy artist, Charles M. Russell, will be published Oct. 24 by the Trail's End Publishing Company. "Charles M. Russell," the biography, is the work of Ramon F. Adams and Homer E. Britzman and is illustrated by 150 reproductions of Russell's pictures, twelve in color.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -New steps aimed at insuring that "royalty oil" from public lands goes to the refineries of Small business are being taken.

The upturn on the Stock Exchange was furthered yesterday although some hesitancy developed in the final hour. In the forefront of the advance were the rails, steels and oils but gains of a point or more were limited and the composite rate rose only 0.43 point on the day.

It was a good night for the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. A company engaged as this one is in rejuvenating itself on a large scale must inevitably have its ups and downs, and this occasion was clearly one of the ups.
The United States Immigration-Naturalization Officers Association will celebrate its silver jubilee with a dinner-dance Saturday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

With business between Lancashire and Canada steadily increasing, British cotton mills are making excellent progress in supplying cotton goods needs of Canadian apparel manufacturers who formerly bought mainly from the United States, according to Norman McCulloch, vice chairman of the Calico Printers Association.

Ireland will never again send forth her sons and daughters in mass emigrations, but she will continue to dispatch missionaries to bring spiritual enlightenment to the other nations of the world, Prime Minister John A. Costello of Ireland said yesterday as he received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Fordham University.

Nineteen students who walked out of a course conducted by Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, head of the Romance Languages Department at City College, returned to their classroom yesterday, "temporarily" and "under protest."
BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- Soviet authorities initiated today another maneuver designed to get as much control of industry in the Western sectors of Berlin as possible.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today two new issues of thirty-year public utility bonds with an aggregate face value of $17,000,000, at prices to yield 3 per cent to investors. A group headed by the Equitable Securities Corporation will offer $12,000,000 of Ohio Edison Company's first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent obligations, and a syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation will offer $5,000,000 of like obligations of Wisconsin Power and Light Company.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept 22 -A new cycle starts m Army football this year. It isn't simply because the longest stretch of invincibility in West Point history beginning in 1944 and enduring through thirty-two games ended on Columbia's Baker Field last fall.

Detective Theresa Scagnelli of the Missing Persons Bureau was called yesterday as the last witness for the Brooklyn Bar Association, petitioner in the disciplinary hearing before Charles O. Lockwood. official referee, of Leon Fischbein and Emanuel Rosenberg, criminal lawers.

General Foods calls it Minute Rice; actually it's Ten-Minute Rice. As its name implies it's jiffy quick to prepare, taking only, half as long as regular white rice. And as one soon finds out, it produces excellent effects, too. Fluffy grains, each separate and distinct, are possible even when an all-thumbsand-no-skill cook presides in the kitchen.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- With the French Cabinet in deadlock late tonight over the wage issue, the delicate political balance achieved by Premier Henri Queuille was being thrown off base by a confused conflict between the parties in the National Assembly over the holding of local elections.

The American Labor party began an action in Supreme Court yesterday demanding a referendum on the return of the five-cent rapid transit fare. The action charges that the voters will suffer "irreparable damage and injury" if deprived of the opportunity to vote on the question at the election on Nov. 2. Hearing on the argument was set for 10 A.M. today.

Disturbed by the failure of motorists to heed traffic signs in the vicinity of Public School 230 on Albemarle Road, between McDonald Avenue and Dahill Road in Brooklyn, fifty or sixty mothers, members of the Parent-Teacher Association there, set up a human barricade yesterday to regulate traffic in the vicinity of the school.

Representatives of Local 282, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and truck operators met briefly yesterday in an attempt to negotiate a new contract. They scheduled another conference for today.

NASHUA, N.H. Sept. 22 (AP) -Royal Little, president of Textron, Inc., today offered to keep its Nashua mills operating if the state would allow a 90 per cent tax reduction for ten years, and if the workers would agree to increased work loads.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -George M. Harrison, director of Labor's Committee for Truman and Barkley, predicted today that the Democrats would gain six seats in the Senate and thirty in the House of Representatives.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) -Capitalizing on three costly miscues in the first half, the Los Angeles Rams roared on to open their National Football League campaign with a 44-7 victory over the Detroit Lions before 17,271 fans in the Coliseum tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- By the time this writing appears a specially called session of the Louisiana Legislature may have reached a conclusion whether the pro-Truman voters of the state shall be given an opportunity to register their choice in the usual manner of marking the names of a set of electoral candidates pledged to the President and duly printed on the ballot.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 -- The University of Pittsburgh announced acceptance today of a $13,600,000 gift from the A. W. Mellon Educational and Charitable Trust for a new Graduate School of Public Health as "an effective answer to a basic, vital-need of the people of the Pittsburgh area."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 22 -- A plea for development, through voluntary leadership, of a strong international hospital association, with regional branches in areas having common interests, to work with a world health organization, was voiced here today by Dr. Thomas Parran, former Surgeon General of the United States.

A grim jest in which a moving man assigned to cart furniture from the closed Soviet Consulate at 7 East Sixty-first Street reported that he had been ordered to remove munitions, machine guns and boxes labeled "explosives," almost erupted into another international "incident" yesterday.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 22--President Truman denounced the House Un-American Activities Committee today as "more un-American than the activities it is investigating," as he came into the San Francisco Bay area for two major speeches in his quest for California's twenty-five electoral votes.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Indians tied Boston for the American League lead tonight, defeating the Red Sox, 5-2. Bob Feller limited the Red Sox to three hits for his fifth straight victory and seventeenth of the season.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Lefty Newhouser hurled his way into a select bracket today, pitching his 150th American League victory as the Tigers beat the Athletics, 5 to 1.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Those never-say-die Cardinals stymied the pennant aspirations of the Braves at least temporarily today by thumping Boston, 8 -- 2, with a 17-hit attack before 10,937 disappointed patrons.

Prof. Maurice Finkelstein, chairman of the City Rent Commission, making public the first annual report of the commission yesterday, said that 15,000 tenant families had been spared court eviction proceedings through the efforts of the commission.

MIAMI, Sept. 22 -- A Florida toll of three lives and at least $25,000,000 in crop and property losses was charged tonight against the tropical hurricane, which moved out into the Atlantic near Jensen Beach at 4:30 P.M.

The purge of Soviet geneticists accused of non-Marxist, "bourgeois heresies" because of their acceptance of the Mendelian laws of heredity has been extended over a much wider front to include all the biological and medical sciences, it is revealed in the latest issue of Pravda, official organ of the Communist party.

Medical examinations for draft registrants here will begin about Oct. 4, and examination of men in the November and December quotas will be completed in time to put them in the armed services before Christmas, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -Longshore picket lines, established nearly three weeks ago with the start of the West Coast maritime strike, were removed from the Port of Oakland Terminal today to permit commercial cargo to be taken from the piers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -The Economic Cooperation Administration today authorized additional expenditures of $70,777,692 in foreign aid for seven European nations. This was the second largest daily authorization under the Marshall Plan.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- As a further precautionary defense measure the British Government intends to set up a new reserve of former army, navy and Air Force personnel who will volunteer for immediate recall in the case of an emergency.

The Communist party offered a $15,000 reward yesterday for the arrest and conviction of men said by Robert Thompson, State chairman of the Communist party, to have stabbed and beaten him early yesterday in Queens.
PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 22 (AP) -- At least one air field capable of handling B-50 bombers and several large enough for the smaller B-29s, are ready in Alaska.
I read with some amazement the startling announcement that the sentence of Ilse Koch had been reduced from life imprisonment to a term of four years.
TOKYO, Sept. 22 -- Major Japanese seaports now can be considered as completely clear of the mines planted during the war, according to an announcement today by Allied naval authorities.

With more Americans eating more meat than ever before, the meat industry faces continued and speedy growth, members of the American Meat Institute heard yesterday at the final meeting of their three-day, session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The wholesale butter market here closed yesterday at its lowest price point since October, 1947. The drop was laid to a long producing season and consumer resistance to high prices.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 22 -- The dahlia display of Henry Wood of Elberon, N.J., was voted the most outstanding exhibit of the 179 classes on display in the fifty-first annual flower show of the Monmouth and Elberon Horticultural Society and Monmouth County Florists Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Eight hundred and eighty-three Federal employes suspected of disloyalty have quit their jobs rather than face trial, a survey of the Government's loyalty program showed today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept 22 (AP) Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said at a bankers' meeting here today that he expects continued prosperity in America for years to come.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -The New York State Association of Magistrates today recommended complete revision of the State Motor Vehicle and Traffic Law and establishment of an institution or farm for alcoholics.

Forty cars with streamers bearing the legend, "Welcome Heroes of Israel," and carrying the squad of visiting soccer players from the new State of Israel who will make their debut against the United States Olympic team at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, bore down upon City Hall yesterday after a tour of Manhattan.

PARIS, Sept 22 -- The United States has decided to the ask the United Nations General Assembly for full approval of the detailed plan for a world atomic control agency worked out during the last two years by the majority of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission and turned down by the Soviet Union, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Trading in September corn ceased at the close of business on the Board of Trade today. Final sales showed net losses of 3 7/8 to 5 3/4 cents a bushel after an early upturn of 5 3/4 cents to the highest mark since late last July.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company, which began forty-five years ago with a paid-in capital of $28,000, now has an asset valuation in excess of $1,000,000,000.

Our plentiful supply of good water in New York City is a blessing which all of us are in the habit of taking too much for granted. We do not, however, have it by accident but by steadily applied forethought. Whatever other inadequacies in planning may be charged to city government through the years, it has not failed to meet demands in this field that stagger the imagination and that increase year after year.

A few days ago a mass of black clouds formed, late in the afternoon, in the west. The barometer cowered before distant grumblings of thunder and an occasional flash of lightning, and all signs said the drought was about to be broken.

The Democratic National Committee has set up a campaign radio budget of $750,000 to $960,000, the latter being the maximum expenditure contemplated, it was learned yesterday. More than $600,000 worth of oratory will be poured forth in October under the National Committee auspices.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 22 -Four passengers, including a United States civil engineer, were shot to death and three others were wounded this afternoon when Arab riflemen ambushed an Israeli convoy traveling under the United Nations flag from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

Directors of Crosley Motors, Inc., declared yesterclay an initial dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share, payable on Oct. 25. Powel Crosley Jr., president, expressed the hope that the company's growth would justify continued disbursements to stockholders.

In a final effort to reach agreement on the Berlin situation before submitting that problem to public debate in the United Nations, the United States, Britain and France have dispatched identical notes to the Kremlin requesting an early and clear-cut answer to the question whether Russia is or is not willing to solve the issues involved and to end the blockade of the German capital.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Former Police Court Judge P. James Pellecchia Jr., who is to be sentenced Oct. 6 on his pleas of non vult to twenty-one charges of obtaining fraudulent mortgages totaling $663,000 from the Columbus Trust Company here, was a witness for three hours before the Essex County grand jury today as that body opened its inquiry into the case.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Abandoning at last his opposition to the partition of Palestine, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin announced in the House of Commons today the British Government's "wholehearted and unqualified support" for the late Count Folke Bernadotte's last plan for peace in Palestine.

Development of a new quicksetting plastic material, the first major new product coming out of its $10,000,000 post-war expansion program, was revealed yesterday by the Plaskon division of the Libby-Owens-Ford Glass Company at a luncheon at the Park Lane Hotel.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 22 (AP) -Republican Gov. Oscar Rennebohm and Democratic aspirant Carl Thompson will compete for the post of Wisconsin's chief executive in the November election.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The suggestion of the President's Commission on Higher Education that colleges put less emphasis on verbal skills and intellectual interests "would be tantamount to paving the way to illiteracy and mediocrity," Dr. William H. Coleman said today.
Max Gordon's first product of the season, "Town House," a comedy by Gertrude Tonkonogy, based on the New Yorker stories by John Cheever, will be put on display this evening at the National Theatre.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The People's Court prosecutor disclosed today he had ordered the formal arrest of two United States representatives of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) now under detention.
GENEVA, Sept. 22 -- Steel production exceeded national targets in every major producing country of Europe except France and the French zone of Germany during the first half of this year.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Sept. 22 -The American Hide and Leather Company's annual meeting, scheduled for today, adjourned until Friday so that a stenographer to make a full transcript might be present. The purpose of the meeting was to elect nine directors and to act on three proposals made by Donald Frager of Los Angeles, a stockholder (all proposals are opposed by directors):

ROME, Sept. 22 -- By a vote of 246 to 129, with four abstentions, the Chamber of Deputies today defeated a motion submitted by the Communists, leftwing Socialists and Republicans, calling upon the Government to increase the salaries of the state employes.

When Foreign Secretary Bevin told the House of Commons yesterday that His Majesty's Government gave "whole-hearted and unqualified support" to the recommendation in the final report of Count Folke Bernadotte, he announced an important advance in British policy on Palestine.

For fleecing war veterans of $60,000 to $90,000 on fraudulent promises to get them profits in deals for war surplus material, George Douras, 32-year-old veteran of 1892 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday by Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett to three to six years in state prison.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22--The State Department authorized the American Mission for Aid to Greece today to release foodstuffs and DDT and to expedite the delivery of urgently needed supplies to refugees in the Near East.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22 -- Recent reports from the capitals of the member states of the Communist Information Bureau strongly indicate that the Cominform governments have entered the organizational phase of the struggle against Premier Marshal Tito.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -Treasury figures showed today that the Federal Government so far in this fiscal year has received less, spent less and gone less into the red than it did last year.

In a move aimed at heightening the offensive power of his team, Coach Ed Danowski of Fordham yesterday promoted Stan Bloomer from third string quarterback to starting left half, a position he held last year.

New York City's weatherman closed his books on the 1048 summer season with a grateful sigh at 11:22 P.M. last night after spending three sticky and uncomfortable months marking up new records at his office in the Whitehall Building, 17 Battery Place.

Coach Lou Little yesterday revealed Columbia's probable starting line-up for the opening game with Rutgers, as the Lions went through a light contact workout at Baker Field. The drill stressed defense against the Scarlet's plays.

Renewed competition with "giveaway" programs faced by major entertainment shows now returning to the air is expected to produce strong "behind-the-scenes" pressure for a showdown on continuance of the prize-awarding epidemic, it was learned yesterday.

The 1948 Community Chest Drive will be opened next Thursday with a special program that will be carried on the four national networks from 10:30 to 11 P.M. In addition to addresses by President Truman and Henry Ford 2d, there will be a variety show starring Bob Hope, Red Skelton, Danny Kaye, Jack Benny, Ronald Coleman, Jo Stafford and the Andrews Sisters.

Under the leadership of David Dubinsky, its president, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, decided yesterday to answer "the challenge of the underworld" by stepping up its efforts to organize non-union dress shops.

While discussing the stunning performance of Marcel Cerdan in lifting the world middleweight title from stout-hearted Tony Zale, boxing followers yesterday looked forward to the second championship struggle on one of the most crowded calendars the ring has known in recent years.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The big powers' failure to reach agreement on atomic control has severely curtailed scientific cooperation on an international scale in the major fields of nuclear physics, Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, wartime director of the New Mexico atomic laboratories, told the United Nations today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- With their so frequently erratic southpaw, Tommy Byrne, turning in a highly commendable mound job, the Yankees tonight put themselves right on the very necks of their rivals in the three-cornered American League flag race by crushing the tail-end White Sox in the opener of a two-game series, 7 to 2.

The United States Maritime Commission, in an unprecedented step designed to bolster private ownership in the nation's merchant marine, announced yesterday the cancellation of the chartering of government-owned ships to companies that own no American-flag vessels.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 22 -- The International Typographical Union, opening its defense against contempt of court charges, offered the New York commercial printing and newspaper contracts as evidence of good faith compliance with a pending injunction and the Taft-Hartley Law.

TOKYO, Sept. 22 -- Effective Nov. 1, if occupation plans mature, the Japanese Government will declare illegal the practice of carrying food in public passenger conveyances. This move is designed to make the transportation of black market rice so difficult and risky that the farmers will sell to the Government at the official prices.

OTTAWA, Sept. 22 -- There will be no devaluation of the pound sterling, Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, told a press conference here today when he submitted to a barrage of sometimes hostile questions.
Three seafaring lads moored their forty-two-foot yawl at the Seaplane Base, Twenty-third Street and the East River, yesterday and got ready for work.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Constance Morabito's My Celeste, recent graduate from the maiden ranks, took the shortest route home today to win the $7,500 added Home Bred Stakes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Coins will be flipped six times Friday at the American League offices to determine a play-off program if the Red Sox, Indians and Yankees end the torrid race in a two-way or triple deadlock.

Tall crowns and side-draped shapes provided the major silhouette interest in the Peter Bondi showing of millinery yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. Employing greige and such high colors as bittersweet, pink, a brilliant shade of blue, purple and tones of gold, this designer combined them with a profuse use of trim.

BALDWIN, L.I., Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Charles Leichner of the Home Club, who posted 40, 40, 80, won low gross honors following a matching of cards with Mrs. Harry McNaughton of North Hempstead in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Willow Brook Club today.

Bonnets and jewelled hats marked the mid-season collection presented by Madame Aranka at a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The designer uses soft fabrics such as jersey, satin and metallic cloth to drape her hats.

Displays as well as specimen blooms won their share of awards on the second day of the American Dahlia Society's annual show, held in the roof garden of the Pennsylvania Hotel. The show closed last evening.

Apparently a "ride victim," the body of 37-year-old Sperio Kavoures with two bullets in his head was found sprawled early yesterday afternoon on an infrequently used concrete road in the isolated Wakefield section of the Bronx.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The stock market here today marked time awaiting delivery of Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin's statement to the House of Commons. Generally, jobbers were content to leave quotations unchanged at the opening and found during trading that only certain issues were wanted.

After a brief hearing yesterday, Federal Judge Edward A. Conger reserved decision on an application by three American Labor party candidates in the November election for a temporary injunction barring city authorities from interfering with the use of sound trucks at street campaign meetings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Full wartime production of essential arms and equipment within eighteen months after the letting of contracts, except for a few highly complex items such as aircraft carriers and heavy bombers, is virtually assured under the National Military Establishment's new program, authorities said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -The argument of Presidential candidates over Western reclamation was echoed in the capital today in an exchange between Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican, of Utah, and Reclamation Commissioner Michael W. Straus, over proposed reductions in Reclamation Bureau personnel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan called upon Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today for "more definite, clear-cut and specific" statements on farm problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The American Steel and Pump Corporation, New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 200,000 shares of convertible Class A stock of $2 par value.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -The Central Railroad of New Jersey has no immediate need to purchase additional freight cars, Earl T. Moore, the road's chief executive officer, said today.

The possibility that the abandoned British freighter Leicester may yet turn into a rich salvage prize was advanced yesterday following reports that the ship was still afloat 635 miles south of Argentia, Nfld.
Winston H. Jones has been appointed director of sales of the Conlon-Moore Corporation, Conlon division, manufacturer of household washers and ironers. He succeeds Roy E. Andree who has resigned.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle, who transferred Lieut. Joseph A. Lawler last Friday from a Harlem fire house to Tottenville, S.I., strongly defended his action yesterday. He said the lieutenant would be detailed there indefinitely because of alleged "pernicious political activity."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closed unchanged to 9 points lower.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Sherry Robertson walked in the top of the tenth to force in the winning run and give the Senators a 5-to-4 victory over the Browns tonight. Just 1,641 persons paid to watch the game. Cliff Fannin retired twenty-two straight men before Jake Early walked in the tenth.
The prevailing fare on the city's privately owned bus lines became 6 cents yesterday. The sole exception was the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, which raised its traditional dime charge to 11 cents.

Henry A. Wallace will leave La Guardia Field at 8 o'clock this morning on his third major campaign trip, in which he and his party will cover 8,500 miles by plane in fifteen days. His tour will start in Ohio, Indiana and Illinois, then he will swing into Texas, for three speeches there, and go on to the West Coast, for nine days of intensive campaigning in California, Washington and Oregon.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- The authority of the United Nations would be used to prevent the carrying out of the Czechoslovak move for the extradition of Dr. Jan Papanek, former United Nations delegate who was replaced after denouncing Russian influence on the Prague Government, official sources said today.

ROME, Sept. 22 -- Italy agreed today to supply a minimum of 9,928,000,000 lire [about $175,500,000] for the United States-British zone of the Free Territory of Trieste between July 1 and Dec. 31 of this year. The agreement was signed in Trieste by representatives of the Italian Government and the zonal military command.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- The Braves announced tonight that they would accept applications for world series tickets starting immediately and would fill them until the supply was exhausted. General Manager John J. Quinn said the tickets would be allocated on a first-come, first-served Basis subject to the following conditions:

The strike of the refinery workers in California again last week resulted in another sharp reduction in crude oil production. The American Petroleum Institute yesterday reported that crude oil output last week averaged 5,294,350 barrels daily, a drop of 51,700 from the 5,346,050 in the previous week.

The excellent article by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, headed "Trained Personnel Lacking in Occupational Therapy," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 12, stressed the fact that many patients in the hospitals are unable to receive the benefits of occupational therapy because of the shortage of women trained for this work.

Anglo-American economic aid to Russia during the second World War was negligible, Deputy Premier Nikolai A. Voznesensky, member of the Politburo, governing body of the Soviet Union, asserts in a book on the Soviet war economy published yesterday.

Ruth Geiger gave her fourth New York recital last night at Town Hall. The young artist after winning the National Music League Award and the Naumburg Award, became a finalist last spring in the first piano contest of the Rachmaninoff Fund.

Today nearly a million women in the United States are in business for themselves, according to Census Bureau figures. They are proprietors, managers or officers in 442 of 451 types of jobs classified by the Government. They knit, crochet, cook, baby-sit, make cigars.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 22 (UP) -- Three Americans were tied for the lead at five-under-par 67 in the $10,000 Canadian Open golf tournament today at the end of the opening eighteen-hole round. They were Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio; Dick Metz of Virginia Beach, Va., and Bill Nary of Los Angeles.
Bubble gum, many feel, is bad enough.

The strike of the refinery workers in California again last week resulted in another sharp reduction in crude oil production. The American Petroleum Institute yesterday reported that crude oil output last week averaged 5,294,350 barrels daily, a drop of 51,700 from the 5,346,050 in the previous week.

The excellent article by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, headed "Trained Personnel Lacking in Occupational Therapy," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 12, stressed the fact that many patients in the hospitals are unable to receive the benefits of occupational therapy because of the shortage of women trained for this work.

Anglo-American economic aid to Russia during the second World War was negligible, Deputy Premier Nikolai A. Voznesensky, member of the Politburo, governing body of the Soviet Union, asserts in a book on the Soviet war economy published yesterday.

Lieut. Col. Humberto Mariles, Mexico's Olymplc winner and his team-mate, Capt. Ruben Uriza, yesterday arrived by plane from London to start training for the international military jumping competition which will highlight the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden Nov. 2 to 9.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- The Israeli Government today protested the United States proposal that Count Folke Bernadotte's recommendations on Palestine be adopted in their entirety but indicated willingness to "explore all proposals which are put forward as a basis for a final and lasting peace."
A 1949 club convertible and an all-steel station wagon were added to the Austin line of cars yesterday at a dealer meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A resolution unanimously opposing proposed freight classifications for fibre tube containers was passed yesterday by the National Fibre Can and Tube Association at the Biltmroe Hotel, Paul S. Hanway, managing director, disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Representatives of the Civil Rights Congress, an organization named by the Attorney General as subversive, demanded today that President Truman "dismiss" indictments against twelve Communist leaders for conspiracy to overthrow this Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A note that was reported to call for a clear-cut reply from the Soviet Union on the Berlin currency question was delivered this afternoon by Robert A. Lovett, as Acting Secretary of State, to Alexander S. Panyushkin, Soviet Ambassador.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson today granted a temporary injunction barring Representative Lyndon Johnson's name from the November general election ballot in Texas.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -Successive doubles by Virgil Stallcup, Ray Lamanno and Johnny Vander Meer sent two runs over the plate in the seventh inning tonight and gave the Reds a 4-3 victory over the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission granted permission today to the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company to abandon the ferry it has operated for eighty-eight years between Tottenville and Perth Amboy, N.J.

A force of 100 lawyers will be sworn in tomorrow by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein as his volunteer, special deputies to enforce the election laws during Registration Week in this city, it was learned yesterday.

Deportation hearings were held yesterday at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue, against two aliens, former functionaries of the Communist party. They are charged with being members of a group seeking the forcible overthrow of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 15, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 22 (AP) -- President Truman's name would go on the Louisiana ballot as the "national Democratic party" candidate under terms of a bill introduced at the opening of a special session of the Legislature tonight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- At least eleven food trains for overseas relief will be assembled between Thanksgiving Day and Dec. 10, bringing such aid to a climax, John D. Metzler, national chairman of the Christian Rural Overseas Program, sponsor of the trains, said here today.

The Motion Picture Association of America plans to make a census of motion picture theatres in the United States biennially, Robert W. Chambers, director of the Association's Department of Research, announced yesterday. The first survey of theatres throughout the country made by the Association revealed a total of 18,351 film houses.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Knight Dream won the $47,528.58 third annual Little Brown Jug 3-year-old pace in straight heats today, picking up $23,764 to boost his earnings to about $80,000.

An issue of $1,560,000 of building bonds of Union Free School District 1, Canandaigua, N.Y., was sold yesterday to Roosevelt Cross at a bid of 100.93 for 2.60s. The bonds, which will mature from Sept. 1, 1949 to 1978, were re-offered at prices to yield to 2.70 per cent.

The Motion Picture Association of America plans to make a census of motion picture theatres in the United States biennially, Robert W. Chambers, director of the Association's Department of Research, announced yesterday. The first survey of theatres throughout the country made by the Association revealed a total of 18,351 film houses.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Knight Dream won the $47,528.58 third annual Little Brown Jug 3-year-old pace in straight heats today, picking up $23,764 to boost his earnings to about $80,000.

After delivering a half hour lecture on cleanliness' and health to a packed Upper Manhattan Court, Chief Magistrate Edgar J. Bromberger imposed fines totaling $850 yesterday on 133 persons who pleaded guilty to sanitary code violations or littering the streets of Harlem.

PARIS, Sept, 22 -- The Soviet Union received a crushing setback today when the General, or Steering, Committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected efforts by Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union to delete five key proposals from the Assembly's agenda. The anti-Soviet atmosphere here indicates that the Assembly will uphold the committee.

A new symphony by Benjamin Britten, composer of the opera, "Peter Grimes," will receive its world premiere during Serge Koussevitzky's forthcoming twenty-fifth and final season as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Many other novelties also will be presented.

Private capital rather than public works funds should provide most of the financing for development of the Twenty-third street area, according to a preliminary report to the Twenty-third Street Association, Inc., made public yesterday.

An issue of $1,560,000 of building bonds of Union Free School District 1, Canandaigua, N.Y., was sold yesterday to Roosevelt Cross at a bid of 100.93 for 2.60s. The bonds, which will mature from Sept. 1, 1949 to 1978, were re-offered at prices to yield to 2.70 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 18 were 909,733 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 121,033 cars, or 15.3 per cent more than in the preceding week, 21,339 cars, or 2.3 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week last year, and 10,681 cars, or 1.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

The theme emphasized in speeches at the opening of Columbia University's 195th academic year could hardly be viewed as a breaking of new ground. "I believe you have come to Columbia for the opportunity it gives of preparing yourself for effective citizenship," said General Eisenhower.

In his address yesterday before the General Assembly of the United Nations, Secretary Marshall outlined again the fundamental propositions of American foreign policy and the faith on which that policy is based. It was a moderate and conciliatory speech which neither challenged nor threatened anybody.

Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic candidate for Vice President, declared here last night that a turnout of 4,000,000 voters in New York City on Nov. 2 would provide a margin of Democratic strength sufficient to put New York State's forty-seven electoral votes in the Truman-Barkley column.

THE world has been transformed, not entirely for the better, since Carlyle called economics the dismal science. Economists may still conduct blood feuds with each other with lusty relish, they may still disagree on basic fundamentals of their subject; but they have acquired a deal of information in a hundred years. The area on which they do agree is large and grow ing.
Weary of the struggle, two newly arrived shows are folding tomorrow night. They are "Heaven on Earth" at the Century, and "Grandma's Diary" at Henry Miller's.
ROME, Sept. 23 -- The discouragement that exists in many sectors of the Italian Communist party was clearly indicated today in speeches heard at the meeting of the party's Central Committee.

There is a time for activity, a time for delving into tested books and a time for listening to great music. When autumn's mellow interlude caresses northern hills and valleys and Nature's paintbrush is applying the first tentative strokes of scarlet, russet and gold, comes the time when it is good to sit alone for a spell on an open upland ridge.

The annual pamphlet report of McKesson Robbins, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on June 30, mailed to stockholders yesterday, disclosed that net sales of $352,719,321 established a new high record, compared with $342,272,742, in the preceding fiscal year, a gain of 3 per cent.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh had begun an inquiry into the purchase by a real estate company of tax liens on more than 200 lots within the area of the $34,642,000 Ravenswood Houses project to be constructed in Long Island City, Queens, by the New York City Housing Authority.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Government has broken into the black on its budget operations for the first time in this fiscal year, Treasury figures showed today.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A strike of 170 plant guards that crippled a segment of Detroit's auto industry for fifteen days came to an end today, and 60,000 idled auto workers prepared to return to their jobs.

A collection of European furniture and decorations, chiefly antiques, chosen for their livableness and good design will get their first showing in the new Lord Taylor "Now and Then Shop" opening Monday on the eighth floor.

Gaining a measure of revenge for past indignities, the Dodgers handed the Giants a 7-to-1 trimmingh)0*0*0*ibefore 9,243 vociferous partisans at the Polo Grounds yesterday. This result, which prolonged the life of the Brooks as a pennant contender, gave them an even break in the season series with their local rivals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Department of the Army made public today two messages from Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States commander in Europe, explaining the commutation of the war crimes sentence of Frau Ilse Koch.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- An American "Communist functionary" is the third and most important of a top list of wartime atomic espionage suspects drawn up by a House Subcommittee on Un-h) 0*0*0*iAmerican Activities, its chairman asserted today.

A gloomy picture of the prospects for production of an adequate amount of housing for rental or sale at prices within reach of the average family was presented by economists and financial experts at yesterday's sessions of the thirty-fifth annual convention of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America in the Commodore Hotel.
NASHUA, N.H., Sept. 23 (AP) -Royal Little, president of Textron, Inc., agreed today to maintain operations at the Jackson sheeting mill here "if and for so long as operations are profitable."

The Paris Opera Ballet last night gave its third performanceand its first change of program in the International Dance Festival sponsored by the Mayor's Committee for the Commemoration of the Golden Anniversary of the City of New York at the City Center.

Clocks will be turned back tomorrow night to signalize the end of Daylight Saving Time, which will depart at 2 A.M. Sunday and be gone until next spring. The event will be marked by adjusted train schedules and changes in the eating and play habits of 8,000,000 New Yorkers.
The air commuter definitely has arrived.

The priceless pleasure that Brooklyn's blooms gave Emmy Olsen was her secret for twentyseven years. But final settlement yesterday of the will the lonely spinster wrote a few hours before her death three years ago disclosed that she gave her lifetime savings $7,000 to the Botanic Garden.

Ari Ibn-Zahav, one of the most distinguished living Hebrew writers who is temporarily in New York but who has made his home in Palestine for fifteen years, is the author of an unusual novel that Crown will publish Oct. 14. "Jessica, My Daughter" is a historical novel about sixteenth-century Venice based upon the author's extensive knowledge of Renaissance life.

A speeial installation service for the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, former rabbi of Vine Street Temple, Nashville, Tenn., and recently appointed senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, will be held tonight in the temple, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The United States Marshall Plan mission here said today that French authorities had as yet made no proposal on the use of the counterpart funds. They added that such a proposal might be made within a few days.
DEVON, Pa., Sept. 23 -- Entries of Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Hale, Greenwich, Conn., carried off four blue ribbons today at the Chester County-Bryn Mawr horse show; combined for the first time this year.

With the freshmen running through Lafayette formations, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday turned the attention of his Fordham varsity toward defensive operations in preparation for tomorrow's contest with the Leopards at Easton, Pa.
