Lawyer Testifies for Himself at Hearing on Bar Charges of Unethical Practices Testifying in his own behalf before Charles C. Lockwood, official referee, Emanuel Rosenberg, criminal lawyer, who, with his partner, Leon Fischbein, is respondent to a complaint of unethical practices filed by the Brooklyn Bar Association, denied yesterday all accusations of improper conduct.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Secretary of State Marshall assured the Soviet Union today that the United States "does not wish to increase existing tension" but "we will not compromise essential principles." His address to the United Nations General Assembly was firm in tone, and he warned that "it would be a tragic error" if any country, after cutting itself off from the rest of the world, mistook "the patience of others" for weakness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -First reports from registration centers indicate America's armed forces will have a pool of about 2,000,000 single, non-veteran men of 19 through 25 in which to dip for draftees.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- British official quarters heartily agreed today with the main principles of United States Secretary of State Marshall's speech to the United Nations General Assembly. Foreign Secretary Bevin could have made almost the same speech without arousing the slightest surprise.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- State Senator Thomas C. Desmond urged today that private industry "reconsider blind employment and retirement schemes which might shatter the hopes and usefulness of older workers."

There was barely a ripple yesterday on the stock market where trading was sparse and prices largely maintained the status quo, although the averages showed ah)0*0*0*ileaning to the lower side. Only a few issues underwent more than fractional changes, and the index slid back 0.29.

BERLIN, Sept. 23 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky and other Soviet representatives at the Military Governors' conferences here early this month tried to halt the United States and British airlift into Berlin by contending a fourpower Allied Control Council decision forbade the use of the air corridors for anything but the supply of the powers' military and civilian personnel in the city.

Marriner S. Eccles, member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, and Dr. Walter E. Spahr of New York University, executive vice president of the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy, presented opposing views last night on how to control inflation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The nation's railroads announced today that they will ask for an 8 per cent increase on most freight rates to offset rising costs. Based on the expected volume of business in 1949, it is estimated roughly that the increase would add $400,000,000 to the annual freight bill.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Reds took advantage of three errors tonight to defeat the Phillies, 3 -- 2, in their final meeting of the season. Johnny Blatnik's homer accounted for the first Blue Jay run in the eighth, even though Philadelphia collected fourteen hits.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers rubbed out a 7-2 fifth-inning deficit here today, coming from behind to beat the Philadelphia Athletics, 8 to 7, with two big runs in the ninth.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 23 -- Development of the peacetime uses of atomic energy must not be left entirely to Government monopoly once the danger that it will be employed by an aggressor as an instrument of conquest is past, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York declared in a speech here tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin's "we stand firm" speech in the House of Commons yesterday and the defense plans were well received in the stock market here today. But apart from long-term and undated British Government stocks, which investment money avidly sought, there was no appreciable amount of business.

Despite the appointment by the Board of Education of more than 1,000 additional teachers for the opening of schools this month, about 250 more substitute teachers are now urgently needed in the city's elementary and junior highh)0*0*0*ischools, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -Price resistance by American buyers helped cause a reduction in imports of woodpulp from Scandinavian countries during July, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The American Jewish Committee called today for amendments of the immigration laws that would permit the unused portion of quotas to be carried over from year to year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 23 -Expansion of United States foreign trade, both import and export, and development of a normal import surplus is "the only real hope for a revival of true world trade," William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Eight members of Congress today presented recommendations for improving the unification of the armed forces to the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government headed by former President Herbert Hoover.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 (UP) -- John Griffith, a United States citizen, was accused tonight of organizing a plot against President Juan D. Peron and his wife, Evita Duarte du Peron.
COLUMBUS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Governor Warren promised a Republican "streamlining of the vast mystic maze" and "topsy-turvey complexity" of governmental bureaus.

The American Museum of Natural History, Seventyninth Street and Central Park West, will offer a comprehensive educational program for adults and children for the fall season, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Charles Russel, chairman of the department of education.

John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, in a political address before the Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., of New York City, declared last night that the Republican party members of the Eightieth Congress had failed so badly to meet the needs of the country that "they will do everything in their power to distract the American people" from remembering this bad record in the Presidential campaign.
The first arrest in this area for evasion of the Selective Service Act of 1948 was announced yesterday by Assistant United States Attorney William Koerner.

A novel development in FM broadcasting, regarded by leading frequency-modulation exponents as one of the major contributions in that field since Maj. Edwin H. Armstrong announced his invention in 1935, was described last night at a meeting of the Radio Club of America, at the Engineering Society's auditorium, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 23 -Miss Louise Nichols of the home club won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association over the Hudson River Country Club course today.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, received an ovation from the student body of Barnard College yesterday when he delivered the main address at the opening exercises of this undergraduate women's college of Columbia. Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh presided at the assembly.

Having located a small but evidently trustworthy source of institutional investment interest in prime A-rated public utility bonds on a 3 per cent yield basis, banking syndicates are back at the pastime of exploring the irreducible minimum in underwriting spreads.

An unusual literary concoction, stimulating the flavor of an otherwise prosaic annual report was served yesterday by the city's Bureau of Alcoholic Therapy. Its prefatory hors d'oeuvre included this quotation from Edmund Spenser's "The Fairie Queene:"

Because of unsettled conditions in the motion picture industry throughout the world, directors of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., decided yesterday to omit the payment of a dividend on the common stock at this time, J. Cheever Cowdin, board chairman, and N. J. Blumberg, president, announced.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Yet another measure in Britain's defense preparedness program was announced today. A. V. Alexander, Minister of Defense; told the House of Commons that the mobili-...

A new modern housing development, unique in that there is no rental to pay and that it accommodates a colony rather than farmilies, was opened to the public for inspection for the first time yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in a unanimous decision today, held that retirement and pension plans, like those affecting wages and hours, must be submitted to collective bargaining negotiations by employers at the demand of unions.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Only the Middle East has the large reserves of oil that can be developed in time to meet the needs of Western Europe, Frank W. Abrams, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, said here today at a luncheon of the American Chamber of Commerce in London.
Attractive fall fashions, priced for a carrer girl's budget and geared to her busy life, made up a showing seen yesterday at Hearns.

Zionist leaders, headed by Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the Zionist Emergency Council, denounced Secretary of State George C. Marshall yesterday for his approval of the late Count Folke Bernadotte's recommendations that call for a drastic revision of the Palestine partition plan.
PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The Palestine question was formally placed on the United Nations agenda today with the approval of all parties and a recommendation from the British that it receive priority.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The recommendation for a 5s [$1] a week pay increase for more than 1,600,000 workers in the British engineering industry, made recently by an independent court of inquiry, was accepted tonight by the Amalgamated Engineering Union on behalf of its 800,000 members.

Business loans in this area, which had been expanding continuously since Aug. 25 underwent a contra-seasonal reduction of $54,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday. According to the figures covering assets and liabilities of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the decline in the commercial, industrial and agricultural loans item is the largest since April 21.

The formal opening of the citywide drive of the United Hospital Fund of New York for $2,845,988 will be marked by a dinner at the Commodore Hotel next Thursday night, with Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, the principal speaker.

Manufacturers of fountain pens and mechanical pencils protested two fair trade practice rules proposed by the Federal Trade Commission at the second hearing on the code in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday. The rules dealing with misuse of the terms "iridium tipped" and designation of gold content in pens and pencils, impose an undue hardship on the industry, it was charged, and must be revised extensively before inclusionh)0*0*0*iin the fair trade practice code.
Random notes.

A group of Long Island housewives, protesting interim increases in gas rates awarded the Long Island Lighting Company, picketed the offices of the Public Service Commission in the Woolworth Building, 233 Broadway, yesterday, as the commission renewed public hearings to fix permanent rates.

Illiteracy in the United States dropped from 20 per cent of all persons over 14 in 1870 to 6.5 per cent in 1920, 4.7 per cent in 1930 and 2.7 per cent inh)0*0*0*i1947. So the Census Bureau has just reported. Reasons are found in the dying off of an older generation of illiterates, in better schools and compulsory attendance and in special training given drafted men during the Second World War.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Monthly reporting on grains under support loans, which lapsed during the last two years when little grain was under loan, was resumed today by the Department of Agriculture.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 23 -Under the shadow of threatening letters from a Stern group offshoot, the Israeli State Council approved unanimously tonight emergency regulations providing severe penalties for membership in outlawed terrorist organizations.

Elizabeth Hawes strives to create a timeless, individual quality rather than follow current fashion trends. In her custom order collection, shown yesterday at 867 Madison Avenue, she stressed this "of-no-period" feeling by including costumes she created in the Thirties that reflected the same trends as her present designs.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP) -- A powerful hurricane sped northeastward in the Atlantic tonight after striking Cuba and Florida.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 23 -- The coffee market in the United States will not be materially affected by the program of the Economic Cooperation Administration, Robert W. Tyson, commodity program adviser of ECA declared yesterday. He addressed 700 delegates to the annual National Coffee Association convention which began here today.

Governor Warren will be the principal speaker at a rally next Thursday evening in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Chairman, said yesterday. The meeting will be under the auspices of the New York County Republican Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 23 -- Dr. Joost Adriaan van Hamel, a Netherland legal expert who presided over the trials of German warh)0*0*0*icriminals by the Netherland tribunal in Amsterdam, has been selected to head a United Nations relief program for German children, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 18 were 11 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

ATKINSONh)0*0*0*iOAlthough Gertrude Tonkonogy's "Town House" is too small for the characters of her play, it is too large for comedy. As produced at the National last evening, it is a thin, loose, mechanical whizzbang that never explodes across the footlights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--There are 2,800,000 Americans over 14 years of age who can neither read nor write, but the figure is the lowest on record, the Census Bureau said today as it announced results of a survey made late last year.

Fred D. Wilson has been appointed to the new position of assistant to the president of Bendix Home Appliance, Inc., South Bend, Ind. He was formerly vice president in charge of operations for Radio Corporation of America, RCA Victor Division.

National Dog Week was observed yesterday in the lower plaza of Rockefeller Center, with 3,000 persons watching exhibitions of sheepherding by border collies, obedience training and a pageant titled "Dogs of the World" in which twenty-six breeds participated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -A deal for James and Theodore Nasser, owners of the General Service Studios, to join Howard Hughes in financing three independent productions for United Artists release has been agreed upon by the parties concerned, it was learned today from James Nasser.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The countries participating in the European Recovery Program will have to make a tremendous effort in production and trade if they expect to reach economic viability when the Marshall Plan aid ends in 1952, the Organization for European Economic Cooperation said today.
Another Left-Wing local -- the Retail Drug Store Employes, No. 1199 -- has voted to secede from its parent union, the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission today ended its hearing on an application by the Central Railroad of New Jersey to modify its outstanding securities.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 23 (AP) -- States Rights Democrats today abandoned efforts to have the Arkansas State Democratic Convention name Presidential elector candidates pledged to the States Rights ticket.
A grand jury will begin today a full-scale investigation into the resurgence of racketeering in the garment industry.

Bernard Gimbel, president of Gimbel's, will undertake to sing two popular songs on the radio at 9 o'clock next Wednesday evening, while Jack Straus, president of Macy's, accompanies him at the piano, it was announced yesterday.

Production of hard surface floor coverings in 1948 will reach a record peak of 80,000,000 square yards, an increase of 5,000,000 compared with the 75,000,000 last year, mill leaders predicted yesterday. They said that the increase is possible because of easing of raw materials supply but emphasized that allotments will continue for the balance of the year.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 -- Following is the text of President Truman's speech as prepared for delivery here tonight:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - A registration statement covering the proposed issuance and sale at competitive bidding of $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due 1978, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by New Orleans (La.) Public Service, Inc.

The six Manhattan bus lines of the East Side Omnibus Corporation and the Comprehensive Omnibus Corporation were purchased yesterday by the city and turned over to the Board of Transportation for operation at a 7-cent fare, beginning at 12:01 A.M. today.

How Ehlers Coffee has climbed from a minor position to the second largest selling brand in the New York metropolitan market, chain store, brands excepted, with highfrequency small-space, newspaper advertising as its major sales tool, is related in the September issue of Advertising Facts.

The new tugboat Socony No. 10, latest unit of the harbor fleet of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, will enter service today. The 102foot craft had a test run from the Battery to Port Socony, S.I., yesterday morning, with a contingent of newspaper and trade journal reporters aboard.

Featured by a rise of 150 points in October cottonseed: oil futures to a new high of 22.50 cents a pound trading in that commodity on the Produce Exchange yesterday totaled 249 lots. The activity resulted from trade demands that touched off stop-loss buying orders at a time when offerings were light.

An armed thief who waited patiently for his victim to return from a visit to a bank held up the traffic manager of the John T. Stanley Company, Inc., soap manufacturers, and escaped yesterday with $10,090 in cash belonging to the concern.

h)0*0*0*iVANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Dick Metz of Virginia Beach, Va., eagled the opening hole today and fought both rain and par to grab a two-stroke lead in the second round of the $10,000 Canadian open golf tournament.

You have had columns on Count Folke Bernadotte's murder and an editorial on his martyrdom, but I missed word from those who knew him. He was singular, as I saw him, for his fearless directness. This could lead, as one of your correspondents noted, to his being thought naive in some respects, and his manner was so unassuming that I can understand it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -Maj. Gen. Frank R. McCoy told the eleven-nation Far Eastern Commission today that Gen. Douglas MacArthur had not violated any Allied policies in having prevented strikes by Government employes in Japan.

Antique English breakfronts in glowing mahogany are among valued pieces recently brought from Europe and used in furnishing four rooms which open today at Altman's. The four settings are among a new series which also includes six rooms devoted to the store's collection of traditional furniture, as well as seven large water color renditions of room plans.

The court fight between the leftwing and right-wing factions of the Council on African Affairs ended yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg after a tentative agreement had been reached to settle the dispute.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The latest Western powers notes to the Kremlin were designed chiefly for the record and to make clear to the public of the Western nations that every effort had been made to bridge the gulf between the Soviet Union and the West, according to officials in close touch with the Moscow negotiations.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- To Gov. Robert F. Bradford of Massachusetts was presented today a bronze medal in behalf of the Burgomaster of Vienna in recognition of his chairmanship of the Silent Guest Committee, Inc., last Thanksgiving.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 23 -New Jersey Methodist churches have made subsantial gains in church school enrollment and other activities in the last year, but still are lagging behind the cost of living in the level of salaries paid to their ministers.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange again were quiet yesterday, and final prices were 7 to 12 points net lower.

In his address before the GeneralAssembly in Paris yesterday Secretary Marshall for the first time placed this country publicly and squarely behind the renewed efforts that are being made to bring about a negotiated settlement between the Netherlands and the peoples of the Netherlands East Indies without further resort to arms.

The introduction of new designs in custom-made furniture marked the opening yesterday of showrooms of the Robert W. Irwin Company at 305 East Sixty-third Street. The furniture was designed by Joseph Platt, who has indicated penthouse-like settings for the pieces in paintings he has made.
Investment banking houses executed yesterday secondary distributions of stock valued at $2,937,006.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 23 -Shafiq Ades, described as an Iraqi millionaire, was publicly hanged in Basra today, after being found guilty of supplying arms and other war equipment to Zionists.

As a veteran of the Air Force who once served in the Anti-Submarine Command during the Second World War, I would like to protest on behalf of thousands of Air Force veterans and myself the prodigious waste of American defense funds in the construction of a hundred-million-dollar aircraft carrier for the Navy, soon to be started at the Newport News, Va., shipyards.

The American Communist party celebrated its twenty-ninth anniversary last night with a rally in Madison Square Garden, attended by 12,000 of the party faithful. While the theme of the meeting was the rising menace of fascism in the world and the consequent threat to civil liberties, the rally was in tone dedicated to the attack on Robert Thompson, New York State chairman of the party, by three unidentified men early Wednesday morning.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23--President Truman appealed tonight to American liberals to unite and eschew Henry A. Wallace's third party, which, he said, is guided by Communists, does not represent American ideals and has no power or chance of power to bring peace abroad or better conditions at home.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 23 -- Any peace which could be negotiated with Russia now over Germany would be "far superior to one after a war no matter how complete" an American military victory might be, Henry A. Wallace declared here today.

Urging 500 persons to turn on three policemen during a rally last Aug. 9 in front of the National Maritime Union headquarters, 352 West Seventeenth Street, was "reprehensible," Magistrate Edward Thompson said yesterday as he sentenced William McCarthy, seaman, to ten days in the workhouse and a $50 fine.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Lou Boudreau, manager of the Cleveland Indians, visioned a tough road ahead for his pennant-minded squad today.

War between the United States and the Soviet Union is inevitable, and only the capitulation of the United States can prevent it, Deputy Premier Nikolai A. Voznesensky, member of the Soviet Politburo, declares in a book on the Soviet war economy just published in translation here.

The Board of Elections could not agree yesterday on the proposal to change the name of the United Laborite party to the United Local party as had been suggested by Tammany Hall. Before the board members split two to two, a warm oral exchange took place in the commission's offices, 400 Broome Street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23 -- The first group of 1,300 Yugoslav apprentices returned last night from Czechoslovakia after a prolonged conflict with Czechoslovak authorities over their support for Premier Marshal Tito against the Communist Information Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a reorganization plan for the Des Moines Central Iowa Railroad Company providing for a reduction in capitalization from $3,572,000 to $999,950.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Primary market prices rose 0.8 percent during the week ended on Sept. 18, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Commerce. Topping the previous post-war peak of Aug. 7 and 21, the bureau's comprehensive index advanced to 169.4 per cent of the 1926 level.

The Board of Estimate adopted unanimously yesterday a report by its special committee on waterfront rehabilitation, recommending that the city "continue the management and operation of its waterfront under the jurisdiction of the Department of Marine and Aviation."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 23 -The urgency of ridding the highways of potential killers through mandatory vehicle inspection, and the winter perils confronting New York City motorists because of the lack of garage space were emphasized today at the annual convention here of the New York State Automobile Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 During the week ended Sept. 22 member bank reserve balances decreasd $43,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 23 -Gov. Earl Warren of California, Republican candidate for Vice President, warned other nations tonight not to mistake a political campaign as evidence of disunity and called on Democrats and Republicans alike to stand shoulder to shoulder regardless of the outcome of the election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -The National Security Resources Board is studying a proposal that the states require oil companies to cut production in order to conserve oil supplies for use in case of war.

A nation-wide program of grading and classifying all garments and fabrics sold in retail stores to determine proper cleaning methods will be started immediately by the Association of Buying Offices in cooperation with the National Institute of Cleaners and Dyers.

The Merchant Marine Veterans of America issued a statement here yesterday declaring that merchant seamen who served during World War II had nothing in common with other civilians serving in combat areas.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The European Recovery Plan was defended here today by a business man before business men, on the traditional free enterprise basis of the "calculated risk."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A fiverun fifth inning was sufficient for the Senators to defeat the Browns, 9-8, tonight after a two-run homer by Ed Stewart and a one-run triple by Sherry Robertson had sent Washington away to an early lead. St. Louis failed to catch up despite three runs in the seventh and two in the eighth.

The Borden Company, which owns the building at 350 Madison Avenue, corner of Forty-fifth Street, and has its main officesh)0*0*0*ithere, has purchased the adjoining two-story building on a lot 22 by 95 feet at 348 Madison Avenue from the Irving Trust Company, the Bank of New York and the Fifth Avenue Bank, as co-trustees under the will of Peter A. H. Jackson.

The first civil contempt proceeding instituted by the local office of the National Labor Relations Board under the Taft-Hartley Acth)0*0*0*iwas filed in Federal Court yesterday against Local 1250 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union of America, CIO, and nine of its officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- In this space recently there was reviewed the testimony before a House committee of Adolf A. Berle Jr. describing how the Communist "apparatus" in this country captured and hopefully prepared for future service an unknown number of young intellectuals in the American Government.

Hickory Corner, the residential property of Miss Agnes Fowler in Far Hills, N.J., has been purchased by Warren H. Meyer, vice president and treasurer of the Chipman Chemical Company of Bound Brook, N.J., according to Previews, Inc. Mrs. Leslie Hyde of Far Hills was the selling broker.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie's request for a small armed guard to protect the United Nations missions was formally put before the General Assembly tonight despite last-minute Soviet protests.
The assassination of Count Bernadotte is a historic tragedy, as well as a cause of grievous personal suffering to his family and friends.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 23 -- Under a searching, forty-minute examination by the judge whose decree he is accused of violating, Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, swore today that union-approved hiring procedures have no ulterior objective, such as theh)0*0*0*iclosed shop, do not discriminate against nonunion printers, and are designed solely to maintain craft standards.

Alexander Bittelman, right-hand man to William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party in the United States, was stopped cold yesterday when he began an attack on President Truman and Attorney General Tom Clark at a deportation hearing against him at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue.

The American Export liner Excalibur will depart at 4 P.M. today from Pier D. Jersey City, on her maiden commercial voyage. On a forty-five day run to the Mediterranean she will call at Marseilles, Naples, Genoa, Alexandria, Jaffa, Tel Aviv, Haifa, Beirut, Piraeus and Leghorn.

Spills spoiled the fun at Belmont Park yesterday. Warren Mehrtens, King Ranch jockey who won the triple crown with Assault in 1946, was knocked unconscious in a second-race fall, and Charles H. Williams, rider of the favorite in the featured Brook Steeplechase Handicap, also was carried from the track after his mount had gone down over a jump.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -Local 10 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, threatened today to cancel its contract with an independent stevedoring company to load Army cargo in the San Francisco Bay area unless the Army ceased using "strikebreakers."

PARIS, Friday, Sept. 24 -- After one of the most incoherent debates of a confusing session, the French National Assembly late last night voted, 304 to 279, to postpone until next March the local elections scheduled for next month.

NANKING, Sept. 23 -- Communist troops attacking Tsinan, besieged capital of Shantung, have crossed its protective moat and broken into the walled city on the northeast, it was learned today. The Defense Ministry acknowledged that the Communists were already in complete control of the business district just outside the west gate.

Retail meat prices today are higher on some cuts and lower on others than they were a week ago. Veal and pork, both scarce, are up 2 to 4 cents. Spring lamb, on the other hand, is fairly plentiful and 2 to 5 cents less than they were last Friday, according to the City Department of Markets.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Grain markets closed irregular on the Board of Trade today. Active deliveries of corn were 1/4 to 7/8 cent lower, with December leading and October down 6 1/4 cents. Wheat was 1/4 cent lower to 1 1/4 cents higher, the latter on July.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Farmers had stored more than 100,000,000 bushels of this year's grains under Government price support programs by Sept. 1, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Anticipating favorable action by the Maritime Commission on its applications for operating and constructionh)0*0*0*isubsidies, the Arnold Bernstein Lines is completing plans for entry of two 18,000-ton liners in the North Atlantic service by late spring.
John A. Costello, Prime Ministerh)0*0*0*iof Ireland, declared here yesterday that the assumption of leadership in world affairs by the United States was the greatest guarantee of world peace.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 23 -- Stringent legislation for the punishment of Korean collaborators who assisted the Japanese colonization of Korea and helped the Japanese to thwart Korean independence movements from 1910 to 1945 became law here yesterday with the signature of President Syngman Rhee.

Walter L. Rothschild and Gene T. Gunn, Inc., were the brokers in the recent placing of a mortgage loan of $137,000 with the North Side Savings Bank on the six-story apartment house at 1895 University Avenue, the Bronx.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Arab Legion charged that an Israeli fighter plane had shot down an Arab airliner today, killing two British correspondents.

Somewhat surprised yesterday morning when his fare asked to be driven to the court house in Long Island City from Huntington Station, L.I., in Suffolk County, John J. Wagner, a cab driver in that community, was even more surprised and chagrined a few hours later when he learned that he would have to wait six months to collect the $14 for the trip.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- With the golden opportunity before them of plunging the American League's epic pennant race into a triple tie, the Yankees today came down with a fearful crash as they lost their final encounter of the year to the tailend White Sox, 4 to 2.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Cold Stream Stud's Rollo won both heats of the $6,250 Old Oaken Bucket for 3-year-old trotters at today's Grand Circuit meeting.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23 -Like Earl Blaik of Army, Charlie Caldwell declines the nominationh)0*0*0*ibut hopes that those who put Princeton on a pedestal as a shining target know more about the virtues of his football team than have been disclosed to him thus far.

The Community Service Society announced yesterday that, in cooperation with the New York City Housing Authority, it would initiate next Friday an experiment in East Harlem to promote a "good neighbor" policy by improving human relationships among families living in a newly built up community.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- George Pirinsky of New York, executive secretary of the fourth American Slav Congress, was arrested today in the offices of the Immigration and Naturalization Bureau on a warrant accusing him, as an alien, of being a member of an organization which believes, advocates and teaches overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Here in the Hub, where a baseball-minded populace appears to be thinking only of the Braves and the Red Sox, 7,428 persons turned out to see the New York Football Giants defeat the Boston Yanks, 27 -- 7, under the lights at Fenway Park tonight.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 23 (AP) -- President Truman appeared assured today of a place on Louisiana's November ballot.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has purchased the one and two-story warehouse buildings on Stewart Avenue, near Garden City, L.I., from the Turner Construction Company in an all-cash transaction.

Tolstoy's drama of brutal squalor and deep religious import, "The Power of Darkness," will be presented with an all-Negro cast for eight performances, beginning Thursday evening, Oct. 7, at the Master Institute playhouse, 310 Riverside Drive, for the benefit of the One Hundred Tenth Street Community, it was announced yesterday.

ATHENS, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Gen. Markos Vafiades, Communist commander of the Greek rebel forces, had been wounded in the fighting in northern Greece and was now recuperating in a hospital at Tirana, Albania, Greek military circles reported tonight.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 23 -- Anh)0*0*0*iIsraeli Government spokesman said tonight that Israel had rejected Count Bernadotte's last proposals for a severance of the Negeb from the Jewish State, conversion Of Haifa into a free port and the placing of Jerusalem under international administration.

In a letter to THE TIMES, Sept. 18 E. Alexander Powell comments on the regrettable incident in which His Excellency Ras Imru, Ethiopian Minister, was ordered by an usher to leave his box in Constitution Hall where he was a guest of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark kept his feud with Senator Homer Ferguson at the boiling point today with a new charge that the Michigan Republican is playing politics with the loyalty program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -The text of Secretary of State Marshall's address today to the United Nations General Assembly in Paris follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -Lieut. Gen. Izydor Modelski, military attache of the Polish Embassy, said tonight that he had refused an order of the Communist Government of Poland to return home. Instead, he said, he is asking the United States Government to grant asylum for himself andh)0*0*0*ihis family.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The United States has agreed in principle to turn over an estimated $230,000,000 to the French Government in Marshall Plan counterpart funds to help stabilize that nation's economy.

The custom collection of Renel of Paris, reviewed and applauded by luncheon guests at the Plaza Hotel yesterday, had a note of elegance in every costume. From the tailored clothes straight through the show to the most formal evening gowns, Renel used rich fabrics and defined his silhouetes with assurance.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The root cause of the tension over Berlin, of the weaknesses of the United Nations and of world uneasiness is the pursuit by the United States of the Eropean Recovery Program, Polish Foreign Minister Zygmunt Modzelewski told the United Nations General Assembly today.

President Truman will serve as honorary chairman for the 1948 Red Mogen Dovid dinner planned for Nov. 22, it was announced yesterday. His letter of acceptance was read by Mayor O'Dwyer at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, sponsored by a group of leaders in business, industry and labor.

Several hundred pickets marched in front of the Department of Welfare Building, 902 Broadway, early last night in protest over the disciplinary action of Welfare Commissionerh)0*0*0*iRaymond M. Hilliard against fifty-three members of the department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A motion was filed with the Federal Trade Commission today by eight companies in the multi-million dollar corn products industry requesting the agency to dismiss a complaint against them and eight subsidiaries charging a conspiracy to "fix and maintain prices."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A preview of foods being perfected for the market was given at nearby Beltsville, Md., today at the first research luncheon ever served by the Department of Agriculture.

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday sold $24,286,000 of temporary loan notes for the financing of the Lillian Wald and the Patterson houses at bids that designated interest rates ranging from 1.10 per cent to 1.18 per cent. Unsuccessful bids designated interest rates ranging to 1.29 per cent.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Postponement of a decision on the Italian colony question by the General Assembly until after the United States Presidential elections was said today by members of several delegations to be likely, despite Russia's intention to bring the matter before the United Nations Political Committee soon.h)0*0*0*iO

The crashing fists of Ike Williams, Trenton Negro who holds the world lightweight championship, shattered the title hopes of Jesse Flores, California Mexican, in the ring at the Yankee Stadium last night, scoring a knockout in the tenth round.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Coming from last place in the six-horse field, E. Barry Ryan's Touch Control charged through the stretch to win the Assemblymen's Purse in a photo finish today.
The editorial in today's TIMES on "Post War Motor Cars" is along lines on which I have been thinking for several years.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 23 -Taking the third straight race, the defender Llanoria of the Seawanhaka Yacht Club today completed a successful defense of the Seawanhaka Cup.

Quick to discount favorable advance notices concerning the Rutgers eleven that will open the season with Columbia at Baker Field tomorrow, Gordon McCoy of New Brunswick invaded Morningside Heights yesterday to assure football observers and other interested bystanders that "Rutgers ish) 0*0*0*inot four deep."

Despite three rounds of wage increases since the end of the war employes have failed to increase industrial productivity to any appreciable extent by putting forth greater effort, an economist and two industrial leaders declared yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 After clearing Hyderabad of the Razakars, the armed Moslem volunteer corps there, the Indian military authorities will turn their attention to the Communists in the state as "menaces to public order,"h)0*0*0*ia high Indian official just returned from Hyderabad declared today.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 -- The Argentine Government today proclaimed Sunday, Dec. 5, the day on which delegates will be elected to the convention that will reform the Constitution. The convention must be held within six months of President Juan Peron's promulgation speech of Sept. 3.

This city's more than a million school children who have said good-by to summer and who have become again reluctant inhabitants of classrooms are engaged, presumably, in the interesting exercise of learning, which consists in part of the process of receiving and fixing in the mind certain stimuli with which the senses are confronted.

" The Olympic Games of 1948" will have its local premiere this morning at the Gotham Theatre. The feature-length pictorial record of the Olympiad, which was filmed in color under the aegis of J. Arthur Rank, is being distributed in this country by Eagle Lion.

A week-end reunion of the Air Force Association started unofficially last night when Lieut. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, commanding the Air Defense Command at Mitchel Field, L.I., welcomed a group that flew in from Hollywoodito participate in the program.

A number of galleries this week are holding group exhibitions solicited from familiar and unfamiliar sources by way of warming up to the new season. At the ACA are examples from the gallery roster, and the pre-season group at Contemporary Arts includes many young unknowns on invitation as well as regular gallery representatives.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Journal of the American Medical Association said today that "the amount of medical care that is given to most people of the world under their compulsory sickness plans would never satisfy the people of the United States."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 23 -- Hospitals throughout the country were called on today by Joseph G. Norby, new president of the American Hospital Association, to provide effective health services for the public on the basis of need and without regard to the individual's ability to pay.
OTTAWA, Sept. 23 -- Canada will take her part, as in the past, if the four-power talks on Berlin collapse and the issue goes before the United Nations, it was stated authoritatively today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 23--British Foreign Secretary Bevin has warned the United Nations that unless member countries had "the will" to work together, no amount of amending the organization's charter could effect a cure.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Dull conditions ruled before the week-end in the stock market here today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 24 -- Dropping in six birdies on the first ten holes, Dr. Ray Bowles and Paul Cavanagh of South Bay registered a par shattering 66 to capture medal honors in the annual member-guest tournament at the Garden City Country Club today.

The board of directors of the Maine Public Service Company decided yesterday to take no action at this time on the declaration of a common dividend normally payable on Oct. 1. In July the dividend was reduced to 25 cents from 40 cents.

Construction of the first atomic plant in the United States to be devoted exclusively to study of the production of power from nuclear energy, adaptable to industrial use, will begin this fall. The facilities will be on a 4,500-acre tract to be acquired in Saratoga County.

PARIS, Saturday, Sept. 25 -- France's long-delayed economy bill, which was framed to help balance the budget and to obtain for France emergency financial assistance from the Marshall Plan, was finally adopted on its second reading in the National Assembly last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Eighteen scientists and research technicians associated with New Jersey institutions received the Certificate of Merit for outstanding wartime service to the Government at a joint Army-Navy presentation ceremony in Nassau Hall on the Princeton University campus this afternoon.

Hunter College was named residuary legatee in the will of Miss Jenny Hunter, founder in New York of the early training schools for kindergarten teachers and a daughter of the late Dr. Thomas Hunter, founder and the first president of Hunter College.

The crimson, blue and yellow flag of the Salvation Army was flown yesterday from one of the staffs atop City Hall soon after it was presented to Mayor O'Dwyer by William Harris, 87 years old, one of the Army's oldest members.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- The General Assembly of the United Nations, upholding the recommendations of its General or Steering Committee, placed on its agenda today seven items that were strongly attacked by members of the Soviet bloc.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers, continuing in their role of spoilers, helped throw the wide-open American League race into a triple tie today when they hung a 4-3 defeat on the Cleveland Indians in the first of a three-game series.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, today urged conservation of our natural resources to prevent "an impending danger of catastrophe."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The United States Army's European Command acted on its own initiative in reducing to four years the life prison sentence of Ilse Koch, wife of the commander of the Buchenwald concentration camp, and the decision is final, Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall asserted today.

Mrs. Jennie Kelly, 80 years old, narrowly escaped death yesterday morning when a practice smoke-bomb dropped from an unidentified plane crashed through the porch roof of her home at 2262 Stuart Street, Brooklyn. The bomb, which did not explode, missed by inches the chair where Mrs. Kelly was dozing.

Tension in Europe has palpably increased with the opening of the General Assembly. This is not only because it meets in a time of crisis, but because the debate going on behind closed doors in Moscow and Berlin has suddenly become near and actual to the nations gathered in Paris.

More than 3,000 New Yorkers braved the cold winds that blew across Wall and Nassau Streets at noon yesterday to witness a ceremony on the steps of the Subtreasury Building in celebration of the enactment 159 years ago of the Bill of Rights.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- Agreement in principle has been reached on the terms of the first multilateral East-West trade deal that will bring credit from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to the countries of Eastern Europe.
Your editorial entitled "The East Harlem Problem" should inspire civic action.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 24 -- The volume of relief packages sent from the United States under the auspices of the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe has fallen off 40 per cent compared with a year ago. The drop is attributed almost entirely to the psychological effect of the European Recovery Program on the United States public.

Charge account collections of leading department, specialty and furniture stores during August were "holding their own" with comparative figures recorded during the same month last year, it was disclosed in figures released by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York yesterday.

Mochigomi, an unusual kind of rice, forms the basis for three cocktail crackers that Devonsheer Melba Corporation brings to town for tipplers. The cereal grains -- "about as large as the head of a hat pin," the manufacturer said -- are pounded into flour, flavored, cut bit-size and cooked.
An unsolicited wage increase of $4 a week by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company has put a union of its 2,100 accounting and general employes out of business.

Ike Williams, world lightweight champion, will make his next defense of the title in Los Angeles in the interests of the Costello Youth Foundation, of which Lou Costello, movie comedian, is chairman, according to present plans. The date will be announced later, as will the opponent, although indications point to Enrique Bolanos, Californian, who is under the management of George Parnassus, as the challenger.

Jerome Greene, operator, has purchased the corner taxpayer building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 733 Main Avenue, Passaic, N.J., from the Hopp estate for a reported price of approximately $70,000. Mr. Greene owns the adjacent property and now has a corner parcel of 100 by 100 feet valued at about $150,000.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation and chairman of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation, announced yesterday formation of an airplane equipment finance company with initial capital of more than $50,000,000 to finance the sale of aircraft to airlines and others.

Retail trade here this week made a fair increase in a week of good shopping weather. Department store sales were estimated as about 5 per cent over the corresponding week last year. It was pointed out that the weather during the comparative week last year was about ten degrees below seasonal average, thereby stimulating fall merchandise movement. Sales last week were up 9 per cent.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 24 -- President Truman charged tonight that his Republican opponents were "me too" candidates, willing to give lip service to support of New Deal reclamation projects while campaigning for votes in the West, but unwilling to carry out their promises when in office.

General Clay's explanation that the reduction of sentence for Ilse Koch, who was convicted of active participation in the atrocities of Buchenwald nternment camp in Germany, was made on a sober and considered judgment of the law and the evidence in her case still will leave many unconvinced that justice is being done.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UP) -- American League officials used five flips of the coin today to settle possible problems which might arise in case of a tie for the league championship, and the New York Yankees had the best break of luck all the way.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Syracuse University squeezed out a 13-9 victory over a fighting Niagara eleven tonight in a game decided by a goal-line fumble.

Local fans will get their first glimpse of intercollegiate football today when Columbia's Lions encounter Rutgers at Baker Field. The game, which will open the season for both teams, is scheduled to start at 2 P.M.
Two ex-convicts were indicted yesterday on charges of participation in the beating of three union organizers and seven pickets in the garment district last Monday.

OTTAWA, Sept. 24 -- Means to direct the flow of commerce between Canada and the United Kingdom have been devised during the last three days in meetings between Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, and his experts here with Acting Prime Minister, Louis St. Laurent, and the heads of the Finance and Economic Departments of the Canadian Government.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A Tass dispatch from Paris today described United States Secretary of State Marshall's address to the United Nations General Assembly as a political maneuver connected with the American Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The United States Government made a sweeping indictment of the Communist Government of Bulgaria for "systematic and ruthless" obliteration of democracy, contrary to the provisions of the Bulgarian peace treaty, and for other violations of the treaty, in a note made public by the State Department today.

Newspaper advertising in fifty-two cities during August totaled 176,799,584 lines, or a gain of 11.9 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. All categories recorded gains, with automotive up 15.7 per cent; classified 14.4 per cent; retail 13.7 per cent; financial 7 per cent and general .5 per cent.

Organizational difficulties that have beset for many months New Stages, Inc., the downtown producing group which brought "The Respectful Prostitute" to Broadway, finally have been settled, according to a spokesman.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The States Rights Democrats were recognized as a new political party in Arkansas today, and qualified for a place on the Nov. 2 general-election ballot.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -"Much of the labor unrest of recent years is management's own fault." Fred Maytag, president of the Maytag Company of Newton, Iowa, declared today at the silver anniversary convention of the National Association of Foremen.

Maine Chance Farm's Myrtle Charm, unbeaten and unpressed in her three trips to the races, today will attempt to become the twelfth filly to get her name on the roster of winners of the Futurity, Belmont Park's great race for 2-year-olds.

BERLIN, Sept. 24 -- Soviet authorities threatened today to close one of the three air corridors into Berlin by announcing they planned a seven-hour anti-aircraft firing practice on the Buckeburg route. United States and British aircraft continued to use the route as American officials made oral protest at the Berlin Air Safety Center.

The Mortgage Bankers Association of America was warned yesterday that lending agencies faced the possibility of government competition if they failed to liberalize their home-financing policies, and was told that the credit needed to carry on their business was becoming tighter.

College football breaks out in full bloom all over today. With all except a few of the nation's leading elevens in action and major contest on the docket from coast to coast, the program for autumn's first Saturday has a midseason savor.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The all-Democratic Louisiana House of Representatives voted today to let President Truman's supporters list him on the state's general election ballot provided they did not call him a Democrat.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Dick Metz of Virginia Beach, Va., clung to a two-stroke lead in the $10,000 Canadian open golf tourney today as a warm sun dried the sodden Shaughnessy Heights course.
To a troubled world it may just have been another day, but 33,609 deliriously happy baseball addicts storming out of the stadium yesterday quite possibly felt that the millenium had arrived.
How hundreds of relief clients previously regarded as unemployable are being turned into self-supporting wage-earners was told yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corst.
A reunion of a kind rare in shipping annals is due to begin at sea today as the American Export Line's "new" passenger-cargo ship Excalibur shakes down on her first voyage as a liner.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Charlie Trippi, in a desperation maneuver, tossed a 64-yard touchdown pass to Mal Kutner in the final four minutes of play tonight to give the Chicago Cardinals a 21-14 triumph over the Philadelphia Eagles in an opening National Football League game.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Timothy Donohue, suspended Paterson patrolman, was convicted in Superior Court of second-degree murder tonight in the slaying of his wife, Mrs. Sarah Donohue, 39 years old, whose body was found in a vacant lot here on March 28.

NASHUA, N.H. Sept. 24 (AP) -Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, said today his Congressional committee would investigate manufacturing in interstate commerce and might take up the whole cotton textile industry.

The right-wing forces in the Transport Workers Union, CIO, won a decisive victory early today when the union's BMT section elected eight of ten organizers pledged to support Michael J. Quill, international president.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night presented "Coppelia" for the first time in its current season at the Metropolitan Opera House, and a generally youthful and gay "Coppelia" it was. Alexandra Danilova and Frederic Franklin romped through the leading roles with infectious spirit, and took time out for some neat and agreeable dancing.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today filed suit to enjoin the Illinois Power Company from restoring a 50 per cent cutback in deliveries of natural gas to fifteen industrial users.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, sponsor of the Atomic Energy Act of 1946, today denounced as "dangerous and alarming" Governor Thomas E. Dewey's proposal for curtailing the Government's atomic energy monopoly in favor of private industry once the danger of wartime aggression is passed.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 24 -- How to revive intra-European trade will be one of the major problems discussed at the joint third meeting of the boards of governors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and of the International Monetary Fund, opening Monday in Washington, it was learned here today.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Britain's only hope of preventing war is to strengthen her defenses and alliances quickly and to make the Soviet Union realize that continued aggression would inevitably lead to war, elder statesmen of all political parties, including Labor Government leaders, unanimously agreed in a debate on foreign affairs today at the concluding session of the House of Lords.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Viscount Samuel, who was Britain's first High Commissioner in Palestine, declared today that to accept Count Bernadotte's peace proposals for Palestine -- as Britain has done -- must sooner or later involve British recognition of Israel.

The first service of worship in the new edifice of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, will be conducted at 11 A.M. tomorrow, marking its official opening. Dr. John Haynes Holmes, the minister, will preach on "Our Church: What Shall We Do With It?"
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 24 -- Of twenty-six members of the Stern group who broke out of jail here tonight, all but one were back behind bars one hour later.

Three women from the Parents Association of Public School 230, Albemarle and Dahill Roads, Brooklyn, asked Magistrate Charles E. Hirsimaki in Brooklyn Traffic Court yesterday to read a letter, drafted by the association, to the 200 traffic violators in court, as part of the association's safety drive to reduce traffic hazards for school children.

Probably in no area of the nation is volunteer work for welfare organizations more intensive than in Westchester County. The families there generally possess above-average incomes and are able to engage in spare-time work that offers no monetary return. The adults, occasionally the children too, possess time and energy for avocational activities such as working for the local Red Cross, the churches, the hospitals, the Boy and Girl Scouts, the social service agencies.

The Lincoln Tunnel was closed to New Jersey-bound motorists for one hour and twenty-nine minutes late yesterday afternoon after a truck had overturned and caught fire in the tunnel's westbound tube, about 1,000 feet from the Manhattan entrance.

Soviet Russia's announcement that she is withdrawing her army from North Korea and inviting the United States to do the same in South Korea may seem on its face an acceptable procedure for giving Korea back to the Koreans. The record gives reason to doubt that this is the Soviet intention.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 24 -- Arab gun positions on the heights near the French Trappist monastery at Latrun halted Israeli traffic today along the alternative route between Tel Aviv and Jerusalem known as the "Burma Road."

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 24 -- An American mystery of some years standing was solved here today when Edward Aborn, chairman of the brewing committee of the National Coffee Association, told delegates at the annual convention why only five cups of coffee come out of a six-cup pot.

We publish on this page today two columns of letters indicating, we believe, a widespread recognition of the importance of improving conditions in East Harlem. These, and other letters received, comment on a news story and photographs earlier this week which described insanitary conditions in that area, and an editorial suggesting the deeper social problems which underlie the surface symptoms.
The gross estate of Jules S. Bache, investment banker and art patron who died in 1944, was appraised at $10,689,554 by State tax authorities yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- The $2,000,000,000 motion picture industry is going through a period of grave crisis at home and abroad and its future economic stability is in serious jeopardy, industry leaders emphasized here today at the opening of the second annual convention of the Theatre Owners of America at the Hotel Drake.

Rabbi Louis I. Newman of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, made public yesterday an open letter to Rabbi Leon Saks of Cincinnati in which he declined to join the Committee to Retain the Union of American Hebrew Congregations Headquarters in Cincinnati.

GDYNIA, Poland, Sept. 24 -- Waldemar J. Gallman arrived here tonight aboard the motorship Batory to assume his post as United States Ambassador to Poland. He will go on to Warsaw during the week-end and he is expected to present his credentials to President Boleslaw Bierut within a week.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (AP) -The Reds put a crimp in the Pirates' hopes for second place in the National League tonight as they survived a seventh-inning rally to nip Pittsburgh, 4 to 3, before a chilled crowd of 18,914. Bob Adams drove in three Cincinnati runs.
Random notes.

George Phocas 45-year-old president of the Mediterranean Middle East Corporation, 25 Broad Street, surrendered to Federal authorities yesterday to face a charge that he had converted to his own use $34,000 sent him for food packages to be shipped to needy persons in Greece.
NANKING, Saturday, Sept. 25 -- Tsinan, capital of Shantung Province, has fallen to the Chinese Communist Army forces under Gen. Chen Yi, the Communist radio claimed this morning.

Francisco G. Obregon, 27 years old and unemployed, allegedly tried the old "Spanish prisoner" swindle scheme in reverse and found himself held in $10,000 bail yesterday for using the mails to defraud.

ROME, Sept. 24 -- Rome's 15,000 municipal employes began to strike at noon today because their demand for increased wages had been refused. The strike was organized on a "progressive" system, whereby one category of employes and workers after another ceases work until in about a week all city services except the fire-fighting and police services will come to a complete standstill.

The top authority of the Soviet Government now admits that the Soviet economy is subject to severe economic crises, analogous to major depressions in capitalist countries but of a type peculiar to planned economies.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 24 -The United Nations held a memorial service here today for Count Folke Bernadotte and seven other men of this organiaztion who have died for peace in Palestine.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- In a somber report to the General Assembly, the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans has called for a "serious warning" to Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia to stop "large scale" aid to Greek guerrilla forces, it was learned today.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- Stories in the Paris press saying the United States already had assented to the use of the Marshall Plan counterpart fund by the French Government, that the money would be used to finance the wage increase and that the purpose was to back the Queuille Government against former President de Gaulle, were regarded by United States officials today as bad propaganda for the French claim to the fund.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- Robert Taylor was named today by Metro-Goldman-Mayer to play opposite Elizabeth Taylor in the screen version of "The Conspirator," which will go before the camers in England about No. 1. The stars will sail from London Oct. 16, in company with Arthur Hornblow, who will produce the film.

Postponement of strike action against the Third Avenue System bus lines will be continued until arrangements have been completed for the payment of an accumulated back salary increase totaling $1,100,000, Mayor O'Dwyer announced late yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Despite a slight decrease in food prices, retail prices of goods and services usually purchased by moderate-income families in large cities rose 0.5 per cent from July 15 to Aug. 15, it was announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

The Selective Service Act of 1948 will cause little or no hardship to industry because only a comparatively small number of employes too young to possess irreplaceable skills will be drafted Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, declared

DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California asserted here tonight that if any of the provisions of the Taft-Hartley law were found to be "oppressive, unnecessary or unworkable" that the Republican party would amend them.

PRAGUE, Sept. 24 -- Two policemen who were accused of having accepted bribes from an agent of the United States Counter Intelligence Corps as part of a plan to free Dr. Prokop Drtina, former Czechoslovak Minister of Justice, were sentenced today by a Prague military tribunal to fifteen years imprisonment.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 24 -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, asserted today that "no official Arab Palestine Government has been formed so far," although correspondents in Gaza of two Cairo morning newspapers have quoted Ahmad Hilmi Pasha as announcing its formation there, with himself as Premier.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 24 -- Korean Prime Minister Lee Bum Suk said today that the Soviet proposal to withdraw its troops from Korea was part of the Soviet policy "to stimulate the people of South Korea to agitate for the withdrawal of United States forces."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Spokesmen for 352,500 telephone workers, meeting here today, decided on a series of "off-hour" demonstrations against the Bell system and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company instead of "on-the-job" stoppages.

Underwriting houses have a succession of varied and heavy commitments in store for them next week. The major transaction will be offering on Thursday by a Dillon, Read Co.-Reynolds Co. syndicate of $60,000,009 of debentures and $26,000,000 of preferred

The Most Rev. Michael H. Yashiro, Presiding Bishop of the Nippon Seikokwai, the Holy Catholic Church in Japan, will receive the honorary degree of "Doctor of Sacred Theology" from the General Protestant Episcopal Theological Seminary Monday at 6 P.M. at a special service in the chapel of the institution, 175 Ninth Avenue.
Regional officials of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service continued yesterday their efforts hers to resolve the two remaining disputes in the local maritime industry.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- Great Britain will ask for immediate action on the Palestine question when the political committee of the United Nations General Assembly meets next week, it was reported here tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 -- Traitors' treatment for Communists who engage in treasonable acts was promised tonight by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York as he opened his West Coast campaign for President.

BERLIN, Sept. 24 -- Discussing the commutation of Ilse Koch's sentence, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said today that there could be no doubt that she was a "despicable character" and that the world "would be better off if she were left in prison for life."
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Milts Lad and Lorraine today won the featured events of the closing day of Grand Circuit harness racing at the Delaware County Fair.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- An investigation of the vast du Pont industrial empire will be started here next week by the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice, it was disclosed today with the serving of subpoenas on five companies, including the General Motors Corporation, and the issuance of subpoenas for the books and records of eight others.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Playing alert football, the Boston College Eagles tonight bumped the Wake Forest Deacons, 26 -- 9, in the curtain raiser of "big time" college football in New England. The Eagles controlled the ball through most of the game, attended by 26,302 fans, except in the final quarter when the Southerners scored all their points.

J. Finlay Allen, secretary of the Home Life Insurance Company of New York, was elected president of the Life Office Management Association at its twenty-fifth annual meeting yesterday in Chicago. He succeeds R.C. Kneil, vice president of the Reliance Life Insurance Company of Pittsburgh, Pa. W.J. Adams, secretary of the Canada Life Assurance Company of Toronto was made vice president.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 24 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed to her Countrymen to do their utmost to promote peace through the United Nations and prevent "the colossal tragedy of a new atomic-war."
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 24 -- Henry A. Wallace struck back at President Truman today for dragging in "the old red herring" and denied that the Progressive party was controlled by Communists.

The American Broadcasting Company made public yesterday its brief opposing the Federal Communications Commission's proposed rules governing the "give-away" prize programs on the air. The FCC plans to hold a hearing in a month's time on the give-aways.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -Russia came up today with a plan that would decrease Gen. Douglas MacArthur's control powers over Japanese industry and increase Russia's.

On behalf of the New York City Mission Society I want to express appreciation for the excellent article and thought-provoking editorial you recently printed concerning the problems of the citizens of East Harlem.

"Strange Victory," a feature-length documentary dealing with the problems of discrimination against minority groups, opens this morning at the Ambassador. Produced by Barnet Rosset Jr. and written and directed by Leo Hurwitz, the picture features Alfred Drake, Muriel Smith and Gary Merrill as commentators and is being released by Target Films, Inc. David Diamond has composed the musical score.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 24 -- The contempt trial of the International Typographical Union ended today with the Government asking the court to condemn all ITU-approved newspaper agreements except those using the New York and Gannett hiring formulas, on which judgment was reserved.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Britain maintained official silence today on the question of an article in the Prague newspaper Svobodne Slovo in which an attempt was made to lay the blame for the failure of the Berlin negotiations on the Western powers.

A thorough reorganization of the Department of Sanitation, effective Friday, was announced yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer. It calls for the establishment of administrative, operating and staff branches, each to be headed by an executive directly responsible to Commissioner William J. Powell.

The Air Force Association, largest organization of flying veterans, will continue to demand a single air arm in the interests of peace, according to its president, Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., at its week-end gathering here. Discussing the serious purposes of the meeting following a series of regional conferences at the Commodore Hotel, Mr. Lanphier said last night:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announced the release today of about $11,000,000 of trusteed Marshall Plan funds to the United States-British zone in Trieste for reconstruction of key industries and the stimulation of productive activity.
Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he had asked Attorney General Tom Clark to inquire "immediately" into increases in the price of milk here.

Mrs. Edith McAllister Alexander, Harlem Community leader and associate director of the Mayor's Committee on Unity, was designated yesterday a presidential elector from the Twenty-second Congressional District by J. Raymond Jones, city Deputy Commissioner of Housing, who said that the selection of a Negro woman by the Democratic party for this honor was "possibly without precedent in the entire country."

In another attempt to smash an alleged monopoly of the country's aluminum industry by the Aluminum Company of America, the Department of Justice asked the Federal Court here yesterday for an order directing the concern to dispose of some of its plants and other properties.

In a statement issued yesterday through the Democratic National Committee, Senator Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico declared that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was in error when, in a speech at Denver, he listed the National Petroleum Council as one of twelve Federal bureaus concerned with petroleum and described the bureaus as "too many cooks spoiling the broth."
Coast Guard air and sea units joined forces yesterday to rescue eight fishermen stranded on the Rockaway Point jetty, Queens, when the rising tide cut off their connection with the mainland.

The Government continued yesterday its round-up of alien Communists for deportation. The Immigration and Naturalization Service announced the arrest of five more personscharged with being members of a group advocating the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- Denying a monopoly in the aduminum business as charged in a Government suit in New York, Roy A. Hunt, president of the Aluminum Company of America, issued a statement here today that characterized the Government action as "pure election year politics."

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- With their ace left-hander, Harry Brecheen, limiting the Cubs to five hits, the Cardinals earned a 4-to-1 victory today to move within six and one-half games of the leading Braves in the National League.

Steamship companies with foreign affiliations were notified by the United States Maritime Commission last night that they would be subject to disqualification as charterers of American-flag, Government-owned ships.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- China urged the General Assembly of the United Nations today to continue pressing for a unified Korea, but indicated she would support the United Nations membership bid of the elected Government in the southern zone.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today with trade largely professional.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 7 points higher to 3 points lower.

The Republic Steel Corporation of Cleveland, which recently perfected a revolutionary method of single-step casting of steel, announced yesterday adoption of a new pressure blowing technique which, it said, will raise its production of pig iron by 20 per cent or more.

ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it has authorized the American Savings Bank, 125 West Forty-second Street, New York City, to act as agent for savings and insurance banks which have established authorized insurance departments.

Rex Ingram, 53-year-old actor, was arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on a charge of violating the Mann Act by inducing a 15-year-old girl to come here from Salina, Kan., for immoral purposes. Arraigned before United States Commissioner Isaac Platt, he was held in $2,500 bail for removal to Kansas City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -Flares for use in emergencies at sea and in the air were among the 431 approved inventions cited for awards this week by the United States Patent Office.

Boatloads of excited youngsters from West New York, N.J. -- 2,600 of them -- boarded an aircraft carrier and seven destroyers of the Atlantic Fleet at their moorings in the North River yesterday afternoon for an inspection of ships and equipment.

In a solemn and simple ceremony the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark was installed last night as senior rabbi of Congregation Emanu-El at a special service in the temple, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street. A capacity throng of 2,500 persons attended.

A bronze tablet will be unveiled tomorrow noon at the grave of Bela Bartok, the celebrated Hungarian composer, in Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, N.Y. At the ceremonies, Adalbert Balassa, acting chief of the Hungarian Consulate General of New York, will speak as its representative.

VIENNA, Sept. 24 -- Col. Gen. Vladimir Kurasov, Soviet High Commissioner, tried at today's meeting of the Allied Council for Austria to induce the High Commissioners of the Western Powers to sanction a Soviet plan for "control" of all Austrian federal officials to "prevent offenses against the occupation powers."

A Supreme Court jury returned a verdict yesterday to Justice Samuel Dickstein holding that Local 1,250, Department Store Union, CIO, had on three occasions violated an order issued by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, said yesterday that Governor Dewey was using his old technique of remaining silent and refusing to deny his charge of waste, inefficiency and extravagance in administration of the affairs of the state.

Drastic curtailment of emergency road service privileges by the Automobile Club of New York owing in part to "sharp practices" by some of its 173,000 members has been voted by the board of directors, it was learned last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Herbert R. Brownell Jr. said today President Truman is resorting to "cheap political tactics" in his campaign tour.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The French must receive 300 jet fighters and equipment for ten armored divisions if France is to play an effective part in the future defense plans of the Western European union, military circles connected with that organization believe.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- E.H. Louw, head of the South African delegation, told the United Nations Assembly today his country might reconsider her membership in the United Nations if the big powers continued to use the world organization to further their own aims at the expense of the smaller nations.

Nat J. Greene, Detroit builder and operator, bought the two five-story tenement houses at 370-372 East 138th Street, the Bronx, containing three stores and sixteen apartments. The sellers were Jessie B. Kuhn, Mabel French Hegeman and Edith H. Meeker, who had held the property for more than fifty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities, closing three weeks of investigation into alleged wartime atomic espionage, asserted tonight that it had uncovered "the gravest matter" in the history of its inquiries.

Expansion of community programs to combat heart disease throughout the country is the goal of the American Heart Association, A.W. Robertson, chairman of its board of directors, told a conference at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

The statesmanship in Governor Dewey's first speeches in the West lapsed a little in the comments he made at Phoenix Friday evening on atomic energy. In the first place, he gave an inaccurate picture of the Manhattan Project when he said that "the genius that split the atom was not furnished by government."
The article by Charles Grutzner published Sept. 21 concerning the sanitary conditions in East Harlem is very provocative.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art disclosed yesterday in its annual report for 1947 that it had made the most extensive purchases of objects of art in its history.
