Leon Fischbein, the second of two criminal lawyers who are respondents to a complaint of unethical practices filed by the Brooklyn Bar Association, made a blanket denial of all accusations on improper conduct in his testimony yesterday before Official Referee Charles C. Lockwood.

Difficulties such as those encountered by shirt and pajama manufacterers will end when a more realistic price level and volume output is reached, according to Dr. Henry Bund of the Research Institute of America.

Coincident with the report of its earnings, Colonial Mills, Inc., announced yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents a share, plus a stock dividend of 5 per cent and the regular quarterly 25-cent disbursement, all for payment on Oct. 28.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- In an hour's talk here today, Secretary of State Marshall and British Foreign Secretary Bevin discussed both the deadlock between the Western powers and the Soviet Union over Berlin and the Palestine problem.
Flagrant abuse of the privilege of reduced fares, given by the city to school pupils riding on the city-owned transit lines, was reported yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Sept24 -- Robert C. Alexander, assistant chief of the visa section of the State Department, filed his answer today to departmental charges of misconduct and dereliction of duty based on his testimony before Staff members of a Senate Judiciary subcommittee that several hundred subversive foreign agents had entered this country as United Nations employes.

December hides futures trading featured market activity on the Commodity Exchange yesterday as prices advanced 35 points from Thursday's closing price of 23.65. March and June, 1949, deliveries, in which trading was light, finished about unchanged. Total transactions yesterday were 57 lots, aggregating 2,280,000 pounds.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- A crusade against highway speeders and "gray-market" operations in over-priced cars was demanded today at the closing session of the annual convention of the New York State Automobile Association here.

Ground breaking exercises were held in Queens yesterday for two new school structures, an addition to Public School 2 at Twenty-first Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street, Jackson Heights, and a new building for Public School 115 at Eightieth Avenue and 262d Street, Bellerose.
A sixth left-wing local has oined the secession movement now under way from the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, it was announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 24 -The National Association of Supervisors of State Banks voted here today to continue its fight for preservation of the dual banking system and maintenance of the rights of states to supervise banking in their respective jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Henry J. Kaiser, chairman of the board of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, filed today with Tom C. Clark, Attorney General, an attorney's brief in which he described as "obviously absurd" charges that leasing of the Government-owned Cleveland blast furnace to his company would violate the anti-trust laws.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association with a score of 42, 39 -- 81 over the Glen Ridge course today.

The stock market remained yesterday on dead center, with greater attention accorded the lower-price issues. The list adhered to a narrow range throughout the session and closed with a bare advantage for the higher side, the composite rate rising 0.13 point.

Your editorial about conditions in East Harlem and the pictures and description previously published were gratifying in the sense that they can be counted on to bring to the public mind the atrocious conditions which exist in this section.

The one-story building con-! raining eight stores at the southwest corner of Utopia Parkway and Forty-sixth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Edward J. Kelly to Iidote .brarnson in a transaction negotiated by Henry Brady as brol}er.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 24 -Tomorrow in Baltimore's Babe Ruth Stadium, Navy will open its football season under the first civilian head coach to pilot the midshipmen since the last year of Rip Miller's tenure in 1933.

The problem of uncollected refuse in East Harlem described in Charles Grutzner's article and commented on in your editorial is neither a new one nor is it confined to East Harlem. Similar photographs can be taken, and a similar article written about any one of the slum sections of New York City in which nearly one third of all New Yorkers are still compelled to live.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Butter consumption in this country is at the lowest level in more than a hundred years, and there is little likelihood of any marked upturn in 1949, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Court Names Nov. 15 -- Accused Would Have Truman Appear WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -Orders were issued today that Mildred Elizabeth Gillars stand trial Nov. 15 on a charge of treason growing out of German propaganda broadcasts known to GI's as the "Axis Sally" program. Her attorney, James J. Laughlin, said he wanted to call President Truman as a witness.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Baylor School football team was at prayer instead of the tackling dummy today and the big opening game will not be played this week-end.

And the reason that is a query rather than an exclamation is that a question has arisen concerning the proper way to burp an infant. So serous is the problem that the United Hospital Fund, which faces the task next month of raising nearly $3,000,000 to keep open the doors of New York's voluntary hospitals, took time out to conduct a survey among some of the most important baby burpers and revealed the results yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24 -- William Henderson, Meadowbrook, and Arthur Lynch of the Winged Foot club, combined to shoot 35, 32 -- 67, three strokes under par, to win the medal in the annual invitation golf tournament at the Meadowbrook club today.

Church attendance in Europe has increased and the people are drawing more spiritual comfort from religion, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday after his return from a two-month survey of religious conditions in ten European countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Anti-trust actions in various parts of the country today and recently are the fruits of an intensified monopoly-breaking program started more than a year ago, and prospects are that it will develop into the most far-reaching in history, it was reported here today.

By gearing pension and employe-security plans to productivity, a manufacturer can avoid increased fixed charges which might in some cases amount to enough to bankrupt his company, Gustave Simons, attorney for the Production Security Counsel, Inc., a private management

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24 -- President Juan Peron personally accused a former United States diplomat tonight of being the chief plotter in an alleged conspiracy to kill him and his wife. In a half-screamed balcony speech to a throng of supporters in the Plaza de Mayo the President savagely attacked John F. Griffith as "an international spy unfit to be an American citizen."

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts yesterday sold $3,000,000 of notes due on June 27, 1949, to Salomon Brothers Hutzler at 0.83 per cent discount plus $47. The notes were reoffered at a yield of 0.75 per cent.

Reporting on the results of the conference on international standards for textiles in Buxton, England, in June, members of the American delegation disclosed yesterday that technicians of many countries were in agreement on the type of tests that would be most beneficial.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 24 -Gradual reimposition of controls on food grains that will bring millions of Indians under rationing again was announced today by Food Minister Jairamdas Daulatram. The action is linked with Indian concern over inflation.

Net profit of the Timken-Detroit Axle Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on June 30 amounted to $7,665,102 after taxes and all charges, the annual report of Willard F. Rockwell, chairman, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Registration statements covering $16,400,000 of debentures, 164,000 shares of capital stock, 20,000 shares of preferred and 20,000 shares of common stock were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by two companies.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Progressive party today sued in Federal Court to place its candidates on official ballots for the Nov. 2 election.

A special committee of six assistant superintendents of schools recommended yesterday that the separate Youthbuilders Bureau, maintained by the Board of Education for several years, be "discontinued as rapidly as feasible."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today announced it will hold hearings here Nov. 8 on a complaint against nineteen firms charging conspiracy to fix prices and restrain trade in the corn products industry.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24 -- John Francis Griffith, charged for the second time in less than six months by the Peron regime with complicity in anti-Government plots, said in Uruguay today that the current charge was baseless.
BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Today was a day of rest for the Braves, who have every expectancy of becoming the National League baseball champions within a very short time.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 24 -- Fifty price-angry housewives held a public meeting last night and came up with a blueprint for boycotting all the butchers and milk dealers in this agricultural industrial city of 77,000.

Net sales and earnings of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., for the six months ended on July 31 were the largest for any similar period in the company's history, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

Fall and winter fashions for the career girl were presented yesterday by Oppenheim, Collins during a lunch-hour fashion show. The clothes were for the most part popular priced. A number of holiday dance dresses were shown as well as casual styles.

Lumber production for the week ended Sept. 18 was 12.4 per cent over the preceding week and 2.3 per cent above the like week last year. Shipments were up 2 per cent compared with last year and orders down 1 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 24 -- The smooth foxterrier, Dynamite of Delwin, belonging to the Wissaboo Kennels of James M. Austin, Old Westbury, L.I., and the wire, Ch. Radar of Wildoaks, owned by Mrs. R.C. Bondy of Goldens Bridge, N.Y., were best in their varieties today in the eighty-fifth specialty show of the American Fox Terrier Club on the Garden City Hotel grounds.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic nominee for Vice President, declared tonight that a prime issue in the national election is whether the people of the country want to exchange their present diplomats, with their intimate knowledge of foreign affairs, for men inexperienced in international matters.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Homer Pardue's 2-year-old colt, Rodger Joe, continued to show improvement in taking down his third straight victory today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 -- Alarmed over the economic consequences of any prolonged maritime strike, Mayor Elmer E. Robinson today offered his services as a mediator in an effort to bring West Coast shipowners and striking unions to terms.

The eating habits of the American male between the ages of 10 and 16 show that steak, carrots, string beans and ice cream are his ideal dinner, according to a nationwide survey just completed by the Boys' Athletic League of New York and announced yesterday.

Pan American Airways started yesterday its $75 one-way fare for tourist air service between New York and San Juan, P.R., with bookings for the cut-rate flight made in both cities for at least thirty days in advance.

A five-point program of enlarged country-wide activities is being advanced by members of the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association, Philadelphia, Robert Giebel, president, disclosed yesterday at his offices at Giebel, Inc., in the Fisk Building, following his return from the annual convention of the AMTDA at Detroit.

Philip Godfrey, head of Godfrey Co., 116-55 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens, said yesterday that he would take court action to stop the New York City Housing Authority from building a 2,650-family apartment project on a Queens site.

The need for extending after-school care for young children of working mothers in certain areas of the city was emphasized yesterday at a meeting of the Child Care Center Parents Association of New York, Inc.
LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The text of the Tass statement of the Soviet Government's position on the Berlin situation, as broadcast by Moscow radio:

THE visiting public inclines to regard anything shown at a museum as of basic intrinsic value: Otherwise, why should it be shown, argues the casual visitor. So the Museum of Modern Art may be well advised in putting an its big retrospective collage exhibition to point out that the purpose of the exhibition is twofold.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Two United States lawmakers suggested today that Congress should deny Marshall Plan aid to countries that persisted in shipping potential war material to Communist-dominated Eastern Europe.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 25 -- Confronted by a Lafayette College team which carried out its assignments with a high degree of effectiveness, Fordham's football squad proved no match for their rivals today and the Leopards were able to roll to a 53-to-14 triumph.
Magistrate Eugene R. Canudo, sitting in Brooklyn Felony Court, called on the Board of Transportation yesterday to provide protection in subway lavatories during early morning hours.

Plans were made at a luncheon yesterday of the Citizens Committee to End Jim Crow in the Panama Canal Zone to send a petition to President Truman urging him to issue an executive order abolishing the "silver-gold" system in the zone.

Henry Steele Commager is to be congratulated for his clear exposition ("Should We Outlaw the Communist Party?") of the dangers of outlawing any political party merely because of its ideas, thus becoming victim to the very Fascist methods which we have always opposed.

As the chill of September nights reaches over into the daylight hours, there is a quickening of the human pulse. There is new vigor in the air. But in the insect world the fires burn low. The bugs and beetles are nearing the end of their time.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- In a speech today indicating India's intention to champion the interests of all South Asian countries, Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, sister of Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru of India, urged the United Nations General Assembly to create a new permanent committee that would safeguard and promote the interests of the 200,000,000 persons in all non-self-governing territories.

New York State's Congressional delegation, consisting of twenty-eight Republican, fifteen Democrats, and two representatives of the American Labor party, may go more heavily Republican in the coming election, political observers believed yesterday.

The Kips Bay Boys Club will be aided by the performance of "Life With Mother" on the night of Oct. 26 at the Empire Theatre. Proceeds will further the work of the organization, which provides instruction and recreational facilities for more than 2,500 boys from crowded districts of the city.
With the promise of 700 wild Brahma bulls, bucking broncos, steers and calves, the twenty-third annual world's championship rodeo will open next Wednesday night in Madison Square Garden.

Business men in Harlem who have met the approval of the Consumer Arbitration Board for fair practices in the sale of merchandise and the employment of Negro help received "seals of approval" yesterday at exercises by the board outside the Theresa Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 125th Street.

With the end of daylight saving time at 2 A. M. today, most New Yorkers turned their clocks back an hour before retiring last night to regain the hour of sleep they lost April 25, when the fast time began. Railroads that ran on the temporary time have reverted to standard time schedules.
PARIS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Defense Minister of the five-power Western European alliance will meet Monday in Paris to consolidate plans for mutual defense in the event of war.

ARCADIA, Calif. -- The tourist eager to capture the flavor of the Old West can absorb more in a few minutes here than he might gain from months of travel in several states. And he'll see a lot of things not found elsewhere, to boot.

THIS story has a plot so wild, so original, as to call for one of those hat-eating statements. Not since "The Big Clock" has there been such an imaginative premise. Not only that, but the writing sustains it. The suspense races, without ever resorting to that smart-aleck toughness which has very nearly been run into the ground in American mystery fiction.

Ever since last December, when Henry A. Wallace announced himself a third-party candidate for President, there has been speculation on his motives. The consensus was that he could not win in 1948, that his candidacy could only help defeat the Democrats -- the party under which he had served as Cabinet member and Vice President.

Space make of it -- as is you may learn from any family that has lived, cramped and uncomfortable, in ten big rooms laid out by a former generation of planners. Reallocation of space rather than additions or exterior alterations was the objective of architects Reisner and Urbahn in the remodeling of the Forest Hills, L. I., home shown here.

MARY RENAULT'S last novel, "Return to Night," won the MGM Prize in 1947. It was also a good and intelligent book, stamping her as an unusual writer. In "North Face" she has written another unusual book -just how unusual can be best expressed by calling it a love story.
The ratified atmosphere which they experienced while sitting briefly in a triple tie on the top of the American League apparently proved too much for the Yankees.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 25 -- The Danbury Fair, Connecticut's leading agricultural exposition, opens next Saturday for a nine-day program. The 1948 Danbury Fair will be the seventy-fifth since it was founded, in 1869.

When John L. Lewis issues a dictum that the bituminous coal miners will not work without a contract, the inclination of many people is to brush away his demands with an "it doesn't affect me" gesture. However, more than 200,000 useful products, other than coal, become involved in the outcome.

A varied and growing number of business concerns are spurring the movement for simpler, sales-potent packaging required by self-service retailing and television advertising, it was declared here last week by industrial designer J. Gordon Lippincott.

THE first of the American Export Lines' new "Four Ace" passenger liners, the 125-passenger, one-class Excalibur, was scheduled to sail Friday on its maiden voyage to the Mediterranean. It was the first sailing of an American - flag first - class passenger ship to the Mediterranean since pre-war days.

SHARPER air and shorter days are not the only portents of autumn to New Yorkers. By night, even city-dwellers can hear familiar seasonal sounds in the sky. There are the thin calls of thrushes and vireos, the resonant quonks of the heron tribe, and a bewildering assortment of cheeps, lisps, whispers and piping notes from other noise-makers overhead. With ordinary binoculars some of the travelers can be seen crossing the face of the moon.
BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 25 -- A black miniature poodle, Champion Smilestone's Bric-a-Brac, received the top award in the 629-dog Suffolk County Kennel Club show at the South Bay Golf Club today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept 25 -- Henry A. Wallace told President Truman's home state folks tonight that the President was "a political acrobat" and accused him of aiding and abetting "the most dangerous election fraud in the history of American politics."

In "What Is an Ism?" you give a list of correct ideological definitions by Daniel C. O'Grady. What we need today is not those definitions as they should be but as "statesmen" and writers of letters to the editor construe them. Such a list follows:

Re Joe McCarthy's article, "The Sergeant Is a Corporal Now," I would like to point out that this disrating without prejudice is a sound move on the Army's part. In my career in the service I found that too heavy rank among the enlisted grades tended to set up a caste system between them and the commissioned ranks.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson said tonight that the United States must rearm so long as Russia's leaders "are bent on pursuing their present policy of aggregation."
FALL vacationists touring eastern states from Maine to West Virginia to see the autumn colors will find quite a list of festivals and civic celebrations during the next few weeks.

Why is there such an atmosphere of Jubilation in "Farewell to Penmanship" -- in the decay (with the Board of Education's approval; it seems to approve everything these days) of the cursive style of writing? I find no praise in allowing a student to use the "block" system of writing, or rather, lettering.

A strong defensive measure against the continual climb of operating costs in retail stores can be established through widening the responsibilities of store controllers, it was stated by a leading retailer here at the week's end.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Sir Waldron Smithers, the Conservative M. P. for Orpington and as fiery a Red-baiter as Washington could boast, made a suggestion to the Labor Government this week. Why not, he asked, set up a committee on un-British activities like the United States Committee on Un-American Activities?

TWO extremes of contemporary photographic activity are typified in shows which opened last week. One is the experimental work of Kathleen and Vladimir Telberg-von-Teleheim, whose purpose is to photograph "not that which is seen but that which goes on in one's mind."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Mustangs of Southern Methodist University crushed the University of Pittsburgh, 33 to 14, today on the solid running of Doak Walker and the sharp passing of Gilbert Johnson.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Formulation of a 10-year program of economic cooperation for Western European recovery is being considered in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, it was learned here today.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The Western powers gave a cold reception to Andrei Y. Vishinsky's disarmament resolution today but credited the Russian delegate with a well-timed and adroit propaganda move.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The French Government formally applied today for immediate release to it of 45,000,000,000 francs from the Marshall Plan counterpart fund in French currency. It appeared certain that the application would be granted promptly, probably Monday, by the mission to France of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Yale opened its football season today under the happiest of circumstances. Opposing a Brown team that was generally regarded as the favorite -- albeit by a slim margin -- the sons of Eli came through with a decisive upset over the aggregation from Providence by the score of 28 to 13.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Rampart did the expected in winning the $15,000 added All-American Handicap, closing-day feature at the seashore course today.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Chuck Congdon of Tacoma, Wash., carding a 69, scorched the Shaughnessy golf course with arrow-true drives and brilliant iron shots to take the $10,000 Canadian Open title today with an 8-under-par 280 for seventy-two holes.

PIERRE LAVAL was hated and despised too passionately to get a trial that made even a pretense of judicial fairness. The presiding judge conducted most of the prosecution and engaged in a running battle of vituperation with the defendant, who usually managed to get in the best word if not the last one.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York tonight accused the Truman Administration of contributing to inflation by "dropping monkey wrenches" into the economic machinery and following "defeatist policies."

ENSENADA, Mexico -- This Baja California resort is awakening from a siesta it slipped into during World War II. Its million-dollar resort hotel has reopened and contracts for a new eighteen-hole golf course, several new motels and a beach-house colony have been awarded.

Central Park Mall resounded yesterday with Indian war chants, tribal songs and the beat of ritual dances in celebration of American Indian Day as an offer was made to buy back for Indian use part of New York City at the price of $24.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -With Rex Barney hurling his fourth shut-out of the waning campaign tonight, the Dodgers retained their dim mathematical pennant hope by beating the Phils, 3 -- 0, at Shibe Park before 10,551, none of whom seemed greatly annoyed by the local loss.

Dr. Max von Laue, Nobel Prize winner, formerly Professor of Theoretical Physics at the University of Berlin and at present Honorary Professor at the University of Gottingen and acting director of the Max Planck Institute of Physics, is lecturing at the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, N. J.

THE fifth annual Garden State Flower Show will be staged by the Garden Club of New Jersey at the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair, Cooper Avenue and Valley Road, on Thursday and Friday from 2 to 10 P. M. Open to members and non-members, the event is the largest flower show held annually in New Jersey.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- A sharpened sense of moral responsibility would help the motion picture industry to remedy many of its economic ills, as well as to elevate its standing as a social force, Samuel Cardinal Stritch of Chicago declared here tonight.

IN a move which has a significance transcending his own program, Bob Hope has stepped out this season as perhaps the first major comedian to recognize that he cannot keep on doing the same old routine another year.

THE countryside is beginning to show a brilliant display of crabapple trees. Their myriads of small fruits, green for most of the summer, take on bright colors of red and yellow during September, bringing them into prominence wherever they grow.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- A series of events commemorating the 250th anniversary of the beginning of Presbyterianism in Philadelphia has been announced by the headquarters of the general assembly, Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A.

ON Sunday, Aug. 15, your Book Review carried an interesting article by Francis Hackett on the service and disservice rendered by modern psychology to the writer of fiction ["The Novel and Human Personality"].

THE Second International Festival of Music and Drama is over. The pipers have performed for the last time their ritual slow march below the flood-lit castle. The flags in Princes Street have been struck and the flowers -- or what as left of them by the tramping crowd at the final ceremony -- by now have faded and been swept away.

THE twenty-eight years that separate "Nanook of the North" and his latest film, "Louisiana Story," have not dulled the enthusiasm of Robert Flaherty. He has had his share of ups and downs from the freezing wastes of Hudson Bay to the steaming jungles of India, but the passing years have left little mark on his ruddy, jovial face.

NANKING, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Chinese Government acknowledged reluctantly tonight the Communist capture of Tsinan in a military reverse that shook Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's regime to its foundations.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Opening his thirteen-state Eastern campaign here tonight, Gov. Earl Warren of California struck out at the "iron curtain" way of life with a declaration that the Soviet- dominated countries were hoping for American failure in international affairs.

Thirteen evening courses in filmmaking for professionals and beginners are being offered this fall by the City College Film Institute. The courses cover subjects ranging from the history of motion pictures to the fundamentals of film production. There is also a course on the management, organization, publicity, labor and legal questions involved in film-making.

Prof. Otto Warburg, winner of the Nobel Prize in Medicine and Physiology for his pioneer investigations on the respiration of cells and other fundamental living processes, has reported in a German scientific journal his latest series of experiments on cancer cells, which, he believes, promise to open a new approach to the problem of cancer.

A PATH may be as accidental as the famous cow track that developed into a city street. In the garden it may be deliberately planned as one of the really important features, and planted accordingly. The planting variations are infinite, and they change with the season and the years.

IN reading your article in last Sunday's edition of THE TIMES, I was glad to see that at least someone besides myself was taking notice of NBC's having at least as many, and perhaps more, crime-ridden programs as any of the other stations.

IN aviation parlance an airpark is, ideally, an airport located in a landscaped community recreation center. From a one-ship, one-strip pasture landing field to such an airpark with a lake, sports field, picnic grounds and restaurant was the progress of Tom Brenton, ex-Air Force pilot in a single spring, and many a struggling GI base operator could envy him.

Fruit growers, especially apple orchard owners, are expected this fall to harvest one of their smallest crops in years, because of recent hot weather, prolonged drought and last spring's heavy rains. A survey of the New York-New Jersey-New England area indicated yesterday that the apple crop may be between 25 and 30 per cent lower than last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- The number of building permits issued during August in 226 cities and counties on the West Coast declined 5.2 per cent from August 1947, with a total of 33,052 new construction jobs started. However, the dollar valuation of permits issued soared to a new high of $192,492,614, which represents a gain of 70 per cent over the same month of last year.

BOSTON, Mass. Sept. 25 -- Hugh D. Scott Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, told Massachusetts Republicans today that the Communist party endorsed Mr. Truman for vice president in 1944, with the result that the President now shows "indifference to Communist penetration at home."

Scientists came from Europe, Canada and many parts of the United States to attend the recent three-day symposium on the relation of hormones to cancer -- a symposium which was held at the University of Wisconsin and arranged by the Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation and the American Cancer Society and which served the useful purpose of evaluating the part that hormones, the sex hormones in particular, can play in the treatment of cancer.

Howard Hughes, whose Midas touch has been the source of amazement to many big business heads and who is currently running things on the Radio-Keith-Orpheum movie lots, would like to know the villain behind those Tucker reports.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Adrei Y. Vishinsky, representing the Soviet Union, proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly call upon the five great powers to reduce their armed forces by one-third in one year as a first step toward disarmament.

FOR THIS WEEK: After raking up crab-grass, sow the resulting bare spaces with lawn seed as soon as possible. . . . Warm, dry weather has stimulated the spread of red spider. Spray affected plants with the new hexaethyl tetraphosphate, sold under various trade names. . . . Thin out some of the chrysanthemum buds in each cluster, even though they are well formed, to permit better development of individual flowers.

In reference to your comment on Irwin Margiloff's letter concerning the bassoon, I would like to say, that although Schumann's "Happy Farmer" cannot be performed by a single bassoon, it was performed by a quartet of bassoons two years ago, a quartet of which I was a member.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The post-war program of exchanging American and foreign graduate students has made a relatively slow start. This week, however, the State Department had reason to hope that 1949 and 1950 would see the real beginning of a system for expanding international understanding through more international education.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The Soviet Union's replies to Wednesday's identical notes of the three Western powers were delivered today.

WHAT with all the murder and mayhem that have cluttered the screen of late -- the shooting and slashing and slugging and the strangling of people with ropes -- it has come as a great relaxation to have had a brief series of recent films in which violence has been inconspicuous and a certain amount of humanity has prevailed.

OF complaints against drama critics there is no end. One of the hardiest concerns the man against whom there are fewest conceivable complaints at all. A critic loved, they say, is a critic lost; popularity is a tea rose entirely out of place in any honest critic's onion patch.

THE story of "The Furies," like Mr. Busch's chromatic "Duel in the Sun," has the high vitamin count that only an overabundance of murder, love and money-making can produce. The characters, most of them low enough to crawl under a flag-stone, are about as subtle as Roy Rogers' wardrobe.

SODDING is sometimes an easier and more practical way to make limited lawn repairs than is reseeding. The squares of grass are excellent for establishing a lawn on steep slopes or banks, or for a pathway where traffic is so heavy that tender seedlings never have a chance to get started.
BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- Not going any place in particular themselves, the Giants today threw a monkey wrench into plans for celebrating the Braves' first pennant in thirty-four years.

Malaria, tuberculosis, venereal infections are rampant in the undeveloped and poorer agricultural regions of the world. There are over three hundred million cases of malaria alone annually, with three million deaths. What the toll from hookworm and other parasitic diseases may be nobody knows.

SINCE the cost of producing musical entertainments on Broadway is colossal, the appearance of three of them within a week argues a race of supermen. But the feeling of awe in the presence of huge pots of money stops there.
FLINT, Mich., Sept. 25 -- Noel Fox of Muskegon, Mich., a labor mediator, today was chosen by the Democratic party for Secretary of State at the convention here.

A plea for simpler spelling to streamline the written language has been made by Falk Johnson, an instructor in English at Northwestern University. On the basis of extensive research into the history and peculiarities of English spelling, Mr. Johnson contends that the English-speaking world's habit of clinging to outdated spelling customs is preventing much-needed changes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals' faint hopes of capturing the National League pennant were jolted almost into oblivion here today as the cellar- ridden Chicago Cubs rallied for three runs in the ninth to beat the Redbirds, 3 to 2.

TWENTY - FOURTH on the program of United States stamps for 1948 is the one honoring Juliette Gordon Low (1860-1927), who in 1912 at Savannah organized the first troop of Girl Guides, which developed into today's Girl Scouts of America.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will be formally installed as the thirteenth president of Columbia University on Oct. 12 at 2 P. M. in the university's South Court, Prof. Grayson L. Kirk, head of the installation committee, announced yesterday.

IT is as certain as anything can be that dozens, perhaps hundreds, of novels about the war are lying unfinished on the tables of young ex-soldier, would-be writers in Britain today. They have not finished them -- they may even not have started to get them down on paper -- because they have been told by booksell ers, agents and publishers that nobody has wanted to read about the war since 1945.

NEW music for small ensembles -- from songs to string quartets -- gets little enough publicity even in the country of its origin. Spreading it abroad is usually a missionary operation, done on the initiative of individual performers. Steps to improve this situation have been taken by the American Library in Paris with an assist from the League of Composers.

The formal autumn opening of the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza on Tuesday night will take the form of a benefit dinner-dance to raise funds for The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind. Many members of society have been serving on several committees to further a philanthropic project giving aid to more than 4,000 sightless persons of all ages, races and creeds.
MADISONVILLE, Ky., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The States' Rights Democratic Presidential candidate, J., Strom Thurmond, said today: "I'd rather be right than President in this age of political expediency."

THE news that there is an increasing request for professional actors to appear in and with university performers sounds rather alarming. One hundred years ago America had a well-organized theatre profession, with hundreds of resident stock companies all over the country.
A general increase in the dividend rate paid to depositors by savings banks in this area is in prospect, it was learned yesterday.
A fishing party of six men and a boy aboard a thirty-foot cabin cruiser were thrown into the ocean yesterday morning when their craft was overturned by heavy seas a mile off Rockaway Point jetty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board has made use of its sharpest weapon under the Taft-Hartley Law, the injunction, thirty-one times, a survey showed today. In only six instances, however, did the board move of its own accord.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -Attorney General Tom C. Clark has added four more organizations to the Justice Department's original list of subversive groups, the Loyalty Review Board disclosed tonight.

AS someone was saying the other evening, this season it's theatre parties that are hurting the theatre. The tone was inclined to be sardonic but the fact is that the recent blasts by Moss Hart and Tallulah Bankhead against the practice of turning over theatres to benefits have been having their repercussions.

Mrs. F. Trubee Davison heads the New York City Women's Committee for the performance of the Ice Follies on the night of Nov. 18 at Madison Square Garden which has been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Village. Proceeds will further the work of the beneficiary which provides care and training for several hundred under-privileged children at its headquarters in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- A "unanimous decision" of the management of Pacific Far East Lines, Inc., to stick with the West Coast shipping industry in its dispute with "Communist party line leadership" of maritime unions was announced today by the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast.
A smooth - working Columbia eleven opened another football year at Baker Field yesterday and routed a rugged Rutgers team by 27 to 6.

TOKYO, Sept. 25 -- Unofficial comment from United States officials on Soviet Ambassador Alexander Panyushkin's Washington statement on Japan's future and urging that the powers of Gen. Douglas MacArthur be reduced, revealed a divergence of views here today.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Holy Cross Crusaders mastered enough of new head coach Dr. Bill Osmanski's Chicago Bears football magic for an impressive 18-7 victory over Georgetown's veteran forces today before 20,000 fans.

World political considerations may impel American-aided restoration of the entire Japanese economy and such restoration would include reconstruction of the Japanese merchant marine at the expense of American maritime interests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Plans for harnessing the economic might of the nation in case of war were opening a new chapter this week as military and civilian experts commenced to translate strategic blueprints into industrial requirements.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- All deliveries of grain worked lower in today's session of the Board of Trade. Toward the close a flurry of selling carried all to the day's low points.

THE first signs of life from RKO since Howard Hughes took over the company appeared last week with the announcement of one important production deal and the disclosure that several others are in final stages of negotiation.
BLOOMER BEACH, N. J., Sept. 25 -- The 410th Engineer Special Brigade came ashore here at 10:31 A. M. today to clear the Palisades area in preparation for an impending Army "attack."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 25 -- Pre-election trends in Kentucky, one of the key states in the fight for control of the United States Senate, indicate the Republicans have an excellent chance of retaining the seat at stake in November.

The soccer team of Israel, the first international athletic group to represent the new State, will make its American debut this afternoon against the United States Olympic booters at the Polo Grounds. Kick-off time is scheduled for 2 o'clock, after ceremonies and services by Jewish organizations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The National Cancer Institute today announced grants of more than $1,300,000 to institutions in the United States, Puerto Rico, Canada and France for cancer control and research.

From one sugar-cookie recipe come all the variations pictured here today. Master this single formula and even the amateur in the kitchen can turn out dainty tea-time wafers, heartier sandwich-type filled cookies, fat circles enticingly encrusted with raisins and nuts.

One of the biggest gangs in New York during the Thirties was that led by Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro. The Lepke-Gurrah gang operated as racketeers in the garment, leather, fur and trucking industries. The gang would "muscle in" on a field by doing a "favor" for a crooked company boss or union official.

Still affected by the great riddle of the post-war period -- the imminence of deflation or inflation -- the market for high-grade investments faces this week a series of challenges likely to yield some clues to the course of long-term interest rates, at least for the time being.

President Peron promoted a daylong circus on Friday to dramatize his charge that he and his wife were the intended victims of an international assassination plot, with a former United States Embassy official as the chief plotter. All transportation and most work were stopped in Buenos Aires during the day, while crowds converged on Plaza de Mayo to hear the Argentine President scream his charges from the balcony of Casa Rosada.

First progress reports from more than 100 companies on results of concentrated executive training programs instituted shortly after the war indicate that top caliber executives can be developed in much shorter periods than was possible up to the end of 1941, Lawrence A. Appley, president of the American Management Association, declared last week.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 25 -- The 50,000-ton Bulkpetrol, one of the world's largest tankers, slid down the ways of Welding Shipyards at 1:50 P. M. today at a launching attended by Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democratic candidate for re-election in November.
HELSINKI, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Soviet note demanding dissolution of Finnish rifle clubs has been handed to the Finnish Government, the leftist press said today.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky today laid on the United States the chief burden of responsibility for "wrecking" the Palestine partition plan. Without committing himself, he indicated that Russia had not changed her policy of backing the original partition plan against any proposed change.

IN his introduction -- an authoritative and inspired one -- to the Faulkner Viking Portable, Malcolm Cowley recorded that "in 1945 all his [Faulkner's] seventeen books were out of print." One might have thought, or hoped rather, that such unavailability was the result of the author's justified international reputation.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Capt. William Henderson and Arthur Lynch of Winged Foot defeated George Van Nostrand and Fred Lazard of Brookville by 1 up at the nineteenth hole in the quarter-final round of the Meadow Brook invitation golf tournament today.

During the war years private industry was not free to expand except for the production of materials used in the conduct of war; now in a continued period of high income taxes it is to be expected that only a small portion of the people's income would find its way into capital investments.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 25 -- After various conflicting announcements and denials of the past week, the formation of an Arab Government at Gaza, claiming sovereignty over all Palestine was confirmed today by a telegram from Ahmad Hilmi Pasha addressed to the Secretary General of the Arab League and to the Foreign Ministers of all Arab countries.

A BOOK by Barbara Ward -- this is her first to be published in the United States -- was certain to be something of an event. An editor of The Economist, a governor of the BBC, a speaker of rare skill and presence, she is (at 34) one of the most influential persons in the British Isles.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ohio State, showing surprising power in all departments, launched its 1948 football campaign today by defeating Missouri's ever-trying Tigers, 21 to 7, before a crowd of 57,042.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- Their confidence unshaken by yesterday's setback, the Indiana rebounded handsomely against the Tigers today, keeping pace with the victorious Red Sox as Gene Bearden fashioned a seven-hit, 9-3 triumph. Thus, with each side to play only six more games, the Cleveland and Boston clubs are locked in a dead heat for first place.

"SINCE the mountain can't get to Mohamet it's time Mohamet went to the mountain," Margaret Webster, Shakespeare's No. 1 huckster, said the other day, paraphrasing Francis Bacon. She was referring to her forthcoming trek across the country as director of a company of twenty-two that will bring "Hamlet" and "Macbeth," literally "by popular demand," to the campuses of America.

Wholesale salesmen in all lines should "take heed of storm warnings and fortify themselves against the threat of business reverses ahead throughout the nation." This warning was issued by Louis A. Capaldo, president of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, following a meeting of the directors last week.

ONE year of American Aid for Greece has been completed, and Greece has just been placed, within the framework of the Economic Cooperation Administration, better known as the Marshall Plan. Our stake in Greece is substantial, our help to the people of Greece will doubtless continue for the next four years, and so it is vitally necessary that American-Greek relations be viewed from a longrange point of view.
SELINSGROVE, Pa., Sept. 25 -- The Crusaders of Susquehanna University opened their 1948 season by rallying to defeat City College of New York, 13 -- 7, today.

Unleashing a powerful ground attack that rolled up a total of 302 yards, Brooklyn College defeated the New Haven State Teachers by 24 -- 0 before 3,000 fans at the Flatbush field yesterday. After scoring early in the first period, the Kingsmen's attack was checked by numerous penalties and they could not score for the remainder of the half.

HAND-MADE toys mean fewer and more expensive ones, but this is accompanied by a tremendous upsurge in quality, durability and brilliance of ideas. This volume is the work of an art teacher in England who has gathered drawings and plans for toys interesting and sturdy enough to be handed down to succeeding generations.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 10 -- Agreements between the United States and the Republic of Korea being concluded here this month will cover payment for $326,032,725 in assistance to Korea from her liberation in September, 1945, to the establishment of Korea's Government under United Nations sponsorship on Aug. 15 last.

Silver objects and rugs, French designed furniture and accessories of the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, will be sold on Friday and Saturday of this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The property is in part from the Princess Charles Murat of New York and Mrs. David Shaw-Kennedy of Englewood, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Thirty-five New Yorkers, and seven residents of New Jersey are among 162 persons named to receive research fellowships by the Atomic Energy Commission. The awards were announced today. The research will be in the physical, biological and agricultural sciences. All winners are graduate students.

During the past week the United Nations General Assembly, meeting in Paris, has heard two outstanding spokesmen for the two opposing points of view which divide the Assembly and the world. Secretary of State Marshall spoke on Thursday not merely for the United States but for every democratic state and every state trying to attain democracy.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 25 (AP) -- George Taliaferro ran, passed and punted Indiana to a 35-to-7 victory over Wisconsin in their Big Nine football opener today. The Negro halfback made Coach Clyde Smith's debut a happy occasion as he scored three times.

Re-examination of textile costs will be undertaken by numerous producers in view of the need for adjustment of prices, it was pointed out in the trade last week. The move by Textron, Inc., to close four of its five mills in Nashua, N. H., because of high costs, has highlighted the problem of adequate returns, textile men said, particularly since contraction of the market has set in.
EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 25 -- Following is the text of President Truman's speech here today:

IT is not professional bias alone which makes the academic visitor to theses shores profoundly absorbed in what is going on here in his field of higher education: American educational developments have deep meaning for the future.

HAVING sat through enough New York music seasons to realize that the bad features recur with predictable regularity, this reviewer would like to offer a little advice to some of the oncoming junior recitalists -- and some not so junior -- who will be heard during the season that is just beginning.

TOKYO, Sept. 25 -- Officials of Japan's Board of Trade have launched a vigorous campaign for the preservation of their jobs despite the occupation's order that the board's personnel be halved and its influence greatly reduced.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- An official close to the House Un-American Activities Committee said today that its forthcoming report on atomic espionage would "shock" the public.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The strategic northeast approach from Europe is the only off-shore military area for which the United States has no unified command, it was disclosed today.

THESE are days to make the dance-minded dizzy. When the season opens, it really opens. There is, of course, the New York City Jubilee's International Dance Festival at the City Center, with Ram Gopal and his Hindu company and Charles Weidman and his American one to join the Paris Opera Ballet in this week's repertoire.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Grinding out four touchdowns against the stubborn resistance of a good Villanova team. Army's gold-helmeted football legions made an impressive 1948 debut today. The Cadets had a battle on their hands at first but once Earl Blaik's powerful machine started to roll it was no contest.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Following is the definition of the present United States foreign policy given by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister, in an address to the General Assembly today:

BRIDGETON, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan declared here today that farmers must fight to preserve their farm programs but urged also that farm prices be correlated to the ability of the consumer to pay.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 26 -- Tass, official Soviet news agency, said today it was up to the Western powers whether a four-power agreement on the Berlin blockade could be attained or whether the talks would be broken off.

ROME, Sept. 25 -- The customs barriers between Italy and France will be abolished by Jan. 1, 1950, fifteen months from now, Umberto Grazzi, Italian Director General of Economic Affairs declared at the Foreign Ministry this evening. This announcement came at the end of a plenary session held by the mixed Italo-French Committee, which since Sept. 9 has been meeting in Rome to discuss economic union between Italy and France.

Making buck sergeants into corporals was less of a surprise to me than it seemed to former Master Sgt. Joe McCarthy in his article, "The Sergeant Is a Corporal Now." It fits in with the officer philosophy of knocking down the enlisted men's dignity to preserve the caste system.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Attacks on British Government's war preparations were made today by a Labor Member of Parliament and by Communist leaders.
"'WELL, in our country,' said Alice, still panting a little, 'you generally get to somewhere else if you run very fast for a long time, as we've been doing.'"

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 25 -- The grounding until further notice of a number of P-47 fighter planes recently received under the United States aid program was ordered this week by the Turkish authorities because of technical defects. United States Air Force men flew out to the base where the planes had been grounded and repaired them.

ALTHOUGH indomitable is hardly the word for Fred Allen, call radio's "premier" comic thus and also list him as tentatively returning to the screen in "The Double Life of Ezra Jones," a comedy drama to be independently produced by J. D. Trop.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Colgate's Red Raiders, opening Coach Paul Bixler's second season in the Chenango, broke a losing streak of almost a year today as they overpowered Buffalo University, 25 -- 0.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Nebraska and Iowa State, ranked the dark horses of the Big Seven Conference, waged a whale of a battle today, with the Nebraskans winning, 19 to 15.

Stimulated by price promotions and favorable weather conditions, retail activity here last week was extremely good, according to a survey made especially for NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. School sportswear, lingerie and toys were leading departments.
To aid the Urban League Service Fund, 100 notables have contributed their artistic efforts for exhibition and auction at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

ON TRUMAN CAMPAIGN TRAIN, Sept. 25 -- The twin personalities of Harry S. Truman -one the President of the United States and the other the candidate of the Democratic party for that office -- have drawn warm, friendly, interested crowds as his train moved West, stopping at more whistle stops" than large cities.

In your issue of Aug. 29 you reprinted an article on the late Chief Justice Hughes from your final edition of the preceding day. Undoubtedly you offered this as a careful and authoritative review of the career of this distinguished man. Considering the intent and the source, the inaccuracies that appear in connection with the loss by Mr. Hughes of California in the 1916 election are surprising.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Rear Admiral Fidel Anadon, Naval Minister, who has been serving also as acting Foreign Minister, resigned this morning because of a "misunderstanding" with President Juan D. Peron. This evening President Peron swore in Admiral Enrique Garcia as the new Naval Minister.

A CHARACTER known as Panty Burke is wanted by the police on a charge of counterfeiting mutuel tickets, and Lieut. Eddie Marsh of the New York police asks his friend Doc Connor to inquire around among his shady acquaintances to see what he can learn.

POWERFUL New York theatrical interests, along with influential Washington citizens, began a series of parleys last week which may become one of the most important episodes -- perhaps the last chapter -- in the long struggle for a legitimate theatre open to Negroes in the nation's capital.

While the police continued a thirteen-state search for two ex-convicts accused of participation in gang attacks on three union organizers and seven pickets in the garment district last Monday, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, announced yesterday that it would begin calling strikes on a building-by-building basis tomorrow.

Stressing many new features in 200 displays, the third National Plastics Exposition under sponsorship of the Society for the Plastics Industry, Inc., will open tomorrow afternoon in the Grand Central Palace. Marking what is hailed as the "beginning of a new era in plastics," the exposition will continue through Friday.
SPECIES tulips are a delightful addition to the low-growing bulbs that flower during April. Their numbers have been increased the last year or two by the introduction of many new varieties.

A GOOD many of the postwar French novels have been as dismally reminiscent of the pre-war spirit as France's recurrent Cabinet crises. Aragon's "Aurlien," Elsa Triolet's "The White Horse," Simon de Beauvoir's "L'Invitee" (not yet published here) and others hark back to the literary climate of the Thirties, to the fashionable romancier's tight little world of mundane intrigue, dilettantism and refined cynicism, with its untiring pursuit of amour.
These are the days when the hunting dog begins to pay his way, and it is encouraging to find that the percentage of hunters with dogs is definitely increasing.

MULES, according to my dossier, are sure-footed animals, immune to most diseases and impervious to all sorts of weather. At least they don't complain about it. They are an inarticulate crew, generally, and when an author comes across one that can not only utter distinguishable speech sounds but also has a fine knowledge of syntax, the Socratic method, the principles of economics and deep-dyed political chicanery, he does well to set down the animal's adventures.

Prices, costs and break-even points moved into first place on the list of immediate problems of many of America's largest manufacturers last week. Interest centered on break-even points for the first time since before the war, although some of industry's elder statesmen, including John Hancock, partner in Lehman Brothers banking firm, argued that clarification of price laws by Congress was the "number one problem."

WHEN a player bids successively one, two and three of the same suit, he shows a long suit lacking the top cards (such as A-K or A-Q or, usually, even K-Q). He also advertises a very strong disinclination to have the hand played at no trump.

ELIZABETH HAWES is a designer of smart clothes for smart women. In her spare time she fights with a bright and sometimes bitter pen for certain wayward and neglected causes, among them honesty of relationship between adult humans, male and female.

Sizable inventories of brass and bronze coils and strip are being offered below regular market prices by hardware manufacturers who are marketing surplus inventories of production materials, industrial executives disclosed here yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 25 -- Federal agents who moved in and told Georgia it could not operate a dove-shooting season in defiance of United States regulations seemed to have won a decisive victory this week. It developed that Georgia hunters themselves did not want to risk their chances in Federal court to make a states' rights issue out of dove-shooting.

CUTTYHUNK, Mass. -- This isolated little island at the sea-going end of Buzzards Bay, with its scant settlement of about twenty houses, continues to attract fishermen well into the fall. To be sure, the daily boat service from New Bedford, fifteen miles away, is cut to twice a week -- Wednesday and Saturday -- but the island's three hotels remain open through most of October.

JUST nineteen years ago this week in this review: Page 1 was given over to "Electrical Utilities: The Crisis in Public Control," by a group of school men from Syracuse University. The trouble, the dons said, was that the power interests were growing faster than was realized and the country had better look into them before they got completely out of hand.

Raw cotton contains what may conveniently be called "trash" -- such matter as stalk, leafy material, seed coat, dust which may be as much as 5 per cent. An underestimate of even a half per cent can cause a serious loss. The estimate is rarely accurate because it is made by eye.

EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 25 -- President Truman came into Texas today to campaign for its twenty-three electoral votes, jointly threatened by Republicans and the States Rights Democrats' rebellion, but in his first speech here avoided the states' rights and civil rights issues, concentrating on what he called the Republican threat to cheap power.

The United Nations General Assembly met last week in Paris to take up the world's explosive problems -- while far from the banks of the Seine there were indications that those problems were becoming more explosive than ever.
IT is tempting to make certain inferences of British and American temperamental divergences from the exhibition of drawings by Augustus John and Isabel Bishop at the American British Art Center.

Despite warnings that acceptance in the Reserve Officers Training Corps at City College would mean only temporary deferment from the draft, enrollments in the college's voluntary ROTC unit increased more than 100 per cent over last semester, the largest percentage rise between terms in the history of the corps at the college it was reported yesterday.
