SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 25 -- The luck 'o the Irish worked overtime today as desperately pressed Notre Dame outlasted Purdue's Boilermakers, 28 -- 27. It was a classic football opener which had a record crowd of 59,343 hysterical from start to finish at Notre Dame Stadium.

Smashing the stake record and missing the world and track mark by only one-fifth of a second, Blue Peter won the $113,110 Futurity at Belmont Park yesterday after a duel with the remarkable filly, Myrtle Charm, that thrilled every person in the crowd of 35,833.

OUT of the richly detailed reporting, the poised yet brilliant conclusions, the historical competence of this book, rises one supremely ironic joke -- a joke on those writers, professors, politicians, moralists who insisted -- and still insist -- that Abraham Lincoln must be established as a marble saint, a spotless ideal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Truman Administration was accused, in effect, today by Representative Carter Manasco, of using anti-trust actions against American corporations in order "to get Communist and extreme left-wing support" in the November election.
Passengers on the IND Concourse-205th Street line, southbound, were delayed for half an hour yesterday because of a fire at noon in the transformer room near the 205th Street station.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- Following is the prepared text of an address here tonight by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey on inflation:

The coming of the day when the influence of veterans of the second !World War, statistically speaking, no longer will be reflected in swollen' college enrollments is clearly forecast in the numbers of day session students who have just begun their studies for the new school year at New York's four municipal colleges.

In your "Farewell to Penmanship" you show a specimen of the brave new (?) hand called "manuscript" which, you claim "is the natural way for kids to write." No scribal authority in either hemisphere would see anything "natural" about it.

AIR travelers temporarily stranded because of lack of funds will be able to buy air transportation on credit to almost any point in the world when a new universal air travel plan goes into operation Friday.

The firewood is being put in now, against the winter. It is stacked along the side of the house, the overflow half cord resting between two trees in the yard. Once again memory rustles the leaves of familiar old phrases, to find that one about the warmth of the hearth.

THE rock gardener has a particularly happy chore ahead of him when he starts scanning fall catalogues. Although he will usually be limited to the smallest bulbs and perennials and the very dwarf shrubs, he can find a wealth of attractive miniatures that are especially well suited to grow among the rocks.

LONDONERS are using the river Thames again as a traffic artery, finding it a relief from the Underground, buses or taxis. A small fleet of fast launches, each capable of carrying 170 passengers, is operating on a half-hour headway between upstream Putney and Greenwich, twelve miles below.

THE time is 1663, and the scene is a small New England village. The villagers believe that there is a witch in their midst. The person who holds most firmly to this belief is Mr. Nowell, the minister, whom Robert Holles first meets at the bedside of a dying woman.

AS revolutionary in its own way as the Picassos and Brancusis of which Alfred Stieglitz was a pioneer champion is the camera work of the Photo-Secession group of which he was leader. Photo Secession is the name taken by those Americans in 1902 who believed in photography as an art and worked toward the kind of creative effects found in painting.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Dr. Samuel K. Allison, director of the Institute for Nuclear Studies where atomic bomb research is centered at the University of Chicago, issued this statement today on the Congressional investigation of activities by Russian spies:

PROFESSOR SLICHTER of Harvard has spent his life studying the American economy. He is hard working and hardheaded; his views are hammered out of his own thinking, carefully stated and tenaciously held in spite of frequent opposition.
Right-wing union leaders in this city have been called to meet in Washington tomorrow with Philip Murray, national president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 25 -- At the end of the first week of his active campaign for President, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York is acting like a man who has already been elected and is merely marking time, waiting to take office.

A MAN seeking to import used Gillette razor blades into Iran should give it up. It is against Iranian postal regulations. If a man in Great Britain has an impulse to export eau de cologne to Basutoland, he should give that up, too.

THE somewhat unusual theme forthrightness of treatment used by Mr. Engstrand last year in his "The Sling and the Arrow" made of that novel a best seller. Viewed by some readers as too clinical, by others as excessively sensational, "The Sling and the Arrow" was the story of a marriage destroyed by a husband's homosexuality.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Within a few days the French Government probably will submit to David K. E. Bruce, chief of the Marshall Plan mission to France, a prospective balance sheet. It will indicate the outlook for the French treasury in the light of the probable tax yield and the probable increase in wages.

VIENNA, Sept. 25 -- Chancellor Leopold Figl complained in a speech in Voecklabruck today that whereas the Western powers were doing their best to help Austria "another power is using us as an instrument in its international policy and, without bothering to advance plausible reasons, is preventing us from obtaining a state treaty."

IN this account of the discovery of oil in Oklahoma, Lois Lenski gives us the fifth in her series of regional stories for children. Like the preceding books, it is a realistic picture of daily living among people whose environment has made them unusual and interesting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- In by far the most thrilling and crowd-satisfying race for Gold Cup speed boats during a summer that has seen rough water and crack-ups cost the owners several hundred thousands of dollars in damage, Dan Arena won the first heat of the President's Cup today on the Potomac in the red and white Such Crust in near record time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Against a background of rising inflation and foreign-exchange difficulties impeding world recovery efforts, the finance ministers and central bank directors of forty-seven nations will meet here on Monday to discuss mutual problems and near proposals for their solution.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Georgia Tech let loose a jet-propelled version of its famous rambling wreck today and sailed to a 13-to-0 victory over Vanderbilt before a sellout crowd of 22,000.

Seventeenth and early eighteenth century music played on instruments of the period was heard yesterday at the formal opening of an exhibition, "French Court and Opera Ballet in the Time of Louis XIV."

Judaism means the practice in everyday life of justice, righteousness and fair dealing, the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark declared yesterday in his first sermon as senior rabbi of Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at East Sixty-fifth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (AP) -The Pittsburgh Pirates hopped on three Cincinnati hurlers for twenty hits today as they walloped the Reds, 16 to 6, before a chilled gathering of 7,766. It was one of the smallest crowds of the season.
INTERIOR decorators and art dealers have been notoriously antipathetical for years. Their differences have been based, however, more on economic than esthetic grounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- As a direct result of the collapse of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission is surveying the practice of stabilizing the market prior to an offering of securities to determine if it might be in the public interest to outlaw such action.

IT'S small wonder that the theatre has been getting fewer and fewer enthusiastic, suggestion. It's Small wonder that while all other forms of entertainment have grown by leaps and bounds, the theatre of today is a small and wonderful thing instead of a great big wonderful thing.

AN interesting challenge to writers and publishers of books for small children has just been issued by one of those literate housewives of whom I have recently been speaking. In the September Atlantic Mrs. Margaret Palfrey Woodrow, eldest of the famous tennis-playing Palfrey sisters of Boston, sets forth her objections to the contemporary writing that is available for reading aloud to 3- and 4-year- olds.

Mayor O'Dwyer will be the principal speaker at 2 P. M. today at an Interfaith Day rally on the Mall in Central Park. Colors will be massed by color guards from veterans' groups at the start of the program.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Cynicism, a far more dangerous enemy of the United Nations than mere pessimism, is a dominant note of this session of the General Assembly, the first to be held on the European Continent.

ADISCORDANT chorus erupts daily near the Fenway Park press box. The Boston natives have named the spot Earache Alley. But the chant never changes. To the tune of "Maryland, My Maryland," the lusty-voiced singers warble a parody. It's only the top two lines of the refrain and this is the way it goes: "He's better than his brother Joe -- Dominic DiMaggio."

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A heart attack caused the death of Stanley Mauldin, star tackle for the Chicago Cardinals, in the team's dressing room two hours after the Cardinals had defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 21 to 14, in a rugged opening game at Comiskey Park last night.

UNION, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Once a farming area and also a battleground in the Revolutionary War, this Union County municipality today began a two-week celebration of the 140th anniversary of its incorporation as a township with a two-mile-long parade.

An upsurge in education on all levels, from primary grades through the university, is now taking place in Europe. Although they face many problems, Western European countries are sponsoring numerous reforms to improve their school programs and provide additional facilities.

A CHILD of the industrial age, Joe Magarac is one of our younger, lesser-known work heroes. But this legendary steelworker, made of steel, born in an ore mountain, has the qualities of his elders -- the swagger, the generosity as well as the out-size proportions of Paul Bunyan and John Henry.

TO a delegation of visiting American workers, twenty-one years ago, Joseph Stalin prophesied that, "there will emerge two centers of world significance, a socialist center draw ing to itself the countries which tend toward socialism and a capitalist center drawing to itself the countries that incline toward capitalism.

AS all but the dewiest readers and writers should recall, it used to be, in pre-World War I days, the George H. Doran Company. Then it was Doubleday, Doran Co. in the days before World War II. Mr. Doran himself, now well along toward 80, was in town recently from Prescott, Ariz., where for the past half dozen years he has made his home.

An operation on the brain called "prefrontal lobotomy" has been performed for the last ten years on persons suffering from worries, persecution complexes, suicidal impulses, obsessions and nervous tensions. The operation was suggested by the Portuguese neurologist, Dr. Egaz Moniz, about thirteen years ago and first carried out under his direction by the Portuguese surgeon, Dr. Almeida Lima.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- The Communist-dominated Socialist Unity party tested its drawing power in the western sectors of Berlin today by calling a rally. Approximately 3,500 persons, mostly hecklers, answered the call.

OTTAWA, Sept. 25 -- The British drive to increase exports to Canada, which Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in his talks and interviews here placed first on the list of means to narrow the gap in the commercial exchanges between the two countries, has already made appreciable progress, according to figures published by the Canadian Department of Trade and Commerce.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- With the first week of the General Assembly of the United Nations drawing to a close, the shadow of the East-West dispute hangs over the Palais de Chaillot like a big cloud, with no rifts as yet apparent in it.

FIFTEEN-YEAR-OLD Zan lives with her family in a Vermont hill community where the small farms barely support their owners. Government agents suggest that the land be sold and the people be resettled, but most of the farmers, Zan among them, want to try again to farm successfully.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Word was received from Washington today of the promotion to the rank of Minister of G. W. Ray, Counselor of the United States Embassy here. In the absence of Ambassador James Bruce, Mr. Ray, who has served for thirty years as a Foreign Service career man, has been the charge d'affaires.

RIGHTNESS is a gift. It has nothing to do with experience, or knowledge, or the sort of liberal thinking which comes of contact with many men of many opinions, classes, nations, religions, manners, prejudices and fancy cuts of coats.

WASHINGTON. THE United Nations Assembly, now convened in Paris, is acting as a kind of coroner's jury. Its sessions represent a grim inquest into the collapse of negotiations for international control of atomic energy.
COINCIDENT with the return to standard time, a large contingent of new and returning radio shows are scheduled to take their places on the radio dial this week.

AT the Ziegfeld Theatre, where "Magdalena" opened last Monday night, a lady was heard murmuring to her neighbor during the second act, more in bewilderment than disappointment, "I thought this was a musical."

ANDREWS FIELD, Md. THE United States Air Force is busy right now not only acquiring a lot of strange new planes but also in training a new kind of pilot to fly them. There is as yet no official name for these fliers, but the pilots themselves have dreamed up something: they are "superboys."

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25 -Senator Alben W. Barkley Democratic nominee for Vice President, called tonight on Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to "state his position" on a plan "known to Republican leaders" to turn over the $3,000,000,000 atomic energy industry to private interests.

STIMULATED by cooler weather, retail trade in most areas showed gains last week. Sales of apparel and accessories were the best of the seasonal buying period thus far, and tended to buttress the view that fall and subsequent holiday trade will reflect continued active consumer demand.

An examination of the examples of "malicious propaganda for war against the U. S. S. R." cited yesterday by Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky indicated that he had been inaccurate in at least one instance.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Sept. 25 -- While white opinion in South Africa appears to be solidly behind Eric H. Louw, leader of this country's delegation to the United Nations General Assembly in Paris, in his stand that treatment of the Indian minority is a "domestic matter," his arraignment of the United Nations as an impotent organization finds this country split along political lines.

According to the Economic Cooperation Act of 1948, American aid under the European Recovery Program is supposed to do double duty. Section 115 of the act requires that as American grants are received each recipient nation must set aside a "special account" in its own currency equivalent to dollar aid.
TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 25 -- The Trenton State Fair, preserving colonial tradition, will open here at the Fair Grounds tomorrow.

Seventy-two vessels of 1,000 gross tons of more and totaling 1,052,869 gross tons, and two large dredges were on order or under construction in United States private shipyards as of Sept. 1, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

TO those who still see in the Negro only an object for exploitation the name of Walter White suggests the most contemptible kind of person -- the light-skinned, educated, race-conscious Negro who moves easily among highly placed whites.

Charges that a large part of Puerto Rico's output is drained off in payments to absentee owners of capital, as frequently alleged by critics of United States policy, are denied in a report just prepared for the Social Science Research Center of the University of Puerto Rico.

A REPETITION of this year's squeeze on transatlantic shipping space is already forecast for the 1949 summer season on the basis of advance applications being received by travel agents and shipping operators.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Rushing favored Texas off its feet with three touchdowns the first four times it got the ball, North Carolina sent the Longhorns down to a crushing 34-7 defeat today.

Several performances of Broadway theatrical productions will raise funds for various charitable oragnizations. The Prescott Neighborhood House will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Summer and Smoke," a new play by Tennessee Williams, on the night of Oct. 12 at the Music Box Theatre.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 25 -- If there is any merit in a moral victory, it lies with Michigan State College tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 25 -- The United States will not compromise "essential principles" for peace, Secretary of State Marshall declared today in a broadcast from Paris in a new radio series, "Memo from Lake Success," produced by the United Nations Radio Division, transmitted over the Columbia Broadcasting System and relayed to Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

IF the parents' association in your town has been run for years by its president, and membership seems so much waste motion, you may wonder whether you are duty bound to join. If your local parent group is alert but floundering, and you've just been named president, maybe you are floundering too.

THE PAS, Man., Sept. 25 (UP) -- The five men marooned for thirteen days in the wilds of northern Manitoba after their United States Navy plane was forced down, were brought here today in a rescue plane of the Royal Canadian Air Force.

I FIND it impossible not to challenge a statement made by your critics in his Sunday review of Bessie Breuer's "Sundown Beach." "It was a scramble and elusive drama," he wrote, "that closed last night with full public approval."

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Clashes in which forty persons were injured, ten of them seriously, broke out in Paris tonight when the Communists tried to break up a meeting of the followers of Charles de Gaulle.

TO an American population of about 143,414,000 India is mostly a geographical expression. To the business section in this country a deal with India is a welcome "extra" To the author and publisher in the U. S. A. India is a British preserve.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- While the House Un-American Activities Committee pursues its inquiry into atomic espionage, the Atomic Energy Commission makes the reassuring statement that the essential secret of the atomic bomb remains unviolated.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor craft union strike against the principal Hollywood film studios, one of the strangest labor disputes in recent history, rounded out its second full year today.

A musical personality of extra-ordinary appeal was introduced to this country last night when Jacqueline Blancard, Swiss pianist, appeared with the Daniel Saidenberg Little Symphony at Town Hall. One's satisfaction was not only in the exquisite performance, but in the fact that so many New Yorkers turned out to hear the "difficult" program, which consisted of three Mozart Concertos.

JONATHAN CARVER, writing in 1780 or thereabouts of travels in America, was first to give the name Shining Mountains to the ranges now known as the Rockies. The more poetic name endured for only a few years, but was in more or less common use when Matt Morgan, hero of this well-paced novel of the frontier, was a boy in Kentucky.

Announcement of the American attainment of speeds in the air "hundreds of miles faster than the speed of sound" was made yesterday by W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Thus far the clamor of the Presidential campaign is a distant echo to Washington, where the largest group in the nation that will be personally affected by its outcome is concentrated.

The absence of constructive developments in the international situation continues to restrict the activity of security traders, while the domestic scene rapidly moves into focus. Stock prices, after a jolt at the beginning of last week, staggered back slowly in quiet trading as the period progressed, although the recovery failed to wipe out earlier losses.

FRENCH film producers are expected to complete about 100 pictures by the year's end, or only fifteen less than the normal annual output in pre-war years. There is one great distinction, however, between the present and the past, for while impressive strides are being made quantitatively the production of first-rate films is dismally low.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25 -- The Ministry of the Interior announced today that 507 citizens of Rumania, Bulgaria, Albania and Hungary -- a large proportion of them Communists -- had fled from their countries since the split within the world of the Communist Information Bureau and had received asylum in Yugoslavia.

THE twenty - fourth annual convention and trade show of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association will be held in the Auditorium in Cleveland Oct. 11-16 with more than 200 exhibits of new photographic products.
BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 25 -- Navy saw the promised land today in its tortuous climb out of the football wilderness, but it proved only a mirage.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 25 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist regime seemed, in the opinion of observers today, to be seeking the Czech equivalent of the alleged Reichstag fire plot in Nazi Germany as a means of discrediting the United States.

Left-wing secessionists from the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, were accused yesterday of having offered $200,000 to the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, in rturn for issuance of an American Federation of Labor charter.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie asked member countries of the United Nations today to stop spending the organization's funds on projects that their own budgetary representatives had tried repeatedly to curtail.

PRICES, profits and automotive fair-trade practices are scheduled for discussion by 2,000 delegates to the annual convention of the National Used Car Dealers Association opening today at the Waldorf-Astoria. The program topics range from estimates of how long the bloom of youth lasts on new cars to the extent of the present boom in all types of vehicles.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Debutantes of this season are aiding members of an executive committee headed by Mrs. Robert W. Dowling in the sale of tickets for two performances of current theatrical productions which have been taken over to raise funds for the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.
DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- The Republican party intends to cease partisan politics at the water's edge, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg told the Michigan State Republican convention today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- Northwestern sank the University of California at Los Angeles, 19-0, today. A crowd of 55,156 saw U.C.L.A. absorb its second loss in two years at the hands of the Wildcats.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The damage caused by the hurricane that struck Bermuda on Sept. 13 was not heavy enough to wipe out the strong gains made by the island's tourism during the spring and summer, or to dampen the enthusiasm with which Bermudians are looking forward to the fall and winter season.
ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Cornell's football forces overpowered New York University, 47 -- 6, scoring seven touchdowns before 14,000 at Schoellkopf Field today.

UNCOMMON as Jimmy Durante is as a public man, he is still more uncommon as a private man. But between the public and private man there is no discernible difference. The wild wit, the uninhibited naturalness, the inspired improvisation, these talents coupled with his love of people, his zest, his winsomeness, his capacity for enjoyment, his modesty, have made Jimmy a beloved entertainer.

DeMille and other seismic disturbances.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 25 -- Two problems have been bothering the Israeli man in the street during the past week -- first, what basic political causes inspired the revival of the terrorist underground, and second, would he turn over to the police anyone he knew for a certainty to be a terrorist conspirator or a gunman?

Registration for the election on Nov. 2 will begin this week in the city and state. Leaders of all political parties have made preparations to get out as large a registration as possible, hoping that it will equal or exceed the record poll for the last Presidential election in 1944, 3,556,377 in the city and 7,212,996 in the state.

The significance that will be attached to Winston Churchill's memoirs leads me to observe that they should be handled with great care. They are replete with serious inaccuracies on the basis of which judgments are made that are unfair to individuals and events.

ATLANTA, Sept. 25 -- Gov. M. E. Thompson today called the Georgia Legislature into special session Monday to pass a measure permitting the names of Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates of all parties on the General Election ballot and to bar the names of unpledged electors.
A CASE should be made for boysenberries, especially at fall planting time. They are an excellent fruit for most home gardens.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- Iva Toguri D'Aquino, Los Angeles- born "Tokyo Rose," was brought back today from Japan to be tried on a charge of treason. She left the Army transport General Hodges with two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as her escorts, while an Army band played "California Here I Come" to welcome returning occupation troops who swarmed the upper deck.

WHEN and if the Metropolitan Opera Association gets around to putting its productions successfully on film, "preferably in Technicolor," as George A. Sloan, chairman of the board, recently declared it is planning to do, it will conclude a frustrating chapter of motion-picture history.

ATHENS, Sept. 25 -- Minister of War Georges Stratos told a news conference tonight that between Sept. 7 and 18 Greece's northern neighbors had violated her frontiers or permitted violations by the Communist-led Greek rebels on at least ten occasions.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept 15 -- Upsets were the order of the day as the first and second rounds of match play were concluded in the seventeenth annual New Jersey State amateur best-ball championship over the Plainfield C. C. links here today.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 25 -- Colorado Republicans are in for a hard pull in trying to unseat Senator Edwin C. Johnson, a big, friendly man with a hearty handshake and an isolationist record.

Despite the fact that the 2,500,000 students entering or returning to college this month are approximately the same in number as last year, college freshmen this year are having no difficulty in finding schools with vacancies. The larger schools are full as usual, but this fall, for the first time since the war, some smaller colleges are advertising for students.

The appearance of Gypsy Rose Lee, at the Air Forces Association's show on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, resulted yesterday in a minor cause celebre for the television industry. What to the viewer at home had all the earmarks of a controversial case of censorship proved upon investigation to be apparently a comedy of errors.

MANILA, Sept. 26 -- The strange and bloody war of attrition being fought on the central plains and in the swamps of Luzon between Government forces and the rebel Hukbalahaps has taken possibly 1,000 lives in the past forty days, while existence in the rest of the Philippines goes on with apparent normality.

A reply to proposals of some Government and industry leaders that diesel-electric locomotives be banned to conserve oil was made yesterday by the electro-motive division of the General Motors Corporation and General Motors Research Laboratories.

Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations mediator for Palestine who was murdered in Jerusalem on Sept. 17, was lauded yesterday morning at a memorial service at the Gustavus Adolphus Swedish Lutheran Church, 155 East Twenty-second Street.

A wage increase of 12 1/2 cents an hour and other contract improvements will be asked today by representatives of 25,000 unionized laundry workers and drivers in the metropolitan area. The demand will be made by the Laundry Workers Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, at a meeting with laundry owners at the joint board offices, 160 Fifth Avenue.
Eight new films, including importations from England and France, will have premieres in local first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- After a breeze brush-off yesterday, the fall post-season racing for the larger and active classes on Long Island Sound got under way today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The congregation of Temple Israel Center, which since 1922 has worshipped in a now-outmoded building at 73 Fisher Avenue here, dedicated a new $450,000 temple this afternoon on a three-acre site at Old Mamaroneck Road and Miles Avenue. Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, chairman of the board of overseers of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, was principal speaker.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Five campaign workers for Henry A. Wallace reported tonight that a band of men had dragged them from their headquarters here, and drove them ten miles out of town where they were released with a warning to "stay out of Augusta."

SUNBURY, Ohio, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Sunbury could use a thousand tickets to Boston right now, but will settle for a celebration for the man who is Mr. Baseball here.

In seaking a further increase of 8 per cent in freight rates, the nation's railroads may be playing into the hands of their competitors, in the opinion of authorities on transportation. If approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the proposed increase, it is estimated, would add around $500,000,000 a year to the gross revenues of the railroads if they are able to maintain traffic at its present level.

Members of Rural Electrification Administration cooperatives that serve more than 2,000,000 farm homes united last week in one of the most vigorous attacks made in their thirteen-year war with private and municipal power groups.

MONTREAL, Sept. 26 (Canadian Press) -- A four-run rally in the ninth enabled the Syracuse Chiefs to defeat Montreal Royals by 5 -- 2 today and even their International League best-of-seven final series at 1 -- 1.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- In the realm of fashions, California is advocating darker shades for winter sunning. Deep off-tones, blueberry, claret, marsh green and deep red violet that is often paired with shadings down to misty pale mauve, project the new subdued mood, even in play clothes and swim suits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -Repeal of the Walsh-Healey Act, which authorizes the Federal Government to set "floors" for wages in industries which have contracts from the United States, was urged today by Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican of New Jersey.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Awaited with considerable trepidation, Foreign Secretary Bevin's statement on the international situation made on Wednesday in the House of Commons, seems to have brought relief rather than intensified anxiety to the City.

School-age children aided by the Play Schools Association will benefit from the performance of "Love Life" on the night of Nov. 15 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. Proceeds will further the work of the association, located at 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, which conducts centers for children between the ages of 5 and 13, who need supervised activities in their out-of-school hours.

After two months of diplomatic efforts to end the Berlin crisis by direct negotiations, the Western Powers have now broken off these negotiations as hopeless and have decided to submit the whole issue to the judgment of world opinion by referring it to the Security Council of the United Nations.

Sales of the Vick Chemical Company for the fiscal year ended with last June amounted to $41,674,040, only 0.03 per cent lower than the peak volume of $41,803,472 attained in the preceding year, William Y. Preyer, president, reported in the annual statement to be mailed today to stockholders.

Executive and editors of The Journal of Commerce, who have been pinch-hitting for idle composing room employes and mailers during the last two weeks, undertook heavier duties last night when all ten of the financial paper's regular press room employes quit work.

Notices of intent to export articles with benefit of drawback should be eliminated, as they serve no important purpose, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., recommended over the week-end to the Commissioner of Customs, Treasury Department, Washington, D.C.
Ten thousand persons attended the third annual Interfaith Day exercises held yesterday on the Mall in Central Park.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture predicted tonight that grain exports during the current crop year may top last year's record by nearly 4,000,000 tons.

The Soviet Government's attempt to compel Russian statisticians to subordinate their science to the propaganda needs of the state at home and abroad has taken a new tack, it was learned yesterday. The campaign of the last several years having achieved what it considers unsatisfactory results, the State Planning Commission is now turning its attack on the mathematical basis of statistics.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The decision to refer the Berlin dispute to the United Nations Security Council has been a foregone conclusion since the last conference with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov in Moscow Sept. 18, but the news is bound to cause a great shock throughout Britain.
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Luck ran out last night on the operator and patrons of a well-equipped gambling establishment in a twelve-room house here.

Mayor O'Dwyer issued yesterday a formal proclamation setting this week as Registration Week in the city. He called the voting process "not only a right but an obligation of good citizenship" and urged all employers, labor unions, civic and political groups and organs of public information to join in the drive.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 (UP) -- United States transport planes alone have flown more than 200,000 tons of food, fuel and medicine into Berlin since the Russian blockade clamped down on the city three months ago, the United States Air Force announced today.

WILLIAM FAULKNER, perhaps the most naturally gifted of contemporary American novelists, has never bothered to master the rudiments of his craft. BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- The Metropolitan Archery Championship Tournament was held today on the play field at Bear Mountain before a record crowd.

THE TIMES honored itself and American journalism by its fairness in printing the complete text of my speech at Buffalo before a national labor union body. I write in appreciation of that act, and also of the friendly tone of your editorial of the following day, Sept. 21, entitled "Our Perennial Socialist."

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The pulverizing Chicago Bears -- rugged on the ground and accurate through the air -- crushed the Green Bay Packers, 45 -- 7, today in a National Football League game before 25,546 fans at City Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Going the route for the first time since July 21 big Ralph Branca today pitched the Dodgers to a 5-1 triumph over the Phils before 14,772 fans, who came out to see the locals for the last time this year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- The West Coast strike went into its twenty-fifth day today with these developments:

While eight seceding locals of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, prepared to set up a joint council tomorrow night, leaders of thirty-two other New York locals joined yesterday in a pledge of loyalty to their parent union.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Two American officials of a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, arrested last week in connection with the alleged sabotage of Hungarian oil production, were ordered expelled from Hungary today by the Ministry of the Interior.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts smeared the Brooklyn Dodgers, 35 to 20, today to tighten their grip on the Eastern division leadership of the All-America Football Conference.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The fourth-place Pittsburgh Pirates closed out their 1948 home season on a happy note today as they swept a double-header from the Cincinnati Reds, 8 to 6 and 8 to 5. The nightcap was called in the eighth inning because of darkness.

Jeanne Rosenblum, winner of a 1946 Naumburg piano award, gave her second Town Hall recital last night. PARIS, Sept. 26 -- The Russian demand for control of Berlin's air traffic would have the same effect, if granted, as the Soviet request to issue and control Berlin's currency: the end of Western co- sovereignty in the city.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 -- In accordance with an order of the Permanent Commission of the Argentine Episcopate, special prayers of thanks that the alleged plot against President Juan Peron and his wife had been foiled were spoken during masses celebrated this morning.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Grain markets developed an easier undertone on the Board of Trade last week, but the aggregate trade was comparatively light and prices held within narrow limits. Most of the pressure came from professional traders, who are inclined to the bear side, but the breaks brought in fair commission house support and some buying in wheat to remove hedges against sales of cash grain to the Government.

Featured were a ninety-four-piece symphonic orchestra -- the Liederkranz Orchestra augmented by members of Local 802, the American Federation of Musicians -- and a mixed chorus of 1,700 voices.

The annual award offered by the Julia Ellsworth Ford Foundation has been won by "The Canvas Castle," by Alice Rogers Hager, considered the best of 300 manuscripts submitted in the contest for children's books conducted by the publishing firm of Julian Messner.

Monroe A. Toussaint has been appointed assistant to the president of the Conlon division, Conlon-Moore Corporation. He formerly was general manager of the American Ironing Machine Division, Simplex ironers, Barlow Seelig Manufacturing Company.

A program to enlighten legislators and public officials on the need for fuller extraction of marketing data contained in Federal and state governments' statistics is being advocated by a number of marketing researchers, it was learned last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The popular Arena brothers, Dan at the wheel and Gene alongside as mechanic, pushed the new Gold Cup class craft Such Crust, owned by Jack Schafer of Detroit, to frightening, unheard-of new speeds today on the Potomac to win the President's Cup.
DUBLIN, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Cavan staved off a desperate second half bid by Mayo today to win the all-Ireland Gaelic football championship by a one-point margin.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Completing its retarded legislative program, scheduled to have been finished in July, the French Parliament adjourned today, to meet again Nov. 19 after elections for the advisory Council of the Republic have been held.

From the facts on school crowding conditions affecting a section of Queens as recently presented to the Board of Education, it appears that the city has an immediate obligation to finish construction of the never-completed quarter-century-old Public School 114, at Cronston Avenue and Beach 134th Street, Rockaway Beach.
With two ballet seasons in full swing, the busy week-end brought forth half a dozen, local premieres, several changes of program and one or two outstandingly good performances.

The new Community Church of New York was formally opened yesterday morning when John Haynes Holmes for the first time in seventeen years preached to his congregation in a church building of its own. All the 1,000 seats in the red brick "modernistic" structure at 40 East Thirty-fifth Street were filled.
Workers for the Travelers Aid Society here met 182 ships and helped 10,000 arrivals from overseas in the first half of this year, the organization announced yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 26 -- James A. Cullen, state director of the National Education Association, warned a state-wide conference of educational leaders here yesterday that a major crisis was developing in the school system of the state because the 1947 Feinberg salary law had failed to iron out the financial problems of the teachers.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- The text of a joint communique issued today after a meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France:

ZURICH, Sept. 26 -- "What does the Marshall Plan Cost Us?" asked the National Zeitung of Basle yesterday in a banner line over a featured article discussing the multilateral payments plan of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation to which Switzerland, as one of 19 European Recovery Plan countries, now is asked to signify adherence.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Two champion six-meter racers vied closely today in a four-boat sixteen-mile race held off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. George Nichols' Gold Cup champion Goose, with Charles Havemeyer of Seawanaka skippering, wrested victory away at the third marker from Herman Whiton's Olympic champion Llanoria.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns overcame a 10-0 halftime deficit today with a three-touchdown last-half splurge to defeat the Chicago Rockets, 21 to 10, before a crowd of 37,190 in an All-America Football Conference game. It was the fourth straight victory for the two-time league champions.
With college football almost in full stride with the start of many campaigns last Saturday, favorites generally completed their initial tests without moving out of the front rank of the procession.

It takes a report like that of the City Rent Commission to make us appreciate the tremendous economic pressure still being exerted against tenants by continuing housing shortages. It is inevitable that many landlords should feel unduly restricted in the administration of their properties by rent laws.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- Warner Brothers will dispatch camera crews to Guam, Okinawa, Midway and Hawaii this week to obtain background scenes for "Task Force," a story of naval aviation, which is scheduled to go before the cameras next month at the studio, with Gary Cooper in the leading role.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- World-wide tributes such as have rarely been paid to a living artist are being showered this week-end on the United States born English poet and critic T.S. Eliot, who is 60 years old today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Four aged but spirited Union veterans of the Civil War opened the eighty-second annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic today with a memorial service.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- The migration of 10,000 Jews a month from Europe into the new State of Israel was called for today by Edward M. M. Warburg of New York, chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee, speaking at its Western States regional conference here.

Fifty-two survivors of the "Lost Battalion," bound together by memories of World War I, met at the Hotel Sheraton yesterday, thirty years to the day after the opening of the Argonne offensive in France in 1918.

DEVON, Pa., Sept. 26 -- Golden Hill, a chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. J.A. Hale, carried off the hunter championship of the Chester County-Bryn Mawr Horse Show as the three-day event ended last night.

Argentina is now expanding her purchases in Italy, while perhaps more significantly there is also a substantial influx of Italian emigrants and industrial plants to Argentina under the commercial and financial treaty negotiated nearly a year ago between the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The question being asked in Washington tonight is whether the Soviet Union will now seek to gain by force what it has failed to win by negotiation in the Berlin crisis.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 -- Steel ingot output last week was up half a point to 96 per cent of capacity. In the face of shortages of scrap metal and lack of pig iron, the industry is operating now at a level that matches peak output in the war years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- With only 20 seconds to go, Dick Poillon kicked a 28-yard field goal today to give the Washington Redskins a 17-14 National League football victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers.
WASHINGTON, Monday, Sept. 27 -- Following is the text of note addressed to the Soviet Government yesterday by the Governments of the United States, the United Kingdom and France:

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Taking the play away from their rivals in decisive fashion in the closing two chukkers of play, the Texas Centaurs defeated the Meadow Brook Tigers, 7 -- 5, in an all-star high goal polo match on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- First place, theirs throughout most of the ferverish American League campaign, again became the exclusive property of the Indians today. Before 57,888 fans, the year's largest turnout at Briggs Stadium, Bob Feller outpitched Hal Newhouser, hurling five-hit ball while fanning nine Bengals, and triumphed by 4 -- 1.
TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 26 -Balmy weather and an elaborate program brought out a record crowd of 65,000 today for the 203d opening of the Trenton State Fair.

Production of domestic gas ranges will reach a record peak of at least 2,400,000 units this year, H. Leigh Whitelaw, managing director of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, predicted over the week-end. He said that the industry expected to produce 2,800,000 units on the basis of output during the first six months, but added that this estimate has been revised downward because of an expected reduction in steel allocations in the fourth quarter.

Twenty-seven fellowships, valued at more than $25,000, have been awarded to college graduates from this country and abroad for professional training beginning on Oct. 1 at the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- The book called for Billy Southworth to order a bunt today at Braves Field as his pennant-bound squad blasted Larry Jansen for two solid singles to launch the battle against the Giants.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- Communist Leader Palmiro Togliatti thanked Russia for the "patience and forbearance" she had shown throughout the Berlin crisis, in a speech he delivered this afternoon to 150,000 enthusiastic Communists at the Foro Italico sports stadium.

BEL ALTON, Md., Sept. 26 -- One hundred clergymen and 1,500 laymen from Southern Maryland and Washington took part today in ceremonies commemorating the construction 150 years ago of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at St. Thomas Manor.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- The deadlock between the Soviet Union and the Western powers over the control of Berlin will be submitted to the United Nations Security Council, the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France decided today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- American business is investing a record-breaking $18,630,000,000 in new plant facilities and equipment this year, it was indicated today in a joint survey by the Department of Commerce and the Securities Exchange Commission.

All displaced persons in this city, regardless of race or creed, who cannot return to their native countries because of political, racial or religious persecution, were urged yesterday by Hugo E. Rogers, Manhattan Borough President, to register now for permanent residence in this country under the Federal Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 26 -- A conference of the leaders of all branches of American labor after the November elections to make plans for "revitalizing" the Democratic party or establishing a full-fledged labor party was urged here today by Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and a member of the executive committee of the CIO Political Action Committee.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday that $1,548,474 had been recovered by the Department of Welfare in the year ended June 30, 1948, from persons who obtained assistance by fraud; from those who although eligible when they received assistance later became financially able to pay it back, and from assets of relief recipients who died.

A program to overcome obstacles to full and expanding employment of American-flag shipping has been submitted to the United States Maritime Commission by Hans J. Isbrandtsen, president of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., merchandising and shipowning concern, it was made known over the week-end.

A freight rate war in the Gulf of Mexico-Cuba trade is threatened as a result of a battle between some of the shipping lines over steamship conference regulations, it became known yesterday. There was some evidence that the signal for the war had already been given when Seatrain Lines, Inc., announced rate reductions up to 50 per cent in the Gulf-Havana service, and shipping men said other lines would be forced to take action.
The present disunity of Christendom is the scandal of modern society, Msgr. James H. Griffiths, Chancellor of the Military Ordinariate, said yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Direst obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $45,904,950,904. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Hezekiah Cobb says he is no master of arts in seasonal bucolics, but a plain, blunt man exposed from his youth to rustic pursuits. His hands, like those of John C. Calhoun and Harry S. Truman, have held the plow.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The unbeaten San Francisco Forty-Niners scored their fifth All-America Football Conference victory of the year today, downing the Buffalo Bills, 38 -- 28, before 31,103 fans in Civic Stadium.

PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Held in check until the last few minutes of the opening half, the Paterson Panthers put their aerial game to good advantage for three touchdowns and a 20-7 triumph over the Wilmington Clippers today.

Since 1941, if not longer, Norman Krasna and Groucho Marx have been putting their heads together on a comedy. The long-threatened result is "Time for Elizabeth," another sun-kissed product emanating from California, where it was first taken in tow by Russell Lewis and Howard Young, a coast team of ambitious producers.

James F. Bruce, United States Ambassador to Argentina, said here last night that recent anti-American demonstrations in Buenos Aires should not be allowed to provoke unfriendly relations between this country and the South American republic.
The annual luncheon meeting of the Federal Business Association, which is composed of Government employes in the Metropolitan area, will be held tomorrow at the Commodore Hotel.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- While Randy Gumpert limited the Browns to six hits, the White Sox pushed across three runs for a 3-0 shutout today. It was the Brownies' last home game of the season.

Nearly two dozen new art exhibitions are opening this week, including a group show of modern European sculpture starting tomorrow at the Buchholz Gallery, and the fifth annual nation-wide Pepsi-Cola exhibition in the galleries of the National Academy, opening to the public on Wednesday.

Belief of leaders and the national candidates of both major political parties that control of the next United States Senate was in doubt was confirmed yesterday by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in fourteen states where the Senatorial contests are regarded in some degree doubtful.
A group of newspaper publishers representing eighteen countries in South America will begin a four-day meeting here today for the purpose of setting up a permanent organization.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Louisiana Legislature today voted to admit President Truman's name to the state's general election ballot without letting him be called officially a Democrat.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 26 -- The Yugoslav press reported today that armed Albanian bands had been penetrating into Yugoslavia's frontier zone with the aim of fomenting a revolt against Premier Marshal Tito and the Yugoslav Communist party leadership.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- While the French Government concorded with the views set forth in the three-power note and took full responsibility for them, well-informed French quarters tonight expressed regret that the action on the Soviet answer was taken with what they regarded as great haste.

Chief William Slater, Westchester County Parkway Police Commissioner, has stated that because people have been carrying boats, baby carriages and, finally, a bathtub on top of their cars, he will no longer permit anything to be carried on the outside of a car, even skis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Representative Estes Kefauver, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, in Tennessee, declared today that Governor Dewey made "a harsh and unwise attack on national unity" in questioning the conduct of the nation's atomic energy program.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- French economic and financial quarters are deeply interested in the meeting of the governors of the International Monetary Fund that will be opened tomorrow in Washington.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals, though counted out of contention when the Boston Braves clinched the National League flag today, didn't break their winning stride. They worked out a 5-2 contest of the Chicago Cubs behind the four-hit hurling of Al Brazle.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 26 -- Opening a centennial observance, Muhlenberg College and the city of Allentown joined today in an academic convocation marking the college's place in the community.

In identical letters sent yesterday to each member of the City Council the Citizens Union urged defeat of the pending local bill to eliminate the present requirement that the fire bureau of the Fire Department, as well as fire-fighting operations in the field, be under the control of the Fire Chief, who is chosen by competitive civil service examination.

PARIS, Monday, Sept. 27 -- The decision of the Western powers to place the German question before the Security Council confronts the United Nations with the gravest crisis in its history, it was generally agreed last night.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Sept. 27 -- The State Department issued a 25,000-word indictment of the Soviet Union this morning, charging that Premier Stalin had agreed to lift the Berlin blockade and then had permitted his subordinates to repudiate the agreement.
BUFFALO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren put aside campaign business for pleasure and relaxation today.

The Air Force Association, at the final meeting of its second annual convention, adopted yesterday a resolution demanding unification of air power in a single command or department. Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., retiring president of the association that represents the largest group of air veterans, supported the resolution on the floor of the Commodore Hotel's ballroom.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Sgt. William W. (Cy) Horton never intended to become a specialist, but he is now "the dog man" of New York State Police and one of the recognized bloodhound experts in the country.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 26 -- M. Donald Grant, Rockaway Hunt, and Mark Stuart, Winged Foot, defeated Bob Townsend, Nassau, and Frank Graven, Sands Point, 1 up, in the final of the Meadow Brook invitation golf tournament today.

It was a more nimble-footed United States Olympic team that spoiled the debut in this country of the soccer team of Israel, first international athletic group to represent the new state, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The New England Regional CIO-PAC made public yesterday its endorsements of Congressional candidates in the Metropolitan area. All those approved were Democrats, with the exception of Jacob K. Javits, Republican-Liberal party nominee in the Twenty-first District. who is opposed for re-election by Paul O'Dwyer, brother of the Mayor.

The Western Governments were taken by surprise when the Tass Agency published the contents of the Kremlin's reply to their latest notes on the Berlin impasse. In rejecting the Soviet note the three Foreign Ministers charged that the publication was a unilateral violation of a Four-Power agreement to keep the negotiations secret.

It would not be right to draw from Welfare Commissioner Hilliard's figures showing a reduced public assistance caseload for August any conclusion that economic conditions here are changing. The Commissioner himself wisely warns against any such hasty conclusion, while conceding cautiously that some improvement may lie just ahead.

It is the function of the church to preach the gospel of peace, break down the barriers between groups of people and do the work of the Lord, the Right Rev. Y.Y. Tsu, Bishop of Yuan-Kwei and general secretary of the Chinese Missionary Council, declared yesterday at St. James' Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Dr. Henry T. Moore,! president of Skidmore College, I said today that man was finding] it more easy to dominate his uni-1 verse and harder to dominate him-I self.

Prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market moved listlessly last week. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts for the 1948 crop on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net changes ranging from an advance of a point to declines of 17 to 26 points, while the distant October and December contracts showed net advances of 16 to 18 points.

The fourteenth school in the Board of Education's special "600" organization will get under way today when the new Public School 611 at 136th Street and Brown Place, the Bronx, opens its doors to 250 maladjusted boys.

Having proved itself to be that sort of ball club all year, it was but natural that the Yankees, in their farewell home appearance of the championship season at the Stadium yesterday, should do another extraordinary about face.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune, Mrs. John G. Winant's imported Scottish terrier that has been cutting a figure in eastern dog shows during this outdoor season, added an important victory in the all-breed event of the Westbury Kennel Association today.

A report yesterday on the first year's findings of a five-year silicosis research and treatment project held out hope for an eventual cure for the disease that each year kills or disables thousands of workers in mines and quarries and in some other occupations.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 26 -- The nation's bankers will re-examine economic trends in the light of current "disinflationary" developments, at a national credit conference to be held in Chicago from Dec. 13 to 15, it was announced here today. The conference will be sponsored by the Credit Policy Commission of the American Bankers Association, which earlier this year conducted the association's so-called "anti-inflation tour," designed to restrict bank loans to productive purposes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Trading in September corn on the Board of Trade ceased at the close of business on Wednesday with uncompleted contracts for 589,000 bushels outstanding and on which cash corn must be tendered by the end of this month.

Buying was active in the wholesale apparel market here last week with buyers primarily interested in completing their holiday purchases and looking for items for special promotions, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 26 -- Air raid sirens sounded Jerusalem's first "truce alert" this afternoon when several Arab League planes were reported to have been flying in the vicinity on "hostile operations," probably reconnaissance.

Half of the 1,052 retailers responding to a recent survey by Max Udell Sons Co., Inc. (Gramercy Park Clothes), expressed the belief that rayons will outsell pure worsted tropicals for spring 1949, it was announced over the weekend. Despite this opinion, however, purchases of rayons will average only 46 per cent of the summer suits bought, with pure worsteds accounting for the remaining 54 per cent.

Dealer deliveries of upholstered furniture from the city's producers stand at a minimum of six weeks because of heavy retail orders, several local producers reported over the week-end. They said that all but a few local plants are producing at capacity and have definitely emerged from the early summer slump when 50 per cent worked only two or three days a week.

Aiming to pierce the censorship in the Iron Curtain countries, the State Department's "Voice of America" broadcasts will begin today to give a factual report in a dozen or more languages of the Western powers' stand on the deadlocked German negotiations with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's top economic official, arrived here by plane today to confer with United States officials and attend the annual meetings of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund.

Foreign exchanges were spotty last week. Quiet and generally firm conditions ruled at the outset, or until Thursday afternoon when a nervous undertone was manifest with particular reaction against the pound sterling. On the other hand, the Canadian and Swiss currencies turned higher.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- There is "little prospect" of private American capital playing a major role in foreign recovery, a study by the Brookings Institution indicated today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A biochemist cited for his work in virus research and development of influenza vaccine and an engineer pioneering in research for supersonic aircraft were named today to receive the 1948 Franklin Gold Medals, prized scientific award of the Franklin Institute.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, the Republican candidate for President, announced today his full endorsement of the measures being taken by American representatives in Paris in collaboration with the British and French to achieve a peaceful solution of the Berlin crisis.

City, state and Federal officials promised yesterday to continue the campaign to have St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church of Morrisania -- the burial place of Gouverneur Morris, "penman" of the Constitution, and Lewis Morris, the only New York signer of the Declaration of Independence -- designated as a national shrine.

There is growing discontent behind the Iron Curtain, and Russia would not dare risk war under such circumstances, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday. Dr. Bonnell preached his first sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, where he is the pastor, since he returned Thursday from a two-month 17,000-mile trip through eleven nations of Europe.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 26 -- Thousands of residents of Stockholm stood silently on the route over which the body of the late Count Bernadotte, borne on an open catafalque drawn by fifty Boy Scouts, was taken this afternoon from Gustaf Vasa Church, where the funeral service was held, to a crematory on the outskirts of the city.

Col. Andre Serot, who was assassinated in Palestine with Count Folke Bernadotte, was a great friend of America. I had the privilege of working very closely with him in North Africa in 1943 and 1944. He was at that time the chief security and counter espionage officer of the French Air Corps.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The first National League pennant in 34 years came to this old city today with one loud scream -- that nearly scared the daylights out of everybody.

With Mayor O'Dwyer declaring that "the people of Israel will be free," the new $750,000 Rego Park Jewish Center on Queens Boulevard, between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets, was opened officially yesterday.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Gordon S. Park and Halsey Smith of Glen Ridge became the new champions as the sixteenth annual New Jersey State amateur best-ball golf championship was concluded at the Plainfield Country Club today.

A net saving of $27,000 has been achieved by Socony-Vacuum Oil Company as a result of its new employe suggestion system which has been in full-scale operation for only thirty days, W. S. Wilcox, assistant manager of the industrial relations department in charge of the system, disclosed in an interview last week.

Mayor William O'Dwyer and Francis Cardinal Spellman will head a campaign to raise funds for the completion of what will be known as the Babe Ruth Memorial Stadium at Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Western powers' appeal to the Security Council of the United Nations against the Soviet Union is generally regarded in Washington as formal repudiation of the basic assumption on which the United Nations was founded.
The long-sought "compounding" of the internal combustion engine has been accomplished by the two principal aircraft engine makers in the United States, it was learned yesterday.

OMAHA, Sept. 26 -- A belief in the spiritual values of free and happy recreation was urged here tonight at the opening session of the thirtieth National Recreation Congress, by the Rev. William H. Alexander, pastor of the First Christian Church of Oklahoma City and a leading exponent of church-sponsored recreation centers for young people.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 26 -- Henry A. Wallace, the Progressive party candidate for President, charged tonight in a bitter attack upon the Marshall Plan that President Truman and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and their advisers were planning a new international crisis before the election.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- The key men in the Palestine question will move this week to Paris as the report of the late Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, goes to the General Assembly's political committee, responsible sources said here today.

Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, vice chairman of the City Council, announced yesterday that he would seek amendment of the local rent laws in order to give large families special protection against eviction. Mr. Sharkey said that he would seek also an amendment to prohibit the sale of any apartment in a hotel without the approval of the City Rent Commission.

THE Yankees and the Red Sox, tense and unsmiling, arrived at the Stadium early yesterday for the rubber match of their vitally important series. It was the final home appearance for the Bronx Bombers unless -- as Bucky Harris thoughtfully added -- we come back here for a play-off game." Subdued and business-like the sterling heroes went about their preparatory chores, acutely conscious of the mental burden they were carrying.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Carleton Smith, director of the National Arts Foundation of New York and music critic, announced today that he had obtained first-performance rights to a new tone poem by Jan Sibelius during his recent visit with the aged Finnish composer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Within two weeks a three-member board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations will investigate charges that the Greater New York CIO Council has consistently followed the Communist party line and flouted CIO policy, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Following is the text of the report issued today by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, relating to atomic espionage:
SEATTLE, Sept. 27 -- Following is the prepared text of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's address tonight:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- The New York State Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences her's opened for its second year today with continuation of original courses in building technology, food administration, electrical technology and mechanical technology, and with new courses in industrial chemistry and medical-dental office technology.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 27 (AP) -- An Arab plane in which two British correspondents were killed was shot down by an Israeli fighter plane when the former craft did not heed a warning to land, a Government statement said today.
A further defection from the left-wing-controlled Greater New York City CIO Council was announced yesterday by Ernest Hebert, president of the Barbers and Beauty Culturists of America, CIO.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Poland accused the United States today of having interfered in the administrative affairs of the United Nations and criticized Secretary General Trygve Lie for not having demanded a formal apology from Washington for a recent charge by a State Department official that spies were using the world organization to enter the United States for undercover activities.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores remained unchanged last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 2 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 27 -- A conflict over cinematic priority to the subject of jet aviation appeared today with the announcement by Paramount of plans for "Wings of the Navy," a film about jet pilots, which Robert Fellows will produce and John Farrow will direct.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Second thoughts about the decision to take the Berlin issue to the United Nations Security Council brought increased anxiety and gloom to Britons today, judging from soundings in official circles and from reactions of the press and public.

THE casual reader of the sports pages -- if such a breed of man actually exists -- would get the impression that sports consist almost exclusively of baseball with slight overtones of football, boxing and hoss racing. But that would be a grevous error. The top sports industries of them all are hunting and fishing with an estimated 15,000,000 devotees each.

The head of a New York technical school charged yesterday that the Teachers union, CIO, was trying to organize trade schools with the objective of undermining the loyalty of their studentveterans "through control of their instructors and dissemination of subversive propaganda."
Persons named by the Un-American Activities Committee of the House yesterday as involved in wartime atomic spying were quick to reply to the accusations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Pro-Truman Democrats in Louisiana, it became known here today, intend to ignore the method offered by the State Legislature to get electoral candidates pledged to the Truman-Barkley ticket on the ballot as independents.

Returning to the friendly and familiar scene of Ohio Field yesterday for the first time since pre-season practice began at Lake Sebago camp on Sept. 1, New York University's football squad engaged in light drill as it prepared for its second game of the 1948 campaign, against Springfield College at Springfield, Mass., on Saturday.

SEATTLE, Sept. 27 -- Governor Dewey today coupled a warning to foreign governments not to interpret the American political campaign as evidence of disunity with a promise to proceed with the speedy development of Western water-power resources.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox, knocked into a second-place tie by the New York Yankees, came home today to an atmosphere of victory.

Strengthened by American aid and her own austerity and exporting regimen, Great Britain has still "a long and difficult journey to travel" toward complete economic independence, members of the Advertising Men's Post, No. 209, American Legion, were told yesterday at the Lexington Hotel.

Amid the sound and fury of the East-West dispute over Berlin the representatives of twenty-two countries met yesterday in Geneva for a four-day secret conference to discuss ways and means of reviving Europe's East-West trade. Delegates from Russia, Byelo-Russia and eight satellite countries (if Yugoslavia is still to be considered such) sat down with delegates from eleven Marshall Plan countries and the United States.

With the Indians perched on top and the Yankees and Red Sox locked grimly in a tie, one length behind, the three contenders in the American League pennant race are poised for the final dash that by next Sunday night may result in the most spectacular finish in the history of the junior circuit. Neither a two-club nor even a three-club deadlock is wholly improbable.

The Board of Higher Education, at one of its longest meetings in several years, declined last night to take any further action in regard to Dr. William E. Knickerbocker, a member of the faculty of City College, despite a resolution by the City Council recommending that he be dismissed.

Plans are being developed by number of manufacturers for extensive introduction of advertising -backed premium offers in foreign countries it was learned yesterday .Premuim specialists here commented that such use of premium amounts to pioneering.
The Army is looking for CATs.

ALBANY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The state's mortality record for July -- 10.1 deaths for each 1,000 persons -- was described today as "exceptionally favorable" by the State Health Department. In July, 1947, the rate was 10.2 per 1,000.

Substantially larger earnings for August and the first eight months of this year over the corresponding periods of 1947 are being reported by railroads all over the country, according to the official statements of many companies issued yesterday.

Last night at the City Center's International Dance Festival, the Paris Opera Ballet stepped down to allow the United States its solitary representation in a performance by Charles Weidman and his Dance Theatre Company. Let it be reported straightway that Mr. Weidman and his colleagues upheld the honor of the nation and are hereby nominated for a Congressional Medal.

PARIS, Sept 27 -- The Ministers of Defense of France, Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, in session here today, examined the military resources of the five nations, anticipating the eventuality that the Security Council's action on the Berlin crisis could lead to an emergency.
BONHAM, Tex., Sept. 27 -- Following is the prepared teat of President Truman's campaign address here tonight:

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Current usage of the word "loyalty" was condemned today by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, at a ceremony marking the opening of the college's seventy-eighth year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Herman Hickman was called away to Boston today on a trip that had nothing to do with scouting Harvard, and the Yale varsity football squad got out of the blood pits for the first time since it reported for training on Sept. 3.

A strike was called against three non-union jobbers yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, in its announced shop-by-shop drive to "clean up" the open shop in the industry and smash racketeering. In Washington Representative Arthur G. Klein of the Nineteenth (Lower East Side) Congressional District called for the appointment of a three-member subcommittee of the House Labor Committee to inquire into the union's charges that racketeers had invaded the garment industry.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 27 (AP) -- New Jersey tapped its three race tracks for $11,318,324.28 of the $148,462,141 poured into the pari-mutuel windows this year, official Racing Commission figures showed today.

Noting that the latest advance in the Canadian cost-of-living index of 0.4 per cent was the smallest since early in 1946, the Bank of Montreal's September Business Review ascribes the condition to a marked leveling off in bank credit, with a resultant stabilizing effect on the money supply.

The Sanitation Department reported yesterday that it was making progress in cutting down litter on Harlem streets. During the department's week-old drive 520 summonses had been issued up to Sunday for sanitary code violations or littering the streets.

ANKARA, Turkey, Tuesday, Sept. 28 -- A Rumanian Embassy spokesman, who announced yesterday that Ambassador Grigor Moisil had died of "food poisoning," suddenly reversed himself today and said that the Ambassador was alive.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 27 -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, condemned here tonight in his only major Texas campaign speech the substitution on the Louisiana ballot of the name of Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, States Rights candidate for President, for that of President Truman.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Although the decision to refer the Berlin dispute to the United Nations depressed the stock market here today, there was no sign of nervous selling.

First came champagne in the kitchens of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Lunch was staged later upstairs; it centered about jumbo squab. Supper on an old-fashioned Ohio River steamboat -- at least, such a menu was duplicated in the hotel's Astor Gallery -- finished off the day's epicurean experiences.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Sessions at the fifth meeting of the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization opened today on a note of tension reflecting the international crisis abroad.

Charles Menaker, 21 years old, son of a textile manufacturer, was shot dead early yesterday in the courtyard of the Bronx apartment house where he lived, by policemen called to investigate prowlers. The youth was said by his family to have been out walking the family dog.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Cleveland's main post office, cooperating with the American League leading Indians and thousands of their fans, today set up special letter containers to hold a flood of world series ticket applications.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Truman called upon labor and management today to cooperate with the Government in a long-range program to reduce industrial accidents.
NANKING, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Chinese Communists pressed widely separated but apparently well-coordinated offensives today, with the Government's South Manchurian corridor the most critical zone.
A sharp division of judicial opinion over wiretapping, as practiced here by the police, enlivened a public hearing yesterday by a committee of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 27 -- The two main problems facing the nation's transit industry are preparation for a possible national emergency and obtaining of additional revenue while holding customers, the American Transit Association was told here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Counsel for the Federal Trade Commission said today that eight companies in the multi-million-dollar corn products industry had "misstated the issue involved" when they asked the agency last week to dismiss a complaint against them charging conspiracy to "fix and maintain prices."
