Much has been done to clarify the pathology of silicosis, a respiratory disease which afflicts about 500,000 workers in the dusty trades and in which large portions of the lungs are blocked by fibrous tissue, but far less to understand the respiratory physiology. Since tuberculosis is the usual end result of silicosis a fundamental large-scale study has long been overdue.

Norman Krasna and Groucho Marx speak disrespectfully of the institution of retiring from business in "Time for Elizabeth," which was acted at the Fulton last evening. Fortunately, their comedy is not very persuasive. Mr. Marx wrote it several years ago at the time when he was retiring from the leer, lunge and grease-paint mustachio of his low comedy masquerade, thus depriving America of one of her greatest inventions.

BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Republican sources stated tonight that the Republican army had seized four Communist strongholds in East Java, but indicated that the drive to recapture the key city of Madiun was meeting strong opposition.

Women joined the Air Force here yesterday. Five former service women went back to active duty in a ceremony at Army and Air Force recruiting headquarters, 39 Whitehall Street. Four chose the WAF (Women in the Air Force) and one the WAC (Women's Army Corps).

SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Food prices have reached their peak and will decline from here on as a result of bumper crops and softening farm prices, representatives of the Government and the food trade told retail grocers here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Standard Airlines, a non-scheduled air carrier of Long Beach, Calif., today asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to act immediately on applications by it and other non-scheduled carriers to start regular low-cost "coach" air-passenger service between the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 27 -- Jerusalem had two air alerts in the last twenty-four hours. What was described as "high-flying planes" flew over the city last night and early today.
The Norwegian America liner Stavangerfjord was forced to alter her course to avoid a severe storm off the coast of Norway at the start of her trip here ten days ago.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration and the French Foreign Office announced today that an agreement had been reached for the release to the French Government this month of a sum "not to exceed 45,000,000,000 francs" from the Marshall Plan counterpart fund.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- The National Wallpaper Wholesalers Association, representing 110 companies throughout the country, at its convention here today laid plans for the 1949-50 "new look" in their product.

Tension over the relations between the Western Allied nations and the Soviet Union was quickly translated yesterday into the sharpest drop the stock market has undergone since mid-July. Under three distinct waves of selling, prices sank to the lowest levels since late March.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A demand for a new trial of Ilse Koch, widow of the commander of the notorious Buchenwald concentration camp, was made by Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, of New York today.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 27 --A strike that idled 4,000 workers and affected production in two plants of the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company ended today. Officials of the CIO United Rubber Workers said that grievances submitted by three employes who started the walkout would be negotiated by the union.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 -- One up and five to go, Lou Boudreau's Indians, confident that they are "in" and ready to resume their drive toward Cleveland's first flag since 1920, were at liberty today. Tomorrow night in vast Municipal Stadium they'll be back in the trenches, as it were, against the eighth-place White Sox.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Much has been said and written about the difficult situation of the Free Territory of Trieste. Little or nothing has been done for this zone that would guarantee it a certain modicum of autonomous life and a less passive economy.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Philco Corporation today lost a suit to restrain the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from interfering with its Philadelphia station, WPTZ, sending to and receiving from the National Broadcasting Company certain television broadcasts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that three companies had filed registration statements with it covering $3,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds and 351,356 shares of common stock.

In appreciation for his services to the Bicur Cholim Hospital of Jerusalem, James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, received yesterday a set of prints of the Holy Land and a silver letter-opener made in Palestine from the board of directors of the Jerusalem institution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Two new research tools from the atomic realm, hydrogen-3 and helium-3, are now available in limited quantities for scientists and research institutions, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

President Truman, taking his appeal to the housewives of America, told them yesterday that they could expect nothing in the way of a "better tomorrow" from the Republican party. He reminded them that day after day they must face "the soaring prices the Eightieth Congress has forced upon you."

Welcomed by scholars from neighboring academic institutions on Morningside Heights, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, received yesterday an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Premier Stalin probably was, and is, a victim of misinformation and bad advice, but he was not overruled on the Berlin agreement, nor has he lost control of his Government. On the contrary, all intelligence reports available in Washington indicate that he is still the whip-handed master.

Consolidated net sales of Oppenheim, Collins Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended on July 31 increased 10.3 per cent to $20,119,731 from the $18,235,987 volume for the preceding fiscal year, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders today.

Playing under lights for the first time this year, Columbia's football squad went through a spirited light practice session at Baker Field yesterday. No contact work was done as the players loosened up before beginning heavier drills for the Harvard game on Saturday.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation announced yesterday that the Navy had ordered $32,000,000 of new high-powered Curtiss aircraft engines to be produced at the Wright Aeronautical plant at Wood-Ridge, N.J.

The exposure of Russian duplicity in the Berlin negotiations issued by the American Government has been reinforced by Foreign Secretary Bevin with a speech before the Security Council of the United Nations which is by all odds the most blistering indictment of Russian policies and methods made thus far.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- When the President made up his mind to spend most of this month and October campaigning among the people instead of at his post he had calculated the risks and rejected them in favor of his project. But he knew these might be the consequences:
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed irregular, .3 points higher to 6 points lower than Saturday's final levels.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Striking into New England on the opening phase of his thirteen-state Eastern campaign for the Vice Presidency, Gov. Earl Warren of California declared tonight that there would be no Communists in the national administration if the Dewey-Warren ticket were elected.

MARK ALDANOV once saw the Empress Eugenie when he was young; and Eugenie knew personally, when she was young, the old painter Isabey, who, when he was young, had painted Marie Antoinette and who had known old men who remembered Louis XIV. It doesn't take many lives to span an imposing stretch of history.
BONHAM, Tex., Sept. 27 -- President Truman declared today that the Republican leaders "don't want unity -- they want surrender."

Five main features of the Third National Plastics Exposition which opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace drew a record attendence estimated at 7,000, according to officials. The show will continue through Friday.
Two meetings in which representatives of maritime unions discussed contract issues with Federal mediators were held here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Sept. 17 there is a letter from Isidor Berger, general manager, Greater New York Taxpayers' Association, which suggests that water from the Atlantic Ocean could be used for many purposes in New York City and thus conserve the Catskill and Croton water, the supply of which is limited.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- A formal request of the Western powers that the United Nations Security Council discuss the Soviet blockade of Berlin may be sent to Secretary General Trygve Lie tomorrow, it was said tonight after United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas, Sir William Strang, permanent British Foreign Office Under-Secretary, and French Ambassador Rene Massigli had worked all day in drafting the request.

Rayon goods suppliers are feeling a definite competitive "pinch" which is a clear indication of a buyers market, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. To obtain orders for some types of rayon goods, suppliers are making keen bids or the business, with price cutting apparent when substantial yardage is involved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Air Force disclosed today that it had two jet bombers faster than early models of the F-80 Shooting Star jet fighter. It rated one bomber at more than 600 miles an hour.

Jackie Robinson, second baseman of the Brooklyn Dodgers, has signed with WMCA to conduct a series of sports programs, designed for youngsters as well as adults, starting early in November and continuing until baseball spring training in March.

An issue of 400,000 new shares of common stock of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company valued at $12,100,000 will be placed on the market today by an investment banking syndicate headed jointly by Stone Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Irving Znaida and Bernie Catropa of the Willow Brook club cut nine strokes from par with a 31, 32 -- 63 to win the weekly amateur-pro event of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Rockville club today.

Prices of coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange continued to advance yesterday in active trading. New highs for the life of the current contract were established. Sales for the day totaled 21,750 bags. Trade house buying and hedge covering of the near-by delivery positions, along with support from Brazilian interests in the distant months, advanced prices 13 to 32 points above the previous close.

Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country, as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press, on the decision of the United States, Britain and France to refer the Berlin crisis to the United Nations Security Council:

Taking its cue from President Truman's Los Angeles speech, Tammany Hall has decided to wage a local campaign to keep the Wallace vote here at a minimum. In this way, while getting additional votes for Mr. Truman at the top of the ticket, the organization also will improve its chances of electing local candidates, it was reasoned.
PARIS, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Excerpts from the text of a speech by British Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin before the General Assembly of the United Nations:

BERLIN, Sept. 27 -- In a five-point declaration directed at the United Nations, the Berlin City Council today called for complete evacuation of the occupation troops from Germany as the only sure way of ending the present crisis and preventing recurrence of new ones.

Bass fishermen had a field day at many of the beaches between Cape Cod and Jamestown, R. I., over the week-end, and while the surf fishing was rather spotty on the Long Island south shore some nice fish were taken.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The international tension has resulted in a practical suspension of negotiations between Britain and the Soviet Union for a trade agreement, it was learned here today. The negotiations have not been broken off formally, but all effective conversations aiming toward a four-year pact ended the middle of last week.

Lou Little, guiding genius of Columbia's football fortunes, usually articulates but never longwinded, grabbed the limelight at the first annual Monday luncheon of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday by making almost, but not quite, the longest speech of the day.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A United States District Court ruled today the dining car regulations on Southern railroads do not discriminating against Negroes.

Leaders of Christianity throughout the world are "too little" aware that Premier Joseph Stalin and other Communist leaders are successfully "adapting" Christianity to further the aims of the Soviet Union, the Right Rev. Michael H. Yashiro, Presiding Bishop of the Nippon Seikokwai, the Holy Catholic Church in Japan, declared last night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- This country's broadcasting industry has virtually trebled its outlets since the end of the war, with the greatest expansion in the field of frequency modulation, Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told members of the FM Association at a luncheon meeting today.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- In a powerful speech, the quiet tone of which underlined the gravity of the crisis between the Soviet Union and the Western powers, British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin announced today that the British Government would seek to establish regional defense agreements "if we find in the end that we cannot proceed on a world basis as we had hoped."

Two new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Sutton, the attraction is "Louisiana Story," a feature-length documentary produced and directed by Robert Flaherty. Featuring an Acadian (cajun) boy, Joseph Boudreaux, the picture deals with life in the bayou country, where it was filmed in its entirety.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Two radioactive warships, the submarine Skate and the attack transport Crittenden, will be sunk in target practice off the Coast of California Oct. 5, the Navy Department announced today.
ASHEVILLE, N. C., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Senator Alben W. Barkley told Southern Democrats tonight a vote for any other candidate than President Truman "is a vote for the Republican nominees."
Cleveland, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would receive bids Oct. 14 on $7,500,000 of electric revenue bonds dated Oct. 1, 1948, and due April 1, from 1955 to 1969.

American shipping will save more than $500,000 in Panama Canal tolls in the six months between Oct. 1 and April 1, as a result of President Truman's deferment of the toll increases, it was estimated yesterday.

DUBLIN, Sept. 27 -- The world premiere of Mrs. H. T. Lowe-Porter's play, "Abdication," produced by Hilton Edwards and offered by Micheal MacLiammoir's Dublin Gate Theatre company here tonight, was certainly an event in this city's drama history.

The thirty-first annual appeal of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York will begin on Oct. 7 with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The goal of $16,500,000 is the largest maintenance sum ever sought by the federation for the support of its 116 affiliated hospitals, and health and social welfare institutions, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Lazrus, campaign chairman.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 27 -- Commercial bankers have failed in their obligation to resist the policies of the "political bankers" as typified by the Federal Reserve Board, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, charged here today. In an address before the Economic Club of Detroit, he asserted that the Federal Reserve System had "degenerated into a tool of the Treasury."
Registration in the city for the November election got off to a surprisingly slow start yesterday, the first day on which the booths were open for voters to qualify.

Paddleduck of the Greentree Stable came through with a thrilling victory in the Imperatrice Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Under a skillful ride by Teddy Atkinson the 3-year-old daughter of Blenheim fought off a closing bid by Sweet Dream of the Havahome Stable to score by a nose in the six-furlong event on the main course.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- The newspaper publishing business is rapidly approaching a critical period because of high labor and other costs, Thomas F. Mowle, controller of The Wall Street Journal, said today at the convention of the Institute of Newspaper Controllers and Finance Officers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Producers and importers of copper, lead, bismuth, zinc and cadmium may be asked to make voluntary set-asides of those scarce metals for the Government's materials stockpile.

The Bridgeport, Conn., Newfields-Steelers were admitted to the American Basketball League and the franchise of the Paterson, N. J., Crescents was transferred to Jess Weiner, Paterson textile man, at a two-day league meeting which ended here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- River traffic handled by the Federal Barge Lines increased markedly the first eight months of 1948 as compared with 1947.

The Federal Government should appropriate funds to insure training of all officers of the active Reserve and the armed services should give the maximum number of Reserves definite mobilization assignments, Col. Clarence E. Barnes, national president of the Reserve Officers Association, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Testimony indicating that the Federal Office of Education knows what it can say in behalf of democracy for use in public schools but does not know what it can say against communism was given today before a Senate Expenditures subcommittee.

The United Nations can take pride in having created one institution which is directly at work rebuilding human life, bringing hope where hope was dying and earning the respect of all its members. That agency is the International Children's Emergency Fund, which is reaching 4,500,000 children with supplementary feeding in twelve European countries and in China.
DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 27 -- Henry A. Wallace came back to the South today without fanfare or furor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- National Amateur Champion Richard Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles, and Glendale's Davis Cup star, Ted Schroeder, head the men's singles entries in the first annual United States hard-court tennis championships, which will be played Oct. 2-10.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The blockade of Berlin started 100 days ago today. The function of the Anglo-American airlift most of this time was to sustain the lives of 2,250,000 Berliners and to give time to the Western powers to negotiate for the restoration of their legal rights in the former German capital.

Distributors in this area, who already receive 3 or 4 cents a quart more for milk than do distributors in many comparable centers, are well able to absorb any increase in price to the farmer that goes into effect Oct. 1, Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh declared yesterday.
Smashing seas and howling gales on the North Atlantic slowed the United States liner America and the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday, delaying their arrivals here by at least a day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A Navy and Coast Guard expedition has returned to the United States from the Arctic with handwritten records left in the Polar regions more than forty years ago by Commdr. Robert E. Peary, discoverer of the North Pole.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that "leading men" in shipyards were supervisors under the Taft-Hartley Law and hence ineligible for membership in a rank and file union.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Calm reigned today in the wake of yesterday's moderately noisy celebration of the town's first National League pennant in thirty-four years.

Already the wise gardener, as he surveys the rapidly fading glory of his summer's work, is thinking about next spring. He knows fall is here; the postman has made its presence official by dropping the fall bulb catalogue in his mail box.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra Association announced today the cancellation of its 1948-49 concert season after deciding unanimously that it could not meet a union demand for increased pay for 102 members of the world-famed orchestra.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin today defended Britain's colonial policy, which had been attacked by some nations, and in an indirect reply to Russia warned he United Nations General Assembly that his Government would oppose the interference by other powers in its administration of non-self-governing territories.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Eastern Europe's reply to the Assembly speech of British Foreign Secretary Bevin came quickly today with a Czechoslovak charge that Britain was abandoning the ideas of the United Nations.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Four shipwreck victims, one of whom identified herself as Martha Sleeper, stage and screen actress, were recovering today from the effects of a ten-hour battle against the sea before their yacht sank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Immediate indictment of five persons for wartime atomic espionage, spying alleged to have been directed by Russian diplomatic representatives, was recommended tonight by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The eight horses the French Army team will use in the international military jumping at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 2-9 arrived aboard the United States Lines' American Shipper yesterday. The mounts, one of them injured in crossing, were in charge of Lieut. Guy Lefrant.
PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The chief delegate of Pakistan told the United Nations today his country would never accept the State of Israel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -- A reduction of 20 to 25 per cent in meats and perishables on the menus of United States Army personnel in Pacific areas may be expected as a result of the West Coast maritime strike, Brig. Gen. Paul F. Yount, chief of the Army Transportation Corps, said here today.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The high purposes and intensive efforts of the United Nations Economic and Sosial Council are being defeated by political wrangling in other bodies of the organization, Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon told the General Assembly today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- All deliveries of corn and soy beans sold at new seasonal low prices on the Board of Trade today, but the markets were irregular as a whole.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 -- Ambassador James Bruce's decision to fly back here to attend an opera performance with President Juan Peron on Oct. 12 has been taken as a gesture aimed at repairing promptly the United States-Argentine relations that again became strained Friday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 27 -- Acceleration of the Berlin airlift operations through removal from the Rhein-Main operations of all air passenger traffic is under study, Lieut. Gen. Curtis E. Le May said in farewell press conference this afternoon at Wiesbaden, headquarters of the United States Air Force in Europe.

Steuben Glass will open a new gallery tomorrow in its building at 718 Fifth Avenue by introducing a large number of new designs. Several of the new pieces are intended for everyday use, while the remainder are decorative vases to be incorporated into the home like works of art.

Anxious to remedy the deficiencies which cost Fordham a 53-14 setback at the hands of Lafayette Saturday, Coach Ed Danowski began overhauling the squad with a heavy scrimmage yesterday. Large scale contact drills, with special emphasis on line play, will be conducted all week in preparation for Saturday's encounter with Kings Point.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (UP) -- A Government and party publication today charged that religion was harmful to the Communist party and "fertilizes the soil" for hostile, anti-Soviet elements.

In an attempt to clear himself of the change that he was a member of the Communist party, Alger Hiss, former high State Department official, filed a slander action yesterday in Federal Court against his accuser, Whittaker Chambers, now a senior editor of Time magazine.

The American Broadcasting Company, which owns the Vanderbilt Theatre and holds under lease from the Shuberts the Ritz Theatre, has closed a deal whereby it will utilize Ben Marden's Playhouse for a period of one year as a radio and television studio.

A countrywide increase in automobile thefts is hampering interstate sales of cars, the annual convention of the National Used Car Dealers Association, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was told yesterday. The stolen-car rings were said to be most active in Massachusetts and Connecticut.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 27 -- The importance of the family as the center of recreation was brought out today in two phases of the National Recreation Congress, for which 1,000 recreation officials have assembled here.
BOSTON Sept. 27 (UP) -- The Braves gave World Series bleacherites a break today.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Three persons were seriously injured and a score less seriously hurt today in riots staged in Le Havre by de Gaullists and Communists. The latter were bent on "drowning" an effigy of Charles de Gaulle.

America's stake in the presen trend toward federation of the democratic Countries of Europe has been made the subject of a book by Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas. The author, who was a Rhodes scholar, business man, president of the University of Arkansas and member of both houses of the national legislature, was recently elected president of the American Committee for a Free and United Europe.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- Reserve requirements imposed on banks to restrict credit might reasonably be extended to insurance companies, savings and loan associations and finance concerns, Frank C. Rathje, former president of the American Bankers Association, declared here today.

Only through the removal of misunderstandings between nations will the basic freedoms of the peoples of the world be guaranteed, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday as he greeted at City Hall a group of South American newspaper publishers.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has agreed to serve as president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in the temporary absence of James G. Blaine, who is sailing on Thursday to assume his duties as chief of the Marshall Plan for Belgium.

The changing composition of assets of New York State commercial banks during the first half of 1948 resulted in interest and discount earnings on loans exceeding interest on Government securities for the first time in five years, Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, pointed out yesterday.

Color schemes consisting both of warm colors, which are stimulating, and of cool colors, which are soothing, are needed for well balanced rooms, Florence Terhune of the Bigelow-Sanford Company declared yesterday. She rejected monochromatic schemes for any room in the house, except possibly a bathroom or closet, because variations of one color are monotonous and tiresome to the eyes, she said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A United States reminder that the currencies of some member nations are over-valued and in need of "orderly adjustment" marked the opening session today of the third annual meeting of the Governors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund.

BONHAM, Tex., Sept. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Ambassador to Moscow, said tonight that he had reported to President Truman that United States relations with the Soviet Union had never been more "critical" than today, but later he changed the word "critical" to "serious" to indicate his belief that the United States was not "trembling on the brink of war."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 27 -- Termination on Friday of the incentive programs for Ruhr coal miners in favor of increases in their basic rations beginning then was announced today by the Germans' bizonal executive committee and the British-United States Control Office.

GENEVA, Sept. 27 -- Under the shadow of the Berlin crisis, top economic representatives of twenty-one European countries and the United States met here today to seek agreement on means of improving East-West trade.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Stewart Warner Corporation exhibited today a console which prints radio facsimile and provides ordinary radio programs.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- Declaring that inflationary pressures are threatening the "welfare of our entire economy," Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, called today on everyone, including the Government, to exercise restraint in spending.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Don Newcombe shaded Eddie Erautt in a mound duel tonight to give Montreal a 2-1 victory over Syracuse and a two-to-one game lead in the International League's final play-off series.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Armour Co. is working with underwriters on plans for sale of about $50,000,000 of debentures to raise funds for retirement of short term bank loans, it was reported today. Financial spokesmen said the packing house has found it required more money to carry high cost inventories, meat prices being even higher than they were a year ago.
Residents in five fashionable apartment buildings in Forest Hills, Queens, reported yesterday that a burglar, who has been seen twice, had been having "a party" since July 1 looting their homes.

A group of Latin American publishers were the guests yesterday of the Pan American Society of the United States at a tea and cocktail party at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. One hundred members of the society attended.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 28 -- The purser and a crew member of the excursion steamer Park City were found guilty in City Court today on charges involving them with the involuntary trip of a Bridgeport policeman to Port Jefferson, L.I., on Aug. 22.

A stamped notation on yellowed commitment papers, together with a record of exemplary conduct as a convict, freed Harold A. Seiler, 46 years old, from Clinton Prison at Dannemora, N.Y., yesterday, twenty years to the day from the time he was sentenced to serve forty years for robbery.
A fully equipped school unit for children afflicted with cerebral palsy is now being constructed at Public School 135, East Fifty-first Street and First Avenue.
Sea birds by the thousands flocked to Central Park late yesterday afternoon and feasted on an abundant hatch of flying aphids now making their annual autumnal appearance in this area.

The small hat was the theme of Saks Fifth Avenue's fall showing yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel. The designer was Tatiana du Plessix. Once again this accomplished milliner showed her ability to create delightful hats. She has a way of achieving newness without sensationalism.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 28 -President Truman made a slashing counterattack today on Republicans who are stressing "the Communist issue," contending that American Communists had "lined up solidly to help put a Republican President in the White House."

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Paris taxis will halt service tomorrow when the French Cabinet meets to act on price increases and to take new measures to offset them for the workers. The taximen are protesting against inflated prices.

Charges that Dr. W. E. B. DuBois, director of special research of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is being removed from his office by "an inside clique which does not represent the masses of Negroes who support the association," were made yesterday by a defense committee.
Following is the text of President Truman's speech yesterday at Oklahoma City as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
The dark-haired young widow of George Polk, the radio correspondent who was murdered last May in Greece, is preparing for a journalistic career.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -John Nance Garner, the former Vice President, still feels that recognition by this country of Soviet Russia in 1933 was a mistake.
Denver, Col., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 17 on bond issues amounting to $8,100,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey, said today that Republican Congressional leaders had failed to "finish the job" of labor legislation in the last Congress.

As 100 housewives picketed City Hall yesterday in protest against high milk prices, milk distributors were preparing notices that starting Friday consumers would have to pay a half-cent more for a quart of milk.

A new edition of the King James version of the Bible, designed to be read and understood easily, will be published Oct. 7, the Oxford University Press announced yesterday. At a luncheon in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Dr. E. Schuyler English, editor in chief of the work described special features that will make the volume specially suitable for young persons.

GENEVA, Sept. 28 -- Great Britain and Yugoslavia are on the verge of signing an important trade agreement, it was learned here today. In United States diplomatic circles, this accord, because of its nature and background, is regarded as the first successful exploitation by the West of the political dispute between Yugoslavia and the Communist Information Bureau.
After tangling with the pennantwinning Braves in the opener of their final series at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers still are in second place in the National League.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Popular support for Foreign Secretary Bevin's strong speech in the General Assembly yesterday was made evident here today. Mr. Bevin is always careful not to make any drastic move unless he knows public opinion is behind him and there is no doubt he was speaking for the vast majority of Britons.

One solution to the problem of finding the right colors in printed fabrics, wallpapers and hand weaves for a room was presented yesterday by L. Anton Maix at his decorator showroom, 162 East Fiftyninth Street. Under his plan the home decorator may have a blended or matched group of fabrics and wallpaper custom-colored and delivered in about three weeks.
MISSOULA, Mont., Sept. 28 -Following is the prepared text of the address by Governor Dewey here tonight:

By adopting a refunding policy aimed at establishing a basic 2 1/2 per-cent interest rate for new issues of Treasury bonds maturing in 1972, the Treasury could in time restore a flexible long-term interest rate structure and a free market for Government bonds without threatening financial markets with instability, August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Secretary Marshall approved tonight the text of the identical notes that three Western powers will send to the United Nations asking that its Security Council discuss the Berlin blockade.

Of forty-eight advertising agencies queried in an informal survey, only three are buying FM radio time and only four expect to in the foreseeable future, it was reported yesterday by Kenneth Godfrey, 4-A's staff executive, at the FM Association's annual convention in Chicago.
BOTOGA, Columbia, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A coal and iron mining and smelting company capitalized at 100,000,000 pesos ($58,000,000) has been organized formally here.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, called war "the least acceptable solution" for the world's problems in an informal address yesterday to 1,100 Columbia College students in the McMillin Academic Theatre.

In a speech in which he placed France solidly at the side of the United States and Britain, Foreign Minister Schuman yesterday arraigned Soviet Russia before the General Assembly of the United Nations for resorting to force in Berlin and appealed to the United Nations to put an end to Russia blockade of that city.

Negotiations between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and a committee representing forty Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators continued yesterday under the auspices of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 28 -Packaging of material so that it was immediately usable when delivered to far places was one of three equal parts of the supply system, "the real secret weapon which won the war," it was declared here today by Admiral Louis Denfeld, Chief of Naval Operations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Commander in Germany, believes that the military strength of Russia has been greatly over-estimated and consequently he is confident that the Soviet is not deliberately going to precipitate war over the Berlin question, it was reported at a news conference today by Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat, of Arkansas.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers, in a sporting gesture, today withdrew a waiver claim to Rookie Tackle Dick Loepfe of the Chicago Cardinals, affording the National Football League champions a replacement for Stan Mauldin, who died of a heart attack last week-end.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -Amid the drab setting of a gray afternoon in Shibe Park, with only 9,051 onlookers cheering and jeering their efforts, the Yankees today saw their pennant hopes receive a staggering blow in the short ribs as they lost the opener of their three-game series with the Athletics, 5 to 2.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Formation of a permanent common military organization for defense of Western Europe was officially announced today at the close of the two-day meeting of the National Defense Ministers of France, Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Park Avenue, the attraction is "Hamlet," the British-made screen version of the Shakespeare tragedy produced and directed by and starring Sir Laurence Olivier as the melancholy Dane.

Your edition of Sept. 20 contained a letter by the Rev. Dr. Roderick Wheeler in which he affirms that there is no religious persecution in Spain. In support of this contention he cites the fact that I, as a Protestant minister, visited Spain, moved freely about with a score of fellow-Protestant clergymen and attended services in Protestant churches.

This summer has seen an unprecedented amount of automobiles on the highways, unprecedented congestion at intersections, and a proportionate increase in new drivers. I have seen cases where "learner drivers" were the cause of added congestion and accidents.

The stock market rebounded yesterday, following Monday's sharp slump, a performance which it has given repeatedly recently. Prices recovered as much as 2 points as a result of professional buying centered in the oils and rails.

Determined that Fordham will be fully prepared to meet Kings Point Saturday, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday conducted the second of a series of heavy contact scrimmages, placing principal emphasis on defensive line play.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- Despite national advertising and modern merchandising methods, the American people at present are drinking more moderately than ever and per capita consumption of liquor now is less than one-half of what it was 100 years ago, it was declared here today by W. W. Wachtel, president of the Calvert Distillers Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, told a National Press Club audience today that "the future of the world is at stake" in the Marshall Plan concept of international cooperation and called for its extension into the field of social, political and defense activities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The mistreatment of soldier-inmates of an Army rehabilitation center at Wuerzburg, Germany, in the winter of 1947 was acknowledged conditionally today by the Department of the Army.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Gradual elimination of the flat city-wide fare and substitution of either a zone fare of the expresslimited-local type to obtain the greatest net revenue was urged on the nation's transit companies here today.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 -- The national commission of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, in session here, is discussing its role in a divided world. While this is the first time UNESCO has admitted even to itself that the world is divided, it ought to know ,what it is talking about, for this is one branch of the United Nations the Soviet Union has never joined.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 28 -- With gold coverage reaching a record low at 31.3 per cent, Finance Minister Havenga told the South African Parliament today that the Government intended to bring the statutory reserve ratio from 30 to 25 per cent "as in the United States."

With the greatest of ease after having taken the lead with a little less than half a mile to go, Miss Request won the $58,700 Ladies Handicap before 18,654 racegoers at Belmont Park yesterday. It was the seventy-eighth running of the oldest race in the land for fillies and mares, and victory in it was an old story to the rider of Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's 3-year-old filly.

A biography of a Maine Congregational minister, "who tackled problems head-on and scorned diplomacy as artful cunning," will be brought out by Macmillan on Oct. 19, under the title "Jonathan Fisher, Maine Parson." It is written by Mary Ellen Chase, Professor of English Literature at Smith College and author of several books.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, will speak tomorrow night at the dinner in the Commodore Hotel opening the campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it had signed a leasehold agreement with the Navy for thirty-three acres of land and buildings on the northeast channel of Port Newark.

Portraiture en masse was the feature of the Washington Square Outdoor Art Show late yesterday afternoon when thirteen youngsters from Harlem and the Bronx sat for ten of the show's professional artists.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 -- The Yankees and Red Sox, who failed to help themselves this afternoon, got none from the White Sox tonight. Against the pennant-bound Indians, the tail-end Chicagoans never were in the ball game, a fact perceived early and duly appreciated by 60,405 fans, who cheered their favorites' every move in an 11-0 victory.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Despite the great public interest in today's address by Paul-Henri Spaak, the Belgian Premier, no official text of his address was available tonight as the usually efficient United Nations verbatim reporting service broke down.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 -- To correct the shortage of venture capital, industry needs an "incentive program for the forgotten man -- the stockholder." Gwilym A. Price, president, Westinghouse Electric Corporation, told the annual convention of the American Bankers Association in session here today.

Mr. Petrillo usually can be counted upon for something, even in the middle of the week. A few days ago the papers reported that he had reversed his field with regard to harmonicas and those, who play them.

The plan for citizen participation in the planting of flowering shrubs and trees in parks and along parkways which was announced to the public yesterday by the Park Association of New York City has already produced an enthusiastic response. Nearly a half hundred civic and other organizations have volunteered their cooperation.

Marcel Cerdan and Tony Zale were the guests of honor at a luncheon of the Boxing Writers Association at, Toots Shor's yesterday. The newly crowned middleweight champion of the world and his immediate predecessor were by no means the only important ring personalities in attendance, however.

Representatives of eight seceding locals of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, voted last night to set up a new joint body known as the Distributive Trades Council of New York, Arthur Osman, president of the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, Local 65, was elected president.

The Staghorn Sumac is autumn's outrider. When the goldenrods' pennants are unfurled and wild asters' faces reflect the blue September sky the sumac lights its maroon candles. You will see them on the typical scraggly-armed candelabra beside sunny country roads, along the brushedged fringes of sidehill orchards, around the stonepiles in upland fields and along pasture lanes.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday, and final prices were 12 to 27 points net higher.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Two new developments, both employing frequency modulation, which are called "storecasting" and "transit radio" were described here today at the convention of the FM Association.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Miss Louise Nichols of Hudson River gained her second straight victory in Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association one-day competition, and her third such triumph of the season, at St. Andrews Golf Club today.
the beatrice foodscompany and its...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today that farmers would be permitted to produce cotton free of Government crop controls again next year. He added that this decision would not affect the price support for the 1949 crop.

A demonstration against the Board of Higher Education was held yesterday outside the office of Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, when fifty student demanded an explanation of the board's decision exonerating Prof. William E. Knickerbocker of charges of anti-Semitism.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 28 -Declaring that an economic collapse in this country was not inevitable, Gov. Earl Warren of California said here tonight that a return to the fundamental virtues of industry, thrift and unity in government could avert it.

A COUPLE of years ago -- or so the rumors go -- Lou Perini of the Boston Braves was offered a fabulous sum for his team by a Los Angeles syndicate which proposed to shift the franchise to the Coast. The Boston president flatly refused. "If the Braves were to go to California," he said naively, "then I wouldn't be able to see them play every day."

Many parties were given at the dinner dance for the benefit of the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind held last night at the formal opening for this season of the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza.
MAYPORT, Fla., Sept. 28 (UP) -A sloop was towed into port here today, piloted by a ship's cook who reported that the master had been swept overboard.

Cuban buyers have resumed purchases of American rayon goods but are proceeding slowly in view of the release of heavy shipments that were held up during the sixty-day embargo period, it was learned from New York exporters yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that industrial production picked up in August and early September. This increase offset most of the decline that occurred in July during the vacation season lull.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet press said today that British Foreign Secretary Bevin's speech to the United Nations raised the possibility that two camps would form in the United Nations, each going its separate way.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Financial observers noted today an unusual trick of the market -- a rise in the price of both gold and Government bonds on the same day.

Commission house and trade buying, coupled with scattered short covering, advanced cottonseed oil futures prices on the New York Produce Exchange 40 to 60 points a pound yesterday. The market felt the influence of a stronger lard and grain tone and maintained most of the early gains, with oil closing 30 to 50 points net higher.

After spending more than two years in prison, nine months of that time as an inmate in Sing Sing's death house, 21-year-old John Valletutti walked out yesterday from the Brooklyn City Prison a free man.

Heavy contact work began for Columbia's Lions at Baker Field yesterday, as Coach Lou Little started preparing his squad for Saturday's game with Harvard at Cambridge. Defensive maneuvers against the single wing and continued offensive work on winged-T plays took up most of the practice session.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- New Yorkers soon will be able to buy powder puffs and other items in the same store they purchase pork chops and canned peaches. Grocers will add nongrocery items to stock in attempt to compensate for the decline in dollar volume expected to result from lowered food prices.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 -- The Argentine police were in possession tonight of two submarine guns, seven revolvers, five automatic pistols and four home-made bombs that they will seek to link with an alleged plot to assassinate President Juan Peron and his wife on Oct. 12. So far, twenty-eight arrests have been made but four of the suspects already have been released.

The American Communist party has embarked on a propaganda campaign against the Bernadotte plan, which would revise the original Palestine partition plan as approved by the United Nations, it became evident yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The United Nations General Assembly, beset by complex, political problems, was asked today to concern itself with "such homely things as a loaf of bread, a bowl of rice and a cup of milk in a child's hands."

SHUSHAN, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- We had two reasons for a trip to this little village -- one was that we always thought of this section as being typical, in hunting and fishing potentialities, of the state, and, second, that Lee Wulff is perched on the bank of the Battinkill there and we wanted to see his new movies.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Two Governors took time out from political campaigning tonight to honor a young girl golfer who said she was so nervous she couldn't remember her speech.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The United Nations General Committee today included in the agenda of its political committee India's proposal to discuss the treatment of Indians in South Africa after the chairman. Herbert D. Evatt, had promised E. H. Louw, South African delegate, that he would be allowed to challenge the right of the United Nations to examine that subject.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 28 -- The first two major commercial products resulting from fundamental and applied research were previewed for the press today at the 261-acre newly completed research center of the B.F. Goodrich Company at Brecksville, Ohio.
MONTREAL, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The National Hockey League closed its doors to Donald C. Gallinger of Port Colborne, Ont.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -Dr. C. Charles Burlingame of Hartford, Conn., and New York City, today called for a "housecleaning" in psychiatry, with less emphasis on sex.

In a demonstration without precedent in the city's post-war industrial experience, 50,000 unionized dressmakers will quit work at 3 o'clock this afternoon as a token of their determination to frustrate attempts by racketeers to obtain a new foothold in the multi-million dollar garment industry.

The record companies decided yesterday to seek a meeting with James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, in a further step looking toward an agreement that would end the union's ban on the manufacture of new disks.

ROME, Sept. 28 -- Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza strenuously defended his policy, which aims at the creation of a European union, in a speech today at the close of the debate in the Chamber of Deputies on his ministry's budget. He said that a European union was the only alternative to a third world war.

The nation's leading oil companies do not intend to increase their posted price for crude oil, despite the action of the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday in raising by 35 cents a barrel the posted price on all grades of crude oil bought by it in the Southwest.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (AP) -Victor Seixas of Philadelphia and Herbie Flam of Los Angeles proved to be the upset kids in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A full-scale Congressional investigation of the reduction of Frau Ilse Koch's war crimes sentence from life imprisonment to four years began today behind closed doors with public hearings promised for a later date.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Israel would defy any United Nations effort to impose the plan of the late Count Folke Bernadotte as it stands but would consider a compromise giving up part of Jerusalem and part of the Negeb, a source in close touch with the Israeli Government said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -Counsel for William W. Remington said today a regional board had ruled there are "reasonable grounds to believe" the suspended Commerce Department official was "disloyal." He announced that Mr. Remington will appeal to President Truman's loyalty review board.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Grain markets moved up rapidly yesterday on the Board of Trade under the leadership of corn.

The Giants were mathematically eliminated as a contender for fourth place in the National League yesterday when they lost the abbreviated nightcap of a doubleheader with the Phillies, 6 -- 3, in six innings. The New Yorkers won the first game, 6 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A self-described former Communist today called the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, the "largest Communist-dominated organization in the United States" and the "pride and joy" of the Communist party.

Net deposits in mutual savings banks of New York State increased $12,990,614 in August bringing total deposits to $10,112,266,619, it was announced yesterday by John Adikes, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York and head of the Jamaica Savings Bank, Jamaica, N.Y.

MISSOULA, Mont., Sept. 28 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today ruled out any compromise of American principles as a means of resolving the war tensions caused by the Berlin crisis. Peace could not be attained through appeasement, he declared, adding that the American people are united in support of the stand taken by their representatives at Paris.

The ranks of the Grand Army of the Republic would be a very thin line now, even if all survivors were able to answer a roll-call. There are said to be twenty-eight members alive; about a dozen other Union veterans, not members of the G.A.R., are also on government pension rolls.
LOUISVILLE, Sept. 28 -- WHAS, Kentucky's oldest radio station, yesterday was sold to the Crosley Broadcasting Corporation subject to approval of the Federal Communications Commission.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,884, compared with 2,060 last week and 1,349 in the corresponding week of 1947, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 947 arrivals yesterday against 978 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Truman Administration, through the Department of Justice, raised today the possibility of a Federal investigation into Representative J. Parnell Thomas conduct of his Congressional office.

Civic groups opposing the projected dissolution of the Youthbuilders Bureau of the Board of Education organized in protest yesterday. They questioned the "validity" of a report by six assistant superintendents of schools that called for the bureau to be "discontinued as rapidly as feasible."

John D. Rockefeller Jr., senior vice president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, will be acting president while James G. Blaine, the president, is in Belgium for the Economic Cooperation Administration, but Mr. Rockefeller will not preside at monthly meetings or make public addresses, the chamber announced yesterday.

Gerald M. Mayer, managing director of the International Division of the Motion Picture Association of America and representative of the Motion Picture Export Association, will leave for Rio de Janeiro by air on Friday in "an effort to avert a break in film relations with Brazil," the association reported yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Large industrial users of electric power have been asked by Niagara Hudson Power Corporation to reduce their consumption 15 per cent. Eighty-nine plants served by the Buffalo Niagara Electric Company in western New York are affected. Buffalo Niagara is the western operating subsidiary of Niagara Hudson.

Four new issues of railroad equipment trust certificates and public utility bonds and preferred stock were sold at competitive bidding yesterday to banking syndicates. The total par value of the offerings was $25,150,000. Awards were as follows:
VIENNA, Sept. 28 -- "The political police wrote out 'confessions' and said that we must sign them or else. So we signed them."

Arturo Toscanini will return as conductor of the NBC Symphony Orchestra for the eleventh consecutive year on Saturday, Oct. 23, at 6:30 P.M., opening the new season with a six-week cycle of music by Brahms. Vladimir Horowitz, the pianist, will be guest soloist on the opening program, playing the Piano Concerto in B Flat.

Wallpapers in deep charcoals, cocoa browns and dull greens, colors popular today, were among new wallpapers and fabrics shown yesterday by Emily B. Hunter of F. Schumacher and Company, who spoke on "The Changing Scene" at Gertz Department Store, Jamaica, Queens.

Joe Kipness, co-sponsor of the hit musical, "High Button Shoes," is a smart producer. Rather than bring in a flop, he and his partners, John Pransky and Al Beckman, have decided to withdraw their new $200,000 musical, "That's the Ticket!" at the end of the week in Philadelphia.
Twenty-nine scientists and engineers from the New York area received yesterday the President's Certificate of Merit for outstanding contributions to the armed services during World War II.
WASHINGTON Sept. 28 -- The United States has asked Russia to reactivate negotiations for a settlement of her wartime lend-lease account of $11,000,000,000, it was learned tonight.

The report of the House Un-American Activities Committee on its investigation of foreign spying on wartime atomic energy experiments is hardly the "shocking" revelation of feverish spy activity, wholesale traitorous conduct by American scientists and official inaction that an anonymous committee source had predicted on Saturday it would be.

The first post-war shipment of French Haviland china will arrive in the United State in December, Theodore Haviland II, disclosed in an interview yesterday. Last supplies of the well-known merchandise were received in this country in May, 1940, one month before France capitulated to Germany, he said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -Paul G. Hoffman, foreign aid administrator, told a delegation of Southern Congressman and tobacco growers today that he will not use the European Recovery Program to "distort" foreign trade for the benefit of American producers.

Resumption of private foreign investment in Japanese industries and services is essential "if the economy of Japan is to recover to a point where it will no longer be a burden to the American taxpayer," according to a report yesterday by the Far East-America Council of Commerce and Industry, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28 -Princeton University, faced with its largest athletic deficit since the depression years, has eliminated junior varsity squads in all except three sports in an effort to make its athletic program selfsupporting, R. Kenneth Fairman, director of physical education, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Wheland Company, foundry operator, of Chattanooga, Tenn., filed yesterday with Tom Clark, Attorney General, a memorandum in which it contended that the KaiserFrazer Corporation was trying to shift the issue in the fight over who should operate a $28,000,000 Government-owned blast furnace in Cleveland.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, and Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education, gave the city's school system, which employs 40,000 persons, a clean bill of health yesterday with respect to Communist infiltration.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP) -The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics today revealed major strides in supersonic speedengine research, including a ramjet test missile clocked at more than 1,600 miles an hour in drop tests.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 -- Red Sox pennant prospects were dealt a painful jolt today at Fenway Park, where, before 10,485 disappointed fans, the seventh-place Senators, in one productive inning, accumulated enough runs to dump Joe McCarthy's squad into defeat, 4 to 2.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -West Coast shipowners were challenged today by Vincent J. Malone, president of the Independent Marine Firemen's Union, and signer of a non-Communist affidavit, to abandon their concentration on the Communist issue in favor of getting the maritime strike settled, and the 375 West Coast ships operating.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 28 -- A psychiatrist and a Government specialist on rural life emphasized in almost identical words today the importance of encouraging children to cultivate their natural impulse for play as a source of recreative experience through life.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Sympathy with Communists is enough to cause dismissal from the Federal Security Agency, Administrator Oscar R. Ewing today told the Senate investigating committee now probing his conflict with John W. Studebaker, former Education Commissioner.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 28 -In five meetings with Yale, Rip Engle's Brown football teams have left the field in triumph twice. Considering that the Bruins have beaten the Elis only ten times in all in the total of fifty-three games played, their mild-mannered, prematurely gray-haired coach has nothing to apologize for.
The auctioneer's hammer mingled with the roar of trains yesterday in the BMT subway station at the southwest corner of Fourteenth Street and the Avenue of the America.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Principal beneficiaries under terms of the will of Dr. Peter C. Cornell are his daughter, Katharine Cornell, actress, and a charitable trust fund.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Cessation of yesterday's slight selling and buying back by bears on the last day of the account led to some recovery in the stock markets here today.

Net earnings of the Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company For the first half of this year were $5,754,745, after taxes and all charges, the largest amount for a six-month period in the history of the company, according to the report issued in Chicago yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of directors.

The beginning of classes yesterday at New York University provided no respite for the Violet football squad as Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin sent his undermanned team through a vigorous drill in preparation for Saturday's game with Springfield College at Springfield, Mass.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- The Riskin Brothers, Everett and Robert, today announced the formation of a new independent film producing company, Equitable Pictures, which has purchased "Half an Angel," a story by George Carleton Brown, from Metro-Goldwin-Mayer to serve as the basis for its first production project.

Alexander Koral, who faced dismissal from his Board of Education job because of his refusal to answer questions of the House American Activities Committee, has applied for retirement on the ground of disability, it was learned yesterday.

A massive golden anniversary planting project, in which all citizens of the city were urged to participate, was started yesterday by the Park Association of New York at a conference in the arsenal in Central Park.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Premier of Belgium, appealed to the Soviet Union today to "make a new start" and "relight the flame that burned in us at San Francisco."

The Permanente Metals Corporation had net earnings in the fiscal year ended on May 31, last, of $9,244,338 after taxes and all charges, equal to $3.55 a share on 2,600,000 shares now outstanding, Henry J. Kaiser, president, reported in the annual statement issued yesterday.
Benjamin Codack, 25 years old, of Akron, Ohio, overestimated the convertibility of several automobiles yesterday and wound up in Bellevue Hospital.

Students at a new college in Liberia now being built by the Protestant Episcopal Church will be taught to plant their own crops and feed themselves, Bishop Bravid W. Harris of the Missionary District of Liberia said yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- For the first time in its history the Security Council was faced today with a harsh public debate on the validity of the credentials of a delegation chief demanding the right to speak for a state.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Al Rosen of the Indians and Ray Sanders of the Braves, two substitutes for disabled players, were included in a roster of eligible players for the 1948 world series announced today by Walter Mulbry, secretary to Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler.

The discovery by a Navy and Coast Guard expedition of handwritten records left in the Polar regions more than forty year ago by Comdr. Robert E. Peary focused attention yesterday on the significance of his Arctic discoveries in the light of diminishing geographical distances.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- As a prelude to the twenty-fifth championship tournament of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association which starts a two-day stand here tomorrow, a field of thirty-four teams toured Westchester Country Club's south course today in Scotch foursomes competition, getting in both a round of familiarity with the layout as well as a chance at prizes.

The Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Plaza, sixty-five stories above the city's streets, was the modern stage last night for a dinner that went back half a century in its elaborate elegance. It was the kind of superb meal that made the old Delmonico's celebrated during a period when one gladly sacrificed avoirdupois to appetite.

After pulling itself steadily upward through its first week at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night took a decided tumble. The feature of the program was the revival of Leonide Massine's "Rouge et Noir," set to Shostakovich's First Symphony and with decor and costumes by Matisse, first seen here nine years ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Registration statements covering 582,000 shares of common and 63,000 shares of preferred stocks were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- In an analysis of the reasons for the main United Nations difficulties Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight cited a different conception of human rights in the Soviet Union from that held by most other countries as the principal stumbling block to international understanding.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Excerpts from Belgian Premier Paul-Henri Spaak's speech in the United Nations Assembly today follow:

Lawyers are in a better position to establish world peace than politicians, diplomats or soldiers, Bishop Bartholomew J. Eustace of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Camden, N.J., declared yesterday at the annual red mass celebrated at St. Andrew's Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Hayes Place, to mark the new court season.

DALLAS, Sept. 28 -- Henry A. Wallace called tonight for an investigation of "recurrent war scares" by a fact-finding commission of representative Americans, as he campaigned quietly at unsegregated meetings in his second invasion of the South.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge and Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century tied for low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Somerset Hills County Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black today stayed a temporary injunction which kept the name of Representative Lyndon Johnson off the Texas ballot as Democratic nominee for Senator.

TOKYO, Sept. 28 -- Foreign Office figures released today revealed that an estimated 140,000 former soldiers and nurses of Japan's once powerful and veteran Kwantung Army were either serving with the Chinese Communist forces in Manchuria or were living independently in Red-held areas.

By a margin of four to one, employes formerly represented by a left-wing Congress of Industrial Organizations union voted yesterday to be represented by an American Federation of Labor affiliate. Harold P. Spivak, counsel for the Motion Picture Home Office Employes Union, Local H-63, AFL, announced that the vote had been cast by office employes of United Artists in a National Labor Relations Board election.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Jack Banta pitched five-hit ball to blank Syracuse tonight, 4 -- 0, as Montreal took a three-to-one lead in the best of seven games Governors' Cup series before 110,622.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -Differences "once held irreconcilable" between Northern Baptists and Disciples of Christ have been settled, according to a, progress report presented to the annual assembly of the international convention of the Disciples of Christ today.

Robert G. Thompson, 33-year-old state chairman of the Communist party, accused the police and the Queens District Attorney's office yesterday of making an inadequate investigation of an attack upon him last week by three men in Sunnyside, Queens.
Federal employes as a group have become the target of a "smear" campaign, it was charged yesterday by Edward H. Foley Jr., Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

Replacement of strategic materials "represents a challenge to the plastics industry," it was declared yesterday at a "remobilization" meeting held yesterday by the Society of the Plastics Industry in the Commodore Hotel. The conference, devoted to surveying current and future uses of plastics by the armed forces, will continue this morning.

Michael J. Obermeier, admitted former Communist whom the Immigration and Naturalization Service has recommended for deportation, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on three counts charging him with false statements in applying for citizenship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today ordered an early hearing to determine whether "public interest" would be served by the transfer of routes now flown by National Airlines, Inc., to other established air carriers.

Spiraling prices for new autos will place the burden of supplying motor transportation on used cars, it was emphasized yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the National Used Car Dealers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Reds became co-tenants with the Cubs of the National League cellar today as they dropped a 6-to-2 decision to the Chicagoans.
RHODES. Sept. 28 (UP) -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche today called for "urgent measures" to prevent the wrecking of the shaky Palestine truce by "an unbridled band of Jewish terrorists."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The bottle containing messages left in the Arctic more than forty years ago by Comdr. Robert E. Peary was found this year as the result of an afterthought in the wake of a near-tragedy.

At a time when official policy is directed toward stabilizing and if possible reducing the cost of living and when production of some major farm commodities seems likely to be ample if not superabundant, it is doubtful whether mandatory price support at 90 per cent of parity will be conducive to desirable readjustments in prices and output, The Guaranty Survey, published today, observes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A plan for military aid to Western Europe, patterned on the European Recovery Program, will be one of the first problems that will be submitted to the Eighty-first Congress next January, it was learned today.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- Acting Governor Joe R. Hanley, in a proclamation designating Oct. 1 to 8 as newspaper week, declared today that no provision in the Constitution of the United States was more vital to American liberties than the amendment securing the freedom of the press.

A preview was held yesterday afternoon in the galleries of the National Academy at which announcement was made of the prizes, awards, fellowships and calendar purchases in connection with the fifth annual Pepsi-Cola competition and exhibition -- the total this year being $41,500.

Celebrating 100 years of law reform, New York University's Law Center opened a three-day symposium yesterday in the Brevoort Hotel to discuss the need for further codification of New York State's code of procedure. The program is being held in honor of David Dudley Field, an outstanding jurist who in 1848 drafted the pioneer code.
The comments made in your editorial entitled "Housing Report" appearing on Sept. 27, indicate a conclusion formed without full consideration having been given to both side of a serious question.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 28 -With a field of eighty-two teams competing, the principal honors of the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament over the Century Country Club course today went to Dan Galgano of Woodway and Peter Gruntal of Sunningdale, who combined for a winning best-ball score of 64.

With silver-plated shovels, Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials broke ground yesterday for two low-rent housing projects in the Eastchester section of the Bronx that will provide homes for 2,140 families and an estimated 7,831 persons.

A five-alarm fire, which spread rapidly early today as it ate through rolls of newsprint and piles of crated merchandise, swept the block-long loading platform of the New York Central Railroad on the north side of Thirty-sixth Street between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues.

Thirty of forty-two families that were forced to evacuate four tenements on West End Avenue between Sixtieth and Sixty-first Streets because of a dangerous seepage of gasoline into the cellars were permitted to return to their homes yesterday.

Any chance of the city's registration for the November election reaching the expected record total of 4,000,000 disappeared early this morning, when tabulation was completed for the first two days of the six-day period. It showed that 865,547 voters had qualified in that period, compared with 944,450 for the first two days in 1944, the last Presidential election year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Currency devaluation "across the board" as a cure for the balanceof-payments difficulties besetting most countries was rejected as an over-simplification today in the annual report of the International Monetary Fund to its Governors.

Flames that spread rapidly despite efforts to smother them with chemicals, burned out the fuselage of a DC-4 transatlantic passenger plane before the Trans World Airline hangar at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon, while the forty-six-passenger machine was being made ready for a flight to Egypt.
TSINGTAO, China, Sept. 28: -The fall of Tsinan to the Communists last week leaves the port city Tsingtao, where the United States Navy is based, without a Provincial capital and without a hinterland.

As a result of last week's television broadcast "Operation Success," sponsored by the Veterans Administration, three disabled veterans of World War II have won on-the-job training opportunities in private employ.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Soviet press suggested today that the United Nations was being broken up and that the East-West camps might go separate ways. Two years ago, this would have created consternation at the State Department.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- German police in the American sector today confiscated dozens of tons of coal and food from trucks that bore Soviet license plates. Tonight the Soviet authorities banned Soviet truck traffic through the American sector of the city.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 28 -Alben W. Barkley, Democratic candidate for Vice President, penetrated this Republican fastness last night to accuse Governor Dewey of ignorance of the real meaning of atomic energy.
New York is one of the filthiest cities in the world, Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican, told the City Council yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J, Sept. 28 -- The New Jersey Federation of Labor today endorsed the candidacy of President Truman and called on the Progressive party leader, Henry A. Wallace, to withdraw from the November election to assure victory for the Democrats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Manufacturers sales during August recovered from a July dip by rising $1,500,00,000 to a total volume of $17,900,000,000, equaling the figure for last June.

The status of union contracts held by major department stores was left obscure yesterday when Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally denied on procedural grounds a motion by the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, to restrain officers of its seceded local at R. H. Macy Co. from carrying on the local's affairs.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept 29 (AP) -- With Bob Morgan stroking a three-run home run and three other hits for a four-for-four performance, the Montreal Royals downed the Syracuse Chiefs, 7 to 3, tonight to win the International League's Shaughnessy play-offs.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 29 -- Indian and Hyderabadi military and police have disarmed 7,000 Arabs who were part of Hyderabad's irregular forces and arrangements are being made to repatriate them to Arabia, according to dispatches from Secunderabad, in Hyderabad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Richard C. Patterson Jr., New York businessman and former Ambassador to Yugoslavia, received a recess appointment from President Truman today as Ambassador to Guatemala. He succeeds Edwin J. Kyle, who recently resigned.

Derailment of a seven-car West End BMT local train about to enter the De Kalb Avenue station in Brooklyn yesterday disrupted local service on the line for nearly six hours. The accident occurred at 8:35 A. M.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Deacon Bill McKechnie came out from the shower room, reached for a towel and displayed his best smile.

Consolidated Railroads of Cuba and its subsidiaries had a net income of $5,001,760 for the fiscal year ended on June 30 after fixed charges, contingent interest and other deductions, it was reported yesterday. This compares with a net income of $5,082,673 in the preceding fiscal year.

Underwriting syndicates launched yesterday financing operations involving the issuance of more than $100,000,000 worth of new bonds and stock of industrial, railroad and public utility enterprises. The offerings are as follows:

GREAT FALLS, Mont., Sept. 29 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, directing his remarks at the heads of foreign governments, gave notice today that the United States would insist on "peace with honor."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture are working on a plan for shipping 140,000,000 bushels of corn to Europe this year to prevent a threatened market glut at home, it was disclosed today.

Impact of spending by the Economic Cooperation Administration is now beginning to be felt in commercial channels, with the volume likely to increase progressively from this point on, A. N. Gentes, second vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, said yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- The pennant flame continued to flicker faintly at Fenway Park today though the shadow of a Cleveland triumph in the race to the American League flag grew darker and more threatening as time was running out.
