LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The start of new account spurred business in the stock market here today. Buying, which was largely professional was seen at the opening, and with the public joining in later, prices improved in all sections.

Madison Square Garden transformed its arena into a wild west corral last night. The top hands of the World's Championship Rodeo put $84,000 in prize money on the line; imported 700 head of wild critters, and brought in 200 iron-muscled cowboys from the open spaces.

Citation's earnings for the year went past the half-million mark and the esteem in which he is held soared to a new high when he ran off with the $29,250 Sysonby Mile at Belmont Park yesterday. It was as easy as eating pecan pie.

The Russian Consulate General at 7 East Sixty-first Street, which had been occupied but not functioning since its head, Jacob M. Lomakin, was recalled as a result of the Kasenkina case, was closed and locked just before noon yesterday.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses gave unqualified endorsement yesterday to the Citizens Golden Anniversary Planting Program initiated by the Park Association of New York.

The furs shown by Dein-Bacher of the Waldorf at the hotel yesterday were impressive in their elegance of detail. The attention of the audience was called repeatedly to the treatments of collars and cuffs.

In a perturbing blow to their world series hopes, the Braves yesterday lost the services of Jeff Heath, their principal left-handed power hitter. The veteran outfielder suffered a fracture of the lower left tibia and a severe dislocation of the left ankle sliding into the plate in the sixth inning of a game against the Dodgers at Ebbets Field.

Many parties will be given at the autumn tea dance in aid of the School of Social Service at Fordham University to be held this afternoon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. Mrs. Basil Harris Jr. heads the committee for the event, which will mark the twenty-third anniversary of the founding of the school.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Secretary General Lie's proposal to tax all United Nations employes under a system of staff contributions and at the same time to increase present net salaries 10 to 40 per cent was approved in principle today by the General Assembly's administrative budgetary committee.

BUFFALO, Sept. 29 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, assailed the Republican party and the Eightieth Congress on the cost of living and labor legislation issues in an address at the Hotel Lafayette to an overflow audience.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 29 (UP) -- Federal Judge John W. Delehant said today that he would rule next month on a defense plea that further action in the Government's railroad anti-trust suit be delayed.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission authorized the Niagara Falls Power Company today to increase rates two-tenths of a cent a kilowatt hour for special power supplied to large industrial customers.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Playing in her first senior tournament, Mrs. R. B. Meckley of Washington, D.C., tied Mrs. Russell Holman of the Innis Arden Country Club, Old Greenwich, for the lead in the twenty-third United States senior championship over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Central Arizona Light and Power Company, Phoenix, Ariz., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 300,000 shares of no par value common stock to be offered publicly at a price to be filed by amendment.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- Robert Mitchum, film actor who was arrested Aug. 31, pleaded not guilty in Superior Court today to an indictment charging possession of marijuana and conspiracy to violate the state narcotics law. His trial was set for Nov. 22.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Julius Emspak, secretary-treasurer of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, and Russell A. Nixon, its Washington representative, refused today to tell a House Labor subcommittee whether they were members of the Communist party.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A suit charging violation of the Sherman anti-trust laws and asking millions in damages has been filed in Federal District Court by Seatrain Lines, Inc., against five steamship companies.
ROME, Sept. 29 -- Pope Pius appealed yesterday for international cooperation in a world-wide drive to eliminate or at least lessen the dangers that beset young girls at their first contact with life.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Duke of Edinburgh, who with Princess Elizabeth will fill a number of public engagements during King George VI and Queen Elizabeth's six-month tour of New Zealand and Australia next year, will be placed on half pay by the Royal Navy at his own request until the King and Queen return.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- The Yankees' shoulders haven't been pinned to the mat yet, even if the clock is now running out on them at an alarming rate.

In seven of the eight quarters since July, 1946, men's clothing manufacturers have produced more coats than retailers sold, according to a statement yesterday by the Market Planning Service, a division of the National Credit Office, 2 Park Avenue.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

Unless members of Local 906 of the News Distribution Employes Union receive salary increases and shorter working hours than are called for in the present contract with the Union News Company, which operates newsstands in railroad terminals and subways, they will consider the possibility of a strike at a membership meeting today in the Capitol Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, told the banquet of the National Guard Association tonight that in his opinion war was not imminent and that, "in the absence of some accidental or unintentional occurrence," he did not envision war in near future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The President's Preliminary Conference on Industrial Safety closed today with the announcement of an accident-reduction program on which 400 experts will work until the general conference is held in March, 1949.

" Edward, My Son," the Robert Morley-Noel Langley play which has been a solid success in London since opening there in May, 1947, will receive its first New York exposure this evening at the Martin Beck Theatre. The importers are Gilbert Miller and Henry Sherek.

The formalization of what amounts to a military alliance of the Western European nations, announced yesterday, coupled with the breakdown of the Berlin discussions, puts the next step in the struggle for the world squarely up to the United States.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Soviet news agency Tass said today the United States had "declined to make a direct answer" to a Russian note proposing the withdrawal of United States and Soviet troops from Korea.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The crisis in relations between the Soviet Union and the Western powers will also bring a crisis for the Marshall Plan, in the opinion of European leaders who have lately concentrated their efforts upon organizing European self-help to insure the success of that plan.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company announced yesterday the acquisition of Lawyers Title Corporation of New York with the purchase of the entire capital stock from Kuhn, Loeb Co. and the C.I.T. Financial Corporation. The announcement followed approval of the transaction by the State Banking Board.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The nation's commercial bankers concluded today in the last session of their four-day seventy-fourth annual convention that they have had little to do with causing inflation. Government spending, they reported, has been the major cause of high prices.
BERLIN, Sept. 29 -- Two potentially dangerous air incidents today touched off the sharpest written protest that United States officials have yet sent to Soviet air officers in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today the new installment buying controls need not apply where delivery of an article was the only incomplete detail in a time-purchase made before Sept. 20.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- The pledging in one year of more than $10,000,000 toward a goal of $14,000,000 for use in "a crusade for a Christian world" was announced tonight to the international convention of the Disciples of Christ.

While small business has maintained its strength in numbers, it has lost some ground in the proportion it does of the nation's business, according to A. D. H. Kaplan, economist, in a report, "Small Business: Its Place and Problems," issued yesterday by the Committee for Economic Development.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The attempt to solve the Berlin crisis may shift from the Security Council to the General Assembly of the United Nations, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the latter body, predicted today before a meeting of the Anglo-American Press Association.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29 -- Miss Prim, an eight-week-old cousin of Handsome Dan, the full-sized English bulldog who serves as Yale University's mascot, was handed here today to Miss Virginia Warren, 20-year-old daughter of Gov. Earl Warren of California.
The richest chorus in history sang New York City's glory to the world last night in a Golden Jubilee program broadcast at 9 o'clock over the NBC radio network.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development reported today that a self-supporting Western Europe demanded "economic unification" of the area through the Marshall Plan and a fundamental readjustment in its business outlook.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- More than 20 per cent of Britain's national income will be devoted to capital investment during the life of the Economic Cooperation Administration, according to a long-term program drawn up for submission to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- An American staff sergeant who killed at least twenty-five German troops before a bullet tore through his throat will receive the nation's highest military award. He was Gus Kefurt, who died Dec. 24, 1944, while battling German infantry and tanks in France.

After being greeted warmly in the first showing of old-time political enthusiasm evidenced here in the campaign thus far, Earl Warren, Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, said at a press conference at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday that he welcomed the support of Democrats.

Five hundred and ninety-nine goldfish went back to Saddle River, N.J., yesterday, their summer in the channel garden pools at Rockefeller Center ended. The fish, survivors of an original group of 600, were displaced when the pools were drained as part of the autumn change-over from summer aquatic flowers to Korean-type chrysanthemums.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 29 -- A further minor firming of interest rates in the near future was predicted here today by Dr. Marcus Nadler of New York University. A speaker at the closing sessions of the seventy-fourth annual convention of the American Bankers Association, Dr. Nadler, who is Professor of Finance at the university, made the prediction and added the warning that bankers should exercise increasing caution in granting loans under current conditions.

Several hundred City College students staged a noisy "sit-down" yesterday before the office of Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, to protest the exoneration of Prof. William E. Knickerbocker by the Board of Higher Education on charges of anti-Semitism.
MADRID, Sept. 28 -- The film "Gentleman's Agreement" has been rejected for Spanish distribution by order of the ecclesiastical member of the Film Censorship Board on moral grounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- With a net gain of thirty-three seats needed to win control of the House of Representatives, leaders of the Democratic Congressional campaign believe the party has a fifty-fifty chance to turn the Republicans out of the majority.

The third consecutive day of declining hide futures prices on the Commodity Exchange brought about commission house stop-loss and dealer selling yesterday. The market was down 30 to 50 points in active deliveries at the day's end.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 29 -- The suggestion made by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Acting Mediator for Palestine, in a report to the Security Council, that Israeli authorities in Jerusalem had been lax in taking security precautions for the protection of Count Folke Bernadotte was vigorously repudiated today by the Military Governor of the Israeli-held areas of Jerusalem, Dr. Bernard Joseph.
With the freshman squad acting as Kings Point, Fordham yesterday sharpened its aerial defense in a long contact scrimmage that saw a new change in the backfield alignment.

Expulsion of racketeers from the garment district was demanded by thousands of shouting dressmakers at a mass rally yesterday afternoon in West Thirty-fifth Street, scene of last week's gang assault on seven union pickets.

Statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reported yesterday that, based upon experience with its industrial policy holders, the death rate from cancer among women continued in 1947 the almost uninterrupted decline in fifteen years.

Task committees of the Navy Industrial Association have made considerable progress in solving many of the problems of government-industry relations, J. K. Richards, executive director, revealed yesterday. He reported on committee activities at the annual meeting of the association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 29 -- Gov. Earl Warren invaded this home town of Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic national committee, for a noon-day rally today as his fifteen-car special train swung south through New England.

With garment deliveries hitting peak loads for the fall season, many New York manufacturers will keep their shipping departments open on the religious holidays, Monday and Tuesday, a survey of the market showed yesterday. Packing companies who combine dress, coat and suit shipments for retailers in principal cities throughout the country said that shipments are up 35 to 45 per cent over a year ago.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The $45,000 Stradivarius of Louisa Terzi, violinist, will be buried with her tomorrow as she wished, it was disclosed today. A spokesman at a mortuary said the family had decided to carry out the last wish of the concert artist.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Barring of a Negro graduate student from the University of Oklahoma was held unconstitutional today.

" I have a warrant, for your arrest, Alexander Munroe," the detective greeted the tall, well-dressed man as they both stopped for a traffic light yesterday afternoon at Forty-eighth Street and Madison Avenue.

Employes of the twenty-eight Childs restaurants in this city voted yesterday to authorize their union leaders to call a strike if they deemed such action necessary to win an acceptable contract with the Childs Company. The present contract, covering 2,300 members of the Chain Restaurant Employes Union, Local 42, AFL, expires at midnight tonight.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- State grocers agreed today to renew its fight for repeal of state and Federal legislation which restricts the sale of yellow margarine and levies taxes on merchants who sell it to the public. A resolution adopted at the third day's session of the forty-seventh annual convention of the New York State Food Merchants Association authorized association officers to work with legislators in the fight to remove the restrictions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Spokesmen for the civil aviation industry here raised today the question whether air transport was moving into a new and revolutionary phase of regulation as the result of action by the Civil Aeronautics Board invoking its power to investigate the economic right of a major line to continue in business.
Hank Briggs, 200-pound tackle, was chosen by Coach Lou Little to lead Columbia's football team as game captain against Harvard, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

" Red River," at the Capitol, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Western, which stars John Wayne, Montgomery Clift, Joanne Dru and Walter Brennan, was produced and directed by Howard Hawks. Borden Chase and Charles Schnee wrote the screen play of the United Artists release from Chase's story, "The Chisholm Trail."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Air Force announced plans today to grant temporary one-grade promotions to about 5,500 officers on active duty before the end of January.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet Monday afternoon to consider a charge by the United States, Britain and France that the Soviet blockade of Berlin is a threat to international peace and security.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A formal order which in effect puts the name of Representative Lyndon Johnson on the Texas ballot as Democratic Senatorial nominee was signed by Justice Hugo L. Black today.

Homemakers are so burdened by high milk prices that 100 of them protested on Tuesday by picketing City Hall. To add to their difficulties, the National Research Council, cooperative organization of American scientists, will soon recommend an increase of 25 per cent in the daily calcium quota for adults.

A delegation from the Civil Rights Congress protested yesterday to assistant Chief Inspector August Flath, Police Department chief of staff, against what it termed "fifty cases of police shootings and manhandlings, particularly against Negroes."

Virtues of New York as a vacation spot have been justly sung and bring hosts of visitors to our city. For New Yorkers who cannot get away from the city streets there is an opportunity for intriguing journeys, at least in the mind's eye, if they will visit -- of all places -- the railroad tracks which still are to be found on the perimeters of Manhattan and the outlying boroughs.

Increases in reserve requirements against time deposits of all banks in New York State which are not members of the Federal Reserve System and against demand deposits of non-member banks in Manhattan to match the action taken early this month by the Federal Reserve Board were approved yesterday by the New York State Banking Board.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The creation of a new permanent military defense committee -- tantamount to a combined general staff -- of the five powers in the Western union, Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, is regarded here in military circles as an epochal move in the struggle against communism.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 29 -- Eggs and tomatoes again splashed around Henry A. Wallace as he appeared at City Auditorium tonight before more than 4,000 persons, believed to be the largest non-segregated audience to gather in Texas and perhaps the South.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Dixie Walker doubled in the first inning and singled in the eighth, driving in a run each time, to give the Pirates a 2-to-1 triumph over the Cardinals tonight. The victory put Pittsburgh into third place in the National League race, a half game ahead of the Redbirds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The United States has made a new demand on Russia for return of three American ice breakers, twenty-six frigates and several small naval craft that were provided under lend-lease during the war.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The United States today threw open the waters of the former Japanese-mandated islands of the Pacific to commercial fishing operations of all nations.

The City Planning Commission closed yesterday its public hearing on a proposed zoning amendment that would permit non-resident doctors and dentists to maintain offices immediately above the first floors of multiple dwellings in residential use districts.

PARIS, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Following is the text of the United States note to the Secretary General of the United Nations on the Berlin dispute. It is identic with the British and French notes. It was signed by Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations:

Financial statements of 2,265 companies making reports to the Securities and Exchange Conxmiszion were certified by 416 independent public accounting firms, according to a survey which the SEC has just released. There were, on the average, about five reportling companies for each accounting firm.

A formal denial that the Teachers Union and the United Public Workers of America, CIO affiliates, have influenced the work of the Veterans Administration in this area was issued yesterday by D.P. Page, deputy administrator for New York State.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 -- Every day in every way the Indians draw closer and closer to their first pennant in twenty-eight years. With Joe Gordon and Ken Keltner twice supplying a devastating one-two punch, they came from behind today and whipped the White Sox, 5 -- 2, advancing to within one victory of clinching a first-place tie, come what may.

What did Senator Taft say to the attorneys for the NLRB in the presence of Chicago newspaper publishers concerning a contempt action against the International Typographical Union on July 28, 1948? We have the following accounts:

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander singled out twenty-nine men from the Police Department roster yesterday, and expressed his personal appreciation for the type of work they had done during his ten-week absence because of illness and his vacation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Grain markets made a firm start and finished tamely on the Board of Trade today. There was a lack of the aggressive buying of the previous day and professional traders took the selling side as soon as it was disclosed that the demand was not aggressive.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Refrigerators for ninety-six members of the Senate were being trundled into the Senate Office Building today.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- The Braves are in and the shouting looks to be over for the Red Sox along with the Yankees, and the local baseball fever shows signs of abating to 105 degrees or thereabouts. For the next few days, until the start of the World Series, Bostonians possibly may awaken to the fact that the football season is on and give some thought to Harvard and Denny Myer's Eagles of Chestnut Hill.
DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser chalked up his fourth twenty-victory season in five years as the Tigers beat the Browns, 4 to 0, today on his six-hit pitching.

HATFIELD, England, Sept. 28 -- From the far side of the Hatfield airfield there could be heard today one of the mightiest voices in Western Europe's rising chorus of defiance to aggression. It was a roar like the rushing of a tornado accompanied by a steady piercing high-pitched whistle -- the sound of a turbo-jet aircraft engine at full throttle.

ANYONE glancing keenly about in search of a trend this morning may find an interesting one in James Gould Cozzens' new novel, "Guard of Honor."* Mr. Cozzens has had the audacity to write a war story mainly about officers -- and officers who appear as human beings, at that. It's not unique, of course. That's what qualifies it as part of a trend.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- Archibald MacLeish, former Assistant Secretary of State, charged the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization today with the responsibility of maintaining the present "precarious peace."
GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- The East-West trade talks here were near failure tonight after injection of political issues by the Soviet Union, Rumania and some other Eastern states.

One of the most disagreeable words in the English language also is one of the shortest. It is the word "but," and the lexicographers should leave it out of their dictionaries and the scholars should banish it from good usage. It is a word meant to cause trouble, a check rein against impulse, a bitterly conservative word in a world meant to grow liberal.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Demon Hanover, the Citation of the sulky circuit, steamed home in straight heats today to win the $3,000 Arden Homestead Stake, a co-feature of the opening day's card of the Lexington Grand Circuit meet.
HADDOCK, Ga., Sept. 29 -- George Stallings Jr. will see the Braves play in the world series after all.

Dr. Clarence F. Hiskey, Professor of Analytical Chemistry at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, denied yesterday charges by the House Committee on Un-American Activities that he engaged in wartime atomic espionage on behalf of Soviet Russia.

George R. Prout, vice president of the General Electric Company and general manager of the air-conditioning department, has been named an assistant general manager of the G-E nucleonics department, effective Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, president.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- In a strong defense of the United Nations made here tonight in the Paris house of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, John Foster Dulles, who is slated to be Secretary of State in the event of a Republican victory in the Presidential election, criticized the pessimists who insist that the world peace agency should be scrapped for its failures.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that it has approved the last major step in the formation of the new $500,000,000 utility being set up through the consolidation of the principal companies of the Niagara Hudson system into a single operating company.
A 33-year-old divorced woman was robbed of $50,000 in jewelry and $70 early yesterday by three unarmed, masked men in her fifth-floor suite in the Madison Hotel, 15 East Fifty-eighth Street.

It has been fifteen years since the city had its last big garment strike. In the interval the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the associations representing employers have established such a profitable and harmonious relationship that most New Yorkers have forgotten the garment district was once identified with incessant and usually violent struggle between management and labor.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Six of only twenty-eight survivors of the Grand Army of the Republic today elected Theodore A. Penland, 99 years old, of Portland, Ore., to steer the G.A.R. through its final year as an active organization.

American clubwomen, to help counteract "vicious" Russian propaganda, will broadcast via short-wave beginning in November to tell Europeans what American women really are like, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Senate investigators sought "the whole story" today on the easing of punishment meted out to at least thirteen Germans in the Buchenwald horror camp case.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 22, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 29 -- Henry A. Wallace was skeptical today that the United Nations debate on the Berlin situation would produce any new facts. "It will be two ex-parte statements," he said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The cached Peary letters are now striped overalls in a diplomatic chowder, it became evident here tonight. Stirring the chowder at various times since Tuesday have been the Navy, the State Department and the Canadian Embassy.

ON PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S TRAIN, Springfield, Mo., Sept. 29 -- Still hammering at the Republican Congressional record on farm prices and reclamation as only a foretaste of what would happen if Governor Dewey won in November, President Truman wound up his campaign for Oklahoma with thirteen speeches today, and moved on into his home state of Missouri for a second series of electioneering talks there.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- A deal for Susan Hayward to play the leading role in the screen version of "Anna Lucasta" at Columbia is in negotiation and probably will be successfully concluded, it was learned today from reliable sources.

The city's radio station, WNYC, which for the last twenty-four years has broadcast detailed local returns on election day, will be unable to continue the practice on Nov. 2 because of a decision by the Federal Communications Commission, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The text of a letter to President Truman from Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey was as follows:

Deere Co., farm machinery manufacturers, and its subsidiaries, reported yesterday for the nine months ended on July 31, last, a net profit of $15,240,647 after all charges, including $13,459,539 for taxes and $2,250,000 for contingencies.

Complaints that hundreds of new voters are being registered in East Harlem without being required to show elementary school diplomas or present literacy certificates set off an investigation yesterday by the State Attorney General's office.

A full-scale sales promotion and advertising campaign on improved Shell X-100 Motor Oil will be launched by the Shell Oil Company during the first week of next month, it was announced yesterday by D. C. Marschner, sales promotion and advertising manager.

Last night saw a revised program by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House, with nothing left of the bill originally announced except the closing number, "Beau Danube," with Alexandra Danilova and Frederic Franklin.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Henry Weber, musical director of WGN, Inc., today called on members of the FM Association in convention to let FM stand for "fine music." Mr. Weber asserted that "the pure, unadorned easy-to-listen-to musical program of twenty years ago" made radio and that it will do the same thing for frequency modulation broadcasting.

Despite the continuing strike at refineries in California, production of crude off last week increased 48,750 barrels to 5,343,100 barrels, according to yesterday's report of the American Petroleum Institute. Crude oil outputaveraged 5,196,000 barrels daffy !or the similar week of last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Selective Service headquarters disclosed today that the recent registration of the nation's 18-to-25-year-old youths totaled 8,584,963 for the pool from which the new citizen army will be drawn.
Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share payable on Nov. 1 out of this year's earnings.

A gifted young pianist was introduced to Town Hall audiences last night in the person of Raymond Lewenthal. Endowed with imposing digital dexterity, enormous energy and unusual understanding of the musical requirements at hand, he also gave ample reason to believe he enjoyed fingering the keyboard.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The Moscow radio said tonight that "there is no doubt but that the forces of progress and democracy will turn a deaf ear to those who try to sing the funeral march of the United Nations."

The current hearings of the Thomas Committee have once again opened the long public debate on Congressional investigations which began with the first Congressional investigation in 1792. As long as there is a Congress, and as long as it exercises its constitutional prerogative of investigation, the debate will continue.

NEOSHO, Mo., Sept. 29 -- Harry S. Truman, who is President of the United States, turned reporter and travelogue commentator here tonight to tell the Missouri home folks about his campaign journeys. And he was his own crowd estimator, too.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- A strike to begin Monday in the French coal mines and a twenty-four-hour strike of protest this Friday in the power and gas plants were called today. The workers affected hold that the 15 per cent wage-increase announced by the Government will be insufficient.

LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Big Bones, owned by Walter Wickes Jr. of West Chester, Pa., today romped home a handy winner of the feature event on the opening card of the annual Rolling Rock Hunt Racing Association steeplechase meeting.

Activity on the television front continued unabated yesterday, with additional sponsors rushing plans for fall and winter programs. Russ Morgan and his orchestra have been signed for a variety revue entitled "Welcome Aboard," which will make its debut at 7:30 P. M. Sunday on the NBC video network.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Glenn Dobbs and the Los Angeles Dons caught fire in the last five minutes of play tonight, scoring three touchdowns and whipping the favored New York Yankees in a bruising All-America Conference football game before 35,655 fans in Memorial Coliseum, 20 -- 10.

The autobiography of Chaim Weizmann, the first president of Israel, has been scheduled for publication early next year by Harper, under the title "Trial and Error." In addition to the regular edition, there will be a limited two-volume edition that will be autographed by the author.
Rent increases are in store for many of the permanent residents of city hotels, it was learned yesterday.

Lace curtains far more practical than those that were the pride of the parlor in grandmother's day are now available in sheer nylon. Because nylon fiber is resistant to dirt, the modern versions require fewer washings and no stretching or pinning, tasks that often proved the undoing of lace curtains of the past.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- Stricter enforcement of the liquor laws was advocated here today by R. E. Joyce, president of the Distilled Spirits Institute at the annual convention of the National Alcoholic Beverage Control Association in the Biltmore Hotel.
Irregularity developed in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchance yesterday. Final prices were 7 points higher to 11 points lower.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said today that if labor, through its leadership, works in the coming national election in New Jersey, it could put the state in the Democratic column by 250,000 votes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A basic Government price support of about $1.44 a bushel for this year's big corn crop was indicated today by a price report of the Department of Agriculture.

Prof. H. J. Muller of Indiana University, Nobel Prize winning geneticist, has notified the Academy of Sciences of the Soviet Union, of which he is a corresponding member, that he is resigning from that body because of the purges in the ranks of Soviet geneticists and biologists that have become intensified recently.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Every Republican from Harold E. Stassen to John Taber, which is quite a distance, would deny emphatically that there is any difference of opinion in the party about the quiet role of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg in the Presidential campaign, but the fact remains that some influential Republicans think the Senator is letting them down.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- The West Coast maritime strike was officially adopted as a political issue today by supporters of Henry A. Wallace for President in the three coast states.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, national singles champion, staging a comeback after losing the first two sets, defeated veteran Australian Davis Cup player Adrian Quist in the quarter-finals of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today, 7 -- 9, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The British press will get just enough newsprint in 1949 to continue its present reduced level of four to eight pages.

TOKYO, Sept. 29 -- Takeo Kurusu, chief of the Economic Stabilization Board and No. 2 man in the Cabinet, was arrested this morning for alleged connection with the Showa Denko bribery scandal. Summoned first to make a voluntary appearance at the procurator's office for questioning, he was served with a warrant on appearance.

Mayor O'Dwyer obviously finds a good deal of satisfaction in the progress made in the city's housing program, and we think he is justified in this. The Mayor, General Farrell of the City Housing Authority, and other city officials have just broken ground in the Bronx for two more public housing projects, one of these being the first in the city's $200,000,000 veterans' housing program without cash subsidy on rents.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The British Foreign Office today issued the text of a three-power note to Trygve Lie. Secretary General of the United Nations, on the Berlin issue accompanied by the relevant documents. The Government White Paper on the Moscow negotiations as a whole has yet to be published but it is expected in a few days.

Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan bluntly warned Communists last night that the United States would take every step deemed necessary to preserve peace in a world threatened by their efforts to revert to the rule of force.

For the third successive day, New York City registration fell behind the registration for 1944, the last Presidential election year. The total registration through yesterday was 1,374,714, compared with 1,469,225 for the first three days four years ago.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds routed Rookie Warren Hacker with a four-run blast in the first inning today to win their battle of the basement from the Cubs, 5 to 3.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra Association and its 102 musicians settled their wage dispute late today, making it possible for the group to open its forty-ninth season on schedule this Friday afternoon.

The State of Tennessee sold yesterday issues of bonds totaling $12,000,000, maturing Oct. 15, 1950 to 1952, to a banking syndicate headed by J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 1.2414 per cent. The next best of seven other bids, submitted by a syndicate headed by Chase National Bank, designated an interest cost of 1,28211 per cent.

All Atlantic air carriers, both American and foreign, reported yesterday heavily increased bookings under the third-day excursion rates to Europe that will go into effect tomorrow. However, they were reluctant to attribute the increases to the excursion fares alone, in view of the general and unexpected increase in domestic and foreign air travel in September.

In identic notes invoking the strongest provisions of the Charter, the United States, Britain and France have now formally cited Soviet Russia before the bar of the United Nations on charges of taking unlawful and coercive action in Berlin and thereby creating a threat to international peace and security.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Beneath the gilt-encrusted ceiling of the main reception room in Lancaster House, which usually looks down on the sober suitings and pale faces of Western statesmen, a colorful conference of African legislators assembled today.

Former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson condemned yesterday the methods of the House Committee on Un-American Activities. Mr. Patterson, now president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, declared that "no responsible member of the bar" would approve current procedures of the Congressional body headed by Representative J. Parnell Thomas.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Despite Moscow's pressure to oust Marshal Tito as a "traitor" to the Communist cause, Foreign Minister Edward Kardelj today pledged Yugoslavia's support to Russia's foreign policy during the first speech delivered before the United Nations General Assembly by a representative of the Belgrade Government since the split between the Yugoslav Communist party and the Cominform last July.

Fernand P. Courtois, a veteran of thirty years' service with the French Line and a well-known figure in New York shipping circles, will head the Cleveland office of the French Line which reopens tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

J. Gordon Dakins, former assistant to the president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, was unanimously voted general manager and assistant treasurer of the association yesterday by the board of directors at their fall meeting in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

A founder in 1903 of the Building Trades Employers Association and the chairman of its board of governors for the last twenty-eight years, Christian G. Norman of Amityville, L. I., will retire next Dec. 31, it was announced yesterday.

Tighter state restrictions against wiretapping were recommended yesterday at a public hearing by a committee of the New York County Criminal Bar Association. At the same time it was proposed that the Federal prohibition against wiretapping be eased to permit listening in and recording of telephone conversations in cases involving national security or felonies.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Britain's Communist party vigorously pursued today its campaign to halt Britain's rearmament -- but without apparent hope of great success.

In an effort to discover current conditions and views in credit operations on a nation-wide basis, a questionnaire entitled "How's Business" will be mailed shortly to members of the New York, Los Angeles and Chicago associations affiliated with the National Association of Credit Men, it was announced yesterday by Mortimer J. Davis, executive manager of the association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The text of a statement issued by the Department of Justice today on the espionage reports of the House Committee on Un-American Activities was as follows:

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The United Nations General Assembly's key Political Committee put the atomic energy stalemate at the head of the list of its work today and put off the Palestine debate for about a month.

Expressing surprise that the Atomic Energy Commission had barred members of the United Public Workers of America, CIO, from atom bomb plants, Lawrence Kammet, publicity director for that union asserted yesterday, "We have not organized in atomic energy, we are not now organizing any such employes and we don't intend to."

Tomorrow marks the opening of the upland game season in many of the northeastern states and provinces, and those who have been stretching the leash with some impatience may begin working out the details of their opening trip any day now.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Atomic Energy Commission ordered two contractors today to bar from atomic plants affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations whose officers are suspected of Communist affiliation.

The stock market recovered further yesterday with a cessation of frightened selling and prices rebounded an average of a point. The rally was not the result of a large turnover, however, as business on the Stock Exchange shrank to 810,000 shares, despite transfers of large blocks of low-price issues, from 910,000 shares on Tuesday.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- The investigation of an alleged plot against President Juan Peron's life resulted today in the arrest by the political section of the police of Geoffrey P. Brooke-Taylor, for a quarter of a century a leading member of the British community.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The defeat today of Anglo-American efforts to bring the report of the late Count Folke Bernadotte on Palestine to immediate debate will work for a better settlement of the Palestine problem, informed Israeli circles here asserted tonight.
The Congressional inquiry here into Communist penetration of the United Public Workers, CIO, was defied yesterday by an official of that union who refused to answer questions on the subject.

Camp Kilmer, Army staging area near New Brunswick, N.J., will be rebuilt as a permanent Army post and will become part of a coordinated group of military installations including Fort Dix, it was learned yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Making his first campaign appearance in the New York metropolitan area, Gov. Earl Warren of California said here tonight that the country's labor legislation should be changed if it is found oppressive.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Jet engines which may produce five times the power of types now in use are being developed by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics at its Lewis Flight Propulsion Laboratory here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Whoever is elected President in November may rot occupy the White House during most of 1949.

Filthy streets represent a serious menace to the city's health and anyone contributing to such "vile" conditions need expect little mercy in her court, Magistrate Doris I. Byrne declared yesterday in Upper Manhattan Court as she imposed fines ranging from $2 to $20 on fifty-nine persons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The cost of the air lift of vital food and fuel into blockaded Berlin has risen to more than $393,000 a day during the peak of operations in the last recorded ten days, the Air Force reported today.

Light scrimmage with the first of the freshman players to report marked a departure in the customary practice program yesterday for New York University's football team. The Violet is now preparing for the game with Springfield College of Springfield, Mass., Saturday.

Light scrimmage with the first of the freshman players to report marked a departure in the customary practice program yesterday for New York University's football team. The Violet is now preparing for the game with Springfield College of Springfield, Mass., Saturday.

Visits by several foreign delegations here to survey and purchase plastic compounds and processing machinery yesterday featured the third National Plastics Exposition at Grand Central Palace. Total attendance for the day was estimated at about 8,500. The exposition continues today and tomorrow.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 29 -- Miss Margaret Hickey, editor of the public affairs department of The Ladies Home Journal, tonight urged 1,000 recreational leaders assembled here for the National Recreation Congress to take the women of their communities into partnership as volunteer leaders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Truman Administration brusquely cast aside today, as a proposal of election-year "publicity-seekers," the demand of the House Committee on Un-American Activities for immediate indictment of five persons for alleged wartime atomic espionage.
Rosh ha-Shanah -- the start of the Jewish High Holy Days and the beginning of the Jewish New Year, 5709 -- will be ushered in at sundown Sunday in temples and synagogues throughout the world.

Criticism of Federal laws regulating unemployment insurance tax rebates for discriminating against new, small concerns that have, nevertheless, good experience records was voiced yesterday by Milton O. Loysen, executive director of the State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance.

In the hour and a half between 3:10 and 4:40 P.M. yesterday Mrs. Earl Warren and her daughter Virginia shook hands with 3,000 women, and a few men. The occasion was a reception given in their honor in the ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel by the Republican Women's Organization of New York State and the Women's State Republican Clubs of New Jersey.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- A division of opinion was developing here today among city officials and welfare workers concerning the wisdom of the city administration's plan to place the Yonkers child care centers on a self-sustaining basis.

Warning that rayon textiles are entering a period of fluctuating prices, Herman Chopak, president of Chopak Textile Company, Inc., urged converters to accept from mills only those goods which they can sell. Converters must keep close tab on their inventory-sales ratios, he said, and avoid over-expansion of stocks even if it means loss of mill position.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery has been chosen as first chairman of the Permanent Defense Organization of the five Western European Union powers, it was authoritatively stated here tonight. He has been released by the British Cabinet from his post as Chief of the Imperial General Staff, it was declared, and will soon take up his new duties.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- As a preliminary to the coal mine strike to begin on Monday the workers in the nationalized gas and electric plants decided tonight to stage a four-hour suspension of service throughout France tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, Newark, N.J., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to issue $50,000,000 of 15-year debentures.

Activity and strength featured the cottonseed oil futures market on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. The market opened barely steady but gathered strength under the influence of buying of October and December. The December month aroused the heavier interest.

The State Department will assume today the preparation and broadcasting of the Voice of America programs previously handled under contract by the National and Columbia Broadcasting Systems, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- The United States called on the United Nations General Assembly today to use the power of world public opinion to force Soviet leaders to accept rigid international control of atomic energy.

A capacity throng of members of society and artistic circles -- many of whom for years have been patrons of the various philanthropic endeavors of the Musicians Emergency Fund -- attended an invitation dinner dance last night in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, which had been arranged as a benefit for the fund.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- United Nations action on a recommendation banning genocide (the systematic destruction of a minority) was delayed today when Yugoslavia requested that a new draft convention of the problem be drawn up to replace the one now being considered by the legal committee of the General Assembly.

The Coronet trophy, an encased coronet and plaque awarded by Coronet Magazine to the store doing the best advertising promotion on Formfit products throughout the country, was won by the C.C. Anderson Company of Boise, Idaho, it was announced yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

Attendance continued heavy yesterday at the National Plastics Exposition at Grand Central Palace. The show, which ends tomorrow at 6 P.M. was estimated as attracting more than 10,000 visitors. Many smaller companies were said to have booked considerable business in plastics merchandise, with interest keen in items in the housewares, hotel, restaurant and automobile accessory fields.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Professional boxing in Chicago today had claimed its second life in seven months with the fatal encounter of Kid Dinamita, a lad from Santo Domingo, in the Chicago Stadium last night on his twenty-second birthday.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 30 -- Officers of Local 1 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilders, CIO, representing the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's 3,300 Camden employes, announced today the withdrawal of the local from the parent union.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer dismissed yesterday a motion by Albert L. Donnellon, chairman of the Independent party formerly designated as the United Laborite party, to gain a line on the voting machines in the coming election under the name of the United Local party.
The following is the text of President Truman's Louisville address, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Frank Parker and Ted Schroeder easily stroked their way into the men's singles semi-finals of the Pacific southwest tennis tournament today.

Directors of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration of $1.50 a share, payable Sept. 30. Previously the company had distributed $2 quarterly. All the stock is owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States note to the Soviet Union on Korea reads:

Behind Plummer's modernized facade, just completed on Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, are new fashion and home accessories assembled especially for the bride. In addition to the store's famous china, crystal and silverware, the bride can now find everything from engraved invitations to a desk set for her home.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Secretary of State Marshall's statement endorsing the plan of Count Folke Bernadotte, slain United Nations Mediator for Palestine, for final settlement of the Palestine ques tion was issued without his having consulted John Foster Dulles or other leading members of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, it was learned tonight.

The recovery by the stock market came to a halt yesterday when buying dried up and sufficient pressure appeared to cancel out some of the lift of the previous session. Losses were moderate, however, except in a few stocks, while the price average dropped back 0.46 point.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 30 -- With a fingers-crossed attitude, Dean Acheson, former Under-Secretary of State, asserted today that the tide had turned against Russia, but the post-war period of crises and problems might not soon be ended.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund each named nine executive directors today, with the political alignments of the voting Governments plainly evident even in this highly technical gathering on fiscal policy.
BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Indonesian Republican troops have recaptured Madium, the Communist capital, and are moving against the Communists south of the city, a Government spokesman said today.
The speech of Gov. Earl Warren of California at Manhattan Center last night follows:

Reflecting the $25,391,627 record sales, which more than doubled the previous year's gross volume, net earnings of Crosley Motors, Inc., rose to $1,496,854 in the fiscal year ended with last July from the $476,065 earned the year before, Powel Crosley Jr., president, reported for publication today.

The shooting of Count Folke Bernadotte two weeks ago was a well planned gangster-type assassination, Frank Begley, the United Nations security agent in Palestine who was the driver of the automobile in which the mediator for Palestine was killed, said yesterday.
PARIS, Sept. 30 (UP) -- General McNaughton told the United Nations today that the United States had atomic bombs probably ten times as powerful as those dropped on Japan.
LAUREL, Md., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Maryland's fall racing season opened at Laurel's rebuilt strip today with Manna H. capturing the featured Capital Handicap.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The United States has ended, temporarily at least, its long stalemate with the Netherlands and Belgium over the shipment of goods through the ports of Rotterdam and Antwerp.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Trans- Jordan charged today that Israeli forces had launched an all-out attack on the Old City of Jerusalem last night, and that the walled area had been placed under "the heaviest fire so far."

MADRID, Sept. 30 -- Senator Chan Gurney, Republican, of South Dakota, chairman of the Senate Committee on the Armed Services, told Generalissimo Francisco Franco today that he favored "complete re-establishment of all relations" between Spain and the United States.

Random notes. In preparation for the coming upland game season, the New Jersey Fish and Game Council has begun quail distribution in the southern counties, and prior to the opening a total of 4,440 quail will be released in ten counties. An additional 1,368 birds will be released on eight public shooting grounds.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A London doctor said today that some continental European athletes during the summer Olympic games were stimulated by drugs, much in the manner of race horses. Dr. Christopher Woodard, director of the athletes' clinic at London's Middlesex Hospital, exonerated all British and American athletes.

The State Attorney General's office issued a subpoena yesterday calling for the appearance for questioning today of a man who was caught cheating while taking a literacy test at Public School 72, 105th Street and Lexington Avenue.

Retirement of bonds before maturity continued last month at a snail's pace, the total falling to the smallest figure for any September in more than twenty years. Nearly 90 per cent of the refundings was for states and municipalities.

John Gilland Brunini, executive director of the Park Association of New York, announced further progress yesterday in the Citizens Golden Anniversary Planting Program, initiated on Tuesday by the association.

A fight for the featherweight championship of the world between Willie Pep of Hartford, holder of the title, and Joe (Sandy) Saddler of New York, was closed by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday.

In THE TIMES of Sept. 12 I saw a story that London police had recovered a painting by Sir Joshua Reynolds the day after it was stolen. The smart police work is certainly to be commended, but the remarkable thing to me is this statement in the story:

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The vast majority of the libraries in the state offer inadequate service to their communities, delegates attending the annual conference of the New York Library Association said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- In an apparent concession to more moderate elements within its ranks, the Progressive party announced today that it had withdrawn or would withhold opposition in more than a score of Senate and Congressional races where liberal Democrats faced stiff contests.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The National Labor Relations Board took under advisement today its first Taft-Hartley case involving conflicting work claims of rival unions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 -- With 98,000 tons of raw sugar strike-bound on ships in San Francisco Bay and 20,000 tons more on inbound vessels, the California and Hawaiian Sugar Refining Corporation announced today that it was closing its big refinery at near-by Crockett tomorrow for the duration of the West Coast maritime strike.

The plan for a coalition of the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, agreed upon by both institutions in January, 1943, has been abandoned by the Whitney's trustees, it was announced yesterday.

Your editorial on Sept. 22, "Solution for Palestine," prompts the recollection best expressed by one who lived in the Holy Land years ago: "Unless the Lord buildeth a house, they labor in vain that build it."
The employer of George Hewitt, a Government witness against alien Communists at deportation hearings, protested yesterday against the Government's failure to protect Mr. Hewitt.

As part of an evangelical campaign to bring 70,000,000 "unchurched" Americans into the Episcopal fold, the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, has asked support for a broadcast this evening starring Walter Hampden in "Cyrano de Bergerac."
Following is the text of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's address on foreign policy delivered in Salt Lake City last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- Several hundred persons from six Northeastern states were on hand today for the third annual New England Winter Recreational Promotion Conference. For seven hours, every phase of skiing was thoroughly aired as resort operators, hotel owners, representatives of state development commissions, transportation companies, the United States Weather Bureau and the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston took part in the forum.

The Argentine iron and steel production expansion program provides for increasing present steel making capacity about 300 per cent, but even then, only 35 per cent of domestic needs will be coverad, Virgil Stark, president, North American Utilities and Construction Corporation, declared last night.

A short series of silent films has been booked by WJZ-TV, with provision for its extension contingent upon favorable acceptance by the television audience. The old-timers will be exhibited each Sunday night at 9 o'clock next month, starting next week.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 29 -- The inability of the prosecution to present a strategic exhibit -- a family journal that was said to have been bound in tattooed skin -- was the decisive factor in the trial of Ilse Koch, a review of the transcript of trial here today reveals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will lease a Government-owned alcohol plant at Kansas City, Mo., to F.W. Boltz Company, Los Angeles.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Leaders of the French Communist party lined up today with the Soviet Union against the Western powers, including their own government, in more categorical terms than they had ever before employed.
C.Z. Hardwick, vice president of the Ohio Oil Company, was elected yesterday to the board of directors to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Otto D. Donnell, former president.

PARIS, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The text of a resolution introduced in the United Nation Political Committee today by Gen. A. G. L. McNaughton of Canada. asking the Assembly to adopt a plan for control of atomic energy, follows:

As a result of modified psychoanalytic treatment, 85 per cent of the mentally ill patients at Hillside Hospital, Queens, recover or show much improvement, Dr. Joseph S.A. Miller, medical director, said in an interview yesterday.

Opera '48, the latest of the small companies to blossom forth in town, opened for business last night in the theatre of the Joan of Arc Junior High School on West Ninety-third Street. Wishing to do something different, the company dredged up "Tiefland," an opera by Eugen D'Albert.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30 -- All property of Pemex, the Government's petroleum monopoly, was attached today by Federal court order because this Government agency refused to pay $400,000 to two German-Mexican companies for royalties accumulated during the last ten years.

It was gratifying to read, on Sept. 15, a letter under the subject "Repatriation of Children," signed, among others, by the associate editor of America, stating that "in principle unaccompanied children should be returned to their parents, in cases where these are known to be alive."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The text of the message left by Robert E. Peary at Cape Sheridan on the north coast of Ellesmere Island during his Arctic expedition of 1905-6 was given out by the State Department today, disclosing that it was a brief factual report of his arrival there.

In a stormy five-hour meeting that led to the suspension of all classes, 2,000 City College students demanded yesterday the immediate dismissal of Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, head of the Romance languages department, who has been accused of anti-Semitism.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Tucker Corporation, auto producer, filed today a brief in a receivership suit in United States District Court, giving an account of its finances up to Aug. 31. The suit, asking that a receiver be appointed for the company, had been filed by a stockholder and two holders of dealer franchises.

Frank Herbst, head of Local 1 of the United Public Workers, CIO, who manages union affairs in the New York Welfare Department, refused yesterday to tell a Congressional subcommittee whether or not he was a Communist.

Senator Glen H. Taylor, Progressive party Vice-Presidential candidate, held up his right hand before 800 persons in the Bronx Winter Garden last night and said, "I swear I never have been a member of the Communist party." He then added:

" Johnny Belinda," Warner Brothers' adaptation of the Elmer Harris play, starring Jane Wyman and Lew Ayres, will have its local premiere this morning at the Strand. The drama, produced by Jerry Wald and directed by Jean Negulesco from a screen play by Irmgard yon Cube and Allen Vincent, features Charles Bickford, Agnes Moorehead, Stephen McNally, Jan Sterling, Rosalind Ivan and Dan Seymour.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade today with rapid price changes at times, especially in corn which had a range of more than 1 cent a bushel, dipping early only to rally later, then react, to close unchanged to 1/4 cent lower.

Porcelain vases and statuettes from China's golden age of ceramics go on display this morning at China House, 125 East Sixty-fifth Street. The exhibition, which is under the auspices of the China Institute in America, is open to the public, Mondays to Fridays, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. through Oct. 22.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- In the first phase of a Government anti-trust investigation of the vast du Pont industrial empire, Federal Judge John P. Barnes today issued an order impounding records of eight companies involved in the case and at the same time indicated he was not impressed with the Government's case.
BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- The Red Sox reached the end of the trail with the Senators with a noisy 7-3 victory today to keep their slim pennant chance alive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment bankers, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to turn down a proposal for the negotiated sale of $13,000,000 in public utility securities. The securities are 400,000 common shares of the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company of Oklahoma City, now held by the Standard Gas and Electric Company of New York, which has asked permission to sell them to underwriters by negotiation.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 30 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of Israel, arrived here today on his first visit to the new state.

Although many retail stores were slow in passing on to customers the benefits of a drop in the wholesale price of meat, Eugene G. Schulz, Commissioner of Markets, reported yesterday "a general opinion in the trade that the high point in meat prices has passed."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation contended today that not itself but the Wheland Company of Chattanooga, Tenn., was trying to obscure the issue in the fight over which should operate a $28,000,000 Government-owned blast furnace in Cleveland.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 30 -- Nathan Friedman-Yellin, leader of the Stern group (Fighters for the Freedom of Israel) and the alleged chief of its splinter group, the Fatherland Front, was arrested in Haifa last night or early today with one of his top lieutenants, according to confirmed reports.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Education increasingly tops the list of expenditures in the states, a Census Bureau report showed today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. R.B. Meckley of Washington, D. C., became the new champion of the United States senior women golfers, when she added an 87 to her first-round 83 for a 36-hole total of 170 over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.
BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- Two leaders of the New York Stock Exchange undertook tonight a vigorous defense of Wall Street against repeated attacks by President Truman during his present campaign tour.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 -- A strong and consistent foreign policy based upon the premises that peace cannot be achieved by appeasing Russian aggression and that the United States, for its own security, must help strengthen free governments in all parts of the world was promised tonight by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York.

Goodbody Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the opening of a branch office at 50 State Street, Boston, under the direction of Maxwell E. Bessell, formerly a partner in O'Connell Co.

Thanks to Robert Morley, the theatre has been restored to professionalism, and the September jinx has been broken. "Edward, My Son," which was put on at the Martin Beck last evening, is no shakes as a work of literary art. It is an actor's play, put together by Mr. Morley and Noel Langley for purposes of performance.

A military agreement now unites the five nations of the Western European Union. How different might be the history of Europe had these five nations -- France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom -- presented a united front in 1914 to the Kaiser and in 1939 to Hitler and Mussolini -- a front united before the fact and not after war had begun.

Would you allow me to make a correction of your dispatch on a press conference which I had at the World Council of Churches Assembly in Amsterdam? I was reporting at this conference on a discussion held in one of the sections on the relations of communism to Christianity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 --The Middle Atlantic States Motor Carrier Conference, Inc., and the New York-New Jersey Tariff Bureau, Inc., presented today to the Interstate Commerce Commission a tariff of increased rates intended to add 10 per cent to the revenues of motor carriers which they represent to offset increased costs of operation experienced since the first of the year.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Although trading in practically all sections of the stock market here today was small a generally firm tone was prevalent.
The cotton futures market continued irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 1 point higher to 24 points net lower.

The Board of Education has dismissed Alexander Koral from his job in the school system, it was announced yesterday, because of his refusal to answer questions of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Lashing out at the Truman Administration in the most pungent campaign language he has used, Gov. Earl Warren of California devoted a major campaign speech here last night to a thorough condemnation of the Democratic party at home and abroad.

In helping finance the migration of Jewish Displaced Persons in Europe to Palestine and elsewhere, New Yorkers of every faith and creed will have contributed more than $50,000,000 by the end of this year, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman said last night at a dinner meeting of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 25 were 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The United States has informed the Soviet Government that the question of withdrawing United States troops from southern Korea must await the presentation of the United States Government's views on the larger question of Korean unity and independence to the General Assembly of the United Nations in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The American manufacturers of machine tools will soon have stand-by orders for 100,000 standard types on which to start production immediately in the event of war, the National Security Resources Board announced today.

A little more than a year ago the sad news was reported here that the collaborating team of Arnaud d'Usseau and James Gow, creators of "Tomorrow the World" and "Deep Are the Roots," had parted, ceasing joint activities forthwith.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on the nation's larger banks for $309,486,000 in its war loan accounts. The call, based on the total of such deposits as of the close of business on Wednesday, requires payment in two installments, half on Oct. 6 and the balance on the following day.

One item in Andrei Y. Vishinsky's bitter indictment of the United States in his speech before the United Nations Assembly was that a private corporation, the Esso Marketers, had issued a "map of the Third World War, Pacific Theatre of Military Operations." If this didn't prove that we were planning to attack Russia, possibly in the neighborhood of New Guinea or Tarawa, Mr. Vishinsky seemed to be arguing, what would?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- During the week ended Sept. 29, member bank reserve balances increased $1,190,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Dr. Gustave Roussy, former rector of the University of Paris and dean of the faculty of sciences, who was relieved of his high academic position following charges of illegal currency manipulations, committed suicide today.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gave the full support of the United States today to adoption by the United Nations General Assembly of the Declaration of Human Rights -- the first step toward a formal international covenant guaranteeing basic liberties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 25 were 907,971 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,762 cars, or 0.2 per cent fewer than in the preceding week; 29,983 cars, or 3.2 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of last year, and 8,544 cars, or 0.9 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, Presidential candidate of the States' Rights Democratic party, predicted today that he would get more than 100 electoral votes, enough to throw the election into the House of Representatives.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Tigers finished their home season today with a 7-to-2 victory over the Browns on Ted Gray's seven-hit pitching and a twelve-hit attack of their own off three St. Louis pitchers.

PEIPING, Sept. 30 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek arrived in Peiping from Nanking today with top-ranking army, air force and navy personnel. His arrival is being taken here as an indication of the increasing seriousness of the North China military situation following the loss of Tsinan, capital of Shantung.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

Pointing out that the total of nearly $50,000,000 in exports from Italy to the United States during the first six months of this year exceeded those for the whole of 1947, Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, yesterday said the Italian handicrafts industries have achieved "amazing results in an amazingly short time."

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie presented for the first time today the complete details of his proposed United Nations guard calling for the immediate establishment of a standing force of 300 men plus international reserve components of 500 volunteers stationed in strategic groups throughout the world to rush to trouble spots.

WITH TRUMAN MOTORCADE IN SOUTHERN ILLINOIS, Sept. 30 -- Residents of six counties of southern Illinois' "Little Egypt" area turned out by the tens of thousands today to see and hear President Truman warn that "big-business Republicans have begun to nail the American consumer to the wall with spikes of greed."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30 -- Offering statistics on living costs and profits before and after price control, President Truman asserted tonight that election of a Democratic Congress in November would mean action against high prices and monopoly, and bring about more housing at lower prices.

Through its president, Max Hirsch, the American Trainers Association has recommended to the New York State Racing Commission that twenty-five additional days of racing be assigned to the Westchester Racing Association for its Belmont Park programs next year.

Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, said last night that individual freedom and medical progress depend upon keeping a "substantial portion" of the nation's hospitals and medical profession out of government control.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark should be impeached if he continues to reject the demand of the House Committee on Un-American Activities for the indictment of five alleged war-time atomic espionage agents, its acting chairman asserted today.

" If you believe the coaches, the Columbia-Harvard game will be a battle of the unknowns on Saturday." stated W. Henry (Hank) Johnston, recently installed public relations sports chief of the Crimson as he addressed the football writers' luncheon at Columbia's John Jay Hall yesterday.

VIENNA, Sept. 30 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, Austria's Foreign Minister, will leave for Paris this week to ascertain among other matters whether chances are favorable for the renewal of the Austrian treaty negotiations. Dr. Gruber's trip will follow a series of conversations with Norbert Bischof, Austrian Minister to Moscow, who returned to Vienna for this purpose.

The United States liner America arrived here yesterday with visible evidence of the recent North Atlantic hurricane marring her sleek silhouette -- three smashed bridge-house windows, seventy-five feet above the water line, and other lesser damage.
A favorite saying of the Pan-American Coffee Bureau, "Good things happen over coffee," was borne out last evening at a dinner the bureau gave at the Ambassador.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 -- Losing ground because they were idle while the Yankees and Red Sox were slicing their lead to one game and a half, the Indians were not the least perturbed today. Manager Lou Boudreau even took the occasion to go out of town, spending the off day with his family at Harvey, Ill.
Mayor O'Dwyer smiled and waved.

Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh accused milk distributors yesterday of "profiteering at the expense of the milk consumer" by their refusal to absorb the half-cent increase in the price of fluid milk paid to farmers starting today.

Fifty horses in training and yearlings were sold at auction yesterday morning under a tent set up in Belmont Park's paddock area. They brought a total of $617,100, an average of $12,342. Another forty will be sold today.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 30 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay indicated this afternoon that the merger of the three Western zones probably would become a reality within the next few days.

After several days of almost continuous meetings, committees representing the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and about forty Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators reached a one-year agreement last night, less than six hours before the present contract expired.

A strike against the Union News Company beginning at midnight tonight was voted last night by 600 company employes who are members of Local 906, News Distribution Employes Union, CIO. Unless last-minute efforts to avert the walkout are effective the strike will affect 1,100 employes in newsstands and soft-drink bars at railroad terminals and stations in New York, Westchester, Connecticut and Long Isyand operated by the company.

Business loans in this area, after dipping contraseasonally two weeks ago, resumed their upward climb last week, rising $38,000,000 it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, outstanding as of the week ended on Wednesday, totaled $5,527,000,000, it was announced.

The Navy would like to get rid of a forty-foot balloon that floated blithely over the rooftops off Flat-bush yesterday causing general public excitement and annoyance to the police before it came to rest on top of a tavern at 1869 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn.

With the international skies darkened by Russia's tactics in Berlin, it is appropriate that the first item on the working program of the General Assembly of the U.N. in Paris should be a new effort to bring under control the most terrifying force unleashed by man -- the atomic bomb.

Charging that the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO, was Communist-controlled, the Prudential Insurance Company refused yesterday to negotiate a new contract with the union unless it filed non-Communist affidavits and won certification through a National Labor Relations Board election.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Ray Milland is scheduled to play the leading role in "After Midnight" at Paramount and the studio is seeking to borrow Alida Valli from David O. Selznick to appear opposite him, it was learned today.

The Third Assembly is the platform of the greatest speeches that have been heard in the United Nations.
