The spokesmen of the Western Powers, Marshall, Bevin and Schuman, have addressed the world in terms that measure up to the scale and gravity of the crisis and express their profound sense of responsibility to save the peace.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Richard F. Uhlmann, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, said today that "farm price supports in a peacetime program should be at distinctly low levels." He spoke at the annual meeting of the Grain and Feed Dealers National Association.

There was plenty of elbow room at Belmont Park yesterday, the turnstile count dipping to 14,034, lowest of the downstate New York season, as the result of the rain. There also was plenty of racing room in the main event. Only four 3-year-olds went after the $7,500 in added money in that six-furlong whirl over the sloppy track.
Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson voiced the hope last night that greater collaboration among nations might yet be obtained through the further evolvement of international law.

The Democratic National Committee charged yesterday that Governor Dewey "in a fit of rage" told a legislative committee of the Veterans of Foreign Wars that all civil service employes were "mediocre'' and that, if he had his way, the "present civil service system in the National, state and local governments would not exist."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Dr. E.U. Condon, director of the National Bureau of Standards, leaves for Paris tomorrow to serve as chief United States delegate to an international conference on weights and measures.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- To Britain's most socially and economically underdeveloped colonial peoples, Colonial Secretary Arthur Creech Jones proposed today an Anglo-African partnership for the development of their territories. At the same time he warned them against "subversive influences" that might attempt to exploit their national awakening.

New handprinted wallpaper designs by Wilton E. Owen as well as new colorings of several of his former patterns have strong colors and deep backgrounds to make tradition-inspired motifs dramatic for contemporary rooms. Bright persimmon orange, rich greens and black were favored in the group shown yesterday at the Ritz Carlton Hotel by the Wallpaper Shop Inc. of 980 Madison Avenue where they are now available.

The Board .of Education moved /esterday t0 speed up integration f the Youthbuilders movement Into the city's :educational system with the appointment of a director for the program at an annual salary of $5,400.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- President Will Harridge said today the regular American League season must end Sunday, regardless of whether any contender should have a postponed game left unplayed. The league constitution provides that any postponements which cannot be played before the regular season ends must be written off.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Not much is heard of the career civil servants in the American Government outside those in the Department of State, but for many years the Treasury has been most competently staffed, and in some respects it is the best-organized unit in the Executive Branch.
Easily one of the season's best presentations from the standpoint of style and accessories, which gave each costume finished perfection, was seen yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen pitched his twentieth victory tonight when the Cardinals beat the Pirates, 4 to 1, to sweep a day-night double-header. St. Louis won the matinee encounter, 6 to 1. The Redbirds gained a second-place tie with the idle Dodgers, while Pittsburgh dropped from third to fourth place.

Pan American Airways again put into effect yesterday an unexpected cut in Atlantic rates when it slashed the charges for a sleeping berth from $100 to $25. The company also announced it would provide plane-to-ground radio telegraph facilities for its passengers on both Atlantic and Pacific runs.

There were premieres all around last night, with Ram Gopal and his Hindu "ballet" making their bow in the City's International Dance Festival at the City Center and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo presenting Ruthanna Boris' "Quelques Fleurs" in its world debut at the Metropolitan.

President Truman made an appeal last night for the support of the Community Chests of America in a half-hour radio program that opened month-long Community Chest campaigns in 1,100 communities for a total of $184,000,000.

BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- The Communist-dominated "democratic bloc" of Berlin moved into the official chambers of the elected City Assembly today and adopted a nine-point winter relief program for the city.

The solution, within twenty-four hours after the crime was committed, of the Loew jewelry theft case is a piece of unusually good police work. Mayor O'Dwyer and Commissioner Wallander have a right to be enthusiastic about the diligence and deductive intelligence that went into it.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 30 -- It's been a good year for the Indians in sport and Tuss McLaughry, the heap big chief of the Hanover Wigwam, hopes that the success of the Boston Braves and Cleveland is a portent of many scalps for his Dartmouth tribe on the football field.
Slow but thoroughly soaking showers that moved North through this area yesterday afternoon brought relief from a general dry spell that had left fields, farmlands and forests parched and dusty.
The Long Island Rail Road has made some progress in its campaign to win friends among its commuters.
EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 30 -- Undisturbed by the eggs and tomatoes hurled at him in Houston last night, Henry Wallace carried his fight against racial discrimination into this border community today.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- The decision to restrict bank credit in France was taken by the Government to meet the desires of the United States, according to today's issue of the financial newspaper Agence Economique et Financiere.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- Under a dripping sky that delayed the start of the encounter half an hour, the Yankees today kept alive their slender thread of pennant hope by defeating the Athletics in the finale of a three-game series, 9 to 7.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Cubs ended their home season today by defeating Cincinnati, 1 to 0, in a left-handed pitchers' duel between Cliff Chambers and Ken Raffensberger.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, Fred Haas Jr. and Gene Webb gave par a five-stroke beating today to share a first-round tie in the seventy-two-hole Portland open golf tournament. They posted 67s against the par 35, 37 -- 72 requirements of the Portland Golf Club course.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Brazil is developing her merchant marine along with her general economic situation.

WHEN Irwin Shaw's harrowing one-act anti-war play, "Bury the Dead," was produced in New York in 1936, Mr. Shaw was only 22 years old and knew nothing about war that he hadn't read in books. Today, twelve years later, Mr. Shaw is a war veteran who knows a great deal about war. He has put much of what he knows into his first novel, "The Young Lions,"* with superb skill and stunning emotional power.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 30 -- While many nations continued their zealous efforts to raise funds for the 230,000,000 undernourished, needy children of the war-torn countries of the world, the United States wing of the global campaign ended quietly today.

Oliver W. Hill, the first Negro in Virginia to be elected to the Richmond City Council in fifty-two years, said yesterday that despite the Lincoln tradition and Progressive party promises, most of the 1,200,000 qualified Negro voters in the South would cast their ballots in November for President Truman and other Democratic candidates.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month increased slightly over the previous month and September, 1947. Business for the first three quarters of this year climbed to 225,503,422 shares, the largest in two years for the nine-month period.

The United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., will celebrate tomorrow the fifth anniversary of its dedication. A full program of events honoring the occasion has been planned, beginning with a formal review of the regiment of cadet-midshipmen on Tomb Memorial Field at 11 A.M. and ending with the alumni homecoming dance in the evening.

A century hence, when some patient historian looks back the years to the radio prize program of 1948, his hair will stand electrically on end. He will find washing machines given away as though they were pencils and iceboxes distributed as easily as shoelaces.

Leading Roman Catholic churchmen and representatives of the Jewish faith joined yesterday in deploring the reasons given by the ecclesiastical member of the Film Censorship Board in Madrid for having rejected for Spanish distribution the film "Gentleman's Agreement."
Clever detective work in deduction and trailing led yesterday to the arrest of five men charged with being involved in two jewelry robberies, in which close to $100,000 in valuables were taken.
GENEVA, Sept. 30 -- Two recent developments in United States economic policy in Europe have caused concern and worry among the countries participating in the European Recovery Program.
Clever detective work in deduction and trailing led yesterday to the arrest of five men charged with being involved in two jewelry robberies, in which close to $100,000 in valuables were taken.
GENEVA, Sept. 30 -- Two recent developments in United States economic policy in Europe have caused concern and worry among the countries participating in the European Recovery Program.

After an extremely slow start, fall lamp sales at the manufacturing level are rapidly increasing and business will be good from now until Christmas, Benjamin Robbins, executive secretary of the Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Pending further consideration of the technical problems involved the Federal Communications Commission today announced suspension temporarily of action on pending or prospective applications for television authorizations.

The rain that caused yesterday's scheduled contest between the Braves and the Dodgers at Ebbets Field to be deferred until today enabled Manager Billy Southworth of Boston's National League pennant winners a chance to devote his full energy to the problem of obtaining a replacement for Jeff Heath.

WNYC, the radio station operated by the City of New York since 1924 as a public service to its millions of residents, has been broadcasting detailed election returns every November for twenty-four years. On other nights throughout the year it ceases operations at 10 P.M., under regulations of the Federal Communications Commission.

A graphic summary of what is happening in certain segments of the men's furnishings industry, notably shirts and pajamas, is contained in the statistical report issued yesterday by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers for the first half of 1948.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- To insure that needed merchandise is on store shelves at the particular time a customer desires it, there is need for greater cooperation between retailers and manufacturers regarding delivery dates as well as production schedules, it was declared here today by Gordon K. Creighton, assistant general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Henry Wallace and his Progressive party are no longer "to be taken seriously," according to Jack Kroll, director of the CIO Political Action Committee, who told a news conference today that "the sound liberal people who at one time might have given voting strength to that movement are no longer behind it."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- An international agreement whereby an English bolt would fit the threads of an American nut under specified standards is expected to be completed soon, according to informed sources here. When the agreement is consummated it will mark attainment of an objective, made urgent by military planning, which industrial users have sought for half a century.

At least one building belonging to New York University is not in the metropolitan area It is the archaeological museum completed during the summer by an expedition from the Institute of Fine Arts on the island of Samothrace in the Agean Sea near the coast of Greece.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A hint that the United States expects to keep its air lift to Berlin operating over the Russian blockade for a long time came today from the Air Force.
Consolidated net sales of the May Department Stores Company and its subsidiaries reached a high of $183,321,000 for the six months ended on July 31, it was reported yesterday.

Registration in New York yesterday -- the fourth of six registration days -- followed the pattern set earlier in the week, a pattern that pointed to an indifference to the outcome of the November elections on the part of thousands of voters in this Democratic stronghold.

The Czechoslovak people, including many former pro-Communists, are showing increasing discontent under the country's Soviet-sponsored dictatorship, Laurence A. Steinhardt, former United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, reported yesterday.

Although there was a sharp increase in bond financing by public utility and industrial concerns in the month, the volume of new issues offered publicly in September went to the lowest level for any month since February as a result of a marked contraction in offerings of state and municipal issues.

Ninety modern European prints just purchased abroad, many of post-war vintage, go on view today in the first floor galleries of the Museum of Modern Art. This collection, which was made possible through the gift of Mr. Victor S. Riesenfield, was assembled by William S. Lieberman of the museum staff on a recent European trip.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The present world crisis is basically a moral rather than a political or economic situation, Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, said to the Federal Bar Association, as he pleaded today for a world-wide return to spiritual values.

GENEVA, Sept. 20 -- The interim commission of the International Trade Organization announced today that it had abandoned efforts to reach an agreement with Switzerland on the terms on which this country might adhere to ITO.
Leo Healy, of counsel for the defense in the case of Nunci Citro, convicted automobile thief, testified yesterday that he was not aware of an alleged "fix" to obtain a light sentence for his client.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The price-support rate for the current bumper corn crop, set by law at 90 per cent of parity, was announced today by the Department of Agriculture: an average corn loan rate of $1.44 a bushel. This compares with a $1.37 rate last year.

An entirely new approach involving complete engineering "carry-through'' and responsibility is being used in organizing the spending of the first $35,000,000 of the $70,000,000 allotted by the Economic Cooperation Administration for industrial purposes under the China Aid Program, Charles L. Stillman, Chief of ECA's Technical Survey Mission to China, said in an interview yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

More than fifty antique dealers began to move their wares into the modern banquet rooms of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel early this morning in preparation for the opening tomorrow at 1 P.M. of the New York Antiques Exposition.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Everything considered it was a pretty good day in Paris today. There was a bright autumn sun most of the time, Marcel Cerdan, man of the hour, arrived among his own, and almost everyone got as much bread as he wanted, ration tickets or no ration tickets.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 1 (AP) -Bobanet Stable's Tenabob won the first section of the Rock Creek Park Purse before 8,892 at Laurel Park today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, reported world-wide economic progress today on the basis of his conversations at the world fiscal conference here. But Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, soon afterward told the assembled delegates that his Government was still hard pressed and was in no position to allow general use of its dwindling store of pounds sterling for world recovery purposes.
An 85-year-old widow taken to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for observation was found to have $128,525 in a silk money belt strapped around her waist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today asked that five leading motion-picture producers and distributors be required to get rid of their interests in about 1,400 movie houses in the United States.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- Hold everything!

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to allow Otis Co., of Cleveland, investment bankers to present witnesses in further hearings on the proposed sale of $13,000,000 of public utility securities.

A study of chronic inebriates and alcoholism has been made the: subject of a book by Joseph Hirsh, associate director of the Research Council on the Problems of Alcohol, entitled "The Problem Drinker." The book has been scheduled for January publication by Duell, Sloan and Pearce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -Former Secretary of State Cordell Hull, who will be 77 years old tomorrow takes a keen interest in the "current turmoil" in international affairs. A patient at Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital, near the National Capital, the veteran statesman is gradually gaining strength following the serious collapse he suffered two years ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, protested to the Atomic Energy Commission today against the "blacklisting" of two CIO affiliates.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP) -Dr. Robert A. Millikan, Nobel award scientist, said today that the atom bomb's greatest service to date has been to crystallize the need for world peace.

The opening of the fourteenth school in the Board of Education's special "600" organization serves to remind us that the city is employing every available modern means to educate not only its normal children but also those who are emotionally disturbed or who are on the brink of delinquency.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -Guinea Gold, lightly regarded entry of P.S. Hungerford of Shelbyville, Ind., upset the 3-year-old champion pacer, Knight Dream, in both heats of the Poplar Hill Pace on a Grand Circuit card today.
Have the Russians an atomic bomb?

A three-member board was designated yesterday to arbitrate a wage dispute between 25,000 CIO laundry workers and organized employers in the city. The arbitrators are Herman Brickman, Moses Shapiro and Max Meyer, all of whom have arbitrated previous industrial disputes.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Scoring two touchdowns in each quarter, Rider College's football team romped to a 49-6 victory over City College of New York at Dun Field tonight. The Beavers got their touchdown on a pass from Sy Kalman to Leo Wagner with fifteen seconds to play.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Oct. 1 -Because of low salaries and poor working conditions, more than a third of the trained librarians of this state have gone to other states for better paying jobs, it was reported today at the annual conference of the New York Library Association.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Oct. 1 -Decision was reserved on the legality of the city of Long Beach's ordinance establishing ten-hour parking meters in certain sections of the seaside city after a trial today in the City Court before City Judge Leonard R. Hanower.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Although the stock market here today had a businesslike air, the actual turnover was small before the weekend.
Mayor O'Dwyer signed yesterday a local law giving the Police Department broad power to regulate the use of sound trucks and other voice-amplifying devices in the city.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Production of plutonium, the man-made active element in the atomic bomb, recently has been stepped up so that output of the substance now is on a "factory-size scale" at the Government's plant in Hanford, Wash., David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, disclosed here today.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle designated yesterday that the week beginning tomorrow be Fire Prevention Week. Calling upon the public to cooperate with the Fire Department to cut down fire losses, Mr. Quayle reported that 169 lives were lost in 1947 and that property losses totaled $21,488,200.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Blanked, 4-0, by Cliff Fannin's three-hit pitching in the twilight opener, the White Sox struck back with a 3-2 decision under the lights tonight to divide a double-header with the Browns before only 2,090 fans.

Robert Bisceglia, 28-year-old president of the 207-209 East 205th Street Realty Corporation, was convicted yesterday of rent gouging and remanded to jail pending investigation and sentence Oct. 15. When his attorney protested against the revocation of bail, Presiding Justice Matthew J. Troy, in Bronx Special Sessions, said: "The time he serves while awaiting sentence will be credited to him when he is sentenced."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- New and improved devices in the field of communications and transport led all others on the list of 435 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- Carrying his campaign for the Vice Presidency into Pennsylvania tonight, Gov. Earl Warren of California told audiences along the way that election of the Republican ticket headed by Governor Dewey would provide the country's greatest protection against communism.

Cleveland's defeat by Detroit yesterday made it impossible for the American League pennant race to be decided before tomorrow -the final day of the regular season. Lending additional spice to this unique situation is the fact that there is no guarantee there will be a definite winner then.

Creston Apartments, Inc., sold the five-story apartment building containing seven stores on a plot 116 by 95 at 2377-9 Creston Avenue, northwest corner of 184th Street, the Bronx, to a client of Norman Siegel, attorney. The property is assessed at $210,000, and was sold for cash over two mortgages totaling $168,000.

The sixteen participating nations in the Marshall Plan recovery program have failed to furnish to the Economic Cooperation Administration a plan to assure an even division of cargo between foreign and American vessels, shipping officials reported in New York yesterday.

Still mounting building construction costs in New York have brought about a drastic revision in the state-city financing of the 1,940-unit low-rent Gov. Alfred E. Smith housing project near Brooklyn Bridge, Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, disclosed yesterday.

The Kings County Savings Bank sold the six-tory apartment building containing forty-two suites at 1236-8 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, to the Senior Management Corporation for investment. Robert Levinson was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $140,000.

The Navy lowered its vision standard for the last war and as a result many a bespectacled sailor earned battle stars for taking part in invasions of Japanese-held Pacific islands. Some lost or broke their glasses hitting the beaches under fire.
PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The death of 22-year-old Kid Dinamita, Santo Domingo welterweight, after a Chicago Stadium bout Wednesday night which paid him $217, was ruled accidental today by a Coroner's jury. Two Illinois boxing code changes were recommended by the jury.

A strike of 14,000 industrial insurance agents of the Prudential Insurance Company in thirty-one states appeared imminent yesterday as plans were made for a national conference of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, to be held here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The State Department sharply attacked in a statement today the Albanian rejection of the recent request of the United States, Britain and France that the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans be permitted to operate in Albanian territory in the course of inquiring into the question of aid allegedly being given there to Greek guerrillas.

Robert Moore Co. of New York, cotton and commission merchants, observed yesterday the 100th anniversary of its founding and the eightieth anniversary of the establishment of its headquarters in this city. It is the oldest active firm in the cotton business and also the oldest member firm in the New York Cotton Exchange, in which the business is conducted by descendants of the founders.

Senator Glen H. Taylor, Progressive party candidate for Vice President, declared yesterday that "a small group of evil men who control the United States Government" were preparing for war against Russia, which, he said, is "arming defensively" against the expected American attack.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -- The West Coast maritime strike enters its second month tomorrow, with no apparent hope of an early solution of the dispute between the striking shoreside and seagoing unions and waterfront employers and shipowners.

Practical homemaking instead of tea ceremony etiquette and elaborate cookery will be urged in the new Japanese school program, Prof. Dora S. Lewis, chairman of the Hunter College home economics department, said yesterday. She has just returned from two and a half months in Japan as home economics consultant to the education division of the United States Army.

In the first ruling of its kind since enactment of the Taft-Hartley Law, Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday found Local 1250 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union of America, CIO, and six of its officers guilty under that law of civil contempt of court for disobeying an injunction he issued on Sept. 14.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- It was denied in informed quarters here today that the question of withholding United States atomic research secrets from Australia ever had come up at a Cabinet meeting attended by Australian Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley July 8 when he was in London.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, struck out directly at President Truman and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today with a furious charge that they were championing an aggressive atomic policy under the "illusion" that the United States had a monopoly on the secrets of atomic power.

The collaboration of architects, designers, painters, sculptors and mosaicists makes one of the most interesting and rewarding of the season's shows. Their work on projects ranging from passenger ships to penthouses is shown in scale models in a newly opened show at the Mortimer Levitt Gallery.
Alexandra Danilova danced her only "Giselle" of the season with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

The seesaw process in the share market on the Stock Exchange was resumed yesterday as fresh recovery set in and lifted prices to the top levels of the week. The oil issues were responsible for much of the new life injected into the list and accounted for the widest gains, although the general increase as measured by the averages held at approximately a point.
The editorial "Your Precious Right to Vote" in THE TIMES urges me to report the following experience:

Trading will be resumed today for the two-hour Saturday session on the New York Stock and New York Curb Exchanges and the other major security markets throughout the country. The markets operated on a five-day week during the summer months.

By state proclamation, Newspaper Week began yesterday. Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley was generously complimentary in this proclamation. He praised New York's newspapers for their "unflinching devotion to their responsibilities." He found that "with exceptions so few as to be negligible they have used their freedom to give their readers a steady stream of accurate, painstakingly acquired information such as is available nowhere else on earth."

GENEVA, Oct. 1 -- Adoption of extreme positions by the Soviet Union on the one hand and the United States on the other has all but extinguished the hopes of the nations of Western and Central Europe for a unanimous accord on means of developing East-West trade.

Edgar Bergen and his alter ego, Charlie McCarthy, will be returning to the NBC network at 8 P.M. tomorrow, but how long Bergen will continue under the sponsorship of Standard Brands was still uncertain. The indications were, however, that it would be for the season's first thirteen-week period at least.

OTTAWA, Oct. 1 -- Two resolutions, one calling for the removal of controls so as to permit the Canadian dollar to find its true value, and the other asking for the establishment of a free market for gold were included today in the Progressive-Conservative party program at its national convention meeting here.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey called on Representative John McDowell, Republican, of Pennsylvania, yesterday to appear before a Federal grand jury here next Thursday to support his charge that the conspiracy indictments obtained by Mr. McGohey against twelve Communist leaders had been drawn up "in such a way that they won't stick."

Jacques Bronstein, Russian pianist, made his formal American debut last night at Town Hall. His program consisted of an unfamiliar Organ Prelude in C minor of Bach, the Bach-Busoni Chaconne, Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata and Schumann's "Etudes Symphoniques."

The automotive industry in the first six months of 1948 continued to hold first place among industrial consumers of steel, but the sharpest increase in steel shipments during that period was made to the oil and gas industries, which are striving to meet unprecedented demands for their products, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Senator Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, today called upon supporters of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's candidacy for the Presidency to refrain from injecting foreign policy into the campaign.
CHARLESTON, W.Va., Oct. 1 -- Following is the text of the address delivered here tonight by President Truman:
BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Supporters of President Truman sought by court action today to restore his name to the Louisiana general election ballot as the Democratic nominee.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Dizzy Dean broke a two-week silence today concerning his and Mrs. Dean's summons to A. B. (Happy) Chandler's office in Cincinnati and disclosed the Baseball Commissioner had received complaints that Diz was betting on games and ridiculing baseball generally.

While more psychiatric aid is needed in correctional institutions, psychiatry alone cannot solve the problem of juvenile delinquency or the adult offender, Dr. Hector J. Ritey, consulting psychiatrist for the Salvation Army's psychiatric service, warned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 -- Victory for the Republican party in the November elections will be "the quickest way to bring on communism in this country," Senator Alben W. Barkley, Vice-Presidential candidate of the Democratic party, asserted here tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1 -One of the best kept football secrets of the year will be out tomorrow. Harvard opens its season under its new head coach, Arthur Valpey, and no one more eagerly awaits the revelation of what he has wrought with the material given him than the young disciple of Fritz Crisler from Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Possible early dissolution of the World Federation of Trade Unions as a result of recent world labor and political developments is foreseen in United States Government and labor circles, according to information available here today.

PARIS, OCT. 1 -- South Africa came out strongly today in the United Nations against the Draft Declaration of Human Rights and subjected to special attack the provisions in the declaration barring racial segregation.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- A last minute request by the French Government caused the secretary general of the Western Union's Permanent Commission to postpone tonight issuance of a communique giving details of its newly formed permanent military organization.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were stronger yesterday and final prices were 2 to 23 points net higher, with near months relatively firmer than the far months.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- A mysteryshrouded shake-up in the front office of the Red Sox spread tonight when it was announced farm director George Toporcer had resigned and that Johnny Murphy, one-time Yankee pitching star, had replaced him.

The United States has had thirtythree First Ladies since Martha Washington. None perhaps filled that unofficial position in our political life more graciously than did the widow of our twenty-fifth President. She made the White House the center of Washington's social life and, at the same time, a real home for her five children and her stepdaughter, Alice, who was married there.

That constant Socialist, Norman Thomas, brings good cheer to the individualist in your columns of Sept. 27. The renunciation of his lifelong idol, the "state," in favor of his new vision, "society," will appear as mere semantic subterfuge but it has a much deeper significance. It signifies the death of a dangerous illusion.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1 -The Princeton eleven will make its 1948 debut tomorrow, meeting Brown in the opener of an eightgame schedule that Coach Charlie Caldwell gloomily terms "the toughest in Princeton history." An estimated turnout of 30,000 persons will watch the Palmer Stadium contest.

Although sales of the Waukesha Motor Company exceeded $26,000,000, attaining a peacetime record for the concern, the earnings for the fiscal year ended with last July declined $242,000 from those of the previous year, according to the report of J. D. DeLong, president, issued yesterday.

For swift recovery of $75,000 in jewels taken from Mrs. Sonja Loew early Wednesday morning in her suite at the Madison Hotel and the arrest of five suspects, three detectives were promoted and three other policemen were commended by Mayor O'Dwyer at Gracie Mansion yesterday.

CORK, Ireland, Oct. 1 -- Premier John A. Costello told a news conference at Cobh on his return today from his tour of Canada and the United States that his Government proposed to cut its last remaining official tie with Britain by removing King George VI as an external executive.
The first group of young men to enter the Army under the new peacetime draft will start to take physical examinations Monday morning, the Army announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- Indications are multiplying that the Ashida Cabinet may be forced to resign as a result of the arrest and detention of Takeo Kurusu, chief of the Economic Stabilization Board, for alleged connection with the Showa Denko company scandal.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 3.5 per cent in September, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The American Farm Bureau Federation today demanded increased allotments for exports of soy beans, vegetable oils, cottonseed meal and other protein feeds.

PANAMA, Oct. 1 -- Domingo Diaz Arosemena, veteran Liberal, was sworn in as President of Panama at a session of the National Assembly today, together with First Vice President Dr. Daniel Chanis and Second Vice President Roberto F. Chiari.
New fabrics, room settings and furniture for the home will be introduced Monday to usher in Home Fashion Time, a week of special events planned by approximately fifty local stores.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Criticizing the Western European defense plan outlined by the Defense Ministers of Britain, France, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg in Paris Wednesday, Charles de Gaulle said today that "Europe must be defended in Europe" and not in London.

Jerome Greene, operator, sold the five-story commercial building under lease to Lane Photographers, Inc., at 112-116 West Eighty-ninth Street to Morris Gottlien and others for cash over a mortgage of $60,000. The property is assessed at $160,000.

Advertising competition for the winter tourist dollar this year is expected to be substantially increased on all fronts as steamship lines carry out an estimated six-fold expansion of cruise facilities, it was said yesterday by an agency official specializing in travel accounts.

With the increased fares on the New York City subways and various bus systems in effect, it is about time for the public to ask a few pertinent questions concerning New York's entire transportation system.

Lisa Kirk signed contracts yesterday to undertake one of the leading feminine roles in "Kiss Me, Kate," the Cole Porter-Sam and Bella Spewack musical, which will be produced jointly by Lemuel Ayers and Arnold Saint Subber. A former night club singer from Roscoe, Pa., Miss Kirk made her Broadway stage debut last year in "Allegro," the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, in which she scored with her song interpretation of "The Gentleman Is a Dope."

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 1 -- The Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin elHusseini, was unanimously elected president of the self-constituted Palestine National Assembly yesterday afternoon at Gaza, provisional Arab capital.

The Rev. Michael A. McGuire has been appointed by Cardinal Spellman as pastor of St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church, 149 East Twenty-eighth Street, to succeed Msgr. William A. Courtney, who died Aug. 30 after serving as the pastor twenty-six years.

REHOVOTH, Israel, Oct. 1 -Hope that the "old traditional friendship between the Jewish people and Britain" would be reestablished was expressed today by Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Provisional President of Israel. He told correspondents at a news conference in the research center here named for him that it was in the interests of both parties that relations should be normal.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -- California's ban on interracial marriages, on the statute books since the first session of the Legislature in 1850, was ruled unconstitutional today by the State Supreme Court in a 4-to-3 decision.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 1 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey made it clear tonight, as he brought his campaign tour of the Pacific Coast and Mountain States to a close, that the State Department was due for an overhauling with all other Federal departments if he is elected President.
High futures prices on the Commodity Exchange reversed a fourday trend and advanced 15 to 25 points on yesterday's trading.

Jake LaMotta of the Bronx scored a knockout victory over Johnny Colan, Astoria light heavyweight, in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. At 1:32 of the final session, Referee Ruby Goldstein intervened.

The Citizens Budget Commission added its weight yesterday to proposals for solving the city's traffic problems by creation of an independent traffic commission with full powers to "initiate, consider and act."

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The workers who conducted a four-hour strike today in the nationalized public service gas and electric plants declared that it was meant as a warning of more drastic action if the Government did not meet their demands.

It was reassuring to read in THE TIMES of Oct. 1 the strong repudiation voiced by Cardinal Spellman and Father La Farge of the shocking statements attributed to the ecclesiastical member of the Film Censorship Board in Madrid in its rejection of "Gentleman's Agreement."

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Final division of the Marshall Plan dollars and adoption of the first year's European program, long delayed by a split in the European Council for the Plan, are now held up by disagreement between the British and the Americans over the payments convention for European trade.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 -- Guy W. Ray, Charge d'Affaires of the United States Embassy here, will fly to Washington tomorrow and confer there with Ambassador James Bruce before Mr. Bruce starts back for his post here.

THE best books about the war, in poetry or prose, in fiction or in fact, is still Bill Mauldin's "Up Front." We got it out again yesterday. Three years -- and an atomic age -later, it reads and looks and wears well. It has the simplicity of greatness, the greatness of simplicity. These are the qualities that so many other worthy war books lack.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Pittsburgh unloaded four of its six hits off Walker Cress after two were out in the ninth inning today and defeated Cincinnati, 2 to 1.

" World Communion Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in virtually every Protestant church in the New York area. The "Last Supper," instituted by Jesus Christ in the "upper room" in Jerusalem, will be commemorated by worshipers in cathedral and humble house of worship, and at every altar prayers will be offered that peace soon may be restored in the Holy City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- "No people have lost their liberties so long as their press remained free," Secretary George C. Marshall said today in a statement released through the State Department in conjunction with the start of National Newspaper Week.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Chiding pessimists who predict the United Nations will fail, Herbert V. Evatt, President of the third General Assembly, declared today that the current session would help to bridge the gap between East and West.

A walkout of 1,100 window cleaners in the five boroughs and Westchester took place yesterday over wage demands. Local 2, Window Cleaners Union, AFL, which called the strike, said that as a result of speedy settlements on the basis of modified demands thirty contractors of the 275 affected, had signed up since Thursday night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Revival of inactive accounts was described today as the most economical and most effective method of increasing a merchant's charge sales by A. L. Trotta, manager of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Good Association.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 -- Beginning a nine-day campaign swing along the Pacific Coast, one of his chief centers of support, Henry A. Wallace tonight warned against an "inevitable economic depression unless we act quickly to protect and increase the buying power of the American people and to stop this war-economy inflation spiral."

The recent letters of R. W. Hubble and Robert Smith in your columns once more emphasize the astonishing failure of New Yorkers to recognize their city as the birthplace of baseball, and to give proper credit to a New Yorker, Alexander Joy Cartwright, as the man who devised the modern game.

Two new films, one each from Hollywood and France, comprise today's new arrivals along Broad way. "The Black Arrow," based on the Robert Louis Stevenson story and co-starring Louis Hayward and Janet Blair, will open at the Ambassador.

No one was surprised when Andrei Y. Vishinsky, chief Soviet delegate to the United Nations Assembly, rose yesterday in a real or simulated fury to denounce the American plan for controlling dangerous uses of atomic energy. More than twenty-seven and a half months have passed since the essentials of this plan were proposed by Bernard M. Baruch.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- A forecast for a record corn crop of 3,550,000,000 bushels, which would be 1,150,000,000 in excess of last year and 300,000,000 larger than the record set in 1946, led today to general selling of corn futures on the Board of Trade, with prices off around 2 cents a bushel at one time.

PARIS, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Following are excerpts from the speech of Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky at today's meeting of the United Nations Political Committee during a debate on atomic energy control:

With 100 special assistant attorneys general working in cooperation with twenty-three assistant superintendents of schools and their staffs, the administration of literacy tests in 350 centers of the city proceeded yesterday to the satisfaction of all the political parties for the first time since registration week began.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- While Britain's scrap hungry steel industry welcomes the prospect of additional supplies from Germany under the Anglo-American agreement announced in Washington and London tonight, the quantity still falls far short of what the industry had hoped to receive.

DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Scoring in every period after playing for the breaks and making them pay off, the University of Detroit routed Marquette, 34 to 6, tonight for the most one-sided Titan victory in their twenty - eight - year - old football series.
Random notes.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The debate in the United Nations on the problem of genocide continued today with the British member of the Legal Committee pointing out that any eventual tribunal to punish genocide should be international, rather than national, in character as recommended by Poland and the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- Dr. Frank L. Tolman, president of the Civil Service Employees Association, Inc., declared today that no representative of his association was present at a meeting at which, according to the Democratic National Committee, Governor Dewey made an attack on the Civil Service system.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 1 -- More than 2,000,000 passenger cars and 1,000,000 trucks have been produced in the first eight months of this year or 11 per cent above the same period in 1947, Karl M. Richards of Detroit, manager of the field service department, Automobile Manufacturers Association, said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Representatives of six Middle Western Stock Exchanges met today in closed sessions in the offices of the Chicago Stock Exchange to discuss a proposal for the formation of a single Exchange to handle the business of all six.

A Brooklyn high school teacher with fifteen years' experience risked the possibility of the loss of his position yesterday when he refused to answer questions from a House subcommittee on communism in the Teachers Union, CIO.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 1 -- Effective Monday blocked Deutscne mark accounts resulting from the currency reform program will be disposable under a law announced today by the Military Governors of the three Western zones.
Two additional charges of unethical practices were made yesterday by the Brooklyn Bar Association against Leon Fischbein and Emanuel Rosenberg, Brooklyn criminal lawyers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Frankie Albert's passes, coupled with a strong running game outside the tackles, gave the San Francisco Forty-Niners a 31-14 victory over the Chicago Rockets in Soldier Field tonight before 14,553 fans. It was the sixth successive All-America Conference victory for the Forty-Niners and the Rockets' fifth loss in six starts.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company in its condition statement for Sept. 30 reported yesterday total deposits of $1,324,085,140 and total assets of $1,477,246,545, compared, respectively, with $1,360,694,693 and $1,515,183,172 on June 30.

The reorganization of the Departmentof Sanitation into threeseparate branches under the generaladministration of Commissioner William J. Powell becameeffective yesterday. The streamlined set-up,, as approved byMayor O'Dwyer, calls for divisions of operations, administration and staff whose directorsare responsible only to IV[r.,Powell.

Products of New England craftsmen, many of whom work in converted barns in out-of-the-way villages, are searched out every summer by the owners of Handmade by Hilary, at 436 East Eightysixth Street. The shop reopens today for the winter with some new home accessories, in addition to recent shipments of already-popular American craft items.
Twenty-two young women raised their right hands, repeated an oath, and found themselves in the United States Navy yesterday.

Many rivers are born on the northland highlands. From underground veins in ages-old layers or granite and volcanic residue springs bubble forth through cracks in the earth's crust. Small rivulets wind down the open slopes above timber line; they join other flowing streams and course downward through the belt of spike evergreens -- the firs, spruces and tamaracks.
Yesterday was "Jamaica Day" in Jamaica, Queens -- a day in which many of the community's stores offered bargains to attract a record throng of shoppers.

Senator Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island, chairman of the nationalities division of the Democratic National Committee, criticized last night as "an unwarranted infringement on operations of the State Department" the action of Senator Chan Gurney, Republican, of South Dakota, in advocating resumption of full relations between the United States and Spain.

Sixty-five warehousemen, members of Local 138, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, went on strike yesterday at the warehouse of Ludwig Baumann, furniture dealers, at 45 Pearson Street, Long Island City, Queens. Members of three other unions refused to cross the picket lines, and employees of the United Parcel Company, who are members of the same local but are working under a different contract, also refused to enter the warehouse.

The Citizens Union on recommendation of its executive committee announced yesterday its endorsement of George Frankenthaler, Republican and Liberal party candidate for Surrogate of New York County, as one having "exceptional qualifications for this important office."
HOPEWELL, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Two sisters were killed and two other persons injured seriously here today when a Reading Railroad interurban car overturned and burned after jumping a switch.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The radio broadcasting industry expects business revenues in 1948 aggregating 7.4 per cent more than in 1947, but its operating expenses will increase by 10 per cent over those of last year, the National Association of Broadcasters announced today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican, of New Jersey, called tonight for national unity on all fronts and for a close stand by the Western Powers, "in light of the critical turn of events at the meeting of the United Nations Assembly in Paris."
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Ministry of Supplies announced tonight it is raising the prices of a number of metals because of increased costs of imported supplies.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Evidence that the Palestine situation was deteriorating rapidly came today in two cablegrams to the United Nations Security Council, one from United States Consul General John J. Macdonald, chairman of the Jerusalem Truce Commission, and the other from Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- An agreement between the United States and the United Kingdom was announced by the State Department tonight under which buyers in each country may purchase immediately 500,000 tons of iron and steel from the bizonal area of Germany.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- If Governor Dewey becomes President there will be a mass exodus from Washington "the like of which has not been seen in history," Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley said here tonight at a Republican rally in Dyckman Hall. One hundred persons attended.

Declines in prices of meats, poultry and table fats will be the first thing shoppers will notice in the stores today. Probably the abundance of fruits and vegetables will not attract so much attention. Nevertheless it offers a better opportunity for thrifty marketing.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Penicillin dust, inhaled directly into the nose, throat and lungs, has cured symptoms of the common cold in one to three days, three physicians reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Institution of less rigid controls of grain exports by the Department of Commerce when the Department of Agriculture returns grain export purchases to private channels on Dec. 1 was recommended today to the Office of International Trade by a fourteen-member advisory committee.

There has grown up this year a somewhat cynical attitude toward political campaigns. This attitude shrugs its shoulders and asks wearily what good President Truman's tours will do, and what good Mr. Dewey's. The average voter already has made up his mind, the doctrine runs, and so why clutter up the presses and the air waves with material of far less importance than football?

BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- All Boston hung on loudspeakers today to hear details from Cleveland of the Indians' defeat by the Tigers and Manager Joe McCarthy of the Red Sox, spending the day in his hotel room listening to radio reports, was no exception.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 1 -- The cablegram of the Jerusalem Truce Commission charged Dr. Joseph and the Israeli Brigade Command in Jerusalem with having led a deliberately hostile campaign that might entail "grave consequences" for United Nations officials. It was made public here today.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, alternate United States representative on the United Nations Security Council, will represent the United States when the Council meets Monday at 3 P.M. to consider the Western powers' charges that the Soviet blockade of Berlin constitutes a threat to peace.

A walkout that is expected to shut newsstand and soft-drink bars at railroad stations and terminals in New York, Long Island, Westchester and southern Connecticut started at 12:01 A.M. today after negotiations between the Union News Company and Local 906, News Distribution Employees Union, CIO, collapsed at 11:30 o'clock Friday night.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Congressional investigators asked today that eleven present and former members of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union, CIO, be cited for contempt of Congress.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis declared constitutional today a New Rochelle ordinance that requires the payment of $25a-day fees for use of highway loudspeakers and restricts the noise to certain hours.

All India will be commemorating today the seventy-ninth anniversary of the birth of its greatest modern leader, Mahatma Gandhi. Indians are divided on many matters. They are not divided in veneration of Gandhi. In time, the date of Oct 2 may become officially a national date of remembrance in India as are the birthdates of Washington and Lincoln in our country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called on Admiral W. W. Smith, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, today to try to effect a resumption of negotiations in the West Coast maritime strike.

Declines in the cost of subsistence items will immediately benefit the clothing industries, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, asserted yesterday. If such declines in the cost of living are possible under the Government's program for supporting farm prices, he said, textile and garment markets will get a much needed boost.

The pace of stock split-ups on the New York Stock Exchange this year has been slower than a year ago. Splitting of stocks has been confined principally to "old-line" companies long listed on the Big Board instead of the conglomeration of enterprises characterizing activity, in 1947, a survey indicates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Class I railroads today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission for an increase of 8 per cent in all except a few freight rates. Estimated to produce an added annual revenue of $672,500,000 on what the railroads think the 1949 traffic will be, the rise is intended to meet a deficiency of $625,000,000 which the roads say is not offset by previous general freight rate increases.
W. L. Cavanaugh has resigned from the rayon fabrics division of North Carolina Finishing Company to join the Housatonic Dyeing and Printing Company, Derby, Conn., as sales manager.
Directors of the Monsanto Chemical Company have approved several major changes in the administrative organization, William M. Rand, president, announced yesterday after a meeting in St. Louis, Mo.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 1 -Plans to expand a program, in which five American union workers are granted scholarships to study in a British university, into a two-way "Rhodes scholar" exchange movement for trade unions of both countries was described yesterday by Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 -Irving Cummings has virtually concluded a deal with RKO for production and release of "The Pasadena Story," which he acquired seven months ago, it was learned today.

The Rokeby Stables' American Way, with an assist from the other half of the Jack Skinner-trained entry, Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Trough Hill, won the $31,425 Grand National Steeplechase Handicap over three miles and nineteen jumps at Belmont Park yesterday.

The possibility that New York and Chicago may join next year in a municipally sponsored opera program, with each city sharing its talent and resources, was disclosed yesterday in an announcement that the New York City Opera Company would present nineteen performances in the Midwestern city, beginning Dec. 1.

The swirling American League pennant race rushed to its climactic stage yesterday as the Yankees entrained for Boston for their concluding two-game series with the Red Sox at the very moment the front-running Indians were battling the Tigers in Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -The Federal Power Commission voted 3 to 2 today to turn down the application of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company to extend its natural gas facilities from northeastern Kentucky to New York at this time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced a $3,500,000 program today to step up the production of "cold rubber," which it said offered about 30 per cent longer mileage in tire treads.

The new tags that are to be attached to New York State 1948 automobile license plates to effectuate registration for 1949 will be offered for sale about the first week of December, it was learned yesterday.

Retail Sales Down in Week Retail trade here this week declined from the corresponding period last year when cooler weather resulted in extremely good volume. Department store sales were estimated as about 5 per cent below those of last year. Sales last week were unchanged.

The viewpoints of the Board of Standards and Appeals are "archaic" as regards parking garage facilities, Borough President Hugo Rogers of Manhattan declared yesterday in endorsing proposed changes in the Zoning Resolution that would encourage construction of such garages by private builders.

Julius Hochman, general manager of the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, said yesterday that the union's drive against gangster attacks on the industry had created a better atmosphere in the garment district.

Fifteen painters, sculptors and graphic artists are to receive scholarships from the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation, 1083 Fifth Avenue, totaling $20,000 in cash grants, the foundation announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -Heavily favored Boston College won a hard-fought football game tonight, 13 -- 6. Georgetown put up a whale of a fight all the way and was on the two-yard line when the game ended.

Having received their first te of actual combat last week, college football squads throughout the nation return to action today for a program that appears to be chockful of "naturals." Tough games are liberally sprinkled through the day's card, a set-up that should help observers gain a true line on a number of elevens after which question marks have been placed.

Nine men are believed to have died early this morning when a tug, towing two barges down the Hudson River, sank after a collision with a northbound oil tanker off Pier 65, near West Twentyfifth Street.
EGLIN FIELD, Fla., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The latest air-ground tactics will be demonstrated here next week when the armed forces unification program is a year old.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- In a candid appraisal of British producers' chances of expanding exports to the United States, the Board of Trade stressed today the need for exporters to study price, design and quality desires of American buyers more closely.

Brushing away the cobwebs left over from their pennant-victory celebration of the night before, the Braves yesterday made their last 1948 appearance at Ebbets Field a winning one. On just four hits they beat the Dodgers, 3 -- 1, as rookie Vernon Bickford went all the way in registering his eleventh triumph.

ATLANTA, Oct. 1 -- At a special session today the Georgia Legislature approved a "free election" measure. This permits Presidential and Vice Presidential electors of any party to get on the November general election ballot, provided they swear they are not Communists.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Yugoslavia's fear of Russia was shown this afternoon in a blunt statement made by I. Mattes, the Yugoslav delegate, made at the meeting of the United Nations Economic Committee, when his nomination by Denmark for the committee's vice chairmanship was opposed by Poland, which nominated V.P. Smolar, a delegate from Byelorussia [White Russia].

A style of living that is twentyfour hours, not twenty-four years, away is the theme of the exhibit, "Tomorrow's World," which opened yesterday at the Museum of Science and Industry under the sponsorship of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
BALTIC, Conn., Oct. 1 (AP) -Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, Democratic nominee for Congress from the Second Connecticut District, rejected today support from the Henry A. Wallace Progressive party.

In-patient and clinic departments of the eighty-six nonprofit voluntary hospitals in New York must be prepared at all times to treat the ill who suffer afflictions that run the medical alphabetical gamut from Assmus (Asthma) to Zymosis (infectious or contagious disease).

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- After weeks of silence, during which time the City Assembly was forced to move its meeting quarters from the Soviet sector to the British sector, Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov, Soviet commandant in Berlin, assured the elected city officials today they could find safety in the Soviet sector.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 1 (AP) -Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans, carding his second 67 in a row, swept into the lead of the 72-hole Portland open golf tournament today with a halfway total of 134.

A strike of 2,300 workers at twenty-eight Childs restaurants in this city was ordered for 5 P.M. today after negotiations for a new contract broke down at 11:30 P.M. yesterday in the office of the State Mediation Board, union leaders announced early today.

Jewish leaders expressed yesterday faith in the future of the new State of Israel, in messages in connection with Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5709, which will be ushered in at sunset tomorrow with services in temples and synagogues.

More than a year ago youthful Anthony Donna of 168 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, photographed the elaborate wedding of his friend, Peter Kichura and Mary Zihal, now of 412 Bradford Street, Brooklyn, at St. Mary's Greek Catholic Church on East Thirteenth Street.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan, denied today that the Government stands to lose millions of dollars through farm price support operations.

Sixteen pounds of pure heroin, valued unofficially in diluted state on the illegal market at approximately $640,000, was seized yesterday aboard the Italian-flag liner Vulcania by search-squad members of the Customs Enforcement Division.

Registration in this city showed a spurt yesterday on the fifth and next to last registration day here, but the five-day total still was below the civilian registration for 1944, the last Presidential election year.

Curtailment of production of men's shoes by the International Shoe Company and the reduction of its tanning operations by the American Hide and Leather Company was held by trade interests yesterday to indicate lower shoe production for the final quarter of this year.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals took over undisputed possession of second place in the National League tonight by turning back the Chicago Cubs, 6 to 4. A three-run homer by Ron Northey highlighted a 5-run inning which clinched the victory for the Redbirds.

The New York Shipping Association, which has been negotiating with the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, for a new contract to replace the one that expired on Aug. 21, was asked yesterday to join with the union in an appeal to President Truman for aid in resolving their dispute.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 1 -Three young men, said by police to be members of a gang wanted for a series of armed holdups and robberies in Bergen, Essex and Hudson Counties, were held without bail today by Judge Anthony J. Botti in First Criminal Court here.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 1 -- Following is the prepared text of a campaign speech here tonight by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York:

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Oct. 1 -President Truman tonight pinned the Republican Eightieth Congress squarely on his opponent, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, and said a Republican victory in November would bring "a headlong dash toward another depression."
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Amid the rolling green hills of Spruce Mountain and blanketed by a warm sun, the Danbury Fair unfolded its seventy-fifth annual edition here today for a nine-day run.

LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Big Bones, brown gelding owned by Walter Wickes Jr., of West Chester, Pa., today won the eleventh running of the International Gold Cup Steeplechase. Handled brilliantly by J. Zimmerman, Big Bones took an early lead and scored by twelve lengths in 5 minutes, 19 4.5 seconds.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Full speaking schedules face the major candidates for the office of United States Senator from New Jersey this week, with the high spot of the campaigning the appearance in the state of President Truman.

ROME, Oct. 2 -- The Pope today issued a warning against systems of taxation that "relegate to last place the people's legitimate ambition to enjoy the fruits of their own labor and their anxiety for the security of their families."

AUTUMN is one of the best and busiest seasons in the Midsouth. Horse shows and tobacco balls, yam fetes and local fairs are on the long list of fall events. Motorists drive through the mountains and along the Skyline Drive to see the fall colors.

MR. Komroff has tried hard to make his middle-class family and their misfortunes credible and appealing. Unfortunately he has involved them in a situation that neither he nor they can manage, has reported their stutterings with maddening accuracy and finally drowned them in an ocean of platitudes.
A combination of factors is affecting retail sales and production of men's clothing, it was reported here yesterday.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Villanova College rebounded from its Army football defeat to rout Duquesne University, 46 to 0, today, ending the Golden Dukes' unbeaten streak at two games.

Ludwig Juht, who plays the contra-bass -- largest and lowest of the viol family -- gave a concert in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon before an enthusiastic audience. He programmed works by Corelli, Bottesini, Gardner Read and first performances of Eduard Tubin, Juhan Aavik and Leo Wirkhaus, Estonian countrymen of the performer.

Beginning tomorrow night at 7 o'clock the New York Power Squadron will launch its weekly class in advanced piloting at Julia Richman High School, Second Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. Enrollments of squadron members are being received at Room 905, 507 Fifth Avenue.

THE house in which I spent my childhood was a three-story box covered with brown shingles. It had cream-colored trim and several porches. There was the usual assortment of rooms inside, except that they were oversized by today's standards.
!Henri Crenier, sculptor, whose Work may be seen in many parts df the country, died Friday in his ]ome at 350 East Fifty-fourth g treet, after a brief illness. His e was 74.

IF this department is occasionally helpful, as its readers sometimes tell me, in directing their attention to books they have missed or ignore, it is only fair to mention the fact that the service is reciprocal. On numerous occasions I have been indebted to readers of this page for putting me on the track of books I had either missed or ignored.

THE nascent "Canadian Pacific" -- Hollywood's first railroad epic since "Union Pacific," of glittering and gun-happy memory -- may or may not win an Academy award, but it certainly will go down in the books as in many respects an exceptional undertaking.

CROTON, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- While the smallest of New York City's reservoirs is almost empty, it was announced today that the city still has 174,000,000,000 gallons of water in storage in different reservoirs despite the long dry spell. This is 69 per cent of capacity.

The New York Public Library's Current Affairs Program that holds open meetings at six of its branches for the discussion of affairs of local national and international interest, opens the new season this week.

MANKATO, Minn., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Senator Albert W. Barkley urged Minnesota farmers tonight to elect Hubert Humphrey to the Senate to help the Democrats in their fight for a "wise and liberal farm program."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2 -- In this baseball-mad community some 20,000 Bostonians forgot all about the Red Sox and the Braves today in a roaring stampede to get on the bandwagon of a Harvard football team without equal in many long years.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP)-- Outmanned and outlucked, Bucknell wilted in the second half today and Penn State began its 1948 football campaign with a 35- to-0 victory before 15,000 fans.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Why and how did Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky make the mistake, in his speech before the United Nations this week, of referring to an Esso map as showing "The Third World War, Pacific Theatre of Military Operations"?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Declaring that he had "just begun to fight," President Truman ended his 8,300-mile transcontinental campaign tour with a noisy Washington welcome today. He went at once to the White House to work on official business for four days before setting out on another vote-seeking appeal in Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and up-state New York.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 2 -- Evenly matched throughout, New York University and Springfield College battled to a scoreless tie for three periods today, but a blocked kick late in the fourth quarter and Keith King's field goal from the N.Y.U. 6-yard line gave the Gymnasts a 3-0 victory before 4,000 fans at Pratt Field.
From Paris last week, a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES cabled this description of the almost daily clashes between the de Gaullists and the Communists:

All freshmen enrolled in the School of Engineering at Princeton University will now be required to take an orientation course known as Industrial Development and an introductory survey course. Faculty representatives of the six engineering departments will participate in the Industrial Development course, which will explain the functions of industry and the engineer's place in it.

"Slow-fuse" nuclear fission, a new type of atomic activity far more violent than the splitting of uranium, has been brought about by the giant 184-inch cyclotron at the University of California. Bismuth, lead, gold and several other metallic elements can be made to undergo slow-fuse fission.

THE Bill of Rights contains a contradiction. The First Amendment to the Constitution upholds freedom of speech. Infliction of cruel and unusual punishments is proscribed in the Seventh Amendment. So, we have our cake and eat it; speech is both free and a punishment.

IF, as is often said, Dad is guilty of buying toys more for himself than for Junior, Mother is equally guilty of encroaching on the juvenile world by planning the nursery primarily as a delight for the eyes of her guest. It seems obvious that children's rooms should have meaning for their young occupants.

LET'S review the case of Mrs. Morton. Every time she asked junior or sister to help dry the dishes or otherwise be useful in the kitchen, she received a barrage of no's, screams and tantrums. She decided to take up these responses with the child's teacher, the school psychologist and other professional consultants, because she thought her kitchen was well equipped and arranged -- in short, a setting in which everyone would enjoy working.

THERE are various kinds of fear -- almost as many as there are men to be afraid -- but we may narrow them down to two main categories: individual fear, which is a natural part of the human character, and collective or mass fear, which comes from the lack of any character at all.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Cornell University's two-year campaign to raise a $12,500,000 Greater Cornell Fund will get underway next week during ceremonies marking the university's eightieth anniversary.

PROFESSOR MILLS, who teaches sociology at Columbia University, tackles the thesis that America's labor leaders lead the only organizations capable of stopping the drift towards war and slump. Will they rise to the opportunities to reorganize modern society, or will they continue preoccupied with their own petty power domains in the established order?

WHEN Lenin died, a quarter century ago, his revolution and the struggle over his inheritance seemed events securely removed from the Western Hemisphere. Today their consequences make daily headlines in the American press; their growing impact demands a better understanding of their motivating forces.
FOLSOM, Calif., Oct. 2 -- A dynamite blast today marked the start of construction on the $50,000,000 Folsom Dam, which will span the American River three miles east of this northern California town.
THE homemaker should analyze her special cleaning problems before deciding which kind of vacuum cleaner is most desirable and which are the best ways of using it. Does her home have one floor or two?

THE question of what is a political film and what is a non-political film has been kicked around a good deal at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer ever since the studio bought Bruce Marshall's novel. "Vespers in Vienna," nearly two years ago. Initially, the studio denied that the project was politically significant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Representative Jesse P. Wolcott, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, today accused President Truman of deliberately trying to keep prices up while blaming the Republican Congress for the high cost of living.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The Navy announced today it would demonstrate the reported advantages of aircraft carriers, over land bases, in a transoceanic re-fueling ferry operation this week.
HOW to think out a room, to settle the arrangement, to decide which pieces to retain, which to discard -- these are problems with which everyone confronts the interior designer.
PARIS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton of Canada said today that "there is no precise indication that Russia has the atomic bomb yet -- but they will have it one day."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The Fish and Wildlife Service reported sadly tonight that in four years of searching it had failed to find the nesting grounds of the whooping crane.

ONE hundred years ago almost nobody except Concordians and a few personal acquaintances knew Henry David Thoreau. Even those few never imagined that he would some day be recognized, and in some cases worshiped, as one of America's great and original writers.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- Observers of the New England political scene agree that Gov. Earl Warren of California completed this week a regional speaking tour that was in the best tradition of Republican strategy, paving the way for the Republican standard-bearer, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.
MORE and more Americas are realizing that a wall without pictures is as unfriendly as an untrimmed window, as unfinished as a lamp without a shade.

District Attorney Frank Hogan is investigating a complaint that a group of men invaded a non-union dress shop Friday afternoon and took a cutter and two other employes to union headquarters for a "talking to," it was disclosed yesterday.
SCENE: In front of Shubert Theatre, Boston. Lerner and Weill are standing breathing in the morning air. A man comes by and stares at the theatre marquee.

Jews the world over will usher in Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5709, today at sunset with services in temples and synagogues. The holiday, observed twenty-four hours by Reform Jews and two days by the orthodox, will begin ten days of prayer and penitence ending with Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The present Supreme Court of the United States has progressed far afield from the area to which that tribunal for many years confined itself in adjudicating disputes over internal matters in the several states. But some observers think that Justice Hugo L. Black this week took a position which, if sustained by his "brethren," may mark a halt in this tendency and perhaps even a moderate retreat from it.

Living flesh is composed largely of nitrogen. Eighty per cent of the air is nitrogen. Neither plants nor animals can convert this atmospheric nitrogen directly into protein and so into beefsteak, egg white, milk and other foods. The nitrogen has to be "fixed" -- that is, transformed into a solid compound that can be chemically utilized.

TABLE settings, like meals, should be planned in advance. A good color scheme, a pleasing arrangement, handsome accessories -- all are wasted if the setting does not prove efficient in the actual service of the meal. For the majority, who have neither butler nor maid and may not even have a separate room for dining, planning the table setting is of special and vital importance.

LONDON, Oct. 2 (Reuters) -- Undefeated Portsmouth strengthened its lead in the first division of the English Football League today with a 1-0 victory over Newcastle United. Second-place Derby County, also undefeated, slipped back a point when held to a scoreless draw at Liverpool.

Industrial mobilization planning is a larger job for American management than has been envisaged so far, and more time will be required for completion of suitable programs because defense agencies are not wholly satisfied with the progress that has been made.

THERE is more versatility in rug and carpet design today simply because manufacturers have become more fully aware of what homemakers expect of a floor covering. Homemakers want value for their money. In addition to quality, style and color they want carpets that are washable, moth-and-mildew-proof; rugs that won't skid; rugs that are fashion-right without being spectacular, rugs that can take real abuse.

ONE of the most reliable group of plants for indoor bloom through the winter is the small-leaved begonia, now being lifted from its outdoor bed in preparation for its annual sojourn in the house. As nearly fool-proof as a plant can be, these begonias will thrive and flower constantly both indoors and out.

IN contemporary architecture the color of a house -- inside and out -- is increasingly the color of the materials with which the house is built. Color, in other words, is not something applied after the house is constructed; it has become a basic part of architecture.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander in Germany, reiterated today the Soviet Union's willingness to reopen the negotiations on the Berlin question "on the basis of the agreement reached at Moscow Aug. 30."
