AIRLINE presidents are beginning to smile. A month ago they were uttering the cry, "Save us or we perish," before the Civil Aeronautics Board. They were asking a 10 per cent increase in air passenger fares, which they got.

BALTIMORE, Oct 2 -- Speaking before 3,500 persons in the Lyric Theatre here, Gov. Earl Warren of California, the Republican candidate -for Vice President, called tonight for a reunited opposition Democratic party.

MR. CARY'S prose has a well disciplined quality which has gone somewhat out of fashion. He is writing in the first person about a feminine character, and the spontaneity of the narrative never slips a notch. Sara Monday, the "I" of the narrative, is a woman, warm and real, and twice as natural as most women in fiction, never mind the gender of the author.

Just as there are bait and fly casters who have never fished, there are shotgun and rifle shooters who have never hunted, and the other day one of them, a man who at one time held a prized shooting crown, inquired of us as to "what makes a hunter?"

DURING the war it was important to obtain the most heat from the least fuel in order to conserve limited supplies. This year, with the increased prices of coal, oil and gas, heating efficiency remains as important as ever.

A diver late yesterday afternoon began operations to raise the tugboat Anne Marie Tracy, which went to the bottom, of the Hudson River in the morning after a collision with the freighter Eliza J. Nicholson.

NOT so long ago resilient tile floor coverings were considered the exclusive concern of the architects. Unless one was building or doing over a place from the ground up, one was not supposed to take an interest in cork, plastic, asphalt, rubber or linoleum tile floors.

THE guest room may be as pretty as a picture and a welcome retreat for the visiting Joneses -- if they arrive in the middle of the day and see it as the sun filters through the windows and the bedspreads look smooth after a final pat. But suppose they arrive at midnight, when the spreads have been removed and the blankets turned back in readiness?

ALL the illusions you've ever acquired from books, magazines or movies about the South Sea islands being a collective paradise will be shattered by reading Mr. Furnas' historical survey of them. He has taken them apart with clinical enthusiasm, and by the time he is finished there is little left except some well-dissected viscera.

WILLIAM COLLINS WHITNEY, President Cleveland's 1892 campaign manager and first-Administration Secretary of the Navy, 1885-89, may be an unduly forgotten man these days. But he was pretty much the incarnation of America's late nineteenth-century success story.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Minnesota, troubled by fumbles, passed its way to a 39-to-13 victory over Nebraska today before 57,209 fans, a record opening home crowd here.

ONE reads in a newspaper, every now and then, of a perfect hand -- a thirteen-card suit, or a hand with all the aces, kings and queens, or any other combination of cards that can be spread for all the tricks -- but until two weeks ago the writer of this column had never met anyone who had seen such a hand dealt.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 2 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion issued a Jewish New Year's message tonight to the people of Israel saying that the Jewish people's "dream of redemption that countless generations kept' alive" was beginning to come true.

THE action of the Federal Communications Commission last Thursday in calling a temporary halt to further authorization of new television stations is a step of critical importance to the burgeoning video art. Yet at the same time, if needless and costly harm is not to be done to the new industry, its immediate effects should not be exaggerated.
QUEBEC, Oct. 2 -- The day of the "ocean giants," such as the Queen /Vfary and Queen Elizabeth, is over, according to T. C. Lock-i wood, president of Cunard-Donaldson Lines.

HEALTH and home comfort beyond the dreams of our forefathers are promoted by the fans and ventilating devices, air purifiers and allied devices which engineering science has recently made available. Most familiar are the standard household fans, equipped with almost any size of blade from five-inch to thirty-inch span, oscillating and non-oscillating.

Hundreds of occupational therapy jobs in this city are "going beging" for want of trained therapists, Miss Wilma West, executive director of the American Occupation Therapy Association, declared yesterday.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company will soon set up plant organizations in its mills at Amsterdam, N.Y., and Thompsonville, Conn., to give foremen and higher supervisors a definite voice in formation of company practices and policies, Albert W. Hendrickson, management information director, disclosed last week.

A drastic shifting of the traffic currents in Journal Square, Jersey City, and the improvement of the business section there have been recommended in plans submitted to the Jersey City Citizens Advisory Committee, it was announced yesterday. The plans were given to the City Planning Board, which will make recommendations to the City Commissioners after public hearings.

IN what many would consider a satisfactory kitchen, it was found that a homemaker had to walk 448 feet to prepare dinner. By altering the room's arrangement, researchers at Purdue University cut the distance she traveled in getting the same meal to 116 feet.

LONDON (By Wireless). HUMANITY'S incurable craving for a symbolic enemy, to whose sinister influence all its problems and difficulties may be conveniently referred, has been well served in this century of science and enlightenment. The latest of these synthetic monsters is the head of the Russians himself, seen as the symbol of a powerful group of terrible men.

THE NEW YORK TIMES recently published the results of a survey of leading musical organizations in the United States. It has never been a secret to the music-loving public that almost every major opera house or symphony orchestra has been operating at a deficit.

PAINTS are available today which were undreamed of a few years ago. Many were developed during the war for special purposes. In peacetime these paints are providing greater comfort and beauty and may, with further development, lead to notable economies in lighting and heating.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin has declined the post of commander of the land forces of Western Europe, which had been assigned to him in the joint defense plan drafted in Paris by the Defense Ministers of the five Brussels treaty powers, Britain, France, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, it was learned today.

ACCORDING to news which has reached me recently from Hungary, there is considerable musical activity which had its start almost immediately after the cessation of war. It is the more amazing because it followed not only the long war years, but also destruction, internal unrest and the occupation.

UNTIL fairly recently there were only about two choices in ready-made bedspreads -- ordinary and extra-plush. Unless the shopper had the taste, the time and the funds to order a custom-made spread, she had to be satisfied with unimaginative chenilles, dull woven designs, or far too elaborate taffetas and satins.

Still battling to finish in second place, Barney Shotton's Dodgers yesterday were given a slight lift by the erring Phils, who finished on the short end of a 5-4 score, with three of the Brooklyn markers unearned and the winning one tallying on a wild pitch.

AS part of the lengthening shelf of fiction about the late war, there may be set down this morning a novel about the Air Force by James Gould Cozzens, a former employe thereof. Differing in scene from most of its fellows, "Guard of Honor" is not set just back of the front lines with planes flying over Berlin or Tokyo, but in Florida.
Retail activity was consistently good here last week according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Seasonal wear was the most active department.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The fundamental opinion of many high-ranking military and diplomatic officials now gathered in Paris is that a world war is not imminent.

COMPARED to the spectacular performances of the dishwasher and the automatic clothes washer, a hot water heater may seem a humdrum affair. But it is only fair to tell prospective purchasers of those other miracle-workers that it takes something more than a flick of a switch to get best results.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Albanian radio announced a shake-up of the Cabinet and the appointment of a new Chief of Staff today.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Edward H. Hufnagel, 69 years old, real estate broker and retired proprietor of a Mount Vernon jewelry store, shot and killed himself shortly after 8 A.M. today in his home at 10 Rich Avenue. In a note found later by members of his family he wrote that a protracted heart ailment had prompted his act.

TOO frequently when a woman shops for an electric iron, she does no more than compare prices. The intelligent homemaker invests in the iron that best meets her needs. The standard electric iron, the steam iron, the combination steam-and-dry iron, the standard iron with steam attachment -- each should have careful consideration before a purchase is made.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Parliament, homebred colt carrying the Christiana Stables' colors of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lunger of Wilmington, Del., earned his first major victory in the Richard Johnson Stakes today.

GOING into the final quarter of the year, business is riding a fairly steady keel with little or no trouble as a result of the Presidential campaign. It would be correct to sum up the current and near-by situation as "quite all right with no diminution of doubts about the future."
KOENIGSTEIN, Germany, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Fritz Thyssen, former Ruhr steel magnate, was found guilty today as a "minor Nazi" by a German denazification court.

DESPITE predictions by skeptics that no studio here would make it, "The Night Watch," first Hollywood picture to be wrought out of the strife and struggle in Palestine, now is rapidly progressing toward actual filming late this month at Universal - International.

THEATRE parties have long been a favorite target in certain theatrical quarters. But this season it has become downright fashionable. The producers of Moss Hart's "Light Up the Sky" advertised no theatre parties in the Sept. 19 NEW YORK TIMES in the tone and spirit of a public service.

OTTAWA, Oct. 2 -- Premier George A. Drew of Ontario was today elected leader of the Progressive -Conservative party of Canada by a party convention that went wild with excitement when the result of the election was announced.

OLD FORGE -- The 1,960 permanent residents of the Town of Webb in the Central Adirondacks, which embraces Big Moose, Old Forge, Thendara, and First, Second, Third and most of Fourth Lakes, are to decide between now and the November election whether to spend about $25,000 next spring to eradicate the black flies that infest the mountains in early summer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -President Truman and Governor Dewey, whatever their other differences, agreed last week that a Government price-support program for farmers was good for the country, while the rising cost of living was, of course, bad.
YOUNG couples expecting a first baby need a lot of specific information and counseling that, according to one recent study, they very seldom get.

A number of out-of-town buyers visited the wholesale apparel market here last week and concentrated most of their purchasing on holiday lines, with particular emphasis in ready-to-wear divisions, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

INCREASE in frozen-food storage space and greater ice-cube capacity are welcome features of the new refrigerators which generally have become roomier inside without becoming larger in over-all dimensions. Refrigerator production, however, has been limited by the shortage of steel, and a one to two month's wait for delivery, depending on the popularity of the model desired, is the rule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A French scientist has announced a new bug-against-bug test for diagnosing infantile paralysis. He says it may provide science with its long-sought method for detecting polio easily, inexpensively and on a mass scale.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 2 -Residents of this region are talking oil, dreaming oil and buying booming local oil-stock issues these days. The state of Utah is an oil producer at long last.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 2 -- The system of dams and reservoirs designed to develop and control the waters of the Tennessee Valley have a combined gross storage capacity of 21,000,000 acre-feet, the Tennessee Valley Authority announced today in a pre-flood season summary.

IF you can believe that Harriet Beecher Stowe was a heel because she wrote books instead of devoting all her talent and energies to being a wife and mother, you can accept Harlan Ware's novel. And furthermore, you will accept the fast that the Pulitzer Prize for novels could be awarded to a published compendium of "Aunt Jennie's Stories."

COVES over 40, idolators of the good old days, skeptics who wouldn't blaspheme the name of George Sisler by so much as a mention of today's first basemen -- these and all others flirting with arterio-sclerosis will have their memories vividly stirred in reading "Sport's Golden Age," ably and tenderly edited by two ancestor worshipers from the staff of this newspaper.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Altering a previous version of the incident, Florence Begay, 17-year-old Indian student, said tonight it was not the driver who ordered her to sit in a section of a bus reserved for Negroes.

The effectiveness of raising the reserve requirements of banks as an anti-inflationary control when the Government is supporting the market for its own securities received renewed attention last week in banking circles. At the annual convention of the American Bankers Association in Detroit, the matter of reserve requirements under current conditions was a frequently recurring topic of discussion.

THE problems that confront car stylists in their effort to combine utility with handsome design were underscored recently by complaints from members of the Automobile Club of New York that some post-war car changes are impractical.

Three alleged hold-up men who dived into the East River to escape the gunfire of pursuing policemen, two of them swimming a third of a mile to North Brother Island, were captured yesterday morning after a three-hour chase.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The grave tone of the speeches in the General Assembly of the United Nations and the beginning of British rearmament have impressed the British man in the street with the danger of war where the long bickering over Berlin left him comparatively undisturbed.

THE CBS network's program "Invitation to Learning" today at 12 noon will begin a new thirteen-week series of discussions which will consider the personalities of as many individuals as revealed in their journals, memoirs, letters and autobiographies.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- At a spirited session, the 500 librarians attending the annual conference of the New York Library Association were told to join unions and go out on street corners if necessary to fight for higher salaries and better working conditions.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 2 -- Riades Solh, Lebanese Premier, has cabled King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan charging him with responsibility for breaking up the unity of the Arab states by having refused to recognize the Palestine Arab Government at Gaza, according to Cairo press reports.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Offcials of the important Catholic unions of French miners today tried without success to call a truce in the impending coal strike in the French mines.

The silhouettes seen at the openings marked a transition between ballerina fullness which is fading off the fashion stage and tubular lines which are making their entrance. Slim skirts, with a flying back panel, or a sudden flare below the knees, or a spreading tunic, are all transitions between Dior's width, to which he still adheres, and Fath's skirts of extreme narrowness.

Brandeis University will hold its inaugural celebration this week. Located on the site of the former Middlesex College in Waltham, Mass., Brandeis University, opening as a small, liberal arts institution, has mapped out a long-range program that includes the eventual establishment of graduate and professional divisions.

The national IQ may be adversely affected by the low birth rate among college graduates, the Population Reference Bureau warned last week in releasing the results of its third annual survey on this subject.

HATTERAS, N.C. -- Everybody says the fishing along North Carolina's Outer Banks is best in October, but then nobody believes everything a fisherman says. This wide area, admittedly one of the great sports regions of America, has its quota of story-tellers and some of them are justly famous.

ALARMED by the melancholy fact that unemployment among actors is terribly high during a period when more people are employed in the nation than ever before, Actors Equity last spring called in some trained economic consultants.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Buddy 2d, guide dog for ten years of Morris S. Frank, vice president of The Seeing Eye, after guiding his master to his office in The Seeing Eye School here, died this afternoon, apparently of old age.

PARIS -- Gay and bursting at the seams is Paris, with tourists, United Nations delegates and even Parisians. As this is written, we are sitting in a hotel lobby, surrounded by a mound of beat-up luggage and vainly hoping we will be able to snare a room for the night.

SO vast is the variety of designs to be seen among the new printed furnishing fabrics that once can make only a single statement that applies to the field as a whole: the prints of 1948 achieve a higher standard -- both as to artistic merit and to usefulness -- than those of ay other year in normal memory.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Cardinals, battling to retain second place in the National League race, handed the hapless Cubs a 9-to-0 lacing tonight. Home runs by Ron Northey and Red Schoendienst sparked the Birds' 13-hit attack, while Al Brazle and Jim Hearn blanked the Bruins with five blows.
American merchant ship participation in the transport of total United States foreign trade has dropped below the 50 per cent mark for the first time since 1942.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- Coming through with a few sharp, devastating blows, including a homer and two-bagger by their renowned Ted Williams, the Red Sox today brought down the Yankees, 5 to 1, in the opener of their concluding two-game series of the year and with this effort, cheered vociferously by 32,118, reduced the American League's long simmering three-cornered pennant fight to a two-horse race for the final day.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) The Senators, liberally sprinkled with second stringers and rookies, hammered out a 7-1 victory over the Athletics today. Washington got to Bill McCahan for ten hits and all its runs in the first eight innings.
ONE of the great impending changes in the building methods, which is being worked out now in numerous research laboratories, has to do with the nature of the wall.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 2 -- With sophomores leading the way, Cornell's alert, hard-hitting football team made two second-period touchdowns stand up for a 13-7 victory over Navy today.

At the four-day American Gas Association Appliance meeting at Atlantic City, which opens tomorrow, heating engineers will see a jeep running what is technically called a heat pump. The engineers know all about heat pumps, for they have been installing them all over the country in homes and commercial buildings to provide year-round comfort.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawarharlal Nehru voiced tonight his Government's determination to "fight to the utmost, whatever happens, Pakistan's brutal, unforgivable aggression in Kashmir."

The great propaganda war that has been waged with increasing vigor for three years between Russia and the West broke out with new intensity in the United Nations last week. There were strong moves by both sides.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Oct.2 -- Two hundred thousand persons, by police estimate, watched a two-and-three-quarter-hour parade here this afternoon that brought to a close this town's Golden Jubilee celebration.

THE thoughtful moaners at the literary bar who point out that there aren't enough good novels around these days invite the uncharitable answer that there aren't anywhere near enough good readers, either. A nation approaching the 150-million mark shouldn't be any too pleased to note that it provides remarkably few readers for the best that is written in our time.

LA PLATA, Md., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the States' Rights Presidential candidate, attacked President Truman's civil rights program here today before a crowd estimated at more than 7,000.

WITH frosty weather due before October ends, the time approaches for lifting and storing those bulbs which flowered during summer. Like the dahlias and gladiolus, which are perhaps best known in this classification, the others will be an investment for many seasons.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Army's power-packed squad of football operatives went into offensive maneuvers on a major scale this afternoon. Opposed by a courageous Lafayette College combination, which had the will to stop them but not the ability, the West Pointers rolled to a 54-7 triumph at Michie Stadium.
The Maritime Commission intends to intervene in a Department of Justice legal action attacking the basic principles of steamship conferences, it became known here yesterday.
At the termination of an academic year in your country I had the opportunity to travel about 20,000 miles through the United States, alone. That it was a wonderful experience goes without saying.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- Packard Motor Car Company shortly will institute a new liberalized policy affecting supervisors and other management representatives, George T. Christopher, president and general manager, announced here today. The new program is designed to make such personnel feel that they "play a highly important role in our management," he said.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The names of Henry A. Wallace and Alger Hiss have been dropped from the "social list of Washington," it was disclosed tonight.

BEFORE the first World War, the phrase, "It's imported," had a special magic. With European imports completely cut off during World War II, our own creative designers came through with rich, original ideas and fine craftsmanship, and we were properly appreciative.

THE news that the Whitney Museum has abandoned its plan of coalition with the Metropolitan raises the important question of the respective functions of New York's three leading art museums -- the Metropolitan, the Whitney and the Museum of Modern Art.

More than customary interest is being shown in the third-quarter condition statements of banks here, which are now starting to appear as a result of the recent increases in reserve requirements on demand and time deposits. Not only will the changes in earnings over a year ago be surveyed but the effect of the higher reserve rates on earning assets will come in for close inspection.

For the first time in many years, there is now no generally recognized scale of wholesale market prices for stainless steel materials, distributors disclosed yesterday. Steel warehouses seeking to discontinue their business throughout the country also were said to be offering their inventories, valued from $100,000 upward, to New York jobbers on a close-out basis.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Walter Coyman, 36 years old, of 310 Washington Avenue, was shot and wounded critically this morning by Edmon Alston, 31, of 1254 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, according to the police.

A ten-year program to rehabilitate the depleted Chinese coastal merchant marine is reported under way. In releasing details of the project yesterday a spokesman for the Cleveland Diesel Engine Division of General Motors announced that his concern had contracted to furnish power plants for six new vessels.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 -- As mysteriously as a ban against the use of cable and wireless facilities by five foreign correspondents had been effected this morning, it was lifted at 10 o'clock tonight after twelve hours.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 2 -- A funeral service for Mrs. Edith Kermit Carow Roosevelt, widow of former President Theodore Roosevelt, was held this morning in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here.

Helen Keller, the blind and deaf author, who is making a tour of the Orient in the interests of the blind, is receiving one of the most enthusiastic receptions granted any visitor to Japan since the American Occupation began, it was reported yesterday by the John Milton Society, 156 Fifth Avenue, sponsor of the tour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Back from his first transcontinental tour, where he undoubtedly made friends and gained votes, President Truman is stepping up the tempo of his campaign with only a four-day pause before he tries to influence the electorate of Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and upstate New York.

PARIS is at once the great lady and the eternal coquette among the cities of the world; and since the French theatre reposes on her bosom like a somewhat tarnished family jewel, drama circles here inevitably reflect the proud feminine tremors of excitement attendant on the arrival in town of the distinguished gentlemen of the UN and its General Assembly.

FOR THIS WEEK: Treat peach trees with paradichlorobenzene crystals for borers. . . . Soak the soil thoroughly around any plants that have been moved within the last month. . . . This is a good time to get rid of broad-leaved weeds such as plantain and dandelion by spraying the lawn with 2, 4-D. Seed the bare areas in two or three weeks. . . .

DEVON, Pa., Oct. 2 -- Ch. Smilestone's Bric-a-Brac, the solid black miniature poodle belonging to Mrs. Peter Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N.J., went to the top in the thirty-sixth annual fixture of the Devon Dog Show Association on the Devon horse show grounds today.

Beset by basic problems, particularly the almost insurmountable shortage of steel pipe, more than 10,000 members of the $6,000,000,000 gas industry are expected to converge on Atlantic City tonight, preliminary to five days of discussion on how to solve them.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 -- Leaving nothing to the imagination of 56,238 fanatics at Municipal Stadium and next to nothing for their closest pursuers, the Red Sox, Lou Boudreau's Indians today clinched at least a tie for the American League pennant by routing the Tigers, 8-0.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Expecting little more than a warm-up in preparation for next week's Columbia invasion, Yale caught a tartar in the small but scrappy University of Connecticut eleven in the Bowl this afternoon and was able to top the Huskies by only 7 -- 0.

THE annual pageant of autumn foliage in Hew England and northern New York has opened spectacularly. No two woodsmen, however, agree on the reason for the exceptional season. One school holds that long sunny days and heavy frosts at night have provided ideal foliage weather.

HEATING and insulation and big upholstered chairs are not the whole story of home comfort. Nor is the electrical appliances the only means of preventing the ache in mother's back. A sensible plan for storage is an indispensable element of both labor saving and comfort.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A new effort, proposed by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, begins Monday before the Federal Power Commission to develop the tremendous hydroelectric resources of the St. Lawrence River. Two affirmative actions are needed, the granting of a license to the state by the Power Commission and approval by the International Joint Commission.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Traders in grains were inclined to even up commitments in today's session at the Board of Trade. There was little buying incentive in any pit.

THE Yankee ball players, who certainly should know about those things, should have tipped off Joe Gordon to the fact that Larry MacPhail had left the Stadium organization. Gordon seems to be operating on the premise that the Rambunctious Redhead is still at the Yankee helm and therefore he's playing with even greater indignation and frenzied zealousness than ever before in his life.

ALTHOUGH last winter's fuel problems vanished with last winter's snows, the home owner still remembers that there wasn't always enough fuel for warmth. Does the outlook for this year indicate the same necessity for rigid controls?

MANY people expect magic from the various packages or cans of detergents, glass cleaners and other chemical specialties now on the market. Sometimes they get just that. In other cases buyers are disappointed to discover that the package contains a substance hardly more effective than so much sawdust.
MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 2 (UP) -- Ed Salem of Alabama tossed a last-second touchdown pass and kicked the extra point to gain a 14-to-14 tie with Vanderbilt today before a capacity crowd of 36,000.

PRICE currently places the dishwasher and that other expediter of kitchen chores, the garbage-disposal unit, in the luxury bracket for many households. The combination arrangement, which includes both appliances and a sink, costs even more.

KEEPING warm on chilly winter nights is a problem which has been met over the years with hot water bottles, heating pads, flannel nightgowns, woolen socks or even a pre-bedtime hot toddy. More recently, however, homemakers have turned to a pretty, as well as a practical solution -- the electric blanket.

THE three-year-old Indonesian Republic has put aside its struggle against the Dutch -- if only temporarily -- to grapple with the Communist enemy within. A showdown that has been in the making since the end of the war has now arrived.

Several department stores yesterday reported that they are substantially ahead of the 1947 fall selling season in furniture dollar volume and expect to finish 1948 with at least a 25 per cent gain. Home furnishings chain buyers and independent furniture store spokesmen, however, said a 1948 gain is uncertain because of the slowing up of sales recently as a result of consumer credit controls.

YELLOW roses seem as plentiful as roses of any other color in many gardens. Yet their yellow is more modern than any other shade, and it only became available in disease-resistant varieties after painstaking efforts.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Britain's new program of rearmament in the framework of Western European defense moved ahead another full stride here today -- to the sound of bugles and drums, to the cheering of spectators and to the sight of sober-faced veterans moving past in parade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The last shreds of ideological camouflage were stripped away from the Communist controversy in Washington this week as angry protagonists for the legislative and executive branches of the Government swapped Sunday punches over the issue in an undisguised, election-year political brawl.

A traveler returned from Western Europe, who tries to analyze the reasons for the political and economic unrest there, cannot help but discover at the root of these troubles the lack of monetary stability. He will become convinced that the great work done there by men who carry the load of directing and executing our European Recovery Program is not central to the problem.

A NUMBER of attractive railroad excursions are being offered this month, and not only rail and camera fans but ordinary excursionists are expected to turn out in large numbers for these rides through the colorful countryside.

THE increased use of electrical appliances is revealing the deficiencies of the wiring system in the average home. Lights that grow dim when appliances are in use, toasters or irons that take too long to heat, are sure signs of inadequate wiring.

NEW YORK, now considered the philatelic center of the world, will see this week an American version of the stamp bourses which for years have been familiar in London, Paris, Vienna, Brussels, Berlin, Rome and other European cities.

TEN years ago the Museum of Modern Art held an exhibition of "Useful Objects Under $5." It was the first time that an American museum had publicly linked high standards of design and low prices. Since then, similar exhibitions have been held nearly every year in New York, and last year twelve museums throughout the United States had shows of recommended designs selected from currently available merchandise.

OCTOBER is the month when attention shifts from outdoor to indoor living. It is the time of year when comfort is thought of in terms of thick rugs and responsive furnaces, of warm lamplight and snug roofs. Traditionally, it is the season of home decoration and house improvements.

THE inroads being made by the British film industry in Canada are indicated by the fact that films representing a cost of some $50,000,000 will be shown in this country during the 1948-49 season, according to Frank H. Fisher, general manager here for Eagle Lion Films.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The Soviet Union shifted its political ground suddenly today and dropped its demand for prohibition of the atomic bomb before the imposition of international control.

PROFESSIONAL decorating, as compared with medicine, law or architecture, is a relatively new field. As it has grown in stature it has become more confident and authoritative. Knowledge and training are now applied to the new spirit in design.

Is there and expert on international choreographic protocol in the house? If so, front and center, please, and on the double! Tonight the Paris Opera Ballet closes the International Dance Festival sponsored by the Mayor's Committee for the Commemoration of the Golden Anniversary of the City of New York at the City Center, and we are all a little embarrassed.

The spur of new competition is making manufacturers more willing to approve revolutionary changes in packaging and trade mark designs, it was reported last week by Jim Nash, veteran industrial designer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The United States high command has drafted a 50-year defense program based on belief that Russia will have the atomic bomb by 1952 and that continent-jumping atomic rockets will be ready by 1977.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Representative John McDowell, Republican, of Massachusetts, today urged prosecution of three former top New Deal lawyers and two alleged Communist spies for refusing to answer the questions of House investigators.

A safety in the last period gave Seward Park an 8 -- 7 triumph over Evander Childs in the opening high school football doubleheader of the season at Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island yesterday. In contrast, the 2000 spectators witnessed a romp in the first game as Peter Stuyvesant scored in every period to down Christopher Columbus, 26 -- 0.

The notes below, taken by U.N. interpreter Nicolas Teslenko during one of Andrei A. Gromyko's blasts in the Security Council against the late Count Folke Bernadotte, U.N. Mediator for Palestine, are a specimen of interpreters' hieroglyphics:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- California has joined New York and Pennsylvania in the 10,000,000 population class, the census bureau reported tonight.

BERNICE KELLY HARRIS has, by now, pretty well established herself as the official chronicler of the back-country folk of North Carolina. She has presented in a series of novels, of which "Hearthstones" is the latest (and which have included "Purslane," "Portulaca," "Janey Jeems"), the people and country she knows so well in affectionate, satisfying terms.

THE electric ironer is not for those who lack the patience to learn its proper use. As a matter of fact, doing flatwork with an electric ironer is simple enough. And since flatwork accounts for well over half the average family wash, using an ironer just for sheets and such saves considerable time and fatigue.

The "import gap" or difference between exports and imports of merchandise in United States foreign trade in 1948 will be substantially smaller than last year, shrinking possibly by 30 per cent, according to estimates here last week.

Textile inventories, rising as the result of increased consumer resistance, are eating into capital assets of manufacturers and suppliers, it was pointed out last week. Many moderate-sized concerns this year will show profits substantially reduced from a year ago despite the higher prices that have prevailed, it was predicted, and a growing number will show losses for the first time in years.

The first round of the Presidential campaign of 1945 last week drew to a close. Yesterday Harry S. Truman returned to the White House after an 8,000-mile, fifteen-day trip that took him on a loop through the Midwest, the Pacific Coast and the Southwest.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Rutgers rallied to defeat a stubborn and early-scoring Colgate eleven today, 34 -- 19. The Scarlet, although riddled by injuries, got 14 points in the second half to overcome a five-point deficit. A record crowd of 16,000 for a Rutgers home opener witnessed the game.

ALTHOUGH the idea of furniture that really works for its owners is by no means a new one -- as a matter of fact, it is centuries old -- the latest furniture collections would indicate that the concept has finally come of age.

Arrangements were announced yesterday for a panel to be conducted on Thursday night, Oct. 21, on the topic: "Salesmen and their importance to the buying office -- what the salesmen and buying offices can do to advance each other's interests."
COLOR is fast appearing in table and decorative glassware. Rich ruby tones, greens and cobalts, while still not plentiful, are beginning to appear in both imported and American-made glassware.

After meeting for eleven and three-quarter hours in the faculty room of City College, its Student Council voted yesterday to sustain student demands for the dismissal of Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, head of the Romance Languages Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The greatest air cargo operation in which man and sky have ever joined -- the Berlin airlift -- is costing this country probably $500,000 a day, but Air Force and Army officials are inclined to view the effort as a worthwhile project in training, peacemaking, propaganda and persistence.

PARIS. DEBATING world problems at the Palais de Chaillot here with leading diplomats of the United Nations General Assembly is 32-year-old Jose Baquero of Ecuador, who only a few months ago was a $77-a-week translator employed by the peace organization.

THE myriad makes and models of household equipment now on the market are a challenge to even the most astute shopper. But the homemaker who is going to buy a new piece of equipment should be encouraged rather than confused by the variety available, since a wide selection means that she can choose the model that is best suited to her own family needs.

Suitable jobs must be found for physically handicapped persons "able and willing to work," said Morris Sayre, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, in a plea yesterday for cooperation on the part Of all employers.

WHEN Robinson Jeffers' "The Double Axe," his first book of poems in seven years, came out last July, it looked as though the author himself were in for a good double-axeing. The book was heavy with sex, violence and eloquent misanthropy, but that was no novelty in Mr. Jeffers. What was new was his super-isolationist, Carmelized ivory-tower stand.

SALZBURG, Austria, Oct 2 -- Mass migration of displaced persons from Austria to the Americas began today when 414 men, women and children left here by train for Genoa, Italy, where they will board ship for Argentina next Friday.
An X-ray microscope has long been considered an impossibility because X-rays cannot be refracted, hence brought to a focus, nor can they be reflected except at a very low angle.
PEIPING, China, Sunday, Oct. 3 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek flew to Mukden yesterday at the height of a battle that may decide the fate of the Government's slim holdings in Manchuria.

JUST twelve years ago this week in this review: Gilbert Seldes looked around the country, found it good, then recorded the fact for his contemporaries in "Mainland," which Francis Brown reviewed on page one. It is a tome, said Mr. Brown, that is "prejudiced, argumentative, disorganized" but one withal which "lots of Americans will wish they had written." . . .

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- A helicopter as big as the planes supplying Berlin and carrying a detachable "trailer" the size of a Greyhound bus is being developed for the Air Force, it was announced tonight.

WRITING an article about your play prior to its New York opening is not going to improve the quality of the play and, moreover, it may have the disadvantage of suggesting to the suspicious that an effort is being made to load the dice.
NOW that contemporary design has achieved respect-ability and we are not ashamed to say "made in 1948," where do antiques come in? The answer: through an open mind.

Operators of variety chain Stores are looking ahead to 1949 with more optimism than they have shown in the last ten years, it was learned here at the week's end. Hopeful that the top of the inflationary cycle is near, they believe that increased consumer demand for lower priced merchandise next year may "put them back in the running" with other chain groups.

EVERY family can probably recall at least one day that went like this: It rained and all the wash on the lines had to be brought indoors and draped over every available object, the damp odor pervading the rooms for hours.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Sept. 24 -- The Government is holding up legislation for the establishment of a State paper mill until it receives next month a report on the engineering and economic possibilities of an ambitious plant at Murupara, on the Rangitaiki River in the Bay of Plenty district, that is being prepared by the Rust Engineering Company of Pittsburgh, Pa.

United States Attorney John F.X. McGohey sent a telegram yesterday to Representative John McDowell of Pennsylvania, acting chairman of the House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities, requesting him for a second time to appear before the October Federal grand jury next Thursday.

PARIS, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- Greece has accused Albania and Yugoslavia of new border violations in support of the Communist-led Greek guerrillas, the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkan's reported today.

THE city of Munich in the twentieth century, like the castle of Canossa in the eleventh, has given its name to the great political surrender of its age. As the medieval emperor was caught between the temporal and spiritual powers of the papacy, so the democratic statesman, of today, facing the alternatives of cataclysmic war and dishonorable retreat before its threat, is deprived of the possibility of successful action.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- United States representatives have concluded contracts for the purchase of 2,000 tons of sisal, material important in twine production, from the British Government's strategic materials stockpile, it was learned authoritatively today.

Work on the foundations of the $7,500,000 central office building of the Board of Transportation to be erected at Jay and Willoughby Streets in Brooklyn will be started soon, it was learned yesterday. Plans for the new structure, a fourteen-story building of functional design, call for its completion by the end of 1949.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it was ready to begin a full-scale "air lift" to Hawaii, other Pacific islands and Alaska if the month-old West Coast shipping strike continues long enough to cause "abnormal conditions," according to The United Press.

IT is safe ordinarily for candidates, barnstorming through the farm belt, to use the old "economic underdog" appeal on the farmer and his wife -- the usual promises of "higher prices and lower taxes," with some harmless, homespun oratory addressed especially to the farmer's wife.

The twelfth annual Pulaski memorial day parade will start at 1 P.M. today from Twenty-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue and move north in the avenue to Fifty-second Street, under auspices of the General Pulaski Memorial Committee, Inc., of Metropolitan New York.

LAST night two more of the new season's crop of plays were plowed under -- "Town House" and "Time for Elizabeth" -- and there is no doubt this morning that in the Broadway book they'll call the month just passed Black September..

HERE is a first novel which is an odds-on bet for popularity. "The Burnished Blade" is one of the best-paced novels of intrigue this reviewer has read since he sat up until 3 o'clock one morning to finish "Captain from Castile."

NOT so long ago a window was simply a square hole in the wall. It was supposed to serve a number of purposes, but adding grace and beauty to the room was not one of them. Nor was it the focal point, the gathering place for people in the room.

AN exhibition of 150 pictures by a group of early twentieth century photographers who believed in photography as an art form, opened last week at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. Formed in 1902 as the Photo Secession under the leadership of Alfred Stieglitz, the organization was a protest against the conventional, record-type photography of that day.

WITH the havoc of last winter's storms still a fresh memory, the homeowner should prepare for the bad weather that must always be expected. During the severe winter of 1947-48 few homes escaped some damage to roofs, flashings, leaders or gutters. This coming winter may be mild, but one can't be sure. One can be only certain that sooner or later bad weather will come.

Discovery in the Belgian Congo of a new uranium-bearing mineral was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul F. Kerr, Professor of Minerology at Columbia University, where the mineral was analyzed and identified.

NOTHING is more exasperating to the home owner than the appearance of all manner of insect life -- plus the animals they attract -- on his newly seeded or patiently nurtured lawn. Ground moles, for example, tunneling through the lawn in search of such delicacies as Japanese beetle grubs and earthworms, are a common lawn pest.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2 (AP) Its line play greatly improved and its ball handling in the T-formation much more deft, the Holy Cross football team overpowered Syracuse, 33 -- 7, today before 15,000 fans.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- Seven in ten residents in the United States zone favor setting up a provisional government for Western Germany, and more than 50 per cent of those polled would have such a government handle Germany's foreign trade, a United States Military Government survey disclosed today.

Confronted with a booming kindergarten and elementary school enrollment, New York State faces a serious problem in education, the State Education Department has warned. Within the next five years, it is estimated, 500,000 children will be added to the state's already overcrowded classrooms.
CHILDREN from 10 to 12 are often as anxious for mystery-adventures as some of the rest of us. This group will welcome a new tale by the author of that delightful Gaspe story, "Pierre Pigeon."

The Holophane Company, Inc., which this year is observing its golden jubilee, had record high earnings of $673,418, equal to $7.13 each on 94.442 common shares, according to the annual report for the fiscal year ended with June, which was issued yesterday by Charles Franck, chairman of the board.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Brooklyn College scored its second straight football victory today by beating Bridgeport, 21 -- 7, before 2,000 fans at Candlelight Stadium.

THIS is a junior "Berkeley Square," the story of a modern girl who makes a backward journey in time. Judy paddles her boat down Crazy Creek and finds herself in the pioneer Oregon setting made familiar by her grandfather's stories.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Flashing a hurricane backfield that smashed 236 yards along the ground, Northwestern whizzed over the first lap toward a Rose Bowl trip today by upsetting favored Purdue, 21 -- 0.

Observance of National Newspaper Week, Oct. 1-8, might deepen reflection of some publishers on increased cost pressures, but a majority could find cheer last week in growing evidence that newspapers are again on their way back to first place in national advertising for the first time since 1941.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Frank T. Griswold Jr. of Wayne, Pa., drove his Alpha Romeo Special at an average of 63 miles an hour today to win the first American Grand Prix.

NEITHER-beauty of line nor special convenience features are of much value in furniture that fail to stand up. During the war and for a while thereafter, some furniture buyers had sad experiences with drawers that warped, finishes that blistered, chair springs that quietly collapsed.

Opening of a Congressional inquiry tomorrow into the secession movement by left-wing locals of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, was announced yesterday by Representative Charles J. Kersten of Wisconsin.

THE rather stiff and formal white calla lily is inevitably associated with occasions of ceremony in this country. In South Africa, its native abode, this same plant is known as the Pig lily and grows wild along streams and trenches.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- Northeastern University celebrated its fiftieth anniversary today, conferred thirteen honorary degrees and heard President James B. Conant of Harvard urge a drastic change in the draft law.

THE salmon have started their long run up British Columbia's Fraser River when young Niels Andersen and his friend Harry Brownjohn discover a skeleton which they believe to be the remains of a sea serpent. The boys learn that they have found what was a forty-foot basking shark.

THE novel notion that what is played and sung is more important than by whom it is played and sung seems to have animated Concert Hall Society, Inc., in its brief career of two years. In that time it has produced two series of albums, issued on a subscription basis in limited editions of 3,000, and now it has completed plans for 1948-49, its third season.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Notre Dame loosed a versatile football powerhouse against Pittsburgh today and rolled over the Panthers, 40 -- 0, before a sell-out crowd of 63,000 which went away convinced that the Irish could have scored 100 points if they had chosen to do so.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Wisconsin's Clarence Self drove over from the 2-yard line for a touchdown in the last three minutes of play to defeat Illinois in a thrilling Big Nine football game, 20 to 16, today.

FASHIONS in plants since the turn of the century have been both as numerous and as well-defined as fashions in furniture and clothes. Through all the changes this has been evident: those who plan rooms and those who live in them acknowledge that something green and growing is an important accessory.

THE nimble Mr. Thurber's latest potpourri (and a sapid one it is) consists of four short stories, a number of satirical essays, some excursions into natural and preternatural history, a couple of autobiographical vignettes, several parodies, a gallery of captioned and captionless drawings, a fable, and a relatively long, lively, and penetrating bit of reportage on one of radio's cretinous offsprings, the soap opera.
THE wine awards made recently at the annual California State Fair have been announced. They constitute the soundest guide to California wines that consumers can find.

HOMEMAKERS who visit New York City stores this week will see a special offering of the newest ideas in home furnishings and decoration. More than fifty New York stores are participating officially in Home Fashion Time, a week-long program sponsored by the Home Fashions League.

THOSE who believe that the Labor-Management Relations Act of 1947 (otherwise known as the Taft-Hartley law) was conceived in a spirit of justice and fairness to all, will nod with approval at this volume of explanation and defense presented by its sponsor in the House of Representatives.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 -- Invading President Truman's home state in quest of its fifteen electoral votes, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today accused his Democratic adversary, by implication, of fomenting disunity by "blackguarding Congress."

THE outside, not the inside, of the foundation wall is the place to apply waterproofing material to correct dampness in the basement. Experiments conducted by the United States Bureau of Standards and educational institutions indicate that the most satisfactory results are obtained when repairs are made on the outside.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 2 (UP) -- Two members of the Arizona House of Representatives had been expelled today following the judgment that their actions were offensive to other members.

Although it may be at least fifteen months before the present tight steel supply situation is alleviated to any appreciable degree, steel consumers will benefit this year from mill shipments of an all-time record tonnage of finished steel products, according to industry spokesmen.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, tearing the course apart with a seven-under-par 65, made a spectacular comeback today to tie Johnny Palmer, Badin, N.C., for the lead in the Portland Open golf tournament with a three-round total of 203.

PLANTS that edge walks and paths occupy one of the most conspicuous places in the garden, and their selection requires thought. After trying innumerable plants over a period of years, we have found what we consider a top-notch list of candidates.

There were jeers before the start and cheers at the finish of the $108,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup race as Belmont Park's great meeting ended yesterday. Reason for the jeers: The management exercised its right to limit the betting activities to the win and place windows.

ALTHOUGH Universal-International has been inordinately quiet since the beginning of August, the company is back in action again and Brooklyn, some three thousand miles east of Universal City, has been witnessing the first evidences of that activity these past two weeks.

BETWEEN 1942 and 1946 practically no silverware was produced in this country and very little was imported. With the relaxing of war strains, manufacturers both here and abroad began to work at satisfying the demand for the more essential pieces of flatware and hollow ware.

IT has been twenty-eight years since the first of the Doctor Dolittle stories appeared, since when the good doctor has become so firmly entrenched in children's affections the world over that one tends to identify him with his creator.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 2 -- Three general patterns of conflict have emerged in the continuing struggle which has rent the Soviet bloc since the Cominform's resolution of June 28 attacking Marshal Tito's "line" in Yugoslavia.

IN any room the accessories assume greater visual prominence than furniture or background, simply because of their greater proximity to the eye and the hand. It is by the accessories that the guest is most apt to judge the taste of the owner.

THE idea of "push-button washing" has made such an appeal to housewives since the first automatic washer appeared that the present emphasis in washing-machine manufacture is decidedly toward automatics.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- The residents of the Western sectors of this city felt they were part of a victorious battle this week when the Western powers submitted the Berlin question to the United Nations. They had this feeling because they had anticipated that the Western powers would sell them out in a compromise solution.

A gradual decline in national beer consumption, as emphasized in figures revealed yesterday by the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, is causing brewers to seek new markets, it has been learned.

Mayor O'Dwyer criticized yesterday the Eightieth Congress and the Republican party for removing controls from food prices and for ineffectiveness on public housing legislation. He was addressing members of the Democratic Women's Business and Professional Club at luncheon in the Commodore Hotel.

MR. GREENHOOD'S novel starts off better than it finishes. In the telling it is cozy and literate, and moves at the same speed as the two people it's about. That is, Mr. Greenhood takes a girl in a publishing house and a clean-cut young-surveyor and leads them through an affair that turns out, finally, to be the real thing.

FOR centuries the implements of the dinner table have been among the hallmarks of civilization. Each period has its taste and has left behind its imprint. Down to us have come a great variety of pieces -- beautiful, elegant, elaborate or utterly simple, depending upon how the artisan of each period was best able top express himself.

HERSHEY, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Jimmy Walthall's sharp eye and strong right arm proved to be too much for a heavier Temple University eleven today as the West Virginia Mountaineers filled the air with passes and defeated the Owls, 27 -- 7.

THE Theatre Owners of America, corporately and individually, concluded their annual convention in Chicago this past week-end as sadder, if not actually wiser, men. The boys, about four hundred strong and representing roughly half of the nation's 18,000 film theatres, descended on the Windy City with their pockets jingling and quite confident that all was reasonably safe in so far as their industry was concerned.

THE Metropolitan Opera company is expected to make known its plans for the coming season when Edward Johnson holds his annual interview with the press in the near future. It was known before the company's difficulties with its unions that the management was considering a revival of "Falstaff."
HOME lighting has a very different role to play from public lighting. That role may be broken down into three parts: attraction, comfort and personality.

With Government bonds continuing to back up in the Federal Reserve System and with the Treasury's savings bonds coming in for redemption about as fast as new bonds are being sold, new scrutiny is being given in financial circles to proposals for getting more of the public debt funded on a long-term basis on terms and into hands other than those that sufficed for the war-finance period.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 24 -- Prime Minister Peter Fraser has requested any Yugoslavs in New Zealand who are being intimidated to return to Yugoslavia to report immediately to the police. "That sort of thing will not be tolerated in New Zealand," he said, "and every effort will be made to find and deal with those responsible for making such threats."

A SURPRISINGLY large number of homes have obsolete, inadequate or undesirable provisions for heating. One reason is that in too many homes the heating was skimped to save costs when the house was built. In heating, as in everything else, one gets about what one pays for, and unfortunately it is not possible to obtain comfort, esthetics and economy of operation in heating without some initial expense.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 2 (AP) -- North Carolina fumbled away two scoring chances in the first half and lost its punch when it needed it most, but in the second half the Tar Heels, led by Charley Justice, ripped through Georgia today, 21 -- 14.

Early American. old English and Continental art objects and decorations collected by the late Annie R. Bird of Kansas City, Mo., will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, in five sessions beginning Wednesday at 2 P.M.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 2 -- Throttling a vaunted passing attack, the University of Michigan extended its football winning streak to sixteen games and snapped the victory chain of the University of Oregon at eight today, 14 to 0, before 65,800 fans.

The 16,000 members of the National Association of Manufacturers have been asked by their president, Morris Sayre, to survey jobs in their companies with the object of finding additional opportunities for the disabled, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Representative August H. Andresen, Republican, of Minnesota, said today Canadian and American officials plan to meet soon on the possibility of putting restrictions on imports of Canadian potatoes.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A series of market drops this week left prices of hogs at the lowest levels since last June. Sharply lower pork markets, increased livestock receipts and larger deliveries of new crop hogs in the coming weeks contributed to the decline. All cattle declined early in the week and the recovery was spotted.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 2 -- By beating Bowdoin this afternoon, 13 to 0, Wesleyan continued its undefeated record of two seasons and hung up its sixteenth consecutive victory. The Cardinals, on the offensive, for most of the game scored in the first and third periods.
The Cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was rather slow, and final prices were 9 points lower to 1 point higher than the day before.

Home Economist, United States Department of Agriculture FROM the wide variety offered, the homemaker in search of a new range should be able to find one that is right for her needs, for despite the steel shortage, supplies are keeping up with demand. In appearance, the new gas and electric ranges are very much alike.

THIS is a very fine biological handbook, intended primarily for the use of young people, but equally helpful to any adult whose enthusiasm for knowing the world in which he lives has not been blunted by the years. Mr. Brown's dynamic approach deserves blanket praise.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The New York State Winter Sports Council was told today that the state-owned Whiteface Mountain ski area near Lake Placid would be open for operation this year.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The German question, which a few months ago was a cloud no bigger than a man's hand, has burst on the United Nations with the violence of a tropical storm. For the last two weeks Paris has been enjoying day after day of summer weather, but the Berlin question has reminded many delegates that similar weather favored the blitzkrieg against Poland nine years ago.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Ohio State's alert, fast-striking eleven racked up its second straight victory today before 75,102 fans, tacking a 20-0 defeat on Southern California -- the first loss in three starts for the Trojans.
GENEVA, Oct. 2 -- A gloomy record of failure is all that the United Nations Kashmir Commission can report to the Security Council, commission sources said today.

A last-day spurt of more than a million registrants for the November election left the city with the disappointing total of approximately 3,300,000 persons who qualified themselves to vote, a tabulation at 2:45 o'clock this morning indicated.

FALL is the most favorable season in which to plant evergreens for a number of reasons. In the first place, soil and moisture conditions are ideal at this time and evergreens, having completed their season of growth, are as dormant as they ever will be.

The $15,000,000,000 utility industry should not encounter any major problems in financing a contemplated $6,000,000,000 expansion program during the next four years, according to a survey prepared by Ebasco Services, Incorporated. Moreover, the industry could undertake an even larger program if it were necessary, its report said.

Newsstands and snack bars at railroad stations and terminals in New York, Long Island, Westchester and southern Connecticut were shut down yesterday by a strike of 1,000 employes of the Union News Company.

FOOD shortages in the United States largely disappeared with the war, and with them has gone the overwhelming demand for freezers that sprang from a squirrel-like desire to stow away as much as possible. But in suburban and rural areas, interest in this appliance, supplies of which are ample, continues to be strong.

The problem of inflation and what to do about it will be debated by four expert at 9:30 P.M. Wednesday over Radio Station WQXR. This will be the first appearance in the 1948-49 season of "What's On Your Mind?" weekly radio forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in a completely new format.

Andrei Vishinsky's adroit propaganda move in proposing that the major Powers reduce their armed forces by one-third in a year has put the Western nations embarrassingly on the defensive. They have not only indicated that they will reject the proposal but have been forced to apologize for their own armament programs.

MANY new bedding products, particularly mattresses, are now on the retail market. The long-awaited extra-long mattresses, which guarantee tall individuals the adequate rest they never received from standard sizes, may be purchased in virtually any retail outlet which carries a good stock of bedding.

GENEVA, Oct. 2 -- Two positive developments toward improving East-West economic relations helped somewhat today to lighten the gloom that hung over the close of the major East-West trade talks at Geneva.

INCIDENTAL to the broadcasting of a boxing match on a recent night, "The Star-Spangled Banner" was sung as a vocal solo. I am not often moved to righteous indignation, but the performance of our national anthem that evening caused that emotion to well up in me to such an extent that it went beyond the bounds of indignation, righteous or otherwise, into the realm of rage and fury.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A wide-awake Lehigh University eleven rolled over Case Tech, 26 to 18, today with sustained drives on the ground ranging from 45 to 78 yards.

Saturday sessions were resumed yesterday on the stock market after the summer recess and the recovery of prices on the New York Stock Exchange was furthered. Gains were modest, although some of the industrials managed to effect major additions.

With direct material and labor costs accounting for more than 73 per cent of each dollar received by the shoe manufacturer, and with manufacturing overhead only 9.4 per cent, the average manufacturer has little leeway to achieve "any very significant economies through spreading overhead and factory costs over a larger volume of production."

Marking the fourth annual National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week, a number of New York employers and social agencies will present an exhibit this week at the American Museum of Natural History to demonstrate that it is good business to hire the handicapped.

The Wagner College Seahawks came from behind to tie Hofstra's Flying Dutchmen, 13 -- 13, at Grymes Hill, Saten Island, yesterday as their fullback, Jay Quintana, smashed through the line for sharp gains

PROBABLY nine out of ten interior designers, if modern-minded, will agree grudgingly that "built-in" is the quintessence of modern room design. Grudgingly, because they admit that they have no glib answers to certain valid objections that can be raised.

IN the sprawling galleries of the home of the National Academy, at Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, the fifth annual nation-wide competitive exhibition under the auspices of the Pepsi-Cola Company has been unveiled.

IMPROVEMENTS in the construction and materials of Venetian blinds have been numerous in the six centuries since Marco Polo reportedly brought solid gold ones from China to Venice. Until recently, the more usual material for the slats has been wood.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A couple of air strategists, speaking for themselves, believe the United States can win another war in from one to three months. They envision a "super blitz" of atomic bombs dropped by only a small force of planes.

THE Foton 35mm miniature still camera with built-in double-spring motor and T lens stops will be available this month, Bell Howell, the makers, announced recently. The camera also incorporates a new-type focal-plane shutter, rapid-sequence operation and fully automatic film transport and shutter wind.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 -- Declaring that the crux of the "world crisis is not Berlin or Bizonia or all of Germany," but the possibility of a war of extinction by atomic bombs, bacterial poison and radioactive dust and gas, Henry A. Wallace urged the American public tonight to demand resumption of negotiations with Russia.
DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Tennessee and Duke matched lightning strikes for touchdowns in the first half of a football game today and then bumped heads in vain the rest of the afternoon.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 2 -- A great California line that wore down the opposition through sheer power and refused to give ground in touchdown territory pulled an otherwise listless squad to a 20-0 victory over the fighting St. Mary's Gaels today before 54,000 fans.

THE campaign of 1948 is shifting into high gear. Like armies, the political parties have been drawing up their lines, feeling out enemy positions, raising smoke screens. Between now and Nov. 2 the battle will rage in many places, on back stoops and in Madison Square Garden, at clambakes and in Grange halls, by the radio in the parlor and at the factory gates.

Earthquake regions such as the West Coast of the United States and other such places where iron ore, coal and limestone occur, can now be used as sites for completely integrated steel mills through the development of an earthquake-proof blast furnace.

Foreign correspondents are no longer welcome in Rumania. Read the newspapers today and you will find little or nothing about that corner of Europe which used to furnish more than its quota of interesting, not to say sensational, intelligence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The General Counsel's office of the National Labor Relations Board was reported today to have determined that the typographical agreements with the New York and the Gannett chain newspapers, on their face, do not violate the Taft-Hartley Law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The proposal made before the United Nations General Assembly this week by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, chief Soviet delegate in Paris, for the five major powers to cut their armaments one-third has a familiar ring in the light of a volume of foreign relations of the United States for the year 1932 published by the State Department tonight.

THE home owner who wants to be prepared for almost anything will do well to consider the convertible furnaces now on the market. A number of widely known manufacturers are now supplying furnaces that can easily be converted from coal to oil or gas -- and back again if necessary.

MODERN fabric design has come of age. Through widening acceptance it has achieved a sense of stability and perspective. It has shed the exaggerations and distortions of its adolescence and its self-conscious striving for the "never-been-done-before." A review of the current fabric offerings reveals solid construction, fitness for function, clarity of color, variety of pattern and increased quality.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Billings, 3-year-old chestnut colt, owned by Ralph W. McIlvain of Chicago, charged home a length and a quarter winner of the $57,800 Hawthorne Gold Cup Handicap today. This was the last major event of Chicago's rich racing season.

NUMEROUS gifts of trees and shrubs have already been made to parks, botanical gardens and parkway plantings in the New York area through the Citizens Golden Anniversary Program, which was launched by the Park Association of New York last Wednesday.

ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- J.P. Hillen of the Georgia Bureau of Investigation reported today that five workers of the Progressive party actually were abducted in Augusta last Sunday.

Brooklyn Tech spotted Lafayette 13 points in the first ten minutes of play but then came back with single tallies in the second, third and fourth quarters to beat the Frenchies, 19 -- 13, at Lincoln Stadium yesterday. Bob Domozych was the Tech scoring ace with two touchdowns.

THE group of twenty-seven pieces of sculpture Curt Valentin has assembled at the Buchholz Gallery for his opening exhibition breathes a kind of discrete, modern vitality. Here in a happy, well-balanced selection the modern research for living shapes and formal essentials is seen at its most impressive in work by Braque, Matisse, Laurens, Maillol, Piscasso, Lipschitz, Modigliani, Moore, Arp and others.

Several Southern furniture factories are offering bedroom suites to retailers at substantially reduced wholesale prices, a top manufacturing source revealed yesterday. He said that reductions run from 10 to 15 per cent.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- This historic resort city on the southernmost tip of the United States came through its worst hurricane since 1919 with damage mostly to the roofs of homes and business buildings and to commercial and pleasure craft.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Russians served notice that their fighter planes would practice aerial gunnery in the airlift corridor to Berlin today. But Western officials said tonight that no British or United States pilots had seen any shooting.

Ordinarily liquidations of corporations are subject to double income taxation; the corporation is taxable on the gain realized from the sale of its assets, and the stockholders, on their gains from receipts of liquidating dividends. The rule works both ways, however, so that in the case of loss a double deduction may result; a loss to the corporation and a loss to stockholders.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Three United Nations guards will be flown here from Lake Success on Monday to give the delegates to the General Assembly the treatment they are accustomed to, it was disclosed tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The survival of the present French Cabinet under Premier Henri Queuille is bound up with the outcome of the national coal strike that has been precipitated by the French Communists.

IN this long first novel of the rise and fall of tobacco dynasties in North Carolina a comment is made, not only upon the changes in that industry but also upon the changes in the American man and in the dream which once motivated what he did.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 2 -- An interval of approximately two weeks will be sufficient to determine the effect of the release of part of the frozen Deutsche mark accounts on the economy of Western Germany, bipartite officials said today.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 2 -- As he ended his first two weeks of active campaigning for President today, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and his advisers believed his first trip had been a decided success.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Two touchdown runs of 69 and 58 yards by Don Blackwell, both in the third quarter, gave White Plains High School at 13-to-0 victory over the De Witt Clinton eleven before 3,500 fans today.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 2 -- A Norwegian flying boat capsized and sank near Trondheim today, apparently killing twenty-two of the forty-eight persons aboard.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 2 -- The sophomores, who have been expected to spark Fordham's postwar football hopes, caught fire today at Tomb Memorial Field and engineered a 48-0 defeat of The Merchant Marine Academy for the Rams' highest point total since returning to football in 1946.

THE U.S.S.R. is unwilling to let Vitus J. Bering (1681-1741), the Danish explorer after whom the straits between Russia and Alaska were named, have the laurels exclusively. The Soviet postal authorities have recalled that in 1648 the Russian adventurer Simin Dezhnov voyaged from the Lena River through the straits, and they will soon issue 40-kopecs and 1-ruble stamps to mark the tercentenary, according to word received from Moscow by J. and H. Stolow.

Referring to the disclosure that his brother, Rudolph Ellis, had refused to admit or deny that he is a Communist when he appeared before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, John Ellis, Republican and Liberal party candidate for Representative in the Eighteenth Congressional District, said yesterday that he had long known of his brother's left-wing leanings and had spent many hours in argument with him.

Pointing out that "prohibitive" prices for men's wear worsted fabrics in Italy and Great Britain had prevented him from spending a $600,000 purchase budget, Leo Perper, president of Roger Kent, Inc., men's clothing retailers, suggested last week that it might prove a "smart" move for the Governments of those countries to subsidize their fabric exports.

The registration figures for this city's five boroughs are discouraging to followers of President Truman and Henry Wallace. They are also discouraging, for different reasons, to all who want popular government to operate at its best. Thousands of our citizens have, in fact, abdicated their electoral functions.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- Rejecting last-minute appeals for mediation and ignoring the new benefits that the Government granted to the miners today, the Communist-controlled General Confederation of Labor tonight maintained its call to all French coal miners to walk out tomorrow for a strike of indefinite duration.

The American Broadcasting Company has purchased the Vita-graph motion picture lot from Warner Brothers and will convert it for use as the network's Hollywood television center, it was announced yesterday by Robert E. Kintner, ABC executive vice president.

Sometimes, when Albert Abba Volk is explaining his epistolary crusades, he will pause and examine his listener. "You think I'm a crackpot," he says. "Well, maybe I am. But what is a crackpot? It is anyone who is cracked about different things than you are cracked on."
Four new films, including importations from Italy and Russia, are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Stimulated by reorders and with out-of-town buyers here for their second fall purchasing trip, the wholesale garment market last week was fairly active, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

GENEVA, Oct. 3 -- The prospects for an effective agreement on an organization to develop EastWest trade were suddenly brightened today by a Russian request for a thirty-six-hour adjournment of the discussions to permit consultation, presumably with Moscow.
World Communion Sunday was observed yesterday for the ninth annual time in more than forty countries on six continents.
The Brookhattans took two points from the Philadelphia Americans, champions of the American Soccor League, when they defeated the visitors, 5 -- 3, yesterday at Sterling Oval in the Bronx.

The public school system in New York City will begin this week its seventh year of "released time" for religious instruction. An estimated 100,000 pupils, from the third to the eighth grade, are eligible for one hour of religious training in church or synagogue of their parents' choice.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The nation's public and private debt jumped almost $17,000,000,000 last year to a record $410,000,000,000, the Department of Commerce revealed tonight.

NORTH BAY, Ont., Oct. 3 -- The Dionne quintuplets saw their first hockey game Saturday night -- an exhibition clash between the Chicago Black Hawks and Kansas City Pla-Mors -- and appeared a bit bewildered by the modified mayhem.

MOST educated Americans have a distant, bowing acquaintance with Henry David Thoreau.
