If his name is mentioned by mutual friends they can speak of him politely and respectfully, although always guardedly, and with innate suspicion. A growing number of Americans belongs to an international cult whose inspired prophet is this same determinedly eccen tric Yankee.

A general trend downward in discounting on all types of accounts, particularly industrial, is shown in the fifth quarterly survey of the Chicago Association of Credit Men, it was revealed over the week-end by A.L. Jones, president of the association.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 3 -- The plan of the International Refugee Organization to begin this month the movement to the United States of groups from the 250,000 displaced persons in this area has been postponed indefinitely by failure of the State Department in Washington to furnish visa numbers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A State Department spokesman said tonight that the department had no knowledge of a postponement of the plan to begin moving displaced persons in Germany to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A top-rung Federal official said tonight there may be unusually heavy business failures if inflation ends and prices stand still or decline for "a few months."
Major league baseball established a new all-time attendance record during the 1948 season by drawing 20,849,524 fans, according to a United Press tabulation released yesterday.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Two more races today at the Larchmont Yacht Club concluded the team match of the Long Island Sound Class S sailors and those of Narragansett Bay.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 3 -- Time ran out on the American League race today and when the clock stopped so did the Indians. With everything to gain and buoyed by the knowledge that at worst they would finish in a tie with the Red Sox, the Tribe of Lou Boudreau had to settle for the worst -- the first dead-heat finish in league history.

The greatest test of the United Nations and the whole concept of the post-war world as envisaged by the victors in their wartime agreements will start in Paris today when Soviet Russia appears before the bar of the Security Council on charges of creating a threat to international peace and security.

I regard as valuable your publication of a letter which violently attacked the appropriation for construction of a $100,000,000 aircraft carrier. In ascribing as the sole motive for the appropriation the appeasement of the vanity of our pompous admirals, Major (A.F. Res.) Charles Beazley's arguments perfectly illustrate the extreme partisan Air Force view.

The Amato Opera Theatre continued its Sunday night series at Our Lady of Pompei Auditorium with Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" last night. It continued also its announced policy of making grand opera good theatre, and, granting a work which has few theatrical merits to start with, made a fair job of it.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Corn continues to be the market leader on the Board of Trade. Confirmation by a private statistician that the 1948 crop will set a record of 3,350,000,000 bushels, compared with 2,400,000,000 in 1947 and 3,250,000,000 in 1946 started a selling movement last week that carried prices off sharply, with new lows for the season being established before the market rallied on short covering.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 3 -- Nine left-wing leaders of the once allegedly Communist-dominated local 248 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, which conducted two prolonged and violence-ridden strikes against the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, were expelled from union membership today after members ratified a trial board's finding accusing them of misusing $83,000 in union funds.

Foreign exchanges showed a firm undertone and rising scale of values last week. The improvement was not accompanied by volume turnover as the markets were thin, with no special urgency to buy or pressure to sell.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 3 -- Rumanian Uniate or Greek Catholic Church was virtually abolished today after an existence of 250 years.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 3 -- The United Mine Workers, under the leadership of John L. Lewis, is expected to demand a work week of thirty-five hours, accompanied by an increase in the pay now received for forty hours, at its fortieth constitutional convention, opening Tuesday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 3 -- A seventeenth century house here has been made water-tight as the first phase of an extensive rebuilding program to preserve this fine example of architecture of the late 1600's in Long Island and New England.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 3 -- The Dutch budget submitted last week has made a decidedly good impression. Whereas the 1948 budget still showed a deficit of 1,750,000,000 guilders, the gap for 1949 has been reduced to 660,000,000.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 3 (UP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina said today "everything, so far, looks good" in his campaign for the Presidency on the States' Rights ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- New York's young Giants, apparently a bit cocky over their recent successes, learned a bitter lesson from one of professional football's old masters today. While 32,593 onlookers at Griffith Stadium roared with approval, the great Sammy Baugh piloted the Washington Redskins to a runaway 41-10 triumph over Steve Owen's club.

There are many confirmed internationalists among us who will center their interest, at least for today, on things strictly "American." It was not Gromyko or Vishinski who was responsible for this turn, either. It was just that a young Iowan known in baseball jargon as "Rapid Robert" Feller, has lost the zing of his fast ball, the zip on his curve.
The St. Louis Cardinals' Star Musial completed one of the greatest one-man shows in baseball yesterday by winning the National League batting championship with a mark of .376.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., Oct. 3 -The annual New York Library Association conference ended today with discussions on "What Have Libraries Done?" and "What Must Libraries Do?"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The down-the-stretch drive for the election of the Dewey-Warren ticket, it became known today, will feature a series of nationwide radio broadcasts by Republican leaders of Congress, object of repeated attacks by President Truman.

International ties in one denomination are not only important as such but are a necessary step toward international ties among denominations, the Rev. Dr. Sidney M. Berry, of London, general secretary of the International Congregational Council, said yesterday.

Cardinal Spellman good humoredly chided himself yesterday at dedication ceremonies at the St. Philip Neri parochial school building, 202d Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, for being unable to lay the cornerstone of the building until after it had been erected.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- Formation of the State of Israel in no way affects the patriotism or loyalty of the Jews in America, according to the Rev. Dr. Nelson Glueck. He emphasized this tonight in a sermon marking the start of the Jewish New Year.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The Israeli Government began its fight tonight against the Palestine proposals of Count Folke Bernadotte, slain United Nations Mediator, with an official statement that the "Government of Israel will oppose any plan separating the Negeb [the desert area of southern Palestine] or any part of it from the territory of the State of Israel."

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey returned tonight from an 8,862-mile campaign trip with the assurances of Republican leaders of the areas that he has a substantial lead over President Truman at present in all fourteen states where he spoke.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Success that has marked the pursuance of a policy adopted by the Carrier Corporation in 1945 to do everything possible to provide jobs for physically handicapped war veterans not formerly employed by the organization will be reviewed here this week by Cloud Wampler, president of the corporation.
Launching highly concentrated attacks in the first, second and third quarters, St. John's Prep defeated St. Francis Prep in football before 4,000 at Boys High Field yesterday, 21 -- 0.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 3 -- Gathering momentum as the game progressed, the Hurricanes defeated Westbury, 18 -- 10, in the final game of the twenty-third Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The stock markets here are on a working day-to-day basis more than ever before. The international political atmosphere has become denser than ever and all attempts to pierce it have been abandoned. The trend of events a week ago sent a shiver through the markets but they stood up to them better than did Wall Street.

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for President, profited much more in his quest for electoral votes during his recent transcontinental speaking trip than did President Harry S. Truman, his Democratic opponent, on his tour to the Pacific Coast, according to reports from correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in twenty states visited by one or both of the candidates.

Continuation of the present program of high support prices of farm products might have the effect of perpetuating war-time production patterns rather than encouraging a shift to meet peace-time demands, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York asserts in its Monthly Review, published today.

In any adult conception of religion there must be the awareness of a stream of consciousness between God and man, Canon Thomas A. Sparks said yesterday in his sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, of which he is the pastor.

A book about Albert Schweitzer, author, philosopher, musician and medical missionary, will be published on Nov. 10 by Harper. It is "The Africa of Albert Schweitzer," by Charles R. Joy and Melvin Arnold. They visited the Schweitzer hospital at Lambarene and the 170 pictures, plus the 50,000-word text, present in effect a day in the life of Dr. Schweitzer.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- "There's a game gang," was Manager Joe McCarthy's tribute to his Boston Red Sox as they put on a mild dressing room celebration after slugging themselves into an American League first place play-off with the Cleveland Indians.

Now and then there is a day which is begun inauspiciously before the shaving mirror with a dull razor blade and which blunders along, its hours plodding by with full sixty-minute measure, marked by limping bus, stalled subway, unexpected callers, poor lunch, grease spot on the coat, an afternoon composed of great harassments and small achievement, and a return home in a shower somehow unforeseen by the weather man and therefore unprovided for.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- Striking members of the CIO Longshoremen's Union, announcing a change of policy, reported today through L.B. Thomas, their publicity chairman, that they were willing to release all cargoes now on docks and available for local distribution.

MADRID, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The president of the Board of Film Censors declared today that the Hollywood picture "Gentleman's Agreement" had been banned because its subject matter -- anti-Semitism -- was no problem in Spain.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -The town of Groton, termed by Cornell University professors a "typical American community" will serve as a testing ground in a survey of eating habits to be conducted by Cornell's School of Nutrition.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander in general orders yesterday cited 369 members of the force for meritorious duty. Among those honored were two detectives and three patrolmen who captured a 65-year-old religious fanatic who killed a schoolboy and wounded six others on March 15.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- The Russians threatened the Western powers tonight with "serious consequences" for what the Russians said were repeated violations of air traffic rules over Berlin and in the corridors leading to the city from the Western zones.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors has reported that an informal survey ten days after the passage of an ordinance against lurid comic books disclosed virtually no objectionable ones on sale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A select committee of the House of Representatives split sharply along party lines today in interpreting the effect of government grain buying, undertaken in connection with foreign aid, on the cost of food to the American consumer.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- Encouraged by a box-office victory over President Truman in Los Angeles last night, Henry A. Wallace today hit the recent trail of both his major-party rivals, moving into the lush farming and oil area of California's inland Central Valley.

The United States Treasury's monetary policy is little less than a conspiracy against the thrifty because it shrinks savings accounts and decreases the value of life insurance, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, declares in a special message to Equitable policy-holders.

Billy Southworth gave his 1948 National League champions a final competitive workout yesterday as the curtain fell on the championship season at the Polo Grounds. He tossed twenty-two athletes into the finale against the Giants, five of them bullpen habitues who spent the campaign practically in anonymity.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Jack Onslow, 59, former major league catcher who piloted Memphis of the Southern Association to second place this year, was named the new manager of the Chicago White Sox today, succeeding Ted Lyons.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, cautioned the nation's press and radio yesterday to "play down, rather than play up, those war clouds."

Frieda Hempel can still pack them into Town Hall. And the noted soprano, young looking in a sumptuous pink creation, gave the audience what it wanted yesterday afternoon in a program of love, spring and folk songs, sung with stage manners to match.

During the coming week every town in the land will ask its citizens to be extra vigilant now against fire because the approach of winter cold makes fire-fighting more difficult and hazards more plentiful. More than intellectual assent to the worthiness of a cause is necessary here.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Staging a spine-tingling rally, the Los Angeles Rams scored three touchdowns in the fourth quarter and finished in a 28-28 tie today with the Philadelphia Eagles in a National League football game before 36,884 onlookers in Memorial Coliseum.

MADRID, Oct. 3 -- The resumption of complete United States diplomatic relations with Spain and the granting of military assistance to her armed forces was advocated here today by James A. Farley. Traveling with his son, James Jr., and business associates Mr. Farley arrived in Madrid from Barcelona last night on a stage of his three-month trip that has taken him through much of Europe.
LONDON, Monday Oct. 4 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet Union's reply to the Western Powers on Berlin (as broadcast by the Moscow radio, attributed to Tass and recorded in London by the Soviet monitor):

Proof that "the disabled are able" -- theme of National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week -- is offered in exhibits by twenty business concerns and social agencies at the American Museum of Natural History.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- September set another new monthly record for new construction with a total value of $1,804,000,000, the Commerce Department reported tonight.

Reversing its downward trend in earnings, Eversharp, Inc., in its report of operations to be issued to stockholders today by Martin L. Straus 2nd, chairman, discloses results substantially improved from those the previous year and a large backlog of unfilled orders.

From Washington comes the news that American and British machine-makers will soon standardize screw threads, so that an American bolt will receive a British nut. The effect on industry and on military police will be profound. Without standardization mass production is impossible, and without the mass production of some ten thousand items armies in the field would be crippled.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers came roaring from behind in the last half today to wallop the Boston Yanks, 24 to 14, for their first National Football League victory and their first triumph in five starts, including four exhibitions.

After meetings that began Saturday morning and lasted into the early hours yesterday, the United Office and Professional Workers Association, CIO, authorized its national strike strategy committee to set a specific strike date if the Prudential Life Insurance Company persists in its refusal to negotiate.

The tugboat Ann Marie Tracy, sunk in a collision with a freighter early Saturday, was raised from the muddy bottom of the North River at 7 o'clock last night, and the bodies of six of the nine-crew members reported missing after the sinking were recovered.
A committee has been formed to bring about the establishment of an art museum in Queens, it was announced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles S. Colden.

Wild asters line the roadside, brightening young October even in drought. For the asters are countless, not only in number but in variety. You can find a dozen varieties in one fence corner, and the amateur who would identify all those in a single field is soon bewildered.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 3 -- South Africans are disturbed over reports from New York that American financial circles are not interested at the moment in foreign bond issues. The man in the street had assumed that an American loan to South Africa virtually was assured.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The disarmament proposal of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, at the United Nations in Paris was compared in today's Sunday Times of London to a similar proposal made before the war by Maxim Litvinov at the League of Nations.

While baseball fans following the American League pennant race were calling their sport "unpredictable,'' college football fans the country over found the autumnal pastime furnishing many surprises last Saturday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 -- The continued high production rate of the steel industry and the probable outcome of the railroads newest request for freight rate increases occupied the attention of steel circles here last week.

Airlines Prepare for Ad Battle With one large national airline planning a substantial round-trip fare reduction, not yet announced, and others working on new fare, service and convenience inducements, experienced advertising observers forecast over the weekend that the nation's airlines are headed for the most aggressive advertising campaigns of their history.

During his recent stay in New York Pierre de Gaulle, the Mayor of Paris, declared to the press that his brother, Gen. Charles de Gaulle, was aiming at introducing into France the principles of the American Constitution, which separate the executive completely from the legislative power, and therefore give the former a greater freedom of action than under the parliamentary regime now functioning in France.

The Urban League of Greater New York reported yesterday that Negro youth of the five boroughs had failed to take full advantage of their opportunities by preparing for some definite occupation. This has made the problem of job placement "extremely difficult," Edward S. Lewis, executive secretary, said.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- The wheat market is regarded as in a rut. Recent price changes on the Board of Trade have been relatively small, with cash interests on both sides on a limited scale, especially in view of the liberal sales of the cash article, which are being made to the Government almost daily.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers scored almost as they pleased after a faltering start to whip the Detroit Lions, 33 -- 21, in a national football league game today before 24,206 fans at City Stadium.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Stocks of lard in cold storage continue to decrease rapidly as the result of large shipments on previous contracts and a relatively light make. As a result October lard advanced 17 cents per 100 pounds on the Board of Trade last week, closing yesterday at $18.10. Limited tenders of the cash product were a factor in the upturn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister on Economic Affairs, said today that his country probably would sign a $300,000,000 loan agreement with the Economic Cooperation Administration this week or next.

Nearly 30,000 pupils in 341 city elementary schools and thirty-nine junior high schools received special instruction and assistance to correct speech defects during the last school year, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Letitia Raubicheck, director of speech improvement for the Board of Education.
There is no reason to expect "an early change," in present peak industrial activity or employment, the National City Bank of New York states in its October monthly letter, published today.

Emphasizing a desire for Poland's freedom from Russian influence, 24,000 Polish Americans marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon in the twelfth annual Pulaski Memorial Day parade. The colorful event marked the 200th anniversary of the birth of Brig. Gen. Casimir Pulaski, Polish patriot who served Gen. George Washington during the American Revolution.

Rare furniture associated with Revolutionary patriots hobnobs with nineteenth-century cigar store figurines at the Thirteenth New York Antiques Exposition, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The display will continue daily from 11 A.M to 10:30 P.M. through Friday.
The Maritime commission has decided to postpone issuing a list of shipping companies affected by its recent, charter revisions pending action on applications for relief under the new rules.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -David O. Selznick announced today that he has agreed to lend Jennifer Jones to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the title role in "Madame-Bovary." Miss Jones will start preparations for "Madame Bovary" in November after she completes her engagement in "Rough Sketch" with John Garfield at Columbia.
LONDON, Monday, Oct. 4 -- The Soviet Government proposed today that the four-power Foreign Ministers' Council be called to consider both the Berlin impasse and the entire German situation.

New York's 196-day racing season heads in to the stretch run today. Six weeks and a day are left in the campaign, and the Empire City Racing Association will put on the shows during that period -- all of them at the Jamaica track except for a two-day move to Belmont Park next week for the $100,000 added Gold Cup race.

The opening of the second annual essay contest, "Selling as a Career," for secondary school students, was announced over the week-end by the National Federation of Sales Executives. The contest offers cash prizes totaling $1,850 plus paid-expense trips to Chicago or Washington, D.C.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The Soviet Union's "peace offensive" of the last few days has had a skeptical reception in British official circles and the press. This goes for the disarmament and atomic research proposals of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, for Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky's offer to resume the Berlin negotiations and for the feelers in Vienna concerning Soviet willingness to agree to an Austrian peace treaty.
Fred Allen, the radio comedian, declared war last night on give-away programs.

The Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, said in his sermon yesterday that these were the days when Christianity must be presented not as an investment but as an adventure, as a challenge to take one's stand with God on the divine side of the struggle between good and evil.

Mayor O'Dwyer will break ground for the $7,500,000 central office building of the Board of Transportation at Jay and Willoughby Streets, Brooklyn, at 2:30 P.M. on Friday, the board announced yesterday. The fourteen-story structure, first to be erected in Brooklyn's new civic center, will be completed by the end of 1949.
A suicide by gas yesterday caused an explosion that ripped out the living room wall of a three-room apartment in the Peter Cooper Housing Development, and sent several families rushing to the street.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3 -- All hope for early pegging of the peso to arrest fluctuation of its exchange value between 6.50 and seven to the $1 disappeared last weekend.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- The Government today announced plans to auction off about two dozen surplus war plants it hasn't been able to get rid of.

Representative Fred A. Hartley, Republican, of New Jersey, coauthor of the Taft-Hartley Act, expressed yesterday the belief hat the legislation might be "softened up at some points" in March or later.

Chicken is a favorite any time in the year; right now heavier-sized fryers are so plentiful as to recommend them in particular for October dinners. Farmers-held them back longer than usual in the hope of a rise in poultry prices. The increase did not come; indeed, quite the contrary.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -Six cabinet members today urged Federal, state and community officials to provide all possible employment opportunities for handicapped veterans and civilians.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs took a 4-0 lead, then staved off a last-minute Cardinal rally to defeat St. Louis, 4 to 3, before 18,086 fans today. Despite the defeat the Redbirds finished the season in second place as the Brooklyn Dodgers were defeated by the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 -- 2.

Rex Barney, who opened the season by beating the Giants at the Polo Grounds, ended it yesterday by losing to the Phils at Ebbets Field, the sixth placers winning the game, 4 -- 2, with only one of their runs earned.

The exuberant Tallulah Bank-head is back in town! And that should be sufficient notice to a legion of her admirers. Tonight the star will settle down at the Plymouth (the curtain is advertised to go up at 8 o'clock) in the first Broadway revival of Noel Coward's five-character comedy, "Private Lives," under the auspices of John C. Wilson, a close friend and partner of the author.

An investing client of A.J. Clarke, broker, bought the six-story apartment building on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 785 Tinton Avenue, corner of 158th Street, the Bronx, from the 668 Tinton Avenue Corporation.

Councilman S. Samuel Di Falco, Manhattan Democrat, announced yesterday that he would try on Thursday to get the City Council to pass his long-pigeon-holed local bill to change the name of Avenue of the Americas back to Sixth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The nine Supreme Court justices, back from a four-month summer vacation, open the fall term tomorrow with a long list of labor cases highlighting the docket.

Back of the international drama being enacted in Paris, two Frances are trying to push into the forefront of the crowded stage. One is Communist France, which issued a statement of policy last week denouncing the "anti-Soviet" attacks of Western delegates in the U.N. Assembly, "thanking" the Soviet delegation for its proposals to reduce armament and declaring categorically that "the French people will never make war on the Soviet Union."

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York in its statement of condition as of Sept. 30, for publication today, reported that loans and bills purchased amounted to $927,435,810. The total was $57,000,000 higher than on June 30 and $138,000,000 larger than on Sept. 30, 1947.

A revolt that has been brewing against left-wing leaders of the American Communications Association, Inc., is expected to be brought into the open at its convention here this week, it was learned yesterday. The session will open at the Governor Clinton Hotel on Wednesday.

Luxurious fabrics that are called "plain" to distinguish them from rough-textured weaves or prints are headliners of Schumacher's fall collection 0f decorative materials officially released today. A few of these are brand new. Others are revivals of cloths that have not been available for years.

On Sept. 25 you carried the story of a death. It appeared in your news columns rather than your obituary columns because it was an announcement of the demise of a labor union, the Communications Workers of America, New Jersey Accounting Division No. 64.

The Civil Service Reform Commission, in a letter made public yesterday, urged Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle not to press for passage of the proposed local law to reorganize the fire bureau of the Fire Department. The measure, sponsored by Councilman S. Samuel Di Falco, Democrat, of Manhattan, is in committee.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The United Nations Security Council will take up the German question at 3 P.M. tomorrow at the Palais de Chaillot. Delegates of the smaller countries fervently hope that some way can be found to compromise the differences between the Soviet Union and the three big Western powers.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- Using the dethroned champions of 1947 as the sacrificial offering in what could well be an epic day in Boston baseball history, Joe McCarthy's Red Sox defeated the Yankees, 10 to 5, this afternoon and with this feat plunged the American League's amazing pennant race into deadlock.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 3 -Peruvian sailors, aviation troops and armed civilians, aided by seized warships, rebelled early today at Callao, the port of Lima.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3 -- Today's inflationary pressures are in great part the result of post-war food and coal shortages, the primary causes of retarded industrial reconstruction, the United Nations reported here today in a survey of the two basic commodities.

As a means or assuring light protection for the Hotel Barbizon, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-third Street, the ' Hotel Barbizon, Inc., has purchased the five-story store and apart-I merit house on a lot 17 by 701 feet at 809 Lexington Avenue, north of the corner of Sixtysecond Street, which is separated from the hotel by one building.

Prominent among new exhibitions on the week's art calendar are two additions to the Museum of Modern Art's roster of shows. Opening to the public Wednesday after a preview tomorrow evening is an exhibition of sculpture by the late Elie Nadleman, American modern.

Babies, of course, are of a primary concern to the eighty-six non-profit voluntary hospitals in New York for more reasons than one. Of the 165,000 babies born in all New York hospitals in 1947, two-thirds were born in the voluntary hospitals.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 2 -From early morning till late afternoon crowds stormed through the gates here today to see the Diamond Jubilee edition of the Danbury Fair. When dusk fell, officials announced that 50,000 persons had attended -- a record in the seventy-five-year history of this famed New England exposition.
PARIS, Oct. 3 -- A bilateral treaty of friendship will be signed and become effective between Italy and Greece within a fortnight, according to responsible diplomatic sources.

The new national council of the National Martitime Union, CIO, will meet for the first time today. It came into office two months ago after the union's president, Joseph Curran, conducted an anti-Communist campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- China was described today by a Congressional subcommittee as "the decisive area" in a world tug-of-war between, Communist Russia and the democratic West. The committee urged greater financial aid to China.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills handed the victory starved Brooklyn Dodgers their fifth defeat, 31 to 21, today before 17,694 spectators, the smallest all-America conference football crowd in Civic Stadium in two seasons.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder, Glendale, Calif., won the men's singles title in Pacific Southwest tennis today when Frank Parker, Pasadena, defaulted at the end of the third set. Parker suffered from blisters on both feet. When he limped off the court he was ahead 6 -- 4, 9 -- 7, 5 -- 7.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Rae Scarborough limited the Philadelphia Athletics to four hits today as the Washington Senators pounded out a 7-2 victory over the Mackmen. Home runs by Sherry Robertson and Eddie Yost helped Scarborough score his fifteenth victory of the year.

Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to move within a relatively limited trading range last week, but the nearer future deliveries showed more firmness. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes ranging from an advance of 33 to a decline of two points.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 2 -Most of western Pakistan and the large province of Madras in the Dominion of India enacted the total prohibition of alcoholic liquor last week. Dry laws are likely to be extended gradually through the rest of the Indo-Pakistan sub-continent, although the Indian Central Government has warned the Provinces that this might not be the time to undertake such a costly experiment.
CLEMENTON, N.J., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A ten-inch bomb accidentally fell from a Navy plane today and narrowly missed striking a 55-year-old pedestrian in this Camden County community.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Chet Sanok of Englewood and Jack Read won the annual Joseph M. Byrne Memorial member-guest golf tournament at Crestmount today with a thirty-six-hole total of 135. Eight strokes under par at the end of the first round, the duo clipped one shot from regulation figures on the final try for a 71, nine under for the best-fall tourney.

A report from the congested dance front over the week-end includes the first performance this season of "Frankie and Johnny" by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House, together with sundry, casting items from the same house, and a return visit to Ram Gopal and his Hindu associates at the City Center for a complete performance.
New York City registration for the 1948 presidential election ended early yesterday morning, with the total the poorest in many years.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Ben Hogan and two younger rivals, Fred Haas Jr. and Johnny Palmer, finished tied in the Portland open golf tournament today, each carding 270 for the seventy-two-hole event.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 3 -- A showdown is approaching between the Finnish Communists and the rest of the country.

Bathing suit and beachwear lines for the 1948-49 season, with significant fabric and style innovations, will be opened in the New York market by local swimwear manufacturers and distributors on Oct. 18, it was announced over the week-end by Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Veteran Johnny Vander Meer teamed with Rookie Steve Filipowitz today to give the Cincinnati Reds a 1-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in the finale of the season before a crowd of 7,255.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 3 -At the annual congress of Swiss bankers, held in Interlaken last week-end, the motion now before Parliament to authorize ratification of the agreement signed in Paris April 16 by the Marshall Plan nations to establish the Organization for European Economic Cooperation was the dominating theme of discussion.

Hope that the world would accord justice to the Jaws in Israel and in displaced persons' camps was expressed by rabbis in sermons last night at services ushering in Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5709.
Cecil L. Hudnall has been appointed manager of the Green Coffee and Tea Procurement Division of Standard Brands Inc.

Revenues of the city's unified transit lines for the fiscal year ended on June 30, fell $30,748,643 short of operating expenses, according to Board of Transportation records made available yesterday. A deficit of $31,000,000 had been estimated by the board on April 20, when it adopted the resolution fixing a 10-cent fare on rapid transit lines and one of 7 cents on municipal bus and street car lines.

City College has decided to allow the nineteen students who walked out of a course conducted by Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, head of the Romance Languages Department, on Sept. 21 to continue their course under another teacher, it was learned last night.

Despite a slight lag in the nation's beer sales during the first eight months of the year, leading brewery officials predicted yesterday an all-time record for 1948. The forecast was made at the eleventh annual convention of the National Beer Wholesalers Association, which opened at the Commodore Hotel.

Intensive promotion campaigns by glass-container and tin-can manufacturers have failed, so far, to effect material changes in long-prevailing proportionate use of these major forms of food packaging, it was declared yesterday by key packaging-industry officials.

John M. Littlefield of Auburn, Me., was named the nation's top ranking Mason yesterday. The twenty-third triennial assembly of the General Grand Council of the Royal and Select Masters of the United States of America elected him its new general grand master at its opening session at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week declined 9 per cent below the corresponding period of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 2 per cent.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Rebel-seized ships of the Peruvian Navy entered Callao Harbor today flying white flags of surrender in a dramatic climax to a short-lived but bloody uprising.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 4 -While preparing to leave tomorrow for the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference in London and a visit to the United Nations General Assembly in Paris, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has taken an extraordinary number of occasions to express publicly his faith in the United Nations as an organ of international understanding and cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Soviet Government has placed new restrictions upon the movement of foreign diplomatic personnel that, to all intents, limit their travel to within the city of Moscow, the State Department said today.

The Automobile Club of New York opened its east mid-town branch yesterday at 109 East Fortieth Street. Located in the remodeled home of Ernest Flagg, architect, it is to provide additional travel and service accommodations for members residing in Westchester and other commuter areas and for those working in the east mid-town area.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 4 -- Whether an attempt will be made within the next few months to restore Dr. Hjalmar Schacht to public life in a financial post comparable to that he once enjoyed as President of the Reichsbank has recently been a subject of speculation.

PEIPING, China, Oct. 4 -Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who returned yesterday from a two-day trip to Mukden, conferred today with the chief of the North China Economic Control Board, Shih Kwei-ling, on economic problems here, which are becoming alarming.

The Israeli Government has protested, and we believe rightly, against that part of the proposals of the late United Nations mediator, Count Bernadotte, which would give the Negeb -- the desert area south of Beersheba -- to the Arabs. It is no reflection on the martyred Bernadotte's memory to say that he erred in suggesting this division.

Boris Karloff, who was seen on Broadway last March as a friendly, benign English professor in J.B. Priestley's short-lived play, "The Linden Tree," is returning to the local boards. This time the noted screen played, adhering to his usual menacing line, will portray an Englishman "with murder in his heart" in "The Shop at Sly Corner," which Gant Gaither plans to bring to New York late in December, after a brief out-of-town trial run.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The country's railroads and two operating unions agreed today on a pay increase of 10 cents an hour for 175,000 employes. The rise, effective Oct. 16, will add about $4.80 weekly to the workers' pay checks and will cost the railroads an estimated $55,665,000 annually.

United World Federalists announced yesterday it would decline any funds from the recently organized Foundation for World Government. The Federalists took this step because of the possibility that Henry Wallace, Progressive party candidate, might be associated with the foundation, set up last month with a $1,000,000 gift from Mrs. Anita McCormick Blaine, a sister of the late Cyrus McCormick.

WASHINGTON, Oct 4 -- The Maine Central Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of a plan to increase the par value to $185 of its preferred stock instead of $100, thus eliminating accrued dividends in arrears totaling $85 a share.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Corn was the market leader in grains on the Board of Trade today, moving up steadily after a firm opening as the result of persistent commmission house buying in small lots which forced shorts to cover and at one time May corn was up more than 2 cents from Saturday's finish.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Five permanent committees have been appointed to study the details of a proposed consolidation of six stock exchanges in the Middle West as a result of meetings held here last week, it was announced today. The meetings, a statement issued by the group said, were for the purpose of fact-finding and to organize "a permanent set-up for future detailed investigation and study of all aspects."

BY no coincidence at all, Edith and Sir Osbert Sitwell will arrive in this country for a joint lecture tour shortly after the publication of the fourth volume of Sir Osbert's serial autobiography, "Laughter in the Next Room."* The literary Sitwells, Edith and her two brothers, Osbert and Sacheverell, for twenty-five years have presented a united front to a public which has never been certain whether to cheer or jeer their efforts.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Experts in supply problems described today steps now being taken under the new military unification program to prevent a repetition of mistakes that they said caused a huge waste of materials, manpower and money in World War II.
Although the equivalent of a good-sized town has been carted away from its path across Queens, Van Wyck Expressway will not open to traffic until the summer of 1950, according to current estimates.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Supreme Court Justice J. Gordon Flannery granted today an application of the Kensico Cemetery Corporation, operator of a nonsectarian burial ground at Valhalla, for permission to sell 73.84 unused acres of its 461-acre tract to the recently organized Hillbrook Cemetery Corporation for development of a Jewish burial ground. Kensico would receive $1,179,348 for the land, which has been tax-exempt since it was acquired in 1907.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (AP) -- To put it mildly, Cleveland went nuts today as its Indians won the American League pennant.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 4 -- The first ship carrying displaced persons to the United States under the new law covering them will leave Bremerhaven for New York on Oct. 17, officials of the International Refugee Organization said today.

THE TIMES account of the recent meeting between Canadian newsprint manufacturers and American newspaper publishers indicates that the manufacturers base their blunt refusal to expand productive facilities on the idle newsprint capacity in the world, allegedly sufficient to meet current world newsprint needs, and the uncertainty of sustained demand for newsprint and the high construction costs of new productive facilities.

MADRID, Spain, Oct. 4 -- There is no basic difference of opinion between the United States Department of State and the United States armed forces on the question of policy toward Spain, the highest United States Embassy authority said today.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The United Nations Security Council deferred its opening debate on the German question for one hour today in a wrangle over what interpretation system to use -- the consecutive or the simultaneous. Finally it threw the packed house into ripples of laughter by a unanimous decision to use both.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration reviewed the first three months of its existence today and found its foreign-aid program making notable progress in spite of active opposition by the Soviet Union and the Communist governments of Europe.

MINEOLA L. I., Oct. 4 -- After a four-month investigation by his office, District Attorney James N. Gehrig suggested today in a report to County Executive J. Russel Sprague that the latter initiate, "through your official channels, legislation which will prevent and prohibit the abuse of charity for private gain."

Residents of New York State increased their holdings of United States savings bonds in the first seven months of 1948 far more than in the corresponding period of either 1946 or 1947, it was announced yesterday by Philip M. Light, state director, the savings bond division for New York of the Treasury Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board, acting on an order by President Truman, today authorized Pan American Airways, Inc., to establish an air route between the Pacific Northwest and Hawaii. The President invoked security powers to authorize the service for five years.

Directors of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., have fixed a subscription price of $10 a share for the 1,223,000 shares of additional stock it plans to offer to shareholders, Stuart M. Crocker, president, announced yesterday.
OTTUMWA, Iowa, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Alben W. Barkley, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, accused the Republican party tonight of trying to foment class division between labor and agriculture.
Following is the text of the radio address by Senator Vandenberg last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4 -- Major innovations in heating, cooking, refrigeration, air-conditioning, incineration and clothes drying for home and business were revealed here today in Municipal Auditorium with the opening of the exhibit of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association.

The Public Service Commission made public yesterday letters sent to the city's privately operated bus lines requesting them to notify the commission of any negotiations that might be under way for sale of the bus lines to the city.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- When the North American College here opens its classrooms on Oct. 15 for the first time since 1940, fifty of America's most talented aspirants for the Roman Catholic priesthood will start their long scholastic grind.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The play-by-play account of the play-off game between the Indians and Red Sox follows:

BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- High-powered master-minding, strategic concepts and Machiavellian managerial maneuvering are awsomely impressive -- when they work. Marse Joe McCarthy carefully studied the wind which blew out toward the short left field fence today and abandoned all notion of using his stylish young southpaw, Mel Parnell.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped $1 to $2 today, but cattle were unevenly $1 higher to 50 cents lower, while sheep were 50 to 75 cents less. Vealers were $2 lower.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- Railroad union leaders are aiming at Government ownership of railroads, Donald D. Conn, executive vice president of the Transportation Association of America, declared today.

The handicappers' best friend, Calumet Farm's Citation, and four thoroughbreds from overseas are among the twenty-seven nominations for the Empire City Racing Association's $100,000 added Gold Cup race, scheduled for a week from Saturday at Belmont Park.

School geographies have a wealth of information for a studious schoolboy, but it is an unusual geography that has monetary wealth hidden between the outer cover and binding. Police Property Clerk Frank Leuci observed this yesterday as he received from the Board of Education $133 in bills found inside a book at John Ericsson Junior High School, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.
DETROIT, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Temporarily at least the automobile industry is back in high volume operation.

A visitor to the show being put on this week at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West, by the physically handicapped will come away, we believe, with a new definition of the word "handicapped." There are blind persons, people without legs, people partially paralyzed.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 4 -- Rhode Island potatoes, being bought by the Federal Government under its price support program for $2.85 for 100 pounds, are being resold to Rhode Island farmers at 40 cents for 100 pounds as hog and cattle feed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- In his speech of acceptance to the Democratic National Convention at Philadelphia and in his campaign utterances thus far President Truman has made slight reference, when he has made any at all, to the part played by the Republicans in transforming his foreign programs into operating policies.

BERLIN, Oct. 4 -- Soviet fighter planes, darting out of heavy clouds, flew dangerously near to British transports today as the Russian campaign to impede the Anglo-American airlift to this blockaded city continued.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Discrimination against twenty-one Westchester County villages in the distribution of state financial aid results now in payments averaging 96 cents a year for each resident, compared with $3 a year in all other villages of the state, the Westchester County Village Officials Association said today in a brochure sent to state and county officials.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- Cleveland is to have its first world series in twenty-eight years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The start made by life insurance companies in the housing field in New York and four other major United States cities has led a large number of people in this country to look for further contributions in the housing field, Frederick H. Allen of New York, housing consultant, said here today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- Speaking tonight before an audience of 4,000 in Syria Mosque in this Democratic-controlled industrial city, Governor Earl Warren of California declared that full production was the sole key to solving the problems of inflation.
The peak of the outbreak of poliomyelitis among New York children was passed in mid-September, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard reported yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 4 -- T.Y. Yun, Minister of Home Affairs, today revealed that he had "uncovered a widespread plot to overthrow the Government, assassinate Government officials including President Syngman Rhee and take over authority by force."

American distribution rights to three foreign pictures, one Italian and two Swedish, have been acquired by two local film concerns. On Oct. 22 Films International of America will premier Giuseppe De Santis' "Tragic Hunt" at the Ambassador Theatre.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Harry Straus' Pilaster captured the Bethesda purse, sixth and top event at Laurel Park today, gaining a length and one-half victory over the Christiana Stable's Alexis. The latter led to the stretch, tired in the final sixteenth, but managed to save the place by a neck over G.R. Watkins' Cat Bridge.
A Coast Guard board of inquiry started yesterday an investigation of the collision last Saturday between the Liberty tanker Eliza Jane Nicholson and the tug Ann Marie Tracy that cost nine lives.

Once-beaten Illinois, host to the Army on Saturday, is capable of playing better football than it has in its brushes with Kansas State and Wisconsin. This is the opinion of Johnny Mauer, one of Earl Blaik's West Point aides, who scouted the Illini in both contests and told all at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday.

Establishment of the state of Israel was cited yesterday by many rabbis, in celebrating the first day of Rosh ha-Shanah, as an inspiration to the people of the world in their attempt to return to the accepted laws of international morality.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Robert C. Alexander, State Department officer, today threatened libel action unless the department grants him a public hearing on his disputed charge that subversive aliens entered this country under United Nations protection.

More dolls than most little girls ever dreamed existed went on display yesterday at Hearn's, Fifth Avenue at Fourteenth Street. By 6 P.M., closing time, hundreds of fingerprints and nose smudges made by small doll-fanciers covered the glass eases and counters where the toys are on show.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The House Committee on Un-American activities began drawing up today two citations for perjury and four for contempt against witnesses in its investigation of alleged wartime atomic espionage.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Democratic leaders and some business men in Westchester protested today concerning a new type of fund-solicitation letter sent to bank presidents, manufacturers and other heads of corporations by the Republican County Committee.

The United States Court of Appeals rejected yesterday the application of Local 1250 of the Department Store Employes Union, independent, for a stay of an injunction issued by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman on Sept. 14 and of all court proceedings resulting from it. The court set Oct. 15 as the date for argument on the union's appeal against the injunction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The office of General Counsel, National Labor Relations Board, decided today that there was nothing illegal in the typographical union agreements made with the New York newspapers "on their face" but that the union must cease construing or interpreting the contracts so as to discriminate against nonunion members.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Local 1 of the shipworkers' union, which withdrew last week from the Industrial Union of Marine and Ship-building Workers of America, CIO, has applied for an independent Congress of Industrial Organizations charter, James C. McKissock, president of the Camden unit, announced today.
Anderson, Clayton Co. declared an extra dividend of $1 and the regular quarterly of 50 cents payable to common stockholders on Oct. 22. A similar extra was distributed in July.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 4 -- United States and foreign-flag shipping lines against which an anti-trust suit was filed in Federal Court here on Aug. 6 will contend that their rate practices have been beneficial rather than restrictive, it became known today.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 4 -- Without uttering a word on his personal preference in the Presidential race, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, found himself the center of a hot political dispute tonight.

The stock market held its upward course yesterday, but trading remained restricted, partly as a result of the Jewish holiday. The session was the third in succession of higher prices although gains were mostly fractional with a few key industrials advancing a point.

GENEVA, Tuesday, Oct. 5 -- The establishment of an all-European organization to promote East-West trade was assured today by the recommendation by a special committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe for such a course.

A wage increase of $3 to $4 a week for telephone operators in the metropolitan area was offered yesterday by the New York Telephone Company to the Traffic Employes Association, an unaffiliated union with 19,000 members in this area.

A toy should not be a mere diversion but should stimulate a child's potential creativeness and usefulness, a group of child-study experts agreed yesterday at a Christmas preview of toys at Creative Playthings, 867 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Supreme Court, opening its 159th year today, paused for a moment of tribute to the late Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes who died on Aug. 27.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The long-planned convention on genocide to outlaw mass murder of racial, national and religious groups now appears slated for completion at this session of the United Nations General Assembly. The legal committee resolved today without a single objection to discuss it in draft form immediately.
Music translated into interior decoration results in a heavy accent on color in the new series of rooms, designed by Karl Steinhauser, that opened yesterday at Bloomingdale's.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- In a sequel to a ten-year judicial inquiry, seven little-known members of the Cagoulards, pre-war semi-Fascist group, were brought to trial today on charges that they had dealt with the Germans.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 4 -- New Jersey's Democrats will play host to President Truman next Thursday night in Elizabeth, Newark and this city, in a demonstration such as only veteran political boss Frank Hague can put on.
The Thor Corporation announced yesterday plans to purchase and retire 88,723 of its common shares from the estate of Edward N. Hurley, its late chairman, and allied interests.

Life could be beautiful, said our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn, settling himself into a chair, if only it were not for people who borrow books. Our visitor was, it turned out, on his way to a bookstore to replace several volumes he once had owned and from which (he alleged) he had been parted by guests with honest faces.

A reduction in the coverage of residence and outside theft policies was announced yesterday by the National Bureau of Casualty Underwriters. The revision is effective immediately in all states except Texas, where it goes into effect on Dec. 1.

The suggestion has been made to the Economic Cooperation Administration that all bookings of ECA shipments be done through recognized forwarders, it was disclosed yesterday by Walter H. Van Hoesen of R.F. Downing Co., Inc., and president of the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association.

The West End Presbyterian Church's call to the Rev. Theodore A. Gill to become its pastor was approved yesterday by the Presbytery of New York, which also approved calls by the Hunts Point Church, in the Bronx, and Fort George Church.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Communists in Eastern Europe have set up the "most ruthless dictatorships the world has ever seen," Christopher P. Mayhew, British Foreign Under-Secretary, charged today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 -- Bryan Foy. Eagle Lion producer, has engaged George Zuckerman to write a photoplay under the title "Trapped" dealing with counterfeiting, it was learned today.

Backlogs have started to increase for larger sizes of conveyor belting, rubber hose and mechanical rubber goods, officials of two of the larger manufacturers revealed here yesterday. Much of the increased demand is a result of European Recovery Plan requirements, now coming through from European agents in larger volume, they said.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4 (AP) -Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said today he had sold American films to the Yugoslavs.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Oct. 4 -- The frost is on the pumpkin and also on the golfers, or so it seemed as 77 teams battled all day for top honors in the weekly Long Island PGA amateur-pro best ball tournament over the Wheatley Hills Course today.

Police and firemen led 200 men, women and children at 132 East 112th Street to safety early yesterday when a fire broke out in the six-story tenement building on a corner of upper Park Avenue. A small boy was burned badly and a woman was hurt seriously when she jumped from a fourth-floor window.

The American Silent Guest Committee, Inc., founded a year ago to aid -- the hungry children of Europe, will seek to raisea minimum of $1,000,000 this year, according to campaign plans outlined yesterday by Miss Iris Gabriel, founder and director of the movement.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a 50 per cent call on its deposits with the nation's smaller, Class A, banks. The call, based on such deposits as of the close of business on Oct. 2, is payable on Oct. 11, and will draw $143,447,500 from the banks, of which $10,892,200 will come from this area.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 4 -Religion's answer to the challenge of communism demands the immediate development of an "aggressive, pioneering" church determined to practice its preachments and to tolerate nothing which might "make a mockery" of Christian or democratic principles, the Rev. Dr. Ralph E. Diffendorfer of New York, executive secretary of the division of foreign missions of the Methodist Church, said tonight.

Rarely has a group of opera singers had a better opportunity to display their talents than did the four Italians who performed at Carnegie Hall last night, for they were accompanied by a well-rehearsed orchestra drawn largely from the ranks of the Philharmonic-Symphony and competently conducted by Alfredo Antonini.

Some independent appliance and radio dealers are demanding that manufacturers and distributors grant larger discounts, store owners disclosed yesterday. They point out that current discounts on some items do not permit an operating profit because of higher handling, service and other costs.

Seven table settings with floral arrangements by Ann Hagan and five house models built and decorated by students of the New York School of Interior Decoration are featured in McCreery's special displays for Home Fashion Time.

A public offering of $2,525,000 of refunding and various purpose 2 1/4 per cent bonds of Minneapolis, Minn., will be made today by an underwriting group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. The bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1949-68, are being offered at prices to yield from 1 per cent to 2.40 per cent, according to maturity.

Twenty-three persons, rescued by the Coast Guard after their chartered DC-3 passenger plane crash-landed just before dawn yesterday on Great Harbor Key in the Bahamas near Nassau, landed safely in Miami last night aboard two Coast Guard PBM planes.

Total deposits of The National City Bank of New York as of Sept. 30 were $4,567,484,131, compared with $4,645,527,279 on June 30, and $4,622,164,738 at the end of September last year, the bank reported in its quarterly statement of condition published today.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France are agreed that until the Berlin blockade is lifted there can be no conference of the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers, as urged by the Soviet Union's latest note, it was said authoritatively today after the three Western officials had met for nearly two hours at the Quai d'Orsay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Awards of merit are to be issued to employers who hire the handicapped, Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin announced today at a luncheon opening National Employ the Handicapped Week.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A second Communist attempt to disrupt the start of the recruiting campaign for Britain's auxiliary armed forces was broken up by police tonight. Husky soldiers bodily ejected hecklers from a meeting that had been addressed by Lord Tedder, Marshal of the Royal Air Force.

Old Buzfuz, who enjoys chomping on tangerines, earned the price of a carload or two of same at the Jamaica track yesterday when he got his head in front at the end of the $29,250 Fleetwing Handicap. The decision, gained in a furious finish, was worth $20,200 to the Buzzer's owner, Mose Rauzin of Miami Beach.

The average interest rate paid on short term commercial and industrial loans during the first fifteen days of September was 2.26 per cent, compared with 2.10 per cent during the similar period in June and 1.77 per cent in the first part of September a year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey talked briefly by telephone today with John Foster Dulles, his principal foreign-affairs adviser who is one of the American delegates to the United Nations General Assembly, preparatory to a full-dress conference tomorrow on the international situation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears slashed and passed to a 28-17 National Football League victory over the defending champion Cardinals before this city's biggest professional game crowd, 52,765, at Comiskey Park tonight.

Victor Emanuel, president, reported yesterday that the Avco Manufacturing Corporation earned $5,323,079 on net sales of $98,957,139 in the nine months ended Aug. 31, 1948. He said that sales and earnings from the corporation's manufacturing operations were running at the highest rates in its twenty-year history.
Fourteen 4-H Club members who summered abroad in seven countries as "grass roots envoys" received a warm welcome home yesterday at the Ambassador Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Michigan-Wisconsin Pipeline Company, a Detroit subsidiary of the American Light and Traction Company of Chicago, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to issue and sell $66,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 5/8 per cent, due in 1968.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- "I've been licked before and I can be licked again, I'm sorry for the boys, that's all. And that's all I have to say, gentlemen."

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 4 -- Efforts on the part of one group within the Brotherhood of the United Lutheran Church in America to have the brotherhood's central office transferred from Bethlehem, Pa., to New York City today caused a three-hour heated debate as sessions of the sixteenth biennial convention of the organization continued in this city.
TOKYO, Oct. 4 -- Changes in Japan's anti-monopoly law are likely. Occupation officials are not objecting to Japanese suggestions regarding stock ownership and international contracts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- President Truman today issued an executive order directing the Displaced Persons Commission to scrutinize displaced persons seeking entry into this country, as required by the Displaced Persons Act, and instructed the State and Army Departments to lend the commission every assistance.
A sharp decline in foreign, commerce, which has been developing since last spring, is causing alarm among shipping companies serving New York.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Appointment of Viscount Montgomery, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, as permanent military chairman of the Western Union defense organization was officially confirmed here tonight in a communique issued by the Secretary General of the Permanent Commission of the Brussels treaty powers.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Sir Stafford Cripps. Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister for Economic Affairs as well as head of the Treasury, came under sharp criticism in business and industrial circles here today for having insisted that Britain's rearmament program could be carried through without disrupting the nation's recovery plans.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Tuesday, Oct. 5 -- Wilbur L. Cross, former four-term Governor of Connecticut, died early today at his home here. His age was 86.

Stanley Raymond Harris, better and more familiarly known as Bucky, yesterday was dropped by the Yankees. After managing the club to a pennant and world championship in his first year, and piloting an overaged outfit -- alive and in the running for the flag as late as last Saturday -- to third place in his second, Harris found himself without a job after two seasons as head field-man of the New Yonkers.

As Greenwich House enters its forty-sixth consecutive year at 27 Barrow Street, I would like to take this occasion to tell those generous New Yorkers who have supported its valuable work the plans of service which are now getting under way.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Lanky Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans, won the three-way play-off for the Portland open golf title today, defeating Ben Hogan and Johnny Palmer of Badin, N.C.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, chairman of the Trade Policies Committee, has ordered public hearings beginning Nov. 9 on the Supreme Court price-policies decision, he said today.

After an excellent day of scoter shooting on Saturday, we found ourselves wondering what had happened to the scoter shooters who once raced to get a good stand on the islands and reefs along the Connecticut shore of the Sound.

Cleveland's victory in the American League pennant play-off yesterday means that television audiences along the Eastern seaboard will see only the world series games played in Boston. Thanks to the victory, however, televiewers in the Midwest will see their first series on video, the Cleveland games being fed to a circuit between Buffalo and St. Louis.

A review of medicine's conquest of disease with chemicals specifically designed to produce a particular therapeutic effect was significantly coupled yesterday with an encouraging report from a field where science has made little headway -- the chemotherapy of cancer.

The American Labor party received a setback yesterday in its fight to bring back a five-cent fare in the city. Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan denied its petition to compel the Board of Elections to list on the ballot a proposition calling for the ratification or rejection of a five-cent rapid transit fare.

The four-legged performers -- the broncos, steers and Brahma bulls -- are the stars thus far in this year's twenty-third annual World Championship Rodeo as it enters its second week at Madison Square Garden.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- A proposal of the nation's railroads to increase freight rates will be opposed by the Associated Industries of New York unless the railroads prove the boost is essential, the Association said today.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The formation here of a group representing trade unions repressed in Soviet satellite areas was announced today. The organization, which appears to have at its disposal a working intelligence division, has pledged itself to propaganda against Communist or any other political domination of unions and to the organization of foreign workers in France and other Western European countries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- President Truman will take to the political trails again Wednesday.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- Gene Bearden, on the shoulders of admiring team-mates, was carried off the field at Fenway Park this afternoon, setting off the greatest celebration any Cleveland club has known in baseball history, a fitting climax to the most exciting flag struggle in the history of the junior circuit.

The first group of forty-nine prospective inductees to be called under the new peacetime Selective Service Act were examined here yesterday for service in the Army. However, when the men in the 25-year-old group had completed their mental and physical tests, only seven were found eligible for induction Nov. 3.

A motorist converted his jeep into an ambulance early yesterday morning to transport a doe, injured by an automobile on the Henry Hudson Parkway, fourteen miles to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals shelter at Twenty-fourth Street and Avenue A.
Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the city would act swiftly on a proposal to establish a "policy making and planning" commission to grapple with New York's costly traffic jam.

The ride of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, once one of the event's foremost eye-catchers, will be revived at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 2 to 9. In making the announcement yesterday, Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman, president of the show, said the "Mounties" would appear at each evening and matinee performance.

Leading chain and independent grocers are dropping the practice of running "week-end specials," it was learned here yesterday. Congestion created in stores by this type of promotion eliminates efficiency and shopping comfort, it was stated.
Differences between Hindus and Moslems in India and Pakistan are not reflected among merchant seamen of the two dominions, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg assured the nation tonight that this country's bipartisan approach to world affairs permitted a change in the national administration "without affecting the continuity of our foreign policy."
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Stan (The Man) Musial joined Manager Eddie Dyer today in reaching a two-year agreement with the St. Louis Cardinals.

Efforts of the State Mediation Board to bring together representatives of the Union News Company and its 1,100 striking employes, who have shut down most of the company's newsstands, soda fountains and drugstores in railroad stations here, proved fruitless yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that breaking ground for a new $9,500,000 home office of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York was an act of faith in the city and the country "when Governments are teetering throughout the world."

Leonard Bacon Clark, 42-year-old Harvard Law School graduate whose father, a Maine sea captain, amassed a fortune in the rum and molasses trade, was accused yesterday of having drained $1,362,000 from the family estate in the last twelve years "to live well."

After seventeen years, Noel Coward's "Private Lives" is still outrageously amusing. Since virtually the same thing is true of Tallulah Bankhead, the revival which opened at the Plymouth last evening is the funniest item in the season so far.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- There can be no peace or real understanding between Hollywood and the British film industry until British films receive "reasonable playing time in the United States," J. Arthur Rank said today. Mr. Rank is head of Britain's largest film producing and exhibiting organization.

What goes on here? It is early October, the season is new, and here are two artists -- Jacqueline Blancard, pianist, and Andre de Ribaupierre, violinist -- appearing in Town Hall with their objective apparently to make good music rather than to establish that they can play faster or louder than any one else.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A call to wage an armed rebellion against the Labor Government unless it mends its ways was issued tonight by J. Gibson Jarvie, chairman of the United Dominions Trust, Ltd.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Chicago North Western Railway obtained a court order today empowering it to increase some commuter fares about 8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today the estimated net income of Class I railroads in August was $86,000,000. That is $33, 000,000 higher than in the same month last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 4 -- The manufacturing end of the gas industry is caught between two seemingly irreconcilable problems: It needs greater economies to attract investor confidence and it needs greater investor confidence to make economies possible.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange moved yesterday into new high ground for the life of the current contracts. The advance was attributed to trade hedge covering of the nearby months and scattered short coving.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Following are excerpts from an address by Warren R. Austin, United States representative, before the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:
FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 4 -- Henry A. Wallace called tonight for resumption of discussions by the major powers of the Berlin question "in good faith" as a means of averting war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- After more than two years of investigation, the Federal Reserve Board announced today that it would begin public hearings here on Oct. 12 to consider anti-trust charges against the huge Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco.

The arrival of almost 3,000 passengers on five liners inbound from foreign ports, between 8 and 9:40 A.M., and a shortage of personnel because of the Rosh ha-Shanah holiday, gave customs inspection officers a busy day yesterday.

ATHENS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Minister of Public Order Constantine Rentis said today that because of clamor in the United States he was exerting pressure on the Salonika police to solve the mystery murder of George Polk, CBS correspondent.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Secretary of State Marshall held a reunion last week-end with a hostess of thirty-one years ago in the course of a sentimental journel through eastern France, an aide revealed here today.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The United States, Britain and France brushed aside today a last-minute Soviet proposal that the Council of Foreign Ministers be convened to take up the entire German question.
PARIS, Oct., 4 (AP) -- Following are the texts of statements on the Berlin situation made today in the United Nations Security Council by the Soviet, United States and British representatives:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Attorney General Clark today filed a new challenge against the freight rates which the railroads charged the Government during the war.

Details of a new housing development at 180th Street and Sixty-ninth Avenue, off Union Turnpike, in the Jamaica Estates North section of Queens, were announced yesterday by Lane Realty, sales representative. The project, to be known as Meadowcrest Homes, will contain sixty one-family bungalow type dwellings.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Sir Arthur Whitten-Brown, who with the late Sir John Alcock made the first non-stop air crossing of the Atlantic in June, 1919, from Newfoundland to Clifden, Ireland, died in his sleep last night, it was announced today. He was 62.

A kitchen designed to conserve energy and time is on exhibition at the Museum of Natural History this week. Though it was planned primarily for women with cardiac conditions who must take things easy when they work, other housewives will find it full of valuable ideas, too.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The British Government has requested authority from the Economic Cooperation Administration to use Marshall Plan counterpart funds, now totaling about $250,000,000. for debt-retirement purposes under a program calling for investment of 20 per cent of the national income in capital equipment.

"The Reign of Queen Victoria," by Hector Bolitho, the story of Victoria from her childhood to her last days as an imperious monarch, has been scheduled for Oct. 26 publication by Macmillan. Mr. Bolitho, author of seven books on the Victorian period and editor of the last volume of the Queen's letters, recently finished a lecture tour of the United States.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Johnny Sain, a strong-armed right-hander who won twenty-four games this season, was named tonight by Manager Billy Southworth to pitch the world series opener for the Braves Wednesday, but Manager Lou Boudreau of the Indians refused to select a nominee.
With the world series coming up, football will have to be satisfied with the crumbs of the public's sporting interest this week, but the Ivy set won't starve despite the competition.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 4 -- The Government announced tonight that customs duties on raw materials, plants and machinery imported into India for industrial purposes would be relaxed "to the extent that this may be practicable without injury to Indian manufacturers of similar goods."
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, 1 to 10 points higher. Considerable of the day's trading was for purposes of price-fixing by mills.

It cost $92,901,520.48 last year to operate the voluntary hospitals of the city. There is always a deficit. This year it will amount to $2,845,988.30, an amount so small that it testifies to the economy with which voluntary hospitals are administered. That small deficit must be made up by contributions from ordinary citizens, contributions that may be as little or as much as the donor pleases.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A Soviet note suggesting a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers on the German issue provided a few hours' sensation for Britain's evening newspapers today but its reception at the Foreign Office was icy so far as can be ascertained.
