WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Lawyers for Representative Lyndon Johnson petitioned the Supreme Court today to support Justice Hugo L. Black's stay of a lower court injunction barring Mr. Johnson's name from the Texas ballot as Democratic nominee for Senator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Any further delay in harnessing the St. Lawrence River to utilize its potential of 2,200,000 horsepower "cannot be justified," according to Francis B. Wilby, chairman of the New York State Power Authority. He expressed this view today as he appealed to the Federal Power Commission to grant a license for the $463,000,000 project.

Notre Dame, picking up where it left off at the end of the regular 1947 season, captured the No. 1 position in the first Associated Press poll to select the nation's ten top teams in the current campaign yesterday by a slim 10-point margin.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Coal production ceased throughout France today as the miners' strike called by Communist unions was reported to have been generally effective in all mining districts. The loss to French industry was estimated at 150,000 tons of coal a day.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The United States warned the world today that no security could result from Russian proposals for the simultaneous signing of treaties outlawing the atomic bomb and setting up international atomic control.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- With sentiment strengthened by the Soviet Union's proposal to hold a new four-power meeting, plus the distribution of 3,500,000 of Argentine rail purchase money, business was brisker in a cheerful stock market here today.

A sulfa drug said to possess a "potentially high degree of usefulness" in the treatment of ulcerative colitis (ulcers of the colon), a disease afflicting thousands, was announced yesterday by Columbia University.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Communist opposition to the European Recovery Program was sharply criticized today by Willard L. Thorp, Assistant United States Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, who in a speech before the United Nations Economic and Financial Committee appealed for a joint effort by all the nations to defeat disease, malnutrition, ignorance and inadequate standards of living.

ELGIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Oct. 4-- Realistic maneuvers intended to demonstrate the unified operation of the armed services began here today with 10,000 men of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines participating.

The American Labor party has lost the first round in its fight to compel the city to hold a referendum Nov. 2 on the question of a return to the five-cent fare on city-owned transit. Supreme Court Justice Cohalan finds that it is "fallacious" to argue that transit is now a matter exclusively of city concern, with the state on the sidelines.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Small business men are getting little opportunity to benefit by the provisions of the Economic Cooperation Act, under which Americans investing in new enterprises in the Marshall Plan countries are guaranteed against exchange loss on their funds.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- It was shortly after noon at Braves Field and Manager Billy Southworth's National League champions were going through their final prepping for tomorrow's opening battle in the world series.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- British Government stocks were the feature in the stock market here today, which was rather subdued under the influence of political uncertainties and the Jewish New Year holiday.

Although cotton textile orders are admittedly smaller, they appear to be coming in with greater frequency, according to Worth Street sources. Commission men pointed out yesterday that this development, which is indicative of conservative short-term buying, has helped to buy the market and give it a stronger tone.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 5 -- The manager of the Grand Colombian Merchant Marine, Alvaros Diaz, has denied the use of unfair methods against independent lines. In a recent speech before the industrialists of the State of Antioquia in Medellin, he countercharged that the United States, Argentina and Brazil were discriminating.

ROME, Oct. 5 -- The Foreign Ministry announced today that from Nov. 1 no passport visas would be required by American citizens entering Italy for "brief visits." The United States has reciprocated by authorizing American consulates to issue special visitor's visas to Italian citizens who wish to go to America for purposes other than taking up residence there.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 5 -- An "action" program defining the role of Methodist women in their denomination's new four-year campaign of Advance for Christ and His Church was adopted here today at a special meeting of the Woman's Division of Christian Service of the Methodist Church.

Those who tune menus to markets will be interested that the Department of Agriculture's October list of plentiful foods is unusually long and varied. Ordinarily, the products on this regular monthly round-up are not only abundant, but moderate in cost, too.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- An immediate military alliance of the United States with the anti-Communist world, including Franco Spain, was strongly recommended today by Chairman Gurney.

LLANDUDNO, Wales, Oct. 5 -The sixty-ninth and largest annual conference of the Conservative party opens tomorrow in a hopeful atmosphere. As the general election of 1950 approaches the Conservatives are getting more confident.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Australia today took the leadership of a growing number of countries in demanding the revival of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission despite the deep rift between the ninemember majority and the SovietUkrainian minority.

The proposed increase in rentals for city pier and bulkhead properties, which is scheduled for consideration by the Board of Estimate tomorrow, was opposed here yesterday by the General Managers Association of New York in a letter to the board and Mayor O'Dwyer.
The golden anniversary shrub and tree planting program of the Park Association of New York City was endorsed yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer.
PARIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The United Nations text of Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky's statement to the Security Council on the Berlin case:

The nation, the State of Connecticut and Yale University had much to be grateful for in the life of Wilbur Lucius Cross. He was an inspiring teacher, an able dean of the Yale Graduate School, a scholarly editor of The Yale Review and, finally, an excellent Governor of Connecticut for four terms.

Cotton futures were steady early yesterday, but closed 5 points higher to 19 points lower, as trading on New York Cotton Exchange continued rather slow. After opening 7 points lower to 3 points higher, the market steadied around the previous closing levels on pricefixing for domestic and foreign mills.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- A Government conference today with delegates of the three chief unions now involved in the French coal strike failed to end the conflict that is now completing its second day.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- Still slightly out of breath from their frantic last-minute rush to catch the world series gravy train, the Cleveland Indians will square off against the Boston Braves here tomorrow, the first outbreak of tribal warfare around these parts in a couple of centuries. The noble redmen donned their war paint today, practiced a few blood-curdling whoops and sharpened their scalping knives.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 5 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California carried his Republican campaign for the Vice Presidency into this State Capital tonight.
LANSING, Mich., Oct. 5 (AP) -Michigan's new labor law, the validity of which once was in doubt, remains on the books.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Radar devices developed during the war for detecting enemy submarines and airplanes have uncovered a new world of sound coming from all around the cosmos. They have provided the first scientific evidence of the existence of something along the lines of the "music of the spheres," postulated by Pythagoras more than 2,500 years ago.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The United Nations General Assembly and its heavy agenda were pushed into the background tonight while delegates from all over the world waited for the next Russian move in the Security Council.
An illicit shipment of Mexican gold pieces bound for Holland was seized by customs authorities on a Brooklyn pier yesterday.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries set a new sales record for the six and twelve months ended on July 31, last, according to the interim unaudited statement of operations issued yesterday by Bernard F. Gimbel, president, for publication today.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 5 (AP) -Horsemen said today they will make a court test case of it the first time the Maryland Racing Commission hauls one of them up on its new regulations against doping.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade today, but in the main showed a firm undertone, especially the near delivery.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 5 -- The night depository of the Fidelity Union Trust Company was looted of cash deposits estimated at $18,000 over the week-end by a thief who operated with nothing more than a key and a crudely sewn but ingeniously devised cloth trap.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5 -Dr. Compton, one of the nation's outstanding physicists, became president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1930. He resigned at the annual meeting of the institute corporation yesterday and was elected chairman of the institute.

A research fellowship to help eliminate the tropical earthworm, which has caused serious damages to putting greens, has been established by golf clubs in the metropolitan area, Eugene L. Larkin, chairman of the green section committee of the M.G.A., announced yesterday.

BRIELLE, N.J., Oct. 5 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey was asked by Mayor Harry H. Kroh of Brielle, in a letter made public today, to discontinue construction of the proposed new highway bridge over the Manasquan River between Brielle and Point Pleasant Beach, pending an investigation.
Nashville, Tenn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 2 on $1,000,000 issue of school bonds dated Oct. 1, 1948, and due Oct. 1 from 1949 to 1968.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Eight new Masonic officers were installed yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel as the twenty-third triennial assembly of the General Grand Council of the Royal and Select Masters of the United States of America drew to a close.

Seth Ramkrishna Dalmia, one of India's wealthiest industrialists and publishers, who has long espoused some sort of world government to bring peace to the world, announced here yesterday the setting up of an annual $15,000 peace prize.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns came from behind to win a grueling battle in the mud by 14 -- 10 from the Baltimore Colts in an All-America Football Conference game tonight.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 5 (AP) -A series of hearings on various plans to reorganize the debtor Central States Electric Corporation opened in Federal District Court today.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, who last winter insisted that his union "never" would make phonograph records again, acknowledged yesterday that both he and the record companies were anxious to reach a new agreement.

The city has offered to undertake its program of building six new sewage disposal plants in the next six years and thus satisfy the immediate demands of the interstate Sanitation Commission to abate pollution of the New York bathing and recreational waters, it was learned yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The new travel restrictions issued by the Soviet Union to foreign embassies last week do not confine foreigners to Moscow, but specify the areas and cities that cannot be visited.

The Philadelphia Orchestra had returned; the same orchestra which had been announced as disbanding a few days previous. It appeared with its customary conductor, Eugene Ormandy, last night in Carnegie Hall, to give the first New York concert of its thirtyfifth New York series.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Eight men were reported missing tonight after the 69-foot tugboat Arundel capsized and sank during a severe storm in the Chesapeake Bay. Five others were rescued.

Two new pictures will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount, the attraction is "Isn't It Romantic?" a Paramount romantic comedy with music featuring Veronica Lake, Billy De Wolfe, Mona Freeman and Mary Hatcher.
Royal Blood of the Maine Chance Farm had the best of it in the White Plains Handicap, the Class C race that held the top spot on the racing program at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Bobanet Stable of Baltimore's Bruce Livie stole the show at Laurel Park today, winning with all three of its representatives, including the feature, which was captured by King Midas. The other winners were Tiger Fore in the first race and Wee Hal in the fourth.
Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister for Economic Affairs, predicted yesterday that Britain would be back on her feet economically by 1952.

A selling drive to obtain more work for New York machine and metalworking shops has been launched by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 5 -One of the low rounds of the season brought the Westchester County Golf Association's season to an end at the Siwanoy Country Club today as the pro-amateur event went to the Round Hill team of Frank Strazza and Jim Linen with a best ball score of 63.

Samuel Wolchok placed before members of the House Committee on Education and Labor yesterday his charge that left-wing leaders were trying to take eight seceding locals of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, into the Building Service International Union, AFL.
The Museum of Modern Art is opening to the public today one of the strangest-exhibitions it has ever put on. It is a one-man show of selected sculpture by Elie Nadelman.

NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE has always been more admired by his countrymen than loved. School children exposed at too early an age to the grimly austere beauties of "The Scarlet Letter" are all too often prone thereafter to shun the writings of one of the most finished artists and one of the most astute observers of life among all American men of letters.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 (AP) -The Washington Redskins apparently are determined to retain their reputation as the "air arm" of the National Football League.
Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal to establish a Traffic Commission was endorsed yesterday by the Traffic Action Committee.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 (AP) -Tomoya Kawakita, 28-year-old American-born interpreter, in a wartime Japanese prison camp, was sentenced to death today for treason.

EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Oct. 5 -- The "outline" phase of the mock war between the mythical countries of Namora and Deluvia, as dramatized by skits, was brought to a close today in the armed forces' demonstration of unified operations here.

MANILA, Oct. 5 -- The Philippine Government permitted itself more optimism today concerning the outcome of the Hukbalahap campaign in Central Luzon than it has shown at any time since the amnesty was rejected six weeks ago.
Despite inroads of other fuels, leaders of the coal industry envisage development of better and bigger uses for that product, spokesmen, revealed here yesterday.

Whether a homemaker wants to add color to her table settings, kitchen or furniture, new displays and demonstrations at Abraham Straus this week during Home Fashion Time offer a variety of suggestions. All of the settings are keyed to the thousand color choices in the Nu-Hue paint system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Union Electric Company of (St. Louis) Missouri asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to split each of its 3,300,000 shares of authorized no par value common stock into 3 1/2 shares of no par value common, or 11,550,000 shares.

It is excellent news that the city administration is now moving in the direction of a real program to cope with traffic congestion. Mayor O'Dwyer's conferences at City Hall and his expressed determination to get action soon are most encouraging. The mere fact that Mr. O'Dwyer in August asked the Citizens Budget Commission to study the feasibility of new municipal machinery to break the jam was significant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, hitting the campaign trail for the Dewey-Warren ticket, declared here tonight that the issue in the coming election was whether the nation should proceed "on American principles of freedom and justice or adopt the road to totalitarian government."

The Buffalo Forge Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock payable on Oct. 28. The company paid 45 cents each in February, May and August and a dividend of 60 cents was declared on Sept. 30. In addition, the company, whose fiscal year ends on Nov. 30, paid an extra of 25 cents last December.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- It'll be Johnny Sain against Rapid Robert Feller, with a possible dash of rain or snow on the side, when the curtain lifts on the 1948 world series at Braves Field tomorrow afternoon at 1 o'clock.
Twenty-five detectives are searching the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn for the murderers of Peter (Baltimore Joe) Del Pozzo.

If some Americans at the United Nations meeting in Paris are noticed walking around today as though their minds were elsewhere, Mr. Vishinsky should not immediately jump to the conclusion that they are pondering some new move in United States-Soviet relations.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 5 -- Excerpts from the remarks made by John L. Lewis on the current political situation at the United Mine Workers' convention today follow:
SAVANNAH Ga., Oct. 5 (AP) -Eight men who were shipwrecked on isolated Ossabaw Island after battling rough seas were brought to this city late last night.

Unfortunately, at the moment of writing, the official text and pertinent facts relating to the order banning the film "Gentleman's Agreement" by the Board of Film Censors in Madrid are lacking. One thing, nevertheless, appears patent: the ruling allegedly voiced by the ecclesiastical representative on the Board is no more than the expression of an opinion by an individual in the exercise of an administrative function, and is not even final.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- In a few weeks the Palladium will be central London's only vaudeville home. Bernard Delfont has decided to give up the struggle at the London Casino. He believed there was a large enough public to support two West End music halls simultaneously but even with a series by international stars, the economics of the game defeated him.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 -Pleased with their successful flotation of nearly $800,000,000 of new and refunding issues in two-and-ahalf years, executives of the natural gas industry were disturbed today by the warning of Edmond M. Hanrahan, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that the federal agency was concerned at their heavy reliance on financing of debt.
Congress is asked to establish a special procedure to review administration of international trade controls in a report made public yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

GENEVA, Oct. 5 -- The United States will support fully the efforts to improve East-West trade through the medium of the new committee to be established in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, an American source said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Truman requested Secretary of State Marshall today to return from the United Nations General Assembly meeting in Paris for a conference on the international situation here on Saturday.

Parents, teachers and the general public will applaud the campaign launched by Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, to reduce New York's child-accident toll. Accidents are the leading cause of death among children more than one year old. The 1946 accident death-rate among those 1 to 4 years old was 48.1 for each 100,000.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP) -- President Truman was urged today as a last resort to take over the West Coast's strike-bound ports for the Government.

While Times Square sidewalks were crowded at the evening rush hour yesterday, an automobile driven by a partly paralyzed war veteran mounted the curb of West Forty-second Street at Seventh Avenue and knocked down two men before it was halted twentyfive feet away.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Secretary of State Marshall reacted sharply today to reports published here that he had intervened in French internal politics.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey indicated yesterday that he might subpoena Representative John McDowell if the Pennsylvania Republican failed to appear voluntarily before a Federal grand jury tomorrow to offer evidence in support of his attack on the indictments obtained by Mr. McGohey against twelve Communist leaders.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Thirty out of forty-four baseball writers at Braves Field today picked the Indians to beat the Braves in the world series which gets under way tomorrow. The writers were polled by The Associated Press.

A memorandum asserting that public school teachers are not subject to City Charter penalties for refusal to testify in public inquiries has been presented to the Board of Education by the Teachers Union, CIO, the union's legislative representative, Mrs. Rose Russell announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Truman reported to Congress today that the effort to contain communism in the Middle East through the Greek-Turkish aid program had been a "conspicuous success." He offered the estimate in a letter transmitting the State Department's quarterly report on the program.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The longterm effect of life insurance companies' purchases of securities directly from big corporate borrowers, either individually or in groups, was analyzed today at the American Life Convention here by Thomas W. Phelps, a partner in Francis I. du Pont Co., New York.

MADRID, Oct. 5 -- Foreign Minister Alberto Martin Artajo denied flatly today that Senator Gurney had entered into negotiations with the Spanish Government, by which the United States would provide armaments to Spain or acquire naval or air bases here.
ON TOUR WITH THURMOND, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, States' Rights Presidential nominee, today challenged President Truman to debate the civil rights issue.
ALBANY, Oct. 5 -- United States relations with Soviet Russia are now worse than at any time since the war, John Foster Dulles reported today to Governor Dewey.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- Two things were at premium here tonight on the eve of the first world series for a Boston National League club in thirty-four years. It was impossible to get hotel accommodations and it was impossible to purchase a ticket for the first game of the series, which will see Billy Southworth's Braves and Lou Boudreau's Cleveland Indians locked in battle at Braves Field tomorrow afternoon.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Moshe Shertok, Israeli Foreign Minister, conferred for half an hour this morning with United States Secretary of State Marshall as both sides in the Palestine dispute continued organizing their forces for the impending debate in the United Nations General Assembly.

Bills strongly curtailing liquor advertising and directed toward national prohibition will be reintroduced at the next session of Congress and will be supported by at least 30 per cent of the population, John E. O'Neill, general counsel of the Small Brewers Association, declared yesterday.
The Public Service Commission was advised yesterday by the Triboro Coach Corporation that it was not negotiating with the city for the sale of its bus line.

PRAGUE, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Czechoslovakia's Communist - dominated Parliament will take up tomorrow a sweeping "law for the defense of the people's democratic republic," making almost any form of political opposition a criminal offense.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Heavy advance bookings for the new type "All-American" motion-picture bills were reported here today by Hollywood London offices. Bookings now being made are for exhibition late in December and through the early part of next year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -"Battleground," a photoplay about the Battle of the Bulge which was projected at RKO during Dore Schary's tenure as production chief there, has been purchased from RKO by Metro-GoldwynMayer, where Schary is now in charge of production, Schary and Louis B. Mayer announced jointly today.
Dr. Arthur S. Abramson, assistant chief of rehabilitation at Veterans Hospital in the Bronx, was honored yesterday as "New York's Disabled Man of the Year."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Twentysix leaders of Labor's Committee for Truman and Barkley called at the White House today.

Three votes for Governor Dewey for President in the family of the late Alfred E. Smith were disclosed yesterday. They will be cast by Lieut. Col. John A. Warner, the "Happy Warrior's" son-in-law; Emily Smith Warner, daughter and favorite of the late Governor and also his eldest grandchild, Mary Adams Warner, casting her first vote this year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The Chicago Tribune, an independent Republican newspaper of which Col. Robert R. McCormick is editor and publisher, which opposed Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's nomination for the Presidency, will say editorially tomorrow that it is supporting him because "we consider him the least worse of the candidates."
PARIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The United Nations text of the statement by Soviet Delegate Andrei Y. Vishinsky to the Security Council announcing Russia's Boycott of the Berlin question follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, of Rhode Island, Democratic National Chairman, asserted tonight that a large part of the New York State Administration, constituting "the highest paid army of bureaucrats in history," are receiving their regular salaries from the state to further the Presidential campaign of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -President Truman leaves at 8:45 o'clock tomorrow morning on another campaign swing which will take him into Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

PRAGUE, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Cabinet approved today two draft bills for forced labor "education" camps and for sweeping wage controls. Both are intended to strengthen the Government drive for production under its-projected five-year plan.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 5. (AP) -Air-tight fielding and the five-hit pitching of Ezra (Pat) McGlothin gave St. Paul a 4-0 triumph over the Montreal Royals of the International League tonight in the first game of the little world series. The Saints, American Association play-off champions, scored all their runs in the seventh off Don Newcombe.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 5 -- Outlines of a United States plan to make the West German Military Government tripartite from top to bottom while drastically reducing its size and scope were disclosed by American sources here today.

The hunting ban has been lifted from all of Maine with the exception of York County as a result of the heavy rain on Saturday, and those who have been delaying their departure may be reasonably certain of decent conditions. Another two weeks of dry weather might result in the closing of a few areas during the early deer season, but the critical period is now over.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The word is beginning to percolate through Tompkins County that one of the best football scraps of the year will be on view at Schoellkopf Crescent Saturday in the meeting between Cornell and Harvard.

The National Federation of Music Clubs will hold its Twentyfifth Biennial Convention in Dallas, Tex., from March 27 to April 3, 1949, it was announced yesterday. The convention's slogan will be "Music, the Handmaiden of Religion; Religion, the Handmaiden of Peace."
New designs in needletuft bedspreads and fifteen suggestions for color coordination in planning interiors are on display in Macy's Plan-a-Home row.
Repeated applause greeted the close-fitting youthful bonnets and small side-tipped cloches that made up an important part of the Peg Fischer showing yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Beryl Lund, pretty amateur musical comedy star who has been poking fun on the stage at the British Government's Communist purge, found out today that the purge is no joke. She has been purged herself.

In my statement carried in THE TIMES for Oct. 1, concerning the banning of "Gentleman's Agreement" by the Spanish Film Censorship Board, I said the Holy See had ordered "expunged" from the Good Friday liturgy the expression "perfidious Jews" (pro perfidis Judaeis).
CINCINNATI, Oct. 5 -- John L. Lewis excoriated President Truman today as a man of "malignant personal hatreds," whose continuance in office was dangerous to the country.

Congratulations to Senator McMahon for so well showing us the obvious in his article of Sept. 26 in THE TIMES, favoring quick establishment of atomic energy control, and a United Nations program of information to penetrate the Iron Curtain. He goes so far in pointing the answer to our life-or-death problem that I wish he might reach a bit farther.

The French miners are not present at the debate in the United Nations Security Council. The grim-faced and grimy men from the pits around Lille, France's "black district," would be out of place among the delegates in the great-windowed, modern galleries of the Palais de Chaillot.

Every citizen should help to solve social problems, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower asserted yesterday. The general, president of Columbia University, spoke at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel opening the annual fund drive of the New York Y.W.C.A.
BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- Berlin was quiet today and the aerial lifeline of the Western sectors was maintained despite Soviet parachute practice in the Berlin-Bueckeburg air corridor just west of the city.

With the posting of new borrowings by the Illinois Central Railroad, the Great Northern Railway and the United New Jersey Railroad and Canal Company, a Pennsylvania-system leased line, the backlog of railroad financing right ahead of the market now approximates $50,000,000.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky served notice on the United Nations Security Council today that the Soviet delegation "will not participate in consideration of the Berlin question." Mr. Vishinsky's statement, which came immediately after the Council had voted to put on the agenda the complaint by the Western Powers that the Soviet blockade constituted a threat to peace, was echoed by Dmitri Z. Manuilsky, Ukraine representative.

A series of programs on the control and prevention of venereal disease, prepared under the auspices of Columbia University, will be heard on many stations throughout the country, starting in November, it was announced yesterday.

Political candidates representing every major political party faced each other last night in a speechfest at the annual Grand Street Boys Association "candidates night" in the association clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

The Pacific Gas Electric Company borrowed $75,000,000 on thirty-five-year first mortgage bonds yesterday at an interest cost of about 3.12 per cent. The bond issue was sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate of 111 bond houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.0399 for 3 1/8S.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Disorders flared again in two widely separated sections of Peru today, but loyal. Government forces quickly restored order.
The two-day celebration of Roshha-Shana, the Jewish New Year, ended yesterday as sermons in many synagogues here hailed the advent of the 5,709th year of the Jewish calendar.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 5 -- Arab refugees from Palestine are threatened with epidemics of "several diseases," Sir Raphael Cilento, United Nations Director of Disease Relief, asserted at a press conference here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 (AP) -The national champion, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, opened his bid for a grand slam of United States outdoor tennis honors with two victories in the national hard court tournament at the California Club today.

Two coastal storms -- one a hurricane that had already caused eleven deaths and $10,000,000 damage in Cuba, the other a fifty-mile-an-hour northeaster -- assailed the Atlantic Seaboard yesterday. The hurricane, then apparently diminishing in violence, raked southeastern Florida from Miami thirty miles northward, before passing out to sea.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Dr. Jan Papanek, Czechoslovak representative at the United Nations until the Communists took over control in Prague seven months ago, told the delegates at the General Assembly's Administrative Committee session today that his Communistappointed successor, Dr. Vladimir Houdek, was representing Czechoslovakia on the strength of forged credentials.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Winston Churchill, addressing a recruiting campaign for Britain's auxiliary armed forces, said today that at present "the frontier of Asia was upon the Elbe" and warned against its being extended westward.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Fans of the Indians ignored rain and cold weather today as they went through a series of lines in their quest for world series tickets.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 5 (AP) -A 50 per cent cutback in natural gas deliveries to industries in five more downstate Illinois cities was ordered today by the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.

ABOARD U.S.S. NEREUS, off California, Oct. 5 -- The radioactive submarine Skate, which fought spectacularly against the Japanese and survived a Bikini atomic bomb test with only "her hat knocked off and her hair mussed," was sunk by naval bombardment today 100 miles off San Diego.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The White House announced tonight the resignation of Dr. Vannevar Bush, chairman of the Research and Development Board of the National Military Establishment, and the appointment to succeed him of Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Disease is the basic problem at every non-profit, voluntary hospital. Diagnosis exposes many ailments such as diabetes, diphtheria and dyspepsia. Dental clinics are a well-known function of the eighty-six non-profit voluntary hospitals that are members of the United Hospital Fund of New York.

In a recent editorial commenting on the report of the City Rent Commission THE TIMES praised the Commission for its "efforts" and stated that it weighed "equitably" all aspects of cases brought before it.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5 (AP) -Martha Doyle, short-priced roan filly from the stable of A. L. Derby, Wichita, Kan., took both heats of the featured Hanover Shoe Stake for 2-year-old trotting fillies at the Lexington trots today. The event was worth a gross of $11,826.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Soviet Union is basing its policy in the Berlin dispute at Paris on two interesting principles. The first is that Russia's interpretation of the United Nations Charter must be accepted or the Russians will not participate in the debate.
Two rooms planned to show how furniture may be arranged around home television sets are included in a series of settings newly decorated by Ludwig Baumann.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe granted yesterday a temporary injunction barring Seatrain Lines, Inc., from putting a 50 per cent reduction in its rates into effect until the United States Maritime Commission had ruled its legality.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 5 -- Miss Peggie Mackie of the Inwood Country Club scored 39, one over par, on the back nine, to finish with 44, 39 -- 83 and take low gross honors in the final Women's Metropolitan Golf Association oneday tournament at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 5 -- A new long-range assistance program for Arab and Jewish refugees is being contemplated here by twenty leading American organizations interested in providing Palestine relief, it became known today.

During the present threat of war the United Nations offers everybody an opportunity for world citizenship through support of the United Nations Appeal for Children, Dr. Aake Ording, Norwegian founder of the appeal, will tell the General Assembly in Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 -- Dropping its long legal battle, the United States Steel Corporation consented today to the entry by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals of a decree enforcing an order issue by the Federal Trade Commission a quarter of a century ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Bing Crosby today asked authority to build three new commercial television stations on the Pacific Coast at a total cost of about $592,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6 -Rear Admiral James Fife Jr., commander of the submarine force of the Atlantic Fleet, presented to each of eight Connecticut scientists and engineers today the President's Certificate of Merit, the second highest award given to civilians by the nation's Chief Executive.

Despite increased costs of raw materials, there will be firm prices quoted for the present season on its new "P-T" permanent type anti-freeze which the Texas Company is now starting to sell through its 37,000 dealers, Walter Hochuli, general sales manager, revealed during a press preview at the company's offices in the Chrysler Building yesterday.

The question: when is a picket not a picket? was raised yesterday when the police arrested nine persons for disorderly conduct on the grounds that they were picketing inside Pennsylvania Station when they should not have been.

The contribution was 1,729 pennies. The donors -- twenty-nine Westchester County children 4 to 6 years old -- had accumulated this sum at Sunday school during a period of several months after being told about the orphaned youngsters of Israel.

There are a number of attractive theories about how best to start the day right. One holds to a suddenly announced holiday from school, the building having burned to the ground during the night. Another, although somewhat more prosaic, yearns for a registered letter containing a check for a million dollars, made out to Cash.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Argentina today accused the great powers of having excluded nineteen small nations from participating in the work of the United Nations Economic and Social Council and in a resolution submitted jointly with Cuba and Colombia asked for representation of all United Nations members in the Council's committees and subcommittees.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 5 -- The Brotherhood of the United Lutheran Church in America elected Ralph Wohlsen of Bridgeport, Conn., as its president today.

Surviving crewmen of the tugboat Ann Marie Tracy, sunk last Saturday in a collision with the tanker Eliza Jane Nicholson off Pier 64 North River with the loss of nine lives, testified yesterday that the tanker "must have been going at a terrific rate of speed" at the time of impact.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The French Government awarded decorations to high officers of the United States Army today for "exceptional services" to France in World War II.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Mrs. Truman's secretariat resumed meetings with the press today, without, however, announcing the official White House social program usually forthcoming the first week in October.

Dollar and unit volume of the veneer industry is running behind last year, I. T. Williams, president of the Veneer Association, disclosed yesterday. He was unable to supply an estimate of the decline and said that the industry is convinced that recovery is imminent.

By acceding to demands that nineteen students who walked out of Prof. William E. Knickerbocker's class on Sept. 20 should not be disciplined but be permitted to transfer to other classes, Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, hopes to avert a threatened "sit-down" strike scheduled for tomorrow.

When the curtain rises at 8 o'clock tonight on "Summer and Smoke" at the Music Box, it will mark Tennessee Williams' second play on the boards. The other one is that hefty success, "A Streetcar Named Desire," winner of last season's triple crown -- Pulitzer, Drama Critics and Donaldson awards.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The British and Americans have reached an agreement on the European payment accord that had been delaying final action here on the division of dollars under the Marshall Plan, it was learned tonight.

The Twentieth Century Sporting Club and the Tournament of Champions, Inc., warring organizations in the promotion of boxing, came to grips yesterday with almost simultaneous claims that each had secured agreements for Ray Robinson, the welterweight champion, to meet Steve Belloise of New York.
The India League of America gave a farewell luncheon yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel to Ambassadordesignate Loy W. Henderson, who leaves Oct. 15 for his new post in India.

The stock market lost its impetus yesterday and weakened by a paucity of interest, prices fell fractionally. Traders, most of whom were professionals, stepped aside to await more concrete developments in the "cold" war between the Western Allies and the Soviet Union.

As was to be expected from the nature of the case, the Security Council of the United Nations has overruled the Soviet challenge to its authority to consider the threat to peace raised by Russia in Berlin and has decided by the now familiar vote of nine to two to put that issue on its agenda.
Many parties were given at the dinner dance in aid of the United Hospital Fund held last night at the pre-opening of the St. Regis Maisonnette, which will be opened formally for this season tonight.

In its fiscal year ended with last July, the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., sold and delivered nearly 40 per cent more typewriters than during the previous fiscal year, according to the annual report to be issued to stockholders today by Maxwell V. Miller, president, and Allan A. Ryan, board chairman.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 5 (AP) -The Government announced several successes today in its fight against the Burmese rebels.

With statistics released yesterday showing that Columbia's football Lions had one of their greatest all-around offensive days in fifty-eight years of intercollegiate football last Saturday, Coach Lou Little continued to polish the Light Blue's attack during a soggy practice session at Baker Field.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled only 743 due to the religious holiday, against 1,884 last week and 1,687 in the similar week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 110 arrivals yesterday compared with 947 last Tuesday.

New York's subway system initiated yesterday the latest wrinkle in local advertising -- the installation of the first of 480 illuminated, three-dimensional signs at the city's principal express stations.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 -- The Government decreed today that the portion of La Prensa's newsprint that has been impounded in a warehouse should be expropriated immediately and turned over to the Subsecretariat of Information. The Subsecretariat will presumably distribute it among the afternoon newspapers, all of which are strongly pro-Peron.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Supreme Court refused today to set aside Justice Hugo L. Black's stay of a lower court injunction barring Lyndon B. Johnson's name from the Texas ballot as Democratic nominee for United States Senator.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 5 -- Dr. Henry Brown Turner, a New York heart specialist, shot and killed his wife and then shot himself fatally at noon today as they sat in their car behind the Yankee Coachman Inn in the center of town here.

When the Lawyers Title Corporation is integrated into the title division of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, Artemus L. Gates will become chairman of the titleinsurance advisory committee of Title Guarantee and Trust, Bernard Townsend, president of the latter company announced yesterday.

Deposits of the Chase National Bank on Sept. 30 this year totaled $4,206,943,483, compared with $4,154,808,627 no June 30 and $4,541,740,606, a year ago, the bank reported in its quarterly statement of condition released for today. Total resources on the respective dates were listed at $4,602,996,417, $4,551,331,951, and $4,917,682,584.

Total exchanges through the New York Clearing House Association during the year ended on Sept. 30, reached $373,761,203,392, the largest volume since 1930, the association announced yesterday following its ninety-fifth annual meeting.

GREELEY, Col., Oct. 5 (AP) -Alben W. Barkley, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, declared here tonight that a Republican victory in November might return the West to "the status of an economic colony of Eastern finance."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 5 -Henry A. Wallace tonight accused Gov. Earl Warren, the Republican nominee for Vice President, of giving aid to a bipartisan "octopus" that had a "stranglehold" on California.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 5 -Comdr. W. T. Greenhalgh of the Industrial College of the Armed Forces at Washington warned today that the position of the United States in the Far East was in a "critical" condition.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company has decided to reduce in size its pending offering of Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company common stock from 400,000 shares to 250,000 shares, and to execute the transaction by competitive, bidding, Edward O. Boshell, president of Standard, announced yesterday, following a meeting of the company's board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association today protested a new wave-length plan which, the ANPA said, would bar newspapers from the use of radio mobilphones for sending news and pictures.

John Gammie, vice president of the States Marine Corporation, will leave here aboard the United States liner America for a four-week tour of the concern's business connections in England, France, Belgium and Germany, as well as to consult with officials of Irish Shipping, Ltd., on final arrangements for two new vessels that will enter service in December.

The wool fabric industry must make prompt and vigorous use of paid-space advertising if it is to survive in the battle with synthetic fibers for the summer clothing market, members of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers' collateral group were told yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel.

The New York Shipping Association has decided to join the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, in an appeal to President Truman for Government action in its overtime on overtime dispute, it was made known last night by J. V. Lyon, chairman of the former's negotiating committee.

Thirty-two foreign and nearly 300 American universities and colleges will be represented at the installation ceremonies of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, which will be held Tuesday at 2 P.M. in the university's South Court.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 (AP) -Federal Judge Oscar Palma Beltran today ordered the arrest of John F. Griffith, former United States cultural attache here, on a charge of having participated in a plot to assassinate President Juan Peron.
TOKYO, Oct. 5 -- Emperor Hirohito today held his first "press conference." It was the first mass interview ever given by a ruler of Japan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, today ordered the headquarters of the three armed forces in nine Western states to consolidate several administrative operations as the beginning of a "far reaching program" for economy and efficiency.

A sharp decline in the price of actual hides in the nation's spot markets yesterday manifested itself in the hide futures market on the Commodity Exchange. Prices declined 20 to 70 points in active trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco demanded today that the Federal Reserve Board clarify its anti-trust complaint against the company and hold its public hearings on the matter in California.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Imminent collapse of wage mediation proceedings involving 1,000,000 "non-operating" railroad workers was predicted here today in Government circles. The chiefs of sixteen unions will refuse to accept a wage increase of ten cents an hour similar to that agreed upon by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and the Order of Railway Conductors yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Herald-American said today that the White Sox will announce tomorrow the removal of Leslie O'Connor as the club's general manager and his replacement by Frank Lane, president of the American Association.

Widespread gains in many parts of the country toward "making planned parenthood a reality for the American family" were reported yesterday as the twentyeighth annual meeting of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc., got under way at the Roosevelt Hotel.

While drugs that relieve distress without curing an underlying cause are important in medical practice, their most significant application is in discovering the fundamental physiology of baffling disease conditions, speakers at the New York Academy of Medicine declared yesterday.

Reopening this week of a Congressional inquiry into the activities of New York's left-wing department store unions calls attention again to a tangled and confusing labor situation, with implications that extend far outside the city.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Secretary of State Marshall has proposed to Foreign Secretary Bevin and Foreign Minister Schuman that the United Nations General Assembly be asked to rescind the resolution it adopted Dec. 12, 1946, recommending the withdrawal of the chiefs of diplomatic missions of the United Nations from Spain.

Erik Boheman, the new Swedish Ambassador to the United States, arrived at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, on a Scandinavian airlines plane at 9:30 A.M. yesterday. He departed immediately for Washington.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Unions representing engineers, firemen and switchmen, apparently confused and surprised by the wage offer accepted by the conductors and trainmen yesterday, abruptly recessed negotiations with the railroads today and turned the whole matter back to their general chairmen for further study.

ROME, Oct. 5 -- Plans for intense labor agitation in the near future were announced in Florence today by Guiseppe di Vittorio, a Communist, who is secretary general of the Italian Labor Confederation. He did not say what form the agitation would take, but made it clear that the Communists were preparing to deliver another attack on Italy's already shaky economic structure.

Fritz Reiner, until recently the Pittsburgh Symphony's permanent conductor, has been engaged by the Metropolitan Opera Company as a conductor for its forthcoming season, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, the company's general manager.

The stock market made another about-face yesterday and recovered most of Tuesday's setbacks. Emphasis was on the steels, where major gains were made in the heaviest group trading of the session. Industrial stocks showed the best gains, while the rise in the composite rate held at 0.37 point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Veterans Administration faced a possible court fight today over interpretations of veterans' benefits as AMVETS (American Veterans of World War II) threatened legal action contesting the VA's regulations limiting aviation training for veterans.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- At dusk yesterday two automobiles raced side by side along Yonkers Avenue. Near Trenchard Street one car passed the other and struck John Sherwood, 65 years old, of Winifred Avenue, here, and hurled him to one side.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The United States export surplus -- the amount by which exports exceed imports -- dropped in August to the lowest point in nearly two years.

There is universal agreement that righteousness should be the basis for a solution to the Palestine problem. Dr. Khalil Totah's letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 1 would have us believe that the Arabs desire such a solution and implies that if the Lord builds the house in Palestine it will be an Arab house.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- December corn was the leader in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, advancing 1 3/8 cents a bushel early to $1.41 3/8, a new high since Sept. 23.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup told the United Nations Security Council today that "the moment" the blockade of Berlin was lifted the United States would be ready to have an immediate meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers "to discuss with the U.S.S.R. any question relating to Germany."
EARLE, N.J., Oct. 6 -- How manufacturers in large and small industries can benefit by employing disabled workers was graphically demonstrated here today at the Navy Ammunition Depot.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Neither Spanish nor British diplomats in London could foresee today any prospect of the early inclusion of Spain in the European Recovery Program or the Western European defense plans. So far as the British Government is concerned, there is no disposition whatever to resume full diplomatic relations with Madrid.

Attorneys for the twelve Communist leaders indicted on conspiracy charges by a special grand jury last July asked Federal Judge Murray Hulbert yesterday to dismiss the indictments on the ground that no legal evidence had been presented to the panel.

LEXINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Miss Morris Chief, bay daughter of Chief Abbedale, finished gamely in the second heat today to win first money in the Hanover Shoe Stakes for 2-year-old fillies, feature of the Lexington Grand Circuit card.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Negotiations now going on to end the shooting war between Government forces and the rebel People's Volunteer Organization were reflected in a quiet Burma front today.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- Governor Dewey, Republican Presidential nominee, will visit nine states in a Midwestern tour starting next Monday and lasting a week, Herbert Brownell, campaign manager, announced today.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The Union of South Africa opened a direct attack today on the United Nations draft convention on human rights with a demand in the General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee that a reference to man's "dignity and rights" be omitted from the very first article.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 6 -- A Postoffice official posted a set of rules today directing mailmen nor to pick fights with dogs.

ROME, Italy, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Pope Pius urged Catholic teachers tonight to oppose "pernicious attempts to separate religion and education" and to combat "the exaggerated importance given to technical and material education."

Part of the 500,000 tons of German scrap metal recently allocated to the United States under an agreement with Great Britain may arrive on these shores within a month, a prominent figure in the domestic scrap trade said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Navy disclosed today figures which described its forthcoming 65,000-ton aircraft carrier, which will be the largest naval vessel ever built.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6. -- In a reversal of Soviet policy, the Russian military command in Germany has called upon the United Nations for assistance for the 6,000,000 German youngsters in the Soviet sector of Berlin and in the Soviet occupation zone.

What the Eightieth Congress has done to the Roosevelt program is nothing to what the Republicans will do if the Dewey ticket is elected, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday in an address at a Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee meeting at Manhattan Center.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Gladys Lanphere Benjamin, aged 55, divorced wife of a Wall Street banker and a relative of Enrico Caruso, the opera star, has died in obscurity here.

Another pianist with a dazzling technique came to brighten the early season at Town Hall last night. This time it was Sigi Weissenberg, Hungarian-born, Palestine-bred, winner of the 1948 Leventritt Award and only 19 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Robert E. Galloway, a businessman of Memphis, Tenn., was named today as chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration Mission to Trieste.

Vastly increased earnings through diversification of land uses were cited to more than 400 coal operators yesterday, during the report of the land use advisory committee at the 31st annual convention of the National Coal Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, has asked the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe to supply 80,000 CARE food parcels by Christmas for orphanages and hospitals in Germany, it was announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's address in Convention Hall tonight:

Tarts and small cakes from the Royal Pastry Shop appear on the pastry trays of many fine restaurants here. The same delicacies may be purchased for dessert at home in the store's retail department at 1056 Second Avenue.

Courtney H. regarded his personal safety and I-Iodges, Commanding General of repeatedly crossed mine fields" the First Army.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow, through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

Recent legal decisions against violators of anti-trust laws in various industries give "unmistakable warning" that large brewers using forceful methods in eliminating smaller competitors are headed for trouble with the Federal Government, Marshall A. Pipin, legal counsel for the National Beer Wholesalers Association told delegates yesterday at the annual convention of the association at the Commodore Hotel.

So quietly that guests near by in the lobby were unaware of the crime, a lone, neatly dressed gunman, who was believed to have staged another robbery earlier in the evening, held up the cashier of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, about 11 o'clock last night, escaping with $7,500.
BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- After thirty-four long years, the Braves, it appears, haven't run out of miracles.

In an effort to insure supplies of newsprint, the News Syndicate Company, Inc., Publisher of the New York Daily News, will purchase 2,500 shares of the common stock of the St. Croix Paper Company of Maine if stockholders of the latter company approve the transaction it was disclosed yesterday.

The late Fiorello H. La Guardia received posthumously last night the first annual Social Justice award of the National Religion and Labor Foundation at ceremonies in the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.
Affiliated Travel Service, to Deutsch Shea, Inc., for advertising of chartered cruises to the West Indies.

The reaction to the piano playing of Ella Goldstein, 21-year-old Palestinian in several previous appearances in the past two years was mixed. Some thought she was one of the great new talents to come along in recent seasons; others found that she lacked depth and maturity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Black Hills Power Light Company, Rapid City, S.D., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 33,730 shares of $1 par value common and 5,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.

How I wish you would throw your powerful influence into cleaning up that annual mess known as Registration Week. I write this apropos of your editorial "Act of Abdication," in which you take eligible voters to task for failing to register. Of course you're right in your strictures, but as an annual victim of that agony known as registration I must say it takes willpower and stamina to register.

As every hunter knows, or should know, Federal law requires that all repeating or auto-loading shotguns be plugged to limit the capacity of the gun to three shells, two in the magazine and one in the chamber. This year, however, a new wrinkle has been added.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 29:
I read with interest your editorial of Oct. 4 entitled "Act of Abdication," in which you "view with alarm" the decrease in local registration.

DALLAS, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A new method of treating wells that may result in substantially increasing the amount of oil that can be recovered from underground formations was announced here today at a convention of petroleum engineers.

ROME, Oct. 6 -- A general stoppage of the whole state machinery, including essential services such as railroads, posts and telegraphs, was threatened in the Chamber of Deputies today by Giuseppe di Vittorio, Communist Secretary General of the Italian Labor Confederation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers voiced support today for the present draft "as an emergency measure," but opposed a long-range universal military training program.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- The United Nations' global drive to collect funds for 230,000,000 needy youngsters throughout the world has reached and passed the $20,000,000 mark, officials of the United Nations Appeal for Children reported here tonight.
Customs agents here and abroad are attempting to run down leads connected with the seizure here on Tuesday of $135,150 in Mexican gold pesos, Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, said yesterday.

New fashions in luxurious furs were presented by Gunther's during luncheon yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. In a handsome collection were capes of white ermine and white mink, coats of matara seal, nutria and black Persian lamb.

Psychoanalytic therapy is a costly and time-consuming procedure that cannot be available to all mental patients and would not be effective in all cases if it were, Dr. Lauren H. Smith told doctors last night at the graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- European recovery loans totaling $815,000,000 to eleven Marshall Plan countries have been approved by the Economic Cooperation Administration and will be closed through the Export-Import Bank as soon as formal letters of notification can be drafted, the ECA announced today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Parliament passed a new bill tonight "for the defense of the People's Democratic Republic." The vote was unanimous.

The United States and the countries of Western Europe must trade with Eastern Europe if this area is not to fall completely into the hands of Russia, I. F. Baker, vice president and treasurer of the Westinghouse Electric International Company, said yesterday.
The Cunard White Star liner Mauretania sailed at 11 o'clock last night from Pier 90, North River and Fiftieth Street, with 915 passengers for Southampton and Cherbourg.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- The Braves had assistance from an unexpected source in beating the Indians at the tepee here today, if the unanimous opinion of the beaten American League pennant winners goes for anything.

Paul Olefsky, 22-year-old American 'cellist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The gifted young artist was granted this appearance by the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation as a winner of its 1948 award.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 7 -- Premier Hitoshi Ashida and his Cabinet resigned on bloc this morning. The official announcement will not be made until this afternoon following its approval by Brig. Gen. Courtney Whitney, chief of the occupation's government section.

"Julia Misbehaves," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic comedy, starring Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon, will have its local premiere today at the Radio City Music Hall. The picturization of the Margery Sharp novel, "The Nutmeg Tree," was directed by Jack Conway and produced by Everett Riskin from a screen play by William Ludwig, Harry Ruskin and Arthur Wimperis and an adaptation by Gina Kaus and Moncton Hoffe.

The Franco Government in Spain has been in the news twice during the past few days for widely different reasons: first, in connection with allegedly anti-Semitic motives behind the barring of an American film, "Gentleman's Agreement"; second, in reports that this country had reconsidered its foreign policy toward Spain, and that Secretary Marshall would recommend that the U.N. Assembly rescind its 1946 resolution calling for the withdrawal of heads of diplomatic missions from Madrid.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 -- Following are excerpts from Henry A. Wallace's two prepared addresses in San Francisco today, one on labor, dealing with West Coast maritime and oil workers' strikes, the other discussing United States policy in the Far East:

Hold a stem of blossoming timothy in your hand and you see the mystery of creation. Humble, unpretentious and taken for granted, grass is Nature's protection for the humus layer which gives man his food. In the temperate zone of Earth wherever the forest does not blanket the soil the grasses weave a coverlet of roots and mulch.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 6 -- Starting of a plan intended to guarantee to 400,000 soft-coal miners and their families full medical and hospital service without cost to themselves was announced here today by the United Mine Workers of America.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Dr. Vladimir Houdek, Communist-appointed Czechoslovak delegate to the United Nations, categorically denied today charges made here yesterday that his credentials bore the forged signature of the late President Eduard Benes.
WAYCROSS, Ga., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A B-29 Superfortress exploded high over Waycross today, killing nine persons and spreading fragments over twenty acres.

William W. Remington, suspended official of the Department of Commerce who was accused by Elizabeth T. Bentley of being a Communist, filed a libel suit in Federal Court yesterday asking $100,000 in damages from the self-confessed former Communist spy, the National Broadcasting Company and General Foods Corporation.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Burnham Finney, editor of The American Machinist, said today that the American machine tool industry was m better shape now to meet a war emergency than it was at the beginning of World War II.
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Great Britain told the Soviet Union directly today that it was fear of aggression by Moscow that made the Western powers cling to the secrets of the atomic bomb.

If the center of population could make a noise we would probably hear it lumbering westward across Indiana with the estimates just made public by the Census Bureau. Between 1940 and July 1, 1948, the largest percentage increases were on the Pacific Coast -- 49.2 per cent for Oregon; 45.2 per cent for California; 43.3 per cent for the State of Washington.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed irregular, 6 points higher to 8 points lower than Tuesday's final prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, disclosed today the rejection of a request for changes in procedure set up for hearing charges made against the Greater New York CIO Council by a group of New York CIO leaders.
The arts and crafts building of Greenwich House at 16 Jones Street reopens formally today after having been discontinued as the community house training center for twelve years.
BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- It was a happy bunch of Braves that trooped into the clubhouse shortly before 3 o'clock this afternoon.

The first contemporary scientific expedition into the independent kingdom of Nepal sailed yesterday on the United States liner America. It is headed by Dr. Dillon Ripley, associate curator and lecturer in zoology at Yale University.

The names of three scientists and four public health administrators to be honored with 1948 Lasker Awards for outstanding contributions to medicine were announced at the New York Academy of Medicine yesterday afternoon by Dr. George Baehr.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Syracuse University is undergoing the greatest period of growth in its history. From a pre-war enrollment of 6,000 the figure has jumped to 17,000 until there is hardly a campus in the country that is so overcrowded and overrun.

Adoption of a program calling for the use of different colored sales tags to distinguish specially priced merchandise from regular priced stock is being considered by a local department store, it was learned here yesterday. One large Southern department store that recently adopted this system has been mentioning it in newspaper advertisements and reports that it has drawn favorable comment from consumers and has aided salespeople.

Jurisdictional warfare between two of the largest unions in the Congress of Industrial Organizations has flared anew in recent weeks, it was learned yesterday, with the United Automobile Workers making substantial inroads on the membership of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 7 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov has made a new demand that the Italian Government turn over Italian naval units to Russia immediately, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The Nuffield organization and the Austin Motor Company, Britain's two largest automobile manufacturers, announced tonight plans for a technical merger to cut production costs. The move made, it is believed, is to cope with keener foreign competition in the export field expected in the future.

A nation-wide program for combating fake use of the market survey approach as a "door-opener" in direct selling was announced yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc. A portion of the program is aimed also at curbing false and misleading use of research data in advertising.

SUNNINGDALE, England, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Flory Van Donck of Belgium held a five-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the 72-hole Dunlop- Masters professional golf tournament today after touring the 6,477-yard Sunningdale course with a record 64 on the first round.
Robert Gordon Menzies, former Prime Minister of Australia and head of that country's Liberal party, added his opinion yesterday to those scouting the possibility of war in Europe.
PARIS, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speech of Dr. Philip C. Jessup of the United States to the United Nations Security Council meeting on Berlin:

BERLIN, Oct. 6 -- The Soviet Military Administration and the German Communists are organizing a police force of approximately 400,000 men in the Soviet zone, according to reliable Western intelligence sources. The ultimate objective of this force is to combat non-Communist Germans in a "civil war," according to Dr. Kurt Fischer, head of the Department of the Interior of the central administrative agency of the Soviet zone.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Harry Strauss saw his colors carried to victory in the eighteenth running of the Maryland Futurity, headline attraction at Laurel Park today, by Nokomis, homebred daughter of Swing and Sway and Ladyinthemoon.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 6 -- The building of a peace based on religious principles is the "supremely important task of our time," President Truman said today in a message read before 3,500 Protestant church officials attending the opening session here of the World Mission Assembly.

Jo Stafford, singer., has been signed t headline' a new musical half-hour at 8:30 P.M. Thursdays over the ABC network and WJZ, starting on Nov. 11. Also appearing will be Clark Denis as her singing vis-a-vis and the Starlighters, a vocal group.

Although Tennessee Williams writes a gentle style, he has a piercing eye. In "Summer and Smoke," which was put on at the Music Box last evening, he looks again into the dark corners of the human heart, and what he sees is terrifying.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The two-member Simpson Commission of the Army has recommended that the death sentences be set aside for a "limited number" of the 139 Nazis sentenced to die for their war crimes, the Army announced today.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A Moscow radio commentator accused the Western powers early today of pursuing a "policy of deliberately ignoring the Foreign Ministers Council in solving various international problems."

NANKING, Oct. 6 -- Between 35,000 and 50,000 Government troops who have been defending isolated Changchun for more than a year were reported to be engaged tonight in evacuating the city that Japan made the capital of its Manchukuo.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Efforts of the National (Railway) Mediation Board to settle the wage and hours dispute between the country's railroads and sixteen unions representing non-operating workers ended in failure today.

The President was right in saying that his regret at the resignation of Dr. Vannevar Bush as chairman of the Research and Development Board of the National Military Establishment will be shared by scientists and higher military officers. Under Dr. Bush's able direction the wartime Office of Scientific Research and Development achieved a record in research never equaled.
Los Angeles County, Calif., announced yesterday that bids would be received on Oct. 26 on bond issues totaling $2,500,000 and maturing from 1950 to 1953 to finance construction of elementary schools.
BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The play-t by-play description of the first game of the world series at Braves at Field today follows:

A resolution to stage a "sit-down" strike today at City College in the controversy over Prof. William E. Knickerbocker was defeated yesterday by vote of 3,122 to 1,841 in a student referendum. The decision to abandon the demonstration followed an announcement on Tuesday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, that nineteen students who walked out of Dr. Knickerbocker's class would be permitted to transfer to other teachers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that the immediate outlook for ceiling or capacity production and employment in this country was "very strong," but that "something of a decline in optimism for a long-term future" had developed in the last two months.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- A new type of telescope for exploring the cosmos, known as a radio telescope, which will serve as a giant "ear" just as the optical telescope serves as a giant "eye," was demonstrated here today at Cornell University, which is celebrating its eightieth anniversary this week.

Capt. Jonathan M. Wainwright 5th, son of Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, accepted yesterday as master of the steamship African Patriot, a naval reserve pennant on behalf of the Farrell Lines, Inc., and the ship's personnel at Pier 33, Brooklyn.

ORADELL, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Steve Berrien, president of the New Jersey Golf Association, scored both as a golfer and a links official today. Berrien and his partner, E. C. F. Arnott of Upper Montclair, captured the special trophy by leading the field of thirty-eight teams in the best-ball tourney with a gross score of 69 over the Hackensack Club course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The International Typographical Union today denied that suggested clauses in its contracts compelled an employer "under any possible circumstances" to hire a union member in preference to an equally competent non-ITU printer.

In his only campaign speech in the North, Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, States Rights Democratic candidate for President, predicted again yesterday that his party would win 100 electoral votes in the Southern States.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 -- The "slavish adherence" by regulatory bodies to low fixed rates of return for the gas industry has forced natural gas companies to seek "cheap money" rather than risk venture capital through junior equity financing, H. Carl Wolf, managing director of the American Gas Association, declared today.
