Initial openings yesterday of resort and spring lines brought enthusiastic buyer response, according to New York manufacturers of dresses and sportswear. Showrooms of firms making official openings were crowded to capacity with out-of-town buyers and in most instances immediate booking of spring business was begun.

With flags on public buildings flying it half-staff at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer, ceremonies honoring the arrival of 7,047 war dead aboard the Army transport Carroll Victory were held at 11 A.M. yesterday at the Brooklyn Army base.

Premium and discount prices for large new bond issues reflected yesterday the shifting fortunes of underwriting syndicates in their game of hide-and-seek with the big insurance companies over the going prices of new high-quality bonds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had filed complaints against three of the largest soap manufacturing corporations in the country charging them with violation of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The French coal strike started by miners for higher wages was moving tonight toward the political objectives that inspired the general strike of last year.

An "alarming" rise in the loss of human life through "reproductive wastage" was reported yesterday by D. Kenneth Rose, national director of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc., at its twenty-eighth annual meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel. Three hundred delegates are at the convention, which will end today.
Operations of the Woodward Iron Company for the first nine months of this year left a net profit of $3,597,029 after taxes and all charges, according to the report issued yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- Thanks to a bumper crop, potatoes went off the ration list in the bizonal area of Germany today by recommendation of Food, Agriculture and Forestry Branch of the Bipartite Administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Displaced persons commissioner Ugo Carusi, in Frankfort on the Main, Germany, revealed in a transatlantic phone call to his fellow commissioners today that the United States Army transport Black, with the first 826 displaced persons bound for the United States under a law passed by the Eightieth Congress, could not leave Bremen-haven until Oct. 21 or perhaps Oct. 22.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Greece has made a request to the United States for more assistance to strengthen her forces to meet the situation created by continuing foreign aid from Russian satellite states to the Greek guerrilla movement.

The need for alerting the citizens to their responsibility in preserving the city's parks was emphasized here yesterday by Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt, chairman of the Park Association's Citizens Golden Anniversary Program Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 -- Henry A. Wallace threw his "100 per cent" support today to Harry R. Bridges and the West Coast maritime strikers, whose walkout of Sept. 2 has stopped the bulk of waterborne commerce out of the coastal ports for five weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- President Truman declared tonight that the unity about which Republicans are talking is actually "unity under the rule of big business" which would destroy American freedoms and ruin American leadership toward peace.

With reference to the current discussion and protest over the right to exclude members of the Communist party from public employment, may I suggest a comment of that Yankee from Olympus, Judge Oliver Wendell Holmes?

Four Russian passengers aboard an American Overseas Airlines plane who maintained a "verbal boycott" of the other passengers and the crew during a flight from Stockholm to New York received subtle rebuke in mid-air yesterday from the aircraft's pilot.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- Clarence L. Adcock, United States chairman of the Bipartite Board, declared this afternoon that he knew of no British or French opposition to the elimination of zonal boundaries in Western Germany.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Reports that France intended to capture the Atlantic "blue ribbon" and a large slice of the transatlantic luxury passenger traffic with the former German liner Europa circulated widely in British and United States shipping circles here today.

Modern design has now become acclimatied to the needs of ordinary living, Edgar Kaufmann Jr., director of the department of industrial design at the Museum of Modern Art, said yesterday. This is particularly evident, he added, in furniture made of metal, a material that used to smack a bit too much of the office and factory.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery told a serious and sympathetic crowd Outside Mansion House here today that the security of Great Britain rested on the creation of a strong Territorial Army.

Moore-McCormack Lines, operators in the New York-South American freight and passenger trade, announced yesterday that it had warned the Maritime Commission that its projected passenger ship construction program might be postponed or canceled.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- All the reports on the big Berlin debate at the Palais de Chaillot are not coming from Paris. Many others are coming from the other capitals of Europe, and what they have to say helps put the United Nations debate in a little better perspective.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Indiscriminate use of the veto might spell the end of the United Nations and lead the world to the brink of war, Premier Paul-Henri Spaak said this evening in a speech that strongly criticized Soviet tactics.

Directors of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., declared yesterday an extra of 10 cents a share in addition to the usual quarterly dividend of 20 cents payable to common stockholders on Oct. 30. This is the first extra since 70 cents was disbursed in December, 1946.

Futures prices of hides continued to decline yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, with closing prices down 20 to 28 points. Observers attributed the decline to the reported weakness in Chicago and other western spot markets due to the seasonal upswing in cattle slaughterings.

Whatever the justice of their specific complaint against proposed increases in pier rentals by the City of New York, the railroads and other tenants would be on sound ground to argue as a general principle that the city should be cautious about raising rents in advance of completion of needed improvements to piers.

MADRID, Oct. 6 -- Generalissimo Franco "could make some pertinent and worthwhile observations to the leaders of the Allied Forces," James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, said today in a press conference after an hour-and-a-half private interview with the Generalissimo in Pardo Palace. "It might be well for them to have them," [the observations] he added.

Having received in his morning's mail, by virtue of the fact that he is a Harvard graduate, a copy of "Harvard's Open Shelf," published monthly in the interest of the Lamont Library Endowment of the Harvard Fund Council, a friend of ours decided that he owed it to himself, as a Harvard man, to give it a casual once-over.

The appeals of three former officers of the National Maritime Union, CIO, who were expelled from membership last month, were turned over yesterday by the union's national council to a special appeals committee for consideration.

Mia Slavenska made her second appearance in "Coppelia" last night with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House in a program which had been revised to allow her to repeat the role which she danced so successfully at a matinee last week.

I was interested to read in THE TIMES that Henry Hands, who recalls the windjammer days when he went to sea in 1876, had sailed on the bark Esmeralda. In 1907, as I stood on the mole one day, I saw the bark Esmeralda under full sail; she came from the sea and went gliding gracefully into the harbor like a great bird under white wings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Unseeded Nick Carter, Tom Brown Jr. and Art Larsen, all of San Francisco, took quite a chunk out of the men's singles seeded lists in the National Hard Court Tennis Championships today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Justice Department has asked the FBI to make a preliminary inquiry into charges regarding the way Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, has operated his Congressional office.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- A holiday spirit animated the crowd which watched the opening of the forty-fifth world series today at Braves Field. But it was a somber, fur-and-topcoated and blanket-wrapped gathering which had little chance for demonstrative expression of its pent-up emotion while a tense pitching duel between Johnny Sain and Bobby Feller progressed.
Meat prices were cut again yesterday in chain stores and at some independent counters, and further reductions were in prospect for the week-end.

A man and wife attended class night exercises last night as two of the eighty-nine members of the final "accelerated" war-time class of the New York University School of Law. Mr. and Mrs. Harold Yoskowitz received the congratulations of Dean Russell D. Niles at the exercises, which were held in the Little Theatre of the Washington Square College of N.Y.U.

Benjamin Gitlow, who helped organize the Communist party here and formerly headed it, has written an expose of the party that will be published Oct. 18 by Scribners. It is entitled "The Whole of Their Lives." Mr. Gitlow, twice the Communist candidate for Vice President and thrice a visitor to Moscow on official party business, traces the evolution of the party into the well-disciplined movement of today.
BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Rapid Robert Feller today-made only eighty-five pitches -- ten fewer than Boston's Johnny Sain -- yet lost the eighth 1-0 game in world seriesI history.

A canvass of the city's health and welfare needs by the Welfare Council gives top priority to the chronically ill, more and better private and public facilities for children and financial assistance to families, the council's delegate body learned yesterday.
Charley Klemovich, starting right guard for Columbia's Lions, has been named captain of the Light Blue by Coach Lou Little for this Saturday's encounter with Yale at New Haven.

An atomic power division which will concentrate solely on the harnessing of nuclear energy for the production of useful power has been formed by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, it was announced yesterday in Pittsburgh by Gwilym A. Price, president of the corporation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Passenger travel on the Pacific stopped today. The President Cleveland arrived and was tied up, the last of the big liners to become strikebound.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Moshe Shertok, Israeli Foreign Minister, said here today that he believed in the possibility of a private peace settlement for Palestine between Israel and the Arab States outside of the United Nations.
Reassurance that India's plans call for a balanced program of development was given yesterday by Sir Benegal Rama Rau, Indian Ambassador to the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Apart from British Government bonds, which scored fresh gains up to 7/16 point on steady investment buying, most sections of stock market here today were quiet. A landmark was reached for the gilt-edge group when the Government Transport 3 per cent stock, which was issued to former railroad stockholders on Jan. 1, 1948 reached parity for the first time. The stock has been as low as 93 3/4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Truman issued today an executive order for the administration of the reciprocal trade agreements program under the Trade Agreements Act passed in the last session of Congress and he formed the interdepartmental committee on trade agreements to coordinate the program.

NANKING, Oct. 6 (AP) -- As long beleaguered Changchun, capital of Manchuria, was abandoned by the Government today, Russian planes from the Port Arthur-Dairen area buzzed American-operated planes carrying evacuees from Manchuria, retired United States Major Gen. ;Claire. Chennault's air-' line an-' nounced.

Nobody knows what it might do in faster company, but as long as it operates against teams of its own class the University of Nevada boasts an offense as potent as anything seen in college football this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury which heard testimony concerning former Representative Roger C. Slaughter, Democrat, of Missouri, was dismissed today without reporting any findings in the case.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Oct. 6 -- Mrs. Hartwell McCarteney of Huntington posted a pair of 44s for an 88 to annex the low gross honors at the weekly tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association over the Sands Point Club course today.

A lively and at times heated discussion of the problem of inflation by four experts last night on this season's first "What's On Your Mind?" program brought unanimity on only one point. That was that about one-fourth of the families in the United States were using up their savings to spend more than current income.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- A report published by the United Nations Economic and Social Council after its meeting in Geneva last August, took some severe criticism from the Soviet Union during a session of the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee today The Soviet delegate, Alexander E. Bogomolov, charged the Economic Council with failure to support the nations that were not part of the Marshall Plan group.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- In an expansion of activities of the State Association of Real Estate Boards, six new county boards are being organized upstate, Robert W. Leavitt of Lake George, president of the State Association, told the Westchester County Realty Board at its annual fall conference here today at the Orienta Beach Club. Two hundred persons were present.

Capt. R.W. Higginson of the Liberty tanker Eliza Jane Nicholson, which collided With and sank the tugboat Ann Marie Tracy in the Hudson River last Saturday, denied emphatically yesterday that his vessel was traveling at an excessive rate of speed at the time of the crash.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Bill Veeck, president of the Indians, when shown The Associated Press picture sequence of the disputed play at second base in the eighth inning of the world series opener, said tonight:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A hearing on an application of Capital Airlines to extend its route 14 from Pittsburgh to New York was set tentatively today for around Jan. 10.
Women in business should plan their careers the way men do, Mrs. Karp Mikhalenkoff, first vice president of the American Woman's Association, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Representatives of the steel industry accepted today only one of nine new Government-backed programs to set aside supplies of their scarce products for "essential" uses.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 6 -- "Greenbrier," a two-act musical satire, opened in the WRVA theatre here tonight amid persistent rumors that Robert R. Young, railway president, might back it for Broadway production.

"Love Life," Cheryl Crawford's new musical, capitalized at $200,000, will be unfolded this evening at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. The opening tonight curtain is scheduled to show at 8 o'clock sharp and the producer warns that no one will be seated during the first scene.

Thirteen persons concerned with left-wing labor activities faced possible charges of contempt of Congress yesterday as a section of the House Committee on Education and Labor ended hearings in the United States Court House.
